column2: Through a series of errors and misunderstandings, the body of an 18-year-old Brooklyn youth, who was rushed by ambulance from his parents' apartment to a hospital late on the night of Dec. 8, lay unidentified in a city morgue for a week until it was finally claimed yesterday. The parents, Theodore and Parthenia Washington, said they dialed the 911 emergency telephone line for an ambulance at 11:45 P.M. on Dec. 8, when their son, Eric, had a severe asthma attack. An Emergency Medical Service crew arrived five minutes later and took the youth to a hospital. He died, apparently of natural causes, less than an hour after arriving at the hospital, city officials said. But his parents said they had been unable to find out where he had been taken -and what had happened to him - for eight days until they asked City Council President Andrew J. Stein for help on Tuesday.

THE Sugarplum Fairy is certainly the plum role in ''The Nutcracker.'' Yet, even though her Cavalier does little more than partner her in a pas de deux, he can still create a pleasant impression with his stage presence, as two talented young dancers demonstrated when they made their debuts in this part at recent performances of the New York City Ballet.

The economy grew at an annual rate of 2.8 percent in the third quarter, the Government announced today, but inflation picked up as well. The Commerce Department's report on the rise in the gross national product represented only a slight revision from the Government's estimate a month ago of a 2.9 percent growth rate in the quarter, but was sharply higher than the six-tenths of 1 percent rate in the spring. Inflation, however, almost nonexistent in the spring, revived as well in the July-September period. A price measure tied to the G.N.P., which is the broadest indicator of the nation's economic health, rose at an annual rate of 3.8 percent during the summer, double the spring pace.

The Federal Communications Commission, ignoring recent criticism, today authorized a formal inquiry into its policies that help women and racial minorities acquire radio and television stations. The commission said it wants to determine if those policies result in greater program diversity. If it finds they do not, the panel is expected to try to abolish the policies.

Officials at Aqueduct announced during yesterday's program that the weight allowances for three apprentice riders - Jerry Belmonte, Tyrone Carter and David Nuesch - were being reduced from seven to five pounds. The announcement was made shortly before the eighth race.

A Louisville distiller, one of its executives and a private club agreed today to pay a ''substantial'' amount to the family of a Louisville man killed last summer in a traffic accident with the executive, who was said to be intoxicated after a company party, an attorney for the victim's family said today. It is believed to be the first time that a major distiller has agreed to settle a lawsuit arising from an alcohol-related death.

China today announced plans for its first high-level official visit to Laos since relations between the two Communist neighbors were frozen in 1979. The Foreign Ministry spokesman, Ma Yuzhen, said Deputy Foreign Minister Liu Shuqing would visit Laos from Saturday to Thursday at the invitation of the Laotian Foreign Ministry.

The Interior Department will unveil an official portrait of a former Secretary, William P. Clark, in a ceremony this morning. Among those expected to be there are the State Department's Ambassador at Large for Cultural Affairs, Daniel J. Terra, and the artist who painted the portrait, Everett Raymond Kinstler of New York.

Most of Spain's high schools were shut today as striking students marched in cities around the country to protest college admission policies. Apparently inspired by students in France, hundreds of thousands of Spaniards joined in the strike, and tens of thousands marched in Madrid, Barcelona, Valencia, Seville and most of the remaining provincial capitals. Protesting French students in recent weeks have forced the conservative Government of Prime Minister Jacques Chirac to abandon plans to tighten university admission. The issues are similar here, where it is the center-left Government of Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez, that has been seeking to rationalize admission to the country's overrun and underfinanced universities.

Daphne Busby described the beginnings of the Sisterhood of Black Single Mothers in the early 1970's as a ''lifting up of those neighborly elements already available'' in the Bedford-Stuyvesant area of Brooklyn. During the early 70's, Miss Busby and other young single mothers helped one another with babysitting, counseling and general child-rearing help.

John Z. DeLorean was found not guilty today of defrauding his failed sports car company of $8.5 million. But prosecutors immediately challenged the not-guilty verdicts on the 15 counts, including fraud and racketeering, saying the jurors may have misinterpreted the legal instructions given by Federal District Judge Julian A. Cook Jr. The jury decided to acquit Mr. DeLorean, 61 years old, despite the fact that 3 of the 12 jurors thought he was guilty, several jurors said in interviews tonight. They said they thought they had to acquit Mr. DeLorean if they could not unanimously agree on a verdict. They apparently ignored the possibility of declaring a hung jury, according to the interviews.

Human rights groups monitoring detentions in South Africa have compiled a list of 390 names of children being detained under the emergency decree. Four on the list are 11 years old, and several are 12 or 13. The document lists only a small proportion of the estimated 8,800 young people detained since June 12. Most of the children identified are said to come from black townships outside Johannesburg and Pretoria.

1967: An operation, described as a transurethral prostatectomy, was performed to correct an anatomical abnormality of the neck portion of Mr. Reagan's urinary bladder and to remove about 30 ''seedlike prostatic stones.'' March 30, 1981: After a speaking engagement at a hotel in Washington, Mr. Reagan was shot, and a bullet passed close to his heart. The President had immediate surgery to remove the bullet, and recovered rapidly.
Flames shooting through the roof of 157 Spring Street last night as firefighters battled a two-alarm blaze.
Carnegie Hall by Ear Is Carnegie Hall still the Stradivarius of the music world? Four critics assess the sound from different perspectives at one concert.

Rule No. 1 is simple: If you want this job, don't make it obvious. If authoriative sources are right, several lawyers, apparently not knowing any better, submitted applications for what may now be the most sought-after job in Washington, that of special prosecutor in the Iran arms affair. The letters of application have been largely ignored. Instead, the three-judge panel that will select the prosecutor, known formally as an independent counsel, has compiled a list of lawyers so prominent and so busy that they have better things to do than promote themselves for the job.

''PRIMES'' and ''Scores'' will soon be joining Cats and Tigers in the lexicon of Wall Street. Just as Cats and Tigers - two of the more popular zero coupon bonds - ''strip'' the interest from the principal of fixed-income securities, Primes and Scores are designed to separate the dividends from stocks. Such stripping of equities has been done before, in 1984 with shares of the old American Telephone and Telegraph Company and last year with Exxon stock. Now the sponsor of those instruments, the Americus Shareowner Service Corporation, plans to offer similar investments for all 30 stocks that make up the Dow Jones industrial average, dubbing the dividend portion Primes and the rest Scores.

Q.We want to convert a large uninsulated barn into a tool shed and studio for year-round use. How can we insulate it without tearing off the exterior clapboard siding? A. Most such barns are unfinished on the inside; that is, the studs are open and exposed, and the inner side of the exterior siding is exposed. If that is the case then all that is necessary is to install regular fiberglass batts from the inside, pressing the batts between the studs.

Sometime today the 1987 American League East title, alias Jack Morris, will walk into George Steinbrenner's office at the American Shipbuilding Company in Tampa, Fla., to determine if the Yankees' principal owner wants it and him. Put up or shut up. ''And with one of our proposals,'' Dick Moss was saying yesterday, ''we'll find out if George is under instructions not to sign Jack Morris, or has made an agreement not to sign Jack Morris.'' Moss, an attorney for the free-agent right-handed pitcher, naturally wouldn't divulge the details of the offer that he believes the Yankees' principal owner can't refuse. At a guess, maybe Morris will be willing to bet his salary on the outcome of the American League East next season. Not much if the Yankees don't win, but a big number if they do win.

The player-ticket policy adopted by National Collegiate Athletic Association members two years ago at the urging of the troubled Southwest Conference is being ignored by many schools. According to figures compiled by the N.C.A.A. and released this week to The Associated Press, football players in 1985 alone accounted for more than 8,000 violations.

To the Editor: In ''Too Much Too Soon,'' the Christmas song that you refer to as ''God Rest Ye, Merry Gentlemen'' should be punctuated ''God Rest Ye Merry, Gentlemen.'' And it's not too soon! ARTHUR J. MORGAN New York, Dec. 8, 1986

''BENDING TOWARD THE LIGHT: A Jazz Nativity,'' a semistaged collection of Christmas carols that was written, arranged and produced by Anne Phillips, had a cast of jazz luminaries for its premiere Monday at St. Bartholomew's Church. Despite some enjoyable star turns, however, it was an unimaginative version of the Christmas story - genteel where it should have been jubilant. The production used narration (by Edmund L. Browning, presiding bishop of the Episcopal Church), a jazz group, a small choir, and solo singers and dancers. It added a slight swing to old carols, introduced three new ones and revived Dave Brubeck's jaunty ''God's Love Made Visible.''

MOTHER AND CHILD REVISITED Numerous generations of artists have drawn inspiration from the story of Mary and Jesus, although the mother-and-child theme gets particular attention at this time of year. It may be seen in an exhibition now on view at the Afro-American Institute, 833 First Avenue, at 47th Street, in the United Nations Plaza. ''Mother and Child in African Sculpture'' consists of 56 items, on loan from museums in Seattle, Los Angeles, from private West Coast collections, and from museums and private collections in New York. The work represents the art of Africa, from Western Sudan and Equatorial and Central Africa to Madagascar. and southern Africa.

The Federal Communications Commission today proposed a streamlining of its regulation of several lines of services offered by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the regional Bell Telephone companies. The panel said it hoped to reduce economic regulation of services that are offered to large users on a contract basis and chosen through competitive bidding.

A private telephone canvassing company has discovered that some of its employees defrauded the Government by inflating the number of requests for a book that has become an important part of the Reagan Administration's campaign against drug abuse in the schools, according to executives of the company. The 78-page book, published by the Department of Education, was introduced at the White House last September by Nancy Reagan, who wrote a forward for it. The book has been hailed by William J. Bennett, the Secretary of Education, as a major part of the Administration's efforts to educate school children about the dangers of drug abuse. As evidence of the program's success, Mr. Bennett often cited the large number of requests for the book, which was distributed at no charge. The company says that less than 10 percent of the more than 100,000 requests for the book involved fraudulent names.

Senator Robert C. Byrd, left, new majority leader, and Senator Bob Dole, new minority leader, next to him. Members of the investigative panel are, from left seated, Senators Paul S. Trible, William S. Cohen, David L. Boren, Sam Nunn, George J. Mitchell, Paul S. Sarbanes and Howell Heflin. Standing are Warren B. Rudman, vice chairman, left, and Daniel K. Inouye, chairman. (NYT/Jose R. Lopez)

TRADITIONAL holidays are not just for traditional families. Terry Greenaway, for example, has been divorced for five years, but her former husband still comes over every Christmas morning so they and their two children can open presents together. ''I can't see doing it any other way,'' said Ms. Greenaway, a teacher from Lawrenceville, N.J. ''This way it's more like Christmas from their parents.'' Similarly, Jane Marques, who lives with her husband and two daughters in Yonkers, has worked full time since her younger daughter, now 4 years old, was 3 months old. She has never abandoned the customs of baking and decorating and preparing dinner for 11 on Christmas Day. ''The kids have to get the whole show,'' said Ms. Marques, a data processing supervisor who uses her lunch hour to do her shopping. ''By the time Christmas comes, I'm beat.''

New York City's three major airports are bracing for record-breaking crowds of year-end holiday travelers, many attracted by discount fares. Airports in the region expect 5 to 15 percent more travelers between tomorrow and Jan. 4 than during last year's holiday period. Airline officials said single-day passenger counts could reach the highs many carriers set on Nov. 30, the Sunday after Thanksgiving, usually the most heavily traveled day of the year. The airports - Newark International, La Guardia and Kennedy International - may together spend as much as $1 million in overtime pay for extra police, traffic supervisors and parking lot attendants to try to speed the flow of vehicles and people.

The United States Ambassador to Switzerland, Faith Ryan Whittlesey, took the unusual step today of publicly denying a Swiss newspaper report that she had any connection to the diversion of Iran arms payments to Nicaraguan rebels. In a front-page article in the Zurich daily Tages Anzeiger, the paper's Washington correspondent cited United States congressional sources as saying Mrs. Whittlesey would be recalled to Washington in mid-January to answer questions from the House Foreign Affairs Committee on her possible role in the covert arms deals. A possible role by Mrs. Whittlesey in the arms sales has been the subject of public debate here, because Swiss bank accounts were used to funnel some money to the rebels and because as a White House aide she had sought support for the Nicaraguan rebels.

* Biogen, Cambridge, Mass., a developer of pharmaceutical products through genetic engineering, elected to its board James W. Stevens, a managing director of the investment banking firm Dillon, Read & Co. * Honeywell Inc., Minneapolis, named Jean-Pierre Rosso president of Honeywell Europe and Michael R. Bonsignore executive vice president of its International Automation and Control business.

Juan Ponce Enrile, dismissed as Defense Minister three weeks ago, re-entered the Manila political arena today, saying he was ''learning to be in public life again in another role.'' In a speech before about 100 supporters, he outlined a political platform for a loyal opposition to President Corazon C. Aquino. ''Democracy is the wish of the party in power; it is also our wish,'' he said. Though he criticized the Aquino Government for not living up to its ideals, his accusations lacked the sharp edge that brought him into confrontation with the President when he was still a member of her Cabinet.

A New York State panel's draft report for highway construction and development along the West Side of Manhattan came under angry attack by elected officials, community groups, residents and environmental advocates last night. But the panel's recommendations, which include construction of a six-lane roadway between the Battery and 59th Street, were lauded by a variety of business and real-estate spokesmen at a public hearing that occasionally strayed into heckling. More than 60 speakers were scheduled to address the panel, known formally as the West Side Task Force, at the hearing at the Fashion Institute of Technology. It was the last opportunity to comment publicly on the panel's suggestions before it completes a final report next month.

Allied-Signal Inc. confirmed yesterday that it was continuing to negotiate its plan, announced earlier this year, to sell its 15 percent interest in the Henley Group. Allied-Signal holds 19.6 million shares of Henley preferred stock, which is convertible to an equal number of common shares.

Charles H. Townsend, 42 years old, is joining The New York Times Magazine Group as senior vice president and publisher of Family Circle magazine, the group's largest publication. He succeeds Thom Redd, 62, the publisher since 1982, who has been with Family Circle for 35 years. Mr. Redd will be senior vice president/advertising of the group.

The PHH Group, which provides vehicle fleet management services, is offering $100 million of 8 percent notes due in 1996, priced at 99 7/8 to yield 8.02 percent. Goldman, Sachs & Company heads the underwriters. Rated A-1 by Moody's and AA- by Standard & Poor's, the notes are not callable and yield about nine-tenths percentage point more than Treasury notes of similar maturity.

A cleanup worker at the damaged reactor on Three Mile Island was injured and contaminated by radiation Tuesday after being hit by lead shielding in the containment building. The 36-year-old worker, who was not identified, was taken to the Milton S. Hershey Medical Center and decontaminated while in the ambulance.

IT is not as efficient as central heating, but if your city apartment has a working fireplace a log fire is just the ticket these chilly days. A number of dealers in the New York City area offer seasoned hardwood logs. Delivery can add appreciably to the cost of keeping a hearth ablaze, but many dealers make free deliveries of minimum orders. However, make certain you have enough room to store the amount of logs you plan to buy. A full cord of wood, for example, fills 128 cubic feet, which is the equivalent of a stack 8 feet long, 4 feet high and 4 feet deep. A face cord is a stack 8 feet long and 4 feet high and 16 inches deep.

A old-fashioned Western gallows built as a tourist attraction has been cut into firewood. Members of a business group, the Wild Bunch, hoped to move the gallows, which was built as part of the Douglas centennial celebration last summer, to a parking lot in town. But they sawed the log structure into small pieces Saturday and gave it away as firewood after the local Chamber of Commerce voted against spending $620 on liability insurance, said Steve Park, a member of the Wild Bunch.

A sea lion with a fish in its mouth in the Ballard Locks in Seattle. A run of steelhead rainbow trout is making its way through the locks, and officials are seeking ways to protect the trout, including harassing the sea lions with bombs and shipping them to California. (AP)

Following are the texts of messages to United States ambassadors from Secretary of State George P. Shultz and President Reagan: SHULTZ'S MESSAGE The President has directed in his letter to each of you upon assuming your duties that ''you will receive policy guidance and instructions from the Secretary of State, who is my principal foreign policy spokesman and adviser, or from me directly.'' In recent years I have sought to emphasize this chain of command by stating in my letter to new ambassadors that the line of authority for any action or decision on your part flows from the President to me and from me through the Assistant Secretary to you. Therefore, you will receive instructions only from or through the department. All messages dealing with policy proposals, policy implementation, program activities, personnel and past operations shall be sent through regular established State Department channels. The only two exceptions to this rule are: (1) if the President personally or the national security adviser instructs you to use a private channel; in such cases you should advise me personally (or the Acting Secretary in my absence) of this instruction unless you are explicitly directed not by the President; and (2) if I, or in my absence, the Acting Secretary or the Executive Secretary, instruct you to use a non-State channel.

A 51-year-old man was charged today with murdering five people over two years, three of them drug and pornography dealers he set up and killed for the cash they carried. The suspect, Richard Kuklinski of 169 Sunset Street, Dumont, was ordered held in $2 million bail. Authorities said he had bragged about spreading cyanide on one victim's hamburger and had kept another's body frozen in a warehouse for more than two years before it was discovered.

Eugene Hasenfus, the American air cargo handler captured when his arms-laden plane was shot down over Nicaragua in October, was pardoned and freed today. Mr. Hasenfus, who had been sentenced to a 30-year jail term by a Nicaraguan People's Tribunal, was turned over to Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, and left the country aboard a jet with Mr. Dodd. ''We want to turn citizen Hasenfus over to the American people and we are doing so through the person of Senator Dodd,'' President Daniel Ortega Saavedra said as he made the announcement. 'A Message of Peace' ''We trust and hope that with this gesture of peace by the people of Nicaragua we can avoid further bloodshed and achieve a true peace.

An inquiry has begun into why Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d ordered the F.B.I. last fall to delay an investigation into shipments of weapons to the Nicaraguan contras. The bureau was reportedly told that an inquiry would hurt talks intended to free Americans held hostage in Lebanon. But a senior law-enforcement official said that if it was also intended to hide the fact that profits from the arms sales had been used to buy weapons for the contras, it could lead to charges of obstruction of justice. [ Page A1. ]

The electronic message board in the Aqueduct infield got into the Christmas spirit when it flashed a jockey change for the No. 5 horse in the feature race the other day. The new rider was Chris Antley, but the board said, ''5 Antler.'' The race was named, by the way, for the late Joe Palmer, the brilliant turf writer, who would have loved it.

The test pilot Chuck Yeager set a speed record of sorts today on the 83d anniversary of man's first powered flight. Mr. Yeager, the first man to fly faster than the speed of sound, flew a Cheyenne 400-LS propjet from Edwards Air Force Base, Calif., to the First Flight Strip where Orville and Wilbur Wright made their historic flight on Dec. 17, 1903.

The General Motors Acceptance Corporation is offering $445 million of asset-backed securities through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. The 6.85 percent instruments, secured by automobile loan receivables, are offered at a price of 99.60 to yield 7.03 percent and have an estimated avergage life of 1.9 years. Moody's rated the issue Aa-1; Standard & Poor's rated it AA.

The Republicbank Corporation of Dallas lost more than one-tenth of its market value yesterday as investors expressed concern over how its proposed merger with another Texas banking giant, the Interfirst Corporation, would affect Republicbank's prospects immediately and long term. Republic's stock closed at $19, down $2.75, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Interfirst finished at $4.85, down 12.5 cents.

The chief prosecutor in the McMartin preschool molestation case took the stand today and admitted that she waited 10 months before giving defense attorneys information that cast doubt on the credibility of a major witness. ''It was negligence,'' said the prosecutor, Lael Rubin. ''Your negligence?'' asked Danny Davis, who represents Raymond Buckey, one of the two remaining defendants in the case. ''That's correct,'' she replied. Miss Rubin was called to the stand by Mr. Davis at an unusual hearing, part of which centers on whether the prosecution deliberately withheld information about the mental instability of a major witness.
The Baltimore Orioles traded Juan Beniquez, a 36-year-old outfielder, to the Kansas City Royals yesterday for two minor league players.

Ridicule remains a President's most formidable foe, a barometer to political popularity, as Jimmy Carter learned repeatedly from television and from jokes that quickly made the rounds. (Why did his Air Force One crew always carry a fresh turkey? Answer: Spare parts.)

Short-term interest rates rose sharply yesterday, to the dismay of corporate borrowers, and securities dealers who must finance their inventories. But the move delighted money managers looking for short-term investments. Traders are accustomed to abnormally high short-term rates around the end of the year, but the extent of the recent increases - and the fact they have come so far ahead of year-end - has been surprising. According to many analysts, much of the recent rise in rates has been caused by the desire of commercial banks to borrow money now, so that their needs will be reduced late this month, when history shows that interest rates can rise sharply. Last year, for example, the overnight rate for bank loans in the Federal funds market rose to as high as 40 percent on Dec. 31, and averaged 13.46 percent on that day, up from about 8 percent in the previous few weeks.

There is an old Russian proverb that the muzhik won't cross himself until he hears the thunder. The proverb is commonly cited by way of saying that a Russian will not rouse himself to action until the last minute, until the crisis is upon him. This trait has repeatedly frustrated Soviet leaders who have tried to impose their will on the people and rouse them to action. Twenty months ago, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, an energetic and capable leader of the postwar generation, came to power vowing to root out this trait, to change the character of the muzhik - meaning in this case the average Russian - and to reverse the decline of a great and richly endowed land through a fundamental and urgent transformation in the way Russians live and work. Call for 'Revolutionary' Change Only a profound, radical and even ''revolutionary'' restructuring, he said again and again, could check the stagnation of the economy, the corruption of the political system, the people's cynicism.

The windy city is becoming the trendy city. Retailers on North Michigan Avenue, this city's premier shopping boulevard, say that with the glittering array of shops lining their ''Magnificent Mile,'' they can now hold their own against the likes of Rodeo Drive, and even Fifth Avenue. North Michigan Avenue already boasts such heavyweights as Saks Fifth Avenue, Neiman-Marcus, Bonwit Teller, I. Magnin, Lord & Taylor and, of course, Chicago's own Marshall Field's. There are also such smaller luminaries as Gucci, Tiffany and Burberry. And Bloomingdale's will add yet more excitement when it opens its first Chicago store in 1988.

Half a century ago there was a series of annual matches between teams representing New York and Philadelphia. From 1960 to 1973 an intercity match was played at the Summer Nationals with the host metropolis challenging the previous winners. Los Angeles won on five occasions and Boston on four.

AND now, the 1986 Holiday Family Quiz: 1. Does your family leave (a)a glass of milk, or (b)a cup of egg nog for Santa Claus on Christmas Eve? 2. When presents go under the tree, will it be (a)a Douglas fir or (b)a Scotch pine?

''Now we know why they were so goosey about leaks,'' says a lawman, speaking of the past year's hypersensitivity about disclosure at the C.I.A. and White House. ''There's plenty of paper on this.'' A relatively wide circle of Government officials and arms merchants knew about the secret arms-for-hostages dealings. A much smaller circle knew of the diversion of profits from those sales to the contras or to sticky-fingered intermediaries.

The Shubert Organization, the largest theater owner on Broadway, has lost the intense competition to house ''Phantom of the Opera,'' the new Andrew Lloyd Webber musical that is the biggest hit of the London theater season, the show's producer said yesterday. The musical, which opened in London on Oct. 9, is expected to be an equally big hit when it opens on Broadway next fall. Cameron Mackintosh, the show's producer, confirmed by telephone from Washington yesterday afternoon that he had told Bernard Jacobs, president of the Shubert Organization, that for ''technical and artistic reasons,'' the Majestic Theater would not be suitable for ''Phantom.''

After-tax profits of United States corporations rose by a revised 5.5 percent in the July-September quarter, the biggest increase in three years, the Commerce Department reported today. It said after-tax profits totaled $135.9 billion at an annual rate in the third quarter, compared with $128.8 billion in the second quarter.

Celtics' Robert Parish reaching over the shoulder of the Pacers' Herb Wiliams to knock the ball away as Williams tried to score in the first period last night at Boston Garden. The Celtics won, 113-101. Page D30. (UPI)

At the center of the old Smolensk Cemetery in a grimy, factory-choked corner of Leningrad is a small chapel surrounded by scaffolding and wooden fencing. At any time of day, in any season, a few people gather there, either walking around the chapel, standing quietly before it or scribbling on the fence's rough planks. Some have come a great distance. Most are older women, but on one cold, overcast day in autumn there were also a young woman with a child and a young bearded man.

''THE FUTURE'S SO BRIGHT, I GOTTA WEAR SHADES,'' a song about an aspiring nuclear scientist, has become an unlikely hit for Timbuk 3. The group - two lanky singer-guitarists, Pat and Barbara MacDonald, and a squat rhythm machine -brought that song and other bleakly sardonic material to the Bottom Line on Monday.

Archie Cooley, the football coach at Mississippi Valley State who resigned yesterday, said he wants to take his his five current assistant coaches, to his new job, at the Unviersity of Arkansas-Pine Bluff. Fifty-three of his Mississippi Valley players say they also plan to go with him.

To the Editor: Residents of San Francisco and Los Angeles have sounded the alarm against the Manhattanization of their cities by approving, 2 to 1, sweeping and drastic controls to limit construction of new office towers, hotels and shopping centers (front page, Nov. 15). In general, the manner in which American cities have grown has been disastrous.

THEY do not advertise it much, but the automobile companies do business with each other all the time. Usually it involves unseen internal components, with the buyer seeking to avoid the cost of designing and tooling for a part on its own and the seller taking advantage of the improved economics of a longer production run. For instance, the head castings for the engines in many Ford Escorts come from Fiat, the Italian car company. The Chrysler Corporation buys engines from the Mistubishi Motor Company for its popular mini-van and other American-made models. Every American Motors Corporation Jeep sold in North America contains a gearbox from Chrysler's New Process Gear division.

SANDWICHED between a Ray's Pizza and an Associated Supermarket, Giles & Lewis is one of the latest additions in the gentrification of Columbus Avenue. The most striking thing about the store, which sells modern home furnishings and accessories, is its facade, a Lego-like assemblage of what look like rusted steel girders. ''Not steel and not rusted,'' said Lewis Dolin, who with his partner, Dr. Giles Forman, opened the shop last Saturday at 464 Columbus Avenue, near 82d Street.

John Sculley, chairman and chief executive of Apple Computer Inc., sold nearly all of his Apple shares last month, according to information filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Mr. Sculley sold 107,503 shares, or about 97 percent of his holdings, at $39.81, the reports said. Barbara Krause, an Apple spokesman, said it was company policy not to comment on executives' private financial decisions but added that Mr. Sculley retains 392,497 options to purchase Apple shares at an exercise price of $16.85.

More than 5,000 of New York City's 35,000 hospital beds are wastes of public health resources and should be eliminated, a key governmental health-planning organization said yesterday. The organization said more than 2,000 of the beds should be removed from some of the city's most prestigious teaching hospitals, most of them in Manhattan. Several of the hospitals have already suffered sharp reductions in the numbers of patients they serve. The recommendations came from the New York City Health Systems Agency. Like others across the country, it was created by Congress in 1975 to cut waste and unnecessary hospital services and to foster the most economical use of public health funds.

As winter comes to this lovely old city, still perhaps the most graceful of Arab capitals, there is a mood of uncertainty. The economy is pinched; President Hafez al-Assad, like others before him, is becoming bogged down in Lebanon, and Syrians are beginning to feel the international isolation accorded them over charges of sponsoring terrorism. This has particularly affected the wealthy, who love to travel abroad and now find themselves pounced upon by batteries of customs inspectors. But despite the presence of grim-faced young men wearing blue jeans, leather jackets and submachine guns on the street corners, it is still a welcoming place.

Richard Andrade, who stabbed a woman at least 14 times in raping and murdering her in 1984, died of a lethal injection early this morning after the United States Supreme Court refused to stay the execution. Mr. Andrade was pronounced dead at 12:32 A.M., said Assistant Attorney General Monroe Clayton. Mr. Andrade, 25 years old, who used a pocketknife to murder Cordelia Mae Guevara at a club she managed in Corpus Christi, was the 10th Texas inmate to be executed this year and the 20th since the state resumed executions in 1982. Both figures are the highest in the nation.

In sealed court settlements, the beleaguered Church of Scientology has agreed to pay former members more than $5 million to settle two dozen lawsuits that allege fraud, misrepresentation and other abuses by the organization, sources close to the church said today. The church agreed to make cash payments to settle at least 15 suits been brought against it by dissident Scientologists and Michael Flynn, a Boston lawyer who represented some of the former members, in negotiations concluded last week in Los Angeles. Also settled under the agreement were three suits brought by the church against Mr. Flynn. In recent months, the organization has settled at least nine other lawsuits brought against it by former members in Massachusetts and Florida.

Suddenly, the worm seems to have turned on welfare. When the Reagan Administration began, it was social welfare liberals who seemed to be out of gas, and ideas. The energy all seemed to come from analysts eager to get the Federal Government out of the anti-poverty business. Now the roles seem to be reversing.

Archbishop Raymond G. Hunthausen of Seattle, who underwent surgery Tuesday to remove a cancerous prostate gland, will retain all his pastoral power in a convalescence that could last three months, church officials said today.

Because of a production error, the page containing the American Stock Exchange tables was omitted in some copies of Business Day Wednesday. Readers wishing copies of the correct page may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N..Y. 10036.

George Steinbrenner said yesterday he would not rush into an agreement with Jack Morris, but if he likes what he hears and sees when he meets with the pitcher today, he would be free to sign him. ''Yes, sir. Absolutely,'' Steinbrenner said when asked if he was free to sign Morris, the free agent, who is trying to escape the Detroit Tigers. ''Nobody has ever told me what I can do or can't do.''

A woman who accused six men of raping her in Big Dan's Tavern in New Bedford, Mass., was killed in an automobile accident, the state police reported today. Four of the men were convicted in the rape case and two were acquitted.

A reference to Jews in a recent issue of the Bulletin of the Metropolitan Museum of Art has drawn a protest from the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith and an apology from the museum. The reference appeared in the Summer 1986 issue of the bulletin.

The limited partners in Ivan F. Boesky's securities firm stand to lose more than $100 million of the $335 million of capital they placed in the firm, some of the investors said last night. The investors, including both individuals and institutions, have learned that the portfolio is worth perhaps $90 million less than on Nov. 14, the day Mr. Boesky settled insider trading charges. The investors who provided this information spoke on condition that they not be identified, but the figures were confirmed by Steven Weinroth, a managing director at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. The investment bank acted on behalf of Mr. Boesky in raising some capital for Mr. Boesky's firm and itself made a $3 million investment as a limited partner.

The South African authorities, who assert they are the target of a revolutionary onslaught, said today that they had intercepted three men trying to smuggle thousands of rounds of Soviet-made ammunition into the country from neighboring Swaziland. The men, all black, were arrested at a border-crossing on Monday, a police statement said. It added that the shipment of ammunition seemed to originate from Mozambique, a black-ruled neighbor whose relationship with South Africa is strained.

Honeywell Inc. said today that it would report a fourth-quarter after-tax charge of $575 million, primarily from the sale of most of its computer business at a discounted price. The loss, which includes other restructuring charges, is substantially higher than expected and would result in a net loss of $380 million for the year. Honeywell has been moving away from computers toward aerospace and military electronics and commercial and industrial controls.

By a 4-to-3 vote, the New York City Board of Education last night approved a plan to give local school boards more control over special education classes in the city's elementary and junior high schools. The board also voted, 5 to 2, to create two new health clinics at high schools in the Bronx, provoking further debate over the role of such clinics in providing birth control counseling to students. In a third action, the board approved, without opposition, a new one-year contract for Schools Chancellor Nathan Quinones, with options for two additional one-year extensions. The Chancellor's current contract expires June 30, according to school system officials.

MONTY ALEXANDER'S tribute to Nat (King) Cole at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street, is much more than Mr. Alexander - a pianist who usually performs as part of a trio - trying to conjure up memories of Cole at the piano. For his program of songs associated with Cole, Mr. Alexander has augmented his regular group - the bassist John Clayton and the drummer Jeff Hamilton - with two musicians who played with Cole: John Collins, who was the guitarist in the King Cole Trio from 1951 until Cole's death in 1965, and the one-time Count Basie trumpet star, Harry (Sweets) Edison, one of four jazz musicians featured on one of Cole's infrequent jazz albums, made in 1956. In addition, Robert Thomas Jr., a virtuosic bongo and conga drummer, fills the role held for many years in Cole's group by Jack Costanzo.

Police officers reacting to six random night snipings urged residents of northern Rhode Island today to draw their blinds and stay away from windows while officers search for a gunman ''shooting to kill.''
A report in Sports Pages yesterday incorrectly listed the yacht club affiliation of the 12-Meter USA. The boat is sponsored by the St. Francis Yacht Club.

MICHAEL TILSON THOMAS'S concert with the Orchestra of St. Luke's Tuesday night at Carnegie Hall was naturally of interest as the first orchestral program in the refubished hall that was free from the noise and glare of Monday's television lighting. From a strictly musical standpoint, the evening had its virtues without satisfying fully. Mr. Thomas offered a conservative program of Mozart - the ''Paris'' Symphony (K. 297), Mahler (the five ''Ruckertlieder'' with Marilyn Horne) and Beethoven (the ''Eroica'' Symphony). Given the fact that St. Luke's at its largest is an expanded chamber orchestra, only the Mozart was played with the forces normally heard in this music. The Mahler and especially the Beethoven are usually played today by ensembles twice the size of the 50 heard on Tuesday.

Directors of the International Monetary Fund will meet today to vote on a new managing director for the agency. The directors met informally yesterday in hopes of settling what has become an embarrassing impasse over who will replace the departing managing director, Jacques de Larosiere.

In the confusion of a four-game losing streak, continued injuries and an uncertain playoff fate, the Jets shuttled more defensive players today. They brought in three people - including Charles Jackson, the linebacker they cut a week ago, and two defensive linemen cut by other teams. Bud Carson, the defensive coordinator, was asked just what the new linemen can do. ''I don't know what they can do,'' he said. Can they help? ''I hope so,'' he added. ''I can't tell you anything because I don't know anything.''

The Reagan Administration is involved in trade confrontations with the European Community, Canada and Brazil that could lead to full-scale trade wars in the new year. In each case, the United States has threatened to curb imports if solutions are not reached by the end of the year.

Fewer than half the students in a Federal study got their college degrees in the four years after high school graduation, the Department of Education reported today. Nearly 1 in 4 took six, seven or more years to get a diploma, according to the report from the department's Center for Statistics. The study was based on an analysis of college transcripts of 4,400 students who were part of a larger group interviewed in the high school class of 1972.

Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d said today that he had not ''seen anything'' to contradict his original finding that only Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter and Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North knew of the diversion of Iranian arms payments to Nicaraguan rebels. Mr. Meese, speaking at a news conference after testifying under oath for five hours before the Senate Intelligence Committee, said he had no evidence that any official other than Colonel North took part in the diversion. ''So far, I have not seen anything that would provide evidence different from what we originally found,'' he said.

INTERNATIONAL A3-23 Nicaragua freed Eugene Hasenfus, the American seized when his arms-laden plane was shot down. Mr. Hasenfus was turned over to Senator Christopher Dodd of Connecticut and left Nicaragua aboard his jet. Page A1 Israelis disputed Donald T. Regan. Senior officials denied the reported testimony by the White House chief of staff that Israel began shipping arms to Iran in mid-1985 without President Reagan's approval. A23 A key G.O.P. Representative rejected White House suggestions that witnesses in the Iran arms affair be granted immunity to compel their testimony before a newly appointed 15-member House inquiry.

The State Department today dismissed as propaganda an assertion by Mikhail S. Gorbachev that the Soviet Union was prepared to be flexible on research and testing for the American space-based missile defense system. The issue has been an obstacle to achieving an arms reduction agreement. Soviet officials have been telling Americans that there is room for negotiation, but these statements do not appear to have been reflected in the arms talks in Geneva.

After successfully rethinking and rebuilding Paine Webber Inc.'s retail brokerage division over the last four years, Donald E. Nickelson is being asked to try his hand on the entire firm. Donald B. Marron, Paine Webber's chairman and chief executive, announced yesterday that the 54-year-old Mr. Nickelson had been named president of the company, the securities brokerage subsidiary of Paine Webber Group Inc. Mr. Nickelson had been president of the firm's profitable Consumer Markets division. The promotion of Mr. Nickelson, an avid sportsman who grew up in Kansas and spent years working as a stockbroker in the Southwest, has two aims. It is an effort to lighten Mr. Marron's day-to-day operating responsibilities at Paine Webber so that he can focus on the firm's broad strategy. The operations, administration, systems, finance, research and consumer markets departments will all report to Mr. Nickelson, who is known as ''Nick.''
Padilla & Spear of Minneapolis, the largest public relations firm in the Upper Middle West, announced yesterday that it had merged with Brum & Anderson, its No. 2 in Minneapolis.

Two elderly men collapsed and died of heart attacks at a City Council hearing, officials said yesterday. The victims, tenants in the Harbor Terrace Apartments, were at the hearing Tuesday to support a proposed change in rent controls.

The White House announced today that President Reagan would undergo a surgical procedure Jan. 5 to relieve ''discomfort'' caused by an enlarged prostate. The prostate, a gland surrounding the urethra at the base of the bladder, often becomes enlarged in older men and may become cancerous. The White House spokesman, Larry Speakes, said there was no evidence Mr. Reagan had cancer of the prostate, although examination of the tissue removed in the procedure is normal to determine whether any malignancy was present. The spokesman did not elaborate on the ''discomfort,'' which often involves increased frequency of urination or urgency to urinate.

The Government, citing known incidents of death from exposure to toxic chemicals, has issued health and safety regulations aimed at protecting nearly 170,000 workers at toxic waste sites. The new regulations by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration, which are effective immediately, were required by Congress last fall when it resuscitated the financially drained program for cleaning up thousands of abandoned toxic waste dumps. The new rules, announced Tuesday, require periodic medical examinations and a minimum of 40 hours of safety and health training for workers at both cleanup sites and currently operating dumps that handle such hazardous wastes such as toxic chemicals and metals. They do not cover workers at landfills and dumps that are used for ordinary garbage and trash.

Constantly changing course to avoid thunderheads, lightning and turbulent air, the aircraft Voyager passed over the Malay Peninsula and Bay of Bengal today in its attempt to be the first to fly around the earth on one load of fuel without landing. Guided by weather forecasters using advanced meteorological equipment, the pilots, Richard Rutan and Jeana Yeager, fought fatigue as they threaded their way through bad weather on the fourth day of what is expected to be a 12-day journey. The two took off in their experimental H-shaped aircraft from nearby Edwards Air Force Base early Sunday morning. If all goes well, they expect to land there next week.

The Minneapolis investor Irwin L. Jacobs said that he had increased his stake in the Borg-Warner Corporation, to the equivalent of 11.3 percent, or 9.7 million shares, from 7.7 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Jacobs, the chairman of Minstar Inc., said that Minstar had entered into an option agreement with Bear, Stearns & Company to purchase more than three million Borg-Warner shares for an average price per share of $41.41, or $125.4 million.

A shooting tip from his goaltender helped Doug Sulliman of the Devils score 35 seconds into overtime tonight for a 3-2 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs at Byrne Meadowlands Arena. ''He was beating me in practice for the last couple days with that kind of a shot,'' said Alain Chevrier, the Devils' goaltender, ''so I told him to use that shot in the game.'' In practice, Sulliman repeatedly used a wrist shot with a defenseman as a screen to beat Chevrier, and tonight it produced his 11th goal and the Devils' 15th victory. He employed the technique after a pass from Mel Bridgman to beat Ken Wregget from 45 feet on the right as the Toronto goaltender was screened by Chris Kotsopoulos, a Toronto defenseman.

City Spirit Holiday Bazaar, Urban Center Galleries at the the Municipal Art Society, 457 Madison Avenue, at 51st Street, 212-935-3960. City museums and cultural institutions will gather their shops under one roof Thursday, Friday and Saturday with a sale of items ranging from jewelry, scarfs and toys to African art. The Brooklyn Museum, the Studio Museum of Harlem, Cooper-Hewitt and the New York Philharmonic are among the 18 shops offering their wares.

The defense rested its case yesterday in the trial of a Manhattan makeup artist accused in the razor slashing of a model last summer. The judge said the jury would begin its deliberations late today after the closing arguments. The defendant, Steven Roth, 28 years old, of 455 West 34th Street, is charged with having arranged the slashing of the model, Marla Hanson, 25.

Yields generally remained flat in the week ended yesterday, with only a slight improvement for certificates of deposit and some softening for bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds. Over the weeks ahead, interest rates are expected to be mostly unchanged, according to analysts at the Corestates Financial Corporation of Philadelphia. At the Treasury's weekly auction of three- and six-month bills, often a strong influence on what many banks and thrift institutions pay their money market account and C.D. customers, rates rose for the third consecutive week, continuing to exert up ward pressure on short-term rates offered at banks.

The Iran arms deal first came to light in a Lebanese magazine on Nov. 3. A week later, the White House issued the following official statement of policy toward Iran, the last such general policy statement issued: On November 14, 1979, by Executive Order No. 12170, the President declared a national emergency to deal with the threat to the national security, foreign policy, and economy of the United States constituted by the situation in Iran.

The Soviet Union has developed plans that it says will defeat an American space-based defense system. It would use dummy missiles, countermeasures against lasers and other steps to improve the survivability of Soviet missiles. The plans, outlined in a book and discussed by officials at a news conference today and in recent interviews, provide the first details on how the Soviet Union intends to respond to the proposed American defense system. The Soviet countermeasures would be intended to destroy orbiting battle stations, neutralize exotic weapons and disrupt battle-management systems and space communications.

A Federal jury in Las Vegas today found that NBC had defamed the entertainer Wayne Newton in a series of broadcasts in 1980 and 1981 that linked him to organized crime. The jury awarded Mr. Newton $19.2 million in damages. The case posed issues of freedom of the press against the rights held by an individual who is a public figure. The jury decided that NBC knew or had reason to know that the three reports concerning Mr. Newton were false and broadcast them with intent to injure the entertainer.

A City Council committee declared yesterday that New York was facing a ''food emergency,'' and unanimously urged the Koch administration to create a new Office of Food Policy that would coordinate hunger relief efforts now shared by more than 20 agencies. In hearings before its vote, the Council's Committee on General Welfare heard testimony from city welfare officials and private social workers describing what one called ''a deepening crisis'' in the provision of food to the poor, homeless and elderly. ''Hundreds of soup kitchens and food pantries in this city have sprung up since 1982 in response to what they believed to be a short-term emergency,'' said the Commissioner of the Human Resources Administration, William J. Grinker, whose agency handles most of the city's food distribution programs. ''As we look forward to 1987, the end to this problem seems nowhere in sight.''

Borough President Ralph J. Lamberti of Staten Island appointed a 15-member committee yesterday to study whether it is economically and legally feasible for Staten Island to secede from New York City. A Federal court decided last month that the Board of Estimate's makeup was unconstitutional, based on the one-man, one-vote principle.

The general secretary of the National Council of Churches said at a news conference yesterday that the ''Iran-contra affair has had a devastating effect'' on the credibility of the United States in the region and would hamper its effort to mediate a peace settlement for years to come. The official, Arie R. Brouwer, returned from a three-week visit to the Middle East.

One of the most important private collections of English literature - a trove of original journals, poems, letters, books and paintings that illuminate the Romantic era of Shelley, Byron, Keats and their friends, wives and lovers -are to be presented to the New York Public Library this morning. The value of the Carl and Lily Pforzheimer Foundation's gift of the Pforzheimer Collection, known to scholars as ''Shelley and His Circle,'' has been conservatively appraised to be more than $20 million. In addition, the foundation has given $3 million to maintain and enhance the collection. The collection contains about 8,000 manuscripts - including the largest assemblage anywhere of autograph letters by Percy Bysshe Shelley -and 13,000 printed volumes that document the creative and personal lives of the English Romantic poets. It also includes political broadsides and prose notebooks describing their intimate relationships and radical views about England, Ireland and Italy.

The investigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation of the Iran arms deal has uncovered evidence of wider Saudi Arabian involvement than previously disclosed, according to Federal law enforcement officials. Today in Switzerland, apparently as a result of these and other discoveries, the United States Justice Department asked Swiss officials to freeze nine more bank accounts, including one for a company named Hyde Park Holdings, American and Swiss officials said. Congressional investigators suspect that these accounts were part of the complex financial path through which the American Government was paid for the weapons sold to Iran and the surplus was used for other purposes, including support for the rebels fighting to overthrow the Nicaraguan Government. Officials declined to give details on Hyde Park Holdings, but corporate records in Panama show that a company with that name was chartered in March. It is headed by Mohamed Said Ayas, a Saudi Arabian described by an associate and other Saudi sources as the manager of the business affairs of Prince Mohammed bin Fahd bin Abdul Aziz al-Saud, a son of King Fahd.

A French pharmaceutical company is expected to market a drug soon in Europe that a study published yesterday has shown can safely end an early pregnancy in at least 85 percent of women who take it within 10 days of missing a menstrual period. The drug is not approved for sale in the United States. The drug, now designated RU 486, for its developer, the Roussel-Uclaf Company, is also under study as a morning-after pill. It acts by blocking the action of the hormone progesterone, which is needed by the uterus to support the development of a fertilized egg. The drug is a steroid that is closely related to norethindrone, one of the oldest and most widely used synthetic contraceptive hormones. No long-term risks have been associated with continuous use of norethindrone, nor are any expected from brief, intermittent use of the new drug.

Air Force Secretary Edward Aldridge said today that the United States had decided not to use French booster rockets to launch American military navigation satellites. Because of the delay in the resumption of space shuttle flights and the fact that new medium-class rockets will not be ready to launch until 1989, the Air Force had considered launching some of the navigation satellites on the French Ariane rocket. Mr. Aldridge said Arianespace, the consortium that markets the Ariane, made a formal proposal within the last month to launch two satellites a year.

IT has been over 50 years since Jean Harlow sat at her vanity in ''Dinner at Eight'' and reached through the three tiers of white silk fringes that skirted it, to open the drawers beneath. The elaborate vanities of the era, which acted like adjectives of beauty and femininity modifying anyone who sat before them, gradually fell out of fashion, victims of the Depression, World War II and, later, the trend to practical, modular and minimal furniture. Vanities themselves became a forgotten furniture type. Women simply retreated to the bathroom and made up over the sink. At the peak of their popularity, however, during the 1920's and early 1930's, vanities were extraordinary objects, created by the most gifted designers for some of the great figures of the era.

Australian military policemen have arrested a United States marine who deserted 17 years ago during the Vietnam War and went into hiding in Australia, an American Embassy spokesman said today. The spokesman said Pfc. Douglas Beane, 39 years old, disappeared in Vietnam in 1969. The Australian authorities today were considering an American request that they hand over Mr. Beane to the United States for court-martial, but Immigration Minister Chris Hurford indicated he did not favor the request.

In Chicago, where politics is a major league sport, Comiskey Park, the oldest baseball diamond in the major leagues, has become entangled in the Byzantine maneuverings for the elections that this city always seems to be having. After years of complaining, months of searching and weeks of political dispute, Chicago has finally decided to replace the aging stadium, which has been the home of the Chicago White Sox for all 76 years of the American League's franchise here. And, perhaps not surprisingly in this present topsy-turvy season of Illinois politics, Chicago has decided that the home team's new home on the city's South Side will be paid for by visitors. The new $120 million stadium is to be financed in part by an increased tax on city hotel rooms, which are usually occupied by out-of-towners who do not often vote here. This means that hotel guests and visiting baseball teams here will find their room bills increased by 12.1 percent, a city hotel tax second only to New York City's.

DESPITE appearances to the contrary, there were some musical events that took place Monday night besides the reopening of Carnegie Hall. A little less than a mile away, at Town Hall, Jean and Kenneth Wentworth played three large works by Franz Schubert for piano, four hands - the Variations in A flat (D. 813), the Fantasy in F minor (D. 940) and the Sonata in C (''Grand Duo,'' D. 812).

Moratorium on S.R.O. Conversions A bill extending for a month a city moratorium on the conversion or demolition of single-room-occupancy hotels is to be considered by the City Council Housing and Buildings Committee. The temporary ban, enacted last year, is in place while the Council considers a Koch administration proposal to convert S.R.O. units to upper-income housing.

The United States today gave the Swiss authorities an additional list of three companies and nine people whose bank accounts it wants temporarily blocked because of their reported use to funnel Iranian arms payments to rebels in Nicaragua. Swiss officials described the American request as a supplement to an earlier request Monday that led to the blocking of accounts in the Geneva branch of Credit Suisse, held in the name of Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, a former member of the National Security Council staff in the White House. Swiss officials said that the supplementary American request listed the three companies as Hyde Park Holdings, Stanford Technology Corporation and Lake Resources Inc., and the individuals as Colonel North, Maj. Gen. Richard V. Secord, a former Pentagon official, and Albert Hakim, a business associate of General Secord. Khashoggi Account Is Blocked The Swiss officials said others on the list were Adnan Khashoggi, a Saudi Arabian, and Manucher Ghorbanifar, an Iranian. The names of Canadians were also said to be included. Donald Fraser and Ernest Miller, Toronto investors, have been linked to the affair.

Many gifts to the 75th annual appeal to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund have come from contributors who are carying on a custom started years ago. Mathilda B. Goldman of Manhattan, who made her first gift 60 years ago, sent a check for $250.

Eugene Hasenfus is lucky, far luckier than the Reagan Administration he thought he was working for in Nicaragua. He escaped with his life when his cargo plane, loaded with weapons for the contras, was downed in October by Sandinistas. Sentenced to 30 years by a ''people's court,'' he was pardoned yesterday in a shrewdly timed propaganda coup. But his liberation comes at a bedeviling time for President Reagan. His return home serves mainly to remind us of the Administration's growing participation in an unsanctioned war and to draw further attention to Lieut. Col. Oliver North, paymaster and coordinator of the contra crusade.

Two gunmen on a motorcycle shot dead a prominent Colombian journalist tonight in Bogota, officials said. The journalist, Guillermo Cano, 61 years old, was editor and part-owner of El Espectador, Colombia's second-largest newspaper, with a circulation of 215,000. Mr. Cano's newspaper had recently published reports accusing drug traffickers of harming the country by dealing in narcotics.

The General Motors Corporation announced plans today to cut production, saying it would furlough 26,400 workers in January, most of them for two weeks. Nine of G.M.'s 30 car and truck assembly plants are to be closed temporarily, a company spokesman said, besides two plants previously closed for installation of paint equipment. Including those two plants, the temporary layoffs will total 30,200 workers. General Motors also has 24,000 workers on indefinite layoff.

A WORLD OF WATCHERS. By Joseph Kastner. With Illustrations by Louis Agassiz Fuertes. 241 pages. Knopf. $25. ACCORDING to ''A World of Watchers,'' a certain ornithologist once defined bird watching as ''a mild paralysis of the central nervous system which can be cured only by rising at dawn and sitting in a bog.'' The remark is amusing but vague. It doesn't begin to explain why there are millions of bird watchers in America today, some 450,000 of whom are enrolled in various affiliates of the National Audubon Society.

A State Supreme Court justice in Suffolk County has awarded custody of a 13-year-old boy to his homosexual father. Legal experts said the ruling was the first of its kind in the state. However, the Appellate Division of the court, in Brooklyn, stayed the decision today and ordered the trial judge to consider new facts in the case. The facts, according to the mother's lawyer, Arnold B. Firestone, are that the boy, who is referred to in court papers solely by the initial B., has tried to commit suicide several times. The attorney said the suicide attempts had led to the boy's being hospitalized in a psychiatric institution for adolescents on Long Island.

IN a political collective I belonged to in the late 1960's, we had a constant debate: is sexual revolution compatible with feminism? A good many of the women thought not, and a good many of the men thought so. I was part of a rather suspect minority who couldn't make up their minds. A few years later, when doing research on women who wrote in the 17th century, I confronted the issue again by an unexpected route. Countless diaries, memoirs and other records of feminine experience from Elizabethan times to the 19th century convinced me that reputation was probably the greatest influence in a woman's life. Reputation depended upon a modest posture, and ''modesty'' implied chastity. The self-censorship that reputation exercised over women then was far more effective than any external restraint. Young women were taught that modesty ought to inform the way they looked, moved, spoke and gestured. ''Let neither your eyes nor thoughts wander,'' a manual written for their benefit advised.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation has begun an inquiry into why Attorney General Edwin Meese 3rd ordered a delay in an F.B.I. investigation last fall into arms shipments to Nicaraguan rebels, law enforcement officials said today. One official said the F.B.I. was told at the time that its investigation, into the activities of a company in Miami, could imperil negotiations for the release of American hostages in Lebanon. Mr. Meese's order to the F.B.I. raises the question whether he may have known earlier than he has acknowledged about the diversion of proceeds from secret Iran arms sales to Nicaraguan rebels. Asserts His Lack of Knowledge Today, after appearing before the Senate Intelligence Committee, Mr. Meese said his own investigation into the diversion of funds to the Nicaraguan rebels had found nothing beyond his original finding on Nov. 25 that only Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North and Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter had known about the scheme. [ Page A20. ] The attempt to delay the F.B.I. inquiry also raises the question why Mr. Meese would not have asked what the hostages in Lebanon had to do with supplies for the Nicaraguan rebels.
Starting this morning, 60 extra police officers are being assigned to enforce laws against illegal street peddling in midtown and lower Manhattan during the holiday season, police officials said.

John Kerr, a Duke forward, was awarded the 1986 Herrmann Trophy yesterday as the nation's best college soccer player. Kerr, who led the Blue Devils to a 1-0 victory over Akron in the national championship game. . . . Joe Paterno of Penn State won the Bear Bryant Award as college football coach of the year.

Republicans reacted favorably today to a plan to raise motor-vehicle taxes in the New York City area, signaling a possible break in deadlocked negotiations over how to pay for improvements in the city's transit system and freeze its fares. They fell short of an outright endorsement of the plan, saying they wanted to study it further. But privately, leading Republicans said its overall concept was acceptable. Warren M. Anderson, the Senate majority leader, said a key part of the plan ''has a good ring to it.''

FREDERICA VON STADE came to the Museum of Modern Art Sunday evening to sing the recital she had to postpone during the museum's ''Vienna 1900'' series in the fall. At first glance her program looked to have little more connection with that period and place than might have been expected to turn up by chance, but it turns out that Debussy's ''Fetes Galantes'' (Book 1) and Schumann's ''Frauenliebe und -leben'' were interspersed with the works of the adventurous Viennese pioneers on the programs of Arnold Schoenberg's Society for the Private Performance of Music. Here, along with Mahler, early Berg and comic Schoenberg, they formed a program well suited to Miss von Stade's exquisite lyric mezzo-soprano and to the spirit that infuses the best of her singing - though on this occasion the spirit seemed somewhat muted.
By Reuters The Manville Corporation's Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization plan satisfies statutory requirements, a Federal bankruptcy judge said.

As if Tim Witherspoon did not have enough problems. On Friday, hours before he defended his World Boxing Association heavyweight title against James (Bonecrusher) Smith, the Internal Revenue Service put a lien on Witherspoon's $300,000 purse for $180,148 in back taxes. Later that night at Madison Square Garden, Smith knocked out Witherspoon at 2:12 of the first round. Now it develops that postfight tests revealed marijuana in Witherspoon's system. There was an identical finding after Witherspoon won the title from Tony Tubbs in January. At the time, he was fined $25,000 and a rematch with Tubbs was mandated.

John D. deButts, former chairman and chief executive of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and one of the nation's leading industrialists in the 70's, died of heart failure yesterday. He was 71 years old and had spent his final days in the Winchester Medical Center near his family farm in Upperville, Va. During the time he led A.T. & T., from 1972 until his retirement in 1979, Mr. deButts led the company through one of its most tumultuous periods. It was a time of vast advances in telecommunications technology; of surprising competition from upstart, feisty competitors, and of relentless attempts by the Government to dissolve A.T. & T. into its component Bell System operating companies.

Leeman Bennett's future with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers seems tenuous, and not without reason. His reputation as a solid football man notwithstanding, Bennett's stay with the Bucs has been one of the least successful head-coaching tenures in N.F.L. history.

Stock prices dropped sharply and trading volume contracted yesterday as fainthearted investors held back with only two days to go before the ''triple witching hour.'' Program trading, which ordinarily occurs just before the expiration of stock index options, index futures and regular stock options, helped push equities higher both Monday and Tuesday. Yesterday, however, with the three simultaneous expirations coming tomorrow, institutional investors were more inclined to sell stocks. The Dow Jones industrial average, which rose 13 points on Tuesday, retreated 17.85 points yesterday, to 1,918.31. Stock prices started off the day lower, held steady during most of the middle of the session before encountering selling pressure just before the last hour of trading.

The State-City Commission on Integrity in Government, charged with finding the causes and cures for New York's corruption scandals, winds up with some sound recommendations - which could fall flat because the commission has done little to dramatize their urgency. Should Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch call for another commission to finish that part of the job? Yes. The expiring commission, headed by Columbia University's president, Michael Sovern, offers a list of sound remedies: limits on campaign contributions to officials who dispense public contracts, public campaign financing, merit selection rather than clubhouse selection of judges and greater uniformity and clarity in the rules for public contractors. It also wants party leaders and legislators to stop practicing before the state agencies they so heavily influence, and a state ethics commission to enforce stronger disclosure laws.

RENOVATING a Victorian house? Chances are you will need replacement gingerbread such as spandrels, balusters, grilles, molding and trim. A number of companies across the country specialize in Victorian millwork.
Newly appointed judges congratulating one another in the State Senate gallery yesterday after they had been confirmed by the Senate to fill judgeships in the city's Criminal Courts.

The prostate operation President Reagan is scheduled to undergo on Jan. 5 is one of the most common performed in the United States. Although all surgery has some degree of risk, doctors do not regard the procedure as particularly dangerous. The death rate in a national survey was seven-tenths of 1 percent. It is the second such operation for the 75-year-old President, who underwent prostate surgery in 1967. Perhaps up to 10 percent of men who undergo prostate surgery for the first time will require similar surgery a second time. Urologists are now in a dispute with Federal Medicare and other health insurance officials who say they will pay for only one prostate operation in a person's lifetime.

Neutrinos, the most bizarre of subatomic particles, took on a new aura of mystery today with the presentation of information obtained from almost 20 years of monitoring deep within a South Dakota gold mine. The data, described at a meeting of astrophysicists here, could be explained if neutrinos were slightly magnetic, something that current theory rules out. The ability of neutrinos to pass through almost unlimited matter has been attributed in part to their lack of electromagnetic properties. Proof that they carryied a charge would prompt a re-evaluation of many theories of particle physics.

Arizona, Tennessee, Nevada and Florida are leading the nation in producing new jobs, while 11 states with economies dependent on energy or agriculture have fewer people at work than a year ago, the Labor Department has reported. Releasing state-by-state employment data for October, the department's Bureau of Labor Statistics said Tuesday that Alaska, Idaho, Louisiana, Montana, Oklahoma and Wyoming lost more than 2 percent of their jobs over the previous 12 months. Other states with job losses over the year were Iowa, North Dakota, West Virginia, Texas and Vermont.

Alexander M. Haig Jr., former Secretary of State and White House chief of staff, has been taking a low-key approach to the 1988 Republican Presidential nomination for several months now, but that may be drawing to a close. Tonight more than 100 potential supporters of his candidacy, financial and political, from 17 states are expected to gather at his home in McLean, Va., for a reception and dinner.
BASKETBALL NETS VS. KNICKS, at Madison Square Garden, 7:30 P.M. (TV - MSG, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 7:20 P.M.; WNEW 1130, 7:30 P.M.) HOCKEY ISLANDERS VS.

A Washington woman apparently opposed to the message on a pair of posters placed on a lampost on Connecticut Avenue carefully covered them over with blue paint. She then thoughfully attached her own sign, which said: WET PAINT.

Representative Lee H. Hamilton, who was named today to head the House's special committee to investigate the Iran arms affair, is in the position of being the soldier leading the generals. But there are few other people in the House who would be considered up to the job. Of the eight other Democrats on the new committee, one is the House majority leader, Thomas S. Foley, and five are chairman of standing committees. One is Dante B. Fascell, chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee, on which Mr. Hamilton serves. Mr. Fascell first opposed the idea of a special committee and then, when there was going to be one, sought the chairmanship.

The former Arizona leader of the Civilian Materiel Assistance, a paramilitary group, turned himself in to Federal agents in Tucson yesterday, a day after he was indicted on firearms charges resulting from a prior drug conviction. Two indictments were unsealed Tuesday involving the former leader, J. R. Hagan, who was released on a $2,500 personal bond after appearing before United States Magistrate Raymond Terlizzi. Mr. Hagan, who is to be arraigned Dec. 29, was charged with two counts of felony possessions of firearms, said Daniel Knauss, an Assistant United States Attorney in Tucson. Mr. Hagan led a patrol by 20 members of his group along the border of Mexico and Arizona last Fourth of July weekend. On the patrol, which Mr. Hagan said was aimed at stopping the flow of drugs across the border, the group was reported to have detained at least 13 illegal aliens at gunpoint.

Dr. Stanley Mandeles, a research biochemist and educator whose work focused on cancer and aging, died of cancer Monday at his home in Freehold, N.J. He was 62 years old. Dr. Mandeles was one of the first scientists to determine the order of chemical links in nucleic acid, which contains all genetic information.

WOOD is no longer enough for the surface of a stage when earth, sand, sea and turkey feathers are available. ''K2'' brought a glacial mountain to Broadway, Peter Brook had tons of soil delivered to the Vivian Beaumont Theater for ''Carmen'' and Tommy Tune and Twiggy danced in water in ''My One and Only.'' The feathers appeared in Ping Chong's ''Angels of Swedenborg,'' simulating a heavenly cloud on stage at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. All these and others called for actors (and dancers) to be nimble-footed. The drift toward sand, a cycle that probably began with Edward Albee's ''Seascape,'' continued this season with ''Neon Psalms,'' which took place in a stretch of the Mojave Desert. Currently there is Tina Howe's ''Coastal Disturbances,'' which is situated on a beach on Cape Cod. In the case of ''Coastal Disturbances,'' the beach is essential to the story. One crucial scene calls for the hero, a lifeguard, to bury the heroine up to her head in sand. Watching the show, I wondered where the sand came from - and the difficulty in carrying it up flights of stairs to the Second Stage's upper-story theater. Perhaps it was transported by sand-hands who specialize in scene-sifting.

Hunched over a table in the ornate National Hotel, Senator Gary Hart and an official of the Supreme Soviet were engaged in delicate negotiations. What the Democrat had envisioned as a quick pilgrimage to Yasnaya Polyana, the homestead of Leo Tolstoy, now loomed on his schedule as a marathon luncheon fete by Communist party officials in nearby Tula, 130 miles south of Moscow. The trip threatened to cut into a meeting here with would-be Jewish emigrants and a bit of ice skating in Gorky Park. Could the luncheon be, ah, shortened? the Senator asked. What if he canceled the trip altogether? Would there be ''political unpleasantness''?

To the Editor: William J. Stern's sweeping attack on minority business programs is an example of a harmful insensitivity to minority entrepreneurial efforts prevalent in New York City. While enlightened individuals may, with pure motive, debate the merits of such programs, Mr. Stern's position contributes little to such debate. He implies that minority-business programs lure minority individuals into becoming entrepreneurs when they are not interested in being entrepreneurs. As a lawyer, I can assure Mr. Stern that many minority individuals want the chance to own and manage a business and to have reasonable access to business opportunities.

First Jersey Securities charged huge markups this year in the trading of two securities, and may have violated securities and fraud statutes, a court-appointed consultant said. A report by the consultant, Benjamin L. Lubin, was filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan last Friday; a copy was obtained yesterday.
