Mr. Lubin, an independent securities industry consultant, was appointed by a Federal District Court in 1985 to review First Jersey's trading practices and to make recommendations about how they might be improved. The court, which appointed the consultant as part of the settlement of earlier fraud charges against First Jersey, has the right to force the brokerage to change its practices.

Last Sunday was a dismal one for followers of the Cincinnati Bengals, who were routed at home by archrival Cleveland in an important divisional game. For a few fans who had begun the day in particularly high spirits, though, the outcome was even worse. After issuing warnings before three prior games, Cincinnati police officers wrote up $50 citations against eight people caught drinking in tailgate parties near Riverfront Stadium.
To the Editor: New York State environmental officials, you report (news story, Nov. 28), recommend that an upstate sewage plant discontinue chlorination. I oppose the proposal.

The driver of a bus that plunged into a river and killed 21 elderly people May 30 was charged Tuesday with 21 counts of felony vehicular manslaughter. The driver, Ernst August Klimeck, was also charged with 21 misdemeanor manslaughter counts. He was ordered to appear in Mono County Justice Court in Mammoth Lakes on Jan. 26, the District Attorney said.

THE scene is the weekly session of News and Views, one of about 80 study groups offered at the Institute for Retired Professionals, an adult education program at the New School for Social Research. In a lecture hall 75 men and women - attorneys, professors, business people - are discussing current events. The talk turns to cocaine abuse, and a social worker tells of her experiences with drug dealers and their motives. Her remarks goad a lawyer formerly with the Department of Labor to defend Government enforcement efforts.

France has parachuted several tons of food, munitions and fuel to northern Chad to help local forces fighting against armored Libyan columns moving into the area, the French Defense Ministry announced today. The move came after a request for help by President Hissen Habre, who is supported by France and who, in an interview published in Le Monde on Tuesday, asked both France and the United States for help to repell new Libyan thrusts. Mr. Habre's Government accused the Libyans of sending three armored columns into Tibesti in northern Chad, to destroy the forces of a former Libyan ally, Goukouni Oueddei, who apparently switched sides in the long Chadian civil war several weeks ago.

Governor Cuomo and key lawmakers, acceding to a plea from Attorney General Robert Abrams and State Comptroller Edward V. Regan, agreed today to raise the salaries of those two officials to $110,000 a year, from $85,000. The increases were in a bill that would go before the current special legislative session.

OF course, almost nothing happens in ''The Widow Claire,'' the latest Horton Foote play to reach a New York stage. In keeping with his writing habits of four decades, the author of ''The Trip to Bountiful'' and ''Tender Mercies'' whisks us into the fictional small Texas town of Harrison and sets his characters about their diurnal business. ''The Widow Claire,'' a 95-minute anecdote in one act, describes only a single long summer night of 1911. Horace Robedaux (Matthew Broderick), a poor but ambitious 21-year-old about to enroll in a six-week business course in Houston, spends the eve of his departure courting the title character (Hallie Foote), a 27-year-old widow with several suitors and two rambunctious kids. Daybreak brings Horace's leave-taking and an exchange of farewells so formal one might wonder whether the couple had in fact stolen a few chaste kisses under the new moon of the night before.

Call it the Meeting of the Miserable. Or maybe the Crummy Classic. Whatever the term, it couldn't go far enough to describe the game tonight at Madison Square Garden, where the Knicks and the Nets, two of professional basketball's worst teams, meet for the second time this season. The only certainty is that one team will experience a feeling that has eluded it for much of the year -the thrill of victory. ''I'm excited about it,'' said Gerald Wilkins, the Knicks' energetic guard. ''We need to start winning some games now.''

A judge has ordered a city-run nursing home on Roosevelt Island to readmit a wheelchair-bound paraplegic whom it discharged one night last month by leaving him and his belongings on a sidewalk in lower Manhattan. The judge, David B. Saxe of State Supreme Court in Manhattan, while acknowledging that the man was ''unpopular'' with hospital personnel, said he had been ''railroaded'' by officials of Goldwater Memorial Hospital. In issuing an order to the hospital last Friday to readmit the 52-year-old man, William Blackman, to the nursing home where he had lived for five years, the judge said he was ''astonished'' at the methods used to discharge him.

Debt * Gannett Co. filed a shelf registration for up to $750 million of debt securities through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers. * Midland Bank is issuing 500 million francs of 10-year bonds at a price of 98.78.

THIS year Hanukkah, the Jewish celebration known as the Festival of Lights, begins the evening of Dec. 26. Traditionally on each of the eight nights of Hannukah, candles are lighted with another candle, called the shamas.

* Terry R. Alday, Richard Baty and Jack C. Sperling have been appointed senior vice presidents at Saatchi & Saatchi Compton. * Nikolai B. Pronovich and Susan H. Royer have been named senior vice presidents at Young & Rubicam, New York. * Mark Goldstein has been appointed executive vice president of marketing at Faberge USA.

There were early signs that this night at Madison Square Garden would be different. First, before the game was a minute old, Ron Greschner made a pass that was so fine, it barely squeezed between two Washington skaters and right to Mike Ridley's stick. Ridley sped in alone and scored. The Rangers have rarely looked so fine. Moments later, Tony McKegney rammed Greg Adams into the boards. The Rangers kept ramming all night long. Rarely have they been so ferocious.

IT costs so much to keep most houses warm in winter that it makes good sense to do everything possible to economize. So much has been written about building energy-efficient, superinsulated houses that many feel this is the only solution - yet for most homeowners it is really not practical. They live in houses built years ago and are basically quite happy with them and have neither the money nor the inclination to build anew or to undertake major renovations. Fortunately, any homeowner can do a number of things to improve heating efficiency. There are basically two problems to tackle: Be sure your furnace or boiler and your complete heating system are operating at maximum efficiency and make certain that most if not all of the heat generated stays inside where it belongs and is not lost to the outside.

Three more people were reported killed in scattered sectarian clashes as army and police forces eased their curfew slightly but continued to patrol riot-torn sections of this port city. The death toll was reported to be about 160 in rioting since Sunday, including seven additional deaths reported today resulting from injuries sustained earlier. The four days of killings have marked the worst outburst of ethnic violence in Karachi since the Hindu-Moslem riots at the time of independence and partition between Pakistan and India in 1947.

The United States Football League suffered what could be the final blow in its effort to resume competition after a ruling by Judge Peter K. Leisure in United States District Court. Judge Leisure ruled against the U.S.F.L. in its attempt to break the National Football League into two independent conferences and remove it from at least one television network.

The Federal Reserve Board will not begin considering First Interstate Bancorp's application to acquire the BankAmerica Corporation until Feb. 2 at the earliest, it was disclosed today. Robert Parry, the president and chief executive of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, informed BankAmerica of the decision in a letter, parts of which were released by BankAmerica today. First Interstate was also informed, Federal Reserve and First Interstate officials indicated.

A state-city panel studying the New York City corruption scandal urged Governor Cuomo yesterday to establish a special commission with subpoena power to investigate corruption and ethics in the state and local governments. A top aide to Mr. Cuomo said the Governor would establish ''some version'' of such a commission. The recommendation of the State-City Commission on Integrity in Government, which was appointed jointly by Mr. Cuomo and Mayor Koch in March, was part of its final report. [ Excerpts, page D20. ] The 16-member commission is headed by Michael I. Sovern, president of Columbia University, and includes two members of Mr. Cuomo's administration and two members of the Koch administration. Mr. Sovern said it voted unanimously yesterday to recommend a new commission with the power to subpoena witnesses and documents, a power Mr. Sovern's commission lacked. 'All the Staff It Needs' Nearly half the members of the Sovern commission have protested that it did too little to prevent corruption, and cited budget and staff constraints along with the lack of subpoena power. The commission's report said a new panel, expected to complete its work in one to two years, should have ''a large budget and all the staff it needs,'' although no specific budget figure was proposed.

AS if Christmas shopping, card-writing and party-going weren't enough to deal with, this is also the season to be inundated with friends and relatives from out of town, all bent on packing as much sightseeing and as many performances of ''The Nutcracker'' and the ''Messiah'' into one visit as the human body can endure. The demands of the season are fierce; even resolute stay-at-homes find themselves battling hordes of shoppers by day and juggling too many festivities every night, and visitors who want to be shown around only accelerate the hectic pace. However, New York offers a rich array of pleasures, and many of those whose work helps create the cultural life of the city are delighted to share their vision with friends passing through. All decked out in stars and spangles, its usual energy level revved up even higher, New York doesn't need snowflakes to seem like a magical place in December. Some New Yorkers have actually worked out a standard itinerary. Sidney Lumet gets excited just talking about his routine - and not surprisingly, he approaches the responsibility of introducing New York to visitors with the highly focused visual sense one might expect of a longtime film director.

Martin L. Sokol, an authority on opera and recordings and the general director of the Bel Canto Opera, died at Roosevelt Hospital Thursday morning of a heart attack. He was 56 years old and lived in Manhattan.

Tommy Davis, who kicked 234 consecutive extra points from 1959 to 1965 when he was with the San Francisco 49ers, blames his failure to stop smoking for the lung cancer now threatening his life. ''I'm taking it day by day,'' Davis, 52 years old, a punter and place-kicker on the 49ers from 1959-69, told The Santa Rosa Press Democrat in an interview published yesterday.

ONE of two versions of a letter written by Albert Einstein on Aug. 2, 1939, to President Franklin D. Roosevelt - the letter that sparked the American effort to build the atomic bomb - will be auctioned today at Christie's. The signed, 25-line typewritten document, urging Roosevelt to coordinate research on nuclear energy, is 20 lines shorter than the one hand-delivered to the White House on Oct. 11, 1939. The longer version has been in the Franklin D. Roosevelt Library at Hyde Park, N.Y., since 1945. Einstein wrote both versions at the instigation of Dr. Leo Szilard, a Hungarian-born physicist who helped develop the atomic bomb. In his hand-penned note to Dr. Szilard in German - which will accompany the letter up for sale - Einstein said he preferred that the longer, more detailed version be sent. The shorter letter remained in Dr. Szilard's family after his death in 1964, and was acquired recently by another owner, the consignor, who has not been identified. Christie's estimates the letter will sell for $60,000 to $80,000.

To the Editor: The clandestine funneling of Iranian funds for military aid to the contras fighting Nicaragua has been widely and rightly condemned. But it's important to remind ourselves of why these activities had to be carried out in secret in the first place. Congress, until its cowardly vote of $100 million in military and nonmilitary assistance this year, had made such aid illegal, reflecting the great popular resistance to financing this war.

The cellist Sharon Robinson will play works by Marcello, Brahms, Bach and Victor Herbert and the New York premiere of Alan Shulman's ''Kol Nidre'' at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue, tomorrow night at 8. Tickets are $11 to $15. Information: 996-1100.

Numerous educational changes aimed at reducing the role of Federal and state government in local schools will be put into effect on a trial basis in 16 school districts in eight states, William J. Bennett, the Secretary of Education, announced today. The pilot project, developed by the National Governors Association last summer, also urges students, parents and school officials to play a greater role in helping form school policy. Mr. Bennett called the governors' report the ''single most important event in American education in the last several years.''

Faced with a sluggish economy and the loss of investment tax incentives, businesses plan to increase capital spending by just two-tenths of 1 percent percent next year, the Commerce Department said today. The small increase would follow a sharp cutback this year.

Some Washington organizations find it almost impossible to make a mailing without also making a statement. The Cato Institute, a research group of libertarian tendencies, has inscribed its holiday card: ''Wishing You Peace and Free Enterprise.''

Holding that the State Constitution provides broader protection for freedom of expression than the United States Constitution, the New York Court of Appeals ruled unanimously yesterday that an adult bookstore could not be ordered closed because homosexual and heterosexual sex acts had been committed by customers in the store. The decision, in effect, supersedes a United States Supreme Court ruling that the Erie County District Attorney could legally seek a court order to close the Village Book and News Store in Kenmore, a Buffalo suburb, for a year to prevent ''indecent and illegal sexual acts'' on the premises. The public health code under which the court order was sought calls for a one-year closing. In its ruling yesterday, the state's highest court declared that the Supreme Court decision ''cannot be considered dispositive in determining the scope of this State's constitutional guarantee of freedom of expression.''

The Soviet Union's multiethnic character has long been the Government's public boast and its private burden. Although more than 90 separate peoples are listed in the 1985 Soviet statistical yearbook, ethnic Russians and their Slavic cousins continue to dominate the ruling Communist Party. This domination, and three generations of erratic, two-track Communist policies that have sometimes allowed limited scope for ethnic pride and other times have singled out ethnic groups for brutal persecution, have left many of these groups with a festering but not always focused resentment. But in Alma-Ata, the capital of Soviet Kazakhstan, the focus of the resentment that led to riots Wednesday and today seemed clear. A leader strongly identified as a native son of this Moslem republic of 16 million people was ousted from the top political post and replaced by an ethnic Russian.

The jury in the trial of a Manhattan makeup artist accused in the razor slashing of a model last summer began its deliberations last night at State Supreme Court in Manhattan, but failed to reach a verdict. The jury of nine woman and three men began deliberating on the case just before 9 P.M., after a full day of final arguments in the case.

Investor demand for corporate and mortgage securities remained strong enough for investment bankers to offer several new issues yesterday, while prices of Treasury issues were little changed in lethargic trading. In the ''junk bond'' market, officials at Salomon Brothers Inc. said they planned to offer about $700 million of debt secuities today for ANAC Holding and ANAC Merger. The ANAC financing, which will finance the purchase of Revco, a large drugstore company, is the second large junk bond financing of the week, following a $510 million offering of Fruehauf Holdings by Merrill Lynch. Salomon declined to identify the yields for the new issues before the registration statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission was declared effective.

William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, underwent surgery today at Georgetown University Hospital here for removal of a tumor from the left side of his brain, the hospital said. The tumor, a lymphoma, meaning it involves the lymph system, was presumed to be malignant by medical experts. But the results of tests to determine whether it is cancerous will not be made known until next week. Mr. Casey, who is 73 years old and has been head of the Central Intelligence Agency since the start of the Reagan Administration in 1981, was said to be in stable condition and ''doing well'' after the surgery, which lasted from 7:40 A.M. to 1 P.M., according to a statement by the hospital.

The Giants have a 13-2 record and the Green Bay Packers are 4-11. The Giants have won eight straight games and have clinched their division title. The Packers started the season by losing their first six games, and things have been so bad that they have not won a game in Green Bay. Obviously, the Giants should beat the Packers here Saturday in their final game of the National Football League's regular season. And the Giants should win if they control the Packers' most dangerous weapon -the blitz.

Two suburban police officers were charged today with torturing a 17-year-old suspect with a stun gun, and the district attorney said the entire Huntington Park department was under investigation. ''The Huntington Park Police Department has a record that is frankly an embarrassment to all of law enforcement,'' District Attorney Ira Reiner said at a news conference. The officers, William Lustig Jr., 31, and Robert Rodriguez, 25, were charged with torturing the youth, suspected of theft, to obtain a confession.

A 73-year-old political administrator who built his career as Hanoi's representative in the south before and after the takeover of Saigon was named head of the Communist Party of Vietnam today. The election of Nguyen Van Linh to the top party post was announced in Hanoi during the closing session of the Sixth Communist Party Congress. It makes him the country's most powerful figure and the first ruler not to be a member of Ho Chi Minh's inner circle. Mr. Linh replaces Truong Chinh, whose resignation as General Secretary of the party was announced Wednesday as part of the most sweeping reorganization of the party leadership in half a century. Five of 13 Politburo members have lost their seats in the last two days.

A court in Rwanda convicted an American wildlife researcher in his absence today of murdering Dian Fossey, a gorilla expert, at her camp a year ago. The three judges delivered the verdict against the researcher, Wayne Richard McGuire, 34 years old, of Hazlet, N.J. Conviction carries a sentence of death, but Mr. McGuire has returned to the United States, which has no extradition treaty with Rwanda.

BASKETBALL HOUSTON ROCKETS VS. TRAIL BLAZERS, at Portland, 10:30 P.M. (TV -WTBS, 10:30 P.M.) FOOTBALL LOS ANGELES RAMS VS. 49ERS, at San Francisco, 8 P.M. (TV - Cahnnel 7, 8 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 8 P.M.) ARKANSAS STATE VS.

In the last six years, the apartment building at 215 West 116th Street in Harlem has been sold five times, its price rising from $6,000 to more than $600,000. The fortunes of the building's tenants, meanwhile, have at best held even, and for them, even means miserable. Once luxurious and now forlorn, long ignored but lately desired, 215 West 116th Street offers a dramatic case history of the real-estate speculation that has swept through Harlem since 1980. The number of building sales in Harlem more than doubled in five years, to 1,131 in 1985 from 503 in 1980, according to figures compiled by the Harlem Urban Development Corporation. The average price per building climbed to period. Against such a backdrop, 215 West 116th is not the exception but the rule.

FOR most of this century, the semiskilled factory worker was the emblem of American labor. The union was his strength, and he came into his salad days in the postwar years, earning for a while a middle-class wage in an almost-tenured job on the assembly line. Then the factory worker lost top billing to the service-sector employee, who accounts today for 75 percent of the nation's 101 million jobholders outside of agriculture. Service employees are not as easy to pigeonhole as factory workers. But any number of experts are trying.

George Steinbrenner received the Jack Morris offer he ''could not refuse'' today - a one-year contract with an arbitrator to determine the salary - and called it novel and innovative. However, he stopped short of accepting it, saying he would make a decision by noon Friday. Morris, one of baseball's premier pitchers, and Richard Moss, his lawyer, met with Steinbrenner for 70 minutes, then flew to New York to await the decision of the Yankees' owner. Steinbrenner said last week that the prospect of signing Morris as a free agent was tempting, and he seemed tempted following the meeting. But he also raised a serious reservation about the arbitration procedure, and that reluctance could dissuade him from adding the 21-game winner to the Yankees' shaky staff.

The experimental plane Voyager passed the halfway mark yesterday in an attempt circle the globe without refueling. The pilots, Dick Rutan and Jeana Yeager, were encouraged by new calculations that indicated they would have enough fuel to complete their flight. They soared past the halfway point at 10:30 A.M. over the Indian Ocean, according to Lee Herron, a spokesman for the ground crew. They were 920 miles east of Somalia and traveling at a speed of 108 miles an hour.

To the Editor: William Safire's column ''The Electronic Informer'' (Dec. 4) states that the Government can wire consenting informants and send them out to tape their conversations with anybody else. In this manner any of us, no matter how much above suspicion, can be overheard by the government and even tempted into commission of a crime. Mr. Safire blames the Supreme Court for making this state of affairs legal. This is not the whole story. If the Supreme Court declines to hold that the Constitution restricts a given police practice, Congress still has the power to enact regulations of its own choosing. Congress could pass a statute that, say, requires a magistrate's initial authorization before an informant could transmit or record a conversation, or try to induce another person to commit a crime. The investigator running the show could be required to prove to the judge that there are reasonable grounds in the first place to believe the target may not be entirely law-abiding.

For some time visitors accustomed to stopping here in the foothills of the Ozarks to rent canoes to float down the scenic Meramac River have been exposed to a mystery. Traffic bustles along once-quiet Route 19, once-empty storefronts in malls along its shoulders are busy shops now, and from light poles hang banners exclaiming ''Viva Cuba!'' For the many who wonder, Prof. David Hentzel, chairman of the economics department at the nearby Rolla campus of the University of Missouri, has an explanation. ''It's a miracle,'' he says. But that also calls for elaborations, and the many Missourians who played a role are quick to provide them.

To the Editor: A front-page article by United Press International (Nov. 10) reported our sinking of two Icelandic whaling vessels that are violating the international moratorium on whaling. The final sentence said Sea Shepherd members had been arrested last summer for ''pouring gasoline on seaborne policemen'' in the Danish Faeroe Islands.

The lymphoma that was removed yesterday from the left side of the brain of William J. Casey, the Director of the Central Intelligence, was once rarely diagnosed. Such diagnosis is now occurring with increasing frequency, but it still makes up only about 2 percent of all brain tumors. Medical experts say it may take several days to determine what, if any, physical and mental deficits the 73-year-old Mr. Casey will suffer on a long-term basis. The lymphoma is presumed to be malignant. Final results of the tests will determine whether the lymphoma is cancerous and what type of lymphoma it is, according to a statement issued at Georgetown Hospital in Washington after Mr. Casey's five-hour operation.

At first glance Michel Camdessus, the International Monetary Fund's new managing director, seems to resemble no one so much as the man he is succeeding, Jacques de Larosiere. But the similarity is misleading. Both are typical high fliers in the French civil service, brilliant graduates of France's elite Ecole Nationale d'Administration who made their careers in the Finance Ministry. Both climbed to the top, holding the prestigious post of Directeur du Tresor, the Finance Ministry's senior civil service job. They are close in age: Mr. Camdessus is 53 years old, Mr. de Larosiere, 57.

Charles Ryskamp, director of the Pierpont Morgan Library for 17 years, will be the new director of the Frick Collection, beginning next June. He replaces Everett Fahy, the Frick's director since 1973, who will move to the Metropolitan Museum as chairman of its European paintings department. Mr. Ryskamp, who also is a professor at Princeton University, is known in the museum world not only as a first-rate scholar and exhibition organizer but also as a vigorous fund-raiser. Since 1980, while major repair programs costing several million dollars were in progress and more than $1.5 million had to be raised annually for basic operations, the Morgan's endowment has more than tripled, from about $11 million to more than $38 million.

IN today's art world, Hans Haacke may be not only inevitable but also indispensable. With the money now invested in art, with the growing corporate and political involvement, with a new breed of collector who approaches art as something to display, like jewelry, or barter, like stocks, it is logical that some artists want no part of art making as usual. Of the artists who are determined to preserve their independence, to define art within a social and political context - and to ask, what is it about art and its institutions that is so attractive to political and business interests? - Haacke is the most influential. His mixed-media works are consistent, meticulous, witty and perverse. They are puritanical. They are not flexible. They are not about empathy and doubt.
The Image Group at Wells, Rich, Greene, which is working on several assignments from Warnaco, has got an additional assignment.

FIRST of all, Christopher Hart was born the year it opened. That was 1948. Then, last year, he saw it at the Old Vic in London and, he said, ''here was the quintessential American backstage story, and the English were having a ball, howling with laughter even though they didn't recognize a lot of the references.'' Not the least of the whole thing was the fact that Mr. Hart's father, Moss Hart, wrote ''Light Up the Sky,'' and that it hadn't been done on a major stage in New York since its original production. As of May 5, it will be back on Broadway, after a seven-week run at Robert Fryer's Ahmanson Theater in Los Angeles. Peter Falk, television's ''Columbo,'' who was last seen on Broadway in 1972 in ''The Prisoner of Second Avenue,'' and Elaine Stritch, who was in the 1970 production of ''Company,'' will co-star. Ellis Rabb, whose credits include ''You Can't Take It With You,'' has been signed to direct. Mr. Hart, who was associate producer of ''Blood Knot'' and part of the producing group of ''Song & Dance,'' is putting the whole thing together.

A group of elected officials yesterday proposed developing a computer system to keep track of city contracts, and the Koch administration responded that it would begin its own version of such a system next week. Administration officials said the Department of Investigation would distribute questionnaires that contractors bidding on jobs worth $100,000 or more would be required to fill out and return.

The death toll in the crash of a Soviet airliner Friday in East Berlin, which carried 82 people, rose to 71 with the death of a 17-year-old East German girl, the state-run East German news agency A.D.N. reported today. An East German Government inquiry Tuesday blamed the pilot, who it said had violated landing rules, for the crash. The entire nine-member Soviet crew died in the crash.

The Pentagon, responding to the Russians' description of how they might attack a space-based missile defense system, said today that ''there are a variety of ways'' in which the system can retain its effectiveness. The Defense Department statement came in reaction to reports about a Soviet book that broadly explained plans to neutralize the proposed missile defense system, known officially as the Strategic Defense Initiative and popularly called ''Star Wars.'' The most significant aspect of the Soviet study may be its emphasis on a direct attack to destroy the defensive shield in the earliest moments of a nuclear war. Such ''defense suppression'' attacks are different from countermeasures meant to insure that long-range nuclear weapons can penetrate or evade the missile defenses that may eventually be deployed by the United States.

He still has some soreness from his encounter with the police in Tampa, Fla., Saturday night, but Dwight Gooden's spirits were reported to have been buoyed yesterday by an outpouring of public support and the start of Federal inquiries into his charges of police brutality. ''I've had more than 500 calls from Dwight's fans in New York - half of them from whites - offering to help him any way they can,'' said Bob Gilder, the head of the Tampa chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. ''And when I told Dwight about them, his eyes lit up like a Christmas tree. He's very appreciative.'' Gilder met with Gooden during the day. He said the Mets' star pitcher was also cheered that the local office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation had begun an inquiry into his charges of police brutality and that an official from the Department of Justice's Community Affairs division in Miami had been sent to Tampa to conduct a separate investigation into the circumstances surrounding the arrest of Gooden and four companions late Saturday night.

Reflecting deep divisions between the chairman and the two new members of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, the agency voted today to extend for only two and a half months a limit on direct investments in real estate development by thrift institutions. The action extended a regulation, first passed in January 1985, that restricts to a maximum of 10 percent of assets the investments in real estate development by savings and loan associations. Thrift institutions can seek approval from the bank board to exceed the limit. The direct investment regulation, as it is called in the industry, has been bitterly debated for months, pitting the more aggressive members of the industry against more traditional lenders that tend to concentrate on home mortgage lending and not real estate development.

''Who authorized it, how broadly knowledge of it extended within the United States Government and to what uses such funds were actually put, I cannot say, and I do not believe the committee has sufficient evidence to be able to draw firm conclusions.'' - Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont. [ A16:4. ]

The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it would take a charge of $250 million or more in the fourth quarter because of the early retirement of 10,000 workers. The computer giant also said it saw ''no signs of improvement'' in its business conditions worldwide. I.B.M.'s stock dropped $1.375 yesterday, to $125.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

Flashlegs, an Italian maker of women's designer hosiery, has retained AC& R Advertising as its first American ad agency. According to the agency, part of Ted Bates Worldwide, the Saatchi & Saatchi subsidiary, the billings will be about $1 million. Initial plans call for ''heavy use'' of television and fashion magazines, the agency said.

ANTIQUES collectors this holiday season are shopping for American and European period furnishings in new places that are upstairs, in town-house settings and hidden away in converted mansions. This is because antiques dealers are on the march again - moving northward and into more discreet spaces, where their presence is acknowledged by little more than a sign on the door. In recent months, three major New York dealers - Stair & Company, Juan Portela and Margot Johnson - have relocated in uptown spaces. Two others -Jordan Volpe Gallery and Bernard and S. Dean Levy - have announced that they will follow suit in 1987. The decisions to relocate were motivated in every case by real-estate concerns and a desire for more suitable addresses on the Upper East Side. Each dealer's strategies were, however, as different as the merchandise they stock and the style of the galleries they operate.

The head of Agence France-Presse resigned today after an eight-day strike by journalists that brought the agency virtually to a halt. Following the resignation, journalists voted to return to work. But they said they were only ''suspending'' their action until a new president came in.

The Atlanta Braves have withdrawn their original offer to Bob Horner, believed to be about $3.5 million for two years, and Bucky Woy, his agent, said the first baseman who is a free agent will continue to pursue a contract with other teams. Horner reportedly was seeking a four-year deal worth $2 million annually.

The White House chief of staff and a former national security adviser today stood by their contradictory accounts of when President Reagan approved Israel's sale of American arms to Iran in 1985. The issue, involving testimony by Chief of Staff Donald T. Regan and Robert C. McFarlane, is important because Mr. Reagan and other current Administration officials have said the President did not approve Israel's arms sales in advance. Only in January 1986 did he sign a special finding approving such sales. Mr. McFarlane, the former national security adviser, insists that Mr. Reagan gave oral advance approval for the Israeli arms shipments. The extent of the President's involvement at the beginning of the arms deals 16 months ago was one of the issues left unresolved today as the Senate Intelligence Committee concluded its closed hearings and the House Intelligence Committee neared the end of its separate investigation.

Friday CELTIC SOUNDS The World Music Institute, a nonprofit organization dedicated to presenting the finest in traditional and contemporary music from around the world, needs $75,000 to continue its programming, and some friends have joined forces to help the institute meet its bills. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8, the Washington Square Church, 135 West Fourth Street, will present benefit concerts for the institute. Tonight's program features traditional and Celtic music by the group Nightnoise, which includes some of the most respected musicians in the flourishing Celtic music movement. Triona Ni Dhomhnaill (vocals, clavinet, synthesizer) and Micheal O'Domhnaill (guitar, vocals) are both veterans of the Bothy Band, the seminal Celtic revival group. The quartet is rounded out by the violinist Billy Oskay and the jazz flutist Brian Dunning. The Clan, which shares the bill with Nightnoise, makes Irish folk-rock that is stylistically descended from Steeleye Span and Fairport Convention. Tomorrow night, Inkhay, Aires Colombianos and the duo of Jeff Rehab and Tiberio Nascimento will be on the program. Those groups will present music of South America. Admission each night costs $12. The number for more information is 362-3366.

CLIVE DONNER, the British director, has come up with one television ''classic'' in the production of ''A Christmas Carol,'' starring George C. Scott as Scrooge. He is evidently trying for a second with ''Babes in Toyland,'' the new three-hour movie having its debut on NBC tonight at 8. Made in West Germany as a co-production of the Finnegan/Pinchuk Company, Orion Television and Bavaria Atelier G.m.b.H., this is still another reworking of the operetta by Victor Herbert and Glen MacDonough. Say this for the new effort: it is no worse than the 1961 movie that starred Tommy Kirk and Annette Funicello. That one lasted 105 minutes. On the other hand, Mr. Donner's ambitious production is not nearly as diverting as the 1934 Laurel and Hardy interpretation. That one originally ran for 79 minutes. Perhaps when it comes to certain kinds of ''family entertainment,'' less really is more.

Iran-contra affair or not, says the Soviet leader, Mikhail Gorbachev, he still wants a nuclear arms pact with the United States and is prepared to make further compromises. ''Propaganda,'' the State Department was quick to snort. Too quick.

The Senate Intelligence Committee concluded closed-door hearings and the House Intelliegence Committee neared the end of its own investigation still unable to determine how much money from the sale of United States arms to Iran was diverted to the Nicaraguan rebels, known as the contras, and who bore overall responsibility. The White House chief of staff, Donald T. Regan, and a former national security adviser, Robert C. McFarlane, again testified and again stood by their conflicting accounts about when President Reagan approved Israel's shipments of United States arms to Iran.
The executive committee of the International Auto Sport Federation (FISA) has voided the results of the San Remo Rally and declared Juha Kankkunen of Finland the world rally driving champion.

Consistency may be the most desired but least achieved aspect of play in football. That's why the Chicago Bears, who are 13-2 heading into their final game of the regular season against the Dallas Cowboys, deserve special mention. The Bears have an 11-yard lead on the Atlanta Falcons in rushing yardage for the season, and if they can maintain their advantage they would be the National Football League's best rushing team for the fourth consecutive year. No team has done that since the Bears of 1939 through 1942. Through 15 games, the Bears have rushed for 2,539 yards; the Falcons, 2,528.

Kate and Anna McGarrigle, the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street (228-6300). The annual New York appearances by the singing and songwriting sisters from Canada are spontaneous folk musicales that cover a lot of territory. Life's joys, frustrations and contradictions are discussed in songs that run from the plaintive (Anna McGarrigle's ''Heart Like a Wheel'') to the whimsical (Kate's ''Move Over Moon'') to the profound (Anna's ''Sun, Son''). The sisters' original hymns, and inspired taste in cover versions (Bob Seger's ''You'll Accompany Me''), and traditional French songs help give their concerts an aura of timelessness. Shows are tonight and tomorrow at 8:30 and 11:30 P.M., and tickets are $10. Fats Domino, the Lone Star Cafe, 61 Fifth Avenue, at 13th Street (242-1664). The 57-year-old rock-and-roll pioneer and New Orleans musical giant brings his classics ''Blueberry Hill,'' ''Ain't That a Shame,'' ''Blue Monday,'' ''I'm Walking'' and others to the relative intimacy of the Lone Star Cafe. The chemistry of the club's friendly atmosphere and Fats Domino's rollicking good-humored music ought to stir up enough warmth to heat up the chilliest December evening. Shows are at 9:30 and midnight tonight. Tickets are $25.

CHOUCROUTE ALSACIENNE, that gutsy gastronomic antifreeze from northeastern France, has been on my 10 most-wanted list for some time now. Following a tip-off from a self-appointed expert on this homey combination of smoked sausages, pork chops, sauerkraut and potatoes, I stopped by Voulez-Vous, a smart and hospitable French restaurant on First Avenue at 76th Street. Sure enough, the choucroute is a delight, combining all of the above ingredients - in quantities to sate a ravenous mountain climber - plus a section of succulent smoked chicken and a few juniper berries in the sauerkraut to lend a nice sharp aftertaste ($14.50). Try it with a glass of crisp Sancerre ($16 a bottle, from Fournier).

Are you a sophisticated single man over 50? Do you do a nifty tango or fox trot and have a way with women? Well, you might have a chance to become part of a new growth area in the travel industry. The scarcity of older men, as compared with older women, on cruise ships is encouraging the lines to provide male escort or ''charming host'' services. The men are paid for their time or given free passage in exchange for acting as partners to women on the ballroom floor, joining them for a drink in the bar, playing cards or other deck games, exchanging light banter or accompanying the women on shore excursions, especially into less savory ports of call. ''The women get a little antsy when there aren't many men around, especially on longer cruises,'' said Nancy Swasey, speaking for the Royal Viking Line, one of the companies now offering this feature. The Royal Cruise Line also promotes a host service. The Cunard Line incorporates such tasks into the duties of the older men who are added to the regular social staff on world cruises ''to give an extra layer of service,'' said Susan Alpert of Cunard. The three lines hired a total of 300 hosts this year. Other lines are said by industry officials to encourage their senior crew members to mingle with single women on board.

Reagan Administration officials are divided over the significance of three new radars under construction on the western periphery of the Soviet Union. Defense Department officials have proposed that the United States formally assert that the Soviet Union is preparing a nationwide defensive missile system, which is not allowed by the antiballistic missile treaty of 1972. The State Department is resisting such an accusation, saying the Pentagon exaggerates the significance of the western radars. The Arms Control and Disarmament Agency also takes exception to the Pentagon position, but takes the view that the new radars warrant scrutiny, officials said.

The Communications Workers of America, perhaps more than any other major union in the country, has made lifetime employment security a key goal at the bargaining table. But the huge cutback of jobs that the American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced today suggests such efforts may be fruitless. ''There's no question that job security has replaced wages and benefits as the focus of collective bargaining in the 1980's,'' said Mark de Bernardo, a labor law specialist with the United States Chamber of Commerce. ''But the jury is out whether they can implement that strategy.''

Reppresentative Beryl F. Anthony, Democrat of Arkansas, was nominated today to be chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, which raises money for the party's House candidates. Mr. Anthony, who was first elected to the House in 1978, was selected for the campaign post by Representative Jim Wright of Texas, the House Speaker-designate, and would succeed Representative Tony Coehlo, who was chosen earlier this month as the House Democratic whip.

Wetlands and peat bogs that often contain splendidly preserved ancient human remains and other artifacts are reported to be endangered worldwide. They are threatened by development and the sinking level of water under the ground, according to archeologists from around the world who met here over the last weekend. ''The lowering of water levels around the world is the biggest archeological catastrophe in the 20th century,'' said Michael Egloff, an archeologist from the University of Neuchatel in Switzerland, who was one of those attending the international conference on wetlands archeology at the University of Florida. Because of Switzerland's need for agricultural development, Mr. Egloff said that country had only a few remaining undisturbed wetland sites that could nurture fragile organic materials for thousands of years by excluding oxygen, preventing disintegration. The peat also has chemicals that preserve animal and vegetable tissue.

Ward Burns, president of J.P. Stevens & Company, yesterday was named vice chairman of the big textile company. Marvin B. Crow, an executive vice president, succeeded Mr. Burns as president. Mr. Burns, 58, remains the No. 2 executive under Whitney Stevens, the 60-year-old chairman and chief executive, according to J.R. Franklin, director of corporate public relations.

Gen. Bernard W. Rogers, the commander of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's military forces, underwent successful cancer surgery last week and will return to his duties in Europe next month, the Pentagon said today. The Pentagon released a brief statement saying the 65-year-old general had undergone surgery ''for re moval of a cancerous prostate gland.''

There was no joy in the New Brighton section of Staten Island seven years ago when the Staten Island Hospital pulled up stakes and moved to a new building miles away. The fear of neighboring homeowners was that the hospital's departure would leave a derelict property in their midst. And so it did, until this year. In the interim, the property changed hands three times. At one point, the late Robert Olnick, a major developer based in Manhattan, tried to redevelop it as condominiums. But he backed away, according to associates, when he found a lack of enthusiasm among Staten Island banks for providing financing in the area.

Mark Gastineau made an unusual admission yesterday - he feels vulnerable. The Jets' strongman, whose remarkable physique, quickness and durability led him in previous years to the Pro Bowl as the league's top sacker, blamed his problems this season on being overweight. Gastineau has played in only 10 of the 15 games this season and has only two sacks. Gastineau has been out of action for a month because of arthroscopic knee surgery, and although he is eligible to return for the game Sunday against the Bengals in Cincinnati, he will not be activated until the playoffs.

The Soviet Union was reported today to have decided to allow the wife of a dissident to leave the country for experimental cancer treatment in New York. The dissident, Naum Meiman, said today that Senator Gary Hart, in a meeting with Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze on Tuesday, was informed that his wife, Inna Kitrosskaya Meiman, would be allowed to leave. Mr. Shevardnadze reportedly did not say how soon she would be given an exit visa. Mrs. Meiman suffers from an inoperable tumor on her neck. Despite years of appeals from prominent scientists and political figures in the West, she has been denied permission to seek the specialized radiation therapy that she believes is her only hope of survival.

The Mannes Opera Workshop will present scenes from operas by Puccini, Strauss and Bizet, among others, tonight and tomorrow night at 7:30 at the Mannes College of Music, 150 West 85th Street. Admission is free. Information: 580-0210.

As he left home today shortly after 6 A.M., Col. Oliver L. North encountered one of the camera crews that have followed his every public move since the Iran crisis first became known. Colonel North, perhaps stung by Nancy Reagan's recent comments about the crisis, was more talkative today than usual, even turning to Bible quotations to explain his position to a CBS News reporter. In an interview with The Associated Press on Wednesday, Mrs. Reagan said Colonel North, a former White House aide, should come forward and testify about his part in the arms sale to Iran and the subsequent diversion of profits to Nicaraguan rebels. He has so far refused to testify, citing his constitutional right against self-incrimination. Here are excerpts from the CBS News interview: Q. What would you say to Nancy Reagan?

FOR several years, Christian Delouvrier has been a gastronomic George Bush to his own celebrated commander-in-chef, Alain Senderens of the venerable Lucas-Carton in Paris. In 1983, Mr. Senderens was hired as a periodic menu consultant to boost the reputation of Maurice, the French restaurant in the Hotel Parker Meridien on West 57th Street. He garnered most of the applause while his man in the trenches, Mr. Delouvrier, dutifully carried out orders. The Senderens connection ended last year, and Mr. Delouvrier parted with him. After a year of dallying with other consulting chefs, the restaurant finally asked Mr. Delouvrier to take the top spot on his own - and a smart move it was. In a short time he has whipped his crew into fighting shape and led them to exciting new heights, transforming Maurice into one of the preeminent luxury restaurants in New York. The dining room is still sumptuous and comfortable: it has a soaring ceiling, mirrored wall panels alternating with flowered murals, a resplendent cluster of illuminated white birch branches in the center, and generously spaced tables. Oriental-style rugs and upholstered banquettes help keep background noise to a minimum.

State and city officials said yesterday that they would investigate why it took a week for a Brooklyn family to find out that their son had died in a hospital emergency room. The son, Eric Washington, an 18-year-old from the Brownsville section, was taken from his family's apartment by ambulance late on the night of Dec. 8. The youth, who had a chronic asthma condition, was suffering an acute attack, his parents said. Results of an autopsy are still pending.
The back spasms that doctors expected to keep Paul Coffey out of the Edmonton Oiler lineup for a game or two have sidelined the All-Star defenseman for eight games.

The Soviet Union announced today that it would end its halt of nuclear testing as soon as the United States conducts its first test in 1987. A statement issued by the Government press agency Tass said that the Russians were prepared to halt testing again ''any day of any month'' if the United States were to reciprocate. Tass said that the Soviet Union's decision to end the test halt was forced by ''grave danger'' to its national security posed by the continuing American testing program. [ In Washington, a White House spokesman said: ''Whether or not the Soviets resume their nuclear testing is their business. Acceptance of the Soviet nucler testing moratorium is not in the security interests of the U.S. or our friends and allies.'' ] Soviet Test Halt Began in 1985 The Soviet Union stopped testing in August 1985 and called on the United States to join in and negotiate a permanent ban on underground testing, the only kind permitted since the 1963 treaty on a partial test ban prohibited explosions in the atmosphere, under water and in outer space.

President Reagan has ordered emergency shipments of up to $15 million in military equipment to help the Chadian Army repel attacks by Libyan troops, the State Department announced today. The department said Mr. Reagan's action was in response to an urgent request from the Government of Chad. The shipments, under the terms of the Foreign Assistance Act, do not require Congressional approval. The department's spokesman said the effort was being coordinated with France, which is also sending help to the Chadian Army.

The military said today that three people had been killed and two others wounded when Communist rebels attacked a bus. It was the most serious accusation so far that the rebels had violated a eight-day-old cease-fire. Bishop Antonio Y. Fortich, head of a bipartisan monitoring panel, said the incident, in which the military said two rebels were among the dead, ''could be a serious violation'' if confirmed.

Senator Albert Gore Jr. yesterday made public his order for a Congressional investigation into whether Dr. James C. Fletcher, head of the space agency, violated conflict-of-interest rules in awarding the contract for shuttle rockets that proved flawed and led to the Challenger disaster. The inquiry, being conducted by the General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress, is to focus on possible violations of a Presidential order on conflicts of interest as well as Federal laws on Government acquisitions and on Federal advisory committees. Dr. Fletcher, who first served as Administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration from 1971 to 1977, awarded the contract in 1973 to Morton Thiokol Inc., then known simply as Thiokol, of Brigham City, Utah. Dr. Fletcher was reappointed to head NASA after the Challenger disaster Jan. 28, in which a leaky booster made by Thiokol touched off the explosion that killed seven astronauts. Denial of Favoritism Critics have charged Dr. Fletcher with favoritism in awarding the rocket contract to a Utah concern. While vigorously denying any bias, Dr. Fletcher has said he would ''seriously consider'' removing himself from any future decisions on shuttle booster contracts.

IAN MCKELLEN is always exciting to watch, and there's a lot of him to watch in ''Wild Honey,'' Michael Frayn's ingenious new adaptation of Chekhov's first extant play. As Platonov, a village schoolmaster in provincial 19th-century Russia, the English actor spends much of the second act juggling four women (one of them his wife) while simultaneously fending off a legal action, a galloping case of the d.t.'s and a halfhearted murder attempt or two. His pants drooping, his face filthy and unshaven, his mouth gummy, Mr. McKellen has the clotted sound of James Mason's Norman Maine and looks like a derelict Pierrot on speed. If he isn't rocking in a low chair that wasn't meant to rock or undulating elastically like a human Slinky, he may well be crawling on the floor in a soiled blanket, assuming the shape of a huge mutant snail.

The Soviet Union has begun telling some Western European governments that it is prepared to join forces in combating terrorism, according to highly placed West German officials. Some experts detect Soviet concern that it and its allies are becoming overly identified with terrorist movements - and that terrorist organizations could pose long-term problems for Soviet interests. One senior West German official said that two recent trials in London and West Berlin, suggesting strongly that Syrian intelligence agents were embroiled in terrorist outrages, had prompted the latest overture, which he said had taken place in Moscow several weeks ago.
An Arab man with an ax attacked an Israeli soldier patrolling the West Bank town of Ramallah today, wounding him lightly, a military spokesman said.

A pilot program in Texas will enable businesses to verify by telephone whether prospective employees have valid Social Security numbers, the Government said today. The program, announced by Dorcas Hardy, Commissioner of Social Security, is part of the Reagan Administration's plan for administering the new immigration law, which prohibits employers from hiring illegal aliens. Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, who joined Ms. Hardy in making the announcement, said the program would help employers avoid criminal sanctions for such hiring.

THE American Telephone and Telegraph Company's announcement yesterday that it would take a pretax charge of $3.2 billion in the fourth quarter will weaken the price of the company's stock in the short run, according to several analysts. But the austerity moves promise to substantially benefit the telecommunications giant and strengthen the stock's price over the long term, these experts believe. ''A.T.&T.'s announcement was widely anticipated and should be viewed positively from a long-term prospective,'' said Harold A. Mackinney, head of the investment policy committee at the Fleet Financial Group in Providence, R.I. ''Reduced costs should allow for a modest increase in earnings in 1987,'' he added, ''and the current $1.20 annual dividend appears safe. In the mid-20's, with a yield of 4.8 percent, the stock is fairly valued.''

Lombard C. Jones, a book illustrator and briefly the managing editor of The American Mercury, died Dec. 13 at the Royal Megansett Nursing Home in North Falmouth, Mass. Mr. Jones, a resident of Sandwich, Mass., was 80 years old. Mr. Jones, born in Brooklyn, began his career as an illustrator on The Harvard Lampoon.

Frank A. Sieverts, a veteran of 24 years with the State Department, is moving to Capitol Hill. Effective Jan. 1, he will become spokesman for the Senate Foreign Relations Committee under the chairmanship of Senator Claiborne Pell, Democrat of Rhode Island. Mr. Sieverts is currently special assistant for public afffairs of the Bureau for Refugee Programs.

THE Christmas that is famous in New York is the Fifth Avenue one - with the immense illuminated snowflake at 57th and Fifth, the Christmas tree and ice-skating rink at Rockefeller Center, and the Empire State Building decked out in green and red. The scale is imperial, and people come from all over the world to see it. But in pockets scattered throughout New York, there is a less obvious, much smaller Christmas of one-man shops, narrow streets, brick houses and eccentric personalities. In these pockets, old neighborhoods that are still physically intact perpetuate 19th-century patterns of socializing - a village life within the larger city - and, during December, a Christmas season that seems antique. It is, to some extent, a shopkeeper's season, characterized by conversations over the counter and individualistic goods chosen by the people who own and run the shops. By stepping into certain stores, a visitor encounters self-contained worlds created by their owner-proprietors. Browsing among shops is a way of entering the spirit of an older holiday.

More than a third of the members of the New York Philharmonic refused to play at a free concert at a Harlem church last week because a minister of the church would not denounce the Black Muslim leader Louis Farrakhan. Most of those who declined to participate were Jewish, although another Jewish musician, the violinist Isaac Stern, decided to perform as a soloist. Forty-one of the 106 players boycotted the performance, on Dec. 9 at the Abyssinian Baptist Church at 131 West 138th Street. Several substitute musicians were hired.

The saxophonist Johnny Griffin will lead his quartet - with Harry Pickens on piano, Curtis Lundy on bass and Idris Muhammad on drums - tonight through Sunday at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, below 11th Street (255-4037). Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $10 cover and a $5 minimum.

Following are excerpts from the final report of the State-City Commission on Integrity in Government issued yesterday: We are at a crisis of confidence in government, a crisis that can only be resolved by the fullest possible disclosure of the inner workings of government. Indeed, the public apathy we have decried may itself be one of the crippling effects of the mistrust and cynicism that corruption breeds. Much was revealed at the trial of Stanley Friedman and his co-defendants. Much more will presumably be revealed in future trials.

A private plane crashed north of Houston today, killing the pilot, slicing power lines and leaving about 30,000 customers without electricity for two and a half hours. The identity of the pilot and the cause of the crash were not immediately known.

Eduardo Rey, a 27-year-old electrical worker from the state of Puebla, had crawled 30 blocks through Mexico City on his knees toward the basilica of Santa Maria de Guadalupe before the paramedics found him a mile short of his goal. He was exhausted and his knees were badly battered, but he would not give up. So the paramedics and bystanders fastened a strap under his arms and around his chest with which to hold him up while he crawled on. Finally he reached the basilica, made his way up the steps and into the crush of humanity inside - still on his knees - and prayed to the Virgin of Guadalupe.

A further drop in the dollar's value and faster economic growth in Europe and Japan will be needed to cure the enormous payments deficit of the United States, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said today. In its semiannual survey of the industrial world's prospects, the 24-nation group said that the outlook for growth and inflation had improved as a result of cheaper oil, a falling dollar and lower interest rates.

INTERNATIONAL A3-19 Two Reagan aides held firm to sharply contradictory accounts of when the President approved the sale of arms to Iran to get American hostages in Lebanon freed. The two are Donald T. Regan and Robert C. McFarlane. Page A1 News analysis: Two aides' invoking their right to remain silent has spurred debate on whether President Reagan can legally force them to testify, or whether he should even try to persuade them to do so. A16 Moscow will end its moratorium on underground nuclear testing in response to the first American test of 1987, the Kremlin said. But it offered to halt testing again if Washington agreed to reciprocate.

OPEC ministers inched closer today to an agreement to curb oil production, but it appeared that any accord would exempt Iraq. The plan under discussion by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries calls for a 7 percent reduction in total output, aimed at pushing the price of crude oil toward $18 a barrel. ''We will not be part of that agreement,'' Qassim Ahmed Taki, Iraq's oil minister, said today. OPEC officials would not discuss whether the 7 percent reduction would be made from the temporary, reduced levels agreed to in August and October or from the previous quotas.

The Thatcher Government ended its long and controversial search for an airborne early-warning defense system today by rejecting Britain's own Nimrod aircraft and announcing a billion-dollar decision to purchase Boeings from the United States. The decision maintains the dominance of the Boeing Company's Awacs in the lucrative airborne surveillance field - the use of elaborate command-post aircraft fitted with the latest in radar, computers and other detection gear to track enemy movements. An estimated $7 billion world market looms for such planes in the next decade, and the Nimrod represented the best effort of the British industry, once a leader in aircraft innovation, to crack the market and guarantee thousands of skilled jobs. Bitterness in Commons The bitterness of the failure was reflected quickly in the House of Commons when Defense Secretary George Younger announced the decision to purchase the first six Awacs, with an option for two more.

Anatoly T. Marchenko, who died in prison last week, was not an ordinary Soviet dissident. The son of illiterate railroad workers, he did not emerge from the ranks of disgruntled writers and scientists or oppose the regime because of ethnic or religious persecution. Mr. Marchenko was first arrested, in 1959, in connection with a brawl in a workers' hostel. He escaped confinement and tried to cross the Soviet border into Iran but was soon caught again and tried for treason. He was given a six year term. He had finished only the eighth grade, but he received an education in labor camp in the 1960's from intellectuals imprisoned for their political beliefs.

A. M. Rosenthal, former executive editor and now associate editor and columnist for The New York Times, is to be given the National Press Foundation's award for distinguished contributions to journalism Feb. 25 in Washington. The award, which was announced by Robert E. Farrell, the foundation's chairman, will be presented at the organization's fourth annual awards dinner.

When the Omnicom Group was formed earlier this year by BBDO International and DDB Needham Worldwide, the merged Doyle Dane Bernbach and Needham Harper Worldwide agency, all the specialty units that were part of the three were combined as Omnicom's Diversified Agency Services division, under the chairmanship of Barry E. Loughrane, the former D.D.B. head. Now all the direct-marketing specialty shops from two of them are being unified into a $100 million-in-billings unit called the Marcoa DR Group, and each of its components will take on that name.

''THIS is the only place you could possibly have a party for Bernie,'' Iris Cantor said as she greeted partygoers gathering in the Metropolitan Museum of Art to celebrate the 70th birthday of her husband, B. Gerald Cantor. No one disagreed with her choice of locale. After all, the financier endowed the Iris and B. Gerald Cantor Exhibition Hall, the B. Gerald Cantor Sculpture Galleries and the Iris and B. Gerald Cantor Roof Garden, which is to open at the museum in May. Though, as Howard Lutnick put it, ''Some of Bernie's best friends are major institutions,'' only close relatives and friends were invited. Guests had a private viewing of the Van Gogh exhibition before dinner and dancing in the Astor Court, decorated with red lanterns, 300 candles and masses of white flowers.
The Lane Company has accepted a sweetened takeover proposal from Interco Inc., the companies said today.
President Reagan gave Israel oral approval in the summer of 1985 to ship American-made arms to Iran, hoping to obtain the release of American hostages held in Lebanon.

The decision by Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter and Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North to invoke their Fifth Amendment rights to remain silent has spurred debate on whether President Reagan can legally force them to abandon those rights - or should at least try to persuade them to do so. The first question is primarily one of law: Does the President, as Commander-in-Chief, have authority to order active-duty officers to give possibly incriminating testimony about their official actions on matters of great public importance, on pain of demotion, dismissal or even court-martial if they refuse? The second question goes to the ambiguous place of the privilege against self-incrimination in the nation's hierarchy of values. Some see it as a bedrock principle of liberty, invocation of which should never be penalized or even criticized; others see it as a limited safeguard against official abuse, to be treated grudgingly because it often shields criminals and hides the truth.

''MISS MARY,'' the new Argentine film by Maria Luisa Bemberg (''Camila''), recalls life in pre-Peronist Argentina, mostly through the eyes of an English nanny, Miss Mary (Julie Christie), who arrives in Buenos Aires in 1938 to care for the children of an aristocratic landowner and leaves in 1945, on the eve of Peron's election to the presidency. Though Miss Mary is played with a good deal of intelligence by Miss Christie, the character doesn't make a perfect periscope through which to examine such a complex social-political scene. Miss Mary's vision of the world is as clouded as the audience's understanding of her. She's a function of the film, rather than its reason for being.

David Murray Octet, Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street (242-1785). The inspiring trombonist Craig Harris and the solidly emphatic bassist Wilbur Morris are the only remaining members of earlier David Murray Octets. But the new players should take care of business nicely. Mr. Murray's writing for the Octet's five horns is a balm and a tonic in any case. And Mr. Murray is the freshest, most formidable young tenor saxophonist around. Shows are around 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M. tonight through Sunday, with a $12 cover charge and $6 minimum.

A high Italian official said today that Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter told him last spring that the White House had followed a policy of secret contacts with Libya at a time when Washington was advocating isolating the regime of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. The contacts included a controversial trip to Libya last year by the United States Ambassador to the Vatican, which was arranged with the help of the Italian Government on the assumption that the trip had been approved by the White House, according to Italian officials. Both White House and State Department officials have previously denied that the Ambassador, William A. Wilson, was authorized to carry out contacts with Libya. Today, the State Department repeated its statement that the trip by Mr. Wilson, was unauthorized.

When Donald T. Regan testified before the Senate Intelligence Committee the other day that President Reagan and Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North had never met alone, there was a shudder of relief among Republican Party officials and Reagan loyalists. But there was intense disappointment in some offices in New York and Hollywood, where agents, producers and publishers are sketching out scenes of high drama that could result in book and movie deals on the Iran crisis. Indeed, one New York literary agent who preferred to remain anonymous hopes that Mr. Regan, the White House chief of staff, turns out to be wrong about a meeting between the President and Colonel North, the National Security Council aide who was dismissed for his role in the arms sales and diversion of profits to Nicaraguan rebels. A Rambo in the Oval Office ''It would make a tremendous movie scene with the President and this sort of Rambo sitting by the fire in the Oval Office,'' the agent said excitedly. ''Imagine North telling the President: 'I'm the guy who got the fellows off the Achille Lauro for you. I'm the guy who got Arab terrorists captured for you. Now I have an even better stunt to help the hostages and the contras. Don't worry, just leave it to me.'

The Portland Trail Blazers traded Walter Berry, last season's college basketball Player of the Year, to the San Antonio Spurs yesterday for another rookie, Kevin Duckworth, a reserve center. The 7-foot, 280-pound Duckworth, who played for Eastern Illinois, was the 33d player chosen in this year's draft.

The practice of quoting anonymous sources in investigative news articles has become so widely accepted that the Saudi Arabian Embassy has reduced it to announcement form. This week, the embassy issued a five-paragraph press release about ''the U.S.-Iranian arms deal'' that was entirely attributed to ''an information source.''

United States and Soviet officials agreed today to widen cooperation on environmental issues, including a joint effort to halt depletion of atmospheric ozone. At a news conference after four days of meetings, Lee M. Thomas, Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, said scientists from the two countries would meet in Moscow next month to consider what measures may be needed to halt the destruction of ozone by man-made chemicals. Yuri A. Izrael, chairman of the Soviet State Committee for Hydrometeorology and Control of the Natural Environment, said his country did not think there was sufficient evidence yet demonstrating the need to limit production of chlorofluorocarbons and other chemicals that destroy ozone in the upper atmosphere. But in response to a question he said such evidence might be presented at next month's meeting.

A proposal to build a national monument on the Mall to law-enforcement officers killed in the line of duty is getting into motion two years after Congress approved it. Jan C. Scruggs, the moving spirit behind the Vietnam Veterans Memorial, has agreed to become project director of the National Law Enforcement Officers Memorial Fund and help organize a $5 million campaign to finance the effort.

President Reagan's supporters on the right are mounting a vigorous campaign for their beleaguered hero. They say the enemy is a familiar one: those liberal critics who have simmered for six years over the success of a conservative President and a conservative movement. The investigation of the Iran arms deal, these conservatives argue, has offered the President's liberal foes an opportunity long denied them - a chance to humble Mr. Reagan and undo his political revolution. ''We recognize that this battle is being fought under the name of truth, but that's not the issue,'' argued Richard Viguerie, the conservative activist. ''These people want to undo the election results. They want to institute Walter Mondale's vision of America and not Ronald Reagan's.''

Look who's home for Christmas! Sid Caesar, no less, back on Saturday night on NBC, not quite as he was in ''Your Show of Shows,'' in which the strong suit was comedy, but in a simple, straightforward play, geared for the younger set. It goes on at 8 P.M. tomorrow.
Bows are certainly appropriate at the holiday season, and diamond and rhinestone bows may be the most appropriate of all.

The board of the Diamond Shamrock Corporation said this morning that it had unanimously rejected a $2.03 billion takeover bid by T. Boone Pickens and Mesa Limited Partnership. By the afternoon, Mesa had withdrawn its all-securities exchange offer, originally announced Dec. 3. As part of its 13-page announcement, the board of the large Dallas-based oil and gas company disclosed that it had voted to delete a significant part of its shareholders' rights plan, or ''poison pill,'' but not the entire plan, as Mesa had requested. Nevertheless, the company's action raised questions about its commitment to remain independent.

The alto saxophonist Lou Donaldson will lead a quartet tonight through Sunday at the West End Cafe, 2911 Broadway at 114th Street (666-8750). Sets begin at 9 and 10:30 P.M. and midnight and 1:30 A.M.; there is no fourth set on Sunday. There is a $6 cover and a $7.50 minimum tonight and tomorrow, a $5 cover and a $5 minimum on Sunday.
John (Jack) Zaremba, a onetime newspaper reporter who became a familiar character actor on several television series, died Monday of a heart attack at the age of 77.

Michel Camdessus, the French Government's top banker, was named managing director of the International Monetary Fund today, ending an uncommon spectacle of open campaigning by two nations for a position of power over the world economy. Mr. Camdessus (pronounced COM-de-sue) was elected unanimously by the 22-member executive board of the 151-nation lending institution, succeeding another Frenchman, Jacques de Larosiere. But he was named only after barely winning a straw vote Wednesday over the Finance Minister of the Netherlands, H. Onno Ruding. Mr. Ruding withdrew from the race just before today's vote. Mr. Camdessus, who is 53 years old, joins the I.M.F. at a moment of acute tensions over a relatively weak world economy and the seemingly intractable loan payment problems of developing debtor nations. The I.M.F. attempts to help those countries, but also tries to discipline them by requiring sometimes severe economic restraint.

BASEBALL CHICAGO (AL) - Sent Bruce Tanner, pitcher, to Oakland as completion of a trade in which Chicago received Donnie Hill, infielder. CLEVELAND (AL) - Sent Bryan Oelkers, Curt Wardle, Don Schulze and Jose Roman, pitchers, to Buffalo of the American Association.

A Federal Bankruptcy Court judge, Burton Lifland, has officially confirmed that the Manville Corporation's reorganization plan, positioning the company to emerge from Chapter 11 bankruptcy in late 1987, meets statutory requirements.
Bowing their heads during a benediction at ceremony at Madison Square Garden yesterday were some of the new city, housing and transit probationary officers. (NYT/Dith Pran)

Griffin O'Neal, son of the actor Ryan O'Neal, was cleared today of manslaughter in the death of Gian-Carlo Coppola but was convicted of negligently operating a boat. Mr. Coppola, 23 years old, the son of the movie director Francis Ford Coppola, was killed Memorial Day on the South River near Annapolis when a boat that Griffin O'Neal was operating went between two other boats and a tow line struck Mr. Coppola in the head. Circuit Judge Martin Wolff of Anne Arundel County also acquitted the 22-year-old Mr. O'Neal of two charges of recklessly operating a boat. But because the judge merged three negligence counts and found him guilty of that one count, the prosecutors said they were unsure of the penalty.

James E. Olson, chairman of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, as he announced yesterday in Manhattan that an 8.5 percent reduction in the work force is to be completed by 1988. Page D1. (AP)

Following is the text of a statement released today by Georgetown University Hospital about William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence: Mr. William Casey, Director of the Central Intelligence Agency, underwent surgery this morning at Georgetown University Hospital. The surgery lasted from 7:40 A.M. to 1 P.M., during which time a craniotomy was performed.
The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, sold $250.1 million of 5 3/4 percent mortgage-backed securities yesterday at an average price of 78 23/32 to yield 8.26 percent.

Mark Shulman's fast rise in the retail business shows no signs of slowing down. The 37-year-old executive has been named president and chief executive of Henri Bendel, the 57th Street specialty store acquired last year by The Limited Inc. He replaces Geraldine Stutz, 62, who left in July after having been president since 1957 and who transformed the store into the symbol of New York chic. Mr. Shulman comes to Bendel from Ann Taylor, a woman's specialty store that is a division of the Allied Stores Corporation.
The tenor saxophonist Billy Harper will lead a quintet tonight and tomorrow at the Jazz Center of New York, 380 Lafayette Street (505-5660).
A firefighter on a small plane that crashed on South Los Angeles Boulevard while trying to land at a nearby airport. A pedestrian was killed and the driver of the car was injured. (UPI)
Garden State Park has canceled its $2 Million Challenge and reduced the Jersey Derby purse by $500,000 for its 1987 thoroughbred meeting in a move to help the financially ailing track.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it would eliminate 27,400 jobs and take a $3.2 billion charge against earnings, in a program to make itself more competitive in its key businesses. The job cuts will reduce A.T.&T.'s work force by 8.5 percent, to 290,000. The cuts are to be completed by 1988. The huge charge, which will cover early retirement and severance costs, write-downs in the value of some assets, and the expenses for consolidating operations, will be recorded in the current quarter. The write-down will cost $1.7 billion, after taxes. As a result, A.T.&T. warned Wall Street to expect a loss, for the three months ending Dec. 31, that will wipe out most of the telecommunications giant's profits for 1986.
