Assets of the nation's 377 money market mutual funds increased $670.7 million, to $235.54 billion, for the week ending Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

The Justice Department asserted today that a call from Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter, the former national security adviser, prompted Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d to seek a brief delay of a Federal investigation of private schemes to aid Nicaraguan rebels. Law enforcement officials have said that the Justice Department is conducting an internal investigation of the decision to ask the F.B.I. to delay its inquiry in October. The internal investigation includes F.B.I agents.

President Virgilio Barco Vargas blamed narcotics traffickers today for the killing of a prominent newspaper editor and issued decrees making it easier for the military to crack down on traffickers. The police, meanwhile, raided an apartment thought to be owned by drug traffickers today and killed five people believed linked to the slaying Wednesday night of the journalist, Guillermo Cano, the 61-year-old editor of El Espectador. In his actions, the President decreed penalties of up to eight years in prison for anyone caught with an illegal firearm used in a crime. The traffickers ''are stopping at nothing,'' he said.

The purists winced yesterday at what they saw on the America's Cup race course off Fremantle, Australia. A special fleet race for 12-Meters other than those slated for the cup semifinals later this month drew eight yachts to the starting line, and, as they rounded the leeward mark and hoisted their spinnakers, the names of advertisers took shape like letters on a circus balloon. The billboards on cloth brought a deserved stir among the spectator fleet, for they marked the end of a pristine era in which advertising, allowed during practice, had been banned from America's Cup yachts during actual competition. The beginning of that end came last month when the International Yacht Racing Union decided to give individual organizers the right to decide the issue. Since the Fremantle trials were already under way with a ban in force, officials decided to leave it that way.
A railroad car carrying nuclear wastes to a Washington State dump took a wrong turn to Minnesota, where utility officials found it parked in a small town west of Minneapolis.
Saatchi & Saatchi Compton has been named agency for Video Digest, a monthly magazine due out in January from GP Group, the same people who publish The National Enquirer.
Frenchman to Lead I.M.F. The head of France's central bank, Michel Camdessus, will direct the International Monetary Fund as it tries to alleviate the debt crisis.

In Midtown, Drivers Beware New York City expects another especially large swarm of pedestrians and motorists on the streets of midtown Manhattan today, and warns drivers to try to keep vehicles out of the area between Herald Square and Central Park. The volume of traffic in Manhattan is expected to be 100,000 higher than normal, with traffic especially heavy at the inbound Lincoln Tunnel from 7 to 9 P.M.

Some of the most powerful merchants on Fifth Avenue fired a barrage of complaints at Mayor Koch yesterday over the proliferation of illegal sidewalk peddlers outside their elegant shops at the height of the holiday season. The merchants - executives of Cartier, Tiffany, Bergdorf Goodman, Saks, the Trump Organization and others - charged that hundreds of peddlers of scarves, windup toys, cheap watches and trinkets were stealing business, evading taxes, strewing litter and destroying the ambiance of the famed thoroughfare. Calling the avenue ''a disaster'' that looked like ''Istanbul on a Sunday,'' the executives of the Fifth Avenue Merchants Association demanded tougher enforcement of peddling laws and accused the Mayor, in sometimes personal terms, of laxity and indifference. ''The Mayor is not doing his job with the peddlers,'' said Donald J. Trump, the real-estate entrepreneur whose Trump Tower soars above the avenue near 56th Street. Mr. Trump said the city's ''management of this situation is horrible, it's atrocious.''

The Haitian band Tabou Combo will appear tonight at Sounds of Brazil, 204 Varick Street, at Houston Street (243-4940). Sets begin at 11 P.M. and 1 and 2:30 A.M.; there is a $10 cover with dinner, $15 without.

A former National Security Council official, linked in an earlier report to the Iran arms affair, has denied that he was involved in or had knowledge of either Iran's purchase of American arms or the illegal dispatch of military equipment to the Nicaraguan rebels. The former official, Charles P. Tyson, left his N.S.C. post of deputy assistant to the President for coordination in April 1984.

What a difference a few years, and a few Surgeon General's reports, can make. Only yesterday the nonsmoker was perceived as odd man (or woman) out. Today, it's the smoker who sticks out. Only 30 percent of adults smoke now, and they may be feeling a bit hounded.

The New Jersey Senate gave final passage today to a bill modifying and extending the state law that limits the amount that municipal budgets may rise from year to year. The law, which was first enacted in 1976, was scheduled to expire at the end of the year. In its final voting session of the year, the Legislature also passed a bill requiring top state officials to live in the state.

Richard S. Strickler Jr. admits to being a bit weary at this point, having been involved in both big bank mergers announced this week - the Chemical New York Corporation's proposed acquisition of Texas Commerce Bancshares Inc. and the Republicbank Corporation's plan to take over the Interfirst Corporation. The Chemical-Texas Commerce proposal is one of the largest bank mergers ever, and the Republicbank-Interfirst deal involves two of the largest Dallas banks. Mr. Strickler, 37 years old, is a managing director at Morgan Stanley & Company in charge of its mergers and acquisitions business involving banks, insurance companies and the like.

The Penn Central Corporation said it expected a fourth-quarter pretax gain of $470 million and after-tax income of $270 million from the sale of its propane distribution and petroleum pipeline businesses. The net cash proceeds of the sales will be about $840 million. Penn Central also said its quarter results would include a charge of about $390 million on a pretax basis - and $220 million after taxes - from the write-down of electronics, drilling-rig manufacturing and other energy businesses.

Companies A.T.&T. will trim 27,400 jobs and take a $3.2 billion charge against earnings, in a restructuring program to make itself more competitive in its key businesses. The job cuts, to be completed by 1988, will reduce its work force by 8.5 percent, to 290,000. The long-expected cutback is primarily a response to continuing losses from A.T.&T.'s effort to establish itself in computers and information processing. [ Page D1. ] The layoffs suggest that efforts by the Communications Workers to ensure lifetime employment are fruitless. [ D6. ] A.T.&T. stock is likely to recover over the long term, according to several analysts. Market Place. [ D8. ] Diamond Shamrock's board rejected a $2.03 billion bid from T. Boone Pickens and Mesa, which responded by withdrawing its all-securities exchange offer. But the Shamrock board deleted part of the company's ''poison pill,'' raising questions about its commitment to keeping the company independent. [ D1. ]

Americans' personal spending climbed 1.1 percent in November, reversing part of a record decline the month before, the Commerce Department said today. Personal income rose three-tenths of 1 percent. The spending increase followed a 2.1 percent drop in October, the biggest decline in 27 years of record keeping, the department said. In September, spending had climbed 2 percent.

Federated Department Stores Inc. yesterday began offering $200 million of 7 7/8 percent notes due in 1996 at a price of 99.25 to yield 7.985 percent, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. Noncallable for seven years, the notes yield about nine-tenths of a percentage point more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. The issue is rated Aa-2 by Moody's Investors Service and AA by Standard & Poor's Corporation.

After a day of fund-raising activities, students at the O. Henry School, Intermediate School 70, at 333 West 17th Street in Manhattan, gave $244.60 to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. The student council set aside a special day for the Neediest this month and pupils in all grades contributed snack and lunch money and allowances, from pennies to dollars, to help children and the elderly. ''It was a beautiful day of cooperation, holiday spirit and caring,'' said the student council adviser, Shelly Kintisch.

Sonat Inc. announced that it is restructuring in a way that will produce a total after-tax charge to 1986 earnings of about $350 million and that it will take a non-recurring fourth-quarter charge of about $160 million to reduce its investment in the oil-service business. The company, based in Birmingham, Ala., said it would take several steps to improve the efficiency of its contract drilling business.
Graig Nettles, the third baseman, and Dave LaPoint, the left-handed pitcher, will not be offered contracts to return to the San Diego Padres in 1987.
The Beneficial Corporation said it plans to make an announcement on its restructuring plans early today, after a four-hour board meeting.

The galaxies that compose the universe may have been created on the fringes of gigantic bubbles expanding from the explosions of what ''cosmic strings,'' a conference on astrophysics was told today. The hypothetical strings could be remnants of an early stage in evolution before matter appeared. Recently a number of theorists have been convinced that these strings may exist.
Jorge Mester will conduct the Juilliard Symphony in works by Dvorak, Shostakovich and Saint-Saens tonight at 8 at Alice Tully Hall. Admission is free. Information: 799-5000.

The appointment of Lawrence E. Walsh as the special prosecutor in the Iran arms investigation is expected to be announced Friday or Monday, people knowledgeable about the search said today. Officials said Mr. Walsh, a former Federal judge who once served as president of the American Bar Association, had been called to Washington by the three-judge selection panel and arrived today.

According to the new arithmetic of drinking ages, the difference between 18 and 21 is 50. That many young New Yorkers may be alive today because the state raised its legal drinking age from 18 years to 21, according to figures from the state Department of Motor Vehicles.

The chairman of the Federal Trade Commission has warned Mayor Koch that by restricting taxi medallions, the city is effectively issuing ''an engraved invitation to corruption.'' In a letter to the Mayor dated Dec. 16, the commission's chairman, Daniel Oliver, said limiting the number of taxi medallions not only leads to ''higher fares and reduced availability'' of taxis in the city, but also creates a window for ''those with a financial interest in regulatory decisions'' who are ''strongly motivated to influence the deliberative process.'' The F.T.C. was invited by the New York City Council to comment on a bill before the Council to increase the number of taxi medallions. Mr. Oliver's letter is an addition to a six-page report by the F.T.C. staff, which supports the bill's goal of increasing ''for hail'' taxis but advocates complete deregulation as a better solution.
The composer-keyboardist David Borden will play new music tomorrow at 9 P.M. at the Experimental Intermedia Foundation loft, 224 Centre Street, at Grand Street (431-5127). Admission is $3.

Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. ARIZONA 206, #206 East 60th Street (838-0440) - **(Nov. 15, 1985) The glowing hearth at this East Side restaurant along with the rough plaster walls suggest the Southwest, and the decor carries through to the natural-wood floors and tables and lovely arrangements of desert flowers. Starter options include grilled-lamb salad with artichoke and fennel; ravioli with goat cheese, and pan-fried sweetbreads with baked squash. For a main dish, you might order seafood risotto with saffron and roast chili; grilled squab with wild-rice ragu, or grilled rib-eye steak with chipotle hazelnut sauce. Dinner entrees $17 to $23. Fridays and

Booker T. Hillery Jr., a farm laborer who was given a second chance at freedom by the United States Supreme Court, was convicted today of a 1962 murder. After indicating earlier that they were sharply divided over three days of deliberation, the jurors returned a verdict of first-degree murder against Mr. Hillery this afternoon. For the son of a black Texas sharecropper from Texas, the verdict appeared to end a long legal battle. He was convicted of the same murder in 1962, but, fighting much of the time as his own attorney, he conducted a legal battle that ultimately persuaded the Supreme Court to grant him a new trial.
The hunt for new players has not deterred George Steinbrenner from another round of moves in the broadcast booth.

Alain Chevrier had plunged to his left and to his right in the 60 minutes 35 seconds of the game, making 32 saves in the process of posting his 15th victory, all the victories the Devils have this season. Chevrier's 3-2 overtime triumph over the Toronto Maple Leafs here Wednesday night tied Glenn (Chico) Resch's record for victories in a season by a goaltender for the Devils and put him one short of the franchise record, also held by Resch, who now plays for the Philadelphia Flyers. ''Something's wrong if I don't break it,'' Chevrier said about setting a franchise record for victories by a goaltender.

Dr. Herbert Dieckmann, a scholar in French literature who in 1949 discovered long-lost manuscripts of Denis Diderot, the 18th-century French philosopher, died Tuesday at a nursing home in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 80 years old and lived in Ithaca. Dr. Dieckmann's critical assessment of the Diderot papers, which he found in a closet in a castle near Fecamp that was owned by Diderot's descendants, was considered a major work in French studies.

Reliance Group Holdings Inc. said it had increased its stake in Tiger International Inc. to 16.2 percent, from 14.8 percent. The move came a day after Tiger International said it had reversed its decision to seek buyers for the assets of its air freight subsidiary, Flying Tiger Line Inc.

The pianist Ronnie Matthews is leading a trio tonight and tomorrow at Cafe Jupiter, 228 West 10th Street (924-9292). Sets are at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M. On Sunday, the pianist Kirk Lightsey will lead a trio at 9 and 10:30 P.M. and midnight. There is a $5 cover and a $7 minimum.

To the Editor: Your Nov. 26 editorial pronouncement (''Transfusion for New York's Lifeline'') that the proposed increase in bridge and tunnel tolls to subsidize New York City's subway system is fair begs the question, To whom? Certainly not to drivers who must use these links to get to and from work each day. They, as individuals, are already bearing the heaviest burden of the present subsidy while paying one of the highest bridge and tunnel tolls in the country. Why should they, rather than all New Yorkers, be selected for this additional tax? Or what makes a bridge different from a city street, and why are Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority bridges unlike all others? BERNARD GREENSPAN Flushing, Queens, Nov. 29, 1986

Arthur A. Hartman has asked to be relieved as Ambassador to the Soviet Union early next year, a State Department spokesman said today. The spokesman said no successor had been chosen. One reported possibility is Jack F. Matlock Jr., the Soviet specialist on the National Security Council staff in the White House. Mr. Matlock has done several tours in the embassy in Moscow and has been Ambassador to Czechoslovakia. He is leaving his White House position.

A move by the developer Abraham Hirschfeld to halt the Jan. 1 inauguration of Representative Stan Lundine as the state's lieutenant governor was denied yesterday by a Federal judge. Mr. Hirschfeld, who challenged Mr. Lundine in this year's Democratic primary, wanted the inauguration postponed pending a constitutional challenge of the sections of the state election law that were used to remove him from the primary ballot.

To the Editor: A report on the Honduran Government's decision to attack Sandinistas operating inside the country (news story, Dec. 8) says the move is a ''gesture aimed both at the Sandinistas and at Honduran public opinion.'' The Honduran public is reported to be increasingly discontent that the border is dominated by Sandinistas. There is no doubt that the residents of the area who have had to leave their lands and homes because of the conflict between the contras, who are based there, and the Sandinistas pursuing them would like both groups out, permanently. On the other hand, public opinion in Honduras is overwhelmingly opposed not to the Sandinistas, but to the contras and the U.S. military there.

An article on Wednesday about a Planned Parenthood poll of teen-agers incorrectly described the financing of an earlier report on teen-agers by the National Research Council. That report was paid for by private foundations, not by Congress.

Much of the world looks pretty well thumbed over, yet pristine realms still await discovery. Two recent books describe such explorations, one in the virgin canopy of tropical rain forests, the other in a bizarre jungle that lies beneath the householder's vision. Tropical forests pulse with life, most of it never seen. The forest floor is comparatively a desert; the real action takes place 100 feet above, in the canopy of vines and high branches that are the forest's roof. A few intrepid biologists have built tree platforms to observe the canopy's profusion of flowers, birds, reptiles and insects. But the aerial pathways through the high canopy seemed almost wholly inaccessible until a tropical biologist named Donald Perry discovered how to step boldly off the imprisoning platform and glide into the realm of butterflies and toucans.

Yesterday's planned closing on the sale of the building at 890 Broadway, at 19th Street, to two dance companies was postponed one day because an inspection document was missing, according to Cora Cahan, executive director of the Feld Ballet, which is purchasing the building with the American Ballet Theater. The dance companies have each raised $1.1 million toward the purchase of the building from theater director and choreographer Michael Bennett.

The Chase Manhattan Bank, the country's third-largest issuer of credit cards, said yesterday that it would reduce the annual percentage rate on all of its cards by as much as 3.3 points. Several smaller financial institutions have reduced credit card rates and fees in the last six months, but Chase is the largest issuer to announce across-the-board reductions.

New York City has decided to sell a rock. A rock nearly three stories high. It is in the craggy Inwood section of upper Manhattan, it has been there, in the words of one city official, since ''God put it there,'' and soon may serve a nongeological function. It could even disappear.

Scott Thomas, the newest member of the Federal Election Commission, was elected chairman Tuesday. Thomas Josefiak was elected vice chairman by the six-member panel, which oversees political campaign activity and makes rulings under the Federal Election Campaign Act. Mr. Thomas, 33 years old, was appointed by President Reagan this fall.

The Alwin Nikolais Dance Theater's second program at the Joyce Theater, 19th Street and Eighth Avenue, started off superlatively on Wednesday night with an early Nikolais work, ''Noumenon.'' The idea that this entire Nikolais season, through Jan. 4, is a holiday treat was furthered even more strongly with a piece called ''Video Game.'' If anybody could convert scooting electronic figures into humans, it is Mr. Nikolais, the mixed-media marvel. Children will love this one.

A lawyer for a Panamanian company owned by Saudi Arabian interests denied today that he was in any way involved in the sale of arms to Iran. The attorney, M. Vere Nicholl, said in a telephone interview from London that the Panamanian company, Hyde Park Holdings, was organized last March to conduct a real estate deal in London but that the deal never materialized. Mr. Nicholl also said that Hyde Park Holdings had no bank accounts in Switzerland. On Wednesday, the Justice Department asked the Swiss Government to freeze a number of additional bank accounts in connection with the Iranian purchases, including a company called Hyde Park Holdings, according to American and Swiss officials.

The Board of Estimate approved yesterday the development of two new homeless shelters in Harlem. One shelter is to provide housing for homeless families and the other is to house single adults between 18 and 25 years old.

The South African police took the unprecedented step today of releasing the names of 28 young blacks who, it said, had been executed or had taken their own lives as dissidents in black nationalist guerrilla training camps. The police action seemed to mark the opening of a campaign to counter the appeal of the African National Congress within South Africa, where some anti-apartheid movements depict the insurgent group as heroic. The congress is the most prominent of outlawed and exiled insurgent movements seeking the violent overthrow of white rule. In more than two years of crisis, one of the biggest political challenges facing the Government has been to try to erode the congress's image among blacks as the custodian of their interests.

The sharp cost cutting announced today by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company shows anew that deregulation is not always kind to business, regulatory and industry analysts said today. Albert Halprin, chief of the telephone regulation bureau of the Federal Communications Commission, said: ''Any time people have been freed from constraints, sometimes your thrill for having new opportunities outpaces your judgment.'' Alfred E. Kahn, a political economics professor at Cornell University, stated: ''It's obvious that deregulation opened up opportunities to lose your shirt, as well as to succeed.'' Mr. Kahn was a chief architect of deregulation as chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board during the Carter Administration.

The operators of the Seabrook nuclear power reactor in southern New Hampshire announced today that they would ask the Nuclear Regulatory Commission to waive the Federal requirement for a 10-mile emergency evacuation zone around nuclear stations and allow them a zone only a mile in radius. The waiver, designed to overcome bitter community resistance in neighboring Massachusetts, would shrink the Seabrook zone to exclude Massachusetts towns two miles south of the reactor site. These towns have kept the plant's operators from obtaining a license to operate at full power by refusing to join in evacuation preparations.

A judge yesterday ordered the family of Jennifer Dawn Levin to give her diary to the court to determine whether it may be used by lawyers defending the man accused of murdering her in Central Park, Robert E. Chambers Jr. After an emotional request by the attorney for Miss Levin's family, however, the judge agreed to allow the diary to be held in a bank safe deposit box pending an appeal. The judge, Justice Howard E. Bell of State Supreme Court in Manhattan, said he could not make a fair ruling on the diary - which has been at the center of a three-month struggle between prosecutors, defenders and Levin family lawyers - unless he had read it himself.
* Crane Co., a maker of pumps, valves and fittings and building products, elected its chairman and chief executive, Robert S. Evans, to the additional posts of president and chief operating officer.

NO American actor can match Richard Gere in making grandiose and often unreasonable claims for himself with each new role. From ''King David'' to the remake of ''Breathless,'' Mr. Gere has consistently demonstrated more confidence in his own magnetism than anyone else seems to feel. Yet there are times when the perception of Mr. Gere as a tough-talking, quietly mesmerizing figure, a man of keen and unpredictable longings, seems wholly justified, and his latest film is one of them. ''No Mercy'' is a passionate film noir that depends heavily upon Mr. Gere to give it credence, and Mr. Gere delivers. ''No Mercy,'' which opens today at the Warner Twin and other theaters, casts the actor as Eddie Jillette, a Chicago policeman, and throws him into as many different settings and adventures as can be crammed into an hour and three-quarters. He is seen, for instance, working at a car wash, party-crashing at a mansion, working his way out of an underwater prison and roaming the Louisiana bayous with a beautiful captive handcuffed to his wrist. And that's only the start of it. Excessive as it sometimes is, ''No Mercy'' also has energy to spare.
More than 30,000 people marched today through the old city here demanding the separation of church and state and for an end to violence spawned by religious differences.

President Reagan's draft budget for the next fiscal year proposes sharp cuts in Federal spending for veterans' health care benefits. Confidential budget documents show that the Office of Management and Budget is seeking to virtually eliminate medical benefits for veterans with income exceeding $15,000 a year and for married veterans with income above $18,000. To obtain Government medical care, such veterans are already subject to certain criteria specified by a law that took effect last spring. Before that, Veterans Administration institutions could provide free health care to veterans 65 years old or older without regard to their ability to pay for such care.

Jocelyn Lemieux, the rookie wing for St. Louis Blues who was the Blues' top draft choice this year, will be sidelined for up to six weeks because of a tendon he cut in his small left finger in an accident during the team's Christmas skating party. The mishap occurred Wednesday night when the 19-year-old Lemieux fell and a skate cut his hand. The cut was repaired and the finger was placed in a splint.

Not prompted by any crying need, but perhaps with an eye toward another deal, the Rangers acquired Bob Froese from the Philadelphia Flyers yesterday to be their backup goalkeeper. In return, the Rangers sent Kjell Samuelsson, a defenseman, to the Flyers along with a second-round pick in the 1989 draft. The trade seemed to have created a number of new questions. What now will be the role of Doug Soetaert, who has been the No. 2 goalie? How does this affect the team's plans, announced just this week, to abandon a platoon system at goal and to give John Vanbiesbrouck more work?

Fritz Goro, who specialized in scientific photography for Life and Scientific American magazines, died at his home in Chappaqua, N.Y., last Sunday of complications related to cancer. He was 85 years old.

Complaining that foes of Communism suffer disadvantages under the democratic system, a group of Cuban-Americans today launched a defense fund for Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North. ''He is a hero,'' said Carlos Perez, an importer who heads Concerned Citizens for Democracy, a mostly Cuban group.

To the Editor: Your thoughtful Dec. 4 article about the efforts of New York City high schools to prepare students for a changing job market did not give some important reasons for optimism about this city's economic future. The decline in the youth population that you say is taking place in other parts of the country is also occurring in New York. A drop of a quarter of a million people in the 15-to-24 age category is expected in the next 14 years.

Beginning next month, all foreign students who come to China for more than one year must present proof that they are not carriers of the virus that causes acquired immune deficiency syndrome or submit to a blood test administered by the Government. Otherwise, officials say, they will not be permitted to enter the country. The Government has also started giving blood tests for AIDS antibodies to foreign students already in residence, the Ministry of Health announced. The presence of such antibodies indicates exposure to the AIDS virus and probable continuing infection with it, but not whether a person has the fatal disease or will develop it.
A big selling point in Jack Morris's free-agent travels is that he's the major leagues' top winner of the 1980's, with 123 victories (18 more than the runner-up, Scott McGregor).
Jason and the Scorchers, the Nashville rock band, will headline a double bill tonight at the Ritz, 119 East 11th Street (254-2800), with the Georgia Satellites opening at 11. Tickets are $13.50.

WHO could have imagined that ''Little Shop of Horrors,'' the 1960 comic horror film shot by Roger Corman in two days' time, would continue to grow bigger, mightier and more formidable, much like the man-eating plant that is its unsung star? From Mr. Corman's charming throwaway film to the Off Broadway stage success, ''Little Shop of Horrors'' has evolved into a full-blown movie musical, and quite a winning one. As directed by the Muppet master Frank Oz, this large-scale new film version has just the right mixture of playfulness, tunefulness and blood lust. Never has any screen killer done his job as innocently as Seymour Krelborn (Rick Moranis), the florist's assistant who tries so hard to accommodate the large, potted creature living in the basement of his ''God- and customer-forsaken'' shop that he cannot help thinking of passers-by as plant food.

Louis V. Gerstner Jr., president of the American Express Company, became a member of the board of directors of The New York Times Company yesterday, according to Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, chairman. The appointment increased the membership of the board to 13.

President Reagan received an honorary degree from Yeshiva University today. In a ceremony in the Oval Office marking the university's centennial, the President was presented with a Doctor of Laws from the president of Yeshiva, Dr. Norman Lamm.

The Soviet Union reported today that there had been an outbreak of anti-Russian rioting in the capital of the Central Asian republic of Kazakhstan. A report by the official press agency Tass said a group of students ''incited by nationalistic elements'' took to the streets of Alma-Ata Wednesday night and today, burning cars and setting fire to a food store to protest decisions made earlier this week by the republic's Communist Party organization. On Tuesday the Kazakhstan Party Central Committee ousted its longtime leader, Dinmukhamed Akhmedovich Kunayev, a Kazakh, replacing him with an ethnic Russian, Gennadi V. Kolbin. City Services Called Normal The Tass dispatch from Alma-Ata reported that city services were functioning normally, but stopped short of saying that the unrest had been quelled. It did not report any injuries or deaths.

To the Editor: In a report on what the United States is doing to remedy deficiencies in foreign-language study (front page, Dec. 2), you quote the executive director of the Joint National Committee of Languages as saying, ''We have a long way to go until we see the end of the tongue-tied American.'' The implication of this and other comments in the article is that greater emphasis on foreign-language study in our schools will result in more Americans being able to converse and write in foreign languages. However, the problem of the so-called tongue-tied American does not solely result from a dearth of foreign-language courses in our high schools and colleges, and it may not even be half-ascribable to that purported dearth.

A business associate of two Canadians who helped finance secret United States arms shipments to Iran has been identified here as a major figure in the World Anti-Communist League, which is believed to have raised at least $10 million to aid Nicaraguan rebels. The associate, John Gamble, told reporters last week that he knew nothing about the secret arms deals with Iran that were financed in part by his business partners here, Ernest Miller and Donald Fraser. But his involvement in the Anti Communist League seemed likely to raise questions about whether the Canadian investors knew that part of Iran's payment for the weapons was being diverted to the Nicaraguan rebels.
James Fassett, a former CBS Radio music director and head of its music division, died Wednesday at Pokono Hospital in Stroudsburg, Pa. He was 82 years old.

THE art world abounds in conspiracy theories, not all of which are paranoid. Yet some of the coincidences nourishing such theories make the scene look less like the court of the Borgias than an orchestra responding to a conductor whom the public cannot see. The maestro raises his baton and, lo! the galleries are showing paper works or Neo-Expressionism or Outsider Art or even, as in the case of a current coincidence, the Great Outsider himself, Jean Dubuffet (1901-1985). Normally, two simultaneous Dubuffet shows would not get a rating on the Richter scale of coincidences. Though Chicago was the first to register the impact of this artist, it was in New York that he made his debut (three years after his maiden solo in the Paris of 1944) and he rarely missed a season here. Besides, it has been only five years since the Guggenheim celebrated his 80th birthday with its ''Retrospective Glance.'' What is remarkable is that the current productions, one at Gallery Urban, 500 Park Avenue, at 59th Street, the other at the Elkon Gallery, 18 East 81st Street, should complement each other so well despite having been independently staged.

The Canadian Government today proposed laws expected to foster a broad restructuring of the country's financial institutions. A policy paper to be translated into legislation in 1987 would relax the ownership barriers that have kept separate the ''four pillars'' of Canadian finance - banks, trust and loan companies, insurance companies and securities dealers. The move will open the way for the networking of financial services through a single parent corporation, with the exception of insurance retailing. At the same time, new restrictions will be introduced to counter the growing trend in Canada toward common ownership of commercial and financial institutions.

Although nothing much ever happens in pro football between weekends, we keyboard warriors must spend our midweek labors trying to sift through the ''test of character'' blather so indigenous to this sport. It has long been my contention that every writer should be limited to one blood-and-guts pronouncement per football season. This is mine for the entire season, first and last: The Jets must win Sunday in Cincinnati. If they don't, they might as well not play their playoff game. That simple.

ALICE NEEL, who died in October 1984 at the age of 84, was in her last years a well-known fixture of the New York art scene, an eccentric personality and an equally eccentric portraitist of undeniable power. Right now, there is an extensive survey of drawings (in pencil, ink and pastel) and watercolors dating from the late 20's to the mid-60's, plus a room of 30's paintings on view at the Robert Miller Gallery (41 East 57th Street). This show, which runs through Jan. 3, simultaneously reveals the foundation of Neel's achievement and expands her stature considerably, for it gives her a serious historical position prior to the onset of Abstract Expressionism. In the process, the exhibition shows us Neel the young artist and, since she frequently drew and painted her friends, children and lovers, it also shows us Neel the young woman. The youthful normalcy of this woman, seen as a wistful, mildly depressed beauty in ''Alice by Alice,'' or, in two watercolors, in bed with a dark, handsome man named Jose, catches us by surprise. It seems at odds with Neel's early and commanding control of the art of portraiture.

Richard Andrade, who raped a woman and stabbed her to death, was executed today after the Supreme Court rejected his hand-printed appeal. Mr. Andrade, who was 25 years old, was pronounced dead at 12:32 A.M., nine minutes after he was injected with poison for the murder of Cordelia Mae Guevara, who was killed in 1984, when she was 28. The warden, Jack Pursley, had asked Mr. Andrade if he would like to make a final statement. The prisoner, strapped down, shook his head and stared at the ceiling, waiting for the needle.

Prices of crude oil and petroleum products reversed a two-day slump yesterday in frantic trading on world oil markets, as traders counted on OPEC to reduce oil output. The volume of crude oil futures contracts traded on the New York Mercantile Exchange reached 101,552, setting a volume record for the second time this week.

The GAF Corporation, noting that the waiting period under Federal antitrust laws had expired, said it would raise its stake in the Borg-Warner Corporation to 25 percent, from its current holdings of 9.9 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, GAF also said it had exercised an option to buy more than 4 million Borg-Warner shares for $39.87 a share, and it had bought an additional 200,000 shares at $38.47. GAF, a chemical concern based in Wayne, N.J., was Borg-Warner's largest shareholder until Wednesday, when the Minneapolis-based investor Irwin L. Jacobs raised his stake in the company to 11.3 percent.

If any of the 1988 Presidential hopefuls can lay claim to using Super Bowl XXI as a fund-raising device, it certainly should be Representative Jack F. Kemp, the Republican from upstate New York who once was a professional quarterback. And he's doing just that, in spades.

Top Israeli officials are convincing when they say they responded to American inquiries and thought they were just doing the U.S. a favor by getting involved in the American-Iranian arms deal. But the claim to have had solid information about the situation in Iran, how the power struggle there might be influenced and who might represent the so-called moderates is not convincing. Two Israelis, the former military attache Yaacov Nimrodi and Uri Lubrani, the Defense Ministry consultant on Shiite affairs and an architect of Israeli deals with Lebanese factions, spent many years in Iran. They were able to keep up some contacts after the Khomeini revolution. But that doesn't validate claims about openings for Western influence. The Israelis have been selling arms to Iran all along, on their own account, in secret arrangements that benefited both sides and did not imply any political trust.

Coopervision Inc., an eye care company based in Palo Alto, Calif., said today that it had agreed to sell its ophthalmic pharmaceutical products business to Johnson & Johnson for about $260 million. The unit had net sales of about $55 million in the fiscal year 1986.

The pianist Cecil Taylor will lead his group, the Unit, tonight through Sunday at Carlos 1, 432 Avenue of the Americas, at Ninth Street (982-3260). Sets begin at 9:30 and 11 P.M., plus a 12:30 A.M. set tonight and tomorrow; there is a $10 cover and a $7 minimum.

It was such a bad night that the Islanders had two losing goalies instead of just one. ''It's tough even finding the words to describe how this affects me,'' said the starting goalie, Billy Smith, who was ushered to the bench after absorbing a six-goal shelling. ''I wanted to go in there and stop the onslaught,'' said Kelly Hrudey, who watched the final trio of Flyer goals zoom into the net behind him, completing a 9-4 rout of the Islanders. ''Killer-instinct is exactly what that team runs on. They're always at your throat, especially if they think they can get away with it.''

A molten lava flow from Kilauea Volcano crossed a coastal road here today, prompting the authorities to evacuate people living in about 50 homes. The rest of the subdivision was placed under a 24-hour alert, and the authorities said they were considering expanding the evacuation zone.
The fiddlers Joe and Willie Kelly will perform tomorrow at 9 P.M. at the Eagle Tavern, 355 West 14th Street (924-0275). Tickets are $5; information, 475-7092.

When Representative Henry B. Gonzalez struck a constituent at a local restaurant earlier this month, because the constituent called him a Communist, he did more than create a furor in the city's newspapers, which hew to old-style tabloid journalism. He also joined a storied group that includes heroes and scoundrels, from border bandits and drug runners to John F. Kennedy, immortalized in a centuries-old musical style that still flourishes in Hispanic South Texas. The form is the corrido, a narrative ballad with roots dating from at least 16th-century Spain. The corrido no longer serves the informational function it did when it was as topical as the town crier. But it lives to the extent it is almost impossible for a major event to touch the Hispanic community here without someone's penning a ballad.

The Winter Regional Championships of the Greater New York Bridge Association begin today at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center with a schedule that will bring cheers from some players and groans from others. The cheers will be for an unusual open pairs plan. Following the British custom, the section-top winners tomorrow afternoon will qualify for a final, which will be scored by the exciting barometer method: simultaneous play of all deals, and standings announced as the session develops.

For a time, the Nets held the dubious honor of having the worst record in the National Basketball Association. Then with six seconds remaining last night, a 16-foot jump shot by Leon Wood helped the Nets relinquish that honor. For Wood's basket, with Rory Sparrow guarding him, enabled the Nets to edge the Knicks, 94-93, at Madison Square Garden. The victory brought the Nets' record to 5-19. The Knicks, who lost their seventh game in a row, dropped to 5-20 and into last place in the Atlantic Division, replacing the Nets.

Ponderosa Inc., ending its efforts to thwart a takeover by the New York investor Asher B. Edelman, said today that it had accepted a sweetened $29.25-a-share acquisition proposal from Mr. Edelman's investor group. The group already owns about 1.8 million, or 18.5 percent, of the restaurant chain's 9.76 million common shares outstanding. The total cost to acquire the remaining stock would be about $233 million.

THE Christmas party is always memorable for first-year students in the Barclay Classes. ''This is their first experience with refreshments,'' said Lois Thomson, the co-director. The fourth-grade girls, who had just finished a cha-cha, removed their white gloves and waited for the boys to bring them a Coke and two cookies. Stephanie Duris, 9 years old, kept adjusting her pink bow headband. On this special day, her mother picked her up after school -Stephanie usually walks home - so there was time to change into a party dress. ''I did my nails last night,'' Stephanie explained, but before she could say more, a voice said, ''Girls pick a partner to your left.'' The two-piece orchestra began to play, Stephanie finished her cookie, put back on her white gloves, excused herself and made her way to the dance floor, for it was ''Fascination.''

President Reagan will nominate Alton G. Keel, the acting national security adviser, to serve as ambassador to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, it was announced today. The President also named Lieut. Gen. Colin L. Powell Jr., commander of the Army's Fifth Corps in West Germany, to fill the post of deputy national security adviser under Frank C. Carlucci.

N.B.A. Bulls 97, Pacers 88: Michael Jordan scored 14 of his 41 points in the fourth quarter last night to lead Chicago to a victory in Indianapolis. Indiana led, 70-63, after three quarters and expanded the advantage to 76-67 in the final period. The Bulls outscored Indiana, 10-0, to take a 77-76 lead with 5 minutes 16 seconds to play. Steve Colter capped the run with two free throws. Chicago pulled steadily away after that. (UPI) Bucks 104, Hawks 95: Jack Sikma scored 11 of his 18 points in the fourth quarter and made a 3-point play that gave Milwaukee the lead as the Bucks won their third straight, beating the Hawks in Milwaukee. The victory moved the second-place Bucks a game and a half behind the Hawks in the Central Division. Terry Cummings led Milwaukee with 32 points. Atlanta got 22 points from Glenn Rivers. Atlanta scored the first 5 points of the fourth quarter, cutting Milwaukee's lead to 75-72. The Bucks rebuilt their edge to 7 points, but the Hawks got even at 95-95 with 1:32 remaining on Wayne Rollins's jump shot. Sikma's layup and free throw following a foul by Rivers, and Pierce's free throw made it 99-95. Then a turnover by Dominique Wilkins with 51 seconds left was followed by a basket by Cummings. (AP)

Mount Mihara shot flames and hot rocks into the sky in a new eruption today, just as more evacuees from a volcanic explosion last month were preparing to return home for the holidays. Officials said the return of residents to O-shima, an island 50 miles south of Tokyo, would continue on schedule but vessels were waiting offshore in case they were needed for another evacuation.

Stock prices fell yesterday as write-offs by several of the biggest corporations put additional pressure on a market that was already worried about today's ''triple witching hour.'' The Dow Jones industrial average, which started to retreat late in Wednesday's session, lost another 5.49 points, to 1,912.82. The big blow came from the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, which announced that it would eliminate 27,400 jobs and take a $3.2 billion charge against fourth-quarter earnings. A.T.&T.'s stock was the most active issue on consolidated volume of 4.8 million shares, losing 1 1/4, to 26. I.B.M.'s Charge: $250 Million I.B.M. disclosed that it would take a $250 million quarterly charge, and its stock fell 1 3/8, to 125 3/8. Meanwhile, General Motors fell 1 1/4, to 66 3/4, a day after disclosing plans to cut car production and furlough 26,400 workers.

J. Patrick Moran Jr., who is apparently making a success of his series of magazines tied to the current America's Cup races, has devised a property that should have greater longevity: Performance Sailing. It will be a controlled-circulation magazine, delivered free only to owners of sailboats who race them.

Debt * Eastman Kodak Co. is offering in the United States bond market $100 million (New Zealand) of 17 percent notes due 1990 at a price of par, through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. Noncallable for life, the four-year notes are rated Aaa by Moody's and AA+ by S.& P. and yield about 1.7 percentage points less than comparable New Zealand interest rates.

The latest victory for Hal Riney & Partners amid the hills of San Francisco comes courtesy of the New Zealand Kiwifruit Authority (not to be confused with the California Kiwifruit Commission), which was formerly served by the San Francisco office of Lowe Marshalk, one of the Interpublic Group of Companies, which introduced kiwi advertising in June. The Kiwifruit Commission returned $70 million to New Zealand in 1984 and more than $112 million in 1985.

MISSION TO CIVILIZE: The French Way. By Mort Rosenblum. 470 pages. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $19.95. THE French have been exporting civilization for a long time, and in the days when they ruled a vast empire their standard was that they were engaged on a civilizing mission. Nor was it only publicists and propagandists who proclaimed the belief, but many of their finest spirits. In his new book, ''Mission to Civilize,'' two of the most ardent apologists for the 19th-century conquest of Algeria quoted by Mort Rosenblum - both of them depicting it as a triumph of progress over barbarism - are Alfred de Vigny and Victor Hugo.

The State Department of Health Services said yesterday that it had found 20 apparent violations of state health codes at a Windsor nursing home where five patients died after an outbreak of salmonella poisoning. The department has scheduled a Jan. 13 hearing in Hartford to give administrators of the Mountain View Healthcare Center an opportunity to explain conditions at the center and show why the state should not institute further proceedings. The findings stemmed from seven unannounced visits to the home by state officials.

Only a day after Republican leaders reacted favorably to a proposed increase in motor-vehicle taxes, rank-and-file Republican senators rejected it tonight, throwing into doubt whether a plan will be in place by the end of the year to rebuild New York City's mass transit system and freeze its fares for three years. In response, Governor Cuomo immediately proposed that as a temporary step, the state draw on its general treasury for the money - $75 million the first year, $150 million in future years - to pay for the transit plan. It was not clear, however, if Republicans, who come mainly from the suburbs and upstate, would accept that proposal. They have traditionally opposed spending money from the general treasury to support New York City's transit system.

MONTY ALEXANDER'S affectionate tribute to Nat (King) Cole, at the Blue Note this weekend, is the culmination of influences that go back to Mr. Alexander's childhood in Kingston, Jamaica. ''Everybody in my family sang Nat Cole songs around the house,'' the pianist recalled recently. ''When I was 7, I was picking out his tunes on the piano and that helped to make my parents decide to send me to a piano teacher. Then, when I was 11, Nat Cole came to Jamaica and I saw the last half of his show because my mother had gone to see it and we had to pick her up.''

The United States Conference of Mayors, citing a survey showing urban poverty increased in 1986, called today for a national response to the problem. The survey of 25 major cities conducted by the conference, composed of mayors from cities with populations of at least 30,000, said the number of poor people increased this year in two out of three cities surveyed. The number of homeless people needing shelter increased in 24 of the 25 cities from the previous year and demand for emergency food assistance increased in all but three, according to the survey.

''NO MERCY,'' which opens today (review on page C22), is a sharp turn in the road for its director, Richard Pearce. His previous movies include ''Country,'' about the plight of American farm families; ''Heartland,'' an American pioneer story told from a woman's point of view, and ''Threshold,'' which dealt with the ethics of unauthorized heart-transplant surgery. ''No Mercy,'' starring Richard Gere and Kim Basinger, is a film noir about a killer, a passionate love affair and the Louisiana bayous. It is what Mr. Pearce calls a ''Saturday-night movie - where people go out and have a couple of beers and enjoy themselves.'' What made him take it on? ''I had never made a film like this before,'' he said. ''And as a director you want to be a moving target, not to allow yourself to get too typecast. This is a kind of high-velocity storytelling. If I hadn't done this kind of film pretty soon, I would be suspicious that I was afraid to do it.''

Outdoorsmen have found it a simple thing to call a moose in the wild, but the Cincinnati Slammers are finding it nearly impossible to call one at home in South Carolina. Since before their season began, the Slammers, who play in the Continental Basketball Association, have been trying to telephone John (Moose) Campbell, a 6-foot-10-inch former Clemson star who ably manned the pivot for them the last two years. Once, Campbell called back and informed a publicity man that he was now a contented construction worker back in Blenheim, S.C. But his phone has since been disconnected, and neither General Manager Denny Petro nor Coach Herb Brown has spoken with the popular big guy.

Outdoorsmen have found it a simple thing to call a moose in the wild, but the Cincinnati Slammers are finding it nearly impossible to call one at home in South Carolina. Since before their season began, the Slammers, who play in the Continental Basketball Association, have been trying to telephone John (Moose) Campbell, a 6-foot-10-inch former Clemson star who ably manned the pivot for them the last two years. Once, Campbell called back and informed a publicity man that he was now a contented construction worker back in Blenheim, S.C. But his phone has since been disconnected, and neither General Manager Denny Petro nor Coach Herb Brown has spoken with the popular big guy.

A 67-year-old Brooklyn woman was found stabbed to death in her ransacked Brownsville's apartment last night, apparently the victim of a robber, the police said. The body of the woman, who lived alone, was found by a neighbor about 10 P.M., in Apartment 12-E, at 60 Glenmore Avenue.

The equity investors in Ivan F. Boesky's arbitrage fund appear likely to lose as much as a third of their investment, and perhaps more, according to figures provided to the investors. At the same time, however, newly uncovered details show that Mr. Boesky received more favorable terms in his settlement of insider trading charges than had been known previously. The terms of Mr. Boesky's $100 million settlement, sources with knowledge of Mr. Boesky's company said, allowed him to collect millions of dollars in fees and possibly helped him to avoid substantial penalty payments. In another development, Guinness P.L.C., the British distiller that is the subject of a stock trading investigation in London that is said to involve Mr. Boesky, announced yesterday that it had made an equity investment of $:69.8 million, or about $100 million, in Mr. Boesky's investment partnership, Ivan F. Boesky & Company L.P. Meanwhile, the FMC Corporation said yesterday that it had filed a lawsuit against Mr. Boesky, his company and other individuals implicated in the scandal, charging insider trading relating to FMC's $2 billion recapitalization this year. The lawsuit, filed in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois, seeks damages in excess of $260 million. The S.E.C.'s charges against Mr. Boesky contended that he had been tipped off about the FMC deal through an information network that included Dennis B. Levine and other investment bankers.

A Federal safety agency today urged manufacturers to voluntarily stop selling recreational motorized vehicles for children under 12 years old, seeking to stem the rising number of deaths and injuries involving the popular machines. The agency, the Consumer Product Safety Commission, said the popular three- and four-wheel all-terrain vehicles had been linked to 559 deaths and more than 230,000 injuries since 1982. ''The A.T.V. issue is the most serious problem this commission has ever addressed,'' said Anne Graham, a commissioner.

Should Donald Regan be dismissed as White House chief of staff? Yes - not because he knew too much but because he says he knew too little; not because his departure would end the Iran-Nicaragua scandal but because he has become a symbol of White House ineptitude and/or arrogance in overriding the law and common sense. One charge alone would justify returning Mr. Regan to Wall Street: He sent the President inadequately briefed and psychologically unprepared to his disastrous news conference on Nov. 19. Mr. Reagan seemed stunned by the detail and lack of deference in the questions put to him; an alert staff chief should have seen what was coming and prepared his boss - perhaps have stopped Mr. Reagan from facing reporters at that point, since in six years of relatively polite news conferences the President had never appeared to best advantage. Mr. Regan at least should have advised the President not to insist that no other nation was involved in the arms shipments, since Mr. Regan himself had told reporters that Israel was part of the scheme. As it was, the White House quickly had to back down on the President's word.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Dec. 18 (UPI) - The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People filed an $800,000 Federal lawsuit today against the Citadel on behalf of Kevin Nesmith, a former black cadet, who charged that his civil rights were violated when he was harassed by five white cadets. The suit said ''racial bigotry has historically been tolerated and sanctioned by officials at the Citadel,'' and that the failure to expel the five cadets was condoning students ''to engage in racially discriminatory conduct.''

* Samuel J. Chisholm joining Mingo-Jones Advertising as executive vice president-general manager. * Barbara Jack and Jordan J. Stanley have been appointed senior vice presidents at Young & Rubicam New York. * Peter Scarperi, chief financial officer, named executive vice president, and William Morrissey elected to the board, of Ogilvy & Mather, U.S. * Henry V. Hayes joining the Radio Advertising Bureau as senior vice president, marketing and sales.

AS its first domestic magazine acquisition, the 65-year-old Reader's Digest Association has bought Travel-Holiday, which is 20 years its senior. The only details on the purchase price disclosed by the privately held Digest was that it was for cash. Travel-Holiday, based in Floral Park, L.I., had been owned by the publisher, Sheldon R. Shane, whose father, the late Herman Shane, got it in 1948 when it was bankrupt. The editor in chief is Scott E. Shane, 30-year-old son of the publisher.

Patrick Ewing, the Knicks' emotional center who has a history of getting into fights both in the pros and in college, was fined $3,000 yesterday by the National Basketball Association. The penalty was assessed by Rod Thorn, the league's vice president of operations. Ewing's second major fine of his two-year professional career was imposed for punching Greg Kite, the Boston Celtics' reserve center, after Ewing battled to get through a screen late in the second quarter of Tuesday night's game against the Celtics.

Robin Auchincloss of New York and London and Henry Dwight Sedgwick of New York and Stockbridge, Mass., were married yesterday at the Episcopal Churh of the Heavenly Rest in New York. The Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony.

Federal investigators said yesterday that they were seeking a second person in the attempted bombing of an abortion clinic last Sunday in Manhattan. A sketch of a woman in her early 20's with sunglasses and long hair was shown to employees at the center, the Planned Parenthood Clinic at 360 Second Avenue, but no leads have developed, said Robert J. Creighton, head of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms in New York, which has joined the police in the inquiry. The first suspect was described as a white man 32 to 37 years old, between 5 foot 7 and 5 foot 9 with brown hair and brown eyes and a mustache.

Eugene Hasenfus, the American cargo handler pardoned by Nicaragua for helping to fly arms to the contras, arrived here today and said he was prepared to tell United States investigators about his role in the rebels' supply network. ''Why not?'' he said in a brief exchange during a flight from Guatemala to Miami aboard a regularly scheduled Pan American World Airways flight. ''I've got nothing to hide.'' Mr. Hasenfus, who parachuted from a C-123K cargo plane that was shot down while carrying weapons to the rebels on Oct. 5, was pardoned by the Nicaraguan National Assembly on Wednesday at the request of President Daniel Ortega Saavedra. Earlier this month, he had begun serving a 30-year sentence, the stiffest possible under Nicaraguan law. The downing of the cargo plane led to the discovery of an extensive supply operation that was based in El Salvador and may have been financed by the profits from the United States' sale of arms to Iran.

A doctor was given the maximum sentence yesterday of 20 years in prison for the 1985 slaying of his wife. The doctor, Russell F. Manfredi, 33 years old, was convicted Nov. 3 of first-degree manslaughter in the death of Catherine Manfredi, who was beaten with a baseball bat and dumped out a second-floor window of the couple's West Hartford home.
President Reagan at first rejected the idea of Israel's selling arms to Iran, but later reluctantly went along with it when he was informed that it had taken place.

Holiday travelers should find gasoline prices unchanged from Thanksgiving and about 35 cents a gallon less than prices a year ago, the American Automobile Association said today. Travelers should fill up on Dec. 24 because 60 percent of 6,000 service stations surveyed on major routes said they would be closed Christmas Day, the A.A.A. reported. Gasoline prices now average 90.4 cents a gallon compared with $1.256 during Christmas 1985, according to the survey.

With the Central Intelligence Agency already facing some of its sharpest Congressional scrutiny in a decade, the agency has been plunged into a period of uncertainty by the absence f its leader. Robert M. Gates, the Deputy Director now in charge of the C.I.A., is generally well regarded in Congress, but he is not viewed as having the political power within the Reagan Administration held by his superior, William J. Casey, who is hospitalized after the removal of a brain tumor Thursday. ''They have got to be feeling quite bad about Casey,'' who has had a long and close relationship with President Reagan, one former C.I.A. official said today. ''And they ought to be real nervous about people on the Hill sharpening their knives.''

Governor Cuomo will not accept an invitation to be the main speaker at a key Democratic dinner in New Hampshire in March, New York State's Democratic chairman said today. The dinner decision had been awaited as a signal of whether the Governor planned to run for President in 1988.
The North Carolina Board of Elections today certified Howard Coble, the incumbent Republican, as the winner in the Sixth Congressional District by 79 votes.
Leonard Bernstein will be the principal speaker at the fourth New Year's Eve Concert for Peace at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street.

In ''Life Simulator,'' the more substantial of two new works being offered at La Mama by Talking Band, the actor-writer Paul Zimet plays Elliot Frank, a contemporary wizard enthralled by his own invention. The clunky gizmo, which resembles a flight simulator cum television set, brings into focus a holographic instructor (Louise Smith), who debates with him in the implacably cool manner of a flight attendant. Working with the machine, in a broad parody of transactional analysis and Scientology, Elliot is able to test and reprogram his own responses to different anxiety-producing situations. He teaches himself how to rebuff a religious proseletyzer, deal with his jealousy of a friend who has suddenly achieved success as a writer and rationalize away his He also gets to see himself die in various ways, from choking in a restaurant to drowning to being hit by a car.

The United States is not the only country that protects farmers. Japan holds its rice farmers sacrosanct. Despite the far higher cost of growing rice in Japan and the $1.5 billion that this country spends to subsidize its rice farmers and to reduce the high price to consumers, Japan bars virtually all rice imports, except for small amounts used to make sake or rice crackers, or rice to be distributed as food aid to other countries. Rice remains a staple of the Japanese diet. But it is a sign of the difficulties Japan faces from the high yen and its expanding trade surplus that this once-inviolable policy has come under fire in recent months.

A young woman's hair blown around her face by winds yesterday that swept in on the heels of the rain Wednesday. The high of 47 degrees hardly felt that warm. Today should be much the same, but cooler still. (NYT/Larry C. Morris)

A jury acquitted three men last night of charges that they robbed a Wells Fargo depot in Manhattan of almost $8 million. One of the men, however, was convicted of conspiracy. The robbery, committed last year by masked gunmen, was one of the largest cash thefts in United States history. About $9,000 has been recovered. Last night, at the end of one full day of deliberations, the jury reached its verdict in the two-week trial in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

The Industrial and Commercial Bank in Beijing will start issuing traveler's checks valid in 11 Chinese cities starting Jan. 1, the official New China News Agency said today. The checks will have face values from 100 yuan, about $27 at current exchange rates, to 1,000 yuan and are limited to personal use. People bearing the checks can withdraw money from savings banks in any of the 11 cities within a month after they purchase the checks.

In an emerging split with Mayor Koch, the seven other members of the Board of Estimate have decided they want a private law firm to appeal a Federal court ruling that threatens the board's survival. Mr. Koch, who knew nothing of his colleagues' decision until a reporter told him about it yesterday, said he wanted the city's Corporation Counsel to pursue the case, which grows out of a ruling holding the board's voting structure unconstitutional. Whether the city has the legal authority to change lawyers has not yet been determined. But that is the route the board members are pursuing. At stake are their positions on the board, or at the least the power inherent in them. The board could be abolished if the city loses the appeal.

Throughout the first weeks of the 1986-87 season, Hubie Brown and his assistants faced heavy pressures to improve a team that had made a habit of losing. Now those same pressures have shifted to the man who made the decision to dismiss Brown, Scotty Stirling. That was evident even before the Knicks lost, 94-93, to the Nets on Thursday at Madison Square Garden when Leon Wood, a reserve guard, rattled in a 16-footer with six seconds remaining. Stirling, the team's vice president and general manager, spent many hours in days before that defeat talking with general managers throughout the league in an effort to construct a deal that would save the season.

Questions appear on page 18. 1. They are Percy Bysshe Shelley's revisions and drawings in a copy of the first edition of ''The Queen of the Universe,'' from a collection of journals, poems, letters, books and paintings that document the lives of the English Romantic poets.

Tom Webster, who began his duties as the new head coach of the Rangers less than a month ago, will undergo an inner ear operation to correct dizziness and imbalance that will interrupt his coaching for more than a month. Webster's interim replacement will be the team's general manager, Phil Esposito, who filled the interim coaching role for three games after dismissing Ted Sator and before hiring Webster.

Houston is making a run for the 1996 Olympics after serving as host for the United States Olympic Festival last summer, The Houston Post reported today. Mayor Kathy Whitmire and other Houston officials plan to kick off a strenuous effort to land the Summer Games next week.

The official Sandinista newspaper reported today that many Nicaraguans are dubious about the decision this week to pardon Eugene Hasenfus. But the newspaper, Barricada, defended the freeing of the American as a step that could bolster those in the United States seeking to end American aid to Nicaraguan rebels. Mr. Hasenfus, who was serving a 30-year prison sentence after his plane carrying guns to rebels was shot down over Nicaragua on Oct. 5, was pardoned Wednesday by President Daniel Ortega Saavedra and flew out of Nicaragua the same day. ''For some sectors of the Nicaraguan public, the first reaction has justifiably been to say that Hasenfus deserved to spend 30 years in jail,'' Barricada said. ''Also justifiably, they say that this could be a negative precedent if more mercenaries fall into the people's hands as the war escalates. Justifiably and correctly, they ask, 'Why fight in the mountains if the prisoners are going to be freed later on?' ''

Fearing that it might send the wrong message to Albany, the Metropolitan Transporation Authority decided yesterday not to offer free fares over the New Year's holiday. Last year, in an effort to reduce drunken driving, two M.T.A. subsidiaries, the Metro-North Commuter Railroad and the Transit Authority, offered free rides from 8 P.M. on Dec. 31 until 8 A.M. on Jan. 1.

Chris Evert Lloyd and her husband, John, confirmed in an interview with The Fort Lauderdale News and Sun-Sentinel that they had agreed to a ''very amicable'' separation, which has lasted three months and is the second for the couple since they married on April 17, 1979. ''We tried very hard to do this in a private and dignified way,'' said Chris Lloyd. ''But unfortunately, due to some nasty and untrue stories, epecially from the British press, we both felt it was necessary to set the record straight.''

A leading contender in the BOC round-the-world race, Jacques de Roux, is missing at sea, race officials said today. An air and rescue team from Canberra found de Roux's 50-foot yacht, Skoiern IV, today with sails flogging and the 49-year-old French solo sailor missing.
'Twas Game Six of the Series when out of the sky, Flew Sergio's parachute, a Met banner held high. His goal was to spur our home team to success, Burst Beantown's balloon claiming Sox were the best.

The Times Square U.S.O. center - long part of a network known as a soldier's home away from home - may soon become homeless. The center, in the basement of the Loews State Theater building at West 45th Street and Broadway, is being evicted to make room for a Times Square redevelopment project. ''It's not just another light gone out on Broadway,'' said the center's executive director, Robert L. Riddell. ''It's a beacon.''

Willy Roy, the Chicago Sting coach, refused to attend a Major Indoor Soccer League game against the New York Express last night, and his status will be considered by team executives next week. . . . Ed Zucker, a Rutgers senior who opened the basketball season with a 27-point performance against Rider, will miss the remainder of the season because of a back problem that has been diagnosed as congenital stenosis, a narrowing of the spinal canal. Coach Craig Littlepage said surgery had not been considered, but that Zucker had been advised to avoid physical activity. . . . Lefty Driesell, who resigned under pressure as head basketball coach at Maryland after the drug-related death last summer of Len Bias, will return to Atlantic Coast Conference basketball in January as a television analyst. . . . Joel Quenneville, a Hartford Whaler defenseman, underwent surgery to have a pin placed in his separated right shoulder and will be out of action for at least three months. . . . George Foreman, the heavyweight boxing champion in 1973 and 1974, has abandoned plans for a comeback that was to begin with a fight in Tucson, Ariz., on Jan 7. The Arizona Republic quoted Johnny Montana of the Arizona Boxing Commission as saying that the fight plans had been canceled.

Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d reportedly told Congress today that the diversion of millions of dollars from the Iran arms sales to the Nicaraguan rebels was uncovered when a senior Justice Department official found an undated memorandum in the files of Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North proposing the idea. According to a Congressional source, Mr. Meese told the House Intelligence Committee that Colonel North was ''ashen'' when he confronted him with the memorandum during an interview in his office on Nov. 23. The document was found by Assistant Attorney General Bradford Reynolds, one of several senior Justice Department officials who were helping Mr. Meese in efforts to draw up a chronology of the Iran arms deal, the source quoted Mr. Meese as having said. Who wrote the memorandum, or whether it was ever circulated to other National Security Council staff members, is not clear. But shortly after it was uncovered, Mr. Meese reportedly told the committee, Colonel North acknowledged arranging the diversion and offered an example of how much money could be realized from the sale of 500 TOW missiles.

The city's highest-ranking uniformed police officer has been reassigned after reports that a Federal grand jury and the Federal Bureau of Investigation were investigating drug-related allegations about the Police Department. The officer, Patrol Cmdr.

So far only the faces are different in Vietnam, but policy changes could be next. If these bring relaxation of control at home and in Cambodia, they could be of enormous importance to the people of Indochina and open some interesting opportunities in the Soviet-Chinese-American triangle. Economic reformers dominate the new leadership lineup announced at this week's Communist Party Congress. Vietnam has been mired in deep poverty, the price of doctrinaire Communism and aggression in Cambodia. The Vietnamese people need relief.

The Department of Agriculture has received complaints from consumer groups opposing a proposal by meatpackers that they be allowed to spray substances on fresh pork to maintain its color. The substances - ascorbic acid, erythorbic acid, citric acid, sodium ascorbate and sodium citrate - are all regarded by Federal officials as safe to consume. A spokesman for the department said that about 50 comments had been received concerning the proposal, including those from consumer groups that object on the ground that no additives should be permitted in fresh foods. The deadline for additional comments is Monday.

76ers in Bid for Free The Philadelphia 76ers gave World B. Free an offer sheet yesterday for an estimated $250,000 to join the club for the rest of the season. Free, a 33-year-old guard, played the last four seasons for the Cleveland Cavaliers.

Prices of crude oil and petroleum products continued to fluctuate in frenetic trading yesterday amid reports that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries was close to signing an accord. Crude oil prices opened sharply higher on world markets on expectations that an accord would be announced during the day, but there was a marked selloff when that failed to materialize.

George Hansen, former Idaho Representative, leaving Federal prison in Petersburg, Va. He had served six month of a 15-month sentence for violation of the 1978 Ethics in Government Act by falsifying financial disclosure statements. (UPI)

I couldn't wait to get my copy of People magazine and see if its list of the 25 most intriguing people of 1986 matched my own. What a letdown. Here are the usual suspects: entertainers whose photos constantly festoon news and gossip magazines, a couple of nowhere politicians (Marxist Nicaraguan Prexy Daniel Ortega and Christian U.S. would-be Prexy the Rev. Pat Robertson, for gosh sakes!), and the customary Royal Promotion Object sent over by the Brits, who this year happens to be Sarah Ferguson, poor girl. Forgive me - poor woman.

WITH more than 1,750 mutual funds to choose from, the 25 million individuals who use this investment vehicle have plenty of alternatives. And more and more of these investors are not limiting themselves to a single fund these days, but are instead moving periodically from one to another. With such organizations as Fidelity, Dreyfus, T. Rowe Price and Federated managing a wide variety of mutual funds in categories that include aggressive growth, municipal bonds and money markets, individuals can easily shift into a different category as their needs change. Investors might typically switch from, say, a money market fund to an aggressive growth fund or from a common stock fund to a bond fund for either of two reasons: primarily an actual or perceived change in economic conditions and secondarily an adjustment in personal circumstances.

A furor over a black man's arrest and his being led through a neighborhood while attached by rope to a mounted officer's saddle has prompted the Police Department to abandon the restraint policy. ''There's no real reason for it, and it presents a very poor appearance,'' Comdr. Keith Enerson of the police said Thursday. Police officials ''looked at the facts of the incident and determined this wasn't a good practice.''

According to the city's Department of Transportation, these will be among the most severe traffic trouble spots in the region today: * The Manhattan Bridge, where the Manhattan-bound upper roadway will be closed. The lower roadway will have three lanes open heading into Manhattan.

Some of President Reagan's calls with foreign leaders have been recorded, but no tapes are known to have been made through a conference system in the White House Situation Room, the White House said today. The White House spokesman, Larry Speakes, said he was not aware of any time, other than in discussions with foreign leaders, that Mr. Reagan's telephone calls had been recorded.

In an effort to save the United Nations from bankruptcy, the General Assembly agreed unanimously today on a resolution to revamp the administration and budget-making process of the world body. The compromise agreement came after months of debate in closed-door sessions, with the major donors, including the United States and the Soviet Union, on one side, and the developing countries, which make up the majority of the United Nations membership but pay little of its costs, on the other. Both sides claimed victory today but acknowledged that member countries would have to exercise good will to make the revisions work.

Three former White House national security advisers said today that the former United States Ambassador to the Vatican had been ordered repeatedly to cease unauthorized contacts with Libyan officials, and that the Ambassador had gone to Tripoli in November 1985 without telling anyone in the United States Government. The former national security advisers said, in interviews and through intermediaries, that the ambassador, William A. Wilson, had apparently misled the Italian Foreign Minister, Giulio Andreotti, into thinking that because of Mr. Wilson's known friendship with President Reagan the White House was behind his request that the Italians set up a meeting for him with Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, in Libya. Official American policy throughout this Administration has been to isolate the Libyans. Italian Aranged the Meeting But Mr. Andreotti, who has urged that there be contacts between the United States and Libya, facilitated the Wilson request and arranged the meeting, which occurred on Nov. 28, 1985. Officials have said they did not learn of it until Colonel Qaddafi mentioned in passing that he had had a meeting, and it was not publicly disclosed until March 1986.

A national environmental group demanded today that a $50 million modernization program scheduled to begin this month at the main United States nuclear reactor producing weapon-grade plutonium for nuclear warheads be delayed for a study of the plan's environmental impact. Such a study could take months or years.

Salvagers, wiser after 22 frustrating days trying to remove a wrecked barge, lifted the vessel today from a Niagara River bridge abutment where it had helped boost Lake Erie past record levels.
