Bad weather and improper equipment had hindered previous attempts to get the barge off the middle abutment of the Peace Bridge, which connects Buffalo and Fort Erie, Ontario.

THE man looked at the teeming masses inside 47th Street Photo and froze in the doorway like a paratrooper making his first jump into combat. ''It's all right,'' said Leah Goldstein in a soothing voice, and she pulled him into the store by the sleeve of his jacket. The man apologized, explaining that he was from Altoona. The perennial Christmas buying frenzy in New York has reached a crescendo, with Salvation Army volunteers complaining of bell-ringers elbow and electronics discount stores experiencing crush loading conditions.

When Republicbank and Interfirst, two of the state's biggest banks, announced their merger this week, Wall Street booed. Investors knocked $2.75 off the price of Republicbank's shares, pushing it down to $19. But here in Dallas, city leaders rallied around the deal. Robert S. Strauss, a prominent Dallas lawyer who was chairman of the Democratic Party during the Carter Administration, said he bought shares of both Interfirst and Republicbank this morning.

The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed early today to cut oil production and promptly raise prices to $18 a barrel. Iraq refused to sign the output-trimming accord, under which the other 12 nations in the group agreed to across-the-board reductions in oil output of more than 7 percent for the first six months of next year. Given Iraq's current production of roughly 1.6 million barrels a day, the agreement appears to reduce OPEC production by one million barrels a day, to roughly 16 million barrels. For days, Iraq had insisted it would not join any accord that did not give it a production quota equal to that of Iran, its enemy in the lengthy Gulf war.

For the first few weeks of class, officials at the University of Miami were afraid that Tito Horford, the much-traveled player, was having a tougher time than expected in the classroom. But as the first semester ends, Horford, who will make his debut against Dartmouth tonight, has pulled his weight in the classroom. According to Jacqui Colyer, who directs the athletic academic support center at Miami, Horford should earn ''between a 2.5 and 2.7'' grade-point average in 14 hours of course work this semester. The improvement, she said, was due less to a change in Horford's attitude than to a change of language.

''Chryptych'' was a misleadingly punning title for a serious piece of choreography that honored a beautiful building. Choreographed by Gus Solomons Jr. for the Solomons Company/Dance, it was performed Thursday night in the austerely elegant sanctuary of St. Mark's Church, the space that was its inspiration. The audience sat where the altar would have been if a worship service was being held and the performance area was ringed by pillars supporting a balcony. Directly opposite the audience was the church's front door.

The National Collegiate Athletic Association confirmed today it had placed the Iowa State football program on a two-year probation and limited its athletic scholarships because of recruiting violations.

The jury in the State Supreme Court trial of a television makeup artist accused in the razor-slashing of a model's face completed its second day of deliberations last night in Manhattan without reaching a verdict. The jury, which was sequestered in a hotel, will resume deliberations at 10 A.M. today. The defendant, Steven Roth, 28 years old of 455 West 34th Street is charged with first degree assault and faces up to 15 years in prison if convicted of the attack on the model, Marla Hanson, 25.

Werner Dankwort, a former West German observer to the United Nations, died Monday. He was 91 years old. Mr. Dankwort, who retired to Cape Cod after serving at the United Nations from 1958 to 1960, was active in bringing Germany into the League of Nations in 1926.

The Consumer Price Index rose three-tenths of 1 percent in November, continuing the mild pickup in inflation that has accompanied firmer oil prices, the Labor Department reported today. The latest figures, which were in line with expectations, showed that if the price index rises by the same amount again this month, the 1986 inflation rate would be 1.2 percent, the smallest December-to-December increase since 1962. Economists said they regarded the November reading as further reassurance that there would little upward pressure on prices in the foreseeable future. 'Low-Inflation Environment' ''I think what it shows is a continued low-inflation environment,'' said Brian S. Wesbury, an economist at Chicago's Harris Trust and Savings Bank. Norman Robertson of the Mellon Bank added, ''We shall continue to hold inflation at bay.''

Lava destroyed 13 houses and forced more than 400 people to flee as molten rock from Mount Kilauea surged into an area of homes early today. The lava has engulfed 26 homes since the Thanksgiving holiday in this village on the south coast of the island of Hawaii. More than 80 homes were still being threatened.

Dr. Morton H. Fried, a professor of anthropology at Columbia University, died of cardiac arrest Thursday night at his home in Leonia, N.J. He was 63 years old. Dr. Fried, who was on the Columbia faculty 37 years, specialized in Chinese anthropology.

INTERNATIONAL 3-8 A special prosecutor was appointed to take charge of the Iran arms sales case. Lawrence E. Walsh, a 74-year-old former Federal judge in Manhattan, will have broad powers to investigate wrongdoing. Page 1 Man in the News: Lawrence Walsh, whose career has included frequent trouble-shooting missions, occasional controversy and moments in the spotlight, has experience as a prosecutor, judge and advocate. 6 Edwin Meese 3d told Congress that the diversion of funds from Iranian arms sales to the Nicaraguan rebels was uncovered when a memo proposing the idea was found in Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North's files, a Congressional source said.

Pactel Personal Communications, a subsidiary of the Pacific Telesis Group, said today that it had agreed to buy a group of Michigan and Ohio cellular telephone companies for $316 million. Pactel currently operates the country's largest cellular system in Los Angeles as well as systems in San Diego, San Francisco and Sacramento.

As another National Football League regular season closes with games last night through Monday, it's only right that certain people be acknowledged for their contributions, some of which have added to (or subtracted from) the general enjoyment of the last four months. In any case, the following awards are officially unofficial and are presented in the holiday spirit of good fun and good cheer: Player of the Year: Doug Flutie of the Chicago Bears. Never before has so much attention been received for so little achieved. Executive of the Year: Ladd Herzeg, the general manager of the Houston Oilers. He traded to the Rams Jim Everett, who figures to be their quarterback for the next 10 or 12 years. Everett fits in nicely with Eric Dickerson, whom the Rams drafted three years ago with a pick Herzeg traded them.

The pianist Barry Harris will lead a trio tonight at the Jazz Cultural Theater, 368 Eighth Avenue, above 28th Street (502-4300). Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M. Tomorrow Mr. Harris will lead a big band with the first set at 7 P.M. Admission is $8, $5 for students and the elderly.

Saturday is an end and a beginning for the Giants. Their 12:30 P.M. game against the Green Bay Packers at Giants Stadium marks the end of their regular season, their best since the glory days of the early 1960's. Their record is 13-2. The 1929 and 1930 Giants won 13 games, but no Giant team has ever won 14.

The second program presented by Dennis Wayne's Dancers on Tuesday at the Triplex Theater at Manhattan Community College is just the thing for those who like their dance pretty and their dancers personable and beautifully trained. The evening gets off to a friendly start with the dancers introducing themselves, as they do at each program, and so one has the sense of watching friends throughout the evening. William Soleau, the company's resident choreographer, contributed three of the program's five dances. In ''Isle,'' performed to music by Henry Purcell, Mr. Soleau offered a well-crafted romantic duet full of muted feeling. Vivien Cockburn was compellingly clear, light and focused and Mr. Soleau moved with quiet power through the foldings, unfoldings and shared journey of this elegiac work.

Lawrence E. Walsh has spent 50 years weaving the threads of public service and private representation into a career that has included frequent troubleshooting missions, occasional controversy, moments in the spotlight, experience as a prosecutor, judge and advocate and service at the highest levels of the profession. Today he said that the job of independent counsel was ''probably the most important that I've been asked to do.'' Then he added: ''And so I wanted to do it.'' Thirteen years ago Mr. Walsh was on the list of potential special prosecutors to head the Watergate investigation. For decades, his name has been on nearly any list of lawyers required for various blue-ribbon assignments. Over the years, one of his former law partners said today that ''private clients have turned to him when they were in trouble and public officials have turned to him when government was in trouble.''

Amid the spate of proposals that Ronald Reagan be restored to respectability by the counseling of ''wise men,'' the question arises, ''Are there no wise women in our nation who might have some sound advice to offer?'' We can hear the groans. Does there have to be a ''woman's angle'' to everything, including the Iranian-Nicaraguan mess? Yes, more than ever. Please note that as in Watergate no women are involved in the latest Government scandal. One can argue whether in today's scandal this is due to superior morality or to the inferior, virtually nonexistent role they play in making foreign policy. But having had no part in the conspiracy, women outsiders could bring more objectivity to the situation than the usual crew of ''wise men,'' themselves entangled in the secret webbing of the establishment's corporate-military-Government network.

A Soviet official said today that ''several hundred'' students had been involved in the anti-Russian rioting that broke out Wednesday night in Alma-Ata, the capital of the Central Asian republic of Kazakhstan. The official said everything was back to normal after the unrest, which apparently broke out in protest at the appointment of an ethnic Russian to replace the Kazakh who had long led the Communist Party in the republic. The official press agency Tass reported tonight that Mikhail S. Solomentsev, a member of the ruling Politburo and chairman of the Communist Party committee responsible for party discipline, was visiting Alma-Ata.

A brief Washington dispatch on the television page on Nov. 27 reported Federal Communications Commission approval for the sale of WOR-TV by RKO General to MCA. The article also included background information on a longstanding dispute between the F.C.C. and RKO.

''Both Academician Sakharov and Bonner have the possibility to return to Moscow, and Academician Sakharov has the possibility to actively participate in academic life.'' - Vladimir F. Petrovsky, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister. [ 8:1. ]

The jazz-blues guitarist Jimmy Ponder will lead a trio tonight at Brown's Cafe, 5601 Second Avenue, in the Sunset Park section of Brooklyn (718-439-5335). There are four sets nightly, beginning at 10; there is a $6 minimum and no cover.

Yonkers Raceway will end its Sunday racing program for this meeting tomorrow night, meaning that there will be no harness racing at the track next Sunday and Jan. 4. ''With both local N.F.L. teams involved in the playoffs, we felt it would be in our best interests not to open on those two Sundays,'' said Bob Galterio, the track's general manager.

Vice President Bush, suggesting that Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter and Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North should waive their constitutional right against self-incrimination, today called on the two former White House officials to ''tell us the truth'' about their roles in the Iran arms controversy. Mr. Bush did not explicitly ask Admiral Poindexter and Colonel North to stop invoking their Fifth Amendment protections. But he said both men, former officials of the National Security Council staff, should ''make a great sacrifice'' by answering the questions of panels investigating the controversy. ''The country cannot wait any longer,'' he said.

Butch Wynegar, who desperately wanted to leave the Yankees, was traded to the California Angels yesterday and sacrificed $127,000 of his 1986 salary for his freedom. The Yankees, as had been expected for more than a month, sent the unhappy catcher to the Angels for Ron Romanick, a pitcher, and a minor league player to be named. The Yankees did not say if they included money in the deal to defray Wynegar's $700,000-a-year salary for each of the next two years.

Finally, after almost seven punishing years of internal exile, Andrei Sakharov, the Soviet Union's most prominent dissident, will soon be back in Moscow. Perhaps the Russians have found some new way of balancing their fear of criticism at home against their wish to be liked abroad. Perhaps they simply found the cost of muzzling someone of Mr. Sakharov's stature to be too high. Whatever the reason, the result is welcome news. He may not be wholly free but at least he's going back home, with his wife, Yelena Bonner, whom the Russians have pardoned. The couple's return warms this holiday season.

A New York businessman who the Director of Central Intelligence says first alerted him to the diversion of Iranian arms profits to the Nicaraguan rebels is one of seven people whose names have been given to Swiss banking authorities for investigation into whether they had accounts used in the scheme. A list of the seven, plus two companies, was prepared by the United States Justice Department. It was submitted to Swiss authorities on Wednesday. The businessman, Roy M. Furmark, is a former business associate of the C.I.A. chief, William J. Casey.

One of two versions of a letter written by Albert Einstein on Aug. 2, 1939, to President Franklin D. Roosevelt -the letter that sparked the American effort to build the atomic bomb -was bought at Christie's yesterday by Malcolm Forbes, the magazine publisher, for $220,000. ''The letter represents an incredible historical milestone; to me, it is the reason we've had peace for 40 years,'' Mr. Forbes said after he made the purchase - of what he called a seminal document - for the Forbes Magazine Galleries, 62 Fifth Avenue, at 12th Street.

Before he was a Lieutenant Governor and then a United States Senator, Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts was a lawyer and Assistant District Attorney in Middlesex County, one of the nation's biggest and most active local jurisdictions. As a Senator, he has spent more than a year directing his staff in an investigation of a private network aiding the insurgents in Nicaragua and the Reagan Administration's part in it.

When the San Francisco Opera canceled its 1987 summer season recently, many people here viewed the decision as another sign that this city had passed its prime. According to leaders of the local arts community, so many of San Francico's largest and oldest employers have left town or run into economic storms recently that corporate contributions to the arts have plummeted. Because of that, the leaders say they are being forced to trim the city's menu of cultural programs. Michael Gehret, director of development for the San Francisco Symphony, which canceled a tour of the Soviet Union after local corporations showed little interest in subsidizing it, said, ''If the business strength of San Francisco continues to weaken, we'll lose not only dollars, but also business leadership on our boards and as volunteer fund-raisers.''

A car trapped in the collapsed pavement of Southern Boulevard after a 36-inch pipe broke and undermined the roadway. Five million gallons of water were released into the Longwood Avenue station before workers could get it turned off. Page 31. (NYT/John Sotomayer)

A mouse strayed into Maxilla and Mandible the other day and never left. It expired in the middle of a laboratory floor for unknown reasons and now resides in the freezer. Standing in the anatomical supply company's basement laboratory beneath Columbus Avenue this week, Henry Galiano, the 35-year-old owner of Maxilla and Mandible, rummaged through the freezer, lifting out frozen tuna tails, iguanas, lizards, squirrel monkeys, squirrels, and the heads of bobcats, flounders, gray foxes and raccoons. ''We scrounge everywhere,'' he said, finding the mouse and lifting it up to the light for a look. ''I used to pick up road kills. The highways of the United States are great places to collect natural history. This is an opportunistic business.''
Stock Volume at a Record A record 244 million shares traded on the New York Stock Exchange - 85 million in the final minute at the ''triple witching hour.''

There are several sure-fire ways in Japan to tell that New Year's is coming. Stores have begun to offer doughy rice cakes for the holidays. Elaborately decorated battledores are on sale near the Asakusa Kannon Temple in Tokyo. And posters have gone up everywhere announcing that the latest Tora-san film is about to open. Tora-san is a fumbling, Chaplinesque vagabond, a bit short on brains but limousine-long on heart, a comforting echo of a once simpler life. Actually, he is not so much a movie character as a Japanese institution.

Oh, to have been a fly on the wall at the meeting where it was decided that the rumors of King Kong's death had been greatly exaggerated. Someone must have noted that Kong certainly seemed dead, having fallen off the World Trade Center and been pumped full of buckshot. But that wouldn't have killed Bobby Ewing, and it didn't kill Kong either. In ''King Kong Lives,'' which opened yesterday at the Criterion and other theaters, it develops that Kong has spent the last 10 years in a coma, waiting to become the recipient of an artificial heart.

To the Editor: You may keep the ''spray-painted worm'' awarded to the Department of Sanitation for its graffiti-covered trucks (''The Worm and the Apple: Trashed Trucks,'' Nov. 28) because clearly it is not deserved and wrongfully blames the victim. Obviously, the best method of graffiti prevention would be good, secure garages or storage facilities. Unfortunately, many communities do not welcome the construction of a Sanitation Department garage, even when it provides the vital cleaning, collection and snow-removal service they are so anxious to receive. One negative result of having to park trucks on the street is graffiti.

Ronald E. Cohen, a longtime Washington journalist recently dismissed as managing editor of United Press International, has signed on at Gannett Company headquarters in Roslyn, Va., as a news executive. A 25-year veteran of U.P.I., Mr. Cohen helped hold the organization together in several economic crises but was ousted a month ago by the editor in chief, Malcolm Hughes.
The U.S.O. is a voluntary, nonprofit organization serving the men and women of today's military and their families.

Mayor Koch said yesterday that the city would push for a law mandating that anyone selling a building set aside enough money from the sale to correct the most severe housing code violations. The Mayor and Housing Commissioner Paul A. Crotty, who appeared together at a City Hall news conference, said they would ask the State Legislature to pass enabling legislation in its session to begin next month. The city needs state authority to require that landlords set up such an escrow fund.

The Metropolitan Transportation Authority, unable to win support from the Legislature for its $8.6 billion plan to rebuild the region's transit system, served notice yesterday that it was prepared to ask riders to pay sharply higher fares rather than scale back its efforts. In what the M.T.A. chairman, Robert R. Kiley, said was ''an insurance policy'' against continued inaction in Albany, the agency's board voted to begin a process that could raise subway and bus fares from $1 to as much as $1.35 on Jan. 27 and increase commuter rail fares as much as 48 percent by March 1. The base tolls at major crossings operated by the subsidiary Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority would rise 25 cents under the plan by Jan. 27. ''What we do, we can undo,'' Mr. Kiley said. He added that he thought a compromise might be worked out in Albany in time to avert the higher fares.

It may not be unprecedented for both husband and wife to have books on the best-seller list simultaneously, but tomorrow a couple who live in Berwyn, Pa., will find themselves in that enviable position. They are Julie Nixon Eisenhower, the daughter of the 37th President, and David Eisenhower, the grandson of the 34th President. Her biography of her mother, ''Pat Nixon: The Untold Story'' (Simon & Schuster), has been a best seller for four weeks and tomorrow will be No. 9 on The New York Times nonfiction list. Mr. Eisenhower's biography of his grandfather, ''Eisenhower at War: 1943-1945'' (Random House), will be No. 15 on the same list. Mr. Eisenhower's book - the first of three volumes - was on the list briefly in October. Its return may have been helped by the author's appearances with his wife (whose book was published two months after his) on the Phil Donohue show and at several book signings. Among these was one at Macy's in Manhattan and another at the Lyndon B. Johnson Library in Austin, Tex., to which they were invited by Lady Bird Johnson.

In a reversal of policy, the Defense Department is asserting its right to play a major role in a proposed space station because of a potential need to use it for ''Star Wars'' research, Government officials said yesterday. The decision threatened to jeopardize delicate negotiations to arrange broad international cooperation in the project. Western Europe, Japan and Canada have agreed in principle to provide financial support for the $8 billion station, but the Pentagon has now asked the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to postpone further talks with foreign participants that had been scheduled in mid-January. The Defense Department's action marked a further assertion of military influence over the civilian space program, especially since the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger. Pentagon officials said a new ''defense space policy,'' expected soon, would encourage greater emphasis on manned military space operations, in part to conduct experiments for the space-based missile defense program, formally the Strategic Defense Initiative.

There were no parades or confetti throwers today for Eugene Hasenfus, the American cargo handler pardoned by Nicaragua for smuggling arms to the rebels there. There were a couple of ''Welcome Home'' signs on storefront marquees. It was a quiet return of the native to this northern Wisconsin town of 12,000 people, where residents are divided over the propriety of Mr. Hasenfus's actions to aid the Nicaraguan counterrevolutionaries. ''We're not talking about an American war hero,'' said Mayor Harold A. Pierce. ''We're talking about a guy who was lucky.''

The Beneficial Corporation, one of the nation's largest consumer lenders, said yesterday that it had rejected a $1.74 billion takeover bid from ''a major U.S. corporation'' as inadequate and decided instead to sell some $1.4 billion of its operations to trim debts. The company also suggested that job cutbacks of its 6,000 employees were also a possibility. Wall Street reacted gloomily to the announcement, with Beneficial's stock sliding $3, a share, to $56, in heavy trading. Last August, when Beneficial announced that the Alleghany Corporation was accumulating shares, the stock jumped $28.50 in one day, to $73. The stock has weakened substantially since then, and Alleghany and others are thought to have lost interest in a takeover.

Consumer prices in the New York-northeastern New Jersey area declined one-tenth of 1 percent in November, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday. The regional commissioner of the bureau, Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, cited an absence of ''upward pressure on prices in major categories.''

Shortly after World War II a friend brought a young student to the Nobel Prize-winning physicist Igor Tamm, proposing the young man for independent study. Professor Tamm interviewed the young student, Andrei D. Sakharov, at length, but finally decided not to take him. Later the professor confided to a friend what he had advised the student: ''You know, young man, it's hardly likely that you will make a real physicist. You have a sort of humanistic cast of mind.''

The New York State Racing and Wagering Board has fined the New York Racing Association's clerk of scales, Charles Sullivan, $500 for an error that resulted in several apprentice jockeys at Aqueduct riding with a two-pound weight allowance to which they were not entitled. The riders involved will suffer no penalty. The clerk, who has been in that job since April 1, 1981, misapplied a rule that an apprentice is allowed a 10-pound weight allowance until he has ridden five career winners, and only a 7-pound allowance until he has ridden an additional 30 winners. After that, his allowance drops to five pounds. Jockeys lose their apprenticeships a year after their 35th winner.

The Ford Motor Company and other car manufacturers must abide by a state law extending warranties on all new cars but do not have to reimburse customers who already paid repair bills, a state judge ruled yesterday. Attorney General Robert Abrams began the lawsuit in March because Ford's warranty covered only the first 12,000 miles on an automobile, but charged $100 to fix breakdowns that occurred later.
The top of the steeple of the former St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church falling to the ground during fire yesterday.

Personnel and institutional changes in the National Park Service ordered by the Interior Department could change the character of the parks over time, Park Service officials asserted today. But Interior Secretary Donald P. Hodel defended the changes. Senior Park Service officials here and around the country contended that the changes had been imposed to wrest control over park policy from the service's professional staff and place it in the hands of political appointees. But Secretary Hodel responded that the charge that the Reagan Administration was trying to strengthen political control over the service ''will not stand up to scrutiny.'' He said in an interview that the job changes would send ''a new burst of adrenalin'' through the service.

New York State officials, saying the New York City suburbs were experiencing a housing shortage of crisis proportions, proposed government incentives yesterday to encourage construction in Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester and Rockland Counties. In a report to Governor Cuomo, the State Housing Director, William B. Eimicke, said the four counties needed at least 100,000 new houses to fill an ''affordable housing gap'' that is growing more acute each year. Mr. Eimicke recommended using new subsidies and tax incentives, revising zoning laws and selling public land to developers.

A stolen legal file about Albert Hakim, a figure in the Iran arms controversy, was returned by a man who put it in an airport locker and left the key for Mr. Hakim's lawyer, the attorney said today. Mr. Hakim, a Los Gatos businessman, is reported to have helped Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North transfer funds from the profits in the Iran arms sales to the Nicaraguan rebels.

An article on Thursday about the donation of the Pforzheimer Collection on the Romantic poets to the New York Public Library misidentified the first editor of ''Shelley and His Circle, 1773-1822.'' He is Kenneth Neill Cameron.

A picture caption yesterday about Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger's arrival for Congressional testimony on arms sales to Iran misidentified the committee that heard him. It was the House Intelligence Committee, not the Senate committee.

The Court of Appeals ruled today that it was unconstitutional for state-regulated utilities to contribute ratepayer money to charity, saying the practice forces customers to subsidize causes they may oppose. The state's highest court, in a 5-to-2 decision, held that the practice, which is widespread, violates the right of free expression. ''Coercion results from the fact that the state establishes the rate that the customer must pay, and the rate includes an allowance for the objected-to contributions,'' the majority opinion said. ''Because the utility is a monopoly, the customer must pay or be deprived of his right to utility service.''

Yesterday's ''triple witching hour'' was a unique event in a number of respects, traders and market analysts said. Not only did more shares trade hands at the close than ever before -over 85 million - but the stock market handled the huge order flow ''without a glitch,'' according to Richard Torrenzano, a New York Stock Exchange spokesman. Of more interest to professionals were the tactics employed at the close, a time when stock index futures, stock index options and individual stock options all expire. Generally, on triple expiration Fridays, most of the attention is focused on the relationship between the expiring futures contracts and the underlying stocks. But yesterday, most of the action, and the reason stock prices rose at the close, was due to the relationship between the price of the March Standard & Poor's 500 futures contract and the underlying stocks.

After days of proposals and counterproposals, Governor Cuomo and key legislators ended the week with no agreement today on a plan to finance a rebuilding of New York City's mass-transit system and freeze its fares. The special session of the Legislature recessed and will resume Monday. The decision to recess came shortly before 3 P.M. as negotiations, already complex, grew even more confused when Senate Republicans agreed to reconsider a Democratic proposal that they had rejected less than 24 hours before. ''We're going around in circles,'' Assembly Speaker Stanley Fink, a Brooklyn Democrat, said as he left an hourlong meeting with Mr. Cuomo and Warren M. Anderson, a Binghamton Republican who is the Senate majority leader.

Tim Witherspoon, it turns out, did not smoke marijuana before he was knocked out in one round by James (Bonecrusher) Smith Dec. 12 in their World Boxing Association heavyweight title bout. On Wednesday, Jose Torres, chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission, said that postfight tests of Witherspoon's urine specimens had revealed traces of marijuana in the fighter's system. At the time Torres said that Witherspoon would be suspended. But yesterday, Torres said that an employee in the commission's office had made a ''critical error'' in the identification of the urine specimen.
BASKETBALL KNICKS VS. INDIANA PACERS, at Madison Square Garden, 7:30 P.M. (TV - MSG, 7 P.M.; Radio - WNBC 660, 7:20 P.M.).

Every Thursday morning, the waiting room in Suite L at New York University Medical Center is crowded with balding men. Once in the doctor's office, they offer their bald spots for measurement and then collect a month's supply of a clear, astringent liquid. That liquid, Rogaine, may offer a touch of bottled youth. It contains minoxidil, the first drug to offer some hope of overcoming a receding hairline. Twice a day, every day, the patients in the New York University study squeeze the solution on their scalps. ''It's a pain,'' said Matti Leshem, a 23-year-old actor. ''I'm lucky,'' said a 27-year-old lawyer. Minoxidil was originally developed by the Upjohn Company as an oral drug to treat hypertension. When patients on the medication started sprouting hair on various parts of their bodies, Upjohn researchers decided to turn the drug's side effect into an asset. They dissolved minoxidil in a lotion and began testing it as an elixir for those suffering from the most common form of hair loss, male-pattern baldness. Since clinical tests began, some patients have grown hair where they had become bald. Even more have thickened wispy strands, and for all the progress of hair loss has stopped. It takes from three to six months for any changes to occur.

The Soviet Ambassador to the United States said today that American scientists could monitor a nuclear explosion when the Soviet Union resumes underground testing. The Ambassador, Yuri A. Dubinin, also stressed continuing Soviet interest in working out a ''gradual'' program for limiting and eventually stopping nuclear tests. The Soviet Union has allowed American scientists from the Natural Resources Defense Council, a private American group, to set up seismic monitoring equipment in the Soviet Union. Three sites have been established 200 miles from a test site at Semipalatinsk, in Central Asia.
To the Editor: Prof. Harry V. Jaffa protests (letter, Dec. 7) that the Founding Fathers did not condone slavery, and quotes James Madison's aversion to it.

An amazing thing has happened to the muddy trickle of a river that separates the United States from Mexico here. For a change, the Rio Grande is living up to its name. Instead of the usual sorry stream along the border with Mexico, it has become a Big River, and in the process it seems to be succeeding in slowing illegal immigration where generations of law enforcers have failed. It has also created a treacherous situation that has led to the drownings of dozens of aliens unprepared for the river's new potency and has led to fears of flooding on the Mexican side of the river.

David Shanks, president of the Berkley Publishing Group, which includes Berkley and Jove books, was named senior vice president of the Putnam Publishing Group on Tuesday. According to Putnam, he will deal with corporate policy and planning for all Putnam's publishing divisions, which include Berkley, G. P. Putnam's Sons and the Putnam Young Readers Group.

A cancer patient who has sought to leave the Soviet Union for eight years arrived in New York yesterday and, amid tears and bouquets of pink carnations, was reunited with the mother she thought she would never see again. ''Mama, it's O.K.,'' the patient, Rimma Bravve, the 32-year-old emigre from Moscow, said as she brushed back tears and embraced her sobbing mother, Khanna Anbinder, 65 years old, a retired Rochester pediatrician who left the Soviet Union in 1980 after the death of her husband. ''It is the happiest day of my life,'' Mrs. Bravve said at a crowded afternoon news conference later at Kennedy International Airport. Speaking in English, she added, ''I was waiting for this day to come for eight years.''

Along with Channel 13's ''Channel Crossings,'' Channel 31's ''Window on World Television'' has been taking advantage of what is supposed to be a ''global village'' by acquiring outstanding television productions from around the world, not just from English-speaking sources. More often than not, the policy has paid off handsomely. The latest example of clever purchasing is a new production of ''Lysistrata'' by Aristophanes, which Channel 31 will broadcast tomorrow night at 10.

No political crisis is complete these days without its footnotes in the form of lapel button, and the Iran-Nicaragua contretemps is no exception. The Young Republicans came up with ''North, American Hero,'' selling for $2 to aid Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North's defense fund, and now the Youth for Democratic Action is selling, for $1, a button that reads, ''Did Reagan know, or was he napping?'' The group says an informal survey attendant to the sale of the button has so far logged 32 respondents favoring napping as against 15 believing the President knew. One repondent, naturally, took the Fifth.

Robert M. Gates, Acting Director of Central Intelligence since William J. Casey was hospitalized, has been Deputy Director of the Central Intelligence Agency since April. Mr. Gates, who is 43 years old, has served in the agency and as a staff member of the National Security Council for 20 years. A native of Kansas, Mr. Gates earned a doctoral degree in Russian and Soviet history from Georgetown University here in 1974.

Bargaining sessions in the five-month-old contract dispute between the USX Corporation and the United Steelworkers of America resumed today with both sides under strong pressure to reach a settlement. The negotiators met in Washington with a labor lawyer, Sylvester Garrett, as their mediator. The meeting was the first since union negotiators declared the talks suspended Nov. 21 because of a deadlock over job security and pay cuts.

Policy makers at the Federal Reserve left monetary policy unchanged at a meeting in early November, according to minutes of the meeting released today. Members of the policy-making group, the Federal Open Market Committee, decided against further moves to ease credit conditions and drive interest rates lower at their Nov. 5 meeting. The committee held another meeting this week and many financial analysts believe the central bank decided again to hold monetary policy steady. Information on that meeting will not be released until next month.
Forever Special, a 3-year-old filly, raced Demetroula into defeat and then went on to post a 2 3/4-length victory in the $33,000 allowance feature for fillies and mares yesterday at Aqueduct.
Bob Moses, center, leading in the recitation of a poem yesterday during funeral service for Ella Baker at the Abyssinian Baptist Church on West 138th Street.

The Nynex Corporation has agreed to buy a British company that offers computer software, professional and other business services for stock valued at $:75 million, or about $107 million. The company, Business International Services Ltd., has been privately owned.

A Federal judge today dismissed charges against John P. McGoff, a publisher accused of failing to register as a foreign agent of the South African Government. The judge, Charles R. Richey, ruled in Federal District Court here that the Government failed to file the charges against Mr. McGoff, who heads the Global Communication Corporation of Williamson, Mich., within the required five-year statute of limitations on such prosecutions. Mr. McGoff's lawyers had moved for dismissal of the charges, citing the time limit.

The heading yesterday on a Washington dispatch about Congressional reaction to the Administration policy on Soviet nuclear testing misidentified Edward J. Markey, Democrat of Massachusetts. He is a United States Representative, not a Senator.

To the Editor: Ihsan A. Hijazi's article on the Shiite-Palestinian battle in Lebanon (front page, Dec. 5) confirms what we've been hearing in urgent communications from partner agencies in that country: civilian casualties are skyrocketing, while emergency assistance isn't getting through, and the essential work of nonsectarian aid agencies is being severely disrupted. We recently received an urgent telex from Secours Populaire Libanais appealing for help to secure the release of a civilian doctor kidnapped by militiamen in south Lebanon. This week we got a letter from the Amel Association describing the impact of a car bomb on its head office and staff in Beirut.

The 17-year-old Columbia County honor student who has been charged with fatally shooting four people - his father, brother, cousin and his father's girlfriend - committed the murders last Saturday as part of an elaborate fantasy game, according to a law-enforcement official familiar with the case. ''This was all plotted out,'' said the official, who did not want to identified. He said the youth, Wyley Gates of Canaan, had been playing a game -possibly on a computer - that he had given the code name ''Infierno,'' a reference to Dante's ''Inferno.'' He said several other high school students were also involved in the game, which they had been playing for more than a month.

The police in Cape Town outlawed a Christmas campaign against South Africa's emergency today, ignoring a strong protest against the nation's crisis issued by the European Community. The nation's violence continued, meanwhile, with The Sowetan newspaper reporting at least five blacks slain in Soweto on Tuesday in fighting between campaigners against the emergency and conservative vigilantes. Britain's Ambassador, Sir Patrick Moberly, representing the 12 European Community members, delivered the protest note to the Foreign Ministry today, a community statement said.

In the toddler day-care center at Union Township High School this morning two juniors, Cathy Humphrey and Lisa Graves, were reading a story to Marisa Hanrahan, 20 months old. Across the hall, in the geriatric day-care center, Yesenia Rosa, 16, was talking quietly in Spanish with Ramon Garcia, 82. Usually, Miss Rosa said, Mr. Garcia keeps to himself. But on Friday mornings, he brightens when Miss Rosa visits and he can tell her stories of his boyhood in Spain in his native tongue.

Someone is putting brandy in your bonbons, Grand Marnier in your breakfast jam, Kahlua in your ice cream, Scotch in your mustard and Wild Turkey in your cake. Americans may be drinking fewer alcoholic beverages, but they are certainly eating more of them than ever before. Wittingly or un. It's not likely that the three-martini lunch of yesteryear will be replaced by topping off two slices of Irish whisky cake with four liqueur-laced bonbons, but such spirited foods often come as a surprise, even a shock, to the unsuspecting.

''To be homeless, hopeless and without family to turn to is one of life's tragedies,'' said Ellen V. Langner of Manhattan, in a note with a $50 gift for the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. She sent the gift, she said, ''to help a person in this situation find some relief.'' A $25,000 gift was made anonymously by a resident of Westport, Conn. A check for $2,500 came from the Charles H. Greenthal Group, a Manhattan real-estate concern; $750 was given by Gerard van Maarseveen of Manhattan, and $1,500 was sent by Curt and Fleur Strand of Manhattan.
Warren McVea, a former University of Houston and National Football League player, was jailed in lieu of $25,000 bond on charges of selling crack to support his drug habit, the Houston police said.

Dorothy Molter, once described as ''the loneliest woman in America,'' died in a log cabin where she lived for 56 years on a wilderness island, officials said today. She was 79 years old. Miss Molter, the last permanent resident of the million-acre Boundary Waters Canoe Area, was found dead Thursday, officials of the United States Forest Service said.

Stanley Hill, new head of District 37, the largest of New York City's government employee unions, charges that the Koch administration is unlawfully using more city workers who lack civil service status than its predecessor did: 24,000 against 9,000. He's right about the numbers, but exaggerates the law's implications. The courts have consistently sanctioned use of ''provisional'' employees until Civil Service produces certified candidates by examination.

Virginia Dorothy Lynch, the daughter of Caroline Hudson Lynch of Palm Beach, Fla., and New York, and Edmund C. Lynch Jr. of Hobe Sound, Fla., was married yesterday to James Howell Dean, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard B. Dean of New York and East Hampton, L.I. Bishop Robert R. Spears performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York. The bride, an independent unit production manager and assistant director of feature films in Manhattan, attended the Chapin School and graduated from the Foxcroft School and Colorado College.

To the Editor: Your ''worm'' to the Sanitation Department for graffiti on its trucks was most appropriate: however, more to the point, in a city where the bureaucracy is notoriously poor at maintaining its physical plant, why would sanitation vehicles be painted white in the first place?

The official responsible for investigating corruption at New York City's Health and Hospitals Corporation was cleared yesterday of allegations that he had impeded an inquiry. The city's Investigation Commissioner, Kenneth Conboy, said his agency had found no evidence of ''criminal wrongdoing'' by the official, Conrad Johns, the hospital corporation's inspector general. In April, the Department of Investigation subpoenaed records from the previous two years of Mr. Johns's inquiries into charges of corruption within the Emergency Medical Service, which operates the city's ambulances.

Living up to its name, the ''triple witching hour'' cast a bizarre spell over Wall Street yesterday as stock prices seemingly beat the odds by rising in the final minutes of the most hectic session in history. Not only was it Wall Street's busiest day, but the number of orders that piled up for execution at the closing bell produced the most frantic minute ever for the New York Stock Exchange, one in which more than 85 million shares traded. In all, almost 244.7 million shares traded on the Big Board, topping the previous record of 240.5 million, set Sept. 12. Despite the record activity, Wall Street seemed to handle the witching hour in stride, without the wrenching price movements of the past. ''The system is working remarkably well,'' said Louis Margolis, managing director of equities, options and futures at Salomon Brothers, a firm that was in the thick of the action.

The crown of grimy chimneys, which once symbolized this steel town, gave way some years ago to soaring office towers, whose skins shimmer at sunrise, beckoning commuters crossing the Monongahela River like so many sweet sirens. Steel City is now a city of glass. Once a symbol of the industrial region sometimes referred to as the Rust Belt, it is now a renowned health and educational center with a wealth of cultural attractions. When it comes time to pay taxes, however, health, education and culture are steel's miserly stepchildren.

The Toyota Motor Corporation, Japan's largest auto maker, predicted that its total production in 1987 would decline by 1 percent, to 3.6 million vehicles, from this year's projected output of 3.7 million.

Prices of long-term Treasury bonds posted modest gains yesterday in lackluster trading, intermediate maturities were largely unchanged and discount rates on bills eased further. In late trading, the offered price of the key long-term Treasury bond, the 7 1/2 percent issue of 2016, rose 3/32, to 101 20/32, for a yield of 7.36 percent, compared with 7.39 percent a week ago. In Chicago, the spot December Treasury bond futures, based on 20-year maturities, expired at noon at 100 22/32, up 10/32 on the day. March, the new spot future, rose 13/32, to 99 24/32.

Three retired admirals have set up a trust and will soon send out letters seeking donations for the defense of a beleaguered comrade, Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter, the President's national security adviser who resigned after disclosures about the Iran arms deal.

With just five important days remaining, the Christmas shopping season has so far failed to show more than sputtering sparks, assorted retailers said yesterday. Sales have barely met the moderate plans of retailers for the 26-day period, but they hope the last few days will make a big difference. ''Few people are having an excellent season so far,'' one top merchant said, ''so it looks like another cliffhanger.'' The retailer, head of one of the nation's best-known department stores and who asked not to be identified, said: ''More affluent people are buying well and our luxury goods are moving. It seems to be the medium- and lower-income customers who are holding off.''

Customs Service agents seized about 700 pounds of cocaine today from a pleasure boat about 10 miles off Miami and arrested the four people aboard, said a spokesman for the agency, Cliff Stallings. He said agents found the cocaine in special compartments behind walls and under decks on the 38-foot boat, Nice Stuff.

Out of Leighton's doors on Broadway walked some of the slickest customers in Times Square - pugilists, promoters, swells and sharps, high-rollers who lived at the edge of fashion and the law. Tonight, after 67 years, those doors will close for the last time. In what has become the end-of-an-era era around the theater district, Leighton's departure stands out every bit as much as the alligator, ostrich, lizard and eel skin shoes that once filled its windows. There are not many places that offer both Oxxford suits and leather ones. Leighton's was such a store. Three generations of the Schlesinger family saw the business through flush times and watched it weather the worst. They had hoped to profit from the very building boom that ultimately doomed their 47th Street location.

A ruptured main that dumped 5 million gallons of water into the Longwood Avenue subway station in the South Bronx, leaving its mark two feet high on the token booth, sent 120,000 riders of the IRT No. 6 line scrambling during yesterday's morning and evening rush hours, transit officials said. ''If Murphy stays away from this corner,'' the Transit Authority's superintendent of track construction, Mike Hardiman, said - referring to the proverbial prognosticator of foul-ups -''we should have all the water out by midnight and service should be restored in the morning.'' The flood forced passengers traveling between the Bronx and Manhattan on what is customarily called the Lexington Avenue line to seek alternate transportation - at least until 30 buses began a shuttle service between the Hunts Point Avenue station in the Bronx and the 125th Street stop in Harlem.

Because of a mechanical error in some copies, an article yesterday about real estate speculation in Harlem omitted part of a sentence that described increases in sale prices. From 1980 to 1985, the average price of a building climbed to $230,000, from $130,000.

At least 20 squatters were ordered out of a Lower East Side building yesterday where some of them had been living without heat or electricity for as long as five years. Three occupants, Gregg Rudd, John Potak and Kathy O'Brien, were arrested and given a summons after they refused to leave and barricaded themselves in the building at 537 East 5th Street, the police said. ''We determined that the building was in imminent peril from a fire safety standpoint,'' said John McCormack, the Deputy Chief of the Fire Department's Division One, who said the department had posted a vacate order on December 10 and obtained a court order on Thursday to remove people from the premises. ''All access points to the building'' would be blocked up by cement, Chief McCormack said.

The blues pianist Pinetop Perkins will perform tonight at the Abilene Cafe, 359 Second Avenue, at 21st Street (473-8908). Shows are about 9:30 P.M. and midnight; there is a $10 cover and a two-drink minimum.

John Gnau, a prominent Michigan Republican, was sentenced today to three years in prison for taking part in a scheme to defraud the United States Postal Service. Mr. Gnau was the Michigan chairman of Ronald Reagan's campaigns for President in 1976 and 1980. Mr. Gnau, the owner of a public relations concern in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., was sentenced to three years for conspiracy to defraud the United States and two years for paying an illegal gratuity. The terms are to run concurrently. Judge George H. Revercomb of Federal District Court also fined Mr. Gnau $10,000.
* Alleghany Corp. said its shareholders had approved a plan of liquidation under which shareholders would receive about $41 a share in cash and stock in the company's Alleghany Financial Corp. unit.

Joe Montana passed for two touchdowns and a rookie cornerback, Tim McKyer, made two interceptions tonight as the San Francisco 49ers won the National Football Conference's Western Division title with a 24-14 victory over the Los Angeles Rams. The 49ers, who finished the regular season with a 10-5-1 record, overtook the Rams (10-6) in the division race by winning their final three games. Los Angeles will go into the National Football League playoffs as a wild-card entry and will play the Redskins in Washington on Dec. 28.

DRESSING UP The Metropolitan Museum of Art, on Fifth Avenue at 81st Street, is in a fashionable neighborhood, and all the well-dressed specimens are not on the street. Among the classiest duds to be seen are on view in the Museum's Costume Institute, which is celebrating its 50th anniversary with a big garment exhibition organized by Diana Vreeland, the arbiter of style who serves as special consultant to the costume institute. This is a show - one flight down from the main floor, but by no means a bargain basement - of 150 ballroom gowns, evening dresses and other such garments and accessories that have been worn to dances on outstanding social occasions tailored for fun. Each item was once dernier cri, whether in the 18th or 19th century at stiff court formals or in the 1960's, when one twisted in short dresses. There are flamenco designs and billowing fashions, all in attractive settings enveloped in the scent of perfume. If you weary of looking at dresses, you can refresh yourself by looking at pictures of dresses and the people in them drawn from the museum's collection.

Olivier Messiaen was only in his early 30's when he composed his ''Quatuor pour la fin du Temps'' in 1941, and he himself may feel that he has progressed much beyond it in the ensuing years. But if he has written a finer, more moving work this listener has yet to hear it. When it was performed as the second and final offering in the New York Philomusica concert at Merkin Concert Hall on Wednesday night, its mystical effect seemed as strong as ever, and the work is 45 years old.

To the Editor: It was ironic to see the appeal to Lord Curzon, the very symbol of British Orientalist thinking and his book ''Persia and the Persian Question'' (The Editorial Notebook: ''Mudakhil in Iran, Then and Now,'' Dec. 1) to make sense of the present fiasco, since Curzon, even in his own time, was considered by Iranian and Western democrats alike to have played a principal part in the tragic fate of the people of that country. If Curzon reported on the Iranian ''mudakhil'' bargaining system, he certainly was himself a master of that art when it came to British colonial policy in the region. Only a year after the successful 1906 Iranian Revolution, which gave the people of Iran for the first time a constitution and a parliament, the Aug. 31, 1907, Anglo-Russian Convention was signed, essentially partitioning Iran into two spheres of influence, giving both unlimited control over all political and commercial concessions of the Iranian Government.

After a month of consistently bad economic news, Brazil was visibly cheered today by word that 17 government creditors had agreed to renegotiate Brazil's outstanding debts without insisting on a prior agreement with the International Monetary Fund. This agreement should pave the way for a restructuring of the country's much larger debt with commercial banks that had demanded that Brazil first come to terms with foreign creditors grouped together in the ''Paris Club.'' Negotiations with the Paris Club, which will now begin Jan. 19, will cover arrears for 1985 and 1986 of $2 billion in principal and $800 million in interest. Soon after, Brazil is expected to present a proposal to banks for a multiyear rescheduling of perhaps as much as $60 billion in medium- and long-term debt.

MY DOG TULIP. By J. R. Ackerley. 160 pages. Poseidon Press. $7.95. Virginia Woolf wrote a biography of Flush, Elizabeth Barrett Browning's cocker spaniel. And John Steinbeck wrote a book about traveling across America with his French poodle Charley. Lesser known - to Americans, at least - is the story of Tulip, an Alsatian belonging to the writer J. R. Ackerley, who immortalized her in ''My Dog Tulip'' - an odd, charming and utterly English memoir, praised by E. M. Forster and Elizabeth Bowen, that has long been unavailable in this country.

Charles Jackson is a pleasant man who asks few questions. He might have wondered, for example, why the Jets cut him a few days before last Saturday's game against the Steelers after he started all 14 games the Jets had played. He wasn't out of work long - one game. Now, he has not only been recalled to the team, he is also scheduled to start again as the outside left linebacker when the Jets end their regular season tomorrow against the Bengals in a game that could decide home-field advantage in the playoffs.

Dwight Gooden, arrested last Saturday night after a scuffle with the police, sought today to calm the racial feelings in Tampa, Fla., that have been stirred by the incident. ''Nobody wants this kind of attention, but hopefully in due time things will get better,'' the Mets' pitcher said. Gooden, flanked by his attorneys and agent, spoke publicly for the first time since the incident left him with minor injuries and charged with disorderly conduct, resisting arrest with violence and battery on a police officer.

As many as 70 patrons at a Brooklyn bar watched early yesterday as two off-duty police officers were attacked by a group of men, the police said. One of the officers, Frank Calamia, 21 years old, sustained facial injuries and the lower third of his right ear ''appears to have been bitten off,'' said a police spokesman, Det.

The Washington Capitals stunned New Jersey with three goals in the game's opening 81 seconds, knocking Alain Chevrier out of the goal, but the Devils recovered marvelously for a 6-4 triumph tonight at Byrne Meadowlands Arena. It was New Jersey's third consecutive victory. Mel Bridgman, the captain of the Devils, who had been without a goal since Oct. 30, scored his sixth and seventh goals of the season. John MacLean also had two goals, his 15th and 16th. Doug Sulliman and Kirk Muller scored the other goals.

The Justice Department is seeking appointment of an independent counsel to investigate the personal finances of a former assistant Attorney General, Federal law-enforcement sources said Thursday. The department has applied to a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia to make the appointment in connection with W. Lawrence Wallace, who resigned last month as assistant Attorney General for management.

Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 54. 1. This is part of one of the most important private collections of English literature. What is it? What is happening to the collection?

Declaring that a jail term would constitute ''a serious injustice,'' a Superior Court judge today sentenced a popular Cherry Hill physician to two years probation for the mercy killing of his mother-in-law. As the sentence was pronounced, about 80 friends, relatives and patients in the crowded courtroom broke into applause, hugging and kissing each other. During the hour-and-a-half courtroom proceeding, many spectators were weeping as the prosecutor and defense counsel described how, in an act of mercy, Dr. Joseph M. Hassman had killed his wife's 81-year-old mother, who suffered from Alzheimer's Disease and had lost control of her bodily functions, including her ability to swallow.

N.B.A. 76ers 122, Celtics 100: In Philadelphia, Julius Erving scored 24 points and Roy Hinson 21 last night as the 76ers ended a four-game losing streak. Charles Barkley had 15 points, 11 assists and 14 rebounds in the Sixers' second victory in three games this season with Boston. Philadelphia turned the game into a rout in the fourth period with a 10-2 surge for a 103-85 lead with 7 minutes 4 seconds left. Philadelphia led by 57-49 after the first half. Boston rallied early in the third quarter to close the margin to 65-63 with 6:04 left, but Philadelphia came back with a 12-4 rally to lead by 77-67.(AP) Pistons 114, Spurs 84: Adrian Dantley and Isiah Thomas led a third-quarter surge in Pontiac, Mich., that lifted Detroit. San Antonio led by as many as 16 points in the first quarter. But Detroit, behind Dantley's 10 points, rallied in the second quarter and trailed, 53-51, at the half. Dantley, who finished with a game-high 26 points, scored the Pistons' first 7 points in the third quarter and gave Detroit its first lead, 58-57, on a 3-point play with 10:12 left in the period. Walter Berry, acquired by the Spurs from Portland on Thursday, missed his flight and arrived shortly after the game started. Berry sat on the San Antonio bench in street clothes.(AP) N.H.L. Sabres 3, Canadiens 2: Mike Foligno returned to the lineup after a five-game absence with a bruised kidney and scored two goals to spark Buffalo to the home-ice victory.

The experimental plane Voyager soared past Africa and into clear skies over the Atlantic today with up to 1,000 pounds more fuel than was previously calculated. ''I'm coming home,'' Richard G. Rutan, co-pilot of the aircraft, told the ground crew here. He and Jeana Yeager crossed the African coast just south of Douala, Cameroon, and headed over the Atlantic about 4 P.M., said Peter Riva, a spokesman at mission control.

Charles Taaffe, who served for the last three seasons as offensive coordinator under Coach Jim Young in implementing the wishbone attack so successfully at Army, was named head coach at The Citadel in Charleston, S.C. Taaffe, the 19th head coach of the Bulldogs, succeeds Tom Moore, who resigned under pressure Nov. 24 after The Citadel failed to win a Southern Conference game for the first time in 22 years and finished the season with a 3-8-0 record. Moore's four-year totals were 18-25-1. Taaffe, 36 years old, resigned at West Point Wednesday, but his wife, Jan, will continue to serve as an assistant trainer on Army's athletic staff until the end of the year.
Dwight Gooden, the Mets' pitcher, at news conference yesterday in St. Petersburg, Fla. One of his attorneys, Ron Cacciatore, is at right. (AP)

Andrei D. Sakharov, the physicist who was banished to the city of Gorky for his support of human rights causes, is free to return to Moscow, the Soviet Union announced today. At the same time, Dr. Sakharov's wife, Yelena G. Bonner, a human rights campaigner who was convicted of anti-Soviet activities in 1984, was pardoned. Dr. Sakharov, who won the 1975 Nobel Peace Prize for his human rights work, was exiled to Gorky without trial in January 1980 and has lived there since, often under harsh conditions. Miss Bonner, who was free to travel during the early part of his exile, was restricted to the same city in 1984 after her conviction.

At a dusty and windy campsite on this city's outskirts, a bedraggled and stunned group of refugees from Afghanistan were struggling this week without water, food or the belongings left behind in a Karachi slum colony that had been bulldozed a few days before. ''We are poor people, just laborers,'' an old man said, showing his calloused hands. ''We have done nothing to deserve this.'' A few miles away, the same anguish was voiced by a cluster of families huddled in the courtyard of a high school, where they had fled to escape the mobs of ethnic Pathans that had set fire to their homes and shot at them with submachine guns and automatic rifles.

In a growing investigation that threatens to engulf much of the Republican Party's state hierarchy, the State Treasurer and a former Pennsylvania party chairman have been convicted of 11 counts of bribery. After four days of deliberations, a jury in Federal District Court in Williamsport, Pa., found the State Treasurer, R. Budd Dwyer, 47 years old, and the former state Republican chairman, Robert B. Asher, 49, guilty Thursday of conspiracy, mail fraud and interstate transportation in aid of racketeering, and perjury. The charges related to an attempt to steer a computer contract to a tiny California company. The two could be sentenced to 55 years in prison and fined a total of $65,000.

International OPEC agreed to cut production and raise prices to $18 a barrel. The accord, signed early this morning by all of the group's members except Iraq, calls for across-the-board reductions in output of more than 7 percent for the first half of 1986. A key question about the agreement is whether the group will maintain enough discipline to defend a fixed price. [ Page 1. ] Prices of crude oil and petroleum products fluctuated in frenetic trading on world markets. [ 41. ] Brazilians were cheered by the agreement of 17 government creditors to negotiate their nation's outstanding debts without insisting on a prior agreement with the I.M.F. [ 39. ] China's Government plans to reduce the $8.1 billion it spends on subsidizing food for its 200 million city dwellers. China buys 50 million to 60 million tons of grain a year from its farmers under contract, about 15 percent of its total harvest. [ 38 ] Markets The ''triple witching hour'' produced frantic trading in the final half hour on the New York Stock Exchange. The number of orders that piled up for execution at the closing bell produced the busiest minute ever for the stock exchange, one in which more than 85 million shares traded. In all, almost 244.7 million shares traded on the Big Board, topping the previous record of 240.5 million set on Sept. 12. The Dow Jones industrial average ended at 1,928.85, a 16.03-point gain for the day and a 16.59-point advance for the week.

Larry Davis, who is accused of shooting six police officers in November, was put in solitary confinement yesterday for tearing up his cell last weekend, a City Correction Department spokesman said. Mr. Davis, 20 years old, was tranferred to a ''punitive segregation cell,'' where, except for an hour of recreation per day, he will spend the next 30 days alone, said the spokesman, Tom Antenen.

Both the conductor and the soloist of the current New York Philharmonic subscription program are making their first Philharmonic appearances this week at Avery Fisher Hall. Esa-Pekka Salonen, the 28-year-old Finnish conductor, is leading a program - heard yesterday afternoon, with the final performance tonight at 8 - of Niccolo Castiglioni's ''Sinfonia con Giardino''; Tchaikovsky's Piano Concerto No. 1, with the 31-year-old, Moscow-born Andrei Gavrilov as soloist, and finally Nielsen's Symphony No. 4 (''The Inextinguishable''). Of the two debutants, Mr. Salonen was the more interesting, and he was most interesting in the Nielsen. This Danish composer (1865-1931) had something of a run of attention a few years ago, with Leonard Bernstein and the Philharmonic leading the way. Mr. Salonen, too, has made Nielsen - or at least this symphony, which he has recorded - a speciality.

A former Federal judge in Manhattan, Lawrence E. Walsh, was appointed today as special prosecutor in charge of the Iran arms affair and given broad investigative powers. The three-judge panel that chose Mr. Walsh said he would have jurisdiction to investigate possible wrongdoing beyond any illegalities in the sale of military equipment to Iran and the diversion of the profits to Nicaraguan rebels. Among other things, Mr. Walsh will be permitted to study charges that the rebels, known as contras, received illegal support that was not tied to the Iran arms sales. The panel's decision to confer the broad powers went beyond the request of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d. Earlier this month, Mr. Meese asked in a court motion that the special prosecutor be given a more limited mandate, dealing specifically with Iranian weapons shipments and diversion of profits.

To the Editor: Elie Wiesel's acceptance speech as winner of the 1986 Nobel Peace Prize (Dec. 11) was one of the most moving statements about human relationships and human interdependence. Although he says that his ''first response is to Jewish fears, Jewish needs, Jewish crises,'' it surely adds to his stature when he goes on to include others among his concerns -Lech Walesa, Nelson Mandela and the Palestinian people.

A judge today turned down a plea from Raymond Buckey, the chief defendant in the McMartin preschool molestation case, to be released on bail. Judge William R. Pounders of Superior Court said he would not set bail for Mr. Buckey, 28 years old, because there was ''a ''substantial likelihood'' that Mr. Buckey would carry out threats the prosecution said he had made to harm children who testified against him.
Frank L. Rizzo, who served two terms as Mayor of Philadelphia, has changed his party registration from Democratic to Republican and says he will seek another term.

George Steinbrenner, citing ongoing contract negotiations with Ron Guidry and Willie Randolph and upcoming negotiations with Don Mattingly, joined three other club owners yesterday in rejecting a chance to sign Jack Morris for one year. Morris, one of baseball's premier pitchers, then beat last night's midnight deadline and accepted the arbitration offer of the Detroit Tigers. Morris' acceptance means he will return - most reluctantly - to the Tigers for a 10th season, with his salary to be determined by an arbitrator. If Morris wins, as clubs generally expect him to, his salary will be close to $2 million.

By choosing Lawrence Walsh, an elder statesman among American lawyers, as independent counsel to investigate the Iran-contra crisis, a Federal court in Washington helps calm the controversy while assuring more satisfactory answers to its mysteries. Mr. Walsh, a former New York lawyer, judge, Deputy Attorney General and Vietnam peace negotiator, combines worldly experience with high ethical standards. His appointment, along with this week's appointment of highly competent Senate and House select committees, betoken a return to trustworthy government and a fair accounting of where the nation's leadership went astray. These reassurances come at a price. The executive branch is in partial receivership, properly stripped of its power to investigate itself. Though some officials plead the Fifth Amendment, the Administration as a whole is pleading ignorance. That leaves Congress and Mr. Walsh to sort out policy misjudgments, flawed execution, deception and perhaps downright criminality.

Before the Senate Intelligence Committee concluded its hearings Thursday on the Iran arms deal, three dozen reporters had spent three weeks of 12-hour days outside the hearing room. Their duty there involved chasing tight-lipped witnesses through the Capitol corridors and begging senators and aides for scraps of information on the connection between the arms deal and the diversion of profits to the Nicaraguan rebels. Such bits of information were occasionally provided, but usually in oblique phrases that would test the skills of a cryptographer, lest the speaker stand accused of breaking his pledge to uphold the committee's rule of secrecy. The stakeout is a journalistic institution, one that takes on added importance in a major world news center like Washington.

Vice President Bush called on Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter, the former national security adviser, and Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, his former aide, to ''tell us the truth'' about their roles in the sale of American arms to Iran and diversion of profits to the Nicaraguan rebels. Mr. Bush, in a speech in Iowa, strongly suggested that the two men should testify regardless of whether they are offered immunity for their statements. President Reagan has declined to ask his former aides to overlook their constitutional rights and instead urged Congressional panels investigating the case to grant Admiral Poindexter and Colonel North limited immunity. Both officers invoked the Fifth Amendment protection against self-incrimination when summoned to testify. [ Page 1. ]

One Greek soldier and two Turkish soldiers were killed today in an exchange of fire on the river border between the two hostile NATO allies. Each side accused the other of provoking the incident by opening fire.

Dorthea N. Roberson and Fred Ward, members of the staff of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence, going over documents from the hearings on arms sales to Iran and the diversion of funds to the Nicaraguan rebels. (NYT/Marilynn K. Yee)

Experts often feel a need for a bunch of bridge hands with particular characteristics. They may wish to practice a systemic idea with a regular partner, to teach some students a convention, to coach an international team, or to test the theoretical desirability of a lead or a bid. A highly sophisticated answer to their prayers is now available to those who have an I.B.M. personal computer or a compatible machine. It is ''The Bridge Hand Generator,'' brilliantly designed by Paul Heitner and available by sending $75, plus $5 for mailing, to him at 8 Mansfield Street, Bramalea, Ontario. L6S 2Y3.
Suspected Sikh extremists killed the teen-age son of a police officer and an aide to Punjab state's former education minister in separate incidents today, officials said.

To the Editor: The auction of President Thomas Jefferson's 1818 letter to Maj. Mordechai Manuel Noah, expressing his distaste for anti-Semitism and other forms of religious intolerance, reminds us that in the same year our second President, John Adams, wrote a letter to the same officer. In his letter, Adams espoused the Zionist movement to revive the Hebrew nationality in Palestine, giving to him the distinction of being the first American President to take this position (the popular notion is that Woodrow Wilson was the first).

The White House said today that it would request funds to design a method for deploying large MX nuclear missiles on railroad cars and to develop a smaller nuclear missile. In an unexpected move, it said the number of missiles to be sought would depend on progress in arms negotiations with the Soviet Union. The announcement reopened a political dispute that has been going on for years over nuclear missiles and how to protect them from attack. Funds for developing the smaller 37,000-pound, single-warhead missile, informally dubbed Midgetman, and for basing the 10-warhead MX, which weighs nearly 200,000 pounds, would require Congressional approval.

The State Department spokesman said today that he had been mistaken in saying that the departing American Ambassador, Arthur A. Hartman, had made ''a personal decision'' to leave his post in Moscow. The spokesman, Charles E. Redman explained that in fact the Ambassador had left the decision to President Reagan and Secretary of State George P. Shultz. ''It would not be accurate to say it was for personal reasons, as I said yesterday,'' Mr. Redman said. ''That was a bit of a misunderstanding.''

PEOPLE wise in the ways of Washington say that in publicizing reports on major domestic issues over the last six weeks, the Reagan Administration was trying to shift attention from the controversy over arms sales to Iran. Whatever their immediate uses, the reports on welfare, federalism, the status of the family and catastrophic medical insurance were conceived months before the uproar over Iran. Taken together, they reflect a serious, systematic effort to formulate domestic policy. Their curious mix of bold proposals and simple verities reflects contradictory impulses to shrink the role of Government in some areas while expanding it in others.

Now that a former chief of French intelligence has disclosed the existence of 10 tons of largely unexamined war documents from the French security police, the French Government is transferring them to the army's historical archives, which means they will be legally sealed from scrutiny for 60 years, as Judith Miller points out. In England, none of the records of the S.I.S. (British World War II intelligence service) has yet been declassified.

Love it or loathe it, Minimalist music, with its patterned repetition, seemingly endless length and stubborn refusal to come to conventional climaxes, is everywhere these days. Right now, the fifth act of Robert Wilson's controversial ''CIVIL warS,'' a full-blown opera with music by Philip Glass, is in the midst of a run at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. But no matter where one turns, Minimalism is being enjoyed by eager young devotees and denounced by rival composers and unsympathetic critics. In either case, it's a subject that won't go away. At a panel discussion on the state of contemporary music at the Aspen Music Festival in 1985, it was finally decided to place a moratorium on any mention of the name Philip Glass, since it otherwise cropped at every point and on any subject as a sign of redemption or corruption. For critical observers, the current ubiquity of Minimalism offers certain ironies. The best-known Minimalist composers, Mr. Glass and Steve Reich, now reject the term as irrelevant to the music they have composed since the late 1960's. Whether one accepts that rejection - composers are notoriously nervous about labels - it still seems accurate to place Minimalist music's creative peak at least 15 years ago.

THE Victory Repertory Theater may be Long Island's smallest theater, housed as it is in a tiny space in the basement of St. Paul's Parish House in Great Neck. But as the troupe has proved over and over again, size has nothing to do with quality. What is lost in space is gained in artistic output.

To the Editor: Smith is in the consumer products business and to be successful in that business he must produce products people want to buy. As a recruiter with recent assignments in the automotive world, I interviewed at least 15 General Motors automobile designers over the past two years.

V.C. Andrews, a novelist whose books dealt with adolescent and family problems against a tableau of horror and suspense, is dead of cancer, according to her publisher. Ms. Andrews, who kept her age secret, was believed to be in her late 40's or early 50's when she died Friday, said Liz Hartman, a spokesman for Pocket Books in New York.

AS a child in the 1950's, the Christmas season began for me in Catholic school with the singing of carols, preparing for the pageant, learning again the story of the first Christmas, and making Santa Clauses and manger scenes for our classroom with construction paper, crayons and glue. At home, we crunched through the snow at a supermarket parking lot to select our Christmas tree from among the many frozen specimens whose branches had been flattened temporarily against their sides during a cramped ride on a truck from the northern forests. The night we trimmed the tree, a week before Christmas, whipped the five of us into a frenzy. My father brought down from the attic the dusty boxes of ornaments, strings of lights and the little manger he had built from the wood crate in which the encyclopedia had come.

In the United States, as elsewhere in the West, players are pretty much on their own, but a new effort to provide assistance in development - the Samford Chess Fellowship - has just been instituted. The program, sponsored by Frank P. Samford of Birmingham, Ala., offers a stipend for a year's coaching by a leading trainer and for research materials and living expenses. The total value of the fellowship is expected to be at least $25,000. If the year is completed to the satisfaction of the American Chess Foundation, which will supervise the fellowship, the recipient may apply for a renewal.

AFTER being arrested for drunken driving early Friday in Windsor, Ontario, Bob Probert of the Detroit Red Wings, who had been convicted of a similar charge earlier this year, was suspended indefinitely from the team. . . .
