Gene Smithson, who was dismissed as Wichita State's basketball coach last March, has reached a $305,000 contract settlement with the school. . . . Louis Espinoza has signed to fight Tommy Valoy for the World Boxing Association junior-featherweight title in a bout in Phoenix Jan. 6. . . . Reggie Jackson lost a bid to dismiss disorderly-conduct charges stemming from a scuffle with an autograph seeker in Milwaukee last May and was ordered to stand trial at a date to be set. . . . Ben Johnson, whose 1986 record included a victory over Carl Lewis in the 100 meters at the Goodwill Games in Moscow, has been ranked No. 1 in the event by Track and Field News. . . . Jack Nicklaus, who hasn't played in the Westchester Classic since 1978, has agreed to play in next year's tournament, set for June 11-14.

''I think we're comparing apples and oranges. The American people need to know the facts, but I'm not sure they need to know all the advice every adviser gives to the President of the United States.''

In South Africa, the picture darkens. The latest repression by the Government makes it hard to know quite what is going on, except that the pace is still set by violence, against or on behalf of the state. The white liberal opposition is helpless, the press stifled. In the circumstances, it is odd that so little has been heard of the latest effort to move toward authentic multiracial reform. But then, the man at the center of the effort is Gatsha Mangosuthu Buthelezi, an ambiguous figure and a widely hated one.

Inspired by California voters' approval of a sweeping new law regulating the disposal of toxic chemicals, environmentalists and political leaders are pressing for enactment of similar controls elsewhere in the nation. ''We're working on a generic version of Proposition 65 that other states can use, and we're getting questions from everywhere,'' said Carl Pope, an official of the Sierra Club who helped draft the California law that was listed on the Nov. 4 ballot as Proposition 65. The statute will prohibit the discharge of chemicals known to cause cancer or birth defects anywhere they could enter domestic drinking water supplies. Richard Gottfried, Democrat of Manhattan, the assistant majority leader of the New York Assembly, said he was working on a bill modeled after the California law that he expected to submit to the Legislature next month.

At the age of 11, Aisha Evans has learned that ''even if you don't agree with everything people say, you can still try to understand them.'' Chantese Mortimer, who is 11 1/2, has discovered that ''math isn't so boring after all.'' Kenya Adams, 12, wants to learn more than she can in school and is interested in calligraphy and drama. They all have chosen to spend Saturday mornings at the new Multi-Ethnic Learning Center in the Mariners' Temple at 3 Henry Street on the Lower East Side. Before the center opened this fall, most of the students said, they spent the time ''sleeping late and watching television.''

If football fans had their way, the National Football League would continue to use the new instant replay system next season, despite feelings to the contrary by some of the 28 N.F.L. clubs. When the system was approved last spring for one season only, four clubs voted against it, and the feeling within the league is that it has not worked well enough to gain the 21 necessary votes at the next meetings in March to be retained. Even so, by an overwhelming margin, fans interviewed in the latest football poll conducted by The New York Times and CBS Sports say the system has made the game better (66 percent), rather than worse (20 percent).

Jean-Bedel Bokassa once spent $50 million to have himself crowned Emperor of the huge, sparsely populated country he had renamed the Central African Empire. But last week, as he stood trial in Bangui, his former capital, on charges of multiple murders, torture and cannibalism, he lowered his sights.

The educational program referred to in Carolyn Battista's article ''Family Violence Law Has 'Growing Pains' but Is Changing Attitudes'' [ Nov. 23 ] is just getting under way across the state. An important fact not mentioned by the article was that people may attend the classes voluntarily - they need not be arrested first.

The engagement of Mary Winifred Allen to William Harper Proom has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. John Cary Allen of Newton and Plymouth, Mass., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Burt Chandler Proom of West Simsbury, Conn., and the late Mrs. Proom.

New Yorkers' utility bills would drop for the first time since the 1960's under a plan proposed yesterday by Governor Cuomo to grant consumers some of the savings that utilities will gain from lower interest rates and Federal tax changes. Mr. Cuomo asked the State Public Service Commission to cut gas, electric and telephone bills by $2.15 billion over two years, a plan that could lower rates by 5 percent to 10 percent. Approval of the plan would reverse more than a decade of annual utility rate increases that were spurred by inflation and rising interest rates. Because the changes in the Federal tax code affect all utilities in the nation, consumer advocates say that consumers may begin to see decreases in their utility bills as early as January and further reductions as the new tax laws are phased in over the next two years. About half the states have begun investigating such rate reductions.

'YULETIDE AT WINTERTHUR' English, German and French holiday traditions are explored in ''Yuletide at Winterthur,'' an exhibition of 21 room settings that includes a midday after-the-hunt dinner, an elaborate holiday dinner party, an evening musicale and a festive Twelfth Night Ball. The settings will remain in place through Jan. 4. The exhibit, at the Winterthur Museum, Winterthur, Del., will include a display of Christmas greetings dating from 1840. There will also be a festive Pennsylvania German Quilting party, based on an 1813 painting by Johann Krimmel, and an elegant evening dessert party and musical presentation, including a Victorian Christmas tree documented by the Victoria and Albert Museum in London.

AS the tailback for North Carolina, Derrick Fenner was the leading rusher in the Atlantic Coast Conference this season, but when the Tar Heels go to Hawaii for the Aloha Bowl, Fenner won't be with them. In announcing that Fenner had been suspended from the team for academic deficiencies, Coach Dick Crum said that despite his problems Fenner could have been allowed to play under National Collegiate Athletic Association guidelines, but not under North Carolina's. ''At this institution,'' Crum said, ''academics are also important, and something had to be done about his current situation.''
Rilwanu Lukman of Nigeria, president of OPEC, after the cartel agreed to cut production and raise oil prices to $18 a barrel. Page 18. (Agence France-Presse)

Major Museum Is Reopened In Madrid Housing more than 1,500 paintings and 800 sculptures by such artists as El Greco, Murillo and Goya, not to mention drawings by Velazquez, Ribera and Rubens, the Museum of the Royal Academy of Fine Arts of San Fernando in Madrid - regarded second in importance only to the Prado among Spain's museums - has reopened to the public after a 12-year hiatus. The museum, with a collection ranging from the 16th century to the present and an emphasis on Spanish, Flemish and Italian artists, traces its history to 1744 when the academy was founded during the reign of King Felipe V. The collection is housed in the renovated and remodeled Palace of Juan de Goyeneche, a banker for whom the palace was constructed in 1710 by the architect Churriguera in the Baroque style. It was later redone in the neo-classical style by Diego Villanueva. The museum (at Alcala 13, between Puerta del Sol and Plaza de Cibeles) is open Tuesday through Saturday from 9 A.M. to 7 P.M. and on Sunday and Monday from 9 A.M. to 2 P.M. Admission is about $1.50. More information about the opening is available from the National Tourist Office of Spain (665 Fifth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10022; 212-759-8822).

You are to be commended for your thorough and thought-provoking article ''Hospitals Extend Care Into Homes'' [ Nov. 16 ] . As executive director of V.N.A. Care (formerly V.N.A. of Stamford), I underscore the fact that shorter hospital stays coupled with increased Medicare restrictions for home care services is the daily dilemma faced by home health agencies. V.N.A. Care, a Medicare-certified agency, has been providing home care for 80 years in the Stamford community. True, home care agencies must be prepared to give a high level of sophisticated nursing care in the home. At the same time, it is our experience that the basic primary need of the patient/family unit is on going skilled care and support services such as a home health aide, until such time as the patient/family are able to assume responsibility for care.

For about 32 minutes today, North Carolina was kept at bay by the patient offense and rebounding mastery of a smaller Illinois squad led by Ken Norman. Then the Tar Heels' trapping defenses and superior size keyed a 16-0 spurt, enabling North Carolina to coast to a 90-77 victory over the Illini. Illinois, which suffered its first loss in eight games this season, led by 8 points several times in the opening half, and was ahead by 35-33 at halftime. But after trailing by 48-41 with 15 minutes 34 seconds remaining in the game, the Tar Heels forced three consecutive turnovers by Illinois while scoring 7 straight points. They tied the game on a jump shot by Dave Popson, a forward, with 13:57 left.

SIGNS OF CONFUSION ''WE weren't notified the signs were going up,'' said Eileen Peters of Island Rides in Melville. ''One day we just started getting these phone calls. People call up and say, 'What road should I take to avoid the construction on Route 110?' And we say, 'The Department of Transportation has decided because of the construction delays you should get into a car pool.' '' The reaction to that comment ''has been pretty horrendous,'' Mrs. Peters said. ''They're calling thinking they're going to get the name of some magic road to avoid the construction, and we're telling them instead of battling traffic you should be in a car pool. It has not been the most effective marketing tool.'' The confusion has occurred because of seven signs recently put up by the State Department of Transportation. The blue and white signs, on side roads leading into Route 110, say, ''Route 110 Alternate Commuting Information call 423-CARS.''

''THANK goodness they were wearing seat belts.'' Capt. Michael Pocchio of the Newark Police Department made that statement last March, following a collision between a school bus and a Newark police car. None of the eight children on the bus was injured, despite the fact that the vehicle turned over on its side. These children were lucky. They were riding in a bus equipped with seat belts, but hundreds of thousands of New Jersey schoolchildren are not so fortunate. Most school districts in our state do not have seat belts as standard equipment on their buses.

On this windswept and isolated Caribbean peninsula, the Sandinista Government is building a deepwater port that Nicaraguans have dreamed of for decades. When the project is completed several years from now, El Bluff will be the first and only large port on Nicaragua's east coast. Today nearly all of the country's exports and imports pass through Corinto on the west coast. Vessels carrying cargo to and from Europe must pay ever-increasing tolls to pass through the Panama Canal. Engineers overseeing the port project here say it will save Nicaragua large sums of money for years. They also say it will help alleviate shortages of food and other products that have become chronic on the east coast.

HOW does a new building, rosy bright in color and designed with a minimum of flourish, fit the stringent requirements of a national historic district? The developers of the Olympic Building in Pioneer Square here have been trying to answer that question for five contentious years. But after a prolonged controversy and nearly $600,000 in design changes, the nine-story, $15 million structure in the heart of old Seattle opened this year, mostly to raves.

In ALL-AMERICAN FOLK ARTS AND CRAFTS (Rizzoli, $45), a patchwork of images of American folk arts and crafts, William C. Ketchum Jr. takes a colorful, spirited look at the handmade objects he calls ''America's glory.'' Geared toward collectors, but avoiding the this-is-how-much-it-costs approach of collecting guides, Mr. Ketchum's book is a personalized journey through the distinctively American themes and symbols that have occupied our collective imagination.

Representative Jim Wright of Texas, who will be the Speaker of the House in the new Congress, says he will advise President Reagan to grant executive pardons to two key figures in the Iran arms affair so they will tell their stories. Mr. Wright, in comments to be broadcast Sunday on the syndicated television program ''John McLaughlin's One on One,'' said: ''If he truly wants them to come forward and tell the whole truth and if he wants them to have immunity from prosecution, that's a simple way.

SOUTH AFRICA'S black majority has long been used to being told what it may not do - hold public meetings, for example, or vote on national affairs. But under the newest tightening of emergency rules, blacks and other dissenters were also told what they may not refuse to do - patronize stores, accept the draft, go to school or use the buses that provide apartheid's umbilical link between white-run cities and black labor in the townships. Under regulations imposed Dec. 11, such activities, their incitement or press reporting of them became ''subversive'' - punishable by maximum fines of $9,000 and up to 10 years in jail. Resistance was outlawed, and the residual channels of peaceful protest seemed closed.

THROUGHOUT the industrial world, women are catching up with men in education and earning power. But if some current trends continue, they may never achieve equality. According to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, women claim a much higher share of places in higher education than they did a decade ago. In the United States, Canada, Norway, Sweden and Denmark, the proportion of women at universities and other institutions of higher education is roughly in line with their proportion in the population, and in a few instances is higher. But many countries, including Japan, Luxembourg, Switzerland and Britain, are lagging in this regard.

The interim president of Carleton College in Northfield, Minn., has been appointed president of Skidmore College in Saratoga Springs, N.Y. The interim president, Dr. David H. Porter, who taught classics and music at Carleton for 24 years, will succeed Dr. Joseph C. Palamountain Jr., who retires on June 30 after 22 years as president of Skidmore.

PEARL HARBOR WAS BOMBED THREE months after I started grade school, and my schoolyard was transformed into an arena of absolute good and evil. As we boys swallowed our graham crackers and milk, we vowed to fight to the death. The girls would all be nurses to tend our wounds. I resolved to become a pilot. As I daydreamed in class, the Messerschmitt came apart under the relentless pounding of my six 50-caliber wing guns. The Luftwaffe was annihilated by morning recess. I solemnly promised myself that one day I would give the thumbs-up salute, just like the youth in the recruiting poster, and then roar off to death or glory, the wind pressing the goggles against my face.

A police official, after quitting his post, said today that only history would show whether a conspiracy forced his removal from an inquiry into purported police brutality in Northern Ireland. The official, John Stalker, 47 years old, the Deputy Chief Constable of Greater Manchester, announced his resignation Friday, seven months after he was taken off the Northern Ireland investigation and suspended pending an inquiry of purported misconduct. In August, the Police Authority cleared Mr. Stalker of accusations that he associated with criminals and used police cars for personal business, and the authority, a law-enforcement monitoring group, reinstated Mr. Stalker to the force.

The chief United States delegate to the United Nations said today that he would ask Congress to restore millions of dollars in dues owed by the United States to the world organization. The delegate, Vernon A. Walters, cited the General Assembly decision Friday to revamp the administration and budget-making process of the United Nations, and said: ''What has been done here is something really historic. We have gotten the things that the United States intended.'' ''I will recommend that the United States meet its assessed contribution,'' he said. ''We will do our darndest.''

In January 1985, President Reagan told the American people there was ''a new danger'' in Nicaragua because the Sandinista Government was receiving support from ''Colonel Qaddafi's Libya, the P.L.O. and, most recently, the Ayatollah Khomeini's Iran.'' At a news conference three days later, the President said the leftwing Nicaragua Government had received ''certain types of munitions from Iran'' and suggested that the Iranian Government was coaching the Sandinistas on how to carry out terrorist acts.

Three defendants were added last week to the roster of associates of Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. who are facing charges in connection with his fund-raising efforts. A Federal grand jury in Boston said the three had conspired to ''obstruct and impede'' its investigation, which had led to the indictment of 10 individuals, two corporations and three campaign committees.
I recently returned from visiting West Germany and Austria, as did your correspondent. I also visited East Germany, Poland and Czechoslovakia.

Mr. and Mrs. J. Keith Alford of Buffalo have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ann Wende Alford, to Andrew Wade Kittross, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jeffry H. Kittross of Suffern, N.Y. Miss Alford and her fiance graduated in June from Trinity College in Hartford.

IT WAS THE FIRST DAY OF rehearsal of a new production at the Arena Stage, in Washington. It was also the first time American actors had had the chance to work with Yuri Lyubimov, the celebrated Russian avant-garde theater director now in exile from the Soviet Union. Invited by Zelda Fichandler, the Arena producing director, he was staging his adaptation of Dostoyevsky's ''Crime and Punishment,'' scheduled to open Jan. 7. Lyubimov, a silver-haired man in his late 60's, seemed as excited about his American debut as the cast. For nearly 20 years, since 1964, Lyubimov had been the artistic director of the most popular theater in Moscow, the Taganka, where he staged avant-garde productions despite harassment by cultural bureaucrats.

There we were, shivering in the chilly Austrian night, in a narrow street next to the post office, where the pay telephones were. We had staked out the telephones when we arrived in St. Anton a few days earlier, planning our calls home to our families on Christmas Day. Our pockets were full of the unfamiliar coins we had been hoarding. We hoped we had enough to last through the few minutes it would take to say ''Merry Christmas! Yes, I wish I could be there, too.'' to each of the many members of each of our families, who, six hours behind us, would be just finishing up the morning's attack on the packages under the tree. It was 1982, my first Christmas away from home. For the last decade or so, I've been doing a pretty fair imitation of an adult. I work, pay the rent, water the plants and generally make sure the five basic food groups are represented in the refrigerator. Christmas, with its implicit and explicit celebration of family, is the one time of year that can make me feel as if something is missing in the way I live. I share my home and my life with someone but am not married and don't have children. If I don't go home for Christmas, it means I am willfully (and for no apparent reason) altering a tradition.

Secretary of State George P. Shultz will meet in Washington next month with Oliver Tambo, president of the outlawed African National Congress, a top State Department official announced today. The talks between Mr. Shultz and Mr. Tambo will represent the highest level of diplomatic contact between the United States and the black guerrilla group, which opposes the white South African Government and its system of racial discrimination, known as apartheid. Michael Armacost, Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, announced the planned meeting after a two-hour lunch meeting with three A.N.C. officials, including Govan Mbeki, a member of the group's executive council.

THEY may be enjoying their new computers, but college newspapers are not enjoying the large debts these systems forced them to incur. But many campus papers are discovering that the same computerized editing and printing systems that caused their financial woes can be the remedy. At the University of Maryland, for example, The Diamondback has established a profit-making publishing subsidiary that prints other college publications, business cards, newsletters and posters. The subsidiary produces $100,000 a year, 10 percent of the newspaper's total revenues. ''We felt we had a lot more capacity for production than our needs, so it made a lot of sense to get outside work for it,'' said Michael Fribush, The Diamondback's professional general manager.

ON Philadelphia billboards, brochures, trash trucks and television and radio announcements, the message is loud and clear: Those who owe city taxes had better pay up while the current tax amnesty is still on. ''Philadelphia is ready to identify tax offenders and enforce tax laws,'' the television announcements say.

A newcomer's recent observation here that New York pedestrians don't stay to the right prompts several explanations. One letter writer said that ever since the cave men, humans have sought security by staying as close as possible to buildings - or to caves, as the case may be.

Andrei D. Sakharov said today that he planned to continue his advocacy of human rights when he returns to Moscow after nearly seven years of exile. Reached by telephone in Gorky, the city to which he has been confined since 1980 for his public criticism of Soviet policies, Mr. Sakharov said he had not promised Mikhail S. Gorbachev that he would curtail his activities in exchange for permission to come back to the Soviet capital. ''I am going to live as I lived before my exile, and resume all of my activities,'' Dr. Sakharov, a 65-year old physicist, said. He confirmed that Mr. Gorbachev had telephoned on Tuesday, one day after the authorities had unexpectedly installed a telephone in the physicist's Gorky apartment. The Soviet leader told Dr. Sakharov that he could go back to Moscow and to his work in theoretical physics.

Everyone wants to get rid of it. And that is why the noxious residue of New York City's 14 sewage-treatment plants has become the subject of a bitter dispute between the city and a group of barge operators. For more than 50 years, the city has been dumping its sludge at a site 12 miles off Sandy Hook, N.J., which has become a veritable dead sea of goo that kills marine life. Now, fearing further ecological danger that could impair public health, the Federal Environmental Protection Agency has ordered the city to dump at a new site on the edge of the Continental Shelf, 106 miles out in the Atlantic Ocean.

An imprisoned Russian dissident psychiatrist says in notes reportedly smuggled out of the Soviet Union that he has been in solitary confinement for three years, on a hunger strike for two years and confined to a punishment cell for half a year. The Russian, Anatoly Koryagin, 48 years old, from Kharkov, has been opposing the use of psychiatry for political purposes. He was arrested, tried and convicted in 1981 for saying that a dissident sent to a psychiatric prison was sane.

RONNELL BRIGHT, a jazz pianist who has been accompanist to such singers as Sarah Vaughan, Lena Horne, Peggy Lee and Carmen McRae, has a delicately balanced versatility that enables him to play imaginative and relaxed jazz in the guise of dinner music. Snuggled with his piano into a corner of Devereux, a restaurant in the Essex House, Central Park South near Seventh Avenue, Mr. Bright quietly weaves echoes of Erroll Garner's joyfully positive rhythms, Art Tatum's airy touch and rolling lines and suggestions of Nat King Cole and Teddy Wilson into a repertory of familiar, standard pop tunes.

INFLUENZA has reached epidemic proportions in Connecticut, state health officials say, and it is likely many of the people jamming shopping malls have been spreading more than holiday cheer. The first reports of the flu, identified as Influenza A, type Taiwan, came from several college campuses, but by last week it had spread to high schools, elementary schools and throughout the general population, health officials said. ''It struck Connecticut with a vengeance,'' said Dr. Morris Ostroff, chief of emergency medicine at Mount Sinai Hospital in Hartford. ''We've been seeing 20 to 30 cases a day.''

COMMUNITY control of New York City's public schools comes and goes. A generation ago, after an extraordinarily bitter teachers' strike, came the elected community school boards, which share responsibility with the central Board of Education; now the president of the board, Robert F. Wagner Jr., contends that the system ''in some ways has led to the worst of all worlds.'' Chief among Mr. Wagner's complaints, voiced in an interview, is the influence of politics and patronage in the 32 local boards. The result, he said, is ''more deadening than anything the central bureaucracy has done to the schools.''

An article in Arts and Leisure on Dec. 7 about Bobby Short incorrectly identified the composer of ''Take the A Train.'' He was Billy Strayhorn. Further, the name of Mr. Short's accompanist on bass should have been spelled Beverly Peer.

STAMFORD residents who complain about a dearth of attractive restaurants in their city have not been paying attention. Within the last two years more than a dozen new restaurants have opened there, several to well-earned accolades. Just a few months ago another newcomer, Il Falco, arrived. Occupying two floors of an office building diagonally across from Bloomingdale's, Il Falco is a study in restraint: dubonnet carpets and matching napkins, white tablecloths and hanging plants and pale pink walls with several art posters provide an understated backdrop for some of the best Italian cooking in town.

For the second time in two visits, a nationally ranked St. John's team moving ahead with full steam was given all it could handle by a hustling Niagara squad bent on an upset. Two seasons ago, the Purple Eagles upset the Redmen. St. John's nearly suffered the same fate here tonight, but surged at the end to escape with a 66-58 victory before 10,438 fans at the Buffalo Memorial Auditorium. With the game tied, 50-50, St. John's (7-0) outscored Niagara by 14-6 to take a 64-56 lead.

With the list of prospective entrants in the 1988 Presidential race already beginning to resemble the Washington telephone directory, a group in California is advancing the name of John Kerry, a first-term Democrat from Massachusetts. Although the Committee to Draft U.S. Senator John Kerry actually registered with the Federal Elections Commission more than a year ago, it has only recently become active, according to its chairman, Joseph P. Shea.
To the Sports Editor: I still can't believe the Mets won Game 6 of the World Series. DOUGLAS LAVINE West Hartford, Conn.

Marion Trozzolo looked at Teflon a quarter century ago and had a vision: kitchens across America filled with nonstick cookware. Such prescience has paid off for the Kansas City industrialist in many ways, including propelling him toward a spot in the Plastics Hall of Fame. This year his company, the LPF Plastics Corporation, is celebrating the 25th anniversary of its Happy Pan of 1961, the first Teflon-coated cookware to be produced in the United States.

Mats Naslund scored a goal and added two assists tonight as the Montreal Canadiens ended a three-game New Jersey victory streak with a 5-2 triumph over the Devils. Brian Hayward turned back 27 shots to help Montreal avenge a loss to the Devils by the same score in New Jersey last Sunday. Montreal started the third period with a 3-0 lead but failed to protect Brian Hayward's shutout bid as Claude Loiselle scored for New Jersey at 6 minutes 15 seconds.

Two years ago, when the state chose this town on Maryland's Eastern Shore as the site for a new $80 million prison, a storm of protest arose. Residents here in Somerset County, which is considered the state's poorest county, said they feared escaping prisoners, swelling welfare roles as the families of prisoners moved close to the prison, and damage to the area's image as a quiet place to live. A rallying cry of protesters was ''Build it in Baltimore, that's where most of the customers are.''

In 1964, the Surgeon General issued a report that eventually led to the now-familiar warnings that smoking can cause lung cancer, heart disease and death. Last week, President Reagan's outspoken Surgeon General, Dr. C. Everett Koop, issued a report he hoped would prove as influential.

GEORGE Overbury ''Pop'' Hart was born in Cairo, Ill., and reared in Rochester, N.Y., but spent the greater part of his life (1868-1933) traveling. Nonetheless, he counts as a New Jersey artist, having made Coytesville in Bergen County his base from 1907 on, and it is at the Zimmerli Art Museum at Rutgers that the legacy of work left by him came to rest three years ago. Bequeathed by the artist's niece, Jeane Overbury Hart, the collection numbers about 5,000 items, of which the sampling that will remain on view here through Feb. 3 is but a small fraction. Still, at 140 watercolors, prints, drawings and paintings, it is the largest Hart survey since the Newark Museum's memorial retrospective of 1935.

A FRIEND of mine, a young doctor from Fairfield, recently came to me with a problem. He can never get around to doing his Christmas shopping, even though his successful practice affords him plenty of time to do so. This bothers him.

FROM a cafeteria window in the New Jersey Veterans Home here, a wheelchair-bound resident watched a chilling rain fall on wet snow. ''It was like this when the Germans came through the Bulge - cold and sad-looking,'' said the former infantryman, now in his 60's, who did not wish to be identified. ''We had nowhere to go and, after a while, we and the snow became part of the landscape.

To the Editor: Granted that there are a lot of foxes, and granted that they occasionally do damage, what right have we to harry them and torture them with a long exhausting pursuit that eventually ends in a frightful death from sheer exhaustion, with hounds behind them? This is no sport for modern man, who has some moral responsibility and has been made aware of the sentient, live beings we have around us, as part of our own life.

To the Editor: To colorize or not to colorize . . . .When a colorized version of a classic is shown on TV, he who casts the first stone should also use the color dial to return said classic to its original black-and-white. That little dial will be the real ballot box. BRUCE STASIUK Setauket, N. Y.

It has worked to preserve tropical forests in Costa Rica, bison in North Dakota, piping plover and ospreys on Long Island, bluestem grass in Oklahoma and blueback char, a rare trout, in Maine. Now the Nature Conservancy, since 1951 a preserver of endangered species and ''ecologically significant natural areas,'' has nearly completed its largest project yet.

The Giants ended their regular season today with a victory, which was hardly different because they now have won their last nine games. But this one was different because the score and the winning streak and the season record all found their way into the record book. It was also different because the Giants are two victories away from Super Bowl XXI Jan. 25 in the Rose Bowl in Pasadena, Calif. Today, they routed the Green Bay Packers, 55-24, their highest score of the season. It was their 14th victory of the season, the most ever in the Giants' 62-year history. Their nine-game winning streak matched a similar streak in 1962.

A five-week trial involving intense British efforts to suppress publication of the memoirs of a retired member of the British Secret Service has ended here, with the Australian judge expressing skepticism about the veracity of London's chief witness. ''Here is a man who would fudge when it suits his purpose,'' Justice Philip Powell said of Sir Robert Armstrong, secretary to Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Cabinet. ''Some parts of his testimony I have great difficulty in accepting.''
To the Editor: Missing from ''Advice for Detroit's Humbled Giant'' (Dec. 7) is an interview with a consumer. Permit me to fill that gap.

To the Editor: December being the month when Nobel Prize winners go to Scandinavia, this may also be the right time to consider instituting a Nobel Prize in Environmental Science. Those men and women who, despite practically nonexistent budgets, work at laying down the fundamentals of environmental science should be rewarded.

Mr. and Mrs. Matthew A. Falcone of Manhasset, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Denise Ann Falcone, to Stephen Craig Snyder, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ivan J. Snyder of Randolph, N.J. Miss Falcone is a senior at Fairleigh Dickinson University's School of Business Administration, and Mr. Snyder is a senior at the University of Miami in Coral Gables, Fla. He is also a vice president of Heroes World Stores of New York, a 10-store retail chain.

This is a land of companies that exist only on paper. There are more than 150,000 of them, and scores more are being set up every day, according to Government officials and corporate lawyers. The companies usually consist of no more than a few typed pages in a manila folder, but they enable their foreign owners to do business anywhere in the world anonymously and tax-free. In the last week, three Panamanian companies have been linked to the United States' sale of weapons to Iran and the diversion of profits to the supply network of the Nicaraguan rebels or contras. Other Panamanian companies may also be involved.

Some dance works are like articles in an intellectual quarterly. They are interesting when you have them in front of your eyes, but ultimately they are disposable. They are not the equivalent of a classic book, one that you can return to repeatedly. These thoughts came to mind during the recent performances by the company of Bill T. Jones and Arnie Zane and the one headed by David Gordon in the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Next Wave Festival. At this point, one might digressively note that ballet and its traditions seemed to be surprisingly strong reference points in both programs. Mr. Jones and Mr. Zane included quotations from George Balanchine's ''Serenade'' in their evening. Mr. Gordon's allusion to Sir Frederick Ashton's ''Patineurs'' was overt in ''The Seasons,'' a work he might not have created if Jerome Robbins had not revived the seasons theme with his Verdi ballet, ''The Four Seasons,'' several years ago. It is obviously unfair to compare Mr. Gordon, Mr. Jones and Mr. Zane to some of the greatest choreographers of all time. But is it disconcerting to suggest that the works on these programs might not endure as long as ''Serenade,'' composed in 1934, and ''Les Patineurs,'' created in 1937? Balanchine was younger than any of these choreographers when he created ''Serenade'' and Ashton was close to them in age when he choreographed ''Les Patineurs.''

THE baseball season ended two months ago, but nobody can prove it. The headlines this past pre-Christmas week dealt, like the game itself, with the physical (Gooden's encounter with Tampa's finest), the cerebral (Morris's salary negotiations), and juridical (a verdict for the Shea Stadium parachutist). And when they said Morris they meant not football Joe of the Giants but baseball Jack, the once and future king of the Detroits. Granted their intrinsic news value, those and other stories have seemed to reflect somehow an added glow - a glow not so much from any seasonable hearth as from what by general consent had to be the most extraordinary sequence of playoff and World Series games baseball has ever known.

MANY students, parents and teachers have for years criticized standardized college admission examinations, such as the Scholastic Aptitude Test, as superficial and unfair. By attaching a number to such an elusive quality as college preparedness, the critics say, the College Board tests create an illusion of objectivity. Now another educational yardstick is under attack. Recently, a growing number of affluent communities like Great Neck have joined elite private schools that have stopped ranking students according to grade point average. Although the Great Neck Board of Education delayed formal action, officials predicted that by next fall students would no longer be ranked at one of the area's two secondary schools, North High School. A decision on South High School is expected later. As the case in Great Neck illustrates, the dispute over rankings has arisen in highly competitive suburban districts where most students plan to go to college. In such schools, the opponents of ranking say, many students earn grades above 90 percent. Slight differences, often less than one-hundredth of a point, can determine whether a student places in the top or bottom half of a class.

Sunday: Nicaragua said Sam Nesley Hall, a self-styled counterterrorist and brother of Representative Tony P. Hall, Democrat of Ohio, had been arrested at an air base near Managua and accused of spying. Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, who was dismissed from the National Security Council staff for his role in the sale of arms to Iran and the diversion of funds to the Nicaraguan rebels, was reported to have helped a campaign to defeat Congressional candidates opposed to aid for the contras by collaborating with a conservative lobbyist, Carl R. Channell. No evidence emerged that funds from the arms sales went to the political campaign.

At the Jewish Community Center in Harrison, N.Y., last evening Judith Lynn Berman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward M. Berman of Bedford, N.Y., was married to Jay Stuart Goldstein, the son of Dr. and Mrs. William L. Goldstein of Brooklyn. Rabbi Norton D. Shargel, assisted by Cantor Lawrence Avery, performed the ceremony.
The engagement of Nanette Streit Heilbrun to Robert Saroga has been announced by the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Heilbrun of New York. A June wedding is planned.

A new report has determined that Philadelphia runs one of the nation's most expensive judicial systems, and the director of the group that conducted the study suggested the system was inefficient. The Pennsylvania Economy League, a nonprofit group that conducted a two-year study of the courts, said each Philadelphia resident paid about 50 percent more for justice in 1982 than the national average for the 30 largest cities.

If New York ran on logic, the combination of an overbuilt midtown Manhattan, a rising vacancy rate in office space, and slightly more restrictive zoning would put an end, at least for the time being, to the mega-projects that have so crowded the city's skyline. After all, why build a huge skyscraper when so many factors argue against it? How naive such reasoning is, however, is proved by the latest proposal for an immense tower in midtown -a building project that is more brazen, surely, than any proposed in the last generation. It is First Boston Corporation's plan to erect a 74-story tower on the east side of Madison Avenue between 46th and 47th Streets, a building that would be more than twice the size of what the city's zoning laws normally allow on that site. If built, the tower would be the fourth tallest building in Manhattan, and it would be squeezed onto a small block on a narrow street in what is already one of the most densely built-up sections of New York City.

THESE days I find my neighbor Ted out in his yard getting ready for battle. He is wrapping 50-yard lengths of vinyl-coated fencing around the foundation plantings of his house and spraying the outlying shrubbery with some black, tarlike repellent. When he is through, his tidy house and yard begin to resemble a redoubt during wartime, fortified against the enemy. Ted has one of those enviable suburban yards. Lush varieties of shrubs bloom in succession throughout the warmer months. His lawn, initially rolled down as sod from a flatbed truck the way carpeting is installed, is as green as a valley in Ireland. He cares about lawns. Retired now, he also enjoys the labor of keeping his space verdant.

As holiday lights threw the plight of New York City's hungry and homeless into even sharper relief last week, the struggle to help them continued. Developers pondered a municipal proposal to swap an East Side building site for the construction elsewhere of low-to-middle-income housing and shelter for the homeless. The Citizens Committee for New York City announced a volunteer effort to bolster neighborhood projects such as soup kitchens and job fairs. And a City Council committee urged the creation of a new Office of Food Policy.

As a print medium, the office copier machine has been used by a number of artists. But it's been given new life by the painter David Hockney, as is evident in his series, ''Home Made Prints'' at the Andre Emmerich Gallery, 41 East 57th Street, through Jan. 3.

Michael K. Deaver, who has during the Iran arms sale crisis re-emerged as a key White House adviser, may soon have more troubles of his own to consider. Last week, the first statement of findings was made public in the six-month inquiry by a special prosecutor into the lobbying activities of Mr. Deaver, a longtime friend of the President and Mrs. Reagan, a former deputy White House chief of staff and now the proprietor of a multimillion dollar lobbying business.
In last Sunday's About Westchester column the name of a restaurant in Armonk was misspelled. It is Le Gueridon.

GENERAL MOTORS produced another batch of bad news last week. Beset by slumping sales and determined not to return to the generous incentives that led to a whopping third-quarter loss, the automotive giant will temporarily cut production by as much as a third, idling more than 30,000 workers. In addition, 11 facilities employing 29,000 workers will close permanently, starting next year. Although the critics of the closings ranged from labor leaders to H. Ross Perot, the recently ousted member of G.M.'s board, it was widely recognized that most of the plants were obsolete and due for replacement. Most auto industry analysts, and company officials themselves, predicted that this would be only the first and least painful round of shutdowns as G.M. adjusts to the new realities of the American car market.

Acting at the request of the baseball players' union, the arbitrator hearing the free-agent conspiracy case has asked the owners' side to produce Commissioner Peter Ueberroth as a witness. Ueberroth, the arbitrator said after hearing arguments Friday, has important, necessary and relevant information in the case and should testify. Donald Fehr, executive director of the Players Association, said yesterday that the union had asked Thomas Roberts, the arbitrator, to act because the owners' lawyers have for the past five weeks refused the players' request to have Ueberroth appear. Roberts has given the owners' side until Jan. 20 to let him know if the commissioner will testify willingly. If not, Roberts could subpoena Ueberroth.

From South Shore sand to North Shore highland, Wassail for Christmas on Long Island! And before you wrap that gift-harmonica, Blow us a chord for Happy Hanukkah. Jesus did from evils free us, But so did mighty Maccabeus. This message goes past rhyme or reason: This is everybody's season. On Garden City's Stewart and Franklin Avenues, Lights wink in trees (you've seen them, havenue?) Quogue, Mineola, Greenport, Roslyn -The storefronts' glow is simply dozzlin'.

To the Editor: May I add a footnote to Olga Carlisle's essay ''Letter From Prague - Voices of a Captive City'' (Nov. 23) and the subsequent letter from Jessica Douglas-Home (Dec. 7)? Seven functionaries of the jazz section of the Czechoslovak Musicians' Union have been arrested in Prague. According to the Communist Party press, they are to be charged with ''unauthorized business activities,'' these activities consisting in publishing books that no official publisher in Prague would touch, such as Bohumil Hrabal's ''I Served the King of England'' and Jaroslav Seifert's Nobel acceptance speech; but also a book on music in the Theresienstadt ghetto; a dictionary of Czechoslovak rock-and-roll; Nietzsche's book on Wagner; a study of the work of E. F. Burian, a prewar Communist avant-garde stage director and historian of jazz; a book on Dada, on minimal and earth and concept art, on New York's Living Theater, etc.

THE most heavily hunted small-game animals on this continent, rabbits and hares, do not inspire the culinary attention given other species, most notably ducks, geese and upland birds, and in an effort to remedy this I have resolved to not let another hunting season go by without preparing jugged hare. During the past two decades I have accumulated several jugged hare recipes, the oldest one coming from Elizabeth Beeton's monumental ''Book of Household Management,'' which first appeared in a bound edition in 1861 and was reissued in facsimile form in 1968 by Farrar, Straus & Giroux. My deliberateness in getting to this project has some justification. It wasn't until this fall while driving through upstate New Hampshire that I spied - in a yard sale - a 2-gallon, wide-mouthed earthenware crock suitable for a classic execution of the endeavor. When I told the keeper of the sale that I wanted the crock for jugged hare, she backed away and called her husband from the barn to do the dickering.

CRADLE SONG By Jane Rawlinson. 174 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $12.95. THIS surreal, impressionistic tale set in colonial Kenya explores a young British mother's irresistible desire to claim her housemaid's black son and the consequences of the extraordinary bond that grows between them. Isaac calls Ursula ''Mummy''; she calls him ''son.'' Ursula feels almost relieved at the sudden and unexplained deaths of her own baby daughter and husband, which leave her a lone white memsahib on a barren plantation surrounded by what she feels are conniving, irresponsible black servants and her beloved Isaac, with whom she even shares her bed. Ursula teaches Isaac to paint, count and read, and dresses him in her dead child's clothes, while her servants look on in perplexity and white neighbors glance away in horror and disgust.

To the Editor: I would like to respond to Vincent Canby's recent essay about film ''colorization.'' Both the pro and con viewpoints about synthetic coloring ignore historical precedents and technical justifications. For example, years before color motion pictures became practical, theatrical releases would have certain sections tinted for editorial effect. The film would be coated with a colored dye so that the images would be homogeneously colored. Also prior to ''true'' color, black-and-white films would be laboriously painted, frame by frame and released.

EVERY year hundreds of cars are abandoned in New York City parkland - to say nothing of many more in the city's streets. Parks and Recreation Commissioner Henry J. Stern proposed a solution in June 1985 - ''a bottle bill for cars.''
Joe De Sa, a former major-leaguer who was playing for Ponce of the Puerto Rican winter baseball league, died in a two-car accident early today, police reported.

Americans are increasingly choosing to live together before marrying or instead, and the number of unwed couples is topping two million for the first time, the Census Bureau has reported. About 2.22 million unmarried couples are living together, reflecting an increase of about 237,000 couples from 1985 to 1986, the bureau said. Young adults have found living together increasingly socially acceptable, sociologists report. The popularity of cohabitation grew explosively in the 1970's and has continued in this decade, although at a slower rate, they found.

HIGH STAND. By Hammond Innes. (Atheneum, $17.95.) In an author's note in ''High Stand,'' his 26th novel, Hammond Innes tells us that for a quarter of a century he has been planting Canadian trees in Wales ''to offset the destruction of the world's forests'' and that this book fulfills a longstanding desire to write an adventure novel about trees.

To the Editor: For the record, I had nothing to do with the choice of the two headlines (''Joy of Sesquipedality'' and ''I Am Lapidary but Not Eristic When I Use Big Words'') imposed on my essay on the use of long words and foreign phrases (Nov. 30). WILLIAM F. BUCKLEY JR. New York

WHO would have believed it? One year ago, the Chicago Bears were finishing a 15-1 season, on their way to a victory in Super Bowl XX while Doug Flutie was at home in Natick, Mass., ''taking it easy, hanging around, playing a little basketball,'' waiting for the next United States Football League season to begin. If someone had told him at the time that less than 12 months later he would be the Bears' starting quarterback, ''I would have thought they were crazy,'' he said. And so once again, truth of the National Football League variety has proved to be stranger than fiction. Flutie, the little quarterback from Boston College who threw the pass that beat Miami, who set a major college passing yardage record, who teamed with Herschel Walker to make the Generals the most intriguing U.S.F.L. team nobody remembers, who started the 1986 football season unsure if he would ever again throw a pass that mattered is, indeed, the Bears' starting quarterback.

For years, say Joan DaCorta Mathes and her neighbors hard by the western edge of La Guardia Airport, life in Astoria and Jackson Heights has been changing for the worse. Now, they say, their patience has run dry. ''I was born here and have lived here for 40 years,'' said Mrs. Mathes. ''I love this community and I see it being destroyed. We are being completely deluged with traffic and other problems.''

To the Editor: Isaiah did not prophesy that one day Israel alone would beat its swords onto plowshares and its spears into pruning hooks (''How Israel Got Hooked On Selling Arms Abroad,'' Dec. 7). His prophesy applies to the entire world.

Nita Helene Salzman, a fourth-year candidate for a joint M.D. and Ph.D. degree, and Bruce Philip Himelstein, a fourth-year medical student, both at New York University, are planning a May wedding. Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Salzman of Maplewood, N.J., have announced their daughter's engagement to a son of Dr. and Mrs. Morgan Y. Himelstein of Garden City, L.I. Miss Salzman, a cum laude graduate of Bryn Mawr College, received a master's degree in basic medical science from N.Y.U. Her father is a salesman for Castleton Furniture in Bloomfield, N.J. Her mother, Temmi Salzman, is chief technologist at the Endocrine and Radioisotope Laboratories in Livingston, N.J. Mr. Himelstein is a cum laude graduate of Harvard University. His father is a professor of English at Adelphi University, and his mother, Libby R. Himelstein, is a tax specialist for Prudential-Bache Securities in New York.

IN WHOSE INTEREST? International Banking and American Foreign Policy. By Benjamin J. Cohen. 347 pp. New Haven: A Council on Foreign Relations Book/ Yale University Press. $19.95. It is now conventional wisdom that economic issues have become as central to international politics and foreign policy as military strategy and the use of force. Arguably - at least until the recent crisis over arms sales to Iran - the attention of President Reagan has been focused more closely on Mexican debt, the United States trade deficit, the depreciation of the dollar and other financial and commercial issues than on arms control and strategic defense.

Joe De Sa, a former major-leaguer who was playing for Ponce of the Puerto Rican winter baseball league, died in a two-car accident early today, police reported.

Americans are increasingly choosing to live together before marrying or instead, and the number of unwed couples is topping two million for the first time, the Census Bureau has reported. About 2.22 million unmarried couples are living together, reflecting an increase of about 237,000 couples from 1985 to 1986, the bureau said. Young adults have found living together increasingly socially acceptable, sociologists report. The popularity of cohabitation grew explosively in the 1970's and has continued in this decade, although at a slower rate, they found.

HIGH STAND. By Hammond Innes. (Atheneum, $17.95.) In an author's note in ''High Stand,'' his 26th novel, Hammond Innes tells us that for a quarter of a century he has been planting Canadian trees in Wales ''to offset the destruction of the world's forests'' and that this book fulfills a longstanding desire to write an adventure novel about trees.

''I thought, 'Here's a bunch of ladies, they'll do it for a week and then give it up,' '' said Michael Bonelli, who coaches a women's ice hockey team at the Harvey School skating rink in Bedford. Instead, the original ''ladies,'' plus about 50 other women 11 to 47 years old, have been playing for more than a year and their progress has been ''fantastic,'' according to Mr. Bonelli, who said they have found a corporate sponsor and their plans include a game at the Meadowlands. Even their slot at the rink has risen from the worst to simply bad: from 10:30 P.M. to 9:30 P.M. on Friday evenings.

Notwithstanding the frigid blasts from Lake Michigan, winter in Chicago offers plenty of warmth and excitement. Residents and visitors alike enjoy the 45-foot-tall Christmas tree in Marshall Field's downtown store, the lights hanging from the trees on North Michigan Avenue and afternoon tea at the Drake Hotel. Even in winter, Chicago is known for its energy - it has bold architectural statements, pulsating jazz and blues clubs, exciting theater and colorful neighborhoods. A good place to start a visit is the Skydeck of the 110-story Sears Tower (open from 9 A.M. to midnight daily; $3), the world's tallest building, at 233 South Wacker Drive. In the sprawling South Side are Hyde Park and the University of Chicago, and farther south and west is Chicago's brawny industrial heart. Also to the west are many ethnic neighborhoods, and beyond them Oak Park, once home to Ernest Hemingway and Frank Lloyd Wright. North of the Sears Tower is downtown, dominated by banks and corporate headquarters. Farther north is the Gold Coast with 90-year-old mansions and lake-view apartments. Beyond that is Evanston, home of Northwestern University. A short drive north of Evanston, on Sheridan Road, is the Bahai Temple in Wilmette. To the east is the lake, threatening in winter, glistening in summer. Architecture Chicago - home of Louis H. Sullivan, Frank Lloyd Wright and Ludwig Mies van der Rohe - is often considered the first city of American architecture. The world's first true skyscraper, the nine-story Home Insurance Building, was built in Chicago in 1885.

Almost daily for many people the mail brings some sort of enticement to travel. Perhaps it is an invitation to join a club that promises substantial discounts on vacation packages. Perhaps it is an offer of reduced air fares or upgrades from coach to first class if you shop at a particular store or submit proof that you bought a certain brand of soap, candy or toothpaste. Perhaps it is the promise of bonus miles in a frequent-flier program if you shop with a particular credit card. Many offers are initiated by airlines as they pursue a dizzying drive to build a loyal clientele and fill seats. Frequent-flier programs, in which you are entitled to upgrading or free flights when you have traveled a certain number of miles, have proliferated with bonus miles for auto rentals, stays at hotels or flying a new route. The programs are aimed primarily at business travelers, although bonuses and temporary reductions in miles needed for awards have become so plentiful that many pleasure travelers can easily benefit, too.

Near the end of a season in which the Giants have done almost everything right, one of them today made a single detached play that is usually only found in athletes' fantasies. The player was the newest of the Giants, Tom Flynn, in his second game with them and against the team that suddenly discharged him last October. Flynn blocked a punt by Bill Renner in the first period. The ball went 12 feet into the air and came down in Flynn's hands at the Packer 36-yard line. ''I just took off,'' he said. The result was the touchdown that helped give the Giants a 14-0 lead and ''a lot of momentum,'' said Flynn, on the way to their 55-24 victory.

AT Yale University's 109-year-old Daily News, reporters still use manual Royal typewriters to produce copy. Legend has it that some of the typewriters were around in 1920, when Time Magazine founders Henry R. Luce and Briton Hadden ran The News. But next year, says Daily News publisher Hans L. Wydler, the newspaper will jump into the 20th century. It is replacing its typewriters with a computer system that will allow all of the stories to be written, edited and set in type electronically.

To the Sports Editor: Dave Anderson's misty-eyed and romanticized picture of Bobby Layne (''Ol' Bobby's Time Ran Out,'' The New York Times, Dec. 4) does a disservice to a premier athlete who, because of his drinking, never achieved his full potential and has died prematurely. It is also a disservice to all of the starry-eyed teen-agers looking for a role model to paint a compassionate picture of the swaggering athlete hero who was a hard ''drinker, not a drunk.'' Regardless of how you slice it, drinking impaired his life. The cute stories of how he ran into a ''parked swerving streetcar'' or how he drove down a one-way street in the wrong direction not only give the readers a laugh, but they imply acceptance of such behavior, if not condoning it. This one article undoes an enormous amount of hard work by many important groups, like Mothers Against Drunk Driving. It's not sexy to say ''don't drink and drive,'' but it sure comes across clearly when Dave Anderson quotes a sign in the Lions' locker room saying ''Ah ain't drunk. Ah'm from Texas.'' Think of how much better he could have been, on and off the field, without the alcohol.

Seventeen years after he ran away from it, the Vietnam War caught up with Pfc. Douglas Beane. A spokesman for the United States Embassy in Sydney, Australia, said last week that Mr. Beane, a United States marine who deserted during the war, had been arrested at the request of American authorities.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Brancatelli of Pearl River, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter Barbara Ann Brancatelli to John S. Ficarra, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Ficarra of Orangeburg, N.Y. Miss Brancatelli, who graduated from Fairleigh Dickinson University, is a registered nurse at the Hackensack Medical Center in New Jersey. Her fiance, a member of the class of '87 at the Pace University School of Law, graduated from Manhattan College.

Basketball Hawks 111, Spurs 96: Cliff Levingston scored 6 of his 12 points during a 13-0 first-quarter run last night that put Atlanta ahead to stay. Levingston broke a 16-16 tie with a tip-in and added two more baskets in the streak, which also saw Randy Wittman contribute 5 points. Dominique Wilkins led the Hawks with 28 points and Wittman added 27. It was the 10th home-court victory in 11 outings for the Hawks, who broke a two-game losing streak.(AP) Mavericks 130, Lakers 119: At Dallas, Rolando Blackman scored 39 points to lead Dallas to its first victory in three meetings with the Lakers this season. The Lakers played without Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, who returned to Los Angeles earlier in the day because of recurring corneal erosion syndrome in his right eye. Abdul-Jabbar, who had started all of Los Angeles's games before last night, was averaging 17.8 points a game. He was expected to be sidelined for two to three days.(AP) Pistons 98, 76ers 88: Vinnie Johnson scored 14 of his team-high 18 points in the fourth quarter to lead Detroit to its fifth straight victory. The Pistons trailed, 71-66, after three periods, but outscored Philadelphia by 12-0 in the first five minutes of the fourth quarter to take a 78-71 lead. Philadelphia, playing at home, could get no closer than 5 points the rest of the way. The loss was Philadelphia's fifth in six games. (UPI) Jazz 91, Bulls 89: Karl Malone hit a 12-foot jump shot with 12 seconds left to cap a fourth-quarter rally for Utah at Chicago.

Hawaiians scattered sacred ti leaves atop rampaging lava flows disgorged by the fiery Kilauea volcano, but the red-hot river of molten rock rumbled along its destructive path today, consuming four more homes. ''Mother Nature is going to go where she wants, do what she wants,'' said Richard Lau, a firefighter on the lines for 31 straight hours.

Years ago, when I was still a young boy, my mother slapped me after I steadfastly refused to remind a bus driver to let us know when to get off, and we had to take a taxi back to our destination from the outskirts of town.

While the surging popularity of rap music represents a brash, youthful rebellion against the pop mainstream, polished, ultra-romantic pop-soul singing continues to hold its own in the black music marketplace. On Billboard's ''top black albums'' chart last week, the two best-selling records - Freddie Jackson's ''Just Like the First Time'' (Capitol 12495; LP; cassette) and Luther Vandross's ''Give Me the Reason'' (Epic 40415; LP; cassette) - are quintessential examples of a cultivated male pop-soul vocal style that is so prevalent it has become a full-blown genre. ''Gregory Abbott'' (Columbia 40437), the debut album of another New York balladeer, stood at No. 5. And the Caribbean-born, English-based pop-soul singer Billy Ocean recently scored his second million-selling album with ''Love Zone'' (Jive/ Arista 8409; LP, cassette, compact disc), a record also dominated by love ballads.

International 30,000 Chinese students protested for democracy and press freedom in Shanghai, according to foreigners who saw the students' demonstrations, the largest since the end of the Cultural Revolution. Page 1 Two prominent Republicans differ in their views about President Reagan's handling of the Iranian arms crisis. Vice President Bush said the idea that he and the President would ''stay down'' is ''complete nonsense.'' But Senator Bob Dole said the President had not yet convinced the public that he had done all he could to get at the truth. #1 Panama companies are used as foils, enabling their foreign owners to do business anywhere in the world anonymously and tax-free. Three such companies were linked to the Iran arms deals last week. #20 Triad America may be near collapse. The Utah-based investment corporation is owned by Adnan M. Khashoggi, the Saudi businessman who played a key role in financing the American arms sales to Iran. #20 Andrei D. Sakharov, in an interview, said he planned to continue advocating human rights when he returns to Moscow after nearly seven years of internal exile. He said he made no promise to curb his public activities. #1 A more flexible human rights policy in the Soviet Union and an acknowledgment that treatment of dissidents affects other issues are reflected in the decision to let Dr. Sakharov return to Moscow, Western diplomats said. #14 A jailed Soviet dissident's notes, reportedly smuggled out of the country, say that he has been in solitary confinement for almost three years and and a hunger strike for more than two years.

BOSTON'S 10-year boom in construction helped the state toward its ''economic miracle,'' but not the women of the city's work force. A total of $2.4 billion was spent on 114 major public and private construction projects monitored by the city last summer, but women did only 3.5 percent of the work, which can pay as much as $20 an hour, said Ann Woodward, a statistician for the city. Kristen J. McCormack, director of the city Office of Jobs and Community Service, said, ''It violates a city ordinance that requires all large building jobs to hire 50 percent city residents, 20 percent minorities and 10 percent women.''

Two members of the House have asked the the Federal Aviation Administration to create an independent panel to decide whether the agency's chief doctor should stay on the job. Representative Cardiss Collins, a Democrat from Illinois who is chairman of the House Subcommittee on Government Activities and Transportation, and Representative Gerald Kleczka, a Wisconsin Democrat who is a member of the subcommittee, suggested that the Transportation Department's inspector general head the review. The F.A.A. is part of the Transportation Department.

To the Editor: We wanted to write you to tell you of our great pleasure with the article ''By Rail to the Other Side of Japan'' (Travel, July 27). Having traveled to many places in Japan over the years, we have had a particular interest in the Kanazawa area, but it was the your article that really stimulated definite plans to visit there.

WHEN Rueben Mayes, the New Orleans Saints' rookie running back, was named to the Pro Bowl last week, he said that playing in the game had been ''a goal of mine, even since I was a little kid.'' Despite that enthusiastic reaction, however, Mayes has decided to pass up the Feb. 1 game in order to have early surgery to repair an Achilles' tendon that has bothered him all season. By having the surgery this week, Mayes, who will face up to nine weeks of rehabilitation, figures he can improve his chances of being ready next season.

BREAKING THE IMPASSE IN THE WAR ON DRUGS By Steven Wisotsky. Foreword by Thomas Szasz. Tables. 279 pp. Westport, Conn.: Greenwood Press. $35. FOR nearly two decades ''objective data'' have been tossed about to prove that drugs are everything from a demonic force unleashed in the heartland of America to an innocent avocation of artists and youth, evil only in the minds of government propagandists.

WHEN the owners of the Quilted Giraffe restaurant in Manhattan opened another, less-expensive eating place last July, they advised the customers not to tip the waiters. The goal, said Barry Wine - who owns the restaurants with his wife, Susan - was to ''convert being a waiter into something more professional.''

Because of an editing error, the On Language column of Dec. 7 referred to an incorrect address. English Today: The International Review of the English Language is available from Cambridge University Press, 32 East 57th Street, New York 10022.

In 1987, Thailand will celebrate its biggest royal festival year in more than half a century of constitutional monarchy. On Dec. 5, King Bhumibol Adulyadej, who has reigned since 1950, will reach his 60th birthday. Events will be nationwide, beginning Oct. 16 with a royal barge procession on Bangkok's Chao Phraya River. These magnificent slender boats, built to transport royalty in a country of rivers and canals, are now seldom seen outside their storage wharf. But they have been refurbished for this event. The Tourism Authority of Thailand plans to erect viewing stands at four points along the Chao Phraya, and will sell seats at about $11.50, on a first-come, first-served basis. Booking requests can be directed to its Marketing Development Division, Ractchadamnoen Nok Avenue, Bangkok 10100. On Dec. 3, there will be a Trooping of the Color, and on Dec. 5, the King's birthday and a national holiday, ceremonies and celebrations are planned for temples in Bangkok and beyond. From Dec. 4 to 6, three royal barges will be on view at Rajaworadit Pier.

GEORGE STEINBRENNER paid Britt Burns $750,000 this year for not throwing one pitch. He paid John Montefusco $966,667 for pitching 12Y innings. He paid Al Holland $450,000 for throwing 40Z innings and then a tantrum when he was released. Burns, Montefusco and Holland will not be on the Yankees' payroll next year. Their absence will make the payroll lighter by $2,166,667. Steinbrenner could have had Jack Morris for less than that. Steinbrenner, though, concluded that he didn't need Morris in his starting rotation, so the 21-game winner, who agreed late Friday to go to arbitration with the Tigers, will open the 1987 season pitching against the Yankees instead of for them. Steinbrenner, in explaining why he didn't want to take a big bite out of the Tigers, said something about taking care of Ron Guidry and Willie Randolph first. At last glance, he was trying to sign his co-captains to 1987 salaries that would be an aggregate 35 percent less than their 1986 incomes, a savings of $875,000. Sometime before the Jan. 8 deadline, the Yankees will offer their most-senior players more money but not as much as they earned this year.

OF all the varied aspects of the real-estate business, large-scale development may be the hardest for the complete outsider to break into. ''One needs a great amount of capital, or the latitude to take substantial risks,'' said Lois Kleinerman Bernstein, president of Women in Housing and Finance, one of the organizations of professional women in New York. Beatrice Gotthelf, who gave herself the title of executive vice president when she started a one-woman business under the name The Catco Group two years ago, had neither a great amount of capital nor the latitude provided by wealthy family members when she set out to develop property. Nevertheless, she finds herself, at the age of 33, a general partner in a group that has been awarded one of the three residential sites of the Battery Place community at Battery Park City. Her partners are Property Resources, one of the city's leading builders of subsidized housing in the 1970's and early 1980's, and Paine Webber, the Wall Street investment house. The group is organized as South Cove I Associates.

Subjects for this year's worldwide Christmas celebration range from ancient customs to cartoon characters. The British Post Office offers a set of five stamps that show how Christmas customs have developed through the centuries. The stamps were inspired by five traditional Christmas customs, some of which survive to this day. A 13-pence issue illustrates the story of the Glastonbury Thorn. The December flowering of the hawthorn at Glastonbury Abbey linked ancient beliefs with the birth of Jesus. The use of greenery at midwinter festivals is rooted in the earliest days of Christianity when evergreens were a symbol of hope.

AMERICAN MUSICIANS Fifty-six Portraits in Jazz. By Whitney Balliett. 415 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $22.95. Whitney Balliett, the jazz columnist for The New Yorker, has been writing biographical pieces about jazz artists since 1962, and this book collects all 49 articles (and 56 portraits) in one place at last. Of Mr. Balliett's 11 previous books - mostly shorter collections -''American Musicians'' makes at least three entire volumes plus hunks of several others obsolete. His biographical articles are his best, so this is his most valuable book. All of Mr. Balliett's subjects are American instrumentalists except for three Frenchmen, including the violinist Stephane Grappelli, and the Belgian-born guitarist Django Reinhardt. Books about jazz seem to proliferate these days - especially books about jazz before the 1950's, when it was among America's most popular musics. That era attracts readers, perhaps because the music is receding into the past, surviving largely in memory, on reissued records and less satisfactorily in revival performances. Among the subjects of these 56 portraits, only the Modern Jazz Quartet and a dozen others are wholeheartedly ''modern'' musicians - that is, post-Charlie Parker. In fact, the majority are past the age of 65 - or would be if they were still alive - and only two are younger than 55.

In real estate, as in many other fields, price is the best measure of value. That was proved again last week in Long Beach, a community that had been in decline but more recently has been enjoying a buoyant revival and attracting the interest and the dollars of developers.

WOMEN-CHURCH Theology and Practice of Feminist Liturgical Communities. By Rosemary Radford Ruether. 306 pp. San Francisco: Harper & Row. $16.95. FLANNERY O'CONNOR once wrote, ''To the deaf, you must shout! And to the near-blind, you must draw large, wild pictures.'' Sometimes it seems as though Rosemary Radford Ruether thinks all of us are deaf and near-blind. But then one must remember to whom Ms. Ruether is used to talking: the Roman Catholic Church - an institution not renowned, as far as feminists are concerned, for its ability either to hear or to see. Ms. Ruether, a professor of theology at Garret-Evangelical Theological Seminary in Evanston, Ill., and author of many books, including ''Sexism and God-Talk,'' deserves a good deal of credit for simply staying in dialogue with this church over the 25 years in which she has taught, lectured and written. It's no wonder, perhaps, that in the process she has lost a measure of moderation.

THERE are women I know who open their hearts to me, at least when it comes to certain subjects. There is no reserve between us when they tell me how they detest the aroma of my cheap cigars and, once the ice has been broken, they go on to let me know that they cannot understand the male fascination with trains, full-scale and model. They will go to lectures to listen to psychoanalytical reflections on the will to return to the womb, but they cannot comprehend why grown men will utter the male equivalent of rapturous squeals at the sight of a tiny engine towing a string of cars over a minitrack through little tunnels. There is no doubt a good explanation, but I do not have time to wait for the translation from the German.

THE first year of Governor Kean's second four-year term is drawing to a close and the atmosphere in the State House is almost serene, despite some serious and nagging problems. Counties and municipalities are looking ahead to a new year without $127 million in Federal revenue-sharing, automobile- and commercial liability-insurance problems persist and the Transportation Trust Fund needs a new infusion of money to complete its highway construction and repair programs. The solutions to all these problems entail some political risks, among them a tax increase for the Trust Fund, repeal of a homeowners' tax break to finance aid to the cities and changes in insurance laws, which are certain to upset either insurance companies or trial attorneys.

IT DOESN'T TAKE MUCH,'' SAYS one well-traveled New Yorker, reeling off his list of essentials for a midwinter island sojourn: an unfurled tatami mat, a terry-cloth towel, Top-Siders and a toothbrush. Sparse and casual though it may be, his inventory is true to the spirit of the season, known in fashion jargon as resort. For during that period occurring roughly from mid-November to March, men hone their travel wardrobes to the basics - a handful of cotton shirts and pullovers, loose-fitting khaki or linen shorts and trousers, a sport coat and little more.

Wayne Newton, who has always done well in Las Vegas, was awarded $19.2 million last week by a Federal jury there that found NBC had defamed him in broadcasts linking him to organized crime. The broadcasts - a 1980 report entitled ''Wayne Newton and the Mob'' and two follow-up reports - described the singer's purchase of the Aladdin Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas.

Parts of Westchester County experienced a minor earthquake early yesterday, apparently the latest in a series registered over the last few years. But seismologists said the event was so small that initial checks of their instruments failed to establish its precise time, location or force. A duty officer at the National Earthquake Center in Golden, Colo., Russell Needham, said information from nearby stations indicated that the quake was centered in the Ardsley area, but that it was ''very minor'' and so weak that it would hardly have been felt.

A year ago, Saudi Arabia's Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani urged the other members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to set off a price war in an attempt to win a bigger share of the world oil market. The result was a precipitous drop in prices, from $28 a barrel in December 1985 to a low of $9 in July. Early yesterday morning, with a new Saudi representative in Geneva, OPEC reversed its strategy, agreeing to cut oil production 7 percent and raise the price to $18 a barrel.

MOST professional football fans do not think there is too much violence in the National Football League, even though they believe serious injuries have increased this season and are caused primarily by dirty play, artificial turf and drug use by the players. Those are the key findings of a New York Times/CBS Sports Poll, which reflected general satisfaction with the state of the game, though about one fan in three called drugs the most important problem facing pro football. Fans were about evenly divided over whether the injury problem was so serious that something had to be done or whether injuries were ''just part of the game,'' but 58 percent of them said there was not too much violence in the N.F.L. Fifty-two percent of the 608 fans responding said they thought serious injuries had increased this season. Of the factors perceived to cause such injuries, dirty play was cited as the most serious by 31 percent of the fans, artificial turf by 23 percent and drug use among players by 23 percent. Smaller percentages attributed injuries to officials' failure to enforce the rules stringently enough and the increased size and speed of the players. The poll, conducted by telephone Dec. 14 and 15, had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus four percentage points.

How well has television been covering the Iran arms affair? All things considered, pretty well. It's hard to think of angles the correspondents have missed. More important, it's hard to think of angles the correspondents should have ignored, but instead went out and reported. Television journalism can be a thing of excess. One remembers the endless interviews with the families of hostages after terrorists hijacked a jet. The Iran-Nicaragua story, so far, has had no equivalent to that. Grant that some of the reporting has been thin; correspondents have speculated endlessly about the future of Donald T. Regan. Grant also that some of the reporting has been bewildering; Barbara Walters' airborne interview with Adnan M. Khashoggi, for example, left us confused. By and large, however, we can live with all that.

PORT poured from crystal decanters into small-faceted glasses is a quintessentially civilized pleasure and one the British know how to enjoy. At this season, when thoughts might turn to figgy pudding and roast goose, having port to sip after dinner or in late afternoon evokes all the richness of a Dickensian Christmas.
