Unlike dry table wines, made from fully fermented juice of the grape, or brandies, which are distilled from wine and aged, port, which is stronger than wine but less alcoholic than brandy, is neither fully fermented nor distilled. Red wine that has not completed fermentation - that is, before all the sugar in the grape juice has turned to alcohol - is poured into casks containing brandy. The brandy stops the fermentation, while it also increases the alcohol. The result is port, a fortified wine that is the splendor of wine-making in Portugal.

IN quick succession, Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger and Secretary of State George P. Shultz came to NATO headquarters recently to reassure the allies that American foreign policy was on course. But an emerging full-dress debate on the alliance's health and destiny goes well beyond the turmoil in Washington over the Reagan Administration's secret dealings with Iran. The North Atlantic Treaty Organization, which has kept a peace of unprecedented prosperity for almost four decades, has been through such reappraisals before, and one useful rule of thumb seems to be that NATO is never the shambles its critics contend it is, nor the model of harmony described by its boosters. Its latest strains and tensions arise from what some Europeans see as go-it-alone impulses in the United States and what some Americans consider insufficient burden-sharing by the Europeans. And the mostly out-of-power European left is formulating ''alternative defense strategies'' which, if implemented, could give a powerful fillip to American isolationism.

Forget, for a moment, all the unknowns about the Iran-contra scandal. What cries out for debate is well known - that Ronald Reagan's passionate crusade against Communism is the engine that has powered the Oliver Norths of his Administration. Never is the President's fervor more intense than when he gazes southward to Nicaragua, seeing a people ''trapped in a totalitarian dungeon, trapped by a military dictatorship that oppresses, impoverishes them, while its rulers live in privileged and protected luxury and openly boast their revolution will spread.''

In 1969, a member of the President's Cabinet was paid $60,000. Today the figure is $86,200. That's nominally a 44 percent increase, but because of inflation it's worth 54 percent less than the 1969 salary. Members of Congress, who make $75,100, have taken a 43 percent hit. Federal district judges, at $78,700, have lost 36 percent.

Curt Warner ran for three touchdowns and Dave Krieg passed to Daryl Turner for two more touchdowns today as the Seattle Seahawks kept their wild-card playoff hopes alive with their fifth consecutive victory, a 41-16 triumph over the Denver Broncos. The Seahawks (10-6) now must await the outcome of games involving Cincinnati and Kansas City on Sunday and, possibly, New England on Monday night. Two of those teams must lose for Seattle to reach the playoffs.

Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Charles Mueller of Far Hills, N.J., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Mueller's daughter Carolyn Marie Mueller to Joseph Philip von Meister, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Frederick William von Meister of Peapack, N.J. A June wedding is planned. Miss Mueller, an assistant to the department head of the jewelry division of Christie's East in New York, graduated from the Far Hills Country Day School, St. George's School in Newport, R.I., and Trinity College in Hartford.

Battling Federal prosecutors in what his attorneys have characterized as a grudge match, John Z. DeLorean ran the score to 2-0 last week. A Federal jury in Detroit found Mr. DeLorean not guilty of defrauding his failed sports car company of $8.5 million. Mr. DeLorean, a former General Motors Corporation vice president, said the jury's verdict gave him ''a chance to restart my life.''

The guns are silent and cold, but the memory of their report still echoes across the land. Vietnam lingers, especially for the eager volunteers and luckless conscripts who crossed the Pacific to fight it. They are in their maturity now. They sit in the Congress, they stand along the assembly line, they sell pencils in the street. Some have tried to bury their past and forget the war. Many more have searched for a way to remember. They have a new mission now, one that began when the fighting stopped. This is the mission to make sense of the senseless, to find some provision in a storehouse laid empty by waste.

FREEDOM from exile for the dissident physicist Andrei D. Sakharov. The end of the Soviet nuclear testing moratorium. The ouster of a non-Russian Politburo member and the open reporting of a subsequent anti-Russian riot in Soviet Central Asia. These extraordinary events last week reflected the growing power and boldness of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, although the Soviet leader was invisible most of the week. The rapid-fire developments seemed to distill in an usually clear way some of the major themes of Mr. Gorbachev's first 20 months in office, including his efforts to enhance Moscow's image, give its diplomacy a new look, induce greater domestic candor and reshuffle the leadership.

THREATENED with defeat at the polls next November, the most prominent female judge on Long Island, Marie G. Santagata of County Court, the supervising judge of criminal courts in Nassau County, has taken the unusual step of seeking and receiving an appointment as a judge of the State Court of Claims. Judge Santagata, a Democrat from Old Westbury who has been a District Court and County Court judge for 16 years, was confirmed last week by the State Senate as one of the 23 new Court of Claims judges who will be handling drug cases exclusively. She said in an interview that she hoped to remain supervising judge in Nassau, however. That is a strong possibility since she was recommended to the Court of Claims by the state's Chief Administrative Judge, Joseph W. Bellacosa.

Dreams of transforming this dusty desert town into a homosexual community have died after promoters of the project were able to raise only $100 of the $2.25 million asking price. ''It's all over but the shouting,'' Jim Spencer, one of the town's 22 residents, said in a telephone interview Tuesday. ''When push came to shove, they couldn't pull it together.''

THE ''Messiah'' performances of Richard Westenburg and his Musica Sacra chorus have a reputation as the town's liveliest concert-hall version of the beloved work. This listener, visiting the annual celebration for the first time at Avery Fisher Hall Friday, found it lively, polished, deft, dancelike - and wished for grandeur and weight.

James L. Casey of Peapack, N.J., has announced the engagement of his daughter Anne H. Casey to A. Markus van den Bergh, the son of Gratia, Baroness Schimmelpennick van de Oye of The Hague, and the late Henri van den Bergh of Wassenaar, the Netherlands. Miss Casey, a daughter also of the late Anna Gambrill Casey, is a city planner with Sasaki Associates in Watertown, Mass.

THREE years after he announced his retirement from tournament bowling, Earl Anthony, the sport's leading money winner, has been lured back to the lanes, starting with an event in his home town of Tacoma, Wash., next month. The 48-year-old Anthony, who won a record 41 titles and a record $1.2 million between 1970 and 1983, said he planned to bowl in a few tournaments, ''just for fun'' and didn't plan to take his comeback seriously.

Back in their homelands, some of the children had seen the police beat neighbors with billy clubs and guns. Others had heard of killings, payoffs and disappearances. ''The police take people off buses to put them in jails and kill them,'' said Carmen Valencia, 11 years old, who grew up in Colombia and moved two years ago to the Flatbush section of Brooklyn. Her uncle, she said, was forced to pay police officials to keep her father out of jail on what she said were trumped-up charges.

The crew on the experimental plane Voyager forgot to add oil to their rear engine today, causing an abrupt rise in engine temperature that gave them the biggest scare of their weeklong effort to become the first plane to circle the globe without stopping for fuel. The pilots, Richard Rutan and Jeana Yeager, who took off last Sunday in the craft, an unorthodox H-shaped design of lightweight materials, were over the Atlantic Ocean at 4 A.M. when they noticed the engine was dangerously hot, said Peter Riva, a mission control spokesman. Within 10 minutes they discovered that the engine, one of two on the plane, was nearly two quarts low on oil.

St. James' Episcopal Church in New York was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Susan DeLong Ball, the daughter of Peter Ball of Stuart, Fla., and Brooksville, Me., and Anne DeLong Ball of Palm Beach, Fla., to Thomas Bedford Lloyd, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward B. Lloyd of Palm Beach and Southport, Conn. The Rev. Susan C. Harriss performed the ceremony.

An article about Ghent, Belgium, on Nov. 23 gave an incorrect date for France's takeover of what is today Belgium. The region was transferred to France from Austria by the Treaty of Campo Formio in 1797.

It was the day before the cobra slithered in front of the car that we rounded the bend in the mountain road a hundred miles or so northwest of Chiang Mai, hit the brakes and stopped just short of the pack of elephants. They were worker elephants, four of them, and they had just stumbled down the hillside and spilled out into the road after a long day of logging. Atop their backs, sitting in broad wicker baskets, was a crew of five loggers, presumably headed home to one of the tiny villages that dot the hillsides of Thailand's northwestern corner, along the Burma border. It's not clear who was more surprised: The two of us looking at the elephant team that had descended from the jungle, or the loggers looking at our once-white Toyota, coated up to the windows with reddish mud. If the loggers were unaccustomed either to visitors or mud-covered rental cars, it would be understandable. Two decades ago, Western visitors almost never ventured into Thailand's remote northwest. Until 1965, there was no paved road connecting the area where the hill tribe people and rice farmers live with the nearest city, the ancient Thai capital of Chiang Mai. Until recently some tribes did not welcome visitors.

JOSEPH E. ANTONINI could have stepped out of one of those classic American rags-to-riches tales, where the young hero starts out as a humble stock boy, works just a little harder than everyone else, climbs over all the obstacles and - lo and behold - ends up at the top of the heap. For Mr. Antonini, 45, the happy ending seems to be in sight: Four months ago, he was named corporate president and chief operating officer of the K Mart Corporation; he is expected to be named chief executive at the retail company's annual meeting in March, and there is little doubt that he will become chairman in September, when Bernard M. Fauber retires. But in real life, nothing is quite that simple. The irrepressible Mr. Antonini has plenty of challenges ahead, for K Mart, the nation's leading discounter and No. 2 retailer, is in a crucial period of transition. K Mart is caught in a continuing race both to catch up with Sears, Roebuck & Company, the No. 1 retailer, and to stay ahead of the fast-growing Wal-Mart, the second-largest discounter. In the last two years, it has had to run faster and faster just to keep its place.

''When you live along this river, it has a special meaning,'' said Wolfgang Kaiser, the Mayor of this little town of half-timbered houses on the Rhine. ''You love it. And you want to know what is happening to Father Rhine.'' Twice last month, the town's 4,000 citizens knew something awful was happening to the river. The big chemical companies of Sandoz and BASF had dumped poisons into it, obliging Unkel to turn off its water pumps and have its supplies trucked in by the all-volunteer fire department.

HAS there been a decline in the rule of law in Israel? The question was raised again last week in a case being considered by the Israeli Supreme Court. The case involves a French Jew, William Nakash, who was convicted in absentia in France of the murder of a French Arab. Mr. Nakash escaped French justice by fleeing to Israel and becoming a citizen. France asked Israel to extradite him. But Justice Minister Avraham Sharir of the Likud party, contending that he had the discretion to ignore the extradition treaty, ordered Mr. Nakash released. If Mr. Nakash were returned to France, Mr. Sharir argued, he would be a target for Arab revenge in prison. Civil rights activists appealed to the Supreme Court, arguing that Israel as a law-abiding nation must hold to its treaty and not harbor Jewish criminals. The court ordered Mr. Nakash held, promising an answer shortly.

Monica Jane Rich, an architect with SKM and Partners, and David Carl Sturm, a compliance counsel for the Commodity Exchange, both in New York, plan to be married in February. The future bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Rich of New York.

To the Editor: I am a junior at Southern Methodist University and would like to respond to ''Time to Bench S.M.U.?'' (editorial, Dec. 6). While our biggest problem at Southern Methodist is our football program, it has also been our greatest asset.

LAST Christmas Eve, the pews at First Church of Christ Congregational in Wethersfield were ''so filled, we were just squeezing them in,'' the minister said. So on Wednesday evening the church will raise its number of services to four, to accommodate the hundreds of worshipers expected. In the shoreline town of Madison, Temple Beth Tikvah is growing at such an ''unbelievable'' rate, the rabbi reports, that the synagogue has had to build an addition. And about 32,000 of the state's Roman Catholics recently participated in Renew, a program to help rejuvenate their beliefs. It is a program, a bishop said, that ''came along at the right time.''

Horses prance through the lobby of the Paine Webber building. Tigers prowl, deer leap, a rabbit scampers, a cat jumps and a pig vaults. Most of the menagerie of carved carousel animals exhibited there, however, are strutters - and that includes a zebra, goat, chicken, dog, giraffe, camel and ostrich. Only the big brown bear seems immobile, his shaggy head cocked, his eyes shining and his weighty limbs stock still, on hold, perhaps, for hugging. ''Everybody calls it a teddy bear,'' the collector Charlotte Dinger said of the life-sized beast, which predates by more than 20 years the 1902 cartoon of President Theodore Roosevelt refusing to shoot a bear cub, the image that sparked the first stuffed toy teddy bears.

THE commercial area of Thornwood, a hamlet in the town of Mount Pleasant, is, in the words of the Town Supervisor, ''rather dilapidated.'' The sidewalks are crumbling, the so-called parking lot can be reached only after traversing knee-deep potholes filled with last week's rain; there are few trees and few shoppers. But Vincent M. Valenti, the Town Supervisor, discussing plans to ''spruce up the area,'' foresees new sidewalks, trees, lights, a paved parking lot, a community center and new stores attracted by the improvements. An allocation of $175,000 from a Community Development Block Grant will be used for the improvements Mr. Valenti outlined, with the town's contribution of $13,000 and town employees' labor used to turn the railroad station into a community center. Since Metro-North was upgraded, Thornwood has not been a railroad stop and the station is currently used by a local taxi.

A television makeup artist was found guilty last night of assault in the razor slashing of a fashion model's face on the West Side of Manhattan last summer. The verdict concluded an emotional monthlong trial in State Supreme Court in Manhattan that featured testimony by the model, Marla Hanson, 25 years old, and by the defendant, Steven Roth, 28, who claimed that the slashing was staged by a jealous homosexual lover with whom he had broken up earlier that day. Mr. Roth, who was held in jail throughout the trial in lieu of $250,000 bail, showed little emotion as the verdict was read about 9:45 P.M. on the jury's third day of deliberation. He faces up to 15 years in prison when he is sentenced Jan. 27 by Justice Jeffrey M. Atlas.

In what has been called ''aviation's last great adventure,'' two pilots, Richard G. Rutan and Jeana Yeager, passed the halfway point last week in their attempt to circumnavigate the earth nonstop on a single load of fuel. Threading its way through a Pacific typhoon and dodging storms over Africa, their plane, the Voyager, headed over the Atlantic toward home.

Reporters covering the closed hearings of the Senate Intelligence Committee, staked out all day in the second-floor corridor of the Hart Office Building, are improving their meager diet. Earlier, Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, a committee member, twice sent them pizza for lunch.

Volunteers with scoop loader removing the body of one of at least 38 pilot whales that died at Eas-tham, Mass. Forty-three of the 3-ton whales beached themselves a mile north of where 28 whales beached themselves Dec. 3 and later died. (AP)

THE LAST WORTHLESS EVENING Four Novellas & Two Stories. By Andre Dubus. 214 pp. Boston: David R. Godine. $15.95. IN Andre Dubus's fine story ''Rose,'' a nameless former Marine Corps lieutenant muses in a bar: ''We like to believe that in this last quarter of the century, we know and are untouched by everything; yet it takes only a very small jolt, at the right time, to knock us off balance for the rest of our lives.'' That could be the keynote of the four novellas and two short stories in ''The Last Worthless Evening,'' dealing mainly with ordinary people whose common bond is a kind of ecstasy of despair, which can also be their source of strength.
Judith Miller writes that Jews seem to be one of the few people who have a collective memory. It appears that Jews also believe in a collective feeling of guilt.

The Senate Intelligence Committee met for three weeks about the Iran arms sales and diversion of money to the contras. We learned a great deal but, in the end, nothing really. The who and whom have yet to come out and may never do so. Can we not then pause a moment to ask why all this happened? In a narrow but intensely active circle here there has emerged a consuming obsession with the expansion of Communism - which is not in fact going on. Something else is going on: convulsive ethnic conflict. We seem to have no feel for that.

The boy had run away to another part of the country, but his problems had run right along with him. Tears streamed down his face as he stood in a telephone booth on a California street, dialing the number of his family in Texas. Although his voice shook as he spoke, his message was clear. ''I want to go home,'' he said. Home Run, a national hot line for runaways, sent him there.

The Last Metro Starring Catherine Deneuve, Heinz Bennent, Gerard Depardieu. Directed by Francois Truffaut.1980 Key Video. 135 minutes. $59.98. Unfortunately, this is a prime example of what bad dubbing can do to a very good film.

Linda Anne Poindexter with her husband, Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter, former national security adviser, and Bishop John T. Walker of Washington outside Church of the Ascension in Gaithersburg. Md. Mrs. Poindexter was ordained a priest in the Episcopal Church at a service with Bishop Walker presiding. (UPI)

While in the Congo last August on a lecture tour to promote economic development and private enterprise, Gov. Dick Thornburgh did something he couldn't do here: he bought a bottle of wine at a privately owned store. ''That was the last nail in the coffin, the straw that broke the camel's back,'' the Governor said. ''That Marxist-Leninist state has privatized liquor sales. But Pennsylvania, this great bastion of free enterprise, has a state-run, socialist monopoly.''

THE Congressional elections this year in Connecticut once again showed how expensive campaigning is. Most of the candidates raised and spent large sums of money. In the end, all the incumbents retained their seats. The Representative who raised the most money, Sam Gejdenson of Bozrah, managed to incur a debt. Mr. Gejdenson, who collected $822,626, took a $76,432 loan from the Eastern Savings and Loan Association of Norwich. At the end of the most recent campaign reporting period, Nov. 24, the three-term Democrat had debts and obligations of $75,040, according to the Federal reports.

THE town of Bedford and State Department of Transportation officials hope that the truck traffic on residential streets that has plagued Katonah for 20 years will be eliminated with the construction of a new road. An $8.7 million state project calls for building a bypass that will divert truck traffic from the hamlet's historic streets onto major roads. Katonah is at a crossroads of the so-called I-684 Corridor, bordered by the Interstate, the Saw Mill River Parkway and Route 35, a major commuting road. For many years, truck traffic generated by Mount Kisco and areas to the south have used its streets. Route 35, on the northern border of the hamlet, is one of two heavily traveled east-west corridors in northern Westchester.

Western diplomats said today that the Soviet decision to let Andrei D. Sakharov return to Moscow reflected a more flexible policy on human rights and tacit acknowledgment that the treatment of dissidents was linked to other issues like trade and arms control. The Soviet Union announced Friday that Dr. Sakharov, the physicist who was banished to Gorky in 1980 for public criticism of Soviet policies, could come move back. His wife, Yelena G. Bonner, a human rights campaigner who was convicted of anti-Soviet activities in 1984, was pardoned. Dr. Sakharov said Saturday that he planned to continue to speak out on human rights and other issues.

A state-appointed commission has urged Massachusetts to reverse its policy of not placing foster children in the care of homosexual and lesbian couples or single people. Sexual preference or marital status should only be one of several factors, like age, income, ethnicity and location, that determine appropriate placement of foster children, according to a report issued Wednesday by a 21-member commission appointed by the State Secretary of Human Services, Philip W. Johnston, to study the state's foster care system. In May 1985, Mr. Johnston announced a new policy requiring the state to ask the sexual preference of potential foster parents and, whenever possible, to place children in ''traditional family settings.''

The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 26 food establishments cited for violating the health code. In addition, it listed 11 restaurants that were allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations and one that was closed for having failed to do so. The establishments are these: Violations MANHATTAN Dallas BBQ, 27 W. 72d St. Fon Lee, 307 W. 38th St. 41 Coffee Shop, 143 W. 40th St. Hung Bo Joy Hang Seafood Restaurant, 105 East Broadway (Pike St.).

The engagement of Summer Diane Herman and Dr. Andrew Pramer has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Herman of Port Washington, L.I. Dr. Pramer is the son of Dr. and Mrs. David Pramer of Highland Park, N.J. A Jan. 31 wedding is planned. Ms. Herman, administrator of the radiology department at Mount Sinai Medical Center, graduated cum laude from Duke University and received a master's degree in health services administration from the University of Michigan.

A new Taiwan influenza virus has made its way into the United States, striking children and young adults in 22 states, Federal health officials say. The new strain, ''A-Taiwan'' flu, is caused by a virus not seen in the United States in three decades and requires a special vaccine for protection, health officials say. They urge that people under the age of 35 with chronic health problems get two flu shots, the Taiwan vaccination and a trivalent vaccine that protects against three other influenza strains.

To the Editor: Your reviewer of ''The Critical Legal Studies Movement'' by Roberto Mangabeira Unger (Nov. 23) misquotes E. C. Bentley thus: ''History is about chaps.'' The clerihew actually reads: The art of Biography Is different from Geography. Geography is about maps, But Biography is about chaps. R. CAMPBELL JAMES Washington

She blazed across the cosmos wielding a flamethrower against deadly extraterrestrials in ''Aliens.'' She ran roadblocks under fire and conducted a steamy Indonesian affair with Mel Gibson in ''The Year of Living Dangerously.'' And in ''Ghostbusters,'' she was a cellist plagued by evil spirits who possessed her kitchen appliances - and then possessed her. In a series of successful movies, Sigourney Weaver has become a screen icon to millions of Americans. The exquisitely chiseled face, the legs that any self-respecting Rockette would die for, the cool intelligence that even the dumbest script can't disguise have combined to make the 37-year-old Ms. Weaver one of the most successful actresses of her generation, not to mention the kind of sex symbol who makes men's eyes glaze.

IN the basement of the Westchester County Urban League headquarters in White Plains, Marie learned the skills necessary to propel her from her former job as a temporary secretary to a position as a data processor for a White Plains law firm. The Urban League has continued operating its Word Processing Skills Center, despite cutbacks in Government financing for job-training programs, because of the strong demand for programs of this kind by Westchester residents. The programs are supported by state and Federal grants, and the size of the grants are linked to the number of students who enter for training. Trainees pay no fees.
One Arizona State football reserve has tested positive for anabolic steroids and will not play in the Rose Bowl game against Michigan, school officials say.
To the Editor: While reference was made in your article on Parkchester on Oct. 26 to three local public schools, no reference was made to six Catholic schools near the housing complex.

RECENTLY I sat on a quiet beach, watching the water and enjoying the late afternoon sun. A father and two small children approached the water's edge. ''Julie, Jimmie, come sit on the rocks,'' Dad commanded. ''I want to take a picture.'' Jimmie and Julie were a photographer's dream. Blond and cherubic, they could do no wrong in front of a camera. But Dad had a preconceived idea. He wanted a picture of his children on the rocks. He waited while Jimmie lifted Julie onto a flat place and smoothed down her bangs. He waited while Julie gave Jimmie a hug. He watched the children compare toes, brush the sand off their hands and wave at a passing gull. Finally, when they were both squinting nicely into the sun over his left shoulder, Dad took the picture. Then he settled into his beach chair to read, while the kids splashed each other at the water's edge.

To the Editor: The enthusiasm among New Rochelle officials for massive development of Davids Island is shortsighted, resting on dubious assumptions about the general social benefit of such a project. For example, the anticipated tax revenue from luxury condominiums will be diminished by the services the city will have to provide for the additional population, among them police and fire protection, road maintenance and garbage collection. Moreover, the ability of the city's sewage-treatment plant to handle the increased load has not been demonstrated.

My Sesame Street Home Video: Bedtime Stories & Songs Featuring Jim Henson's Sesame Street Muppets and the Sesame Street Live cast. Produced by Random House Inc., in cooperation with Children's Television Workshop 30 minutes.

To the Editor: Fumiko Mori Halloran in her essay on ''The Tale of Genji'' (''Japan's Shining Prince Turns 1,000,'' Nov. 30) says that ''in the West, readers learned of 'The Tale of Genji' when Arthur Waley . . . translated it into English in 1925.''

Siren, Prism, Prime Minister To provoke good rhetoric is one of the lesser functions of political leaders. In ''The Oxford Book of British Political Anecdotes'' (Oxford University), edited by Paul Johnson, John Maynard Keynes's portrait of Lloyd George is a brilliant piece of controlled apoplexy. How can I convey to the reader, who does not know him, any just impression of this extraordinary figure of our time, this siren, this goat-footed bard, this half-human visitor to our age from the hag-ridden magic and enchanted woods of Celtic antiquity? One catches in his company that flavour of final purposelessness, inner irresponsibility, existence outside or away from our Saxon good and evil, mixed with cunning, remorselessness, love of power, that lend fascination, enthralment and terror to the fair-seeming magician of North European folklore. . . . Lloyd George is rooted in nothing; he is void and without content; he lives and feeds on his immediate surroundings; he is an instrument and a player at the same time which plays on the company and is played on by them too; he is a prism, as I have heard him described, which collects light and distorts it and is most brilliant if the light comes from many quarters at once; a vampire and medium in one. Neither Drums Nor Harp In literary criticism, attack is easier than praise because displeasure is more accessible, and more fun. In celebrating Elizabeth Bishop, Howard Moss is almost obliged to define poetry itself.

Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d told a Congressional committee that President Reagan might not remember approving the first shipment of American arms to Iran because he was recovering from an operation at the time and may have been taking medication, according to a member of the committee. Representative George Brown, Democrat of California, said today that Mr. Meese made these remarks on Friday when he appeared before the House Intelligence Committee. But a spokesman for Mr. Meese said Mr. Brown had misrepresentaed what Mr. Meese told the committee. Mr. Reagan underwent surgery for colon cancer on July 18, 1985. The first of four shipments of American arms to Iran was sent by Israel in August 1985.

The nucleus of Halley's comet rotates once every week as it sails through space instead of every 2.2 days, the rate previously suggested, an astronomer has reported. The astronomer, Robert Millis of the Lowell Observatory in Flagstaff, Ariz., reported in the British science journal Nature that computer-enhanced images of the comet taken for 21 consecutive nights when it passed over the Southern Hemisphere of Earth last spring showed that the comet rotated once every 7.4 days. ''We saw absolutely no evidence of a 2.2-day rotation in our set of data,'' he said in a telephone interview. ''We saw a repeat of features that could only be explained with a 7.4-day rotation.''

National Geographic's Yukon Passage Vestron Video. 60 minutes. $29.95. Four outdoorsmen - a surveyor, a photographer, a skier and a logger -undertake an eight-month, 1,800-mile trek, by foot, raft and dogsled, in this National Geographic television special.
Benjamin Franklin may have discovered electricity, but Samuel Ramey brought it to the opera stage (''A Voice Like a Lion's Roar,'' by Jane Scovell, Nov. 30).

DEEP IN THE BACK streets of Naples, the Convent of Santa Chiara has been an oasis of tranquillity and culture since the 14th century. But on an evening in early November, it provided an exceptional backdrop for a dinner party. Some 300 guests gathered there to help celebrate Naples 99, a foundation that arranges for corporate sponsorship of art restorations in and around that city. First, they sipped champagne in the garden cloister, for which the CIGA hotel chain had financed a technical study of the deteriorating majolica tiles that mimic the foliage with subdued colors. Glasses in hand, some strolled to a vestibule to see a small series of frescoes recently cleaned and restored under the sponsorship of the fashion designer Mario Valentino. Then it was on to the Baroque refectory for dinner. Among those present were two Cabinet ministers; a bevy of politicians; the film director Lina Wertmuller; Wanda Ferragamo of the Florentine fashion family, which has just sponsored the restoration of a piece of the Triumphal Arch of Alfonso on Naples's Castel Nuovo; Cesare Romiti, managing director of Fiat, and senior executives of a number of banks, publishing houses and other businesses. Watching the sequins and jewels glittering in candlelight, one woman said, ''It is very special that these people are here for a serious purpose. Fifteen or 20 years ago they would have been doing la dolce vita.''

JOHN W. EPLING clutched at the lapels of his jacket as he rushed across the breezy Rutgers Commons, grumbling that he should have brought along an overcoat. Since he moved from northern Virginia to New Jersey a few weeks ago to take over as executive director of the new Office of State Planning, similar oversights have left Mr. Epling shivering through several afternoons. But Mr. Epling is quickly learning to adjust not only to New Jersey weather, but also to its political climate. Most observers agree he is in the hot seat, facing a monumental task, an unforgiving deadline and the uncertainty that goes with being first in a complicated and controversial new endeavor. Governor Kean signed the new State Planning Act last January, establishing a commission and charging it with creating a state development and redevelopment plan within 18 months.

NOBODY REALLY cares who shot John. That's because who shot John is inherently dismissive, always used in the sense of a question that the speaker is not about to answer because it involves loathsome finger-pointing, unworthy of the fair-minded. When Marlin Fitzwater, press spokesman for Vice President George Bush, was asked about Bush's support of the President's policy to ship arms to Iran, he said, according to The Washington Post, ''that Bush does not want to discuss the process of 'who shot John' in making the Iran decisions.'' The reporter, David Hoffman, quoted the spokesman directly, adding, ''This is a classic example of the kind of thing for six years that George Bush has never commented on, in good times or bad.'' That derogation concerning blame-fixing has been steadily gaining currency. A 1977 recording by Nathan Page used those words as its title, and the expression must have been helped along by the ''Who Shot J.R.?'' promotion of the television drama ''Dallas.'' ''For the first three months of his campaign,'' wrote The Washington Post's T.R. Reid about Senator Edward M. Kennedy's quest for the Presidency in 1980, ''Kennedy flailed around on a sprawling spectrum of issues ranging from who-shot-John-in-Teheran to the wiretap provisions of the criminal code bill.''

WIDELY hailed as the most esthetically pure city-satellite settlement of the 1960's, this celebrated ''new town'' in the northern Virginia suburbs of Washington is preparing to shed its carefully nurtured urban-village cocoon and go assertively ''downtown.'' Developers are adding a new kind of citylike high-rise Main Street to Reston's 11.5 square miles of seemingly undauntable neosuburbia, where curving streets named Stirrup Road, Trotter Lane and Gallant Fox Court weave among timbered ''executive campuses'' filled with more office space than in downtown Richmond, the state capital. In planning an urban, straight-line street grid that seems deliberately antithetic to the pseudorustic theme set by Reston's Colt's Neck Road and Polo Fields Court, the well-financed owners of one of America's most successful ''new towns'' may be setting a new national pattern for what could be called a ''new city.''
Get Ready, Get Set, Grow Created by Ian Clark. Brooklyn Botanic Garden. 1000 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn, N.Y.11225. 15 minutes. $29.95 (plus $2.50 for postage and handling).
Burlington has received an early Christmas gift: nearly eight acres of waterfront beach property from the Mobil Oil Corporation.

The reference to Brooke Astor's personal munificence to the New York Public Library, accompanying the pictures of her exquisite personal library, serves as a reminder of our longstanding debt of gratitude to this extraordinary woman (''A Private Library,'' by Barbaralee Diamonstein, Home Design, Nov. 16). On behalf of the many card-carrying book lovers whose lives have been enriched by her contributions, I wish to say: Thank you, Brooke Astor. GENEVIEVE THIENELL New York City

IN its tranquil setting at the foot of the Ramapos, the Rockland County village of Suffern seems somehow out of sync with its bustling neighbors to the south and east. From its quaint central business district, nearly surrounded by well-kept turn-of-the-century homes, to the northern areas where large properties off quiet country lanes overlook the western mountains, it seems more like a remote upstate hamlet than a village at the hub of one of the most rapidly developing areas in the New York metropolitan region. The pace of development, however, has begun to quicken into a boom in this 2.3-square-mile municipality 33 miles northwest of Manhattan at the interchange of Route 17 and the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway. Just to the south, in Mahwah, N.J., International Crossroads, a 3 million-square-foot high-rise office park is under construction at the site of the former Ford Motor Company auto-assembly plant. The complex, when completed, is expected to provide employment for nearly 7,000 workers.

In London, some will argue, there are three kinds of places for men to get a haircut: the unisex emporiums, the traditional barbershops and Truefitt & Hill on Old Bond Street in Mayfair. Truefitt & Hill, London's oldest barbershop, has snipped the locks of Britain's high and mighty ever since it was established in 1805, the year of the Battle of Trafalgar. Over the years, its clientele has included King George IV, Sir Winston Churchill, Field Marshal Montgomery, Alfred Hitchcock, Rod Steiger, Lord Olivier and Prince Philip. Queen Elizabeth's husband gets his hair cut ''up at the palace,'' as one employee put it, a singular departure from the shop's policy of no house calls.

The question of President Reagan's age and memory, discussed fleetingly in the last Presidential election campaign, is back in the news again as he prepares to enter the hospital for minor surgery. Assuming that he bounces back to his normal self, as usual, he will still leave doubts here about his casual executive style, and the competence of his staff. For the moment, it's not what we don't know about the recent conduct of his office that counts but what we do know. We do know a good deal about his alarming unpreparedness for the summit meeting with Mr. Gorbachev at Reykjavik, and we do know that his handling of the Iran-contra scandal was almost as clumsy as the original plan, if that's the right word.

HEARING SILVER experts describe their prized pieces is not so very different from listening to an architect discuss the details of a room or a furniture dealer talk about the lines of a chair. Words like shape and proportion invariably crop up in the conversation. So do such familiar ornamental motifs as swags or grapes, shells or beads. Indeed, earmarks of any particular design style recur in everything from architectural elements and wallpaper patterns to the designs of tables and chairs, spoons and forks.

Rabbi and Mrs. Stanley M. Urbas of Yorktown Heights, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elisheva Shulamit Urbas, to David Marc Morris, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald A. Morris of New York. A May wedding is planned.

Ronald W. Pelton apparently picked up a lot of knowledge he didn't need during his 14 years as a communications specialist at the National Security Agency. So, after quitting his job in 1979, Mr. Pelton decided one day to sell some of it to the Soviet Union, making what his lawyer, Fred Warren Bennett, described as ''the biggest mistake of his life.''

IN this season of chilling winds and frozen ground, the University of Connecticut Cooperative Extension Service is looking for gardeners. The Extension Service wants people who like growing plants and working with the public to join its Master Gardener Program, which provides instruction during the winter for gardeners who will share their knowledge with other gardeners come spring. This is the 10th year for the program, which in early January begins offering daylong classes, once a week, for participating gardeners. A total of 60 hours of instruction covers such topics as soils, fertilizers, insects, pesticides, vegetables, fruits, ornamental plants, lawns and ground covers and plant diseases.

At Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I., last night Sharon Mindy Kass, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene L. Kass of Merrick, L.I., was married to Frederic Scott Spike, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Spike of Philadelphia.

Parallels may be drawn between the invention of the phonograph by Thomas Edison about 100 years ago and the invention of a system of musical notation by Guido d'Arezzo about 1,000 years ago. In both instances, the aim was the preservation and conveyance of music - whether in symbols or in the actual sound -and both events proved pivotal in the history of the art. D'Arezzo's scheme of representing pitch on parchment is to music what writing is to literature: a medium of transmission. So is the phonograph, and it is certainly reshaping the course of music in our time. Recording has altered the way most of us listen to music. In contrast to the past, most music today is not heard in the presence of the performer but is electronically transported to some other time and place.
To the Editor: In his review of Laurence Olivier's ''On Acting'' (Nov. 16) Fritz Weaver refers to Lord Olivier's sense of being, like Richard III, a sort of usurper.

MARILYN By Gloria Steinem. Photographs by George Barris. 182 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $24.95. ON June 1, 1962, her 36th birthday, Marilyn Monroe began what would be her final attempt to tell her story. Lies had been told about her, she insisted, and she was going to set the record straight. In addition to the biographical information she had contributed in interviews over the years, she had launched a previous full-scale autobiography in conjunction with the novelist and playwright Ben Hecht. Minus the name of its co-author, ''My Story,'' as that unfinished manuscript was called, was published in 1974 and reissued in paperback this year. For her new venture Marilyn Monroe also had a collaborator, a photojournalist, George Barris. Mr. Barris was obviously a sympathetic co-adjutant. Through June and July Marilyn talked and posed - and drank champagne. Mr. Barris took many soft gentle pictures of her, in bathing suit, towels, beach robe, sweater. But this project, too, was not completed. On Aug. 4 Marilyn Monroe died of an overdose of sleeping pills. More than two decades later, Mr. Barris turned over his photographs to Gloria Steinem for use in her present thoughtful and absorbing biography of the actress.

In the days when Northeastern University was a commuter school, its students spent so much time driving to the inner-city campus from outlying suburbs that they were known as the ''thundering herd of Route 93.'' These days the herd of Northeastern students does most of its thundering on the athletic field. In November the basketball team stunned cable television viewers across the country when it upset Louisville, the defending national champions, in a tournament in Alaska. The hockey team, which had lost Boston's prestigious local ''Beanpot'' tournament 28 years in a row, has surprised regional sports enthusiasts by winning three of the last four tournaments. Also, the football team and track teams now play against top-ranked schools.

''PEOPLE have a very strong feeling about living here,'' said Supervisor Lois Q. Lippmann of North Salem. So strong, she added, that they often wish to be buried in the town. But as there are no church-owned or private cemeteries in North Salem, the town feels responsible for providing burial plots for its 4,700 residents.
Like it or not, attached townhouses are creeping up on Woodstock, N.Y. ''The people around here were up in arms,'' said Harold Graff, a former Hurley town councilman. ''They still glare at me.''

Camille Williams Taylor and William Robert McDuffie Jr. were married yesterday at the Peachtree Presbyterian Church in Atlanta. The Rev. Dr. W. Frank Harrington performed the ceremony, assisted by Associate Justice Harry A. Blackmun of the United States Supreme Court.

AFTER 10 years of playing jazz and pop arrangements from the time of World War I to the early 1930's, Vince Giordano has built his band, the Nighthawks, into an ensemble that has a remarkable versatility in what he calls ''the musical dialect'' of the period. The group's versatility includes its ability to adapt its full strength of 12 musicians to smaller ensembles without losing the flavor of its performances. Currently a seven-piece variation of the Nighthawks is playing on Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays through Dec. 30 from 3 P.M. to 6 P.M. in the Park Avenue Plaza, 55 East 52d Street, in a narrow corridor lined with shops. Set up in front of Singular Editions and facing Chartwell Books, playing to an audience that is either standing or sitting on the floor, Mr. Giordano's group moves from early Duke Ellington to classic Jelly Roll Morton, from James Reese Europe's 1914 hit ''Too Much Mustard'' to Louis Armstrong and Sidney Bechet a decade later, and they play with spirit, polish and a full sense of the joy inherent in this music.

A MOTORIST driving north on Palisado Drive in South Windsor, Conn., who turns left at Settlement Hill Road may feel as if he's slipped backward two centuries in time. Three faithfully restored 18th-century houses are clustered in their own little village, another is being rebuilt using old-fashioned building techniques and space has been left for three more. Ellsworth Village is the first multi-unit development for Sunderland Homes, a builder whose work until recently involved restoring a room, or sometimes an entire house, under contract to the owner. The relocated and restored houses in the village have found a ready acceptance from buyers, said Edward T. Sunderland 3d, president of the company. ''By the time we get to the framing stage, it's usually sold.''

When Dennis Conner's designers were gearing up for the 1986-87 America's Cup challenge last spring, they used a computer to simulate a kind of sailing war game. Taking what they knew at the time about each opposition boat, they plugged numbers into a computer to simulate its shape, weight, sail plan and crew strength. Then they ran their own series of boat races, 100 in a day, in mock competition. John Marshall, the team's design coordinator, said during a recent interview that when the results were in, they were largely a mirror of the semifinal scorecard here. Tom Blackaller's USA was unpredictable. The results showed up in ''peaks and valleys.'' As for Chris Dickson's New Zealand, the front-runner in the elimination series, the computer simulation showed a series of races in which Conner's team won or lost by small margins.

IT takes a special courage to venture into the family attic. As a youngster it was one of those places to be avoided simply because all of the players in those bad dreams of childhood were hiding in the darkness of that space. In truth, those harmless demons of my youth were nothing more than the wrenching squeaks of a settling house and the concealed mysteries floating in my imagination. It was a fear I learned to deal with as any child might. In those early years, that same attic provided the hiding space for things that had to be set aside: precious toys, pointless gifts, outgrown clothing, useless collections and, naturally, Christmas artifacts.

''LET us now praise famous women,'' says Dr. Lola L. Szladits, curator of the Berg Collection of English and American Literature, backing her words with an appealing new show in the scholarly enclave she bestrides on the third floor of the New York Public Library. ''Women and Literature: English and American Writers From the 18th Century to the Present'' offers a behind-the-scenes look at writers who received recognition, often belated, at times when they were considered presumptuous for invading the ink-stained masculine world of the novel, poetry and history. ''When women in the 19th century wielded pens, they were called poetesses or authoresses,'' Dr. Szladitz says. ''Fanny Burney published her novel 'Evelina' anonymously. Margaret Fuller said that she had 'a man's ambition with a woman's heart.' At least one changed her name - we know Mary Ann Evans as George Eliot. 'Most women do whatever they can,' Louisa May Alcott wrote. Many women 'authoresses' wrote children's stories to make a living. And several books by women - Harriet Beecher Stowe's 'Uncle Tom's Cabin' and Margaret Mitchell's 'Gone With the Wind' - changed history.''

''ABSURD PERSON SINGULAR,'' by the English playwright Alan Ayckbourn, appears to be just the show for the holidays. The play takes place over three Christmases: the last one, this one and the next one. And, ostensibly, it's a comedy; a farce, in fact.

PANAYIS LYRAS is a pianist of enormous talent and technical facility, but his recital Thursday evening at Alice Tully Hall was a disappointment, especially after his past success here. The basic problem was a persistent dryness of emotional tone and clipped tightness of phrasing. These tendencies turned his opening Haydn Sonata in C (Hob. XVI, No. 50) into almost a parody of modern Haydn playing, the naturally sonorous inclinations of his Steinway grand bled of nearly all their expressive warmth.

Avelar Cardinal Brandao Vilela, head of the Roman Catholic Church in Brazil and Archbishop of the northeastern city of Salvador, died of stomach cancer Friday in a hospital there, the hospital said today. He was 74 years old.
Up until his death, John D. deButts, the former chairman of A.T.&T., fervently believed in the Bell telephone system.

The marriage of Terri Jean Seligman, an associate at the New York law firm Willkie Farr & Gallagher, and George David Hagen, a screen writer, took place last night at the Loft at 126 Fifth Avenue. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel performed the ceremony. Ms. Seligman, who will retain her name, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Seligman of New York. The bridegroom's parents are Mr. and Mrs. David Hagen of Lawrenceville, N.J.

WALLACE STEVENS The Early Years 1879-1923. By Joan Richardson. Illustrated. 591 pp. New York: Beech Tree Books/ William Morrow & Company. $21.95. IT'S hard to conjure up a picture of the young Wallace Stevens. As a poet, he was a late bloomer - 35 years old when he began to write the poems in his first book, ''Harmonium,'' and 44 when it was published in 1923. In the best-known glimpses we have of him he is already the imposing, remote vice president of the Hartford Accident and Indemnity Company composing verses in his head as he walks to work. Even the famous story of his fist fight with Hemingway comes from his later years - he was close to 60 when he threw those drunken punches. No youthful high jinks there.

THIS has been a head-scratching week for the Jets. They are a team granted a reprieve, learning they had made the playoffs a day after they dropped their fourth straight game. In fact, they even can win the American Conference East title. They will meet the Bengals today in the regular-season finale in Cincinnati, but the questions still remain. They not only concern whom New York faces in the playoffs - as well as when and where - but more important: Just where are they at right now?

To the Sports Editor: Before we Giant fans start feeling too upbeat about our impending home-field advantage, let us remember all the things we still have to worry about: * The X-6 Flu Virus: A new strain never before seen in the Meadowlands. Sure to arrive before Christmas.

After every defeat, every embarrassing performance, someone suggests that it couldn't get any worse. And yet it does. Last night, before an announced crowd of 9,535 very displeased spectators at Madison Square Garden, the Knicks sank to new depths, stumbling through a performance so utterly without value that the team was booed throughout the final period. That was when the Indiana Pacers, a team that had lost six consecutive games on the road, humiliated the Knicks. Led by the most explosive performance of the season for Chuck Person, the rookie forward, the Pacers scored 42 points in that final 12 minutes to cruise to a 123-99 victory. The Knicks suffered their eighth straight defeat and their 21st over all, more than any other team in the league.

Six Italians were detained for almost 24 hours in Teheran this week when port workers in Genoa blocked the departure of an Iranian ship, the Italian authorities said. The standoff, which followed reports that a stowaway aboard the Iranian ship was seeking asylum, ended when the ship was allowed to leave Genoa and the Italian travelers were released by Iran, the officials said. The stowaway remained aboard the ship.

AFTER seeing his team get off to a 1-6 start, Ron Kornegay, the Monmouth College basketball coach, has decided that someone else might have a better chance to change things. ''The program needs to go in another direction,'' the 39-year-old coach said as he stepped down and turned the team over to his assistant, Ron Krayel, 41, who will serve as interim coach. Kornegay, a former Hawk guard who spent seven years as an assistant before taking over as head coach in 1976 and compiling a 129-130 record, will retain the post of assistant athletic director he has held for five years.

MOST pro football teams are coached by strangers in town with little or no feeling for a team's past. But the coach who has restored the Giants' glory grew up rooting for other Giants teams of glory. Bill Parcells is a New Jersey guy who had Giant pennants on the wall in his room as a youngster. And now, in guiding his Giants to a 14-2 record, the most victories in any of the franchise's 62 seasons, he deserves to be the National Football League's Coach of the Year. ''You've got so many people you know here,'' the 45-year-old coach was saying. ''And they're genuinely happy that somebody from New Jersey is doing it. You can see it, you can feel it. And they have a tremendous loyalty to you because you're one of them.''

Mayor Koch, acknowledging that the city is not doing enough to place children awaiting foster care into homes, has recommended a drastic reduction in the time it takes to approve foster parents. He said foster parents should be approved within two weeks. Such approval now takes as long as six months.

THE 92d Street Y assembled a formidable assortment of chamber musicians for its program this week, and the Wednesday evening concert was, by and large, a delight. One's reservations had to do with the dubious need to play a mid-1950's pastiche of quintet music by Boccherini when so many fine, unadulterated scores by that composer are waiting to be heard, and the otherwise estimable acoustics of the Kaufmann Concert Hall, which seemed to rob the concluding Mendelssohn Octet of some of its gossamer lightness. The musicians on hand were the violinist Jaime Laredo, who leads the Chamber Music at the Y series and who took the dominant first-violin part in the Mendelssohn; Peter Oundjian, first violinist of the Tokyo Quartet; Michael Tree, violist of the Guarneri Quartet, and Sharon Robinson, the cellist and Y regular. Joining them were the young members of the Ridge String Quartet, Krista Bennion Feeney, Robert Rinehart, Ah Ling Neu and Ramon Bolipata, who sounded in no way deferential to their seniors.

A Sunset Boulevard fingernail salon that refused to give a pedicure to a hairdresser who has AIDS has become the first business to be charged under the city's AIDS antidiscrimination law. The establishment, Jessica's Nail Clinic, violated a year-old city ordinance intended to discourage businesses from denying employment, housing and services to people with acquired immune deficiency syndrome, City Attorney Michael Jenkins said Friday.
Peter A. Quinn has not only lost track of where he's going, but also of why he's going (''A Sense of Direction,'' About Men, Nov. 9).

The shutdown of the Government-owned nuclear reactor at Hanford, Wash., one of the main sources of plutonium for the nation's nuclear arsenal, has set the stage for a major debate over how this country produces the raw material for nuclear bombs, and how much more is needed. Costs, jobs, environmental concerns and the security of the nation all promise to weigh as factors in this debate. For years the Department of Energy has asked Congress for a new plutonium-producing reactor, at a cost that the department puts at $2 billion to $3 billion but that critics say would be much higher. Congress has refused to provide the money. In addition to the facility at the Hanford reservation, the N-Reactor, the Government has three more plutonium producers at its Savannah River Plant, near Aiken, S.C. But one of those, the C-Reactor, has been shut since June 1985 because of cracks in the reactor vessel that technicians are not sure how to fix. Roger Rollins, a nuclear engineer for the department, said Friday that engineers had so far found no way to weld the cracks, raising doubt about whether the reactor could ever be operated again.

In the largest student demonstrations since the Cultural Revolution, 30,000 to 35,000 students marched on the streets of Shanghai today shouting demands for democracy and press freedom, according to foreigners who saw the protests. Throughout the day, thousands of students poured into a huge expanse of pavement known as People's Square. Thousands of others demonstrated outside city government offices on the tree-lined Bund, the promenade along the west bank of the Huangpu River. In People's Square, students carried huge placards reading, ''Long Live Freedom,'' and ''Give Us Democracy,'' the foreigners said.

What Robert Frank's ''The Americans'' was to the 1950's, Nan Goldin's ''The Ballad of Sexual Dependency'' is to the 1980's. The 800-image ''ballad'' - a sweeping, diaristic and critical account of life within the photographer's own artistic, urban subculture - reflects the same dissatisfaction with contemporary life evident in ''The Americans'' and extends the narrative potentials of still photography that Frank's book revealed. At the same time, it serves to gauge the distance between the existential angst of Frank's time and today's sense of social and cultural atomization. Goldin, at the age of 33, has created an artistic masterwork that tells us not only about the attitudes of her generation, but also about the times in which we live.

Peace, Jean Mayer acknowledges, has become a flabby notion, and he would like to firm it up. So Mr. Mayer, the president of Tufts University, got university leaders from around the world together to try to arrive at some common understandings about peace and international security.
The counterman at a seafood house in downtown Washington noticed recently that he had been getting a fair amount of currency, dollar bills, tens and twenties, looking new but dated 1969.

''If you affirm the N.Y.S.E. request, it will be a blot upon the escutcheon of corporate democracy and the S.E.C.'' Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum warning against a Big Board plan to list companies with different classes of stock.

UNTIL about six weeks ago, those who profess to know who's who in this town said that Paul A. Volcker had become a lame duck - a man whose chances of being reappointed head of the Federal Reserve had fallen well below 50-50 and who had begun to weigh seriously some of the juicy seven-figure-a-year offers dangling before him. Some observers even said they detected a certain detachment in Mr. Volcker's performance in the world's mightiest financial job. He had, they said, not engaged in the subtle lobbying that would have signaled his eagerness to remain in power. Mr. Volcker's departure, in many eyes, would be a sharp blow to confidence in American economic policy making and could lead, among other things, to a run on the dollar. Like two of his modern predecessors, William McChesney Martin Jr. and Arthur F. Burns, Mr. Volcker has come to be seen as an almost impossibly tough act to follow.

At a news conference in St. Petersburg on Friday, Dwight Gooden projected calm and good neighborliness. When the children he plays catch with come by his parents' house and ask him about the fight with the police last Saturday night, Gooden said, ''I just put it as a misunderstanding.'' But that is not what Jerry Halstead, a regional vice president for A. L. Williams, a national marketing firm, said he saw when he stopped for a minute at the scene that night. ''I saw these two guys down on the ground, and they were beating them,'' Halstead said. ''One was lying face down on the ground, and they were hitting him with with nightsticks or flashlights or something.''

SANTA CLAUS, who will make his traditional rounds Wednesday night and early Thursday morning, has already come a-calling in the Hartford area. And when he calls, he really does know if you have been naughty or nice. A Santa working for a Hartford telemarketing company has been extending greetings, warnings and even telling jokes via telephone - for a price. The company, TBS, an affiliate of the Telebroadcasting System based in Beach Lake, Pa., offers 16 different recorded messages from Santa for $3 each. In addition, the TBS version of Kris Kringle will send out a personalized message for $5.

A man charged with beating and robbing a woman on a Bronx street has been freed after the prosecutor in the case refused to cross-examine a witness who is a juror in the fraud trial of former Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan. The prosecutor, Philip Gaynor, an assistant Bronx District Attorney, said he feared that if he ''vigorously'' questioned the witness he might affect her status as a fair and impartial juror in the Donovan case. Mr. Donovan and eight other defendants in that trial, now 12 weeks old, are accused of perpetrating a $7.4 million fraud against the New York City Transit Authoriity. Mr. Gaynor asked the judge in the robbery trial, Acting Justice Elrich A. Eastman of State Supreme Court, to suspend proceedings until after the Donovan trial, which he said could take another two or three months. Justice Eastman instead ordered the dismissal of charges against the defendant, Bennie Lovett. He had been accused in a six-count indictment of beating a nurse on Fordham Road near Fordham University and taking her pocketbook containing $75 in May 1985. The prosecution had completed its presentation of the evidence. The defendant was freed immediately after the judge's ruling on Tuesday.

Senator Bob Dole of Kansas said today that President Reagan had not yet convinced the American public, including many of his fellow Republicans, that he had done all he could to get at the truth about the Iranian arms sales. ''The President has done a lot of things,'' Mr. Dole, the Senate majority leader, said in an interview. ''He urged the appointment of a special counsel, he let his people testify on the Hill, and so on. But there's still a lot of confusion out there, still a feeling that he has to do something bold himself to clear the air.''

A MOOD of frustration and uncertainty gripped the capital last week as three Congressional committees tried unsuccessfully to discover the full story behind the Administration's secret arms deal with Iran. The attempts by investigators to follow all the twists in the tale kept running into the same obstacle: the refusal of the two key players, Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter and Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, to tell what they know. At week's end, Representative Lee H. Hamilton of Indiana, the Democrat who heads the House Intelligence Committee, said, ''We really don't know the answers to the key questions.'' The task of finding those answers now shifts to two select committees, one in each chamber, that were named last week by Congressional leaders. But these panels, which will be formally established when Congress reconvenes in January, will also have responsibilities far broader than the search for specific facts and figures.

The engagement of Victoria Frances Lawford to Robert B. Pender has been announced by Patricia Kennedy Lawford of New York and Southampton, L.I.,, mother of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mrs. James C. O'Shea of Barneveld, N.Y., and the late Dr. Robert B. Pender.

Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

THIS is the annual season of frauds; of the false Santa and the fake charity. So warns W. Richard Bruner, head of the Better Business Bureau office in White Plains. ''Now, more than any other time of the year, it's caveat emptor, or let the buyer beware,'' said Mr. Bruner, who is surprisingly cheerful for one who deals with flimflams, scams, broken contracts and the myriad other problems consumers are heir to year-round. ''Basically I'm optimistic because the majority of people are honest,'' he said. ''But Christmas is the time to especially watch out for the charities that are out-and-out frauds, as well as those who spend more to raise money than they do on the charity program. ''We run checks on all the familiar charity organizations,'' he continued, ''and we know how much they spend for what. In the philanthropic business, 25 to 30 percent is the accepted amount allowed for salaries and overhead; anything beyond that is suspicious. We turn up several every year that spend more than 50 percent of the money collected on salaries alone.''

THE briefing officer at the Strategic Air Command headquarters in Omaha tapped his pointer on a bar graph comparing targets in the Soviet Union to nuclear warheads in the United States arsenal. ''To retaliate,'' he said, ''it would take more than double what we have on the ramp now.'' Despite President Reagan's multibillion-dollar modernization of strategic forces, begun five years ago, the armed services say the gap between targets and warheads has not been closed. There are more and stronger Soviet targets, and Administration policy decrees that the military be able to hit them repeatedly; in addition, political disputes and technical problems have delayed parts of the President's program.

Gaetano Donizetti had already composed approximately 70 operas, was wracked with syphilis and near mental collapse when he wrote his comic masterpiece ''Don Pasquale'' in 1842. That the resultant work is so youthful and affirmative, with melodies and characters that have lost none of their vividness in the last 145 years, is something of a miracle. Indeed, one thinks of Mozart's Clarinet Concerto, written on what the composer knew would be his deathbed yet imbued with a graceful, almost teasing wit and serenity.

TWO years ago, as Christmas and Hanukkah neared, Virginia Commonwealth University in Richmond tried a new way to sell its continuing education courses: gift certificates. ''We sold a few,'' the vice president for continuing studies, Dr. Howard Sparks, says.

Mary Lyon, who in 1837 founded the women's school that became Mount Holyoke College, will appear next year on a postage stamp. The 2-cent stamp will be issued Feb. 28, the 190th anniversary of the birthday of the education pioneer. The current 2-cent stamp honors the composer Igor Stravinsky.

HE is so deaf that family members have to jump up and down to get his attention, and his arthritis is so advanced he can no longer negotiate the stairs. But Tucker, a mix of collie, German shepherd and Other, has become in his 15 years with the Zager family in Pleasantville an ''old family friend.'' The Zagers hope the New York State Supreme Court will agree. Elissa and Jonathan Zager, backed by the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals and the Animal Legal Defense Fund, have asked the court to reverse a lower-court decision in the case, which involves injuries to the dog, and support their position that ''an animal who has achieved the status of a member-of-a-family unit cannot simply be treated as if it were a vase or other inanimate object of personal property.''

To the Sports Editor: We would like to express our very real concern at what we here interpret as a serious blow to the image of American sportsmanship. Over many years, your great country has produced fine sportsmen who were true champions - people who strove their hardest to win but accepted reversals with good grace and dignity. It is, therefore, particularly disappointing to see the heritage of sportsmanship that these great people have bestowed on your country (and the world) besmirched by the petulant posturing and sour grapes of some of the yachting people presently competing in the America's Cup.

At Our Lady of Perpetual Help Roman Catholic Church in Bernardsville, N.J., yesterday Patricia Ann Barkhorn, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Barkhorn of Bernardsville, was married to Peter F. Moore, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Moore of Stonington, Conn., and Kilcolgon, County Galway, Ireland. Msgr. John R. Torney performed the ceremony and concelebrated the nuptial mass with Msgr.

As the Gorbachev administration in the Soviet Union appears to loosen controls and to encourage more open discussion of public issues, an increasing number of Government-approved construction projects have come into question in the press. The most widely publicized example has been opposition to a long-planned diversion of rivers from Siberia to arid Central Asia. Public criticism led the Government to abandon the project earlier this year as too costly and possibly harmful to the environment. But other undertakings such as dams and associated hydroelectric power plants, some well along in their construction, have also become embroiled in public debates.

Triad America, the Utah-based investment company of Adnan M. Khashoggi, the Saudi businessman and arms dealer who played a key role in financing the American arms sales to Iran, appears to be on the verge of collapse. Creditors have filed foreclosure and other legal actions to recover overdue interest payments on loans, as well as unpaid bills for goods and services to Triad and its subsidiaries. Alarmed that Triad may be unable to pay millions of dollars in debts, one of its creditors won a temporary restraining order in Federal District Court here on Dec. 10 to block the proposed sale of a profitable oil company owned by the Triad subsidiary, Triad Energy. The sale would be to a Canadian company in which Mr. Khashoggi and Triad's president, Donald Fraser, are major stockholders and officers. In papers filed with the court, the creditor, Sheraton Corporation, asserted that the plan to sell Edgington Oil Company of Long Beach, Calif., to Skyhigh Resources, based in Vancouver, was made with ''intent to hinder, delay and defraud Triad's creditors.''

To the Editor: Tom Wicker's argument (''Beware That Mandate,'' Dec. 5) that four modern Presidents (Roosevelt, Johnson, Nixon and perhaps Reagan) have been stalemated after landslide election triumphs can be carried much further. Landslides are not the only cause of that dangerous combination of ignorance and arrogance that has bedeviled modern Presidents and us. Commonly perceived crises or unusually high Presidential popularity may also produce a suspension of our traditional constitutional system of separated institutions sharing, and struggling over, power. Our recurring national crises are not just the result of venal and mean-spirited Presidents and their aides or of a gullible public, although we have experienced both. I would argue that the country suffers from a kind of constitutional schizophrenia, between the traditional constitutional system and a 20th-century version of elective kingship or constitutional dictatorship.

To the Editor: Our domestic oil industry is on the verge of collapse. Within a year, it will be extracting over a million barrels a day less than now. Exploration is at a virtual standstill, while demand is increasing. All this is happening because of the low price of oil. We all enjoy paying as little as possible, but the old adage penny-wise and pound-foolish is most appropriate today.
A VIEW FROM THE STANDS: Of People, Politics, Military Power and the Arts. By John Kenneth Galbraith. Edited by Andrea D. Williams.

Gloriana By Benjamin Britten. Performed by the English National Opera. HBO/Cannon Video. 146 minutes. $39.95. The plight of Elizabeth and Essex is one of English history's larger tragedies, and its convolutions of personal love and political power have interested several opera composers.

Lorraine Johnson, chief of the currency verification division of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, and Peter Donaldson Prentis, an associate vice president for investments with Prudential Bache Securities in New York, plan to be married in February. The future bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wayne Johnson Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., who have announced her engagement to a son of Edmund A. Prentis 3d of Delray Beach, Fla., and Westhampton Beach, L.I., and Helen D. Grant of West Palm Beach, Fla.

THIS is the dawning of the age of the Aquarium in New Orleans. Plans for a $40 million aquarium and riverfront park in downtown New Orleans linking several major developments moved a step closer to reality Dec. 11 with the selection of a design team of 15 architectural and engineering concerns. The proposed 10-acre site of the aquarium, the financing for which was approved last month in a property-tax referendum, is along the river at the foot of historic Canal Street in the central business district. Construction is scheduled to begin late next year and be completed by the fall of 1989.

Football Jets vs. Bengals At Cincinnati, 1 P.M. Television Channel 4, 1 P.M. Radio WABC 770, 1 P.M. Eagles vs. Washington Redskins At Philadelphia, 1 P.M. Television Channel 2, 1 P.M. Dallas Cowboys vs.

IF you are a string player in search of an orchestra but do not like the idea of auditions, take heart. The Fairfield County Symphony Society welcomes you. Every Tuesday night the 50-member Norwalk-based group rehearses orchestral music at the United Congregational Church in Norwalk, under the leadership of the conductor, John Swartz. Occasionally, the players give free concerts for the elderly.

The Christmas season has a deep and joyous meaning for many in the Philippines, Asia's only predominantly Christian nation. Beginning Dec. 1, with the hanging of lanterns called parols, the celebration stretches well into January.

A National Notebook item Dec. 7 on an artist-in-residence program at the Regents Park apartment complex in Chicago misidentified the latest recipient of the fellowship. He is Tom Arndt, a photographer.

THE DREAM DREDGER by Roberta Silman. Persea Books. 223 pages. $14.95. Lisa Branson seems to have had a fortunate life : As the daughter of cultured parents who escaped Vienna before the arrival of the Nazis and moved to a pretty Hudson River town; as a gifted pianist and successful Vassar College graduate with a career as a biologist; as the wife of a brilliant scientist; and as the mother of an adult son and daughter. But when Lisa Branson dies under mysterious circumstances, her daughter recognizes the dark side - the death of a third child, the growing madness, and the efforts, which finally fail, to conceal her emotional state from her children.

REPRESENTATIVE Frank J. Guarini is likely to become New Jersey's sole representative on the powerful House Budget Committee when the 100th Congress convenes on Jan. 6. Mr. Guarini has been nominated to serve on the committee by Representative Dan Rostenkowski, Democrat of Illinois. Mr. Rostenkowski heads the House Ways and Means Committee and serves on the Democratic Steering and Policy Committee, which makes recommendations for committee assignments to the full Democratic caucus. The Steering Committee's recommendations are almost always approved.

Film buffs can savor an array of family nuggets at home this Christmas Eve. Wednesday afternoon repeats the sterling TV version of ''Little Lord Fauntleroy'' (1980) with Ricky Schroder and Alec Guinness - 1 P.M. on Channel 9. Then comes that golden showcase for young Judy Garland, ''Meet Me in St. Louis'' (1945) - 8 P.M. on Channel 5; and, as Santa approaches, the superb British version of Dickens' ''A Christmas Carol'' (1951) - 12 midnight., same station. At 2 A.M. there's a double flow of Jerome Kern, and Rodgers and Hart -the Astaire-Hayworth ''You Were Never Lovelier'' (1942) on Channel 9; and ''Words and Music'' (1948) on Channel 5.

To the Editor: Hats off to Ray Brady for his story ''Ireland's Zest for the Chase'' (Travel, Oct. 19). Age and economics have prevented my hunting with any of the famous packs he mentions, but I have been in the ''hill toppers'' parade more than once.

Samuel Ramey is a perfectly splendid singer, but to claim, as Jane Scovell does, that he ''has won the international stardom enjoyed by only two other basses in this century - Feodor Chaliapin and Ezio Pinza,'' is absurd, as I'm sure Mr. Ramey would be the first to acknowledge. The following short list of those I have heard at the Met over the years occurred to me as I was reading: Cesare Siepi, George London, Hans Hotter (all bass-baritones, like Ramey and Pinza), Emanuel List, Salvatore Baccaloni, Fernando Corena, Jerome Hines and Alexander Kipnis, perhaps the greatest of them all. MAURICE $:EE Cranbury, N.J.

THE PERPETUAL ORGY Flaubert and Madame Bovary. By Mario Vargas Llosa. Translated by Helen Lane. 240 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $17.95. What does Madame Bovary Look Like? We know that she has dark hair and eyes of a complicated color, but what of her nose, her chin? Does she tuck neatly into your shoulder? Are her ankles trim? How do you visualize the set of her shoulders? Of all the great fictional heroines, Emma is probably the one about whose appearance readers are most likely to disagree. We cannot, as with Dickens, refer to some foxed engraving in an early edition, since Flaubert hated and forbade illustrations of his works. Moviegoers might picture Emma as Jennifer Jones, but since this would entail Flaubert himself resembling James Mason, it doesn't take us very far. Mario Vargas Llosa fell deeply in love with Emma from the moment he first read ''Madame Bovary'' - in Paris in 1959 -and at the start of this unconventional, shiningly intelligent and fiercely sensible homage to Flaubert he recounts how ever since he has been in thrall to Emma's social rebelliousness, her erotic power, her vulgarity and her promise of violence. But at no point does he describe her physically. Is it possible to be in love with a woman and not know what she looks like? Or perhaps he is jealously guarding his image of her from the rest of us.
