EVERY home handyman knows that if he wants to cut a piece of wood he will need a carpenter's saw, and if he wants to cut metal he will pick up a hacksaw. But what does one use to cut a piece of ceramic tile, or a brick? Many will be surprised to learn that these materials can be easily cut at home with a hand saw or a power saw - as long as you have one of the special abrasive saw blades that are made for just such difficult-to-cut materials. Originally manufactured by only one company - the Remington Arms Company of Bridgeport, Conn., which is still the leading producer of these blades and sells them under the brand name of Grit Edge - abrasive blades of this type are now made by several other manufacturers. The principal difference between these blades and conventional saw blades is that these do not have cutting teeth in the usual sense. Instead of lots of little teeth that serve to chisel through or chip away the material being cut - saw teeth work like so many tiny little chisels - these blades have thousands of very sharp abrasive particles embedded along the cutting edge. The abrasive material is tungsten carbide, a manmade abrasive and one of the hardest materials known to man.

THERE was once a shoe company that sent its two best salesmen to a third-world country. After a day, the salesmen sent back separate telegrams. One said: ''Poverty everywhere. No one wears shoes. Situation hopeless.'' The second said: ''Poverty everywhere. No one wears shoes. Potential unlimited.''

Vice President Bush has acknowledged that because of the Iranian arms controversy he is ''no longer the front-runner'' in the race for the 1988 Republican Presidential nomination. But he said the suggestion that he and President Reagan are ''going to stay down is complete nonsense.'' ''The truth, when it comes out,'' will clear up any questions about the role he and President Reagan may have played in the arms transactions with Iran and the Nicaraguan rebels, he said in a nearly hourlong interview with reporters aboard Air Force Two on Friday as he returned from a speaking engagement in Iowa. Declines to Answer But while he called on two former National Security Council officials, Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter and Lieut Col. Oliver L. North, to ''tell the whole truth'' about the Iran arms controversy, he refused to answer certain key questions about his own role. ''I don't discuss inner workings of the White House,'' he said.

IN the new Center for Direct Marketing on the campus of New York University in Greenwich Village, a communications studio furnished with state-of-the-art audio-visual equipment bears the name of Wesley T. Wood of Laurel Hollow. ''N.Y.U. opened my eyes to the world,'' said the 43-year-old marketing expert, who made a substantial donation to the center as an expression of his gratitude. Mr. Wood, an N.Y.U. graduate who parlayed a $1,700 investment into financial success as a founder of Candlelite Music, which marketed millions of dollars in ''golden oldies'' recordings on television, is today the president of the Marketing Capital Corporation. The privately held concern, founded in 1972 by Mr. Wood and based in Cold Spring Harbor, provides direct marketing management and creative consulting services to companies eager to market their goods to consumers. And it acts as a venture capital company - investing start-up funds sought by companies or individuals developing new products, usually to be sold by direct mail.

According to the city's Department of Transportation, these will be among the most severe traffic trouble spots in the region today: * The Manhattan Bridge, where the Manhattan-bound upper roadway will be closed. The lower roadway will have three lanes open heading into Manhattan.

Because of a film distributor's change of plans, a picture caption on page 17 of the Arts and Leisure section today and a film listing in The Guide, section 2A, carry outdated theater information for ''The Morning After.'' It opens Thursday at the RKO National Twin, Gotham Cinema, Embassy 72d Street, Bay Cinema, 86th Street East and Waverly Twin.

Melinda Lugo, 4 years old, talking to Santa Claus yesterday at a party sponsored by the Community Relations Office. The gift to neighborhood children was at the 9th Precinct station house on East Fifth Street in Manhattan. Twenty performers from the Theater for the New City presented a pageant, and there were refreshments, toys and, of course, Santa, who took some time from his busiest week to drop in. (NYT/John Sotomayor)

There are people who take up going to concerts and listening to recordings with a singleness of purpose and fervor that would not have been out of place in the Children's Crusade. Rather often, these are authentic melomaniacs, amateur musicians or metamusicians whose whole beings tremble at the sound of music and want nothing more than to allow it to possess them, body and spirit. However, the ranks of the afflicted include many more whose plight is less explainable: people who took piano lessons as children and were quickly persuaded to give up, failed voice students or literary critics who have lost interest in books and turned to record connoisseurship as a substitute.

ON the Bingham estate overlooking the Ohio River outside Louisville, Ky., Barry Bingham Sr. and Barry Bingham Jr. live in houses separated by a short walk across a tended lawn. But each rarely crosses that short space to visit the other's home. ''It's like the green line in Beirut separating the Christians and the Moslems,'' said Joan Bingham, an in-law. The father and his only living son have barely spoken since Barry Sr. announced last Jan. 9 his decision to sell the family's media empire, including The Courier-Journal and The Louisville Times, the Pulitzer Prize-winning newspapers that had been in the family for nearly 70 years. Barry Jr., who had managed the enterprises for the last 15 years, denounced the sale as ''a betrayal'' and, almost overnight, the Binghams became a public archetype of a family destroyed in a struggle over business. The year since then has been a period of lingering bitterness, grief and unrepentance. Barry Jr. crossed the lawn on Thursday to bring Christmas presents to his parents, a gesture he described as ''correct.'' The whole family has not gathered for Christmas since 1983, and this year will be no exception.

KAREEM ABDUL-JABBAR, the 39-year-old Los Angeles center in his 18th National Basketball Association season, missed last night's game in Dallas and will not be able to play until at least Tuesday, the Lakers said yesterday, because of a painful cornea disorder. ''Apparently he's been poked in the eye so many times in his career that something like this is going to happen from time to time,'' said a team spokesman, Josh Rosenfeld.

FOR the first time since the Communists took power in China nearly four decades ago, opportunities are being created for foreign nationals living and working in its major cities to buy their own apartments or town houses. The Chinese have customarily been been reluctant to allow foreigners to occupy local housing (except in emergencies or by special permit), since it is in desperately short supply. In addition, it is usually deficient by Western standards. Until now, foreigners generally have either lived in hotel rooms that they used as offices or rented hotel-service apartments or suites attached to hotels on a short-term basis. Lately, a severe shortage of available space and an increasing demand by foreign businesses has driven rents up - a suite at one of the better Western-style hotels costs as much as $9,000 a month - and increased the pressure for alternatives. There are no controls on the prices foreigners can be charged for housing.

Nancy Ellen Marx, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Marx Jr. of Mamaroneck, N.Y., was married in New York last evening to James Marc Better, a son of Clifford Better of Los Angeles and the late Sandra Lee Better. Rabbi Leonard H. Poller performed the ceremony at the Pierre.

To the Editor: Representative Stephen J. Solarz said on television that he was ''perfectly comfortable'' with his view that everything points to the President of the United States in the Iran-contra matter.

There is new life bubbling beneath the barrenness of the American small town, a place that once embodied our rosiest ideals and has long since fallen on hard times. The sober plainness of middle-American existence is seldom represented as such any more; indeed, the town itself has become something of an anachronism, replaced in our imaginations by the suburb, the urban backwater or the family farm. What was once the center of both fond imaginings and satirical outrage - of Norman Rockwell's world and of Sinclair Lewis's Main Street - has grown more and more apt to be regarded, with sadness and pity, as a wasteland. Lately, though, something different has begun to color the ways in which small-town life is depicted. It's something encouraging, and something mischievous too. As Jonathan Demme's ''Something Wild'' presents it, and as such other new films as David Byrne's ''True Stories'' and David Lynch's ''Blue Velvet'' have suggested, it's the energy that bursts forth from what at first seems to be a moral and emotional vacuum, a vacuum so absolute that it holds forth a kind of promise. This life looks so lifeless, these films seem to say, that there must be huge reserves of energy and imagination hidden beneath it. And liberating the lost souls who are trapped there becomes an act of inspired subterfuge.

This Week: Time off for a Merry Christmas. Books, Books Last minute shoppers can often satisfy the gardener, who has everything, with a new book. Here are some recent highlights. The once private collection of Redoute's masterful paintings of the Lily Family have been reproduced in a remarkable volume, ''A Redoute Treasury'' with text by Peter and Frances Mallary (Vendome, $50). The original watercolors painted on vellum were sold at auction in 1985 for $5.5 million and this extraordinary book contains reproductions of 468 of them known to survive.

The Yankees and the Chicago White Sox are at it again. The teams that seem to be engaged in a ceaseless series of transactions have made another, a source familiar with the deal said yesterday. This one has Scott Nielsen, who led the Yankees in shutouts this year, and Mike Soper, an infielder, going to Chicago for Pete Filson, the American Association pitcher of the year.

On Jan. 5, three days after he returns from a week's vacation in California, President Reagan will undergo surgery to relieve ''discomfort'' caused by an enlarged prostate, the White House announced last week. The operation, a transurethral resection of the gland, is one of the most common performed in the United States; the 75-year-old Mr. Reagan had it once before, in 1967.

RAMBO and other so-called action toys are facing their toughest foes ever this year, and the battlegrounds are Connecticut's department stores and toy manufacturing plants. People who believe such toys encourage violence among children and who want to persuade consumers not to buy them have held several demonstrations in front of stores and toy companies in the last two months. One protester was arrested for blocking the entrance to a store and another was arrested for placing stickers on toys, advising shoppers not to buy them. Toy manufacturers say the protests have not hurt sales so far.

Nicaragua evidently decided last week that Eugene Hasenfus would do it more good in Washington than in jail. President Daniel Ortega Saavedra, announcing a Christmas ''gesture of peace,'' turned the captured American over to a visiting Senator, Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut.

At the Roman Catholic Church of the Presentation in Upper Saddle River, N.J., yesterday Sheila Anne Heffron, who is studying for an M.B.A. degree at Harvard University, was married to Michael Louis Rankowitz, a principal of the fixed income division at Morgan Stanley & Company in New York. Msgr. John McDermott performed the ceremony.

Several thousand Libyan troops, backed by Soviet-made tanks and warplanes, launched a major attack today in northern Chad in an effort to crush anti-Libyan resistance forces, United States officials said. In Ndjamena, Chad's capital, the Government radio said the Libyan offensive was being waged ''with incredible violence'' and it called for ''a general mobilization.'' The radio said the Libyan attack was principally directed against the Tibesti mountain towns of Bardai, Wour and Zouar, which have been occupied by Chadian forces that had rebelled against their former Libyan allies. U.S. Considers Its Response United States intelligence confirmed the Chadian account, officials said. Washington, they said, was coordinating its possible response with France, which has close military and political ties with its former colony. In Paris, a French military spokesman said French air units in Chad had been put on alert.

Following are answers to some recent questions from readers of the Personal Finance column. Q. I just quit my job to start my own business and have received about $50,000 in a lump-sum payment from my pension. I'm tempted to invest it in Australian bonds, which I hear are yielding 14 percent. Is that wise? Also, if I roll over the proceeds into an Individual Retirement Account within 60 days, I can defer paying tax on the distribution. Is it all right for me to use the earnings on the $50,000 during this two-month period to meet my operating expenses, rather than plowing them back into an I.R.A.? And because I'm considering using part of the money to buy an apartment, what would happen if I rolled over only part of the $50,000? A. Alexandra Armstrong, head of a Washington financial planning firm, takes a dim view of Australian bonds, no matter how appealing their yield. ''When you invest abroad in individual bonds, you have to think about not only the company issuing the bonds - and foreign accounting rules are not the same as ours - but also exchange rate fluctuations.'' If you're determined to invest abroad, Miss Armstrong suggests mutual funds, particularly the new Templeton Income Fund, which invests in debt securities of foreign governments. The fund carries an 8 1/2 percent sales charge.

AS the Christmas tree was going up last week in an atrium at the State Capitol, legislators and advocacy groups were preparing their wish lists for the 1987 session of the General Assembly. As usual, not everyone wanted the same thing. Although the session will not convene until Jan. 7, the clerk's offices of the State Senate and House of Representatives were receiving stacks of bills that lawmakers hoped would become new state laws next year. Many of the measures had a common theme - to reduce state taxes.

WHEN many states raised their legal drinking age to 21 a few years ago, business managers at campus publications began to worry that liquor and beer advertisements, which had long served as the financial backbone of college newspapers, might simply cease. In one sense, the fears were well-founded. ''Alcohol advertisers have pulled out, causing quite a void,'' said Mr. Bryant of American Passage. Seagram's, for example, once one of his firm's largest clients, has completely stopped advertising in college newspapers. ''They went from a seven-figure budget to zero,'' he said.

ALVIN AILEY has created stronger and more cohesive dances than ''Memoria,'' which the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater performed on Thursday at City Center, but the piece is certainly one of his most affecting. ''Memoria'' can be seen as a bittersweet elegy with a sudden burst of high spirits at the close. It also alludes in a vivid but poetically understated way to the life and personal qualities of Mr. Ailey's friend and colleague, the late Joyce Trisler.

Most of the lobbyists were graying and many were frail, but their combined musclepower swept all before them. Starting next Oct. 1, thanks to a bill passed by the New York State Legislature last week with no dissenting votes, New Yorkers 65 or older whose incomes fall below certain levels may charge to the state as much as 60 percent of their out-of-hospital prescription costs. The plan will be open to single people with gross annual incomes of less than $15,000, including Social Security benefits and pensions, and married couples with incomes of less than $20,000. Sliding scales, deductibles and annual fees within those categories will channel the greatest benefits to single people with incomes of $9,000 or less and married couples with incomes of $12,000 or less.

To the Editor: ''It is very strange, and very melancholy,'' said Samuel Johnson more than two centuries ago, ''that the paucity of human pleasures should persuade us ever to call hunting one of them.'' I find it very strange that so distinguished a journalist as Ray Brady continues to run happily ''After the Fox in Ireland,'' and more than melancholy that The Times elects to promote and glamorize this ''sport.''

To the Editor: Half the opinions in ''Show Me One Page in 'Anna Karenina' That Contains an Idea'' (Nov. 16) are dead on target. The only things bad in Bill Henderson's compilation of ''bad blurbs'' are the as sumptions (a) that critical judgments make any sense out of context and (b) that the general public, in its infinite wisdom, is always right. GERALD GUINNESS Northampton, Mass.

Times are tough at the United States Civil Rights Commission. Congress has cut its budget by $4.1 million, giving it $7.5 million for the current fiscal year as opposed to $11.6 million for last year. John H. Bunzel, a Democratic member of the commission whose term expired Dec. 5, has asked President Reagan not to reappoint him. He says the agency has lost its credibility and ''moral strength.''

Police officials here are investigating the possibility that a reported burglary that appeared to be linked to the clandestine transfer of American money to the Nicaraguan rebels was a hoax. Last week, Horace Dunbar, a lawyer whose office is in the San Jose suburb of Cupertino, told detectives that a file concerning one of his clients, Albert Hakim, had been stolen in a burglary at the office on Dec. 13. On Friday, he said the file had been returned to him under mysterious circumstances.

With Texas banks turning in the performances one would expect in the Texas economy, the Legislature acted this fall to allow their acquisition by out-of-state banks. Last week, the Chemical New York Corporation became the first to move in, announcing that it would buy Texas Commerce Bancshares Inc.

Flanders$242,000 86 Moony Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 19-year-old colonial; 3 brick fireplaces, family room; taxes $3,500. Hackensack$179,000 289 Parker Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 50-year-old Tudor; 1-car garage, landscaping; taxes $4,410.

The tenor Paul Sperry has been named director of Joy in Singing, an organization that helps young singers receive coaching and offers them a chance to perform professionally, with the added goal of furthering the art of the song recital. Mr. Sperry is a recitalist and a teacher of 19th- and 20th-century music at the Juilliard School and the Aspen Music Festival. As director of the organization, Mr. Sperry will hold biweekly master classes from January through May.

TALKING HIS WAY TO THE TOP THE FALL OF KELVIN WALKER A Fable of the Sixties. By Alasdair Gray. 144 pp. New York: George Braziller. $14.95. PEOPLE entrapped and grotesquely transformed by a civilization obsessed with power and bloodless abstractions hardly represent a recent condition. But finding a means suitable to present this is challenging to artists of any age precisely because the true horror and pain of most people's lives usually seem so routine, so natural. This is why many of the most compelling portrayals of civilization's deforming and alienating influences have been produced by eccentric visionaries - artists such as Hieronymus Bosch, William Blake or Franz Kafka, who break through the comfortable veil of what passes for realism to reveal realms of nightmarish intensity and uncomfortable familiarity.

The city's inspector general system, established by Mayor Koch in 1978 to prevent corruption and waste in government, will be overhauled to correct serious flaws disclosed in the municipal corruption scandal, city officials said yesterday. After months of debate within his administration, Mayor Koch said in an interview yesterday that he was convinced that changes were needed in the system of 28 inspectors general, who oversee activities in city agencies and several quasi-independent authorities. The central change will be that final control over the inspector general in each city agency will now be held solely by the city commissioner of investigation, who will set the salary, budget and agenda for the inspectors general. Inspectors general now report to both the commissioner of investigation and the commissioner of the agency they oversee, who controls their salary, budget and promotion.

Seven leaders of an unauthorized jazz society are in jail awaiting what their supporters contend will be a show trial intended to control cultural freedom. Originally organized as a legal jazz group, the society, with its 4,000 members, was officially disbanded when the Czechoslovak Government charged that it was engaging in activities that extended beyond the spread of jazz. But the society, initially known as the Jazz Section of the Musicians' Union, continued to operate unofficially, and its bulletin, with articles on art and cultural life abroad, was mimeographed and passed from hand to hand. Now, after three years of skirmishing, the Government is seeking to put a stop to the organization on what its members say is the pretext of engaging in illegal economic activity.

The Saudi Arabian Government has denied having had anything to do with the American arms sales to Iran. But that doesn't seem to square with the discovery by the F.B.I. of Saudi links to a suspect Swiss bank account that may have been used in the complicated transaction; and the denial is taken with a large grain of salt by some Middle East experts who are familiar with Saudi affairs and attitudes. They say it was only to be expected that Adnan Khashoggi, the Saudi arms peddler who helped arrange the U.S.-Iran deal, insisted to Barbara Walters on national television that the Saudis had not been involved. In their view, his statement provided only another layer of ''cover'' for a Saudi royal family that could have stopped but instead gave the green light to the arms sale.

Prime Minister Jacques Chirac won a bitter political test of strength with President Francois Mitterrand today. After a tumultuous session of Parliament lasting all night and most of today, Mr. Chirac, a neo-Gaullist, won enactment of a new law allowing more flexible working hours in French offices and factories. Mr. Mitterrand's Socialists had opposed the measure. The move was seen by political observers as an attempt by Mr. Chirac to regain some of the authority he lost this month when protesting students forced his Government to abandon a plan to change the educational system. Earlier this week, Mr. Mitterrand refused to allow the Prime Minister to enact the measure on working hours by administrative decree, saying it was socially regressive and must be voted on by Parliament. It was the third time the President had prevented the Government from enacting special legislation by witholding his signature since the two leaders began their power-sharing experiment seven months ago.

Mark Young, a sophomore quarterback and J. R. Ambrose, a junior flanker, set Independence Bowl passing and receiving records, but Mississippi needed Bryan Owen's tie-breaking 48-yard field goal early in the final period to defeat Texas Tech, 20-17, tonight. Young, who set records by completing 31 of his 50 passes for 343 yards, threw a third-quarter interception that let Texas Tech get back in the game.

IN Poland, the story of the Nativity is usually presented in the Pastoralka, or Shepherd's Play. Whether performed by small community groups or professional theater companies, the Pastoralka uses elements of medieval miracle plays and fuses them with a variety of traditional music. The Polish Theater Institute of New York has mounted a touring production of the Pastoralka created by the Polish director Leon Schiller, and will present it next Sunday at 1 P.M. at Haller Veterans Post in New Britain. As in commedia dell'arte, there are a number of stock characters who invariably show up in the Pastoralka, including Satan, Herod's wife (usually played by a man), a donkey, and, of course, angels. Within this framework, however, any number of theatrical and musical variations are possible.

GREG BERGAN, the man in charge, watched the shoppers filing through the jazzy angles of the Southdale Center, clutching their bulging shopping bags. From the outside, the three-level mall looked like a pile of blocks. Inside, however, everything was engineered to cause people to spend money. The spatial grandeur and the tranquillity acted as a balm to jerky nerves. Christmas ornaments festooned the central walkway, where squalling children were lined up to get their pictures snapped with Santa Claus. Shopping malls are fantasy cities in which no one lives but everyone buys. Southdale is 144 stores, 1.1 million square feet, 6,500 parking stalls, an indoor structure where the temperature is always 68 degrees - a climate-controlled, rigidly programmed selling machine. As Mr. Bergan roamed through Southdale, the hubbub registered as sales per square foot, a key ingredient of the rent formula. He looked at J.B. Hudson Jewelers, one of the prides of the mall, and saw $650 a foot. The jewelers, he pointed out, do best. Women's apparel stores, though, dominate the mall. Mr. Bergan grinned when he passed The Limited; it was doing better than $600 a foot.

THERE should be enough fur to keep many a body warm this winter, judging from the price and volume of sales at the fall fur auction in Bethel, Vt. When the bidding was done, trappers from around New England had sold 7,400 pelts and collectively pocketed $99,000, 400 pelts and $22,000 more than last year. Fishers were fetching up to $185 per pelt at the auction last week. A Massachusetts trapper sold 56 of them. More than 2,000 raccoon pelts sold for an average of $19.08; the nicest brought $42.50. The tally also included 300 minks, 444 red foxes, 80 gray foxes, 198 coyotes, 109 beavers and 27 otters, 4,053 muskrats and 5 bobcats.

IT HAS BEEN 16 years since my friend Sherley Koteen and I decided that a small dinner at home with close friends was a more compatible way to spend New Year's Eve than going to the splashiest party at a restaurant or club. Nothing in the intervening years has changed our minds. Or the minds of our regulars, several of whom have been guests at our black-tie dinners in Washington since 1970. Looking back over those menus recently, I was struck with the story they told about our changing tastes. Not only how much simpler the meals have become, but how the lines have been blurred between culinary styles. Pure French food has virtually disappeared; rich sauces have been replaced by spices. Our New Year's Eve dinners are a microcosm of the evolution in American dining, though from time to time my co-host puts her foot down at what she considers my avant-garde ideas. When I suggested that this year we serve diner food - meatloaf and mashed potatoes - she suggested that I had taken leave of my senses. It was hardly a suggestion I would have made, even in jest, in the early 1970's, a time when a formal meal was incomplete without beef and six courses.

To the Editor: Most surprising in ''Pick a Card, Any Card, Every Card'' (Nov. 30) was your view that American Express was ''imperiling its traditional snob-appeal'' because of its warranty extension program. While tarnishing the Amex image is always a possibility if the card becomes positioned more for refrigerators than resorts, I believe the warranty extension program will have the opposite effect.
Jennifer Drew Beal and Clyde Cebron Tuggle, second-year students at the Yale Divinity School, were married yesterday at Trinity Episcopal Church in Concord, Mass.

A decade ago, when Omus Hirshbein was in his third season as director of the 92d Street Y's performing arts program, he decided to present Bach's six Brandenburg Concertos as a festive holiday concert. For the occasion, he engaged Gerard Schwarz - then the New York Philharmonic's principal trumpeter and a sometime conductor -who assembled and led a freelance orchestra, and played the second concerto's solo trumpet part in the bargain. As Mr. Schwarz and company played, Mr. Hirshbein wondered whether he could persuade the Y's board to sponsor a resident chamber orchestra. At intermission, he hinted to a few reviewers that the Brandenburg concert was something of a trial run for a planned series; and the critics, delighted with the performance, carried Mr. Hirshbein's notion to the Y's board by reporting that a new ensemble of this group's caliber would be a valuable addition to the city's musical life. Within a week, Messrs. Hirshbein and Schwarz had mapped out the five-concert series that became the inaugural season of the Y Chamber Symphony. Since then, the orchestra, with Mr. Schwarz at its helm, has become one of this city's musical success stories. It plays nearly 40 concerts a season, including subscription programs, a Baroque series, children's concerts, a series of lecture concerts called ''Musically Speaking'' and a few out-of-town performances.

DEAR SIR: We regret to inform you that the person you address no longer does business at this location. His establishment failed some years ago due to unsound business practices and such total managerial indifference to the bottom line that the operation more nearly approximated a philanthropy than a growth enterprise. To avoid catastrophe, the owner filed for bankruptcy protection under Chapter 11. His business, at that time confined largely to the manufacture and delivery of toys, was acquired by Boozu Playthings of North America and reorganized as a division of Boozu, doing business as the S. Claus Company Inc.

Extracurricular activities and good grades tend to go together for high school students, a Government study has found. The study by the Department of Education's Center for Statistics drew on a survey of 30,000 high school sophomores and 28,000 seniors taken in 1980, along with additional information about the sophomores that was gathered two years later. ''The more activities students were involved in, the higher they ranked'' on such measures as grades and test scores, the center said in a newsletter published Thursday. These students also tended to take more academic courses.

President Reagan said today that the American family was ''under virtual attack'' and people should not take society's basic social unit for granted amid the holiday rush. ''All our lives, it is the love of our family that sustains us when times are hard,'' Mr. Reagan said in his weekly radio address.

A SEASON OF INQUIRY The Senate Intelligence Investigation. By Loch K. Johnson. Illustrated. 317 pp. Lexington: The University Press of Kentucky. $31. PRESIDENTS' SECRET WARS CIA and Pentagon Covert Operations Since World War II. By John Prados. 480 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $22.95. THERE is nothing that can damage a reputation - or a Presidency - like a secret war. And now Ronald Reagan has his.

A COMPLETE, vintage wardrobe by Coco Chanel for $3.95? A sampling of haute couture from the 50's by Dior, Balenciaga and Charles James for the same low, low price? They are actually available, if not precisely wearable, in a series of full-color fashion paper doll books created by a former fashion illustrator, Tom Tierney. Each of the $3.95 volumes, now in most bookstores through Dover Publications, is a book of 32 stiff pages, printed on only one side. The books are so satisfying and inexpensive, one might want to buy pairs - for cutting and keeping.

To the Editor: Driving home to Massachusetts after a short stay in Washington, I noticed truckloads of evergreen trees en route to places along the East Coast. It brought to mind our traditional family celebration of Christmas, when we hike into the woods to decorate a young evergreen.

A 15-year-old Madison High School sophomore has been charged with setting one fire and is a suspect in seven more. The teen-ager, Toby Thibeault, was arrested Dec. 12 and on Monday was ordered confined tot he Maine Youth Center in South Portland until a trial Feb. 2.

GANDHI TO PAINE Officials of the Thomas Paine National Historical Association in New Rochelle were surprised recently to receive a phone call from Sir Richard Attenborough, British producer of the film ''Gandhi.'' A great admirer of Paine, Sir Richard is working on the production of a film about the Revolutionary American writer and wanted to establish a connection with the association for research purposes. The association, situated on property containing Paine's tiny cottage at 983 North Avenue, has parlayed the relationship into a fund-raising dinner honoring Paine's 250th birthday Jan. 29. Sir Richard will be the speaker.

IF one had to sum up 1986 in personal computing, one would probably call it the ''Year of the Clone.'' In countless businesses throughout the land, the old motto ''You can't be faulted for buying I.B.M.'' has been displaced by ''I saved the company a bundle by buying (fill in the blank) personal computers.'' I would not say that the International Business Machines Corporation is about to roll over and pull a Peanut on its PC line. Its personal computers, after all, are what transformed Big Blue's logo from a corporate icon to a household name.

The Bonus Payoff Here's a thought for the bonus season: According to F. Thomas Juster, professor of economics at the University of Michigan, fewer than 10 percent of American companies give bonuses. If more did, he says, it would give the nation's savings rate - and thus the economy - a lift, as more money would be available for business investment. People tend to save, not spend, lump-sum payments, if they are large enough, says Mr. Juster. In Japan, where the savings rate is high - about 15 percent of the gross national product, compared with about 3.1 percent in the United States - workers get most of their annual income in the form of bonuses.

The plight of those with AIDS is often cited by contributors to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. Steven Seifert of Manhattan gave $100 and requested that, ''if at all possible,'' it be given ''to one of the truly neediest cases - a person with AIDS whose traumatic experience with the disease has forced him into hardship.'' From Philadelphia, Andrew E. Behrendt sent $25, saying, ''I am concerned that this year not enough support services are being provided to persons with AIDS.''

Ending a five-year legal dispute, Donald J. Trump and tenants of a Central Park South building announced yesterday that they had reached an agreement allowing the developer to renovate the structure he once wanted to demolish. A 30-page contract, formalizing details of a tentative agreement last March, was signed last Thursday by Mr. Trump, the 40-member 100 Central Park South Tenants' Association and William B. Eimicke, Commissioner of the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal.

ARCHITECT-DESIGNED houses, usually associated with people who get around in yachts and limousines, have in recent years become competitive housing alternatives for less well-traveled home buyers. One reason is that home prices in parts of metropolitan New York have risen faster than the prices that the careful consumer needs to pay for land and custom-home construction. Building a house, though, is rarely in the realm of alternatives for most home buyers who are not familiar with the process of assembling land, lender, builder and architect. The following profiles of three home-building projects provide an anecdotal guide to some different ways of dealing with the financial, construction and design challenges.

The Reagan Administration has exaggerated the Soviet Union's ability to invade Iran, according to a study made public this week by a Washington-based research group. The report, by a research associate at the Brookings Institution, asserts that Soviet forces would find it difficult to conduct a full-scale invasion of Iran because some of the terrain is difficult to cross and the Iranian transportation system is limited and vulnerable to attack. ''A Soviet invasion of Iran would be an exceedingly low-confidence affair,'' said Joshua M. Epstein, a research associate at Brookings, who wrote the study. ''That is a fact they have known for roughly 40 years.''

I AM an addict, but it is not heroin, cocaine or alcohol that I'm hooked on: It's the mall. To paraphrase A. A.'s introductory greeting, ''My name is Caren, and I'm a mall-aholic.'' Whenever life becomes oppressively mundane, a dose of the Stamford Town Center, or simply ''the mall,'' makes me high.

It may not save New Yorkers much on their utility bills, but a ruling by the state's highest court last week may have calmed the pulses of a few wrought-up ratepayers. The Court of Appeals declared it unconstitutional for state-regulated utilities to contribute their customers' money to charity.

The marriage of Heather Helen Evans, senior vice president of CSB Holdings Inc., a financial services concern in New York, to Matthew Clay Baumgardner, an artist, took place yesterday at The Restaurant in Manhattan. The Rev. Terry Manahan, an independent Baptist minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony.

BEGINNING in January, corporations will be able to own cooperative apartments without endangering the tenant-shareholders' special tax status, a change that raises a host of new issues for co-op boards and their shareholders. In the past, the Internal Revenue Service has held that maintenance income from units owned by corporations was commercial, as opposed to shareholder, revenue. Under the I.R.S.'s ''80-20'' rule, no more than 20 percent of a co-op's total revenue can be derived from commercial sources or it will lose its special tax status, under which tenant-shareholders are allowed the traditional tax advantages of home ownership. These are deductibility of their proportionate share of the building's mortgage interest and property tax and deferral of the profits from the sale of the apartment.
An article about the technology of down-filled clothing in The Week in Review Nov. 30 incorrectly defined a micron, a unit of measure. It is one-millionth of a meter.

IN his novel ''Roger's Version,'' John Updike pits a skeptical theologian, desperately clinging to the distant God of Karl Barth, against a conservative and naive divinity student in a fierce debate over whether the existence of God can be proved. As I sit at my desk, looking at a slender volume entitled ''Jesus and the Word'' (1926) by the skeptical and sometimes Barthian Rudolf Bultmann, and the much larger and more confident ''Jesus and Judaism'' (1985) by E. P. Sanders, I wonder whether the 20th century has not witnessed a similar debate over the historical Jesus. The comparison is not quite apt. Mr. Sanders, neither conservative nor naive, does not represent the antithesis to Bultmann; that role belongs to the exegetical acrobats of an earlier generation, conservative Protestants and Roman Catholics who wrote lives of Jesus that desperately sought to harmonize the discordant testimony of the four Gospels. The Catholic lives seem especially poignant today, since often they were the result of official pressure. Many of their authors knew better, but they were subjected to censorship and silencing by the Vatican. Mr. Sanders' book, by contrast, is an honest attempt to avoid both the minimalism of a Bultmann and the uncritical acceptance of the Gospels by fundamentalists who treat them like videotape replays.

CHRISTMAS WONDERLAND Mervin Whipple's Christmas Wonderland contains 143 animated figures. Begun 18 years ago as a labor of love and a change from his work as a cemetery superintendent, the collection of Santas, elves, reindeer, and all manner of motorized figures has cost him about $150,000. Each Christmas, his friends in the Ballouville section of Killingly help Mr. Whipple haul his collection of figures out of storage and set them up for public exhibition in scenic vignettes of Santa waking up on the day of Christmas Eve; Christmas in picturesque, old Bavaria; medieval monks celebrating the birth of Christ; the saga of Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer, a family of beavers industriously preparing for the holidays, and so on. ''I made some of them myself,'' Mr. Whipple, 58 years old, said. ''Others I purchased from manufacturers who make the window displays for Saks Fifth Avenue and Lord & Taylor. I started with three figures the first year, now we spend eight weeks setting up for a display that lasts four weeks. Last year we had 29,094 people come to see it from 29 states and 12 countries.'' There is no admission charge.

To the Editor: In ''Iran 1: What Needs to Be Known'' (editorial, Dec. 14) you state as fact, in connection with arms sales to Iran, that Oliver North ''used the profits, deposited in a C.I.A. Swiss bank account, to purchase arms for the contra rebels in Nicaragua.'' The statement is false.

Every now and then, in a moment of uncommon quiet, the distinctive wail of a rural love song rises from some unseen corner of Bangkok, and the urge to get out of town becomes overwhelming. The sound of upcountry music, the rare scent of fresh earth or flowers, or the sight of hill tribe people in traditional dress squatting in front of a video shop are reminders that beyond this polluted, traffic-clogged city, there is another Thailand. It can be found in almost any direction: north to the cool mountains, south along an endless seacoast, west into peaceful river valleys, northeast into the majestic world of the Mekong. Although the number of tourists traveling beyond Bangkok from Japan, Hong Kong and Europe is increasing, this is a country that is mostly still off the tourist track, while easily manageable for independent travelers. Visitors willing to put up with some fairly basic hotels and eating places enjoy in return remarkably varied scenery and the atmosphere of a nation reflecting Sinetic, Indic and Malay cultures, yet always very Thai. That means Thai (or Chinese-Thai) food in every town, and the ubiquitous enthusiasm with which Thais try to please visitors.

SUPPOSE, just suppose, that Santa leaves a new camera under your tree this week. What is the first thing you should do, besides give your personal Santa a thank-you kiss? The first thing, of course, is to open the box - but gingerly, so as not to drop its contents or damage the box, which will come in handy if the camera is returned or sent for repairs. In the typical camera package, a shallow tray or depression on the top block of Styrofoam holds an instruction book, a warranty card (unless, heaven forfend, this is a gray-market camera) and the battery for the camera's meter, shutter, shutter release and who knows what else.

Last week The Times asked readers to respond to this question. The Times also made a special request to Jerry Girard, the WPIX broadcaster, to provide his wish list. Dear Santa I speak for the truly needy, those you may have missed only because of your hectic schedule. So, here is my Christmas gift list: For the Knicks, a new schedule without the two places that give them the most trouble - home and away.
The wedding of Sarah Flanagan to George William Arguelles took place yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Richard Stearns performed the ceremony.

The Christmas season is slipping into high gear in Puerto Rico and for many the party will not stop until mid-January. There are religious observances, of course, but the triumph of consumerism shows the increasingly secular grip on the holidays in San Juan, the capital. The Plaza de las Americas in the Hato Rey section, described as the most successful shopping center in the Caribbean, is thronged with shoppers all week, as usual at this time of year, and now on Sundays, too, since a ban on Sunday shopping was ended over the protests of religious groups. Consumer debt is reported up 53 percent on an island whose three million residents have a negative rate of personal savings and where 6 out of 10 people qualify for food stamps.

THE parking lot of the local train station is something of a La Brea Tar Pits for fossil cars - littered with rows and rows of jalopies and old relics, formerly splendid coupes and heroic hot rods. The ''station car'' is a sorry creature, a truly persecuted vehicle. Bruised and scratched and kicked around, it is like a poor old nag that should have been put out to pasture ages ago but must continue to labor for the sole purpose of shuttling communters to and from the train station each day. It is well past its prime - beauty and paint long since faded, muffler now sagging, body speckled with rust spots that come with age. It is an object of ridicule, carefully camouflaged in the evening (covered with twigs and branches and leaves) because it is such an eyesore in the driveway. Indeed, the status of the station car lies rather shakily near the bottom of the spectrum, where it perhaps outshines only that most ominous roadster driven by ''the new teen-age driver.''

On her 76th birthday Katherine O'Connor received dozens of phone calls from children saying that they loved her. And not a single child knew who she really was. ''Ho, ho, ho,'' Mrs. O'Connor said in a thick Irish accent to each caller. ''This is Mrs. Santa Claus. Who am I talking to? What do you want Santa to bring you for Christmas?''

Jean-Bedel Bokassa sat in a hard-backed wooden chair today and squirmed under hard questioning from a judge. Witnesses were lying, said Mr. Bokassa, who was once His Imperial Majesty Bokassa I, Emperor of the Cradle of the Bantus. The former Emperor, in mumbled replies that were broadcast live over the national radio, assured the court that contrary to other testimony, the Cabinet minister who had been chained in a windowless cell was to be fed more than ''a piece of meat and half a glass of water a day.'' For Africa, where human rights violators rarely face their victims in a court, the public trial of Mr. Bokassa in a civilian court sets a precedent. For the leadership of this landlocked country, allowing the deposed Emperor to address the nation in daily live broadcasts represents a bold political gamble.

State legislators, unable to decide how to deal with fiscal trouble caused by the depression in the oil industry, went home today after giving Gov. Edwin W. Edwards authority to cut the state budget. After 16 days of debate on how to deal with a $188 million deficit, the Legislature voted Friday night to let Mr. Edwards cut up to $275 million in any spending anywhere he wanted. ''This is the only way out,'' State Senator Don Kelly, a Democrat, said as a deadline for adjournment of the special session neared.
THE EARTH ABIDETH. By George Dell. (Ohio State University, $14.95.) ''The Earth Abideth'' is a novel both of and from another time.

The Dec. 7 article ''Shortage of Social Workers?'' glossed over economic factors that would preclude college students from entering social work. The altruistic values of the 1960's, when it was far more affordable to live on Long Island, have been replaced by the cold reality that Long Island is the most expensive region of the country in which to live.
A correction in this space on Dec. 7, about Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan's background, misstated his activities from 1969 to 1973.

TO the three Communist nations of Indochina, it has been a season for candid introspection and leadership change. Such ''renewals'' are a trademark of ruling Communist parties from Moscow to Havana, a reflection of the difficulty of motivating societies with a centralized economy and an ideology that for the most part admits no heresy. For Vietnam, Cambodia and Laos, the problem is greatly exacerbated by severe economic hardships. At party congresses in Hanoi last week and in Laos last month, there was an extraordinary outpouring of self-criticism, expressed in usual catchwords such as ''shortcomings,'' ''serious mistakes,'' ''selfishness,'' ''laziness'' and ''corruption.'' Cambodia, too, has acknowledged its troubles, reshuffling its leadership in the last several weeks.

A Feb. 7 wedding is planned by Dorita Hammond and James Sheehy Normile, the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. B. Clinton Hammond of Garden City and Westhampton Beach, L.I., have announced. Mr. Normile is a son of Margaret Sheehy Normile of Hampton Bays, L.I., and Clearwater, Fla., and the late Daniel Francis Normile. Miss Hammond, who is known as Dore, graduated from the Cushing Academy and Boston University.

Mr. and Mrs. Sanford F. Grill of Riverdale, the Bronx, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Fern Tracy Grill, to Dr. Richard Samuel Gold, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Gold of Plainview, L.I. Ms. Grill, a third-year student at the Pace University School of Law, graduated from the Horace Mann School and Clark University. Her father is president of the Ross-Viking Corporation in Melville, L.I., a distributor of General Electric lamps and products.
A GIRL, it seems, is never too young for a fur coat.

THE China News, a Taipei newspaper, published a long editorial this month with a stark headline lamenting the ''Worrisome Financial Situation.'' It captured the concern throughout the island over Taiwan's grave economic distress. The problem? Taiwan's economy is mired in success, generating so much wealth from exports - mostly to America - that no one knows what to do with the cash. That is creating financial and political difficulties that might seem humorous from afar but that are taken very seriously here. So seriously that the Government is loosening its strict currency controls to allow the private sector access to some of its foreign-cash hoard. The nation's huge foreign-exchange reserves, accumulating at a rate of more than $1 billion a month, are at the center of the Worrisome Financial Situation.

Governor Cuomo, responding to widespread confusion over the new Federal immigration law, has formed a special panel to inform New Yorkers about the legislation and protect them from discrimination. The panel, according to its chairman, will develop safeguards against potential discrimination, evaluate how state agencies respond to the changes and prepare a plan within 90 days to inform New York residents and businesses of the law's provisions. ''We need to make sure that in carrying out the legislation, we protect all affected individuals from possible discrimination in both private and public sectors,'' the Governor said in announcing the creation of the panel last week.

Gov. Michael S. Dukakis on Thursday signed a tougher new drunken driving law that includes a provision allowing some licenses to be suspended without trial. ''This law will help insure that families stay intact, and it will insure that we move swiftly against drivers who have tragically shattered the lives of so many men, women and children in this commonwealth,'' Mr. Dukakis said.

Increase Upon Increase Question: When the two-year lease expires on my rent-stabilized apartment, not only will the rent be raised by the percentage allowed by law, but also a further surcharge will be added because the rent is less than $400 a month. Is this surcharge allowed? . . . F. K., Flushing, Queens Answer: In your case it may not be. Eric Weinstock, a spokesman for the Rent Guidelines Board, said such an increase is not a surcharge but a supplementary adjustment and it was approved by the board's Order 18. That order allows landlords of apartments that rent for less than $350 a month to raise the rent up to $15 a month beyond the guideline increase upon renewal of any lease that expires between last Oct. 1 and Sept. 30, 1987. If your current rent is more than $350, the adjustment is not allowable and you should point this out to your landlord. Even if it is less than $350, your landlord may not be eligible to collect the full $15 because the new rent, including the adjustment, may not exceed $371 for a one-year renewal lease or $381.50 for a two-year renewal.

LEONARD GORDON recently spotted an artistic rendering of Dizzie Gillespie that transfixed him. It looked like a photograph, but it had certain uncanny, eye-catching qualities that photography cannot produce. Remarkably, it existed in three dimensions, with Mr. Gillespie's bloated cheeks and upturned trumpet hovering in midair. And even more surprising, when Mr. Gordon side-stepped to view the image from another angle, it changed. The trumpeter now held his instrument away from his mouth, his cheeks were deflated, and a wide smile swept his face. ''Astonishing,'' Mr. Gordon blurted. ''I don't understand the technology, but the final product is amazing.''

When hundreds of elderly people confronted Governor Cuomo outside his office the other day demanding a new state plan to subsidize the cost of their prescription drugs, the angry voice of one elderly Brooklyn man shouted above the others: ''Governor, don't you go to New Hampshire! We want you here with us now!'' At dinner here this week, a top New York City transit official was asked whether Mr. Cuomo and key lawmakers would reach an agreement to freeze fares through 1989. ''I don't know about 1989,'' the official said. ''But I think the Governor will see to it through November of 1988.''

HUSTLE and bustle are integral components of New York's charm. The throngs surging out of the subways each morning in midtown Manhattan attest to the city's vitality, as do the crowds that pour into the South Street Seaport at lunchtime and the holiday shoppers who filled Fifth Avenue and Herald Square last week. In recent years, though, some New Yorkers have begun to wonder if they might have too much of a good thing. At the most congested intersection on Fifth Avenue, at 47th Street, as many as 12,000 pedestrians pass in an hour, according to a 1982 study by the City Planning Department. By comparison, the study said, people walk through the busiest intersections of large cities such as Chicago and Toronto at a rate of 4,000 to 6,000 an hour. And the peak sidewalk volume on the main downtown thoroughfares of San Francisco and Seattle - 1,500 to 3,000 people an hour - is roughly equal to that on many side streets in Manhattan.

The end came quickly for Randa Marie Lago, a 15-year-old high school sophomore from Mystic who today became the first girl to wrestle on a boys team in Connecticut. Miss Lago's first match - against Kenneth D. Plouffe, a 16-year-old junior from Coventry, R.I. - was over in seconds when Mr. Plouffe threw her to the mat and, after a moment or two of tangled limbs and taut muscles, pinned her shoulders. But Mr. Plouffe, who last year placed second in a 32-state regional competition in his 98-pound weight class, praised his opponent, who many officials believe to be the first girl to wrestle on a boys team in New England. 'She's Really Good' ''She's really good, she knows the moves,'' he said, ''I think she should have the right to wrestle. She'll do really well.''

In an operation involving virtually every agent in the criminal division of the New York branch of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, a group of 41 juveniles was rounded up recently and brought to the F.B.I.'s offices in lower Manhattan. The juveniles, escorted by armed agents, were photographed and fingerprinted. Then they were showered with gifts and affection at a lavish Christmas party.

Of all of the great pre-rock songwriters, none wrote lyrics that speak more directly to the emotions than Lorenz Hart who was born in 1895 and died at the early age of 48. ''The Complete Lyrics of Lorenz Hart,'' a glorious new book, edited by the lyricist's sister-in-law Dorothy Hart, with Robert Kimball and published by Alfred A. Knopf, collects 650 of his song lyrics, 300 of them never before published. The appearance of the book has inspired two different cabaret shows in Manhattan. At Michael's Pub, 211 East 55th Street, the club's ongoing ''All Hart'' tribute will continue through the end of the year with the singer-author-raconteur-disc jockey Jonathan Schwartz serving as host and jazz-singer Mark Murphy, the special guest.

THE JOURNAL OF NICHOLAS THE AMERICAN. By Leigh Kennedy. (Atlantic Monthly, $16.95.) This story of a first-generation Russian-American is anything but what one expects, and therein lies much of its appeal.

Additional titles of interest: THE MIRACLE TREE. By Christobel Mattingley. Illustrated by Marianne Yamaguchi. Gulliver/ Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $11.95. (Ages 5 and up) An unusual Christmas story written by a popular Australian writer.

For several years now, those of us who have been devoted to remembering the Holocaust have focused our attention on the revisionist movement of pseudo-scholars and neo-Nazis who deny that the Holocaust ever happened (''Erasing the Past,'' by Judith Miller, Nov. 16). Ms. Miller correctly reminded us of the more widespread and much more dangerous - even if not more pernicious - phenomenon of amnesia, the self-willed forgetfulness and the desire to silence painful memories. BENJAMIN MEED President American Gathering/ Federation of Jewish Holocaust Survivors New York City

William J. Casey, Driector of Central Intelligence, remained in stable condition today, recovering from removal of a tumor from his brain, a spokesman for Georgetown University Hospital said. The spokesman said Mr. Casey's doctors believed his ''postoperative recovery is progressing satisfactorily'' after the surgery Thursday. The hospital said no further medical statement on the 73-year-old Mr. Casey was planned before Monday unless his condition changed.

WINFIELD'S, a new contemporary American restaurant in Glen Cove, is one to watch. The food is stylish and inventive and, while the cooking is not without flaws, it is on the right track. As long as the complete dinner for the bargain $21.50 price continues to be offered, it certainly merits a get-acquainted visit. And after that you may return just because the menu is worth exploring for the often unpredictable turns it takes.

At Temple Emanuel of the Pascack Valley in Woodcliff Lake, N.J., last night Ellen Fern Ruzinsky, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin H. Ruzinsky of Old Tappan, N.J., was married to Evan Jay Lerner, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Larry Lerner of Englewood Cliffs and White Meadow Lake, N.J. Rabbi Andre Ungar, assisted by Cantor Mark Biddelman, performed the ceremony. Wendy Goldman, the sister of the bridegroom, was matron of honor, and Bruce Jay Ruzinsky, the brother of the bride, was best man.

RALPH NADER is outraged. Dr. Arthur Maass, a professor emeritus of government at Harvard University, maintains that it is a good idea. Mark Russell, the comedian, thinks it is a joke. Those three observers of the bureaucracy and others addressed a special commission's proposal, presented to President Reagan last week, to increase the salaries of members of Congress, Federal judges and high officials of the executive branch, in some cases by more than 80 percent. Under the new pay scale 3,037 top Federal officials would receive salaries of more than $100,000. Except for the President, whose $200,000 salary is set by special Federal law, only the Vice President, the Speaker of the House and the Chief Justice earn that much now. (Their salaries are $100,800, $100,800 and $111,700 respectively; under the proposal each would earn $175,000.) The $135,000 recommended for members of Congress, who would otherwise get $77,400 next year, pales in comparison to the estimated $1.9 million a year in salary, bonuses, cost-of-living adjustments and deferred payments received by Dave Winfield, the Yankee slugger.

Dan Blaszczuk has spent the better part of the last year trying to dispel the notion that life on an island off the coast of Maine is idyllic. It's not that he thinks living in Frenchboro on Outer Long Island, seven and a half miles from the mainland, is anything less than glorious. It's just that he wants people to be realistic, for Mr. Blaszczuk is not a travel agent trying to book tours to Frenchboro. He is looking for permanent residents. The population of this quaint fishing village has been dwindling since 1910, when 197 people lived here. The two World Wars showed soldiers there was more to life than isolation and fishing for lobster, and many chose to live elsewhere.

VISITING THE ART MUSEUM Written and illustrated by Laurene Krasny Brown and Marc Brown. 32 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $11.95. (Ages 3 to 8) THOUGH children and art museums are fairly incompatible, they should, I suppose, occasionally be exposed to each other. Such exposure is the theme of ''Visiting the Art Museum,'' which portrays a family trip to an institution that suggests both the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Museum of Modern Art in New York City.

At least one resident died tonight when a fast-spreading fire broke out in a three-story motel and firefighters were unable to get into much of the building, the authorities said. ''It's an old hotel and they don't know how many people are in there,'' a city police spokesman, Officer Diana Urban, said. The blaze in the Bayview Motel, a block from the waterfront, was still burning out of control two hours after the first alarm at 9:21 P.M. ''We can't make entry into the third floor,'' said a fire dispatcher who would not be identified.

''The Spiritual in Art: Abstract Painting 1890-1985'' surveys a great adventure. At a time when a new generation of abstract artists experiences the grids of Mondrian not as spiritual threshholds but as prison bars, the exhibition reminds us what was at stake when a handful of artists in different parts of Europe first painted without reference to the external world. It helps us measure the leap they made and understand the doubt - and assurance - that was required to make it. The exhibition inaugurates the Robert O. Anderson Building of the Los Angeles County Museum of Art and suggests the path this expanding museum hopes to pursue. It wants to be inclusive. It is concerned with East and West, with East Coast and West Coast, with modern and anti-modern, and it is looking for subjects, like this one, that will make bridges possible. ''The Spiritual in Art'' is also a direct challenge to the picture of modernism that has been painted by the Museum of Modern Art. This large show pays almost no attention to the Cezanne-Picasso-Matisse axis around which much of the permanent installation of the Modern now revolves. It has little or no interest in art-historial questions of who came first, or who influenced whom.

TODAY, President Reagan and Jimmy Carter might find it difficult to recognize Charlotte Street, where each made a campaign stop and pledged to do something about the deterioration exemplified by the blighted Bronx thoroughfare's abandoned tenements and littered lots. Now, more than a decade after the first Presidential campaign visit - and promises that fell victim to budget cuts - local citizens have taken redevelopment into their own hands and a transformation is taking shape. Charlotte Street, abloom with ranch houses, looks like a suburban tract under construction. ''We're coming up with plans that make things work instead of doing tours and showing foreigners the worst urban blight in the country,'' said Genevieve Brooks, director of MBD Community Housing Corporation, one of the groups working to rehabilitate the Charlotte Street area.

Boston College had Georgia Tech on the ropes, but Bruce Dalrymple and Duane Ferrell would not let the Yellow Jackets lose. Dalrymple led a pair of comebacks and Ferrell broke a 59-59 tie in overtime with two baskets as Georgia Tech (4-2) beat the Eagles, 65-62, today at the Suntory Ball tournament. The two teams finished regulation tied at 55-55 and were even at 59-59 with 2 minutes 40 seconds left before Ferrell took over, hitting twice while Tech's defense shut down the Eagles.

The standard form of housing in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn is still the two- or three-family house in which the owner occupies one floor and rents out the rest. But large down payments, landlord responsibilities and maintenance of such housing have made condominiums an appealing alternative.

Mr. and Mrs. Harold Grabino of New York and Orange, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amy Maude Grabino, to James Kenneth Landau, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Burton Landau of Rydal, Pa. Miss Grabino, an associate at the New York law firm Rosenman Colin Freund Lewis & Cohen, and Mr. Landau, an associate at the law firm Rubin, Glickman & Steinberg in Lansdale, Pa., plan to be married in May.

DURING THE 10-YEAR period (1966-76) known as The Great Proletarian Cultural Revolution, education in China came to a standstill. Schools closed down, teachers were persecuted and students made revolution in the streets. In the last decade, with the death of Chairman Mao Zedong and the ascension to power of Deng Xiaoping, much of the madness has subsided. On the educational front, schools are open again, teachers command respect, students struggle to pass the college entrance examinations. And as part of Deng's policy of pursuing modernization and ''opening up'' China to the West, foreign teachers have been allowed to live and work there. From August 1982 to July 1984, I was one of them.

Tours in India Question:Where can I find out about moderately priced tours of India that include cities and sightseeing? - E. S., Washington Answer:A budget traveler's 16-day tour to four Indian cities for a basic $1,895 is offered by Flag Tours (38 West 38th Street, New York, N.Y. 10018; 212-921-3366 or, out of state, 800-223-8889). The price, which is a person, double occupancy, includes air fare from New York to Bombay and back from Delhi, flights within India, hotels and sightseeing but excludes meals, which cost another $140. From June through August and in December there is an air-fare supplement of $107. The tour also goes to Jaipur and Agra.

What began as a civilized discourse in the 18th century and became a vehicle for Romantic individuality in the 19th has taken on a political tone in our own age. Our subject is, of course, the solo concerto, with its dual themes of ''the one with the many'' and ''the one against the many.'' It is particularly interesting to watch the Russian piano concerto's gradual transformation into Soviet terms. The process is not an unnatural one, for what better way to celebrate individual and collective heroism over the threatening forces of chaos than one musician's virtuoso outpourings set against a panoramic instrumental background? Struggle is native to the concerto format, so why not political struggle - where the individual tames the inchoate mob and leads it to crashing major-triad victory.

Following is a transcript of a telephone interview today with Andrei D. Sakharov from Gorky, as recorded and translated by The New York Times: Q. How do you feel? A. I feel - well, it is complicated. The news arrived at the same time as that of the death of our close friend Anatoly Marchenko in Chistopol Prison. My health is more or less fine. And Yelena Grigoryevna, although she has gotten no worse, is generally a very sick person. Q. When will you be in Moscow? A. I am going to come to Moscow for several days to prepare for my move. And then, after a certain period, the overall move is going to take place. But we don't know anything exactly.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Dugald Angus Fletcher of Locust Valley, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter Mary Martin Fletcher to Kane Kendall Baker, the son of Mrs. Rolla D. Campbell Jr. of Palm Beach, Fla., and Center Island, Oyster Bay, L.I., and the late George F. Baker Jr. Miss Fletcher and her fiance, members of the class of 1988 at Rollins College, plan to be married in June.

THE debate on the hastily enacted Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986 has seldom addressed one of the key immigration questions: What is the effect of immigration policy on the job skills of immigrants to the United States? Under our present, nepotistic policy, the workplace ''quality'' of immigrants is declining steadily, putting strong pressures on our already strained welfare system. Obviously, no one wants to return to the racist policies enacted in the 20's, and I want to emphasize strongly that talking about quality is not a racist smokescreen. What we need is a policy that encourages admission of immigrants from anywhere in the world who have the skills to prosper in a post-industrial society. Immigration quality refers to the myriad of skills, entrepreneurship, ambition and motivation embodied in the immigrants. The question of quality is important because immigrants receive wages and salaries in accordance with their productivity. In an earlier era, when there was little government obligation to the poor, there was little concern for skills. Today, with an elaborate income transfer (or welfare) system providing benefits not only for the aged, disabled and single parent families but also for the ''working poor,'' we cannot be so cavalier about skills.

Francis Fergusson, a literary critic who wrote extensively on the theater and lectured for many years at Rutgers and Princeton Universities, died Friday night at Princeton Hospital after a long illness. He was 82 years old and lived in Kingston, N.J. Professor Fergusson, who wrote extensively on the classics, joined the faculty of Bennington College in Vermont in 1934 and helped organize its theater workshop. He taught literature and theater at Bennington until 1947, when he was invited to become a member of the Institute of Advanced Study at Princeton.

I agree with Peter Quinn; I have never met a man who could peacefully ask for directions. I have spent hours with men who search rather than pull in at the next gas station: ''Make a left, go two blocks and turn right'' are not the answer to an existential question. They are simple directions. LAURA WINTERS Madison, N.J.

It's about time. Breakfast is finally making a comeback. While the revolution in American cooking swept into kitchens all over the country, transforming dinner and lunch menus, nobody had time to consider the first meal of the day. The restaurant breakfast just continued on its stodgy way. Glitzy brunch got all the press, but take away the bloody mary, and it's breakfast as usual: homestyle fries dumped straight from the freezer bag onto the hot griddle, rubbery scrambled eggs and throwaway toast. That is, until a few San Francisco Bay Area chefs stepped into the arena and began giving the great American breakfast the attention it deserves. And in true Bay Area fashion, where chefs are used to going it alone and forging new territory, each of these revival breakfasts is very different. Whatever the style - American country, uptown haute, le French cafe or retro diner - this is the real stuff: fresh eggs, baked-to-order biscuits, yeast-raised waffles or buckwheat crepes, country hams and apple-smoked bacon, jams and warm fruit crumble. There's something to please everyone from the early morning chirpers to the languid late-to-rise.

The Islanders rebounded from their worst defeat of the season two nights ago to score a 5-2 triumph over the Rangers tonight at Nassau Coliseum. ''Like everybody else, I wanted to get my act together after the game in Philly,'' said the Islanders' Brent Sutter, who had his first hat trick of the season. ''I was ready to play.'' It was obvious from the outset that the Islanders were eager to erase the memory of the 9-4 defeat in Philadelphia Thursday night. Except for the early stages of the second period, when the Rangers were the aggressors and were often in Islander territory, the Islanders were the better team, limiting the Rangers to 17 shots against Kelly Hrudey.

A cat in distress Nothing more or less Good folks I must faithfully tell ye As I am a sinner It wants for some dinner To stuff out its own little belly . . . PERCY BYSSHE SHELLEY Elizabeth Shelley thought enough of her brother's poem about a cat, written when he was 10, to copy and illustrate it. Her careful, early-19th-century penmanship preserved it as the great English Romantic's first extant poem, presented last week -among about 8,000 manuscripts, 13,000 printed volumes and other documents in the Carl and Lily Pforzheimer ''Shelley and His Circle'' collection - to the New York Public Library.

Barbara McFadden Cushman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis E. McFadden of New Canaan, Conn., and Anthony A. Sirna 3d, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Alfred A. Sirna of New York, were married yesterday. The Rev. Dr. David H. C. Read performed the ceremony at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.

MOST of us - about 70 percent - live and work on Long Island. That's because there are more opportunities here than ever before. Unemployment is at a record low and job growth is phenomenal. In the first half of this decade, Long Island gained 174,000 jobs, a 19.3 percent increase. According to the United States Department of Labor, the Island had the third largest employment growth in the nation, exceeded only by the Sun Belt cities of Dallas and Atlanta. And that trend is continuing. During the first half of 1986, 22,000 new jobs were created here. Compare that to a slight statewide decrease in jobs in the same six months, and you'll see that Long Island is the economic jewel of the state.

IF the first two weeks of December are among the busiest on the county's cultural calendar, the rest of the month usually turns silent, with only Christmas church services carrying forward the musical torch. This year, however, we find the holiday bracketed by Sunday concerts, with a run of ''Nutcracker'' ballets into the bargain next weekend. The first two events are today: a 2:30 P.M. recital at the New Rochelle Public Library, and an orchestral program in Scarsdale at 8. The library concert is not part of the popular ''Music, Wine and Cheese'' series, so don't expect any wine or cheese, but admission-free music there will be, as Rowena Arietta, a 22-year-old pianist from the Philippines, plays works of Soler, Beethoven, Chopin, Prokofiev, Scriabin, Ravel and Albeniz. Miss Arietta, now a scholarship student at the Manhattan School, was a laureate at the 1982 Tchaikovsky Competition in Moscow, and this year won two other international contests, the Jose Iturbi in Spain and the Piano Teachers Congress in New York City. It is unlikely that anybody will be answering the information phones on Sunday, but, just in case, the number is 632-7878.

As the Deschutes River flows out of Lake Billy Chinook in central Oregon, it pours through a hyroelectric dam, generating enough electricity to serve more than 2,000 homes a year. Although the Warm Springs hydroelectric plant at the site does not break any record for the power it produces, it represents a milestone for its owners. Unlike any other hydroelectric plant in the United States, the plant is jointly owned by a utility company and a group of American Indian tribes. In Oregon, Maine, Arizona, Mississippi and in the West, Indian tribes in the last year have acquired local companies and experimented with joint ventures and other investments they once shied away from. In many cases, those ventures have stimulated the economy on and around the tribes' reservations and turned impressive profits.

THERE are times when life flashes out at you so quickly, so blindingly, that you know it happened even though you don't. Like those subliminal messages that appear on the screen without our realization, life breaks through the routine of our perceptions and bestows not a subconscious command, but a ''vision,'' a touch of beauty, an experience of reality beyond reality. At mass, Cathy and I had just returned to the pew after the reception of communion from which our 3-year-old, Tim, is barred by age. He had walked up to the priest with us and, of course, returned without the reception of the breaded host, the meaning of which he is deemed incapable of grasping.

IF THE Italian playwright Dario Fo isn't well known in this country, don't blame the Whole Theatre. In 1979, ''We Won't Pay! We Won't Pay!'' by Mr. Fo, who has been called Italy's political clown, had its first American reading at the theater here. Now, with all theatrical accoutrements on display, including an accordionist in the aisle who greets the incoming audience, actors peering through the curtains and then bursting into song and dance and a set that resembles a real working-class Italian kitchen, Mr. Fo's play is back on the Whole Theater stage through next Sunday.

Howard Beach, a community on Jamaica Bay where a young black man was killed yesterday, has long been an insular neighborhood. Strangers are eyed by private security agencies employed by residents to patrol streets in two sections of Howard Beach. Community leaders in the southern Queens neighborhood have vigorously expressed their concerns about issues ranging from crime to the noise of supersonic transports flying into and out of nearby John F. Kennedy Airport.

A faded grandeur is signified by the Baroque urns that preside over the dingy neon sign at the entrance to the Century Paramount Hotel, at 235 West 46th Street. Some of that luster could be recaptured with a $30 million renovation, planned by Arthur G. Cohen and Philip Pilevsky, two New York developers who bought the hotel last month for $35 million.

In an action laden with domestic political and economic consequences, Britain decided last week to cut its losses on a $1.3 billion attempt to develop a home-grown alternative to the American surveillance and command planes known as Awacs. Despite nine years of effort, a British version of the plane did not measure up, the Government of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher announced.

The engagement of Catherine Louise Murphy to David Cordiner Lione has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Murphy of West Hartford, Conn. Mr. Lione is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick M. Lione Jr. of Rowayton, Conn. Miss Murphy, who attended Hartford College for Women, is the confidential secretary to the controller of The Washington Post.

Jim Barton scored 40 points to lead Dartmouth to an 88-86 basketball victory over Miami of Florida tonight and spoil the collegiate debut of Miami's 7-foot-1-inch center, Tito Horford. Horford, the most highly recruited player in the country two years ago, scored 17 points and led Miami in rebounds with 10, assists with 8 and blocked shots with 2.

IT was shortly before dawn when Pakistani army troops swept through a densely populated slum colony of Afghan refugees in the northern outskirts of Karachi, searching for narcotics and illegal guns. Two days later, half the city was engulfed in rioting, looting and burning in the most gruesome outburst of violence among ethnic minorities here since the Hindu-Moslem clashes before independence and the separation from India in 1947.
