As military and civilian authorities struggled to regain control, all of Pakistan was shaken by the implications of the riots. The violence represented the coming together of Pakistan's three most pressing problems: ethnic tensions, the debilitating effects of the seven-year-old war in neighboring Afghanistan and a fundamentally weak, corrupt and polarized political system.

After five weeks of testimony by 67 witnesses, the state has rested its murder case against two avowed revolutionaries in the shooting of a New Jersey state trooper. In denying a defense motion for acquittal, Judge Michael R. Imbriani of Superior Court agreed with the prosecution Thursday that the jury might reasonably find from ballistics evidence, fingerprints, gun ownership and the testimony of eyewitnesses that the defendants, Thomas W. Manning and Richard C. Williams, were guilty. Lieut. Lorenzo V. Hillman, former head of the state police ballistics laboratory, testified this week that microscopic comparison of markings showed that bullets that killed the trooper, Philip J. Lamonaco, on Interstate 80 in Warren County Dec. 21, 1981, came from a 9-millimeter Browning semiautomatic pistol bought by Mr. Williams in Kittery, Me., a year earlier.

A 23-year-old black man was struck and killed by a car on a Queens highway early yesterday after being severely beaten twice by 9 to 12 white men who chased him and two other black men through the streets of Howard Beach in what the police called a racial attack. Though the police responded to reports of trouble at the scenes of both beatings, which occurred 10 blocks apart, they had believed the reports were unfounded until they discovered the man with his skull crushed and a companion wandering nearby dazed and bruised. The dead man, Michael Griffith, of 1650 Pacific Street in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, was found shortly after 1 A.M. lying on the Shore Parkway at Cross Bay Boulevard. He had been struck by a car whose driver, the son of a New York City police officer whose name was not released, apparently had no connection to the assailants, the police said. 'You Don't Belong Here' When he was struck, Mr. Griffith was fleeing from the beatings - one outside a pizza parlor on Cross Bay Boulevard at 157th Avenue and another at 158th Avenue and 84th Street - by a gang who accosted the black men after their car had broken down.

OFF campus, college newspapers have never been taken too seriously, except perhaps as a training ground for daily newspapers. But in the past few years, that has been changing. Technological advances have made the papers look better, and consumer product companies are pouring in ads.

The marriage of Caroline Newberry Woodward to Richard George Grant took place yesterday in the Alumni Chapel at the Hill School in Pottstown, Pa. The Rev. Robert L. Hammett, assisted by the Rev. John W. Riegel, performed the Episcopal ceremony.

DADDY WAS A NUMBER RUNNER, by Louise Meriwether. (Feminist Press, $8.95.) The central character in this novel of ghetto life in 1930's Harlem is 12-year-old Francie Coffin, whose out-of-work father runs numbers to support his family. Francie is ''a remarkable heroine'' and her father ''becomes, with Louise Meriwether's skillful handling, a figure of heroic proportions,'' Paule Marshall said in The Book Review in 1970. ''The novel's greatest achievement lies in the strong sense of black life that it conveys; the vitality and force behind the despair.'' AN OMELETTE AND A GLASS OF WINE, by Elizabeth David. (Penguin, $8.95.) The English author Eliza-beth David is believed by many to be the most impor tant living writer on food, our reviewer, Charles Rosen, said last year. Her position, he added, is confirmed with the appearance of this collection of her food writing over the previous 35 years. While her style is ''serviceable, plain and a little brusque,'' he said, she is ''a writer of pastoral . . . a literary form that evokes a golden age, a time when life was uncomplicated and pleasures were simple. . . . Books like Elizabeth David's are the last gasp of the Romantic movement.'' THE FAT WOMAN'S JOKE, by Fay Weldon. (Academy Chicago, $5.95.) Betrayed by her husband, diet-conscious Esther Wells retreats to a basement hideaway and goes on an eating binge in Fay Weldon's novel of mid-1960's English domestic life. In 1968 our reviewer, Martin Levin, called it ''a delicious tour de force that the author carries off elegantly.''

To the Editor: A coincidence located an article in The New York Times Magazine, called ''Erasing the Past: Europe's Amnesia About the Holocaust,'' in the same issue (Nov. 16) as your In Short review of Richard Plant's book ''The Pink Triangle: The Nazi War Against Homosexuals.'' The fate of homosexuals under Nazi terror has been the occasion for far greater amnesia than that of any other victims, except perhaps gypsies.

If those travelers whose bumper stickers boast, ''I survived the Alcan,'' deserve a 10 on the scale of adventurous touring in Alaska, we rate a modest 5. Two of our threesome vetoed any thought of undertaking the 2,350-mile drive from the United States-Canadian border to Fairbanks. Yet the prospect of viewing America's last frontier from the luxury of a cruise ship or the safety of a tour bus struck all three of us as incongruous. Was there a middle way? If so, we would settle without apology for a 5. This premise having been agreed upon six months earlier, my husband, our friend and I waited at the Seattle dock of the Alaska Marine Highway for one of its ferries, popularly known as big, blue canoes, to load 17 semitrucks, a long line of smaller trucks, recreational vehicles, campers and boats; 30 or so backpackers lugging bedrolls, bicycles, guitars, grocery sacks, fishing rods and coolers; a few woodsy types returning to the wilderness; several military families taking the scenic route to base, and assorted, slightly unconventional tourists.

FOR 40-year-old John Viola, holidays are a time to share with family and friends, and being at a veterans' nursing home that is only an hour away from them is important. ''I can relate to some people here,'' Mr. Viola said of those in the home, ''but seeing my family makes a big difference.'' A Navy veteran from Jersey City who served in Vietnam, Mr. Viola now has multiple sclerosis. He lives at the New Jersey Veterans Home here, the newest of three state-run facilities that offer round-the-clock care.

THE musical tonic for the real cockeyed optimists among us is not ''South Pacific,'' which recently closed at the Darien Dinner Theater in nearby Connecticut. It's ''Annie,'' which just opened there. ''That's something I haven't heard since 1928: Optimism!'' remarks one of the Depression-era street people who dispense apples, soup and songs such as ''We'd Like to Thank You, Herbert Hoover.'' That sums up the musical's shrewd blend of cynicism and cheer.
THE RICHEST MAN IN THE WORLD: The Story of Adnan Khashoggi. By Ronald Kessler. (Warner, $18.95.) ''For the world's richest man, saving the world was the next logical step in his career.''

The engagement of Allene Russell to Dr. Richard Norris Pierson 3d, the son of Dr. Pierson Jr. of Englewood, N.J., and Mrs. Richard T. Wright of Old Lyme, Conn., has been announced by the parents of the future bride, Dr. and Mrs. Paul S. Russell of Chestnut Hill, Mass. A June wedding is planned.
Laszlo Kadar, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Eger, died today, church officials reported.

THE Board of Legislators, nearing the deadline for approving a 1987 Westchester budget, was advised last week by its independent auditors to cut the county work force by 75 jobs. Democratic legislators sought a sharper reduction, saying 400 positions should be eliminated, while other groups sought similarly deep cuts. The recommendations were directed at unfilled but financed positions, estimated at 700 to 1,000 in a work force of nearly 8,500, that the county government maintains to provide a source of cash for unexpected expenses. These vacancies, called a ''phantom army'' by detractors of the accounting practice, have become the subject of acrimonious debate this year, with the controversy likely to extend well into 1987, an election year for all 17 members of the county legislature. Harvey Bennett of Bennett, Kielson & Company, the county's auditors, said 923 county jobs were unfilled as of Nov. 15, a figure that he termed ''substantially higher than previous years'' and one that represented a surplus of $20 million.

The body of the woman whose complaint began the McMartin preschool molestation case was found in her home on Friday, and the police today began investigating the circumstances of her death. The woman, Judy Johnson, 42 years old, whose mental stability has been the focus of a pretrial hearing going on in Superior Court here, was found dead Friday afternoon in her home in the affluent, seaside community of Manhattan Beach. The authorities performed an autopsy, but said further toxicological and neurological tests were needed to determine the cause of death. She had been identified in court as Judy J. and was expected to testify in the pretrial hearing.

THEORETICALLY, personal Christmas gifts are exchanged by people who know each other well and who, one hopes, have a certain regard for one another. This should mean that these gift-exchangers have some idea of what would be welcome and appropriate, but it doesn't. Talk to anyone - almost - and they'll tell you that an astonishing percentage of the things they receive bear no relationship to anything they like, need or want. Take Parker Ladd, for instance, a man who says he has absolutely no sweet tooth. What's inside many of the decoratively wrapped presents he receives? Fruitcake, candied nuts, homemade brownies and similar goodies - pounds and pounds. Every year.

Since returning New York State's income tax windfall as a result of Federal tax reform ought to be a priority of the newly elected State Legislature, I am encouraged that Assembly Ways and Means Committee Chairman Arthur J. Kremer [ ''New York Needs Tax Reform, Too,'' Opinion Page, Nov. 9 ] included a sales tax rate reduction among the options to return the windfall. In 1985 I strongly advocated the elimination of sales taxes on clothing costing less than $50, a proposal to benefit lower- and middle-income families. The decision not to retain deductibility of state and local taxes affords an opportunity to go further and benefit all New Yorkers. The Federal income tax changes will result in a $2.5 billion windfall to the state and a $300 million windfall to New York City, according to the most liberal estimates, unless they lower their rates. Federal tax code changes - such as eliminating the sales tax deduction, limiting individual retirement accounts, repealing the two-earner deduction for married couples and increasing the deductible for medical expenses from 5 to 7.5 percent - will result in higher taxable income for state and city, as well as Federal, purposes.

ebuts at the Waldorf Dec. 29 - Fifty-eight young women, ranging in age from 17 to 22, will be presented at the International Debutante Ball at the Waldorf-Astoria. Adriana Echavarria-Eisenhower, a great-granddaughter of President Dwight D. Eisenhower, will be among the group, and she will be following in the footsteps of her mother, Anne Eisenhower. The white-tie evening, which benefits the Leukemia Society of America and the Soldiers', Sailors' and Airmen's Club, begins at 7:30 P.M. Tickets, $200, from 212-861-5911. Keeping a Tradition Dec. 29 - John Reed, a veteran of the D'Oyly Carte company, often appears here in productions by the New York Gilbert and Sullivan Players as he is now doing in ''Patience'' at Symphony Space. The actress Jean Stapleton will be the hostess at a cocktail party to honor Mr. Reed and to raise money the Gilbert and Sullivan Players. The party, from 5 to 7 P.M., will be at Hanratty's, Amsterdam Avenue at 96th Street. Tickets, $25, include membership in the Players. Telephone 212-769-1000. For Auld Lang Syne Dec. 31 - Just as in homes 95 years ago when Carnegie Hall opened, such Victorian foods as miniature hams, leek pies, flummery and trifle will be served after a New Year's Eve concert at the restored hall. Isaac Stern will be the host at the 8 P.M. concert, and performers will include Robert Tear, Benjamin Luxon, Marvin Hamlisch, Yo-Yo Ma, Richard Stoltzman and Nancy Allen. Tickets for the concert and supper on the stage afterward, $200, from 212-247-7800.

Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d told a Congressional committee on Friday that President Reagan might not remember approving the first shipment of United States arms to Iran in August 1985 because he was recovering from surgery for colon cancer the previous month and may have been taking medication, a committee member reported. This could explain the conflicting testimony from Robert C. McFarlane, the former national security adviser, and Donald T. Regan, the White House chief of staff, over whether the President approved the shipment. A spokesman for Mr. Meese said the member of the House Intelligence Committee, Representative George Brown, misrepresented what the Attorney General had said, but he did not elaborate. [ Page 20. ] Senator Bob Dole, the Senate majority leader and expected candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, said President Reagan still had not convinced Americans that he has done everything he can to uncover the truth about secret United States arms sales to Iran. Senator Dole said in an interview that the President had told him, ''People like me, but they don't believe me.'' [ Page 1. ] Vice President Bush acknowledged in an interview that the crisis had made him ''no longer the front-runner'' for the 1988 Presidential nomination. But he predicted that he would recover. Mr. Bush said that ''the truth, when it comes out,'' would clear up any questions about the role he and President Reagan played in the debate over the Iran arms sales and the Nicaraguan rebels.
Bebe Miller is a performer for the most hedonistic of dancegoers. To see her dance her solos is to see performing that is exceptional both for its sensuousness and its sense of measure.
MUSIC can be used in many ways, and not all of them need involve concert performance. Somehow, Merkin Concert Hall seemed the wrong place for the Duo Arpeggione's Thursday evening program.

An hour before I read Judith Miller's examination of revisionist tendencies which threaten to impede an honest appraisal of the Holocaust in Western Europe, a swastika-emblazoned youth crossed my path in a concourse of Stapleton Airport in Denver.

For the last three weeks, Canadian newspapers have focused on two dominant stories: the Reagan Administration's secret arms sales to Iran and a domestic battle over Sunday shopping. The struggle at home was settled, at least temporarily, when the Supreme Court of Canada ruled Thursday in favor of an Ontario law requiring most retailers to close Sunday. But underlying issues, arousing strong feelings among religious, labor and business groups, remain to hound politicians. At immediate issue was the disposition of 4,000 cases pending in Ontario courts against retailers who have chosen to defy the Sunday closing law. But political analysts have cast the matter against a backdrop of a nation adjusting, sometimes reluctantly, to its own evolution from an inherently conservative and Christian society to something more complex.

THE Afro-American Historical Society in New Haven could soon be forced to close, depriving people of what members say is the chance to learn about the black people of the past who made significant contributions to society. ''Any historical society is important, but especially a black one,'' said the society's president, Russell Hamilton. ''There aren't too many records kept on black history.'' The society is in jeopardy of being evicted from its present home for want of $5,000 to complete payment for the building by the beginning of the year.

Describing this round as a positive refocusing of strategy rather than a retrenchment, A.T. & T. announced last week its second write-off and its third major set of layoffs since the local telephone companies split from American Telephone & Telegraph in a court-ordered divestiture in 1984. While the actions were long anticipated, they were more sweeping than many analysts expected.

Boy George, the British pop singer who underwent treatment for heroin addiction last summer, was arrested today in connection with a possible drug offense, the police said. The 25-year-old singer, whose real name is George O'Dowd, was released more than 12 hours later and ordered to report to the police in February, Scotland Yard said. He was not charged, pending analysis of substances seized when he and two other men were stopped while they walked home from an all-night party.

THE CENTURY'S DAUGHTER By Pat Barker. 284 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $16.95. IN her new novel, Pat Barker is concerned with two kinds of death - the transient one-time-only death of the flesh, and the living death of long-term unemployment. Her setting, as in her first two novels, ''Union Street'' and ''Blow Your House Down,'' is along working-class streets in the north of England. But she is no provincial writer working in a narrow or marginal genre. Her vision is worldly and in the grand tradition of political fiction that she has entered so ambitiously.

NOT long ago, like hundreds of other working people I participated in a ritual that is annually re-enacted by businesses around the nation: the office party. Since my athletic ineptitude rendered me incapable of participating actively in the softball game that opened the proceedings, from my lonely position in right field I had an opportunity to reflect upon the nature of the festivity. On the surface of things, the activity seemed harmless enough: an occasion characterized by the easing of the regulations and restrictions that normally govern the office environment; a day in which a sense of equality is fostered, when the boundaries that sustain the office hierarchy become blurred and the distance that normally separates employers from employees is abolished. Nevertheless, as the afternoon advanced, I began to perceive that the office party serves also a more complex purpose.

The Broughton Lumber Company's nine-mile-long lumber chute, thought to be the last flume still in use in the United States, ceased operating today. So did the steam-powered sawmill that fed the flume with roughsawn lumber. And the planer mill here that received the lumber will close down soon. ''We're calling this Black Friday,'' said G. Ross Jones, the 44-year-old head millwright at the sawmill, which was built in 1922 in the mountains of the Columbia River Gorge. Mr. Jones, who has worked for Broughton's for 18 years and in mills since he was 16, is one of 105 loggers and millworkers who are losing their jobs.

Older players who have been bridge devotees for half a century or so have seen many changes in the laws of the game. Sometimes they are a little out of date, applying the laws of an earlier period by an unwritten grandfather clause. More rarely, as in the diagramed deal, out-dated laws can be invoked by a tolerant director.

A State Supreme Court judge has issued a preliminary injunction blocking the city from placing any more homeless families in a handful of midtown hotels. But the injunction may not affect the city's system of sheltering families because city officials said they would appeal the order before it takes effect next week.

Ever since 1796, when Edward Jenner began using injections of cowpox virus to inoculate patients against smallpox, vaccines have been developed to trick the immune systems of healthy patients into producing antibodies that prevent infection. Last week, researchers were astir with news that French and Zairian scientists were working on a different kind of immunization intended for people already infected with a virus - in this case, AIDS.

Allison Brandes Conway, a vice president in the investment banking sector of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company in New York, and Richard Brian Carey, a vice president in the London office of the investment banking sector of Manufacturers Hanover, plan to be married in March. The future bride's parents, Audrey Oehler Conway of Brooklyn Heights and E. Virgil Conway of Bronxville, N.Y., have announced their daughter's engagement to a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph P. Carey of Needham, Mass.

Dr. and Mrs. Burton I. Korelitz of New York and South Salem, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jean Hanff Korelitz, to Paul Muldoon, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Muldoon of Moy, Northern Ireland. A late-summer wedding is planned.

JUGGLERS IN POMONA ''The Flying Karamazov Brothers, while neither Russian nor brothers, are certainly the best jugglers anyone would want to see,'' wrote Frank Rich in a New York Times review. If you want to see for yourself, theywill be at Stockton State College in Pomona Friday in their latest frolic, ''Juggle & Hyde.'' And while we are disposing of misconceptions about their wonderfully illogical name, they are are not circus acrobats, either, despite the ''flying.'' What the five nonflying, non-brother Flying Karamazov Brothers do is juggle all sorts of things.

Chemical New York will buy Texas Commerce in one of the biggest banking acquisitions ever. Chemical's offer consists of $7 a share in cash and a diverse array of securities, with an estimated total value of $1.19 billion. Many analysts credited Chemical's chairman, Walter V. Shipley, with a courageous move that, they say, may turn out to be brilliant. Two other Texas banks merged just one day later. Republicbank, the second-largest in the state, agreed to acquire the troubled Interfirst for a package of stock and notes that Republicbank put at $571 million.

Lizanne Teitelbaum, the daughter of Dr. Seymour Teitelbaum and Lilian Ostrovsky de Teitelbaum of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., and Buenos Aires, was married in New York yesterday to Barry Rosenstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Rosenstein of West Orange, N.J. Rabbi David Kahane and Cantor Dov Kerin officiated at the Plaza. The bride, a cum laude graduate of Barnard College, is studying for an M.B.A. degree at Columbia University. Her father is the chief of dental and oral surgery at the Phelps Memorial Hospital in North Tarrytown, N.Y. Mr. Rosenstein, a corporate takeover specialist associated with Asher Edelman, a financier, graduated summa cum laude and Phi Beta Kappa from Lehigh University and received an M.B.A. degree from the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania. His father is a senior partner in the tax accounting firm of Rosenstein, Schantz & Jacobson in Cranford, N.J.

A bus carrying soldiers home for the holidays fell into a ravine today, killing three paratroopers and injuring the other 38 paratroopers aboard and the civilian driver, the police said. The accident occurred near Loja, 30 miles east of Granada, the police said.

The Metropolitan Transportation Authority's sensible capital program clings to life, thanks to an ingenious suggestion from Stanley Fink, the outgoing Assembly Speaker, and the willingness of Warren Anderson, the Senate Republican leader. The program deserves to prosper.

ON A RECENT Wednesday morning, six people sat in the waiting room at the walk-in clinic of the Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. A young man in a white coat, a stethoscope bobbing around his neck, approached one of them. ''My name is Michael Gillette,'' he told a patient in his mid-30's whose neck was in a brace. ''I'm a second-year medical student at Harvard, and if it's O.K. with you, I'd like to interview you before the doctor sees you.'' The man was suffering from a dull ache in his back that was keeping him from his engineering job; one doctor had diagnosed the problem as a herniated disk, and had recommended surgery. The engineer wanted a second opinion. Although Mr. Gillette asked several questions about his specific symptoms, he focused more on the patient's life at home and on the job. ''I haven't slept in my bed for several days,'' the engineer told the Harvard student. ''I've been sleeping in a recliner chair in the living room.'' As he talked, the man seemed unaware of his role in Michael Gillette's unusual medical education.

Governor Cuomo won 57 of the state's 62 counties and gained a record 64.6 percent of the statewide vote in winning a second term in November, according to the official canvass of the election by the State Board of Elections. The official results, released last week, produced no significant changes in unofficial election returns compiled election night, but they filled out details of the statewide elections for governor, United States senator, state comptroller and attorney general. Democrats and incumbents had a clear advantage as Mr. Cuomo and his fellow Democrat, Attorney General Robert Abrams, won pluralities of 1.4 million and 1.2 million votes, respectively. Mr. Abrams won 65.1 percent of the total vote for attorney general.

Mel Lewis and His Big Band V.I.E.W. Video. 38 minutes. $34.95 until Jan. 15, 1987, then $24.95. The pianist Phil Markowitz and Mel Lewis's five-man reed section show why they are two of the strong points of Mr. Lewis's big band in this concert performance in Jerusalem in 1985. Mr. Markowitz adds colors and accents behind all the soloists and creates a compelling unaccompanied solo that builds over spidery, extending lines.

The two-story house that Sarah J. lives in looks like most of the others in her quiet Staten Island neighborhood. A smooth concrete walk slices through the lawn to the front door, and inside, Christmas ornaments hang from the branches of an evergreen and stockings dangle from a railing. But for many years, that peaceful facade was deceiving. The house was the setting for violent outbursts from Mrs. J.'s husband, from whom she is now separated. An alcoholic and a cocaine user, he subjected her to constant verbal and physical abuse.

Telephone lights blink like tree ornaments. Messages pile up. Cheery red bags overflowing with gifts spill into hallways. People staggering under piles of clothing rush in and out. For the next four days, (they work Sundays) this scene will confront the nine personal shoppers in Saks' Fifth Avenue Club. For them, shopping really is work.

FELIX MENDELSSOHN: A Life in Letters. Edited by Rudolf Elvers. (Fromm International, $22.50.) ''Dear silent Schleinitz: Can such a thing be plausible? Isn't your own hair standing on end? That I, the worst correspondent in the kingdom, am writing for the second time already, and you, one of the best, have yet to write one at all. . . . Oh Schleinitz! This is atrocious beyond all atrocity; I am writing this entire letter con fuoco.''

The Justice Department has filed separate lawsuits against two Detroit suburbs, charging them with discriminating against blacks in hiring. The lawsuits accuse the two suburbs, Dearborn and Lincoln Park, of violating civil rights laws by failing to recruit and hire blacks on the same basis as whites in requiring applicants for city jobs to have lived in the cities for up to one year.

Even now, a decade later, they still talk of him in the present tense. Ten years ago today, in a doctor's office on Michigan Avenue, Richard J. Daley died of heart failure. He was 74 years old on that cold December afternoon. To the nation and parts of the world, he was the last of the big-city bosses, the all-powerful kingmaker whose endorsement of a candidate was tantamount to election, if his loyal battalions of precinct captains had anything to do with it. And they usually did, one way or the other.

The consensus, when Leonard Bernstein and the New York Philharmonic, Zubin Mehta and Yo-Yo Ma, Vladimir Horowitz and Frank Sinatra had finished, was that Carnegie Hall is still the best concert hall in America. The hall reopened Monday after a seven-month renovation, its seats all sold and its sonority intact. For Isaac Stern, the violinist and Carnegie Hall president, the quest had been long; he began in 1957, when it was announced that Carnegie would be razed and replaced with an office tower. (AP)

PUBIS ANGELICAL. By Manuel Puig. Translated From the Spanish by Elena Brunet. Aventura/Vintage. 236 pages. Paper, $6.95. THE literal meaning of the title ''Pubis Angelical'' is finally explained in the closing pages of Manuel Puig's elaborately imagined new novel, the seventh to be published in this country by the Argentine writer who is probably best known for the book on which the successful film ''Kiss of the Spider Woman'' was adapted.

The National Archives will soon try to make public 1.5 million pages of the ''special files'' of the Nixon Administration, papers that officials of the period regarded as sensitive and stored in segregated space in the White House. This material includes the files of key staff officers like H. R. Haldeman, John D. Ehrlichman and Charles W. Colson but no classified documents or national security information.

Normally, this is a jolly season for Japanese employees, the time they receive winter bonuses worth several months' salary. But this year, about 7,000 managers at the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company got envelopes stuffed not with cash but with coupons good for Matsushita products. That was a sign of the toll the strong yen is exacting on the giant electronics company and on other pillars of Japanese industry. The last time Matsushita employees got part of their bonuses in products was right after World War II, when the company handed out light bulbs - at that time its main product.

The largest labor movement in the Philippines voted today to campaign against the Aquino Government's proposed constitution on the ground that the Government has drifted to the right in its policies. The resolution was passed unanimously by 350 delegates attending the weekend congress of the May First Movement, a leftist labor federation that says it has more than half a million members. Officials of the labor federation had said it would back ratification of the charter in the Feb. 2 plebiscite so as not to be linked with supporters of Ferdinand E. Marcos, the ousted President, who have opposed the document since its promulgation.

Iran said Iraqi jets bombed residential areas in western Iran today, killing more than 80 civilians. Iran vowed to retaliate. But an Iraqi military communique issued in Baghdad said the targets were an air base and military camps in Kermanshah and nearby Dizful.

The Jets' defense, one that gave up 52 points and 621 yards to the Cincinnati Bengals today, had a patchwork lineup near the end. Jerome Foster, signed as a free agent last week, was playing left end. Tom Baldwin was at nose tackle, Barry Bennett at the other end, Troy Benson and Matt Monger at linebacker, Bobby Humphery and Carl Howard at cornerback and Rich Miano at safety. ''I thought they were trying, trying hard,'' Coach Joe Walton said of these second-line players.

Corruption in New York City is undermining the city's ability to attract a new generation of ''first-class'' civil servants, the chairman of a commission appointed to study the city's municipal corruption scandal said yesteray. ''Just ask yourself whether you would advise someone who had lots of choices to go into government at this moment,'' said the chairman, Michael I. Sovern, the president of Columbia University. ''The answer to that from many people would be 'no,' '' he said. '' 'What do you need that stuff for? People will think you are a crook.' ''

John Cardinal O'Connor, who is to leave this week for a 10-day trip to Jordan, Israel and Egypt, hopes to make the achievement of peace between Israel and its Arab neighbors one of the central concerns of his leadership, according to an American Jewish leader who spoke with him. The Jewish leader, Rabbi Marc H. Tanenbaum, director of international affairs for the American Jewish Committee, said in a recent interview that Cardinal O'Connor ''indicated to me that no other cardinal or bishop in the United States hierarchy has ever made the issue of peace in the Middle East between Israel and its Arab neighbors a central concern in his ministry.'' ''He said that he would like to play that role in the Catholic hierarchy, try to make some basic contribution to improving relationships with Israel and its Arab neighbors,'' Rabbi Tanenbaum said. The Cardinal's visit to Israel, his first since assuming the leadership of the Archdiocese of New York in January 1984, was arranged after a personal invitation last September by Shimon Peres, then Prime Minister and now Foreign Minister of Israel. The invitation was extended when Mr. Peres called on the Cardinal at his residence at 452 Madison Avenue.

The Irish Republican Army has claimed responsibility for wrecking two hotels and a pub in what the police said was a pre-Christmas bombing campaign. An attempt to bomb a nightclub was foiled. The bombings took place Saturday night about 30 miles west of Belfast, in County Tyrone. No one was hurt, but officials estimated damage at more than $1.5 million.

Police stood guard as bulldozers leveled houses in the Sohrab Goth district of Karachi. Riots last week were set off by a military crackdown in the district, which is believed to be a major center for heroin and weapons trafficking. At least 166 people were killed in the rioting. (AP)

IN the island town where I was a child, many Christmases were brown, and a new, shiny sled might hang unused in the toolshed most of the winter to be gazed upon and touched hopefully whenever black clouds hanging low over the gray sea and the sere meadows seemed too heavy to pass by without a gift of snow. And when snow did come you had to make the most of it because in less than a week the wind would back from northwest to southwest. And even if it didn't rain the ocean's warm breath would set the trees dripping, and the tracks of rabbits weaving through thickets of scrub oaks would turn to pools of water on sodden leaves. For those who wanted snow, the weather was perverse. Often after a three-day thaw had done its work, the skies would clear and there would be a time of bitter cold when ice would form in the salt pond until the only open water was at the mouth of its largest feeder brook - an ever-shrinking haven for ducks and geese, beside which Beany and I made a hunting camp from the crate in which my aunt's Christmas piano arrived.

In the past, institutional investors operated out of the glare of the public spotlight, but now managers of pension funds and other holders of huge blocks of stock are seeking public attention as they challenge corporate actions. The Wisconsin Investment Board, for example, filed a shareholders' resolution late last week with the General Motors Corporation, condemning G.M.'s $700 million buyout of the shares held by the Texas billionaire H. Ross Perot. Patricia Lipton, executive assistant to the board, directs its new Active Investor Program, which filed the resolution. ''This is the first proxy season we've really been active,'' she said.

The National Security Council is being restructured so that it can assume a more important role in coordinating Government policy when Frank C. Carlucci becomes the White House national security adviser in January, according to experts close to the council. Under the direction of Mr. Carlucci, an effort is being made to upgrade the quality of the professional staff while reducing its size, from about 55 to about 45. Some offices within the council are being abolished, and new offices will be created. The council has gained notoriety for managing covert operations, including the arms sale to Iran and the transfer of profits from the sale to the Nicaraguan rebels, but it is regarded as relatively weak in its intended role of advising in Government decisions and coordinating policy.

Last year, en route to the conference championship, St. John's arguably had the best starting five in the Big East. The bench was so fragile that each starter was forced to play almost 40 minutes a game, and not foul out. A season later, St. John's, along with Georgetown, has one of the deepest benches in the Big East. ''We're trying to settle on eight guys right now,'' said Lou Carnesecca, the coach whose team came from 10 points down Saturday to defeat Niagara, 66-58, for its seventh straight victory this season.

An ostrich farmer was critically injured when he was trampled by a 400-pound ostrich that he was trying to lasso. The farmer, J. T. Coody, 65 years old, of Cache, Okla., was helping to load 13 ostriches into two trucks at a farm near here last Sunday when one of the birds ran over him, John O'Connor, director of Ada County paramedics, said Friday.

A LITTLE before midnight in a Florida city a week ago Saturday night, a hero was arrested. He became embroiled in a scuffle with policemen and was beaten about the head and body with night sticks and flashlights, and he bled and was bruised, like any mortal. He was a young man, a young black man, and maybe all that separated him from being an ordinary young man, an ordinary black man, were his special skills. But that makes all the difference, at least in terms of notoriety. The young man was Dwight Gooden - Doctor K -ace pitcher for the New York Mets.

To the Editor: Oh, Mortimer Adler, I get so tired! You tell us that the schools fail to educate (''Schooling Is Not Education,'' Op-Ed, Dec. 2). You tell us that no one is able to learn. You tell us that none of us have trained our minds. You tell us to ''read and discuss,'' and then we will understand.

Crowds filled Fifth Avenue yesterday as the thoroughfare was closed to traffic from 34th Street to 57th Street from 11 A.M. to 3 P.M. Strollers and shoppers were entertained by performers ranging from Ukrainian dancers to jazz ensembles to Christmas carolers. (NYT/Barton Silverman)

FRITZ GLAUS learned of the incident from several players who belong to his informal congregation known as the tennis ministry. They brought word from Lagos, Nigeria, about the bizarre incident that occurred in late November, when three American tennis players - born-again Christians - destroyed their passports, cash, traveler's checks and a Bible in an act of religious fervor at a hotel housing players during a satellite Challenger Series event on the professional tour. It was one of the stops Glaus chose not to make in his year-round travels as a tennis preacher. It was one he now wishes he had.

On three occasions over the past 20 years, Elizabeth Bagaaya Nyabongo, a Ugandan princess, has fled her homeland to live in exile. And now, for a fourth time, she has left Uganda, but this time to come to Washington as her country's new Ambassador to the United States. Her journey across the Atlantic is but another unusual twist in her life, which in good part has been the stuff of novels. Besides being an exile and a diplomat, Princess Elizabeth also has been an actress, a lawyer and a high-fashion model known in the salons of New York, Paris and London as Elizabeth of Toro.

A TOURING blues and soul show starring Frankie Lee, Sonny Rhodes and Eddie Ray appeared at Tramps over the weekend. The featured artists have been popular attractions at West Coast blues festivals and clubs for several years now, but this is their first chance to make an impression in New York, and they made the most of it.

Hearing on the Homeless The City Council's Select Committee on the Homeless is to hold a hearing to determine if there are staff shortages at welfare hotels and shelters for the homeless. 1 P.M., 23d-floor hearing room, 250 Broadway.

The more imaginative of New York City's politicians have predicted from the start that the scandals of 1986 would lead to reforms -but nobody expected that corruption would bring the practices of corporate America to City Hall. In a way, it has. For the first time in memory, the city is hiring an executive search company - better known as a ''head hunter'' - to recommend candidates for some jobs. A panel Mayor Koch named in February to propose people for jobs on nine city boards and commissions, like the Planning and Tax Commissions, found it needed help, especially in developing a pool of women and minorities. So the panel's chairman, Floyd Abrams, spoke to Patrick F. X. Mulhearn, the Mayor's counsel. Mr. Mulhearn spoke to Mr. Koch. And on Oct. 28, Mr. Koch wrote to Milton Petrie, philanthropist and head of the Petrie Stores Corporation, asking if he would finance a $43,000 pilot project using a search firm.

The White House strategy for handling the Iran arms affair, an insider said the other day, has been to offer one concession at a time in the hope of quelling the public furor, then to wait a few days to see what happened. In quick succession, President Reagan has urged the naming of an independent counsel, conceded that mistakes had been made in carrying out his policy, announced that he would permit his aides to testify before Congress and urged that Congress grant immunity to recalcitrant witnesses. Nothing has worked, in the sense that none of Mr. Reagan's gestures have stilled the storms of controversy. The situation is still as the President described it recently to Senator Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas, ''People like me, but they don't believe me.'' Now, key White House staff members said this weekend, Mr. Reagan's inclination is to do nothing for a couple of weeks -until Congress reconvenes Jan. 6 - in the hope that silence will prove palliative. ''The fact is,'' a senior Republican senator said, ''they don't really know what the devil they should do.''

The man whose 1962 flight set a record that stood until the Voyager broke it says his flight was the easiest of his career and a far cry from the cramped, risky trip of the Voyager crew. ''I'm elated for them,'' Clyde P. Evely, 64 years old, said of the craft's crew of two. ''Anybody who can stay in that airplane for 11 days has earned my respect.''
Free Call for Theater Facts A computer system will provide free nationwide telephone calls for up-to-the-minute information and tickets to theater in New York.

The new United States Ambassador, Charles J. Pilliod Jr., is openly determined to portray Mexico in a favorable light in Washington, according to his aides. As a result, Mexican officials, who were surprised at first by his approach, are now hailing a new warming in relations. Mr. Pilliod, 68 years old, the retired chairman of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, replaced John Gavin as Ambassador at the end of October. Now he regularly orders diplomats under him to revise their reports, telling them to stress the positive in their messages to Washington, according to his aides.

An article in Business Day on Nov. 19 about investors in a partnership with Ivan F. Boesky mistakenly described Lewis Lehrman's affiliation with the Rite Aid Corporation. He was part owner and president, but is not sole owner.

A string of national and international incidents involving Swiss financial and business institutions have shaken assumptions about the country's traditional values of discretion and privacy. The Swiss, an intensely private people, have voted by comfortable majorities in recent years to stay out of the United Nations and to uphold their traditionally stringent financial secrecy laws. But recently much of the publicity for Switzerland has been bad. The latest incident involved the reported use of Swiss banks to funnel covert Iran arms payments to Nicaraguan rebels.

To the Editor: The myth about St. Patrick and the snakes is again raised, by Nicholas Scott, Minister of State for Security, Northern Ireland (news story, Dec. 8), who states there may never have been any snakes in Ireland, which may well be true. Certainly during the last ice age (25,000 years ago), Ireland was covered entirely by the glacier, and thus all species of flora and fauna would have been destroyed.

The initial Congressional investigations into the Iran arms sales are about to end, but many central questions seem certain to remain unanswered for weeks, at least. The uncertainty is likely to delay foreign-policy making throughout the Government and complicate foreign relations, Congressional and Administration officials said this weekend. The independent counsel, Lawrence E. Walsh, is only beginning to organize his staff for his investigation into the Iran operation and the diversion of funds to Nicaraguan rebels. The Senate and House select committees, which begin work next month, are due to hold hearings that could last for months. As a result, the normal running of the Government is expected to be severely constrained.

Sadanori Yamanaka, not a household name even in Japan, suddenly became one of the country's most influential politicians this month. Mr. Yamanaka headed a committee of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party that two weeks ago proposed the most sweeping tax revisions for Japan since the end of World War II. They amounted to a junior version of the changes adopted in the United States this year, and, as such, attracted considerable attention both here and overseas. A few weeks earlier, a parallel Government committee had also studied the tax system and announced its proposals. While its opinions were hardly insignificant, they drew far less interest. There was never a question that the Yamanaka panel was the dominant force and would have the final word on which specific proposals were to underlie the critical policy debate that is now under way.

Dr. Maxwell M. Wintrobe, who invented methods of identifying blood disorders that led to improved treatment of anemia, died of heart failure on Dec. 9 at his home in Salt Lake City. He was 85 years old. Dr. Wintrobe, who in 1942 wrote a major textbook on blood and its diseases, trained dozens of the country's leading specialists in the field. He codified the methods of measuring blood and invented a device to quantify the number and concentration of red blood cells. That device, the hematocrit, allows physicians to diagnose and treat different kinds of anemia.

Two people were killed when they were trapped by a fire Saturday night in a rooming house here. The cause of the fire in the three-story frame rooming house, the Bayview Hotel, was termed accidental by the Union County arson squad.

FOREIGN investors have been buying American equities at a record clip. ''It has been a steadily strong year for purchases from overseas,'' said Peter Gregory, a senior vice president in the international division of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. ''November and December are generally slow months, but volume this year is holding up very well.'' ''Our equity market appears cheaper than some markets abroad,'' said Klaus Hedbabny, a managing director of Cyrus J. Lawrence Inc., in citing one reason for the appeal of United States stocks. ''The cash flow abroad is enormous, and some foreign countries with huge trade surpluses find financial assets in the American market attractive.''

It is Christmas countdown time in the Rockies, and last-minute gift orders are still arriving at Me & My Dad, a catalogue for fathers. A hot item is a book called ''The Father's Almanac'' (''A fine addition to any father's library and a great gift for the new father,'' the catalogue says). Another big seller is the Baby Jogger stroller (''An extra-tall model is available for those over 6-foot-3''), and sets of Magnetic Blocks are moving briskly (''If they were on your desk, you'd feel compelled to play with them''). Dinosaur books are popular, as is the fold-out children's book ''Papa, Please Get the Moon for Me.'' ''I think our catalogue copy portrays the idea of fathering with gusto and joy,'' said Matthew Back, seated in his office in Denver. ''It also says that we men don't know exactly what we're doing and will need to help each other.''

''IT'S sad when the dream is over,'' a man said as he left the Lehman Center for the Performing Arts (at Lehman College in the Bronx) on Saturday night, after a performance by the Eglevsky Ballet of ''The Nutcracker.'' Staged by Michael Vernon, the ballet was a dream, with well-schooled, lively dancing, an amazing variety of stage effects for a small touring production and inventive bits of dramatic business that for the most part make this holiday classic even more believable. Mr. Vernon has continued to tinker with the ballet, set to the familiar Tchaikovsky score, since it was seen last year at Lehman Center. But it is still a version that does honor to the ballet.

Rumrill-Hoyt, New York, has become agency in the United States for the National Tourist Office, which has a budget of $2 million to $3 million. Plans have been made for an ad campaign for print media that will break in March in major markets. The previous agency was Martin, Sturtevant, Silverman & Marshall.

A group of conservationists says it is within $27,000 of reaching its goal of $1.25 million to save a special stand of centuries-old red oaks from logging. The oaks, which stand more than 100 feet tall, are in a 283-acre forest on Burt Lake in the far-northern part of Lower Michigan. They are nearly 200 years old and have the potential of lasting another 150 to 200 years, according to scientists.
A picture caption on Friday about a Fifth Avenue peddler receiving a summons gave the time incorrectly. The incident occurred the previous week, not last Thursday.

Basketball Blazers 128, Bullets 101: In Portland, Ore., Kiki Vandeweghe scored 18 of his 29 points in the second half last night for the Trail Blazers. Jim Paxson came off the bench to add 20 for the Blazers, who won for the 10th time in their last 12 games and their 11th straight at home. Portland used its fast break and defense, outscoring the Bullets by 16-2 over a four-minute stretch to take a 117-91 lead with 4 minutes 30 seconds to play. (AP) Lakers 103, Rockets 96: Magic Johnson scored a season-high 38 points, including 8 in a fourth-quarter Laker comeback. Los Angeles went into the fourth quarter in Houston leading, 80-77, but the Rockets charged ahead by 91-86 with 4:29 left. The Lakers then outscored Houston, 17-5, the rest of the way. The Lakers played the game without Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, who is out with a recurring cornea problem in his right eye. Lakers officials said his status would be determined today.(AP) Georgia Tech 63, S.M.U. 54: Duane Ferrell scored 17 points and Tom Hammonds added 16 to lead Georgia Tech over Southern Methodist in the final yesterday of the Suntory Ball tournament in Tokyo. Hammonds led the Yellow Jackets to two victories in the three-team tournament and was named the most valuable player. (UPI) Hockey Soviet Takes Tourney: The Soviet Union won Izvestia hockey tournament in Moscow with a 1-0 victory over Czechoslovakia, the defending champion, as Sergei Makarov scored the only goal in the 13th minute of the first period.

DWIGHT GOODEN may not think so, but he was lucky four different ways in his incident with the Tampa police a week ago Saturday night. 1. He was lucky he was not more seriously injured in a brawl that may have developed racial overtones at some point. 2. He was lucky he is a prominent athlete who can gain a settlement convenient to all. 3. He was also lucky he was not tested for alcohol on the scene, given the .111 level of his blood system in a subsequent hospital test. 4. Since his alcohol level was probably higher at the time of the brawl, he may even be lucky he didn't kill anybody while he was driving. Harsh? Maybe, but there are a lot of people mourning loved ones because somebody could manage to insert a key into the ignition after ingesting some alcohol. As a colleague of mine, who lost a child to a drunk driver, puts it: ''All those beer commercials during sports events, showing men driving to a bar. What do they do with all their cars after they drink? Or, are these sleep-in bars?''

Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet dissident whose banishment to Gorky has been lifted, said today that he and his wife, the human rights activist Yelena G. Bonner, expect to travel from that city to Moscow on Tuesday. In a brief interview by telephone from here, he said that he did not want to meet reporters right after returning to Moscow, and that ''there are no conditions'' on his release from nearly seven years of isolation. Deputy Foreign Minister Vladimir F. Petrovsky announced Friday that Dr. Sakharov's internal exile had been lifted and that Miss Bonner had been pardoned on her conviction for anti-Soviet activities.

Reduced output of crude oil by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries during the first six months of next year is likely to raise oil prices from current levels, but not to OPEC's stated target of $18 a barrel, in the view of many oil specialists in the United States. They said that the agreement by all OPEC members except Iraq to reduce their oil production by 7 percent during the first half of 1987 was too ''modest'' to support OPEC's price goal. Further, they said, OPEC has yet to get members to adhere to the fixed prices set for its various grades of crude oil, which the analysts said is essential to insuring that the $18 price will hold. Scenarios for Rise However, other oil specialists said that prices for OPEC oil could reach $18 a barrel, but offered different reasons why it would.

The right to do something does not mean that doing it is right. Nobody denies the right of an American citizen to refuse to incriminate himself. Nor does anyone sensitive to individual liberty impute guilt to anyone who invokes the Fifth Amendment. What John Poindexter and Oliver North, officers of the armed forces on active duty, should reconsider is this: Does exercising their right to remain silent help or harm the country they are sworn to serve?

The Treasury is adhering to its regular schedule of financings, even while investor activity and new offerings of corporate and tax-exempt issues decline sharply during the holiday season. Besides today's regular weekly auction of new three-month and six-month bills totaling $15.6 billion, the Treasury plans to sell $9.75 billion of new one-year Treasury bills tomorrow.

Representative Stephen J. Solarz, Democrat of Brooklyn and chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, discussed Pakistan's security problems today with Prime Minister Mohammad Khan Junejo, senior Foreign Ministry officials said. Pakistan is expecting $4.02 billion in American military and economic assistance over the next six years, and the aid is subject to Congressional approval.

A hush fell over the congregation at Our Lady of Grace Roman Catholic Church in Howard Beach, Queens, yesterday morning as the Rev. Kenneth Leona delivered his homily, an unsparing message about racial prejudice and violence. ''Many people ask a priest: 'Is this a sin? Is that a sin?' '' said Father Leona, who jolted his parishioners with blunt references to a racial attack in the area early Saturday that left a young black man, 23-year-old Michael Griffith of Brooklyn, dead. ''Well, racial prejudice is a sin. Discrimination is a sin. Violence and hatred are sins. And all the beautiful Christmas lights of our neighborhood cannot hide that type of darkness.'' ''The reality of sin and evil has shown forth in our own neighborhood,'' Father Leona continued, as weak sunshine spilled through the stained-glass windows. ''But there is more to our neighborhood than that, and we must show that 'more.' ''

The Paramount Pictures Corporation is having a boffo year. From ''Pretty in Pink'' in February to ''Top Gun,'' '' 'Crocodile' Dundee,'' ''Star Trek IV: The Voyage Home'' and this month's ''The Golden Child,'' starring Eddie Murphy, Paramount has produced an almost unbroken string of hits. So far this year, its films are expected to account for as much as 21 percent of the industry's total box office gross, pulling in about $600 million, twice as much as its nearest competitors. In the history of the film business, that is an extraordinary gap. ''The studio will end up with a huge chunk of the top 10 films of the year,'' said Art Murphy, the film industry expert for Variety, the trade newspaper.

Nigeria, once a proud symbol of oil wealth, has in recent weeks won approval of key elements of a complex package to reschedule its crushing foreign debt. Much of the $20 billion in debt was incurred in the early 1980's, after economists predicted that the $26 billion Nigeria earned from oil in 1980 would swell to $40 billion in 1986. But oil revenues, which account for almost all of the country's export earnings, were crippled when world prices plummeted and are expected to amount to just $5 billion this year. Now, encouraged by the Government's year-old austerity program, foreign banks and creditor organizations are beginning to reach agreements designed to ease the country's financial woes. Those accords include the following: * Last month, Nigeria negotiated a preliminary agreement with a group of the country's commercial bank creditors to reschedule $1.5 billion in debt. The deal requires formal approval by Jan. 15.

The nation is meeting many of its goals for better health but will miss targets for others, such as reducing infant mortality and teen-age pregnancy, the Public Health Service said today. The agency reported in a study that the nation would probably meet 110 of its 226 objectives for better health by 1990. ''We can be extremely pleased at the high level of public awareness about life style factors and their contribution to health,'' Dr. Robert E. Windom, an Assistant Secretary of Health and Human Servics, wrote in the preface to the 253-page report.

It's been 17 days now since they went public with an offering of limited-partnership units representing about 40 percent of their ownership, and so far the Boston Celtics have fared better under the boards than on the Big Board. The Celtics' shares, listed on the New York Stock Exchange, were worth $18.50 apiece when trading began Dec. 5.

Marla Hanson, the 25-year-old model whose face was slashed in an attack last summer, yesterday called the man who was convicted in the assault ''a dangerous person and a vicious person.'' Miss Hanson said that while she was trying to avoid bitter feelings toward the convicted man, ''It's hard to forgive someone who doesn't show any remorse.'' Steven Roth, a 28-year-old television makeup artist, was found guilty of assault Saturday night in State Supreme Court in Manhattan. The verdict ended an emotional monthlong trial in which Mr. Roth claimed that the slashing was staged by a jealous homosexual lover with whom he had broken up earlier that day.

THE life story of Fanny Mendelssohn, whose ''Oratorio on Biblical Themes'' was given its first American performance by the St. Cecilia Chorus Saturday at Carnegie Hall, is happy with a deep sharp strain of sadness. Like her famous brother, Felix, she was trained in music from an early age, and like him she composed throughout her short life; some 500 of her works are extant. Despite the conventions of her time, she aspired to combine motherhood with a public career as a composer. Her brother, while maintaining close relations and protesting concern for her wifely nature, played a cruel role in the frustration of her wish by refusing his endorsement at a critical juncture (though he had condescended to publish some of her songs, under his name, several years earlier).

The United States has already paid a heavy price for its scandalous weapons sales to Iran. Yet if some of the sweeping arms proposals put forth last October at Reykjavik - which remain on the table at Geneva - are ever accepted, the damage to vital American interests will immeasurably eclipse even the most harmful consequences of the Iran affair. Realistic and verifiable agreements substantially reducing the nuclear stockpiles of the two superpowers remain highly desirable. But the proposals advanced in Iceland were not only unrealistic and unverifiable but undesirable as well. From the American point of view, Mikhail S. Gorbachev's proposal to abolish all nuclear weapons is the strategic equivalent of the apple Eve offered Adam. It is a tempting offer but one fraught with catastrophic consequences. In the first place, such a proposal is inherently unverifiable. Mobile intercontinental ballistic missiles can be hidden in garages or caves. Weapon components can be manufactured and maintained separately, to be assembled in a time of crisis. In an open society such as ours cheating is almost impossible, but in the closed Soviet society, violations of treaty-imposed restrictions would be considerably more difficult to detect.
Only the French could do it. The nation that a couple of years ago had the world chattering about its self-cleaning outdoor urinals now has made a cult item out of its yellow subway tickets.

A new, ultra-sophisticated information and ticket-buying system to be introduced in February could have the biggest effect on theatergoing habits since the advent of credit-card purchases more than 13 years ago. The system, NYC/On Stage, promises to make decisions about attending New York City performance easier than ever, according to its creators. Callers will be able to get up-to-the-minute details about the performing arts - from musicals on Broadway to new-wave dance in Soho lofts -and about ticket-buying options. The new system will be available 24 hours a day through an 800 number, and will provide access from anywhere in the country at no charge to the caller, said Henry Guettel, executive director of the Theater Development Fund, the nonprofit support group for which it was designed.

It is time to stop focusing on the unanswered questions, as if they were all that mattered. What remains unknown about the Iran arms affair is much less important than what we do know. We have learned enough to have a picture of the Reagan Presidency in operation: an unforgettably chilling picture. At the top we see a President numb to facts and consequences. Below, on the national security staff, we see a zealot pursuing his obsessions, using his position to advance political causes.

The investment banking and brokerage firm L. F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin Holdings Inc. announced the completion of its management restructuring in the wake of recent resignations by its chairman, Thomas I. Unterberg, and vice chairman, A. Robert Towbin. Franc,ois J. P. Mayer, 45 years old, and Robert Schoenthal, 44, the co-chief operating officers of the company, were named as co-chief executives.

Residents in Westchester County were shaken Saturday morning by blasting at a construction site, not an earthquake as some people might have thought, according to a spokesman for the Eastchester police. The spokesman, Sgt. Joseph Schembri, said yesterday that the noise and vibration that occurred about 8:20 A.M. Saturday in Yonkers, Arsdley and Eastchester was a result of blasting at a construction site here. The sound and sensation from the blasting prompted at least two dozen people to telephone local agencies and radio stations to report what they thought was an earthquake.

The Internal Revenue Service, contending that at least 1.1 million Americans have failed to provide their financial institutions with accurate Social Security numbers, has begun a tough enforcement program to combat the problem. The I.R.S. believes that problem of inaccurate or missing numbers reflects, at least partly, attempts by individuals to underreport dividend and interest income. Some tax experts say that 1.1 million is a conservative figure and that the real number is many times that. Whatever the magnitude of the problem, the I.R.S. is fighting back. According to top tax accountants, the agency recently sent letters to 23,000 financial institutions - banks, savings and loan associations, credit unions and brokerages - informing them that in at least 50 instances each, customers had failed to provide the financial institution with a Social Security number or had provided an incorrect one.

On Dec. 31, 1987, the last remnants of a measurement system that used an astronomical device in Greenwich, England, as a reference for determining longitudes will be abolished. The traditional system, which defined latitude in terms of the poles and calculated time according to the earth's rotation, is not accurate enough to suit the needs of modern science. New techniques, based on ''landmarks'' in the sky, have made it possible to measure variations in the earth's spin, shape and geography with far greater precision than before. Some are already in use by agencies like the National Geodetic Survey of the United States. Sailors navigating the seas and travelers setting their watches will notice no difference when the new systems go into effect, for the bases of measurement will conform as closely as possible to the existing ones.

More than 50 detectives canvassed homes yesterday in the Queens neighborhood where a black man was struck and killed by a car while he and two other black men tried to flee a gang of whites who had attacked them. A police spokesman, Officer James Coleman, said the investigation was ''progressing.'' But he said the detectives had not identified the assailants, believed to number from 9 to 12. Office Coleman said the police believed the attackers, who beat the black men with baseball bats and sticks as they left a pizza parlor on Cross Bay Boulevard in Howard Beach, live in the neighborhood.

The District Attorney here, after charging two former police officers with torturing a suspect, has begun a major investigation into the use of excessive force by the entire Huntington Park Police Department. Ira Reiner, the Los Angeles District Attorney, said the two former Huntington Park police officers were ''thugs'' who tortured a juvenile suspect with a stun gun Nov. 30. The city of Huntington Park, roughly three square miles in size, is in southeast Los Angeles County, between downtown Los Angeles and Watts. It has 54,000 residents, 85 percent of whom are of Hispanic descent. The department would not say how many Hispanic officers are on the 60-member force.
* Judy Cacciola, Patricia Deneroff, Jean Fitzgerald and Debra Goldstein have been named senior vice presidents at Ogilvy & Mather, New York.

A project to attach radio collars to Florida panthers is scheduled to resume next month despite criticism from some environmentalists that the program poses too much risk to the endangered animals. At one time, hundreds of panthers -or cougars, or pumas, or catamounts, depending on what they were called locally - roamed the southeastern United States, but excessive hunting and land clearing caused their habitat to dwindle to the Everglades of southwest Florida. Only about 30 panthers are thought to remain.

The General Motors Corporation's apparent determination to cut production to meet its sagging sales rate may entail as much danger for its current and future profitability as the sales incentives the company has renounced, auto analysts contend. G. M. said last week that it would temporarily close eight plants and lay off 24,200 workers to cut output in an effort to bring its inventories more in line with sales. The cutbacks came on top of earlier moves to trim production in the face of declining sales. But analysts said late last week that the company's share of the American car market has fallen so low in the wake of the 2.9 percent financing campaign of last fall, that G. M. is in danger of falling below its break-even point if it actually attempts to match production to sales. 33% Share Not Enough ''G. M. is out there with a 33 percent share of the North American market,'' said Douglas K. Laughlin, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. ''They can't make break-even producing at a 33 percent rate.''

THERE is sometimes an uncomfortable pull between body and mind in Bebe Miller's choreography. Just as one wonders why she is doing what she is doing, however, a moment of such inherent rightness comes along that one accepts the inevitability of it all. But there is no such dichotomy in ''Two,'' a new duet created by Ms. Miller and Ralph Lemon that was performed by the two on Friday night at Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater. Heart, mind and acute physicality come together in what promises to be one of the most powerful dances of the year.

QUESTION: In the days when the Giants were in New York and the Dodgers were in Brooklyn, how many home runs did Willie Mays hit as a visiting player at Ebbets Field? In the six seasons he had a chance to play at Ebbets Field before the Giants and the Dodgers moved to California in 1958, Mays hit more homers in Brooklyn than he hit in 16 years as a visiting player in Los Angeles. Mays's 23 homers in Los Angeles consisted of 12 at the Coliseum in the four years from 1958-61, and 11 in 12 years at Dodger Stadium. But his 28 homers in Brooklyn represented 30 percent of the 93 homers he hit on the road for the New York Giants from 1951-57.

Carl W. Nichols and Raymond J. Petersen, both former chairmen of the American Advertising Federation, have been elected to its Advertising Hall of Fame along with the late Arthur C. Nielsen Sr., founder of the A. C. Nielsen Company, and the late Robert W. Woodruff, longtime head of Coca-Cola. Mr. Nichols and Mr. Petersen are rarities.

At Temple Hillel in North Woodmere, L.I., yesterday Lori Marcia Fierstein, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sam Fierstein of Elmhurst, Queens, was married to Michael Tutelman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Tutelman of Oldsmar, Fla. Rabbi Maurice Aronoff officiated.

The Transamerica Occidental Life Insurance Company will sell its group life and health operations to the Provident Life and Accident Insurance Company in a transaction valued at $275 million, the two companies announced Friday. Provident, based in Chattanooga, Tenn., said it would purchase Transamerica Occidental's interest in group life and health insurance, including its partnership stake in a venture the two companies have with a third concern, American Healthcare Plans.

For the first time in 15 years, the Kansas City Chiefs will be spending the holiday season with more than just family and friends. A 24-19 victory over the Pittsburgh Steelers yesterday, the final Sunday of the National Football League season, put them into the American Football Conference wild-card game next Sunday. With the exception of New Orleans, which has never been in the playoffs in its 20 seasons, the Chiefs are the only N.F.L. team that has not participated in postseason play since 1971. The Chiefs' opponent, however, will not be determined until tonight, when the New England Patriots play the Miami Dolphins in the final game of the regular season and the Dolphins' last game in the Orange Bowl.

THE continuing celebration of the lyrics of Lorenz Hart at Michael's Pub, 211 East 55th Street, has taken a new and interesting direction with the appearance of the veteran jazz singer Mark Murphy. Mr. Murphy, who settled into the club for a three-week engagement on Tuesday, is a stubborn iconoclast who projects the risky sense of discovering for the first time the musical components and the lyrical essence of a song in the process of singing it. At Tuesday's opening-night show, Mr. Murphy, adeptly supported by the house quartet, turned a number of familiar songs into spontaneous vocal safaris that yielded idiosyncratic, sometimes exhilarating insights.

In its response to charges by the Federal Communications Commission of obscenity and indecency on a morning radio show, Infinity Broadcasting Corporation has asserted that the Howard Stern Show is humor and that complaints about it are part of a crusade. The F.C.C.'s charges, made in a letter 30 days ago, marked the commission's first against a commercial station on the obscenity issue in eight years. Similar letters were recently sent to two public broadcasting organizations in California. Infinity's response is to be filed late today in Washington. The company, a Manhattan-based owner of 11 radio stations around the country, was ordered by the federal agency to respond to listeners' complaints.

An estimated 5,000 people a day have been jamming a small Chicago church to see a painting of the Virgin Mary that has streaks of moisture streaming from the eyes and hands. Braving the wintry weather, believers and the curious alike patiently wait on long lines for a glimpse of the ''weeping Virgin'' behind the altar of the St. Nicholas Albanian Orthodox Church on the city's Northwest Side. The church, one of the smallest in Chicago, has had visitors from as far away as Sri Lanka and Pakistan ever since the parish priest, the Rev. Philip Koufos, first noticed moisture on the icon on Dec. 6. That date is the Feast Day of St. Nicholas, the church's patron saint.

Nearly 30 years have passed since the Dodgers abandoned Ebbets Field for Los Angeles, and Brooklyn has never stopped pining for a team of its own. That may explain the enthusiasm of borough politicians for a dubious plan to build a $58 million stadium for minor-league baseball.

Racz & Dessimoz Associates, specializing in boating, camera, hi-fi, video, wine and toy advertising, is going to be promoting television sets for Kawasho International (U.S.A.) with a budget of between $3 million and $4 million, starting Jan. 1. There was no previous agency.

Senators Daniel K. Inouye, left, of Hawaii, head of special Senate committee to investigate Iran arms affair, conferring with Warren B. Rudman of New Hampshire, the ranking Republican on the panel, before a televised interview yesterday in Washington. (AP)

AS the lead singer of Bronski Beat, and now with his new band the Communards, Jimmy Somerville has one overriding theme: that homosexual love is legitimate and romantic. ''Our love is like forbidden fruit,'' he sang Wedneday at the Ritz.

Chadian guerrillas have badly mauled a Libyan armored column, killing at least 100 Libyan soldiers in fierce fighting in the mountains of northern Chad, diplomatic sources said today. The Chadian Government reported today that the guerrillas killed 400 Libyans, destroyed 3 tanks and 14 armored personnel carriers, and captured 4 armored personnel carriers with their Libyan crews. The Government said one guerrilla was killed and three were wounded. In this capital, 400 miles south of the fighting, it was impossible to verify these reports. Attack on Rebel Strongholds The most recent fighting is reported to have started Saturday when, after extensive aerial bombardment, three Libyan columns of about 700 soldiers apiece attacked four mountain strongholds of guerrillas loyal to a northern chief and former President of Chad, Goukouni Oueddei.

Roughly half the young lawyers surveyed around the nation five months ago disagreed with President Reagan's contention that the Sandinista Government in Nicaragua is a threat to American national security. The 1,800 members of the American Bar Association, 35 years of age and younger, responded to a questionnaire published in July, long before the public learned that insurgents' efforts against the Sandinistas were being financed with proceeds from secret sales of arms to Iran.

When Harvey Saligman, the chairman of Interco, announced an agreement last week to buy the Lane furniture company, he completed a corporate shopping spree. Lane is the third acquisition that Mr. Saligman, 48, has made in the last four months for Interco, the St. Louis-based furniture, footwear and retail company whose roster of brand names includes Florsheim Shoes and Broyhill furniture. In September, Interco acquired Converse, the athletic shoe company, in a $145 million deal, and the next month, it purchased Highland House, a furniture manufacturer in Lenore, N.C., for an undisclosed amount.

After 21 seasons, the Miami Dolphins play in the Orange Bowl for the final time tonight. Their next home game is Aug. 16, 1987, when they meet Chicago in an exhibition at Dolphin Stadium, a 73,000-seat park being built with all the luxuries and conveniences by the team's owner, Joe Robbie, on his 432 acres near the line that separates Dade and Broward Counties to the north. The Dolphins leave without formal goodbyes. No ceremonies have been scheduled for tonight's game, against New England - an appropriate void, given the frequently heated nature of the squabbles between Robbie and the city over the lack of luxury boxes at the municipally owned stadium and its generally sad appearance.

The Nicaraguan armed forces have just completed three days of large-scale military maneuvers in this remote region bordering Honduras, From the Nicaraguan briefings and the way the exercise was conducted, it was clear the Sandinistas wanted to demonstrate that although their army has shortcomings, it is rapidly improving and capable of fighting more than a counterinsurgency war against the contras in the forested mountains of Nicaragua. In the largest Sandinista maneuvers ever held in the region, a total of 6,500 Nicaraguan soldiers and airmen conducted a mock war with live ammunition. Military attaches accredited to Nicaragua and invited members of the press were trucked to the area to observe the last day of the exercise. Somotillo is in Chinandega Department in northwest Nicaragua, 155 miles from Managua, the capital. The Pan-American Highway passes from Honduras into Nicaragua over a bridge at Somotillo, but the bridge is down and the border is closed at that point.

Sylvester Garrett has spent a lifetime finding common ground between adversaries. He has resolved labor disputes involving shipbuilders, teachers, pilots, bus drivers, postal employees and iron and steel workers, among others. Now, Mr. Garrett, who is 75 years old, has been called in to mediate in the labor dispute between the USX Corporation and the United Steelworkers union. The dispute is nearly five months old and is the longest work stoppage in the history of the American steel industry.

The Government of Singapore has announced that it would introduce legislation enabling the country's hospitals to remove the kidneys of victims of fatal accidents who have not previously indicated they do not wish to be organ donors. The legislation, the Human Organ Transplant Bill, has been planned to meet an urgent need for kidney transplants, according to the Singapore Ministry of Health.

A rare coincidence in the relationships between the Sun, the Moon and the Earth next week will produce extreme tides that could increase the threat of coastal flooding, according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. The tidal extremes, both high and low, are expected from Sunday to Jan. 4.
Participants in a candlelight vigil and march yesterday at Ninth Avenue and 57th Street.

Pedro Gil, a 50-year-old electrician with two grown sons, sat by the Christmas tree in the living room of his modest red-tile-roofed home here today, talking about the three and a half years he spent as a combat adviser to rebel soldiers in southern Nicaragua. He shifted on the couch and pulled up his shirt to show a three-inch welt where he said he had been grazed by a Nicaraguan Government soldier's bullet. He had bled a lot, he said, but he kept firing his American-made M-16 rifle on full automatic. A moment earlier, another bullet had knocked him off his feet, he said, but had lodged in an ammunition pouch on his thigh. When the shooting stopped, Mr. Gil said, 11 Government soldiers lay dead.
