He did not know if he had shot any of them, he said, but he had fired seven magazines of 30 shots each, 210 rounds altogether.

IF Jack Morris is back in Detroit, can Lance Parrish be far behind? Yes, Tom Reich, Parrish's agent, said yesterday, he can be, is and will continue to be. ''Lance Parrish is not going back to Detroit,'' Reich said emphatically. ''He'll be in another uniform next year. We talked about it over the weekend and he doesn't like any part of the way he's treated and he's not going back.''

Six months after having jumped off a 30-foot bridge after dropping out of a race, Kathy Ormbsy says her suicide attempt was not planned. ''I do think God wants us to do our best,'' she said in an article in today's edition of The Charlotte Observer. ''But I don't think he wants us to be obsessed with that or to do it in such a way that it doesn't leave time for ourselves to enjoy life.''

Some people contribute to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund instead of buying gifts for friends and relatives. ''This is my Christmas gift to my family,'' said Penelope Wisner of Geyserville, Calif., in giving $250 to the fund's 75th annual appeal. ''Every year I have contributed to the Neediest Cases Fund in lieu of giving presents to friends because this is the best present of all,'' said Harry Handler of Brooklyn, who sent a check for $150. His gift this year honors his wife, Cindy.

The first super final of the Greater New York Bridge Association was played Saturday night at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan. Instead of, as is customary, qualifying about half of the original field for the final, only pairs who had topped their sections during the afternoon were able to advance. The winners of the super final, whose excitement was heightened by the use of barometer scoring, and therefore results round by round, were Steve Adumkin and Linda Danas, both of Manhattan.
Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday Durable Goods OrdersNovember Wednesday None Thursday None Friday None

Almost imperceptibly, below the blank stone gaze of Table Mountain, a train pulls out of Cape Town every other day, offering its passengers a luxury from the past that seems to contrast with the sadnesses of the present in the land it traverses. For the last 40 years the Blue Train, successor to older African expresses that once spanned the empire of Cecil John Rhodes, has made its way between Cape Town and Johannesburg, a distance of 895 miles. A plane takes roughly an hour and 50 minutes to make the journey. The Blue Train, leisurely and matronly, takes a day, an express defined more by the pace of slower trains on the route than by any great proclivity for speed.

One pilot was killed and a second escaped uninjured yesterday when their small, single-engine airplanes collided 300 feet over Kingston-Ulster Airport in upstate New York, the police and the airport manager said. The accident occurred at 10:05 A.M. as an airplane taking off struck the underside of a second aircraft that was landing.

Cohabitation, the Census Bureau finds, continues to increase. Some 2.2 million Americans now are counted as ''persons of the opposite sex sharing living quarters'' - and still no one knows what to call them.

When Mikhail S. Gorbachev called for more openness in Soviet society and signaled greater freedom for the arts, the response was heady. Poets and playwrights scrambled to assault bureaucratism, publishers searched for novels to rehabilitate, and film makers purged the old-guard leadership of their union and scoured the censors' shelves for movies to release. Newspapers printed candid exposes of national ills, and the staid state television weighed in with daring interviews. The clamor to climb on the bandwagon now generates almost daily sensations. A recent exhibition entitled ''Masters of Culture for Peace,'' the sort that used to be patronized only by delegations of aspiring Communists, became the hot running event in town with hard-rock concerts, spontaneous debates and multimedia happenings.

''THE Christmas Revels,'' an always merry production that mixes music and dance, harking back to ancient solstice celebrations, returned for its annual visit to the Symphony Space this weekend. The new edition had a French theme - incorporating church music, medieval and Renaissance carols as well as stately dances described in a well-known 16th-century treatise by the French clergyman Thoinot Arbeau. The rest of the program, on Saturday afternoon, retained the old British mummers' plays and ritual country dances related to the death of winter and to rebirth that are at the core of every ''Revels'' show. The ingenuity with which this framework is stretched and adapted to other national Yuletide customs from year to year constitutes one of the many delights of the ''Revels.''

Surgeons implanted an artificial heart into an unidentified patient over the weekend and were searching for a human heart donor, a hospital spokesman said today. It was the 10th artificial heart to be implanted at Presbyterian-University Hospital in Pittsburgh as a temporary, lifesaving device. The Jarvik-70 heart, a scaled-down version of the Jarvik-7, was implanted in a six-hour procedure, said the spokesman, Chris Shirer, who added that the patient was in critical condition.

Two strong earthquakes shook the city of Mamassani in the southern Iranian province of Fars early today and damaged at least 80 houses, Iran's official press agency reported. There were no immediate reports of casualties. Last summer, six people were killed and 300 homes damaged in an earthquake in Mamassani, the agency said.

Benjamin Colarossi, who has been president and chief executive officer since March of Cato Johnson/Y&R, a Young & Rubicam division with $32 million in billings, is leaving to do something else. Mr. Colarossi, who came up on the creative side of the agency business, was formerly president of Ross Roy/ Colarossi Griswold.

Faced with the desperate need to start winning with the playoffs looming, the Jets instead collapsed offensively and defensively today, ending the regular season with their fifth straight loss. The beneficiaries of the collapse were the Bengals, whose 52-21 victory produced the highest number of net yards, 621, ever generated against the Jets, whose late-season collapse must rank with the great folds in National Football League history. The Jets weren't that concerned with winning today. They just wanted to look good. They did neither.

THERE is ample confusion in the conception of James Simpson's production of ''The Merchant of Venice,'' but there should be no mistaking the locale. The evening at the Classic Stage Company begins with a gondola, or rather, with a raft standing in for a gondola. Propelling the craft are Antonio's cronies, Salerio and Solanio, in this production a pair of Venetian clowns. The gondola and gondoliers reappear with such frequency that the play begins to resemble a Grand Canal version of ''Big River.'' The vessel misses only the courtroom scene, but is poled on stage for the climax as the characters - five on a raft - embark, presumably for calmer dramatic waters. As for the play, it sinks. Mr. Simpson's directorial style is eccentrically eclectic, veering from mock Peter Brook (a rug, but no magic in the carpet) to Bunraku, as represented by shrouded stagehands who scurry along at a stoop in the vaudeville manner of Rowan Atkinson. They shift chairs and tables, occasionally give a prod to a recalcitrant actor and earn unintentional laughter. There is nothing else Oriental about the production, unless one includes the odd twangs that emerge sporadically from a small combo perched over the stage.

Americans owe Uncle Sam some $250 billion under various Federal loan programs. Selling those loans to private investors is one of Washington's new tricks for reducing the budget deficit. The Government gets cash quickly and painlessly; the investor gets a discounted loan that should eventually pay off at face value and pays interest in the meantime. While there is some merit to this undertaking, it is poor deficit-reduction strategy.

The Department of Education reported today that college enrollments rose this fall instead of dropping. Colleges have been preparing for several years for a sharp drop in enrollments as a result of a steady decline in the number of people in the age group that customarily attends college.

International Report Oil prices will rise, but not to OPEC's stated target of $18 a barrel, many U.S. oil specialists said in assessing the new accord on production. The planned cutbacks during the first half of 1987 are too ''modest'' to support that price, they said. [ Page D1. ]

To the Editor: Mortimer J. Adler tried eloquently (''Schooling Is Not Education,'' Op-Ed, Dec. 2) but failed to improve on Mark Twain's one-line admonition, ''Don't let school interfere with your education.'' JOHN WEINER White Plains, Dec. 2, 1986

Jimmy Rodgers, the Boston Celtics' director of player personnel and an assistant coach, was at the Rockford (Ill.) Metro Centre Saturday night, the final stop of an eight-day scouting trip in which he saw 11 of the 12 Continental Basketball Association teams play. But instead of watching the Rockford Lightning defeat the Savannah Spirits, Rodgers could have been coaching the Celtics in the closing minutes of their 122-100 loss to the Bucks at the Milwaukee Arena, about 100 miles away. With 7 minutes 14 seconds remaining in the final quarter, both Coach K. C. Jones and Chris Ford, his other assistant, were ejected from the game for arguing with the officials.

John Z. DeLorean, the embattled automobile entrepreneur, said this weekend that he had raised $20 million to build a new car, a $100,000 sports car to be designed by a West German designer. The announcement follows Mr. DeLorean's acquittal last week of charges that he had embezzled $8.5 million from investors in his previous enterprise. In that venture, Mr. DeLorean made a stainless-steel sports car with gull-wing doors, the DMC-12, at a plant in Northern Ireland in 1981 and 1982.

High unemployment and falling wages were the factors most responsible for the 7 million increase in the number of poor Americans since 1979, not the rise of single-parent households, a Congressional study says. The report by the staff of the Joint Economic Committee challenges the view held by some supporters of the Reagan Administration that an increase in teen-age pregnancies and single-parent families has accounted for much of the decade's rise in poverty.

The wave of student protests in Chinese cities in the last two weeks finds its roots in a tradition of activism, marked by street demonstrations, that ranks among modern China's most venerated forces for social change. In both style and timing, though not in stated motivation, the current protests can be traced back 51 years to a December in which students took to icy streets in Beijing and other cities to protest the spread of Japanese power. The advancing armies, the students contended, directly threatened their nation's independence. Today, according to reports from China, some of the issues that have caused student demonstrations in at least seven provinces are seemingly mundane: bad food and lighting in universities, rising school fees in one case, complaints about bureaucracy.

ABC, NBC and CBS, locked in a tight evening news race, are competing intensely for the services of Diane Sawyer, the ''60 Minutes'' correspondent, whose contract with CBS News expires next week. Ms. Sawyer has been in negotiation with CBS for weeks, and has indicated to the network that she may leave for either NBC or ABC. The three networks are vying for her with assorted packages involving more money, more air time and the potential of an anchor role.

Just like their constituents, many members of Congress send out Christmas cards each year decorated with pictures of their families. Although no Government agency keeps definitive records, the 1986 population prize for such holiday messages would appear to go to Rep-resentative Howard C. Nielson, Republican of Utah, whose card, signed ''Howard, Julie & Family,'' shows a total of 36 people, ranging from the 62-year-old Congresman down to five babes in arms.

Representatives of Governor Cuomo and of the State Senate today supported a temporary plan that would put off for six months a decision on how to pay for rebuilding New York City's mass transit system and would freeze fares. But the Assembly Speaker, Stanley Fink, and officials of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority expressed reservations about the proposal, intended as a way out of a deadlocked special session of the Legislature. They said the temporary plan might be too uncertain for the M.T.A. to be able to go ahead with its rebuilding program on schedule.

To the Editor: Dr. David Baltimore and Dr. Sheldon M. Wolff, chairmen of the Committee on a National Strategy for AIDS, Institute of Medicine and National Academy of Sciences, take issue ( letter, Nov. 29) with ''Don't Panic Yet, Over AIDS'' (editorial, Nov. 7) for overemphasizing prevention focused on traditional risk groups, drug addicts in particular. They believe this is an antiquated approach to the acquired immune deficiency syndrome epidemic. The writers point to heterosexual transmission as a reason for massive public-health education.

On the Upper West Side, they collected Dutch tea biscuits and artichoke hearts. In Chelsea, macaroni and cheese and V-8 vegetable juice. In Englewood, N.J., powdered milk and tuna fish. And when the first day of winter -the shortest, darkest day of the year -neared an end, more than 1,000 of them marched through the heart of Manhattan in a candlelight vigil for the New York region's homeless and hungry.

To the Editor: In your front-page article (Dec. 1) on dissent in the Roman Catholic Church, various United States bishops claim that dissatisfaction over the disciplining of Archbishop Raymond G. Hunthausen of Seattle has been magnified by the press. For example, Archbishop Roger M. Mahony of Los Angeles says only a small fraction of the three million Catholics in his archdiocese have ''voiced concern.'' That may be so in Los Angeles, but as a priest of the Archdiocese of Seattle, I can attest it is not the case here. In practically every gathering of priests - no matter how informal -the issue inevitably surfaces. Lay people, especially our most committed church workers, continue to ask questions. In Seattle the issue will not simply go away.

The marriage of Jan Ellen Cornell, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Albert Cornell of New York and Centerport, L.I., to Matt Neuman, a son of Estelle Neuman of Miami and the late Milton Neuman, took place yesterday. Rabbi Judah Nadich officiated at the Manhattan home of the bride's parents.

Julie Ellen Hyman, a third-year medical student at the University of Pennsylvania, and Dr. Aron David Wahrman, a resident in surgery at the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania, were married yesterday at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I. The bridegroom's father, Cantor Henry Wahrman, and Rabbi Mordecai Rubin performed the ceremony.

It is called the Friday syndrome. And, last Friday, just as was the case for several weeks running, traders in the stock market hunkered down as they approached a weekend, fearing the market chaos that could ensue if the Government dropped the next shoe in the ongoing Ivan F. Boesky insider trading scandal. From midday on Thursday to the close of trading on Friday, rumors that the Government would announce new indictments or revelations of further investigations after the close of trading swirled around the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, depressing stock prices of companies already in the takeover spotlight, thus reflecting a new-found caution on Wall Street. 'Triple Witching' in Shadow And though the presence of the ''triple-witching hour'' in related stock options and futures last Friday caused a surge in prices at the close of trading, traders contended that the shadow of another Boesky-type case was paramount on everyone's minds throughout the day.

It is not even a subway - only 150 yards or so are enclosed in a tunnel. But that did not prevent the Staten Island Rapid Transit system from doing what subways in New York seem destined to do: fall apart. The bridge carrying the railroad's two tracks over Bay Street in Clifton, having moved six and a half inches while no one was looking, is now braced with timber, awaiting permanent repairs. Floods at Richmond Valley sometimes cover the third rail, knocking out service.

Travelers during these busiest flying days of the year understand that the combination of winter weather and holiday crowds often means late departures. But what explains the delays that have become almost routine at big airports - delays that waste some 2,000 hours of airliner time a day, all year round? The 25 percent increase in late flights this year is one sign that the deregulated airline industry flourishes. Total traffic has mushroomed 60 percent since a 1978 law allowed airlines to enter new markets and cut fares. But Washington has failed to manage existing air traffic capacity efficiently, let alone expand it. Fundamental changes are needed to break the institutional gridlock.

November new product introductions into supermarket and drug stores was 230, according to the DFS Dorland New Products News. That was an increase from the 225 in the same month last year. That brings the total for the first 11 months of the year to 2,327, compared with 2,031 in the 1985 period.

Uncertain that their fuel supply would last and suffering fatigue after a bruising week of nonstop flight, the crew of the experimental plane Voyager had clear weather today as they neared their craft's goal: being the first to fly around the world without stopping for fuel. With more than 21,373 miles behind them, the pilots, Richard G. Rutan and Jeana Yeager, were so tired at times that they could not provide accurate information to the mission's controllers, said the designer of the plane, Burt Rutan. The craft's fuel gauge was not giving accurate readings, opening the possibility that headwinds might leave the plane with ''barely enough to glide back to Edwards with the engine out of gas,'' said Mr. Rutan, who is the pilot's brother.

* Remember Clifford Allen? He's the 6-foot-10-inch center who wound up as yet another unlikely prospect for Coach Jerry Tarkanian's Nevada-Las Vegas basketball team. The 18-year-old Allen, though regarded as one of the best school-age pivot men in California, has been in so much trouble for most of his life that he's managed to play only one high school game - a tournament loss last February in which he scored 32 points and grabbed 18 rebounds for the El Paso de Robles juvenile-detention center in Paso Robles.

Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew said today that a prolonged crisis over the Iran arms deals could throw American foreign policy into confusion just as the Reagan Administration had begun to give it coherence. Mr. Lee, one of Washington's strongest supporters and oldest friends in Asia, was speaking in an interview at his official residence here on a range of topics from the future of Singapore's entrepreneurs to the promising role of China and the limited prospects for the Soviet Union in a coming ''Pacific century.'' He predicted that in the next 100 years, ''the Pacific is where all the action will be: a focal area of great advance, as the Atlantic was in the 19th and 20th centuries.'' Asked about regional perceptions of the United States, Mr. Lee, 63 years old, who has governed Singapore since it first achieved self-rule in 1959, said the projection of a clearly defined American policy to this region had been ''getting much better under six years of President Reagan, until this Iranian arms deal and the contribution from it to Nicaraguan contras.''

UNFORTUNATELY for the Jets, the National Football League constitution forbids a team from trading a playoff berth. But now that the Jets have limped into the Super Bowl XXI tournament on a five-game losing streak for a 10-6 record, they would be better off trading their playoff berth to the Seattle Seahawks, who didn't qualify even though they finished at 10-6 with a five-game winning streak. The Jets' price would be an offense to be named later. Without a word or a glance, the Jets filed into their locker room at Riverfront Stadium after yesterday's 52-21 rout by the Cincinnati Bengals, but they should have stumbled in backwards. That's how they got into the playoffs.

Eight Latin American Governments have announced that the Secretaries General of the United Nations and the Organization of American States had agreed to join them in a new initiative aimed at reviving peace negotiations in Central America. A special delegation is expected to visit the capitals of Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras, Nicaragua and Costa Rica in January in the hope of persuading the five Central American Governments to return to the bargaining table. The delegation will include the heads of the two international organizations and the foreign ministers of the eight countries organizing the effort.

Craig Hall, a real estate syndicator in Dallas, said that his company, the Hall Financial Group, had completed restructuring of $84 million in loans with its second-largest savings and loan lender, Beverly Hills Savings. The renegotiated agreement ended a year of discussions with Beverly Hills and nearly completed a previously announced $550 million debt restructuring plan begun in December 1985. The company, which has been plagued with mortgage problems in the last year, struck a similar deal on Nov. 25, modifying $157 million in debt with its largest lender, Westwood Savings of Los Angeles.

Hulan E. Jack, the Harlem politician who in 1953 became the first black Borough President of Manhattan but lost office after a conflict-of-interest scandal, died Friday night at St. Luke's Hospital. Mr. Jack, who would have been 80 years old on Dec. 29, was a 45-year resident of West 110th Street. Mr. Jack, a native of the West Indies, rose to the highest administrative political office then held by a black in the United States. As a politician, he came to symbolize for many blacks an important milestone in a long struggle for political and social equality. His widening influence in the Manhattan Democratic organization earned him election to the State Assembly in 1940. Halfway into his seventh term, in 1953, he resigned after being elected to the borough presidency, to which he was re-elected for a second four-year term in 1957.

The Giants spent Sunday like most people in most lines of work. They took it easy or spent time with their families or watched football on television or visited friends or any combination of the above. Their glorious regular season ended here Saturday with a 55-24 victory over the Green Bay Packers. Because their 14-2 record won the division title, they have a week off before their first playoff game Jan. 3 or 4.

BOOKISH SATISFACTION The modern bookstore, with its here-today best sellers and reprints, often conveys the mood of a flighty society. The browser in search of literary depth may find satisfaction at the Antiquarian Booksellers' Center in the lobby of the Associated Press building, 50 Rockefeller Plaza. This ground-floor store has 2,000 items on its shelves, including rare books, maps, prints and autograph material. Its inventory always changes because the center, a cooperative venture, receives its stock from its members, who are affiliated with the Antiquarian Booksellers' Association of America.

The Oyster Creek nuclear power plant was restarted yesterday after an extended shutdown prompted by concern over corrosion that had left the main containment wall thinner than expected, officials said. The 650-megawatt plant, which has been out of service since it was shut in April for refueling and routine maintenance, is expected to return to full power within 7 to 10 days, said a spokesman for General Public Utilities, Sandy Polon.

A dispatch on Dec. 9 from Sighet, Rumania, the birthplace of Elie Wiesel, misstated the place and arrangements for his Nobel Peace Prize award. The prize, conferred by the Norwegian Parliament, is always presented in Oslo. It was formally given to Mr. Wiesel on Dec. 10 by the chairman of Parliament's Nobel committee, in the presence of King Olav V of Norway.

An article in Business Day on Dec. 6 about a gathering of the Securities Industry Association misattributed a remark about the Glass-Steagall Act, which generally prohibits commercial banks from underwriting most corporate securities. The comment, calling the act outdated, was made by John H. Goldsmith, chairman and chief executive of Prescott, Ball & Turben Inc., not by John W. Bachmann, the association's new chairman.

International A3-20 China lashed out at protesters, accusing them of trying to ''disrupt stability and unity'' and ''derange production and social order.'' As many as 50,000 protesters flooded a Shanghai square. Page A1 A tradition of activism in China ranks among the most venerated forces for social change. In both style and timing, current protests can be traced to a similar outbreak 51 years ago.

Gasoline prices remained virtually unchanged from two weeks ago, as retailers battled it out to win over motorists with lower prices, an industry analyst said today. ''Street competition is so hot, in many cases a wholesale increase cannot get passed through to the consumer,'' said Trilby Lundberg, publisher of a twice-monthly nationwide survey of prices at 15,000 gas stations.

A CAUTIOUS Cyndi Lauper performed Friday at Madison Square Garden. Visually, she was the same madcap, flamboyant, volatile performer whose 1983 debut album, ''She's So Unusual,'' made her one of the major stars of the 1980's. She wore layers of clothes - a black velvet cape, a red tutu, a puffy-sleeved flowered top, antique lingerie with suspenders - and went through a repertory theater's-worth of facial expressions. Vocally, she delivered shouts, sighs, yelps and hiccups while in constant motion on stage.

Greyhound Lines released a statement Friday that said the Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions, which represents about 6,300 bus drivers and other employees, tentatively agreed to extend the current contract through March 18, assuring passengers that buses would continue to run during the holiday travel season.

THE cultivation of violin playing has flourished astonishingly in postwar Japan, as we are often reminded by the presence on the musical scene of so many distinguished Japanese soloists and orchestral musicians. We hear less frequently the body of music that has grown up with and around this phenomenon, a distinctive and often fascinating tradition of violin writing. It was impressively sampled by Koichiro Harada, the founder and until 1981 the first violinist of the Tokyo String Quartet, Saturday afternoon at the Asia Society.

BASKETBALL SAN ANTONIO SPURS VS. KNICKS, at Madison Square Garden, 7:30 P.M. (TV -MSG, 7 P.M. Radio - WPAT 930, 7:20 P.M.) FOOTBALL NEW ENGLAND PATRIOTS VS. DOLPHINS, at Miami, 9 P.M. (TV - Channel 7, 9 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 8:50 P.M.) OTHER EVENTS COLLEGE BASKETBALL: Morgan State at Seton Hall, 8 P.M. (Radio - WSOU-FM 89.5, 7:30 P.M.); Columbia at Delaware (Radio - WKCR-FM 89.9, 8 P.M.) HARNESS RACING: Yonkers, 8 P.M. THOROUGHBRED RACING: Aqueduct, 12:30 P.M. (TV - SportsChannel, 6:15 P.M. and 11:15 P.M.)

Indian and Pakistani officials reached an agreement today to step up coordination of their border security forces to prevent Sikh extremists from using Pakistan territory as a base for attacks in India. The agreement, reached after two days of talks, was highly limited in scope, but it nonetheless marked the first time in a year that the two nations had found common ground on any steps to reduce tensions. Relations had seriously worsened in recent months as Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India repeatedly charged that Pakistan was aiding Sikh militants. A few weeks ago, he said that India could easily send its troops into Pakistan to wipe out supposed extremist ''training camps,'' but that it had not done so because it would violate international law.

Doug Flutie threw two touchdown passes in his debut as a starter for the Chicago Bears today, and Walter Payton tied the National Football League of 106 career rushing touchdowns in a 24-10 defeat of Dallas that gave the Cowboys their first losing season in 22 years. Chicago set a record for fewest points allowed in a 16-game season with 187, breaking Pittsburgh's mark of 195 set in 1978. Payton tied Jim Brown's record for rushing touchdowns on a 1-yard plunge in the first period. The Bears, who won the National Conference Central Division title, finished the regular season with a 14-2 record. The Cowboys fell to 7-9, their worst record since they were 5-8-1 in 1964. It was Chicago's seventh consecutive victory.

RECENTLY, the R. T. French Company of One Mustard Street in Rochester helped add spice to the life of Richard D. Thomson, president of Rumrill-Hoyt in that city, by slipping his agency a number of assignments. Although for security reasons the jobs cannot be identified at this time, Mr. Thomson in his bosom knows what they are and the knowledge warms and cheers him in those chilly northern climes. What it means is that a well-known corporate neighbor is aware of the fact that Rumrill-Hoyt, once a firmly entrenched industrial agency (now called business-to-business), has embraced a consumer goods orientation. And that's where Mr. Thomson's career roots are.

Only the playoffs will tell whether the defending Super Bowl champions can repeat, but one thing is already certain: The Chicago Bears are the gabbiest team in the land. According to statistics compiled by the National Football League, various players, coaches and officials of the 28 clubs participate in 118 regularly scheduled radio and television programs each week. Of that total, 25 are accounted for by the garrulous Bears, who have more than twice as many as their main chitchat rivals - the Washington Redskins, not surprisingly. In the nation's capital, where talk is the No. 1 pastime, the Redskins have a dozen weekly shows. (By contrast, the Giants and the Jets, who play across the river from the world's media capital, account for only four between them: two by Coach Bill Parcells of the Giants, one by his veteran linebacker, Harry Carson, and one by the Jets' public relations director, Frank Ramos.) The N.F.L. chitchat stats actually understate the league's penetration of the nation's airways, since multiple appearances, such as a radio report carried five days a week, are counted as a single program. In achieving their tongue-wagging supremacy, which gives new meaning to the nickname Windy City, the Bears demonstrate both vocal strength and depth. Coach Mike Ditka, for example, has four separate programs, and the team's broadcast roster boasts 13 players, although one is notably absent. That's William Perry, who apparently concentrates more on what goes into his mouth than on what comes out.

The Executive Life Insurance Company, whose guaranteed investment contracts have been widely used to back issues of taxable bonds offered by various local government authorities, received a medium-grade claims-paying rating of A-3 late last week from Moody's Investors Service Inc. The Moody's rating, which is far lower than the AAA claims- paying rating assigned by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, caused yields of many bonds backed by Executive Life contracts to rise about 15 hundredths of a percentage point, according to analysts at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.

Tony McKegney stomped at the referee. Ron Greschner argued through the glass with the goal judge. Phil Esposito stood on the bench, his arms folded, watching. The ruling would not be reversed. McKegney would not get a last-ditch third-period goal, and the Rangers would be denied a storybook ending. Instead, moments later, Kevin Dineen scored with 2 minutes 3 seconds remaining in overtime, and the Hartford Whalers claimed a 4-3 victory over the Rangers at Madison Square Garden last night.

Debt * Arvin Industries has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for up to $200 million of debt securities. * Iowa-Illinois Gas and Electric Co. has filed for a shelf offering of $60 million of first mortgage bonds.

It's a pleasant little room that looks out on a tranquil garden in the West Village, a place where people with AIDS can gather for food, conversation, relaxation and the sharing of information. Called the Living Room, it is run by the People With AIDS Coalition, which is operated for and by people with AIDS. And that's what makes it special. ''There are other groups for people with AIDS, but this is the only group of people with AIDS doing something for themselves,'' said Michael Hirsch, director of the coalition and its only paid employee. He and a few volunteers are the only ones of the 20 or so active members who do not have acquired immune deficiency syndrome or AIDS-related complex. The coalition was founded 18 months ago to convince people with AIDS that they have control over their own lives. It cooperates with other social service agencies and with the National Association of People With AIDS, which was formed last March.

For the people of New Mexico, Christmas means posole, a hominy and chili stew, and the anise-flavored cookies known as bizcochitos as well as Christmas ham and egg nog. It means both decorated trees, a legacy of northern Europe, and streets lined with paper bags aglow with small candles sunk in sand, luminarias that, according to legend, light the way for the Magi seeking the Christ child. But perhaps the most integral part of the holiday for many in New Mexico is ''Las Posadas'' - ''The Inns'' - a ritualistic verse drama that reveals both the depth of their religious feelings and the determination to keep their Iberian heritage alive and meaningful. In the days before Christmas, Hispanic New Mexicans re-enact the coming of Christ in folk dramas whose roots scholars trace to the Nativity plays of medieval and Renaissance Spain. ''Las Posadas'' was a prelude to the larger Nativity play, ''Los Pastores'' - ''The Shepherds'' - which is rarely performed today.

The General Electric Company has agreed to provide several billion dollars to Kidder, Peabody & Company, which it acquired earlier this year, to help fund a move by the firm to invest aggressively in corporate mergers and buyouts, according to sources close to the two companies. On Friday, Kidder announced internally a reorganization of its investment banking division that sharply escalates its commitment to such merchant banking activities. The sources said that the fund, voted on by G.E.'s board late last week, would be in excess of $2 billion, and would probably grow over time. Shift in Direction These steps culminate an important shift in direction by both Kidder and G.E. It also pits them more directly against the other major players in merchant banking, which is becoming the hottest, and most competitive, area on Wall Street, even with the huge risks it involves.

The eldest son of the Speaker of the Iranian Parliament has apparently fled to Canada ''after receiving at least $6 million'' for his role in the sale of American arms to Iran, a London newspaper reported today. The newspaper, The Observer, cited ''Iranian sources'' in London in reporting that Mehdi Bahremani, son of Hojatolislam Hashemi Rafsanjani, the Speaker of Parliament, ''left his home in Brussels on Nov. 15, closely pursued by an official Iranian investigator.''

LIKE the commercial networks, public television this week is offering a number of holiday specials, most of them crammed with the standard collection of carols. On Christmas Eve, for instance, Shirley Verrett joins the Mormon Tabernacle Choir for a program that includes everything from ''O Holy Night'' to ''Go Tell It on the Mountain.'' That same evening, ''James Galway's Christmas Carol'' is a touch more adventurous, as the Irish flutist also explores a number of English folk and traditional melodies. But of all the special projects - some of them containing appeals to help your local public-television station -none are more thoroughly charming than ''A Ceremony of Carols,'' a choral work being broadcast tonight at 11 on Channel 13. The presentation is the second in a three-part series packaged as ''A Benjamin Britten Retrospective,'' marking the 10th anniversary of the British composer's death. The tribute began last week with a superb 1980 documentary called ''A Time There Was,'' a title taken from a folk-song suite by Britten. Directed by Tony Palmer and produced by Donald Mitchell, it traced Britten's life and work through the recollections of his family and close friends, notably the tenor Peter Pears, who lived and worked with the composer for some 40 years. Mr. Pears died last April.
A Superior Court judge has dropped a six-month suspended jail sentence against a teen-age girl who refused to testify in a sexual assault case against a man she said she loves.

The Chinese Government, in its first formal reaction to the student protests in Shanghai, lashed out today at the tens of thousands of demonstrators for trying to disrupt ''stability and unity'' and ''derange production and social order.'' During the day, crowds of students and workers in numbers approaching 50,000 flooded into People's Square in a third day of protests for broader democratic rights. The official New China News Agency, in an article issued late this evening, accused the students of beating up 31 policemen during a sit-in at City Hall, marching in ''utter disorder'' and breaking into the building housing the Shanghai People's Congress. Rumors of large-scale arrests swept through the crowds, but they could not be confirmed.

On the horizon off the port bow a pillar of smoke climbs to the deep blue sky. That is the direction of Lark Island, where Iraqi bombers struck an Iranian oil terminal and two tankers on Nov. 25 and others since. To starboard a laden tanker heads into the Gulf of Oman for the long run around Africa to Europe. An unladen tanker makes for Lark Island and a chance to run into the Persian Gulf by night and load.

The South African authorities have further tightened reporting restrictions on three anti-Government newspapers. The measures, as well as some of the nation's violence, seem to focus on an anti-apartheid campaign called Christmas Against the Emergency. It is a 10-day protest supposed to include candlelit vigils and a consumer boycott to promote demands including the release of political detainees.
Lightolier Inc., of Secaucus, N.J., a division of Genlyte, has decided to give its advertising to Isidore & Paulson.

To the Editor: As I pondered Michael Burns's ''How Should History Be Taught?'' (Op-Ed, Nov. 22), I saw that his prescription for the classroom does not fit mine. This is no doubt partly be-cause I teach at a large state university where students are not subject to a selective admissions policy; rather than being Napoleons, they are the ''Parisian working women who served on the front lines.'' Of course the very idea of the centrality of Western civilization is suspect when a large portion of the student body is Asian, as at my university. Nevertheless, we offer two semesters of Western civilization.
An intense fire before dawn today killed three children and injured their parents in a mobile home here, officials said.

Some analysts are saying the stock market could be in for a bumpy ride this morning. Nimble stock index futures traders, who were a force behind the record-setting trading pace on the New York Stock Exchange on Friday, when more than 244 million shares were traded, may decide to sell stocks to take advantage of a wide price differential between the nearby March Standard & Poor's 500-stock index futures contract and the underlying cash market.

Mayor W. Wilson Goode goes on television here at the end of World War III and tries to explain to unhappy Philadelphians why the Russians ignored the city and did not vaporize it. But if residents are disappointed, the Eagles football team is delighted. They win the Super Bowl. It may be by default, but they will take it. And happily. The skit, by the No Respect for the Human Condition Players, one of a growing number of local comedy groups, in many ways is typical of the way comedians have long made fun of Philadelphia. Ever since W. C. Fields, comic bullies have made the city the municipal equivalent of the four-eyed, knock-kneed kid with the cap and the lisp.
A soldier on guard near the wreckage of a hotel in County Tyrone, west of Belfast.

Whether Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, when he was a member of the National Security Council staff, acted on his own to divert money from the Iran arms sale to assist Nicaraguan rebels intrigues several former officials and practioners of the craft of intelligence. But if Colonel North did not act on his own, these former officials and others say, they are mystified as to why his superiors apparently entrusted him with such functions as evaluating, planning, managing, financing and concealing the existence of the diversion to the contras and other covert actions. The Iran arms sale, these former officials say, reinforces old lessons about the hazards of covert intelligence actions and underlines a newer lesson about entrusting the direction and execution of secret operations to amateurs and deputized private citizens. The former officials say White House officials may have forgotten or misunderstood a series of mishaps that crippled United States intelligence circles in the 1970's. Breaking Protective Barriers Several of the former officials said one of the more obvious mistakes was a try to avoid legal and customary practices of notifying Congress of covert actions. But they said an even graver criticism would be that the laws and Presidential directives on intelligence activities enacted in the Ford and Carter Administrations, and in theory carried on by President Reagan, apparently were ignored or failed in practice.

Greeting cards from Unicef, the United Nations Children's Fund, have always said different things to different people - ''Season's Greetings'' to some, ''Meilleurs Voeux'' or ''Felices Fiestas'' to others. But according to Louis Gendron, head of Unicef's greeting card operations in the United States, to most Americans they say nothing at all. ''Most people have never heard of them,'' he said, adding: ''Sometimes they confuse Unicef with unisex. Sometimes that opens doors.'' Profits from Unicef cards, which last year totaled $22 million worldwide, were used to provide food, medicine and fresh water for children around the globe. But while the end is charity, the means are business, and so are the problems. In recent years, the greeting card operation the United States has been battered by bad management, high production costs and low visibility. Mr. Gendron, who was called out of retirement two years ago to lead the faltering operation, is trying to change this. 'Selling a Product' ''I'm not fund-raising, I'm selling a product,'' he said. ''The only difference between me and Hallmark is that my profits go to the children of the world instead of to shareholders.''

''IT'S no fun playing tennis unles the guy on the other side of the net has a racquet.'' Lewis Frumkes, writer and humorist, was quoting Ring Lardner and speculating on the intangibles in what makes for a shared sense of humor. Humor is being taken very seriously in some circles these days. Since 1974 there have been nine national conventions of people - including anthropologists and linguists -who are interested in the subject. On Apr. 1, appropriately enough, a five-day International Humor Convention, the sixth, will begin at Arizona State University. Hospitals are using laughter therapy groups with patients who have chronic pain. And on the Johnson Memorial Hospital bulletin board in Stafford Springs, Conn., an exhortation appeared: ''Jest for the Health of It.''
Chinese and American officials today formally inaugurated the first United States-supplied satellite ground station to be sold to a Communist nation.

Hopes for lower interest rates in coming months helped to insulate the note and bond markets from the sharp rise in short-term interest rates last week, but were not enough to move Treasury bond yields from about the middle of the trading range that has prevailed since April. Over the remainder of the year, analysts expect that trading will remain lethargic in the absence of any major economic announcements or sharp moves in oil prices following of Saturday's OPEC agreement to cut oil production. Late Friday, the Treasury's 7 1/2 percent bonds due in 2016 were offered at 101 5/8 to yield 7.36 percent, about the same yield as has prevailed the past two weeks. Portfolios Held Stable ''This is not the time of year for any large portfolio restructuring,'' said William B. Budd, executive vice president of Favia Hill & Associates, an investment advisory firm. Although Mr. Budd expects long bond yields to decline as economic growth remains sluggish and the Fed reduces short-term rates, he noted that trading has been so light recently that large transactions would cause disadvantageous price changes.

John Dahlsen, the chairman of Herald and Weekly Times Ltd., Australia's biggest media concern, said Friday that the Australian financier Robert Holmes a Court was considering making a bid to acquire the company.

With the White House and Congress convulsed by the ever expanding Iran-Israel-Saudi Arabia-Canada-contra arms affair, the Supreme Court has been going about its own measured routine with stately detachment, here carving a little First Amendment hole in the campaign spending laws, there making it a bit harder for corporations to challenge mergers between their competitors. Someday the Reagan Administration turmoil may spawn a great constitutional case for the Court to resolve, like the Watergate tapes case of 1974. Meanwhile, the Justices have plenty of other work to take with them as they take a four-week holiday recess. It is too early to say how the changes in the Court's membership over the last summer will affect its work product. But some who watch it closely already say that under its new Chief Justice, William H. Rehnquist, the Court seems a more good-natured place than before.
Even on Capitol Hill, the old order changeth. In the next Congress, women will function as press secretaries for both the Senate majority leader and the Speaker of the House.

The Census Bureau estimated today that the world's population would reach 6.2 billion by the year 2000, an increase of 27 percent over the 1985 figure. But it said that the world population was growing more slowly than in the 1960's and 1970's. In a report made public today, the bureau estimated that Mexico's population would increase by almost 42 percent, from 79.7 million in 1985 to 112.8 million in the year 2000. Mexico City is expected to surpass Tokyo-Yokohama as the world's largest urban area in about 20 years, the study said. The bureau estimated that the population of Mexico City would grow from 16.9 million in 1985 to 27.9 million in 2000.
''Many people ask a priest: 'Is this a sin? Is that a sin?' Well, racial prejudice is a sin.

Here are key passages from notes of a talk by Mikhail S. Gorbachev on June 19 at a closed meeting with a group of Soviet writers. The notes, taken by one of the writers, were translated by The New York Times. Although the note-taker's identity is not known, writers who attended have confirmed the authenticity of the material. A very profound and serious movement has begun, and a very profound and serious struggle lies ahead.

Six years after Jean S. Harris was convicted of killing Dr. Herman Tarnower, the author of the best-selling ''Scarsdale Diet,'' the case is once again arousing debate. The issue this time is punishment. Mrs. Harris, the 64-year-old former headmistress of the Madeira School in Virginia and now New York State prisoner 81-G-98, has written a letter to Governor Cuomo requesting clemency, which would make her eligible for immediate parole. Convicted of second-degree murder in the shooting, she is serving 15 years to life at the Bedford Hills state prison in Westchester County. The Governor has said he will give Mrs. Harris's request his ''very, very best judgment'' when it reaches his desk, but has declined to comment further. His office has declined to say when he might announce decisions about clemency. It has been a tradition in the state for the decisions to be made in the December holiday period.

The scene, outside on West 34th street, resembles a street bazaar, with vendors hawking Saudi Arabian headdresses, Korean sunglasses and ''Gucci'' watches made in Taiwan. Inside, it resembles a bargain basement, with clothing-strewn counters, inexpensive holiday decorations and merchandise from last season. This is the last Christmas for Ohrbach's, once one of New York's most exciting retailers, known for its copies of Paris couture clothing, its daring advertising and its fashion savvy. ''A business in millions, a profit in pennies'' was its slogan.

A judge has ruled that an infant girl caught in a custody battle between her surrogate mother and the couple who hired the woman to bear the child can be visited Christmas Eve by the natural mother's family. Judge Harvey R. Sorkow, who is to begin hearing the custody trial in Superior Court on Jan. 5, issued the ruling Friday.

The agreement announced Saturday by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries represents an ambitious bid by the 13-nation group to regain its former role as the price-setting manager of the world oil market. But to achieve that goal, OPEC will have to display a measure of unity, production discipline and political will that the aspiring cartel has often lacked during its 26-year history. The production-cutting accord is expected to lift free-market oil prices up toward the OPEC target of $18 a barrel during the next few days, analysts say. But in the longer term, OPEC's ability to enforce fixed prices is uncertain.
Lava flow from Kilauea volcano blocked an intersection in Kalapana Gardens.

A 41-year-old black who began his working life pumping gas at his grandfather's service station in rural middle Georgia has emerged as a powerful figure of political transition in this city, which is saddled with a reputation for racial intolerance. The appointment last week of Richard Knight Jr. to City Manager, the top municipal job, symbolizes not only the personal evolution of one black American but also the stunning transformation of a city long dominated by a conservative white business establishment. ''This is the one city people thought this would not happen - it's a terrifically important symbolic step,'' said Lee Simpson, a former City Councilman. ''It has to send a message to a lot of people in this community who wondered if we'd reached the point where the color of skin was irrelevant.''

* Black & Decker Corp., Towson, Md., said its president, Nolan D. Archibald, had been elected chairman. * Bell Atlantic Corp., Philadelphia, said James G. Cullen had been elected president and chief executive of Bell Atlantic Enterprises.

After three days of increasingly large and tumultuous street protests by university and college students here, the Shanghai police today banned all further demonstrations without a permit. The step effectively made any public protest illegal. It came a day after 50,000 people demonstrated in People's Square here for broader democratic rights and freedom of the press and expression. On the campuses of Shanghai's colleges and universities, officials posted large notices urging students to return to classes and halt the campaign of street demonstrations.

Having escaped from T. Boone Pickens only to come up against plummeting oil prices, the Unocal Corporation is paying a price for its independence. ''They have managed reasonably well in a difficult environment,'' said Sanford L. Margoshes, an analyst at Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. ''They're muddling along.'' Unocal's problems started when Mr. Pickens, the chairman of the Mesa Petroleum Company, made a run at the company last year. Unocal successfully fought off his takeover attempt in May 1985, but at the cost of taking on a huge debt load - an additional $4.4 billion, bringing total debt to a peak of $5.9 billion - to buy back 40 percent of its shares at a premium. Several other concerns, including the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company and CPC International Inc., have recently initiated expensive stock buyback programs in moves to fend off corporate raiders. Unocal's performance has been closely watched since the Pickens episode by those who wonder how much such companies can afford to pay for their freedom.

After an all-night debate that was interrupted by fistfights, the House of Deputies today overwhelmingly approved an amnesty for soldiers accused of human rights violations during the 1973-85 military rule. President Julio Sanguinetti promptly signed the bill into law. The Senate approved the amnesty Sunday, and the House's 60-to-37 vote averted a showdown between the armed forces and the 21-month-old elected Government. During its 12 years in power, the military jailed tens of thousands of people and tortured many of them as part of a crackdown on the left.
Ted Sator, who was dismissed by the Rangers earlier this hockey season, yesterday became the third man this season to coach the struggling Buffalo Sabres, replacing Craig Ramsay.

On Dec. 8, 1985, four days after he left his post as President Reagan's national security adviser, Robert C. McFarlane delivered what he thought was a final order to the Israelis and arms dealers brokering weapons sales to Iran. By Presidential decree, Mr. McFarlane said, the weapons shipments were finished. But within six weeks, the covert operation that was to capture the imagination of key staff members at the National Security Council rose from the ashes. A senior Israeli official, Amiram Nir, came to Washington later last December with word that the Iranian middlemen had sweetened the terms. Just one more arms shipment, Mr. Nir reported, would win the release of the five American hostages in Lebanon and open ties to moderates in Teheran. President Reagan changed his mind, and the arms were sent in February. But the hostages were not released, beginning a pattern that would recur again and again.

When Bob Hill took over as head coach three weeks ago, he stressed that the Knicks would be more concerned with themselves than their opponents. How well they executed was more important than hours of reviewing scouting reports and game films. Or so he thought. Ten games later, and with only one victory for his efforts, Hill changed his strategy. It paid off. The Knicks played perhaps their best defense of the season last night at Madison Square Garden, and gained a much-needed 103-99 victory over the San Antonio Spurs that snapped an eight-game losing streak, their longest of the season.

At the Winter Regional Championships during the weekend, the Greater New York Bridge Association ended its first year in the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center. Contestants gave the arena top marks for playing comfort, but were less happy with the external circumstances - a lack of places to eat sites and taxicabs. Winning the last event of the year, the Regional Swiss Teams, was a group that has been in the forefront in regional tournaments for several years - David and Lisa Berkowitz of Secaucus, N.J., and Bob and Jill Blanchard, Drew Casen and Jim Krekorian, all of Manhattan. The winners of the Flight B Swiss Teams were Lesley Decker of Woodbury, L.I.; Janet Schiff of Port Washington, L.I.; Jo Ann Grauerholz of Seaford, L.I., and Carol Frimet of Long Beach, L.I., tied with Robert Christman, Judith Boies, David and Nan Robinson, all of Manhattan.

A coalition of national organizations and individuals joined today in a ''statement of principles'' calling for a major overhaul of the welfare system that would guarantee all Americans a minimum standard of living. The statement, composed over a three-month period by 20 organizations and endorsed by about 70 others, said the Federal Government had the ''primary responsibility'' for fighting poverty. Individuals joining in the call for national debate on the issue included Arthur Flemming, the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare under President Eisenhower, and Representative Richard A. Gephardt, Democrat of Missouri.

John Cardinal O'Connor has urged New York City to take several dramatic steps to preserve single-room-occupany hotel rooms for low-income and homeless people, including the public acquisition of such hotels and the payment of subsidies to hotel owners who cannot stay in business. In a column in the current issue of Catholic New York, the newspaper of the Archdiocese of New York, the Cardinal notes that a moratorium banning the conversion of S.R.O. hotels and rooming houses ends Dec. 31. Current plans in the City Council, he said, call for only a one-month extension.

In a bid to cut costs, Coleco Industries said it planned to close the two plants and offices of its Selchow & Righter Company subsidiary at Bay Shore and Holbrook, L.I., and would lay off approximately 100 people employed there. Although some layoffs have begun, the company said the shutdowns would occur early next year.

A Federal district judge has set aside a jury verdict in his court against the nausea drug Bendectin, which was made by Merrell Dow Pharmaceuticals Inc. The three-year-old suit charged that the drug caused birth defects in a girl who is now 10 years old. In a 14-page opinion, Federal District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson, in Washington, said that, based on the evidence presented in the trial, ''no reasonable jury could find on the basis thereof that this infant plantiff's birth defects were more likely than not to have been caused by her intrauterine exposure to Bendectin.''

To the Editor: The Central Intelligence Agency is again recruiting potential servants of secrecy, and colleges and universities are again lending this enterprise their support and facilities; students are again protesting the use of academic facilities for nonacademic purposes. Their protests are misguided, for they tend to substitute force for reason.

A state watchdog agency called yesterday for the abolition of New York City's Taxi and Limousine Commission and said the Mayor should be ultimately responsible for regulating the taxi industry and setting rates. The agency, the State Commission of Investigation, in a report on corruption and irregularities at the Taxi Commission, asserted that the taxi panel, in its 16 years of existence, had failed to supervise the taxi industry properly. The ''bottom line indicates,'' the chairman of the Investigation Commission, David G. Trager, said at a news conference that the Taxi Commission has been ''co-opted by the industry that it was set up to regulate.'' In urging the removal of the nine-member Taxi Commission, the state body proposed that the day-to-day supervision of taxi matters be handled by a mayoral agency, the Department of Transportation.

Pactel Personal Communications of Dallas, a unit of Pacific Telesis Group, said that it had agreed to pay $316 million for cellular telephone companies in Detroit-Ann Arbor, Flint, Lansing and Grand Rapids, Mich., and Toledo, Ohio.

Vietnam's poor economic performance was the overriding concern of Hanoi's governing Communists when they assembled last week for their Sixth Party Congress. But it is not the only problem to which the country's new leaders are giving immediate attention, records of the meetings indicate. As diplomats and scholars begin to sift through voluminous speeches, articles and the comments of Vietnamese officials, they say it is apparent that the leadership faces factionalism within the party, a disgruntled army and, most important, a south that is still wayward and uncooperative. The south, in the view of some Hanoi officials, is the source of corruption, political deviation and ''many-faceted sabotage.''

To the Editor: In saying that the gods in Pretoria are crazy, your editorial speaks a truth that has long been evident and often stated. Pretoria's rejection of the ''KwaNatal option,'' Chief Buthelezi's proposal to merge the governments of Natal Province and KwaZulu, is only the latest evidence of its madness.

The Wolf Trap Farm Park for the Performing Arts has named Alan A. Rubin as its chief operating officer, succeeding Carol V. Harford, whose retirement was announced this year. Mr. Rubin is president and chief operating officer of Partners of the Americas, a private voluntary organization that promotes economic and social development in 29 countries in the Western Hemisphere. Wolf Trap, built in Vienna, Va., in the suburbs outside Washington in 1968, is the country's only national park for the performing arts. Ms. Harford, a former foreign service officer, had been its head since 1978.

James Hercules McMullen, a former chief inspector of the New York City Housing Development Administration, died of a heart attack Sunday at the home of his daughter, Patricia Silvestri, in Dongan Hills, S.I. He was 70 years old and lived in Bricktown, N.J. Mr. McMullen had been the chief inspector in Manhattan and on Staten Island. Also surviving are his wife, the former Lillian Wakefield; a son, James, of Manhattan, and a brother, Charles, and a sister, Eleanor Hawkins, both of East Brunswick, N.J.

The Del E. Webb Corporation, a Phoenix-based company involved principally in managing and developing real estate, recreation and gambling operations, announced yesterday that its president, Thomas E. Arnold, had resigned. Mr. Arnold, 42 years old, had been president since January. He said yesterday that he had decided he liked private ownership better and was planning to return to it. ''I would prefer to go off and do my own thing, so to speak,'' he said. ''I didn't want to spend the rest of my life as president of a public company.''

A city law that required owners of vacant single-room-occupancy hotels to rehabilitate their buildings and rent the rooms back to low-income renters was declared unconstitutional by a judge in Manhattan yesterday. The judge, Justice David B. Saxe of State Supreme Court, said the law -which was challenged in several suits brought by landlords - was ''unconstitutional and unenforceable on the grounds that it violates basic constitutional due process rights of S.R.O. property owners.'' In a related development, John Cardinal O'Connor has urged the city to take several steps to preserve the hotel rooms, including the public acquisition of such hotels. [ Page B3. ] The ruling affects between 6,000 and 10,000 vacant housing units that under the law would have been restored as rentals, according to estimates by the Mayor's Office of S.R.O. Housing and by the Coalition for the Homeless, a nonprofit advocacy group.

Dr. William Nolen, a small-town physician who wrote several books, including ''The Making of a Surgeon,'' has died at the age of 58. Dr. Nolen died Saturday at the University of Minnesota Hospital, where he had undergone quintuple bypass heart surgery Dec. 10 after suffering his third heart attack in about a week.
Turf writers are a clannish lot, their racing world and the rest of life joined as one.

On the morning of a Giants home game, Chris Godfrey arrives at Giants Stadium 3 hours 45 minutes before the opening kickoff, give or take two minutes. That never varies. The next players to arrive are Brad Benson and Karl Nelson. Benson picks up Nelson and then drives onto the Garden State Parkway through a closed exit. That never varies.

Had Michael Griffith been swifter or luckier, he might have escaped, beaten but alive, from the gang that attacked him and two companions Saturday morning in Howard Beach, Queens. Had he not fled onto a parkway and been killed by a passing car, the rest of us might have escaped confronting this harrowing incident and the attitudes it has exposed. There is no escaping now. The awesome fact, as Mayor Koch said in rightful anger, is that a ''racial lynching'' occurred on the streets of New York. Commissioner Benjamin Ward and the Police Department responded with appropriate urgency, assigning 50 investigators to the case, in which 11 white teen-agers have now been arrested. Though the case involved the purest, simplest racism, arrests alone cannot clear it. After a long spell during which it seemed to ebb, racism is once again on the rise - and not just in the dark of night or in the Howard Beaches of the land. It's plenty dirty, but it's not little and, after an era of civil rights gains, it's no longer much of a secret.

A tempest is brewing at a state forest 200 miles north of here that pits the national bird against the National Guard, creating a debate over which is more American. For the first time on record, a pair of bald eagles have been reported roosting in the Pigeon River Country State Forest near Grayling, Mich. But the Michigan Air National Guard tests combat maneuvers over the forest, and the nest is in the Guard's flight path. Environmentalists fear that the roaring jets may hit the birds or scare them away. The pilots fly so low, Ned Caveney, the forest manager, said, that ''there are times when you're on a hill and you're looking down on the planes.''

In the Brooklyn blocks where Michael Griffith grew up, the tension yesterday was as biting as the cold wind. Though divided in their opinions of Mr. Griffith, those who knew him or who live in his Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhood spoke in one voice about the horror of his death last weekend and the fears of racism and violence in parts of the city. Police officers answered ''no comment,'' for the Griffith family yesterday and barred reporters from the floor where Mr. Griffith's mother and family live.

''Special operations'' is a military term of art encompassing commando tactics, antiterrorism, insurgency and counterinsurgency, psychological warfare, infiltration, foreign training, rescue and just about anything else short of full-blown war. This little-understood facet of military affairs as practiced by special units of the Army, Navy and Air Force has received increasing attention in these days of terrorism and hostage-taking, and legislation was enacted last fall to reorganize the hierarchy in charge of such forces. As a result, a joint command is being created for a general who will control military units dedicated to special operations. There will also be a new assistant secretary of defense in charge of making policy for the forces.

Virginia Tech has chosen Frank Beamer of Murray State to replace Bill Dooley as football coach. Dooley resigned during a dispute with the school that evolved into a $3.5 million lawsuit. . . . John Paye, the starting quarterback for Stanford, underwent arthroscopic surgery in his right shoulder yesterday and will miss Friday's Gator Bowl matchup against Clemson in Jacksonville, Fla. . . .The former Maryland coach, Bobby Ross, has been named quarterback coach and passing-game coordinator for the Buffalo Bills, Coach Marv Levy announced yesterday. . . . .Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, who has missed the Lakers' last two games because of an eye irritation, may play tonight against the Sacramento Kings.

THE dynamic young biotechnology industry predicts substantial gains from the relaxed drug export measures that Congress approved on the last day of the recent session. ''It will put us on a level playing field with the big guys,'' says Brian C. Cunningham, vice president and counsel of Genentech Inc. Drug exports already provide a rare spot of sunshine amid the dark shadows of the nation's record $170 billion trade deficit. With a trade surplus running at $700 million, total drug exports will be $3 billion this year, up from $2.7 billion in 1985, the Commerce Department says, and the numbers are likely to be even better under the new rules. The Senate Labor Committee, for instance, estimates that drug exports may grow by $400 million to $500 million a year under the loosened restrictions.

His athletic accomplishments are hardly the stuff of legend, but there are those who believe that David Derdeyn will prove to be the one college athlete of the 1980's whose name most lives on in history. Derdeyn is not a football or basketball star but a cross-country runner at Colorado who is not even No. 1 among the Buffaloes. And those who believe in his chance for immortality are civil liberties lawyers. At a time when athletes at more than 100 American colleges have been dutifully lining up for urinalysis conducted by those schools, Derdeyn is the only one who has come forward to file a court challenge to mandatory mass drug testing.

''Veruschka is a character I created,'' said Vera Lehndorff, who played her creation in 60's fashion magazine spreads and in the film ''Blow-Up.'' In 1966, the former art student began to experiment with painting her body. In a new photography book, '' 'Veruschka': Trans-figurations'' (New York Graphic Society, $35), she writes that she hoped to create ''a strangeness that would distract attention from the often very boring dresses'' and a camouflage so ''the public could not trap me so easily.''

When Harlan Foss was first asked to play the role of Abraham Lincoln in the Rome section of Robert Wilson's opera ''The Civil Wars,'' he was thrilled. ''I was really looking forward to working with Mr. Wilson, to sitting at the feet of the master,'' says the 45-year-old opera singer, a former company member of the New York City Opera. ''I got into rehearsal and at first I was very puzzled. I was asked to do these things that didn't seem to have anything to do with what I was singing. I was asking questions all the time, and I couldn't wait for Bob Wilson to get there so I could get the answers. But when he came, the first thing he said was, 'I have no answers, so don't ask me any questions.' ''

In a move not altogether unexpected, Dan Henning was released today as coach of the Atlanta Falcons, a team that began the season with high expectations and four victories, only to finish 7-8-1. Rankin Smith, the Falcons' owner, also dismissed the five assistant coaches who worked with the offense but invited Marion Campbell, the defensive coordinator, and the other defense assistants to remain. The offensive coaches who were dismissed were Larry Beightol (line), Bobby Jackson (tight ends), Bob Harrison (receivers), Sam Elliott (running backs) and Steve Crosby (quarterbacks). In a statement released by the club and attributed to Smith and his son, Rankin Jr., the president, the Smiths called Henning's dismissal ''a most difficult decision.''

Chinese interviewers are conducting interviews in five urban-surburban centers in China in what is probably a first-of-its-kind survey designed to discover the habits and attitudes of the country's television viewers. A different scientifically designed random sample of 1,000 consumers will be interviewed twice each year and subscribers can, for a moderate price, have product-related questions included in the interviews. The research project has been mounted by China Communications, a New York-based firm of which DFS Dorland Worldwide is a minority investor. Penelope Queen, the executive vice president, director of domestic and internatonal relationship of the agency, has supervised much of the preliminary groundwork including the focus-group interviews that helped design the questionnaire.

Bob Nystrom, an Islanders assistant coach, has been suspended for 10 games for confronting a fan in the stands following an Islander game with the Devils Dec. 11. Nystrom went after a fan who threw beer on him following the game at Brendan Byrne Arena in East Rutherford, N.J. Nystrom held the fan until security personnel arrived.

Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi is spreading death beyond Libya's borders again, this time in neighboring Chad. Past efforts by the United States, France and African neighbors have only contained the colonel's adventurism temporarily. But the lesson is to keep trying. Washington and Paris do right to help Chad defend itself against this new surge of aggression.

N.W. AYER INC., announced yesterday that it had, as expected, reached an agreement to acquire Cunningham & Walsh, or at least big parts of it. The purchase for an undisclosed amount of cash will not include the agency's Chicago office, BBDM/Cunningham & Walsh, but will include the Direct Marketing Agency in Stamford, Conn., and the Reiser Williams deYong agency of San Francisco and Irvine, Calif. The Chicago office is not being included because about a third of its billings comes from clients that compete with Ayer clients. However, there is very little conflict elsewhere and Ayer already has a Chicago office billing about $70 million.

As the temperature climbed into the high 70's on June 13, 1975, the Penguins' luck ran out: The ice melted and they went belly up. Shortly after 2 P.M. that day, a squad of agents from the Internal Revenue Service streamed into the Civic Arena, or ''The Big Igloo'' as the Penguins' domed home is called here, and seized the team's only assets - its player contracts - for failure to pay payroll taxes. When the agents left. they padlocked the doors. Eight years after the National Hockey League team first took to the ice, it had gone bankrupt. But the City of Champions, as Howard Cosell nicknamed Pittsburgh, barely noticed. The Pirates and Willie Stargell were on the way to winning a division championship, while the hard-hitting Steelers and Franco Harris seemed to personify the grit and determination of this city.

Westchester County's legislature approved an experimental program today that would subsidize the rents of tenants facing eviction, to avoid the higher costs of sheltering them in hotels and motels. It is planned to provide $1 million in limited, direct rent supplements for families facing rent increases beyond their means. The program is part of a $770.8 million budget for 1987 approved by the Board of Legislators today.

Crash. Boom. Bang. That's what's going on these days at the Gershwin Theater, where they're knocking down walls, ripping up seats and banging out the rafters to prepare for ''Starlight Express'' -the new Andrew Lloyd Webber musical extravaganza about a roller-skating race scheduled to open here in February. With computer-controlled bridges, nearly a mile of race tracks that extend over the heads of the audience and an ambitious backdrop of America that includes the Grand Canyon, the Rocky Mountains and Mount Rushmore, the set is expected to be the most elaborate and expensive - at more than $2.5 million - in Broadway history.

To the Editor: As a South African visitor to the United States, I should like to comment on your excellent editorial (''The Gods Are Crazy in Pretoria,'' Dec. 2), concerning the reforms agreed by the people of Natal - the ''KwaNatal option,'' as they are known - which have just been rejected (once again) by our governing National Party. You refer to these ethnic rulers as ''South Africa's white minority government.'' But the truth is, they are not even that. How could they be, when the white people of Natal have plainly rejected them, in favor of Chief Gatsha Buthelezi and effective majority rule in that province?

Two helicopters collided today over western South Korea, burst into flames and then crashed, the police said. Three United States soldiers were killed and three others were reported injured in the accident, which occurred over the town of Sosan 65 miles southwest of Seoul. The bodies of the three Americans were burned beyond recognition, according to the police.

The Government said today that it had no record of an entry to Canada by the son of the Speaker of the Iranian Parliament, who was reported by a London newspaper to have fled here with at least $6 million in commissions from the secret United States arms sales to Iran. Paul Frazer, press director for the Ministry of External Affairs, said that a check of immigration records had shown no trace of Mehdi Bahremani, eldest son of Hojatolislam Hashemi Rafsanjani, the Iranian Speaker.

The conversation was becoming heated, as barroom debates between fans of opposing college football teams often do. This one involved a Penn State student and an older Notre Dame fan, their voices rising above the din of the jukebox and more pleasant cocktail conversation surrounding them, in the Gipper Lounge in a South Bend, Ind., hotel in 1982. Just when it looked as if the student was going to discover why Notre Dame is nicknamed the Fighting Irish, his female companion nudged him, as if to say, ''Let's change the subject.'' The disagreement was not about mundane matters such as the relative strength of their favorite team or which school played the toughest schedule. Rather, the Penn State student was claiming that his school graduated a higher percentage of football players than Notre Dame. And the older man was insisting the opposite was true. Imagine. Punches were almost exchanged over academics. It is the kind of story that makes Joe Paterno smile, evidence that on some campuses around the country, the primary function of the university has not been forgotten in the heat of athletic competition. In times such as these, even some college presidents have been guilty of losing their perspective on occasion.

The Consumers Power Company and the Dow Chemical Company have suspended negotiations on converting the Midland nuclear power plant to natural gas and will resume talks after the holidays, the companies said today. The companies have been seeking an agreement on joint conversion of the plant. Consumers stopped work on the plant as a nuclear generator in 1984 after Dow pulled out of an agreement to buy steam from the project amid cost overruns and construction delays.

History buffs in need of information about any of the 11,700 people who have served in Congress turn to the best available resource, the latest volume of the Biographical Directory of the American Congress. But the best, scholars say, is far from good enough. The current volume, last updated in 1971, is riddled with misinformation. Key dates for many entries are wrong or missing. Party labels are incorrect. Crucial political information is lacking, and mythology is presented as fact. For example, the volume credits several Congressmen with having been the one who caught John Quincy Adams when he collapsed of a stroke on the House floor in 1848; researchers have been unable to confirm that anyone caught the former President when he fell.

The Roman Catholic Church, whose 800 million members stretch from the slums of Bangladesh to the wealthy suburbs of San Francisco, is in the midst of a fierce struggle over its identity as it moves toward the third millennium after the coming of Christ. The questions being raised are fundamental: What is the nature of the orthodoxy it upholds and who will determine it? How much diversity can the church allow without losing its identity? How much liberty can Catholic scholars be allowed to question, and the faithful to ignore, official teachings?
