How much freedom will local bishops and national churches have to exercise their authority? A Wider Significance Underlying all the issues is a question that the Second Vatican Council purported to answer two decades ago: What is the relationship between Roman Catholicism and a modern world that seems in turn inhospitable to all orthodoxies and demanding of absolute clarity? The battles within the Catholic Church thus resonate well beyond the confines of its membership. Arguments over human sexuality, the place of the sacred in modern life and the best route to a just social order inevitably draw in and affect those for whom the church's promises of eternal salvation hold little meaning.

Oil prices advanced strongly on world markets yesterday, as the oil community welcomed OPEC's decision to cut production. The key American and British grades surged to nearly $18 a barrel during hectic trading, before slipping back somewhat at day's end. The near-month futures contract for West Texas Intermediate crude oil, the American benchmark, rose to $17.22 a barrel, up 83 cents, on the New York Mercantile Exchange, and to $17.05 a barrel, up 55 cents, on the London-based open market. These were the highest levels since September.

First Nationwide Bank said it had acquired the St. Louis Federal Savings and Loan Association of Clayton, Mo. The association, which has assets of approximately $959 million and 25 branches, will be merged into First Nationwide, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Ford Motor Company. In making the acquisition, First Nationwide said that it had received financial assistance from the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation to offset the Missouri association's negative net worth and that the San Francisco savings bank would provide sufficient additional capital to build and maintain net worth at positive regulatory requirements.

In a stunning finish that affected the playoff fortunes of three teams, the New England Patriots beat the Miami Dolphins tonight, 34-27, in the final game of the National Football League regular season. The triumph gave the Patriots their first Eastern Division title in eight years, forced the Jets into the American Conference wild-card game next Sunday and eliminated the Cincinnati Bengals from playoff contention. The margin of victory was a 30-yard touchdown pass from Steve Grogan, an unlikely hero, to Stanley Morgan with 44 seconds remaining. That pass ended the race between the Jets, who had finished the season Sunday with a fifth straight loss, and the Patriots, who would have been eliminated had they lost to the Dolphins in the Orange Bowl, where New England has lost so many other games over the years.

WITH progress against many cancers virtually stalled, the National Cancer Institute is casting a wide net for new drugs in nature, whose plants, animals and microorganisms first produced perhaps a fourth of the 50 or so drugs commonly used in cancer treatment. An important drug against leukemia, for example, came from a periwinkle plant in Madagascar, while other cancer drugs came from oceanic sponges or were brewed in microbial broths. An experimental drug against lung cancer is derived from a mold discovered in damaged lungs of cows that had consumed rotten sweet potatoes.

An article yesterday about the reaction of residents of Howard Beach, Queens, to a racial attack on three black men misidentified a priest at Our Lady of Grace Roman Catholic Church. He is the Rev. Kenneth Liona.

To the Editor: You gave prominent space to the views of Amy Carter, a Brown University student, regarding recent events at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst (news story, Dec. 5). Her comments and accusations were carried without checking on their accuracy or consulting the university administration for a response. The following is to set the record straight.

The Zambian Government said today that it was deporting a correspondent for The Associated Press, John Edlin, on immigration charges, but that the proceedings had bogged down in paperwork, the reporter's lawyer said. The lawyer, Solly Patel, said in a telephone conversation from Lusaka, Zambia, that immigration officials told him this morning that they had begun procedures to expel Mr. Edlin, but that the paperwork was not finished and ''may take a while.''

If it's indeed more blessed to give than to receive, then William Perry's heart, if not gladdened, is at least in the right place. The Bears' coach, Mike Ditka, confirmed yesterday that the 350-pound Fridge had been denied all $38,000 that he would have pocketed had he met weight-loss incentives included in his 1986 contract. That sum is in addition to three weight-related fines already levied by Ditka, who, uninclined to Christmas amnesty, promised that the next one would leave Perry substantially lighter in the wallet.

MADE in association with the pay-cable service Showtime, ''Blood Ties'' seems to be something of an experiment designed to give Italian television a foothold in the lucrative American marketplace. For the most part, Italian productions have stumbled over obvious language barriers. Subtitles are generally thought to be too cumbersome, and most dubbing processes tend to produce a ''lifeless'' soundtrack. The solution for ''Blood Ties''? Make the film in English, with actors who can speak English, even if heavily accented. Presumably, the production will be marketed elsewhere, even in Italy, as a ''foreign film.'' On a purely technical level, the gambit works quite effectively for the co-producers - Italy's RAI broadcasting organization and Viacom International. As late-night viewers can discover tonight at 1:20 A.M. (repeats are scheduled for Monday at 8 P.M. and the following Friday at 11:45 P.M.), the soundtrack for ''Blood Ties'' is as ''natural'' as audiences in this country have come to expect and demand (for whatever reasons, Europeans are not so finicky on this issue).

Kenneth L. Adelman, director of the United States Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, has been shuttling between his office at the State Department and duty at the White House, where he has had a key role in the reorganization of the National Security Council. Mr. Adelman is a close friend of Frank C. Carlucci, who was brought in as the national security adviser by President Reagan in an effort to repair damage done by the disclosures that staff officials there had worked on an arms deal with Iran and a diversion of the profits to the rebels fighting the Nicaraguan Government. As in many other Washington instances of someone calling on a trusted aide, this one has old roots. Mr. Adelman once worked for Mr. Carlucci when he headed the Office of Economic Opportunity.

AFTER two decades of dreaming, planning and development, India's space program has come of age. Once merely a symbol of the nation's pride and ingenuity, Indian space technology has become an integral part of its communications, weather forecasting and resource management systems. ''We started modestly and built step by step,'' said U. R. Rao, director of the Indian space program. ''There was a lot of criticism along the way. But today everyone is convinced that this is the best way to meet the country's needs.'' A few major developing countries, such as Brazil and China, have also developed space technology, principally for military purposes. But Western scientists say that no other country outside the United States, Europe and the Soviet Union has achieved India's broad and deep ability to use space in civilian life. Scientists say India offers a case study of how a developing country can exploit advanced technology to meet fundamental needs.

OUR neighborhood star has been growing steadily dimmer during the last five years, and if the slump doesn't end pretty soon all of us will be in serious trouble. A gadget aboard the Solar Maximum Mission satellite began measuring radiation from Old Sol in 1980, and for the five years for which data are available sunshine has been declining by a steady 0.019 percent each year. That adds up to a net loss of nearly one-tenth of one percent, which may not sound like much. But climatologists point out that a sustained increase or decrease in solar luminosity of less than three-tenths of a percent would be enough to produce dire results; depending on the direction of the change, the Earth could become a tropical oven or an arctic deep freeze.

A barge carrying 86,000 gallons of diesel fuel began sinking in the Hudson River yesterday morning, prompting her captain to run aground near Englewood Cliffs, according to the Coast Guard. Fifty gallons of oil spilled through the vents of the barge, the Jane Frank, owned by Standard Marine of New Jersey, but the flow was quickly plugged and the fuel dissipated, a Coast Guard public affairs specialist, Loren Bullard, said.

THE sun was bright, the wind whipped off Great South Bay, and the temperature was near freezing. Still, Ray Lyons decided it was better to spend Sunday outdoors in the cold, given the alternatives. ''My wife and daughter have gone to fight their way into the malls,'' Mr. Lyons said. ''They left at 9:30 this morning.'' Even as he spoke, he could envision them, embroiled in several holiday savings events and many gigantic storewide sales.

The Sterling National Bank and Trust Company of New York will have a new chief executive and president effective Jan. 5. He is John C. Millman, who was chosen last week at a board meeting. Mr. Millman, 44, succeeds John F. Fowler Jr., who is retiring at age 65 because of ill health. Mr. Fowler has been president since 1978. The bank said he was expected to continue as a director and would become a consultant.

SOME of the most widespread beliefs about the quest for satisfaction with life are misleading or dead wrong, psychologists have found. Achieving a long-held goal, for instance, seems to be less satisfying than simply avoiding unpleasantness from day to day. And while financial security, a happy marriage and fulfilling social activities are all related to contentment, they and similar factors are weak predictors of who will be satisfied with life and who will not. Altogether, such factors explain less than 30 percent of people's reports of satisfaction. Instead, temperament, which changes little over the course of life, is emerging as an unexpectedly strong determinant of how satisfied people report they are. Even stronger is how much time people are able to spend doing things they find most meaningful, are most competent at, and take the most pleasure in.

Senator Patrick J. Leahy said tonight that a four-member Democratic senatorial panel had been appointed to review and hold hearings on President Reagan's judicial nominees. The Senator, a Vermont Democrat, said he had been named to head the committee. The panel, selected by Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., the Delaware Democrat who will head the Senate Judiciary Committee, was established to provide more vigorous screening of the Reagan Administration's judicial choices, Mr. Leahy said.

Investors are selling stocks these days for what ordinarily might be a most unusual reason: They want to record their capital gains this year, rather than next. Typically, investors who want to cash in their gains wait until the new year, so they can delay paying taxes for a year or more. But taxes on capital gains go up to a maximum 28 percent in 1987, from 20 percent, causing selling pressure that is likely to persist through year-end, tax experts say. Stocks fell very slightly yesterday, but analysts said the tax change is an unknown that is hanging over the market. [ Page D6. ] Wall Street brokers are spreading the word about the lower capital gains rate this year.
The bodies of a man and woman were found Sunday in the locked trunk of the woman's car. The car had been in an Elks Lodge parking lot here for at least nine days, the police said.

The United States women's championship, held at the Stanley Hotel in Estes Park, Colo., was won by Inna Izrailov of Brooklyn. The 22-year-old international woman master, a Russian emigre, scored 7-2 to top a round-robin field of 10. Second place was captured by 18-year-old Liz Neely of Tucson, Ariz.

A caption yesterday with a review of ''A Ceremony of Carols,'' the Benjamin Britten retrospective on Channel 13, misidentified the subject of the picture. He was not Britten but the tenor Peter Pears, whose recollections of Britten were part of the program.

EXASPERATED by slow progress against leading cancer killers and armed with a sensitive new testing technology, the National Cancer Institute is making a major change in the way it searches for anticancer drugs. The new screening method, officials hope, will be more successful in identifying drugs effective against lung, colon, breast and other common cancers that have resisted chemotherapy up to now. At the same time, the institute has begun a far-flung search in nature for ''biologically active'' chemicals so as to collect a rich trove of novel materials for sifting through the new screen. In coming months the Federal agency will introduce a new testing system that officials expect will determine more quickly and accurately which chemicals out of thousands examined each year might make useful drugs. At present, researchers select chemicals for study by watching their effects on mice with a single form of animal leukemia. This test has yielded some notable successes, mainly against leukemias and lymphomas, but has failed to produce drugs that work against the country's worst cancer threats.

MEMORIES OF MISTRESSES. Reflections From a Life. By Luigi Barzini. 311 pages. Collier Books/Macmillan. Paper, $12.95. ''MEMORIES OF MIS= TRESSES'' is a collection of 22 essays by Luigi Barzini, who died in 1984. The title is not only deplorable but actively misleading as well, and there is no indication where or when any of the pieces originally appeared; but in other respects the publisher deserves a wholehearted vote of thanks. Barzini was one of the outstanding journalists of his time, and most of the articles and sketches that have been salvaged display the same sparkle that he brought to his celebrated account of his countrymen, ''The Italians.''

Excerpts from ''The Next Nuclear Power?'' by Harold Freeman, professor emeritus of statistics at Massachusetts Institute of Technology, published in the latest edition of Foreign Service Journal, the magazine of the American Foreign Service Association: In a few years, possibly a few months, Pakistan may well be the possessor of an unsophisticated but effective nuclear device. All of the technology is already in place. For the United States and other countries, this presents a dilemma: how to indicate their concern over Islamabad's aggressive nuclear program while supporting that country in its exposed strategic position. The answers are far from clear.

To the Editor: Your Dec. 6 Associated Press item about Big Ben (''The Clockwork Heart of London Skips Beat'') describes the sudden absence of ''the note E in the sequence G sharp, F sharp, E and C.'' Assuming the first three notes were named correctly, the fourth would have to be a B. Try it on the piano if you don't believe me. Someone has been listening to too much Debussy. ALECK KARIS New York, Dec. 6, 1986

JACKIE MASON is a man who can move mountains. At least he has moved the mountains to Manhattan. The mountains in question are the old resort-riddled Catskills that were noted for clear streams, cold borsht and hot comics. In his one-man show, ''The World According to Me!,'' which opened last night at the Brooks Atkinson, Mr. Mason gives hilarious testimony to the art of the stand-up comic. He is such a deft stand-up comic that he is no less funny when he sits down. One starts chuckling as soon as he enters to the regal strains of the ''Masterpiece Theater'' theme and suggests that the stage is bare because you have come to see him, not furniture. He segues through an astonishing quantity of themes. His style is not that of Henny Youngman, which both will be grateful for. No one-liners. No stories, either, a la Sam Levenson. No? What then? No jokes, no stories? From this he makes a living as a comic?

EDITH STEPHEN called ''The Unthinkables'' an ''homage to Samuel Beckett.'' That it may well have been. Yet the work that the Edith Stephen Dance Connection offered Friday night at the Marymount Theater did little to illuminate the plays and novels of this distinguished writer.

A panel on Government regulations headed by Vice President Bush today proposed abolishing United States fuel economy standards, saying the standards hampered the ability of domestic makers of automobiles to meet the demands of the market. The Presidential Task Force on Regulatory Relief, assigned by President Reagan to review Federal regulations, also recommended shutting the Interstate Commerce Commission and called for consolidating responsibility for regulating the banking industry. The group would abolish the Corporate Average Fuel Economy standards, passed during the oil crisis of the 1970's when gas prices were regulated by the Government. The law requires auto makers to meet fuel efficiency standards or face fines. The Department of Transportation, which is headed by Elizabeth Hanford Dole, enforces these standards.

Dissatisfied with the bids it had received since deciding to sell its real estate operations, Merrill Lynch & Company adopted a new tack yesterday. It said it would convert those operations into a master limited partnership, retaining control but selling units to the public. When it put them up for sale in September, Merrill valued the operations at about $500 million. It said yesterday that it could not speculate about details of the offering, including the percentage that would be marketed. It said the offering would be by prospectus, probably early next spring.

Buying a fur coat, especially for the first time, can be traumatic. Whether it is a $2,000 opossum or a $10,000 mink, a fur coat represents a major investment. Many women feel they are singularly unprepared to make a wise decision. Still, the consistent increase in fur business over the last 15 years reflects the fact that more women are buying their own furs -for warmth, glamour or as a sign of success. The independent woman who spends her own money has helped change the fur business, says Viola Sylbert, the fashion designer who has worked for several fur manufacturers. Protests from conservationists who object to the use of pelts from endangered species or inhumane trapping methods have also affected the business.

David B. McCall, the 58-year-old chairman and chief executive officer of McCaffrey & McCall, is turning over the chief part of his title to Robert H. Cherins, 46, the president and chief operating officer since February. At the same time, Bruce McCall, 51, who is not a relative, is promoted to vice chairman and chief creative officer from executive vice president and creative director.
Rescuers at the scene of a crash in Hillje. A station wagon carrying 10 people veered off a highway and crashed into a parked truck, killing 9 on board.

John McMichael is well known as the owner of the local pub who likes to quote Thomas Paine and lead the Protestant loyalist vigilante group here lately accused of burning the Roman Catholic nationalist minority from their homes. ''Time makes more converts than reason,'' he declares. He is quoting one of the passages of Paine that seems more paradoxical than appropriate when applied to the centuries of the unresolved Irish conflict that has been flickering steadily, almost routinely now, through the past tense year in Lisburn. Speaking with the odd mix of lilt and bite that marks the polemics of both sides in the northern troubles, Mr. McMichael professes absolute innocence of the months of residential gasoline bombings, a selective reign of terror that has been driving Catholic families back to the hard ghettos of Belfast, away from this rare mixed community.

''CANDLE IN THE WIND'' is an unprecedented look at religion in the Soviet Union. The word ''unprecedented'' should be used with caution, of course; it is often misapplied. In the case of the documentary on Channel 13 at 11 o'clock tonight, however, it fits. ''Candle in the Wind'' is a scholarly, balanced, impressive piece of work.

The Oakland A's say one of several vacancies on their roster might be filled by Reggie Jackson. The 40-year-old Jackson, who began his major-league career with the A's, lives in Oakland and has talked to the club about the possibility of returning.

Samuel Belzberg, the corporate raider, yesterday suggested that the GTE Corporation spin off its Sprint long-distance telephone service to its shareholders. He also said shareholders would benefit from the sale or spinoff of GTE's mobile phone operations. Mr. Belzberg, a Canadian with a reputation for profiting from unsuccessful takeover attempts, made his comments in a delicately worded letter sent yesterday to GTE's chairman, Theodore Brophy. The letter said a partnership headed by the First City Financial Corporation, which Mr. Belzberg owns, possesses a ''large'' number of GTE shares.
A Shiite Amal militiaman firing a machine gun toward Palestinian positions as fighting continued in refugee districts in Beirut. (Agence France Presse)

The Cannon Group Inc. said that the previously extended deadline for a $75 million debt payment to Bond Corporation Holdings Ltd. had been extended again, through today. Those close to Cannon, an independent film producer and distributor, said the company was likely to secure the financing through bank credit with the assistance of Warner Communications Inc., which would, in return, obtain rights to some of Cannon's releases.

Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d refused today to turn over documents on the Iran arms case to the House Judiciary Committee, saying the material had already been provided to Congressional panels. A Justice Department official said Mr. Meese had notified the committee chairman, Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr., of his intention not to comply with the panel's request. Mr. Rodino, a New Jersey Democrat, sent a seven-page letter to Mr. Meese on Dec. 11, asking for material to help a special House committee that will investigate the arms case when the 100th Congress convenes Jan. 6.

Although the attention of most Americans is now diverted from the Israeli-Palestinian issue to the Reagan Administration's strange involvement in the Iran-Iraq war, a new drama is taking place in the territories occupied by Israel. The American press, picking up only when the violence begins, reports an occasional killing. Meanwhile, the Israeli press speaks of ''the longest week of bloodletting . . . since the Six-Day War,'' warns that this kind of violence is ''part of a way of life'' because of Israeli settlements in the territories and fears growing vigilantism among the settlers. Opinions vary on why the Palestinians on the West Bank are suddenly becoming more politically active, thereby triggering the harsh repression. But one cause is undoubtedly the new effort by Israel and Jordan to pressure the West Bank population to abandon the Palestine Liberation Organization and accept King Hussein's leadership.

CARLOS SAURA has set ''El Amor Brujo'' on a stage the size of an airplane hangar, with a sand floor and a horizon that changes color with the film's many moods. The landscape is crisscrossed by telephone wires and populated by shacks in which the film's gypsy characters reside. This setting is imaginative and versatile, and it is by far the most striking thing about ''El Amor Brujo,'' Mr. Saura's flamenco film made in collaboration with Antonio Gades. This is their third such collaboration, after ''Carmen'' (1983) and ''Blood Wedding'' (1981). This film, which freely adapts its story to fit Manuel de Falla's music, is the second version of ''El Amor Brujo'' in which Mr. Gades has appeared (the first, a little-known version that has not been seen here, was directed by Rovira Beleta). In Mr. Saura's film, which opens today at the Cinema Studio 1, Mr. Gades dances the role of Carmelo and also co-choreographed the film with Mr. Saura. The result is a large, colorful production with dance sequences that are a lot livelier than the dramatic passages, though the film divides itself equally between the two. The flamenco choreography is so intrinsically dramatic that the acting passages often seem superfluous anyhow.

Lloyd Honeyghan, the undisputed world welterweight champion, gave up his World Boxing Association title in London yesterday for political reasons, but he will defend his other titles against Johnny Bumphus in February. The 26-year-old Honeyghan, a black Londoner, surrendered his W.B.A. crown rather than obey an instruction to defend it against Harold Volbrecht, the white South African, who is the W.B.A.'s No. 1 contender.

New Zealand's fiberglass yacht, bombarded with gamma rays and pierced with a drill, met all weight distribution requirements for a legal America's Cup contender today, ending three months of bitter controversy. After a thorough resurvey with ultrasonic, gamma measuring and hull drilling tests, R. J. Rymill, the principal surveyor for the Lloyds Registry of Shipping in London, issued certificates stating that all four boats in the challenger's semifinals - New Zealand, Stars & Stripes, USA and French Kiss - had been found ''fully in compliance with the scantling, weight and weight distribution requirements for 12-Meter yachts.'' ''All of the necessary physical and electronic tests have been carried out,'' said Gianfranco Alberini, commodore of the Costa Smeralda Yacht Club, organizers of the challenger series. ''There is no more reason for the rumors and gossip to go on.''

Queen Elizabeth II will drop her traditional horseback ride at her annual birthday parade, the Trooping the Color, in favor of a carriage instead because her horse is too old, Buckingham Palace said today. The announcement said the 61-year-old Queen feels that Burmese, the Canadian-bred black mare she has ridden side-saddle at the mid-June ceremony for the last 18 years, should be retired and she does not want to use a new horse. Burmese, who was given to the Queen by the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, is now nearly 24.

J. Wesley Silk, 63, the publisher of Better Homes & Gardens since 1979, has been promoted by the Meredith Corporation to senior vice president and executive publisher, in preparation for his retirement in 1988. Stepping into the publisher's slot is Del F. Rusher, 45, who has been associate publisher, development, for the last three years. Mr. Rusher joined Meredith in 1969 after graduating from Coe College and getting a master's from Drake University.

In the stormy aftermath of remarks that were called racist, the sheriff who made them has found wide approval among his predominantly white constituency. The sheriff, Harry Lee, a Chinese-American who is the chief law-enforcement officer in Jefferson Parish, has received an outpouring of support for announcing that his deputies would stop blacks seen in white neighborhoods. The parish, or county, is a New Orleans suburb that is 84 percent white. In hundreds of telephone calls to his office and to radio talk shows, Sheriff Lee's constituents and other whites have strongly backed his proposed action, although not necessarily his choice of words.
Jeff Van Note is now two days into retirement, and he earned it.

A new study concludes that many American children may be suffering mild hearing loss from exposure to lead. Using data collected on more than 3,000 children and teen-agers, the researchers found that even low levels of lead in the blood increased the likelihood of subtle hearing loss that could affect a child's ability to understand speech.

An Israeli nuclear technician who sold information about this country's atomic weapons program to a British newspaper has made an extraordinary gesture to indicate that he was later abducted in Rome. The technician, Mordechai Vanunu, wrote a message on his hand and then held the hand up for journalists who were waiting outside the courthouse where he was appearing on Sunday. Israel's military censor banned all publication of the message until today. The message, scrawled in English, read: ''Vanunu M. was hijacked in Rome Itl 30.9.86. 2100 came to Rome by BA fly 504.''

SHOPPING for software can be frustrating, confusing and expensive. Wouldn't it be nice to have someone else track down and evaluate the best programs, and ship them to your door? That's the idea behind the ''Software-of-the-Month Club.'' An advisory board chooses a series of best-selling programs and automatically sends one or two a month to the subscriber unless instructed otherwise. Selections in the series range from $19.95 for educational software for small children to $39.95 for a software selection service for grown-ups. Subscribers receive one or two disks each month (Apple II and MS-DOS programs are available now, and Macintosh may be added later), a newspaper, a newsletter and a magazine for children.

Representative Jack F. Kemp, a Republican Presidential hopeful, said today that he still considered Vice President Bush the front-runner in the race for the Republican nomination in 1988. In a meeting with reporters, Mr. Kemp downgraded Senator Bob Dole's strong showing in an Iowa poll released last week, arguing that at this stage of the campaign, polls largely reflected name recognition. He said that Mr. Dole's improvement resulted from his heightened visibility on television in recent weeks as a result of the controversy over the Iran arms deal.

The chairman of the Federal Trade Commission gave a ''national consumer fleece award'' to the New York State Agriculture Commissioner, Joseph Gerace, yesterday, saying Mr. Gerace had used his authority ''to deprive consumers of the benefits of competition.'' Mr. Gerace denied a New Jersey dairy a license to sell milk throughout the city two weeks ago, saying the license would lead to ''destructive competition.''

Commuters in the new West End Concourse. The $7.1 million concourse under Eighth Avenue will allow direct access to the Eighth Avenue subways as well as the avenue at 33d Street. The work is part of the Long Island Rail Road's capital improvement program for the station. (NYT/Ruby Washington)

In the debate over Iran and Nicaragua, President Reagan's most outspoken advocate has been Patrick J. Buchanan, his communications director, and now some conservative Republicans are starting to talk about Mr. Buchanan as a possible Presidential contender. Mr. Buchanan scoffs at the possibility, but conservatives say his spirited defense of the Administration has won him support in the Reagan wing of the Republican Party, which will be critical in the nomination process.
Samuel R. Pierce Jr., the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, is adding some high-level foreign policy diplomacy to his domestic portfolio.

Residents were allowed back in their palm-shaded homes near a quiescent lava flow, but the authorities warned them today against standing on the cooling, newborn rock that had oozed from Kilauea Volcano. ''Be aware that the lava is very hot directly under the surface, and cave-ins are a real hazard, so stay off,'' Hawaii County's Civil Defense chief, Harry Kim, warned in lifting an evacuation order.
BASKETBALL UTAH JAZZ VS. NETS, at Byrne Meadowland Arena, 7:30 P.M. (Radio - WNEW 1130, 7:30 P.M.) LOS ANGELES CLIPPERS VS.

Coach Joe Walton remained rigid today in his tenacious support of his young quarterback, Ken O'Brien, in the face of a pervasive slump that cost the Jets a division title. O'Brien has been at the helm of the Jets' five-game losing streak that has failed to keep them out of the playoffs, albeit as a wild-card team that will be host to the Kansas City Chiefs next Sunday instead of having the weekend off. Before the new England Patriots won the A.F.C. East title tonight by beating the Miami Dolphins, Walton said O'Brien again would start, regardless of the Jets' playoff opponent. But he did not close the door to the possibility O'Brien could be yanked in mid-game for Pat Ryan if things weren't going well.

Debt * Borden Inc. announced that it plans to offer up to $315 million of medium-term notes on a continuing basis through Salomon Brothers Inc. Proceeds will be used to repay commercial paper issued in connection with the acquisition of BCI Beatrice Dairy Products Inc. * Dallas County Hospital District, Texas, is offering $25.4 million of hospital revenue bonds through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Co. Yields range from 5.25 percent for issues due 1989 to 5.75 percent in 1991, 6.85 percent in 1996 and 7 percent in 1999.

The shareholders of Lucky Stores Inc. approved the reincorporation of the supermarket chain in Delaware, clearing the way for Lucky's repurchase of 14.4 million shares, or 28 percent of outstanding shares, as part of a restructuring. The approval followed the denial earlier today by a Federal district court judge of a request by the invester Asher B. Edelman for a preliminary injunction to block the reincorporation.

No nation can solve a problem by creating a crisis. At a time when America needs cool heads and calm cooperation to overcome the mistakes of the Iran arms sales - mistakes that President Reagan has admitted - partisan politics are threatening not only the historic recovery of America's leadership in the world engineered under Mr. Reagan's stewardship but also the capacity of the Presidency to conduct foreign policy in a decisive manner. The stakes are great. The world of 1986 is far different from the world of 1981, when the French historian Jean Francois Ravel's warning that democracy might turn out to be only a footnote in history seemed perilously close to prophecy. A steady erosion of clarity and confidence in Western ideas and values had pushed the West into a decade of decline. Acceptance of a moral equivalence between East and West led many to embrace the notion that detente and economic concessions would attenuate Soviet belligerence. Too many succumbed to the weakness of unilateral restraint and accepted the inevitability of the Brezhnev Doctrine - a nation, once conquered, must and will remain forever in the Communist camp. Small wonder that an emboldened, ever-expanding Soviet empire captured nine nations, and more than three million innocents died at the hands of these brutal dictatorships.

Markets Oil prices advanced strongly in hectic trading on world markets, as the oil community welcomed OPEC's decision to cut output. The key American grade surged to nearly $18 a barrel, before slipping back to $17.22 at day's end, for a gain of 83 cents a barrel. Futures prices for heating oil and unleaded gasoline also increased markedly. And U.S. oil companies continued to ratchet up the prices they pay for crude oil, to just above $15. [ Page D1. ] Investors have a new reason to sell stocks: They want to pay taxes on capital gains this year because the capital gains rate will increase next year. Tax experts say this thinking could mean selling pressure in the market through year-end. [ D1. ]

An American captured outside a restricted Nicaraguan air base was presented publicly today for the first time since his arrest, and gave a confused account of his motives and background. The American, Sam Nesley Hall, was seized Dec. 12 near the Punta Huete base a few miles from Managua. Authorities showed hand-drawn maps they said they had found hidden on his person. Mr. Hall's statements to interrogators, as well as the apparently amateurish manner in which he was operating at the time of his arrest, have led Sandinista leaders to conclude that he is probably not connected to any official American espionage operation, according to informed officials.

Celius Dougherty, accompanist to many of the great singers of the 1930's and 40's and a composer of tuneful, witty songs, many of them used as recital encores, died of cancer yesterday. He was 84 years old and lived in Effort, Pa. Mr. Dougherty was born in Glenwood, Minn., and graduated from the University of Minnesota. He came to New York after winning a competition sponsored by the St. Paul Schubert Club. He quickly found himself in demand as an accompanist, and played for Alexander Kipnis, Povla Frijsh, Eva Gauthier, Richard Crooks, Florence Easton, Edward Johnson and many others. At the same time he began to establish himself as a composer, and many of his works - songs, predominantly - were issued by the leading publishers.

The Chrysler Corporation's automotive capital spending program for 1987 will total $2.9 billion, a slight decrease from the $3.1 billion spent this year, Gerald Greenwald, the chairman of the Chrysler Motors subsidiary, said today. In a year-end statement, Mr. Greenwald said Chrysler would introduce a longer version of its mini-van in the coming year that would be manufactured in a second plant, which would add 400,000 units a year to the company's capacity and would make V-6 engines available as options in minivans.
''Vanunu M. was hijacked in Rome Itl 30.9.86. 2100 came to Rome by BA fly 504.'' - Mordechai Vanunu, in a message scrawled on his palm. [ A1:3. ]

Students in People'S Square Sunday, as about 50,000 people campaigned for broader democratic rights, freedom of the press and expression. Yesterday, Shanghai police banned all further demonstrations without a permit. A12.

The pilots of the Voyager reached the Pacific Coast of Mexico earlier than expected today on their nonstop flight around the world and prepared to land at their starting point in California. The extralight paper-and-plastic plane was scheduled to touch down at Edwards Air Force Base Tuesday shortly after dawn, having flown more than 26,000 miles around the globe without refueling. Fatigue and Headwinds Fighting fatigue and high winds -some so strong they turned the craft upside down at one point - Voyager crossed Central America, after flying west over the Atlantic Ocean from Cameroon in West Africa, turned right and headed north toward home. Reports varied all day about precisely when Voyager would reach its goal, because of the vagaries of the winds. Concern about fuel supply was dispelled when the Voyager's designer, Burt Rutan, told its pilots, Jeana Yeager and Richard G. Rutan, who is his brother, not to worry. ''We have at least 30 hours of fuel left,'' he told the fliers this afternoon.

A Federal bankruptcy judge approved a plan yesterday to allow the Wedtech Corporation, a South Bronx military contractor, to resume limited operations and rehire several hundred employees. The judge, Howard B. Buschman 3d of Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan, signed an order that would allow Wedtech to borrow $1 million.

A former Ku Klux Klan leader and Government informer who served as a consultant to the political extremist Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. has emerged as a pivotal figure in the Government's fraud case against leaders of the LaRouche organizations. The Federal trial of 13 top aides, fund-raisers and associates, plus five political committees and corporations, is not expected to start until at least April 6, but prosecutors and defense lawyers offered a preview last week in two days of testimony in a detention hearing for three of the aides. Federal prosecutors showed an enlargement of a credit card slip they say is evidence of a scheme used by four fund-raisers based in Boston to obtain more than $1 million to finance Mr. LaRouche's 1984 Presidential effort. Obstruction Is Also Charged The Government will also seek to prove that high-ranking officials in the LaRouche inner circle conspired to block the investigation.

The Reagan Administration professes a desire to improve education for poor children - but proposes to do so with tuition tax credits and education vouchers. A new willingness to improve existing remedial programs is welcome; these approaches are not, for they would undermine public schools and vital Federal education programs.

SOME of the best-performing stock groups during 1986 were tobacco, pollution controls, chemicals, apparel manufacturers and building materials. Since this is the season when stock pickers peer ahead, what looks good to them for 1987? There is, obviously, no gilt-edged guarantee in the forecasts. All the same, investors like to know what Wall Street is thinking.

The list of chemicals contaminating the ground here reads like the Periodic Table of the Elements, with special emphasis on the heavy metals. For most of this century a succession of companies have made dyes and intermediate chemical products on this hilly 35-acre site a quarter-mile from the center of Ashland, dumping the bad batches and the wastes in lagoons carved in the dirt. Now, in an area where three million people are potentially affected, the soil is yielding its burden of mercury, lead, chromium, cadmium and arsenic to the ground water, along with more complicated substances, chemicals that cause cancer or are suspected of causing it, like trichloroethylene, nitrobenzene and chlorinated benzenes. In turn the water pollutes the Sudbury River, once considered a potential source of drinking water for the Boston metropolitan region.

Even with its breathtaking scenery and relaxed life style, the Pacific Northwest was no place for Walter Berry. And he made no secret of it. So last Thursday, the unhappy forward got his wish. Sort of. Berry, the former St. John's forward who was the 14th selection in last spring's collegiate draft, was traded by the Portland Trail Blazers, a team for whom he played only sparingly because of various injuries. But he wasn't sent back East, close to his home in the Bronx, as he had wished. He was traded to the San Antonio Spurs, in exchange for Kevin Duckworth, a 7-foot, 290-pound backup center who was the 33d player selected in last spring's collegiate draft.

For Jose Luis Torres, these have not been easy times. As chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission, the 50-year-old Torres has been at the center of controversy in the convoluted events leading up to and following the Dec. 12 fight for the World Boxing Association heavyweight championship. On that night at Madison Square Garden, James (Bonecrusher) Smith became the champion when he knocked out Tim Witherspoon at 2 minutes 12 seconds of the first round. And while Smith's work was fairly definitive - he knocked Witherspoon down three times before the bout was stopped - what Torres did as commissioner before and after the bout was fuzzy enough to raise questions about his handling of the $66,649-a-year job to which the former light heavyweight champion was appointed by Governor Cuomo in November 1984.

A Federal child-support program helped collect $2.7 billion from absent parents last year and the 1986 figure is expected to be nearly $3.2 billion, the Department of Health and Human Services said today. ''We have made substantial progress in collecting the support which absent parents owe to their children, and today we are poised for even more dramatic advances,'' Dr. Dr. Otis R. Bowen, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, said in a statement accompanying his annual report to Congress on the department's child-support enforcement program. The program, established in 1975, is operated by state and local governments with Federal assistance. It locates missing parents, determines paternity of children born out of wedlock and enforces support agreements and court orders.

The New Mexico Supreme Court today upheld Gov. Toney Anaya's commutation of five convicted murderers' death sentences. Chief Justice Harry Stowers Jr. said the court was denying a petition to compel a District Court judge in Albuquerque to set an execution date for one of the inmates, Joel Lee Compton. The Governor, who leaves office Jan. 1 after serving one term, the maximum allowed by law, had vowed since his campaign in 1982 that no one would be executed in New Mexico while he was Governor.

Sam Perlazzo, who compiled a 364-237 record as a minor-league manager in the Mets farm system the last five years, has been added to the Mets' coaching staff for 1987. Perlazzo managed Tidewater of the International league to a 74-66 record last season.

The Postal Service will deliver mail this Friday, the day after Christmas, even though President Reagan has declared the day a Federal holiday, the agency said today. In a notice informing employees that Dec. 26 and Jan. 2 would be official business days, the agency added, ''The Postal Service simply cannot afford to incur the enormous additional costs which would be involved in declaring these days as nonwork days.''

Joseph Court with a hand-delivered present from Santa yesterday at the Burn Center at New York Hospital. Daniel Prince of Ladder 156 dressed as Santa as he visited patients at the center. The visit was sponsored by the city's firefighters. (NYT/Marilynn K. Yee)

In these final days before Christmas, a change has come over the Ascension Roman Catholic Church on Carnation Drive here. It is more than the addition of the Christ Child to the manger, more than the presents for the poor around the Christmas tree, more than the children's pageant of angels and wise men, more than the voices of the choir members rehearsing. ''It is a state of mind,'' said an usher, Edward Rooney. ''It is a feeling,'' said the pastor, the Rev. Thomas E. Davis. ''Whatever it is,'' added a parishioner, Brendan Suter, ''it completes our Christmas.''

WATCHING I.B.M. has long been a favorite pastime in the computer industry, and none of that company's products have been more closely scrutinized than its personal computers. It was Big Blue, after all, that made the personal computer respectable, allowing executives to roll up their sleeves and delve right into Flight Simulator along with the most ardent of the hobbyists. Over the last couple of years, I.B.M. has introduced the Jr., portable and convertible models, but for all its past victories in the personal computing arena, Attila from Armonk hasn't won any battles lately. That precious benchmark, its market share, is slipping.

Black civic and political leaders, both loudly and softly, said yesterday that the attack by white youths on three black men in Queens last weekend was convincing evidence that racially motivated violence was a ''pervasive problem and not an isolated one,'' as some people had maintained. The attack has generated demonstrations and calls for multiracial efforts to improve race relations, as well as more confrontational tactics, such as conducting hearings in the mostly white Howard Beach area on racial violence. The incident has also spawned the formation of at least two ad hoc committees, each with the goal of trying to examine the causes of such incidents. Searches for an Explanation One is a multiracial panel organized by the New York Civil Liberties Union. The other involves a group of black ministers and civic leaders who inspired hearings on charges of police brutality against blacks in New York City three years ago.

Pope John Paul II said today that the day of prayer for peace at Assisi two months ago should serve as a model for interfaith cooperation and ecumenical initiatives. He said the day of prayer ''seems to have been the religious event that was most closely followed by the world this year.''

The Quebec Court of Appeal today struck down a provision in the province's nine-year-old language law that prohibits the use of languages other than French on public signs. The ruling was a victory for store owners and others in the province who have persisted in displaying English signs alongside French ones. But it seemed likely to stir further ferment among groups that have made their insistence on French-only signs a central issue in recent demonstrations against the Quebec government.

A former criminal justice professor at the University of Nebraska, wanted as a fugitive from justice in New York State since 1975, has decided to turn himself over to New York authorities, his lawyer said today. The defendant, Paul Stewart, ''will be appearing in the courts of New York State sometime this week or next,'' said his attorney, Kirk E. Naylor Jr.

''This is 'Brigadoon,' '' a resident of Howard Beach told a reporter a few years ago, when questions about the neighborhood were asked in a more innocent context. Yet now, in the aftermath of the beatings of three black men by a dozen whites, the comment has taken on a new and different resonance. For while Brigadoon was a paradise, as many in Howard Beach see their community on Jamaica Bay, it was fixed in the past. So, too, Howard Beach seems to have existed independent of the rest of New York City, isolated by natural barriers, belatedly tethered to the mass transit system and largely unmarked by the racial integration that has transformed the face of dozens of other neighborhoods. ''Howard Beach is a small town,'' said Andrew Hacker, a professor of political science at Queens College and an expert on New York neighborhoods. ''It is isolated and it is insulated. There is something about it like Bay Ridge in 'Saturday Night Fever.' It's far from the city, a long way from the city.''

It's time to put on the dancing shoes and kick up your heels. From now till New Year's Eve, there'll be plenty of excuses to get dressed up. Whether dressed up means long and sleek or short and puffy, whether shoulders are bared or covered up, the look this year is glamorous. It's a safe bet that not since Louis XIV has there been such a choice of fancy and fanciful foot coverings.

How do you make a movie out of ''Native Son''? Richard Wright's book, which was published in 1940, is still assigned in hundreds of high school and college classes. It has now been made into a movie, which opens Wednesday in New York, Los Angeles and Chicago. The first commercially successful novel in which a black writer confronted white America with his anger, ''Native Son'' has long been considered of great sociologic as well as literary importance. But critics, both black and white, also acknowledge that from today's perspective the book has serious flaws.

Stock prices fell yesterday as trading reverted to more normal levels after the record-breaking session on Friday caused by the ''triple witching hour.'' Yesterday's turnover of 157.6 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange, while hefty by ordinary standards, was far below the historic 244.7 million shares traded Friday. The simultaneous expiration of stock-index futures, index options and regular stock options on Friday caused an avalanche of orders in the final minutes of trading.

''FOR centuries,'' said the program notes at Sunday afternoon's Empire Brass concert at Carnegie Hall, ''these instruments have had specific functions entirely separate from the standard ensembles of 'elevated' music-making,'' and so, in a way, they still do. There is something about the sheer brave sound of brass instruments that appeals beyond the constituency of the normal symphony orchestra, crosses some of the pop-classical dividing lines and rouses an audience to special approval -particularly when the players are as good as Sunday's, and whether or not the music is. Indeed, the program notes were devoted more to the instruments and their sounds than to the music - and when they got around to the latter, it turned out to be the music for a different program! That's not to say that the music played at Carnegie Hall was second rate, but that it played second fiddle.
Robert B. Bannerman, regional security officer at the United States Embassy in Kenya, was killed Saturday night in a car accident in Nairobi, the State Department said today.

To the Editor: Londoners may have felt a skipped heartbeat when Big Ben snapped a rod. They would suffer a collective heart attack if the repaired clock played your notes. Stockhausen or Boulez might appreciate the effect. TONY KALLET Boulder, Colo., Dec. 6, 1986

Three white teen-agers were charged last night with second-degree murder in the beating of three black men in Howard Beach, Queens, the police said. One of the victims was killed by a car as he fled early Saturday from what the authorities called a nightmarish racial attack. The arrests, in what Mayor Koch described as ''a racial lynching'' and ''the most horrendous incident'' of his nine years at City Hall, came as city officials, clergymen, civil-rights activists and community leaders expressed outrage at the crime and began a reassessment of race relations in the city. The police said the suspects had left a party when they heard that the three blacks were walking through their mostly white, middle-class community early Saturday, and, in two attacks in an eight-block chase punctuated by racial taunts and insults, kicked and beat the victims with fists, a baseball bat and a tree limb. Details of the Beatings One of the black men escaped with a single blow of the bat. A second was beaten severely. A third, Michael Griffith, a 23-year-old Brooklyn construction worker, was also beaten severely and was struck and killed by a car on the Shore Parkway near Cross Bay Boulevard as he tried to run away.
A Dallas dispatch yesterday about Richard Knight Jr., the new City Manager, misidentified his predecessor. He is Charles Anderson.

Governor Cuomo and key lawmakers announced agreement tonight on an $8.6 billion, five-year program to rebuild New York City's subway, bus and commuter rail lines and to freeze their fares for three years. But they put off until next year a decision on how to pay for parts of the program. The agreement, which is expected to be voted Tuesday, averts the immediate fare increases that had been threatened by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. Instead, an existing tax that would have expired Dec. 31 is to be extended.

The creation of 23 new judgeships to beef up New York City's ability to try crack cases gave Governor Cuomo a chance to fight the state's boss-ridden system for picking judges. His ''merit selection'' method falls short of convincing reform but still constitutes a welcome step forward.

Because of a mechanical error, a Washington dispatch in some copies on Saturday, about President Reagan's proposals for MX and Midgetman missiles, omitted part of the identity of President Ford's national security adviser, who headed a Reagan Presidential commission on the subject. He is Lieut. Gen. Brent Scowcroft, a retired Air Force officer.

RESEARCHERS have found, contrary to their expectations, that a facial expression of contempt does not significantly vary from culture to culture - but is, instead, universally recognizable, from West Germany toto West Sumatra. The research, conducted by Dr. Paul Ekman and Dr. Wallace V. Friesen of the University of California at San Francisco, was reported in the journal Motivation and Emotion.

President Reagan considered, but rejected, the idea of granting a pardon to Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter and Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North in the hope that they would then tell what they knew about the Iran arms affair, the White House said today. The chief White House spokesman, Larry Speakes, said Mr. Reagan had discussed the option last week, but had decided instead to urge Congressional investigative committees to grant limited immunity to the two former White House officials. Mr. Speakes's acknowledgment was the first public confirmation that Mr. Reagan had considered using a pardon as a tactic to assure the public that he is interested in full disclosure regarding the secret sale of arms to Iran and the diversion of money to Nicaraguan rebels.

One in five American adults suffers from some type of disability, a Census Bureau study disclosed today. Difficulty in walking and lifting were the most common problems. The rate of disabilities increases with age, affecting more than half of those 65 years old and over, the report said. But physical limitations also hinder the work of many younger people, 12 percent of those 16 to 64.

Shortly after he becomes Governor of Arizona next month, Evan Mecham plans to do something no other governor has done: rescind a state holiday honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. The move has angered and surprised many Arizonans and has drawn criticism and concern from civil rights leaders and politicians around the country. ''I'm disappointed,'' said the Rev. Warren Stewart Sr., pastor of the First Institutional Baptist Church here. ''I have said it before and I stand behind it: I think Mr. Mecham has a racist mentality.''

IN February 1984, Martha Rusk Sutphen decided that she could make a contribution to New York City's public schools. For six years, she had run a consortium of eight private schools and published a newspaper for them. She had taught at one and been on the board of another. Although she had never been licensed to teach in public schools, the public schools were calling for new teachers. She decided to seek a license to teach English.

Andrei D. Sakharov returned to Moscow before dawn today, ending nearly seven years of banishment in the city of Gorky for his outspoken advocacy of human rights. Dr. Sakharov, a physicist, and his wife, Yelena G. Bonner, were greeted by a crush of Western reporters and cameramen as they stepped off train No. 37 from Gorky, an industrial city 260 miles east of Moscow that is closed to foreigners. A few friends were on the platform to meet them, but there was no official greeting party. No unusual security measures were evident at the station.

David Charles Penhaligon, a prominent Liberal Member of Parliament, died today when a skidding van collided with his car on an icy hill. He was 42 years old. The collision occurred in Mr. Penhaligon's electoral district in Cornwall, the police said. Mr. Penhaligon was the Liberal Party's finance spokesman.

With Christmas near at hand, the old Remington Products plant here is stacked to its rafters with thousands of electric shavers. And Victor Kiam, the chairman, marketing guru and sole stockholder of Remington, is an exhausted man. ''The opportunities are endless; my only problem is time,'' said Mr. Kiam, who has starred in his own television advertising around the world for five years. In 18 languages, some of them hastily memorized, he has made the cheery pitch that Remington's shavers ''shave as close as a blade, or your money back.'' But now he is trying to extend his pitch beyond shavers, which were scheduled to be shipped out of Remington's plant by the thousands for the holiday sales rush. Having built Remington into the world's second-largest manufacturer of electric shavers - it trails only Norelco, a subsidiary of Philips N.V., the Dutch concern - Mr. Kiam has added a host of offbeat consumer goods that range from machine washable neckties to a portable vacuum that chemically cleans rugs.

This listless town seemed to shake today as an American cargo plane touched down with the first shipment of United States military equipment since Libya began an offensive in northern Chad. The shipment arrived as Chadian Government officials announced that Libyan warplanes, flying during a break in desert sandstorms, repeatedly bombed Chadian guerrillas today. Ahmed Moussa-Mi, chief of staff to President Hissen Habre, asserted that in addition to conventional bombing, Libyan forces had dropped napalm and poison gas near Zouar. The report could not be verified.

The union representing employees of the New York City Housing Authority has broken off contract talks with the city, and is threatening to strike public housing projects on New Year's Day. A strike vote is to be taken among union members at a rally tonight at the Felt Forum. Barry Feinstein, president of the city employees' local of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, said he would recommend a walkout.

Up to 1,000 youngsters from the Washington area plan to demonstrate today near the South African Embassy to call attention to the plight of young people detained in South Africa. According to a spokesman for TransAfrica, the anti-apartheid organization that is leading the protest, some of the youngsters will provoke their arrest by demonstrating in front of the embassy.

Two members of the National Security Council staff have resigned as part of a shake-up ordered by the new national security adviser, Frank C. Carlucci, White House officials said today. One of the staff members, Raymond F. Burkhardt, senior director for Latin American affairs, will return to the State Department and will be sent to the United States Embassy in Beijing, a spokesman said.

THIS year may long be remembered as the Year of the Big Dismissals. Many of those who find themselves suddenly out of work will have the benefit of outplacement services to help them find jobs. Others, however, especially those who take early retirement, often are not offered outplacement help. Buying such assistance on an individual basis can be not only expensive but also disappointing. Some firms presenting themselves as career counselors have been investigated by various state attorneys general for misrepresentation. Those seeking counseling should inquire about such help at Better Business Bureaus, attorney general's offices and consumer fraud units.
The Ford Motor Company is discussing a United States-based joint venture with the Nissan Motor Company to produce V-8 and V-6 engines in the 1990's, American Metal Market-Metalworking News said.

Thirty-seven drilling rig workers who had been evacuated in two small escape capsules to avoid a possible blowout in the Gulf of Mexico were rescued today in heavy seas. Just before midnight Sunday, the crew left the offshore drill rig Oceanic Triton IV, situated 70 miles south of Galveston Island, because of the danger of a natural gas explosion, said Chief Michael Martin of the Coast Guard.

* Adolph Coors Co., Golden, Colo., said it would start the second phase of construction at its Shenandoah Brewery site near Elkton, Va., in January. * Ethyl Corp., Richmond, said it had signed a definitive merger agreement with Nelson Research and Development Co. for the acquisition of Nelson by Ethyl at a price of $5.75 a share cash, or about $53 million.

Up to now, the thousands of satellites sent into orbits around the earth since 1957 have been strictly utilitarian, serving in global communication, weather forecasting, mineral prospecting, spying and many other practical activities. But in 1989 a consortium of French interests hopes to launch a satellite whose function will be strictly aesthetic: to treat earthlings on all continents to a blazing ring of light in the sky that will circle the world every 90 minutes or so.

Charles P. Young & Company, a financial-printing subsidiary of the Service Resources Corporation, offered yesterday to acquire Pandick Inc., the market leader in that printing field, for $28 a share, or about $280 million. The bid came just one week before the expiration of a tender offer by Pandick senior executives to buy the company for $25.50, or about $250 million. It was not known how many shares have been tendered.

To the Editor: It is imperative your readers have the facts about decisions I recently made on this country's fighter-aircraft needs (''Off We Go, Again, on Fighter Planes,'' editorial, Nov. 14). Apparently, you think Secretary of Defense Caspar Weinberger and I should be playing games and ''making deals'' in determining America's defense needs. There are no games and no deals when it comes to protecting the nation's security. Our weapon-systems decisions are not driven by our own desires or political pressures, but by what we must do to counter the technically sophisticated threats we face.

* Conchemco Inc., Wichita, Kan., a maker of mechanical controls and plastic parts, said Darwin H. Deaver and William C. Hanes had resigned from its board because of pressures from other business interests. * Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Atlanta, a bottler of Coca-Cola soft drink products, appointed H. Richard Hiller Jr. senior vice president of the company, as well as president of Coca-Cola Enterprises, South Central; Larry Smith was named vice president of the company and president of Coca-Cola Enterprises, West.

International A3-15 The President considered pardoning Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter and Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North in hopes that they would tell what they knew about Iran, but then rejected the idea, the White House said. Page A1 Canada said it had no entry record for the son of the Speaker of the Iranian Parliament, who was reported to have fled there with $6 million in commissions from Washington's secret arms deals with Iran. A14 Iran said an Iraqi air raid killed more than 100 people in the western town of Eslamabad-e Gharb, and it announced an extension of its reprisal shelling of military and economic targets inside Iraq.

Q.To reduce the expense of decaffeinating coffee, why not develop plants that produce caffeine-free coffee beans? A.Caffeine represents only 1 percent of the coffee bean and it is highly unlikely that coffee breeders could eliminate it, according to Dr. William Pardee, chairman of the department of plant breeding at Cornell University. But it could be reduced, he said, if coffee plants were cross-bred with related plants that produce beans low in caffeine. The offspring would then be crossed with other coffee plants. The procedure would be repeated until it resulted in a plant producing flavorful, low-caffeine beans. This process, which might require many generations of plants, would take years, he said.

Some short-term interest rates rose by more than a percentage point yesterday as major banks began borrowing money in anticipation of a flurry of year-end loan demands. ''It's the normal year-end phenomenon, exacerbated by some special circumstances this year,'' said Allan Lerner, a managing director at the Bankers Trust Company. As the year draws to a close, he said, large banks expect to see heavy loan demand related to leveraged buyouts of corporations, merger and acquisition activity, and the financing of large inventories held by securities dealers. The latest jump in short-term rates, which followed steep increases last week, resulted in some banks paying as much as 9 percent for 30-day time deposits in London. While most 30-day deposits in London went at 8 percent to 8 1/2 percent, even those rates were well above the 7 3/16 percent of last Friday or the 6 1/4 percent of Dec. 15.

Robert M. Wilkis, a former investment banker with Lazard Freres & Company, pleaded guilty in Federal District Court yesterday to four felony charges involving insider trading. Mr. Wilkis, 37 years old, had been accused of swapping tips about pending corporate takeover bids with Dennis B. Levine and earning more than $2.5 million by illegally trading on this information. He faces a sentence of up to five years in prison on each of the four counts, and a total fine of $850,000. His sentencing was scheduled for Feb. 9.

Lou Carnesecca, basketball coach at St. John's, on the 411 arcane pages of rules and regulations that make up the N.C.A.A. Manual: ''Our Lord gave us Ten Commandments, and look at the trouble we have with those.''
Sakharov Back in Moscow Andrei D. Sakharov, free after seven years in exile in the closed city of Gorky, returned to Moscow with his wife, Yelena G. Bonner.

Mayor Koch, other members of the Board of Estimate and the Democratic organizations in the five boroughs have raised $30 million in campaign funds in the last six years, much of it from people doing business with the city, a Democratic state senator said yesterday. A staff study released by the Senator, Franz Leichter of Manhattan, lists the 200 largest contributors; they gave a total of $10 million to the Democratic Party and the Board of Estimate members. Sixty percent of the donors did business with the city. The Leichter study comes amid the city's corruption scandal - which involved at least one former member of the Board of Estimate, the late Donald R. Manes - and investigations of two other board members stemming from the scandal.

One thing on which leaders in Egypt and Israel and Palestinians in the West Bank tend to join is their complaint about lack of momentum in U.S. Middle East policy. It isn't correct to say there is no policy. There is a deliberate policy of marking time, waiting for the principals to signal they are ready for new peace negotiations. Since Lebanon exploded in his face in 1983, Secretary of State George Shultz has determined that the best place for the U.S. is in the back seat, not trying to drive.

N.B.A. Jazz 114, 76ers 111: Bobby Hansen's basket after a steal by John Stockton with six seconds left gave Utah the victory last night in Philadelphia. The victory was Utah's third straight and 10th in its last 11 games, while the Sixers have lost six of their last seven. (AP) N.H.L. Penguins 4, Canadiens 4: Craig Simpson scored his third goal of the game with four minutes left to give Pittsburgh a tie with the Canadiens in Montreal. Simpson scored two of his three goals with less than eight minutes remaining in the third period as the Penguins rallied from a two-goal deficit. It was the Penguins' first game without their scoring leader, Mario Lemieux, who injured his knee Saturday and will be sidelined for three weeks. (AP) College Basketball North Carolina 95, Furman 65: Dave Popson had 16 points and Kenny Smith and Ranzino Smith scored 14 each for North Carolina (7-1). The Tar Heels, playing in Charlotte, N.C., led by only 6 points with 5:44 left in the first half, but Popson scored 4 straight points and North Carolina expanded the margin to 47-33 at halftime. The Paladins (5-3) hit the first basket of the second half to close the gap to 12 points, but could draw no closer.(AP) Duke 74, Miami 67: Tommy Amaker scored 21 points and Kevin Strickland added 19 to lead slow-starting Duke to the victory in Miami. Danny Ferry contributed 13 points and Billy King had 12 for the Blue Devils (6-1).

The deal sounded too good to be true: Buy a new car and receive a free ''trip for two to Mexico, includes airfare, hotel and more.'' The hundreds of people who responded to the newspaper advertisements soon discovered that the deal was indeed too good to be true. According to the Long Island Better Business Bureau, although they were entitled to a round-trip they received only a run-around.

DAYTIME Lincoln Center's Alice Tully Hall is working overtime today in the season of joy. In a schedule that rivals the old Palace vaudeville calendar, ''A Holday Celebration'' goes on a two-a-day basis, but for today only. This two-part event performs at 10:30 A.M. and again at noon, with emphasis on song and dance. The program is part of Jacques d'Amboise's ''Celebration'' series -a product of the Lincoln Center ''Meet the Artist'' project and the National Dance Institute - a series created to introduce students to live performance. More than 150 of the institute's children will perform ''Fat City,'' a story-ballet set in an imaginary place. In this production, conceived and directed by Mr. d'Amboise, Maureen McGovern, who recorded ''The Morning After'' and had a starring role in both ''Nine'' and ''The Pirates of Penzance,'' will be featured, along with the dancers Valerie Wright and Donlin Foreman. The piece itself, which was performed in the film ''He Makes Me Feel Like Dancing,'' is said to include original music by George Balanchine and Christopher d'Amboise.

A defense witness testified yesterday that Richard C. Williams, who is charged with killing a state trooper in 1981, had short hair 10 days before the shooting, an account that contradicted another witness's description of a long-haired passenger in the getaway car. Last month a prosecution witness, Joan Gouger, testified that she followed the getaway car through Hainesburg, N.J., 15 minutes after the killing of Trooper Philip J. Lamonaco and that the sole passenger had hair so long she first thought it was a woman.

Auditors and lawyers for Intelsat are examining the possibility that two former senior executives may have used contracts with outside consultants to divert funds to the executives' personal use, according to United States Government officials and Intelsat sources. These sources said today that the investigators have discovered transactions that contravened the agency's standard procedure for procurement of services. The transactions were authorized by one or both of the executives, these sources said.

''While I marvel at the wonders of this great city, I am saddened by the suffering and the squalor which linger in the shadows of our Christmas lights,'' said Elliott R. Peters, a New Yorker who gave $500 to the 75th annual appeal of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. A gift of $50 came from Mary H. Casey of Silver Spring, Md., who wrote that when she ''first went to New York as a graduate student at Fordham University,'' she ''was thrilled by the cultural and educational opportunities of the city, but I was very disturbed by the poverty and suffering I saw there.''

Congress The House and Senate Intelligence Committees: The Senate committee, headed by Senator Dave Durenberger, Republican of Minnesota, has completed three weeks of closed hearings. The House committee, led by Representative Lee H. Hamilton, Democrat of Indiana, is expected to complete closed hearings within a few days. The House Foreign Affairs Committee: Headed by Representative Dante B. Fascell, Democrat of Florida, the panel has been conducting open hearings at which Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter, the former national security adviser, and Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, who was dismissed from the National Security Council staff, refused to testify under the Fifth Amendment right not to incriminate themselves.

The White House said President Reagan rejected the option of granting a pardon to Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter and Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North to encourage them to tell what they knew about the Iran arms affair.

Panel on Municipal Corruption The city's municipal corruption scandal will be discussed by a panel of prosecutors at a public hearing sponsored by the State Senate Investigations Committee. Panelists will include United States Attorney Rudolph W. Giuliani, District Attorney John J. Santucci of Queens and the city's Investigation Commissioner, Kenneth Conboy. 10 A.M., 25th floor hearing room, 270 Broadway, Manhattan Cab Medallion Hearing Mayor Koch's proposal to issue 1,800 new taxi medallions, which would have to be returned to the city if licensees give up driving their cabs, will be the subject of a hearing by the City Council's Committee on Transportation. 10:30 A.M., Council Chamber, City Hall

Orders for ''big ticket'' durable goods, powered by a big military buildup and a last-minute rush to take advantage of expiring tax breaks, soared 5.9 percent in November, the biggest rise in two years, the Commerce Department reported today. However, because the strength was limited to those two areas, analysts generally dismissed the big gain as telling little about future economic growth. Without the huge military increase, orders would have risen a much smaller six-tenths of 1 percent.

In time, the investigation into the Iranian arms controversy will end. There may be prosecutions, new laws, a reorganization of the National Security Council. But one thing that is vitally necessary may not happen at all - creation of a new compact between the executive and legislative branches that will permit the United States to discharge more effectively its responsibilities as a great power. From Vietnam, through Watergate, to the present, in Democratic and Republican Administrations, the estrangement between the White House and Capitol Hill has deepened. Congress distrusts the President and insists on multiplying checks - oversight committees, the War Powers Act, media leaks and legislative vetoes. The White House responds in kind - building up the National Security Council staff as an isolated and autonomous operational agency, appealing over the heads of Congress to the public, managing its own pattern of leaks and counter-leaks.

Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North was hospitalized for 10 days in 1974 for emotional distress, but the White House was unaware of his medical history when it hired him in 1981 for the staff of the National Security Council, according to an authoritative Pentagon source. Richard V. Allen, who was President Reagan's national security adviser until January 1982, said today that he did not know about the hospitalization when he hired Colonel North in the summer of 1981. Had he known, Mr. Allen said, Colonel North probably would not have been asked to join the White House staff.
''This was the last major event of atmospheric flight. That we did it as private citizens says a lot about freedom in America.''

EVER wonder just who thinks up those toys that every kid wants for Christmas? To find out, we take you not to the North Pole, but to the elegant Claremont Hotel in Berkeley, Calif. Walk through the spacious lobby, down one flight of stairs, past the restrooms and into the cluttered offices of one Stephen Beck, engineer, inventor, artist, entrepreneur and elf. Mr. Beck and his company, Beck-Tech, helped develop Talking Wrinkles, a stuffed dog that talks, sings and barks electronically. This is not just another talking dog story.

A Government safety agency today urged Volkswagen of America to recall about 250,000 Audi automobiles to correct a sudden-acceleration problem. The request, covering 1978 through 1986 Audi 5000's with automatic transmission, came in a letter to the automaker from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, which has been investigating reports of accidents. The agency did not order a recall, pending a full investigation. Instead, it asked the company to undertake on its own ''a safety recall and diagnosis and correction of faults in engine idle control systems.''

The new Kazakhstan party leader, Gennadi V. Kolbin, today denounced party operations in the Central Asian republic. He called for ''radical change'' in the party's handling of economic and cultural development, emphasizing the need for instilling a more ''interethnic'' spirit in the population of this ethnically mixed republic.

A team of microsurgeons used a rare emergency procedure early this morning to try to reattach the severed foot of a 13-month-old boy whose mother leaped in front of an oncoming A train in upper Manhattan yesterday while carrying the infant. Doctors at Bellevue Hospital Center were trying to sew the left foot of the baby, Vladomir Ramos, to his right leg.

Maurice Grosser, a painter known for his picturesque landscapes, still lifes and portraits, died of congestive heart failure Monday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived in Manhattan. A writer as well as a painter, Mr. Grosser moved in a circle of avant-garde authors and musicians. He devised the scenario for two operas by Virgil Thomson and Gertrude Stein, ''Four Saints in Three Acts'' (1934) and ''The Mother of Us All'' (1947). In 1985 he again worked with Mr. Thomson on ''18 Portraits,'' a collection of original lithographs accompanied by the composer's musical ''portraits.'' At his death he was completing a memoir, a section of which, ''Visiting Gertrude Stein and Alice Toklas,'' has appeared in The New York Review of Books.
