The Scouting column in Sports Pages yesterday, reporting on a cross-country runner who sued the University of Colorado over drug testing, misidentified him. He is David Derdyn.

Every time Tony McKegney's name comes up these days, it is followed by ''again'' as in ''McKegney again.'' The Rangers had just lost their entire three-goal lead. Another late breakdown seemed imminent, but there came McKegney again, charging down the slot to score the go-ahead goal. Then, a few minutes later, he scored another one. The Rangers, thriving on two big scoring outbursts, beat the Devils last night at Madison Square Garden, 8-5. The hero was McKegney, again.

Andrei D. Sakharov, once vilified in the Soviet press as a ''renegade and turncoat,'' was greeted with applause today by colleagues at a scientific seminar at his Physics Institute. Participants said that the 65-year-old physicist, who returned to Moscow earlier today after seven years of exile in Gorky, was welcomed warmly when he appeared for a discussion on contemporary science. ''Sakharov is Sakharov - there is only one such man,'' said a fellow scientist after the seminar. ''God grant that he remains Sakharov.''

Joseph A. Califano Jr., former Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, is the likely candidate to head a new commission being set up by Governor Cuomo to investigate unethical conduct by public officials, according to people familiar with the Governor's thinking. Mr. Califano, a lawyer who served in the Administration of President Jimmy Carter, did not return a half-dozen telephone messages left yesterday at his Washington office. State officials said a formal announcement setting up the commission, which would be statewide and have subpoena power, was likely by the end of the week.

A system called pixel-planes, now being developed at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, holds the promise of generating realistic three-dimensional images on a video screen at a fraction of the current cost, researchers there said. By manipulating 3-D video images with computer joysticks, an architect, for example, could take a ''walking tour'' of a building before it is built, or a surgeon could examine 3-D images of organs inside the body of a patient. The system contains more than 2,000 computer chips and can perform 12 million operations a second, according to Dr. John W. Poulton, one of the principal researchers. Dr. Poulton said the research group had received a patent on the system and was exploring ways to market it.

The Koch administration yesterday announced a plan to renovate nearly 5,200 apartments in abandoned city-owned buildings in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn. The proposal, which represents the first phase of a 10-year, $4.2 billion municipal housing plan put forward earlier this year, calls for the apartments to go primarily to low- and moderate-income New Yorkers. The renovations, to be done by private developers, nonprofit community groups and contractors hired by the city, would be underwritten by $240 million of the city's capital funds, the largest such investment made by the city for housing. Mayor Koch called the effort ''the largest such commitment by a city in the country,'' and he said it would have ''a substantial impact on the supply of housing.''

Mike Archer was promoted from defensive coordinator to head football coach at Louisiana State University, replacing Bill Arnsparger, who resigned to take the post of athletic director at the University of Florida. The school's board of supervisors picked Archer over Mike Shanahan, the offensive coordinator for the Denver Broncos, and George Haffner, the assistant at the University of Georgia. Arnsparger led the Tigers to a 9-2 won-lost record, good for the university's first Southeastern Conference championship in 16 years and a berth in the Sugar Bowl, where Arnsparger will coach his last game for L.S.U.

FOR makers of wrapping paper, Santa's red suit is a little bolder this year, Christmas trees are a more brilliant green, and silvery winter scenes are glistening more brightly. The sparkle of this season's wrapping paper has been preserved through advances in resin technology and water-based inks, despite a major change in the way wrapping paper is printed as a result of Federal regulations aimed at reducing air pollution. When the air pollution regulations caused paper makers to abandon petroleum-based inks, which released solvents into the atmosphere as the ink dried, manufacturers reluctantly turned to expensive nonsolvent water-based inks, which had been limited to a small, specialized segment of the $1.6 billion Christmas wrap industry. These inks were not known for their color integrity and their use in high-speed, high-quantity presses was virtually untested.

Street protests by students calling for democracy spread to the capital tonight. Several thousand students from Qinghua University in Beijing poured into the streets in below-freezing temperatures demanding an end to authoritarianism and urging the granting of democratic rights for the Chinese people. The rally in Beijing, which included a march through the city's northern university districts was the first time this city's students have publicly joined the wave of student protests that has erupted in at least six cities in China over the last three and a half weeks. Catalogue of Students Demonstrations held in Shanghai in the last week were are the largest to take place in China since the end of the cultural revolution in 1976.

Burglars broke into a small theater off the Champs-Elysees today and stole six paintings by J. Edouard Vuillard, a post-Impressionist artist who was commissioned to do the works for the theater's opening in 1913.

The Government has begun an investigation into whether an Israeli nuclear technician was abducted by Israeli agents on Italian soil, and if so, whether any Italian laws were violated. ''We will insist that this be cleared up,'' Prime Minister Bettino Craxi said today. Mr. Craxi, speaking at a news conference, said there were reasons to suspect that the Israeli, Mordechai Vannunu, 31 years old, had been kidnapped in Rome by Israeli agents and taken back to Israel to face trial for spying and treason. Specifically, Mr. Vanunu has been accused in Israel of selling information to The Sunday Times of London about the Dimona nuclear plant in the Negev, where he worked for 10 years. The newspaper reported that the plant is the key part of a nuclear weapons production complex.

An article yesterday about a proposal to abolish the New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission omitted part of a comment from Mayor Koch about a State Commission of Investigation finding that major policy decisions on taxis were made at City Hall. Mr Koch said, ''There is no question that I seek to get the Taxi Commission to agree with me on taxi policy.''

At least eight people drowned when a 28-foot boat loaded with 48 people from the Dominican Republic was swamped in turbulent waters within a few hundred feet of shore, the authorities reported today. Officials said the people on the boat were trying to sneak into the United States through Puerto Rico. A huge wave swamped the vessel Monday night at a beach off the town of Rincon on the westernmost tip of the island, an area famed among surfing enthusiasts as ''the Hawaii of the East.''
A theater listing in The Guide on Sunday misidentified the star of ''Me and My Girl.'' He is Robert Lindsay. Jim Dale substituted for a week, ending Sunday.

United States and Soviet officials have agreed to broadcast a series of joint television programs by satellite that will depict the political and cultural life of both countries. The programs reflect a cultural exchange agreement reached between President Reagan and Mikhail Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, last year in Geneva, and will be paid for by contributions and foundation grants, according to officials from both sides. Internews, a nonprofit organization with experience in international productions, is coordinating the venture, which will be monitored by a six-member bipartisan Congressional steering committee headed by Representative George E. Brown Jr., Democrat of California, and Representative Claudine Schneider, Republican of Florida. The first broadcast, a simultaneous exchange between policy makers in the United States and the Soviet Union, is tentatively scheduled for March.

The dilemma for China has long been clear. Without reform and greater openness, the nation was doomed to poverty and decay. Yet with them, Chinese Communism would be threatened. The tens of thousands of students and workers who have been demonstrating for democracy in Shanghai and now Beijing provide dramatic evidence that Deng Xiaoping's success in raising his people's hopes for a brighter economic future has also deepened the political side of the dilemma.
Tomorrow is Christmas Day. Following are holiday schedules: Parking - Sunday rules.

The Federal Trade Commission is investigating at least six major Wall Street firms in connection with the possible illegal accumulation of stock for clients planning hostile takeovers, agency officials said today. In announcing the investigations, the F.T.C. warned that such practices, including buying large amounts of stock for a client without filing a premerger application with the agency, violated antitrust laws. The agency said that the investment banking firms and their clients were subject to penalties as high as $10,000 for each day they failed to file. The warning was issued by Jeffrey I. Zuckerman, director of the F.T.C.'s bureau of competition.

Coopervision Inc., an eye care company, reported earnings today for the fourth quarter ended Oct. 31 of $16.4 million, or 73 cents a share, up 32.2 percent from $12.4 million, or 59 cents a share in the comparable period a year ago. Revenues rose 40.8 percent, to $140 million, from $99.4 million.

The drive that won it, the drive that made the New England Patriots division champions and pushed the Jets into a wild-card game, took about seven minutes of the last quarter of the season and was orchestrated by a player who hadn't been heard from in quite some time. Not that Steve Grogan's contribution to the Patriots was ever inconspicuous. As the backup to the starting quarterback, Tony Eason, who is younger by six years and less experienced by eight seasons, Grogan calls the plays for Eason from the sidelines, a novel situation by most standards. But Monday night, in the final National Football League game that would be played in the Orange Bowl, Grogan was calling his own plays, now in charge because of an odd injury Eason suffered earlier.
Ron Kornegay resigned as Monmouth College's basketball coach last Friday, saying that ''the program needs to go in another direction.''

With a dire need for more scoring from the small-forward position, the Nets invested three draft choices and $1.5 million over two years to bring Orlando Woolridge to New Jersey from the Chicago Bulls. Tonight, he began paying back on the investment. Returning from a four-game layoff caused by muscle pulls in both thighs, the 6-foot-9-inch Woolridge, who replaced Jeff Turner in the lineup with 5 minutes 45 seconds remaining in the opening quarter, scored 23 points that helped the Nets defeat the Utah Jazz, the hottest team in the National Basketball Association, 119-96, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena. While the Nets, running their fast break better than at any time this season, brought their record to 6-19 with successive victories for the first time this season, the bigger, stronger and deeper Jazz, playing their sixth game in the last eight nights, lost for only the second time in the last 12 games. The loss dropped their record to 17-9.

At the age of 30, Eugene (Buddy) Teevens yesterday became the youngest head coach in Dartmouth's 105-year football history and the 19th head coach since 1881. Teevens replaces Joe Yukica, who compiled a 36-47-4 record in nine years before being let go at the end of this season, in which the Ivy League team posted a 3-6-1 record.

Beset by creditors and exhausted by a feat that had defied all others, Richard G. Rutan and Jeana Yeager took their places yesterday among the legendary pilots of history. Their world-circling flight in the Voyager was a family affair, in which ingenuity and courage served in place of the big budgets and engineering teams of the aerospace industry. Like the Wright brothers' Flyer, the Voyager incorporates a pioneering aeronautical design and some of the most advanced structural materials of its day. But in other respects the Voyager is as crude as any airplane that ever flew, and its flight into the record books had less to do with space-age technology than with the personal sacrifices, improvisations and dedication of its impecunious creators. The peculiar looking airplane will probably take its place in the National Air and Space Museum with Charles A. Lindbergh's Spirit of St. Louis, Wiley Post's Winnie Mae and one of Amelia Earhart's Electras, but for all its celebrity, the Voyager is made mostly out of paper and plastic, and its builders expect to have to go on selling souvenir T-shirts and tie tacks to help pay the estimated $550,000 that it cost to build the plane.

THE Alwin Nikolais Dance Theater presented the world premiere of Mr. Nikolais's ''Velocities'' Monday night. Like much of the current engagement, running through Jan. 4, the new piece stresses the quicksilver muscular control of the 10 dancers who serve their choreographer so well. Other works in this third program of the season at the Joyce Theater, Eighth Avenue and 19th Street, were ''Cantos,'' ''Persons and Structures,'' an item entitled ''Excerpt From Arporisms'' and ''The Mechanical Organ.'' A program note for ''Cantos'' (1957) states that it was ''one of Mr. Nikolais's early abstract pieces, which used his new theory of decentralization and minimal motional poetry.'' The decentralization of the stage picture, whether that is what Mr. Nikolais means by the term, is obvious in that there is no single hero or heroine. Instead, our attention is dispersed - often, we see the activity initially out of the corner of an eye.
A fire heavily damaged a shelter for homeless women yesterday afternoon, injuring a firefighter and forcing the residents to be housed elsewhere for the night.

Lately, his goals have been slow in coming and executed with awkwardness instead of the renowned artistry, but Mike Bossy has retained his knack of pure positioning, and tonight it yielded a 4-3 overtime victory for the Islanders. But the scar on the side of the puck revealed that this goal, which moved Bossy into fifth place on the league's career scoring roster with 557 career goals, was inelegantly obtained. With the overtime session threatening to remain indecisive as the hour of hockey that preceded it, Bossy stationed himself within whispering distance of the Pittsburgh goalie, Roberto Romano. When Steve Konroyd launched a slapshot, it caromed off Bossy's skate, and between the goalie's legs for the winning goal with 1 minute 35 seconds left on the clock.

Cole & Weber of Seattle, part of the Ogilvy Group, is now the Boeing Company's only agency, which means that the Seattle manufacturer has added two more operating companies to the four already being served by the agency. They are Boeing Vertol, formerly served by VanSant Dugdale Advertising, Baltimore, and Boeing Computer Services, a former account of Stacking, Sanderson & White, McLean, Va.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (Reuters) - The Unisys Corporation has been awarded a $509 million Navy contract modification for the production of navigation and other equipment for the Trident missile program, the Defense Department said. Unisys, based in Detroit, was created by the merger of the Burroughs and Sperry corporations.

FOR the second time in three months, the International Business Machines Corporation has sent analysts scurrying to lower their earnings estimates. Yesterday I.B.M. shares dropped 2 5/8 points, to 120 1/2, in heavy trading as analysts revised downward already depressed 1986 earnings estimates for the company. Analysts now expect I.B.M. will report 1986 earnings of $8 to $8.25, down from the $8.50 to $8.75 previously projected. Analysts attributed their revised 1986 estimates to I.B.M.'s announcement last Thursday that it would take a $250 million fourth-quarter charge to cover the early retirement of 10,000 employees. But I.B.M.'s simultaneous announcement that it would have to continue cost-cutting efforts because it saw ''no signs of improvement'' in business worldwide prompted many analysts to lower estimates for 1987 as well.

The Internal Revenue Service intends to assign fewer workers to help process income tax returns during the coming filing season, officials said today. There will also be fewer to answer taxpayer questions. The disclosure came as the revenue service presented the 1986 income tax return forms that will start appearing in taxpayer mailboxes the day after Christmas.

The Giants will play their first playoff game here Jan. 3 against the San Francisco 49ers or the Los Angeles Rams and officially they do not care which. Unofficially, they do have preferences, generally depending on whether they play on offense or defense. The Rams meet the Redskins in Washington Sunday in the National Conference wild-card game. If the Rams win, they will play the Giants. If the Redskins win, the Redskins will play the Chicago Bears and the 49ers will face the Giants.

Debt * Citicorp sold $50 million of 91-day commercial paper at an average rate of 6.458 percent, up from 6.13 percent last week, and $50 million of 182-day paper at an average rate of 6.096 percent, up from 5.96 percent. * Federal Farm Credit Banks is offering 6.1 percent interest on $701 million of bonds due on April 1, 1987, and $1.15 billion of bonds due July 1, 1987, through various securities dealers.

CHRISTMAS EVE With wide-eyed caffeinated stares we struggle to assemble the radio-controlled turbo race car batteries not included while surrounded by overstuffed stockings and a barely decorated tree until we take a break to sneak a look at softly sleeping children and then pretending to find some falling snow we hug recharged and assembled again. - ROGER GRANET The scene: St. Augustine School of Fine Arts, a parochial school (kindergarten through eighth grade) in the South Bronx. A recent visitor: Leonard Bernstein, who is known for his encouragement of fledgling musicians. On this particular occasion, Mr. Bernstein is particularly taken with a rendition of ''Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star'' as performed by a pair of sixth-grade double-bass players.

BIGGER THOMAS, the 19-year-old hero of Richard Wright's seminal 1940 novel, ''Native Son,'' is not easy to take either as a character or as a man, but he's a figure of mythic proportions. He's a mountain in the flat literary landscape that surrounds him. Raised in black poverty in the greatly depressed Chicago of the 1930's, Bigger is unrelenting in his anger with the white world. He's especially scathing about the do-gooders who mean well, but who patronize him by assuming they can understand what black poverty, hopelessness and ignorance are all about. Bigger has murder in his heart.

At Christmas 40 years ago, a young man named Carl Bozenski lay in a tuberculosis sanitarium and made this vow: If he recovered, he would go back to his hometown and build a Christmas Village. It would be an honest-to-goodness replica of Santa's home at the North Pole. There would be elves making toys, reindeer feeding on the lawn and Santa - not some skinny department store impostor - seated upon a red throne to greet his young, wide-eyed visitors. There would be no commercialism, no price tags, no admission fees. And every child, rich or poor, would get a gift from Santa.

SO that they can concentrate on their New York restaurant, Gilbert Le Coze and his sister, Maguy, have sold the original Le Bernardin in Paris. The new owner of the Paris restaurant is Guy Savoy, who says he intends to move the two-star Michelin establishment that bears his name from its intimate space at 28 Rue Duret to the larger site at 18 Rue Troyon near the Etoile.
Senator Patrick J. Leahy's neighbors, taciturn New Englanders through and through, are determinedly protective of his privacy.

The Cannon Group said today that it had avoided possible bankruptcy through a complex $75 million agreement with Warner Communications Inc. Warner will receive a number of considerations in return, including an option to buy into a theater chain at favorable terms. Cannon, an aggressive film producer that grew rapidly, only to run into financial straits and difficulties with Federal regulators, was close to defaulting on a debt to Bond Corporation Holdings Ltd., a company headed by Alan Bond, the Australian businessman. Cannon said the deal with Warner allowed it to pay off the debt of about $76.2 million today.

Sometimes this can be a contentious country, the kind of place where discord can disrupt the calm surface of everyday life like a fist through cellophane, puncturing even a Christmas season with strikes, lines, bad tempers, and memories of even worse conflicts in the past. A sign of the mood came here the other day when the transportation authorities of Paris painted 10 city buses in a large black-and-white pattern as part of a $250,000 advertising campaign by Black and White Scotch, which wanted the buses to roam through the seasonally festooned streets, suggesting the whisky as a gift. But, then, the Autonomous Machinists Union, which represents the bus drivers, frustrated the plan by refusing to operate the painted vehicles. ''The Parisians are used to the color of their buses and they don't want that to be overturned,'' explained Roland Dufeu, a leader of the union. Paris buses are a classic green and white with large rectangular spaces reserved for advertising.

Less than eight years after graduating from Graduate School of Business Administration at Harvard and being recruited for Time Inc., Elizabeth P. Valk has been named publisher of Life, the first woman to become a publisher in Time's history. She will replace Charles Wittingham, 56 years old, who is retiring at the end of the year.

Three white teen-agers were ordered held without bail yesterday on second-degree murder charges in the racial attack last week in Howard Beach, Queens. At an arraignment in Criminal Court in Queens, a prosecutor said the three defendants had admitted taking part in the attack, which began outside a pizza parlor and continued as a gang of whites chased three black men down a dead-end street. The white youths entered no pleas at the hearing. The authorities were also investigating two other attacks the same night in Howard Beach, a small, middle-class community near Kennedy International Airport. The police said yesterday that the three incidents appeared to be unrelated, although students from the same high school were involved in two of the incidents.

TO THE LIVING SECTION: Betsy Wade's experience in her article ''Holiday Hitch: Shape of the Table'' [ Nov. 26 ] with parents of the 3-to-6X crowd who found the idea of a tot's table ''disgusting'' reminds me of a successful dinner at my grandparents' 60 years ago, at a low, small table with my three cousins. We ranged in age from 3 to 6. It was a quarter-century later when it occurred to me that the arrangement might not have been for our benefit. MARY GRIMES

A PRICELESS bit of recording-studio chatter has been preserved in ''The Sun Country Box,'' a new 10-record boxed set from West Germany's Bear Family label. The country and rockabilly singer Warren Smith has just finished a performance and is asking to try again. ''Let's do it once more so I can put out on it,'' he says. ''I was just gettin' the feel that time.'' The intuitive recording method that was developed at the Sun label in Memphis during the 1950's has never been more trenchantly expressed. First the singers and musicians agreed on a ''feel'' - a rhythmic and emotional stance - for each song. Once they'd arrived at the feel, they could ''put out'' - inject some intensity into the performance. The Sun label's owner, Sam Phillips, used the same method whether he was recording bluesmen like Howling Wolf and B. B. King, creating some of the first rock-and-roll with Elvis Presley, or making country recordings like the ones collected in ''The Sun Country Box.''

Surely, things are not bleak only for the Jets. They are, after all, in the playoffs and will be facing either a quarterback with such a severely injured thumb he can't practice or his backup. Coach John Mackovic of the Kansas City Chiefs said yesterday he would wait until Sunday before deciding whether Bill Kenney or Todd Blackledge would play against the Jets. Kenney, the starter, banged his right thumb on a teammate's helmet last month and Blackledge started for him the next game as the Chiefs beat the Broncos. Kenney returned and the Chiefs beat the Raiders. But Kenney reinjured the thumb in the regular-season finale against the Steelers Sunday and Mackovic is now preparing Blackledge to start. But if Kenney's sore thumb heals dramatically, he will take the field.

Yuri Lyubimov, the Soviet theater director who was stripped of his citizenship two years ago, said today that he has received a message from a colleague that he would be welcome back in the Soviet Union. Mr. Lyubimov said he has sent a telex to Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, to negotiate his return. Mr. Lyubimov said he received a telephone call in Washington on Monday from a representative of Moscow's Taganka Theater, which he ran for two decades, suggesting that Kremlin officials would restore his citizenship and allow him to resume his role there.

Robert E. Brennan's First Jersey Securities, which has been fighting Government fraud charges, announced yesterday that it was selling its retail branch system to the Sherwood Capital Group Inc., an investment firm based in Jersey City. Both firms announced the deal yesterday, but they refused to disclose how much Mr. Brennan, First Jersey's sole owner, would be paid or any other terms of the sale. The announcement follows what Mr. Brennan said were months of negotiations with several parties.

THE possibilities for garnishing salads, sandwiches and all sorts of cold dishes are limitless, especially if you have a few tricks up your sleeve. When I make a buffet lunch for friends or family, for example, I like to decorate plates with lettuce, hard-boiled eggs and tomatoes.

There's a touch of Bedford Falls along upper Broadway: garlands of red, green and gold Christmas lights hang above the streets, providing the momentary illusion of small-town life chronicled in the classic Christmas movie ''It's a Wonderful Life.'' Frank Capra's ageless fable of the triumph of goodness, charity and family love over wealth and power turned 40 this year. It's still known to make grown men weep, even as the opening credits roll, and it's not hard to pick sides in the struggle between the pure good of Jimmy Stewart - as George Bailey, the people's champion - and the pure evil of Lionel Barrymore's avaricious Henry F. Potter. Potter, the banker, owns half the town (and all its slums); Bailey pilots his sinking building and loan so that poor people can buy their own homes.

For The Associated Press, covering the Iran arms affair has become a daily balancing act between a responsibility to provide full coverage and a desire not to endanger the lives of the Western hostages in Lebanon, according to the news service's top managers. Those hostages include The A.P.'s chief Middle East reporter, Terry A. Anderson, who was forced at gunpoint into a green Mercedes in Beirut in March 1985 and is apparently still the captive of a Moslem extremist organization. A.P. executives have said that in the months since Mr. Anderson's abduction, they occasionally have removed their journalistic hats to confer with State Department and White House officials, including Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, on an off-the-record basis as they sought Mr. Anderson's release. Restraints on Reporting According to a memorandum issued Nov. 6 by Walter R. Mears, the executive editor, anxiety that A.P. coverage could put Mr. Anderson's life and the lives of the other hostages at risk has prompted careful internal scrutiny of the A.P. report and a prohibition on originating ''investigative reporting about the inside details of efforts to gain freedom for American hostages still in Lebanon.''

TONIGHT, Santa Claus will deliver lots of toys to little girls and boys - unless they happen to be gifted little girls and boys, in which case he will probably give them distasteful learning aids. If Santa is on an enrichment kick, a lot of children will be disappointed to find surprises such as Fun With Sums mathematics drills under the tree tomorrow morning instead of something halfway decent, like Rambo toy jungle weaponry. Richard Clymore, shopping in a toy store this week, said his gifted 7-year-old came right out and asked whether he was going to get some ''cool'' toys this year - you know, He-Man, Lazer Tag and the rest of that good stuff he sees on television - or if the old red-suited taskmaster would be slipping down the chimney again with more mineral-identification kits and figure-analysis games. Mr. Clymore and a lot of other parents of gifted children were shopping in a store in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn. It was the same store where a man peeked his head in recently and told the proprietor that the very name of the store made him ''nauseous.''

The Cuomo administration announced tonight that it had turned down a request for clemency by Jean S. Harris. Mrs. Harris, the 64-year-old former headmistress of the Madeira School in Viginia, is serving a sentence of 15 years to life for the murder of Dr. Herman Tarnower, a prominent Westchester County cardiologist and the author of the ''Scarsdale Diet.'' A statement issued by the Governor's office said that clemency was denied by Mr. Cuomo's screening committee and that the matter never reached the level of a personal decision by the Governor.

Nynex Mobile Communications has assigned its cellular telephone/paging system to Lohmeyer Simpson Communications in Morristown, N.J. The agency said the billings would be $1.5 million. The agency for the last two years has been doing collateral and sales support material for Nynex cellular markets.

Using a combination of 1980's computer technology and the 1830's Braille system, an experimental device developed at I.B.M.'s Thomas J. Watson Research Center for the first time offers blind computer users the ability to ''read'' characters directly from a computer screen. The device, a ''mouse'' pointer, has been specially modified to include six tiny ''pistons'' that rise and fall, forming standard Braille characters like those on a printed page.

As Platonov, the incorrigibly rakish schoolmaster who seduces every woman he meets in ''Wild Honey,'' Ian McKellen has just flung himself in front of an oncoming locomotive -although whether in despair over the romantic muddles he has created or in befuddlement induced by all the vodka he has drunk is not entirely clear. Moments later, however, Mr. McKellen is dispensing champagne and receiving congratulations in his dressing room at the Virginia Theater, where he is telling well-wishers what a good time he is having with the play. ''Not like some other plays, where you're emotionally ripped to shreds by the time it's over,'' the actor observes. ''This is a bit of a caper, really.''

New Republic Books, a subsidiary of The New Republic magazine, will join Basic Books in a joint publishing venture, effective Jan. 1. The agreement, announced yesterday by Basic Books, Harper & Row's subsidiary for scholarly titles, is expected to result in up to 12 New Republic titles a year. New Republic Books has published about 24 books with Henry Holt since March 1980. Holt said recently that it would no longer distribute or sell the 1985 New Republic title ''Merger Mania'' by Ivan Boesky, the arbitrager who pleaded guilty to insider trading. In the statement explaining its decision, Holt said that when it and New Republic books agreed to publish the Boesky book, ''he was reputedly the top arbitrager in the country - possibly the world.'' The statement then cited the revelations about Mr. Boesky by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

TO THE LIVING SECTION: I want to cast my vote in the aye column on the Barbie issue raised by Anna Quindlen in her Life in the 30's column [ Dec. 17 ] . But first, on the issue of guns, I, too, said no guns under my roof.

FOOD and Christmas are inextricably bound in memory. For most people, Christmas conjures up the smell of cinnamon, cider and chestnuts, of turkey or goose roasting and ham baking, and the vision of friends and family at the table making merry. For writers, the holiday often means ritual with food at its heart, ritual that inevitably becomes the seed of a story. This year six writers, Eudora Welty, Garrison Keillor, Mary Lee Settle, Samuel R. Delany, Reynolds Price and Joyce Maynard, share their memories of Christmas food and the people with whom they savored it. EUDORA WELTY IN our house while I was growing up, I don't remember that hard liquor was served at all except on one day in the year. Early on Christmas morning, we woke up to the sound of the eggbeater: Mother in the kitchen was whipping up eggnog. All in our bathrobes, we began our Christmas before breakfast. Throughout the day Mother made batches afresh. All our callers expected her eggnog. It was ladled from the punch bowl into punch cups and silver goblets, and had to be eaten with a spoon. It stood up in peaks. It was rich, creamy and strong. Mother gave full credit for the recipe to Charles Dickens.

The Suffolk County Legislature, overriding a veto by County Executive Peter F. Cohalan, voted today to ban steel-jaw leg traps. The law is the first by a county in New York State prohibiting the spring-loaded devices, which are used by trappers to catch small animals including foxes, raccoons and otters.

Don't tell me you believe that there's collusion, too. Silly boy. It's all happenstance, all a great big coincidence. They've never discussed it among themselves. That would be illegal. The 26 baseball owners (may their tribe increase), awoke one day two years ago from a deep dream of peace, and each at that moment decided that he and she would no longer compete in the free-agent market. All of them. All at once. All totally and inexplicably serendipitous. Frank, what are you doing here in Northfield, Minnesota? Just passin' through, Jesse. Well, Bro', as long as we're here, whattya say we knock off that bank over yonder?

PERHAPS one day, when cable priorities are straightened out in New York City, I shall not have to describe the Bravo pay service as ''currently unavailable in Manhattan, though it is in many suburbs.'' But for the time being, that is the sorry state of things, despite the fact that a service offering top foreign and ''art'' films plus performance specials would seem tailor-made for New York viewers. An exceptionally fine example can be found in ''The Mystery Plays,'' being offered this week at 10 o'clock on three consecutive evenings - tonight, tomorrow and Friday. The plays, adapted by the British poet Tony Harrison, are taken from 15th-century ''mystery'' cycles, notably those from York. They focus on the life and death of Jesus while spanning everything from the Creation to the Last Judgment. In medieval times, they consisted of ''scenes'' mounted on wagons and performed before clusters of spectators gathered at ''stations.'' In churches today, there remain the Stations of the Cross, depictions of events leading up to the Crucifixion. The mystery plays were generally performed, from morning to evening, by members of various guilds, amateur actors who would be neighbors to those watching. In a seamless community of religious beliefs, performers and audience became a tightly knit unit.

Eight years after development began and with its ultimate future still in doubt, the MX missile has gained operational status with the first 10 moving to full alert beneath the plains of Wyoming, the Pentagon announced today. The declaration of ''initial operational capability'' for the MX on Monday night marked the first addition to the nation's land-based nuclear arsenal in 16 years, when Minuteman III's were deployed. The MX, for missile experimental, is an intercontinental ballistic missile with an estimated range of 6,674 miles that has been termed the Peacekeeper by the Reagan Administration. It is ''in place, in the ground, ready to be called on should the President decide that it is needed in a national emergency,'' said a Pentagon spokesman, Robert Sims.

The Transworld Corporation said late yesterday that its agreement to sell its Hilton International subsidiary to KLM Royal Dutch Airlines had fallen through, but that UAL Inc., the parent company of United Airlines, would buy the hotel chain. The price is about $980 million. Transworld said it had been informed that KLM's supervisory board voted not to approve the agreement. That agreement, according to sources, was for $975 million in cash. KLM's offices were closed last evening, and it was not immediately clear why the board had voted against the purchase. $632.5 Million in Cash Transworld's agreement with UAL consists of $632.5 million in cash, 2.56 million common shares of UAL and $200 million of UAL debentures.

The Alleghany Corporation, which is in the midst of a liquidation, sold 3.6 million shares of American Express Company stock yesterday for about $208 million. The sale, which came in a single block of stock handled by Salomon Brothers, leaves Alleghany with about 2.65 million shares of American Express.

To the Editor: ''The Africans'' on public television and the host of the series, Ali Mazrui, have been accused of being anti-democracy and anti-West for blaming the West for many of Africa's problems. Lynne Cheney of the National Endowment for the Humanities, a Reagan appointee, called the series an ''anti-Western diatribe,'' refused to release $50,000 for publicizing it and requested that the Endowment be dropped as a sponsor. One is hard pressed to find a basis for the claims. Mr. Mazrui does not blame the West for all of Africa's problems. He blames Africans as much as he blames the West. Mr. Mazrui pokes subtle fun at Africans when he shows the women in high-heel shoes and Western dress and the men in wool suits in tropical climes. He does not blame the West for this as much as he blames Africans for being prone to unnecessary Western influence. ''Our ancestors,'' he says, ''will not be happy with the deal modern Africa has struck with the 20th century because we have traded much of our cultural heritage for Western civilization.'' Not that he lets the West off completely.

Laced with rules that invite annoying nitpicking, New York State's election laws are commonly rated the nation's worst. This year's campaign antics confirmed that judgment. Almost 200 would-be candidates, including an employee of the rule-saturated Board of Elections, were disqualified because of mistakes in their nomination petitions.

International A3-7, D15 An arms-for-hostages deal was explicitly described by William J. Casey in a memo written soon after the United States began the deals, an official who has seen the document said. Page A1 Mr. Casey's tumor was cancerous, his doctors confirmed, and therapy will begin as soon as he recovers from the surgery. The lymphoma tumor was removed from the left side of the C.I.A. director's brain last Thursday. A7 Mr. Reagan urged early disclosure of a Senate panel's initial findings on the Iran affair so that he could make them public. A leader of the committee suggested that the request had a political motive and would be denied.

The presentation of evidence at the trial of seven former Miami police officers, accused of possession of cocaine, racketeering and involvement in a drug case in which three suspects drowned, ended tonight with the rebuttal testimony. About 150 witnesses have testified in the 13-week trial, which lawyers consider one of the most important in a generation here involving allegations of police corruption. Federal District Judge Kenneth L. Ryskamp, who has presided over the trial in the Federal Courthouse in downtown Miami, recessed the proceedings until Jan. 5 when closing arguments are to be presented by the prosecution and a battery of defense lawyers.
1. A Tree for Eating For last-minute holiday shoppers, here is a Christmas tree fit for chocolate lovers - four ounces of milk chocolate colorfully wrapped in green foil.
The Nassau County Democratic chairman, Martin Mellman, announced his resignation yesterday.

Years of fiscal irresponsibility have finally caught up to the Knicks. At a time when they most need to make a trade, the team's general manager, Scotty Stirling, is discovering two things: the first is that every player of any value around the league is being paid more than other teams believe he is worth, and secondly, that the salary cap restrictions have handcuffed him from making the few trades teams are willing to discuss. ''Right now, I just don't think our personnel is good enough,'' Stirling said on Monday after the Knicks broke an eight-game losing streak with a victory over the San Antonio Spurs. ''But when you talk about Player A, Player B or Player C who can help us, they just aren't available. The better players are on the better teams and we just can't get those guys.''

One of the first steps the New York Express took in an attempt to become a credible franchise in the Major Indoor Soccer League was to sign Rick Davis, the former American star of the Cosmos. Davis has yet to score a goal, and other players haven't done much better. As a result, the team has lost its first 10 games, tying the league's record for the worst start. The management of the Express realized today that 10 consecutive losses are no way to make fans forget the Arrows, the Express's predecessor in the M.I.S.L. So management came up with a familiar solution - it dismissed the coach, Ray Klivecka.

The diary of Jennifer Levin, who was killed in Central Park in August, will be turned over to court officials next week for a ruling on whether the book may be used by the defense attorney for the man accused of killing her, the lawyer for the Levin family said yesterday. The defendant, Robert E. Chambers Jr., who is 20 years old, has pleaded not guilty to murder, asserting that he killed Miss Levin accidentally while the two were having sex in the park. Mr. Chambers's attorney, Jack T. Litman, has said the diary is relevant evidence because it ''chronicles'' Miss Levin's previous sexual activities. State Supreme Court Justice Howard E. Bell last week ordered the Levin family to give him the book so he could read it himself before ruling on whether Mr. Litman could use its contents in preparing his case.

Vodkas With a Twist Flavorings such as pepper, lemon, tea, cherries, honey and herbs are frequently added to vodka in the Soviet Union, either at home or by commercial producers. Recently a number of flavored vodkas have become available in this country. The first to be introduced was Stolichnaya Pertsovka - pepper vodka - seasoned with cayenne. It is a pale vermilion color, has a decided cayenne kick and is good on the rocks or straight, especially if it has first been put in the freezer to soften the bite. Try it in a bloody Mary or a bullshot (vodka and bouillon). Headington Wines and Liquors, 1135 Lexington Avenue, at 79th Street, has it for $11.99 a standard 750 milliliter bottle.

The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday charged a former clerk at the law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom and eight of his relatives with illegally trading on inside information about planned takeover bids by the firm's corporate clients. The S.E.C. contended that Samuel M. Aksler, who had been in charge of handling the firm's files on takeover offers, had stolen information about pending takeovers and given the information to his relatives.

WE will have a cold antipasto and chicken parmigiana for dinner tonight. I could have told you this a week ago. I could have told you this in March. It is an Italian tradition to feast on Christmas Eve, to crowd the table with calamari and scungilli, bacalla and pieces of fried eel. But my husband does not eat any of those traditional dishes, so I have adapted the menu. Afterward we will read ''A Christmas Carol,'' alternating chapters. I realized years ago that he got the best chapters. He gets the first, gets to intone, ''Marley was dead, to begin with.'' And he gets the last, so that at the end he can say, ''God bless Us, Every One!'' But it has always been so. It is too late to change now.

A grand jury condemned fraternity hazing but refused to indict anyone in the drinking death of a University of Texas fraternity pledge who drank a fatal amount of rum. No state laws were violated when the pledge, Mark Seeberger, an 18-year-old freshman from Dallas, drank the liquor while handcuffed in a van last September, said H. Moak Rollins, a spokesman for the Travis County grand jury.

Michael D. Madden, who will head the day-to-day operations of Kidder, Peabody & Company's expanded investment banking division, is a fighter - in the business sense, of course, but also in the boxing ring. Mr. Madden, 37, fought in the Golden Gloves tournament when he was a youth and still boxes at athletic clubs in New York City. Twenty years ago he was a middleweight; his weight, he said, has ''gone up from there.''

Senator Jesse Helms has acquired an unlikely ally in his struggle to become the top Republican on the Foreign Relations Committee in the next Congress. Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. of Connecticut, a liberal Republican, has taken up the conservative North Carolinian's cause.

WITH holiday preparations and parties in full swing, you may be longing for some quiet time at home. By late January or February, however, you may start wondering whether you can stand another dark, cold, lonely winter day. Depression, irritability, sleepiness, inertia, boredom, restlessness, impatience and dissatisfaction seem to characterize the postholiday months for millions of Americans who reside in the so-called frost belt. The problem is so common that medical science has given it a name - cabin fever. In Anchorage, where the sun barely rises above the horizon in December on the winter solstice, the shortest day of the year, a special clinic deals with victims of cabin fever, many of whom abuse alcohol or each other after weeks of being cooped up. The situation is only slightly better in many of the 48 lower states, in which people commonly leave home before sunrise and leave work after sunset. Sometimes they don't leave home at all. Bundling up to confront the cold and snow, they reason, simply isn't worth doing - unless absolutely necessary.

Markets The F.T.C. is investigating six major investment banks to determine whether stock was illegally accumulated by the firms for clients planning hostile takeovers. The Federal Trade Commission, which refused to identify the firms, said the firms might have violated reporting requirements of antitrust laws. [ Page D1. ]

Household International Inc., the diversified financial services and manufacturing concern, said it had agreed to sell its National Car Rental System subsidiary to an investor group led by Paine Webber Capital Inc. for $459 million in cash. The buyout group said it would refinance $1.04 billion in debt that National, the nation's third-largest car rental company after Hertz and Avis, owes to investment houses and banks.
A report on Saturday in the Briefing column of the Washington Talk page misidentified the headquarters community of the Gannett Company. It is Rosslyn, Va.

Last March, dread gripped the neighborhood of Clinton Knolls atop an ancient limestone cliff here in rural Hunterdon County. Unusually high levels of radon had been found in many houses, and residents feared another Love Canal - a potential environmental disaster that threatened health and property values. The early sense of crisis is gone, overcome, according to residents and government officials, by the neighborhood's pluck and pragmatism and an intensive Federal research project. The research has yielded valuable tools to deal with the radioactive gas in houses. The tools are new ventilation systems.

One of the reasons for dividing time into years is that it gives us a week or so for reflection on the past and the future. The American people and their leaders here have much to consider at the end of 1986. It has not been a good year from top to bottom: too much cheating and chiseling; too many lies, too many cardboard heroes ducking behind the Fifth Amendment. On the whole, we are very rich and as we say, some of us are ''having a good time,'' but the bills are coming due, and there's a general anxiety in the land that something is wrong.

A flurry of controversy has sprung up surrounding activities during last Friday's ''triple witching hour.'' In separate developments, the Securities and Exchange Commission expressed dissatisfaction with the way the last half-hour of stock trading went, and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission said it was ''looking into'' reports that options trading was conducted at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange after the close at 4 P.M., Eastern standard time.

REMOVE the white chef's jacket and Louis Outhier could pass for a stockbroker. Dressed in a pencil-striped shirt with white collar and dark blue tie, the slightly nervous but engaging three-star French chef looks every inch the businessman. Of course he is. If his restaurant L'Oasis on the French Riviera is not as well known in this country as the restaurants of Paul Bocuse and Jean Troisgros, it is because he has not engaged in American promotional tours, lent his name to a line of china, canned goods or wines, or written a cookbook. He calls such promotion ''show biz,'' refuses to participate and will brook no further comment on the subject. Mr. Outhier's newest venture, Restaurant Lafayette in the Drake Hotel at 56th Street and Park Avenue, is one of seven Swissotel restaurants in such widely scattered places as London, Bangkok, Osaka and Boston for which he is consultant. Mr. Outhier staffs the top positions in these restaurants with chefs who have trained at L'Oasis for at least four years. Three are now at the Lafayette, and the chef de cuisine, Jean-Georges Vongerichten, opened several of the other Swissotel restaurants for Mr. Outhier before coming to New York.

Richard Serra, whose ''Tilted Arc'' sculpture in Lower Manhattan has been the focus of intense controversy for nearly two years, has filed suit against the General Services Administration, the Federal agency that commissioned the work, charging breach of contract and other violations of the artist's rights. The suit, filed last week in Federal District Court in Manhattan, also names William J. Diamond, the regional administrator of the General Services Administration in New York, as a defendant, and seeks a total of $30 million in punitive damages and to compensate for harm to the artist's career and reputation. The sculpture, a 12-foot-high, 112-foot-long steel wall, bisects the plaza in front of the Jacob K. Javits Federal Building at 26 Federal Plaza. In March 1985, a five-member panel named by Mr. Diamond heard testimony in a three-day public hearing on the sculpture, at which many local office workers and professionals of the art world testified. The panel ultimately recommended that the work be removed.

President Reagan and the Senate intelligence committee disagreed today over whether the White House or the committee should be responsible for making public the panel's findings on the Iran affair. Mr. Reagan, asserting that he wanted the American people to ''judge for themselves,'' urged the committee to provide its initial findings so that he could declassify the information and make it available to the public. But Dave E. Holliday, a spokesman for the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence, indicated that the panel would not honor the request, although he said it was considering releasing a public report on its own. ''We are not moving to produce a report for the White House that would contain classified information,'' he said. ''We are moving to produce a public report.''

To the Editor: You report a dispute between administration and students of Boston University over a political banner outside a dormitory (news story, Dec. 4). It reminded me of a peaceable episode in cold-war confrontation.

For several months this year, one of the suspects in the Howard Beach racial attack had dated a black girl, who said yesterday that ''he treated me better than all my other boyfriends, even my black boyfriends.'' The girl, Ernestine Washington, insisted that the former boyfriend, Jon L. Lester, was not a racist. At the same time, a second suspect, Scott Kern, was described as ''a normal kid'' by a black youth who said he socialized with him. Mr. Lester, Mr. Kern and Jason Ladone were arraigned yesterday before Criminal Court Judge Randall T. Eng in the Queens Criminal Courthouse in Kew Gardens.

G. Norman Widmark, chairman emeritus of Butler International Inc., an aviation and engineering services company based in Montvale, N.J., died Friday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 65 years old and lived in Montclair, N.J. Mr. Widmark became chairman of Butler in 1971 and retired last July.
State police officers at scene of an accident Tuesday on the Wilbur Cross Parkway in Orange, Conn.
TO THE LIVING SECTION: Jane Brody's Personal Health column [ Nov. 19 ] on diabetic retinopathy offered much helpful advice.

THE way they tell it in my family, at first there was no Hanukkah. My immigrant grandparents, once pious, felt overwhelmed, it seemed, by six children clamoring for melting-pot America. In December, presents were exchanged. It wasn't Christmas, but it wasn't Hanukkah either. The calendar obliged: it juxtaposed, or even overlapped, the holidays. Assimilation? Hardly. The family dinner was likely to be pot roast and potato pancakes, called by their Yiddish name, latkes. Slippage. What happened after that is the story of how an immigrant family, by its third generation, reclaimed traditions abandoned in its first.

Many contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund express the wish that others will follow their example. ''May love and caring touch more of us, so that we take a part in helping those who are needy,'' said Lilian Zwyns of Manhattan, who sent a $200 gift to the fund's 75th annual appeal. ''We all tend to forget the richness of life that so many people miss, particularly impoverished children,'' said Cathy and Mark Johnson of Short Hills, N.J., who sent a gift of $1,000, hoping that it would be used for children in need.

All Ronald Reagan's problems are not in Washington: Thousands of people here are protesting plans to build his Presidential library in the rolling foothills west of Palo Alto. ''They want to put it on one of the last undeveloped hills in the community,'' said Samuel Brain, one of the protest leaders. ''There are a lot of people who are attached to that hill, and they don't want it ruined.'' It remains to be seen who will prevail in the dispute over construction of a Reagan library and museum on a bucolic bluff at Stanford University.

In what commercial bankers called an important victory in their attempts to take on Wall Street, a Federal appeals court ruled yesterday that the Bankers Trust New York Corporation may act as a commercial-paper agent. The ruling, by a panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia, means that Bankers Trust may continue placing commercial paper - short-term i.o.u.'s issued by large corporations that are traded in the open market. The New York banking company's commercial paper group had been hamstrung by the possibility that the court would rule against it. ''A legal cloud has been removed from the bank's commercial paper operation,'' said Thomas Parisi, the Bankers Trust spokesman.

The waters of Lake Michigan are rising at such a rate that they soon may engulf as much as 35 feet of shoreline a year in some areas and erode part of Lake Shore Drive, officials of the Army Corps of Engineers say. A study by the corps indicates the waters are eroding sections of 26 miles of a sea wall that has protected Chicago's lakefront for half a century. In areas unprotected by the wall, corps officials estimate that the lake will eat as far as 35 feet into the shoreline each year, said Paul Mohrhardt, chief of the agency's plan formulation branch.

Washingtonians can now raise a special toast to the Redskins. In celebration of the team's 50th anniversary, a northern Virginia vineyard, Meredyth Winery, recently introduced two new wines - one gold, one burgundy, of course - both of which feature the Redskin logo on the label.

President Reagan's new budget will propose sweeping changes in farm programs designed to save more than $16 billion over the next five years, Administration officials said today. James C. Miller 3d, the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, said the proposals were based on the assumption that current farm programs, which cost more than $25.5 billion in the fiscal year 1986, had become politically unsustainable. Referring to members of Congress, he said, ''A lot more people represent nonfarm districts than farm districts.'' Support for Some Proposals Because key concepts in some of the proposals resemble ideas contained in legislation introduced last year by Senators Rudy Boschwitz of Minnesota, a Republican, and David L. Boren of Oklahoma, a Democrat, the Administration says some of its proposals may receive a favorable reception in Congress. But other proposals, especially those that would cut farmers' income most sharply, are sure to face opposition on Capitol Hill.

The Vietnamese radio has broadcast an official biography of the new Vietnamese leader, Nguyen Van Linh. The broadcast last Thursday said that his real name is Nguyen Van Cuc and that he was born in July 1915 in Hai Hung Province.

EVERY year in late fall, a group of owners of some of the better-known Bordeaux chateaus pack up their bottles and a few shirts and hit the road to plug their products. They call themselves the Union des Grands Crus de Bordeaux because they represent all the classified chateaus, as they are known, in the Bordeaux region. There are several thousand chateaus, but only 61 hold the classified status. For this year's road show, the fourth since the union was created, an impressive sampling of 52 of the best-known wines of the Medoc, St.-Emilion, Pomerol, Graves and Sauternes were to be offered at simultaneous tastings on Nov. 28 in Paris, London, New York and Montreal. As in the past, the tastings, which are held mostly for journalists and wine professionals, were to be coordinated by Steven Spurrier, the Paris and London wine merchant, who also runs L'Academie du Vin, a Paris wine school with branches in London and New York. The tasting always marks the public debut of the previous year's vintage, in this case 1985. Interest was high because 1985 had been billed as particularly good.
The capital's obsession with the Iran arms deal has been unrelenting. Before this uproar, it was the 1986 elections. Before that, it was the change in the composition of the Supreme Court.

Spending in the United States for research and development in 1987 is expected to rise $8.8 billion, to $127.4 billion, according to a forecast by Battelle, the Ohio-based nonprofit research contractor.

More than 40 religious and civil-rights groups, condemning the attack by white youths against three black men in Howard Beach, Queens, last weekend, formed a new coalition yesterday. They said the group, the New Civil Rights coalition, would join a demonstration planned for Howard Beach next weekend. In Howard Beach, leaders allied with the National Ethnic Coalition of Organizations termed such a demonstration ''counterproductive'' and announced plans to ease racial tensions in southeastern Queens. The group selected the recipients of the Ellis Island Medals of Honor last fall.

To the Editor: ''Speaker Wright, Meet Mr. Wright'' (editorial, Dec. 10) examined campaign financing in response to the announcement of Robert D. Wright, president of NBC, that NBC employees should contribute to corporate political action committees. In calling for Federal election law reform, you urge extending public campaign financing to all Federal elections.
Hitachi Ltd. said it plans to start making its most advanced variety of computer memory chips at its plant in Irving, Tex., next summer.

ANYWHERE BUT HERE. By Mona Simpson. 406 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95. MONA SIMPSON'S stunning first novel opens simply with a glimpse of a mother and a daughter driving westward in a Lincoln Continental. They are driving from their hometown of Bay City, Wis., to California so that the girl - Ann - can become a child star. In lieu of eating at restaurants, they steal vegetables from convenient farm trucks, and they use a borrowed credit card to charge gasoline and one-night stays at cheap motels. Behind them, to the east, is their old life, a life of modest expectations, modest comforts and modest rewards; ahead lies California, and all the glittering promises of that golden land.

THE rediscovery of cabbage may be partly attributed to health-care professionals' announcements that cabbage and all members of that family - broccoli, brussels sprouts and so on - are excellent sources of vitamin C. I prefer to think this newfound passion springs from cabbage's inherent good flavor. I first became aware of the new vogue in cabbage cookery when I dined nearly a decade ago at a two-star restaurant during a visit home to Burgundy. I feasted on cabbage filled with fresh foie gras and briefly steamed. I recently cooked my own variation by filling cabbage leaves with a mousse of chicken flavored with a bit of grated fresh ginger and then served with a sweet and sour sauce. The dish goes well with plain rice or rice with smoked ham.

The owner of the Atlanta Falcons, Rankin Smith Sr., said Dick Vermeil, the former coach of the Philadelphia Eagles, was a ''good prospect'' to replace Dan Henning, who was dismissed Monday as coach of the Falcons. Smith said his family had a candidate in mind, but he declined to say whether Vermeil had been contacted.

EARLY RAISERS: A Christmas tree should never be put up before sundown on Christmas Eve, yet increasing numbers of people have them glittering in the parlor by mid-December. It is an evil custom which people should abandon. A Christmas tree is lovely during the first 24 hours of its fully decorated life. Then it becomes a prodigious nuisance: needles fall on the carpet, burned-out light bulbs demand replacement, branches begin to sag. It must be watered, and despite water, may become an alarmingly dry fire hazard.

WELLS, RICH, GREENE is ending up the year on a sweet note - Cadbury Schweppes. Cadbury, the Stamford, Conn., subsidiary of the British confectionery and soft-drink company, has consolidated almost all its United States advertising at the agency, and the billings are estimated to be about $60 million. The biggest segment consists of candy products, formerly owned by Peter Paul: Mounds, Almond Joy, PowerHouse and York Peppermint Pattie. They were all being served by DFS Dorland Worldwide. Also, there are the Canada Dry beverage line, which was at Young & Rubicam; Sunkist orange drink, which has been at Foote, Cone & Belding, and Rose Holland House, which was with Ammirati & Puris.
Government and rebel negotiators meeting yesterday in Manila. Representating the Government were, from left, Jaime Guerrero, Teofisto Guingona and Maris Diokno.

Investors looking to take capital gains on stocks in the current year charged into the market yesterday, sending prices broadly lower and volume up sharply. But professional traders said the investors, apparently unwilling to abandon the stock market altogether, appear to be turning right around and rebuying the stocks they just sold. ''It's called tax swaps,'' said Larry Greenwald, co-manager of the equity trading department at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company. ''People who have long-term gains are basically selling stock to lock in the lower longer-term tax rate and then buying them back.''

Whose regular-season schedule turned out to be the toughest in all of college football? Here are the 10 schools that hoed the hardest row, ranked according to the records of their Division I-A opponents against I-A teams other than the ranked school.

The Argentine Congress adopted legislation tonight that is expected to bring an end to the prosecution of military officers accused of murder, torture, kidnapping and other crimes during the late 1970's and early 1980's. Crowds of demonstrators opposed to the bill gathered outside the Congress as the voting occurred just before midnight, and riot policemen filled the surrounding streets to assure safe exit for members of the Chamber of Deputies. Earlier in the evening, the majority leader of the Chamber, Cesar Jaroslavsky, was struck by demonstrators when he went outside briefly. The law establishes a period of 60 days for the continued filing of charges, but after that ''penal action will be extinguished'' on cases arising from the so-called ''dirty war'' against leftists. It was drafted under pressure from military leaders, who have argued that their actions during that era had ample public support.

Indiana 67, Louisville 58: Rick Calloway scored 21 points, including 13 in the second half, to lead Indiana at home. Indiana (7-1) trailed by 11 points in the first half but scored the first 5 points of the second half to cut a 6-point deficit to 34-33 on a 14-foot jumper by Calloway. The Hoosiers then took the lead when Steve Alford's field goal made it 37-36 with 14:57 to play. But Louisville (4-5), led by Herbert Crook's 6 straight points, went on a 13-5 run in the next 5:50 to go ahead, 49-42, with 9:07 remaining. Crook finished with 24 points. (AP) Brigham Young 93, Pittsburgh 73: Mike Smith scored 34 points and grabbed 13 rebounds to lead Brigham Young (6-4) at home. Charles Smith led the Panthers (5-2) with 22 points before fouling out. (AP) Georgetown 94, Florida A&M 65: Mark Tillmon scored 17 points and five other Georgetown players were in double figures to lead the Hoyas at home. Georgetown (8-0) got 10 points each from Reggie Williams and Dwayne Bryant in taking a 52-33 halftime lead and never let the advantage slip below 16 points. Williams had 16 points and 10 rebounds, and Bryant finished with 14 points. The Rattlers (2-6) dropped their sixth straight game despite getting 26 points from Leonard King. (AP) L.I.U. 89, Morgan State 80: Calvin Lamb scored 32 points, 19 in the second half, and Freddie Burton added 18 to lead L.I.U. Troy Brown's 22 points paced the Bears (3-4), who trailed at halftime, 43-28.

To the Editor: I am very concerned about the White House announcement that Friday, Dec. 26, has been designated as a Federal holiday (news item, Dec. 11). My concern, however, is not with providing Federal workers an extra vacation day in the holiday season, but with the double standard used by the Administration in determining what days should qualify as Federal holidays. Specifically, during the 99th Congress, my colleague from Pennsyl-vania, Representative Thomas M. Foglietta, introduced legislation to make next Sept. 17 a one-time national holiday to commemorate the 200th anniversary of the United States Constitution.
Sometimes it's the little things -the way he wears his hat, the way she sips her tea - that say the most about somebody. Sometimes, too, it's the little things that say the most about a state.

Treasury note and bond prices rose modestly yesterday in quiet trading. Although some market participants professed to be nervous about the near-unanimity of forecasts calling for a weak economy and lower interest rates early next year, their skepticism has not been evident in recent trading. The 7 1/2 percent Treasury bonds due in 2016, for example, have managed to improve slightly for three consecutive days, rising 5/32 yesterday to an offered price of 101 31/32 to yield 7.34 percent. The strength of the bellwether Treasury bond led officials at one securities firm to say in an internal memorandum that the bond market's performance is ''defying the law of gravity.'' They noted that earlier this year the combination of weakness in the value of the dollar and rising oil prices often led to lower prices for Treasury issues. Crude oil futures prices fell yesterday, but are still higher than the levels that prevailed before oil-exporting countries agreed during the weekend to curtail output.

Bill Cosby, one of the country's best-liked and respected entertainers, has signed a three-year contract with Kodak to be an all-media spokesman for its Kodak Colorwatch System, a photofinish program. It was suggested by J. Walter Thompson, Kodak's consumer ad agency.

To build for the 21st century, the Harvard Club has borrowed its architectural plans from the 19th. Wishing to expand its overburdened landmark home at 27 West 44th Street, the club submitted plans yesterday to the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission. A two-story addition at the west of the clubhouse and an adjacent three-story structure at No. 35 would be razed and replaced by an eight-story brick building designed by Edward Larrabee Barnes Associates. Its most arresting feature would be a neo-classical arched window, fully two stories high, complete with an enormous semicircular light and flanking limestone columns.

Fog caused short circuits that cut power to as many as 200,000 homes and office buildings here today, stopped commuter trains and knocked broadcasting stations off the air. Much of a nine-square-mile section of the North Side was blacked out before dawn. Emergency crews restored electricity to about half the area by this afternoon, officials of the Commonwealth Edison Company said.

The Greyhound Corporation, after opening up the nation to travelers for 73 years, said yesterday that it would sell its famed bus operations. ''This is the end of an era,'' John W. Teets, the chairman of Greyhound, said in an interview. The prospective owners, who agreed to pay $350 million for the bus division, will have a relatively free hand in restructuring the operation to increase its modest profitability. The purchasers are buying only the assets and contend that they are under no obligation to honor union contracts or to keep the current work force of 8,500, which has been under pressure to accept wage cuts.

* Crossland Savings named Salvatore S. Citrano executive vice president and chief retail officer. * Federal Reserve Bank of New York elected as a director Alberto M. Parachini, chairman, president and chief executive of Banco de Ponce, Ponce, P.R. * Incomnet Inc., Westlake Village, Calif., named Robert K. Potter president, succeeding Charan Lohara, who will continue as chairman and chief executive.

The lymphoma tumor removed from the left side of the brain of William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, was confirmed as cancerous, his doctors said today. Therapy will begin as soon as Mr. Casey has sufficiently recovered from the surgery, the doctors said in a statement issued by Georgetown University Hospital. But they gave no indication of what the therapy would be or when Mr. Casey would reach that stage. They said only that his condition was ''stable'' and that he would undergo more tests.

IN 1972, when the sprawling 31-square-mile Hackensack Meadowlands Development Area was created, one plan called for a mini-city along Berry's Creek near the Meadowlands sports complex. The site was known as the Berry's Creek Special Planned Area. It was to be a ''downtown'' for the Meadowlands, with 3,800 housing units, a shopping mall, some three million square feet of office space, at least 1,000 hotel rooms as well as recreational and cultural facilities. But after 14 years, only one office building and a hotel have been built.

Federal regulators, reaffirming a 1985 decision, rejected today New York City's last attempt to use administrative measures to block the trucking of spent nuclear fuel on city thoroughfares. New York City officials had sought to override a route set by the Federal Transportation Department for shipping the fuel from the Brookhaven National Laboratory in Upton, L.I. The officials had argued that the Federal route - the Long Island Expressway, the Clearview Expressway and the Throgs Neck Bridge to Interstate 95 - was unsafe because it passed through densely populated areas. Proposal for Barges to New London In September 1985, the Transportation Department rejected a New York proposal to ship the fuel on barges across Long Island Sound, load it on trucks in New London, Conn., and truck it for disposal in Idaho.

THE mezzo-soprano Eileen Davis announced from the stage of the Merkin Concert Hall on Monday night that she was indisposed but had decided to sing anyway. As it happened, Ms. Davis need not have apologized, for most of her singing was actually very fine.
The Mayor of Tampa, Fla., said yesterday that the city is conducting its own investigation into the arrest of Dwight Gooden, the Mets pitcher.

Exactly half a century ago one of the metropolitan area's leading tournament organizers, Al Sobel, married one of the area's top players, Helen Martin White, due to become even more famous with her new name. The first event since then in any way comparable occurred Sunday when two White Plains residents, Joan Levy and Ron Gerard, were married. The new Mrs. Gerard has long been the prime mover in planning tournaments - highly successful ones - in Westchester, New Jersey and the Hudson Valley.
To the Editor: The New York City Police Department is often criticized for corruption, brutality and other wrongdoing.

In a memorandum written at the beginning of the United States arms sales to Iran, the Director of Central Intelligence explicitly described the program as a trade of arms for hostages, according to a high ranking Government official who has seen the document. In addition, the official said, the memo written by William J. Casey said that if the matter became public, President Reagan was prepared to portray the secret operation as a political opening to Teheran. The document, written about a year ago, acknowledged that the arms sales conflicted with Administration policy on terrorism, but described Mr. Reagan as determined to rescue the American hostages in Lebanon, the official said. Recipient Unknown The disclosure seems to contradict President Reagan's assertions in the last two months that he approved the arms sales only as part of a broad diplomatic initiative aimed at making contact with ''moderates'' in Iran.
To the Editor: Opposition to war toys is often portrayed as a concern of women, especially mothers. But men care too. Adm.

The Transportation Department cleared the way for Alaska Air Group Inc. to buy Horizon Airlines, a regional carrier that serves five states in the West and Northwest. The Federal agency said the purchase ''does not raise any significant competitive or public interest issues,'' and exempted the transaction from merger approval procedures. Alaska Air Group, which already owns Alaska Airlines and Jet America, had asked for the exemption, arguing that the purchase increased its national market share by only about 1 percent.

In the beginning, Dottie Spatcher tried to bathe the foster children who were delivered to her apartment in the middle of the night, then bundle them in fleecy pajamas and tuck them into warm beds. But some of the children, removed from their homes under emergency circumstances, flinched when she approached them, or cried at her touch, and so Mrs. Spatcher changed her way of going about things. ''I realized, 'This child is frightened to death, doesn't know me, doesn't recognize these surroundings,' '' she said. ''So, now I say, 'O.K., sweetheart, if you want to just lie there for a while, we'll fix you up in the morning.' ''

The Legislature tonight delayed passage of a plan to finance a five-year, $8.6 billion rebuilding of New York City's subway, bus and commuter rail lines and to freeze fares for three years. The snag came when Senate Republicans representing the New York suburbs held out for more aid for the commuter railroads. ''We are, to put it mildly, disappointed,'' Governor Cuomo said. The night before, he had heralded an apparent agreement with the Senate and the Assembly on mass transit as a major achievement of the special legislative session that he had summoned here two weeks ago.

Imagine that you were President and two trusted aides were found to be executing their own policy toward Iran and the Nicaraguan rebels, a policy so reckless that its exposure threatened the work of your entire Administration. Acting in your name, they had blundered, perhaps committed crimes. What would you do?

Shawn Halloran's 5-yard touchdown pass to Kelvin Martin with 32 seconds remaining tonight gave Boston College a 27-24 victory over Georgia in the Hall of Fame Bowl. game. The game-winning throw capped a 12-play, 76-yard drive that was kept alive when Georgia was called for a pass-interference penalty.
Retailers, bankers, the Postal Service and the stock markets will operate this Friday, the day after Christmas, but many other employers will be shut down.

DENNIS WAYNE'S company, Dancers, concluded its engagement at the Triplex on Sunday afternoon by honoring Norman Walker, one of Mr. Wayne's teachers. A versatile choreographer and a former director of the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, Mr. Walker has taught at the School of Performing Arts and is currently chairman of the dance department at Adelphi University. All performances of Dancers at the Triplex have begun with members of the company introducing themselves and commenting on their work. On Sunday, the dancers discussed Mr. Walker as teacher and choreographer and everyone praised his devotion to his students and his ability to instill them with a love of performing.
TO THE LIVING SECTION: Judith Cummings' article, ''Movie Fare That Goes Beyond Popcorn'' [ Nov. 26 ] left several questions unanswered.
Reggie Jackson will apparently rejoin the Oakland A's. The A's scheduled a news conference for this morning but declined to reveal its purpose.

Long before it was popular to do so, a Roman Catholic clergyman from the United States favored celebrating mass in English instead of Latin, the election of the leadership of the American church by its own priests instead of its appointment by Rome, and a strong role for the laity. The man in question was not a latter-day Catholic dissident, but John Carroll, the first Catholic Bishop of the United States, elected by his fellow clergymen in 1789. Pope Pius VI agreed to leave the choice to them, which was not unusual at the time.
