The story of Bishop Carroll underlines the unusual role that America has played in the Roman Catholic Church and the fact that conflicts today between Rome and elements of the American church are not new. Genuine Conflicts The recent struggles have been bitter, however, dividing the American church itself. And despite the insistence of some American bishops that differences between Rome and American Catholics are exaggerated, Vatican officials say the conflicts are genuine and have an importance that transcends the United States.

THIS has not been the jolliest of holiday seasons. Indeed, as the year draws to an end, the worries about the economy are intensifying. Christmas sales have been disappointing so far for most retailers. Consumers appear to be overstretched in terms of debt. Economists at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company say that the higher debt levels and the low savings rate left by the four-year boom in consumer spending are likely to limit the help consumers can provide to the economy's further growth. In fact, consumers have already begun to move to cut back their debts.

CHRISTMAS BELLS There is no older tradition in the Western world for marking great occasions, or great catastrophes, than the one that involves the ringing of church bells. In metropolis or hamlet, the church bells remind the people that momentous events are at hand. Tonight, in virtually every section of the city, church bells will ring to announce the eve of one of Christendom's holiest days. Among the most beautiful bells to be heard are the 74 bells in the Laura Spelman Rockefeller memorial carillon atop Riverside Church, on the heights above the Hudson River, at 120th Street and Riverside Drive.

Senator James Abdnor, the South Dakota Republican who was defeated for re-election in November, was nominated yesterday by President Reagan to head the Small Business Administration. The agency has not had a permanent director since March, when James C. Sanders resigned to take a post in the brewing industry. The acting director has been Charles L. Heatherly.

The architect Philip Johnson has donated his Glass House - a six-building complex spread over a 30-acre estate in New Canaan, Conn. -to the National Trust for Historic Preservation, the trust announced yesterday.

The Younkers department store chain announced today that it had agreed to purchase a major Middle West competitor, the Brandeis department stores, for $30 million to $35 million, depending on Brandeis's year-end financial performance. Brandeis, based in Omaha, operates 11 department stores in Iowa and Nebraska. The transaction will give Younkers a total of 37 stores in five states.
The Seattle Mariners signed Dave Stapleton, a free agent infielder who had spent his entire major league career with the Boston Red Sox.

Prices of crude oil and petroleum products slumped yesterday, as traders decided to take profits ahead of the holiday weekend. Trading was moderate. The agreement by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to restrain output had pushed prices to levels not seen since February.

Tony Pinkston was crushed to death the other morning at his last known address, a trash bin where he had spent the night. He died when the bin was picked up by a truck for dumping and no one realized he was in it. It is not the sort of tragedy that is supposed to happen in Lexington. This is palmy bluegrass, the home of fast horses, beautiful women and 86-proof bourbon. It is the place where people talk about the quality of their lives.

The Food and Drug Administration today approved a drug that is intended primarily for the treatment of a form of leprosy but also has been used to treat an infection common in AIDS patients. Ciba-Geigy, the maker of the drug, stressed that it was not a potential AIDS cure. The drug is clofazimine, which Ciba-Geigy will market under the brand name of Lamprene. Its stated purpose is to treat a form of leprosy that has become resistant to other drugs, and it has been used for that purpose for the last decade outside the United States.

Senator Patrick J. Leahy sat in a rocking chair in the living room of his secluded 1850 farmhouse, watched the sunset over Camel's Hump mountain and pointed out deer and bear tracks and his own cross-country ski tracks in the newly fallen snow. ''I wouldn't be a Senator if I couldn't come home,'' he said. ''I find that no matter how tough it gets in Washington, I come back here and get an entirely different perspective. Problems that seem insurmountable in Washington evaporate up here.''

Richard V. Secord, the retired major general who has emerged as a figure in the clandestine arms sales to Iran and has been linked to support for contra rebels in Nicaragua, refused again today to testify before a Congressional hearing into the operations, according to a Congressional official. His brief appearance before a House committee brought to a close this year's efforts by Congress to investigate the arms transactions and the subsequent diversion of funds to the contras. Members of the Select Committee on Intelligence have said the refusal of key witnesses to testify has thwarted full discovery of the facts so far. It was the second time that the retired Air Force general had invoked his Fifth Amendment rights against self-incrimination.

Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger will ask for money next year to begin construction of two additional nuclear-powered aircraft carriers, the Pentagon said today. Mr. Weinberger's decision on the Navy request, which is part of the Defense Department's budget requests for the fiscal years 1988 and 1989, will insure the Navy's ability to maintain ''15 deployable carrier battle groups beyond the year 2000,'' said Robert Sims, a Pentagon spokesman. The two new carriers, as yet unnamed, would be completed in 1995 and 1998 and would probably replace the Forrestal and the Saratoga, which were built in the mid-1950's and would be nearing the end of their 45-year service lives by the year 2000.

Two Canadian Sikhs were convicted today of conspiring to bomb an Air-India flight from New York to New Dehli that was carrying an Indian Cabinet minister. The Quebec Superior Court jury deliberated for about four hours before delivering guilty verdicts against Santokh Singh Khela, 24, and Kashmir Singh Dhillon, 41.

The 1988 Presidential season's first big parade of Democratic hopefuls could come next month in California. At least 3,000 to 4,000 activists are expected at the California Democratic Party's annual convention to be held Jan. 30-Feb. 1 in Sacramento.
DDB Needham Worldwide, Chicago, has won the NEC Home Electronics (U.S.A.) account with some $5 million in billings.

MORE than anything else in the world, Lone Z. Wolf, the protagonist of the Jule Styne-Bob Merrill-Robert Emmett musical ''The Dangerous Christmas of Red Riding Hood,'' desires respectability. ''Just because I'm a wolf doesn't mean I ain't refined,'' he insists to his fellow denizens of the forest. Unfortunately for Lone, his gentlemanly blandishments are peppered with malapropisms. ''Your riding hood is of a beauteous exquisivity,'' he gushes to Red Riding Hood when they first meet. Handing her his card, he explains that his name is Wolf, ''as in Thomas and Virginia,'' and tries to pass himself off as a vegetarian.

Tension between the State Department and the Defense Department on arms control usually arises when the Pentagon hawkishly attacks diplomatic moves to restrain nuclear weapons. The State Department, for its part, is seen as more amenable to limiting nuclear arms. But that pattern only pertains to the arms race as classically defined, the contest for nuclear supremacy between the United States and the Soviet Union. When it comes to halting the spread of nuclear arms to more nations, experts say, the Pentagon turns strict while the State Department becomes lax.

The criminal sanctions threatened by Mayor Raymond L. Flynn of Boston aren't the only legal avenue being discussed these days as a weapon against gratuitous violence in professional sports. It was Mayor Flynn, of course, who was so upset by a brawl between the Bruins and the Montreal Canadiens a month ago that he threatened to order the arrest of any hockey player who went beyond hard checking on the Boston Garden ice. While he presses his point in meetings with the Bruin front office this week, there's a large body of practitioners eager to impose a solution of their own: multimillion-dollar damage suits on behalf of players injured by acts of flagrant violence.

Sweeping out of a clear desert sky and into aviation history, the experimental airplane Voyager landed safely here early today, completing the first nonstop flight around the world on one load of fuel. The journey of 25,012 miles set records for distance flown without refueling and for endurance by aviators on such a flight. The trip, which began and ended at Edwards Air Force Base, 60 miles northeast of Los Angeles, took 9 days 3 minutes 44 seconds. ''This was the last major event of atmospheric flight,'' Richard G. Rutan, 48 years old, said at a news conference after he landed the plane. ''That we did it as private citizens says a lot about freedom in America.''

THE first ''Rigoletto'' of the season Monday night proved a dispiriting illustration of the Metropolitan Opera's dilemma over bread-and-butter Italian operas. They must be increasingly relied upon for their box-office draw, yet the company's roster is shallowest in the area of singers who can perform them with distinction. The schedule is inevitably a house of cards, waiting to collapse if there are withdrawals, cancellations, vocal problems or what have you. Such a precarious situation is not improved by indifferent conducting and stage direction.

To the Editor: Robert F. Wagner Jr., president of the New York City Board of Education, proposes that ''master teachers'' be taken out of the classroom to train new teachers and that they be paid $60,000 a year - more than the salaries of assistant principals and principals (news story, Dec.1). He overlooks that we already have master teachers working with those entering the system.

One recent night, a Christmas shopper we know, armed with shopping list and credit card, plunged into a large New York department store. She was prepared for anything, except for where she found the longest lines.
Italy Seeks Abduction Facts Italy has begun an investigation into reports that an Israeli nuclear technician was abducted by Israeli agents in Italy.

The state's special corruption prosecutor, Charles J. Hynes, is investigating a long 1983 luncheon meeting attended by the Queens District Attorney, John J. Santucci; two police officials; a Queens political leader, and a reputed organized-crime figure, law-enforcement officials said yesterday. The meeting took place at the Altadonna Restaurant in South Ozone Park, Queens, and lasted for more than 10 hours, according to the officials. In addition to Mr. Santucci, they said, the luncheon guests included Peter Prezioso, the deputy police chief who is head of the department's intelligence division; Michael Doyle, a retired police lieutenant; Anthony Sadowski, a City Commissioner of Elections, and Salvatore Reale, who has been linked by Federal law-enforcement officials to the Gambino crime family.

The report of a year-old memorandum proposing an exchange of arms to Iran for American hostages in Lebanon has contradicted the White House's insistence that it sold arms to Iran solely to open a dialogue with Iranian moderates. The document, reportedly written by the Director of Central Intelligence, William J. Casey, analyzed the political problems that could arise if the arms shipments were found out.

Angela Guerrero sold her meager belongings in the Dominican Republic to raise $250 for passage on an open boat that was to carry her to a prosperous life in the United States, but all she found was tragedy when the boat swamped 200 feet from its destination, carrying at least 14 of her 48 fellow passengers to their deaths. Mrs. Guerrero, 25 years old, recalled today how the 28-foot wooden boat swamped within sight of shore Monday night when the captain veered away after he saw what he believed was the light of a police car on land. ''We did not have any trouble in the ocean because the waves were not high,'' said Mrs. Guerrero at the police station in the west coast city of Mayaguez in Puerto Rico where she was being detained until she could be turned over to the Immigration and Naturalization Service. ''We were coming into a beach during the night when the captain thought he saw the light of a police car on shore,'' she said. ''There was a lot of confusion on the boat because some people wanted to turn around and go back because we would be arrested, but others wanted us to land because we had not eaten since we left Punta Junillo,'' the departure point in the Dominican Republic.

Dr. Lisa Reeves Mahoney, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jesse W. Mahoney of Old Field, L.I., was married yesterday to David Woods, a son of Mrs. John Woods of Dunkirk, N.Y., and the late Mr. Woods. The Rev. Dr. James Henry, a Baptist minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Moorten Botanical Gardens in Palm Springs, Calif.

Lord Grade, the canny and flamboyant show-business entrepreneur who celebrates his 80th birthday today, has suggested ''What I Promise, I Keep'' as his epitaph. ''I'm in the middle of a conference and can't talk right now,'' he told a reporter this week from his London office, ''but I will call you back in half an hour.'' Exactly 30 minutes later -not 29 minutes, not 31 - the phone rang. The conference was over and Lord Grade was ready to converse.

Scientists seeking to explain why a pod of pilot whales beached themselves and died on Cape Cod this month have found that 14 of them were infected with an unidentified flu virus. ''This is the first recording of a large-scale influenza outbreak in stranded whales,'' Mimi Simpson of the New England Aquarium in Boston said Tuesday. ''We have had isolated cases before, but nothing of this scale.''

A town Nativity scene destroyed by a fire Tuesday was replaced yesterday by a family touched by pleas for donations for a new creche. ''It gets your faith restored in humanity,'' Mayor Bob Norman said.

ON the afternoon of May 30, 1667, an inquisitive crowd of onlookers gathered to witness a remarkable sight: Margaret Cavendish, the ''mad'' Duchess of Newcastle, was coming to visit the Royal Society. She had been invited - at her own request - to view firsthand some of the astonishing experiments of the society's members. The gentlemen liquified a leg of mutton, mixed cold ingredients to produce hot and performed other wonders, but the real attraction was the Duchess. Among the curiosity-seekers straining to see her was Samuel Pepys, who wrote in his diary that the Duchess of Newcastle's dress was so eccentric and her ''deportment so unordinary'' that he decided he did not like her at all.

The Jets made a dramatic switch in quarterbacks today, benching Ken O'Brien for Pat Ryan in their wild-card playoff game Sunday against the Kansas City Chiefs. ''I just felt we needed a little lift,'' said Coach Joe Walton. ''We've got to win this week and there's no tomorrow.'' After their first 11 games, the Jets had the best record in the league at 10-1. And at one point, O'Brien was the highest-rated quarterback in the league. He wound up being voted by his peers as the alternate to the Pro Bowl.

An Associated Press correspondent, John Edlin, returned to Zimbabwe today after five days in what he called a ''medieval prison'' in Zambia. Mr. Edlin, a Harare-based reporter who was in Zambia covering the aftermath of food riots earlier this month, was jailed Friday.

A 13-month-old boy was given a 50-50 chance yesterday of keeping his left foot, which was grafted to his right leg after his mother carried him when she leaped in front of an A train. The infant, Vladimir Ramos, was listed in serious but stable condition at Bellevue Hospital after eight hours of surgery.

MOHAMMED al-Fayed, an Egyptian businessman who owns the Ritz Hotel in Paris and Harrods department store in London, has taken a 50-year lease on the former home of the Duke and Duchess of Windsor, Le Bois, in the Bois de Boulogne. The house, a graceful 19th-century villa of 14 rooms surrounded by a large tree-filled garden, belongs to the City of Paris. Although he refuses to say how much he is paying, Mr. Fayed calls it ''a peppercorn rent.'' The City of Paris is equally taciturn. Bernard Niquet, a city official, said, ''The city rented the house to Mr. Fayed because it was absolutely neccessary that it remain a private residence and be well kept up.''

Bedeviled, belittled and finally banished, the Grumman Flxible buses are back on city streets, but in Newark, not New York. Since September, 120 of the much-maligned vehicles, selected from the 851 exiled for years to a Brooklyn pier after the New York City Transit Authority branded them too dangerous to use, have been put in service in New Jersey. New Jersey's mass-transit agency, N.J. Transit, paid about $55,000 for each bus, a markdown from the $100,000 or so the Transit Authority had paid and the $140,000 a new Model 870 costs. Each vehicle comes with a full warranty of 150,000 miles or three years, whichever comes first.

As frantic last-minute shoppers struggled from store to store along Fifth Avenue at noontime yesterday, the only sidewalk peddler in sight from 42d Street to 59th Street was Junior Grandison, selling children's books and Webster's Dictionaries on the southwest corner of 45th Street. It was a far cry from the scene a week ago, when hundreds of peddlers of scarves, trinkets, watches, jewelry and wind-up toys jammed the sidewalks and caused some of the most powerful merchants on Fifth Avenue to complain publicly to Mayor Koch. The merchants called the spread of illegal peddlers along the elegant avenue ''a disaster.''

Walter Beinecke Jr., credited with transforming Nantucket's aged commercial district and waterfront into a picturesque tourist center, has sold his sprawling commercial holdings on the island to a real estate firm for more than $50 million.

The Parks and Recreation Department offers walks and workshops throughout the winter with the Urban Park Rangers, who are also naturalists. Listed below are possibilities for celebrating the holidays outdoors; the events are free, except where noted. BRONX (For more information call 212-548-7880): Kazimiroff Nature Trail Tour, Hunter Island, Pelham Bay Park, Saturday, Dec. 27.

The National Basketball Association has fined Clemon Johnson of the Seattle SuperSonics $3,500 and Akeem Olajuwon of the Houston Rockets $3,000 for their roles in a fight last week during a game. Rodney McCray of the Rockets was fined $500 for leaving the bench area during the fight. . . . Mike Sheppard, formerly of Long Beach State, was named head football coach at the University of New Mexico. Larry Reisbig, an assistant under Sheppard, was promoted to head coach at Long Beach.
In Washington, the holiday season was heralded with traditional tones: a tree aglow with lights outside the Capitol and a wreath at the entrance to the Treasury Building. NYT/Jose R. Lopez)
A dispatch yesterday from Palo Alto, Calif., on planning for the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library misidentified the president of Stanford University. He is Donald Kennedy.

Andrei D. Sakharov said today that he had ''great respect'' for Mikhail S. Gorbachev and his efforts to change the Soviet system and to encourage public discussion. ''I find the new policy of openness in this country very important because openness has always been in short supply,'' he told The Associated Press in one of several interviews with Western reporters. Dr. Sakharov, who returned Tuesday from seven years of banishment in Gorky, also raised the possibility that the status of dissent might be undergoing change in the Soviet Union and that he might play a less confrontational role than he did in the Brezhnev era.

The cavernous department store off J.E.B. Stuart Road in the middle of Fort Bliss here has regulation-issue Christmas music and decorations. It has Lazer Tag and Snuggle Bears, Bruce Springsteen and Lionel Richie, Liz Claiborne and Gucci Pour Homme. It also has a preponderance of shoppers in military fatigues, no sales tax, requires identifications for admittance and plows all its profits into things like day-care centers and swimming pools on military bases. Known simply as the Fort Bliss Exchange, the store is part of the nation's 10th-largest retailer, but it is a store that most shoppers can never enter. It is one of 258 such big stores that are part of the military PX, or post exchange, system (officially known as the Army and Air Force Exchange System). That system does $4.9 billion of busineess annually, serving armed forces personnel around the world.

Before the Christmas show began Tuesday in the Fort Washington Armory shelter that night for 936 homeless men, one of them walked up to the makeshift stage. ''You a boonie rat?'' he asked Tom Bird, who was there to play Santa Claus. ''Yeah,'' Mr. Bird said. ''First Cavalry, Central Highlands.'' And then he and the homeless man, whose name was Leonard, went through the ritual greeting both remembered from the Vietnam War - a regular handshake, a soul handshake, a finger clasp and an embrace.

To the Editor: ''Expensive Babies'' (editorial, Dec. 17) focuses on the tragic relationship between low birth weight, large numbers of newborn deaths and huge costs for neonatal intensive care. With such devastating human and fiscal consequences, no one can afford to ignore the problem. This is why the Greater New York March of Dimes has begun a three-year campaign for healthier babies aimed at fighting the problem of low birth weight. The solutions are no mystery. We know what works. Early prenatal care, as you point out, makes a real difference.
Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds decreased $1.73 billion, to $233.81 billion, for the week ended yesterday, the Investment Company Institute said.

EVER wonder what your house is up to when you're not looking? According to David Bodanis, a British science writer, that seemingly sedate structure of brick, wood or stucco shimmers, breathes, melts, hisses and otherwise is often up to no good. His book ''The Secret House: 24 Hours in the Strange and Unexpected World in Which We Spend Our Nights and Days'' (Simon & Schuster, $18.95) zooms in relentlessly on the mundane matters of modern life, proving once again that the difference between the ordinary and the exotic is only your point of view. It's nothing short of astounding, the things we routinely ignore. That annoying static on your radio as you hunt for the right station may be lightning striking on distant continents.

Oui, Vanessa, there is a Santa Claus. But he does not live, as she addressed her letter, on the ''Street of the Shooting Star, fifth floor, left apartment, Milky Way, The Sky.'' Santa lives right here in the Gironde, one of the richest wine regions of France. Santa is slight - about 5 feet 6 inches tall. He wears a cuddly gray sweater and wire-rimmed glasses. Today, he's battling a fierce cold.

Yields on money market mutual funds rose sharply for the week ended yesterday, fueled by higher rates on some short-term securities, such as 30-day commercial paper. The rise in short-term rates, however, did not spill over into certificates of deposit or money market accounts, which were unchanged to slightly lower. Treasury bill rates, often used as a benchmark for rates on bank money market accounts or certificates of deposit, were little changed last week, even though some other rates rose because of unusual year-end financings.

The National Association of Securities Dealers Inc. reported yesterday that short interest on Nasdaq stocks was down 6.5 million shares, or 2.8 percent, in the month ended Dec. 15, to 206.4 million shares. The short interest figures for Nasdaq stocks reflect the total number of shares sold short by N.A.S.D. members and their customers. A short position can result from the sale of borrowed stock in the hope of buying the same issue at a later date and a lower price. The following companies show large changes:

Gathering around the family piano to sing Christmas songs is the fondest part of many people's holiday memories. Something a little more sophisticated, but homespun enough, was fondly offered by the New York Vocal Arts Ensemble Tuesday evening at Alice Tully Hall. The mixed vocal quartet (Lise Messier, Wanda Brister, Gregory Mercer and John Arbo) and its director-accompanist, Raymond Beegle, ranged widely in language, style and period; the piano was big and grand; there was no fire. But there was a handsome sofa for the singers to wait their turns on, and Mr. Beegle's anecdotes were welcoming and familial.

When Pope John Paul II travels the globe, it is in the squalid slums of the third world that his message seems most urgent and compelling. During a visit to Guyaquil, Ecuador, last year, he dropped in on El Guasmo, a sprawling collection of tin and bamboo shacks where the streets are usually nothing but mud and where several hundred thousand people often lack the most basic necessities, including drinkable water. In his address to the relatively small crowd that came to hear him, John Paul sounded like no one so much as Eugene V. Debs, the American Socialist who once said he was not free as long as someone was in prison. ''May no one feel tranquil,'' the Pope thundered, ''while in Ecuador there is a child without school, a family without a home, a worker without a job, an ill or elderly person without adequate attention.'' In El Guasmo, tranquillity is a long way off.

Heavy rains in the late fall have helped ease the effects of the South's worst drought in a century. But from Alabama to South Carolina, moisture levels in farm fields and pastures remain well below normal, with the start of spring planting only three months off. That means farmers in the region are now hoping for a rainier than usual winter to restore the deep soil moisture that agricultural experts say is needed to nourish next season's corn, wheat and other crops and to restore pastures burned out by last summer's hot, dry weather. All across the South, heavy rains throughout October and November, and again this week, helped soak fields, although the moisture came too late to save most crops, already damaged beyond salvation by drought.

To the Editor: The original compact was simple enough: a free credit card and a grace period between purchase and settlement dates. Then came innovations, among them an annual user fee, a penalty fee for months when the user left no unpaid balance on which a finance charge could accrue, the ''average daily balance'' and other exotic formulas for increasing the finance charge on unpaid balances, the unconscionably high interest rates. The latest innovation among banks and other credit-card issuers (''Credit Cards: No 'Free Ride,' '' Your Money column, Nov. 29), is to eliminate the grace period altogether. This development and the new tax rules, which eliminate deductibility on credit-card interest, suggest that for many of us the credit card may have outlived its usefulness. It has become an unnecessarily expensive way to do business, burdening as it does each transaction with a hefty surcharge to feed the appetite of a hungry servicing apparatus.

To the Editor: With the recent visit to the White House by the Zairian President, Mobutu Sese Seko, the debate on whether or not to continue American aid to Zaire in light of President Mobutu's alleged human-rights abuses has again come to the fore (news story, Dec. 11). It is a debate without proper focus, conveniently ignoring the truly difficult problems that confront Zairians. The primary object for participants in this debate is the American link to an unsavory third-world dictator. Rhetoric that excoriates Zaire's ruler invites dangerous comparisons with Ferdinand E. Marcos and Jean-Claude Duvalier. Zaire is neither the Philippines nor Haiti; in the most basic sense, it is barely a nation.

Two of the world's largest chemical companies, Hercules Inc. and Montedison S.p.A., are offering shares of their joint venture, Himont Inc., to the public in an initial offering worth more than $330 million. Himont is the world's largest producer of polypropylene, a material used in the production of plastics.

An article yesterday about the formation of a civil rights coalition in New York City misidentified the group and the head of the Research and Advocacy Center for Equality. The new group is the New York City Civil Rights Coalition; the head of the research center is Michael Meyers.

Eric Garcia, 2 years old, waiting for his father, Jose, to get moving yesterday as they took in the sights and sounds of Christmas and toured stores along Fifth Avenue for those last-minute purchases. (NYT/Don Hogan Charles)

Federal agents seized time cards, employee logs, computer disks and other items in a search of the Northrop Corporation's Warner Robins unit in Georgia as evidence in a criminal investigation of charges that the company may have overbilled the Government on military contracts, Federal officials said today. The nine-hour raid, which began Tuesday morning, was conducted by agents from the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the Postal Service and the Air Force Office of Special Investigations.
The Army has grounded almost three-quarters of its AH-1 Cobra helicopter gunships for a safety inspection of their main rotor-blade fittings.

The Federal Reserve Board, failing to resolve a battle between the securities and banking industries, said today that it will not decide until April whether to give banks an expanded role in underwriting securities. The question before the Fed is whether banks should be permitted to underwrite commercial paper, mortgage-backed securities and municipal revenue bonds. The banks are partway toward achieving that goal. On Tuesday, a Federal appeals court reversed a lower court's ruling and said that the Bankers Trust Company of New York might place commercial paper, short-term corporate debt. That means that Bankers Trust may line up buyers of commercial paper, but not actually own the securities.

It does not take long to realize that the pianist John Bunch, who is playing through Saturday at Zinno, 128 West 13th Street, with the bassist Michael Moore, is firmly rooted in the days of the big bands. This is not just because of his choice of tunes - such products of the big bands as ''Green Eyes'' and ''I'm Getting Sentimental Over You,'' or the songs of that period, such as ''Alone Together'' and ''Can't We Be Friends.''

Tougher drunken-driving laws cause more drunken drivers to flee the scenes of traffic accidents, according to a Purdue University study. The report showed that while stiffer penalties for driving while drunk reduce the number of alcohol-related automobile accidents, they cause more hit-and-run accidents involving motorists who are intoxicated. ''Because the chances of paying a fine and going to jail are much greater, drivers who risk drinking are more likely to want to escape from the scene,'' said John R. Umbeck, a professor of economics at Purdue's Krannert School of Management who is co-author of the report.

To the Editor: Walking by the windows of Saks Fifth Avenue in New York City, I was swept into the crowd admiring the cozy picture of an ideal Christmas in the Lapland home of the reindeer, complete with the cherubic figures of Ricka, Flicka and Dicka, snuggled in native Scandinavian finery, and two reindeer standing as testimonials to the magnanimity of Santa Claus. Despite the joyful homeyness of the scene, I could not help being reminded of the reserve of Santa's reindeer that is rapidly being depleted in Lapland because of the trail of contaminating radiation wrought by the Chernobyl nuclear-plant accident that took place this year in the Soviet Union. How sad it is that not even the cheerful sight of such a quaint Christmas scene can remain untarnished by the technological ''advances'' that threaten our very existence. JILL SANCHIA COWEN New York, Dec. 17, 1986

The assets of the syndicate division of Rupert Murdoch's News America Holdings Inc. are being sold to the Hearst Corporation's North America Syndicate Inc. subsidiary, the two companies said yesterday. No price was announced.

About 100 blacks who live outside this city in small, gray structures that have no running water and rent for $40 a month will move next month into Government-subsidized housing at a former Air Force base, according to the Mayor here. Rent at the new houses will be about the same or less, depending on income, the Mayor, Joe Smitherman, said Tuesday. No one will pay more, he added.

The Administration has traced at least $20 million in contributions intended for the Nicaraguan rebels, $10 million from the Sultan of Brunei and roughly $10 million from private donors, according to an Administration official. The statement marked the first time that an Administration source had put a dollar figure on the amount of money thought to have been raised for the rebels, known as contras, from private and non-American government donors. The $20 million would come atop money apparently diverted from profits from arms sales to Iran, a figure that has been variously estimated at $10 million to $30 million. The estimate of $10 million from Brunei is significantly more than initially suspected by Congressional investigators. One Congressional official familiar with this estimate said today it was ''much more than we had previously heard about.''

Gerald R. Ford's Presidency took on an element of immediacy here the other day as a high school social studies class viewed footage of the fall of Vietnam, from refugees in the countryside to the havoc at the United States Embassy as the last evacuation helicopter pulled away from the roof. Soon after, several students watched scenes of President John F. Kennedy as he traveled the country lobbying for his economic and social programs. Those images, among more than 2,235 bits of footage from 1893 to 1985, are stored on 36 silver disks that comprise the Video Encyclopedia of the 20th Century - one of the country's newest educational tools. The students in Stephen J. Paskiewicz's 11th grade class at Riverhead High School are among the first in the region to have access to the encyclopedia, according to the Manhattan-based company that produced it, CEL Educational Resources. Mr. Paskiewicz praised the encyclopedia as a research device that ''helps get kids to think critically, analyze and draw their own conclusions.'' #77 Hours of Film ''Kids are programmed into music and audio-visual entertainment,'' he said, ''but this isn't entertainment, it's history.''

The Justice Department has obtained a consent decree requiring five Ramada Inns in Virginia and Alabama to insure that blacks are accorded the same bar service as whites. The agreement Tuesday settles a civil rights suit charging that the employees of the Adam's Lounge in each of the hotels were instructed to serve blacks only after all white patrons had been served.
The Wary Curators Until it can find out more about what it is getting, the Municipal Art Commission will no longer consider gifts of art to New York City. Page 33.
A second major union agreed yesterday to a new contract with the Long Island Rail Road, thus averting a possible mid-January strike, the railroad announced.

Until it can find out more about what it is getting, the municipal Art Commission, which has the ultimate say in such matters, will no longer consider gifts of art to New York City. The commission wants to avoid what happened earlier this year in Brooklyn and Queens, where its critical esthetic judgment of sculptures offered by private donors for city parks led to hard feelings all around. Both gifts had been welcomed by Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern.

The Dalai Lama, Tibet's exiled spiritual and temporal leader and a staunch foe of the Chinese regime, proclaimed his support today for the student rallies in China demanding greater freedom. ''These demands are just, inalienable rights of all peoples and are to be supported by everyone throughout the free world,'' the Dalai Lama said in a statement issued through his office in New Delhi. ''We, the people of Tibet, as a neighbor of China, express our solidarity with the Chinese people in their rightful

In Potosi's central plaza, an oasis of greenery more than 13,000 feet above sea level, people born to the lowlands can become quickly light-headed and deeply burned by the Andes sun. Mario Soliz Vargas, the energetic public relations man at city hall, says the setting is ''close to the sky and near the angels.'' People describing other aspects of Potosi are far less lyrical. The Rev. Gustavo Evens, a Belgian priest whose European skin looks as if it has undergone perpetual roasting during his 21 years here, said he could not recall a time that had been truly good in Potosi, only some ''least bad years.''

Nabisco today announced a voluntary recall of all its Baby Ruth candy bars after tests showed salmonella bacteria in several batches. Some of the nutty chocolate bars were recalled last week by the company after the salmonella was discovered at a Nabisco manufacturing plant in Franklin Park, Ill.

Neil Simon is hardly Norman Rockwell, but his ''Brighton Beach Memoirs'' has a warmly nostalgic quality, something that has traveled very nicely to the screen. ''Brighton Beach Memoirs,'' the first and perhaps the most sweetly rueful play of Mr. Simon's autobiographical trilogy, has become a film of surprisingly gentle charms. Mr. Simon's humor is much in evidence, but it is not the film's strongest selling point. Even more effective are the sense of a place and a way of life long vanished and the care and affection with which they have been summoned up. ''Brighton Beach Memoirs,'' which opens today at the Paramount and other theaters, is Mr. Simon's first portrait of the young would-be writer Eugene Jerome, and of the family life whose very closeness is a touching anachronism. The play is set in 1937, in a house small enough to insure that no one ever, under any circumstances, is afforded one shred of privacy. There, Eugene (Jonathan Silverman) is experiencing the libidinous throes of adolescence. His changing behavior is closely observed by his hardworking, hard-worrying mother (Blythe Danner); by the older brother (Brian Drillinger), who's forced to share a room with him (''If I was your sister, I wouldn't sleep on the same block with you,'' this brother declares.), and even by his discouraged, exhausted father (Bob Dishy), who holds down two jobs and movingly embodies the film's Depression-era ethos.

Fire swept through a home for the elderly before dawn today, killing six people and injuring four. Jim Crawley, a fire investigator, said the blaze started in the room of a 71-year-old man, Robert Davis, who died in the blaze.

THIS may have been one of the largest years for corporate takeovers on record, but it was also the year of the broken deal. Time and again when a company seemed like a goner, it either bought off a corporate raider with the equivalent of greenmail or decided at the last minute that there was a better alternative to getting hitched. As these stocks plummet, shareholders usually wonder if their management did the right thing and question if they will ever see such lofty heights again. The Beneficial Corporation's rejection of a $1.74 billion takeover by the Transamerica Corporation last week was an especially bitter pill for some of its shareholders because the stock at one point had run up more than 25 points from the mid-40's level on the anticipation of a done deal. Yesterday the stock closed at $54.25, down 50 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

A lawyer and longtime member of the board of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, Paul J. Henry, was appointed board chairman yesterday by Mayor Koch. The post had been vacant since last June, when Victor E. Botnick resigned as chairman after admitting he had lied about his educational background. Mr. Botnick, for many years a close aide to the Mayor, had falsely claimed on a background check and in a conversation with a reporter that he was a college graduate.
Forsaking storybook Celesteville, the King of the Elephants has jetted in for a Connecticut Christmas of gadgets and cross-country skiing. His author unwraps it all for The Home Section. Page 37.

Michael Botwinick said today that he would resign next summer as director of the Corcoran Gallery of Art, a position for which he gave up the directorship of the Brooklyn Museum four years ago. Mr. Botwinick said he had no immediate plans, but, noting that his resignation would not take effect until June 30, added, ''This gives me some time to look at options to see what I want to do.'' The appointment of Mr. Botwinick was announced in 1982 by the Corcoran Gallery and School of Art, which is the largest nongovernmental art museum in Washington.

While the market for high-grade corporate bonds was inactive this week, underwriters proceeded with public offerings of low-quality ''junk bonds'' totaling $550 million and $275 million of convertible debt or preferred stock. Earlier this month, yields on junk bonds moved higher as many potential buyers turned cautious amid questions about the liquidity of such bonds if officials at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the leading firm in the business, were implicated in the insider trading scandal.

A South African civil rights group said today that a black political detainee, held under an emergency decree, had died in a hospital soon after being transferred there from prison. The reported death of Simon Marule, aged 20, was the second in detention reported since the proclamation of the state of emergency last June 12, according to the Detainees' Parents Support Committee. The independent body monitors the number of detainees and the conditions under which they are held. It has estimated that more than 22,000 people -mostly blacks - have deen detained for varying periods over the past six months.

Dr. Russell F. Manfredi, sentenced last week to 20 years in prison for the bludgeoning death of his wife, was released today from Somers State Prison on bail after filing an appeal of his conviction. Dr. Manfredi, 33 years old, was convicted on Nov. 3 of first-degree manslaughter in the death of Catherine Billings Manfredi, who was beaten with a baseball bat and dumped out a second-floor window of the couple's West Hartford home on March 8, 1985.

Gum chewers might remember Beemans gum, once promoted as a cure for indigestion and sea sickness. Or Clove gum, said to help drinkers disguise the rum on their breath. Or Black Jack, flavored with shredded licorice. These are just a few of the old-time products now making a comeback as gum companies, like movie producers and all manner of other businesses, are finding it profitable to go back to the future. Other golden oldies undergoing a revival include player pianos, Barbasol shaving cream and Life magazine, products that had either experienced declining sales or been pulled from the shelf altogether.
A THERMOMETER can be your best friend. If you feel sick, reading it can tell you how sick you are. If you get worse, it can warn you.

Following is a transcript of remarks made by Andrei D. Sakharov and his wife, Yelena Bonner, to Western reporters today, as translated by The Associated Press: Q. Do you have any Christmas wishes? SAKHAROV. As usual on this day, I wish people and their families happiness, love, peace and health. On this day, a family day, a day when people must think about or, at least, hope that everything will be all right in the world, for all nations of the world.

Mary Beth Whitehead with her husband, Richard, their son, Ryan, and daughter, Tuesday, as they arrived yesterday in Hackensack to visit the child Mrs. Whitehead bore under contract nine months ago. The child, known as Baby M, is in the custody of Elizabeth and William Stern, who hired Mrs. Whitehead to bear the child. The surrogate mother has been trying to regain custody of the child. (AP)

THIS spring, it will be 75 years since Juliette Gordon Low announced, ''I've got something for the girls of Savannah and all America and all the world, and we're going to start it tonight.'' Gathering up 18 girls, she started the Girl Scouts. Since then, the organization has grown to more than two million girls, sold countless mint-chocolate cookies, offered its aid in two world wars and dropped merit badges in sick-nursing in favor of those in computers. It has seen its membership rise and fall and has had to confront issues such as drug use and child abuse, but has never lost the spunky ''can do'' spirit of its somewhat eccentric founder. ''We try to really understand and respond to the needs of girls, the needs of American families,'' said Frances Hesselbein, the current executive director of the Girl Scouts of the U.S.A. ''We accept the demands and imperatives of leadership.''

William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, may be in more critical medical condition than his doctors have publicly acknowledged, according to news reports today. CBS News reported tonight that Mr. Casey, who is hospitalized at Georgetown University Hospital here, is ''in a semi-coma and is responding to only painful stimuli.''
A Transit Authority police officer was found shot to death early yesterday behind a Bronx building, and investigators called the death an apparent suicide.

Shawn Halloran capped a season of redemption Tuesday night in his final game for Boston College. His 5-yard touchdown pass to Kelvin Martin gave the Eagles a 27-24 victory over favored Georgia in the Hall of Fame Bowl.
An engine fire forced a Delta Air Lines jet to return to the airport just minutes after it took off for New York with 136 passengers aboard.

On the November morning in Vancouver that Phil Esposito dismissed his coach, Ted Sator, the general manager talked once again about his desire to make a big trade. That night Tony McKegney scored four times and the Rangers rallied and won. One afternoon, a few weeks later, Esposito said that he still had a ''dream of making the big one.'' That night McKegney scored twice and the Rangers beat Los Angeles by a goal. And two nights ago, after the Devils had scored three times to draw even, McKegney went out, scored twice, and the Rangers won. Still, afterward, as if looking the other way, a Ranger player said that one of his Christmas wishes was for a high-scoring teammate. Taking what they do have for granted or perhaps conditioned to yearning, always yearning, the Rangers may have missed their Christmas present arriving early and slipping through a side door.

An important session of Vietnam's National Assembly opened today in Hanoi, according to the official radio, the Voice of Vietnam. The assembly is expected to name the country's President and Prime Minister.

Some movies ease their audiences over the credibility gap by being so apparently reasonable. Since everything else makes sense, we accept the film's incredible premise and move on. Other films begin so mysteriously that the audience can't tell right away what's possible or impossible. ''The Morning After,'' Sidney Lumet's entertaining new romantic thriller, opens by challenging the audience. It says, in effect, believe this or not: Early one morning a beautiful woman, who turns out to be Alex Sternbergen (Jane Fonda), comes to hazy consciousness in a niftily modern Los Angeles loft apartment, sharing a bed with a man she doesn't know and, under the circumstances, never will. He's dead, with a large kitchen knife stuck into his chest. There's blood all over him and, very quickly, all over Alex. What would you do if you were Alex? Have hysterics? Call the cops? Flee? Alex pours herself a drink, then dresses. She's so adept that, though her hands are bloodied, she doesn't get a spot on her clothes. She can't call the cops, we eventually learn, because she was once booked for assault with a deadly weapon.

WHEN you pick the furnishings for a room you arm yourself with swatches of curtain fabric, books of wallpaper samples and snips of cushion material. You juxtapose and juggle them this way and that, walk to the window, cock your head on one side, click your tongue, discuss them with innocent bystanders. Does this one go, or that? Suppose we settle for the crimson curtains, does that mean switching from the forest green carpet? Who color-coordinates their garden in the way they would a room? Scarcely anybody. Why? Mostly, I believe, because they feel it is beyond their competence. Fabrics and paint are known quantities. Flowers and leaves are far less predictable Flowers, most of them, are only present for a month or so. Trying to recall or capture their precise colors is a challenge.

Spud Webb will be lost to the Atlanta Hawks for at least three more months because of a knee injury he suffered Dec. 5. Dr. Jack Hughston, who examined Webb's right knee, told the team's president, Stan Kasten, that he had found damage at the connection of the thighbone and knee cartilage. He said Webb would be on crutches for six weeks, and would then undergo six weeks of rehabilitation before he could return.

The dollar ended mixed in sluggish activity yesterday on world currency markets, which closed early for the Christmas holiday. Gold prices rose slightly. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted gold at $390.00 at about 1P.M., up 85 cents from late Tuesday.

The Ford Motor Company has begun recalling 226,000 Ford Escort and Mercury Lynx automobiles from the 1982 model year that exceed Federal and California air pollution standards, the Environmental Protection Agency said Monday.
Dave Currey, football coach at the University of Cincinnati, which lost to both Miami and Penn State this year: ''They're both great teams. One you'd date, and the other you'd marry.''

These are some of the events figuring in the controversy over the secret sale of American arms to Iran and the diversion of profits to help the Nicaraguan rebels. The shaded areas indicate events that occurred behind the scenes. 1984 March 16: William Buckley, a political officer at the United States Embassy in Beirut, later identified as the C.I.A. station chief, is kidnapped by pro-Iranian Moslem militants. July 8: The Rev. Benjamin Weir, a Presbyterian missionary, is kidnapped. November: Manucher Ghorbanifar, an Iranian exile, raises the issue of ransoming hostages in meeting in Hamburg with Iranian officials and Theodore C. Shackley, a former C.I.A. agent, who relays the proposal to Washington.
In percent

To the Editor: The president of the Automobile Club of New York, Donald T. Phillips, attacks some of the measures, such as a gas tax or toll increase, that are being suggested for financing the rebuilding program for New York City's subways (letter, Dec. 11). Mr. Phillips says, ''The motorist simply cannot pay both the highway system and mass transit.'' The incorrect implication is that automobile users do not benefit from taxes, tolls and transit improvements.

Hugh McCabe, the linebacker coach at Seneca Valley High School in Gaithersburg, Md., died of lung cancer last week at age 47. McCabe, a single parent of two teen-age boys, had known the worst since last February, when doctors who performed exploratory surgery gave him six months.

LARRY WOOD'S craft is inlaying gold, silver, abalone, rubies, emeralds, teak and ebony into furniture, walls or musical instruments, even the dashboards of cars. At Magus Design, his studio in Brooklyn, Mr. Wood, left, has inlaid borders on coffee tables, backgammon boxes and briefcases.
The nation's stock and commodity exchanges, banks, Government offices and most businesses are closed today in observance of Christmas.

High cholesterol levels appear to be associated with an increased risk for colon cancer, offering another reason for people to reduce the amount of fat in their diets, researchers said today. Two new studies conducted separately in Sweden and West Germany and published in The New England Journal of Medicine found that people with high cholesterol levels had significantly increased risk of developing cancer of the colon and rectum. Dr. Robert Mayer, an associate professor of medicine at Harvard Medical School, said the findings indicated those with high cholesterol levels might need to be monitored more closely for such cancer.

BASKETBALL CHICAGO BULLS VS. KNICKS, at Madison Square Garden, noon, (Television -MSG, noon) WASHINGTON BULLETS VS. 76ERS, at Philadelphia, 8 P.M. (Television - WTBS, 8:05 P.M.) FOOTBALL SUN BOWL, at El Paso, Alabama vs. Washington, 9 P.M. (Television - Channel 2, 2:30 P.M.) BLUE-GRAY ALL-STAR CLASSIC, at Montgomery, Ala., 5 P.M. (Television -Channel 11, 5 P.M., FNN-SCORE, 5 P.M.)

After months of inattention, Mayor Koch of New York now admits that the city is not acting fast enough to place infants in foster homes. He suggests the city give prospective foster parents conditional approval within two weeks and allow them to take the children pending a thorough investigation. It's a sensible way to ease a genuine emergency.

A dispatch last Friday from Annapolis, Md., reported that Griffin O'Neal, son of the actor Ryan O'Neal, had been acquitted of manslaughter in the death of Gian-Carlo Coppola but had been convicted on one count of negligently operating a boat.

The Davis-Besse nuclear plant, which had been shut down for more than 18 months, resumed operation on Monday, a Toledo Edison Company official said. The reactor, on the shore of Lake Erie about 25 miles east of Toledo, was running at 10 percent of capacity and should return to full operation around Jan. 5, the official said. It had been idle since June 9, 1985, when 14 pieces of equipment failed, causing a temporary loss of cooling water.

We know what we know, but why do we know it? In the final episode of ''The Day the Universe Changed,'' James Burke, the exuberant host of the series, argues a case for comfort: What we know, more or less, is what makes us feel good. The episode, ''Worlds Without End,'' can be seen on Channel 13 at 10 o'clock tonight. As always, Mr. Burke is provocative. He begins by walking on a beach, musing about great minds in Western history. Darwin, Einstein, Gutenberg, Newton - their acts of discovery, he says, were mystical experiences. Then Mr. Burke is at a launch site, watching a spacecraft lift off. ''Thanks to science,'' he says, ''the way lies onward and up.''

* Consolidated Rail Corp., Philadelphia, has asked its chairman and chief executive, L. Stanley Crane, to continue in those positions through December 1988. * Cox Enterprises Inc., Atlanta, a newspaper publisher, announced that James Kennedy had been appointed executive vice president. * JB's Restaurants Inc., Salt Lake City, announced the retirement of its founder and chairman, Jack Broberg, as well as Paul W. Warner and Richard B. Huntington, senior vice presidents. * McKesson Corp., San Francisco, a maker of drugs, drug sundries, liquors and chemicals, elected to its board James R. Harvey, chief executive of Transamerica Corp.

Nigel D.T. Andrews has a hard act to follow. Yesterday the General Electric Company announced that he would be the company's new vice president for business development and planning, effective Feb. 16. Mr. Andrews succeeds Michael A. Carpenter, who held the post during G.E.'s extensive reshaping program and was the architect of the recent RCA acquisition. Mr. Andrews said yesterday that one of his principal tasks would be to identify new industries in which G.E. might seek acquisitions. ''I certainly hope that I can come in and pull off an RCA, too,'' he said.
Two limited partners have opposed Genentech Inc.'s proposed buyout of two of its research and development partnerships.

* Banc One Corp., Columbus, Ohio, has received approval from the Federal Reserve Board to complete its merger with American Fletcher Corp. of Indianapolis. * BellSouth Corp., Atlanta, will not have to face the Monopolies Commission over its proposed $96.6 million purchase of Dataserv Inc., the British Trade and Industry Department reported.

Two convicted murderers and a rapist who escaped 23 days ago from a prison in Delaware were captured Tuesday night in a creek bed after a daylong search of the desert near here, officials said. The three men were armed with two pistols and a derringer, but they surrendered after they were discovered hiding in the creek bed just north of Interstate 15, the Department of Safety reported. They were taken to a command post in this northwestern Arizona town, where they were positively identified through tattoos and scars and from photographs, according to a spokesman for the department, Allan Schmidt.
''I think that the word 'dissident' may be losing some of its resonance.

Interest rates were little changed yesterday in quiet trading, as securities firms and institutional investors were either closed for the holiday or lightly staffed. In the face of widespread forecasts of a weaker economy and lower interest rates early next year, securities dealers are still willing to hold large inventories of government, tax-exempt and corporate bonds. The forecasts, plus the absence of significant selling by institutional investors, have been enough to lift prices of notes and bonds modestly since the middle of the month.

For Frederick G. Currey, the $350 million purchase of the Greyhound Corporation's domestic bus operations is just the next phase in his long involvement with the transportation industry. For more than 30 years, the 54-year-old Dallas businessman has either been analyzing or running aircraft and bus companies. Now, with two other investors, he will bring the Greyhound bus operation to Dallas and become its chairman, president and chief executive after the deal is completed in March, he said.

Lane Kirkland, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. chief who is a leading American supporter of the trade union movement in Poland, learned yesterday that his plans to meet with the Solidarity leader, Lech Walesa, in Poland had been dashed. ''As a condition for granting of visas, we were informed by the Polish authorities that we would be required to meet with official trade unions set up by General Jaruzelski's Government after it crushed Solidarity,'' Mr. Kirkland said.

Scientists at the Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory announced Tuesday the discovery of a giant exploding star 250 million light-years from Earth and about 10,000 times too dim to be seen by the unaided eye. Richard Muller and Carl Pennypacker, who headed the team that made the discovery, named their discovery the Christmas Supernova after the observation was confirmed this week.

Tom Webster, the Rangers' coach, was in good condition at Lenox Hill Hospital yesterday after undergoing surgery to relieve an inner-ear infection. He was expected to be released from the hospital today and might be able to coach again next Tuesday night.

Phil Simms and Joe Morris, who have helped the Giants win their last nine regular-season games, won another kind of battle this week. They finished their Christmas shopping with a day to spare. When the Giants ended their workout Tuesday at Giants Stadium, Simms and Morris dressed quickly. Then it was off to the war: Simms optimistically, Morris resigned to a struggle.

An obviously annoyed chairman of the GTE Corporation said yesterday that his company would not sell two Canadian telephone subsidiaries to Samuel Belzberg, the Canadian investor who suggested such a move. Theodore F. Brophy, who heads the communications company based in Stamford, Conn., sent a letter to Mr. Belzberg saying that although ''we always welcome comments from any shareholder,'' GTE would not go along with his suggestions. Mr. Belzberg, in a letter dated Monday and immediately made public, suggested that GTE might better serve its shareholders' interests by selling the British Columbia Telephone Company and its Quebec-Telephone unit to him. Mr. Belzberg also suggested that GTE's Sprint long-distance telephone operation be spun off to the company's shareholders. In response, Mr. Brophy wrote, ''We do not believe that it is generally in the best interest of GTE shareholders for this corporation to treat its businesses like commodities that are always for sale.''

President Reagan's Christmas message: Every December across America the images of the Christmas season accumulate as this great holiday approaches. Preparations are made in homes and churches and shops in every city and town, and the land is full of traditional signs and symbols of its coming: Fresh snow resting lightly on the holly bush, package-laden crowds crushing the storefronts and bus stops, strings of lights gleaming from the housetops, chestnut vendors and street-corner Santas, school plays with children dressed -hardly needing the costume - as angels, and choirs joining heart and voice in joyous song. Because of these traditions, no Christmas celebration truly stands alone. For most of us, the holidays bring back such a trove of memories, evoked by things as simple as the scent of pine or the painted scene on a greeting card, that our Christmases become not separate events on a calendar but a chain in which all are linked together as one. This is as it should be, for Christmas is a holiday that we celebrate not as individuals nor as a nation but as a human family - and not merely as a family living in this age and time but as a family linked through history, in ways we still cannot fully comprehend, to that first Christmas in Bethlehem. May our prayers this Christmas call forth that serenity of heart and confidence in the future that are the best of all possible gifts. May the song of our people be one of thanks for God's blessings on America and of petition for His continued blessings upon us, especially on those who face this Christmas in want or loneliness.
Larry Bethea, a former lineman with the Dallas Cowboys, faces up to 20 years in prison after pleading guilty to stealing his mother's life savings of $64,000.

The Tandon Corporation today reported a loss of $45.2 million in the fourth quarter, compared with a loss of $85.1 million for the quarter last year. Revenues rose 3.1 percent, to $56.4 million, from $54.7 million a year ago.

To the Editor: ''Governor Cuomo and the Milk Cartel'' (editorial, Dec. 13) clearly conveys your displeasure with the denial of a license for a New Jersey dairy to distribute milk in four boroughs of New York City, but your tone of criticism is extreme and unfair. First, in criticizing the Commissioner of Agriculture's decision, you simply ignore his statutory obligation to make a judgment based on the requirements of the existing state milk licensing law.

Christmas Day Parking - Sunday rules. Sanitation - No collections; no street cleaning. Governmental offices - Closed. Post offices - Closed; special delivery and express-mail delivery only. Banks - Closed. Financial markets - Closed. Transportation - Subways, buses, Long Island and Metro-North railroads on Sunday and holiday schedules; some N.J. Transit schedules altered. Libraries - Closed. Schools - Closed.
Here's how the major college football conferences and groupings of independents fared during the regular season in interleague games against Division I-A opponents.

Richard J. Ferris, the chairman of UAL Inc., has long wanted to offer the business traveler a way to fly, rent a car and stay in a hotel all under the canopy of the parent company, but he apparently still has to persuade Wall Street. The acquisition by UAL, the parent company of United Airlines, of the Hilton International Company, announced on Tuesday, speeds UAL toward its goal. Hilton International owns 88 hotels in capitals and major cities, catering mainly to business travelers.

To the Editor: Russell Baker, describing a book he wrote as a small-fry reporter on Nathan Witt, who took the Fifth in the 1950's (column, Dec. 13), attributes to Descartes the phrase ''the book fell stillborn from the press.'' As all my students in Philosophy 1510 know, it was David Hume, in his ''Autobiography,'' discussing his own poorly received ''Treatise of Human Nature,'' not Descartes, who wrote that the book ''fell dead-born from the press, without reaching such distinction, as even to excite a murmur among the zealots.''

The Yankees fulfilled one of their pressing needs yesterday when they announced the signing of a right-handed power hitter, Gary Ward, a free-agent outfielder. Ward, who played the last three seasons with the Texas Rangers, agreed to a reported two-year contract, with an option for a third year, worth about $550,000 per season. Incentives could bring the value of the pact to more than $800,000 a year. Ward and Reggie Jackson, who signed a one-year contract with the Oakland A's yesterday, became the first major free agents to switch teams since the season ended.

MAKING a safe fire is easy once you know the rules. Firewood is generally broken down into two categories: hardwoods and softwoods. Hardwoods like maple, oak and elm - trees that lose their leaves in the fall - give off the most heat and burn longer than softwoods, like spruce and pine, which are easier to ignite. The Wood Heating Alliance in Washington recommends burning a mixture of hardwoods and softwoods for the best fire - one that is easily ignited and long-lasting.

Kelvin Bryant, the running back for the Redskins, was released from Arlington Hospital in Washington and was listed as probable for Sunday's wild-card playoff game against the Rams. Bryant's release came two days after he had been admitted for tests when blood was discovered in his urine.
A police officer outside the chained doors of the Communist Party headquarters in Shanghai.

A rare combination of foggy weather, dirt and the residue of air pollution caused the power failure that left 200,000 residents without electricity for up to 12 hours Tuesday, officials explained today. The power failure, which began about 4:30 A.M., darkened about nine square miles on the city's North Side, closing major downtown office buildings, businesses and hotels.

MOST people would like noise inside the home held to a reasonable level, but opinions differ as to what that means. What is simply loud music to one listener may be an intolerable racket to someone in an adjoining room or apartment. The problem of noise pollution has been heightened by the increasing number of television sets, stereos, radios and other audible appliances in homes and apartments. Many homes are more compact and better insulated than ever before, so internal noises are more confined and often exaggerated.

FRANK NORRIS: Novels and Essays. Edited by Donald Pizer. 1,232 pages. Library of America. $27.50. There is a fairly straight line in the American naturalistic novel from Frank Norris to Theodore Dreiser to John Steinbeck. Some of the themes they tackled through their characters first appeared in nonfiction form at the turn of the century, when the muckraking magazine journalists examined the excesses of various industries, from the stockyards to the oilfields. Looking at the popular books published today, it's hard to imagine that powerful works of fiction and fact that exposed unsafe conditions in the mines or the travails of migratory workers once led to legislative changes. Few modern novelists grapple with such issues affecting everyday lives in the manner of the influential naturalists; when they sometimes attempt to do so, critics with narrow historical vision reproach these authors (or dramatists or scenarists) and brand their work agitprop. One need hardly add: how shortsighted and discouraging to present-day writers who have something significant to say.

Israeli troops supported by attack helicopters today struck guerrilla installations two miles north of an Israeli-designated security zone in southern Lebanon, the army announced. It was the first time in 10 months that the army announced it had carried out a ground operation beyond the buffer zone.

One victim in the racial attack last week in Howard Beach, Queens, has refused a subpoena from the Queens District Attorney, according to law-enforcement officials, who said the case could fall apart without him. The victim, Cedric Sandiford of Brooklyn, also failed to appear at the 106th precinct in Ozone Park, Queens, on Monday to view a lineup. Officials said his absence contributed to the release of eight of the teen-agers who had been questioned in the attack. The purpose of the subpoena, according to aides of District Attorney John J. Santucci, was to get Mr. Sandiford to review the case with prosecutors before a preliminary hearing Monday for three white teen-agers who are charged with second-degree murder in the attack. The three, all of Queens, are Jon L. Lester, 17 years old, of 81-17 149th Avenue, Ozone Park, and Scott Kern, 17, of 87-14 158th Avenue, and Jason Ladone, 16, of 161-23 89th Street, both of Howard Beach.

Stock prices rose yesterday but trading slowed as investors seemed to care more about the Christmas holiday than the market. Attendance at the major brokerage houses was light, and it will probably be the same tomorrow, as many on Wall Street stretch the one-day Thursday break into a longer vacation. The Dow Jones industrial average, which fell because of tax-related selling on Tuesday, gained 12.51 points yesterday, to finish at 1,926.88.

Joe Cirella, the Devils' 23-year-old defenseman, felt some pain after he was hit by a puck on the side of his right foot early in the first period in Tuesday night's 8-5 loss to the Rangers. He ignored the pain and played the entire game, not missing a single shift.

Japan's Finance Ministry announced today that it would provide two loans to the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank totaling $6.2 billion, and said the loans would be offered with no strings attached. Fumiya Iwasaki, the deputy director general of the ministry's international finance bureau, said the loans would be used to aid developing nations and debtor countries that want to rebuild their economies. With the announcement, Japan hoped to ward off further criticism that it has been stingy with aid for developing nations, despite its huge trade surplus - which is estimated to exceed $94 billion next spring. When Japan has given aid in the past, critics have charged, it has attached conditions that have meant, in practice, that countries receiving the aid had to buy Japanese products or offer contracts to Japanese companies. 6 Percent Average Interest Japan is lending $3.6 billion to the International Monetary Fund over a four-year period beginning in June 1987. The loan will be used within developing nations and as a reserve fund for the I.M.F. The expected average interest rate on these loans, Mr. Iwasaki said, will be about 6 percent. Japan will also lend an additional $2.6 billion over a three-year period to the International Development Association, an arm of the World Bank that lends money without conditions.

The New York Medical College in Valhalla received a $5.5 million Christmas gift from the Starrett Housing Corporation today in the form of a campus apartment complex for 200 students. The apartments were built in the early 1970's under the auspices of the Urban Development Corporation on 8.7 acres of land donated by the county. In announcing the gift, the president of the college, John J. Connolly, said, ''We were talking with Starrett, which was exploring the idea of selling the complex, when we suggested they donate it.''

Senator Paula Hawkins, Republican of Florida, was defeated for re-election last month, but she is certain to be heard from again on a subject that has been one of her principal concerns: drug abuse. Mrs. Hawkins, who in her tenure founded the Senate Drug Enforcement Caucus, has been chosen by Bob Dole, the Senate Republican leader, as the first appointee to the board of directors of a National Trust for Drug Free Youth, which was established by Congress in the Drug Act of 1986.

Jose Torres, chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission, is no stranger to boxing politics. Torres is under attack for various decisions he has made in recent weeks in response to controversies arising from the World Boxing Association heavyweight match in which James (Bonecrusher) Smith won the title from Tim Witherspoon on Dec. 12. As a professional fighter from 1958 to 1969, Torres had his share of problems from the politics that have undercut the sport in virtually every era. Torres, who fought first as a middleweight and later as a light heavyweight, was 26-0-1 in his first five years as a pro. Yet his way to a title shot was blocked because the fighter's manager, Cus D'Amato - the same man who guided Floyd Patterson and later Mike Tyson - was often at odds with the boxing establishment, including the International Boxing Club, an organization that eventually was declared in violation of antitrust law.

Five Mississippi mayors have complained about a remark Mayor Koch made after the death last weekend of a black man in Howard Beach, Queens, after a racial assault. One of the mayors used an ethnic slur against Mr. Koch, who in turn wrote him a letter saying he would ''turn the other cheek.'' After the black man, Michael Griffith, died after what prosecutors have called a racial attack, Mr. Koch said in nationally televised interviews, ''I'd expect this kind of thing to happen in the deep South.''

Debt * Moscow Narodny Bank Ltd. is offering through its Singapore branch, Kansallis International Bank (Asia-Pacific) Ltd., $30 million of five-year floating-rate certificates of deposit. Interest is set at one-tenth of a percentage point more than the six-month Singapore interbank offered rate. Common Stock * Ciatti's Inc. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for 800,000 units, each unit consisting of one share of common stock and one common stock purchase warrant, through Wessels, Arnold & Henderson. * Lowrance Electronics Inc. is making an initial offering of 800,000 common shares at $8 a share through Eppler, Guerin & Turner Inc. Ratings * Control Data Corp.'s senior debt rating was raised to BB- from B+ by S.& P.

A NEW LOOK Isaiah Sheffer has, demonstrably, been taken with ''The Rise of David Levinsky,'' the story of a Talmudic student, a young immigrant and sweatshop worker, who finds success along a road paved with cynicism and exploitation. ''The Rise'' was originally a book written in 1917, in English, by Abraham Cahan, an immigrant newspaperman who made The Jewish Daily Forward the leading Yiddish periodical. Mr. Sheffer translated the Levinsky story into a theatrical musical, with Bobby Paul writing the music, and they finished in 1975. A year later, translated into Yiddish by Zvi Scooler, it made a successful appearance with the Folksbiene Theater. In 1983, it was even more successful in its native tongue, English, in a lively production by the American Jewish Theater at the 92nd Street Y. The authors did further work on the piece, and it was presented last April at the George Street Theater. Now, tonight at 8, in its latest revision, ''The Rise of David Levinsky'' starts performances as an Off Broadway presentation at the John Houseman Theater, 450 West 42d Street.

The night is cold, but who can drag himself back to life-size reality from the line in front of Lord & Taylor's Christmas windows? There, animated dolls in period costumes that reflect a century and more of New York's past rehearse over and over the seasonal repertoire. Father holds a ladder, having affixed the star atop the tree. Mother awaits her guests in her finest ball gown. Norah, the maid, touches up with a vacuum cleaner while the two youngest play their own game on the wrought-iron balustrade. Love fills each storied room; peace suffuses the imaginary city surrounding them.

Gustatory notes from all over: The French Embassy reports in its newsletter that the Prix Veuve Cliquot has been awarded to the proprietors or chefs of six restaurants in the United States for being ''ambassadors of French gastronomy abroad'' and that two of them are in Washington, which is certainly good news for the hungry envoys at the embassy. The winners presumably sell lots of the bubbly from the champagne company whose name the award carries.

A deputy sheriff's pistol accidentally fired and wounded a volunteer Santa Claus today at the state penitentiary, the authorities said. The deputy, Dickson Womack, who had had trouble earlier in the week when two inmates he and another deputy were escorting escaped, was unloading and storing a .25-caliber pistol before entering the penitentiary, the authorities said.

A gift of $10,000 to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund was given by Iphigene Ochs Sulzberger in memory of her father, Adolph S. Ochs, the publisher of The Times from 1896 to 1935. With the gift, Mrs. Sulzberger included a note telling how Mr. Ochs was inspired to start the Neediest Cases appeal. On Christmas Day 75 years ago, a young man approached Mr. Ochs on the street and asked him for money to find shelter for the night. Mr. Ochs gave the man his card and enough money for a few days' rest and to buy new clothing. The man was a Dane, a penniless orphan, who had been sent to the United States by a friend to get a new start.

Crises of confidence in government and race relations were on the minds of several of the city's spiritual leaders yesterday as they prepared what they would say today when their parishioners gathered to celebrate Christmas. But others, as they chose their words, tended toward traditional reaffirmations of the message of the day - hope, new life and the possibility of peace. The Episcopal Bishop of New York, Paul Moore Jr., was not without hope in the sermon he prepared for delivery at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. If anything, he said, he wanted to call forth the light of truth in speaking of ''a darkness on our land, a cloud of darkness over our leaders.''

The Reagan Administration has decided to offer Egypt, Israel and 36 other countries the opportunity to defer some interest payments on military loans, an action that could cost the Treasury about $3.5 billion in uncollected revenue in the next six years. The loss, as projected by budget officials, would be made up later, as loans come due and deferred payments are made. Officials explained the step as an effort to ease the debts of pro-Western countries that are considered important to United States security interests but too heavily burdened by economic problems to carry the full weight of their military expenditures. They include Spain, Greece, Thailand, Turkey and South Korea, among others.

The Merrill Lynch Investment Information Center, in the main concourse of Grand Central Terminal, is closing after providing market quotations and advice to commuters for more than 20 years. The large, free-standing booth attracted as many as 3,000 people a day during the hectic market years of the 1960's as they lined up to punch out symbols on stock-quotation machines. The use has trailed off, but up to 2,000 visitors came in daily this year.

The Rev. Robert West has a special plea for families in his flock this holiday season.
