He wants them to make room in their hearts, and their homes, for some of the abused and abandoned black children of Mississippi. ''I want my families, some of them, at least, to become adoptive parents,'' says Mr. West. Mr. West, a Baptist preacher, is the spokesman for the Ministers for Adoption, a statewide group of black clergy.

G. Gordon Liddy should pay income taxes on $45,630 he received as a Nixon campaign official, a Federal appeals court ruled today. A three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, in a 2-to-1 decision upholding a United States Tax Court ruling, said Mr. Liddy failed to prove that he made no personal use of money he received from a campaign fund. Mr. Liddy, a former aide in the Nixon White House, was convicted of conspiracy, burglarly and wiretapping in the June 1972 break-in at the Democratic National Committee's offices in the Watergate complex, and served more than four years of a 20-year prison sentence. The burglary and the attempt to cover up White House involvement in it led to Mr. Nixon's resignation of the Presidency on Aug. 9, 1974.

Marquette Frye, whose scuffle with the police after a routine traffic incident on a muggy summer night in 1965 ignited the Watts riot, has died of pneumonia, a coroner's spokesman said today. Mr. Frye, who was 42 years old, died Saturday at his home in central Los Angeles, said Dean Gilmore, a deputy coroner.

The Boston Symphony Orchestra plans to buy about 100 acres of land near Tanglewood, its summer home, possibly to build a new concert hall, the president-elect of the orchestra's board said today. The president-elect, George H. Kitter, said the orchestra may develop the land, the price of which was not disclosed, for parking and a new concert hall.

Richard J. H. Johnston, a New York Times correspondent whose 41-year career included assignment to World War II battlefields and extensive service in the Far East, died yesterday at Winter Park (Fla.) Memorial Hospital after suffering a stroke about two weeks ago. Mr. Johnston was 76 years old and had moved from New Jersey to the Florida community after his retirement in 1975.

In the literary marketplace, the stock of the Romantic poets is steadily on the rise. The Shelleys, both Percy and, thanks to the feminists, Mary, are blue chips; Byron is holding steady; Keats, after fluctuating, is making a second comeback, and it is worth betting a few bob on Leigh Hunt, who first introduced Keats and Shelley at his house in Hampstead. Dr. Bruce Barker-Benfield, the librarian in charge of the voluminous Shelley papers at Oxford's Bodleian Library, said the other day: ''It seems that every English Department on your side of the Atlantic has a specialist in our Romantic poets. We do, too, but then there are fewer universities in England. Their literary era is very much alive with the younger generation on campus and also with readers on trains and in pubs.''

The Economy An immigrant surge in New York's Chinatown has lifted rents to the level of midtown Manhattan, making the commercial real estate in one dingy corner of the city among the most expensive in the nation. The demand for space is so strong, local real estate brokers say, that the operators of vegetable stalls near one bustling intersection pay more rent per square foot than the owners of Tiffany's on Fifth Avenue. [ Page 1. ] The Fed plans to decide in April whether to expand banks' role in underwriting securities. The question is whether banks should be permitted to underwrite commercial paper, mortgage-backed securities and municipal revenue bonds. [ 45. ]

An Italian magistrate formally opened a judicial inquiry today into allegations that an Israeli nuclear technician was abducted here and taken back to Israel to stand trial for treason and espionage. The announcement came as Israel was said to have asked the Government ''not to take into account'' an allegation by the technician, Mordecai Vanunu, that he had been kidnapped in Rome on Sept. 30, apparently after arriving here from London. Mr. Vanunu had written this information on the palm of one hand, and he flashed it to reporters as he was being taken to court in Jerusalem on Sunday.

International#2-11 The U.S. will offer to delay payment from 38 countries of interest on military loans, the Reagan Administration has decided. The action could cost $3.5 billion in uncollected revenue. Page 1 A French hostage was freed by his Shiiite Moslem kidnappers in Lebanon in a good-will Christmas gesture. Aurel Cornea, a soundman for a French television network, was kidnapped nearly 10 months ago. #1 The release of a French hostage in Beirut came several days after the arrest in a Paris suburb of six Arabs who sources say were Moslem fundamentalist opponents of the Syrian Government. #10 Iran mounted a major offensive against Iraq in the southern part of their war front, but Iraqi forces had ''wiped out'' the leading edge of the Iranian force and blunted the attack, Iraq reported. #8 $20 million intended for the contras, including $10 million from the Sultan of Brunei and $10 million from private donors, has been traced by the Reagan Administration, an Administration official said. #1 Andrei Sakharov praised efforts by Mikhail Gorbachev to change the Soviet system and to encourage public discussion. He said the new openness is important ''because openness has always been in short supply.'' #3 News Analysis: Moscow's release of Andrei D. Sakharov from his exile in Gorky appears to mark a potential turning point in the Government's tolerance of dissent, Russians and Western diplomats said. #3 The Pope can sound revolutionary in his advocacy for the poor, but he has also battled unceasingly against Marxist influences on Catholic theology and efforts to ''politicize'' the Gospel.

Reggie Jackson came home to the Oakland A's today. Jackson, a free agent, signed a one-year contract and rejoined the franchise he began his celebrated career with 19 years ago. ''I don't need any Christmas gifts, this is enough for me,'' the 40-year-old slugger said during a news conference as he received his green and gold A's cap and jersey No. 44.

Eight months after the Koch administration was required to give Governor Cuomo a plan for a ground transportation system to serve disabled residents, the city's consultant has not finished the plan, city officials say. Disputes with the consultant and additional work will delay the plan until February, and the system will not serve customers until next fall at the earliest, the officials added. In the meantime, the 125,000 New York City residents classified as ''transportation disabled'' will continue to use the informal network of private van and bus services available to them. Advocates have said repeatedly that these services cannot meet the needs of the disabled.

To the Editor: Responding to an editorial on the report ''The Status of Federalism in America,'' Gary L. McDowell, associate director of the Department of Justice's Office of Public Affairs, states (letter, Dec. 4), ''A once robust scheme of popular government has been allowed to decline into something approaching a tyranny of clerks and accountants.'' This attitude, pervasive in this Administration, reflects the depths to which it has fallen.

Iraq said today that Iran had mounted a major two-pronged offensive in the southern part of their war front, but that Iraqi forces had ''wiped out'' the leading edge of the Iranian force and blunted the attack. The state-run Baghdad radio and television interrupted regular programs shortly after midnight to alert the nation to an imminent announcement. Minutes later the radio, monitored in Bahrain, quoted a military spokesman as having said that the leading Iranian units had been ''wiped out with concentrated firepower'' by the defenders.

Albums of popular music lead two lives, especially for critics. Their first life comes when the album is listened to for the first few times. This is the period when the critic is working - a task that doesn't preclude pleasure, as some critic-critics presume, but working nonetheless - to form an initial opinion. Then the album enters a larval stage from which it may or may not emerge. If it does not, it dies - the record is dispensed with to make room for more records or the significant other's potted plant. Or it is neatly filed away, ready for reference but otherwise ignored. This state is known to Dracula fans as the ''undead.'' The record is still in the critic's possession, but it no longer does what records do for ordinary people, which is periodically to get played and provide pleasure.

Andrei D. Sakharov's homecoming this week appears to mark a potential turning point in the Soviet Government's tolerance of dissent, in the view of Western diplomats and Russians. At the same time, it has revealed a congruence of views between Dr. Sakharov and Mikhail S. Gorbachev on some issues that may help explain why the physicist's exile in Gorky was ended after seven years. Dr. Sakharov, who granted brief interviews to separate groups of Western news agency reporters today, told The Associated Press that he had ''great respect'' for the new Soviet leader. ''I find the new policy of openness in this country very important because openness has always been in short supply,'' Dr. Sakharov said of Mr. Gorbachev's efforts to foster more discussion of public issues.

The focal point of organized bridge in America is in Memphis, where the American Contract Bridge League conducts its business. As one might expect, the office is well provided with expert players who seldom have much opportunity to play. One of these is Richard Oshlag, who was the business manager of the monthly ''Bulletin,'' until he took to programming the league's computer.

''Religion is the sigh of the oppressed creature,'' wrote Karl Marx, ''the spirit of unspiritual conditions. It is the Opium des Volkes - the opiate of the people.'' Opium at that time in Germany was known mostly as a painkiller; Marx's point was that religion deceptively eased the painful symptoms of the exploitation of labor by capital. To bring on the revolution, religion's succor had to be removed, allowing the working class to suffer until the pain was intolerable; at that point, the permanent cure would come from Communism. Marx made that a top priority: ''the first requisite for the people's happiness is the abolition of religion.''

Amateur ski racing has traditionally brought winners simple gold, silver and bronze pins or flashy trophies to display in the family room. But the purity and innocence of amateur racing changed three years ago when Hunter Mountain, N.Y., started the Silver Series to mark the ski area's 25th anniversary. The winners of these races get flashy trophies, and all participants are eligible for prizes in drawings that follow the races. Racers also get a goodie bag with assorted trinkets for their $10 entry fee.

National civil rights leaders and other prominent blacks are citing the incident in the Howard Beach section of Queens as the latest in a growing list of incidents involving racial violence and intimidation not only against blacks, but also against members of other minorities. Many of these leaders in the past warned that unless efforts are undertaken to improve racial relations in the United States, worse incidents could occur. They have repeatedly criticized the Reagan Administration for what they view as its insensitive attitude toward minority groups - an attitude, they say, that has contributed to heightening tensions between blacks and whites in this country. Benjamin L. Hooks Jr., the executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, accused the Administration of building a climate that ''somehow blacks have been receiving preferential treatment.''

With his team beating the Chargers at halftime, but not looking very good doing it, Coach John Mackovic of the Kansas City Chiefs replaced his quarterback, Todd Blackledge. ''At that point, the coach's responsibility is to the entire team,'' Mackovic said today in a telephone news conference, reflecting on that move in the seventh game of the season. Mackovic inserted Bill Kenney, who became the quarterback to lead the Chiefs to their first playoff berth in 15 years.

The release of a French hostage in Beirut today followed by several days the arrest of six Arabs in a Paris suburb. Sources here say the Arabs were Moslem fundamentalist opponents of the Syrian Government of President Hafez al-Assad. Some sources here close to French intelligence said the arrests might have paved the way for the release of Aurel Cornea, 54 years old, a French television journalist, after 292 days of detention. Mr. Cornea was held by a group calling itself the Revolutionary Justice Organization, which French Government analysts believe to be close to Syria.

As Christmas began today, the bells of St. Peter's Basilica rang wildly at midnight, and Pope John Paul II celebrated an ancient liturgy for a congregation that extended electronically across 41 countries. Addressing the dignitaries and pilgrims gathered around him, as well as ''our brothers and sisters to whom this solemn rite is being transmitted by radio and television,'' the Pope said, ''The event of Bethlehem night unites us all.'' John Paul's global audience is at its peak with his Christmas midnight mass, which is broadcast more widely than any other papal event.

Finally, Naomi Miller says, she approached her Christmas shopping with something resembling relief. ''For the first time in his life, my son isn't screaming for something all his friends have that I can't find,'' she said earlier this week while waiting at the F.A.O. Schwarz cash register to buy some ''good old-fashioned toys'' - an Erector Set and a toy truck -which 5-year-old Andrew will find under the tree this morning. Santa's list was longer and more diverse this year, toy makers, retailers and shoppers say. Business was as good as ever, but no single hot toy, no unobtainable but have-to-have gift, sent frantic mothers and fathers scrambling from one emporium to another.

Chuck Foster says he's just trying to give Everyman the chance for a little recognition. He must be trying hard, because the truth is that he has built an entire career on that notion, organizing strange sporting events with big-time trappings for ''the masses, the un-jocks who aren't normally catered to.'' The 42-year-old Foster, who wears combat fatigues and enjoys zipping around southern California in a jeep fitted with emergency lights, started his career as an impresario of the slightly weird when he was an officer for the Sheriff's Department in Ventura, Calif. There he organized the Pig Bowl, a football game between policemen and prisoners that served as the model for ''The Longest Yard,'' the Burt Reynolds movie. In 1969, he promoted a motorcycle competition for riders who had never before won a race, and handed out trophies to more than 1,000 participants. Among the goofy games that followed were the U.S. Toobing Olympics, contested on a river by teams of 10 men and women in inner tubes, and the Natural Light Championship Salad Toss-Off.

A flood of immigrants from Hong Kong has pushed commercial rents in New York's Chinatown up to the levels of midtown, making the real estate in one untidy corner of Manhattan among the most expensive in the United States. The demand for space is so strong, local real estate brokers say, that the operators of vegetable stalls near the bustling intersection of Catherine and Division Streets pay more rent per square foot than the owners of Tiffany & Company at Fifth Avenue and 57th Street. City officials describe the frenzy in the Chinatown real estate market as ''hysteria.'' ''Everytime you turn around the prices have shot up again,'' said Michael Dirzulaitis, an assistant commissioner in the city's Division of Real Property, which has been involved in several development projects in Chinatown this year. ''It's hard to believe that there is enough money around to keep it going, but there is.''

Q.My kitchen counter top is covered with plastic laminate. The plastic on the top meets the plastic laminate along the edge in a neat angle, but this edge has developed very small chips and one or two small cracks. I fear a cloth may catch on a nick and then tear a larger piece of the plastic laminate. Is there a sealant to prevent this? A.This corner should have been beveled slightly to prevent the chipping. Sharp corners or edges can still be smoothed or beveled with a file, but stroke downward only and use a mill file (made for use on metal), not a rasp or coarse file.
A representative of the Savannah Airport police inspecting wreckage of a twin-engine aircraft that crashed near the airport. Five people were injured in the crash. (UPI)

The Republic New York Corporation, parent of the Republic National Bank, said yesterday that it would buy the Williamsburgh Savings Bank of Brooklyn. Republic is paying about $80 million for Williamsburgh, a mutually owned savings institution that now is ailing but that for years was one of New York City's most successful home lenders. It has $2.2 billion in assets. Completion of the takeover appears virtually assured. The boards of both organizations have given informal approval and regulators are likely to support the deal because of Williamsburgh's poor financial condition caused by high interest rates in the early part of the decade.

When the holiday season rolls around and talk of miracles is in the air, Mickey Lolich sometimes remembers a boy named Vince, and wonders what happened to him. In fact, the thought of Lolich was triggered by the arrival recently of the ballot for the Baseball Hall of Fame. One of the names on it for the third straight year - he has received only a modest number of votes in the past - is Mickey Lolich, who pitched for 16 years in the big leagues, mostly with the Detroit Tigers. Besides having won 25 games in one season, and having started, completed and won three games in the 1968 World Series - in the seventh game he defeated Bob Gibson and the Cardinals, 4-1, and was named the most valuable player in the Series -besides all that, Mickey Lolich stood out because, from the neck down, he looked like Santa Claus in a baseball uniform.

John W. Macy Jr., a former chairman of the United States Civil Service Commission and a career public servant for more than 30 years, died of a heart ailment Monday at his home in McLean, Va. He was 69 years old. Mr. Macy's career as a top official in Federal Government service spanned the administrations of five Presidents, starting with Dwight D. Eisenhower and ending with Jimmy Carter. In that period, the only Presidential Administration he did not serve was that of Gerald R. Ford.

President Corazon C. Aquino, in a Christmas Eve address to a nation at peace for the first time in nearly 18 years, called for support in her efforts to settle two rebellions left over from the Marcos era. Last month her Government signed a cease-fire with Communist rebels, who started their insurgency in 1969, and she said today that it was preparing for talks next month to end a 14-year-old Moslem revolt. Mrs. Aquino directed her Christmas message to all ''those who have not yet joined; those who harbor anger and hate; those who refuse to have hope in what we offer; those who remain indifferent and cynical of all our efforts.''

A few days after arriving here last week on a record-setting pace in the single-handed race around the world, Philippe Jeantot made a discovery that turned him ashen. A local yard pulled Jeantot's 60-foot aluminum sailboat, Credit Agricole, out of the water for repairs. The boat had been leaking during the last two weeks of his 6,900-mile voyage from Cape Town. The water had come through the floorboards in volumes -close to 100 gallons an hour. Jeantot knew he had had a problem. But when he saw the underside of his boat, he found out how serious it was.

Floyd Carter comforting relatives Tuesday night outside the wreckage of the Mount Canaan Missionary Baptist Church east of Ocala, Fla. From the left are Elizabeth Davis, Mr. Carter's aunt, and her daughters, Gwendolyn Davis and Junie Davis. The church was destroyed by a tornado that whipped through the area. (AP)

''How do I feel?'' repeated the old man, as the trans-Atlantic telephone line crackled, ''Well, I certainly don't feel like 75. I feel like 17. I do really.'' ''Well, you certainly sound fine,'' said Linda Opper, who has carried on a special telephone relationship with the old man for nine years now. ''Happy Birthday, dear friend.''

In a time of so much violence and injustice, the world has one piece of transformingly good news. The release of Andrei Sakharov from his enforced exile in Gorky is a beacon of hope for his people and the rest of us. It is, first of all, a testament to the human spirit. One man, no longer young, and his frail wife stood up to the power of the authoritarian state. Removed from their home and friends, kept in degrading isolation for seven years, harassed and humiliated, they held to their principles.

Today, when most Americans are probably preparing for a Christmas meal of turkey or perhaps a roast goose, a group of vegetarians will be singing Christmas carols and making gifts of exotic fruits and nuts to the primates in the National Zoo.
