''How do I feel?'' repeated the old man, as the trans-Atlantic telephone line crackled, ''Well, I certainly don't feel like 75. I feel like 17. I do really.'' ''Well, you certainly sound fine,'' said Linda Opper, who has carried on a special telephone relationship with the old man for nine years now. ''Happy Birthday, dear friend.''

Alaska has flown 59 of its most dangerous convicts to Minnesota under an agreement in which that state will keep them for a year, when construction of Alaska's first maximum-security prison is expected to be completed, Alaska corrections officials said Tuesday. Art Schmidt, Deputy Corrections Commissioner of Alaska, said the flight on Saturday from Anchorage to Minneapolis-St. Paul was the largest single movement of prisoners Alaska had conducted.

A COUPLE of times a year, often before the start of the heating and air-conditioning seasons, residential customers of utilities receive bill inserts urging them to schedule a home-energy audit. These notices are often ignored because many people are unaware of what an audit entails or why they might need one. According to Federal and state energy officials and utility representatives, it is never too late to take advantage of the service, which they say can shave hundreds of dollars a year off energy bills. ''The point of the energy audit is to give people a sense of what they can do and how to gain energy benefits,'' said Sam Swanson, an expert in energy conservation and environmental analysis for New York State. ''There are some real opportunities for people to save a lot of money.''

The disclosures of arms shipments to Iran and the diversion of funds to the Nicaraguan rebels have created a fundamental problem for Vice President Bush in his effort to succeed President Reagan, aides and other supporters said today. The problem, they said, is that much of his strategy has turned on his loyalty to Mr. Reagan, which advisers have said is important among the conservatives who will be influential in nominating the Republican Presidential candidate. The disclosures have threatened to undermine that strategy, some of his advisers acknowledged, and have caused a precipitate drop in his poll ratings among Republicans. The aides, who discussed the situation on the condition that their names be withheld, said Mr. Bush, out of loyalty to Mr. Reagan, has placed himself in a precarious situation by rejecting any suggestion that he distance himself from the President over the Iran affair. In effect, the aides said, he is gambling that the public clamor will subside.

If Rube Goldberg had invented an energy policy, it might have looked like fuel economy standards for automobiles. These are so clumsy that most economists and other believers in free-market incentives cheered this week when the Reagan Administration proposed to abolish them after 11 years. But before this unloved regulatory program is dumped by acclaim, it's worth asking what Washington would substitute as a defense against OPEC extortion. There's one thing worse than a fuel economy policy: no policy at all, and so far, that's all the Administration offers.

Fewer than half of the first graduates of the City University of New York Law School who took the bar exam in July passed it. The dean of the three-year-old school said, however, it was a good showing for a new program. Of the 5,317 people in the state who took the exam, two-thirds passed. The figure was higher, at 73 percent, for those taking the exam for the first time - the category into which the City University students fell.

In a time of so much violence and injustice, the world has one piece of transformingly good news. The release of Andrei Sakharov from his enforced exile in Gorky is a beacon of hope for his people and the rest of us. It is, first of all, a testament to the human spirit. One man, no longer young, and his frail wife stood up to the power of the authoritarian state. Removed from their home and friends, kept in degrading isolation for seven years, harassed and humiliated, they held to their principles.

Today, when most Americans are probably preparing for a Christmas meal of turkey or perhaps a roast goose, a group of vegetarians will be singing Christmas carols and making gifts of exotic fruits and nuts to the primates in the National Zoo.

''The Entrepreneurs'' has a point of view: risk-taking capitalists contribute to the general well-being. The third episode in the six-part monthly series, on Channel 5 Sunday night at 9, looks at the people who have fostered transportation.

The drug rehabilitation program Synanon has dropped its libel and defamation suit against the local newspaper, The Point Reyes Light, and has agreed to pay two journalists $100,000, the paper says. Synanon sued the paper's publisher, David Mitchell, and his former wife, Cathy, in 1979 after the rural weekly won the Pulitzer Prize for a series of articles that said Synanon had turned into a cult.

''I'm glad to see you,'' Aurel Cornea told the Prime Minister of France at Orly Airport today. ''I don't believe it. I feel as if I'm dreaming.'' After 292 days as a hostage in Lebanon, Mr. Cornea was home for Christmas.
A group of Washingtonians is apparently hoping to challenge New York's primacy in the area of St. Patrick's Day parades.

Japanese, as a rule, do not fall down on the job. After work, though, it's another story. Every evening, as faithfully as a bartender listening to a woeful tale, Tokyo's gray-flanneled samurai cluster in bars and pubs to drink themselves into states of near collapse. Late at night, the ones who have not entered the primary stages of paralysis try uncertainly to make their way home. Commuter trains at about 11 P.M. are filled with businessmen in tan raincoats literally falling all over each other.

When James (Bonecrusher) Smith landed the World Boxing Association's heavyweight title by knocking out Tim Witherspoon at Madison Square Garden two weeks ago, he also won a March 7 shot at Mike Tyson for a purse of at least $1 million. That, anyway, is what Smith and most everybody else thought. Now comes another reminder that in the fight game, so little is ever what it first seems to be.

Many an ad agency executive, when welcoming a new low-billing industrial client, has harbored the generally futile hope that somehow, someday it would explode into a free-spending consumer account. It has happened in Boston.

The Jaycees' sign on the outskirts proclaims ''the good life is here to stay'' in this town where hundreds of meatpackers went through a second straight Christmas without work, the bitter aftermath of the long Hormel strike. ''It's hurt, definitely,'' said Robert Foss, a 71-year-old resident of this southern Minnesota town since 1954. ''It's split families, it's split friends,'' I don't think I'll live long enough to see this settled.'' In September, union members at Geo. A. Hormel & Company's flagship plant in this town of 22,000 people approved a contract ending the strike that began Aug. 17, 1985. But they got no guarantee of recalls for those who refused to cross the picket line.

WHEN ''The Morning After'' opened yesterday, audiences saw Jane Fonda, whose image has been successfully transformed from political activist to physical-fitness specialist, playing a down-on-her-luck has-been of an actress who is also a serious alcoholic. How important is an audience's image of an actress to its acceptance of her in a role? Will viewers believe that a woman with the back muscles of Jane Fonda has lived a profligate and degenerate life? Sidney Lumet, the film's director, said he never considered Ms. Fonda's image a problem. ''In this instance,'' he said, ''I wasn't even aware of it. I'm not really aware of that whole world.'' He pointed out that the film's first scene was of a television program showing women pumping iron. ''Jane said we can't use that, people will think it's a commercial,'' he said. ''But I didn't agree with her.'' ''Basically,'' Mr. Lumet said, ''I think that if an actress or actor begins with a strong persona but is a very good performer, which Jane is, as soon as the acting begins that persona disappears in an instant.'' The film, he said, is one that Ms. Fonda developed and sent to him for the first time about four years ago. ''There was something in it that really interested her,'' he said, ''and we wanted to work together for a long time.''

THE weekend between Christmas and New Year's traditionally brings a lull in performing-arts schedules in New York, but not in the world of cabaret. Clubs around town are teeming with talent. Rising young stars like the singer Laurie Beechman and the comedian Bob Nelson refresh a genre that sometimes seems to languish on the brink of extinction. At the same time, persevering veterans like Anita Ellis and Jon Hendricks continue to define unshakeably high standards of excellence in a different mode of jazz singing. Laurie Beechman, who is currently starring on Broadway as Grizabella in the musical ''Cats,'' has been appearing off and on in New York clubs since she arrived here from Philadelphia in the mid-1970's. Her current appearance at the Ballroom, 253 West 28th Street, is the first local club date in four years by a singer who has steadily grown in power and command to become the best young emotive belter in the dramatic tradition of Judy Garland and Barbra Streisand.

The United States Ambassador to Costa Rica helped secure initial Costa Rican permission to build a secret airstrip for the Nicaraguan rebels early this year and was deeply involved in overseeing its use, according to a senior Government official in Central America. According to United States Government and Nicaraguan rebel officials, the Ambassador, Lewis A. Tambs, as well as other officials in the American Embassy in Costa Rica, maintained close contact with others involved in a so-called private supply network for the rebels that was set up by Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North of the White House National Security Council. The supply operation was established at a time when Congress had made it illegal to send military supplies to the rebels, known as contras, who are seeking the overthrow of the Nicaraguan Government. Ambassador Denies Report Early this month, asked about a published report linking him to secret arms shipments to the contras, Mr. Tambs denied that he had had anything to do with such an operation. But he declined a request for an interview for this article and efforts to reach him by telephone for comment were unsuccessful.

Agencies concerned with the homeless and the hungry have requested that $15 million raised last spring by the organization Hands Across America be spent immediately. ''We have no particular interest in getting the money released to us,'' said Robert Hayes, counsel for the National Coalition for the Homeless, a nonprofit group representing more than 4,000 shelters, soup kitchens and food banks.

To all the sparkle of the holiday season another light will be added tonight, as Jews begin the celebration of Hanukkah with the lighting of the first candle on the menorah. Probably the most visible of these symbols is the 32-foot-tall candelabrum at Fifth Avenue and 59th Street, at Grand Army Plaza. The Lubavitch Hasidim who put up the menorah say that it is the biggest one in the world. The group has been lighting a giant menorah on the spot since 1977, but this year they are using a new menorah designed by the Israeli artist Yakov Agam.

To the Editor: The system of criminal sentencing that has prevailed in the United States for most of this century has been called, in the recent past, lawless, inhumane and a national disgrace. After many years of trying to come to terms with the problems that produce such reactions, states across the country and Congress passed laws to move from a system of indeterminate, often unpredictable sentencing to one with more coherence and predictability. The effort at the national level is in the hands of the Sentencing Commission, charged by Congress with designing and implementing the new sentencing system. The work of that commission is at a critical stage, when clarity and public understanding are most important. I'm afraid, however, that David Anderson's Editorial Notebook may have caused confusion and incited needless disquiet.

Casino operators here are eager to ease some of the strict anticorruption rules governing their industry, and the growing political awareness of their 38,000 workers may help them press the point. Already, elected officials from the area are trying to alert the rest of the state to the emerging political realities of a gambling capital with a number of strong grievances against state regulators. The casino workers' political strength will be tested in coming months as a number of bills to lighten the state's regulatory hand are introduced in the Legislature. ''A lot of people go to Atlantic City for the day and then go home, and they don't understand the politics of the situation down there anymore,'' said Assemblyman Rodney P. Frelinghysen, Republican of Morristown. ''But the closer you live to Atlantic City, the more you feel that the casino workers are being treated like second-class citizens.''

A lawyer for a victim in the racial attack in Howard Beach, Queens, last week said yesterday that his client wanted to cooperate with prosecutors but was not yet well enough to do so. The lawyer, Alton H. Maddox Jr., also said he telephoned the Queens District Attorney, John J. Santucci, on Wednesday to explain that the victim's injuries had kept him from viewing a police lineup earlier in the week and would prevent him from meeting with prosecutors in the next few days. Mr. Maddox said Mr. Santucci did not return his calls. Mr. Santucci said that he had called back, but that Mr. Maddox had not been in his office. Mr. Santucci also said the lawyer had not responded to repeated messages left with Mr. Maddox's secretary. On Wednesday, the day the calls were being made, Mr. Santucci asserted that second-degree-murder charges against three white teen-agers would be ''tough to prosecute'' without the cooperation of the victim, Cedric Sandiford, 36 years old, of Brooklyn.

When Madison Avenue decided last spring that bigger was better for advertising agencies as well as for products, it took a couple of relative newcomers to put together the biggest of them all. After only four years in the United States, the London-based Saatchi & Saatchi Company became the world's largest agency by purchasing Ted Bates Worldwide - the nation's third-ranked advertising firm - for $450 million.
A man died early today of injuries suffered in a gasoline storage tank explosion and fire, the second person killed by the blaze, officials said.
Harvey Stephens, a longtime character actor who appeared on Broadway and in films, died Monday at the Saddleback Medical Center. He was 85 years old.

Aerospace industry groups have expressed sharp disapproval of new Pentagon rules meant to lower the profits of companies doing business with the Defense Department. The new profit policy ''is completely out of step with the realities and the economics of the defense industry,'' officials of five industry groups said in comments filed Wednesday in response to the Pentagon rules. The rules, which were developed over two years and published Dec. 1, alter in several ways the complex formulas used by the military to set profit objectives in negotiating contracts that are awarded noncompetitively. Competitive contracts are handled differently, on the premise that prices and profits will be kept low because of competition.

I am neither a writer nor a historian but a victim of torture who was forced to leave his home. My home is Afghanistan, and I left on Dec. 27, 1979, when the Soviet Union invaded. That evening, the blue skies of Kabul were blackened by bombs and missiles. Nine hours later, the fighting died down and the leader of the new regime, Babrak Karmal, addressed our nation. Two days later, the K.G.B. began establishing secret prisons throughout the country. President Karmal declared that all political prisoners would be freed. But even as a Soviet camera crew filmed the release of inmates from Pul-e Charkhi prison, the largest in the country, a new generation of political prisoners were escorted in through a different door.

The defeat suffered by the chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board on his proposal to extend a limit on real estate investments by thrift institutions signaled a major shift in the balance of power at the agency, industry experts said this week. The inability of Edwin J. Gray to muster support from the agency's two other members, both Reagan appointees, may have even neutralized his tough regulatory stance on the industry's widespread problems, some experts said. In the agency's packed boardroom last Thursday, Mr. Gray had argued for a two-year extension of a measure limiting direct investment in real estate ventures to 10 percent of a thrift institution's assets. But after two hours of debate, he lamented: ''Ladies and gentlemen, there has been some consultation as to where the various board members are coming out. I have indications that the other two members do not want to extend it. So it seems somewhat ridiculous for me to make that motion.''

A sharp debate has developed among Government experts over a tentative plan by the Reagan Administration to improve the monitoring of Soviet compliance with two 1970's nuclear test-limitation treaties, according to classified Government documents and Administration officials. The treaties limit the size of underground nuclear explosions. Experts from the Central Intelligence Agency have complained that the plan is ''deficient.'' Energy Department officials have also criticized the plan because they believe it would allow Soviet experts to gather sensitive intelligence information.

A Libyan diplomat based in Syria was killed today in a Syrian-controlled section of eastern Lebanon by gunmen who opened fire on his embassy car, the police reported. Police identified the slain envoy as Mosbah Mohammed Gharibi, financial attache of the Libyan Embassy in Damascus.

Despite strong domestic and overseas pressure to stimulate the economy, the Japanese Government today approved a preliminary budget that provides for the smallest spending increase in three decades. The budget calls for total spending of $336 billion for the 1987 fiscal year, which begins next April 1. This amount represents virtually no growth from this year's budget - far less than one-tenth of 1 percent. For public works, an important category affecting domestic demand, the national Government would actually spend 2 percent less next year.

A rare, 1872 enlisted man's dress blouse traced to an Ohio man who rode with Lieut. Col. George Armstrong Custer has been acquired by the Custer Battlefield National Monument. The blouse belonged to Pvt. William C. Williams, who served with a company that split off from the Seventh Cavalry just before Custer led 225 men to their deaths at the Battle of the Little Bighorn on June 25, 1876, said Neil Mangum, the battlefield's historian. While Custer and the troopers under his command were being annihilated by a combined force of Sioux, Cheyenne and Arapahoe Indians, Williams and the rest of the Seventh Cavalry, led by Maj. Marcus Reno and Capt. Frederick Benteen, were pinned down five miles south of here by another large force of Indians.

THE long countdown to New Year's Eve has begun. This grand ritual of resolutions and remembrance is as much a state of mind as a place on the calendar. Dangling between old and new, it is also a mini-season for celebration, as champagne corks pop, fireworks explode and reflection gives way to revelry. This year, New Year's Eve ''weekend'' embodies a crescendo of six days of festivities that culminates in that ultimate witching hour: midnight, Dec. 31. In addition to the plethora of public celebrations in nightclubs, hotel ballrooms and restaurants, New York City offers a remarkable assortment of ways to enjoy a holiday period that embraces 6 of the 12 days of Christmas, Hanukkah, the African festival known as Kwanza and New Year's Eve itself. Music will resound from concert halls, churches, parks and even a barge in Brooklyn. Fireworks will bedazzle millions of bleary midnight eyes near the South Street Seaport and Central and Prospect Parks. Runners dressed in tuxedos and gowns will make champagne pit stops in Central Park, as a small army of readers in SoHo makes its way through the tongue-twisting cadences of Joyce's ''Finnegans Wake.''

David Steinberg, the comedian, has directed six TV commercials to promote the Jefferson-Pilot Life Insurance Company, which comes into being Jan. 1 as the Jefferson-Pilot Corporation of Winston-Salem, N.C., as a result of the merger of two of its 80-year-old subsidiaries. Despite the director, the commercials, which were written by Long, Haymes & Carr of Winston-Salem, are not funny, nor were they intended to be. But they seem effective.

HE is a ubiquitous and, at 6 feet 6 inches tall, a looming figure in the New York art world today. His frequent presence at blue-chip functions is no surprise, however, given his multiple roles as a private collector of 20th-century art, the founder of a major corporate art collection, and, for the past year, president of the Board of Trustees of the Museum of Modern Art. He is Donald B. Marron, and for a full-time job, he is chairman and chief executive officer of the Paine Webber Group Inc., one of the world's largest financial service and brokerage concerns. Now at the one-year mark in his post at the Modern, Mr. Marron spoke recently in his midtown office about his hopes for that museum, about his corporate collection and the business-art connection.

Israeli security forces uncovered a terrorist cell whose members are suspected in the stabbing deaths of two Israeli civilians in the Gaza Strip in September and October, the Israeli radio said today.

A self-ordained bishop convicted of controlling congregants in three states through beatings and sex must spend at least eight years in prison for what a judge called a barbaric crime. The Rev. Wilbert Thomas Sr., 55 years old, founder of the Christian Alliance Holiness Church in Trenton, Miami, and Akron, Ohio, was sentenced Wednesday to 20 years in prison.

As raiding and restructuring raised corporate dust during the year, many business people were thrust into the news. The European financier Sir James Goldsmith made a run at the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, and was met by a defensive restructuring by Robert E. Mercer, Goodyear's chairman. Sir James - Mr. Mercer would not use the ''Sir'' -eventually went away with a profit of $93 million on his stock.

President Reagan and his wife, Nancy, enjoyed a traditional Christmas in the White House today, with an exchange of gifts, a dinner for longtime friends and telephone calls to family members. Elaine Crispen, Mrs. Reagan's press secretary, said the First Lady, who received a spaniel puppy from her husband last year, got a red robe this Christmas. Mrs. Reagan gave the President a horse blanket that will be shipped to their mountaintop ranch in California.

Allegations that shoddy workmanship and drug and alcohol abuse were jeopardizing safety at the Seabrook nuclear power plant either brought remedies or were unsubstantiated, a Federal report said. But a member of the House involved in a separate inquiry condemned the report, by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, saying the findings made the agency appear to swallow the plant management's story ''hook, line and sinker.'' The report, released Wednesday, followed a commission investigation of charges by the Massachusetts-based Employees Legal Project of drug or alcohol abuse among some construction workers at the $5 billion plant, which is completed but not yet operating. The group submitted a list of 61 possible safety problems.

Vietnamese Roman Catholics, embroiled in a bitter dispute with the Diocese of San Jose over demands for their own parish, rented a high school to ''pray for reconciliation'' with church officials on Christmas Eve. The service came two and a half weeks after the diocese suspended masses in the Vietnamese language when protests and scuffles broke out at two churches. Bai An Tran, a leader of the dissidents in the nation's third largest Vietnamese community, said his group invited Bishop Pierre DuMaine and other church officials to the service. Bishop DuMaine, who opposes the creation of a separate Vietnamese parish because, he says, the community is not independent enough and cannot afford to maintain its own church, declined to attend the service.

IN ''Therese,'' the French director Alain Cavalier's detached, elegantly photographed depiction of the life and death of a young Carmelite nun in the late 19th century, Catherine Mouchet radiates a striking mixture of beatified radiance, obsession and stubbornness. Throughout the movie, which was shot in a diorama rather than on a conventional set, the Carmelite nuns emerge before the camera and recede like translucent apparitions in a 19th-century French painting. Perhaps the one image from the picture that sticks the most is Ms. Mouchet's enigmatic gaze, avid with expectation at the beginning of the film, when she is a 15-year-old burning to become a saint, and anguished but still burning at the end of the movie, when she is near death from tuberculosis. In life, Ms. Mouchet is as much of an enigma as in the film. During a recent interview, she declined to talk about her personal life beyond the bare facts that she is 27 - three years older than Therese at the end of the movie - and Parisian. The director himself has said that Ms. Mouchet, whose performance in ''Therese'' has won critical acclaim, would not answer when he asked precise questions about her origins and religious orientation.

JOHN S. WILSON FIVE years ago Dorthaan Kirk, the widow of the versatile reed instrumentalist Rahsaan Roland Kirk, organized a quintet called the Vibration Society, the name of her husband's group, to carry on Mr. Kirk's music. Mrs. Kirk was not able to keep the group going then but she is now making a second effort to renew the Vibration Society, this time with a sextet under the joint leadership of the pianist Hilton Ruiz and the trombonist Steve Turre, both of whom played under Mr. Kirk. The group is playing at Carlos 1, on the Avenue of the Americas between Ninth and 10th Streets through Sunday.
The nation's stock and commodity exchanges, banks, Government offices and most businesses were closed yesterday in observance of Christmas.

Opportunities for pop-jazz aficionados to hear their favorite groups are not limited to just the weekend. A sampler of some of the notable acts appearing in clubs and halls in the New York area from Monday to New Year's Eve follows. Most of the groups appearing on Monday and Tuesday also have New Year's Eve shows at the same venues. Monday Art Blakey and the Jazz Messengers, Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, between Bleecker and Grove Streets (242-1785). The Messengers are going through another change in personnel that has marked their three successful decades. Now the group is Wallace Roney, trumpeter; Kenny Garrett, alto saxophonist; Donald Brown, pianist; Peter Washington, bassist, and Art Blakey, drummer, with additional guest horns on New Year's Eve. Shows Monday and Tuesday at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; $10 cover, $6 minimum. New Year's Eve, 9 P.M. to midnight; $35 cover, $35 minimum, or dinner and show, $99, with unlimited champagne. 1 to 4 A.M.; $25 cover, $15 minimum. Phyllis Hyman, Fat Tuesday's, 190 Third Avenue, at 17th Street (533-7902). Phyllis Hyman is a singer whose range goes from sultry funk to high-stepping scat and even whistles. Monday and Tuesday at 8 and 10 P.M.; cover $25, minimum $10. New Year's Eve, 9 P.M. show, including dinner and one bottle of champagne a couple, $65 a person; at 11 P.M., dinner, show and champagne, $95 a person.

Democrats and Republicans have good reason for sitting on different sides of the aisle in the Senate chamber. Political considerations so infect every decision on Capitol Hill that it takes an unusual issue to bring lawmakers together on a genuinely bipartisan basis. But one topic that has the power to bridge the gap of party rivalry is arms control. And for more than three years now, two Republican Senators and two Democrats have been working closely together on a single goal: pressuring the Administration into adhering to the strategic arms limitation treaty signed with the Soviets in the 1970's. Although the treaty was never approved by the Senate, Washington and Moscow agreed to abide by its key provisions anyway.

The Reagan Administration says it will propose new regulations early next year to crack down on many personal long-distance calls made by Federal workers at Government expense. At the same time, the draft regulations would redefine what constitutes abuse so that ''reasonable'' but unofficial calls would be permitted, according to Joseph M. Slye, a spokesman for the General Services Administraton. The Office of Personnel Management, in a study requested by the President's Council on Integrity and Efficiency, found recently that 36.5 percent of long-distance calls were not for official Government business.
Jack Curran of Archbishop Molloy in Queens now has more victories than any other head basketball coach in New York state high school history.

The 15,811 fans drawn to Madison Square Garden yesterday were no doubt expecting and even rooting for a Michael Jordan spectacular. What they got was an awesome 28-point, 17-rebound performance from Patrick Ewing that included the winning basket in an 86-85 Knick victory over the Chicago Bulls. With six seconds remaining and the Bulls leading, 85-84, thanks to a 3-point play by Dave Corzine, the Knicks called time and designed a play for Trent Tucker to take the final shot behind a Ewing pick. Tucker Misses Louis Orr passed the ball inbounds to Tucker, who planted his feet just inside the 3-point shootng area and got off a shot within 2 seconds. The ball hit the left side of the rim but took a long bounce toward the middle, skimmed off Jordan's fingers and headed toward Ewing, who was wide open. Corzine, his man, had left him and jumped out to contest Tucker's shot.

THE year 1987 will confront the United States, Japan, West Germany and the other industrial countries with the necessity of finding solutions to the most dangerous set of problems that the world economy has faced since the end of the 1920's. Worries have intensified among economists and business executives that another breakdown in the system could happen. Yet, paradoxically, the securities markets remain strong, reflecting the widespread belief of investors that solutions can and will be found to the dangers that lie ahead. But skeptics may retort that stock market confidence also reached a high in 1929, just before the crash.

Mayor Koch and landlords continue to joust over a new law that would force some owners to reveal how much money they earn on their buildings. Mayor Koch signed Local Law 63 on July 8, after a frantic weekend of budget balancing. The law required some landlords to file annual statements of their properties' incomes and expenses. The city planned to use the information to make more accurate property assessments and, it was hoped, generate an extra $10 million in taxes to meet the budget next year.

To the Editor: Raoul Felder's description of inefficient matrimonial courts (Op-Ed, Nov. 22) extends to Suffolk County, where the Equitable Distribution Law and the new one judge, one case system have resulted by the end of this year in virtual elimination of such rights as trials and temporary support orders. Instead, the pretrial conference dominates all.
Homeless in Kansas City Despite data in a national report, local leaders say the growing number of homeless families is a grim problem.

The migration of illegal aliens across the border with Mexico usually reverses itself this time of year, with people sneaking out of the United States to spend the holidays with relatives to the south. United States Border Patrol agents in Texas, New Mexico, Arizona and California will not even attempt to guess how many undocumented workers travel to Mexico and Central America this time of year. But those who are familiar with the situation say changes under the new immigration law seem to have sharply curtailed the exodus this year.

Although it's not a national holiday, so many people take off the week between Christmas and New Year's that Detroit can't run its assembly lines, stockbrokers can't reach their clients on the telephone, advertising agencies close their offices, and hospitals reject elective surgery. General Motors sends half a million people home during the week between Christmas and New Year's. Perry Ellis, like other companies in the fashion industry, takes off this week, which falls coveniently between the completion of its spring lines and the beginning of its summer collections. And Congress prolongs its recess until the first week in January.

Frank Lorenzo might have finished 9,024th in the New York Marathon this year, but no one in the airline industry came close to him in the running for the most ambitious, colorful and controversial top executive. Mr. Lorenzo, 46 years old, continued his acquisitive ways in the deregulated industry, and before the year was over he put Eastern Air Lines Inc. in his pocket in a $676 million deal. He is also buying People Express to put together the nation's largest aviation empire.

The capital is entering its budget season, and among the omens and portents of the Federal Government's fiscal future is this: The cover of the budget document, this year, will be maroon. In recent years, it has alternated between blue and gray. James C. Miller 3d, director of the Office of Management and Budget, suggested to reporters this week that the color had some symbolic value. Mr. Miller said maroon ''consists of the colors red and black'' and then added somewhat optimistically, ''This is a budget that is red but turning black.''

The Food and Drug Administration has rejected a petition by six Senators calling for the agency to regulate the reuse of kidney dialysis filters and conduct clinical studies to determine whether the growing practice poses health risks. The Commissioner of Food and Drugs, Dr. Frank Young, ruled that applying the agency's regulations for good manufacturing practices to the nation's 1,400 dialysis clinics ''would set a major precedent in terms of F.D.A. regulating medical practice,'' according to an agency report to field offices released Wednesday. The petition filed last spring by Senator John Heinz, Republican of Pennsylvania, chairman of the Senate Special Committee on Aging, and five other panel members, asked the drug agency to promulgate new regulations for the reuse of kidney dialysis filters and tubes. It also called for controlled clinical studies to determine if reuse was a safe practice. The other signatories were Senators Larry Pressler, Republican of South Dakota; John Glenn, Democrat of Ohio; Lawton Chiles, Democrat of Florida; Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, and Bennett J. Johnston, Democrat of Louisiana.

After just three months at the helm of CBS Inc., Laurence A. Tisch has made change commonplace at the once-unshakable network. Cost cutting has become routine, layoffs are the norm and entire departments have been eliminated. Mr. Tisch, 63 years old, and his brother Preston Robert Tisch, 60, who is the United States Postmaster General, are major stockholders in the Loews Corporation, a diversified conglomerate that owns 24.9 percent of CBS shares. Laurence Tisch, along with the network's founder, William S. Paley, ousted Thomas H. Wyman as chairman and chief executive in September.

A memo book that Jennifer Levin kept in the kitchen of her family's SoHo home has become the center of a bitter, but subtle legal debate among prosecutors, defense attorneys and legal scholars. The dispute concerns whether the diary of Miss Levin, who was killed last August in Central Park, should be turned over for use in the defense of the man accused of murdering her, 20-year-old Robert E. Chambers Jr. His lawyer, Jack T. Litman, has argued that the diary is crucial to Mr. Chambers's defense because it contains the names of Miss Levin's previous sex partners and ''chronicles'' her sexual activity. Mr. Chambers has said he killed Miss Levin accidentally while the two were having sex in the park.

The United States cannot guarantee victory to the Afghan freedom fighters, but it can help deny victory to the Soviet Union. Washington must make Moscow want out. The key is to convince the Russians that the continuing costs of the war - military, political and economic - outweigh the potential gains. Only then will they seek a negotiated withdrawal. Moscow has steadily escalated its military activities, incurring mounting casualties and killing almost one million Afghans since Soviet tanks rolled into Kabul on Dec. 27, 1979. It has also made cosmetic changes in the Quisling Communist regime in Kabul, but it is no closer to winning today than it was in 1979. Far from giving up, however, the Russians are settling in for the long haul, threatening to defeat the resistance in a grinding war of attrition.

THE star of the evening was clearly Alexandra Danilova, the former prima ballerina of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo, whose memoirs, ''Choura,'' have just been published. That was the reason for Don Smith's Christmas party Tuesday evening on the Upper East Side, to which the entrepreneur invited 40 or so pals. But when your chums include the likes of Licia Albanese, Margaret Whiting, Julie Wilson, David Susskind, Taina Elg, Al Hirschfeld, Charles Strouse and Carmen, the model, even a prima ballerina is going to have a bit of competition. ''I'm late because I just came from seeing Dorothy Loudon in the hopsital where she had four wisdom teeth removed, and then I went to buy my turkey,'' said a breathless Lionel Larner. As an entrance line, that was hard to beat.

In this sprawling tundra community, large rusting shipping containers form ramshackle apartment complexes. The containers, 8-by-24-foot metal boxes that look like vans or trailers, were once used to barge freight into Bethel. Now they sit side by side atop 55-gallon drums in ramshackle clusters known as ''The Tundra Apartments'' and ''Two-Slough View.'' The boxes rent for $200 a month, and with affordable housing only a dream hereabouts, there are takers.

William J. Casey, Director of Central Intelligence, remains in stable condition at the Georgetown University Hospital, a hospital spokesman said today. Mr. Casey was operated on Dec. 18 for removal of a cancerous brain tumor. There were reports Wednesday that Mr. Casey was in a semicoma and that his doctors were uncertain he had regained motor functions. The reports were not confirmed by the hospital.

From the coastal road below Latakia, a four-lane highway suddenly materializes, climbing up to this tiny mountain village, and then just as suddenly peters out. The village is not much to look at: a single main street of low, stone shops on a rise in the rocky, barren hills. But near the only gas station there is an imposing abstract monument with a bas-relief of the flag of the ruling Baath Party thrust into a map of the Arab world with Syria at its heart. And a couple of blocks away, behind a high yellow wall, guarded by troops in the reddish tiger-stripe camouflage and burnt orange berets of an elite unit, stands the opulent palace of Qardaha's favorite son, President Hafez al-Assad.

The architect James Stewart Polshek will resign as dean of the Columbia University Graduate School of Architecture, Planning and Preservation on June 30 after 15 years in the post. In a statement, Mr. Polshek said he was resigning to devote more time to his architectural practice at James Stewart Polshek & Partners in New York.

According to the race's organizers, 19,689 runners completed the New York City Marathon last month, making it the biggest marathon ever. In figures released by the organizers yesterday, 96 percent of the 20,502 who started the event finished it.

Two musicians with different styles of madness, Victor Borge and Peter Schickele, will carry on in separate halls tonight, but that should pose no problem for mutual fans. Both men will appear several times in the days ahead. The 77-year-old Mr. Borge, who has taken his ''Comedy in Music'' almost everywhere, somehow neglected Lincoln Center. He will be making a debut when he strides onto the stage of Avery Fisher Hall, acknowledges the applause with an urbane nod and - his signature opener - exhales smoke.

Commercial airline pilots often fight intense drowsiness and sometimes even fall asleep while flying planes on long overnight trips, a researcher said. ''When you are in the cabin and your head is rolling over and you can't stay awake, just remember that the guy up front is human, too,'' said the researcher, Dr. Martin C. Moore-Ede of Harvard Medical School. Occasionally, everyone in the cockpit nods off at the same time while the plane flies on automatic pilot, he said. Planes have been known to cruise past their destinations as the pilots and navigator sleep, he added.

International Japan's Government approved an austere preliminary budget that calls for total spending of $336 billion in the 1987 fiscal year, an increase of $75 million, the smallest rise in three decades. Besides providing for virtually no growth from the current year's budget, the proposed budget includes a drop of 2 percent in the important category of public works. The spending restraint could be a concern to Japan's major trading partners, especially the United States, which has urged Japan to bolster its economy to stimulate demand for American goods. [ Page D1. ]

When the Federal Government began a program last spring to slaughter dairy cows in a move to reduce milk production in the United States, a small, nonprofit agency here decided that it was a waste of a valuable resource. Thus was born the ''Save the Cows'' program of Heifer Project International, an agricultural development agency that has been donating livestock to the needy around the world since 1944. Under the program, cows facing slaughter as part of the Federal Government's Dairy Termination Program to reduce the nation's surplus of dairy products are being shipped to low-income families in other countries where milk is needed. ''When the Federal program was first introduced, farmers called us saying they had worked all their lives to breed good cattle and were distressed at having them destroyed,'' said Jerry L. Bedford, director of development for the project. ''What a dreadful waste when the rest of the world needs milk. We thought there was a better way to use these cows.'' #900,000 Cows Slaughtered Since May, 1,067 heifers, mostly Holsteins, have been shipped from farms throughout the country to small farmers in Jordon, Honduras and Mexico through the Save the Cows program. And although 900,000 cows have already been slaughtered and 47,000 more have been exported commercially under the Federal program, the project hopes to donate 2,500 heifers to underdeveloped nations by next August, said Jim Hoey, coordinator of the project.

Bradley Hall doesn't think he's a hero. But the Carnegie Hero Fund Commission and the handicapped man he dragged from a burning home a year ago say otherwise. ''He went the last mile - he could have easily gotten killed,'' said Roland Winters of Placentia, Calif., about the teen-ager from Anaheim who saved his life. Bradley was one of 24 people honored this week by the commission, which recognizes people who risk their lives to save or attempt to save the lives of others.

To the Editor: Hidetoshi Ukawa, Japan's distinguished Consul General in New York, struck the right note in his Dec. 18 Op-Ed article, addressing this country's trade deficit and its relation to Japan. Recognizing the complexity of the problem, Mr. Ukawa properly concludes that protectionist legislation is not the answer.

Noel Ignacio likes his job with the Federal Government - he is an engineer on a small Coast Guard boat -and his superiors like the way he does his work. But the 24-year-old native of the Philippines almost lost his job because of another arm of the Federal Government: the Immigration and Naturalization Service. Delays in processing Mr. Ignacio's citizenship application put him perilously close to missing a deadline to re-enlist for his second term in the Coast Guard.

Which major college football team has the best cumulative record over the years? It's Notre Dame, although second-place Michigan is gaining fast and has shaved seven percentage points off the Irish lead this year alone.

''We're making it as good as old,'' read the T-shirts that were worn proudly by the electricians, plasterers and other workmen responsible for the $30 million renovation of Carnegie Hall. The promise was amply fulfilled.
Helen Thurber, an editor and the wife of James Thurber, died at Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital, on Monday. She was 84 years old and lived in Weston, Conn.

''Every organization has one project that causes a lot of pain and headaches,'' said Leah Schneider, executive director of the Manhattan Valley Development Corporation, a nonprofit community-based housing group. ''This has been that project for us.'' The diminutive, 73-year-old husky-voiced director was referring to the Manhattan Valley Town Houses, a publicly assisted condominium complex, sponsored by the corporation and geared toward middle-income homebuyers. The project has been delayed two years by numerous problems.
According to A. C. Nielsen, the monitor of the monitorable, the highest per capita sales of grocery products this year have been in Norway, with Sweden being in second place.

To the Editor: Your article on plans to commemorate the 100th anniversary of the poet Joyce Kilmer's birth (Weekend, Dec. 5) noted that the white oak supposed to have inspired Kilmer to write ''Trees'' was once on the Rutgers University campus in New Brunswick, N.J. However, according to a Sept. 19, 1963, news story describing the destruction of the tree, The Times reported, ''Rutgers said it could not prove that Kilmer . . . had been inspired by the oak.'' It further stated that the towns of Mahwah, N.J., Montague City, Mass., and Swanzey, N.H., have also claimed the distinction of possessing the tree Kilmer had in mind when he wrote his poem.

Among the biggest headaches suffered in the Pentagon has been the responsibility for the medical care of 10 million people in peacetime and for the wartime treatment of men and women wounded in battle. By law, the 2.2 million members of the armed forces and their 2.8 million dependents are entitled to free medical care, as are 5 million more retired military people, dependents and widows. That free medical care is a strong point used by recruiters trying to interest young people in enlisting in the armed forces. But the military system that provides peacetime medical care has been strained, Pentagon officials say. Overcrowded military hospitals try to treat 50 million outpatients a year. Costs of sending the overflow to civilian doctors and hospitals approaches $2 billion a year. And the quality of the care has been criticized in highly publicized cases of malpractice.

FREQUENTLY it is the small detail that is bound to stick in memory. In this evening's ''Kennedy Center Honors,'' while Glenn Close and Hal Linden are singing a love ballad from the musical ''I Do, I Do,'' Nancy Reagan reaches over to hold President Reagan's hand. Not responding immediately, the uncharacteristically subdued President finally turns to the First Lady and manages a smile. A purely impulsive moment? Or the seizing of a good photo opportunity during a period of political and no doubt personal stress? Either way, the image - seen by few in the theater but now available to millions - is striking. The ninth annual broadcast of ''The Kennedy Center Honors: A Celebration of the Performing Arts'' was taped on Dec. 7 and can be seen tonight at 9 on Channel 2. Once again directed by Don Mischer, the event has evolved into one of the more consistently classy awards shows designed for television. The point is not the recognition of a single performance in a passing season. These honors, bestowed by the President in a White House ceremony, celebrate an entire career. The youngest honoree this year, Ray Charles, is 56 years old. All of the others are in their 70's: Lucille Ball, Hume Cronyn and Jessica Tandy, Yehudi Menuhin and Antony Tudor. There are lifetimes of accomplishment here.

Ellen Barry, widow of the playwright Philip Barry, has presented Georgetown University Library with a collection of Mr. Barry's manuscripts and papers. The bulk of his papers went to the Yale University Library after his death in 1949, but Mrs. Barry kept some letters, contracts and drafts of some of her husband's later plays for sentimental reasons.

THERE are some words particularly appropriate to theater production: planned, hoped-for, scheduled and tentative are just a few. And the sad fact is that a number of planned, hoped-for, scheduled and tentative productions, announced with varying degrees of fanfare each year, fizzle before they even get near a stage. The money people bow out, Dustin Hoffman decides he doesn't want to sing and dance, Mike Nichols is busy for the next five years, the package didn't jell - name a reason, any reason, and it's bound to have been used to explain why a show that was highly touted hasn't yet seen the light of day. Which doesn't necessarily mean that silence about announced projects is a death knell. Sometimes, the postponement is actually that - raising the money took longer than expected, the star who was ready to sign didn't, the book and music needed work. And not infrequently, the project eventually does get going, or seriously looks as though it's going to get going. And sometimes while it's not really alive, it's not dead either - it's on a back burner, but the flame is still on.

The Defense Department says it has completed three more successful tests of its new air-to-air missile, including an experiment marking the first time that two missiles have been fired from the same plane at two different targets. The tests were conducted Friday at Eglin Air Force Base in Florida and Saturday at the White Sands Missile Range in New Mexico, the Pentagon said in a statement Tuesday.

New York City traffic patterns swirl across state and city lines, but traffic agencies have always been insular. No longer. A compact between the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and the transportation departments of New York City and State and New Jersey creates a new agency, Transcom, to serve as a clearinghouse for traffic information.

A customer fired a rifle in a restaurant, killing a short-order cook who refused to serve him chicken on Christmas Eve, the authorities said today. The police arrested Willie B. Hamilton, 43 years old, and charged him with murder three hours after the death of Percy Lee Jones, shot in the crowded Corner Lounge diner.

Those who want to dance their way into the New Year can choose between ballroom and disco dancing on New Year's Eve at Roseland, 239 West 52d Street. Ballroom dancing to three live bands will be featured from 8 P.M. to 1 A.M., followed by disco dancing, also to live bands, till 5 A.M. Admission is $30 till 1 A.M., $25 afterward. Information: 247-0200.

She works in a small clothing factory - or she did until recently, when she was dismissed for refusing to work an extra 12-hour shift on Sunday. The 30-year-old worker, who declined to give her name for fear of being blacklisted by employers, was used to long hours - she had worked 10-hour days, six days a week, sewing buttons on clothes for an average monthly salary of $185. But after attending evening classes at a local church, where she learned about labor organizations, she grew to believe that her employers' demands were unfair - and says she is willing to go into factories and organize strikes. ''They fired me,'' she said, ''for being an agitator.''

'Corpocracy' Excerpts from a recent address, ''The Attack on 'Corpocracy,' '' by Murray L. Weidenbaum, former chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, now director of the Center for the Study of American Business at Washington University in St. Louis. The address was given to a meeting in Washington sponsored by Chief Executive Magazine.

International A3-17 An Iraqi plane, reportedly hijacked, crashed on a desert airstrip in Saudia Arabia, killing 62 people, Jordanian officials said. Iraqi and Jordanian officials accused Iran of being behind the attempted hijacking. Page A1 Iran said it killed more than 1,500 in an attack on four islands in the southern waterway separating Iran from Iraq. Iraq acknowledged the fighting, but said it had driven the Iranians off.

This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. CAFE DES ARTISTES, #1 West 67th Street (877-3500) - *(May 30, 1986) In winter, any number of occasions may call for particularly festive dining - holidays, birthdays or anniversaries. This West Side restaurant with dark wood walls, lead-paned windows and bucolic turn-of-the-century murals is one of the most gracious and romantic spots in town and might be just the place for your celebration. Appetizer choices are bresaola with figs, Parmesan and rosemary olive oil; sliced duck liver, with toasted brioche and duck cracklings, and white anchovies with buffalo mozzarella and tomato. For a main dish, you might order steak au poivre; sauteed calf's liver with mild sesame-and-mustard-seed sauce; rack of lamb encrusted with basil and breadcrumbs, or rare roasted slices of lamb in pan gravy surrounded by pale-green French beans. Dinner entrees $13.50 to $25; also prix-fixe dinner $25.50. Fridays and Saturdays, noon to 3 P.M. and 5:30 P.M. to 12:30 A.M.; Sundays, 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. and 5 to 11 P.M. LE CIRQUE, #58 East 65th Street (794-9292) - ***(Sept. 19, 1986) The dining room of this elegant East Side restaurant crackles with high-voltage energy, and the rich and famous from around the world are squeezed in elbow to elbow. The food is classically rooted and generally conservative.

THE National Register Publishing Company, whose Red Book directories are a necessary possession on the business side in both the agency and advertiser side of the industry, has acquired the Creative Black Book, which in its 16 years has become fairly indispensable to many people on the creative side, worldwide. It, too, is a directory, and it seeks to list all the suppliers from whose efforts a final print ad, radio spot or TV commercial is constructed. And there are many, since advertising agencies are largely for idea generation. And their ideas are the bare bones of a concept whose finished product must be fleshed out by suppliers, such as photographers, illustrators, photofinishers, retouchers, TV directors and production houses and post-production houses and so on.
A 25-year-old woman was assaulted and raped early yesterday while waiting to buy a ticket at a railroad station on Long Island, the police said.

Cape Cod Potato Chips are not sold in many places, but in the stores that carry the product, it is frequently the top-selling chip. A thick and very crisp potato chip made by old-fashioned methods in this seaside resort town, Cape Cod Potato Chips are going the way of David's cookies, Ben & Jerry's ice cream, Dove Bars and other new versions of traditional snack foods that have recently risen from the ranks of junk food to the status of ''premium'' or ''gourmet'' treats. More Expensive Than Rivals Like their counterparts in the ice cream, cookie and candy world, Cape Cod Potato Chips cost more than their competitors ($1.49 for a seven-ounce bag compared with, say, $1.29 for an eight-ounce bag of mass-produced potato chips); they are made without chemical additives (just potatoes and oil); and, to many, they taste better. John O'Shaughnessy, a consumer behavior expert at the Columbia University Graduate School of Business, says the chip company is part of a growing coterie of small food entrepreneurs tapping a special pocket of consumers willing and eager to treat themselves to a $2 piece of chocolate or $1.75 ice cream cone. ''There are a lot of little luxury segments out there,'' Professor O'Shaughnessy said, ''and big manufacturers do not cater to them. They're not big enough.''

Last winter, Regina Days of Georgia Southern set a single-season record for Division I women's basketball by scoring on 234 of 332 shots from the floor, an accuracy rate of 70.5 percent. As remarkable as that figure is, it's already being threatened with eclipse, maybe with demolition.

The Politburo today approved the creation of joint economic ventures with foreign companies as a way to increase exports of Soviet-made goods. The official Tass news agency said the 12-man ruling body indicated that the ventures were ''a component part of improving the foreign economic performance of the U.S.S.R. and deepening international cooperation.''

An Iranian secret agent and arms smuggler went to the South Bronx in 1981 to meet with the top officials of the Wedtech Corporation in an unsuccessful effort to purchase spare parts sought by the Iranian army, according to company officials. The discussions fell through, Wedtech officials said, when they became suspicious of the agent -who they originally thought was a wealthy Arab investor. They hired a private investigator to check out his background, and discovered his links to Iran. ''After obtaining a report on him, they concluded that his past was nefarious, that he had some contacts to Iran,'' said Wedtech's corporate counsel, Martin Pollner. ''They did not want to get involved with him. There was no contract, no deal, and nothing was ever consummated.''

After five years of growing cooperation, Roman Catholic and Jewish spokesmen in Brazil have taken a new step toward eliminating generations of mutual distrust by publishing a detailed manual to promote interfaith discussion. The 187-page booklet, which was distributed this month to Brazil's 229 Catholic archdioceses and dioceses by the National Bishops' Conference, covers a broad range of subjects. These include the history of the Jewish people, the roots of anti-Semitism and the Nazi horror, Judaism in Brazil and specific ways of handling differences between the two religions. Its publication is considered significant not only because Brazil is the world's most populous Catholic country but also because, although only about 170,000 Jews live here, Brazil's bishops appear to have moved faster than the Vatican in trying to establish a closer relationship with Judaism.

The Bill Barron All-Stars, featuring Kenny Barron, will perform Monday and Tuesday at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street (475-8592). The Barron Brothers, on saxophone and piano, are appearing with Ray Drummond on bass and Ben Riley on drums. Shows both days are at 9 and 11 P.M. and 1 A.M.; $7.50 music charge, $5 minimum.

A New York evironmental panel has recommended the appointment of a full-time executive to oversee the state's cleanup of hazardous-waste sites. The recommendation was one of several made public yesterday by the panel, the State Superfund Management Board.

For H. Ross Perot, the scrappy Texas billionaire who founded the Electronic Data Systems Corporation, the year was full of new and resurrected crusades. Frustrated by the bureaucratic weight of the General Motors Corporation, which acquired E.D.S. in 1984, Mr. Perot bristled as his goal of intrepidly revolutionizing the auto industry bogged down.

Two national Hispanic organizations representing more than 200,000 people have announced a nationwide boycott of all Japanese products in response to remarks made by Japan's Prime Minister. Members of the League of United Latin American Citizens, or Lulac, and the American GI Forum, a group founded by veterans of Hispanic origin, said at a news conference that the boycott became necessary when Japanese officials refused to meet with them to discuss remarks made by Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone that were thought to be racist.
A girl, believed to be 3 years old, at Lutheran Medical Center after she was found abandoned early yesterday on a street in Sunset Park section of Brooklyn. Page B2.

The pro-democracy demonstrations by university students over the last several weeks have revealed a depth of discontent among the elite of China's youth that was unsuspected until now. That university students, the chosen young, should demonstrate in such numbers in favor of political principles closely associated in the minds of Chinese with the non-Communist West, particularly the United States, has raised disturbing questions among many here about the direction of economic and political change in China. The largest rallies were in Shanghai last weekend, where close to 50,000 people were estimated to have gathered on Sunday alone. But they also occurred in Beijing and about half a dozen other cities. Today there were reports that 3,000 students demonstrated in the port city of Tianjin to show their solidarity with the Shanghai protests.

TRUE to form, Wall Street security analysts are looking ahead to 1987 with rosier profit projections than economists and market strategists who work for the same brokerage houses. In the past, however, analysts often scaled back their estimates as the year progressed. As a group, the analysts now expect earnings growth of 21.1 percent next year in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, the most popular benchmark for corporate profits. But economists and strategists expect an earnings increase of only 12.8 percent.

A 27-year war against the alfalfa weevil is being won by an imported stingless wasp, according to the Agriculture Department. From 1959 to 1980, the wasps were used so effectively in the Northeast that spraying of chemical pesticides to control the weevils dropped 73 percent in 11 states, saving farmers about $8 million a year. Some of the states reported that the wasps alone provided virtually 100 percent protection from weevils.

Sentencing has been set for Jan. 29 for John Robert Lowrey, who pleaded guilty Monday to second-degree manslaughter in the death of a man who drank Mr. Lowrey's race car fuel methanol at a party. Mr. Lowrey, 18 years old, was accused of passing the methanol as moonshine whisky at the party Nov. 24. The man who drank it, Timothy Scott Tilson, 23, died Nov. 28.

When professional football teams have 14-2 seasons, as the Giants did this year, almost everything must go right. Not so, said Coach Bill Parcells. Because everything worked out for the Giants, who won their division and are Super Bowl favorites, it just seemed hassle-free. ''I don't think you realized how concerned I was with the backfield situation early in the season,'' said Parcells, ''when Joe Morris had that allergic reaction and Lee Rouson's knees weren't doing good and we talked of ways to scope him and we didn't know about George Adams, and Maurice Carthon had a broken thumb. I was very, very concerned at that time, particularly when we went to St. Louis.

About 30 advocates for the homeless, some with signs reading, ''Why is there no room in the inn?,'' demonstrated Wednesday against a proposed vagrant-free zone along Peachtree Street. The Atlanta Advocates for the Homeless suggested that for every $100 the city spends on the development of entertainment spots, sports arenas, convention halls, luxury hotels and condominiums, $10 should be put aside for the construction and maintenance of low-income housing for the homeless.

Richard Keating recalls with wonder those hectic days after he first moved to Houston from Chicago as a young architect in 1976. Those were days of wild Texas growth, when a 20-story building was a small job, when he and his ambitious young colleagues often worked all night, fueled on take-out pizzas and the sheer excitement of building a dazzling new city, with their dogs curled up under the drafting tables. A few months ago Mr. Keating, who cut a tall figure in Houston in his aviator glasses, 40-foot sailboat and Porsche Cabriolet, transferred to Los Angeles to take over the busy Skidmore Owings & Merrill architectural office there. Departing with him were about a dozen other architects from the Houston office who, he said, felt that they ''want to go where the action is.'' Vanguard of Outflow The group was in the vanguard of a small but growing outflow of professionals - architects, lawyers, writers, scholars, bankers - from Texas as its oil economy slows. They are part of a larger demographic shift in which, for the first time, more people are moving out of Texas than into it.

Brian Bosworth, the all-America linebacker, and two of his University of Oklahoma teammates have been barred from playing in the Orange Bowl game against Arkansas Jan. 1 because they tested positive for anabolic steroids, a university spokesman said yesterday. The ruling was made by the National Collegiate Athletic Association, which instituted tests for some championship events and some football bowl games this year in an effort to prevent the use of more than a hundred banned generic drugs. At least six players have now been barred from bowl games because of positive drug tests, but the action on Bosworth was the most dramatic so far. He is a charismatic player, noted for his unusual hair style and his prodigious strength. He finished fourth this season in voting for the Heisman Trophy as the nation's best college football player and has been rated as one of the top prospects for the National Football League draft next spring.

The American Jazz Radio Festival, heard on WBGO, 88.3 FM, will present live music on New Year's Eve from 10 P.M. to 5 A.M. It begins with a live broadcast from WBGO's studios at 54 Park Place in Newark, featuring the bassist Bill Lee's group, including the singer Ronnie Dyson, the trumpeter Virgil Jones, the saxophonist Harold Vick, the pianist Stanley Cowell and the drummer Joe Chambers. They will be followed by the pianist-singer Tania Maria and her trio.

King Fahd issued a royal decree on Wednesday naming Hisham Nazer the Minister of Petroleum and Mineral Resources, the official Saudi Press Agency reported. Mr. Nazer, planning minister for more than two decades, was named acting oil minister on Oct. 30, when Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani was dismissed by the King.

A holiday wreath made of sardine cans will be among the varieties of wreaths on view through Jan. 9 at the Arsenal Gallery of the City's Department of Parks and Recreation, Fifth Avenue and 64th Street. The wreaths, 29 in all, were made by artists, horticulturists and others. Hours are Monday through Friday, 9 A.M. to 4:30 P.M.
Eight computer dealers who charge that Wang Laboratories breached a contract entitling them to become authorized Wang dealers have sued the computer company for $32 million.
''It all happened like lightning. The captain had just announced that we'd entered Saudi airspace when one passenger from the economy class jumped up with a hand grenade and ran towards the cockpit.

Asserting that new Medicare provisions in a law adopted this year would discriminate against the elderly and the disabled, the American Medical Association has asked a Federal judge to declare the law unconstitutional. The A.M.A., in a lawsuit filed Wednesday, is also seeking a preliminary injunction to stop the law's Medicare provisions from taking effect until the recipients are given more information about the changes. The provisions on Medicare, which finances health care for 28 million elderly people and 3 million disabled people, are to take effect Jan. 1, a week from today. The suit was filed by the association, which represents 272,000 physicians, and several other parties in Federal District Court in Lubbock, Tex., against Dr. Otis R. Bowen, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, whose department is charged with carrying out the new provisions.

The headlines about the Reagan Administration's crisis of leadership and direction have been so thick and constant that the passing of another arms control opportunity was too little noticed or mourned. On Dec. 18, Soviet officials announced that they would not continue the nuclear testing moratorium that they had maintained for 17 months, while President Reagan disingenuously refused to join; and a White House spokesman replied almost insolently that that was ''their business.'' Well, it's also the business of a lot of Americans who want a reduction in the danger of nuclear war, not just between the superpowers but among the numerous other nations that either have ''the bomb'' or can quickly develop it. These Americans believe with a power of evidence on their side that a nuclear test ban would be a useful step in the right direction.

Ken Peplowski and Frank Vignola will perform Monday night at J's, 2581 Broadway, between 97th and 98th Streets (666-3600). Mr. Peplowski on clarinet and Mr. Vignola on guitar are in the classic tradition of jazz duos of the 1920's and 30's. From 8 P.M. No cover, $10 minimum at tables, two-drink minimum at the bar.

Ken O'Brien, calm and controlled, supported Pat Ryan today but not necessarily Coach Joe Walton's decision to switch quarterbacks for Sunday's wild-card playoff game against the Kansas City Chiefs. When asked whether the change could give the team a lift, as Walton contended it might, O'Brien said: ''You'll have to ask him. That's his decision.'' And asked whether he agreed with Mickey Shuler, the tight end, that there is less pressure for a quarterback coming off the bench, O'Brien said, ''I wouldn't, no.''

A woman and her 10-year-old son were killed by a fire that swept through the upper story of their two-story home in Neponsit, Queens, early yesterday, the fire department said. The woman's husband and three other children were taken to hospitals for treatment of smoke inhalation and other injuries. The fire broke out on the second story of the brick home at 429 Beach 140th Street sometime before 4 A.M. and firefighters had the blaze under control less than an hour later. Delores Doherty, 37 years old, was taken to Peninsula General Hospital where she was pronounced dead. Her son, Joseph Hutchby, died at Coney Island Hospital, said a Fire Department spokesman, Assistant Commissioner John Mulligan..

''THE ADVENT OF MODERNISM: Post-Impressionism and North American Art, 1900-1918,'' currently on view at the Brooklyn Museum (200 Eastern Parkway), feels a bit like a rough draft or an outline of an exhibition that still needs to be properly filled in and shaped. Crowded into the museum's big fifth-floor rotunda, with some 125 works strung out along walls that seem to go on forever or awkwardly displayed on the space's four fat columns, it also looks like an exhibition waiting to be installed. This is not a robust show, chockablock with masterpieces. It needs the quiet intimacy of a succession of small galleries that it must have enjoyed at its point of origin, the High Museum of Art in Atlanta. In Brooklyn, it is nearly done in by the space that contains it. Nonetheless, ''The Advent of Modernism'' (on view through Jan. 19) offers the first in-depth look at the earliest, which is to say the pre-Cubist, roots of Modernism on this side of the Atlantic. It shows how 54 American and Canadian artists struggled to master the lessons of late Cezanne, van Gogh, Gauguin, Seurat, the Fauves and finally early Matisse. This gamut of styles and innovations - gathered under the generous umbrella of Post-Impressionism by the British art critic Roger Fry in 1910 -initiated North American artists into the pictorial powers of stronger color, freer paint handling and increased attention to surface flatness as opposed to spatial representation.

An Iraqi airliner was hijacked yesterday and later crashed and burned on a remote desert airstrip in Saudi Arabia, killing 62 people, Jordanian officials said. The Jordanian Government said the Iraqi Airways jetliner en route from Baghdad to Amman had been commandeered by gunmen shortly after takeoff. Witnesses said that unidentified armed men set off least one hand grenade in the cabin before the Boeing 737 hit the ground and that a fire on board spewed smoke through the cabin. One witness said that when the plane, Flight 163, hit the ground, the fuselage split apart. Emergency Landing The plane crashed during an emergency landing at Arar, 60 miles south of the Saudi-Iraqi border and 250 miles southwest of Baghdad in northern Saudi Arabia, the Saudi Defense Ministry said.

For a beleaguered state like Israel, arms exports are a tempting way to seek foreign friends, earn money and promote military self-sufficiency. So tempting that, remarkably, Israel has by some estimates climbed to ninth place in the world's arms bazaar, with annual sales of $1.2 billion or nearly a fourth of its industrial exports. It's not a distinction Israelis uniformly relish, and the no-longer secret dealings with Iran have ignited arguments about the rightness of arming avowed enemies in Teheran and dubious customers of convenience like South Africa.

Eugene R. Canudo, a retired Acting State Supreme Justice, died of a stroke last Monday at St. Charles Hospital in Port Jefferson, L.I. He was 76 years old and lived in Ridge, L.I. Justice Canudo was appointed to the Supreme Court in 1974 by Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller. He retired in 1980.
A man lost his legs and suffered serious internal and head injuries yesterday when he was struck by a Long Island Rail Road train in Woodside, Queens.

Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu is urging the Reagan Administration to institute a new policy toward South Africa, offering Pretoria a choice between extensive financial and diplomatic support for dismantling apartheid, or greatly increased ostracism. Such a strategy, Archbishop Tutu said, would entail a decision by Washington to stop vetoing mandatory United Nations sanctions and to sever all telecommunications with South Africa if the country's white rulers refused to accept a timetable for change. His proposal, he indicated, would include possible American backing for white minority rights in a post-apartheid South Africa.

Government efforts to curtail tin mining, for which Bolivia made its mark on the world in pre-cocaine days, have set off a dispute that goes to the roots of the country's political and economic life. It is highlighted by a battle of two titans of modern Bolivian history, each now in his eighth decade, who fathered the nationalized mining system over which they now confront each other. The Government of President Victor Paz Estenssoro, 79 years old, says that in the face of low world prices for tin and production costs that are the highest in the world it has no choice but to close some mines and impose efficiency on others. And for future mining development, it intends to put its faith in private enterprise.

An engine fire forced a Delta Air Lines jet to return to the airport just minutes after it took off for New York with 136 passengers aboard. Delta officials said they did not know what caused the flames to shoot from the L-100 jet's rear engine Tuesday as Flight 144 lifted off. It appeared that a compressor pump stalled, said Ron Gardner, information manager of the Hollywood-Fort Lauderdale International Airport.

Tom Webster, the Ranger coach, was discharged from Lenox Hill Hospital a day after undergoing surgery to relieve an inner ear infection. According to a team spokesman, doctors found the infection to be more serious than they had believed, but Webster will probably be able to return to work next Tuesday. . . . Dick Stockton of the United States and Ken Rosewall of Australia were named by Tennis Magazine in its year-end rankings as the top Men's 35 and Men's 45 players, respectively.

Friday HOLIDAY 'PATIENCE' Ah, for the love of a poet. Tonight, the New York Gilbert and Sullivan Players present ''Patience,'' the Gilbert and Sullivan operetta about two poets' ardor for an unpretentious village milkmaid. John Reed, the veteran principal comedian of D'Oyly Carte, the British opera troupe that disbanded in February 1982 after 106 years of touring the world, will star as the poet Bunthorne. His rival is Keith Jurosko as Grosvenor. The object of their affections, Patience, will be played by Maureen Born. The work lampoons the Pre-Raphaelites and the Esthetic movement, championed by Oscar Wilde. The performances this weekend are tonight and tomorrow at 8 and tomorrow and Sunday at 3 P.M. at Symphony Space, Broadway and 95th Street. Tickets are $15 to $25 (children and the elderly get a $5 discount). Information: 769-1000.

A Federal district judge has refused to block the removal of Chumash Indian bones from an ancient tribal cemetery discovered six months ago in dredging a flood-control channel. Judge Pamela Ann Rymer denied the injunction sought by a Chumash faction that sued to halt dredging of the Calleaguas Creek channel near Point Mugu on the ground that disturbing the remains would violate their religious practices.

EVERY once in a while, the craving strikes for a favorite food - a crusty and succulent steak perhaps, a mile-high pastrami sandwich slathered with zesty hot mustard, or an unconscionably rich slab of luxurious chocolate cake (''Sure, a scoop of vanilla ice cream with it would be just dandy!''). The following list of 50 wintertime favorites just might be your emergency survival kit when the next overpowering urge arises. This selection of best dishes around town is excerpted from a longer compilation that will appear in ''The New York Times Guide to Restaurants in New York City,'' by this critic, to be published next month.* Apple pie. Coach House (110 Waverly Place, west of Washington Square).

Michael D. Dingman, chairman and chief executive of the Henley Group Inc., claims that his taste in businesses runs to the pedestrian. ''We like plain vanilla industries, things that are commonplace or have fallen out of favor,'' he said of the mishmash of 38 companies spun off early this year by Allied-Signal Inc.

Some contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund mention their concern for New York City in sending their gifts. ''All of us have a love for New York and feel terrible concern, especially at this time of year,'' said Jenny Semans, whose family in Hillsborough, N.C., sent $1,000.

BASKETBALL CHICAGO BULLS VS. KNICKS, at Madison Square Garden, 1 P.M. (Television - MSG, 1 P.M.) WASHINGTON BULLETS VS. 76ERS, at Philadelphia, 8 P.M. (Television - WTBS, 8:05 P.M.) FOOTBALL SUN BOWL, at El Paso, Tex., Alabama vs. Washington, 9 P.M. (Television - Channel 2, 2:30 P.M.) BLUE-GRAY ALL-STAR CLASSIC, at Montgomery, Ala., 5 P.M. ''What I have feared for a long time,'' says Representative Dan Glickman of Kansas, ''is that the public will view agricultural spending in the late 1980's the way they view defense spending in the mid-1980's.'' If so, it will be none too soon. Mr. Glickman thinks of the golden goose as a treasure. To most Americans, when they learn about it, it'll be a scandal.
