Direct farm subsidies are now running $70 million a day with no decline in sight. And in spite of Congress' coy attempts to limit payments to rich farmers, hundreds of them still receive six-figure checks from Uncle Sam.

A NINE-YEAR worldwide study of photography auctions - one of the newest and most volatile areas of the art-auction market - has produced a highly sophisticated reference work that is expected to have repercussions in other areas of art research. Bhupendra Karia's ''Artronix Index: Photographs at Auction,'' published last month by Artronix Data Corporation, 9 East 96th Street, documents, according to Mr. Karia, each of the 264 photography auctions held in a score of houses throughout the world between 1952 and 1984. He chose 1952, he said, because it was the year Swann Galleries in New York held this country's first postwar auction of photography - from the estate of Albert C. Marshall, a Rhode Island industrialist. Mr. Karia is completing a second volume, which will cover 1985 and 1986; it will be issued in March 1987, he said. Distribution for both works is being handled by the photography dealer Daniel Wolf, 30 West 57th Street. The first volume costs $2,500; the second volume will be $700, Mr. Karia said.
An Icelandic freighter carrying 19,000 barrels of herring sank in rough seas in the north Atlantic early today.

A Brazilian all-star team defeated a United States squad, 82-80, today to gain third place in a Christmas basketball tournament. The American club was composed of players who formerly played in the Continental Basketball Association in the United States or had been in the European leagues.
The talk about Dick Vermeil's return to profesional football as a coach continues to heat up.

The murder trial of two avowed revolutionaries under way here is one that Wilfred P. Diana, the assignment judge for Warren, Hunterdon and Somerset Counties, calls ''difficult.'' That is why he assigned it to Judge Michael R. Imbriani. ''He's unflappable,'' Judge Diana said of the 57-year-old judge who went through Harvard Law School on scholarship. ''He's even-tempered but firm. He has a lot of experience with difficult, high-visibility cases that call for administrative ability as well as judicial acumen.''

FANS of blazing Southwestern cooking may want to stop by the new Arizona 206 Cafe, a smart and neighborly annex to the Arizona 206 restaurant at 206 East 60th Street. Done in clean desert tones of stucco and unfinished wood, this casual spot sports firm fabric-covered banquettes, little tables scattered about and an exposed kitchen behind a tile service counter. Brendan Walsh, the resourceful young chef, has created an all-day tasting menu that features appetizer-size portions for $6 to $12.

The commander of the Honduran armed forces said today that if Sandinista troops violated Honduran territory again, as they did earlier this month in a battle with Nicaraguan rebels, Honduras would consider a retaliatory air strike deep into Nicaragua. In the December battle, which the Hondurans asserted took place on its territory, Honduras mounted an air strike with its air force against Sandinista positions inside Honduras. The senior Honduran commander, General Humberto Regalado Hernandez, also offered details of an earlier Honduran announcement that President Jose Azcona Hoyo telephoned President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua and demanded the withdrawal of Sandinista forces from Honduras before ordering the air strike against the Nicaraguans on Dec. 8. General Regalado, speaking in an interview here, did not specify the targets he had in mind for a possible future retaliatory strike. But he said the attacks would not be related to the dipute between the Sandinistas and the Nicaraguan rebels known as contras.

Pope John Paul II called today for a radical change in the way man exercises his dominion over the earth, saying the world's leaders should listen to the poor and the silent and those who pray for peace. The Pope made the appeal in his annual ''Urbi et Orbi'' Christmas message to the city of Rome and to the world, and afterward he offered his Christmas greetings in 51 languages. The form of John Paul's address today was unusual. It was written in free verse, and it was more of a prayer than a speech. The themes were ones he talks about frequently: the dangers of war and the special importance of the World Day of Prayer for Peace he held in the Italian town of Assisi last Oct. 27.

To the Editor: On behalf of my Government I wish to comment on the Dec. 7 article on Bolivia (''In Bolivia, Only a Faint Hue and Cry Follows Cocaine Corruption Charge,'' Week in Review). Despite extensive quoting of sources, the article contains information that distorts the reality of my Government's campaign against cocaine trafficking. The article frequently quotes ''accusations'' made by a police major, Ciro Jijena, to a committee of the Bolivian Congress, to throw doubt -unwillingly, I am sure - on the moral integrity and honesty of some Bolivian authorities, among them, the Minister of the Interior, Fernando Barthelemy.

N.B.A. Bullets 102, 76ers 97: Moses Malone, in his first game in Philadelphia against his former team, scored 28 points and pulled down 21 rebounds last night to lead Washington. Malone, who was traded with Terry Catledge to Washington last June for Jeff Ruland and Cliff Robinson, received a standing ovation that lasted nearly a minute when he was introduced before the game.
The Newark Museum will receive a $4 million state grant to help it complete a renovation and expansion project under a bill signed by Governor Kean.

Fire swept through a home for the elderly before dawn Wednesday, killing six people and injuring four. Jim Crawley, a fire investigator, said the blaze started in the room of a 71-year-old man, Robert Davis, who died in the blaze.

In this region, where three great religions were born, the issues of faith and promise are again stirring societies. They are not simple issues, long settled, because religion is about how men and women behave toward each other as well as about belief in their relations to God. Change has been coming at a rate never known in human history and it imposes ever new demands. The changes are welcome for what they bring in well-being, health, protection from the rigors and cruelties of nature. And they are frightening for what they bring in uncertainty and challenge. So they create new questions in everyday personal and social life and questions about the role of religion.
Bob Dorough and Bill Takas will appear on Monday at Gregory's, 1149 First Avenue, at 63d Street (371-2220).

One reason House members value increasing seniority so much is that it enables them to move to what they regard as choicer office space. Generally, the accepted progression is from the oldest, the Cannon Building (1908), to the Longworth Building (1933) and finally to the Rayburn Building (1965).

It was only a few weeks ago that Delia Overbaugh, a 29-year-old mother, found herself deeply moved as she listened to a broadcast report on a homeless family. ''I was almost in tears,'' Mrs. Overbaugh said as she sat with her three children on Christmas Eve in a public shelter here. ''I never thought that the same thing would happen to me.'' Mrs. Overbaugh and her children were sitting on an old convertible sofa, a bed for her and her two sons, Carl, who is 10 years old, and Tony, 6, since last Friday. Her daughter, Christel, 8, sleeps on a folding cot at their feet. Their sleeping quarters are a dimly lit public hallway of the Pilgrim House, a shelter for homeless families run by the City Union Mission, a charitable organization.

With conference play set to begin in January, coaches are using the semester break to review their teams' progress and chart an early course. But for a select group of freshman student-athletes, this is a time for a different kind of reflection. They are the so-called Propsition 48 casualties, the ones who failed to meet new minimum entrance requirements and were forced to sit out their first year of competition. ''It's not a real good feeling sitting at the games,'' said Rumeal Robinson, a former McDonald's high school all-America guard from Cambridge, Mass., now a freshman at the University of Michigan.

Bobby Humphrey, a sophomore tailback, scored on runs of 64 and 3 yards and caught one of two third-quarter touchdown passes by Mike Shula today as Alabama beat Washington, 28-6, in the Sun Bowl. It was Alabama's 22d victory in a postseason bowl game, a record. Shula threw a 32-yard scoring pass to Greg Richardson midway through the third quarter and threw a 17-yarder to Humphrey with 13 seconds left in the period as the Crimson Tide pulled away from a 7-6 halftime lead.

MCA Inc. is discussing the purchase of the Motown Records Corporation for up to $75 million, The Los Angeles Times reported today. According to the newspaper, Sidney Jay Sheinberg, MCA's president and chief operating officer, on Wednesday refused to deny that MCA is engaged in talks to acquire Motown, which nurtured such musical acts as Stevie Wonder, the Supremes and Smokey Robinson.
To the Editor: Everyone agrees the New York taxi problem is awful.

A burst of rifle fire rang out, and two squads of men in camouflage uniforms dived for cover in the scrub brush. Armed with loaded combat-style rifles, the men inched up to a gravel road, darted across, one by one, and disappeared in the tall grass. The men snaking through the bush were Cuban-Americans who say the most important thing in their lives is fighting Communism and the man who brought it to their homeland, Fidel Castro. If they can't get at him, they say, they'll do what they can in Nicaragua, where, they say, he is heavily involved.
What is the well-dressed dog wearing for the holidays? Well, a Santa suit in one instance.

A deputy sheriff's pistol accidentally fired and wounded a volunteer Santa Claus Wednesday at the state penitentiary, the authorities said. The deputy, Dickson Womack, who had had trouble earlier in the week when two inmates he and another deputy were escorting escaped, was unloading and storing a .25-caliber pistol before entering the penitentiary, the authorities said.

Fifteen months after the historic meeting at the Plaza Hotel where the United States and its major industrial partners agreed to drive the value of the dollar down, currency traders and economists are wondering where the governments of the industrial nations want to see exchange rates settle. The majority view is that the dollar is likely to decline further against leading foreign currencies, but few foreign exchange experts predict that the drop will exceed 10 percent. 'A Two-Sided Question' ''We've clearly taken some of the disequilibrium out of the system,'' said David Munro, an international economist for the General Motors Corporation. ''From 1982 to 1984, it was clear that the dollar had gone too far, and the job was to bring it back. Now it's a two-sided question.'' The leading contrary view is that the dollar might actually strengthen in the next year if the United States performs well economically and its trade deficit subsides.

Christmas morning, a time of giddy celebration for most children, was colored with sadness for a small girl and the people who found her abandoned on a Brooklyn street corner early yesterday morning. The girl, whom the police believe to be 3 years old, was found about 2:30 A.M. yesterday at the corner of Seventh Avenue and 46th Street in the Sunset Park section of Brooklyn. Soaked and scared, she clutched eerie symbols of her abandonment: a banged up stereo speaker and a broken clock.

State police today were trying to determine the identity of a middle-age man whose body was found in a partly burned pickup truck parked at Bradley International Airport. An attendant at the airport parking lot reported the smoke-filled vehicle to the police about 3:15 P.M. Wednesday.

Sonny Smith, Auburn's basketball coach, on his dour counterpart at the University of Alabama: ''It takes 15 muscles to smile and 65 muscles to frown. This leads me to believe Wimp Sanderson is suffering from muscle fatigue.''

PATRICK MAHONEY said he wouldn't swear to it but he had been told that in Los Angeles they had limousines 40 feet long ''with a midget who serves drinks, and a hot tub.'' He sounded the way Easterners do when they talk about excesses indulged in by residents of that other coast. Considering the vagaries of New York winter weather, it would seem more logical to have a limo hot tub, if indeed there is such a thing, in cars here but, alas, the Big Apple's fast lane apparently still hasn't caught up with all of life's refinements. But just so no one thinks the city is somewhere on the back track when it comes to transportation, it should be known that there is at least one 40-foot beauty in Manhattan - a white Lincoln with a red interior that has three bars, two television sets, two video-cassette recorders and one laser disk. It is so popular that an identical car, except that its interior will be gray, is expected any day.

Hans Olsson, captain of the Swedish team that is attempting to win its third consecutive Davis Cup title, named Mikael Pernfors yesterday as his second singles player. The three-of-five-match final series between Sweden and Australia is scheduled to begin today in Melbourne.

BOSWELL: THE ENGLISH EXPERIMENT, 1785-1789. Edited by Irma S. Lustig and Frederick A. Pottle. Illustrated. 332 pages. McGraw-Hill. $24.95. IN November 1785, when ''The English Experiment'' opens, James Boswell was 45 years old. Samuel Johnson had died the previous December, and Boswell, who had just published his account of the tour that he and Johnson had made to the Hebrides, was getting ready to start work on a full-scale biography. Over the next three years or so he completed a first draft, and at the same time continued keeping the journal that was eventually, after coming to light in the 20th century, to give him a secondary but substantial claim to lasting fame.

A 37-year-old man from North Carolina, wanted by the police on Staten Island for wounding his daughter with gunshot fire on Tuesday, was killed in a shootout with city and Housing Authority police officers yesterday afternoon. The man, identified as James Dudley of Laurinburg, N.C., was confronted by Officers Matthew Dryer and James Rocco shortly before 6 P.M. at Castleton and Sharpe Avenues in Port Richmond.

IF you like Jean Jacques Rachou's Cote Basque - and legions do - chances are you will like Le Festival, the two-month-old reincarnation of his former Cafe Lavandou on East 61st Street. While Le Festival's young staff, all-seafood menu and decor are new, the restaurant essentially reflects the classic and copious approach of the boss. It's a timely idea, this all-fish theme, and in characteristic Rachou style, no effort is spared to obtain the best of everything for his devoted fans -then assemble it on plates the size of hubcaps. The menu flirts with a few Oriental-inspired modern preparations, but it still remains faithful to dishes that are lavish with butter, cream and garnishes. Many of the creations are exceptionally good, but don't expect to leave the dining room with a lilt in your step.

In January 1979, a railroad tank car spilled a tiny amount - less than one teaspoon - of dioxin in Sturgeon, Mo. In February 1984, the trial of a lawsuit filed by residents of Sturgeon began in St. Clair County Court in Belleville. And in December 1986, nearly three years later, the 12 jurors and 2 alternates hearing the case were looking forward this week to their third Christmas break since it began.
A woman carrying a sundae used it to prevent a man from taking her purse, the police said today.

United States and Iranian officials are to meet Monday to resume negotiations on returning to Iran $500 million in frozen assets. The issue figures in an Iranian offer to intercede on behalf of American hostages in Lebanon. The officials agreed to continue talks on the Iranian claim instead of turning it over to the Iran-United States Claims Tribunal for arbitration. The tribunal - made up of three Americans, three Iranians and three people from other countries - ruled earlier that either nation could go to it for adjudication if no agreement were reached by Dec. 20.

On Christmas Day, 1986, a crowd of 15,811 gave themselves a gift and came to watch Michael Jeffrey Jordan, a k a Air Jordan, perform his daredevil, death-defying hoop feats in Madison Square Garden. Michael Jordan, who scored 50 points the last time he was here, the home opener of the Knicks in November, showed up in his customary cherry-red traveling uniform, and his customary assortment of riveting moves. He is magical on the basketball court and does everything except saw people in half. Sometimes, it seems he saws himself in half, and then in thirds and fourths, and never gets shorter.

JOHN STORRS may be one of those artists that each generation has to discover for itself. He will never be a household name. There is nothing flamboyant about his work, and his most public and monumental sculptures - in Chicago and Cork, Ireland - may be his most problematical. But he is one of America's most important early modernist sculptors, and artists continue to be inspired by his attempt to realize an international, utopian ambition in economical, unpretentious form. Storrs was born in Chicago in 1885, the son of an architect and real-estate developer whose family founded Storrs, Conn. From an early age, he traveled extensively. In Paris he either knew or studied with Rodin, Bourdelle and Lipchitz. In 1914 he married Marguerite Chabrol, a French writer from Orleans. Seven years later, he bought a chateau that remained his base in France, where he died in 1956. Throughout his career, he had one foot in France, which he described as a ''peaceful lap of culture and age-old beauty,'' and one foot in the United States, which he identified with hope and the future.
Pete Crivaro, the Mayor of Des Moines, died Wednesday night of complications resulting from brain cancer. He was 73 years old.

Good times are coming to an end for the only part of the American steel industry that has been consistently profitable. For the last five years, while the major steel producers' losses mounted, steel service centers flourished as one of the few oases of profit in the beleaguered industry. As the industry's middlemen, the centers buy steel from both domestic and foreign mills, then cut and shape it to customers' specifications. The rise of steel service centers resulted as manufacturers became more and more skittish about keeping huge inventories of steel products in their warehouses. Playing an increasingly vital role in inventory control, the centers began to profit by allowing manufacturers in the automobile, appliance and machinery industries to have the steel parts they needed when they were needed.

The topsy-turvy existence of Alice, in Wonderland and in the Looking Glass, often has bridge-table parallels. A quarter of a century ago, some of them were described by Jeff Rubens in a series of articles in The Bridge World.

Disneyland Hotel and more than 1,000 of its employees have agreed to a new labor contract, ending 10 months of picketing, officials said Wednesday. About 90 percent of the members of Local 681 of the Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees Union voted Monday to ratify the new contract, which includes increases in wages and health benefits over the next three years, said David Schultz, president of the union.

DURING the last two years, six young New York architects met regularly at one another's homes and studios to discuss alternatives to what they called ''the flatness of present architectural discourse'' and ''the dense wall of post-modernism.'' The six - Neil Denari, Wes Jones, Peter Pfau, Ken Kaplan, Ted Krueger and Chris Scholz - said they believed that post-modernism's retreat into classicism had limited architecture's range and technical capabilities, and that a machine-inspired architecture offered possibilities for richer buildings better tuned to contemporary culture. The results of their discussions are on view at a new show at P.S. 1 in Queens, ''Building Machines,'' and the exhibition is a manifesto. The three rooms of the show have architectural models and drawings of small and large buildings, all equipped with operable parts - roofs retract; floors flip up; stairways roll and lift; sun screens rotate. Buildings as humble as huts and as vast as ocean liners are designed to be kinetic rather than static - operable by hand or, like a convertible, at the push of a button. Some have rudimentary 19th-century mechanisms; one is really an electronic environment that senses the airwaves - the environment is not one of breezes and sunlight but of information.

To the Editor: David C. Anderson's remarks (''Tinkering With Justice,'' Editorial Notebook, Dec. 4) on the U.S. Sentencing Commission are disappointing, not because he paints a less than rosy picture of commission efforts, but because he seems not to understand our motivations. Guided by explicit statute, the commission is not ''tinkering with justice,'' but attempting to develop guidelines to insure fairness and certainty in sentencing. These ideals, extremely difficult to balance when dealing with a multitude of Federal statutes, are at the heart of the commission's preliminary draft of sentencing guidelines, published Oct. 1 in the Federal Register.

People no longer try to burn down the Adirondack Park Agency headquarters here, nor do they dump manure on the lawn or punch the employees. But while the more overt forms of hostility have disappeared in the 15 years since the Adirondack Park Agency was founded, many of the 120,000 people who live inside the park still nurse a deep resentment against it and say it has acquired too much control over local life. In a recent expression of this resentment, the governments of 11 of the 12 counties that lie wholly or partially inside the park - an unusual combination of public and private land - voted to finance a lawsuit challenging the agency's zoning rules as an infringement of residents' constitutional rights. Impoverished Region The people of the Adirondacks, who pride themselves on retaining the stubbornly individualistic spirit of the frontier, have never held government in high esteem. The nation's power centers seem remote to residents of this area, where most towns are little more than an intersection and Albany is considered the southern part of the state.

The television networks and Hollywood studios may be headed for a showdown over the often-hefty profits from rerun rights to prime-time shows. The issue is among the most contentious in the entertainment business today. For the most part, the networks are now barred by Federal regulations from owning shows or sharing in the proceeds from the syndication of reruns. But the rule prohibiting the networks from producing more than a small amount of their own programming is set to expire in 1990. And when that rule, the one of most immediate concern to the Hollywood studios, runs out, the networks effectively will gain the right to share in some syndication revenues - largely at the studios' expense.

The last time they played was New Year's Day 1984. The Washington Redskins had won the previous Super Bowl and looked no less invincible as defending champions, winning 14 games and a division title. The Los Angeles Rams squeezed into the playoffs as a wild-card team with a 9-7 record, beat the Cowboys and won a trip to Washington. Some prize. ''They were a fantastic team that year,'' Eric Dickerson of the Rams remembered the other day. He was a rookie that season, the National Football League's leading rusher and a man smart enough to know a buzzsaw when he walked into one, especially one he had seen before. The Rams had also played the Redskins during the regular season and lost, 42-20. ''We came into the playoff game a little scared,'' Dickerson said. ''After that first game, we didn't think we could beat them the second time.''

A man killed his in-laws and wounded the couple's two young sons because he did not want his wife going to Christmas Eve mass with her family, then committed suicide today, according to the Houston police. The body of the assailant, 44-year-old Espiridion De la Cruz, was found in front of his childhood home in Bay City, 50 miles southwest of here, Sgt. John Burmester of the Houston police said Mr. De la Cruz had left several suicide notes before shooting himself in the chest with a .38-caliber revolver.

On a day when a white Christmas was a distant dream and the runners in Central Park wore shorts, Irene Tar celebrated the holiday yesterday as she has for 12 years, gliding across the ice at Rockefeller Center. Alice and Robert Riddell, from Queens, went to the Palm Court at the Plaza Hotel for brunch, as they have for some 20 years. And thousands of miles away at the Vatican, as popes have for hundreds of years, Pope John Paul II said midnight mass. But for the first time, this mass was broadcast on state television in his native Poland. A Friend Is Remembered All over the world, traditions were embraced, in churches, at homes and at familiar landmarks, among loved ones as well as among strangers connected through the shared celebration. It was a time for families to stay close and count their blessings as well as for remembering those who were alone and dispossessed. In Paris, Aurel Cornea was thankful to be home for Christmas after 292 days as a hostage in Lebanon. [ Page A12. ] In the cavernous waiting room of Grand Central Terminal, a group of homeless men and women remembered the friend they knew only as Mama. The woman, still unidentified, was found dead last Christmas on the long wooden bench in the waiting room that had become her only resting place. She died of pneumonia and pulmonary emphysema.

Parliament was finally told recently about one of the worst kept secrets in this nation, where official secrets are at least as rampant as the spies that regularly broker them: ''There is a room in the turret of Westminster which does not exist in which are held meetings that do not take place.'' The revelation in mock-hushed tones from a member in the House of Commons concerned journalism, not espionage. The nonmeetings in the turret occur promptly every working day at 4 P.M., when the reporters who cover the Government and House of Commons hear from Bernard Ingham, the Prime Minister's press secretary, and his aides. They answer questions on various current issues with the stipulation that none of what they claim, contend, assert and say can be attributed to the Downing Street office of the Prime Minister in news reports.

R. Gordon Wasson, a former banker who wrote scholarly books about cults involving hallucinogenic mushrooms, died Tuesday at the home of his daughter in Binghamton, N.Y. He was 88 years old. A former resident of Manhattan, he lived in Danbury, Conn. Mr. Wasson, who was a retired vice president of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, was awarded the Addison Emery Verrill Medal of the Peabody Museum of Natural History at Yale University in 1983. The citation said that, together with his wife and co-author, Dr. Valentina P. Wasson, he had ''illuminated the sanctity of psychotropic mushrooms, not only in Russia and Siberia, but also in the most ancient of Hindu scriptures, in the mystery cults of ancient Greece and among the native peoples of Mexico and Guatemala, both ancient and modern.''

As the year draws to a close, Gary Hart of Colorado is closing out his Senate office and preparing the official opening of the new headquarters of his Presidential exploratory committee in Denver. The committee will formally open its doors Jan. 5 at the auspicious address of 1600 Downing Street, which evokes the domiciles of not just the President, at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue, but also the British Prime Minister, at No. 10 Downing Street. Mr. Hart is seeking the former office.

A British cargo ship sank today after running onto a rock off the east coast of Iceland, killing all 12 crewmen, Iceland's National Rescue Organization said. It was the second fatal sinking of a ship in the North Atlantic in two days. An Icelandic freighter, the Sudurland, sank midway between Iceland and Norway on Thursday. Five crewmen were rescued by a Danish helicopter, three were killed and three others were missing and presumed dead.

For the transient Japanese community concentrated here, the New Year celebration will not be the same as it is in Japan, but it will still be very Japanese. Many people will telephone relatives in Japan to wish them well and to hear the ringing of temple bells at the stroke of midnight Japanese time. The Aki Oriental Food Company has imported such holiday delicacies as sweetened sardines. The Dorcas Japanese bakery has special cakes on hand. And next Saturday there will be celebrations at the Japanese school in nearby Ridgefield. In Japan the New Year is welcomed with homes decorated in bamboo, feasts of sea bream and rice cakes, visits to relatives in the villages and to Shinto or Buddhist shrines, and parades of kimono-clad marchers. People often take the whole week off to celebrate.
''David Abshire has what it takes - both the respect and the experience - to be the President's point man on the Iran affair.'' - Senator Robert Dole, Republican of Kansas. [ 8:6. ]

Prices of fixed-income securities were virtually unchanged yesterday in extremely light post-Christmas dealings. Most senior dealers had taken a four-day holiday; many of those who came in yesterday left by early afternoon. Most overseas financial markets were closed, while domestic financial futures and options markets were only open for a few hours.

All stock exchanges, most commodity markets and banks and some businesses were open yesterday. But Federal offices and the New York Mercantile Exchange, New York Cotton Exchange, New York Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange and New York Commodity Exchange were closed. Because of the holiday closings, the Federal Reserve Board will release its weekly money supply report Monday.

Markets Wall Street's slowest day in two years revived a debate on whether the New York Stock Exchange should open at all on the day after Christmas. The thin trading left employees of brokerages with little to do but toss a football, read newspapers, play cards, take long lunches or tackle their backlog of paperwork. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed an insignificant 3.52 points, to 1,930.40, on volume of 48.9 million shares. [ Page 1. ]

To the Editor: With all the bad press that bicyclists have been receiving lately, it is ironic that you chose to publish a photograph of the Brooklyn Bridge (wearing nets for repairs and captioned ''Urban Vista,'' Dec. 9) that shows a jogger in clear disregard of a bicyclist's right of way.
Iran Denies Hijacking Role Iran dismissed accusations by Iraq and Jordan that it was behind the hijacking of an Iraqi plane in which 62 people reportedly died.

Two American mercenaries have escaped from a Brazilian prison and returned to the United States to tell a tangled tale of a foiled effort to overthrow the Government of Ghana. The two men, Timothy M. Carmody of San Francisco and Steven W. Hedrick of Ocala, Fla., were among eight Americans arrested 10 months ago off Brazil, with a ship bearing six tons of weapons. They say they were headed for the West African country to join in a coup attempt aimed at the military Government of Lieut. Jerry Rawlings. Mr. Carmody and Mr. Hedrick said in interviews today that they believed they were participating in a plan sanctioned by the United States Government and led by Godfrey Osei, a Ghanaian dissident and expatriate living in the New York City borough of Queens. Mr. Osei led a failed coup attempt in 1983. Mr. Carmody, a Vietnam veteran and a co-founder of the Rhodesia Veterans Association, a group of Americans who worked as private soldiers in Rhodesia in the late 1970's, said that once in Ghana, they were to meet with supporters of Mr. Osei who would attack the capital city of Accra while the Americans attempted to free Ghanaian nationals jailed on charges that they were working covertly for the Central Intelligence Agency.

The Alvin Ailey American Dance Company has announced that it will reconstruct historical dances choreographed by Katherine Dunham in the 1930's and 40's for performance by the company in its 1987-88 season. Among the works under consideration, all rarely performed, are ''L'Ag'Ya,'' ''Shango,'' ''Choros,'' ''Tango,'' ''Homage to Dorival Kaymmi'' and a suite of American dances including ''Barrelhouse,'' ''Flaming Youth'' and ''Florida Swamp Shimmy.'' The works will be reconstructed by Miss Dunham and several former Dunham dancers over a six-week rehearsal period next summer.

Bobby Czyz retained his International Boxing Federation light heavyweight title tonight when he knocked out David Sears in 61 seconds of the first round of a scheduled 15-round bout. Czyz, a 24-year-old from Wanaque, N.J., hurt the 27-year-old Sears with body blows, then staggered him with a right hand to the head. Czyz landed one punch after another as he worked Sears against the ropes, near the challenger's corner.

Somalia's official radio announced today that President Mohammed Siad Barre had won a new seven-year term with more than 99.9 percent of the vote in an uncontested election. The Somali radio, in a broadcast monitored in Nairobi, said 4,887,592 people voted for General Siad Barre and 1,486 against him in the election on Tuesday.

President Reagan is to leave Saturday for a one-week California vacation, including his usual New Year's stay at the Palm Springs home of the publisher Walter Annenberg. The President and his wife, Nancy, are to return here on Jan. 2.

Automobile defects not addressed by the Department of Transportation in the last six years have led to 500 deaths, 7,000 injuries and 20,000 traffic accidents, a consumer group said today. The group, the Center for Auto Safety, also charged that one of every five cars sold in the United States in the last eight years was subject to a Federal recall request that was not acted upon by the manufacturer. ''The Department of Transportation's dismal record on auto safety defects and recalls is no accident,'' the group said in a report.

* Centerre Bancorp., St. Louis, said that it had received approval from the Federal Reserve Board to buy Goppert Bank and Trust, a unit of Goppert Bancshares Inc., and that the aquisition is expected to be completed in January. * Computer Identics Corp., Canton, Mass., said it had completed new financing worth $900,000 of subordinated demand notes with N.V. Bekaert S.A. of Belgium and affiliates and clients of Eberstadt Fleming Inc. * Danners Inc., Indianapolis, said it had reached an agreement with Consolidated Stores International that, after the necessary government approval, will allow Consolidated to assume the leases and manage the inventory liquidation of 17 of the Danners 3D discount stores.

Celia Goldberg felt ''so sick I had nothing to lose'' when she signed up last year for a new kind of insurance for the elderly. ''Now the fear, for me, is gone,'' she said. ''When I pick up the phone, I get help immediately. They call you back. They tell you what to do.''

The police yesterday interviewed the parents of a 3-year-old girl who was found wandering the streets in Brooklyn early on Christmas and held the girl's mother for questioning. The girl, Monserrate Cadiz, remained in the care of the city department of Special Services for Children. The mother, identified by the police as Anna Almond, was found at a Brooklyn rooming house yesterday afternoon. She has not been charged.

The Atlanta Hawks have signed Mike Wilson, a journeyman guard who was cut last month by the Nets, to a 10-day contract in hopes that he might fill the gap left by the injured Spud Webb. Webb, who backed up Glenn (Doc) Rivers at point guard, underwent arthroscopic surgery on his left knee Tuesday and is expected to be sidelined for about three months. . . . The Golden State Warriors, who have been doing well without Purvis Short, their high scorer, may have to wait longer than expected for the 6-7 forward's return.

Archbishop Raymond G. Hunthausen of Seattle has been released from the Providence Medical Center here after surgery for prostate cancer. His physician, Dr. Jerry Minzel, authorized the release Wednesday because the 65-year-old prelate's recovery ''has gone very smoothly,'' said the Rev. Michael Ryan, chancellor and vicar general of the Roman Catholic archdiocese here. The Archbishop, who has been involved in a running dispute with the Vatican over some of his liberal stands, had been expected to be spend up to 18 days in the hospital after his surgery Dec. 16.

In ''Barbra Streisand: One Voice,'' on the Home Box Office cable channel tonight at 10, we have the entertainer as singer doing battle with the entertainer as concerned advocate. Fortunately, the singer wins, though just barely. I must confess to a chronic allergy to show business personalities who become soapbox orators. Whether it's Charlton Heston on the right or Jane Fonda on the left, just for starters, the sincerity-laden performances inevitably tend to leave me cringing in embarrassment before such profound superficiality. For the most part, I am entirely in Ms. Streisand's corner so far as her causes are concerned, but I keep wishing she would just sing. That's what she does best. This pay-cable special was taped Sept. 6 in the exquisite garden of Miss Streisand's imposing California home. Warming up the audience, Robin Williams says, ''Welcome to the Malibu Shakespeare Festival.'' An exclusive audience of 500 Hollywood celebrities paid $5,000 a couple, with the proceeds going to politicians, including the then-campaigning Senator Alan Cranston, Democrat of California, and to the Barbra Streisand Foundation. A note at the end of the program explains that the foundation ''supports qualified charitable organizations committed to antinuclear activities, the preservation of our environment, our civil liberties and human rights.''

Two days after thousands of university students demonstrated on the streets of Beijing, the city issued rules today that make any further public protest virtually illegal. Even as Beijing was joining other cities in clamping down on student protesters, 10,000 students in Nanjing, the industrialized capital of Jiangsu Province, were reported to have marched through the city calling for greater democracy, part of a continuing student campaign that is sweeping China. The action by the Beijing city government follows a similar action on Monday by the Shanghai authorities, who in effect banned demonstrations. In five days of protests in Shanghai that were brought to a halt earlier this week, more than 50,000 students marched through the streets with banners calling for democracy and freedom.

HOLIDAY WEEKEND This is the weekend of holidays, post-Christmas, pre-New Year, the start of Hanukkah. Even New York pauses on such occasions for a moment's contemplation that intrudes into the ceaseless work schedule. Down at the South Street Seaport, on the East River at Fulton Street, more than a century and a half of holiday seasons have drifted by the clippers and schooners tethered to the piers, and such occasions may have become more festive in recent years. For one thing, the seaport is a museum and a shopping center, though it retains the workaday fish houses, with their smell of the sea. Every evening for a month now, aboard a 25-foot-high platform, there has been special acknowledgement of the holidays. As darkness brings forth a burst of brightness from the skyscrapers that form a backdrop to the seaport, 65 singers, dressed in green and red capes, arrange themselves on the platform, producing an effect of being part of a large Christmas tree.

To the Editor: I was interested to read your recent screen review of ''The Mission,'' a film about 18th-century Jesuit missionaries who tried to defend Indians from colonist invasions and slave raids in Paraguay. What is not apparent from the film or the review is that the remaining Indians in South America today face loss of their lands, epidemics and a threat to their very existence. Tragically, the horrors depicted in ''The Mission'' are not only history, but are the daily reality of a number of Indian groups who have survived.

Drexel Burnham Lambert seems to be holding its ground in the $120 billion ''junk bond'' market, even after weeks of attack by other Wall Street firms. With the Securities and Exchange Commission's investigation of arbitrager Ivan F. Boesky and his relationship to Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., other investment bankers - always quick to seize opportunities -have stepped up their efforts to loosen Drexel's grip on the business it pioneered. Drexel commands nearly half of the market for high-yield bonds. ''They're saying, 'If anything comes up that makes you want to reconsider your relationship with Drexel, let us know,' '' said Harold Simmons, the Dallas investor. $6.6 Billion Since Nov. 14 So far, though, Drexel's grasp appears firm. Since Mr. Boesky admitted guilt to insider trading charges and agreed to pay $100 million in penalties on Nov. 14, Drexel has brought more than $6.6 billion of new issues to market. This total is said by specialists in the bond market to be substantially higher than Drexel's usual 50 percent of new issues. Of the $6.6 billion, almost all has been raised through Drexel's famed high-yield junk bond department orchestrated in Beverly Hills, Calif., by Michael Milken.

A contrite, hurt and, at the same time, defiant Brian Bosworth apologized today to his teammates and the public for being ruled ineligible to play with Oklahoma against Arkansas in the Orange Bowl Jan. 1 because a test showed the presence of steroids in his body. ''I accept my punishment,'' said the flamboyant 238-pound, 6-foot-2-inch linebacker. But he criticized the application of a rule on steroids by the National Collegiate Athletic Association. Bosworth, an all-America and two-time winner of the Butkus Award as the nation's outstanding linebacker, has one year of college eligibility remaining but could also enter next spring's National Football League draft because he was red-shirted as a freshman. He indicated he was thinking of joining the pros.

An escaped prisoner who had impersonated a college professor and a Federal agent and was wanted for a string of robberies in the south was found dead today from what the authorities said was a self-inflicted gunshot wound. The Southampton Police Chief, Conrad Teller, said the man, John Joseph Sousa, 42 years old, was found dead in a Noyac home after he held the authorities at bay for several hours. An agent in the Federal Bureau of Investigation's office in New York City, Stuart Sturm, said Mr. Sousa died from a self-inflicted gunshot wound.

The events of the past few months, especially the Dec. 6 parliamentary election, show that Taiwan is moving steadily toward a more representative government and a two-party political system. This is happening just as Beijing is making clear, in its talks with Hong Kong representatives, that it is unlikely to allow either development after it takes over the British colony in 1997. The contrast is all the more ironic since the advertised leniency of Beijing's control measures for the ''Hong Kong Special Administrative Zone'' post-1997 were intended as a model and an inducement for Taiwan's reunification with China.

Alton H. Maddox Jr. has been involved in many widely publicized cases involving juveniles, and colleagues say he has often come up with startling theories. Mr. Maddox, the 41-year-old son of a Baptist minister from the small town of Noonan, Ga., once headed the Juvenile Defense Project of the National Conference of Black Lawyers. Eleven months ago, he successfully defended Jonah Perry, a 19-year-old Cornell University sophomore who had been charged with assaulting and trying to rob a police officer who had fatally shot his younger brother, Edmund, during the scuffle. The case received widespread attention because the Perry brothers had risen above their impoverished Harlem surroundings to attend exclusive boarding schools on scholarships.

The Nicaraguan Government is pursuing a military strategy of ''forward defense'' in its war against the American-backed rebels, Sandinista officials say. The strategy is designed to keep the rebels, known as contras, out of Nicaragua by aggressively engaging them along the Honduran-Nicaraguan border. Col. Javier Carrion, who in a recent interview in Managua identified himself as the Sandinista officer in charge of operations against the contras, said the strategy had proved successful. The contras, he said, are so busy defending themselves along the border that they have little success infiltrating guerrilla teams into Nicaragua.

Knudsen Foods Inc., the troubled West Coast dairy concern, said it had agreed to sell operations in Texas and Louisiana for $25.5 million to Associated Milk Producers Inc., a dairy cooperative in Arlington, Tex. The sale includes the operations of Schepps Dairy in Dallas as well as other facilities in Dallas, in San Antonio and in Shreveport, La.

There are three rules to running for mayor of Chicago. Unfortunately, no one knows what they are. So this week with the campaign already well under way but its form and direction far from clear, more than a half-dozen hopeful men and women are seriously scrambling around the nation's third-largest city, organizing their own campaigns and their own sets of rules. And more than 300 other candidates are running for the 50 seats on the City Council.

As Louisiana bickers over solutions to its oil-related economic crunch, a quieter but no less acid dispute is simmering over an aquarium proposed for the French Quarter. A bitter fight against the aquarium has begun within the leafy courtyards and graceful architecture of the quarter, the old city settled by the French in the 18th century. The historic district is now a prime tourist attraction. For those who live there, the fight is another battle in the war against creeping commercialism, which they say is hurting the residential and historic character of the Vieux Carre. Preservationists are preparing to challenge the aquarium project in court.

Hundreds of friends and relatives filled the small Our Lady of Charity Catholic Church last night for the funeral of Michael Griffith, the 23-year-old black man who was killed last week in a racially motivated assault in Howard Beach. More than 400 people filled every corner of the brightly lit 250-seat chapel and spilled into the darkened streets of the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn. Television camermen and most other reporters were kept outside during the two-hour ceremony, which was led by an multiracial group of clergymen.

The quarterback is not only the most glamorous player in football, he is a symbolic figure, too. He represents stability in a sport with a high turnover rate. He is a leader, by design, if not nature, the coach's emissary on the playing field. Running backs may tumble and defenses crumble, but a quarterback is expected to withstand a blitz of adversity. When the Giants' golden era of the 1950's and early 60's ended in 1964, no words could have captured their demise any better than the photograph of Y. A. Tittle - the grounded bald eagle - on his hands and knees, bloodied and dazed, after being battered during an early-season game against the Pittsburgh Steelers.

For a while now the Transit Authority has been taking its message directly to its customers, informing riders in black-and-orange-bordered signs of line reroutings and major service delays. Lately, though, the news from the authority's Jay Street headquarters has been distinctly upbeat. A new batch of signs, put up in stations, cars and buses, extol the virtues of the authority's reconstruction efforts. ''New and Overhauled Cars - Subway cars like they ought to be'' is the headline on one. ''Fast Track - the trains are getting up to speed again'' reads another. ''The concept started over the summer,'' said a spokesman, Donna Evans. ''We felt it was one of the best ways we can get information to passengers on why service was delayed. And we figured while we were putting them up we should tell them what we're doing to the system, tell them the good news, too.''

Katie Wells was born in 1981 with serious birth defects. Her parents attributed them to a contraceptive jelly and sued the maker, Ortho Pharmaceutical. Judge Marvin Shoob of the U.S. District Court in Georgia ruled they had proved their case and assessed $5 million in damages against Ortho. The Court of Appeals declined to overturn the judgment and last month the Supreme Court refused to intervene. What is wrong with that?

For 130 years the bell at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church pealed each Sunday to call worshipers to the imposing white structure, a center of community life that was built in 1810. Today the bell. cast in 1858, and the large three-faced clock from the church steeple sat in puddles of water left on the floor by firefighters after a fire broke out 10 hours after the Christmas service, leaving only a shell. ''It wasn't just a church,'' said Louise Newcombe, 50 years old. She is not a member of the 800-family parish, which was established in 1725, but she was in St. Andrew's every week anyway.

It may be an unusual toy, but 6-year-old Ritchie Alegre and a friend finally persuaded his father to buy one - a genuine, 70,000-pound, World War II-vintage Sherman tank in working order. Dick Alegre, 57, a farmer, apartment landlord and self-described tinkerer, was known among youngsters in this community for not finishing what he set out to do.

Gaye and Roy Raymond scored a smashing success with Victoria's Secret, a small chain of stores offering fine lingerie directly and by mail order: In 1982, they sold the chain to The Limited for a reported $4 million. But their efforts to score again with My Child's Destiny, selling elegant -and elegantly priced - children's products, did not fare nearly as well. In October, four years after they invested their personal profits from Victoria's in the new business, they filed for Chapter 11 protection, ending their catalogue sales and closing the doors of their children's department store here. Baby Bjorn Potty Chair The concept was a simple one: well-heeled parents could shop for everything from an Apple computer to a Baby Bjorn imported Swedish potty chair to a Galway Irish crystal baby bottle labeled ''for decorative use only - not to be used to feed baby,'' all under one roof, or by catalogue. The Raymonds figured that imported clothing, home computers and quality toys would hold great attraction for the growing number of professional couples having their first, and possibly only, child.

The lobbying response to the report of the President's Commission on Americans Outdoors is heavy, heated and starting to turn a bit nasty. And the report won't even be issued for several more weeks. Enough information has trickled out about the draft report to raise hopes and hackles in various quarters of the nation's capital. The draft report recommends that at least $1 billion a year be put into a new trust fund to acquire, preserve and protect some of the nation's remaining open space. It also calls for the creation of protected ''greenways,'' open, natural corridors between urban centers, some of them along rivers. Among its many other proposals is a call for a new ''outdoor ethic'' under which Americans would be encouraged to value and protect natural areas.

To the Editor: A Dec. 7 front-page article exposes the increasingly serious problem of the rise in truck accidents across the country. Crashes involving big trucks kill 4,500 people each year, and it is auto occupants whose safety is most in jeopardy.

Four Cubans, one of them dead, were found floating on a makeshift inner-tube raft in the Straits of Florida off Key West on Christmas Day, the Coast Guard reported today. Officials said the men had been adrift for four days. Two of the survivors were turned over to immigration officials and the third was taken to Florida Keys Memorial Hospital for treatment of exposure.

Here in eastern Nevada, everything is dry: The climate, the rivers, the humor. ''We like to say that nobody moves to Baker - they're committed here,'' said Reita Berger, co-owner of the Outlaw Bar and Cafe on Main Street. ''There's not much to see in Baker,'' said Mrs. Berger's daughter, Marie Jordan. ''But what you hear makes up for it.''

International 2-8 A special White House team on Iran will be created by President Reagan to coordinate the Administration's responses about the Iran-contra arms deals, and it will be headed by David M. Abshire, the departing delegate to NATO. Page 1 Mr. Abshire, a Republican, is adept at dealing with both parties. As the U.S. delegate to NATO since 1983, he has urged bipartisan consensus in foreign policy and has kept Congressional contacts. 8 Beijing limited demonstrations in an effort to head off new protests in the city by students demanding democracy. At the same time, 10,000 students marched in Nanjing, the capital of Jiangsu province.

A major diplomatic dispute has erupted over the itinerary here of the Archbishop of New York during a Middle East trip in which he plans to visit Israel beginning Jan. 1. The argument grows out of what Israeli officials say are changes that the Vatican and the Archbishop, John Cardinal O'Connor, want to make in whom he will meet and where he will meet them during an official four-day visit to Jerusalem. The thrust of these changes, Israeli officials said today, appeared to be an effort to eliminate any hint that Cardinal O'Connor was having official political contacts with the Israeli Government or recognizing its control over Jerusalem. However, the Cardinal's office in New York said today that the unanticipated appointment of a new Auxiliary Bishop for New York had made it necessary for the Cardinal to be in Rome by the evening of Jan. 5, requiring him to shorten his stay in Israel and cancel a stop in Egypt. Comments on Palestinians The origins of the Cardinal's trip lie in comments he made last June, in which he spoke of how, from ''a moral perspective,'' it was clear that ''a homeland has to be provided for the Palestinian peoples.'' His remarks were criticized by some American Jewish groups, who urged Shimon Peres, then Prime Minister, to meet with Cardinal O'Connor.

Amid a flurry of conflicting claims of responsibility by anonymous callers, Iran yesterday dismissed accusations by Iraq and Jordan that it was behind the hijacking of an Iraqi airliner in which Saudi Arabia has said 62 people were killed. The Iranian statement, reported in a state radio broadcast that was monitored in Cyprus, was issued as callers claiming to speak for four different groups said they were responsible. The Iraqi Airways Boeing 737 crashed in a remote desert region in northern Saudi Arabia Thursday after being commandeered by armed men who, according to witnesses, subsequently battled with security men as the crew struggled to control the plane. Government sources in Amman said the gunmen confessed to Saudi interrogators that they had planned to take the plane to Damascus and on to Teheran. But the Saudi Government, which provided the first official announcement of the crash, remained silent about the hijacking, and questions remained about many aspects of the disaster, including the number of people on board the flight, the number who died or were injured, the number of hijackers involved, and to what group, if any, they were linked.

The pilots of Voyager are set for more globe-trotting, this time using more conventional means for a more mundane purpose. The pilots, Dick Rutan and Jeana Yeager, are seeking publicity in an effort to recoup the cost of their historic, nonstop, unrefueled flight around the world. They began their publicity blitz this morning with appearances on all three television network news programs. ''We had a lot of enjoyment out of it, and I'm just real thrilled that a lot of other people kind of shared it with us, and we're certainly happy to share it with them,'' Mr. Rutan said on the ''CBS Morning News.''

WHEN W. C. Hall Jr., pastor of the Asbury United Methodist Church in Pasadena, Tex., went shopping in midtown Manhattan in New York in May, he found what he thought was the deal of a lifetime, a $48,000 Hereke Oriental carpet for only $5,000. Mr. Hall said that at Nikora International, a store at 727 Seventh Avenue, Jimmy Sultan, a salesman, showed him a book that said Hereke rugs, woven in Turkey in the 19th century, usually cost at least $1,700 per sqare foot. The carpet Mr. Hall was considering was 3 feet by 5 feet, a $25,500 value by that estimate; Mr. Sultan told him it was worth $48,000. He said Mr. Sultan told him the store was willing to sacrifice its usual markup because it needed cash to buy the building it was in.

Misleading information about the risk of a new strain of influenza has led to a shortage of the vaccine, a consumer group has charged. The Public Citizen Health Research Group, in a letter earlier this week to the Secretary of Health and Human Services, charged that misinformation about the Taiwan A flu from the Government and the National Foundation for Infectious Diseases had prompted many doctors to give the vaccine to people who did not need it.

Allan Mannarelli, 30 years old, and Erik Jacobs, 27, eventually want to take over Gulf and Western and sign themselves as players for the Knicks. In the meantime they are slum busters. They take New York buildings where rent strikes, squatters and drug dealers are commonplace and make them profitable without evictions. In a generation in which living well and making money are the standards of success, Mr. Mannarelli and Mr. Jacobs are misfits. Theirs is a hand-to-mouth entrepreneurship and a full-time occupation, providing a modest 10 percent return on their holdings -seven Harlem buildings with an annual rent roll of about $750,000.

Over the past few months, just about every kind of complaint has been registered about this column, from disparagement of mother's home cooking to the use of slang, from an inability to find a recommended store to the proper method for opening a pomegranate. But before pomegranates, a word from maligned mothers who think their cooking is better than that of any restaurant. A quote from the letter of an angry 70-year-old mother is typical of response to the column in which several American chefs said their mothers did not cook very well. A Mother Complains ''Im so sick and tired of people putting down real mothers,'' she wrote. The further she got into the letter the angrier she became, and the rest of what she had to say cannot be printed.

It's catching. While he was chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities, William J. Bennett occasionally visited schools to teach a class, and he has continued the practice in his new job as Secretary of Education.

Just when it seemed that the controversy over New Zealand's fiberglass hull was a dead issue in America's Cup racing, the debate has resurfaced. The French Kiss syndicate has asked organizers of the challengers' races for more thorough testing of the New Zealand boat.

Marcia Miller has been hired by the incoming Democratic majority to become a trade specialist for the Senate Finance Committee, an indication that the panel will make a strong push for some kind of legislation to protect textiles against lower-priced imports, since that is a field in which Miss Miller has a strong background. Miss Miller had been working as an economist for John D. Greenwald, a lawyer with the firm of Wilmer Cutler & Pickering who is chief counsel for the American Textile Manufacturers Institute.

With a sales surge in the final week, the 1986 Christmas shopping season ended strongly but with less than the normal seasonal increases, retailers around the nation said yesterday. ''We had a strong finish that pulled everything out,'' said Elliott J. Stone, chairman of the Jordan-Marsh Company, the Boston-based chain of 19 department stores that is New England's largest. Ric Wanetik, senior vice president, sales promotion, of Chicago-based Marshall Field & Company, which operates 25 department stores, said, ''It came late, but the last week was surprisingly strong and helped us exceed our expectations.'' 'Very Small Improvement' In New York, Robin Farkas, chairman of Alexander's Inc., with 14 stores in the metropolitan area, reported that the company had a ''very small improvement over last year.''

Japan's exports of cars, trucks and buses fell 15.1 percent in November from a year earlier, to 516,928 units, the sharpest decline on record, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said today.

THE BROOM OF THE SYSTEM. By David Foster Wallace. 467 pages. Viking. Cloth, $18.95; paper, $7.95. This novel, chosen by Viking to kick off its new series of contemporary American fiction, was written by a 24-year-old graduate of Amherst College who is working for his M.F.A. at the University of Arizona. It's an unwieldy, uneven work - by turns, hilarious and stultifying, daring and derivative - but at the same time, it's a novel that attests to the publishers's committment to risky new fiction and its young author's rich reserves of ambition and imagination.

Two Mexicans have been arrested in Los Angeles in connection with the murder of a United States drug agent who was kidnapped and tortured last year while working in Mexico, Federal officials said today. The Drug Enforcement Administration said the two men were being charged with violations of Federal narcotics laws and were also being accused of taking part in a conspiracy to kidnap and murder the drug agent, Enrique Camarena Salazar. Mr. Camarena Salazar was abducted in Guadalajara on Feb. 7, 1985. His beaten body, wrapped in a plastic bag, was found a month later.

My name's Hudge. I was details man at the White House. Had the job through five Presidencies. It's not political, just a housekeeping job, like being White House barber. All you do is keep track of details. This leads to some funny experiences.

The lawyer for a victim of the racially motivated beatings in Howard Beach, Queens, last Saturday charged yesterday that the driver of the car that killed one of the victims was a willful participant in the attack from the beginning. The attorney, Alton H. Maddox Jr., said both the police and the Queens District Attorney had known that his client, Cedric Sandiford, made the allegation the night of the attack and they had failed to act on it. ''I think this raises serious questions about the integrity of the investigation,'' Mr. Maddox said at a news conference. Reaction by Santucci But the police, providing for the first time a detailed account of the motorist's actions, sharply contradicted the charges. They also disclosed that a woman had been with the driver, Dominick Blum, at the time of the crash. [ Page 26. ] The prosecutor, John J. Santucci, said at another news conference that it was the first time he had heard Mr. Sandiford's allegation. He said it would be ''virtually impossible'' for anyone to identify the driver of the car that night on the Shore Parkway or for an attacker involved in chasing the three black men to time his entrance to the highway so as to deliberately hit someone.

There is a foreboding implication in the current year-end deluge of fund-raising appeals: give now - before it is too late. The implication is that the tradition of charitable giving in America is linked inextricably to the tax benefits it yields and that therefore the charitable impulse will disappear at midnight on Jan. 1, when tax reform takes effect. This notion is both false and disturbing. It stems from the unspoken assumption that all behavior is dictated solely by economic gain. It distorts, to the detriment of donor and recipient, the fundamental nature and purpose of gift-giving.
Marie Bullock, founder and president of the Academy of American Poets, died Thursday at her home in Manhattan after a long illness. She was 75 years old.

It was the latest in a 500-year-old tradition of clever theories explaining the sly smile, the veiled hair, the crossed hands, the regal pose: the Mona Lisa was not a woman at all, but a man. She was, in fact, Leonardo da Vinci himself in the guise of a woman. The theory was put forward in a magazine, Art and Antiques, last week, and within hours it became elevator chat and cocktail party conversation. At the Louvre in Paris -as happens with every flare of publicity about what is arguably the world's most famous painting - the crowds swelled around the work.

Facilities for producing America's nuclear warheads are decrepit, safety procedures lax and management complacent. The Reagan Administration did not create these problems but it has made them worse. It doubled production of nuclear warheads since 1980, mostly for new weapons ordered by the Carter Administration, but spent little to modernize the aging plant. Now, maybe just in time to avert a serious accident, the Department of Energy has placed some plants under new management and ordered others shut down. It's a step toward protecting health, and national security, but too small and too aimless.

Rabbis Shmuel M. Butman, left, and David Raskin lighting a huge menorah at Fifth Avenue and 59th Street last evening, the start of the eight-day celebration of the Jewish holiday of Hanukkah. Shoppers crowded stores yesterday, a bonus holiday for many, for after-Christmas bargains. Page 27. (NYT/Ruby Washington)

W. R. Grace & Company, which has been undergoing a major restructuring, completed the sale of its 690-unit restaurant group to a new company led by the group's management. Grace said the purchase price of $536.7 million might be adjusted, depending on the new company's performance, but a spokesman said that Grace expected to make a profit on the deal.

David M. Abshire, the 60-year-old foreign-policy professional named by President Reagan to help steer the White House through the Iran-contra arms crisis, is an affable and undramatic Republican who has proved adept at working with both parties. As Washington's delegate to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization since 1983, he has urged bipartisan consensus in foreign policy, has maintained close contacts with both Republicans and Democrats on Capitol Hill and has written of the need for Presidential consultation with Congress. Western diplomats have given Mr. Abshire high marks during his tenure at NATO, praising his energy and enthusiasm in fostering consultations among allies, improving efficiency and lobbying members of Congress by telephone from Brussels when sentiment arose in 1984 to withdraw United States troops from Western Europe. He has been one of the Administration's most articulate advocates of a new generation of American chemical weapons, arguing that they, and not nuclear arms, are the appropriate deterrent to Soviet use of chemical weapons in Europe.
Cavaliers' John Williams going up against two Net defenders as he took a shot in the first quarter last night. Cavaliers won, 121-112. (UPI)

Hungary and Rumania are engaged in an increasingly public struggle over one of this region's historically divisive issues: minority rights. Experts on regional affairs say that not since the creation of the Soviet bloc at the end of World War II has there been such open and sustained tension between two members. They say that, although the disagreement does not put into question loyalty to Moscow, the surfacing of the long-submerged rivalry indicates a new will to assert conflicting national interests and demonstrate the less than monolithic nature of the Soviet camp. At issue are the ethnically Hungarian people who have been living under Rumanian rule since Transylvania, once part of the Austro-Hungarian empire, was assigned to Rumania after World War I. They are said to number between 1.7 million and 2 million.

Although she is at least in her 80's and uses a wheelchair, Mrs. Chiang Kai-shek casts a long and perplexing shadow over Taiwan's politics. Mrs. Chiang moved to the United States shortly after her husband died in 1975 and lived there for 11 years. She returned to Taiwan in October to celebrate the 100th anniversary of his birth, and this capital city is full of theories about what she is up to. Although she was born Mei-ling Soong, she is best known, in Chinese as well as English, as Mrs. Chiang Kai-shek. Her husband ruled China until 1949, when Communist forces triumphed on the mainland, and then he governed the island of Taiwan.

As the New York metropolitan region's problems with transportation, energy, water, affordable housing and garbage continue to grow, appearing to become more intractable each day, business and academic leaders are renewing calls for some form of regional government. The calls, which are perhaps being heard the loudest on Long Island, are from some of the most influential people in the region, many of whom are saying that local governments, from municipalities to counties, cannot handle their troubles by working alone. ''We must find a way to govern ourselves as a total, interrelated and interdependent community rather than as a series of independent and competing townships, each with its own bureaucracy,'' said John C. Bierwirth, chairman of the Grumman Corporation, Long Island's largest employer. Reluctant to Change Mr. Bierwirth, who recently delivered a blunt speech about Long Island's future, described municipal handling of solid waste management as ''pathetic'' and the fight over the Shoreham nuclear power plant as a ''depressing spectacle of political and business paralysis.'' Even with comments like Mr. Bierwirth's, which were echoed by business leaders across the region, most government officials appeared reluctant to endorse significant change in how municipalities and counties operate. They say they fear the imposition of yet another governmental layer or just as significant, the loss of home rule.

Davis Cup Tennis Swedes Tie Australians: Mikael Pernfors, who had played only four previous matches on grass, scored a surprise 6-3, 6-1, 6-3 victory over Paul McNamee yesterday and lifted Sweden into a 1-1 tie with Sweden in the Davis Cup final in Melbourne, Australia. Pat Cash gave Australia its victory by outlasting Stefan Edberg, Sweden's No. 1 player, 13-11, 13-11, 6-4. Pernfors, who played tennis at the University of Georgia, stunned a sellout crowd of 11,000 with his 91-minute victory over the 32-year-old McNamee.(AP) Horse Racing Ferdinand Returns in Form: Ferdinand, the Kentucky Derby winner, making his first start in six months, came from well off the pace yesterday to score a 1 1/4-length victory over Snow Chief in the $117,300 Malibu Stakes at Santa Anita in Arcadia, Calif. Ferdinand was timed in 1:21 3/5, well off the track record of 1:20 set by Spectacular Bid in this event in 1980. Ridden by Bill Shoemaker, Ferdinand was last at the start of the seven-furlong race, but worked his way through the field of 12 until the stretch. There, he caught Snow Chief in the final quarter and pulled away for the triumph. Snow Chief, also making his first start in six months, held on for second. A long shot, Don B. Blue, was third.(UPI) M.I.S.L.

The Kansas City Chiefs are one of those middle-of-the pack playoff teams that scare the opponent. ''What worries me are their intangibles,'' said Barry Bennett, a Jet defensive end. ''Sometimes that's more frightening than their offense.''

The Israeli Foreign Minister, Shimon Peres, says a negotiated solution to the Palestinian problem based on ''an equal right to a life of dignity and self-expression'' seems more imaginable now than ever before. And, Mr. Peres says, peace in the Middle East may be closer even though there was no visible progress toward a settlement in 1986.

One result of the 1986 tax law that few people in or out of Congress anticipated is that life insurance companies have a greater incentive to acquire brokerage firms. Although some insurers have already built a stake on Wall Street, executives in the field and securities analysts see a new push developing. The key reason is that with individual income tax rates lower and capital gains rates higher under the new law, many of the insurance products sold by brokers have become more attractive to investors. These products include single-premium life insurance and other policies that benefit from cash value buildup free from current tax. ''The law may encourage some of the larger companies to look at stock brokerage firms because they'll be looking at expanded distribution efforts,'' said Fred Townsend, an analyst at Conning & Company, based in Hartford, which specializes in insurance stocks. ''Stockbrokers are sort of a natural avenue.''

To the Editor: Steven J. Yohay, president of the Areba-Casriel Institute, says (letter, Dec. 4): ''That tradition began 17 years ago, when the namesake of the program I head, Dr. Dan Casriel, founded Daytop Village.'' That is not the fact. Joseph A. Shelly, former chief probation officer of the probation department of Kings County Supreme Court conceived the idea of starting a drug-free facility for treating drug users in the late 1950's. He enlisted the support of the professional staff of his department in that undertaking. Dr. Alexander Bassin, then a case supervisor and director of education and research of Kings County's probation department (he is now professor of psychology in the School of Criminology, Florida State University, Tallahassee) wrote the proposal, and the grant was made by the National Institutes of Mental Health.

The White House announced today that President Reagan was creating a special team to coordinate the Administration's responses and strategy in the Iran-contra arms affair, and that it would be headed by David M. Abshire, the departing delegate to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. The announcement said the President had appointed Mr. Abshire to coordinate ''responses to Congressional and other requests for information in a timely manner.'' Mr. Abshire is expected to have direct access to Mr. Reagan and is to serve as an adviser to the President. To Draw From Other Offices The working group Mr. Abshire will direct is to comprise officials detached from other White House offices, such as press, legal and Congressional relations, officials said. But there was no word on how large a staff Mr. Abshire would have. There was also no announcement on where the office would be situated.

The game's pivotal play tonight was a personal matter, and a novelty, shared by a rookie goaltender from Washington and a seasoned Islander forward. Bob Mason, who has become something of a savior for the struggling Capitals, had never faced a penalty shot in his life and was attempting to preserve a 2-1 lead that suddenly was very much in jeopardy. Brent Sutter, the center who foraged on Mason's doorstep much of the evening, had never in his National Hockey League career been put in the role of the soloist who skates from center ice headlong toward a waiting goalie. Tonight, Sutter was awarded his shot after being tripped by Mike Gartner on a breakaway attempt 6 minutes 22 seconds into the third period. He checked his stick as he sprinted toward the crouching Mason, and he also recalled some advice from Mike Bossy, who told him to blast the puck point-blank at a goalie whenever he got the chance for a private confrontation.

Bobby Joe Leaster with his fiancee, June Wallace, in Boston after a Suffolk County prosecutor announced yesterday that Mr. Leaster would not be tried again in a 1970 slaying. He had served 15 years in prison for the murder of a variety store owner during a robbery. He was released last month when his conviction was overturned as new evidence cast doubt on his guilt. (AP)

People returning Christmas presents collided in the department stores aisles yesterday with people shopping for Hanukkah presents. People who had not yet sent cards for Christmas 1986 were lined up behind people buying marked-down cards for Christmas 1987. And for the fourth year, Gordon and Carol Swan came in from South Bend, Ind., to celebrate the wedding anniversary of their son, Rory, and daughter-in-law, Julie, even though the elder Swans were recently divorced. ''We'll have drinks at the Plaza, do Trump Tower, go to all the places we always go,'' said Julie Swan, a sales representative for the 1928 Jewelry company. ''It sounds strange but my in-laws are very civilized.''
Park Communications Inc., a newspaper publisher and operator of television and radio stations, announced today that it had acquired The Milton (Pa.)

This was the night that Kelly Kisio was officially discovered by the Rangers. First he scooted down the middle of the ice and scored with the quickest of wrist shots over the goalie's right shoulder. Second, he broke down the middle and scored. And third, he broke down the middle and scored.

Many companies in the New York metropolitan area are contributors to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. Among them are the Color Film Corporation of Stamford, Conn., $1,000; the Theodore Williams Construction Company of Manhattan, $300; Eli Cohen Real Estate of Teaneck, N.J., $1,000; Lazarow & Company, of Manhattan, $2,000; Paul A. Downey, investment banker in Manhattan, $2,000, the Maxam Group Inc. in Manhattan, $50, and Pratesi Linens in Manhattan, $100. Also, Spartan Display Inc., in Manhattan, $750; PKO Television Ltd., in Manhattan, $1,000; the Cromwell Leather Company in Larchmont, N.Y., $50; the Component Hardware Group Inc., in Lakewood, N.J., $100; Henry Weingartner & Company in Scarsdale, N.Y., $25.

President Daniel Ortega Saavedra has proposed that Nicaraguan rebels in Honduras be returned under an amnesty program or sent to other countries, the official Barricada newspaper reported today. The newspaper, voice of the governing Sandinista National Liberation Front, said the plan presented to President Jose Azcona Hoyo of Honduras also provided for the repatriation of Nicaraguan refugees living in Honduras.

PAUL CAPELLI, a young executive, came to New York from another state recently to start a new job and, like many other transferees, decided to open a checking account at a local bank. However, every bank Mr. Capelli contacted insisted on different forms of documentation and verification before he would be allowed to become a depositor. After settling on Citibank, he had to return to the nearby branch three different times before his records from his previous bank were accepted - the Citibank officer wanted the most recent statement from his previous bank, not an earlier one - and the account was opened. ''I had a hassle,'' Mr. Capelli said. ''It was pretty frustrating, because they seem to make it more complicated than it should be. And even after opening the account, they told me it takes four to five working days before I could begin writing checks.''

Mail carriers, just relieved of their heavy burden of Christmas cards and packages, today began to deliver nearly 100 million pieces of much less welcome mail - 1986 tax forms.
