The Internal Revenue Service said it was sending out 85 million forms, but a spokesman for the Postal Service said the figure was probably closer to 100 million.

Western Europe's food surpluses, which have saddled taxpayers with crippling bills and created sharp political tensions with the rest of the world, are now threatening to push the European Community into bankruptcy early next year. The community's 12 member states are storing 1.5 million tons of excess butter and nearly three-quarters of a million tons of unwanted beef. Another million tons of surplus milk is stored in powdered form. Western Europe's grain mountain currently stands at close to 17 million tons, stockpiled in regiments of ugly concrete silos that disfigure the countryside. And some 300 million gallons of undrinkable rotgut are swilling around in its ''wine lake.''

Coal miners were working alongside men installing new equipment when a fatal methane gas explosion rocked a Ukrainian coal mine this week, Soviet reports said today. Reports by the Soviet press agency Tass and Soviet television, which sent a reporter to the Yasinovskaya-Glubokaya mine in the coal-rich Donets region 575 miles south of Moscow, did not include a casualty figure for the disaster. The television report revealed that the accident occurred at about 11:15 A.M. Wednesday after a sudden buildup of methane gas in the mine's No. 7 shaft.

Increasing economic pressures will force more doctors to seek salaried jobs with established health-care organizations rather than to open private practices, a new report concludes. The report, prepared by the American Medical Association's Council on Long-Range Planning and Development, said one effect of the trend would be that doctors in health-care organizations might become too cost-conscious. The report was published in the current issue of The Journal of the American Medical Association.

A $43.6 million award to thousands of retired men who contended that Florida's retirement system for government workers was sexually biased has been upheld by a Federal appeals court. The decision by a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit affects 11,600 former state, county, and local government employees.

Trying to set a national example in Washington, the American Trucking Association is planning to operate a two-car ''safety patrol'' on the Capital Beltway around the city, reporting unsafe acivities by truckers to their employers and, if necessary, to the police. Beginning in February, the association will staff the patrol with ''experienced safety professionals,'' who will also monitor the language truckers use on citizens' band radio ''to insure CB's are used for their intended purpose.'' The association hopes the trucking industry will undertake similar campaigns in other cities.

The Soviet Union's first solar power station began commercial service in the Ukraine today, the official press agency Tass said. Tass said the station, with a capacity of 5,000 kilowatts, was in the Crimean peninsula, but it did not give an exact location.

Egypt's Defense Minister said today that the use of more advanced weapons by both sides in the Iran-Iraq war carried an increased risk that hostilities would spread to neighboring countries. Moreover, he said, hopes for a cease-fire ''are diminishing.'' The Defense Minister, Abdel Halim Abu Ghazala, who is also Deputy Prime Minister, said possibilities that the conflict would worsen had increased in a way that would menace Egypt's interests, those of the region and those of the West. ''There is no way to predict the course of the Iran-Iraq war,'' he said. ''Most of the fixed elements of the old formula become variables,'' he said, apparently referring to the changes imposed on standard military assumptions in the region by the introduction of new weapons technology. ''The old variables become more variable.''

Tom Osborne, the Nebraska football coach, whose team has a New Year's Day date with Louisiana State in the Sugar Bowl, blamed the arrests of nine of his players early Wednesday in the French Quarter of New Orleans on a police misunderstanding. The nine were detained after what the police said was a warning issued for unruly behavior that included shouting obscenities and whacking parked cars. All were immediately released by a traffic judge, and Osborne said no disciplinary action was planned.

There is only one creature who would come up with the notion of holding onto a balloon to float across the sky to attract bees to get some honey. That creature, of course, is that bear of all bears, the venerable Winnie the Pooh, who this year celebrated his 60th birthday. It was in England in 1926 that A. A. Milne first published the antics of Winnie the Pooh. That he continues to be a hero in Britain and the United States should hardly come as a suprise, but last year Milne's books sold more than 3.5 million copies in the Soviet Union, where he is known simply as ''Vinnie,'' or, more formally, ''Vinnie Pookh.''

High-technology companies and their financial backers are strongly criticizing a proposed accounting change that could threaten the use by such companies of employee stock options for financing and to attract and keep talented employees. The worries of entrepreneurial companies, like those in Silicon Valley, have been touched off by the Financial Accounting Standards Board's re-evaluation of accounting standards used for employee stock options since 1972. The F.A.S.B. has tentatively concluded that companies should assign a value to such options, which would then be charged against earnings as compensation expense. Options typically allow an employee to buy shares within some specified time period at a set exercise price.

The MCI Communications Corporation said that its write-offs in the fourth quarter would total between $500 million and $550 million. The estimate is at the low end of the range of $500 million to $700 million that the long-distance telephone company, based in Washington, had projected early this month when it announced plans to reduce spending, consolidate operations and lay off a portion of its work force. In over-the-counter trading yesterday, MCI's shares closed at $6.625, down 12.5 cents.

In May 1919, students in this port city, following the lead of students in Beijing, organized a city-wide protest against the Chinese Government's humiliating capitulation to Japan's colonial designs. On street corners and in parks, students harangued crowds of Shanghai residents to oppose the Government's meek attitude toward Japan's claim on the province of Shandong. Students marched the streets lecturing and cajoling merchants to boycott Japanese-made products. The ubiquitous broad-brimmed straw hats that students wore disappeared overnight, replaced by simple white cloth caps when it was discovered that the straw hats were fabricated in Japan.

Ann Dore McLaughlin, the Under Secretary of the Interior who has been mentioned frequently as a possible successor to Larry Speakes as the White House spokesman, plans to resign her post soon, but to work in private industry and lecture, not to speak on behalf of the President. Since Nancy Reagan has expressed the hope that President Reagan will select a woman as his next spokesman, Mrs. McLaughlin's action would seem to enhance the chances of another woman who has been mentioned for the White House job, Sheila Tate. Mrs. Tate once served as the Mrs. Reagan's press secretary.

Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir leaving district court yesterday in Tel Aviv after he became the first Israeli prime minister to testify in a criminal trial. Mr. Shamir appeared for the defense in the case of Shmuel Einav, who is accused of bribing officials for permits to sell land in the occupied West Bank. Mr. Shamir testified that he had met with the defendant several times during the Likud bloc's 1984 election campaign, but that he had never discussed campaign contributions with him. (AP)

The police said yesterday that their investigation of the accident in Howard Beach, Queens, that killed Michael Griffith indicated that the motorist who struck him was not an accomplice of the white youths accused of his murder. In doing so, they contradicted a lawyer for one of the two other blacks who were victims of the attacks that preceeded the crash. They also provided for the first time a detailed account of the actions and movements of the motorist, Dominick Blum, on the day and evening before the crash, which occurred on the Shore Parkway about 1 A.M. last Saturday. The police account contained much new information, such as the fact that Mr. Blum was not alone in his car at the time of the crash, and it corrected some previous misinformation, such as where Mr. Blum lives.

Medical malpractice suits are at crisis proportions; we've been hearing about them for years. At the same time, the question of whom or what to blame has been elusive. ''Diagnosis: Malpractice,'' an ABC ''Closeup'' documentary to be broadcast at 10 o'clock tonight on Channel 7, fixes the primary blame in the obvious and most sensible place: the malpractice crisis is caused by malpractice.

One is tightly wound, deer-like, spectacular. The other is controlled, keeping thoughts to himself, able to concentrate in a crowd. Together, the speedy Wesley Walker and the single-minded Al Toon formed one of the most dangerous receiving tandems in Jets' history as the club surged to its league-best 10-1 mark. But that seems almost a season ago instead of only last month. Now, after a five-game losing streak, the pair will have a new quarterback throwing to them in their most critical game of the season - tomorrow's wild-card playoff affair against the Kansas City Chiefs.
Fireboats spraying a fire that destroyed 170 junks yesterday in a cove on the Hong Kong waterfront.

When the Beirut magazine Al Shiraa reported in early November that a former United States national security adviser had been to Iran to sell weapons, it touched off a controversy that continues to reverberate. That a scoop of such dimensions could be scored by a Beirut magazine has shown that, despite 11 years of civil war in Lebanon, Beirut continues to be a major listening post for the Middle East. Al Shiraa said it was not serving any political motive when it reported that the former security adviser, Robert C. McFarlane, had been to Teheran to offer arms and improvement in American-Iranian relations to the Government of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.

In blackface and clown-white makeup, minstrels of the 1800's were gawkers and buffoons, high steppers and jokesters who lived an illusion on stage through a mask of thick makeup. These were the early entertainers who intrigued the playwright Samm-Art Williams, whose latest play, ''Cork,'' explored the feelings of black minstrels and the reasons they participated in an entertainment genre that established and perpetuated negative stereotypes of black people in America. ''I have a tremendous respect for the minstrels because they paved the way for black entertainers today,'' Mr. Williams said recently. ''Minstrelsy was wrong. But black minstrels were talented performers, and we have turned our backs on them and the conditions in which they had to perform.''
BASKETBALL KNICKS VS. MILWAUKEE BUCKS, at Madison Square Garden, 7:30 P.M. (TV -MSG, 7 P.M.; Radio - WPAT 930 7:20 P.M.) NETS VS.

Life is getting easier. I know, because I had to take a lesson to learn how to use my new telephone, which, once I master the instructions, is supposed to save me time and trouble. The company I work for recently installed an updated ''communications system'' known as the SL-100, which I assume stands for ''Submarine Launched - 100 megatons.''

Hiromitsu Ochiai, a three-time triple crown winner in the Japanese Baseball League, was traded last Tuesday by the Lotte Orions to the Chunichi Dragons. Yesterday, he signed a contract worth 130 million yen ($807,000) for next year, which would make him the first Japanese baseball player to earn more than 100 million yen ($621,000) in a season. The Kyodo News Service said the agreement marked an estimated increase of 33 million yen ($207,000) over 1986.

The New York Cornet and Sackbut Ensemble, featuring the soprano Julianne Baird, will present vocal and instrumental works of the Renaissance at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street tomorrow night at 8. Admission is $8.50; information: 362-8719.

In the 25 days since he woke up one morning to find himself a head coach for the first time, Bob Hill has lost 15 pounds. He said he sometimes forgets to eat. He hasn't slept much, either, which becomes evident as he yawns uncontrollably just a few minutes into a conversation. So there was the thought that Hill might have been the one to leap into the arms of Patrick Ewing following the Knick center's game-winning shot Thursday against the Chicago Bulls.

Iraq regained control today of four islands in a waterway dividing Iran and Iraq after a 24-hour Iranian offensive, United States Government officials said. Both Iraq and Iran said they had inflicted heavy casualties on the other during Iran's brief attack on Iraqi positions on four islands in the Shatt al Arab, a waterway near the major Iraqi city of Basra. Administration analysts said they could not judge the magnitude of the losses, but said the Iranian operation was clearly a limited one, and not the ''final offensive'' long promised by Iranian leaders to win the six-year-old war. Since last summer, 700,000 Iranian soldiers have been stationed along the southern front near Basra, presumably in preparation for the ''final offensive.'' Iranian leaders have apparently been wary of committing their forces against 500,000 Iraqis, equipped with superior armor and air power, American officials said today.

Questions appear on page 5. 1. Mordechai Vanunu, an Israeli nuclear technician who sold information about his country's atomic weapons program to a British newspaper and then was mysteriously returned to Israel, held up his hand to journalists as he was taken to court in Jerusalem. The message said he had been abducted by Israelis in Rome after arriving there on a flight from London. 2. Rescind the state holiday honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. 3. Paper. 4. Chinatown. 5. A public-opinion poll published in The Des Moines Register showed that Mr. Bush's standing among voters in that state, the site of the first major test in the 1988 Presidential campaign, has plummeted as a result of the Iranian arms controversy. 6. The Greyhound Corporation is selling its bus operations. 7. The French Government's Center of Mail Research, which is the place in France that receives letters addressed to Santa Claus, is in the Gironde, one of the country's richest wine regions. 8. Texas. 9. The first Teflon-coated cookware to be produced in the United States. 10. Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet dissident, was warmly greeted on his return to Moscow after seven years of exile in Gorky. 11. Contempt. Researchers have found that it is expressed on only one side of the face, whereas the other feelings manifest themselves symmetrically. 12. The Duke and Duchess of Windsor. 13. The police banned protests without a permit by students who had been demonstrating for broader democratic rights and freedom of the press and expression. 14.

An injured pilot spent almost nine hours in the wreckage of his small plane less than a mile from an airport while teams searching for him groped through dense fog. William E. Allison, 53 years old, of Prairie Village, Kan., was listed in critical condition with multiple fractures today at St. Luke's Hospital in Kansas City, a spokesman said.

To the Editor: As described in your Dec. 13 report on New York State prisons, state leaders are more open now to developing alternatives to incarceration. State policy makers should therefore take a close look at the Correctional Association's recent report, ''The Road Not Taken.'' The document describes how New York can save $750 million in prison-construction costs, plus $60 million a year for operating expenses by implementing a program of alternative penalties.

The Moser Farms Dairy has announced a voluntary recall of all fluid milk in half-pint containers bearing a Dec. 27 expiration date. The milk is sold in Connecticut, Massachusetts and Rhode Island, the dairy said.

Tim Murphy has been elevated from assistant to head coach of football at the University of Maine. He replaces Eugene (Buddy) Teevans, who left to become the Dartmouth coach. Nine months younger than Teevans, the 30-year-old Murphy thus becomes the nation's youngest Division I-A or Division I-AA football coach. . . . Mario Lemieux, the Pittsburgh Penguin center, has been selected the city's man of year.

Soviet authorities, in a highly unusual move, permitted two United States television networks to use a Soviet studio tonight to interview Andrei D. Sakharov, the dissident who was allowed to return to Moscow this week after seven years of internal exile in Gorky. Dr. Sakharov gave separate interviews to CBS News and NBC News from the Gostelradio television studios in Ostankino, the site of an old estate in Moscow. The interviewers, Charles Kuralt of CBS and Garrick Utley of NBC, conducted the interviews from their networks' studios in New York.

Protest March Civil rights groups will lead a march down Cross Bay Boulevard in Howard Beach, Queens, today in response to the death of Michael Griffith, a black man who was struck and killed by a car after being beaten by a group of white teen-agers earlier this month. 12 P.M., Cross Bay Boulevard and Belt Parkway, Howard Beach. Trouble Spots for Traffic According to the city's Department of Transportation, these will be among the most severe traffic trouble spots in the region today: * The Harlem River Drive, where the right lane is closed in each direction at 148th Street; * The Manhattan Bridge, where the Manhattan-bound upper roadway will be closed.

The head trader at one Wall Street brokerage firm had a bone to pick with John Phelan, chairman of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. ''I called John Phelan to indicate that nothing was going on, and it was foolish to have the market open,'' the trader said. ''And he wasn't in.'' Mr. Phelan was on vacation. But he was not the only one on Wall Street who had the day off. Trading was numbingly slow, the slowest in exactly two years. Stock prices, because they had to do something, drifted higher.

The Federal Highway Administration has told the state to increase the number of female construction workers on federally financed highway and bridge projects in New Jersey, a state official said yesterday. The agency said a failure to increase the number of women laborers could jeopardize some Federal financing, but no formal warnings have been issued, said a deputy assistant transportation commissioner, Judy Berry.

With their first playoff game in two seasons two days away, the Washington Redskins found their preparations disrupted today when Dexter Manley, their leading pass rusher, failed to report for practice. The Redskins and the Los Angeles Rams play Sunday in Washington in the National Conference wild-card game.

The Chicago Bulls, sorely in need of big men, primarily a center, gambled that Brad Sellers might be the answer when they used their No. 1 choice, the ninth pick over all, in last June's college draft to select the Ohio State all-American. But the 7-foot Sellers has failed to crack the starting lineup as a rookie, and in his 26 games, he has averaged 5 points a game and 16 minutes of playing time.

Every morning thousands of New York City parents leave their children with a friendly neighbor. If that neighbor cares for at least five children or if any of them are under age 2, she is, strictly speaking, running a family day-care center. Chances are, though, that the Health Department won't know it. Almost all such centers are unlicensed. That means they can operate without smoke detectors, fire exits and fire extinguishers, window guards, first-aid kits and adequate space. Never having asked for clearance from any city agencies, they need never fear inspection.

A cardiologist at the Westchester County Medical Center decided yesterday against heart surgery for Jean Harris, the convicted killer of Dr. Herman Tarnower, author of the ''Scarsdale Diet'' and a prominent cardiologist. A spokesman for the hospital, James Patrick, said Mrs. Harris, who has suffered two heart attacks in prison, was examined for an hour by the cardiologist, Dr. Richard Kay.
BASKETBALL ATLANTA (NBA) - Signed Mike Wilson, guard, to a 10-day contract.

For Bruce Dalrymple, today's Eastern Collegiate Athletic Conference Holiday Festival game at Madison Square Garden is the continuation of what has already been a dreamlike career. The 6-foot-4-inch guard for Georgia Tech grew up on 141st Street and Eighth Avenue in Harlem, attended Benjamin Franklin High School ''for about a day,'' then enrolled at St. Johnsbury Academy in Vermont, where he dominated competition for the next four years. In his final year at Georgia Tech, Dalrymple is on the verge of becoming the first player in Atlantic Coast Conference history with more than 1,500 career points, 750 rebounds and 500 assists. ''When I look back on it, my career's gone better than I could ever have imagined,'' said Dalrymple, whose team was scheduled to face Rutgers at 12:30 in the opener of the doubleheader. Undefeated St. John's was to play Virginia at 2:30, with the winners meeting in the final Monday night.

To the Editor: Senator Paul S. Trible Jr.'s Op-Ed article on the United Nations (Dec. 15) is lopsided. As a United States citizen and former ''international civil servant,'' I can set the Senator straight on U.N. salaries.

The $18-a-barrel goal of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting countries is only a minimum price sought by the group, Saudi Arabia's King Fahd said. In remarks reported Thursday by the official Saudi press agency, the leader of OPEC's most influential member also said the group must adhere strictly to an agreement reached last Saturday aimed at eliminating the surplus of oil that has depressed prices by more than 50 percent since last year.

New racial violence was reported in Queens yesterday, but the police soon discovered that the incident had been invented by the victim to disguise a household accident. The episode began when a 15-year-old black male was admitted to the Long Island Jewish Medical Center between 4 and 5 A.M. yesterday with serious burns, claiming that he had been set on fire by three white youths in a racially motivated attack, the police said.

The State Commission on Judicial Conduct has recommended the dismissal of a Columbia County justice, saying he mishandled court funds. The judge, Albert Montaneli, Town Court Justice of Ancram, N.Y., was cited by the commission for having misused funds, including a $2,500 bail check that had been sent to him by the Columbia County Sheriff's Department. The Commission on Judicial Conduct oversees matters of judicial propriety and is empowered by the State Constitution to remove, censure or admonish judges based on the findings of administrative hearings.

A city permit allowing an Orthodox Jewish group to display a menorah at a public park was revoked today, the day that Hanukkah begins, after a civil rights group threatened to sue the city. But members of the Chabad Community Center of North Orange County, a Hasidic Jewish group, lighted a smaller menorah at Sasser Park shortly after sunset and defied the city by leaving behind the traditional symbol of Judaism used during the annual festival.

Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 32. 1. Palm readers saw this secret message. Whose palm is it and what did the message say? 2. Shortly after he becomes Governor of Arizona next month, Evan Mecham plans to do something no governor has done. What is it? 3. The Voyager, the experimental aircraft that completed the first nonstop flight around the world on one load of fuel, was made of plastic and another material. What is it? 4. In one untidy area of Manhattan, demand for commercial real estate is so strong that operators of vegetable stalls near a bustling intersection pay more rent per square foot than the owners of Tiffany & Company on Fifth Avenue. The area is (Chinatown/Little Italy/Tribeca). 5. ''I don't think it's bad to get your people all fired up and realize they have a lot of work to do,'' said Vice President Bush. To what was he referring? 6. After opening up the nation to travelers for 73 years, a transportation company said it would sell what made it famous. Identify what that is. 7. Oui, Vanessa. He is in a Bordeaux atelier. Explain. 8. A small but growing number of professionals are emigrating from a state that, for the first time, has more people moving out of it than into it. What state is it? 9. A product called the Happy Pan celebrated its 25th anniversary.

The Des Plaines River was reopened to shipping today after cleanup crews contained a pipeline leak that had spilled up to 1,000 gallons of a petroleum product into the river, the authorities said. James O'Brien, manager of the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency's office of emergency management, said the fuel ''doesn't pose a health hazard, and I think the environmental hazard has been limited.''

The Oil City Symphony, a quartet of actors and musicians, will give two performances on New Year's Eve at the South Street Theater, 424 West 42d Street. The shows - at 8 and 11 P.M. - will feature a combination of classical, ragtime, rock, gospel and big-band music. Tickets are $20 for the 8 P.M. show and $25 at 11 P.M. Reservations: 279-4200.

An overwhelming majority of experts now favor the transfer bid, introduced to American players by the late Oswald Jacoby three decades ago. One of the advantages of an agreement to make a red-suit response to one no-trump show the next-higher suit is that the stronger hand becomes declarer and the opening lead is less likely to be damaging.

To the Editor: One of the longer-range aspects of heavy-duty truck safety (front page, Dec. 7) is the need to keep the country's truck fleets in reasonably new condition. Consideration must be given to economic conditions that favor early replacement of older vehicles, thereby insuring that vital safety components are not worn out and that vehicles are equipped with the latest safety improvements. America must avoid the condition that has afflicted the Indian trucking industry at the cost of thousands of lives. In India, trucks are kept in operation so long that, in wear and age, they are beyond the point of being junk heaps and may be classified as museum pieces. This results from a chronic shortage of hire-purchase credit (caused by chronic government deficits), coupled with a value-added tax that makes new trucks in India extremely expensive.

Two trains collided and derailed today, forcing the evacuation of about 300 people from their homes as a precaution because one of the trains contained hazardous materials. No injuries were reported in the 8 A.M. accident at the Alton & Southern Railway Company's yard in south-central East St. Louis, a railroad official said. At least two tanker cars on one of the trains contained traces of phosphoric acid and other hazardous materials.

Michael A. LoGrande, who will become Suffolk County's top official today, is an immigrant to Long Island, one of the hundreds of thousands of people who moved here to flee the tempest of New York City. But Mr. LoGrande, a Republican who until 10 days ago was the Supervisor of the Town of Islip, said he sees some ''slippage'' in the ''better way of life'' that proved so attractive to the families who came to Long Island in the 1950's and 60's. ''The disappearance of open space, the traffic generation, the noise -these were never problems when I moved out here,'' said Mr. LoGrande, an urban planner by training. ''The quality of life is seen to be deteriorating rapidly here.''

A teen-ager was arraigned yesterday in the fatal stabbing of a man who apparently became offended when the youth bragged that he looked better in women's clothes than the man's girlfriend, the police said. The teen-ager, Jomahl Hurdle, 17 years old of Waterbury, has been charged in the Thursday morning death of Elgin R. Yates, 22, who was stabbed once in the chest.

The BankAmerica Corporation said it had closed the sale of the Banca d'America e d'Italia to Deutsche Bank A.G. for $603 million. The sale of its 98.3 percent stake in the Italian bank, which had assets of $4.2 billion and a book value of $321 million, should give BankAmerica a $282 million pretax gain in the fourth quarter. Analysts have said the sale would give the bank a profit for the quarter.

Lionel Manuel is back, more or less. For the last three weeks, the Giants' wide receiver has taken part in practice, doing most of the things he did before he was injured in the fourth game of the season. But he is still on injured reserve, though he is expected to be activated for the Giants' first playoff game here Jan. 4. ''I'm going to play because I'm ready,'' said Manuel.

Strictures about drinking and driving are not new. Indeed, in recent years they have multiplied. More states have adopted laws to punish drunken drivers. In a way, however, the laws are misdirected. They penalize drivers after they have been drinking; they do not necessarily prevent drivers from drinking. ''Drinking and Driving: The Toll, the Tears,'' a remarkable documentary, tries to bridge the gap.

Ron Harper, a rookie, scored 25 points and John Bagley added 21 as the Cleveland Cavaliers held off a New Jersey rally in the final period to defeat the Nets, 121-112, tonight. The Nets trailed by 94-80 entering the fourth quarter, but outscored Cleveland, 13-2, to cut their deficit to 3 points with less than seven minutes remaining. Mike Gminski, who led New Jersey with 24 points, scored 5 points during the surge.

An internal review by the city's Department of Investigation places blame for the municipal corruption scandals in part on ''serious deficiencies'' in the network of inspectors general that was intended to detect and prevent wrongdoing. In 46 percent of the cases sampled, the department found that the inspectors general had conducted ''poor or very poor'' investigations. In some cases, no investigations were done at all.
The Times Mirror Company said it had purchased the 60 percent of the stock of Rhode Island Cable Television that it did not already own.
France and Yugoslavia advanced to the final of a four-team French Christmas basketball tournament by posting victories today.

LAST FALL, after seven years as a re-fusenik - a Soviet Jew refused an emigration visa - I was abruptly allowed, with my wife, to leave the Soviet Union for New York. The event was precipitated by a remarkable coincidence: the intervention with Soviet authorities of the American industrialist, Armand Hammer, whom I had never met; and at the same time, the fortuitous, if unfortunate onset of an international political crisis in which I unwittingly played a part. Two years earlier, I had refused to cooperate with the K.G.B., the Soviet secret police, when they first tried to entrap my friend and occasional dinner companion, the American journalist Nicholas S. Daniloff. It was only last summer, when Nick was at last arrested on the false charge of espionage, that the previous episode was made public.

DWIGHT D. DOUGHERTY, also known as The Chief, was the best teacher in the world. Mr. Dougherty (he was never addressed otherwise) headed the mathematics department at Eastside High School in Paterson. He was of medium height and slender and he had a way of cocking his head a little to the right. He wore circular steel-rimmed spectacles and had an inverted-V mustache that reached just to the corners of his mouth. His facial expression at repose was one of quizzical anticipation, as if about to ask, ''You what?''

THREE programs of films and videotapes by black women, telling stories that its organizer says ''other film makers and video artists simply have not told,'' will be shown by the Whitney Museum of American Art starting Tuesday. Valerie Smith, a Princeton University associate professor interested in black feminist criticism and theory of literature, has put together 12 feature and short films and videotapes for the museum's newest program in its New American Film Makers series. Ms. Smith's program, ''The Black Woman Independent: Representing Race and Gender,'' will begin Tuesday at 2 P.M. and end Jan. 16. Each of the three programs has four films that are shown in two sittings - two films to a sitting - on the same day.

There were no last-second heroics needed, and the opposition was not a team with dubious credentials. Rather, this was a rout of a legitimate contender, and it was truly the Knicks' finest moment in a long while. In a victory that may have signified the end of their arduous transition from one coaching philosophy to another, the Knicks pummeled the Milwaukee Bucks last night at Madison Square Garden, 114-100, to extend their winning streak to three games, their longest in more than a year. In winning for just the eighth time in 30 games this season, the Knicks dominated a team that had a 15-game winning streak against them, and one considered by many observers to be the league's hottest. The Bucks had won five straight games and 9 of their last 11. But they Knicks broke from a 50-50 tie at intermission and led by as many 20 points in what became their most convincing victory of the season.

AN incident of racially motivated violence that at first seemed as brutally simple as a lynching, to which Mayor Koch compared it, took a twist last week that threatened to heighten the bitterness surrounding it even while jeopardizing the case against those accused of committing it. Three black men from Brooklyn, afoot late at night after their car broke down in predominantly white Howard Beach, Queens, were set upon by a gang of white youths who shouted racial epithets and beat them with baseball bats and fists. One of them, Timothy Grimes, escaped with slight injury. Two others, Cedric Sandiford and Michael Griffith, were chased for blocks and repeatedly beaten.

Margaret Ann Murdich, the deputy general counsel of the Home Group Inc., an insurance holding company in New York, was married yesterday to Robert Edward Shearer, a senior programmer and analyst at the New York University Computer Center and a doctoral candidate in higher education at N.Y.U. The Rev. Phillip S. Washburn performed the ceremony at the Scarsdale (N.Y.) Congregational Church. The bride, known as Peggy-ann, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Haig Murdich of Scarsdale.

Mr. and Mrs. George Edwin Brown Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Susan Hunter Brown to Thomas Goodall Bailey Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bailey of Nashville. The wedding is planned for Feb. 28.
Arsenal, celebrating its 100th birthday, beat Southampton, 1-0, today and opened a 7-point lead in the English League First Division soccer standings.

AS soon as Doug Jarvis took the opening face-off for the Whalers against Montreal Friday night in Hartford, he was assured the National Hockey League record of playing in 915 consecutive games. The streak started 12 seasons ago when he broke into the league with the Canadiens, but his pattern of durability had been ingrained long before.

The person, perhaps Will Rogers, who observed that at any given moment half the American population is on the way to a meeting while the other half is returning from one, was obviously not very familiar with Washington. The situation here seems much worse. Meeting-mania has not only blossomed to magnificent excess in the capital - 900 major conventions, seminars, conferences and other gatherings are held here each year by current estimate - but it has also become a rarefied sociopolitical art form that is sometimes so frenetic that it rivals a commodities trading pit. What with problems of protocol, security and overscheduled, egocentric politicians, it is sometimes a wonder that any Washington meeting runs smoothly even when planned by the capital's growing cadre of full-time professionals.

St. John's, through its first seven games, had followed an interesting pattern of falling behind early, pulling even at the midway point, then being saved, more or less at the end, by a three-man rescue squad: Mark Jackson, Willie Glass and Shelton Jones. Yesterday, against a Virginia team that had it boxed in and nearly stripped of all weapons, St. John's was saved by reinforcements. This time it wasn't just by Jackson, Glass and Jones but by another, unlikely crew led by Matt Brust. The 6-foot-5-inch sophomore, who transfered to St. John's from North Carolina last year, scored a career-high 12 points, made three steals and grabbed four rebounds to help St. John's to a 64-58 victory over Virginia in the opening round of the Eastern College Athletic Conference Holiday Festival at Madison Square Garden.

The normal checks-and-balances system of government has been taken away from this coal mining town of 780 people in southwestern West Virginia. ''I've got the power,'' said Don Wilkes. And he has. Appointed as receiver to run the town, he has been serving since Nov. 19 as Mayor, Recorder and Town Council.

I was appalled to read the article on Thomas S. Gulotta [ ''Gulotta Cautious on Future Path,'' Dec. 7 ] . First of all, quoting Hannah Komanoff as a Democrat does an injustice to John Matthews, who has been an active and vocal proponent for issues the article credits to Mr. Gulotta. Since Mr. Matthews may oppose Mr. Gulotta for election for the county executive, his opposing opinion should have been printed in the same article. Bruce Nyman should also have been consulted for the Democratic viewpoint on the Board of Supervisors in Nassau County.

The engagement of Patricia Ann Taggart to James Latimer Bellis Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bellis of Bedminster, N.J., and Vero Beach, Fla., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. William F. Taggart of Oldwick, N.J., parents of the bride-to-be. A July wedding is planned.

In a recent article about a vacant municipal office in Rockville Centre, it was erroneously stated that the members of the Board of Trustees, who serve part time, are not paid. The trustees receive $6,000 a year, and the Mayor, who is a member of the board, receives $10,800 a year.

The days and weeks before Ash Wednesday, which marks for many Christians a 40-day penitential period running until Easter, are a time for steel bands and sambas, for gorging on pralines and drinking beer in heroic quantities, for masked balls and elaborately costumed processions. In a word, carnival. Music and parades are a constant, but every culture puts its own stamp on carnival, which may embrace just the few days before Ash Wednesday (March 4 next year) all the way to Cologne's 17-week marathon: Mardi Gras and Jouvert, Sambadrome and Vivaldi, the Women's Carnival and even survivals of pre-Christian Roman feasts. Following are reports from six cities in the Americas and Western Europe where the celebration has been refined to a fine art.

THE official Soviet publishing agency prints textbooks in 52 languages to serve the disparate minorities of the Soviet Union. The state radio broadcasts in 67 languages. Flip on the state-run television here, and the show may be a Georgian comedy or Uzbek folk dancing. But Moscow's affection for ethnic diversity has its limits, as the Republic of Kazakhstan was sternly reminded last week. A few days after students - apparently angered that Moscow had replaced a longtime Kazakh party chief with an ethnic Russian - took to the streets and burned cars in the Republic's capital, Alma-Ata, the newly installed leader in the Kazakh Republic began to assert himself.

Sarah L. Van Cleve, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William M. Van Cleve of LaDue, Mo., and John C. L. Van Doren, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Van Doren of Cornwall, Conn., plan to be married in June, the future bride's parents have announced. Miss Van Cleve, the public information officer for the city of Sante Fe, N.M., where her fiance is the assistant to the head of the Gerald Peters Gallery, graduated from Princeton University.
Matt Brust of St. John's grabbing a rebound from Virginia's Mel Kennedy in opening round of Holiday Festival. Page 6. (NYT/Larry C. Morris)

THE COMPLETE NOTEBOOKS OF HENRY JAMES Edited by Leon Edel and Lyall H. Powers. Illustrated. 633 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $30. NEAR the end of his life Henry James destroyed many of his personal papers. Probably without intending to, he left behind nine notebooks or journals now deposited at Harvard's Houghton Library. Except for one small notebook, they resemble the old composition books, about 6 by 8 inches, which would have cost him only a few pennies each. They were not meant for posterity. They were a place where, in entries dated by James between 1878 and 1911, he could jot down the ''germs'' - things picked up at dinner parties or in his reading - that eventually would become novels or tales. Some notes are skeletal, others develop into full scenarios, and all are far more concerned with his possible method or treatment than with an ostensible subject. The notebooks became a workshop both for his fiction and for his subsequent commentaries on it in the prefaces to the New York Edition of his works, later collected in ''The Art of Fiction'' by R. P. Blackmur, who called them ''the most eloquent and original piece of literary criticism in existence.''

Music is featured in new releases from New Zealand which is celebrating the 40th anniversary of its national orchestra. A 30-cent value salutes the influence of the New Zealand Symphony Orchestra which performs about 100 concerts annually and is an important part of the country's musical life. Brass bands are featured on a 60-cent stamp. They were introduced into New Zealand in 1845 with the arrival of a British regimental band. In the ensuing years, local volunteer forces formed brass bands that gradually were reorganized into town bands around the turn of the century. Pipe bands, which appear on an 80-cent value, date back to 1773, when Captain Cook arrived in New Zealand and had a Scottish sailor play the bagpipes to attract the attention of Maoris on shore. Country music is a more recent tradition with roots that trace to United States television programs and movies as well as the folk music of New Zealand. The country music stamp is the $1 value in the new set.

''MAN, this is the place to be,'' said Victor Sampson of Vineland, the payroll clerk on the battleship New Jersey. ''It's the world's best battleship. I mean it's historic and a real thrill to be here. It's taken me to Hong Kong, Korea, the Philippines, Thailand, Japan - places I'd never get to see. And I'm only 21. ''I even got to meet the Governor of New Jersey here. Kean visited our ship in Thailand last September and threw a fancy-cake party for us guys from New Jersey. There are 34 Jersey boys here on the Big J. We hang out together on ship and even on shore. We're like one big happy family. No kidding.''

What the coelacanth is to zoologists, the par contest is to bridge-players. The coelacanth is a primitive creature that was believed to be long extinct and suddenly surfaces, alive and well. Unlike virtually every other form of competitive bridge, a par contest consists of prepared deals in which the players must solve a specific problem in play or defense to earn points. Secondary points are awarded for accurate bidding. One partnership has little to do, and must wait for a later deal for a chance to score.

Pat Cash and John Fitzgerald defeated Sweden's world doubles champions, Stefan Edberg and Anders Jarryd, 6-3, 6-4, 4-6, 6-1, today and moved Australia to within one victory of ending Sweden's two-year reign as Davis Cup champion. The doubles triumph gave the Australians a 2-1 lead in the three-of-five-match final. Cash, 21 years old, who defeated Edberg in the opening singles match Friday, has a chance to clinch the championship when he meets Mikael Pernfors in the first singles match Sunday. Paul McNamee is scheduled to play Edberg in the closing singles, a match that will be meaningless if Cash defeats Pernfors, the University of Georgia's two-time national collegiate champion.

Watch on the Rhine With Bette Davis and Paul Lukas. 1943. Key Video. 114 minutes, $59.98. This is a sensible, ultimately stirring version of Lillian Hellman's anti-Nazi war drama, with the handsome production stamp of the Warner studio, specialists in patriotic, pre-Pearl Harbor texts.

THE executive suite of any company, large or small, public or private, is fraught with obstacles for the ambitious. A corporation can be thrown suddenly into crisis, like Union Carbide after Bhopal and Johnson & Johnson after the Tylenol poisonings, and careers can hinge on how well executives handle the problem.
Basketball L.A. Lakers vs. Philadelphia 76ers At Inglewood, Calif., 10 P.M. TV - WTBS, 10 P.M. Football A.F.C. Wildcard Playoff Jets vs.

MORE STORIES JULIAN TELLS By Ann Cameron. Illustrated by Ann Strugnell. 82 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $10.95. (Ages 5 to 8) THE stories Julian tells are good fun. They deal with everyday events in the life of a small boy - a day when it's too hot and nothing is happening, a bet with a friend, the trouble that teasing a younger brother can get you into, a frustrating attempt to launch a bottle with a note inside in the river. But they are not told in an everyday way. These stories meander around and take unexpected turns, they double back on themselves and end up in surprising places, almost like shaggy dog stories. They are frequently funny and full of the warmth of a close family.

To the Editor: ''Betting That a Stock Will Drop'' (Investing, Dec. 7) does not make clear that short-selling is most and best used by big players. Their commissions are lower, they have the financial and psychological resources to sit out an updraft in a shorted stock, and the big players are given a portion of the interest on the proceeds generated by the short sale. Finally, it is misleading to state that shorts ''will be on an equal tax footing with the longs,'' since shorts must eventually take their profit (if any), whereas longs can let any profits run indefinitely. CHARLES STEIR New York, Dec. 7

''MY boss ruled like a dictator,'' recalled Iris Marchaj of her days at an executive placement firm in Massachusetts. ''He liked to threaten people, to keep them on edge. He transferred me from one city to another arbitrarily. When I wanted to know why, he said it was none of my business. ''One day he found the coffee machine had been left on overnight, and he hit the roof.'' said Ms. Marchaj. ''When his secretary came in, he started yelling, blaming her for things she hadn't done. I stood up for her. For weeks after that, he wouldn't speak to me. When I finally went to talk to him, he said, 'You've made my staff lose respect for me.' I told him I couldn't exist in that closed, lying environment, even though top management had assured me I would be promoted to his level in six months. I quit.'' The tale told by Ms. Marchaj, now a stress-management consultant at Northampton Wellness Associates in Northampton, Mass., is an old one: the unbearable boss who makes life miserable for subordinates.

This is the year of the unknown quarterbacks and the unknown teams in the National Football League playoffs, which start today with the Jets facing the Kansas City Chiefs at Giants Stadium. Just who are these clubs? Indeed, who are the quarterbacks? Pat Ryan for the Jets, Todd Blackledge of the Kansas City Chiefs? Neither has ever started a playoff game. But Ryan is starting because Coach Joe Walton finally decided, after five straight season-ending losses with Ken O'Brien at the helm, to bench O'Brien. And Blackledge, benched in midseason, is expected to start because Bill Kenney has an injured thumb and index finger. And even if Kenney is able to play, it would mark his first playoff start, too.

THIS was the year that some restaurant cliches of the past gave way to a few new ones, notably Cajun-inspired dishes and mesquite-grilled meats and seafood. Chocolate-mania also was rampant. But 1986 was a first for this column: Only one new three-star restaurant was uncovered. Le Coq Hardi, Westin Hotel, 2701 Summer Street, Stamford (357-0098), is the namesake of its Ridgefield parent and like it offers a nouvelle cuisine menu, under the supervision of the chef, Carl Wright. Celebratory dishes included a nest of spaghetti squash and snails with Pernod butter; seafood sausage with a mustard and chervil sauce; celery-root salad with smoked mussels, snails and cepes sauteed in Burgundy in a brioche; sliced duck breast in hazlenut sauce and desserts such as white mousse cake layered with fresh strawberries and a devilishly rich dark-chocolate torte. Prices are far from cheap and service early on was flawed, but should have smoothed out by now. Because the menu changes frequently, these dishes may be gone by now, but replacements should be equally imaginative.

The owner of the largest share of the idle Seabrook nuclear power station has long asserted that the plant is necessary to fill a growing demand for power in New Hampshire. But the owner, the Public Service Company, disclosed last week that it was going to pay two small power companies $1.25 million to withdraw their plans to build six wood-burning energy generators. The disclosure last Wednesday before the New Hampshire Public Utilities Commission, which took some people by surprise, highlights the already vigorous debate in the state over how to provide for future energy needs. After 10 years of cost overruns and construction problems, the Seabrook plant needs only a Federal operating permit to begin generating power. Its opponents have assailed the planned payments, asserting that the company is trying to stifle competition from alternative energy sources.

After four months of delay and reinvestigation, a report on the illegal dumping of tons of construction waste in western Vermont has been forwarded to the State Attorney General's office. ''It was not a model of expeditious investigation,'' said Jonathan Lash, Water Resources Commissioner, who approved the report sent by the State Environmental Agency's Waste Management Division to the Attorney General's office at the end of November. The Attorney General has not indicated whether any charges will be filed against truckers responsible for hauling the waste to Vermont. Environmental officials would not disclose the details of the report except to say they were requesting that ''enforcement action'' be taken in the case.

For centuries, roses have been the subject of poems and paintings. They are also the new American national flower. But their allure is an international one. As the following pages illustrate, the thousands of varieties of colors, scents and blossoms make them a favorite among leading florists in Paris, London and New York.

The year's biggest sports story? Len Bias, unfortunately. JEROME AGEL New York rrWhat was the year's biggest sports story? Dwight Gooden is human. LLOYD KHANER New York rrWhen the U.S.F.L. found George Washington waiting for them at the foot of the stairs in Foley Square. VICTOR M. PEREZ Jr. Bronx rrSpeaking as a Red Sox fan, there can be little doubt about what was the year's biggest sports story: Jack Nicklaus's victory in the Masters. PETER B. DRAGONE New York rrThe biggest sports story of the year, in my opinion, was the death of Len Bias. His death affected not only those involved with basketball, but America in general.

THE NEW YORK PUBLIC LIBRARY: Its Architecture and Decoration (Norton, $35) by Henry Hope Reed is not about the treasures stored inside the building but a lavish tribute in word and photograph to the architecture and decoration of the palatial structure on Fifth Avenue and 42d Street. This handsome volume pokes into every cranny, every archway, every artifact - from wastebasket to water fountain to flagpole - and forces us to concentrate on the wealth of detail that went into the assemblage of this fantastic storehouse.

THIS seems to be a time when certain venerable social traditions that all but disappeared in the 1960's and 70's have come back into fashion, proudly and with bells on. The Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball is a striking example.
To the Sports Editor: Jack Morris should be embarrassed by his insensitive remark, ''I feel sort of like Jackie Robinson must have felt.''

Jacob Lew, a chief aide to the retiring Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., is leaving Capitol Hill to join the Washington law firm of Van Ness, Feldman, Sutcliffe & Curtis, where he will specialize in energy and regulatory law. He has been serving as executive director of the House Democratic Steering and Policy Committee.

JACK PARKER isn't selling. Not just now, at any rate. In 10 years, he may feel differently. Francis Greenburger, on the other hand, certainly is selling. And buying too. The difference between the two - or rather, between the two housing businesses in which they find themselves engaged after years of rent regulation, low production and housing shortage in New York City - tells a great deal about the current and prospective course of the city's neighborhoods and its multifamily housing stock.

The days and weeks before Ash Wednesday, which marks for many Christians a 40-day penitential period running until Easter, are a time for steel bands and sambas, for gorging on pralines and drinking beer in heroic quantities, for masked balls and elaborately costumed processions. In a word, carnival. Music and parades are a constant, but every culture puts its own stamp on carnival, which may embrace just the few days before Ash Wednesday (March 4 next year) all the way to Cologne's 17-week marathon: Mardi Gras and Jouvert, Sambadrome and Vivaldi, the Women's Carnival and even survivals of pre-Christian Roman feasts. Following are reports from six cities in the Americas and Western Europe where the celebration has been refined to a fine art.

Andrei D. Sakharov used an interview here today to draw attention to several imprisoned dissidents and to urge that they be freed. ''There are many of them, it would be impossible to name them all,'' he said. ''I would like to mention the names and plight of a few of them.''

Marjorie Child Husted, who helped develop Betty Crocker and championed the ideals of ''good housekeeping,'' died Tuesday in Minneapolis. She was 94 years old. Mrs. Husted, born in Minneapolis, graduated from the University of Minnesota with degrees in home economics and German. She developed the image of Betty Crocker from an idea generated in a 1921 contest. By 1948, a national survey reported that the General Mills trademark was known by 91 percent of American housewifes.

The ultimate goal of the Long Island School for the Gifted seems to be to get high scores on the S.A.T. test [ ''School for Gifted: Where the S.A.T. Is Just Another Test,'' Nov. 23 ] . This raises concerns that should be answered: Are children crammed with more knowledge than they really need at that age? Are we increasing the number of lost kids who develop overconfidence? Are we contributing to stress, fatigue and alienation? Are we turning out pupils who are always looking for special privileges for the rest of their lives because educators inflated them?

An article in the Arts and Leisure section today about the tenor Vinson Cole's debut at the Metropolitan Opera next Saturday evening misidentifies the role he will sing in ''Die Fledermaus.'' It is that of Alfred.

Transcripts of a series of conversations, secretly recorded a year ago by the Federal Bureau of Investigation as part of an investigation of two construction unions, have provided a rare glimpse of the relationship between city judges and union officials. The transcripts, which were made public late last week, show that a large but undetermined number of Philadelphia judges had longstanding, close and profitable relationships with the leaders of the union locals, which have been linked by prosecutors to organized crime. The investigation has so far led to the indictment of two judges and 19 other people, and comes on the heels of several studies that found the city's court system rife with cronyism, nepotism and patronage based on campaign contributions. Impression of Justice for Sale Taken together, Federal prosecutors and police officials say, the courts' problems have created an impression that they deliver anything but justice and that justice in Philadelphia is for sale, cheap. That view has become so widespread that Judge James R. Cavanaugh of Superior Court has become something of a folk hero here for refusing cash gifts offered by the unions, Local 30 of the United Slate, Tile and Composition Roofers, Damp and Waterproof Workers Association and Local 30B of the Residential Reroofers Union.

BOSTON'S first skyscraper will finally belong to the city it once dominated, now that the Federal Government, which has owned the 495-foot Custom House since it was built in 1847, has agreed to sell the landmark to the city for $11 million. City officials say they have been negotiating for more than a year with the Federal General Services Administration to buy the unusual, needle-shaped building, in the heart of Boston's downtown financial district.

Because of an editing error, a review Nov. 30 of ''Northrop Frye on Shakespeare'' incorrectly characterized an earlier book by Mr. Frye, ''Anatomy of criticism.'' Mr. Frye's discussions of Milton's epics, Blake's ''fearful symmetry,'' English Romanticism and T. S. Eliot are found in his other writings. Noted with Pleausre on Dec. 7 misstated the title of a book about Samuel Beckett, edited by S. E. Gontarski and published by Grove Press. The title is ''On Beckett: Essays and Criticism.''

RETURNING last week from their latest fiscal pilgrimage to Albany, executives of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority still had their hats in their hands. While legislators seemed to accept the authority's argument that it needed virtually every dollar of the $8.6 billion it proposed to spend over five years to restore the nation's largest transit system to a state of good repair, there was apparently no rush to provide a means to finance the $1 billion or so the authority still needs to complete the ambitious task. Perhaps the M.T.A. had done too good a job convincing the lawmakers that the $8.3 billion committed during the last five years for improvements to subways, bus lines and commuter railroads was well spent. Perhaps a system that is no longer so intolerable has become politically tolerable.

Thousands of Indian families across the nation are homeless because new controls are severely limiting Federal financing for housing construction, Indian leaders say. Tribal officials in Arizona say the controls, designed to spur new housing starts, have instead delayed construction.

All Dr. Oldham and his colleagues are doing is providing a privately financed supplement to Government-financed research efforts. Gramm-Rudman will require even more of this as the meat-ax approach is used to deal with the Federal budget deficit. Given the fiscal reality of today, we will see more and more research financed privately and for profit. IRA M. ELSKY New York City

LIKE many a storefront operation, the Bronx River Art Center and Gallery lives from hand to mouth on the support it gets from Federal, state and city agencies and sometimes from corporations. Still, neither this nor the Spartan-ness of its premises at 1087 East Tremont Avenue in the Bronx deters the organization from conceiving of ambitious schemes. Or so it appears in its current group show, ''Origins,'' on view through Jan. 7. This is the first of a three-part series whose title, ''Dale Que Dale,'' is an idiomatic Spanish expression that translates none too clearly into ''Hit on it and then hit on it again.'' The lights go on, however, when the dictionary's definition of ''dale'' as an interjection expressing displeasure at the obstinacy of another is taken in conjunction with the series' subtitle, ''Ethnocentric Histories of Art.''

THE Minnetonka Corporation doesn't look like much. Its headquarters are in an anonymous one-story cinder-block building across from some cornfields. But in the consumer products industry, the company has been the mouse that roared, churning out revolutionary new products that have thrown industry giants on the defensive. Minnetonka, based 15 miles west of Minneapolis in Chaska (Population 8,643), first upset the industry in 1979, when it introduced Softsoap, the first mass market liquid soap - and in the process, created a whole new product concept that put the lackluster industry into a lather. Then came Minnetonka's Check-Up toothpaste, the first anti-plaque paste and the first in a pump dispenser. Now with its risque, pace-setting advertisements and its huge marketing blitz, the company's Obsession scent is going up for the No. 2 spot among the nation's fragrances, behind Giorgio. The company reached $100 million in sales last year, and Robert R. Taylor, the tall, suave, blue-eyed chairman and founder, said it should surpass $200 million in sales next year. Mr. Taylor, who started Minnetonka in 1964 with a $3,000 investment, said he hopes to reach $500 million within five years. The company's success, he said, lies in a willingness - almost a passion - to go out on a limb with an unusual, often untested idea.

TO local activists, it seemed like an intractable problem: Midnight dumpers kept throwing refrigerators and mattresses into the empty lots dotting the northern Bronx neighborhood of Williamsbridge. Now two-family houses are under construction on the lots, and the development activity is scaring off the dumpers. ''We were working on a proposal to deal with all the dumping,'' said Pinkie P. Freeman, treasurer of the Williamsbridge Federation, an alliance of block associations. ''Then, a couple of months ago, we realized there really wasn't much of a problem any more.'' It is a milestone in Williamsbridge to have a problem fade away without a fight. Though never ravaged like the South Bronx, the neighborhood endured blockbusting and a bad bout of malaise. ''Ten years ago, I thought about selling and moving on,'' Mrs. Freeman said. ''But I decided I'd stay here and fight. And I'm glad I did.''

Whether the driver of a car that killed a black man fleeing a white gang was part of the gang could be crucial to efforts to convict the gang's members of murder, legal experts say. They say that if the driver was part of the group that had beaten 23-year-old Michael Griffith in Howard Beach, Queens, on Dec. 20, there would be a firmer legal connection between the assault and his highway death than if the motorist had simply been a passing stranger. The issue gained significance Friday when a lawyer for a second victim of the assault disputed the authorities' version of Mr. Griffith's death. The lawyer, Alton H. Maddox Jr., said the driver had been a willful participant in the attack and that information had been withheld by the authorities partly ''to insure that no one will suffer conviction for a charge more serious than assault.''

WHEN Orchestra New England has its fifth annual New Year's Eve party for 700 guests in New Haven's Chapel Square Mall, it plans to make sure that they make it home safely. ''We are not turning off the tap,'' the orchestra's conductor, James Sinclair, said of the organization's efforts to curb excessive drinking at the party. ''But we're emphasizing that this is a party where you are to act responsibly.'' The orchestra, its corporate sponsor, the Connecticut Bank and Trust of Hartford, and its co-hosts, Channel 3 of Hartford and radio station WELI, have gone to great lengths to insure what they believe will be an enjoyable and safe evening.

IT is often hard enough to square the findings of one business poll with those of another. But what about contradictory findings in a single poll? This is the case in a poll released earlier this month by Louis Harris and Associates, famous for its political surveys, that sought to determine what American corporations considered the ideal place to do business. Its client was Cushman & Wakefield, a real-estate company based in New York.

Two private planes with student pilots at the controls collided in flight over the Pacific Ocean on Friday afternoon, but both pilots managed to land their damaged aircraft safely, the authorities said. One pilot said he never saw the other plane because he was wearing a hood over his head so he could train for instrument landings in poor visibility. ''I took the hood off and saw the damage,'' said the pilot, Robert Muzzy, 44 years old.

THIS was a year of significant remembrances, from the centennial of the birth of Edward Weston, the great Modernist photographer, to the 50th anniversary of Life magazine, the erstwhile beacon of photojournalism. These have not gone unnoticed: Weston has been remembered with a half-dozen museum shows, and Life has published a special commemorative issue and a book of its all-time greatest pictures. Two anniversaries in the realm of color photography, on the other hand, have not received all the attention they deserve. Fifty years ago, Kodak's Kodachrome film was made available in 35-millimeter size for color slides. A quarter-century later, in 1961, Kodak announced the Carousel projector, its warhorse system that has allowed photographers to show their 35-millimeter slides at home, as big as life or bigger.

THE SEARCH FOR EXTRATERRESTRIAL INTELLIGENCE Listening for Life in the Cosmos. By Thomas R. McDonough. Illustrated. 244 pp. New York: John Wiley & Sons. $19.95. GET out your calculators, please. Take the number of stars in the universe and multiply it by the number of planets per star; subtract those that are too cold, hot, wet or dry to support life; take into account the lifetime of a typical alien civilization; correct for the inconvenience of interstellar travel (''assume ten tons of spaceship per colonist'') and don't forget that the travelers might have to zigzag; consider also U.F.O.'s, the Anthropic Principle and the Garbage Hypothesis; and you arrive at the probability that someone out there is trying to get in touch. If your answer is somewhere between impossible and certain, you know as much as the scientists debating this question, and you probably know as much as anyone will know in your lifetime. Unless, that is, the international coterie of astronomers now engaged in the search for extraterrestrial intelligence (SETI) finally does ''answer the greatest long-distance call in history,'' as Thomas R. McDonough hopes and expects.

To the Editor: While I believe every reviewer has the right to his opinion, I also believe an editor has the responsibility to assign the review to someone qualified to understand a book's intentions. Sven Birkerts's inability to discern the design or purpose of my novel ''Bad Guys'' (reviewed Dec. 7) - its multiple points of view, its questions concerning free will and fate, its exploration of the natural origins of ethical behavior - says more about him than it does about the novel.

There are 2 18-hole golf courses, 2 polo fields and 150 polo ponies, 13 tennis courts, 8 swimming pools, a small gymnasium with saunas and massage, 9 restaurants, a fleet of fishing and sailing boats, a skeet-shooting range, a discotheque, an art colony, a small museum, a bookstore and several thousand acres of peace and quiet. The setting for all this is the Casa de Campo resort in the Dominican Republic. What is probably the biggest and most varied vacation place in the Caribbean is, above all, a place of beauty and relaxation where the service is cheerful and efficient, the food is better than average and the pace of life is whatever you make it. The resort is set on 7,000 acres of gently rolling coastal land a little more than an hour from the international airport in Santo Domingo. The red tile roofs and stucco walls of the casitas and villas give Casa de Campo a Latin look and the mostly sunny and mild days are unmistakably island tropical.

Twenty-three students from four sixth-grade classes of the Ward School in New Rochelle recently had an unusual opportunity to experience life without electricity. In a day spent at Philipsburg Manor in North Tarrytown, they did farm chores, open-hearth cooking, milling and textile work as they would have in the 18th century. ''A Day Without Electricity'' comprised one aspect of a larger program, the goal of which is to increase the awareness by young people of electricity and its use. The other - and major - segment of the educational program was the introduction of a new computer software program, ''Watts in a Home,'' underwritten by the State Power Authority. The Power Authority, in conjunction with Teachers College, Columbia University, developed the program to teach middle-school and junior-high-school students about energy conservation. Through the work of ''Wattson the Robot'' - the ''star'' of the computer program - students can see how many watts of electricity each household appliance uses on a typical day. To complete the program, students have the option of turning various appliances on and off depending on energy needs; they must also maintain their budget and avoid ''blacking out'' through the use of too much energy.

IN what is believed to be a first for New York State's Department of Corrections, a grant has been awarded to prisoners - a group of inmates operating a video-production center at the Taconic Correctional Facility, a medium-security prison in Bedford Hills. The $10,000 grant is a donation from the Self Development of People Fund of the Presbytery of the Hudson River. It will allow the inmates to purchase $6,000 worth of equipment for the Taconic video center and to use the remaining $4,000 to develop a training tape for inmate tutors working with Literacy Volunteers, a national organization that provides volunteer tutors in reading and math in programs throughout the country. ''This is the first time, so far as anyone here can recall, in which a group of inmates and staff applied for an outside grant for an in-prison program,'' James B. Flateau, a spokesman for the department, said last week.

1 THE MAMMOTH HUNTERS, by Jean M. Auel. (Bantam, $4.95.) Ayla of ''The Valley of Horses'' resumes her adventures in the prehistoric world. 2 LIE DOWN WITH LIONS, by Ken Follett. (Signet/ NAL, $4.95.) An Englishwoman in Afghanistan, caught between the C.I.A. and the K.G.B.

Democrats loyal to Mayor Harold Washington have voted to oust his City Council nemesis, Alderman Edward Vrdolyak, from the chairmanship of the city's Democratic Party for running for mayor on a third-party ticket. Organizers of the ouster, approved at a special meeting Friday by 13 of 50 party committee members, said today that it was perfectly legal. Others said a court challenge was likely.

The developers of a large office complex in Milford, Conn., are making the most of a prime site. One side of the 32-acre property overlooks a large natural pond, the other abuts an exit ramp off Interstate 95.
