In the Dec. 14 article on holiday music, the captions on pictures of J.S. Bach and Handel were transposed. The Times, we are told, is hardly e'er wrong.

PAINTING over a wall that has a rough or textured surface is seldom much of a problem. But trying to hang wallpaper over such a surface is much more difficult. The wall must be smoothed down first to create a reasonably sound and level surface that will be suitable for hanging. This is particularly a problem when dealing with walls that have been covered with grooved wood paneling or finished with a heavily stippled or textured-finish coating. Smoothing and leveling a rough wall is usually quite a chore - low spots, grooves and other depressions must be filled in, and high spots or rough areas must be sanded smooth. However, there is a much simpler method that can be used to prepare such walls for any regular wallcovering: Hang a type of heavy-duty lining fabric over the wall that is heavy-duty lining fabric over the wall that is specifically designed for ''problem'' walls of this kind. Although these lining materials are not new, most homeowners and even many professional painters are not familiar with them.

IT was the start of the seven-day Feast of Lights, Hanukkah, and at dusk, as I took the large bronze menorah down from the mantle piece, memories came flooding in: Our home was always filled with countless uncles and aunts. While we saw less of Aunt Bella than of the other relatives, she was our great favorite and she never failed to join us for our Hanukkah celebration. I can still see her well-loved face before me, the light of the Hanukkah candles reflected in her thick glasses, and I can hear her deep voice joining in the Hanukkah song, Ma-oz Tzur. Aunt Bella, my father's youngest sister, was an odd contrast to the tall, handsome uncles and chic, vivacious aunts - indeed, an ugly duckling. But to us children Aunt Bella meant fun, games and unstinting love. From the moment she arrived and extricated herself from four pairs of arms - mine, my sister's and two brothers' - the house echoed with her booming laughter as we vied for the privilege of sitting next to her at dinner, or, best of all, on her lap at story time.

Something went wrong for the Plymouth red-bellied turtle centuries ago and the development of a modern industrial society in Massachusetts only made things worse. But now museums across the state are helping in an effort to build the numbers of the nearly extinct turtle, the only endangered animal in the state that is not found anywhere else. And the Federal and state governments have set aside about 180 acres on the edge of Plymouth, Mass., as the Massasoit National Wildlife Refuge, which contains part of its remaining range. These black, yellow-striped turtles, which weigh up to 10 pounds and live up to 55 years, are thought by wildlife experts to have ranged centuries ago to Ipswich, north of Boston, inland to Concord and out along Cape Cod to Provincetown, said Thomas W. French, a zoologist with the State Division of Fisheries and Wildlife. But their range has been so whittled down over the years that they are now found only in a small area centered in Plymouth.

State Senator Franz S. Leichter has made a point in recent years of tracking campaign contributions to top New York City officials, and last week the West Side Democrat produced his latest conclusion: Of the 200 biggest givers to Board of Estimate members and county Democratic organizations over the last six years, 60 percent do business with the city. The Senator's staff study covered the period from Jan. 1, 1981, to Oct. 31, 1986.

A gas leak forced the police to release about 70 people without making any charges aaainst them early today after a raid on a house where alcohol was believed to have been sold illegally, the authorities said. Six people were arrested and 36 others were ticketed before a gas line in the house broke, said Charles Loughrin, a police officer in this small resort city in southwestern Michigan.

The Giants interrupted their three-day layoff with an 80-minute workout today and then started a two-day stretch away from football. They will return Tuesday to begin practice for their first-round playoff game here the following Sunday against the San Francisco 49ers or the Los Angeles Rams.

Dr. Bruce Chabner's remark that ''You can't buy high-quality research'' is off the mark. Almost every new antibiotic in the last 20 years was the result of privately sponsored and in-house research done by pharmaceutical companies - obviously for profit. MARVIN S. AMSTEY, M.D. Rochester

Rodney Williams, the sophomore quarterback, guided Clemson to a 27-0 halftime lead today before the Tigers stopped a furious Stanford rally for a 27-21 victory in the Gator Bowl. Clemson (8-2-2) was insured the victory when Stanford's final chance ended when Greg Ennis underthrew an intended receiver on a fourth-down play with 1 minute 24 seconds to play. Coach Danny Ford said his Clemson team did not learn to finish off the enemy while watching the new Clint Eastwood movie, ''Heartbreak Ridge,'' on Friday night. ''We didn't deaden them; we wounded them,'' said Ford of Stanford. ''We came within a cat's whisker of getting beat.''

SEVEN years ago, when the Public Health Service drew up a list of 226 goals for improved American well-being by 1990, no one had even heard of AIDS. So while the agency last week reported progress on many of the objectives it did set, it conceded that acquired immune deficiency syndrome is the No. 1 health priority.

FOUR times in six years, the Pentagon has changed the nameplates on the offices in which decisions about weapon purchases are made. The latest procurement czar, Richard Godwin, a former Bechtel Corporation executive who was sworn in this fall, holds a newly created title, Under Secretary of Defense for Acquisition. He will be dealing with a system of developing and buying arms that has been altered dramatically in the years since the Reagan Administration's defense buildup began. Dozens of changes - intended to drive down prices, increase weapons reliability, speed up research and development, punish fraud and lend stability to roller-coaster production cycles, to name just a few goals - are being digested. Now many experts are hoping for a respite from reform, so the military-industrial complex can absorb the changes.

A gas explosion at an Alpine ski resort frequented by United States military personnel and their families killed 6 people today and injured 26, the police said. A seventh person was missing and presumed dead.

A deer jumped through the dining-room window of a home here, raced through the house for 20 minutes, then cut an artery in its leg jumping through another window and died, a state wildlife official said. The doe may have thought she was entering a wooded area when she jumped into the home of Dawn Pizzo Friday.

THIS 12-square-mile subtropical Florida island of 28,000 inhabitants, whose laid-back pace helps it attract two million visitors a year, has become one of the country's hottest real-estate markets. The quiet of this one-time backwater of bicycles on narrow streets and sailboats offshore is pierced these days by the din of construction cranes and trucks, backhoes, chainsaws and hammers as developers, builders, renovators and architects have become the money-making work force. Record prices have failed to deter buyers; the Monroe County Recording Office reports that recordings of sales and other real-estate transactions have soared to more than 1,000 a week. Recent ones include the sale last September of 100 acres of the Navy's historic Truman Annex, including President Harry S. Truman's Little White House, to Pritam Singh, a Maine and Massachusetts developer, for $17.25 million; the sale of the designer Calvin Klein's house for more than $400,000; the $20 million renovation of the La Concha Hotel, built in 1925, and the sale of a house owned by Jerry Herman, the Broadway composer-lyricist, for $435,000 (another house belonging to Mr. Herman is for sale at $585,000).
I think that all players who can lose themselves in a physically demanding sport experience a high.

IN 1972, when Dr. Bal K. Thaper left his post as the administrator of 200 schools in his native Delhi, India, to pursue his education career in the United States, he had every reason to expect success. He had attended the University of Wisconsin in 1961 on a Fulbright scholarship, and now was going back there on a fellowship to earn his doctoral degree. His subsequent dissertation in the field of program budgeting in 1974 was called ''exceptionally well done and a significant contribution to the field'' by Dean Stephen J. Knezevich of the School of Education at the University of Southern California, one of those who conducted Dr. Thaper's oral examination. LLoyd E. Frohreich, professor of educational administration at the University of Wisconsin while Dr. Thaper was there, wrote that his work was ''exemplary,'' adding: ''Mr. Thaper is a congenial and delightful person to know. Although he was born and raised in a foreign country, he writes and speaks with more clarity and understanding than most American graduate students.

EACH year contains about 8,760 hours, but for a married suburban male - at least this married suburban male - only 42 hours of that is available for listening to the stereo as it is supposed to be listened to, according to the results of a 28-year study. As is well known, the stereo should be listened to at full-room volume so as to approximate the sensation of being in a concert hall. Basically, that means loud. Loud enough to shake the floors and walls of a 30-year-old suburban split-level. At the same time, there should be no extraneous noise to distract you from the music.

''LESS is more,'' said Walter Gropius, or Alberto Giacometti, or Laszlo Moholy-Nagy, or Henri Gaudier-Brzeska, or Constantin Brancusi, or Le Corbusier or Ludwig Mies van der Rohe; the remark (first made in fact by Robert Browning) has been severally attributed to all of those more or less celebrated more or less minimalists. Like the bauhaus motto, ''Form follows function,'' it is itself a memorable specimen of the minimalist esthetic, of which a cardinal principle is that artistic effect may be enhanced by a radical economy of artistic means, even where such parsimony compromises other values: completeness, for example, or richness or precision of statement. The power of that esthetic principle is easy to demonstrate: contrast my eminently forgettable formulation of it above - ''artistic effect may be enhanced,'' etc. - with the unforgettable assertion ''Less is more.'' Or consider the following proposition, first with, and then without, its parenthetical elements: Minimalism (of one sort or another) is the principle (one of the principles, anyhow) underlying (what I and many another interested observer consider to be perhaps) the most impressive phenomenon on the current (North American, especially the United States) literary scene (the gringo equivalent to el boom int he latin American novel): I mean the new flowering of the (North) American short story (in particular the kind of terse, oblique, realistic or hyperrealistic, slightly polotted, extrospective, cool-surfaced fiction associated int he last 5 to 10 years with such excellent writers as Frederick Barthelme, Ann Beattie, Raymond Carver, Bobbie Ann Mason, James robison, Mary Robison and Tobias Wolff, and both praised and damned under such labels as ''K-Mart realism,'' ''hick chic,'' ''Diet-Pepsi minimalism'' and ''post-Vietnam, post-literary, postmodernist blue-collar neo-early-Hemingwayism'').

A captured black nationalist guerrilla killed two white police officers and escaped today after a series of skirmishes in northern South Africa. Four other guerrillas were shot to death, the police said. The incident reflected a rare, if modest, setback for South African security forces dealing with insurgents said to belong to the outlawed and exiled African National Congress. It also seemed to be one of the most dramatic escapes in many years.

To the Editor: As director for North American operations of Jamaica National Investment Promotion Ltd., the agency responsible for economic development on behalf of the Jamaican Government here in the United States, I would like to express dismay at ''A Costly Cover for a Failing Policy'' (Forum, Nov. 23). Mr. Bovard states that Jamaica is ''more Socialist'' than before the Caribbean Basin Initiative. Yet all the recommendations for the deregulation of the Jamaican economy have been faithfully carried out.
Leon Wieseltier replies: Mr. Bronner is too reverent. There is nothing unseemly about justifying a philosopher.

THE town of Somers, already suffering growing pains from two new corporations building there and embroiled in both traffic and litigation, is now facing growth of another type: 1,136 new housing units, either in the concept stage or under construction. Eleven percent of the town's land - 2,200 acres of the town's total of 20,800 acres - would be developed if all the plans that are now before the town go through. Forty percent of the land available for development in the town currently is undeveloped. The new houses would increase the town's total of about 5,000 residences by 22 percent. Most of the houses would be clustered, a relatively new arrangement in the rural community. These statistics were gathered by David Fuller, of Fredrick P. Clark Associates, the town's planning consultants, in response to a request by the Planning Board, which has been engulfed with development proposals. The inventory is the first step toward a revision of the master plan, which the town has ordered because of the wave of growth.

THERE were noisy, emotional and sometimes violent reactions last week to the enactment of a law that will largely halt prosecutions of Argentine military officers accused of human rights violations. But more notable, perhaps, was the indifference with which the law was greeted by most Argentines. They were concerned about Christmas and departures to the beach or countryside, so the opposition was left primarily to human rights groups and several small leftist political parties. Some observers here said this may indicate that many Argentines agreed with the military's argument that all share a burden for the excesses of an era in which doctors did not denounce torture, lawyers were afraid to file habeas corpus petitions, the Roman Catholic hierarchy was silent and the dominant newspapers generally took safe positions.

A committee monitoring compliance with a cease-fire agreement between the Government and Communist guerrillas ruled today that the rebels had violated the truce by displaying arms at a rally. It was the first incident ruled a violation since the 60-day truce went into effect Dec. 10. The military has brought 29 ''possible violations'' to the attention of the National Cease-Fire Committee.
THE HEIST: How a Gang Stole $8,000,000 at Kennedy Airport and Lived to Regret It. By Ernest Volkman and John Cummings.
THIRTY years ago, before there were construction and drainage projects in the marshes near Titusville, Fla., there were thousands of dusky sparrows. Five years ago, there were six.

To the Editor: Senator Ernest F. Hollings labels the Iran-contra affair President Reagan's Watergate (Op-Ed, Dec. 14), invoking ''the adage that historical phenomena always happen twice - the first time as tragedy, the second time as farce.'' That's no adage; that's the opening of ''The 18th Brumaire of Louis Bonaparte,'' an 1852 essay by Karl Marx.

Dr. Jaclynn Ila Faffer, director of human services for the United Jewish Appeal-Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York, and Dr. Leonard Silverstein, a senior human factors engineer for the Grumman Aerospace Corporation in Bethpage, L.I., were married last night at the Park Avenue Synagogue. Rabbi Hillel Friedman performed the ceremony.

LONG ISLAND police officers say that Prospect Avenue in New Cassel has long been a major marketplace for illegal drugs, especially the form of cocaine called crack. But a large-scale predawn raid recently conducted by the Nassau County Police Department has left the street, once bustling with drug sellers, almost deserted. Community leaders, residents and officials have publicly praised the raid and the dozens of arrests. But privately they express concern that if the pressure is not kept up by the police, the drug problem will resume. For the people around Prospect Avenue in New Cassel, the evening of Oct. 28 was like every other night. Some were there just to hang out, but others sold drugs to buyers in passing cars. The dealing went on into the early morning hours, the sellers unaware that not far away, at Police Headquarters in Mineola, a lengthy investigation into the drug sales was coming to a head at a predawn briefing.

Reacting to the rapid development of this hilly city's wooded suburban outskirts, the City Council has adopted a moratorium on building outside its downtown in an effort to channel development toward the city center. The one-year measure enacted last month bars development of multi-family housing or large commercial buildings on the city's outskirts. It is a step more often taken by suburbs under the pressure of urban expansion. Several smaller cities in Massachusetts, like Amherst and Framingham, have had construction moratoriums in effect for several years, but Worcester, the second-largest city in New England, is the largest city in the region to enact such a restriction.

WHILE politicians of all persuasions are lately encountering crowds of journalists seeking the latest details and comments on the Iran arms scandal, there are few radio reporters among them. But television reporters and camera crews fill the hearing rooms and news conferences, competing to fill expanded news shows. Once the backbone of electronic journalism and the first source of live reporting, radio news is on the skids. Its decline in many cases reflects a deliberate retreat by station owners who see cutting news as an easy way to reduce costs. In other instances the trend reflects acquiescence to ambitious television stations that have used video and satellite technology to gain the edge in local news.

With a touch of Hitchcock melodrama, the accused Israeli spy waited until he was close to journalists outside the Jerusalem courthouse where he was about to make an appearance, escorted by police. Then he flashed open his left hand for the reporters to see and the photographers to shoot the message he had written in English on his palm: ''Vanunu M. was hijacked in Rome Itl 30.9.86.2100 came to Rome by BA fly 504.'' The newsmen understood. The suspect, Mordechai Vanunu, was telling them that Israeli agents had kidnapped him in Rome on Sept. 30, after he had arrived there, apparently from London on a British Airways flight. The flashing took place on Sunday, but the Government censor had forbidden any publication of the message until Monday, and Israeli papers at first published pictures of the raised hand with the message blacked out by the censor's felt-tipped pen.

Mr. and Mrs. Sterling Lee Pierson of Pottersville, N.J., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Pierson's daughter, Anne Appleton Ives, to John Lee Hopkins, a son of Mrs. John Hopkins of New York and the late Mr. Hopkins.

''Communicating When Your Company Is Under Siege,'' by Marion K. Pinsdorf. Lexington Books, D.C. Heath & Co., Lexington, Mass. 171 pages, $21.95. FIRED employees are not the only people who develop blinders about impending disaster; so too do business executives who think they can handle a corporate crisis by stonewalling or dissembling.

Timothy Grimes, one of the three men attacked in Howard Beach, Queens, on Dec. 20, was arrested yesterday at his Brooklyn home and charged with stabbing the woman he lives with. Mr. Grimes, 20 years old, was been charged with second-degree assault and criminal possession of a knife, a police spokesman, Sgt. John Venetucci, said.

BROTHER ENEMY The War After the War. By Nayan Chanda. Illustrated. 479 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $24.95. ELEVEN years after victory, Vietnam lurches in the company of the world's poorest nations, far behind its non-Communist neighbors in Southeast Asia. Its 60 million people live in conditions not much better, and in some cases worse, than prevailed during the 30 years of war. While unable to produce enough food or goods, the Hanoi Government maintains the world's third-largest standing army (after the Soviet Union and China), and uses it to subjugate its neighboring country, Cambodia - just the way the big boys used to treat Vietnam. The successors of the legendary Ho Chi Minh have made Vietnam a pariah among nations, almost entirely dependent on parsimonious Soviet patronage and continually threatened by its ancestral enemy, China.

In a New Jersey subdivision that one official said had ''just unbelievably high'' levels of radon last spring, the Federal Environmental Protection Agency has reported success with a new ventilation system for houses. The neighborhood, Clinton Knolls in rural Hunterdon County, became a laboratory of sorts when the E.P.A. determined that a cluster of radon-contaminated houses there was the worst ever reported.

IN DAN RATHER'S office on the perimeter of the sprawling CBS newsroom, on a desk next to his aquarium, rests a 1909 copy of Sir Edward Creasy's ''The Fifteen Decisive Battles Of The World.'' To the anchorman, it is a prized volume, and, although its principal considerations are ancient, he regularly gives it current application. There was, for example, the dark Tuesday last summer when Rather and his staff learned that, after more than 200 weeks at the top, the ''CBS Evening News With Dan Rather'' had fallen in the ratings battle to NBC. That day, Rather called a meeting of the ''Evening News'' staff and gave them a locker-room pep talk - ''We're not going to feel sorry for ourselves, we're not going to let this get us down.'' After a dramatic pause, he pronounced to the hushed group: ''Syracuse, 413. Read it.'' Then he turned, and left the room. His staffers puzzled over that. Syracuse 413?

WHEN a book asks if you really want to make a million, it can be hard to put down. So it is with ''Sweat Equity: What It Really Takes to Build America's Best Small Companies by the Guys Who Did It,'' by Geoffrey N. Smith and Paul B. Brown (Simon & Schuster, New York, $17.95), a collection of accounts about entrepreneurs. Mr. Smith, an editor at Forbes magazine, and Mr. Brown, a Holmdel man and columnist for the magazine Inc., provide lively reading. Among ''the players'' - the authors' name for the 37 small companies they evaluate -are Conair and Metex, both in Edison; Sealed Air in Saddle Brook, Tofu Time in Rahway and Timeplex in Woodcliff Lake.

''I thought there was some mistake,'' said Alain Cavalier about the response to his film ''Therese'' at its Cannes Film Festival premiere. The French director was hardly prepared for the awed reactions of the audience, the unanimous raves, and finally the awarding of the Special Jury Prize. ''When I made this film, I assumed it would be for a small audience,'' he said of his dramatic portrait of an adolescent saint. ''During the screening in Cannes, I left the theater because I didn't want to see people walking out.'' ''Therese,'' now playing at the Lincoln Plaza, was hailed as the revelation of this year's festival. Although the international press had been anticipating awards for some of the heavyweights - from ''The Mission'' to ''The Sacrifice'' - expectations were not running high for a low-budget, no-star, and hardly-contemporary story of faith. Indeed, the box-office figures for another French entry, ''Menage,'' had indicated that trendy cynicism and hyperbole were components for success in 1986.
Having played four-wall handball for the last 35 years, I was delighted to read William O'Fallon's article ''The Handball High'' (About Men, Nov. 23).

A month ago, both teams had loftier ambitions than entering the playoffs as a wild-card team. In one division, the Washington Redskins were tied for the lead with the Giants, as they had been for six weeks. In another, the Los Angeles Rams were leading the San Francisco 49ers by a game and a half. Then the Redskins lost to the Giants, never to catch them again, and in the final game of the season the Rams lost a game and the division to the 49ers.

Gov. Michael S. Dukakis smiles broadly when asked if he has ambitions for office beyond Massachusetts, and he promises to think about the question next year. But it is no secret that he has already thought about the White House and whether he can get there on the strength of a reputation in New England that has been sweetened with a blossoming local economy and a resounding re-election triumph. Mr. Dukakis won his third term on Nov. 4, the day after his 53d birthday, with the biggest victory margin of any Massachusetts governor in this century. He was helped in part by an economy so strong that it has created a labor shortage in eastern Massachusetts and a budget surplus so large that disposing of it may have been his biggest political problem in 1986.

OPEC's agreement to slash output by 7 percent in the first half of 1987 sent oil prices above $17 a barrel for the first time since September. OPEC's target is $18 a barrel, but most analysts say the spurt in prices was an overreaction to the OPEC agreement. Reached after two weeks of disharmonious talks led by Rilwanu Lukman, Nigeria's oil minister and the chairman of OPEC, the agreement requires all members except Iraq to cut production. More significantly, it requires them to adhere to a price system for crude products that analysts say will not likely be followed. Other OPEC agreements have failed as members - fearful of losing revenues - cheated on quotas or undercut pricing agreements. The effect of any increase on heating oil and gasoline prices remains uncertain, however, because those refined products often do not respond until crude prices stabilize. But most analysts expect at least slight increases at the pump, possibly dampening Americans' new-found enthusiasm for driving.
THE WINK. By Evelyn Harter. (St. Martin's, $14.95.) An American couple, Leland and Andria Holt, arrive in India, each with a mission.

As one who is engaged in a race against time with advanced metastatic colon cancer, I applaud Dr. Robert Oldham's move to do research in the private sector if it means that state-of-the-art cancer research can advance more rapidly, with less red tape (''In Business to Treat Cancer,'' by Robin Marantz Henig, Nov. 23). Exciting and sophisticated experimentation is under way in Europe, work that will not occur here for, perhaps, years, due to overregulation by the Food and Drug Administration.

Mr. and Mrs. Allen Dean Kremer of Berkeley Heights, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Julia Joanne Kremer, to David William Flemming Ross 3d, the son of Mr. Ross 2d of Stamford, Conn., and the late Joan R. Ross. The future bride attended Goucher College and the Sorbonne in Paris and is a senior at the University of Virginia.

ONE of Nassau County Executive Francis T. Purcell's favorite expressions is ''snow melts.'' Indeed, many of Mr. Purcell's fellow politicians believe that it is more than an expression, it is a Purcell philosophy of government. ''If you wait long enough, snow melts,'' said the 68-year-old Republican, who is retiring next month after almost 40 years in public office. ''Everything takes care of itself in due time. The world doesn't come to an end if I'm not here tomorrow or if a problem isn't solved.'' Critics see that as a rationale for doing nothing, and they say Mr. Purcell let little problems slide until they became bigger problems.

The days and weeks before Ash Wednesday, which marks for many Christians a 40-day penitential period running until Easter, are a time for steel bands and sambas, for gorging on pralines and drinking beer in heroic quantities, for masked balls and elaborately costumed processions. In a word, carnival. Music and parades are a constant, but every culture puts its own stamp on carnival, which may embrace just the few days before Ash Wednesday (March 4 next year) all the way to Cologne's 17-week marathon: Mardi Gras and Jouvert, Sambadrome and Vivaldi, the Women's Carnival and even survivals of pre-Christian Roman feasts. Following are reports from six cities in the Americas and Western Europe where the celebration has been refined to a fine art.

THERE is a Clean Air Act and a Clean Water Act. There is a law establishing the proper handling and disposal of hazardous substances and one requiring the cleanup of dangerous pollutants that have been improperly disposed of. But, experts and government officials say, there is a gaping hole in the legal shield protecting public health and the environment. ''We need a Clean Soil Act,'' says Dr. Ellen Silbergeld, a senior scientist with the Environmental Defense Fund. ''Soil is a really bad actor because it is a major source of exposure to heavy metals like lead and other toxic substances.'' Dr. Barry L. Johnson, associate administrator of the Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry of the United States Public Health Service, agrees, citing ''a lot of research on air and water pollution but not much on soil.''

For ''Columns by Artists,'' the 14 Sculptors Gallery, at 164 Mercer Street, asked 38 artists to make columns that in some way reflected their responses to New York City. The restrictions were that the sculptures not be taller than seven feet or wider than two feet.

The American Medical Association filed suit last week in an effort to keep new Medicare provisions from taking effect Wednesday. Under the new rules, physicians who charge more than the Government-approved fees will be reimbursed at lower rates than those who accept the fee schedule.

The bloody New Year's Day riot at the West Virginia Penitentiary, followed by months of unrest, turned 1986 into the most violent year at the prison in 26 years. Prisoners took control of an entire wing, holding 15 guards and one other worker hostage. By the time it was over two days later, three prisoners had been killed, correction officials had signed an agreement with the prisoners and Gov. Arch A. Moore had met with the inmates after they released the hostages and returned to their cells. Since then, 6 prisoners have been killed and 12 injured at the 120-year-old prison in Moundsville.

Love Is Sweet as Blue It's reassuring to reflect that love letters continue to exist. In ''Ceremony'' (Henry Holt), the anthropologist Nigel Barley describes the style of the amatory epistle in a North African village. The young are particularly a prey to scribal insecurity and a whole sub-industry provides love letters for all occasions. These are passed around between college students with a rapidity and fervour reserved in our own schools for works of dire pornography.

MATISSE The Man and His Art, 1869-1918. By Jack Flam. Illustrated. 523 pp. Ithaca, N.Y.: Cornell University Press. $75. THE life of Henri Matisse doesn't offer much in the way of drama, and Matisse's painting and sculpture, though radiant with feeling, are just a tad impersonal. The Olympian clarity of his art depends on a certain denial of the autobiographical impulse. Matisse is one of those artists - more in the line of Raphael than of Michelangelo - who are reluctant to leave shreds of undigested feeling hanging around. In the midst of his gigantic achievement, it may seem foolish to regret the absence of a more personal note; but Matisse can sometimes project the off-putting, holier-than-thou aura of one of those great writers who have burned - or have meant to burn - all their personal papers. Matisse would probably be glad to know that more than 30 years after his death the relationship between his art and his life looks as elusive as ever. The basic paradoxes remain: he is still the timid slow starter who went farther than almost any other artist of his age; he is still the conventional-mannered bourgeois - people called him ''Professor,'' ''Doctor'' - who smashed every convention of bourgeois art.

There appears to be revived interest in both Expressionist art in general and, specifically, in the Expressionist modern dance that flourished in Germany until the Nazis squelched it in the 30's. Expressionism is the inspiration for Phyllis Lamhut's ''Klein Kunst (Small Art),'' which the Phyllis Lamhut Dance Company presents Sunday afternoon and Monday, Tuesday, Friday and Saturday nights at the Bessie Schonberg Theater.

Trouble Spots for Traffic According to the city's Department of Transportation, these will be among the most severe traffic trouble spots in the region today: * The Harlem River Drive, where the right lane is closed in each direction at 148th Street; * The Manhattan Bridge, where the Manhattan-bound upper roadway will be closed. The lower roadway will have three lanes open into Manhattan; * The Queensboro Bridge, where one lane will be closed in each direction on the lower roadway; * The Madison Avenue Bridge, where one lane is closed in each direction; * The Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive, where two lanes in each direction may be closed intermittently until 8 A.M.; * Riverside Drive, where one-half of the roadway is closed from 153d to 161st Streets. Two-way traffic on the remaining roadway will be maintained at all times.

By now, the Penguins, who tonight played their fourth consecutive overtime game, probably feel they're being toyed with each time they get off to a good start against the Islanders, who nudged them out of second place in the Patrick Division earlier this month. Tonight, after being defeated three times in previous meetings with the Islanders, the Penguins at least gained a 3-3 tie. The Islanders seemed on their way to victory until Dan Quinn tied the game with the Pittsburgh goalie pulled and just 28 seconds left in regulation at the Civic Arena. The Islanders, who had swept the Penguins in a November series and stunned them in a come-from-behind overtime victory Tuesday at Nassau Coliseum, scored three straight second-period goals tonight to wipe out a 1-0 Penguin lead.

''New York without a theater district might as well be Newark,'' cracked a jaded taxi driver in the comedy that opened 1986, Terrence McNally's ''It's Only a Play.'' Twelve months later, Times Square is still unlikely to be confused with the Garden State, but does anyone doubt that the New York theater district is less a place than a state of mind, as hard to pin down as ''the oldest established permanent floating crap game'' of ''Guys and Dolls''? The most warming new American play of 1986, Tina Howe's ''Coastal Disturbances,'' is to be found in a living-room-sized auditorium two flights up from ''The Common Pursuit,'' 30-odd blocks north of Shubert Alley. The year's boldest musical theater experiment, Martha Clarke's ''Vienna: Lusthaus,'' was born in the tiny St. Clement's, in the shadows of the Broadway periphery, before finding a berth at the Public downtown. The most original performer Broadway has seen in ages, Robert Lindsay of ''Me and My Girl,'' turned up innocently at the neighborhood's most widely despised venue - the antiseptic hotel auditorium that usurped three venerable playhouses - and, like it or not, legitimized the place as a theater. And who would have imagined that a 1971 Off Broadway hit by John Guare, ''The House of Blue Leaves,'' would reawaken both the Newhouse and Beaumont theaters at Lincoln Center before moving south for its belated midtown debut?

The cost of paying interest on the Federal debt has leveled off after rising rapidly for more than 25 years and may even decline in the current fiscal year, according to budget experts in the Reagan Administration and Congress. Although the Government is borrowing more, it is paying less in interest as a result of a dramatic decline in interest rates that has in effect produced a windfall for the Administration. Interest payments have long been considered one of the biggest uncontrollable elements in the Federal budget. When the Government borrows money and agrees to pay interest, it incurs a legally binding obligation and would risk default if it failed to pay the full amount of interest due at a particular time.

LIFE has a way of running away with time and the stoutest of resolutions. I should know. The first New Year's resolution I made - with innocence, when I was 5 or 6, so long ago now it seems to my son to have been sometime during the reign of Henry VIII -was to become a ballerina.

Because of the Iran-Iraq war, Iraqi Airways' Flight 163 from Baghdad to Amman, Jordan, took a detour over Saudi Arabia on Christmas day. Shortly after the plane crossed the Saudi border at 28,000 feet, a hijacker brandishing plastic grenades ran up the aisle, and Iraqi security officers began shooting.

As a participant in the protest theater held in the Yale Forest on Thanksgiving Day, I would like to respond to the hunting apologia offered by David M. Smith of the Yale School of Forestry and James Spignesi of the State Department of Environmental Protection's Wildlife Bureau [ ''Protectors Take On Hunters in Forest,'' Dec. 14 ] . Mr. Smith and Mr. Spignesi assert that there is a ''severe overpopulation of deer'' in the forest. By what measure? In 1984, population estimates went from 200 to 500 in three days' time as we pressed for evidence for ''overpopulation.'' By October of this year, Mr. Smith was using a figure of 540. Mr. Spignesi now says there are 360 deer.

Elizabeth Rosa Schreier and Thomas Grahame Davis, 1986 and 1985 graduates, respectively, of Tulane University, plan to be married in June, the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Charles Schreier Jr. of Garden City, L.I., have announced. Mr. Davis is the son of Leroy Grahame Davis of Glen Ridge, N.J., and Sheila Higgins Davis of Ridgewood, N.J. Miss Schreier graduated also from the Ethel Walker School. She is a granddaughter of the late Henry C. Schreier, who was a senior partner of L .F. Rothschild & Company.

WHEN Dr. Joel Clifford Newman asked a few dozen friends and potential business clients over for some Christmas cheer and buffet earlier this month, they came not to his fifth-floor condominium apartment at the Kingsley but to the Sky Lounge on the 31st floor. It was for exactly this purpose that the lounge, complete with kitchen and bar, was incorporated into the 217-unit apartment house at 400 East 70th Street when it was built two years ago - to allow tenants to throw parties that they could not accommodate in their own small apartments. ''There are limitations to apartment living in Manhattan, such as catering to large numbers of people,'' said Dr. Newman, a physician who is a biomedical-technology analyst at Salomon Brothers, the investment banking house. ''You also don't want a crowd of people messing up your apartment and breaking things.'' Other advantages, he said, were the modest $150 charge for the use of the facilities and the pleasing vistas eastward over Manhattan and Queens as far as Shea Stadium. But the main advantage that he and other tenants of the 30 or so Manhattan apartment houses with communal social rooms emphasized was the convenience of being able to entertain in one's own building.

FREDDY the Frog is ''a college frog,'' explained his creator, Gerry Holzman of Islip. ''He's going to wear argyle socks and white bucks and he'll be carrying a book. When he's finished he'll even carry a pennant which will say, ''I Love N.Y. - Bugs,'' Mr. Holzman said. But for now Freddy, a wooden carousel figure that is only half complete, shares the limelight with other carousel animals created by Mr. Holzman, and Jim Beatty of Port Washington, at the ''Art of the Carousel'' exhibition at Guild Hall in East Hampton. The show, which is to run through Jan. 4, also features carved carousel animals from a leading collector, Charlotte Dinger.

Rex Chapman, a freshman guard, scored 26 points today as Kentucky dominated Louisville in posting a 85-51 victory. It was the worst home loss suffered by Louisville in Denny Crum's 16 years as head coach. Kentucky (6-1) hit 11 of 17 3-point shots, with Chapman making five of eight. The Wildcats shot 54.2 percent on 32 of 59 shots, while Louisville managed 21 of 58 field goals for 36.2 percent.

He says his reasons are merely legal, but Governor-elect Evan Mecham of Arizona is drawing fire as a new kind of grinch. Following through on a little-noticed campaign pledge, he says he plans to rescind a state holiday honoring the Rev.

Carin Rand Collins, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Collins of Wesley Hills, N.Y., was married yesterday to Arthur Baer Cavataro, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas T. Cavataro of Rye, N.Y. Rabbi Abraham Krantz and the Rev. William Naughton, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Tamcrest Country Club in Alpine, N.J. Mr. Cavataro, a first-year law student at Loyola University in New Orleans, and Mrs. Cavataro are graduates of the State University of New York College at Oneonta. The bride's father is an independent realtor in New York. Mr. Cavataro's father is a senior associate at the New York public-relations firm of Douglas G. Hearle & Associates.

SINCE the 19th century, Chinese scholars have been debating how to preserve their country's ''Chineseness'' while at the same time embracing Western science and technology. Some Confucian scholars used to argue that Western scientific knowledge was only a tool that could in the end be used to strengthen traditional values. But others insisted that opening the doors would inexorably erode and destroy the Confucian ethos. Last week, as tens of thousands of students marched through Shanghai's narrow streets shouting slogans for democracy and freedom, the dilemma facing China's leaders was much like the one that had troubled Confucian traditionalists. For as China methodically opens itself, creating an economic landscape akin to the West's, intellectuals are asking: Can the political principles that nourish Western economies be far behind? And if so, what does that entail for the Communist Government and its political values?

GIFT BOOKS IN PHILADELPHIA Bibliophiles will not want to miss ''A Bookman's Holiday: Gift Books in the Fine Press Collection,'' currently on view at the Rosenbach Museum and Library in Philadelphia through Feb. 1. The collections, given to Dr. A. S. W. Rosenbach over the years to mark the holidays, includes ''Dr. Sam: Johnson in the Stolen Christmas Box (as related by James Boswell, Christmas 1774) by Lillian de la Torre, ''The Awful History of Bluebeard,'' by William Makepeace Thackery, privately printed for Jerome Kern, and Christopher Morley's ''The Christmas Tobacco,'' one of 300 copies. The museum, at 2010 DeLancey Place, near Rittenhouse Square, has more than 30,000 books, 270,000 manuscripts and letters, 20,000 works of art on paper and 300 paintings. It is housed in an elegant 19th-century townhouse, listed in the National Register of Historic Places, the former home of Dr. Rosenbach, a rare book dealer, and his brother, Philip, an art and antiques dealer.

McGUIRES IN MILLBURN The McGuire Sisters and their orchestra, direct from Las Vegas with a new nightclub act, will be at the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn New Year's Eve for two shows at 7 and 10 P.M. Tickets are $30, $40 and $45. The songs ''Sincerely,'' ''May You Always,'' ''Something's Gotta Give,'' ''Sugartime,'' ''Just for Old Time's Sake'' and ''How Much Is That Doggie in the Window?'' are among the more than 30 hits the sisters have had since they first performed on the Arthur Godfrey Show on radio and television. Their distinctive sound - the harmonizing of three voices - has won the sisters, Chris, Phyllis and Dorothy, many fans, and they have entertained Queen Elizabeth and four Presidents.

''When we first started out, we thought of it as the frontier,'' said Ira Krauss, president of First Sterling Corporation, ''but now I don't think this is pioneering anymore.'' He was referring to the Ellington, the 29-story rental building his company is putting up on the southeast corner of Eighth Avenue and West 52d Street in a partnership with Rose Associates.

Judge and Mrs. Sol Wachtler of Manhasset, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alison Toni Wachtler, to Barry Glenn Braunstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Braunstein of Weston, Mass. The wedding is planned for June.

The days and weeks before Ash Wednesday, which marks for many Christians a 40-day penitential period running until Easter, are a time for steel bands and sambas, for gorging on pralines and drinking beer in heroic quantities, for masked balls and elaborately costumed processions. In a word, carnival. Music and parades are a constant, but every culture puts its own stamp on carnival, which may embrace just the few days before Ash Wednesday (March 4 next year) all the way to Cologne's 17-week marathon: Mardi Gras and Jouvert, Sambadrome and Vivaldi, the Women's Carnival and even survivals of pre-Christian Roman feasts. Following are reports from six cities in the Americas and Western Europe where the celebration has been refined to a fine art. Cologne is called the city of four C's -churches, commerce, culture and carnival.

You couldn't hurry through Savannah if you wanted to. The city's 20 squares of parks, landscaped with palmetto trees, azaleas and native flowers and shaded by giant live oaks, are spaced throughout the heart of the city, and the single-lane streets that encircle the squares carry traffic one way only. The mansions clustered around the squares evoke a period of antebellum self-confidence and extravagance. In winter, the squares are uncrowded and it is easy to survey the city's surpassingly lovely landscape. House Museums Three of the most elegant and sophisticated houses in Savannah were designed by a young Englishman from Bath, the fashionable watering place of Jane Austen's England. William Jay designed and oversaw the building of these three Regency houses at a time when Savannah's economy was experiencing a great cotton boom. The Owens-Thomas House (124 Abercorn Street; 912-233-9743), considered one of the best examples of Regency architecture in the United States, is a fawn-colored, two-story stone building completed in 1819. In the dining room, there is an ingenious indirect lighting system and on the second level a graceful wooden bridge connects the front and rear of the house. The house is open Tuesday through Saturday, from 10 A.M. to 4:30 P.M.; Sunday and Monday, from 2 to 4:30 P.M. Admission is $3; $2 for students.

Unlike the French, who have tried to limit American influences, Italians think American culture is ''tutto O.K.'' Whereas the French Government has taken steps to keep Americanisms from ''corrupting'' the French language, words and phrases from across the Atlantic pop up often in Italy's media and popular speech. American movies, books, athletes, music, entertainers, language and humor have captured a seemingly unlimited market. Recent newspaper headlines that used a mixture of Italian and English included: - ''Non abbiamo alcun centro spirituale o idealogico, ma molti shopping centers.'' (We don't have any spiritual or ideological center, but a lot of shopping centers). - ''La TV e una pessima baby sitter.'' (Television is a bad baby sitter). - ''Una lady tra i grandi della scienza'' (A lady among the greats of science).

Mr. and Mrs. Victor A. Sachse of Baton Rouge, La., have announced the engagement of her daughter, Alison Elise Paul, to Douglas Gilmore Miller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan B. Miller Jr. of Stamford, Conn., and East Grand Lake, Me. The wedding is planned for April 25.

Lucinda Douglas Hale, a manager at Coopers & Lybrand, the accounting and consulting firm in New York, and Lawrence Alfred Willis, the partner in charge of bank consulting at Coopers & Lybrand, plan to be married Feb. 28. Mr. and Mrs. Ben Gaynes Jr. of Weston, Conn., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Gaynes's daughter to the son of Mr. and Mrs. James Russell Willis of Las Vegas, Nev., formerly of Richmond.

The death of a black man in Howard Beach, Queens, in what is widely perceived as the worst racial incident in New York City in years has, after more than a week of intense scrutiny, left a host of unanswered questions. Some facts are not in dispute: a group of white youths at a party, hearing that three blacks were walking through their community, chased and beat them with a baseball bat, a tree limb and fists. One victim, Michael Griffith, a 23-year-old construction worker, was killed by a car as he fled across a busy highway. But as the investigation of the case has unfolded, gaps and contraditions have emerged, leaving elements of mystery and doubt over many of the things that happened on the night of Dec. 19-20 and in the tense aftermath of the episode. Some questions involve the roles of the assailants, including three white teen-agers charged with second-degree murder, and of the motorist whose car killed Mr. Griffith. Others pertain to the victims. Still others arise from apparent contradictions in accounts by the police and by witnesses.

THERE'S still time to ring out the old year in music - the Concert Society of Putnam and Northern Westchester has a Baroque fest at 8 o'clock this evening in Somers' St. Luke's Church (Bach, Manfredini and Couperin concertos for trumpets and strings: call 225-9204 or 277-8564 for reservations) - and ballet lovers can pull in three more ''Nutcrackers'' through the Westchester Ballet Company performances at 2:30 P.M. today, tomorrow and Tuesday at Marymount College (762-4228). For the most part, however, our tonal sights are already on 1987, which gets off to a nice start with a bonanza of free concerts. Let us start at the New Rochelle Library, where virtually all the recitals sponsored by the music review committee do not require admission, although donations are gratefully received. Next Sunday we find an intriguing 2:30 P.M. program by three young Korean artist-students from the Manhattan School: first the flutist Hae-Kyung Lee joins the pianist Young-Ho Kim for Sonatas by Hummel and Reinecke; then Miss Lee changes partners for Rana Park, for the Flute and Harp Sonata by Johann Krumpholz, plus another piece for that lovely combination by Adrian Schapo-Schnikov.

The days and weeks before Ash Wednesday, which marks for many Christians a 40-day penitential period running until Easter, are a time for steel bands and sambas, for gorging on pralines and drinking beer in heroic quantities, for masked balls and elaborately costumed processions. In a word, carnival. Music and parades are a constant, but every culture puts its own stamp on carnival, which may embrace just the few days before Ash Wednesday (March 4 next year) all the way to Cologne's 17-week marathon: Mardi Gras and Jouvert, Sambadrome and Vivaldi, the Women's Carnival and even survivals of pre-Christian Roman feasts. Following are reports from six cities in the Americas and Western Europe where the celebration has been refined to a fine art.

Race car designers, builders and drivers spent the 1986 season in their inevitable pursuit of higher speed. And as usual, the rule makers did their best to reduce speeds - or at least slow the rate of increase. Racing fans still enjoyed a vintage year of competition as Alain Prost aced out Nigel Mansell and Nelson Piquet to become the first driver to win consecutive world championships in a quarter-century. Prost's Porsche-powered McLaren wasn't always the fastest car. But success in modern grand prix racing calls for a delicate balance of raw speed and finesse. Keke Rosberg, the recently retired former world champion who was Prost's teammate this past season, says that the French driver ''is in a class by himself'' as a modern grand prix driver.

China's powerful Central Military Commission, headed by Deng Xiaoping, has concluded its largest meeting since 1978, the official newspaper People's Daily reported today. The newspaper, which described the Dec. 11-25 meeting as ''historically significant,'' said the main theme was ''political work'' and the promotion of socialist ethics within the military.

CHAMBER-STYLE NEW YEAR An unusual way to spend New Year's Eve could be in church. At St. Luke's Episcopal Church at 1864 Post Road in Darien, the Fairfield County Chamber Ensemble will perform all six Brandenburg Concertos beginning Wednesday at 8 P.M. The audience and musicians will ring in the New Year afterward with a champagne reception. The soloists include Douglas Myers, horn player; Janet and Donna Davis, violinist and cellist; Bernice Stochek-Friedson, violinist, and Martha Salzman, harpsichordist. The music director of the church, Stuart Gardner, is the conductor. Among the ensemble members, all of them Connecticut musicians, are Jane Shelly, flutist; Robert and Sue Tenca, violinist and violist; John Havlik and Janet Rosen, oboists; Kathy McGovern, violist; Charlotte Moulyn, Nabuo Kitagawa and Randy Scholtz, cellists; Marie Elaine Baskin, bassist, and Mary Drake, bassoonist.

LINDA JOSEPH'S neck began bothering her after she spent several evenings reading '' 'The Clan of the Cave Bear' and the two sequels while lying on my side,'' she said. Before long, the pain had grown so agonizing she could barely hold her head up. Mrs. Joseph, a medical technologist at Yale-New Haven Hospital, was cradling her head in her hands at work one day when a doctor suggested she seek help at the hospital's new Center for Pain Management. After treatment there, Mrs. Joseph's neck pain has diminished. ''The thing about acute pain is that, after 24 hours you're holding on by a hair and after 72 hours, you're suicidal,'' said Mrs. Joseph.

The same instinct that assures us that the sun will rise tomorrow also allows us to believe that an object, transported over any distance, will be the same when it reaches its destination. A lawn mower bought in Dallas and trucked to San Francisco will, barring any catastrophe, be the same lawn mower. But what about cars? In America the car is more often than not a reliable tool, as easy to operate as a blender and as familiar as the old sofa in the den. Transport that car abroad, however, and it can turn into an exotic species, full of quirks and hidden agendas. No longer the patriot's best friend, it becomes a cantankerous tutor, showing the driver a side of the country -and himself - that he never expected to see.

''Land of Opportunity: The Entrpreneurial Spirit in America,'' by Donald Lambro. Little, Brown & Co., Boston. 176 pages, $17.95. ''Breakthroughs!'' by P. Ranganath Nayak and John M. Ketteringham. Rawson Associates, N.Y. 371 pages, $16.95. BILL Bowerman began designing track shoes in the early 1950's, when he was a third-year track coach at the University ofOregon. When the leading American sporting-goods companies showed no interest in his designs, Mr. Bowerman, following instructions given him by a shoe repairman, began making the shoes himself. Today, Nike Inc., the company Mr. Bowerman founded with Philip Knight, is not only a billion-dollar business employing almost 2,000 workers, but is also the shoe of choice for many celebrities as well as runners.

AN ECONOMICAL diarist looks back at 1986. Jan. 7: Violent illness during the night and all this day. Jan. 9: Intense yearning to be in Barbados, Acapulco, Tahiti. Anyplace with sun. Not Los Angeles, though. Jan. 20: Onset of cold this afternoon about 5 P.M.

WHEN ROCKS DANCE. Elizabeth Nunez-Harrell. (Putnam, $17.95.) Set in Trinidad around the turn of the century, this first novel by the Trinidad-born writer Elizabeth Nunez-Harrell begins with Emilia, a native woman whose lover is an Englishman, giving birth to twin sons whom she has been instructed by an obeahman to sacrifice.

A PISTOL-PACKING Samuel Colt hob-nobs with the rifle-manufacturer Christian Sharps while a nattily attired Mark Twain, poised by his handsome red high-wheel bicycle, looks on. Meanwhile, hot-air balloons race across the New Haven Harbor. Elsewhere, Charles Goodyear is busy vulcanizing rubber, while, across the state, no less than the entire History of Civilization marches on. The activity is on walls around the state, as mural painting enjoys a new vogue. ''I think you are going to see murals blossoming in the coming years,'' the chairman of the Central Connecticut State University art department, Dr. Michael Cipriano, said. ''It is a cyclical thing, and it does follow trends. But murals have been neglected, and people are starting to pay attention again.''

A Cuban revolutionary hero who spent 22 years in prison said this week that Fidel Castro, in his first year in power, rejected helping Nicaraguans who wanted to overthrow Anastasio Somoza Debayle. The Cuban, Eloy Gutierrez Menoyo, 52 years old, was freed last Sunday after having been imprisoned since 1965 for leading a quixotic effort to mount a counterrevolution against Mr. Castro, his former ally. By then Mr. Gutierrez Menoyo was then a leader of the anti-Castro group known as Alpha 66. At a news conference this week, Mr. Gutierrez Menoyo said he was secretly sent to Nicaragua shortly after Mr. Castro came to power in 1959. He said he had met clandestinely with nascent forces building against General Somoza, who was then in power.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Harold J. Eckardt of Somers, N.Y., of the engagement of her daughter Allison Meder Eckardt to George Macgill Ledes, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John George Ledes of Katonah, N.Y. Miss Eckardt, a daughter also of the late Mr. Eckardt, and her fiance plan to be married in May. The future bride is an associate editor at The Magazine Antiques in New York.

Next week, seven teams of sculptors wielding chain saws and chisels will carve oversized statues out of 87,000 pounds of ice that will be delivered to Copley Square in Boston. By the time the sculptors are finished, the ice cream magnates Ben and Jerry will be 160 miles away, concocting 800 pounds of cherries jubilee for 3,000 people in Albany. They plan to ignite the confection at nightfall. Across the country, extravagant events like these will occur simutaneously on New Year's Eve in cities that have organized First Night celebrations. Although the practice of holding a citywide arts celebration -in which public and private spaces are turned over for one night to artists - originated in Boston, where it is in its 11th year, other cities have recently adopted the idea. This year's new First Night cities include, in addition to Albany, York, Pa.; New Bedford, Mass.; Charlotte, N.C.; San Francisco and Milwaukee.

ON Dec. 31, you will find me slipping into the approaching year as comfortably as a child into mittens, but it wasn't always that way. When I was younger, I was haunted by that universal law: a girl over the age of 15 must have a date on New Year's Eve. This didn't pose problems for the sweater girls, who looked cute in bobby sox and saddle shoes - the girls so neatly impersonated by Kathleen Turner on the screen. They had boyfriends, wore makeup and were invited to so many parties they bounced from one to the other.

Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Sanford of Fox Chapel, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter Kristie Lee Sanford to Ronald Steven Staffieri, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Roland Staffieri of Hicksville, L.I. An April wedding is planned. The future bride, a branch divisional merchandiser at the M. O'Neil Company, a department store in Akron, Ohio, graduated from Southern Methodist University, having studied in Paris her junior year.

A mild earthquake today shook a small island to which residents recently returned after a volcanic eruption, the Meteorological Agency reported. No damage or injuries were reported. Agency officials said the tremor on O-shima, 70 miles south of Tokyo, registered 3.0 on the Richter scale.

When Vinson Cole makes his Metropolitan Opera debut on Saturday, it will be one more of his frequent appearances as a pinch-hitter, a not unusual phase at this point in an operatic career, but one that he hopes is about to give way to a steadier diet of first-time-around appearances. ''This year, I've become the tenor who jumps in for indisposed tenors in the Verdi Requiem,'' Mr. Cole said with a laugh at lunch last week, referring to recent performances with Carlo Maria Giulini in Berlin and a few weeks ago in Chicago with Claudio Abbado. ''And I was asked to substitute for Pavarotti in the last of four Requiems by the New York Philharmonic on Dec. 16, but I was already covering - for the tenor in 'Fledermaus' at the Met, - and they wouldn't release me.'' It is in ''Die Fledermaus,'' in fact, that Mr. Cole will make his Met debut, as the second Eisenstein of the season in the new production of the Strauss opera. He also will step in as Rodolfo for the season's final ''La Boheme'' in the house in April and during the company's tour of city parks in June.

THIS year brought the greatest surge in sales of new closed-end investment funds since the late 1920's - about $4 billion worth. While that made a banner year for Wall Street underwriters and the fund managers, results for investors who bought into most of the 28 new funds have been disappointing. All of the largest issues are trading below the prices of their initial public offerings. The dismal tally is no surprise to professionals accustomed to the risks of I.P.O.'s. In August, Legg Mason Wood Walker Inc. led an underwriting group that distributed $60 million worth of the World Wide Value Fund Inc., at $20 a share. After underwriting fees of $1.50 and portfolio losses, the net asset value of the multi-country fund has slumped to about $17, the share price to $15. Investors who bought on the initial offering in August have lost 25 percent.

Thousands of Orthodox Jewish women who have received civil divorces remain unable to remarry because their husbands are unwilling to grant them traditional Jewish divorces, according to Jewish leaders. And since only the husband can grant the divorce - known as a Get - many Jewish wives have become victims of recalcitrant husbands who refuse, some out of spite, others for blackmail and extortion, according to statements at a recent forum on Jewish divorce and civil law. ''This problem has left thousands of devout Jewish women in a painful marital limbo,'' a co-sponsor of the forum, City Council President Andrew J. Stein, told more than 300 women, matrimonial lawyers and rabbis gathered at the Association of the Bar of the City of New York. Estimating that there are 15,000 of these women in New York State alone, Jewish leaders noted that in the closed, relatively autonomous Jewish communities of the past, religious authorities could level effective sanctions against a husband. In modern times, however, the rabbinical courts have authority only over those people who voluntarily submit themselves to its dictates.

ONCE, the musical theater was ruled by Americans. The English, it was believed, had no knack for creating and producing musicals with flair. The success of ''Oliver!'' proved an exception. Now that the American musical is in jeopardy and the English seem to have cornered the new Broadway song-and-dance market, ''Oliver!'' first presented in London in 1960 and then in New York in 1963, remains an exception, though of a new and different sort.

Michel Goulet scored with 2 minutes 2 seconds remaining in regulation tonight to allow the Quebec Nordiques to salvage a 2-2 tie against New Jersey after Alain Chevrier made 38 saves for the Devils. Goulet scored his 20th goal of the season after taking a pass from Jason Lafreniere and firing a shot from the slot that beat Chevrier to his stick side.

I have long been a fan of the genre Richard M. Levine writes about in his article ''Murder, They Write'' (Nov. 16). What draws me to these books, besides the fact that they contain all the elements of a fast-paced whodunit, is the alluring, disturbing fact that the stories are true and could happen right in one's own backyard.

MENTION salary arbitration and club officials will recoil in horror. It is just about that time again - eligible players can begin filing next Monday - but to the owners and general managers, it seems like only yesterday (10 months ago, actually) that Orel Hershiser was winning a $1 million salary after earning $212,000 the previous year and Bret Saberhagen was grabbing a $925,000 prize after pitching one season earlier for $160,000. Hershiser, they will tell you even if you didn't ask, had a 14-14 record this year and Saberhagen was 7-12. The club officials still feel the pain. Club officials do not like salary arbitration, never have. George Steinbrenner recently called it the ''real cancer, the villain'' of players' salaries that owners are methodically trying to lower. The owners know they can't make arbitration disappear, but they are trying to do something about it. The Player Relations Committee, the owners' labor arm, has commissioned a study of the arbitration procedure by two university professors. The P.R.C. hasn't publicized the existence of the study, but in a recent report to the clubs, a copy of which was obtained by The New York Times, the committee said, ''In conducting the study, we've asked the professors to focus primarily on how to make the present system work better for the clubs. The study will also suggest changes which could be proposed to the Players Association during the next basic agreement negotiations.''

RELATIVELY few summertime hiker-naturalists are abroad when the forests and mountains are deep in snow, and this is a pity because there is much to be seen at that time of year. Long before rope tows and lifts were hauling marvelously attired downhill skiers to the summits of hills and mountains, hardy, dedicated groups of winter enthusiasts were touring forest and meadow on snowshoes or heavy, hand-crafted slabs of hickory or ash, and their descendants continue the tradition, albeit with superior equipment. It is the snow and cold that stops most people, but proper clothing, skis or snowshoes -and a dash of caution and maps and compass if one is planning an extended tour - are all that is needed to enter a sparse and wondrous world of white in which earth-bound creatures leave their signatures for all to see and decipher, and the riotous greenery of warmer months is stripped from the forest, baring the essential shapes of trees and shrubs. Many winter wanderers are content to be exercising, paying only casual attention to the world about them. But a little curiosity - a few pauses in the rush from place to place - can add spice to the endeavor.

A brilliancy prize is a grand thing even if it won't pay the rent. It expresses appreciation for the exceptionally creative, imaginative performance that everyone delights in but cannot expect to see often. Whereas first prize in a tournament is awarded to the player who fights his way through to the top in game after game - no matter how -the brilliancy prize is given for producing four or five glorious hours in one day. It is usually set at approximately 1/20th of the first prize.

This was a year when small gifts seemed to be the biggest blessings. There was no new esthetic, no dominating style, no giant sale of photographs to the J. Paul Getty Museum. But there was enough activity in terms of pictures on the walls to make categorization necessary. Here, then, are the year's highlights: Really big pictures: ''The Real Big Picture,'' organized by Marvin Heiferman for the Queens Museum last January, challenged the notion of photography as a medium unto itself better than any other exhibition to date. The show included 50 artists whose allegiances lie primarily with the tradition of painting and sculpture, not photography, and as it happened their photographs are mostly much larger than lap size. But size was not the real point of ''The Real Big Picture''; the future of photography as an art was. Mr. Heiferman's essay also contained one of the year's most provocative lines: ''Photography's true gift may not be the closeness it provides, but the distance it allows.''

If you fancy horseback riding through countryside around an abandoned limestone quarry once owned by Thomas A. Edison, a new residential development in Franklin Township, N.J., may be just the place. Tentatively called the Cliffs at Emerald Lake, after what is to be the new name of the larger of its two quarry-formed lakes, the development is planned as three separate villages with an equestrian theme on 536 acres bounded by Edison, Stewartsville and Good Springs Road that were used around the turn of the century by the Edison Cement Works.

Announcement has been made by Elaine Kanter of New York and Miami Beach of the engagement of her daughter Stacy Jaye Kanter to Eric Martin Kornblau, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jules H. Kornblau of New York and Fair Harbor, Fire Island, L.I. The future bride, a daughter also of the late Ronald I. Kanter, is a law clerk to Judge Raymond J. Dearie of the United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York. She graduated magna cum laude from the State University of New York at Albany and is an alumna of the Brooklyn Law School, where she was the managing editor of The Law Review.

ON Nov. 19, 1985, the headline in a local newspaper announced: ''$225,225: Average Price of a Home in Westchester Hits New High.'' By July 12, 1986, the headline read: ''Westchester Home Price: $301,239.'' To purchase such a home today would require a minimum annual income of $130,000. Yet according to the 1980 Census, the average household income in Westchester County was $29,626. The County Planning Department's revised figure for 1984 was $37,434. The fact that there is a housing crisis in Westchester has been amply documented and there is growing realization that single young professionals, young families and the elderly can't find housing. But the implications of the crisis on the quality of life in the county may not be fully grasped. It is also a fact that the housing shortage has a direct effect on the employment market and the future economic health of the county. Notice the number of ''Help Wanted'' signs on supermarkets, all kinds of small retail shops, even in the larger malls.

Victoria Barton looks younger than 17 years old as she crosses a deserted playground on Chicago's South Side. She seems small and vulnerable against the bleak backdrop of high-rise buildings of the Robert Taylor Homes, where 20,000 residents, virtually all black, live in concentrated poverty. Her first child is expected in February. The unmarried teen-ager, who lives in the project with her mother and some of her nine sisters and brothers, admits she is worried about feeding and caring for an infant. But she is comforted now, knowing that her child, even before birth, is eligible for an innovative program of benefits and services for all babies born next year in 6 of the 28 Taylor houses. About 125 to 150 children are expected to qualify. Most will be born to unwed teen-agers.

Bernard Jackson scored 31 points, including three key free throws in the last three minutes today, to give Loyola of Chicago an 83-82 upset over Illinois. Illinois was ranked No. 9 in The Associated Press poll and 10th in the United Press International poll. The score was tied 18 times and the lead changed hands 17 times during the contest. With the score tied at 65-65, Loyola (5-3) scored the next 10 points, including a 3-point play by Gerald Hayward and a 3-point basket by Jackson, to take a 75-65 lead with 7 minutes 39 seconds left.

To the Sports Editor: Regarding the recent survey of pro football fans (''Fans Perceive Rise in Injuries,'' The New York Times, Dec. 21), the poll focused on the cause of injuries rather than the impact of injuries on the game. The bottom line, unfortunately, is that no longer does the best team win - the most desired result in any sport - but the team(s) that can survive the season relatively injury-free have the best chance of success. Decimation is the rule rather than the exception, and it will steadily worsen. HERB BODENSTEIN The Bronx

Andrei D. Sakharov said today that because of physical infirmity and a desire to renew his work in physics, he could not serve as the rallying point for dissent in the Soviet Union. But he said in an interview that he would continue to seek ''the liberation of prisoners of conscience.'' ''This is an area where I cannot spare my efforts,'' he said. The interview was one of a series he has been giving to Western reporterssince he returned Tuesday from exile in the city of Gorky. He was banished in early 1980 for public criticism of policies under Leonid I. Brezhnev.

Digitech Inc. may not be a household word to investors, and it has not attracted much of a following among Wall Street analysts. But the small - 200 employees - St. Louis-based company is near the top of the charts of best-performing stocks of 1986.

The United States defeated Czechoslovakia, 8-2, today in the World Junior Hockey Championships for players under age 20. The Americans built a 3-0 lead in the first period, then broke the game open with five goals in the last period. The defending champion, the Soviet Union, routed Switzerland, 8-0, for their second straight victory.

Watching the crowds at the year's three most conspicuous popular successes - ''Vienna 1900'' at the Museum of Modern Art, ''Henri Matisse: The Early Years in Nice'' at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, and ''Van Gogh in Saint-Remy and Auvers'' at the Metropolitan Museum - we cannot imagine them as even partial failures, but in point of fact it is by a mysterious process, akin to alchemy, that an exhibition becomes unforgettable. Size alone is no guarantee. We can all remember huge undertakings, hugely subsidized, that went nowhere in particular. Timing can be important. People stood in line this year to see what they would not have crossed the road to see 10 years ago. Magic is magic, and cannot be willed into existence. A memorable surprise, in that context, was the exhibition of Indian sculpture and painting at the Asian Art Museum in San Francisco that was the final event in the Festival of India, which made itself felt in almost every state in the union. Unlike almost all the other events in the festival, this was made up entirely of very superior loans from India. Arranged according to categories of feeling, from euphoria to dejection, the sculptures were displayed and lit in ways that had an exceptional immediacy. Of the distanced formality of conventional museum practice, there was never a trace.

A South Korean pilot who took off behind Korean Air Lines Flight 007 on its flight into Soviet airspace in 1983 believes that an airline policy of punishing crew errors deterred the crew from turning back and led to the plane's being shot down, according to an article published in Seoul. Concern for loss of face could also have been a factor, the article suggests on the basis of interviews with the pilot, Capt. Y. M. Park, and other pilots from the airline. Captain Park, now retired, is quoted as saying that he radioed the pilot of the doomed plane to ask why his flight was slipping behind schedule. The answer from the pilot of Flight 007, Capt. S. I. Chun, was, ''The wind is strong.'' This indicated to Captain Park that something was not right aboard, the article says.

The Chinese have the charming habit of naming their years after animals - the Year of the Rat, the Year of the Tiger, and so forth. If the past year in audio were to be characterized in this way, it might well be called the Year of the Badger. It was a time for the cozy consolidation of past gains, of curling up comfortably in one's lair to mull over noble adventures gone before. The noblest adventure of recent years has been, of course, the advent of digital recording early in the decade, and in 1986 the audio industry was still, in various ways, catching up with that momentous step. For example, during the last year intensive engineering efforts were aimed at fortifying amplifiers and loudspeakers against the more strenuous demands of digital sound. The period of consolidation, therefore, was not exactly a matter of resting upon laurels. Rather, the year was devoted to bringing important design details into line with the general standards of the digital era.

The Iraqi authorities have started an investigation into the possibility that security officers at the Baghdad airport aided the hijackers who tried to take over an Iraqi airliner that was on its way to Amman on Thursday, according to a senior Jordanian official. The plane crash-landed on a remote Saudi airfield and burst into flames after a shootout on board between the hijackers and security guards and the explosion of several grenades. The Saudi authorities have said that there were 107 people on the plane and that at least 62 were killed. Other sources have said there were fewer passengers, and reports on fatalities varied. Unconfirmed reports today said the death toll might have risen to 71.
To the Sports Editor: There is no mystery about the nosedive of the baseball winter meetings. Once, they were the kind of take-your-shoes-off-and-partake-in-the-chicken-wings kind of affair.

Three recent events of widely different kinds and in widely separated parts of America remind us that despite all of our self-congratulation - and denials - relations between blacks and whites are rarely better than uneasy, and often burst out terrifyingly. The events - in Howard Beach, Queens, N.Y.; Jefferson Parish, La., and Arizona - and their aftermaths tell us a lot about racial relations. In all three cases, individuals who had spoken or acted against black people or their interests or symbols found that disapproval of their acts was far from universal and that indeed they had many supporters. The most recent event was the beating of three young black men by a group of white teen-agers in Howard Beach and the subsequent death of one.

The Reagan Administration budget proposal due next week is expected to include a provision that drug manufacturers pay a hefty fee to the Food and Drug Administration for examining drugs submitted for marketing approval, and the pharmaceutical industry is gearing up for a fight to oppose it. The stakes are large, with the industry expecting the Federal agency to propose charging $160,000 to $170,000 to process an application for a new drug.

TO THE EDITOR: One point in Howell Raines's review of ''Bearing the Cross'' prompts a footnote. The passage from Martin Luther King Jr.'s account of his crucial ''kitchen experience'' in Montgomery, quoted without further explanation in the book and in the review, is itself a nearly exact quotation from the old hymn ''Never Alone.''

WANT to bet? Perhaps not. Perhaps you're no gambler. Perhaps you think gambling is irresponsible, immoral or even pathological. Well, I'm no gambler either, but I'll bet that you're a speculator or a dealer in speculations. Otherwise, why are you - and I - reading the business pages? Sure, there are bits and pieces of news that have some bearing on our businesses, but most of the stories, all of the gossip and all of the pages of tables and graphs interest us mainly because of what we grandly call our investments.
