''Nonsense,'' you are probably saying. ''I am a prudent investor, in for the long term. I put my money into a mutual fund and let it grow. I don't fiddle with options or futures, and I'm philosophically opposed to program trading, even if I don't understand how it works.''

''FROM the skewed view of my clientele, 1986 was a terrific year,'' says Robert A. Clarfeld of Clarfeld & Company, a Manhattan accounting firm that specializes in financial planning for executives. For one thing, with taxes on capital gains rising to a maximum 28 percent in 1987, from 20 percent now, many asset-rich owners have been cashing in appreciated stock, real estate and even their businesses, while many professionals profited by helping them cut the deals. One of Mr. Clarfeld's clients, a young investment banker, received a bonus check for $1.5 million. Aside from the huge year-end bonuses that have become customary on Wall Street in the 80's, increasing numbers of people are earning large sums of money over a relatively short working span -entrepreneurs, models, actors and professional athletes, for example. ''People are moving in and out of the top in a shorter time,'' said Gary N. Skoloff, a Newark family lawyer with a high-income clientele. ''When they flop, there is nothing left.''

President Reagan today offered a favorable assessment of the year in terms of superpower relations, saying that ''this year, relations between the United States and the Soviet Union advanced.'' In his weekly radio address, the President added that ''1986 has been a good year for the cause of human freedom and good for the cause of world peace.'' Mr. Reagan made the broadcast on the day he arrived here from Washington for a weeklong vacation in Los Angeles and Palm Springs, Calif. Before he left Washington, the White House issued a statement in which the President urged the Soviet Union to offer a ''realistic timetable'' for the withdrawal of troops from Afghanistan. He said in the statement that the United States strongly endorsed ''resistance'' efforts by the Afghan people.

A new wave of controversy over New Zealand's top-scoring fiberglass yacht has cast a pall over the semifinal races set to begin Sunday for America's Cup challengers. Rene Marqueze, chairman of the French Kiss syndicate, said today that his group planned to lodge a protest against New Zealand when French Kiss meets the Auckland boat in the semifinals. Marqueze said he would wait for an alternate plan to ask the New York State Supreme Court to resolve the impasse. The court maintains control over the conditions for the America's Cup despite the New York Yacht Club's loss of the trophy to Australia in 1983.
ALL IN A DAY. By Mitsumasa Anno and Raymond Briggs, Ron Brooks, Gian Calvi, Eric Carle, Zhu Chengliang, Leo and Diane Dillon, Akiko Hayashi and Nicolai Popov. Philomel.

WHEN the Coca-Cola Company said early this year that it had successfully tested its soft drink in a new plastic can, environmentalists objected loudly to any full-scale marketing of the container, even though it was labeled ''recyclable plastic.'' For about 10 years, environmental groups have watched nervously as the use of plastic bottles has grown.

To The Editor: In reading the review of David J. Garrow's ''Bearing the Cross,'' I was struck by the similarity between the martyred civil-rights leader and the courageous ''martyr-to-be'' who was the central figure in Graham Greene's novel ''The Power and the Glory'' - a ''whisky priest'' in rural Mexico with a child by a peasant woman, but staunchly refusing to leave his flock or his mission. Fascinating parallel indeed! NEIL HURLEY, S.J. New York

By Horseback In the Alps Of Provence High in the Alps of Provence next spring, a journey will take its participants through cedar-filled forests, along trails bordered by cypresses and through stands of evergreens into a valley where fields are abloom with broom, lavender and wild iris. The transport for this journey is appropriate - the horse, one of the small, agile, surefooted horses typical of Provencal stock, fitted with randonnee saddles - lighter versions of the Western saddle characterized by a small horn in front, a slightly built-up seat and long stirrup that is comfortable for extended periods. The trip originates in Marseilles and proceeds by bus to Chateau-Arnoux. From there, on horseback for four or five hours daily, it proceeds to Banon, Roussillon, Lauris, Mallemart and Salon-de-Provence before returning to Marseilles by bus. Three of these horseback tours are scheduled next year by Butterfield & Robinson, a tour operator whose offerings in various parts of the world also include walking trips, bicycle trips and cross-country ski touring.

YOU have heard the term ''house poor.'' Well, I'm doubly house poor, or is it rich? I am the proud owner of two homes in Fairfield County. We decided to leave our lovely, executive colonial for a ranch overlooking a wooded pond right at the height of the hot housing market. Everyone told us we would have no trouble selling our house. But no sooner had we put it up for sale than real estate came to a screeching halt.

THE 210th anniversary of the Battle of Trenton, which took place on Dec. 26, 1776, coincides with the current Battle of Trenton State College. One faction, led by the college administration, wants to remove ''Trenton'' from the school's name, while Trentonians claim that the place where George Washington defeated the Hessians in a surprise attack the morning after their Christmas revels still bears a name to be proud of. If the campaign to rename Trenton State succeeds, it may be the next-to-the-last step in dissociating our state institutions from the old industrial cities where they began. Only Jersey City State College will retain any ties to its urban origins.

Mrs. Robert O. Swados of Buffalo and Boca Raton, Fla., and Allan S. Lerner of New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter Caryn Ann Lerner to Hilary G. Bergman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard D. Bergman of Delray Beach, Fla. The wedding is planned for April. Ms. Lerner, a dress buyer at Bloomingdale's in New York, graduated from the Harley Day School, attended Vassar College, and graduated from New York University.

The world's population is expected to reach 6.2 billion by the year 2000, according to a report released last week by the Census Bureau. The bureau found a decline in population growth in all regions except Africa, which it said is growing at twice the rate of the rest of the world. The report also said the number of cities with more than 2 million people would double over the next 15 years, with nearly half the world's population living in urban areas by the year 2000.

A lot of people think Jean Harris has suffered enough since she was imprisoned six years ago for murdering Dr. Herman Tarnower, who planned to end their love affair. Supporters, including several prominent journalists and the former judge who sentenced her to 15 years to life in prison, have called on Governor Cuomo to grant Mrs. Harris executive clemency, making her eligible for immediate parole.

AFTER one of the sharpest budget debates in years, the Board of Legislators last week approved a $770.8 million spending plan for 1987 that cuts $3.6 million from the proposal made by County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke in mid-November but raises the property tax rate by 8.7 percent. It cuts about 55 unfilled positions from the county payroll, a major concession to complaints this year about a ''phantom army'' of nearly 1,000 funded but vacant county jobs, and reduces the spending for the Hudson River Museum, the Council for the Arts and the Youth Bureau. It provides funds to begin work on a countywide 911 emergency telephone system, kills the start of a geographic information system in the Department of Planning and initiates a rent subsidy fund to help tenants facing eviction, to avoid adding to the county's homeless population. The $1 million ''pilot project to prevent homelessness,'' which the legislators said should reduce the county's obligation to provide costlier motel and hotel accomodation for the homeless, is under study by administration officials who have until Jan. 15 to prepare a plan of operation.

To the Editor: Bob Graham's Dec. 11 Op-Ed article on the candidate's campaign shows one state's evolving election experience. While Florida may be focusing on the glitz and blitz of television to conduct campaigns, there are still places in this country where the people do control the process and the media have not encroached on an influential electorate. Although the second smallest state might not be typical, a 1984 race for an at-large Congressional seat in Delaware convinced me that old-fashioned electioneering still thrives. To me, as a campaign press secretary for the Republican candidate in that race, it was clear that Delaware voters, much to their satisfaction, had their politicians at their beck and call.

With an overhauled program, expanded staff and larger financial resources, the Community Service Society of New York will increase its services to the poor, according to its general director, David R. Jones. The society, which traces its history to 1848, is New York's leading private family-welfare organization. Mr. Jones is the society's first black director and at 38 years old, its youngest administrator. The organization, which is supported by an endowment and government and private funds, has assets of $86 million, up from $60 million two years ago, largely as a result of the strength of the stock market. It has an operating budget of $8.5 million.

Anne Melissa Dowling and E. Patrick Logue, who are with the Aetna Life and Casualty Company in Hartford, plan to be married Feb. 14. The future bride is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Kevin V. Dowling of West Hartford and Madison, Conn., who have announced her engagement to a son of Ernest J. Logue of Fountain, Fla., and Deanne Surette of Leominster, Mass.

CONNOISSEURS of great singing - any singing, in any style - are hereby directed to the Mark Hellinger Theater, 51st Street west of Broadway, where Smokey Robinson opened a run Friday night that will extend through New Year's Eve. Mr. Robinson has been with us, off and on (he had a commercial dry patch in the late 1970's), since 1960. Now 46 years old, his voice is still recognizably what it was 26 years ago, however much it's darkened and developed. His style has changed, too, but if anything that has simply improved over the years. Since the hallmarks of any great singer are a pleasing, individual set of tonal characteristics allied with a penetrating musicality and sense of style, and since Mr. Robinson has all those attributes in excelsis, he becomes by definition a great singer. And without belaboring the point, that greatness is absolute - not confined, ghetto-fashion, to ''popular music.''

Everybody supposedly loves a bargain. Without making a firm commitment, however, it is often difficult to tell whether a supposed bargain is as good as it may initially seem. Nowhere is this better illustrated than in advertisements, handbills, mass mailings and telephone campaigns that promise large discounts in travel and entertainment if you provide a credit-card number and make a deposit or pay a form of dues in advance. The wise traveler should not necessarily avoid such offerings automatically but examine them carefully, especially before you authorize any-one to charge anything to a credit-card account. If you have authorized a charge and are later unable to get a refund that you feel is warranted, your only recourse might be to consult the company that issued the card about laws that protect you in such circumstances. Two prominently advertised offerings of the last year serve as examples. Based on information from law-enforcement and watchdog agencies, legality is not at issue. Travel and Leisure World Club This year-old organization first attracted widespread attention last spring with newspaper advertisements promising 30 percent savings on dining and up to 30 percent on travel. One ad was simply a coupon requesting a membership application. A week after I mailed one in, I received a packet of material from the club at 225 West 34th Street, Suite 2203, New York, N.Y. 10122 (212-239-4855).

THERE are scowling faces of wood and mud, effigies of leather, doors that sprout navels and drawings recounting ancient tales of passion and power. In these and some 80 other objects of beauty, fear, faith and doubt, a little of traditional Africa has come to Nassau County. ''African art is rarely seen out here,'' said Rosalind Jeffries, the guest curator responsible for putting together ''The Artists' Language: African Traditional and Modern Art,'' now on display at the Nassau County Museum of Fine Art in Roslyn Harbor. ''But interest in it is growing and more and more information is now becoming available.''

Law-enforcement officials say they are beginning a new crackdown against massage parlors that are actually illegal houses of prostitution clustered south of 30th Street in Manhattan after being driven from the Times Square area and from Queens. The establishments, most of them owned by Korean-Americans, go by the name ''Oriental Spa'' or ''Health Club'' and offer ''body shampoo'' and ''shiatsu.'' Officials say, however, that most of them offer prostitutes to their clients. According to city officials, about 20 of them moved to such neighborhoods as Murray Hill, Gramercy Park and Chelsea in the last three years, seeking to avoid prosecution by the city's Office of Midtown Enforcement.

To the Editor: It seems quite outrageous that ''A Timeless Collection of Skulduggery'' (Dec. 7) should include Ivan Boesky with scoundrels of financial flimflam who collected money from people on the basis of lies. Boesky offered fairly sure bets and enriched his investors.

AFTER watching a battery-powered television set at the local school, villagers in the Ivory Coast, the West African nation, were asked to comment. A brooding old man inquired: ''Why are whites always stabbing, shooting and punching one another?'' The baffled elder's question, in the largely traditional village of N'zikpi, might have popped up in any of the two dozen or so African countries that have set up television stations but find themselves without enough programs of their own. Almost without exception, they have fallen back on Western soap operas such as ''Dynasty'' and ''Dallas,'' which are easily available but clearly not tailored for a non-English or French-speaking audience unfamiliar with Western notions of entertainment. Result: a cultural conflict that, along with perennial lack of cash and political restraints, hampers the growth of a communications medium with great potential for Africa.

Competition is intensifying for the attention and the affection of the committee choosing the site for the Democrats' 1988 Presidential nominating convention. Kansas City, still regarded as a long shot, has sent each of the 57 committee members an individualized edition of a promotional newspaper that features the member's name in a front-page headline together with a picture of him or her taken during the committee's inspection tour of Kansas City.

The big ongoing story came only at the end of the year. The Iran arms affair took over news broadcasts and showed signs that it would remain. In a curious, even perverse, way, this was a relief. Think quickly now: When were Reykjavik, Bitburg and Bhopal? Was the midterm election this year or last? Great events, big scandals and terrible tragedies are disposable commodities on television; it is the nature of the medium to hasten on to other matters. News is speeded up, so to speak, and leaves behind mostly images. Reykjavik (or was it Geneva?) was a cold correspondent in a trenchcoat; Bitburg was a row of cemetery markers. This is unsatisfactory. Surely there should be more. How do we make sense of what is happening? What saves us, and also saves television, are the intermittent shafts of light. Someone pauses for thought.

Of Business and Boxes In preparing predictions for the new year, some economists count boxes. Not the gift-wrapped goodies under the tree (though they can help measure the economy's current strength), but another sort of box: containers ordered by manufacturers. So far, the count is encouraging for 1987.

The Presbyterian Church of Old Greenwich, Conn., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Karen Lee Dell, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Glen Arthur Dell of Old Greenwich, to William Arthur Stratton, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur George Stratton Jr. of Stamford, Conn. The Rev. Douglas James Rumford performed the ceremony.

WHEN Mike Kittredge was 17 years old in 1969, he had no money to buy Christmas presents. So he decided to make them. Using milk cartons for molds, Mr. Kittredge made candles on his parents' kitchen stove. ''The shock came when somebody entered the house, saw the new candles and offered to purchase them for $2,'' Mr. Kittredge recalled. ''That was all the applause I needed. I went right out, bought more wax and sure enough, sold some more candles.'' This year, Mr. Kittredge's company, Yankee Candle Inc., the self-proclaimed largest producer of handmade candles in the world, made some 30 million candles and took in revenues of $6.5 million. Incorporated in 1976, when it had a full-time staff of one and sales of $21,000, the South Deerfield, Mass., company now has 150 employees working in a 40,000-square-foot factory.

WHILE most people this week will make New Year's resolutions to change bad habits, state and private health agencies have resolved to make life healthier for more than a million people. The State Department of Health Services and the Local Health Areas Planning Committee are planning to organize full-time health districts in 85 towns that do not have them. ''It's been a No. 1 priority of the committee for as long as I've been a member, to get full-time, public-health coverage for all towns,'' said William P. Quinn, a member of the committee's executive board and the health director in Danbury. In many small towns, building inspectors serve as part-time health officers, inspecting restaurants and checking septic systems, said Michael A. Rosetti, chief of local health administration for the Health Services Department.

THE FIRST COMING How the Kingdom of God Became Christianity. By Thomas Sheehan. 287 pp. New York: Random House. $18.95. THOMAS SHEEHAN is a philosopher whose effort to construct a ''postmodern and postliberal'' interpretation of the meaning of Jesus aroused considerable debate even before ''The First Coming'' was published. Along with many other works of modern theology, this book provides an interpretation of the Gospels that supports and legitimizes secular philosophical thought in the context of theological debate, in this case the ''hermeneutical'' method. In what represents a more radical pattern of exegesis, the work joins a growing corpus of contemporary Catholic treatments of Jesus that finds in the Gospels no basis for major elements of Catholic dogma. ''The First Coming'' endorses the disarray within Catholicism as a hopeful sign that the Church - and the distinction between God and man - will dissolve to usher in the Kingdom that Jesus actually proclaimed. Expertly documented and compellingly written, it is likely to be stimulating even for those who, on account of some stubborn, sentimental or superstitious attachment to the idea of Jesus as the Christ, cannot respond to the sound of this trumpet.

Internaional A change in Beijing city elections was announced. City officials said that, for the first time, there would be more than one candidate for each seat in the legislative elections that are to be held within the next six months. Page 1 Plans to build two large U.S. radars in Greenland and Britain are moving ahead, officials said, despite a renewed proposal from the Soviet Union and the view of some arms experts that they violate a 1972 treaty. #1 Andrei D. Sakharov will limit his role as leader of the Soviet human rights movement, he said, because of physical infirmity and a desire to renew his scientific work. Dr. Sakharov spoke in an interview. #14 Afghan exiles burned Soviet flags and an effigy of Mikhail S. Gorbachev in Pakistan in protests marking the seventh anniversary of the Soviet troop move into Afghanistan, witnesses and Afghan sources said. #3 An airline policy was blamed by a South Korean captain for deterring the crew of Korean Air Lines Flight 007 from turning back on its flight into Soviet airspace in 1983. The policy punished crew errors. #8 The new N.S.C. staff seeks advice from a group of former Iran experts in the Government to help produce a policy toward Iran that would avoid the mistakes of the arms-for-hostages operation run by the National Security staff. #6 A setback for South African forces occurred when a captured black nationalist guerrilla killed two white police officers and escaped, the police reported.

The mother of a 3-year-old girl found wandering alone in Brooklyn early Christmas morning was charged yesterday with abandoning the girl to attend a Christmas Party. The mother, Anna Almono, 24, was also charged with endangering the welfare of a child, reckless endangerment, second-degree burglary and two counts of petty larceny, according to a police spokesman, Sgt. Norris Hollomon.

Amityville $350,000 120 Ocean Avenue 6-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 56-year-old colonial; center hall, 2 fireplaces, large riverfront boathouse; taxes $7,000. Belle Terre $457,000 19 High Path 7-bedroom, 4-bath, 50-year-old Tudor; hearth fireplace, dual staircases, 3-car garage, 1.9 acres; taxes $5,200.

''The question remains of whether the market will believe in higher prices or consider them like Santa Claus - something you'd like to believe in but really can't.'' Peter C. Beutel, assistant director, Elder Futures, of the surge in oil prices in the wake of OPEC's agreement.

Jimmy Lyles was third in a line of eight, waiting his turn to feed 116 bottles into a machine outside the A.& P. at 55th Street and Ninth Avenue in Manhattan, and get nickels - $5.80 total - in return. The man behind him had about 400 containers in three shopping carts. All the people in line said they collected returnable bottles and cans for a living. In the more than three years since New York instituted a ''bottle bill,'' the nickels returned on deposits have become an important source of income for thousands of poor people, particularly in New York City, said Benjamin A. Marvin, the spokesman in the city for the State Department of Environmental Conservation, which enforces the bill. In ''hundreds of cases,'' Mr. Marvin said, the containers are proving to be a sole source of income.

LEONEL CASTILLO, the Immigration and Naturalization Service Commissioner under President Jimmy Carter, spent a lot of his time last week doing what he calls ''playing the hypotheticals'' in Houston's Hispanic community. ''I'll go into a restaurant,'' he explained, ''and someone will say, 'Mr. Castillo, if I had a cousin who came here five years ago from Mexico and doesn't have his papers, and he's working at a restaurant, can he be fired from his job?' People have become very good at playing the hypotheticals over the past month or so.'' The reason for the upsurge in such speculation - actually the use of convenient fictions that allow people to ask questions about their own situations - is the sweeping immigration legislation that became law Nov. 6. Many of the bill's key provisions, most notably the amnesty program for illegal aliens who entered the country before Jan. 1, 1982, are not yet in effect. The amnesty program begins May 5. But the new law promises such dramatic changes in patterns of living that it has set off an extraordinary surge of apprehension and confusion, turning the nation's Hispanic communities into rumor mills finely attuned to pick up every report about it.

''Sacked: Why Good People Get Fired and How to Avoid It,'' by Richard Gould. John Wiley & Sons, Inc., N.Y. 202 pages, $18.95. LEE Iacocca's success at Chrysler after he was fired as president of the Ford Motor Company - not to mention his boasting about it in his best-selling autobiography - has helped remove some of the stigma of dismissal. But it has not eliminated the myths surrounding firings.

The marriage of Meegan R. McGoldrick, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. McGoldrick of Garden City and Westhampton Beach, L.I., to Peter E. Baxter, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald E. Baxter of Cincinnati, took place yesterday. Msgr. John J. Barry performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Church in Garden City.
Those of us at Biotherapeutics thought Ms. Henig's article was balanced and fair.

BACK in the 50's, we did a lot of drag racing in Allentown, Pa., heading west on Linden Street, down 17th, east on Hamilton to Fifth, then back again, round and round. The nightly routine was informal, with worry about Kenny the Cop ranking right up there with worry about missed shifts. But it was fun. It also was long ago, and the cars -most of them gutsy-sounding Fords - weren't really that fast, zero-to-60 taking maybe 10 seconds. Today's performers are a lot hotter than that, but even they seem ponderously slow compared with the automobile that another Kenny, this one named Bernstein, drives on dragstrips all over the country.

Writing about Chekhov's first extant full-length play, Henri Troyat (in his biography, ''Chekhov'') says, ''For all its melodrama, chaos and verbosity, this immature work contains all the great Chekhovian themes in embryo.'' Acting as Chekhov's collaborator and editor, Michael Frayn has reduced the melodrama, trimmed the verbosity and made the chaos seem more comic. The result, ''Wild Honey,'' is one of those rare adaptations that is faithful to the spirit, if not the letter, of the original. The play draws strength from the dual authorship - the young Chekhov's ebullience and incipient sensibility, combined with Mr. Frayn's knowledge of dramaturgy. If Chekhov had had the time and the inclination to revise and polish his early play, it might have become ''Wild Honey'' - the comedy that Chekhov never wrote.

HAVE I got a treat for all of you. I am about to conduct a raffle. Right now. Today. Right here. ''What on earth is she talking about?'' I can hear somebody out there asking. And, in a rather nasty tone of voice, I can hear another somebody saying: ''What is the fool up to? Raffle what?''

That Jets defense - the one that is last in the National Football League against the pass, the one that has been trampled for five games, the one whose best players watched from hospital beds or the sideline - gets another chance today, led by its combative coordinator, Bud Carson. Carson once was dismissed by Coach John Mackovic, whose Kansas City Chiefs face the Jets in the American Conference wild-card playoff. That is the sort of stuff that football players are supposed to rally round - win it for your coach who was canned by the enemy.

Because of an editing error, several words were omitted from a paragraph in Joan D. Abrams's Dec. 14 Opinion article supporting school district takeovers by the state. The paragraph, referring to provisions for the removal of central office personnel and for a one-year review of principal effectiveness, should have read as follows: The same procedures of due process must be afforded these persons as Commissioner [ of Education Saul ] Cooperman assures us will be afforded a board of education before it is removed.

A NATIONAL community-revitalization group that came to the Lower East Side armed with innovative plans, $1 million and the backing of Congress to build affordable apartments is finding out how difficult it can be to acquire New York City-owned tenements to produce such housing. In 1982, Representative Bill Green, Republican of Manhattan, asked the Neighborhood Reinvestment Corporation to use the Lower East Side to demonstrate new redevelopment programs. The organization, established by Congress to help rebuild cities, hesitated for two years because it felt it did not have anything realistic to offer the pockmarked neighborhood. But in 1984 the group determined that an appropriate response would be to test the concept of mutual housing, a type of collective ownership that would build and manage low- and moderate-income rental apartments. While the mutual-housing concept is new to the United States, it has been popular in Germany, where such associations run more than 4 million dwelling units. With the help of government representatives and private-sector financial and construction experts, residents form a nonprofit organization to build or rehabilitate low- and moderate-income apartments in several buildings. Prospective tenants pay a fee to join the association and also pay monthly dues - in effect, rent - to the association, which uses the revenues to cover all costs.

THE impossible request, ''Name your favorite restaurant on the Island,'' is more difficult to fill today than it was in 1976 when I began reviewing. The variety of cuisines has expanded. New, handsomely decorated places serving designer pizza, radicchio, buffalo mozzarella, goat cheese, duck breast, New York State foie gras, tandoori chicken, dim sum, sushi, monkfish and shiitake mushrooms, all unknown here a decade ago, have become familiar. Wine lists have improved, and dozens of Long Island wines are now among the choices to sip with dinner.

MAYBE it's age, maybe it's that more people are getting smarter, but somehow New Year's Eve doesn't seem to be what it once was. The number of people who stay home that night seems to increase each year, and if they're not home, they're having quiet little dinners with friends at other homes or in restaurants. But no matter how quiet, or even nonexistent, current celebrations are, there's usually at least one memorable eve in most people's backgrounds. For Ann and Bob Shanks, New Yorkers brought up in the era of Carole Lombard-Clark Gable movies and transplanted to Los Angeles for several years, it was the year they decided to celebrate in what they considered the traditional Hollywood way.

In schools around the New York metropolitan region, pupils have joined to contribute to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. For the 16th year, the social-study classes of the seventh and eighth grades at Lawrence (L.I.) Junior High School have contributed, this year with $287.81. A gift of $57 from Class 5-312 at Public School 32 in Flushing, Queens, was raised through a flea-market sale. The donation arrived with a note saying, ''We hope the way of life of the children and adults you give the money to becomes better.''

To the Editor: I recognize that Don Wycliff in his Editorial Notebook of Dec. 13 meant only to consider the violence and crime committed by blacks. Perhaps blacks do more than their share because of their hardships, but people of all races commit murder.

It may be a common expression out West, but how many on this side of the nation have ever heard Los Angeles referred to as La-La Land? That's in the title of Robert Campbell's IN LA-LA LAND WE TRUST (Mysterious Press, $15.95). Robert Campbell is also known as R. Wright Campbell, whose fine mystery-suspense novel ''Malloy's Subway'' was published in 1981. More recently, writing as Robert Campbell, he came out with ''The Junkyard Dog,'' one of the best crime paperbacks of 1986. His hand has not deserted him here. The book introduces a private eye named Whistler, who is a rather nondescript type. Nevertheless, he is a pure, if somewhat aging, white knight who feels impelled to ferret out the truth even when there is nothing in it for him. Indeed, when at the end he adds up his expenses he is deep in the hole. That's life. As his friend Bosco, the philosopher who runs a coffee shop, reminds him, there are certain other inalienable truths. Iron rusts. And you should never try to eat the holes in Swiss cheese.

Jeana Yeager and Richard G. Rutan landed at Edwards Air Force Base last week in their paper-and-plastic airplane, the first ever to circle the earth without stopping or refueling. The pilots were wobbly but elated, and even ahead of schedule.

The marriage of Hedva Alegra Danieli, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Isaac Danieli of Kew Gardens Hills, Queens, to Ethan Solomon Etzioni, a son of Dr. Amitai Etzioni of Bethesda, Md., and Dr. Eva Halevy-Etzioni of Canberra, Australia, took place last night at the Hillcrest Jewish Center in Jamaica Estates, Queens. Rabbi Efron V. Mordecai, assisted by Cantor Paul Zim, performed the ceremony.

FINDING clear and clean trout-stocked waters in New Jersey has become, in recent years, a disappointing search for anglers. The state's waters were once unspoiled, but time, neglect and disrespect have changed all that. In the 1980's, New Jersey's waters rapidly became dumping grounds for chemical conglomerates, which do not fish the murky, polluted lakes and streams that they have helped to contaminate. Other than Lebanon's Round Valley Reservoir, the lone impoundment in the state that generates a multitude of lunker lake trout and other stocked species, New Jersey has only a handful of healthy trout-inhabited waterways remaining.

While I was peddling my educational wares a few short years ago in a pristine elementary school overlooking Huntington Harbor, a P.A. announcement persistently demanded, ''Will the gifted come to the bus for your field trip!'' I didn't know who to expect - the custodian, kitchen help, principal, teachers, kids? Historically speaking, Einstein and Thomas Alva Edison would be left behind to plod at their mundane tasks - bored, distracted and disturbing. Only the gifted and their equally gifted teachers would be seen. Now, gloriously, we have schools for those endowed, either anecdotally established by a proud, if not elite, citizenry, or by grant-seeking bureaucrats.

Rosalind Alice Alpert, a vice president in the investment banking department of the Bankers Trust Company, and Toby Salter Myerson, a partner in the New York law firm Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, plan to be married Feb. 28. Mr. and Mrs. Norman Alpert of Lewiston, N.Y., have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Myerson of Santa Barbara, Calif. Miss Alpert graduated from Princeton University.

KNOWING how to vary a recipe, to take off on one's own from what is printed on the page, makes for inventive cooking. Some recipes are especially suited to revising. Here's a case in point. Start with chicken cutlets, the boned and skinned breast halves that are sold in supermarkets. (Or you can start with whole breasts and bone and skin your own.) The recipe that calls for stuffing them, then cooking them in sauce can be varied almost infinitely.

WET PAINT By Gwynn Popovac. 373 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $19.95. GWYNN POPOVAC'S first novel, a Portrait of the Artist as a Young Woman set in the early 1960's, narrates Flora Jackson's coming of age in a suburb south of Los Angeles. Like many adolescents, Flora struggles to make sense of the adult world, whose complications most actual adults seem unable to master after a lifetime of practice. She has the added burden of her father, an airplane pilot turned realtor whose bullying temper keeps the whole family in a permanent state of low-level terror. Henry Jackson, with a face ''like a thin piece of wrinkled gray leather'' and a mouth ''like a zipped-up zipper slit,'' cuffs his children, hides their toys and skates, and keeps a pistol underneath his mattress. Small wonder that Flora withdraws from the family: sometimes, she thinks, ''it was as though she had been anesthetized and kidnapped and she had just come to.''

Most analysts of the Administration's actions in Iran have spoken of President Reagan's excessive delegation of authority or of his preoccupation with the hostages. But in some respects the Administration's handling of the ''opening'' toward Iran betrays a flaw that has been common among many Administrations: the assumption that an expression of good will on our part is important in modifying the behavior of hostile regimes. Americans tend to believe in good will: if we show interest in making a deal, the other side will be equally accommodating. Such a notion comes naturally to a commercial nation that thrives, in the business and political worlds, on making deals - on reaching agreements considered beneficial to both parties.

MURDER UNDER TWO FLAGS: The U.S., Puerto Rico, and the Cerro Maravilla Cover-up. By Anne Nelson. (Ticknor & Fields, $17.95.) On July 25, 1978, Puerto Rican police shot and killed two young supporters of Puerto Rican independence who had allegedly planned to sabotage communication transmission towers on a mountaintop called Cerro Maravilla.

To the Editor: In Howell Raines's review of David J. Garrow's ''Bearing the Cross: Martin Luther King, Jr., and the Southern Christian Leadership Conference'' (Nov. 30), Mr. Raines refers to the ''inner torments King suffered because of his compulsive sexual adventuring'' and suggests that King's actions in this regard may have been related to the civil-rights leader's desire to re-create the atmosphere of ''the epic-making days in Alabama and Mississippi,'' i.e., of the days of King's brave struggle with and partial victory over Southern racism. Women also have a history and also have lives and, I might remind both Mr. Garrow and Mr. Raines (and King posthumously), an equal right to both a personal and social/civil status that sexual users like King deny. The sexual use of women is not a mere peccadillo like, say, one's failure to keep a neat desk, but is a lived expression of an ideology of contempt and misogyny that should not be sanitized or mystified as Mr. Raines has done, but rather should be censured as the sexual bigotry it is - even if, as was the case with King, that ideology and that bigotry found a home within a life that was otherwise devoted to justice and good works. MELINDA VADAS Oak Ridge, N.C.

When in doubt, say it was a bad year. Nobody would dare question you. It also means that you don't have to defend yourself. When you cite such self-proclaiming lulus as Prince's ''Under the Cherry Moon'' and Willard Huyck's ''Howard the Duck,'' all can nod in safe agreement that movies are continuing the downhill slide they began sometime before the advent of the talkies. I had no idea of the extent of this alienation until, not long ago, a film scholar said to me, quite seriously, ''I don't think I want to see 'The Birth of a Nation' anymore.'' Yet, in fact, 1986 was an improvement over 1985, in spite of rising production costs that bend the mind. While it was going on, it looked decidely grim. More films were released, for the most part meaning more bad films, everything from ''Mountaintop Motel Massacre'' and ''Girls School Screamers'' to big-budget flops like Alan Alda's ''Sweet Liberty'' and Roman Polanski's ''Pirates.'' If we analyze the year's hit movies as if they are our collective, wish-fulfilling dreams, we are a nation of sentimental sadists and birdbrained yahoos, permanently arrested in our 15th year.

THE Mets won the World Series. Jack Nicklaus won his sixth Masters at age 46. Bill Shoemaker won his fourth Kentucky Derby at age 54. Mike Tyson won the World Boxing Council heavyweight championship at age 20. The Giants won 14 games, the most victories in any of the pro football franchise's 62 seasons. But in 1986, the glory of those success stories was diminished by the gloom of the year's most significant sports story -the death of Len Bias at age 22 from cocaine intoxication. Shortly after dawn on June 19, the 6-foot-8-inch all-America forward collapsed in his University of Maryland dormitory suite. Two days earlier, Bias had been selected by the Boston Celtics with the second choice in the National Basketball Association draft.

More than 1,200 people, showing both anger and grief at the death of a young black man who was attacked by a group of whites, marched through Howard Beach, Queens, yesterday in a protest against racism. A crowd of white people, who taunted the marchers with calls of ''animals'' and ''go home,'' were kept apart from the demonstration by 250 police officers. The police said there were no arrests or injuries. The marchers, including both black and white people, moved 10 abreast up the wide lanes of Cross Bay Boulevard, stopping for a moment of silent prayer outside the New Park Pizzeria at the corner of 157th Avenue, where what the police say was a racially motivated attack began early Dec. 20. The silence was quickly broken by a shouting match between some demonstrators and white adults and young people who began taunting the marchers.

Several American Jewish leaders voiced regrets yesterday over changes in John Cardinal O'Connor's impending visit to Israel, saying it has now been tainted by Middle Eastern politics. They suggested it might have been better not to have gone ahead with the trip under the circumstances. The Cardinal, the Archbishop of New York, left last night for Jordan. Traveling as the president of the Catholic Near East Welfare Association, he was to continue to Israel on Thursday after meeting with King Hussein in Amman.

A senior Nicaraguan leader has returned from Moscow with promises of aid that the Sandinista Government said would be ''of great importance.'' No figures were made public, but diplomats said Soviet economic aid to Nicaragua will probably total hundreds of millions of dollars next year, as it did this year. An official communique published today said that the Minister of Foreign Cooperation, Henry Ruiz Hernandez, returned to Managua this week after a series of meetings with Soviet officials. Mr. Ruiz is a member of the nine-man Sandinista National Directorate and is considered the principal Sandinista link to the Soviet Union.
''Buy generic'' would seem to be a good guide for saving money on prescription drugs. Not necessarily so, according to a survey just published in the Journal of the American Medical Association.
An article about the Standard Oil Company on Dec. 14 incorrectly reported volume of production from Alaska's Prudhoe Bay oilfield. The correct figure is 1.5 million barrels a day.

''In order to promote democracy and in order to give the people the opportunity to select the candidates that they will be satisfied with, this time the election will have more candidates than slots available.'' - She Diqing, of the standing committee of the Municipal People's Congress of Beijing. [ 1:5. ]

The historian Dumas Malone, whose multivolume biography led to a reputation as the foremost authority on the life of Thomas Jefferson, died yesterday at his home in Charlottesville, Va. He was 94 years old. Dr. Malone's work on the six books collectively titled ''Jefferson and His Time'' spanned four decades; it was awarded the Pulitzer Prize for history in 1975 and was completed in 1981. ''To all who cherish freedom and abhor tyranny in any form,'' he wrote in the final volume, Jefferson ''is an abiding symbol of the hope that springs eternal.''

Judith Ellen Hersh, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Hersh of Freehold, N.J., was married last night to Alan Howard Kurland, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Kurland of Clifton, N.J. Rabbis Yale Fishman and Stanley Skolnick officiated at the Richfield Regency in Verona, N.J. The bride, who will be known as Mrs. Hersh-Kurland, and her husband graduated from Emory University and are first- and second-year students, respectively, at the Robert Wood Johnson School of Medicine. Her father is a senior associate of the Systematics General Corporation, an engineering and computer consulting concern in Wall Township, N.J. Mr. Kurland's father is the director of marketing for Dassault Systems International, a computer software company in Hasbrouck Heights, N.J. His mother, Susan Kurland, is a consultant on public relations and fund raising in Clifton.

The business of television was, more than ever, the significant factor concerning what you may or may not have watched in 1986. The commercial networks appeared to have stemmed, at least temporarily, the severe erosion of their audiences. The enormous success of one sitcom, the two-year-old ''Cosby Show,'' continues to prove a boon not only to NBC and its much vaunted ratings victories but also to industry statistics as a whole. As in the theater, a smash hit is good for everybody's business. At the same time, however, faced with new economic realities, most notably a slackening in advertising sales, the networks have been drastically cutting both staff levels and production budgets. There is little joy on Broadcast Row this holiday season. And the corner-cuttings are slowly but surely being reflected in on-screen product.

The President's Task Force on Regulatory Relief, established to make good on Ronald Reagan's promise to ''get the Government off the backs of the people,'' was quietly disbanded in 1983, some said in anticipation of potentially bruising debate in the 1984 elections. This month, it was back in action again with a new mandate: to promote productivity and international competitiveness.

It may be optimistic, but I hope 1986 will be remembered in architecture as the year in which a few lessons were learned. After all, a lot of big projects changed course this year, and for the better. Most notable, surely, is Television City, the mega-development Donald Trump wants to build on the 76-acre site of the old Pennsylvania Railroad yards on the Upper West Side. The design for Television City by Helmut Jahn that Mr. Trump unveiled with much hoopla last year, an outlandishly simplistic exercise in urban gigantism, has now passed to a well-deserved oblivion and been replaced with a vastly more sophisticated scheme by Alexander Cooper. Whereas the old design looked like a series of rocket ships lined up in bleak open space, the new one attempts to create boulevards, streets and parks that bear some resemblance to real urban places. It is still far, far too big - the overall plan calls for more than 17 million square feet of space - but at least it is a decent and intelligent framework, and if the long process of public review can bring about a reduction in the amount of building that will occur on the site we might actually see a viable project.

La Nueva China Restaurant, 3393 Broadway (137th St.). Snack Kebob, 42 E. 14th St. Third Ave. Bagels and Appetizers, 1642 3d Ave. (91st St.). Tiffany's Coffee Shop, 256 3d Ave. (20th St.). The article on James Lovelock and his Gaia hypothesis contained some misleading information. One might inadvertently infer that microorganisms produce heat-regulating, volatile compounds with the goal of maintaining the Earth's atmospheric heat balance.

The new National Security Council staff has sought the advice of a group of former Iran experts in the Government to help produce a policy toward Iran that would avoid the mistakes of the arms-for-hostages operation. Frank C. Carlucci, who will officially take over as White House national security adviser on Friday, has given priority to formulation of an Iran policy, an aide said today. The aide said the policy would deal not only with how the United States should approach Iran, but also with what to do to help free Americans being held hostage in Lebanon by groups close to Iran. 'Looking Ahead to the Future' The plan to tap outside expertise was separate, White House officials said, from the announcement on Friday that David M. Abshire, the departing delegate to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, would become a counselor with Cabinet rank to coordinate White House strategy on the Iran-Nicaragua crisis.

This Week: Keep handy bags of sand, fertilizer or sawdust as substitutes for salt to make icy drives, walks and steps safe. . . . Plant live trees outdoors. . . . Keep bird feeders well-stocked. Winter Is Here Winter came quietly a week ago at 11:02 P.M. when the sun entered Capricorn. It was the shortest day of the year. Every day from now until spring will be filled with hope and more daylight.

NOT every child ''grows up'' to be an adult, and not every adult grows into an ''old person.'' Recently, driving home after dark, I saw a woman I know, an old person, walking along the poorly lighted main road. She was carrying a brown bag filled with groceries. I wouldn't have noticed her except for the reflection of her pale yellow cardigan in my car's lights. I offered her a ride home.

For the first time in a year, India and Pakistan found common ground last week on steps to reduce tensions along their border. Officials of the two nations reached an agreement to accelerate coordination of their frontier security forces to prevent Sikh extremists from using Pakistani territory as a base for attacks in India.

Biscuits and coffee in a truck stop before dawn, a drive through morning fog to the hometown of Walter Payton. After a pleasant visit with Payton's former coach, Charles Boston, and a sunny afternoon drive through the Delta to New Orleans, Stupor Bowl week will take care of itself. Dallas, Feb. 8 - Spud Webb's relatives at Webb's Soul Market tell a visitor how proud they are that the tiny Atlanta Hawk has been invited to pro basketball's slam-dunk contest. To their amazement, the hometown hero will win the judging the next day.

To THE Editor: John P. Roche, reproving what he calls ''egregious exaggeration'' of the Phalangist massacre at the Sabra and Shatila refugee camps in Lebanon in 1982, writes that the ''official report of the Lebanese Government,'' stating that just 425 men were killed, and 35 women and children, ''has not been seriously challenged'' (Letters, Dec. 7). This is nonsense. First, there was no Lebanese investigation in any real sense of the word and no final report was ever issued to the public in any detail, so no wonder it was never ''seriously challenged.'' The bogus casualty figures Mr. Roche cites were leaked by Lebanese officials, who were interested in playing down the number of women and children killed, from what they said was the ''official report.''

WHAT is a Feydeau farce? It is about the importance of infidelity and it usually is set in a hotel or in a bedroom. At its best, the farce's plot is giddy and convoluted, yet clear and logical - and funny. And it is immaculately constructed, abounding in complex twists, turns and counterturns. Stylishness and precision of performance are essential to make it work.

Douglas J. Widman of Wayside, N.J., has announced the engagement of his sister, Denise Laura Widman, to Dr. Allan Lauer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Lauer of White Plains. The wedding is planned for March.

ISLAND CAMPING Question:Do you know of any books or other sources that describe camping opportunities on any of the Caribbean islands? I do know about the national park on St. John. - H. R., Amherst, Mass. Answer:No one has compiled a comprehensive list of camping sites, according to the Caribbean Tourism Association, which represents most of the islands. Several islands either do not allow camping or do not have any official campgrounds for visitors. Furthermore, Caribbean guidebooks generally do not mention those that do exist, although there is a brief section on the subject in ''Birnbaum's Caribbean, Bermuda and the Bahamas'' (Houghton Mifflin, $13.95).

ON a pedestal in the office of the president of the prestigious Manhattan School of Music on the West Side stands a life-size bronze bust of Hugh Ross of Manhattan and Amangansett. The bust, executed by Peter Lipman-Wulf of Sag Harbor, honors Mr. Ross's many years as leader of the Choral Society of the Hamptons. Unveiled last month at the school, where he taught for 50 years, it depicts the 88-year-old musical conductor and choral director, whose devotion to his art shows scant sign of abating as he heads toward his 10th decade. These days, as he has since 1927, he is conducting the New York Schola Cantorum, a choral group founded in 1909. He is also serving, as he has for the last 15 years, as executive director of the Sullivan Foundation, which fosters the careers of young singers trained in the United States.

PEOPLE should not believe what they hear about the callousness of New Yorkers. My husband and I were attending a meeting of the Parents' Association of Mount Sinai Medical School. We parked the car between Central Park and the hospital. Our briefcases were in the trunk.

I WILL UNDOUBTEDLY spend New Year's in the country with friends,'' Jonathan Waxman was saying, ''and the menu I plan for New Year's Day will probably include at least one dish to be cooked on an outdoor grill. It's good for re-oxygenating the brain cells when you go outside to check on the heat.'' Jonathan, one of the most talked-about young chefs in Manhattan, had come into my home to prepare a proposed feast for the first day of the year. ''To my mind, the menu should be accordion-pleated so you can alter it as you go along,'' he said. ''People have a tendency on New Year's Eve to stay out too late, and if they don't have a hangover, they have a vicarious case of the holiday jitters.

For the visitor to Aveleda, there is, first, the ritual stroll through the gardens of Quinta da Aveleda, past the weathered granite main gate with the family coat of arms, past the monumental window from the ruins of the palace in Oporto where Prince Henry the Navigator was born, past the stone fountains and great masses of mimosa, camellias, azaleas, rhododendrons and other blossoms that form dazzling outbursts of color most of the year. Then you come to the vine-covered mansion and its private chapel, built in 1671, where members of the Guedes family have always lived. It was here, in 1860, that Dom Manuel Pedro Guedes da Silva da Fonseca introduced modern techniques to Portuguese grape growers and laid the foundation of one of the country's principal wine empires. The Quinta da Aveleda Company is the leading exporter of bottled vinho verde, or green wine, a light effervescent wine with low alcoholic content, which is only produced in Portugal. Although it has been producing vinho verde since Roman times, the northwestern corner of Portugal was not officially designated as the vinho verde region until 1908; the designation was internationally recognized in 1973.

Everything looks the same in Washington now, shining in the winter sun, but in a way things are quite different. It's not only a New Year approaching but a new prospect for all the main characters on this political stage. The 100th Congress will be different when it convenes in January dominated by the Democrats, with new chairmen of the committees and a new Speaker of the House of Representatives. The White House will be different with a new National Security Council and new problems with the budget, the allies and the Soviet Union. Suddenly, the fads and follies of the past are over.

The best public document of the season - no blather about geostrategic politics - is the annual report published by Unicef, the United Nations Children's Fund. It shows that a pittance can save millions of children in poorer countries. What's more heartening, ''The State of the World's Children'' reports that in the last year, countries poor and rich have united to save at least 1.5 million children by vaccines and hydration therapy. The target of total immunization by 1990 looks increasingly feasible.
The U.S.O. is a voluntary, nonprofit organization serving the men and women of today's military and their families.
An article in Arts and Leisure on Dec. 14 about the ''New Photography 2'' exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art omitted the name of the show's sponsor. It is Springs Industries.
The Jets and Chiefs have met only once before in the playoffs.

ON the night of Oct. 25, Edward G. McGuire 3d, a sophomore from Falmouth, Mass., attended a school-sanctioned party at Saybrook College, one of the 16 residential colleges at Yale University. Alcohol was served at the party. Later, friends say, he continued drinking at a private dormitory party in the same college, where he eventually passed out and was taken to his room in Silliman College. The following morning, Mr. McGuire, 19 years old, was found dead in his bed by his roommates. An autopsy by the office of the Chief State Medical Examiner showed Mr. McGuire had died of alcohol poisoning. Yale officials will not comment on the circumstances surrounding Mr. McGuire's death, since it is still being investigated by the New Haven Police Department and the Yale campus police.

''THE first piano was built long after they didn't have any at all,'' explains Victor Borge in his nutty professor's version of keyboard history. ''Since there was only one big white key, it was monotonous to go to a piano recital. It wasn't until someone invented the cracks that everything changed.''

WORLDWIDE VIGIL At noon, Greenwich Mean Time, Dec. 31 (7 A.M. here), when the whole world is poised for an hour on the same day of the year, a worldwide vigil observing the International Year of Peace is planned in dozens of locations. Several churches in the metropolitan New York area are holding special services or events. Among them is a nondenominational hour of prayer from 7 to 8 A.M. at Wainwright House, 260 Stuyvesant Avenue, Rye, in association with Programs for Human Development of Greenwich and Logos World University. The Rye Presbyterian Church is one of the local churches holding a peace vigil at the same time. In Manhattan, WBAI radio will participate with Gostel Radio, Moscow in a program from 6 to 11 A.M., written by Americans and Soviets; in New York Alan Ginsberg will be the host.

DONNA MURPHY'S stage career has taken so many unexpected turns, it is no surprise to find her in a musical that is itself full of surprises. The 27-year-old actress, who grew up in Hauppauge, has played three major roles and one minor one in the same show, first as an understudy and finally as a replacement. And now that the show has had an official name change - from ''The Mystery of Edwin Drood'' to ''Drood,'' to make it appear newer and catchier -it can be said that Ms. Murphy has gone from playing the title role to playing the whole title. When ''The Mystery of Edwin Drood,'' a tricky musical with a multiplicity of possible endings, was first seen at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park during the summer of 1985, Ms. Murphy was a member of the ensemble. She played the small part of Miss Florence Gill, and understudied the roles of Princess Puffer and Helena Landless (the exotic creature with a ''strange, untraceable accent''), then played by, respectively, Cleo Laine and Jana Schneider.

Pop music is a form of entertainment, a medium of expression and a cultural barometer. In 1986, it was all these things and more. Developments such as the Amnesty International benefits, Bruce Springsteen's increasingly evident social consciousness and the rapprochment between black rap and white rock effected by the Run-D.M.C./Aerosmith hit ''Walk This Way'' were evidence that the music can still serve as a kind of conscience for its audience, and perhaps become a catalyst for change. The year in pop began with widespread concern over a growing reaction against suggestive lyrics, especially over the lobbying efforts of the Parents Music Resource Center, which found some lyrics objectionable because of their references to sex or drugs. Many observers feared that if such pressures were successful, socially and politically relevant rock would be the ultimate victim. By year's end, at least some major record labels seemed to be quietly backing away from the kind of monitoring the group had sought. And rock with social and political conscience seemed to be making a comeback.

I found Robert Gottlieb's logic in ''Politics and Judges Shouldn't Mix'' badly flawed. Mr. Gottlieb argues that the current system of party selection of judges is undemocratic and fails to protect those he calls competent judges who must run for re-election. I would strongly disagree. Party selection of judicial candidates finally allows the electorate a direct say in who their judges will be. The previous practice of cross-party endorsement of the incumbent denied this right to the voters.

Frances Williams Roberts, a daughter of Thomas Williams Roberts Jr. of Villanova, Pa., and the late Frances Roberts, was married yesterday to Richard Burger Hill, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Scott Hill of Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Steven K. Jacobson assisted by Canon E. Rugby Auer performed the ceremony in the chapel of St. David's Episcopal Church in Wayne, Pa. Elizabeth McCahan was her sister's matron of honor and Michael Oliver Hill best man for his brother.

In a dramatic change in the way local elections are held in Beijing, the city government announced today that there would be more than one candidate for each seat in municipal elections. It did not explain, however, how candidates would be nominated or how any election campaign would be conducted. ''In order to promote democracy and in order to give the people the opportunity to select the candidates that they will be satisfied with, this time the election will have more candidates than slots available,'' She Diqing, a deputy chairman of the standing committee of the Municipal People's Congress, said in a speech to the committee. Student Protests Banned The announcement, which appeared in Beijing Daily, follows an official crackdown on the wave of student demonstrations that have swept across China demanding wider democracy. On Friday, the standing committee issued a set of rules that in effect banned any public protest by students in the capital.

At St. George's-by-the-River Episcopal Church in Rumson, N.J., yesterday Susan van Wyck deGersdorff, a daughter of Mrs. Francis Eugene Gilbertson of Rumson and Carl August deGersdorff of New York and Alford, Mass., was married to John George Stamatopoulos, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George John Stamatopoulos of Melrose, Mass. The Rev. George Willis of St. George's performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. George Tsoukalas, a Greek Orthodox priest.

It's very easy to spot a black person in this neighborhood, and whenever I see one, I know he's up to no good. They come in the neighborhood and rob everybody. It's a known fact. That's why everybody has a thing about them.

Elizabeth Jane Albert, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold G. Albert of Hamilton, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Stevan Ralph Hubbard, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Hubbard of Lincoln, Neb. The Rev. Francis Malooly performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church.

At least three major legislative packages introduced in the 99th Congress and dozens of recommendations from policy institutes and political caucuses that are out or expected soon have made clear a general agreement that the Federal welfare system badly needs fixing. But the extent of disagreement about how to fix it was also clear last week as a coalition of national organizations came forward with its approach. Like most proposals already aired, the coalition's ''statement of principles'' emphasized work for welfare recipients. But unlike some plans, notably the Reagan Administration's, the linchpin was the ''primary responsibility'' of the Federal Government for fighting poverty.

Hats off to Lawrence E. Joseph for his article ''Britain's Whole Earth Guru'' (Nov. 23)! With all respect to James Lovelock and Richard Dawkins, this writer has very well described a quarrel of personal viewpoint that must necessarily get in the way of their science.

More than any recent year within memory, 1986 was the year of the reissue. And not grandly packaged exhumations of disks long dead, like last year's ''Record of Singing'' Vol. 3 and ''Mapleson Cylinder'' sets. This year, fueled by the burgeoning market in compact disks, the record companies devoted a major portion of their resources to the reissuing of fairly recent analog and digital recordings, along with some classics of the 1930's through the 1960's, on digitally remastered LP's or, ultimately, onto CD's themselves. Thus a survey of the best new recordings of 1986 - albums that appeared in the United States for the first time this year - draws from a slightly smaller pool than in the past, and there are some curious shallow areas. Not many top-of-the-line sets of standard-repertory chamber music were released this year, for instance. And the more marginal forms of contemporary music, the kind put out by labels not yet plugged into CD technology, have become more marginal than ever, as far as the average interested consumer is concerned.

MYSTERY OF THE SARDINE. By Stefan Themerson. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $14.95.) Who blows up the black poodle, inadvertently killing poor Mr. McPherson, a dull but persistent scholar ferreting out a bit of literary trivia on the English coast? ''The Mystery of the Sardine'' doesn't offer a satisfactory solution to this conundrum but most readers won't mind a bit.

Piece by painstaking piece, NASA is revamping the space shuttle system that disintegrated, along with a good measure of the nation's technological self-confidence, 11 months ago today. The next shuttle orbiter that astronauts clamber into on the Kennedy Space Center launching pad will probably include a crude but effective escape system for them to use in case disaster strikes again. Its landing brakes will be improved. Its main liquid fuel engines will be upgraded, and for the first time astronauts may fly without harboring the seldom-spoken fear that a malfunction in a simple 17-inch valve could choke off the craft's liquid fuel supply and send it crashing into the sea. Much Safer Craft Is Seen The safety changes being made by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration thus go far beyond the redesigning of the solid-fuel booster rocket whose failure killed seven astronauts 73 seconds into the flight of the Challenger last Jan. 28. While the debate over how to redesign those boosters has drawn much attention, both agency officials and outside experts are concerned that other critical elements of the shuttle may have been neglected amid the pressures to keep flying that contributed to the Challenger's destruction.

PASSAGE THROUGH ARMAGEDDON The Russians in War and Revolution 1914-1918. By W. Bruce Lincoln. Illustrated. 637 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $22.95. THE great battles in the Old Testament that took place in the mountainous har megiddo supplied a label for the scene prophesied in Revelations of Armageddon, the ultimate battle between good and evil at the world's end. W. Bruce Lincoln, a professor of Russian history at Northern Illinois University, has adapted the concept to his seventh book on Russian history, a sequel to his 1983 survey ''In War's Dark Shadow'' and an extension of his earlier studies, ''The Romanovs'' and ''In the Vanguard of Reform.'' ''Passage Through Armageddon: The Russians in War and Revolution 1914-1918'' carries the lively story of the fall of the autocracy and the explosion of the Revolution up through peace with the Central Powers in World War I, the Czar's execution and the beginnings of the civil war.

''YES,'' SAID President Reagan affirmatively, in defense of his stewardship of foreign policy, ''it is in our interest to stand with those who would take arms against the sea of darkness.'' That was a play on a Shakespearean phrase that is often misunderstood. Hamlet, contemplating self-destruction in his ''To be, or not to be'' soliloquy, asks, ''Whether 'tis nobler in the mind to suffer/ The slings and arrows of outrageous fortune,/ Or to take arms against a sea of troubles,/ And by opposing end them?'' A sea of troubles was, in Shakespeare's day, a way of characterizing this weary life: it did not mean a whole bunch of difficulties as much as it stood for life itself. Just as an optimist in the 1930's would think of life as a bowl of cherries, a pessimist in Elizabethan times would call it a sea of troubles.

The Pentagon doesn't really want it, the White House may be playing games with it, and the new weapon will cost billions that the deficit doom-shouters will be reluctant to put up. Nevertheless, President Reagan's decision to seek production of the mobile Midgetman missile may prove to be his most important contribution to national security. If Mr. Reagan is serious about the Midgetman, he deserves real credit - given the sea of adversity in which he now struggles - for taking this first step toward a smaller, more survivable, less threatening nuclear deterrent. The decision appears also to have signaled that this President will not again ask for more than the 50 MX missiles already approved.

It was almost a tie for New York City's housing shortage last week: Mayor Koch announced plans to renovate nearly 5,200 apartments in abandoned city-owned buildings, and a State Supreme Court judge issued a ruling that could reduce the potential number of single-occupancy hotel rooms by as many as 10,000. The renovations would be undertaken in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn by private developers, nonprofit community groups and contractors hired by the city.

A pylon snapped at this Alpine ski resort today, sending two cable cars crashing 40 feet down onto a parking lot and injuring 36 people, 12 seriously, officials said. ''People were screaming with fear and pain,'' a witness said.

THE MOTHER OF DREAMS And Other Short Stories: Portrayals of Women in Modern Japanese Fiction. Edited by Makoto Ueda. 279 pp. New York: Kodansha International. $19.95. MAKOTO UEDA, the editor of this noteworthy anthology of modern Japanese short stories, has divided the book into five sections: the Maiden, the Wife, the Mistress, the Mother and the Working Woman. It is an indication that the influence of roles, even with the changes in postwar Japan, is still felt. The authors are all established -among them, the 1968 Nobel laureate Yasunari Kawabata and other popular writers such as Kobo Abe, Kafu Nagai and Fumiko Enchi - and include an almost equal number of men and women writers. (Readers be warned that the table of contents lists the authors in the traditional Japanese order, with surnames first.) The surface of these stories, mostly written since World War II, is often deceptively placid. The writing is spare. Because the stories have various translators -all, in fact, students of Mr. Ueda (who teaches at Stanford University) - it is hard to measure how much of the voice and style of a story is the author's own. Some are smoother than others. Still, throughout the placid prose there is strong emotion. In ''A Woman to Call Mother'' by Taiko Hirabayashi, a daughter's failure to visit her dying mother is ''an indication that their emotions were too strong.'' By refraining from frenzied description, the writer renders the drama in a story all the more powerfully.

To the Sports Editor: Phil Hochberg's column on the Giants-Redskins rivalry (''Sweet Memories of a Bitter Rivalry,'' The New York Times, Dec. 7) shows what poor sports the Redskins and their fans are. If his fondest memory of the Giants-Redskins rivalry is the Redskins' kicking a field goal with time running out in a game in which they already led by 28 points, he should be re-examining his values. L. WEITZMAN New York

IT was a splendid Christmas present - perfect in its timing, perfect in its fulfillment of national longings - the sight of the frail aircraft known as the Voyager settling awkwardly to earth in California last Tuesday after a nine-day circumnavigation of the globe, an epic journey that bore the stamp of Lindbergh and Magellan. In a season of optimism thwarted, of pervasive dissatisfaction and uncertainty, the flight of the Voyager seemed all the more remarkable. A President in whom a whole nation had invested so much hope and who had seemed to repay that hope with a restoration of public purpose and pride, found himself embattled, his Administration all but paralyzed, by a controversial policy made worse by the uses to which it was put. At the same time, the two other great powers in the world found their authority challenged - the Soviets by riots in the Central Asian republic of Kazakhstan against the imposition of authority by the far-off ethnic Russians, the Chinese by demonstrations in Shanghai and Beijing itself against the slow progress in implementing reform.

To the Editor: A Dec. 9 item reports that New York City's Transit Authority has come up with a ''crowding index'' to quantify the subway rider's experience. As you note, the T.A. assumes that standees take up 2.36 square feet of floor space. That number was obtained by assuming that riders were ellipses with axes of 2 feet and 1.5 feet. The T.A. then measured the available standing room of each car type and divided by 2.36 square feet, supposedly yielding ''the number of standees each car type can hold when crowding begins to be intolerable.''

Isn't the key word ''business,'' not a selfless concern for those with cancer? Does there always have to be some kind of selfish motive? Cancer treatment expected to cost $35,000, or more, means that many won't even have a chance to gamble in the Biotherapeutics Inc. ''wheel of fortune.'' ELEANORE TONS SCHNURR New York City

Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Sternheimer of Richmond have announced the engagement of their daughter Stacy Lew Sternheimer to John Randolph Smith Jr., a son of Dr. and Mrs. Smith of Martinsville, Va., and Litchfield, S.C. A March wedding is planned.

WHEN he upset Kenneth A. Gibson last spring to become the chief elected official of New Jersey's largest city, Sharpe James recalled recently, ''I knew it would be the worst and the best of times to become Mayor.'' On one hand, there has been a resurgence of development interest in Newark. Last week, announcing that they would purchase and rehabilitate the Prudential Insurance Company's 60-year-old Gibraltar Building, officials of Time Equities, a real estate concern, referred to Newark as ''well along the road to a vigorous recovery.'' But even while Mayor James hailed the project as one with the potential to create thousands of jobs, a less happy matter involving employment in Newark awaited resolution. In preparation for reducing its payroll by as many as 100 early next year, City Hall sent layoff notices this month to virtually all of the 4,500 people it employs.

To the Editor: For me, Don Wycliff's ''How Many Larry Davises?'' (The Editorial Notebook, Dec. 13) served only as a symbol of sociological myopia. Mr. Wycliff's statement, ''The need to do something about such young men is a concern now,'' demonstrates the view of the after-the-fact crowd that readily expresses dismay and frustration at seemingly unpreventable criminal acts. Much of my difficulty in understanding Mr. Wycliff's view - that military service and the Job Corps are acceptable solutions for young black men who behave as their own worst enemies - was that on one hand he looks at these young black men as victims of broken families, and on the other, he implies they are psychological powderkegs waiting to explode. In my view, neither military service nor the Job Corps is an effective solution to a continuing social problem.

The competition among four Australian 12-Meters for the right to defend the America's Cup forced the two leading defense camps into a point-score tie today. The defense trials resumed after a two-week break. Alan Bond's redesigned Australia IV beat Syd Fischer's Steak 'n Kidney by 19 seconds. The victory moved Australia IV into a first-place tie in the standing with Kookaburra III at 53 points over all. Kookaburra III is owned by Bond's business rival, Kevin Parry.

At St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in New York yesterday Jeanne Marie Delsener, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony H. Delsener of Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich., was married to John Curtis Galbraith, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Galbraith of Naples, Fla., and Summit, N.J. Msgr. John Nienstedt performed the ceremony.

As in any theatrical event, many of the key players in American business during 1986 operated from behind the scenes. They received little notice although their work this year produced stunning revelations on Wall Street and generated millions of dollars worth of new products. For the most part, 1986 was a year in which Americans were swept up by national pride, a spirit generated by the celebration of the Statue of Liberty's centennial. People were eager to buy just about anything that smacked of Americana - from a $40 photo essay of the nation, which becamse the hottest Christmas seller in the bookstores, to a $400 gold coin newly issued by the United States Mint. The health binge this year put the spotlight on calcium, which turned up in the most unlikely places: orange juice, for example. And despite the drop in the dollar and the burst of patroitism, Americans purchased imports in greater volume than ever beofre in '86. That generated a big payoff for one South Korean automaker who dared to bring a new car into the oversupplied American market. The following is a glimpse of some of the year's unsung heroes: The Packagers Who Finally Scored A Publishing Coup RICHARD S. SMOLAND and David E. Cohen do not dress for success. The 37-year-old Mr. Smolan, known as Rick, sports granny glasses, a mustache, and a shoulder-length mane of brown hair. The 31-year-old Mr. Cohen has put his buttoned-down Yale days behind him and let his dark blond hair grow long.

MRS. CALIBAN By Rachel Ingalls. 125 pp. Boston: The Harvard Common Press. $12.95. BEFORE this year, when the British Book Marketing Council made ''Mrs. Caliban'' controversial by naming it one of the 20 ''greatest [ American ] novels since World War II,'' Rachel Ingalls's concise, affecting and highly original 1982 work was almost unknown. Now, republished and book-clubbed, it is for the first time accessible to a wide audiece. Readers will not be disappointed.

GIANT KILLERS. By Michael Pertschuk. (Norton, $17.95.) With all of the headlines about national security, portentous events, sounding brass and brass sounding off, it is refreshing to read a book about how hard work, imagination and good humor can deflect and deflate juggernauts.

To the Editor: The discussion of major capital improvements in ''The Turn of Rental Rehabilitation'' on Dec. 7 failed to make any mention of the impact that the process of ''upgrading'' has on tenants in occupancy. First, work within the apartment such as plumbing violates the tenants' ''quiet and peaceful'' enjoyment of their living space. Not only must tenants deal with the opening of walls to expose the pipes, but they also have to live with it for weeks or months. Windows, while perhaps not taking as long, are equally a bother. Occupants may even have to take time off from work, losing wages, to oversee personal property.

Mr. and Mrs. Franklin G. Gaderick of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Joanne Marie Gaderick, to Jeffrey Toll Reynolds, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Russell S. Reynolds Jr., also of Greenwich. The wedding is planned for May 23.

The marriage of Stacey Scott, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Scott of Montclair, N.J., to Robert Jerome Fishman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred N. Fishman of New York, took place last evening at the Crestmont Country Club in West Orange, N.J. Rabbi David J. Seligson performed the ceremony.
