The bride, an associate jewelry buyer at Bloomingdale's in Manhattan, graduated from the Rhode Island School of Design.
John Mackovic, right, with Bill Parcells at Giants Stadium yesterday during Giants practice. (AP)
Verdi's 'Don Carlo' Starring Placido Domingo, Mirella Freni, Grace Bumbry, Nicolai Ghiaurov and Louis Quilico. Metropolitan Opera Orchestra conducted by James Levine.

Three recent recordings of Bach's choral music, each differing in interpretation, show how different approaches can all be valid. Of primary interest because of the magnitude of the work is John Eliot Gardiner's version of the Mass in B minor (Archiv CD 415514 AH2, two disks). The English conductor, who has made quite a reputation in the field of Baroque music, leads the Monteverdi Choir and the English Baroque Soloists. The singers number 30 (women sopranos, the rest men), and the many soloists are drawn from that group. Their names will not be familiar to most American listeners, but they are equal to the demands made on them. The instrumental ensemble of 38 uses period instruments. All of this, of course, is in the current vogue for correct Baroque style and sounds fine. The question remains whether the conductor can bring the music to life in these terms - too many musicians assume that if you have the right forces the music will take care of itself. Mr. Gardiner begins the Mass disappointingly. He has chosen a tempo for the Kyrie that is meaningless, being neither slow nor fast enough to suggest any emotional impulse. From then on, however, the performance becomes assertive and generates interest.

After 73 years on the road, during which its racing dog emblem became a symbol of American restlessness and mobility as well as of cheap and reliable travel, the Greyhound Corporation is turning the driving over to someone else. Calling it ''the end of an era,'' John W. Teets, the chairman of the corporation, announced an agreement to sell its domestic bus operations to an investor group based in Dallas. The price, for 3,000 buses, 70,000 miles of routes and 60 percent of the intercity bus market, was $340 million.

Terrorists thought to be Sikh extremists killed 10 people, including a family of 4, over a 24-hour span in the Punjab, and the police imposed a curfew today in Amritsar to prevent retaliatory violence by Hindus.

LENDERS have long been aware that their more affluent customers frequently need the sort of services that may not not be part of standard banking fare. This is certainly true of home purchase. The normal mortgage application procedure, for example, may not be appropriate for certain self-employed people. Perhaps the profitability of their business or profession, as reflected on their tax returns, does not accurately reflect their ability to carry a loan. Others may have a stronger capital position but a small income and are willing to make a down payment of 40 percent or even 50 percent for the right to borrow more than is normally permitted.

THEY perform plays about cocaine, incest, teen-age pregnancy, fallen heroes and broken dreams. Off Broadway? No, junior high schools -so students can watch on stage dramas that mirror life in the streets. A college basketball star smokes a crack pipe, a father forces himself on his daughter, a man flings his wife across the kitchen table - not ordinary fare for auditoriums in junior high schools. But the Creative Arts Team, a theater company in residence at the Gallatin Division of New York University, is no ordinary troupe.

It began as a legal support network for the civil rights movement then under way in the South, but today the Center for Constitutional Rights is just as likely to be found challenging American foreign policy in Central America as bringing voting rights cases in Mississippi. That the center, founded in 1966 by four civil rights lawyers and activists, is around to observe its 20th birthday is ''the miracle of the age,'' said William M. Kunstler, one of the founders along with Arthur Kinoy, Morton Stavis and Benjamin E. Smith, who died in 1976. ''I never thought we would be together for 20 years,'' Mr. Kunstler said. ''I thought we were just a thing for Martin King. After he was killed I thought we might just struggle along for a couple of years and then disband.''

The black-suited security guards have left the Boise Cascade Corporation's paper mill in this small town in the mountains of western Maine. Gone, too, are the angry, jeering picketers. What remains from this summer's 76-day strike by the United Paperworkers International Union against the Rumford mill is a deeply troubled community, so wounded in spirit that many residents believe it will take years, possibly generations, to heal. ''This was a close-knit town,'' said a shopkeeper who did not want to be identified. ''There didn't seem to be any reason to hold a grudge against anyone. There's a sad feeling now. A lot of families are very, very bitter.''

A NATURAL MAN The True Story of John Henry. By Steve Sanfield. Illustrated by Peter J. Thornton. 48 pp. Boston: David R. Godine. $13.95. (Ages 8 to 12) THE best way to tell if a book based on a piece of folklore works is to hold it in the mouth. Tell it aloud. If it has not lost its ability to sing, to pump the heart - buy it!

I agree that we should promote existing recycling processes and stimulate technology to devise methods for efficiently utilizing household waste, but the final solution lies within the citizenry. The recurring theme, ''Not in my backyard,'' is understandable. No one wants an incinerator, landfill or transfer station close to his home. However, I don't think our protests are justified if each of us does not, with equal aggressiveness, reduce the amount of garbage we produce.

The start of a new effort to revive peace negotiations in Central American was announced last week by eight Latin American governments, who said the Secretaries General of the United Nations and the Organization of American States would join them. The initiative was announced after a meeting in Rio de Janiero of the four members of the so-called Contadora group - Venezuela, Colombia, Mexico and Panama - and four nations supporting the negotiation effort - Brazil, Argentina, Peru and Uruguay.

Two remarkable Republicans are leaving the Senate in a few days. Barry Goldwater of Arizona departs after 30 years and one hopeless campaign for the White House. Charles Mathias of Maryland goes after 18 years as a Senator following another eight years in the House. One has long been thought of as the Republicans' Mr. Conservative, the other as a leader among liberal Republicans, but such easy labels do them little justice. Whatever their differences in stance, the essential qualities of both men are the same: integrity and service.

Richard M. Levine writes that the ''Son of Sam'' law ''might prevent Jean Harris from profiting from her own best-selling account of Dr. Tarnower's killing.'' More than a year ago, I proposed the establishment of a foundation for the educational needs of children of inmates of the Bedford Hills Correctional Facility.

CENTURY-OLD inventories of furniture and a 19th century stereopticon image of the Governor's office in the Vermont State House in Montpelier provided the clues for a recently completed restoration that has left the chamber looking as it did 127 years ago. In 1859, the Governor's office was an Italianate splendor, newly rebuilt after a fire, said Jay White, an architect in Waitsfield, Vt., who coordinated the renovation project. But over the years, the office was redone several times. The ornate plaster medallions were removed from the ceiling, the plush upholstery was exchanged for leather and the two-tiered gas chandelier was replaced with more pedestrian electric lights.

THE FIRST TIME I MET HIM, he fell asleep in his spaghetti. It didn't matter. I was in love. Not with him, but with his mother. She had kept Sebastian from napping so that we wouldn't be interrupted after dinner. He was only 18 months old, a tiny little body topped off by a big head covered with blond hair. His divorced mother and I, both 25, dated for a month, lived together nine more, and then married. It was Karen I wanted, not Sebastian, but they were a package deal. Ironically, he turned out to be the best part of the bargain.

To the Editor: In the context of the recent shootout between Larry Davis and the New York City police, Don Wycliff speaks of domestic consequences of the elimination of the military draft under the pressure of anti-Vietnam War sentiment in this country: the lost opportunity for low-income minority youth to break away from the restricting circumstances of their lives, and the crime, violence, unrest and disorder that arise when these young people have nothing but such circumstances in prospect. The military draft was not the only opportunity lost to minority youth as a result of antiwar sentiment, however: Reserve Officers Training Corps programs on campuses also went into decline and the financial aid and career opportunities that went with them.

Jonathan Silverman, who has spent the last few years of his life playing the alter ego of Neil Simon on Broadway and now, in the film version of ''Brighton Beach Memoirs,'' on the screen, is the kind of young man every mother wishes her daughter would marry - bright, polite, clean-cut, charming, modest. And he seems to have his share of interested young women - many of whom he meets when they come backstage at the Broadhurst Theater, where he is starring in ''Broadway Bound'' - to tell him how good he is. He is playing Eugene Morris Jerome at the age of 23, as the Simon character begins his writing career. ''It's great for my social life,'' Mr. Silverman said with an unabashed grin. ''I sometimes do ask some of those girls to go out with me. It may be taking a kind of advantage of my position, but heck, I'm 20 years old.''

Saul Schindler, a retired schoolteacher who lives in Hewlett, wrote an Opinion Page article [ ''Let's Save Our 'Surplus' Schools,'' Dec. 7 ] expressing his feelings about surplus schools and his views of enrollments and related matters. While I respect his right to hold and express whatever views he chooses, errors of fact need to be corrected. Mr. Schindler contends that school enrollments in District 14 (Hewlett-Woodmere) ''would continue to grow,'' and he states that the Board of Education ''admit(s) that it has now stabilized.'' This is incorrect.

It was built in the 1920's off Grand Army Plaza, in what was then one of Brooklyn's most fashionable areas. But 44 Butler Place started to slip as the suburban exodus accelerated, and by the late 1960's the building had been abandoned.

Big principles are sometimes tested in unlikely places, and last week the sidewalk at the southwest corner of Fifth Avenue and 45th Street was one of those spots. Selling dictionaries and children's books to Christmas shoppers, Junior Grandison claimed exemption from efforts to clear the sidewalks of illegal peddlers.

DARRELL GRIFFITH of the Utah Jazz, who missed the last National Basketball Association season because of a broken foot, will be sidelined with a shoulder injury for another 10 days to two weeks. Griffith, who has averaged 16.9 points per game far this season, sprained his left shoulder in Chicago last Saturday when he collided with Gene Banks of the Bulls while both were pursuing a loose ball and hasn't played since. . . . The five-mile Midnight Run New Year's Eve in Central Park will have among its 4,00 partcipants Wendy Sly, who took the silver medal in the 3,000 meters at the Los Angeles Olympic in 1984, and Vince Braddy, the event's defending champion. . . . The World Cup soccer star, Diego Maradona, who led his native Argentina to triumph in Mexico last summer, will lead a South American all-star team against Japan's all-stars in Tokyo next month in a game called XEROX Super Soccer '87.

Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

WHEN Dick Vermeil left his job as coach of the Philadelphia Eagles in 1982, he complained of burnout. When he told the Atlanta Falcons yesterday that he was not their man to replace the dismissed Dan Henning as head coach, it was obvious there was no burning desire to coach again in the National Football League.

MONTY: Final Years of the Field-Marshal, 1944-976. By Nigel Hamilton Illustrated, 996 pp. New York: McGraw-Hill Book Company, $29.95 IF American readers can get beyond their anger or anguish over the portraits of Gen. Dwight David Eisenhower and Gen. Omar Bradley in the more than 900 pages of this third and final volume of Nigel Hamilton's biography of Field Marshal Bernard Law Montogmery, they will be rewarded. The will find an incisive protrait of Viscount Montgomery, commander of the northern group of Allied armies in Europe from D-day to the end of the war in Europe in 1945.

Students at Beverly High School are complaining that they are being unfairly videotaped by hidden police cameras on the lookout for illicit drug sales. School officials in this coastal town northeast of Boston concede that they have allowed the police to use hidden cameras because they need help to combat drug sales.

For video fans, the year was marked by a colorful spectrum of main events, technical, commercial and political. The chief technical development was the debut of digital methods in home video; commercially, an imbroglio erupted over formats for portable camera-recorder combinations; and in politics, Congress entered the fray over scrambled satellite transmissions. With nearly every aspect of electronic communications currently being converted to digital techniques, it is not surprising that the trend is reaching home video. Yet, oddly enough, digital methods entered the video field by the back door, so to speak.

Sherelyn Ogden pulled the original manuscript of Laura Ingalls Wilder's popular children's book ''Little House on the Prairie'' out of a cardboard box. She flipped through the thick tablet, with its pages of neat, penciled script, that the author purchased in Springfield, Mo., in 1930. ''Sherwood Anderson used the same kind of paper,'' noted Ms. Ogden, who is the chief book conservator at the Northeast Document Conservation Center. ''I restored his, too.''

Three neighborhood groups have filed a petition that demands a halt to condominium development along the city's waterfront. The move Monday by the Working Waterfront Coalition is the latest round of a battle for the direction of Portland's growth. It was the most recent sign of bitterness among residents who believe that as Portland basks in the glitter of an economic and cultural renaissance, the problems of the 20 to 30 percent of the population who the city says live at or under the Federal poverty level have been brushed aside. While the story of gentrification and displacement is repeated across the country, some civic leaders say the contrast is sharper here because the city has recently been well publicized as a mecca for affluent young professionals.

A defendant has won the right to a new trial because he was not allowed to act as his own lawyer when he was convicted of burglary and arson. In reversing the conviction, a Federal appeals court declared last week in Manhattan that a constitutional right of defendants to represent themselves in criminal trials reflected ''values of individual integrity, autonomy and self-expression.'' The case involved Gregory Johnstone, who wanted to act as his own lawyer in State Supreme Court. The trial judge rejected the request, stressing that the 18-year-old had no occupation and ''scarcely any formal education.''

To the Editor: To answer the question in the headline of Kurt Vonnegut's Dec. 14 Op-Ed article, ''Can't Prague Leave Even Jazz Alone'': Not only do we leave it alone, but we also treasure it. Jazz has been played, admired and loved in Czechoslovakia from the earliest days of its popularity in Europe.

AT first glance, Spruce Bank Farm, a brand-new cluster of 24 gray-and-white attached cottage-style homes on a grassy hillside not far from the center of Woodbury - a rustic Connecticut town of some 7,000 people thinly scattered over 37 square miles - looks like a small, elegant condominium development. The appearance is deceptive: Spruce Bank Farm is a low-rent housing project for the aged, which only a decade ago would have been unacceptable to a residential community that prided itself on its dignified, affluent image. The project, completed last summer at a cost of $1.25 million, offers one-bedroom units for as little as $282 a month - about a third of the market rate for a rental in that area if such an apartment can be found. Not surprisingly, more than 100 people rushed to sign up for the 24 homes, despite strict income and age limitations.

To the Sports Editor: As a Brooklyn native, I am somewhat perplexed by the snowballing enthusiasm among local politicians to bring minor league baseball to my home borough (''Brooklyn Delegation Starts Pleading Case for a Baseball Team,'' The New York Times, Dec. 6). Whatever has given anyone the impression that Brooklynites would support a minor league team, especially with two successful major league teams that enjoy support throughout the borough? Do we need to be reminded of the ill-fated Brooklyn Dodgers professional football team of the now defunct Continental Football League of the late 1960's? This team, despite the glamour of Jackie Robinson as general manager, played to empty seats while Brooklyn football fans continued to flock to see the Giants and the Jets. That's hardly an encouraging precedent.

LAST week's column gave an overview of the cloning of I.B.M.'s PC, with the promise of coverage of three specific machines to come. Digging right in, let's look at one rather nicely designed machine, the Equity II ($2,690 with a 20-megabyte hard disk from Epson America, Torrance, Calif., 90509, (213) 539-9140). Epson long since made a mark for itself as one of the largest producers of low-cost dot matrix printers in the country. The company has been making personal computers for some time as well, but its efforts have been less successful, veering off into incompatible operating systems proffering lots of promise and little delivery.

Sea gulls, the toughest and most prolific of Eastern shore birds, are the latest creatures to come to dinner on Cape Cod and stay on to take over the household, and the United States Fish and Wildlife Service would like to be rid of them. Especially those on Monomoy Island, where more than 20,000 nesting pairs of great black-backed and herring gulls are forcing off smaller and more timid species of shore birds, like the rare piping plovers, laughing gulls, Arctic and least terns, as well as the endangered roseate terns. In 1963, when Monomoy Island became this area's largest Federal Wildlife Refuge, there were only five nesting pairs of gulls on the island, a 2,750-acre sand strip that begins about half a mile south of Chatham.

To the Editor: In his excellent review of Ernst Bloch's ''Principle of Hope'' (Nov. 23), Leon Wieseltier remarks that Bloch is a philosopher of process. I do not know if this is an oblique allusion to Alfred North Whitehead, who is widely recognized in the English-speaking world as the philosopher of process.

ROCK OF AGES The Rolling Stone History of Rock & Roll. By Ed Ward, Geoffrey Stokes and Ken Tucker. Illustrated. 649 pp. New York: Rolling Stone Press/Summit Books. Cloth, $24.95. Paper, $14.95. WE never did outgrow it, this hopped-up musical hybrid, this raucous noise that ultimately made all of popular culture march to its beat. When rock first began to shake, rattle and roll its way across the American consciousness, we children of the 1950's were told that it was at best a freakish fad - the musical equivalent of the Hula-Hoop or Davy Crockett's coonskin cap. At worst, it was the sound of the civilized social fabric unraveling. By the end of that decade, there were signs that this rude, frenzied musical aberration had spent its energy. When the Beatles gave rock-and-roll a much-needed jolt, the moptops were generally regarded as a sociological phenomenon of a particularly silly season. We would soon leave this awkward age behind, we were assured. We would outgrow rock and adolescence together, and if we listened to music at all it would be good music, adult music. Guy Lombardo. Jerry Vale. Broadway show tunes. We would reflect on that loud, crazy music of old and laugh at the follies of youth.

Buoyed by the repeal of mandatory seat belt laws in Massachusetts and Nebraska, a group entitled Citizens Coalition Against a Mandatory Seat Belt Law has renewed its efforts to have a similar law repealed in Connecticut [ ''Repeal of Law on Seat Belts Is Sought,'' Dec. 7 ] . The group's primary objection to the law is that it is felt to be an invasion of privacy.

To the Editor: In his review (Nov. 23) of William Wright's ''Lillian Hellman,'' Frank Rich reports that one of the issues Wright is unable to resolve definitively is whether Miss Hellman ever joined the Communist Party. I cannot answer the question with absolute finality either, but I can refute the main item cited by Mr. Wright on the affirmative side: the testimony of Martin Berkeley before the House Committee on Un-American Activities that she ''was one of the group that met at his house in Hollywood in June of 1937 to organize a Hollywood branch of the Communist Party.''

IF you find yourself with some half-empty bottles of wine or champagne in this season of gustatory excess, don't throw them out. At least, don't throw them out without good reason. The good reasons are these: * The wine was awful to begin with.

Many articles have been printed about replacing the system of electing state judges with the system of appointing judges by an executive, usually the governor [ ''Politics and Judges Shouldn't Mix,'' Opinion Page, Dec. 7 ] . No evidence is ever presented that this would result in better judges; the people would simply lose the vote for a questionable and unprovable benefit. There is simply no proof that appointed judges are better qualified than elected judges, or that appointed judges are less susceptible to influence than elected judges. We need merely recall a Federal judge's actions in a famous Chicago Vietnam-era case or President Nixon's visit to a Federal judge in a Pennsylvania case to belie these assertions of reform.

THE New England Patriots' quarterback, Tony Eason, injured last Monday night against the Miami Dolphins, got the go-ahead from the Patriots team physician yesterday to resume full practicing for next Sunday's American Conference playoff game in Denver. ''He looks fine,'' said Dr. Bertram Zarins.

IN a pro football game, a team normally has 60 to 70 plays on offense, 60 to 70 on defense and 20 to 25 in kicking situations. Over a 16-game regular season, that works out to 2,240 to 2,640 plays. Of all those plays in the Giants' glorious 14-2 season, one stood out above the rest. Years from now, it will be remembered simply as fourth and 17. It occurred on Nov. 16 in the noisy Metrodome in Minneapolis. With 72 seconds left and the Giants on their 48-yard line and trailing the Minnesota Vikings, 20-19, the Giants faced fourth down and 17 yards to go for a first down. Phil Simms then passed 22 yards to Bobby Johnson to keep the Giants alive, and with 12 seconds left Raul Allegre kicked a 33-yard field goal that won the game for the Giants, 22-20.

THE MEDICAL IMPLICATIONS OF NUCLEAR WAR Institute of Medicine/ National Academy of Sciences. Edited by Fredric Solomon and Robert Q. Marston. Foreword by Lewis Thomas. 619 pp. Washington: National Academy Press. Cloth, $43.50. Paper, $33.50. THE title of this collection of papers, ''The Medical Implications of Nuclear War,'' suggests a discussion cast in narrow clinical terms. In fact, the volume offers a comprehensive survey of the consequences of a major nuclear exchange, ranging from the carnage caused by blast, fire and radiation to long-term effects on the environment and on human society. This marshaling of the work of experts in many scientific fields creates a harrowing prospect, a kind of multidisciplinary vision of doomsday. On scientific grounds, the work shares the weaknesses, as well as the strengths, of such assessments. The reliability of the source is not in question; the volume is based on a symposium organized by the ultraresponsible National Academy of Sciences' Institute of Medicine. The catch is that credibility in science depends on verifiability. Until a nuclear war occurs, the results remain hypothetical. And who would want the hypothesis tested?

MOST of my friends kept their surnames when they got married. As one who chose this alternative, I can report few problems. Except for the paperboy and a few stubborn relatives, my social and professional acquaintances have adjusted easily to my decision. While introductions are longer than they might otherwise be, there have been no real disadvantages. But now some of these friends who have kept their names are having children, and others of us are talking about having them, and the question of the child's surname arises.

The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has ruled out using unmanned rockets to ferry space station components into orbit during the early stages of the project, even though such expendable rockets could speed up construction. A study conducted by John Dunning, a space station manager at NASA's Lewis Research Center at Cleveland, found that use of new expendable rockets, along with the shuttle, could accelerate assembly by up to nine months, rather than using the space shuttle alone to take components into orbit. But Mr. Dunning said the schedule advantage provided by unmanned rockets was offset by a 10 percent to 40 percent increase in potentially dangerous space walks by astronauts required in the first four shuttle construction flights to assemble the components.

COMMUNITY organizations that lost city funds last September have had to cut back their counseling services for low-income tenants or find interim subsidies, but the organizers hope their programs will be included in the city's budget next year. ''We used to help about 50 tenants a month, mostly elderly people, but we can't service that many people anymore,'' said Nicole Levin, executive director of the Strykers Bay Neighborhood Council, an Upper West Side organization with a storefront office at 561 Columbus Avenue at 87th Street. When the group lost its $37,000-a-year consulant's contract with the city last fall, it had to lay off a social worker, reduce the salaries of the organization's other five employees and discontinue a neighborhood newsletter.

Announcement has been made by Jean Wallace of Syracuse of the engagement of her daughter Amy Beth Wallace to Steven J. Sklar, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Sklar of Kew Gardens Hills, Queens. The wedding is planned for May 17.

To the Editor: While I would not dispute that Robert Skidelsky's ''John Maynard Keynes. Volume One: Hopes Betrayed 1883-1920'' was one of the best books of 1986, as you state in your Dec. 7 issue, I do not think it is correct to say, ''This is the first biography of the economist to bring together the two sides of his early life - the formidable public person he was by the age of 30 and the circus rider of the social and homosexual whirl of Bloomsbury.'' I believe it can be demonstrated that I did that in a book published in the United States in April 1984 by Macmillan (Charles H. Hession, ''John Maynard Keynes: A Personal Biography of the Man Who Revolutionized Capitalism and Changed the Way We Live'') and reviewed by Peter Stansky in The Book Review on May 20 of that year..CHARLES H. HESSION Bellport, L.I.

Mr. and Mrs. Francis Giammattei Jr. of Greenville, Del., and Mantoloking, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jane Seymour Giammattei, to E. Laurence White 3d, a son of Mrs. White Jr. of Washington, Conn., and the late Mr. White. The future bride is an advertising sales representative of Historical Times Inc. in New York. Mr. White is a vice president in the municipal bond department at Drexel Burnham Lambert in New York. A March wedding is planned.

Most conductors are so involved with orchestral sounds and balances that when they write for orchestra (either as composers, like Wagner, Strauss, or, in our time, Leonard Bernstein, or simply as arrangers, like the late Leopold Stokowski) they tend to do so brilliantly. Two highly enjoyable recent releases exemplify each of the categories: one devoted to nine of Stokowski's arrangements (Telarc CD-80129, also on LP), the other devoted to theater music by Mr. Bernstein (EMI/Angel CDC-7 47522 2, also cassette and LP). Mr.Stokowski was noted for his orchestrations of organ works by Bach, in which he managed an uncanny preservation of organ sonorities in orchestral garb. Telarc's disk includes two of them, the Toccata and Fugue in D Minor and the ''Little Fugue'' in G Minor, along with an intriguingly successful orchestral translation of the slow movement from Beethoven's ''Moonlight'' Sonata. It also includes two arrangements Stokowski made in direct competition with famous pre-existing ones: Albeniz's ''Festival Day in Seville,'' in a more imaginative setting than the familiar Arbos version, and Mussorgsky's ''Night on Bald Mountain,'' which seems to differ for the sake of difference from Rimsky-Korsakov's more convincing orchestration of the same work. There are also some shorter transcriptions of music by Boccherini, Debussy and Rachmaninoff. Erich Kunzel leads the Cincinnati Pops Orchestra in strong performances, and Telarc's recording is superb.

After hailing Andrei Sakharov's return to Moscow after seven cruel years of banishment in the closed city of Gorky, hail the sequel: his welcome at the Physics Institute and the Soviet Government's calm response to his public criticism of the Soviet assault on Afghanistan - the very ''crime'' that led to his banishment under Leonid Brezhnev. A fellow scientist spoke for the world after the Nobel laureate again took part in a seminar: ''Sakharov is Sakharov - there is only one such man.

SEVERAL years ago Notre Dame and Pittsburgh both had potentially good teams, but did not play each other that season. We are both independents, and I remember kidding with the Fiesta Bowl people, telling them that if my school, Notre Dame, and Pittsburgh both wound up undefeated we could go to their bowl and play for the national championship. And I said, ''I bet you'd get enough money to make it worthwhile.'' It didn't happen that year, but the idea was not long in arriving. More people seem to be talking about the college football bowl games this year than at any other time in recent memory, and most of the discussion has been caused by the fact that Miami and Penn State, two independents, will be playing in the Fiesta Bowl Friday night for a clear-cut national title. Already there has been an incredible amount written and said about the matchup, the money involved, the moving of the bowl date and the possible use of overtime, which was considered, then ruled out. And I feel all the attention is great for college football.

Americana - from ancient pueblo pottery to 20th-century modern - dominated in exhibitions of decorative arts at museums and galleries and in what collectors pursued throughout 1986. The wealth of materials that were exhibited and auctioned this year cover the vast range of styles and categories of works produced on this continent over more than 1,000 years. What historians, curators and collectors share in tracking these objects is an intense curiosity about this nation's past - as seen in ancient artifacts, folk art fantasies, the furnishings of Victorian mansions, Bakelite radios and pop-up toasters. The Metropolitan Museum of Art presented some of the oldest and most lavish examples of such works in two dramatically different exhibitions. The boldly graphic pottery crafted between 550 and 1150 in what is now New Mexico was presented in ''Mimbres Pottery: Ancient Art of the American Southwest.'' These haunting works are among the most expressive of painterly ceramics from the ancient world. The wit, mysticism and sophistication of the pueblo-dwelling people we call Mimbres (named after a local tree) was captured by gifted potters in ritual vessels - bowls, platters and jars -works that are among the most important documents of a society that vanished about 800 years ago.

''I THOUGHT greenmail was dead,'' said Martin Lipton of Wachtell, Lipton Rosen & Katz recently. ''Now all of a sudden it is back, alive and well.'' Mr. Wachtell, the well-kno wn takeover lawyer, was noting a remarkable comeback. It is one that has rendered distinctly uneasy people who are concerned about small stockholders' interests, such as pension-fun d managers.

FOR the first time in 20 years, Chad's many tribes have suspended their civil war to confront a common enemy: Libya. As recently as this fall, 11 armed factions had been vying for power in the landlocked central African nation, which, in a population of five million, is fragmented into 200 ethnic groups. The main group of insurgents, recently allied with Libya, turned against its northern neighbor after Goukouni Oueddei, the rebels' leader and former President of Chad, was arrested in Tripoli Oct. 30. He was wounded in a shootout when he resisted. Mr. Goukouni was overthrown in 1982 by Hissen Habre.

C. of O. for Artist's Lofts Question: We manage a loft building in Manhattan. One floor is used as a business and artists live and work on the second and third floors. The Department of Buildings issued certificates of occupancy for these artist-in-residence spaces in October 1962; they were not registered with the Loft Board because it did not exist at that time. Do we need a C. of O. for the building even though we have these documents? . . . Y. Z., Manhattan

Its initials stand for tender loving care, and that's just what New York City's Taxi and Limousine Commission has been giving the taxi industry too much of, the State Commission of Investigation said last week. The chairman of the watchdog agency, David G. Trager, said the taxi commission had been ''co-opted by the industry that it was set up to regulate.''

Maryland scored a 76-58 victory over Winthrop tonight in the belated season-opener for the Terrapins under their new coach, Bob Wade. Derrick Lewis scored 13 of his 23 points in the second half to lead Maryland.

In the normal course of events, the stenotypists who produce transcripts of Congressional hearings are the most literal and colorless of transcribers. But recently, at a field hearing of the House Subcommittee on Energy Conservation and Power, such a recorder added one small touch of atmosphere.

PUBIS ANGELICAL By Manuel Puig. Translated by Elena Brunet. 236 pp. New York: Aventura/Vintage Books. Paper, $6.95. ALL of Manuel Puig's books are something of a hustle, but when he's in command of what he's doing, he succeeds in making that the point.

Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d has rejected a request from an independent counsel to widen her investigation of whether a senior Justice Department official acted improperly in withholding documents from Congress, according to sources familiar with the investigation. The sources said that Alexia J. Morrison, the independent counsel investigating Theodore B. Olson, who oversaw the Department's Office of Legal Policy, was denied permission to widen her investigation to two other former high-level officials. The allegations against Mr. Olson, who has left the Justice Department, concern whether he gave false testimony to Congress as it was investigating the Reagan Administration's withholding of documents about the activities of the Environmental Protection Agency in 1982 and 1983.

The chairman of the ruling Democratic Justice Party has agreed to consider opposition proposals in a parliamentary debate over how to alter the country's form of government. The move Friday by the ruling party's chairman, Roh Tae Woo, came in response to a statement Wednesday by the president of the opposition New Korea Democratic Party, Lee Min Woo, that his party would consider the ruling party's demand for a parliamentary cabinet system if the ruling party agreed first to democratic initiatives.

A report on Nov. 30 on Connecticut's celebration of the bicentennial of the United States Constitution misidentified a book by David Bollier about the state and the Supreme Court. The title is ''Crusaders & Criminals, Victims and Visionaries.''

The early tidings announced that the British were coming. And so they did - along with the French, the Chinese, the Spaniards, the Canadians and many more. It was the year of the foreign invasion in dance. The impact of visiting companies was the strongest in a decade - both in numbers and the quality they demonstrated. Nonetheless, it was Lar Lubovitch, an American, who shot to the front ranks of choreographers in 1986. Very clearly on a creative jag after several years spent in a minimalist rut, Mr. Lubovitch offered a modern-dance premiere, ''Concerto Six Twenty-Two,'' that heralded a flamboyant inventiveness. Along with his recent ''Brahms Symphony,'' this ingenious work to Mozart delivered a cornucopia of glorious dancing. The year, however, did not bring out the most inspired new work on much of the home front, especially in the ballet companies. That the Americans were doing business as usual is a factor to consider in determining the extent of the foreign visitors' impact.

The marriage of Anne Louise Wuesthoff, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Winfred Wm. Wuesthoff of Milwaukee, to Robert Shaw Bridges, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. S. Willard Bridges of Marion, Mass., took place yesterday in Milwaukee.

To the Editor: There is something unseemly about justifying a philosopher of Ernst Bloch's stature or defending the legitimacy of his intellectual enterprise. Unfortunately, however, this has become necessary given Leon Wieseltier's review, which simply has not given this significant philosopher his due.

Mrs. Vincent T. Tracy of New York has announced the engagement of her daughter Heddie Virginia Tracy to William Edward Tinker Jr., the son of Mr. Tinker of Falls Church, Va., and Mrs. Sidney Kweller of Pittsburgh. The wedding is planned for May 30.
The pianist Herbie Hancock juggles two careers. One identity is the amiable technophile who leads a funk band and knocks out an electronic-toned dance hit every few years.

A news summary in The Week in Review last Sunday described charges against associates of Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr., who is the focus of a Federal investigation into whether he and some of his supporters violated income tax laws.

WHEN United Technologies of Hartford spent $50 million to build the Living Seas Pavilion at EPCOT Center in Orlando, Fla., it wanted to leave the audience with a clear idea of the scope of United Technologies' operations. And to get its message across, it commissioned a Mamaroneck company, BHA Design Inc., to create a corporate logo -a multi-video display. When the Detroit Institute of Arts wanted to mount an exhibition of American art from 1876-1883, it hired the Leone Design Group of Larchmont to do the work. Both design groups moved from the city to the suburbs when they needed more space, but, equally important, say the principals in each company, has been the gain in productive working hours. ''When we have to, we work around the clock against deadlines,'' said Barry Howard, founder and president of BHA. ''Since I live in Westchester, I saved over two hours a day in commuting after I moved the company to Mamaroneck.''

CHEKHOV By Henri Troyat. Translated by Michael Henry Heim. Illustrated. 364 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $22.50. WITH the publication in English of his study of Anton Chekhov, the Russian-born Henri Troyat has once again demonstrated that he is an excellent biographer. Whether his subject is one of Russia's despotic rulers, like Ivan the Terrible or Catherine the Great, or one of its complicated writers, such as Pushkin, Dostoyevsky, Gogol or Tolstoy, Mr. Troyat has a storyteller's skill for dealing with real-life characters. Their intimate worlds, their defeats, pains and triumphs, become the reader's. Mr. Troyat refrains from cluttering his biographies with mountains of details; instead, he selects only those events - large and small - that contribute to the whole picture. The academically inclined might like to know more about an event or person, but Mr. Troyat refuses to comply if he feels it would impede the dramatic flow of his story. Unobtrusive and seductive, his biographies read like novels. And that's no small achievement.

The Knicks gave up on James Bailey last August and refused to pick up the option year of his contract. The Nets, looking for a backup power foward who could also play center, quickly signed the 6-foot-9-inch, 230-pound Bailey as a free agent for almost $200,000 a year less than the $450,000 a year he earned with the Knicks the previous two years. Tonight, Bailey came off the bench to score a career-high 35 points, grabbed 10 rebounds, blocked two shots and had two steals in 30 minutes of playing time to lead the Nets to a 120-111 victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

CENTENNIAL PARK in Roosevelt is an ideal place for children to let their imaginations run wild. A large sand area is filled with brightly colored play equipment, and cement animals form a square next to tennis courts. There are slides, picnic tables and swings.

ACCORDING to Bill Arnsparger, the football coach at Louisiana State, it was a private physician who was unaware of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's ban on any form of anabolic steroids who prescribed the steroids to Roland Barbay that were detected in a drug test and that will keep the Tigers' defensive end out of Thursday's Sugar Bowl meeting with Nebraska. The school received notice from the N.C.A.A. Friday that Barbay had tested positive for steroids and was ineligible to play in the game.

Elizabeth Irene Briggs, who teaches piano at the Mary Johnson Piano Studio in West Newbury, Mass., and Dr. David Dubuisson Jr., a neurosurgeon at Beth Israel Hospital in Boston, were married yesterday at their home in Wayland, Mass. Justice of the Peace Robert English performed the ceremony.
Sailors, more often called frostbiters, during race last weekend on Long Island Sound. Article, Page 13. (NYT/Gary Guisinger)

THE PORNOGRAPHY OF REPRESENTATION. By Susanne Kappeler. (University of Minnesota Press. Cloth, $35; Paper, $12.95.) The author, a lecturer in English at the University of East Anglia, England, argues that pornography is merely the most obvious example of the objectification of women in all areas of modern culture.

OVER dinner recently I became enmeshed, as one still does in the United States 30 years after C. P. Snow's ''Two Cultures'' appeared in The New Statesman and Nation, in a discussion on the relative merits of the sciences and the humanities. One of the writers present, an essayist and medical administrator, argued for the objective truth of the sciences and the overwhelming role of opinion in literature and literary criticism. Another, a much-published science writer, argued that science writing is always about the unknown, its discourse an eternal questioning. But, I said, isn't the subject of all writing the unknown? Absolutely not, the science writer retorted. Remember what we tell students in creative writing courses: ''Write about what you know.''

DOROTHY SANKER, postmaster of the Purdys post office in North Salem, likes to tell of the three elderly ladies who meet each day at the post office on their way to the senior citizens center, stop on their way back to check on their mail, and later in the afternoon stop again to chat a little and ''just to be sure nothing else came in.'' ''It's a homey place,'' she said of the tidy white frame building that houses one of the county's smallest post offices. ''We are crowded here and we bump into each other. They put in more P.O. boxes, so there's no room for anything. But on a nice day, with the sun streaming in and people stopping by, it's so pretty here I feel I don't want to ever move anywhere.''

IN July 1966, Governor Rockefeller signed a bill that introduced radical changes at the City University of New York. Enacted in response to criticism that black and Hispanic youths were underrepresented in the city's university system, the new law provided the money needed to open the doors of its prestigious four-year colleges to ''educationally and economically'' disadvantaged students who otherwise would have been ineligible for admission. Begun in September 1966 with fewer than 1,500 students, the program offered remedial instruction in basic skills, counseling and stipends for books and other expenses. It immediately caused an ideological split in the university. Proponents argued that the program - called SEEK, for Search for Education, Elevation and Knowledge - was fulfilling the traditional role of the university to educate the city's poor. Opponents warned that the changes would lower academic standards.

N.B.A. Pistons 107, Bullets 105: Isiah Thomas hit a 23-foot jump shot at the buzzer to give Detroit a victory over Washington last night at Landover, Md. Thomas scored 11 of his 26 points in the final period as the Pistons rallied. The Pistons have now won seven of their last eight and 13 of 16 to improve their record to 16-9. Washington, which led through most of the game, went cold in the closing minutes. The Bullets failed to score for 2:20 after Moses Malone's 3-point play gave Washington a 100-98 lead with 2:37 remaining. Washington led by 13 early in the game, after scoring 15 straight points. But the Pistons worked their way back into it, and trailed by 53-52 at halftime. The Bullets extended the lead to as many as 7 points in the second half, the last time at 91-84, before hitting their scoring drought. The loss dropped Washington's record to 13-14. It was the fourth time this season the Bullets have failed to win a game which would have put them over .500. Malone led all scorers with 32 points. Jeff Malone added 25 for the Bullets. The Pistons were led by Adrian Dantley with 27 and Thomas's 26.(AP) Hawks 119, Warriors 108: Three free throws by Glenn Rivers keyed a fourth-quarter surge that helped the Hawks hold off the Golden State Warriors in Atlanta and win their 20th game of the season.

A Sri Lankan delegation held talks with Tamil guerrillas today in the island's north in an effort to end three years of ethnic fighting that has cost thousands of lives. It was the first direct meeting between the two sides in a year and a half, and it took place in the Tamil insurgent stronghold of Kankesanturai on Sri Lanka's northern tip, near Jaffna. The four-member Sri Lankan group was led by Vincent Perera, a legislator from President J. R. Jayewardene's ruling United National Party. Mr. Perera is a Sinhalese, but he apparently won the confidence of the main rebel group by arranging an exchange of prisoners between the two sides last week.

Film buffs planning a quiet New Year's Eve vigil, with some homescreen sampling, will find the best bets on broadcast TV; cable has the edge on Thursday. The Wednesday evening fare is strictly escapism, starting with Hollywood's great romantic version of ''Wuthering Heights'' (1939) - at 8 on Channel 5. So it's shown to death; but with Merle Oberon and Laurence Olivier and Alfred Newman's glorious backgroud music, who cares? Musically, along with some wonderful dancing, Channel 11 is pouring it on at 8 and then 11, in parts one and two of ''That's Entertainment!'' This M-G-M potpourri of speciality numbers over the years, with no bothersome plot, should make festive viewing over the rim of a champagne glass. Then at midnight there's ''Gigi'' (1958) on Channel 5, a festive eyeful of bygone Paris customs and costumes, plus Leslie Caron, Louis Jourdan, Maurice Chevalier and Hermione Gingold, and those delectable Lerner-Loewe songs.

In my interview with your reporter for a recent article [ ''Repeal of Law on Seat Belts Is Sought,'' Dec. 7 ] , I mentioned a certain safety issue sometimes brought up in conjunction with discussions of the mandatory seat belt law, viz., the probability of survival in a car accident if the occupants remain within the car during the collision. The article did not include even a suggestion of the fact that I had an answer, much less what that answer was.

Soviet visitors often profess to be unimpressed by American technology, but there are exceptions. Earlier this month, a Soviet delegation that included Viktor G. Afanasyev, the editor of Pravda, was in Washington to confer on arrange-ments for Congress Bridge, a series of satellite television exchanges between policy-makers in the two countries that is scheduled to take place next March.
The Wine Video Richard Marcus Productions. 250 West 54th Street New York, N.Y., 10019. 144 minutes (two cassettes).

Freed to return to Moscow and to his work after seven years of exile in Gorky, Andrei D. Sakharov, the dissident Soviet physicist, had cautious words of praise last week for the man who sprung him. Dr. Sakharov said he had ''great respect'' for Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who has lately encouraged a more open society and who ordered Dr. Sakharov's release to underscore that policy. The physicist said that when Mr. Gorbachev telephoned to inform him of his release, he encouraged the Soviet leader to free other political and religious dissenters.

DEBORAH RAIZES hesitates to describe herself as a ''housewife.'' Not that the vivacious mother of two isn't proud of her home and family, but the term doesn't quite convey the reality of her daily life. Unlike many women of her generation - Mrs. Raizes is a Scarsdale resident in her late 30's - she does not work at a paid job. She does work, however, often for up to eight hours a day, in volunteer positions with at least nine organizations in the community. Mary Beth Buck also lives in Scarsdale and has four children in the public schools. She often works 40 hours a week - including time on weekends and in the evenings - on volunteer projects she has undertaken for four community organizations. Although the two women have never met, they share a common outlook. Volunteer work, they say, gives them more intellectual stimulation and satisfaction - as well as freedom - than they can imagine ever getting from regular paid employment.

Most visitors to this city think of the Alamo as a tiny shrine where brave Texans died fighting for liberty. Mayor Henry Cisneros wants them to think of a domed sports stadium. Despite Texas' economic woes and a deficit of $26.9 million in San Antonio's budget for this fiscal year, Mr. Cisneros wants the state's oldest city to spend up to $200 million building a modern, all-purpose stadium, to be called the Alamo Dome. Mr. Cisneros's ambitious vision says something about San Antonio's aspirations as well as the city's inferiority complex. In 1920, San Antonio was the most populous city in Texas. A decade later it was a distant third behind Houston and Dallas, were it has remained.

THE descendants of ''The Trail of Tears'' - the Cherokee Nation of Oklahoma - broke new ground a year ago this month by installing Wilma P. Mankiller, the daughter of a full-blooded Cherokee father and a white mother, as Chief. She became the first woman to lead a large Indian tribe in the United States. The Oklahoma Cherokees - 72,000 today - were forced by the Federal Government to move in the winter of 1838-39 from Georgia to Oklahoma along a trail on which thousands died of disease and exposure. They maintain cultural ties with the Cherokees of North Carolina, whose ancestors fled the forced march.

James G. Scripps, a grandson of Edward W. Scripps, the founder of United Press and Scripps-Howard Newspapers, died at his home today, apparently of a heart attack. Mr. Scripps, who was the head of two newspaper groups, was 75 years old. Mr. Scripps was board chairman, president and director of Pioneer Newspapers and of James G. Scripps Newspapers.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. Mastoloni of Scarsdale, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Ann Mastoloni, to Russell Jagoe 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jagoe of Trumbull, Conn. Miss Mastoloni and her fiance graduated with the class of '84 from Pennsylvania State University. Her father is president of Frank Mastoloni & Sons in New York, an importer of cultured pearls.

The United States is pressing ahead with plans to construct two new large radars in Greenland and Britain, according to officials, despite a renewed proposal from the Soviet Union and the opinion of some arms-control experts that building the radars would violate the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty. The Soviet Union repeated an offer this fall to decommission an advanced radar being completed at Abalakovo, near Krasnoyarsk in central Siberia, if the United States would agree to mothball its radar being built in Greenland and abandon plans to build a new radar in Britain. The American effort to build the radars has led to a sharp debate among policy makers and arms control experts outside of Government as to whether the United States is violating the 1972 ABM Treaty, as the Russians contend. Some experts say the treaty does not allow the United States to build the new radars. A classified Government assessment prepared during the treaty negotiations also suggests that the construction of these radars is not permitted under the treaty, which restricts the testing and deployment of missile defense systems.

Julia Fletcher Averett, widow of Elliott Averett of New Vernon, N.J., former chairman and chief executive officer of the Bank of New York, was married yesterday to Edwin Fullarton Peet, a widower and former president of Burns Brothers & Denton, an affiliate in New York of the Toronto investment-banking house of the same name. He retired as an institutional-bond salesman for Wood, Struthers & Winthrop in New York. The Rev. George E. Chorba 3d performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in New Vernon.

There should be a standing joke about the kind of game the Rangers and Blues played tonight. It was long and boring, but then, the hockey was not very good either. The Blues defeated the Rangers, 3-2, on a goal from a defenseman, Brian Benning, with 3 minutes 20 minutes remaining in the game, but the referee seemed to take center stage from the players tonight. Dan Marouelli kept blowing his whistle, calling penalty after penalty, much to the displeasure of many fans.

At Temple Beth Sholom in Lawrence, L.I., last night Susan G. Dauber, the daughter of Edith Feldman of Brooklyn and the late A. Gerald Dauber, was married to Benni Jakubovic, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Jakubovic of Brooklyn. Rabbi Max Zucker performed the ceremony.

To the Editor: I am grateful for the generosity of your reviewer in dealing with what he calls my ''excellent'' ''Robert Frost Himself'' (Nov. 30), even for crediting me with ''engineering'' Lionel Trilling's speech at Frost's 85th-birthday dinner, which readers of my pages 101-107 will excuse as a slip of the pen. I'm unable to understand, however, why he allowed key parts of his eighth and ninth paragraphs to appear as his own observations when the points he makes on William H. Pritchard, Richard Poirier and Frost's ''idea of poetry'' are so very clearly given on pages 285, 248 and 119 (without excisions), respectively.

To designate with confidence a handful of musical events out of the hundreds or thousands that filtered through one's ears during this year is both easy and impossible. Easy, because a couple of eagerly awaited major happenings lived up to advance billing and thus became lock-tight certainties to find a place in musical history. The appearance of Joan Sutherland in the Metropolitan's ''Puritani'' will go down in music's annals, I feel sure, as will the architectural facelift that brightened the face and sound of Carnegie Hall. At age 60, of course, Miss Sutherland did not sing with quite the creamy tone and airy abandon above high C that first brought her into the international spotlight. But this ''Puritani,'' coming 25 years after her Metropolitan debut, left one persuaded that opera historians will single her voice out as one of the technical marvels of a voice-poor era. In terms of durability and voice preservation into advanced age - and probably in artistry as well -Miss Sutherland compares favorably with another soprano immortal, her Australian forerunner Nellie Melba. If an important musical happening of 1986 is defined as one likely to be remembered in the next century, Joan Sutherland singing Elvira with bel canto brilliance in her 60th year cannot be overlooked.

SOON after the Iran affair erupted, Israeli officials rushed to emphasize that it would have no negative effect on bilateral relations with the United States. A troop of visiting Congressmen passing through Jerusalem during the holiday season repeated the message that all is well between Jerusalem and Washington. In fact, this assessment seems to be at best premature and at worst wrong. No one knows this better than Israeli officials themselves. There is a good deal of quiet anxiety here over what Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North will say about Israel if he testifies on the inside story of the Iran affair. Israeli officials are confident that, regarding the first phase of the operation, before January 1986, they have little to worry about save the possibility that private Israeli arms dealers somehow profited from the arrangments.

Two armed men hijacked an armored van carrying up to $500,000 in a crowded shopping area of West New York, N.J., yesterday, kidnapped the driver and a courier, and fired at least nine times at police officers in a 20-minute chase through four northern New Jersey communities. The chase ended when the van slammed into a police roadblock on Route 17 in East Rutherford. One of the bullets struck the right front tire of a North Bergen patrol car, but did not strike any officers or motorists on heavily traveled local streets and major highways of Hudson and Bergen Counties. ''With all the shots being fired, thank God nobody was hurt,'' Deputy Chief William Sybel of the North Bergen Police Department said. The pursuing officers did not return fire, he said.

WHEN Christopher M. Owens, a guard for 14 years at the St. Johnsbury Community Correctional Center in Vermont, signed up for a training session in ''Officer Awareness,'' he expected a lecture, slide show, coffee and doughnuts. But to his surprise, after the doughnuts, ''The doors to the class burst open. People barged in carrying automatic weapons, threatening us with violence and death,'' recalled Mr. Owens, 37 years old, about the session held in November 1985 at a National Guard Armory near the prison.

A University of Wisconsin officer has accepted the job of president of Westfield State College, which has been thrown into turmoil by charges that its former president sexually molested two male students. Irving H. Buchen, vice chancellor of academic affairs at the University of Wisconsin at Stevens Point, said in a telephone interview Wednesday that he plans to start April 1.

The engagement of Elizabeth Gorham Hanna to Stephen Williams Morss has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John Hanna Jr. of Old Chatham, N.Y. Mr. Morss is a son of Charles Anthony Morss of Lincoln, Mass., and Shelley Christine Morss of Concord, Mass. A July wedding is planned.

At St. Peter of Alcantara Roman Catholic Church in Port Washington, L.I., yesterday Kathleen Ann O'Connor and John Quinn Donovan, 1986 graduates of Princeton University, were married by Msgr. Walter E. Simmons.

QUESTION: One way of measuring a baseball player's production on offense for a season is to add his total runs scored and total runs batted in, then subtract his home-run total, since a homer counts as both a run scored and one driven in. Under that condition, would Jose Canseco of the Oakland A's still warrant being voted American League rookie of the year over Wally Joyner of the California Angels? It reinforces the selection. With 85 runs scored, 117 batted in and 33 home runs, Canseco had a total run production of 169 (202 minus 33). Joyner was 9 behind with 160, based on 82 runs scored, 100 driven home and 22 homers. The major league leader was Don Mattingly of the Yankees with a 199 total fashioned from 117 runs scored, 113 r.b.i. and 31 homers. QUESTION: Down by one run, two outs from defeat and runners on first and third, Team A pulls a surprise bunt play in an effort to accomplish two things: fetch the tying run in from third and advance the potential winning run into scoring position at second base. After the batter bunts the ball, though, the Team B pitcher makes a surprising catch, then turns and throws to third in an attempt to double the runner off that base and end the game. As the runner dives back into the base, the ball hits him and rolls toward left field and the runner winds up going home.

Aside effect of the phenomenal increase in the value of duck, goose and shorebird decoys over the past decade has been the spate of books devoted to the craft or art of creating them. None of these books suggests that anyone clever with his hands is going to make a living at decoy carving; for most, the rewards will not be financial. There are two categories of waterfowl decoys, working and decorative, and most who begin carving the first-named do so because they want to use them for hunting. The decorative birds, often in miniature and highly detailed, are intended to please the eye rather than to lure ducks and geese within range on some storm-tossed bay.

Thousands of New Yorkers, living in a city where usable public bathrooms are few and far between, were fined $50 to $250 this year for using streets, sidewalks and subway stations as urinals. Many of the summonses, city officials say, went to cabdrivers in a rush. Some other offenders were homeless people. Others, they say, were too lazy, too rude or too drunk to search for a restroom. Almost all were men. And all of them are part of a problem - public urination - that was addressed in the first century by the Roman Empire, lessened in the 20th century by several European cities, but today in New York City remains perplexing and unpleasant.

Virginia Tech officials said today the school will forfeit two basketball victories, including a Dec. 22 upset over Wake Forest, because of an ineligible player. The player, Russell Pierre, had sat out last season as a transfer student after two seasons at North Carolina State.

An apparent malfunction in a water-flow monitor today caused a shutdown of the N Reactor at the Hanford nuclear reservation, a company spokesman said. The reactor, which produces plutonium for nuclear weapons and steam for electricity, was shut down after the monitor was tripped, indicating a low flow of the water that serves as the primary coolant, said Rudy Cortez, a spokesman for UNC Nuclear Industries, which operates the reactor for the Federal Department of Energy.

Despite the contrasting market conditions in Brazil, where new cars are in great demand, and in Argentina, where the automotive industry is in a slump, the Ford and Volkswagen subsidiaries in both countries have one thing in common: they are operating deeply in the red. Hoping to forge strength out of weakness and, above all, profits out of losses, the two giant corporations announced plans in November to pool their resources and merge their subsidiaries in South America's two leading economies in what some industry analysts have described as a creative attempt to remain in business. Owned 51 percent by Volkswagen and 49 percent by Ford, the new company will be known as Autolatina, potentially the world's 11th-largest car manufacturer, with a productive capacity of 900,000 vehicles a year, and a market share of 61 percent in Brazil and 34 percent in Argentina. The combined auto company will have assets worth $1.8 billion, annual sales of $4 billion and 75,000 employees working in 10 factories in Brazil and five in Argentina.

REGAINING 'LOST HORIZON' With the coming of the new year, Frank Capra's 1937 film ''Lost Horizon'' will celebrate its 50th birthday, and its popularity shows no sign of diminishing. The movie, about Western travelers who find themselves stranded in a mythical mountain land of Asia called Shangri-La, was adapted from James Hilton's novel. During World War II, when queried about the point from which American planes left for the first bombing raid on Tokyo, President Roosevelt smilingly replied, ''Shangri-La,'' thus ensuring the story's niche in history. The film stars Ronald Colman, Margo, Jane Wyatt, Sam Jaffe, H. B. Warner, Edward Everett Horton and John Howard.

The New York-based Shadow Network, which supplies 73 radio stations in the New York-New Jersey-Connecticut area with traffic reports and lives on the advertising it generates, has been acquired by the Shadow Communications Corporation of Philadelphia for a reported $5.2 million from a group of New York investors. Roy Schwartz will continue as president of the New York operation.

Surrounded by the sheer marble cliffs of what is sometimes called Taiwan's Grand Canyon, Hsu Kuo-shih reflected on Taiwan's rush to curb pollution and create national parks. ''We've had 30 years of high-speed development on Taiwan,'' he said. ''But sometimes we damaged nature in the process. Now people have higher incomes, and they begin to think of nature. This is our environmental age.''

Dennis Conner brought Stars & Stripes from behind in the final minutes to score a 10-second victory over Tom Blackaller's USA as the semifinals of the America's Cup challenger series opened here today. The largest spectator fleet of the trials - more than 50 boats -jammed the finish line as the two 12-Meters approached. It wasn't clear who would win until Stars & Stripes tacked one last time and dashed across the line to victory to the cheers of the waterborne crowd. In the other challengers' semifinal, Chris Dickson, the skipper of New Zealand, had far less trouble defeating Marc Pajot's French Kiss, winning by 2 minutes 46 seconds.
Two New Year's Eve shows are planned by the First Amendment Comedy Theater, 2 Bond Street, between Broadway and Lafayette Street (473-1472 or 677-1409).

A United Nations film about projects that aid the homeless will not include two New York programs because of objections from the United States Mission, according to American and United Nations officials. The film, planned to commemorate the 1987 Year of Shelter for the Homeless, would have featured projects from Brazil and Sri Lanka along with two groups working in New York, the Urban Homesteaders Assistance Board and Habitat for Humanity. Film officials said they did not realize the United States Mission would object to the inclusion of the New York projects because of the nature of the organizations involved. Urban Homesteaders is financed largely with contributions from the philanthropist Leonard Stern and is training more than 12,000 people to manage the city-owned tenements in which they live, for future purchase. Habitat for Humanity, through which people are rebuilding vacant buildings on the Lower East Side, is closely associated with former President Jimmy Carter.

Avian enthusiasts aiming their optically enhanced eyesight skyward as they took part yesterday in the 62d annual Christmas bird count at Wave Hill. The object of the exercise is to count as many species and individual birds as you can. A sharp-eyed watcher can expect to spot cedar waxwings, turkey vultures and brown thrashers, among others. (NYT/Alan Zale)

Mayor Koch went to a church in Howard Beach, Queens, yesterday in search of what he called an honest and forthright discussion about race relations and found himself interrupted, booed, shouted down and snubbed. Some refused to enter the church because Mr. Koch was there. Others walked out as he stood before them in Our Lady of Grace Roman Catholic Church on 159th Avenue, a short walk from where a 23-year-old black man, Michael Griffith, lost his life nine days ago in a racial attack by a group of white men. Shouts of ''Go home,'' ''Resign'' and ''You have no right here,'' greeted the Mayor's arrival. Members of the congregation treated his visit and departure just as angrily - in contrast with the friendly reception he got later yesterday at another Queens church. That was the Morning Star Missionary Baptist Church in the predominantly black community of St. Albans.
Freeman McNeil about to catch a pass from Pat Ryan (10) for a touchdown against the Chiefs at Giants Stadium. The Jets advanced with a 35-15 victory. SportsMonday, page C1. (NYT/Sara Krulwich)

Security forces are on high alert at Leonardo da Vinci Airport and other potential terrorist targets around Rome, Government officials said today. The added precautions were in part a response to recent terrorist threats against Italy, the officials said. Police officers armed with submachine guns were out in large numbers at the entrance to the airport's international terminal today, and travelers were randomly challenged to produce tickets and passports before they were allowed to enter. Helicopters swept low over the airport, which is also known as Fiumicino, and police vehicles patrolled the utility roads near the runways. The security measures were stepped up at the beginning of the Christmas holidays and were further increased after the crash of an Iraqi Airways plane in Saudi Arabia during a hijacking attempt on Thursday, officials said.

About 20 members of the Jewish Defense Group demonstrated across from St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday to protest the decision to cancel formal meetings between John Cardinal O'Connor and Israeli leaders, an official of the group said. ''We want to let the Cardinal and the Vatican know that we're absolutely outraged that there was a change of plans,'' said the official, Rabbi Yakov Lloyd, New York State coordinator of the group. He said the group, which recently broke away from the Jewish Defense League, planned to demonstrate at St. Patrick's again on Jan. 11, when the Cardinal is scheduled to return.
''Those people who beat and ultimately caused the death of a black man, they don't represent you, they don't.

President Hafez al-Assad, who in his 16 years of power has come to be regarded as one of the most cunning - and ruthless -strategists in the Middle East, is facing a host of problems at home and abroad. ''So many things have gone wrong for Hafez al-Assad in the last six months,'' a senior Western diplomat here said. ''There's just a huge, long list of problems. He's in trouble.'' Chief among Mr. Assad's problems is the unraveling of his effort to impose his will on the chaos of Lebanon, where a Syrian-brokered pact, signed with considerable ceremony here a year ago, broke down, and where Mr. Assad's enemy Yasir Arafat is rebuilding the Palestine Liberation Organization bases he lost in the 1982 Israeli invasion.

SATURDAY night's ''Fidelio'' at the Metropolitan Opera brought a debut that was promising but not so successful as one had hoped, along with three other changes from the opening lineup. The debut artist was Faith Esham, familiar from her many roles at the City Opera, as Marzelline. The role proved to suit her voice better than it did her style as an actress. She projects knowing artfulness and sophistication more readily than innocent sincerity, and Marzelline depends on the latter. Here, Miss Esham played girlish high spirits and petulance with such insistence that even before the first number was over one felt she had protested too much.

Frank Lorenzo: Chairman, Texas Air Corporation He created the nation's largest air carrier by taking over Eastern Airlines and People Express in separate deals this year. ''We are not interested in size for size's sake.
BASKETBALL NETS VS. MILWAUKEE BUCKS, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:30 P.M. (TV - SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio -WNEW 1130, 7:20 P.M.) E.C.A.C. HOLIDAY FESTIVAL, St. John's vs.

After working through this year at a breakneck pace, merger and acquisition specialists doubt they will have much time to catch their breath in 1987. They expect that most of the same forces that stimulated deals this year will be at work during the next 12 months as well. Money, the lifeblood of the takeover game, remains cheap, making it easier for corporate raiders like Carl C. Icahn, Ronald O. Perelman and Asher B. Edelman to finance a string of hostile takeover bids. The Reagan Administration's antitrust policy remains favorable. And a number of industries, including commercial banks, utilities and technology companies, seem to be on the verge of major consolidations.

Dissident Iraqi policemen or security agents appear to be the most likely suspects behind the hijacking Thursday of an Iraqi airliner, a senior Jordanian official said today. Three days after the incident, the Jordanian official said the Iraqi authorities were still keeping a cloak of secrecy over it. The plane crash-landed in Saudi Arabia after a battle between the hijackers and security agents. At least 67 people were reportedly killed. The Saudis have said 107 people were on the plane, but other reports on the number have varied.

Ken O'Brien spoke easily today about life as a backup, even though it was clear it was not a role he wants to get used to. The erstwhile Jet quarterback was on the bench today as Pat Ryan led the team to a wild-card playoff victory over the Kansas City Chiefs.

Sha Yexin has returned to China with the hope of taking back something different from the usual high-tech and high-finance concerns that usually bring his countrymen to the United States. Mr. Sha's gift could be Jose Quintero. If all goes well, Mr. Quintero, a director who has staged many productions of Eugene O'Neill plays, will direct a production of O'Neill's bitingly satirical ''Marco Millions.'' Mr. Sha and Mr. Quintero had a meeting in mid-December at the director's home in California and reached a tentative agreement on the joint effort. The will is there on both sides, Mr. Sha said before he left for home on Dec. 18, but the question, as is often the case, is money. Mr. Sha estimated that about $30,000 would be required to get the American director and an aide to China. While the Chinese Government may be able to pay part of this, private and governmental help is being sought in the United States.

A Justice Ministry inquiry has found that Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir did not order the killing of two captured Arab bus hijackers in 1984 and that he did not know of a cover-up of the killings, the Israeli television reported today. Avraham Shalom, former head of the internal security service, Shin Beth, had hinted that Mr. Shamir was implicated in the killings and a cover-up. Mr. Shalom asserted in a request for amnesty that all his actions in the affair ''were done with permission and authority in order to preserve the security of the state and prevent the disclosure of its most guarded secrets.'' Most of Mr. Shalom's actions in the affair were carried out while Mr. Shamir was Prime Minister in 1984. As such, Mr. Shamir was Mr. Shalom's direct and only superior.

The comedian Emo Phillips will perform on New Year's Eve at Caroline's, Eighth Avenue at 26th Street (924-3499). Shows are at 8:30 P.M., with a $25 cover and a two-drink minimum, and at 11:30 P.M., with a $50 cover and a $10 minimum.

The revival of a military draft is an issue that endures even though the present volunteer force shows every sign of success. Now, for the first time in many years, the issue appears to have become partisan, with many Democrats favoring a return to conscription. When they take control of the Congress in January, they have indicated that a new draft will be considered. In marked contrast, most Republicans, including President Reagan and Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger, oppose compulsory duty. Mr. Reagan, however, compromised on a 1980 campaign pledge to do away with draft registration, keeping it on the books.

An excursion train that had just let off 180 passengers today was hit by gale-force winds and some of its cars plunged 135 feet onto a crabmeat processing plant, killing six people and injuring six, the police said. Six of the train's eight cars fell, one after another starting from the rear, ''like match boxes,'' said one witness who was interviewed on television.

Jess Atkinson knows about rejection. ''Two weeks ago,'' he said, ''I had eight National Football League games under my belt and I had been cut four times. But I finally knew how to get along in this league.'' How? ''You've got to have faith,'' he said. That faith was rewarded when the Redskins, unhappy with the erratic place-kicking of Max Zendejas, signed Atkinson, a former Giant. Last Sunday, in his first game as a Redskin, he kicked three conversions in three attempts against the Philadelphia Eagles, but he did not try a field goal.

Israeli officials said today that the President, the Prime Minister and the Foreign Minister would not meet with the Archbishop of New York during his coming visit here except in their offices in an official context. Considering that the Vatican appears to be opposed to any such official meetings because of the formal political recognition that they might imply, the Archbishop, John Cardinal O'Connor, is not expected to see any members of Israel's top leadership. Other meetings with Israeli officials will depend on Cardinal O'Connor's willingness to see them officially. Vatican Position The Vatican has given de facto recognition to Israel as a nation, though not full diplomatic relations, and the Apostolic Delegate has held meetings at the Foreign Ministry and the Ministry of Religious Affairs. Other official contacts, however, are kept to a minimum.

The southern tip of Matagorda Island, one of the nation's most important natural wetlands, is being purchased by a conservation group, a transaction that will eventually put the entire 41-mile-long island under government control as a wildlife preserve. The southern tip of the barrier island between Corpus Christi and Galveston provides a winter home for part of the last flock of endangered whooping cranes, said William Blair, president of the Texas chapter of the Nature Conservancy. That part of the island is also home to four other endangered species: alligators, brown pelicans, arctic peregrine falcons and the Kemp's ridley sea turtle.

Bernie and Marilyn Moschenross got married last July - traveling at twice the speed of sound, 55,000 feet in the air. ''We didn't want a traditional wedding,'' said Mr. Moschenross, a 32-year-old general manager of a fabric store chain in Vancouver, British Columbia.
