In an era in which jetliners have become the subways of the skies, the Moschenrosses joined the growing ranks of air travelers yearning to put the fancy back into flight by riding the Concorde, the needle-thin, droopy-nosed, supersonic plane. Price Break on Charters The chariot of corporate executives and the super-rich - regular one-way trans-Atlantic fares now cost more than $2,100 - the Concorde has now been put within the reach of many erstwhile armchair travelers, thanks to an array of cheaper charter flights offered through Air France and British Airways, operators of the planes.

To the Editor: Harrison J. Goldin asserts (''The Divestiture Con Game,'' Op-Ed, Dec. 16) that recent divestment announcements by I.B.M. and others is nothing more than a ''con game'' to permit circumvention of economic sanctions on South Africa. This misinforms your readers about I.B.M.'s motives for selling our South African subsidiary and the conditions under which our products will be sold there.

Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d has rejected a request from an independent counsel to widen her investigation of whether a senior Justice Department official acted improperly in withholding documents from Congress, according to sources familiar with the investigation. The sources said that Alexia J. Morrison, the independent counsel investigating Theodore B. Olson, who oversaw the Department's Office of Legal Policy, was denied permission to widen her investigation to two other former high-level officials.

Law-enforcement experts say 1987 will be a watershed year for the city's five Mafia families. The experts, who monitor organized-crime activities, say that for the first time since the families were formed in 1931 the leadership of each will change all at once. The upheaval is the result of a campaign by Federal and local authorities that has led to convictions or indictments of those identified as the heads of each family and many of their top lieutenants. With these figures facing long sentences - in Federal prisons far from their bases in the city - officials say their authority will disintegrate and there is likely to be an extraordinary scramble for power in each group.

Last month, T. Y. Chao sold his collection of jade, lovingly assembled over a lifetime, to help pay his shipping company's $850 million in debts. Mr. Chao, whose Wah Kwong Shipping Group is in the middle of a painful restructuring with creditor banks, raised less than $10 million from the jade sale. But if the gesture was more poignant than meaningful, it was a reminder that the industry that created so many fortunes in the past now is erasing them at a dizzying pace. Five Years of Tumbling Rates From the Port of Los Angeles to the docks of Liverpool and the shipyards in South Korea and Japan, the shipping world has been turned upside down by five catastrophic years of tumbling freight rates, rising costs and sinking values of used ships. While the problems are rooted in cyclical overcapacity, many executives now say the downturn is so deep and traumatic that the industry is changing permanently.

On St. Helena Island, 45 square miles of flat brown salt marshes and vast plantation fields, a dispute over the mailing address used by the United States Postal Service is pitting advocates of a 100-year-old nickname against the descendants of slaves who favor a name four times as old. The island, between Charleston and Hilton Head Island, is the largest of some 15 islands off Beaufort County. It was discovered by the Spanish, who called it St. Helena, about 30 years after Columbus found the New World. The first post office on the island began operating in the mid-1800's on Frogmore Plantation, which is believed to have been named after a mansion and grounds at the royal manor in Windsor, England.

Two prominent Soviet scholars have leveled charges of scientific fraud against an Ohio professor, saying that he plagiarized the 30-year-old work of a Soviet physicist in an engineering textbook published in the United States in 1983. In an article in the Moscow weekly Literaturnaya Gazeta in late October, the Soviet scientists called the American, Hollis C. Chen, who teaches at Ohio University in Athens, ''one of the greatest, most cynical and shameless plagiarizers in the history of science.'' They said several chapters in Professor Chen's textbook, ''Theory of Electromagnetic Waves,'' had been lifted ''virtually in their entirety'' from work published by the Soviet physicist, Fyodor I. Fyodorov, including a book that appeared in Russian as early as 1958. ''Even illustrations wandered into the American book in the form in which they were published by Fyodorov,'' the complainants wrote. ''Occasionally Chen, evidently for camouflage, changes the sequence of formulas or adds relationships of his own that are a trivial consequence of the Fyodorov equations. The total number of formulas 'borrowed' by Chen exceeds a thousand.''

Fire raced through a frame house before dawn today, killing two children and their 19-year-old baby sitter, who apparently was trying to rescue the children, the police said. The bodies of the children, Anthony Gill, 2 1/2, and his 16-month-old sister, Savannah, were found in a bed and the baby sitter, Todd D. Thrane, was found on the floor near the bed, Police Chief Gary Spencer said. ''It appears as if Thrane was trying to rescue the children,'' Chief Spencer said.

International A3-9 Cardinal O'Connor's visit to Israel will include a meeting with Jerusalem's Mayor, Israeli officials said, but any other meetings with Israeli leaders will be determined only after he arrives on Thursday. Page A1 The Cardinal considered canceling his trip to Israel because of the embarrassment caused by last-minute schedule changes, he said, but he decided that doing so would have been ''foolish.'' B8 The Vatican-Israeli thicket B8 Jews protest at St. Patrick's B8 Yitzhak Shamir has been cleared by the Israeli Government of any role in the killing of two Arab bus hijackers in 1984 or in a cover-up, the Israeli television said. A6 The spread of AIDS to the Philippines has begun to stir debate over the presence of American military bases there. The virus has apparently been introduced to prostitutes by American servicemen.

Community centers established to handle disputes such as landlord-tenant disagreements or consumer complaints are a good complement to the traditional court system, a Government report said today. In its report, ''Community Dispute Resolution Programs and Public Policy,'' the National Institute of Justice said 180 cities and towns had set up community dispute resolution centers in the last 15 years. The centers handle minor civil and criminal cases, such as conflicts between consumers and merchants, neighbors, family members, landlords and tenants, and petty criminals and their victims.

Soviet art experts have discovered a set of valuable 15th-century icons on the walls of a church in the Ukrainian town of Ovruch, the Government daily Izvestia said today. The 14 icons from the Novgorod school were discovered two years ago on the walls of the Vasilyevsky Russian Orthodox Church, the newspaper said, but news of the find was kept secret until experts could authenticate it.

The minister in a black church in Flushing, Queens, began yesterday by quietly preaching about Jesus weeping over Jerusalem. Soon, emotions swelled and churchgoers fell to their knees or stood waving their hands overhead in a spontaneous memorial service for Michael Griffith. The service was held at the Ebenezer Missionary Baptist Church in the northern part of the borough, but all thoughts were on a community in the southern part of Queens, Howard Beach. It was there nine days ago that Mr. Griffith died in what the police say was a racially motivated attack.

Pat Ryan or Ken O'Brien, what's the difference? The Kansas City Chiefs, in their preparations last week, concluded there would be few significant differences in the Jets' offense with Ryan at quarterback rather than O'Brien. The Jets would be ''more conservative'' with Ryan, as the veteran Kansas City linebacker, Gary Spani, said later. There would be more emphasis on running plays and shorter pass routes. ''We knew Ryan liked Mickey Shuler, the tight end, while O'Brien will throw the ball downtown,'' Spani said. ''We also knew Ryan was a runner while O'Brien will never run. That's exactly what they did. And we weren't able to stop it. A simple game.''

Outward Bound, the rigorous program that develops inner strengths as well as skills in outdoor activities, opened its first school in the United States 25 years ago in a Colorado mountain town. It was an offshoot of a program founded in Wales in World War II to help merchant seamen survive German torpedo attacks by teaching them leadership, teamwork and self-confidence. When Outward Bound began here the program took on a distinctly American character, although its emphasis remained the same. Five schools now offer courses in activities such as white-water rafting and cross-country skiing. But today Outward Bound also helps high school students in New York City to improve their reading skills, Vietnam veterans to cope with their painful memories and cancer patients to adjust to their illness.

Among the 14 publicly held ad agencies operating in 1985, income growth dropped to 4.4 percent, from 15.5 percent in 1984, according to figures that are included in newly released portions of the Communications Industry Report, a bit of self-promotion issued annually by Veronis, Suhler & Associates, investment bankers. It also noted that, by the barest margins, last year missed out on having the worst operating and cash flow margins.

At times during the final stages of the regular season, the Washington Redskins played without enough patience on offense and aggressiveness on defense, which is like leaving the yeast out of bread. It leaves things sort of flat. Today, however, the Redskins mixed all the proper ingredients into a 19-7 victory over the Los Angeles Rams in the National Conference wild-card game to set the pairings for the divisional round of the playoffs next weekend. The Redskins will move on to face the Chicago Bears next Saturday in Chicago, and on Sunday the Giants will play the San Francisco 49ers for a second time in five weeks, only this time in Giants Stadium. The victory over the Rams was a triumph of style as much as substance, with a big assist from Jess Atkinson, the former Giant kicker who joined the Redskins just before the final game of the regular season. He hadn't kicked a field goal in more than a year and today kicked four, tying a Redskins playoff record.

THE increasing preoccupation with fitness and weight control among consumers should combine with growing farm surpluses to again fatten the earnings of food companies in 1987. In addition, cost increases for labor and other expenses are expected to be moderate, and food processors and marketers should benefit from the new Federal tax rules. Some analysts would not be surprised to see industry earnings climb 15 percent in 1987, not counting the gains expected from the new tax rules. The earnings of the major food companies are expected to show an aggregate gain of 13 percent this year. This would compare with gains of 11 percent in 1985 and 9 percent in 1984.

The most remarkable club duplicate played anywhere in the United States, and perhaps in the world, is the Wednesday night game at 105 East 73d Street in Manhattan. National champions often take part; scoring is by international match points instead of match points; bidding boxes are used, and the players enjoy the comfort of the prestigious Cavendish Club.

A pilot who survived a plane crash that killed his co-pilot spent a cold night in the Tehachapi Mountains and climbed down five miles of steep terrain before he was rescued by deer hunters. The pilot, John Howerton, was in serious condition today with first- and second-degree burns and bruises to his heart and lungs, said June Egema, administrative coordinator at the Antelope Valley Medical Center. His plane, a Piper Cherokee, crashed late Friday 15 miles southwest of this community in Kern County, 75 miles north of Los Angeles. Mr. Howerton, a pilot for Gold Coast Air in Hawthorne, was found the next morning by hunters.

College Basketball Washington 72, Idaho 53: Chris Welp scored 17 points and Phil Zevenberger added 16 points and 15 rebounds yesterday to power Washington in a consolation game of the Far West Classic in Portland. The Huskies (7-5) took a 10-2 and never trailed. Southwestern Louisiana defeated Mississippi State, 62-56, in the first game to advance to the consolation finals today against Washington.(UPI) Adelphi 89, Southampton 69: Charles Webb, a junior guard, scored 34 points and Reggie Fitzgerald added 22 to lead Adelphi in the consolation game of the Adelphi holiday tournament in Garden City, L.I. Villanova 63, Houston 60: The Wildcats' defense forced three turnovers in the final three minutes of play, and Doug West and Harold Jensen sparked an 11-5 game-ending surge as Villanova (7-3) won the opening game of the Sugar Bowl tournament in New Orleans. Tim Hobby of Houston (5-3) hit a 3-pointer to tie it at 60-60 with 14 seconds left, but Villanova's Mark Plansky put the Wildcats back on top to stay with a 15-foot jumper.(AP) C. W. Post 81, San Francisco State 79: Michael Hammond, scored 39 points to lead C. W. Post (8-3) over San Francisco State (3-6) in the opening round of the Porecco Cup in Erie, Pa. Hammond's 15-foot bank shot with two seconds remaining broke a 79-79 tie. Horse Racing Tinchen's Prince Wins: Tinchen's Prince dueled for the lead into the stretch with Landing Plot and the favored Judge Costa, then thrust a nose in front at the wire to win the $70,900 Alex M. Robb Stakes for New York-breds of 3-years-old and up at Aqueduct yesterday.

Something happened today for the Jets - the kind of call and the kind of play that often can elevate a team when it is mired in confusion. Here were the Jets, with a five-game losing streak, down 6-0 after one Kansas City drive, and stalled on the Chiefs' 33-yard line in the first quarter. It was a fourth-and-6. A 50-yard field-goal attempt by Pat Leahy into a light wind might not have been unreasonable. Dave Jennings, one of the best in the league at placing punts, might have tried to knock one inside the Chiefs' 20.

The Seattle-First National Bank has been fined $25,000 by the Commerce Department, which said the bank gave Arab officials information related to the Arabs' boycott of Israel. Seafirst lawyers neither admitted nor denied the accusations in the consent settlement, according to a statement from the department issued Friday.

Detectives investigating the death of a black man in Howard Beach, Queens, reported new details yesterday that they said showed that the motorist whose car killed the victim was not an accomplice of the white youths accused of his murder. The investigators recounted the actions of the motorist, Dominick Blum, on the night of Dec. 19-20 when Michael Griffith was killed, and they provided new details about Mr. Blum's companions, whereabouts and movements, and about the police effort to verify the information. Among other things, the investigators said they had cross-checked Mr. Blum's account with those who were with him, verified seats at a play they had occupied, and found a waiter who recalled serving them at a diner. They retraced the routes taken and administered a lie-detector test to one companion that indicated he was giving a truthful account.

The Jets found themselves, and the Kansas City Chiefs, just in time today. A combination of a revived Jets squad led by a new quarterback and a Chiefs team that could not connect on key plays paced the Jets to a 35-15 wild-card playoff victory today at Giants Stadium. It propelled them to the American Conference divisional playoffs against the Browns in Cleveland next Saturday - in other words, two victories from a Super Bowl appearance. First, however, the Jets had to win. They brought in the burden of their five-game losing streak that had brought, according to Dan Alexander, ''everyone in the nation down on us except my mother.''

John Cardinal O'Connor said today that he considered calling off his trip to Israel because of the embarrassment caused by his last-minute decision, under Vatican orders, to cancel meetings with Israel's President and Prime Minister. But Cardinal O'Connor, the Archbishop of New York, said he ultimately concluded, after talking with Israeli officials in New York, that calling off the trip would have been a ''foolish thing to do'' and ''totally inappropriate.'' ''I made a mistake, and it resulted in some embarrassment for some Government officials,'' he said. ''But I would have to be naive to think that Prime Minister Shamir and President Herzog have never been in an embarrassing position, that they would not be sensitive to a mistake made by someone they know to have great respect for them.''

For the nation's computer industry, 1986 was the year when the long-awaited consolidation of I.B.M.'s competitors began in earnest. And if the computer and electronics business fails to improve soon - and there is little evidence it will - more mergers and cutbacks are likely. The biggest combination of the year was the purchase of the Sperry Corporation by the Burroughs Corporation, a $4.4 billion merger that created the world's second-largest computer maker - though one that is still less than a fourth the size of the International Business Machines Corporation.

Next year, corporate boards may have a harder time fighting off suitors because of some key judicial decisions this year. In 1985, the judiciary had given corporate boards the green light to use powerful new weapons to fight takeover bids, but 1986 will be remembered as the year when many courts posted a ''Caution'' sign to directors who adopt defensive measures. In a half-dozen important cases, the courts weighed whether ''poison pills'' - measures that make takeovers prohibitively expensive - were being used as legitimate tools to deter inadequate offers or as an inappropriate way to entrench management. In several cases, courts rejected pills on the ground that they interfered with the shareholders' aim of obtaining the highest price for their stock.

Huang Kecheng, a military leader who accompanied Mao Zedong on the Long March and became Chief of Staff of the Chinese Army but was purged during the Cultural Revolution, died today in Beijing. He was 84 years old.

Albert W. Sherer Jr., a career diplomat who specialized in Eastern Europe, was thrown out of Hungary at the height of the cold war and went on to write the draft of the human rights provisions of the Helsinki accords of 1975, died of cancer Saturday at Northwestern University Medical Center in Chicago. He was 70 years old and had moved to Chicago in 1984 from Greenwich, Conn. Mr. Sherer, who was known as Bud, retired from the Foreign Service in 1979 after two years at the United Nations Security Council and two more at international conferences and other assignments. At the time of his death, he was adjunct professor at the Northwestern University Legal Clinic, where he worked with inner-city children in trouble with the law.

To the Editor: In ''The Word for Takeovers: Pernicious'' (Op-Ed, Dec. 6), Walter Kissinger makes a number of points that my own experience has found to be otherwise and others in which his argument is flawed. Mr. Kissinger begins by claiming that the Ivan F. Boesky insider-trading scandal has succeeded, at last, in awakening people to the evils of hostile takeovers. If it has, it has awakened people to the wrong issue. Mr. Boesky's illegal operations, whatever sums they encompassed, were no more than a tangential outgrowth of a fundamental macroeconomic process occurring inevitably throughout the industrialized world. It can no more attest to the evils of takeovers than the presence of a gambler who has succeeded in persuading a college athlete to shave points in a basketball game can indict the fundamentally healthy drive and legitimacy of young men and women to participate in competitive sports.

It is hunting time in American retailing as the industry undergoes the greatest transformation of ownership in its history. If 1986 was the year of mergers, consolidations, divestiture and reorganization among the nation's stores, predictions on Wall Street and within the industry are that 1987 will be the same and perhaps even more so. Realization that parts of a company may be more valuable than the whole has gripped the imagination of financiers and acquisition-minded retailers. Price-earnings multiples that are still low for many listed retailing companies have been a spur to action, as has the valuable real estate that so many retailers command.

After prospering in relative obscurity for 20 years, a rapidly growing manufacturing program in Mexico has become a focus of increasing concern in the United States. Labor and Congressional leaders say it poses the kind of threat to American jobs that is usually associated with the Far East. At issue is the hugely successful twin-plant, or maquiladora, program, in which foreign goods, most of them from American companies, are assembled at low-wage Mexican manufacturing plants and then shipped back across the border at reduced duties. The rapidly growing program is being hailed in Mexico as the most positive development on the nation's economic scene, and it is being enthusiastically pushed by economic development groups in America's economically depressed border communities. Anger Over Loss of Jobs But it is coming under fire from labor groups and Northern members of Congress who say the program has become an increasingly potent incentive to relocate American manufacturing jobs across the border.

He held a conference in a grimy cement passageway underneath the seats, standing alongside a van and some spare nets. Phil Esposito, smartly dressed in an off-white sports jacket, dark slacks and cowboy boots, looked as if he had scrubbed up to come talk in somebody's garage about the glory days. ''Back-to-back games,'' he said, and he shrugged. ''Come on. Me and Giacomin and Cashman, we played back-to-back games and we flew on planes and it didn't matter. We played better the second night.''

As a high school student, James J. O'Connor admits, he spent a fair amount of time in detention after hours for, among other things, devising schemes of which his teachers disapproved. ''It was unavoidable,'' said the 49-year-old Chicago native, who is now the chairman and chief executive of the Commonwealth Edison Company, one of the nation's largest utilities. Recently, Mr. O'Connor has been spending a lot of time after work in his Chicago office crafting a rate plan that would radically change the status of three nuclear power plants Edison currently has under construction. Proponents hail it as the first step toward utility deregulation.

Gasoline that was being unloaded from a river barge spilled and exploded at a Queens oil company early yesterday, causing a fire that seriously injured two employees, fire officials said. The blaze threatened to ignite six large oil storage tanks within blocks of major traffic arteries and main Long Island Rail Road lines, the officials said. More than 200 firefighters from 50 companies and 2 fireboats responded to the explosion and fire, which occurred at 1:20 A.M. at Ditmas Oil Associates, at 53-02 11th Street in Long Island City. The company is directly beneath the Pulaski Bridge and one block south of the Queens-Midtown Tunnel toll plaza.

With the recent accord of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries sending the price of oil above the $17-a-barrel mark, Damon S. Ankenman hopes that the much-watched count on active rigs compiled by the Hughes Tool Company will also climb. After collecting data from around the country, Mr. Ankenman each Friday releases the weekly count of working oil and gas rigs - a figure that spreads either despair or encouragement through the energy industry. ''I'm kind of like a weather man,'' the 42-year-old Houston native said. ''When it's going good, everything's great. When it's going bad, you get blamed for it.''

THE joy of seeing John Reed in Gilbert and Sullivan lies partly in the reflection that someone who has done something over and over for 30-odd years can still have fun at it. Ever since the D'Oyly Carte troupe closed down in England, Mr. Reed - who had been its principal comedian - has circled the globe guesting in his old roles, and for his fourth annual engagement with the New York Gilbert and Sullivan Players he is appearing as Bunthorne, the opportunistic esthete of ''Patience,'' at Symphony Space (Broadway and 95th Street). The production runs through Sunday.
John D. MacDonald, whose mystery novels sold in the millions of copies, died yesterday of complications from heart surgery. Page B15.2 NEWS SUMMARY, PAGE A2.

More and more college students are borrowing more and more money under Federal programs, raising concern that debt will overburden a generation of Americans, a Congressional report said today. As Federal loans to students have almost tripled in the last 10 years, while grants that do not have to be repaid have declined sharply, a third to a half of all undergraduates now leave school in debt, according to the report released by the Joint Economic Committee. More research is needed, it says, to determine how such debt affects students' later lives, including their ability to pursue further studies, their choices of career, and their decisions to marry and bear children. Burden on Families Growing The study showed that paying for college has become a much heavier burden for families than it was a decade ago, according to Representative David Obey, the Wisconsin Democrat who has been chairman of the committee, and Senator Paul Sarbanes, the Maryland Democrat succeeding him. ''College costs have risen sharply, up about 10 percent in real dollars for public institutions and up by more than 25 percent at private ones, while family income has remained stagnant,'' the legislators said in a joint statement.

For 26 days, the Knicks underwent a transition from one coaching philosophy to another that could not have been more traumatic. They were asked to forget that they had been conditioned to respond to the whims of one man, to adhere to the confines of his system or risk the punishment of public embarrassment. Now, they were told to play, as the players call it, ''their game.'' They were free to run and shoot almost as they pleased. And they were ordered to, most importantly, enjoy themselves. That the transition period occurred during the regular season, without the benefit of a training camp or exhibition games, was reflected in the team's dismal results.

The 15,000 commuters who can't find seats on the Long Island Rail Road each day stand in witness to the Island's need for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's capital investment plan. But 13 Republican Nassau and Suffolk County state senators led by Norman Levy now block a reasonable plan to maintain present transit fares and finance $8.5 billion in new capital.

In traveling to Israel John Cardinal O'Connor is wandering into an area of Vatican foreign policy that is as delicate as it is ambiguous. Although more than 100 nations have diplomatic missions accredited to the Holy See, the Vatican has never established full diplomatic relations with Israel. Vatican officials are often quick to note that the absence of full diplomatic ties does not mean that the Vatican refuses to ''recognize'' Israel or that it somehow denies Israel's existence.

To the Editor: Another example of the law of the unintended consequences of a well-intended act: Express cross streets from 49th to 52d Street, an interesting idea, forces traffic off these streets by signs and traffic police.

Workers at the Latrobe Steel Company here have overwhelmingly rejected a 44-month contract that the company said was one of the best offers made to any steelworkers' local this year. After the 491-to-77 vote Saturday, the company agreed to a fifth extension of the old contract, which expired Aug. 1, to allow talks to continue, said William Ehman, president of Local 1537 of the United Steelworkers of America. Mr. Ehman had earlier recommended that the 650 union members reject the pact, which would have frozen wages and benefits, because it offered no profit-sharing and no cost-of-living increases beyond the current year.
A man was decapitated by a Queensbound IRT train when he apparently slipped and fell while walking between cars, the transit police said.

The Economy Big business in America is overhauling itself and its operations faster than at any time since World War II. [ Page A1. ] Great transformations have been felt by a number of industries, including retailing [ D4. ] , communications [ D5. ] , airlines [ D4. ] , and computers [ D4. ] . Meanwhile, merger and acquisition specialists expect next year to be filled with as much activity as 1986. [ D4. ] Judicial trends this year may encourage takeover activity next year, as courts seem reluctant to approve certain types of defenses. [ D5. ]

A few hundred years ago, in the rich wilderness that is now New York State and beyond, the Oneida Indians, at peace with other tribes and themselves, formed a thriving community. They eventually became allies of George Washington, supplying food to his troops at Valley Forge during the harsh winter of 1778. Today, the last of the Oneidas in New York number under a thousand. Largely impoverished, afflicted by high rates of unemployment and alcoholism, they are also a people bitterly divided. Their feud involves history, politics, philosophy and many millions of dollars. In recent days, an effort has been made to settle the conflict. The outcome, some American Indian leaders believe, could have a significant impact not only on the future of the Oneidas in New York, but also on Federal-Indian relations nationwide.

The ads promise that your new fur coat will give you ''a wonderful feeling.'' A ''fashion'' page shows toddlers ''making the scene'' in furs. A news story says that grown women ''are turning their fuzzy fantasies into luxurious wraps.'' The financial columns report that the American fur industry is reaching new heights of prosperity, approaching a record $2 billion mark in 1986. What those ads and stories don't point out is that to experience these ''wonderful'' feelings and to drape those tots in furs and to realize the ''fuzzy fantasies'' and to enjoy those bulging profits, it is necessary to pay a certain price. The price is paid, however, not by the fur-wearers but by the fur-bearers.

Few issues have so divided New York City as the struggle in the late 1960's over school decentralization, which produced the current system of community school boards. Now Robert Wagner Jr., president of the Board of Education, argues that the system has become so mired in politics and patronage as to stifle educational reform. His criticisms, though justified, have raised fears that he means to scrap the present system of decentralization. So far, those fears are unwarranted.

A Connecticut man was arrested on Long Island after a car accident and charged with attacking his wife with a meat cleaver, the police said yesterday. The man, Alfonso DelSanto, 38 years old, was arrested Saturday and charged with first-degree assault in the attack Friday at the couple's home here, said Sgt. Edward Lawrence of the New York State Park Police in Babylon, L.I. The man's wife, Carol DelSanto, 42, remained in critical condition at Yale-New Haven Hospital yesterday. A passing motorist found her lying by the road in front of the couple's Tudor-style home at about 7:30 P.M. Friday, the police said.
H.L. Mencken and Washington did not get along. The writer always hurried back always hurried back to his home in Baltimore so he would not have to spend the night in the capital.
John Flansburgh and John Linnell, the two songwriters who call themselves They Might Be Giants, will perform New Year's Eve at Darinka, 118 East First Street, near Avenue A (598-0157).

There are 68,000 children under 3 years old in need of out-of-home day care in New York City but only 5,000 licensed places for them, according to city officials and child-care advocates. The problem is particularly critical for working parents whose salaries are too high to make them eligible for public assistance but not high enough for them to afford private baby sitters. Of the 5,000 places available, all but 234 are for children whose parents qualify for some kind of public assistance, according to Child Care Inc., an advocacy group. But these 234 licensed spaces, in 119 family day care homes throughout the city, are slowly being added to as a handful of community groups and churches work to get certification for day care providers.

Jane Ellen Monness, the daughter of Ellen Gretsch Monness and Andrew James Monness, both of New York, was married yesterday to Keith Douglas Brickman, a son of Barbara Leeds Brickman of Peabody, Mass., and Dr. Gerald Sumner Brickman of Malden, Mass. Rabbi Gary M. Bretton-Granatoor performed the ceremony at the Harmonie Club in New York.

While the municipal and corporate markets enjoy another week of vacation, the Treasury will be raising more than $8 billion of new cash from short- and medium-term financings. Today's regular weekly sale of new three- and six-month Treasury bills was reduced to $15.2 billion, from $15.6 billion in recent weeks, but will still raise about $1 billion of new cash after the maturing bills are repaid.

Dark and abandoned on the East Side, factories that once helped to make this city one of the most important manufacturing centers in the United States now stand as a symbol of the nation's industrial decline. But just up the road from this industrial ghost town, a bustling campus-like complex of neat lawns and buildings has become one of Cleveland's great hopes for rejuvenating its economy. This oasis in a desert of urban decay is the Cleveland Clinic, the medical institution that has gained international renown for its treatment of cardiovascular disease and other serious illnesses. Lately, though, the Cleveland Clinic has earned another distinction: Its 8,879 employees make it the city's largest private employer, edging out the LTV Steel Company, the nation's second-largest steelmaker, which is now in bankruptcy proceedings. A Star in the Service Economy Economists and political leaders have voiced concern that the transformation of the United States from a manufacturing-based to a service-based economy would leave in its wake a country of hamburger flippers. But a look at the clinic, with its assortment of low- and high-powered jobs and the prominent role it has come to play in the local economy, shows this is not necessarily so.

The problem with friends is that most people don't feel they have enough of them. ''Or they think the friendships they have aren't close enough,'' said Letty Cottin Pogrebin. ''I interviewed so many people who had rich social lives, yet they were all so worried that they were missing something. When friendship is involved, people really believe they are somehow lacking. They worry if they're calling enough. They feel guilty. They worry that their friends go to others when they want close companionship.'' Ms. Pogrebin herself shared these concerns, as did many of the 150 people she interviewed for her new book, ''Among Friends: Who We Like, Why We Like Them, and What We Do With Them'' (McGraw-Hill, $19.95). Yet the reality was ''that most everyone had a best friend, and many had incredibly satisfying networks of friends,'' she said. ''Even then, they felt their friendships weren't all they could be.''

Gunmen opened fire during a wedding reception at a Chinese restaurant Saturday, starting a gun battle that killed three people, including one of the attackers, the police said today. The police searched for an undetermined number of suspects in the gunfight, which occurred shortly after 9 P.M. Saturday outside the Yit Ing Ho Restaurant in downtown Houston.

The price of a gallon of unleaded regular is down below a dollar, and while OPEC has finally agreed to a modest price increase, few analysts believe the squabbling cartel will be able to make it stick. That means our energy policy is working, right? Wrong, oh so wrong. Unless Washington stops focusing on the prices at the gas pump and starts looking at the prices and dependency just over the horizon, the United States will be in deep trouble all over again.

The man was perhaps in his late 40's, and he wore the dark sunglasses that for years had been the trademark of the Tontons Macoute, the thugs who had been the enforcers of the dynastic Duvalier dictatorship. He averted a handshake with a foreigner and moved away on the cool, shaded patio to avoid conversation. He would not say who he was. Neither would the two men with him, although eventually one of them did allow a conversation to begin.

Filipp T. Yermash, longtime chairman of the Soviet cinematography committee and the target of some Soviet film makers who complained he was a barrier to creative expression, was sent into retirement today. The official Tass news agency said Mr. Yermash, 63 years old, was replaced as head of the state film industry by Aleksandr I. Kamshalov, 54, a former teacher and official of the Communist Youth League. The agency said Mr. Yermash was replaced by decision of the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet, the national parliament.

New orders for American-made machine tools dropped 26.3 percent in November, compared with the encouraging levels of October, according to a report to be released today by the National Machine Tool Builders' Association. Analysts and machine tool manufacturing officials attributed the decline to the same factors that have plagued the industry for the entire year: the sluggish economy and confusion surrounding the impact of recent changes in tax laws. The decline came just a month after a sharp 30.1 percent increase in October from the previous month's levels. Industry analysts had attributed that surge to a large volume of new orders that followed the International Machine Tool Show in Chicago in early September.

CONSIDERED by many to be the Great Reflector of society at large, television entertainment is watched closely for supposed trends. During the last several years, for instance, a somewhat conservative bent in manners and life styles has been detected among the inhabitants of television sitcoms and movies. Marriage is in again, having children is fun, making money is bliss - that sort of thing. What, then, is one supposed to make of ''Blue DeVille,'' the television movie being slipped into NBC's schedule tonight at 9? Here is a genially dopey on-the-road caper that laughingly rejects weddings and family togetherness in favor of having, as the writers put it, ''some stupid, crazy times.'' The executive producers and writers, Eugenie Ross-Leming and Brad Buckner, begin their tale in St. Louis. J. C. Swift (Jennifer Runyon), looking like Barbie come to life, is about to marry upwardly mobile Kevin (Robert Prescott) and assume an obviously promising position in her father's company. J. C. spends a good deal of her time at home doing crossword puzzles. Meanwhile, Gus Valentine (Kimberly Pistone) is saying goodbye to her mother (Micole Mercurio), an aging hippie concerned about nobody but herself. Gus, for Augusta, is on her own, setting out for Colorado in search of the Vietnam-veteran father she has never met. To envision Gus, think of Cyndi Lauper.

Three skiers were injured in a 25-foot plunge from a chair lift at a state-owned ski center yesterday after the equipment apparently malfunctioned, a spokesman said. ''It was a malfunction of the chair or the lift or both,'' said John Moore, a spokesman for the State Department of Environmental Conservation, which operates the Belleayre ski center in the Catskill Mountains.

Just when it seems the last Pearl Harbor attack story has been told, a new one crops up. The latest fills out the tale of a Japanese pilot who tried to take over the small island of Niihau after crash-landing his Zero there on Dec. 7, 1941. Shigenori Nishikaichi landed on Niihau, expecting to be picked up by a submarine, after his plane took a bullet through the gas tank while he was strafing an Army airfield on Oahu, according to a series of articles in The Honolulu Star-Bulletin. The paper interviewed survivors and used Freedom of Information statutes to obtain Government documents not previously available.

Senator Mark Andrews, a North Dakota Republican who is among a group of departing senators who are seeking new jobs, has been campaigning to succeed Carl Bagge as president of the National Coal Association. Mr. Bagge, who has become something of a Washington institution during his 17 years at the helm of the coal companies' group, is retiring next year for health reasons. Although most former lawmakers are more likely to seek other sorts of positions, such as joining prestigious law firms, there is a precedent for the Andrews move. In 1970, after losing to a Republican, William E. Brock, now the Secretary of Labor, Senator Albert Gore Sr., Democrat of Tennessee, surprised many colleagues and constituents when he became the chairman of the Island Creek Coal Company.

The year of the Constitution is upon us. Through 1987 we shall be celebrating the 200th birthday of the extraordinary document that created our country. There is every reason to celebrate. But there is also reason to wonder whether we really understand and believe in the essential idea of the Constitution. The men who framed it in Philadelphia 200 years ago put their faith in limited government. They had seen unlimited power in the hands of the King and they feared it. So they divided power in the government they made, hedged it about with rules, made it accountable to the people.

A paraplegic who regained the use of her legs with the help of a computerized system walked down the aisle at her wedding Saturday. The 26-year-old paraplegic, Nanette Davis, wore an ivory-colored gown over a two-legged brace fitted with cables that allowed her to transfer upper-body motion to her legs.

New York-based Ad/Sat, a relatively new company that is in the business of transmitting ready-to-run advertising to newspapers via satellite, announced that it has successfully completed its tests involving a dozen daily papers and now expects to be servicing the top 100 markets by the end of 1987. It eliminates the need to ship hard copy and it gets copy to the papers fast. According to the company, it already has 80 newspapers signed up, and they represent 37 percent of the daily paper circualtion and 50 percent of Sunday circulation.

A TEST offer for a consumer promotion called The Rebate Book will soon be made on local TV stations so the entrepreneurs behind it can find out what cover price - between $12.95 and $19.95 - viewers find most attractive. The 3 1/4-by-8 1/2-inch booklet contains rebate coupons on hard goods with a combined value of $1,000. ''This is new, it's never been done before,'' said Earle Bower, president of Earle Bower Associates, the ad agency that will be promoting the book. The idea is his and he has an equity position in Rebate Books Inc., of 350 Lexington Avenue, of which Nancy E. Kieffer is president. He called it ''a marketing program for consumer durables companies.''

The people who champion causes, who know how to form committees and call on their connections to get things done, are as much a part of the life of New York as the artist and the author. They are part banker, advertiser, public relations director and legal counsel. They work long hours, trade contacts, raise capital and wield influence. Elinor Guggenheimer, 74 years old, knows that world intimately. She has served on the National Committee for the Day Care of Children, been chairman of both the Day Care Council of New York and the Council of Senior Centers and Services. She was vice president of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies and has served on the boards of numerous organizations. She has also been a public servant, with positions on the New York Planning Commission and a tenure as the Commissioner of Consumer Affairs. She was once a candidate for City Council President.

The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has made substantial progress in carrying out the most extensive managerial and technical review in its history, according to space officials and outside experts. The agency appears well on its way to repairing defects blamed for the disaster last January that grounded the space shuttles. And it has begun to reorganize its faulty management structure along the lines recommended by the Presidential commission that investigated the accident, which killed the seven Challenger crew members. In only 11 months, a vast majority of the top officials in shuttle operations have been replaced. NASA headquarters in Washington has a new Administrator, a new Deputy Administrator and a new Associate Administrator for Space Flight; the directors of NASA's three most important field centers have changed; and all the key engineering managers at the Marshall Space Flight Center who were faulted in the accident have been swept out.

The whole world is going bananas. Here I am, home on the ranch, and what do I see? I see the Russians giving Sakharov a television studio to broadcast to all the American television networks, and Gorby's men smiling as that fearless dissident denounces the Red Army's occupation of Afghanistan. Crazy. I see Chinese students rioting against Deng for being too slow on democracy, and the authorities in Beijing patting the kids on the head and telling them to go home and be nice. Unbelievable.

In an age when electronic gadgets and games are everywhere, many teachers, librarians and private citizens are betting that Americans can be encouraged to develop a love affair with the printed word. With the help of a recently enacted Federal law, they hope to refocus attention on reading and books. The Federal measure is Public Law 99-494, signed two months ago by President Reagan. Officially designating 1987 as the Year of the Reader, the law is further designed to encourage efforts ''aimed at restoring the act of reading to a place of pre-eminence in our personal lives and in the life of our nation.''

Radio and television broadcasters may go back to the Federal Communications Commission or Congress next year for further deregulation of the industry. The target this time is comparative renewal proceedings, the process of handling competing applications for the same license.

The tenor Robert Tear and the baritone Benjamin Luxon will take part in an ''Evening of Victorian Songs and Instrumental Music'' at Carnegie Hall on New Year's Eve, with Marvin Hamlisch at the piano and guest appearances by Isaac Stern, the cellist Yo-Yo Ma, the clarinetist Richard Stoltzman and the harpist Nancy Allen. The concert begins at 8 P.M. Tickets are $20 to $100 for the concert alone, or $200 for the concert and a buffet supper afterward onstage, which will be decorated with antique furniture for the occasion.
* Michael Mims has been promoted to publisher at Connecticut Magazine, Bridgeport. * Carla J. Edwards is joining Coming Attractions magazine as publisher.

DERLAND Moore used to watch the other guys play the postseason games on television. ''Ticked me off, but I watched 'em,'' he said. For 13 seasons, he watched other people cavort in the playoffs, long after the New Orleans Saints had turned in their playbooks for the year. But this year Derland Moore did something about it: He defected. Went over the border. Split. Packed it in. Went home and waited for the phone to ring. ''The percentages were against me,'' Moore said yesterday, after participating in the first postseason game in his honorable 14-year professional career.

With a nucleus of three outstanding players and a bench made up of role players with varying degrees of talent, St. John's has gone through its first eight games without a loss and has even looked formidable in stretches. On Saturday, St. John's overcame a 10-point deficit and defeated defensive-minded Virginia, 64-58, in the first round of the Eastern College Athletic Conference Holiday Festival at Madison Square Garden. Tonight, the Redmen face an even tougher test when they meet Georgia Tech (5-2) in the championship game. The Yellow Jackets, who advanced by defeating Rutgers, 79-61, are nearly a mirror image of St. John's, with speed and size on the wings, talent at one guard spot and adequate play at center.

As Ronald Reagan spends the last days of his troubled year in relative seclusion in Los Angeles and Palm Springs, he and his wife, Nancy, are surrounding themselves with longtime friends. One of these friends, Charles Z. Wick, director of the United States Information Agency, has been especially close to President Reagan in recent days. Mr. Wick spent Christmas Eve and Christmas Day with Mr. Reagan and plans to join the Reagans on New Years Eve in Palm Springs at the estate of Walter Annenberg, the millionaire publisher and friend of the Reagans. ''The President has great resilience, great self-confidence, his mood is certainly not one of being battered,'' said Mr. Wick, a former Hollywood agent and business executive. ''His mood is, 'Let's get the job done and do what's necessary.' ''

The bowl games this New Year's Day may be remembered more for steroids than for any meaningful game. Two all-America players were among a handful of athletes declared ineligible by the National Collegiate Athletic Association for their team's games because they tested positive for anabolic steroids. Brian Bosworth, the flamboyant Oklahoma linebacker, will not play in the Orange Bowl, and Jeff Bregel, the Southern California offensive guard, will miss the Florida Citrus Bowl. It will be one of the very few times in football history that a team won a bowl game and then was voted the national championship without playing that game on New Year's Day. The meaningful game comes Friday night when Miami and Penn State, ranked first and second by the news-agency polls, meet in the Fiesta Bowl.

The communications industry, which once seemed impervious to mergers and takeovers, has been transformed by the same forces that are restructuring the rest of American industry. The changes in the publishing, broadcasting, and cable television businesses have been dramatic. Control of the three major television networks, for instance, has passed to new hands.

Boxing will look back on the 1980's as a decade of sad decline in the heavyweight division. Except for Larry Holmes, and perhaps Michael Spinks - a special case as a very good light heavyweight who stepped up in class for the larger purses - the landscape has been dotted by a procession of mediocre titleholders whose reigns have lasted roughly as long as the fragrance of the cheapest perfume. It has been an era of revolving-door champions, and devotees can only hope that the emergence of Mike Tyson signals its demise.

Jody Dee Katz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Katz of New York, was married at the Burden Mansion in Manhattan yesterday to Giulio Andrea Martini, a son of Giuseppe Sergio Martini of Callicoon, N.Y., and Leila Mori of Florence. Justice Richard W. Wallach of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Manhattan officiated.

The marriage of Susan Marie Phillips, a creative director at the advertising agency of Hicks & Greist, to Anthony J. LoPinto, the vice president and general manager of the New York real-estate division of the First National Bank of Chicago, took place yesterday. The Rev. George La Porte performed the nondenominational service at the Church Center for the United Nations. The bride, a graduate of Northwestern University, where she received a master's degree in journalism, is the daughter of Ruth M. Phillips of Eveleth, Minn., and the late Samuel B. Phillips. Mr. LoPinto, a graduate of Loyola University in Chicago, is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph LoPinto of Garden City, L.I.

Jose Antonio Maravall, a leading Spanish historian, died of heart failure in Madrid on Dec. 19. He was 75 years old. Mr. Maravall specialized in what he called the history of mentalities, and he was credited with changing the study of Spanish and European history by linking the popular and intellectual mentality of a period to its economic, social and political structures.

A former Israeli technician accused of selling Israeli nuclear secrets to a British newspaper pleaded not guilty today to charges of spying and aiding an enemy in wartime, his attorney said. The former technician, Mordechai Vanunu, was taken to Jerusalem District Court at 5 this morning in a curtained van and escorted in with burlap covering his body and a red umbrella held by one of his 10 police guards covering his face. The early hour was apparently chosen in an effort to prevent him from passing any more messages to the press. Last Monday, Mr. Vanunu held up a message written on his hand that suggested he had been abducted by Israeli agents in Italy. He also managed to shout to reporters the word ''Rome!'' Two Italian newspapers said they had confirmed that Mr. Vanunu was registered on British Airways flight 504 from London to Rome on Sept. 30.

Amy Skopp and Rabbi Mark S. Cooper were married yesterday at Temple B'nai Abraham in Livingston, N.J. Rabbi Harold Kushner performed the ceremony assisted by Rabbi Shawn Zell and Cantor Robert Scherr. The bride, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Skopp of Clark, N.J., graduated from the Solomon Schechter Day School of Essex and Union in Cranford, N.J., and with distinction from the Hebrew University in Jerusalem.

John D. MacDonald, the novelist whose best-selling mysteries sold millions of copies, died yesterday at St. Mary's Hospital in Milwaukee of complications from heart surgery. He was 70 years old and lived in Sarasota, Fla. Claire Ferraro, associate publisher at Ballantine/Del Rey and Fawcett, said Mr. MacDonald underwent bypass surgery in September and had been in a coma since Dec. 10 . From a modest beginning in 1946 with the sale of a short story for $25, Mr. MacDonald's writing career blossomed to produce about 70 books. Of those, 21 made up the highly successful Travis McGee series - about the adventures of a tough, cynical, philosophical knight-errant living on a houseboat in Florida.

The Iran arms issue has given the Watergate crowd the status of elder statesmen of scandal. In one of the oddest commercial offshoots of the Iran crisis, G. Gordon Liddy believes there will be increased interest in a board game he is developing for Maruca Industries in New York, the company that markets ''A Question of Scruples.''

The National Security Council may have gotten into trouble for doing everything secretly before, but the new director has promised a more open style. The director, Frank C. Carlucci, provided a preview of this the other night at Germaine's Restaurant when he showed that he was not paranoid about Washington's favorite indoor sport, eavesdropping. In a city where information is power, no place is sacred. But some places - rest rooms, elevators, the Eastern shuttle and Germaine's, a favored spot for Washington journalists - are less sacred than others.
Lighting the City Hall Menorah Mayor Koch lights menorah at City Hall to mark the Hanukkah holiday. 4:45 P.M., City Council chamber, City Hall.

* Boston Edison Co. has elected Stephen J. Sweeney chairman to succeed Thomas J. Galligan Jr., who will retire as chairman but continue as a director. * Crazy Eddie Inc., Edison, N.J., has formed an office of the president, consisting of Mitchell Antar, Sam E. Antar and Isaac Kairey as executive vice presidents and Solomon E. Antar and David V. Panoff as senior vice presidents.

HE'S country, he's cool and except for his senior season in high school, Pat Ryan has always been exactly what he is - a backup quarterback. He played behind Condrege Holloway, Randy Wallace and Jimmy Streeter at the University of Tennessee for three years, and behind Tommy Brantley at Putnam City High in Oklahoma City for two years. After he joined the Jets, he played behind Richard Todd for five years. Pat Ryan is still around, but whatever happened to all those other quarterbacks. For the moment, whatever happened to Ken O'Brien?

To the Editor: Your report of increased military tensions on the Norwegian-Soviet border (news story, Dec. 7) casts a distorted light upon Soviet-Norwegian relations and their prospects, as well as on the situation in northern Europe as a whole. And, of course, the statement that ''the Kremlin is rapidly turning the nearby Kola Peninsula into what Western officials call a huge concentration of Soviet military power'' is absurd. During his recent meeting in Moscow with the Prime Minister of Norway, General Secretary Mikhail S. Gorbachev made it pointedly clear that the Soviet Union has ''no malicious intentions with regard to Norway and that we in the Soviet Union have longstanding friendly feelings toward your people.''
A rookie New York City police officer was suspended yesterday after being charged on Long Island with harassment and resisting arrest after a dispute with his girlfriend, authorities said.

Eamonn Coghlan suffered a broken wrist during a training run Saturday night after two youths set a snarling dog on the track as he tried to break up a fight. The incident happened near the home of the 34-year-old runner, who said he saw the youths harassing a mother and her child. He went across the street to help and one of the youths unleashed the dog.

Many city services continued to improve this year but the Koch administration is doing only a routine or poor job managing some key functions, from cleaning streets to fighting fires, a private study said yesterday. After surveying 16 city services, the Citizens Budget Commission, a nonprofit group supported by the local business commmunity said, ''We could find only two that were well managed.'' Mayor Koch and city officials sharply disputed the conclusions as ''simplistic'' and ''superficial.'' The Mayor also assailed the methods the group used in drawing its conclusions.

The Brooklyn District Attorney's office and the New York City Department of Investigation have opened separate inquiries into how a real-estate development firm in which Michael J. Lazar was a partner obtained an apparently bogus document and used it to get public financing of a $6.8 million Brooklyn apartment building. Spokesmen for both offices said the investigations centered on a New York City certificate of occupancy submitted by Rose Garden Associates to Federal, state and city agencies in 1984. Mr. Lazar and the other principal partner in the firm, Samuel Pompa, in interviews last month, said they had nothing to do with obtaining the document, which authorities have said was fictitious. Mr. Lazar, a former city transportation administrator, is a major real-estate developer in the city. He was one of five men convicted last month on Federal charges of corruption arising out of contract awards in city's Parking Violations Bureau. He is awaiting sentencing.

To the Editor: To underscore your recent editorials concerning babies boarding in hospitals, here are some additional facts: * The number of children in hospitals awaiting foster-care placement has almost doubled since last year. In 1986 thus far, there have been at least 1,000 children who fall into this category in hospitals throughout the city. * The recent increase in the number of these children is due to drug abuse and AIDS-related cases.

A 36-YEAR-OLD patient recently told Dr. JoAnn Magdoff, a Mahattan psychotherapist, that she had decided to marry a man she did not love after reading a study that suggested a college-educated woman who was single at age 30 had only a 20 percent chance of marrying. Another patient, a 45-year-old man, admitted bullying his wife into doing his bidding, using the same study to convince the wife that she would have no chance of finding anyone else if he became dissatisfied and left. These are not isolated incidents. Mental-health professionals say it is no longer unusual for people to base important life decisions or strategies on the findings of generalized studies.

Thai national planners have discovered what most Bangkokians have long suspected: The city's traffic is gradually grinding to a halt. On a good day, cars on thoroughfares cover six to nine miles an hour, when they move at all, according to a report delivered last week to the National Economic and Social Development Board. During rush hours, which can occur at almost any time of day or all day, the average motorist clocks about three miles an hour.

THE COUNTERLIFE. By Philip Roth. 324 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $18.95. NEAR the end of Philip Roth's experimental new novel, ''The Counterlife,'' there occurs a scene that this reader particularly wished he could have felt more directly. In it, the writer Nathan Zuckerman and his English wife, Maria, have just returned home from celebrating her 28th birthday at a London restaurant. During dinner, Nathan is the target of an anti-Semitic outburst from a woman at a neighboring table. Earlier in the evening, at a reception at the end of a Christmas carol service at a church in the West End, Maria's older sister, Sarah, attacks Nathan's Jewishness. She warns him not to ''stand in the way of a christening'' after Maria gives birth to their child. Now, at the end of a nerve-racking day, Nathan begins to press Maria for her real feelings about his Jewishness.

Like a lot of other boys growing up around Lawrenceville, Ill., Doug Novsek had a basketball hoop in his driveway and learned to shoot under the country sky. A 20-footer was a shot he could make stepping out of the kitchen with a bologna sandwich in one hand.

International Thomson Business Press's CES Publishing has bought Convenience Store Merchandiser magazine, having earlier this year acquired four monthly retail magazines from United States Business Press. The latest purchase, from Associates Business Publications, brings the total of CES titles to 12. Stuart J. Horton, president of CES, was quoted as saying he hoped to keep most of the magazine's people, including Wayne Pierce, publisher.

THE competition offers huge stadiums right on their campuses, not far from where the alums spent some of the best times of their youth. Here, the campus stadium is an unrealized dream as old as the institution itself. Traditionally, the members of college football's elite have supplied a background of ivy-covered buildings constructed when our great-grandparents were young. Each time a team from the University of Miami competes, its nickname holds the reminder of a crippling storm. The hurricane struck on Sept. 16, 1926, killing more than 130 people and damaging more than 10,000 homes. On Oct. 15, the new university began classes in the abandoned Anastasia Hotel, with rooms created by cardboard partitions. Eight days later, the school known as the Cardboard College played its first football game, a victory over a freshman team from Rollins College, before a crowd of 304 on a hastily-built field without grass.

The Nomura Securities Company, the world's-largest brokerage house, extended its reach into the United States real estate industry yesterday with the acquisition of a half-interest in Eastdil Realty Inc., the innovative real estate investment banking firm founded by Benjamin V. Lambert. Real estate analysts said the deal, through an affiliate known as Nomura Babcock & Brown Real Estate Inc., was worth more than $50 million to Mr. Lambert and the 15 other stockholders in Eastdil. As part of the agreement, Eastdil will serve as Nomura's real estate investment arm in the United States, as the giant securities dealer joins other Japanese companies in expanding its share of the real estate business here. Earlier this year, in the first step in its expansion strategy, Nomura purchased an interest in Babcock & Brown, a mortgage broker.

Despite widespread efforts by merchants and financial institutions to combat it, credit-card fraud is still a huge, worldwide problem, and a problem that gets worse at Christmas, when stores are jammed and credit card use peaks. ''It's the biggest volume period for us, and the fraud goes up correspondingly,'' said William D. Neumann, a former F.B.I. agent who is now chief of security at Visa. ''The sales clerks are often part-timers, and frauds figure that if they are going to cheat, Christmas is the time to do it.'' Although heightened law enforcement has actually led to a decline in losses from card fraud in percentage terms, to around 15 hundredths of 1 percent of credit-card sales, worldwide fraud losses this year at Mastercard International Inc. and Visa U.S.A. Inc. will still exceed $200 million, experts say. That is up from roughly $125 million in 1982. Fraud losses from counterfeit Visa and Mastercard cards alone, which law-enforcement officials thought they could eliminate through such anti-counterfeiting tools as holograms, will exceed $30 million.

To the Editor: In an editorial ''Topics'' (Dec. 7) about a family traveling through Newark Airport, you suggest that there is no reason that both men's and women's restrooms could not have a changing room for babies -no reason except the assumption that changing diapers is women's work. Thanks to a law suit filed in Federal court, changing diapers is no longer ''women's work'' in Syracuse.

Tens of thousands of university students in China have risked their future careers by demanding democratic freedoms that are guaranteed in the Constitution but denied by China's leaders. Why? Having traveled in China for more than two months last summer and fall, I can testify to the depths of disillusionment with Deng Xiaoping's reforms that motivate such courageous, dedicated behavior. In private talks, whether in the northernmost city of Harbin or southern Guangzhou, coastal Shanghai or interior Wuhan, the alienation felt by men and women in their 20's and 30's was uniformly communicated. Part of the disillusionment began in September 1985 when students, in their first demonstrations in this decade, protested Japanese Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone's homage to Japan's fallen soldiers, including war criminals executed after World War II, at the Yasakuni Shrine in Tokyo. Several hundred demonstrators managed to parade publicly in Beijing, but on most campuses meetings were confined indoors. Anxious officials conciliated student unrest with better food, increased allowances and lengthy discussion of grievances, including Japan's dominant role in China's economic modernization. But the bottom line was clear: no more demonstrations.

The House of Representatives, faced with union organizers, unhappy employees and mounting deficits, is getting out of the restaurant business. Under an arrangement approved by a House Administration subcommittee, a private company, the Service America Corporation, is scheduled Jan. 3 to begin operating the members' dining room, two large cafeterias for the public and House staff and five take-out restaurants. The same 245 employees will continue cooking, serving and cleaning up, but changing to a private contractor will mean, at least for the time being, forfeiting a pay increase and some fringe benefits.

Beginning Sunday, the writers Denis Donoghue, Cynthia Ozick and Marilynne Robinson will join Anatole Broyard in the About Books column of The New York Times Book Review. The column, which has been printed monthly, will now appear weekly.

SEMESTER finals were completed and a cold, gray morning was brightened by the prospect of going home for the holidays. But as their fellow students packed their bags, some assisted by parents playing chauffeur for a day, the Penn State football players prepared for a weekend that would be the equivalent of the first days of fall practice, a time of pure drudgery. As many of them already knew, not all college finals are given in the classroom. Dressed in sweatsuits or jeans, some with wool caps pulled down over their ears, the players wandered sleepy-eyed into the dining hall, beginning at 8:15 A.M., mostly in pairs or groups of three, many not bothering to remove their jackets or hats. They sat like zombies over plates of bacon and scrambled eggs, tater tots and cold cereal - a football player's breakfast of champions - eating from habit.

To the Editor: Congratulations to North High School of Great Neck, L.I., for joining the ranks of non-class-ranking schools (news story, Dec. 16)! And fie on Joseph J. Biscoglio, who voted against it at Bronxville High - and he a guidance director! You have to be evaluated compared with others in life, he says.

John E. Olson: Chairman American Telephone and Telegraph Company ''We will make the tough decisions necessary to insure that we are in the best position to thrive in the years ahead.'' Laurence A. Tisch: Acting Chief Executive Officer, CBS Inc. ''This is no takeover,'' Mr. Tisch told reporters on the evening of Sept. 10, when the board of directors named him acting chief executive officer of CBS, succeeding Thomas H. Wyman.

When Jenny leaves for work as a bar hostess in the evenings, her live-in boyfriend, an American sailor, sometimes calls after her jokingly, ''Don't catch AIDS, now.'' Jenny, a small and delicate woman of 18 whose mother was a prostitute and whose father was an American serviceman, says she calls back, ''I hope not.'' In fact, although her boyfriend does not know and she herself seems to be confused about it, Jenny is already infected with the AIDS virus. Based on her account, it seems probable that she was infected by one of the many American servicemen with whom she has had sexual contact since she came to work two years ago in the garish bars that cluster around Subic Bay Naval Station.

In lackluster trading the last few weeks, credit market participants have appeared content to accept the standard forecast: a weakening of the economy in the first quarter, accompanied by an easier monetary policy and lower interest rates. The complacent attitude has left Treasury bond yields little changed in the last several weeks, and still in the middle portion of the range that has prevailed since April. The newest 30-year issue, the 7 1/2 percent bonds due in 2016, were offered Friday at 102 2/ 32, to yield 7.33 percent. ''Clearly this is a market with a bullish bias,'' analysts at Griggs & Santow noted in their latest newsletter. They noted that the bond market seems to have overlooked certain devolpments, such as stronger-than-expected economic data and higher short-term interest rates.

Pat Cash staged the comeback of his life today to give Australia its 26th Davis Cup triumph. Cash, who recovered from a back injury and an appendectomy in 1986 to improve his world ranking from 418th to 24th, beat Mikael Pernfors, 2-6, 4-6, 6-3, 6-4, 6-3, to clinch the victory for Australia over Sweden, which had won the trophy the last two years. ''This is a fantastic feeling,'' the 21-year-old Cash said. ''In a way, this is my greatest moment in tennis.''

Three Trenton State Prison inmates escaped from their cell by chiseling through the ceiling but were recaptured yesterday when an alert correction officer spotted them in the prison yard, a correction department spokesman said. The inmates used a makeshift rope to lower themselves 25 feet from the roof of their cellblock, the spokesman, James Stabile, said.
Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

When David H. Komansky switched from the securities side to the real estate side of Merrill Lynch & Company some 15 months ago ''it was the beginning of an adventure,'' he said. The adventure is continuing, with plans announced by Merrill Lynch last week to convert its real estate operation into a master limited partnership, retaining control but selling units to the public. Mr. Komansky, who is president of Merrill Lynch Realty, will be head of a Merrill Lynch subsidiary to be created to act as general partner under the plan.

PHYLLIS LAMHUT'S dances once tended to be witty, solidly crafted little gems. With ''Passing,'' created in 1980, her pieces took on a look of grandeur and became larger and more spectacular. And her current work refers increasingly to the expressionism that is the modern-dance heritage of Ms. Lamhut, long a dancer with Alwin Nikolais, who himself claims the lineage of Mary Wigman, the German Expressionist modern-dance choreographer. ''Klein Kunst'' (''Small Art''), a full-evening work performed on Saturday at Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater, seems at first to belong unequivocally to Ms. Lamhut's recent body of clearly expressionistic dance. But the piece also recalls her earlier, thematically slighter dances.

Big business in America is overhauling itself and its operations faster than at any time since World War II. Corporations are shucking unrelated product lines, marrying or buying up competitors and rejiggering their finances in hopes of restoring growth and prosperity. These wrenching changes promise higher short-term profits to shareholders, but have loaded many companies with unprecedented levels of debt, raising widespread concern about the companies' ability to weather any recessions that may lie ahead. Billions Change Hands This year, the rush to streamline and to concentrate energies on more narrowly defined lines of business has fueled a record of more than $150 billion in mergers and acquisitions that transferred corporate assets from one set of hands to another. In addition, according to the investment banking firm of Salomon Brothers Inc., in the first 11 months of 1986 some 233 companies bought back, or announced plans to buy back, an estimated $36 billion of their own stock, making themselves less vulnerable to takeovers.

THE deteriorating state of large segments of the nation's infrastructure, particularly in the Northeast and Middle West, is due to get heightened attention from the next Congress. The price tag for rectifying the problem, according to a number of studies, could be several hundred billion dollars and require the kind of public and private sector partnerships that have become increasingly attractive to the Federal Government, albeit on a selective basis.

The Reagan Administration is expected to remove most controls before the end of January on exports of oil and gas equipment and technology to the Soviet Union, Administration trade officials said this weekend. The move would be a response both to the depressed conditions of the American industry and the reluctance of United States allies to impose similar export restraints. The industry and its supporters contend that European and Japanese suppliers have picked up business that might have otherwise gone to American exporters. Share Less Than 2 Percent The American share of total Western exports of such equipment has fallen from 25 percent before the ban eight years ago to less than 2 percent today, according to figures from the Petroleum Equipment Suppliers Association.

DUMB fun, bad attitudes and rude noise are vital to rock-and-roll, and as the music absorbs one shock tactic, along comes another. Right now, there's a new kind of rude rock in the making. It mixes two styles that grate on parents and appeal directly to teen-agers: rap and heavy metal. Run-D. M. C. pioneered rap-metal music with ''Rock Box''; the Beastie Boys, abetted by Run-D. M. C.'s producer, Rick Rubin, have made rap-metal music a vehicle for teen-agers' jokey, antisocial fantasies. On their album, ''Licensed to Ill,'' the three Beastie Boys - King Ad-Rock (Adam Horovitz), Mike D (Michael Diamond) and the hoarse-voiced MCA (Adam Yauch) - are loudmouthed brats backed by loud guitars and a lean rhythm-box beat.

A thick blanket of fog descended on Hartsfield International Airport today, grounding all flights out of the busy air hub and leading to delayed flights all over the nation. ''The weather went down about 7 this morning and was pretty bad,'' said Jack Barker, a spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration.

A few years before he received the 1934 Nobel Prize in Literature, the Sicilian playwright Luigi Pirandello, one of the 20th century's great innovators in the theater, wrote another letter to Marta Abba, a leading Italian stage and screen actress, who inspired several of his plays. ''I write with my mind's eye fixed on you,'' he wrote. ''Should your divine inspiring image abandon me for an instant, I would not be able to move ahead with one single word. Without realizing it, from far away, maybe not even thinking at all about me, consumed by other thoughts, by other preoccupations, you are doing the work for me. You, with all the power of your art, the tones of your inimitable voice, with the splendor of your eyes, which find the expression for each passion.

Many New York corporations are matching gifts made by their employees to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. Among those companies are the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, Chemical Bank, Reader's Digest, Newsweek magazine and Avon Products. Gifts that are to be matched by companies came from Laura Shapiro of Manhattan, $300; Lynn and Arthur Boulanger of Flushing, Queens, $50; Mary L. Ciecierski of Manhattan, $25; Alison M. Martier of Manhattan, $50; Tonya and Robert Stallworth of Brooklyn, $300; Deborah and Leonard B. Gordon of Manhattan, $250, and John E. Long of Manhattan, $500.

For three years, people here have known their community was going to be the home of the nation's MX missile system. So when Pentagon officials announced last week that the first 10 MX missiles had been installed in underground silos and were ready for launching if needed, many Cheyenne residents paid little attention. ''It hasn't made the slightest difference in my life style,'' said G. John Veta, president of Western Ranchman Outfitters, a downtown clothing store. ''Why the tremendous to-do about the MX? We've had Minuteman 3 missiles here for years.''

''Hello,'' starts one note penned by a 15-year-old schoolgirl. ''Elephant fails and cannot stand up. Dele Giwa, good-bye.'' Another, typed by a college student, contains an ode to ''Giwa, the Honest and Patriotic Son of the African soil.'' Mourning a man they never met, these letter writers are two of thousands of Nigerians who recently have flooded the offices of Newswatch, Nigeria's largest news magazine.

AN impish-eyed lug of a man who totes a suitcase full of props onto the stage, the 28-year-old Long Island-based comedian Bob Nelson has a special knack for spoofing athletes whose dumbness is exceeded only by their hulking arrogance. In this vein, Mr. Nelson, who is appearing at Caroline's, 332 Eighth Avenue, at 26th Street, through tomorrow, has perfected a routine that may become a comedy classic, as he portrays a football player doing a live television commercial for the United Way at halftime.
