The New York String Orchestra, an ensemble of 60 musicians from 15 to 22 years old from schools across the country, will play Vivaldi's Concerto in C minor for Violin and String Orchestra (''Il Sospetto'') under the direction of Alexander Schneider in a concert at Carnegie Hall tonight at 8.

He coached in the big-time spotlight for so long, and so enjoyed the attention heaped not only on his teams but also on his notable wisecracking, that the thought of his prospering in a low-profile milieu would once have seemed incongruous. But life in the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics has been kind to Abe Lemons, whose Oklahoma City University squad has a 13-0 record this season and a No. 1 N.A.I.A. national ranking. During three decades in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division I, spanning an earlier tenure at Oklahoma City as well as stays at Pan American and Texas, Lemons never quite made it to the national championship. In his first stint at Oklahoma City, he did take the Chiefs to six N.C.A.A. tourneys and five National Invitation Tournaments from 1956 to 1973, but by the time he returned there in 1983 (having been dismissed by Texas a year earlier), the program was in shambles. The Midwestern Cities Conference's minimum-seating regulation forced the Chiefs, whose gym can accommodate only 3,600, to play their games in a large arena off campus, and the rent was such that they were losing money whether they traveled or stayed home.

Hours before the Aeroflot daily flight was scheduled to depart from Kennedy International Airport to Moscow, Taras Kordonsky sat in the terminal eating and repeatedly looking at his Swiss watch. He had come to the United States from the Soviet Union eight years ago ''to discover the western world.'' Now he was part of a group of five dozen Russians preparing to start the 14-hour journey home, the largest group of Russian emigres ever to return to the Soviet Union from this country.
What is the name of the country's largest agency specializing in marine goods? You were wrong if you said Wolff Whitehill Advertising, but only by a few days.

THE nation's work force is expected to grow only moderately in 1987, but some industries are likely to show significant employment gains, labor analysts say. Richard Belous, labor economist for the Conference Board, a business research organization, said the economy was strong enough to generate two million jobs in 1987, about equal to the growth in the labor force. He added that unemployment would continue at around 7 percent, or eight million people. Manpower Inc., a nationwide firm that deals in temporary services, took a survey of 13,000 employers and said it was not very sanguine about the job outlook. Mitchell S. Fromstein, Manpower's president, noted ''a weak but relatively stable hiring pattern for the first quarter.'' Regional differences are apparent, he said, citing the ''Northeast corridor as clearly having a better outlook than the country as a whole.''

Libyan troops seized control of a strategic oasis in northern Chad today after more than two weeks of heavy fighting against Chadian forces, French officials said. According to the Chadian Government, the town that was reported overrun, Zouar, is one of three crucial points in Libya's plan to regain control of the northern Tibesti region. The other points are said to be the towns of Bardai, north of Zouar, and Wour, in the west.

The Eastman Kodak Company said it would raise prices on most of its consumer and professional photo products, including all Kodacolor film formats, effective Jan. 24. A Kodak spokesman, Henry K. Kaska, said the increases would range from 3 percent to 6 percent. Prices on photographic paper will increase, Kodak said, but photofinishing charges and videotape prices will remain the same.

''LA BAYADERE,'' one of the classics of the 19th-century Russian ballet repertory, can be seen tonight at 10 o'clock on the Bravo cable network in a fine performance by the Kirov Ballet of Leningrad, the company for which it was originally choreographed by Marius Petipa in 1877. Back then, the Kirov was known as the Maryinsky Ballet, and Leningrad was St. Petersburg. Yet, though times have changed, ''La Bayadere'' remains a splendid example of a form of choreography popular a century ago.

The Pacific Realty Corporation, which earlier this year was rebuffed in a bid for the U.S. Home Corporation, said today that it had formed a joint venture with Trafalgar Holdings Ltd. aimed at increasing its stake in U.S. Home. Pacific, a closely held company based in Dallas, said the new venture intends to buy a significant amount of U.S. Home stock to obtain board representation and influence the management of the company, one of the nation's largest home builders. A U.S. Home spokesman said the company, which had received a copy of the details of the agreement, had not been contacted by either party.

Bradley O'Leary, a devout Republican, and Victor Kamber, a staunch Democrat, are publishers of the Washington-based political dope sheet called the O'Leary/Kamber Report. They admit they don't agree on much of anything, at least as far as politics is concerned.
On the day last week when indoor soccer's New York Express sent Coach Ray Klivecka packing after an 0-10 start, Rick Davis's mind drifted back to similarly frustrating yet happier times.

Speaking softly and slowly, apparently still nursing his wounded pride after the latest setback in his plan to become President, Leonel Brizola was hardly recognizable as the Socialist firebrand who for a quarter of a century has been the politician most feared by Brazil's ruling elites. Twice this year he gambled his prestige and twice he lost. First he attacked a Government-ordered price freeze that proved to be enormously popular. And then, last month, he converted the election to pick his successor as Governor of Rio de Janeiro into a referendum on President Jose Sarney - and his handpicked candidate was trounced.

Treasury bill rates climbed and bond prices plunged yesterday in a somewhat unsettled and thin money market. Some dealers attributed the selling mainly to a fumbled effort by the Federal Reserve to inject liquidity into the banking system. Others cited the decline in the dollar and the rise in oil prices, along with various other factors. Whatever touched off the decline, the bellwether long bond, the 7.5 percent issue due in 2016, traded late in the day at an offered price of 100 26/ 32, down 1 7/32, and now yields 7.43 percent, compared with 7.36 percent at last Friday's close.

Tom Blackaller's USA was beaten again today in the America's Cup challengers' semifinals, losing to Dennis Conner's Stars & Stripes by 3 minutes 2 seconds. Conner's winning margin was far greater than that on Sunday, when he beat Blackaller by only 10 seconds. It appears that Stars & Stripes may have picked up a speed advantage when new wings were attached to her keel after the end of the round-robin racing earlier this month. The opposite may be true for French Kiss, a boat that was outfitted with a new keel and had 30 inches trimmed from her stern. She lost to New Zealand today by 2:40 after being defeated the previous day by 2:46. Winds were moderate today, at 15 to 19 knots.

The Weill Recital Hall, the space east of the main auditorium at Carnegie Hall formerly known as Carnegie Recital Hall, will open next Monday at 12:30 P.M. with a song recital by the baritone William Parker and the pianist William Huckaby. The program is the first in an expanded schedule of Carnegie-sponsored concerts in the smaller space, which will continue as well in its long-established role as a rental hall for debut artists and other visitors. For the opening week, concerts have been scheduled at a density of three a day, a circumstance that ordinarily arises only on heavy debut weekends. After Mr. Parker's recital of American music, Toby Hoffman and Liba Shacht - two string players associated with Affiliate Artists - will give an ''informance'' at 3 P.M., with music by Bach, Handel, Mozart and Paganini. ''Informance'' means an informal performance with conversation and questions.

Entries for the 111th annual show of the Westminster Kennel Club at Madison Square Garden on Feb. 9 and 10 have closed with 2,640 dogs representing 139 breeds or varieties. It was the earliest closing in more than a decade. Poodles lead with 130 dogs, followed by golden retrievers with 86, Rottweilers with 68, Akitas with 60 and dachshunds with 57.

Japan crossed a politically critical threshold today, abandoning a 10-year-old policy that had limited military spending to 1 percent of the gross national product. Government leaders agred in a late night meeting to a 1987 military budget of $22 billion, equivalent to 1.004 percent of the projected G.N.P. Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone's Cabinet is expected to ratify the agreement. The National Security Council was scheduled to discuss a possible new definition for restraining military outlays. The decision, which had been encouraged by Mr. Nakasone, was welcomed by the United States and was attacked by opposition parties as potentially dangerous. The opposition, led by the Socialist Party, has long said that the 1 percent ceiling keeps Japan from ever again becoming a military power.

A survey of city government officials made public today found that more than a third of those polled believed they could not maintain current services without raising taxes. Thirty-six percent of officials surveyed in 396 cities and towns by the National League of Cities said that without higher taxes, they could not maintain services in the coming year. Fewer than half, 47 percent, said they would be able to maintain existing services at current tax levels.
Flights Delayed Nationwide Heavy fog at Atlanta's busy airport disrupted nationwide flights and delayed thousands of travelers for the second consecutive day.

Authorities in the Punjab moved today to minimize the effects of a two-day general strike by Sikh militants, rounding up more than 500 people for what was termed preventive detention. Nonetheless, the first day of the largely peaceful strike forced the closing of businesses and offices around the northern state and crippled road and rail traffic.

Workers at the Hanford nuclear reservation today investigated a device believed to have caused a malfunction that triggered an automatic shutdown of the trouble-plagued N reactor, a spokesman said. The aging reactor is scheduled to be shut down for six months Jan. 7 for $50 million in safety modifications recommended by a six-member independent panel. The N reactor, the only United States facility similar in design to the Soviet Union's crippled Chernobyl reactor, was shut down Sunday night when a water-flow monitor gave a false reading, said Rudy Cortez, a spokesman for UNC Nuclear Industries.

Fifty emigres, disappointed with their attempts to build new lives in the United States, returned to the Soviet Union today to a warm official reception. Soviet officials said it was the largest group to be repatriated under the new policy of the Gorbachev administration to allow emigres to return. On arrival by an Aeroflot flight from New York, the returnees, some of them Jews, said at Sheremyetevo Airport that they had been driven back by the stress of urban life in the United States and by the difficulty of fitting into American society. Some mentioned street crime, social ostracism or the lack of guaranteed jobs as factors. Others spoke more fondly of their lives in the United States, but said they had begun to miss the Soviet Union and their relatives.

New Year's Eve revelers who drink too much in northern New Jersey bars can ride home in a taxi at a brewing company's expense. On Long Island, some people will toast 1987 with ''mocktails,'' concoctions that look like mixed drinks but contain no alcohol. Later they will wait for a Gus Bus. And in some communities in upstate New York, inebriated residents will be sent home in limousines hired with fines collected from motorists convicted of driving while intoxicated.

Pennsylvania Turnpike officials were restocking toll booths across the state today with new tickets that reflect a 30 percent fare increase, the first increase in eight years. The action will raise toll charges from an estimated 2.4 cents per mile to 3.1 cents, and increase minimum charges between interchanges, now 30 cents, by a dime.

Wall Street yesterday recorded its sharpest drop in nearly six weeks as trading volume remained unusually low. Both big and small investors, with the end of 1986 just ahead, seemed uninterested in buying any more stock. Some, worried about the expensive impact of tax law changes that go into effect on Thursday, appeared to be unloading stocks to take capital gains this year. The Dow Jones industrial average, which had risen last week almost solely on a 12-point rise in Merck & Company, one of its 30 components, retreated 18.28 points yesterday, to 1,912.12. Merck, on profit taking, fell 4, to 125.

Patrick Ewing was rewarded for his role in the Knicks' recent resurgence yesterday when he was named the National Basketball Association's Player of the Week. In leading the Knicks to victories over the Spurs, Bulls and Bucks for their first three-game winning streak in more than a year, Ewing averaged 26.3 points, 13.3 rebounds and 2.0 blocked shots.

A State Supreme Court justice yesterday approved a new housing development that would raise Roosevelt Island's population by about 45 percent. Justice George Bundy Smith dismissed an attempt by the Roosevelt Island Residents Association to stop the proposed five-building complex, scheduled for completion in 1991.

FALSE PROPHETS. By Alexander Kohn. Illustrated. 226 pages. Basil Blackwell. $24.95. AMONG the many scientists and doctors whose names adorn the pages of ''False Prophets,'' I have found myself haunted by three in particular: Johnson S. Caulder, Ph.D., Lawrence D. Bergmann, M.D., and Myron C. Filstein, M.D. All three are thanked at the end of a paper published in the New England Journal of Medicine in 1981 - Caulder ''for performing the amino acid analyses,'' Bergmann ''for obtaining the heart tissue during pacemaker placement,'' Filstein ''for referring several family members'' - and they sound a solid enough trio. The only trouble is that none of them actually exist; they were being invoked to prop up a series of findings which were themselves in all probability fictitious.

Several American Jewish spokesmen said yesterday that even at this late date, John Cardinal O'Connor should cancel a trip to Israel rather than risk snubbing Israeli leaders by refusing to meet with them officially in Jerusalem. It was the third day in a row that American Jewish groups criticized the agenda for the trip, which was changed at the insistence of the Vatican so it would not appear to be formally recognizing Jerusalem as Israel's capital. The Cardinal, who is Archbishop of New York, is in Jordan and plans to go to Israel on Thursday.

A LONGSTANDING puzzle in evolution has been the global distribution of large, flightless birds, as well as their small cousin, the New Zealand kiwi. The ostriches of Africa, cassowaries and emus of Australia, and rheas of South America are native to habitats that have been isolated from one another for millions of years.

Leeman Bennett, who won only four games in two years as coach of the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, was dismissed yesterday by the National Football League team. Hugh Culverhouse, the owner of the Buccaneers, told a packed news conference in Tampa that he had struggled over the decision to dismiss Bennett for two weeks and made up his mind shortly before the announcement.

Harold Macmillan, who as Prime Minister from 1957 to 1963 helped Britain to adapt to its changing role in the world and its reduced military, economic and diplomatic power, died yesterday after a short illness. He was 92 years old. A statement issued by his family last night in London said Mr. Macmillan had died peacefully at his home, Birch Grove, in Sussex. He had been in poor health for some time, after a bout with pneumonia. A cool, adaptable Conservative leader, Mr. Macmillan, a book-publishing heir who was educated at Eton and Oxford, was philosophical about the need for change.

The Department of Transportation's proposal to allow more flexibility in its air bag rule for cars may spur more widespread use of passenger safety devices by automobile makers but it could also damage efforts to get states to adopt mandatory seat belt use laws, some safety groups and advocates fear. Federal officials disagree with the fears on seat belt laws. The agency is considering scaling back its requirement that automobile makers install automatic restraints for both front seats by the model year 1990. Under its new proposal, the agency would allow a manual belt on the passenger side until about 1994, if an auto maker installed an automatic air bag on the drivers' side only, In response to the proposed air bag change, the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation announced this month that they would collectively install close to 2 million air bags by model year 1990 if the rule change was ultimately adopted.

The man accused of killing Mayor Edward King and wounding two City Council members earlier this month over a dispute about a backed-up sewer pleaded not guilty today. The accused, Ralph O. Davis, filed his plea by mail in Henry County District Court, said County Attorney Michael Riepe. Mr. Davis waived his right to a trial within 90 days, and no trial date was set.

Among the many difficulties of life in Poland in recent years has been a shortage of hard currency for the purchase of medical texts and journals for the country's 10 medical and dental schools, according to Friends of Poland Inc., a nonprofit group based in New Bedford, Mass. Some medical texts retail for $100 or more each.

First Nationwide Bank, a subsidiary of the Ford Motor Company, said today that it had acquired the Lincoln Federal Savings and Loan Association of Louisville, Ky. With the acquisition, First Nationwide, which is based in San Francisco, received the rights to expand into Virginia and Maryland through a bidding process conducted by the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation.

The Defense Department today asked Congress for funds to speed research on an immense new space vehicle that the Pentagon says will be needed to lift heavy objects into orbit for the ''Star Wars'' missile defense program. The new program, on which $110 million would be spent for research in the next several months, was introduced as part of a request for $2.8 billion beyond what Congress provided for the military in the current fiscal year. Major new programs are rarely begun through such a supplemental budget request, and some budget analysts said that in the current political and fiscal climate the new funds might be denied. Extra $500 Million for 'Star Wars' The project to develop space-oriented defenses against nuclear missiles, formally called the Strategic Defense Initiative, would account for $500 million of the additional budget request. The request is designed to restore some funds that were cut by Congress when it passed a $289.2 billion military spending bill for the fiscal year 1987, which began Oct. 1.

Andrei Tarkovsky, the Russian director who won acclaim in the West for films that were criticized and banned in his homeland, died of lung cancer yesterday in Paris. He was 54 years old. Mr. Tarkovsky and his wife, Larisa, had made their home in Western Europe since July 1984, when, during the shooting in Italy of a film about a man's detachment from his own country, he resolved not to return to the Soviet Union. He said at the time that ''the Soviet authorities left me no other choice.'' Noting that he had been allowed to make only six films in nearly a quarter of a century, he concluded that the Soviet authorities considered him ''a dead soul, a zero.''

Antiquated collection methods, legal challenges and uncooperative court officials make it unlikely that Chicago will ever see most of the $250 million it is owed in delinquent fines and fees, officials say. City Comptroller Ronald D. Picur said Sunday that officials of the Cook County Circuit Court were not cooperating with the city in its efforts to collect parking fines and penalties.

* Cigna Investments, Bloomfield, Conn., a subsidiary of Cigna Corp., appointed Neil Kelleher senior vice president and senior portfolio manager in its Common Stock division. * Coeur D'Alene Mines Corp., Coeur D'Alene, Idaho, named Dennis E. Wheeler, president and chief administrative officer, to the additional post of chief executive, replacing Justin L. Rice, who continues as chairman.

The Pittsburgh Pirates announced that two catchers, Junior Ortiz and Tom Prince, and a pitcher, Barry Jones, have signed contracts for the 1987 season. . . . The San Diego Chargers announced that John Sanders, the general manager, would be re-assigned and that his assistant, Paul Younger, would be dismissed this week. . . . Ralph Miller, the basketball coach at Oregon State, was hospitalized for observation Sunday night in Portland after suffering dizzy spells before his team's game in the Far West Classic.

To the Editor: First, thank you for your editorial praise, on Dec. 12, of the Senate Republican plan for preventing a $2.4 billion windfall in New York State taxes as a result of Federal tax reform and reducing taxes by an additional $2.1 billion on a phased-in timetable. The $4.5 billion plan, which you described as ''elegantly simple,'' is the result of months of painstaking craftsmanship by State Senators John J. Marchi and Roy M. Goodman and their professional staffs, and it is most gratifying that the work is appreciated. However, I regret very much that you went on to say that the Legislature should now adopt Governor Cuomo's proposal, which he said was intended to return all of the windfall to the taxpayers. But it doesn't even do that - it would return only $1.7 billion of the windfall while retaining the rest for some as yet unexplained purpose.

Police removing members of the Atlantic Life Community from an entrance to the Pentagon. The group is opposed to United States nuclear policy, including Trident submarines, MX missiles and nuclear testing. At left is Philip Berrigan, the former priest and Vietnam War protester. (AP)

President Reagan applauding Richard Rutan and Jeana Yeager, pilots of the ultralight plane Voyager, after presenting them with Presidential Citizen's Medals at a ceremony in Los Angeles yesterday. Mr. Rutan's brother Burt, the craft's designer, was also presented with a medal. The first nonstop, unrefueled flight around the world was completed by the Voyager last week. The medal recognizes citizens ''who have performed exemplary deeds of service for their country or their fellow citizens,'' the White House said. (AP)

The grisly racial attack on three black men in Howard Beach inflamed race relations in New York City. The temperature shot up yesterday when a judge dismissed murder, manslaughter and assault charges against the three defendants, leaving only charges of reckless endangerment. To call what happened in Howard Beach reckless endangerment would mock justice, yet this reduction is not the work of a racist judicial system. It results from the refusal of two key witnesses, the surviving black victims of a white mob, to cooperate with the police and prosecutors. They and their attorney now must bear a heavy share of responsibility for the reverberating tensions.

The Colombian Defense Ministry says it has found no evidence to support an American official's assertion that Patricia Lara, a reporter for a leading newspaper in Bogota, has any links to the guerrilla group M-19 or has ever acted as an agent of Cuba. In October, United States immigration authorities barred Miss Lara from entering the country but gave no reason. Her visa, which was issued in Paris in 1985, was revoked and she was held in detention for five days, then deported to Colombia. A month later, the Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, Elliott Abrams, publicly accused Miss Lara of being ''a member of the M-19 terrorist organization in Colombia'' and of being ''an active liaison between that terrorist organization, which is in the business of murdering people, and the Cuban secret police.'' He added that Miss Lara had ''been a member of some of the sort of ruling committees'' of the M-19.

COPYRIGHT battles in the computer business are not new. In Hong Kong, for example, shadowy companies have been making copies of well-known American computers and peripherals for years and selling them to unsuspecting - and sometimes suspecting - customers at a substantial discount. Kevin Jenkins, president of Hercules Inc., the graphics-board maker, said he has seen his boards copied so meticulously that they even included the Hercules trademark. Computer companies have not been shy about suing these foreign counterfeiters.

A helicopter with 17 people aboard crashed off the western Australian coast today as it carried workers from an offshore oil rig, and two passengers were missing. An official of Woodside Offshore Petroleum Ltd. said the French-built Puma helicopter went down seven miles from the Karratha airstrip, 800 miles north of Perth, as it returned from the North Rankin oil rig. Rescue boats picked up the two-member crew and 13 passengers.

Thousands of real estate lawyers, sales agents and accountants are working around the clock to close deals before the big apple descends in Times Square, ringing in the new year and tolling goodbye to the advantageous income tax provisions that have helped make real estate a favored investment for many. James L. Mooney, managing director of Landauer Associates Inc., a real estate consulting company, has been drawing up the last documents on 10 deals of $25 million or more. ''I knew I was falling behind when the Christmas cards began arriving from our Japanese clients,'' Mr. Mooney said. ''It's not even a holiday for them, but they managed to get the cards out on time. Mine will be dated Jan. 2.''

To the Editor: I was disappointed to see the Dec. 8 report of National Cancer Institute conclusions on the upswing of breast-cancer deaths in younger women. It is also disturbing that breast-cancer mortality figures have not changed much for the last half-century. If these statistics are true, then it further emphasizes the need for the use of reliable screening methods, such as mammographic screening, proper breast self-examination and correct physical examination.

SOFTWARE marketing has attained the stage reached by old cars in '58. Not only are the packaging and the advertising full of fins and flash, but there's an option available for virtually everything and everyone except lefties. As with the cars, however, many of the options in software serve little purpose and are rarely utilized. This lack of real function explains why those once touted integrated packages encompassing everything but the kitchen sink did not sweep the world of personal computing as expected. Consider spreadsheets, for instance. Most spreadsheet users spend the majority of their time massaging numbers. On the whole, their need for a communications package or a database manager is not great. When they do require a different program, chances are that they will simply transfer any data it demands from the spreadsheet to whatever software they normally use for that other purpose.

The Reagan Administration announced today that it would propose legislation allowing local school districts to provide parents with federally financed vouchers to pay for remedial education classes of their choice. The proposal was submitted as part of overall legislation to reshape the Federal remedial education program, which is meant primarily to serve poor children. Education Department officials said the plan was a significantly scaled-back version of the Administration's two earlier unsuccessful efforts to introduce parental choice into the $3.9 billion program, which is the department's largest. Under the final version of the Administration's bill, localities could choose to offer vouchers, or ''compensatory education certificates,'' if they believe this method would best serve the needs of educationally deprived children. But states could mandate a voucher plan in school districts whose remedial programs are found to be ineffective.

Gen. John Chain, head of the Strategic Air Command, stirs a passionate controversy with his proposal to base MX missiles on rail cars instead of in silos. His plan goes to the heart of a long-disputed issue - how to protect America's silo-based missiles from increasingly accurate Soviet missiles. Are mobile missiles the best way? No, says a group of Pentagon experts. Their solution is to stick with missiles in silos and add antimissile defenses. This plan would convert the Strategic Defense Initiative from Mr. Reagan's dubious goal of protecting the whole country to the easier task of defending missile fields.

Dr. George Charles Escher, a leading researcher on advanced breast cancer, died of a brain tumor yesterday at Montefiore Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y. At the time of his death, Dr. Escher was the director of the United Hospice in Port Chester, which he helped found as its cancer specialist in 1979.

The parsonage where the Bronte sisters were born is up for sale and is likely to be converted into apartments, a realtor has said. The house was built in 1802 in Thornton, a suburb of the Yorkshire industrial city of Bradford.

As prizes go, this one was a doozy: The Chicago Bears. In Chicago. In January. Such is the bittersweet reward of making the playoffs as a wild-card team and winning the game to advance to the divisional round of the Super Bowl tournament, as the Redskins did Sunday with a 19-7 victory over the Los Angeles Rams.

Gas leaking from a ruptured line of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company forced the closing of the Bayonne Bridge for a little more than an hour today. No injuries were reported. A spokesman for the Port Authouity of New York and New Jersey, Joseph Lanciotti, said a construction crew working on Route 169 in Bayonne cracked the gas line near Avenue A and Fifth Street at 11:37 A.M. The bridge links Bayonne and Staten Island.

The Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company estimated today that the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation would lose $1.6 billion on the troubled loans that Continental turned over to it as part of the Federal plan to rescue the bank. The loss estimate is $340 million more than the estimate made a year ago. The latest estimate, while quite provisional, indicates that the F.D.I.C. - and the Federal Government - will suffer a larger loss than originally expected in bailing out Continental, which was the nation's sixth-largest bank before it nearly collapsed in 1984. Effect on Original Shares Today's announcement also increases the chances that the value of Continental's original shares will be wiped out under a provision of the rescue plan that takes effect if the F.D.I.C. loses more than $800 million on the loan portfolio as of September 1989.

Hunters here used to shoot bald eagles for a $2-a-head bounty, and there was anger four years ago when the state carved an eagle sanctuary out of logging and mining land. But today, with the timber mills closed and the mining industry marginal, the town is looking on the birds more favorably. ''When the mills started going down, we started casting around looking for things to help the economy, and the eagles are it,'' says Dianne Halliwill, the local chapter president of the town's new entrepreneurial hope: the American Bald Eagle Foundation. Civic leaders dreamed it up five years ago with a plan to raise $2 million for research in the mountain-rimmed ''valley of the eagles,'' where 1,800 people share the Chilkat River banks with an annual congregation of up to 4,000 bald eagles.

THE Neubert Ballet Company and the Children's Ballet Theater, two groups of young dancers under the direction of Christine Neubert, joined forces Sunday afternoon at Ms. Neubert's newly renovated Studio Theater in Carnegie Hall. Consisting of short, lighthearted works, their program resembled a box of choreographic sweets for the holidays.

'LES MISERABLES,' VINTAGE '25 In 1862 ''Les Miserables,'' Victor Hugo's epic novel of poverty and pursuit, appeared, and it has never failed to attract interest since then. At the moment, the story is being performed as a hit musical in London and will open in New York in March. Between its first publication and its appearance as a hit musical, ''Les Miserables'' has appeared as theatrical production and, several times, as film. Today New Yorkers have a rare opportunity to see a vintage ''Les Miserables'' movie, at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street, as part of the museum's homage to the Cinematheque Francaise. The film was made by France's Henri Fescourt in 1925 and is about six hours long. At the museum, Part I will be screened at 3 P.M., Part II at 7 P.M. It is a silent film and will be shown without a musical sound track.

ONE interesting thing about ''The Fourth Annual Report of the Secretaries of State'' is the date it was taped: Nov. 21, 1986. The attempt to divert funds to the Nicaraguan rebels had not yet been disclosed, although the Iran arms shipments had provoked a furor. The four former secretaries on the program, however, scarcely refer to Iran. They are on to broader, and sometimes more personal, issues.

The American premiere engagement of the London hit musical ''Les Miserables'' became a bit rocky Sunday, when a $200,000 rotating stage at the Kennedy Center Opera House malfunctioned 30 minutes into the afternoon performance, forcing its cancellation and that of the evening show. The about 4,600 ticket-holders were sent home with promises of refunds or ticket exchanges, although the eight-week pre-Broadway engagement is almost sold out. Kennedy Center officials estimated Sunday's losses at $60,000.
BASKETBALL KNICKS VS. WASHINGTON BULLETS, at Madison Square Garden, 7:30 P.M. (TV - MSG, 7 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 7:20 P.M.) DETROIT PISTONS VS.

John Cardinal O'Connor, Archbishop of New York, with youngsters as he toured the Baqaa center near Amman, Jordan. American Jewish groups called for the Cardinal to cancel visit to Israel to avoid snubbing leaders whom he would not meet officially. Page A2. (AP)

One recent morning Sheldon Hansel, a third-generation dairy farmer in this upstate village, got up at 5:30, as always, to milk the cows. When the chores were finished, Mr. Hansel and his wife, Hope, picked up their shotguns and went outside to meet a delegation that included seven officials from the New York Power Authority, two state police officers and two lumberjacks, who were to chop down a stand of trees to make way for a power line. ''I'd like to put you on notice that we're going to be doing some target shooting today,'' Mr. Hansel informed his visitors. ''I don't want anybody to get hurt.''

Senior church officials expressed concern today about the dispute over Cardinal O'Connor's itinerary in Israel. ''It would be very unfortunate if the confusion and emotion generated this trip somehow blurred the Holy See's very carefully developed positions on the complex Mideast issues,'' a senior Vatican diplomat said. ''Confusion of any kind in that region tends to set back the cause of peace.''

THE New York Cornet and Sacbut Ensemble returned to Merkin Concert Hall Sunday evening with a program entitled ''Voice of Gold, Brass of Old,'' and devoted mostly to music from Italy. The ensemble - Allan Dean, Raymond Mase, Ben Peck, Ronald Borror, Terry Pierce and David Titcomb - began with a selection of anonymous Renaissance dance music. One piece, describing the strength of Hercules, brought forth some startling squawks; brass of old is still subject to some mishaps in handling. But both here and in a nicely varied set of six canzonas by Lappi, Gabrieli, Merulo and Priuli, the playing was spirited and alive to the dancing lines of the music.

The 22 starters for each team in the five New Year's Day bowl games and the Fiesta Bowl on Friday night may be subjected to drug tests after the games, according to Dave Cawood, assistant executive director of the National Collegiate Athletic Association. He added, however, that the N.C.A.A. postseason drug testing committee, which oversees the tests, may decide to test players from only one or two of those six bowls. ''You can pretty well count on some of those bowls being tested,'' Cawood said yesterday. ''But the committee members aren't saying which ones, and I don't even think they've decided which ones they'll exit test.''

Twenty-two extra police officers have been assigned to Howard Beach, Queens, including nine plainclothes officers, to prevent any more racially motivated violence, Mayor Koch said yesterday. The Mayor said the new officers were being sent to the area beginning today because of ''information'' the city had received suggesting that additional attacks were possible. He would not reveal the nature of the information.

It wasn't quite a matter of loose lips sinking ships, but something Lou Piniella said last week may have poked a small hole in the baseball owners' defense against charges of collusion on the free-agent front. ''Once Texas decided they weren't interested in re-signing him, we decided he was the free agent we really wanted,'' the manager said on the day the Yankees announced the signing of Gary Ward, a 33-year-old outfielder who had spent the last three seasons with the Rangers. The notion that the Yankees had waited for Texas to pass on Ward ''illustrates what's really going on'' among owners, says Donald Fehr, executive director of the Major League Baseball Players Association. The union has charged in a grievance that the owners have violated the collective-bargaining agreement by conspiring not to pursue players who become free agents until their previous teams are no longer interested. Piniella's comment, made Wednesday in an interview with The New York Times, is further proof, says Fehr, who plans to ask Piniella about it.

Dominick Blum, the motorist whose car killed a young black man 10 days ago in Howard Beach, Queens, has volunteered to testify before a grand jury without immunity, a spokesman for Mr. Blum said yesterday. The spokesman, Dennis Quirk, the president of the New York State Court Officers Association, said that Mr. Blum, a 24-year-old court officer, had notified the Queens District Attorney that he wanted to testify. Mr. Quirk said that Mr. Blum expected to be called before a grand jury later this week or early next week. The grand jury is to examine an incident that began when a group of white youths attacked three black men in Howard Beach. One of the men, Michael Griffith, ran onto a highway while fleeing the attackers, and was struck and killed by Mr. Blum's car.

Bob Dianuzzo, an electrician, checking bulbs on the Big Apple atop the building at 1 Times Square. A dress rehearsal was held yesterday for the dropping of the ball; it will descend for real tomorrow at midnight as throngs of merrymakers herald the coming of the year 1987. (NYT/Dith Pran)

The assignment for the staff member at a Far Eastern embassy here last spring was to write an assessment of American domestic politics in 1986. The staff member, who works for the embassy's political office, is not an authority on American politics; she holds no doctorate and knows no politicians. But she has a qualification that in the view of this embassy suits her to this task: She is American. Behind iron gates and brick walls throughout the city, scores of American citizens like her are quietly serving foreign governments.

Kenny Smith scored a career-high 23 points and led North Carolina into the final of The Dallas Morning News Classic with a 94-81 victory over Purdue. Southern Methodist downed Towson State, 79-65, to join Carolina in Tuesday's final. Purdue (7-1) plays Towson State in the consolation game. With a Classic record crowd of 15,605 watching, North Carolina (9-1) of the Atlantic Coast Conference dominated the Big Ten Boilermakers after the first 10 minutes.

Angry readers reaching for writing materials in order to pen indignant letters about the typography of this column are asked to stay their hands: the bidding shown is an accurate record of the proceedings. South opened four spades, and an East player who had not been listening then ''opened'' one club. South could have accepted the one-club bid, but chose not to. His four-spade bid was reinstated and this time East passed.

Thomas I. Unterberg and A. Robert Towbin, who recently resigned as senior executives from L. F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin Holdings after losing a key board vote, will join Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. early next year as managing directors, according to Wall Street sources. The sources, confirming reports in the Wall Street Letter, an industry newsletter, said that Mr. Unterberg would head a new division for financing emerging high-technology companies.

As the Reagan Presidency enters its last two years, the environmental counterrevolution it began in 1981 has achieved only some of its far-reaching goals. Government officials and outside critics interviewed over the past several days agreed that programs to ease the burden of antipollution regulation on business and the economy and of removing obstacles to the rapid development of land and mineral resources by private industry have been only partly successful. These programs, unveiled to heated debate at the outset of the Reagan Administration, have been slowed, and in some cases stopped, in the face of resistance in Congress, the courts and the arena of public opinion. The Administration has made some progress toward its environmental policy aims. Among other things, it has opened broad new off- and onshore lands for oil and mineral leasing, although the leasing itself has been sluggish because of world market conditions. It has slowed the acquisition of new parkland, subjected antipollution rules to rigorous cost-efficiency tests, held up acid rain legislation, cut conservation budgets and, by Presidential veto, blocked an $18 billion renewal of the Clean Water Act.

Officials in the Environmental Protection Agency say their agency is being inadvertently pushed into what amounts to an acid rain control program even though Congress has refused to adopt one. New regulations being considered by the agency, which sets standards for the level of pollutants allowed in the air, do not mention acid rain. Instead, they are intended to protect a small fraction of the nation's asthmatics.

The Minneapolis-based investor Irwin L. Jacobs said he had raised his stake in the Borg-Warner Corporation to the equivalent of 12.4 percent, or 10.6 million shares, from 11.3 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Jacobs reported that Bear, Stearns & Company had agreed to add an additional 970,800 Borg-Warner shares to an option agreement between the New York-based brokerage and Minstar Inc., of which Mr. Jacobs is chairman.

A 557-acre expanse of woods, brush and waterfront in the Hither Woods area of East Hampton town was sold by a developer today for $8.3 million for use as public parkland. The buyer, the Nature Conservancy, a private land preservation group, will in turn sell the land for the same amount to New York State, Suffolk County and the town of East Hampton under an agreement government officials announced in November. The officials said the purchase was needed to protect the environmentally sensitive area, part of which lies atop a supply of underground water they said would be needed by Montauk and other surrounding communities in the future.

South Africa's white authorities announced new measures under the nation's emergency decree today to combat dissent in segregated black schools and to counter plans for an ''alternative'' syllabus called people's education. The action, commentators said, seemed to reflect official concern about plans by anti-Government educators to offer alternative courses in history, English and other subjects as a means of promoting protest against apartheid and to establish what is called people's power. In a separate development, the Government confirmed that it planned to build an airstrip on a remote South African-owned island between Cape Town and Antarctica. But the authorities offered no direct comment on British news reports that the strip was part of a joint Israeli-South African plan to test nuclear weapons.
* American Telephone and Telegraph Co. said it would purchase two of ITT Corp.'s communications companies: All America Cables and Radio Inc. and ITT Communications Inc. Virgin Islands.

The day after the Republicans lost control of the Senate to the Democrats last month, staff members of the committee responsible for electing Republicans to the Senate paid themselves and their consultants $225,250 in bonuses, according to records filed with the Federal Election Commission. The 87 bonuses were dispensed at a time when the committee, the National Republican Senatorial Committee, was listing its debts as nearly $2.2 million, part of it offset by cash on hand. Thomas C. Griscom, executive director of the Senatorial Committee, gave himself $50,000, the second largest bonus. Assuming that his annual salary, which is not a matter of public record, is more than $25,100, that means he was paid more than the senators for whose election his organization works.

The National Marine Fisheries Service has opened a school to teach salmon the rudiments of avoiding predatory cod. According to Science News, the teaching program was developed by the service in collaboration with Oregon State University as a technique for reducing the number of baby salmon that are eaten by cod.

New York City, faced with a growing number of homeless families, has been increasing its use of New Jersey hotels to provide them with shelter. In September, the Koch administration began by sending 20 families to a Newark motel, but Newark Mayor Sharpe James objected. A few weeks later, New York City said it would put no more than 40 families in that motel. Since then, city official have referred families to a number of hotels and motels in other parts of New Jersey.

Five days before the Sunkist Fiesta Bowl, the prime-time match between Miami and Penn State created to establish an indisputable victor in the college football polls, the spirit of respectful competition suffered the first defeat of the week. A steak fry on Sunday night, one of the activities leading up to higher education's version of the Super Bowl, was interrupted when a series of satirical skits performed by Penn State players led to the abrupt departure of the Miami team. The confrontation between the teams, which had been moved back from New Year's Day to Friday night, suddenly came sooner than scheduled. The Penn State skits included a spoof of the Heisman Trophy, which was won by the Miami quarterback, Vinny Testaverde; a reference to the always-in-place hair style of Jimmy Johnson, the Miami coach, and a discussion of Penn State team unity in which John Bruno, a Nittany Lion senior punter, jokingly said that white members of his team allowed black players to eat at the training table once a week.

To the Editor: Fred M. Hechinger says (About Education column, Science Times, Dec. 9) that Secretary of Education William J. Bennett errs in claiming that Federal student aid has encouraged colleges to raise prices. Mr. Hechinger cites as evidence that from 1970 to 1980, when Federal student aid was increasing rapidly, college costs rose 25 percent slower than the consumer price index. Mr. Hechinger's figures are correct as far as they go, but he overlooks a key point.

New York City tap water is as good as the best bottled variety, and so is most of that in Los Angeles, according to Consumer Reports. After testing the water of six cities as well as 50 brands of club sodas, seltzers and mineral and ''bulk'' waters, the magazine's January issue gives top ratings of ''excellent'' to both cities as well as to about 20 bottled products.

Alton Asa Lennon, a former United States Senator and Representative from Wilmington who was known as one of North Carolina's most conservative Congressmen, died Sunday at Cape Fear Memorial Hospital. He was 80 years old.

Ever since the death of Len Bias from cocaine intoxication last June, the University of Maryland basketball program has been in turmoil. But the similar death of Don Rogers a week later appears to have had a stabilizing effect on the Cleveland Browns, whom the Jets will oppose Saturday in the Super Bowl XXI playoffs. ''I think it sobered our team,'' Ernie Accorsi, the Browns' executive vice president, was saying yesterday. ''A year ago our defense did a lot of celebrating on second down, which always seemed premature. And the youngest guy on that defense was Rogers, but he didn't like that. This year all that celebrating isn't there.''

Anticipating that his colleagues will stumble over the pronunciation of his name, Representative-elect Kweisi Mfume, Democrat of Baltimore, has sent a note to all other members of the House stating, ''The following is a phonetic pronunciation of my name, which is of African derivation: Kwhy-E-See Oom-Foo-May.''

Thomas W. Manning testified today that he killed a New Jersey state trooper in self-defense after the trooper stopped him for speeding, recognized him as a fugitive and fired at him. Mr. Manning and a second avowed revolutionary, Richard C. Williams, are charged with murdering Trooper Philip J. Lamonaco on Interstate 80 in Warren County Dec. 21, 1981. Mr. Manning, who except for lunch and a break, was on the stand for five hours, said his co-defendant was not at the shooting scene. He said he had left Mr. Williams half an hour earlier at a bar near Netcong, N.J. State witnesses said earlier that they saw a passenger in the Manning car at the shooting scene, but Mr. Manning said his passengers were a Hispanic couple he had picked up as hitchhikers.

The McDonnell Douglas Corporation announced yesterday that it would start production of the long-delayed MD-11 wide-body jetliner, a move that will keep the company in the business of building large passenger jets. The decision came after an influx of orders for the three-engine plane in recent weeks satisfied criteria that the company's board had established for production to begin. McDonnell said it has orders from 12 customers for a total of 52 aircraft, as well as options from those customers on an additional 40 planes. The orders, some of which are still subject to various approvals, would be worth more than $5 billion.

By selling half of his company, Eastdil Realty Inc., to the Nomura Securities Company, Benjamin V. Lambert would seem to be giving up some of his hard-won independence. ''I do value my independence,'' Mr. Lambert said yesterday, ''but I also value this partnership with Nomura. The relationship is so structured that the company continues to operate with me as chief executive and having full management controls.''

If Miami beats Penn State this Friday night, Vinny Testaverde will become the seventh player in college football history - and only the second in 39 years - to capture both the Heisman Trophy and the national championship in the same season. Here are the six earlier Heisman winners whose teams finished with the No. 1 ranking in the major polls.

John Cardinal O'Connor, the Archbishop of New York, toured Jordan's largest Palestinian refugee center today, visiting children in their flimsy classroom buildings and walking the rutted streets. ''No one can spend any time out here without suffering with the Palestinian people,'' the Cardinal told reporters at the end of his visit to the refugee center, Baqaa, outside Amman. Earlier, in a classroom at Baqaa, one of 10 such centers in Jordan, the Cardinal was serenaded by Palestinian boys with short-cropped hair who sang ''Abu Omar Had a Farm'' to the tune of ''Old MacDonald.'' In another classroom, 15-year-old girls, their heads and necks draped modestly in white scarves, answered questions in faltering English about an episode in ''Jane Eyre.''

NOTHING is more ephemeral than fashion. But pinning down its passing fancies can tell us something about our world. This year, for instance, saw a dramatic splintering of style. While some believed they could still issue dress decrees, American fashion in 1986 was whatever people wanted to make it.

ANTHONY TARABOCCHIA Jr. is an athletic, outgoing boy, normal in every way, except that he was born a dwarf. ''Since birth,'' said his mother, Mary, ''my goal has been to find something for him. I thought if they could transplant hearts and send people to the moon, they could help Anthony grow.'' She took him to doctors for hormone injections when he was 2 and to Lourdes for the baths, but still Anthony stayed small. Then she heard of an operation being done in Europe that could add a foot of height. She asked a dozen American doctors, but could find none to do it, because they felt it too painful and risky.

To the Editor: At a time when the Secretary of Health and Human Services proposes a Medicare catastrophic-care plan and New York's Governor Cuomo seeks legislation to subsidize the elderly's purchase of prescription drugs, an initiative proposed by the New York State Department of Social Services would reduce care available to indigent recipients of Medicare: the indigent elderly living in the community or in nursing homes, the indigent mentally retarded living in the community or in community care residences and the chronically disabled. The effect of the proposed regulation would be virtually to eliminate all co-insurance under Medicaid for all services provided under Medicare.

The crisis over arms sales to Iran is described in Middle Eastern terms, but it's really about America. It has very little to do with Iran. That country is pursuing its course more or less as it was doing before the bizarre arms deliveries. The Iranian revolution is savage and gives no indulgence to the gentler parts of human nature. It is a serious chapter in the history of ideas and it is not going to be dethroned or humanized by trivial cloak-and-dagger gestures. But the fact that some officials in Washington believed that the way to win the hearts of ''moderates'' was to send inconsequential packages of arms to an extremist regime tells an ominous story about decision-making in the control tower of the free world.

Mayor Koch yesterday called 1986 ''a terrible year'' for him, and went further than ever before in apologizing for the corruption scandal that has marred the beginning of his third term, the term he had predicted would be his best. Surrounded by newspaper reporters and photographers during his traditional year-end interview, the 62-year-old Mayor conceded, when asked, that he had let down the people of New York. ''I hold myself to the highest standards,'' he said. ''I'm sorry these things happened on my watch. And in that sense I let them down. I didn't meet the standards I set for myself.''

The police said yesterday that a ''failure of communication'' between officers investigating the death of Michael Griffith had caused several hours of confusion over what car killed him after he was chased and beaten in the Howard Beach racial assault. The concession of the procedural error was the latest of several revisions, additions and contradictions that have emerged in official accounts since Dec. 20, when Mr. Griffith, a 23-year-old black man, was struck and killed on the Shore Parkway near 156th Street after being chased by a gang of whites. These inconsistencies have also involved erroneous information about Mr. Griffith's occupation and the name of the company that the police initially said employed him, and differing accounts of why Mr. Griffith and two companions were in Howard Beach at the time of the attacks. Discrepancies Cited Other variations have included differing estimates of the time that elapsed between the departure of two officers from the scene of the first beatings and the beginning of the attack and the police's initial failure to say that the driver of the car that killed Mr. Griffith, Dominick Blum, was not alone when his car struck Mr. Griffith. Other questions, such as why Mr. Griffith was apparently carrying an electronic paging device and who owned a silver-colored cap pistol found near his body, remain unanswered.

Crude oil prices rose to their highest levels in 10 months yesterday on world futures markets, signaling increased confidence in last week's production accord of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. The near-month futures contract on the New York Mercantile Exchange advanced 38 cents to close at $17.65 a barrel. Its price had not been so high since Feb. 7, when it closed at $17.68 for a 42-gallon barrel.

A Republican Senator today criticized the Reagan Administration for supporting construction of the Midgetman missile, saying it would waste Defense Department funds. But the Democratic chairman of the House Armed Services Committee defended the Administration's position.

WITH a remarkable absence of fanfare on Wall Street, shares of the world's two largest oil companies have been climbing to record prices. ''It has been an astonishing performance,'' R. Bryan Jacoboski, international oil analyst for Paine Webber, said admiringly. The stock of the Exxon Corporation, kingpin of the industry, closed yesterday at 72 3/4, down 3/4, after setting a new high last week at 74 1/8. It has been advancing in a steady, but unspectacular, fashion since selling as low as 48 3/8 in February.

Q.Do ostriches hide their heads in the sand when frightened? A.Although ostriches may lie on the ground with neck outstretched to escape detection, the belief that they bury their heads in the sand is unfounded. Ostriches can usually rely on their speed and keen eyesight to escape predators.

The Northern Trust Company, Chicago's fourth-largest bank, is the most prominent medium-sized bank in this key market that is not yet part of a larger financial company. But now that it has worked its way out of a morass of bad loans - it was nearly dragged under by the failed Penn Square Bank of Oklahoma City in 1983 and by third world lending -Northern Trust is looking so good that it is repeatedly said to be a takeover candidate. ''Management gets high marks for damage control,'' said James J. McDermott, an analyst with Keefe, Bruyette & Woods Inc. ''They identified the problems, resolved them and now have the bank on fine footing for the future growth.'' Evidence of Northern's improvement can be found in many places. It is headed toward record profits this year. It has reduced nonperforming loans to $49.3 million, from a peak $176.7 million in 1983. Its return on equity has risen to 12.5 percent, from 7.6 percent last year. And its stock, which closed at $39, down 25 cents a Continental Illinois raised its estimate of the F.D.I.C.'s loss on Continental's troubled loans to $1.6 billion. Page D5. share, in over-the-counter trading yesterday, is about twice its 1985 low of $19.75.

Beyond his 70th birthday, the man appears taller and sturdier - if a little grayer - than the one in the pictures that were taken in his youth. Fifty years removed from the basketball revolution he began as a junior at Stanford University, Hank Luisetti was talking about the consistency of his game. ''Basketball has not changed,'' he said. ''The plays haven't changed. Attacking a zone defense in college is the same. Man-for-man, that's always been the same. Nobody's come up with some sure-fire idea. The fundamentals in basketball are still the same. The only change is the jumping. And better shooters.'' Luisetti had overlooked one of the most significant developments in the evolution of the game, of any game: his resourceful means of putting a ball into the basket. He did not modernize basketball single-handedly, just one-handedly. Fifty years ago tonight, long before athletic reputations were made or broken by the presence of television cameras, Luisetti's performance on a New York stage forever altered the structure of the sport.

CLOCK time is inexorable in its steadiness. But, as the physicists concluded about time in the physical universe, social scientists are now finding that time as a psychological concept is relative - that it is almost totally subjective. Time as experienced in its most profound sense has less to do with the clock than with a mental state or with the psychological realities of life. In this individual orientation to time lie some of the most important elements of personality. Although the coming of the New Year may evoke reflection on the passage of time, few people realize how deeply their orientation toward time shapes their experience.

Everyone who follows the Jets would assume that Pat Ryan will be the quarterback again when the team continues the playoff route next Saturday at Cleveland. But Ryan doesn't know that. ''I saw Joe earlier today and he didn't say anything,'' said Ryan, a day after Coach Joe Walton benched Ken O'Brien for Ryan, who led the team smartly to a wild-card victory over the Chiefs. Yet Walton withheld a vote of confidence from Ryan, despite Ryan's three touchdown, no-interception performance.

Gregory Powell, convicted of the 1963 ''Onion Field'' murder of a Los Angeles police officer, today was ordered paroled by the California Supreme Court, which said the state parole board erred in canceling his 1982 release date.

As workers at Cape Canaveral prepare for the somber task of burying the debris of the space shuttle Challenger in an abandoned missile silo, the greater wreckage of the American space program still lies everywhere, picked over but by no means reassembled into a vibrant whole. Thus, 11 months after the worst disaster in spacefaring history, the United States finds itself well into the space age without a bold vision of where it is going and what it wants to achieve in space and without a coherent, comprehensive national policy guiding its diverse endeavors, according to aerospace experts, members of Congress and space officials. As a consequence, they say, the nation is in danger of forfeiting its position as the leader in space, a loss that could have economic and strategic implications well into the 21st century. The non-military space program, its many triumphs a receding memory, is especially seen as in grave danger. Visions and Realities Once there were manned voyages to the Moon, regular, unmanned departures for the distant planets and a fair wind of shared national commitment that seemed sure to carry those who ventured far beyond the Earth. Once there were dreams of bases on the Moon, humans tramping on the red plains of Mars. The dreams, it once seemed, were so manifestly achievable as to be less like visions than expressions of tomorrow's reality.

While no super teams have surfaced thus far in the college basketball season, distinct echelons have emerged from the nation's top-20 teams. Last night, St. John's stormed into the upper echelon with a convincing 62-53 victory over Georgia Tech in the championship game of the Eastern College Athletic Conference Holiday Festival at Madison Square Garden. It was the third straight Festival championship for St. John's and the Redmen's ninth victory in nine games this season. Georgia Tech is 6-3. 411th for Carnesecca The victory was also the 411th career victory for Lou Carnesecca, the St. John's coach, who passed Clair Bee for 47th place on the career coaching list.

Charges of murder, manslaughter and assault against three white youths in the death of a black man in Howard Beach were dismissed by a Queens judge yesterday after the prosecution's key witness - another black man who was attacked - refused to testify. The dismissals for insufficient evidence brought cries of ''injustice'' from some spectators and left only a lesser charge of reckless endangerment against the youths. The words of the youths on the night of the attack, as recounted by police officers who interrogated them, generated shocking testimony in Queens Criminal Court. ''There's some niggers in the pizza parlor - let's go kill them,'' one defendant, Jon L. Lester, purportedly said in recalling how the whites were summoned from a party to the attack. ''They came toward us and we started swinging,'' the youth was quoted as saying.

The browser frowned as he tried to make up his mind between an engineering textbook published in 1915 and an old cowboy paperback entitled ''Law Man of Powder Valley.'' After looking again at the prices of the two books, both of which had been read many times, the man reluctantly put them back and went to another stall to try to find something cheaper. Dozens of other people inspected the piles of old books and magazines in the stalls, slowly looking at tattered books that were often older than the browsers.

N.B.A. Cavaliers 107, Hawks 106: Phil Hubbard hit a foul shot with 3 seconds left for the winning point last night as Cleveland overcame a 16-point third-quarter deficit to edge Atlanta in Richfield, Ohio. Atlanta's Dominique Wilkins, who led all scorers with 25 points, tied the game at 106 with 15 seconds left with a 3-pointer. Hubbard got the offensive rebound off a missed shot and was fouled by Kevin Willis. He made his second attempt.(AP) Bullets 125, Warriors 105: At Landover, Md., Moses Malone scored 35 points to lead Washington past Golden State. The Bullets led by 19 points in the first period but saw the lead trimmed to 70-69 midway through the third quarter. The Bullets then went on an 11-2 spurt, with Malone scoring 7 of the points.(AP) Jazz 109, Spurs 101: In Salt Lake City, John Stockton scored 9 of his 14 points in the fourth period and handed out 15 assists for Utah. The victory gave the Jazz a 12-1 record in December, the best month in franchise history. The Jazz led by only 102-98 with 1:33 remaining, but seconds later, Stockton hit a 3-point goal and added another basket on Utah's next possession.(AP) Horse Racing Spring Beauty Wins: Spring Beauty took the lead early, relinquished it briefly and then, after regaining command in the stretch, raced to a two-length victory in an allowance feature for fillies and mares 3 years old and up at Aqueduct yesterday.

VALUES was the buzz word of education in 1986. Stern demands for the teaching of values came from liberal Democrats like Governor Cuomo as well as conservatives like William J. Bennett, the Secretary of Education. Why? Probably because values seemed in short supply everywhere, from Wall Street to Washington. As usual, the schools were asked to undo society's failure. But they got little help in defining the values they were expected to teach. Threats to the nation's economic competitiveness also raised demands for a response from the schools, particularly for better science teaching. Ironically, at the same time fundamentalists sought to elevate creationism to a science and to give it equal time with the teaching of evolution. Arguments over ''creation science'' went to the Supreme Court in a suit brought by Louisiana's Attorney General against the state's education authorities. The attorney general was supported by religious fundamentalists and conservative groups; the educators were backed by many scientists and liberals. A decision is expected next year.

The Reagan Administration is expected to announce Tuesday retaliatory measures against some European farm exports, White House officials said tonight. The action would be part of a trade dispute that the United States contends is costing American farmers $400 million to $500 million a year. Decisions dealing with this and another trade dispute, involving Brazilian computer imports, will be announced by Clayton K. Yeutter, the United States Trade Representative, the officials said.

OF all phenomena that affect the human condition none has perplexed scientists more than the forward march of time, its link to the seemingly relentless tendency toward disorder known as entropy, and to the expansion of the universe. Some of the world's leading theorists have speculated that, if the current expansion reverses itself and the universe begins to contract, the arrow of time will change direction. People - if there are any - would live from the grave to the cradle and would ''remember'' what is to happen tomorrow. Some of them have suggested that those living in such a universe would not be aware that time was running backward, because their perception of time would be reversed. But they would live in a universe whose future, in every detail, is predetermined. Scientists have also suggested that our universe might have a twin, formed of antimatter, in which time runs backward.

The Justice Department said yesterday that the families of four astronauts who died in the Challenger disaster had agreed to settle all claims against the Government, the space agency and its contractors in exchange for ''payments over an extended period of time.'' Although the department named no figure, each family is said to be in line for at least $750,000. In a brief statement, the Justice Department said families of each of four astronauts - Francis R. Scobee, the mission commander, Air Force Lieut. Col. Ellison S. Onizuka, Gregory B. Jarvis and Christa McAuliffe, a New Hampshire schoolteacher - had agreed to settle ''all potential claims'' in the Challenger explosion, which also killed three other astronauts. Two other astronaut families have filed suits and a third has not taken any action.

Following in that grand and glorious tradition of Bill Bradley, Jack Kemp, Vinegar Bend Mizell, Jim Bunning, et al., Ernie Terrell, the former heavyweight champion, is the latest erstwhile athlete to seek public office. He's running against nine other Democratic candidates for one of 50 seats on the City Council in his native Chicago, and Round 1 is the primary election Feb. 24.

The changing world of women has had a dramatic impact on Americans in the last 30 years, and reconciling their many roles poses the challenge of the future, a new study reports. ''The shift of women out of the home and into the labor force and out of marriages and into independent living arrangements represents changes which are out of step with the ability of social institutions to support the changing economic role of women,'' the study's authors, Suzanne M. Bianchi and Daphne Spain, said. As a result, three crucial issues confront society: wages, child care and housework, according to the study, entitled ''American Women in Transition.''

Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos in Boston has done it again. This time it has won the $10 million plus advertising account of the Bank of New England, which is also based in Boston. The assignment had been at Kenyon & Eckhardt (now Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt) for more than 20 years.

The dollar drifted to a six-year low against the West German mark yesterday and its lowest level in several months against the Japanese yen in thin year-end trading, With most traders on the sidelines, volume was at best one-quarter to one-third the normal level, foreign exchange dealers estimated. ''Most of the activity has been in the dollar-yen market because the Japanese trading companies and real estate investors are cleaning up their books for the end of the year,'' said Christopher Bourdain, a dealer who handles corporate foreign exchange business in New York for the Bank of America. ''The dollar is just drifting against everything else. Nothing is pushing it but nothing is stopping it either.''

The International Monetary Fund, which provides loans and advice to ailing economies, finally has a new director. It needs a new direction, too. Jacques De Larosiere, who piloted it skillfully through the opening phases of the world debt crisis, has resigned after eight years. He and all his predecessors were chosen by consensus of the fund's European members, but this time a stubborn showdown between France and the Netherlands forced an election. After a campaign with no speeches, no public promises and no vision of the fund's future, the prize went to Michel Camdessus, governor of the Bank of France. By all accounts he is well qualified as financier, civil servant and diplomat. He will need all of those talents.

When Trivial Pursuit hit the American market in 1984, it single-handedly revived the board game industry. An estimated one out of five households bought the question-and-answer game, which racked up nearly $800 million in sales. But while Trivial Pursuit showed how a new board game could capture America's fancy and raised industry expectations of how much money there was to be made, it is proving a hard act to follow. No single new game has had the success of Trivial Pursuit, and sales for the entire adult board game category have fallen off substantially from their $777 million crest, reached in 1984, when Trivial Pursuit was at its height. Last year, sales fell to $304 million, and this year is expected to be about the same.

International A2-8 An Israeli suggested diverting money from the Iran arms sale to Nicaraguan rebels, Oliver L. North told Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, Congressional sources said Mr. Meese told them. A1 U.S.-Iran negotiations resumed on the return of $500 million owed to Teheran by Washington, and a top American official said this might lead Iran to use its influence to free the American hostages in Lebanon. A6 Thailand will close a refugee camp, Khao I Dang, Indochina's most famous and a symbol of hope to thousands of Cambodians. 26,000 residents will be displaced, losing their legal status as refugees. A1 Japan enlarged its defense budget, abandoning a decade-old policy that had limited military spending to 1 percent of the gross national product. The 1987 budget is $22 billion, or 1.004 percent of the G.N.P.

The author of a book that was not listed in The New York Times Book Review's compilation of best sellers cannot sue the newspaper for damages, the California Supreme Court ruled today in dismissing a $3 million suit. In ruling against the author, William Peter Blatty, the court held that a suit for false statements could never be maintained by anyone who was not identified, expressly or by implication, in the challenged writing - in this case, the best-seller list. Allowing such a suit ''poses an unjustifiable threat to society,'' Justice Stanley Mosk wrote in the court's decision.

Two scientists at Sandia National Laboratories in Albuquerque, N.M., have discovered a simple chemical method by which nitrogen oxides can be removed from engine exhaust gases, thereby reducing smog and acid rain. Dr. Robert A. Perry and Dr. Dennis L. Siebers report in the journal Nature that their method is based on cyanuric acid, a common chemical used to stabilize the chlorine disinfectants in swimming pools.

To the Editor: Henry C. Wallich, who has resigned from the Federal Reserve Board because of poor health, has always been a generous mentor of young economics professionals, as well as an original thinker and distinguished international financial diplomat. His main historical role, however, is to have been in the forefront of those who warned of the dangers of inflation.

Michael Schler had just put a large brown felt animal on top of his head and was peering into a mirror to see whether or not he looked sufficiently like a gopher. ''I think it used to be a dog, but I'm going to give him a bow tie and a hat and call him Mr. Gopher,'' he explained cheerfully. Mr. Schler, who had had a good day shopping, was also holding a frog head, a tree costume with curly green plastic leaves (''I could put more vines on it,'' he mused), a crown encrusted with paste pearls and rubies and a star-studded purple cape. The loot would eventually represent a day's work for Mr. Schler, a costume designer who was rummaging through the Theater Development Fund's Costume Collection. On this particular occasion, he was putting together costumes for a play about bad children's theater, and his needs encompassed the requisite princess and fairy godmother as well as Mr. Gopher and a frog who turns into a prince.

Three violin-piano duos have been named winners in a United States Information Agency competition to select musicians to appear as American ''ambassadors'' abroad, and two of the three had foreign-born citizens as principals. The naturalized citizens among the winners were Ali Forough, a violinist from Iran, and Violaine Melancon, a violinist from Canada.

Reaction among blacks to the dismissal of murder and manslaughter charges in the Howard Beach racial attack ranged from disappointment to the assertion that it was ''predictable'' in a criminal-justice system that they said has often failed to heed cries by blacks for justice. ''But all is not lost,'' said the counsel for the state conference of local chapters of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, Laura Blackburne. ''There is still the possibility that the more serious charges could be restored in the grand jury investigation of the incident.'' The decision, by Judge Ernest Bianchi in Criminal Court in Queens, also prompted many of the black leaders active in public protests of the incident to renew their call for a special prosecutor in the case.

The Accuray Corporation and Hercules Inc. said their boards had approved a merger agreement under which Hercules would acquire Accuray for $40 a share - $5 more than a recent offer by Combustion Engineering.

Before the game, Coach Dave Wohl was talking about how much the Nets missed Darryl Dawkins, the center who was sitting out his 22d game since injuring his back in a fall while showering at home on Nov. 13. The Nets may miss Dawkins, but you couldn't prove it by the play of his replacements in the last two games. Tonight, as the Nets beat the Milwaukee Bucks, 122-117, Mike Gminski scored 27 points and pulled down 17 rebounds, season highs in each category for the 6-foot-11-inch pivotman. In Saturday night's victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers, James Bailey scored 35 points.

The J.M. Smucker Company, the little jelly and jam maker that has giants such as Kraft Inc. and Welch Foods on the defensive, announced a series of management changes yesterday that lay the groundwork for the fourth generation of Smuckers to lead the Orrville, Ohio, company. Paul H. Smucker, the 69-year-old chairman, will become chairman of the executive committee and will continue to be chief executive. His eldest son, Tim, 42, who is the company's president, will assume the title of chairman.
Kim Il Sung, who has led North Korea since the peninsula was partitioned after World War II, was re-elected President today by Parliament, North Korea announced. A new Prime Minister was also named.

Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d has told Congress that Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North told him that the idea of diverting proceeds from the Iran arms sale to Nicaraguan rebels came from a senior Israeli official, according to Congressional sources. The Congressional account of Mr. Meese's testimony was confirmed today by a Justice Department official.
