The official said the department had been unable to corroborate Mr. North's reported assertion. The Israeli Government has repeatedly and emphatically denied any connection to the diversion of money to the Nicaraguan rebels or knowledge that such an operation had taken place. According to the Congressional sources, Mr. Meese said in a closed committee hearing that Colonel North had described the purported Israeli role when he was questioned by Mr. Meese on Nov. 23.

Fog at Atlanta's busy airport disrupted nationwide airline operations and delayed thousands of homeward-bound Christmas travelers for the second day yesterday. But the inconvenience was modest contrasted with the snarl Sunday when Delta Air Lines, a major operator in Atlanta, reported average flight delays there of more two hours and some of more than four hours. In all, 70,000 passengers across the country were estimated to have been delayed Sunday by the problems in Atlanta. Coast to coast, the total number of airline delays Sunday was 1,174, the Federal Aviation Administration reported. This did not approach a record. But because the planes were full of passengers, and Atlanta is a major hub for flight connections, the effect was much greater than it would otherwise have been.
In countless refrigerators all over America a turkey is sitting, swathed in Saran Wrap and missing its legs. Yes, there's enough left for another meal.
''I feel like I was born and raised in a plane.

An engine on a United Airlines jet caught fire tonight while it was making an emergency landing at O'Hare International Airport, but the pilot sprayed foam on the blaze and put it out in less than a minute, officials said. The 85 passengers and seven crew members aboard the Boeing 727 were safely evacuated after the fire was extinguished, officials said. The plane had just taken off from O'Hare on a flight to San Antonio when it was forced to return after one of its engines shut down.

In yet another blow to the nuclear power industry, the Financial Accounting Standards Board ruled yesterday that utilities that cannot recover all the costs of completed nuclear plants must take charges against earnings. Utilities abandoning nuclear plants still under construction must also take charges, the rule-making body determined. Until now, utilities could spread out the impact of such costs over time. But many companies, such as the Long Island Lighting Company, did take charges, believing that they were inevitable.

A burglar-alarm salesman who had lost his job barricaded himself in his former employer's midtown office with a rifle yesterday, used a hatchet to turn the place into a ''shambles,'' then surrendered after six hours without injuring anyone, the police said. The salesman, Lani Evans, 53 years old, destroyed furniture, telephones and computer terminals in the office, and he ripped up records about his employment, according to Police Lieut. Robert Cividanes. The police closed parts of Third Avenue and 56th Street for most of the working day, snarling traffic in the area. They evacuated some apartments across the street from the company's office because the residents were in the potential line of fire.

The Comptroller of the Currency has begun to approve applications by several major New York City banking companies to set up operations in the District of Columbia that could give the institutions broad new securities powers in addition to full banking powers. An agency spokesman said today that the Comptroller, Robert Clarke, last Wednesday had quietly approved an application by J.P. Morgan & Company to establish the Morgan Bank D.C. Through that new institution, set up under a now-closed loophole in the District's banking law, Morgan would be able to enter a full range of underwriting activities, such as the issuing of commercial paper, mortgage-backed securities, government revenue bonds and corporate equity and debt securities. Full Banking Activities The Morgan Bank D.C. would at the same time be able to conduct full banking activities, such as deposit taking and the making of commercial loans. Such a development could be a blow to the existence of the longstanding law that separates commercial banks from securities firms. However, Morgan's new banking operations still require approval by the Federal Reserve Board, which regulates bank holding companies. And some experts expect that the Fed will try to block the securities activities.

A 38-year-old Hispanic man was beaten by a group of black men in Brooklyn late Sunday in what the police said yesterday was a racially motivated attack. The police said that the victim's injuries were minor and that he had refused medical aid.

Markets The dollar drifted to a six-year low against the mark and to its lowest level in several months against the yen in thin trading, which accentuated the currency's movements. There was also growing market sentiment that there would a realignment of the European Monetary System after West Germany's elections late next month. In New York, gold ended at $388.75, down $1.25. [ Page D1. ] Crude oil prices advanced to a 10-month high on world futures markets. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, crude oil was up 38 cents, to $17.65 a barrel. [ D16. ]

Leaders everywhere are wringing their hands about the loss of United States credibility after the Iran-contra affair. But the problem may be even more in the wild ideas people are prepared to believe when they can't be sure than in loss of trust in the word of the U.S. Government. Credulity has always been a corrosive element in affairs between nations, especially in the Middle East where there are often some grounds to enhance the temptation of conspiracy theories. The corrective has to be a demand for evidence, stubborn insistence on common sense short of proof to the contrary.

John Mockovciak Jr., an aerospace engineer with the Grumman Corporation, faces the pleasant prospect next spring of moving from Bayville, L.I., to Houston. He will probably be able to sell his 2,000-square-foot ranch house on Long Island for at least $350,000 and buy something similar here for less than half that. And when the Mockovciaks arrive in Texas they will find almost everything else bargain-basement cheap too: fuel, utilities, parking, insurance, taxis, restaurant meals, air fares, taxes. It costs only about 62 cents a gallon for regular unleaded gasoline here, compared with $1.03 in Manhattan and about 85 cents on Long Island. ''Even dating a chick here is cheaper,'' said Ken Lehrer, an erstwhile New Yorker who is a real estate consultant here and who still complains of having to pay $800 for two season tickets for the Metropolitan Opera in New York.
Grete Mosheim, a leading Berlin and West German stage actress, died of cancer yesterday at her home in Manhattan. She was 81 years old.

WHEN Gov. James J. Blanchard of Michigan signed a bill into law last week creating a statewide tuition-guarantee program, Michigan became the first state to adopt an idea that more than a dozen private colleges are already using to help parents cope with the crunch of college expenses. Under the Michigan law, which Mr. Blanchard proposed in January, the state guarantees a child's tuition at any public college or university in the state if parents deposit as little as $3,000 in a new state-sponsored trust fund. How much they will be required to deposit to qualify will depend on the age of the child, with infants' parents paying the least and teen-agers' parents paying the most because they will go to college sooner. The program covers the University of Michigan and 14 other four-year state colleges, as well as 29 two-year schools.

A new transistor has been designed at the University of Illinois that may improve supercomputers and communication systems, the university says. Hadis Morkoc, who led the engineers who designed the transistor, said the device should allow more information to be transmitted to and from satellites and should allow reception of very low-level radio signals. The transistor was fabricated and tested for performance at the General Electric laboratory in Syracuse, N.Y. More testing, which could take one to two years, will seek to establish the transistor's endurance.

THE human brain converses with the entire universe, but it maintains a strange and stringent isolation from its own body. Many substances that circulate in the blood hardly enter the brain at all. Some chemicals in the brain will not diffuse outward into the general circulation. This strange selectivity is vital to the brain's proper function. But recently scientists have learned much about how to manipulate it to help the whole body fight disease.

The press room at the New York Jets' training camp here was not quite dripping with suspense, though one significant question about the team had not been answered in regard to Saturday's playoff game against the Browns: Who would be the starting quarterback? The coach, Joe Walton, had said after Sunday's wild-card playoff victory over the Chiefs that he had not yet decided who his quarterback would be. Many could hardly believe their ears or eyes. Who else could it be but Pat Ryan?
Lothar Bolz, a former Foreign Minister of East Germany, died today, the official press agency reported. He was 83 years old.

Ann Dore McLaughlin, often mentioned as a possible successor to Larry Speakes as the chief White House spokesman, resigned today as Under Secretary of the Interior to go back to school as a student and a teacher. Mrs. McLaughlin, who will leave March 1, said she would take courses in business and international economics and lecture on public policy at the Wharton School of Business at the University of Pennsylvania.

At an 11-minute meeting, People Express stockholders yesterday approved the airline's acquisition by the Texas Air Corporation, ending a tumultuous drama in airline deregulation. Donald C. Burr, the chairman of People, presided at the meeting, turning over the airline that he built at Newark International Airport to his one-time boss and later rival, Frank Lorenzo, the chairman of Texas Air. Mr. Burr was long regarded as the champion of the economy-minded traveler and as the founder of a new management system where workers were also managers. In the past, he had conceded making major errors, such as too-rapid expansion, and yesterday his mood was subdued.

Facing a deadline only two nights away, state lawmakers reconvened in special session today but failed once again to agree on a plan to finance New York City's mass transit system. As has been the case since the special session first began, on Dec. 11, they remained divided over how to distribute between the city and its suburbs the burden of paying for an $8.6 billion five-year program to rebuild the city's subway, bus and commuter rail lines and freeze their fares for three years. The dispute today centered on a proposal by the Assembly Speaker, Stanley Fink, to change the way proceeds from a mortgage-recording tax are distributed.

Harold Jensen personally outscored South Carolina, 12-5, over a four-minute stretch of the second half to lead Villanova to the title in the Sugar Bowl tournament. Jensen, named the tournament's most valuable player, scored 24 points, as Villanova lifted its record to 8-3. In the earlier consolation game, Rolando Ferreira's 19-foot jumper with two seconds left stifled a rally by Vanderbilt (10-3) and gave Houston a 73-72 victory.

BARBARA HANNAH MARKS, who was named a ''young achiever'' by Advertising Age in 1984, has turned 30, decided that is her fighting age and is about to take on some heavyweights. As publisher of unachieving TeenAge magazine, circulation 200,000, she is declaring war on the well-entrenched forces of Seventeen, with a circulation rate base of 1.7 million; 'Teen, with one million, and YM (previously Young Miss), with 885,000. At her office at 928 Broadway yesterday, Ms. Marks explained her tactic. It's called niche building.

To the Editor: ''The death rate from breast cancer in young and middle-aged white women has swerved sharply upward after more than a decade of steady decline,'' the National Cancer Institute reports, adding, ''The reasons for this increase are not known'' (news story, Dec. 8). It is possible, however, that these findings are related to increased stress, which has been shown in both laboratory animals and humans to increase the incidence and rate of growth of breast cancer. It has now been clearly documented that emotional stress is associated with a decline in immune-system parameters responsible for defenses against cancer. Inability to express anger, frustration, loss of important emotional relationships and social isolation have been particularly incriminated, especially for breast malignancies.

The Giants will meet the San Francisco 49ers here Sunday in their first playoff game, and Bill Parcells, the Giants' coach, says it will not be easy. Tim Rooney, who scouts future opponents for the Giants, agrees. ''I think the 49ers are playing very well,'' Parcells said today. ''They have been doing that for the last month. They've been turning over the ball a lot on defense. They have big-play capability.''

An estranged husband yesterday shot and killed a man he erroneously thought was having an affair with his wife, then called the woman to tell her what he had done and killed himself, the police said. The shootings began at 7:10 A.M. as 35-year-old Gregory Bilges of 85-49 80th Street in the Woodhaven section of Queens was walking his dog at 85th Street and Forest Parkway.

The Philippine Government filed suit today for possession of four buildings in Manhattan and a sprawling estate in Long Island, saying Ferdinand E. Marcos acquired them illegally while President. The lawsuit for the $350 million in property, filed here by a special presidential commission, also asks that Mr. Marcos, his wife, Imelda, and 19 other defendants pay the Philippine Government $500 million in damages as an example to ''those who are unfaithful to the duties of their trust.'' The filing of the suit, announced by the commission's chairman, Jovito Salonga, came after a United States Court of Appeals upheld a ruling by a lower court freezing sale or transfer of the properties until the Philippine Government claims are settled.

The wife of the chairman of the board of the Wedtech Corporation, a troubled South Bronx military contractor, disappeared six weeks ago from the couple's apartment on the East Side of Manhattan, and has been the subject of wide search by the police and private detectives, officials said yesterday. The Wedtech chairman, Fred Neuberger, reported his wife, Eileen, missing Nov. 10 and said that she was last seen at the couple's town house on 33 East 85th Street the night before, according to the missing person's report.

John B. Connally would probably just as soon forget the 1980 Republican precinct caucuses in Iowa, which marked the beginning of the end of his Presidential bid. But the proprietor of the Twin Torch Inn in Waterloo, Iowa, has not forgotten Mr. Connally. The former Texas Governor's defunct campaign still owes the motel $1,634 for lodging its workers six years ago. Rena Langenberg, who runs the inn, says she has initiated a new policy on the Presidential campaign entourages that slog through her state every four years.

Japan's large postal savings life insurance fund will be free to invest $18 billion more in foreign bonds under new rules announced today. The move could increase Japan's growing investment in the United States and other countries. The life insurance fund, administered by Japan's Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications, has about $180 billion outstanding. Until today, only 10 percent of those assets could be invested overseas. Now, the Finance Ministry has raised the limit to 20 percent, freeing $18 billion more for overseas investment.

The Queens District Attorney and the lawyers for the victims in the Howard Beach racial attack will have to make several key decisions in the coming days as a result of the dismissal yesterday of murder charges against three suspects in the case, legal experts said. Those decisions, they said, could determine whether criminal charges, and what charges in particular, would be presented to a grand jury. What happens now, the experts said, depends on what the prosecutors do and on the two surviving victims, who have refused to cooperate. Politically Loaded Options For the district attorney's office, the options, like the case itself, are sensitive and politically loaded: The prosecutor could force the victims to testify under court order, could bring the case before a grand jury without the victims' testimony or could grant immunity to certain participants in the crime in return for their testimony.

A three-judge panel agreed today to a four-week delay in the trial of a retired American autoworker accused of killing thousands of people as a guard in a Nazi death camp. Justice Department spokesmen said the judges accepted a request from a lawyer for the defendant, John Demjanjuk, to postpone the war crimes trial from Jan. 19 to Feb. 16.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said its planned price cut for dialed long-distance calls could be greater than the 8.1 percent it previously announced. The price cut follows an order by the Federal Communications Commission for a reduction in the rates local telephone companies charge A.T.& T. for transmitting the local portion of long-distance calls. The F.C.C. is scheduled to announce on Tuesday how much of the $375 million in reductions A.T.& T. will be required to pass on to customers.

For the first time since the outbreak of pro-democracy student demonstrations four weeks ago, senior Chinese leaders were quoted by name today as denouncing the protesters. In addition, for the first time students were threatened with jail if they persist in their protests. Meanwhile, in the bitter predawn cold this morning, university students in Beijing, after six days of quiet, and despite a ban on public demonstrations without a police permit, marched on snow-covered streets with calls for greater democracy. [ United Press International reported that some of the students marched with torches - brooms dipped in some sort of flammable liquid - and drums. ] Everywhere in the university district, which is in the northwest corner of the city, policemen roamed the streets in cars and vans.

The big, pouffed skirts that burst out of Paris recently had something to do with it; they loosened the attitude of many women toward fashion. So did the feeling for luxury and opulence this past fall, reflected in the preference for cashmere in daytime clothes and glitter and lavishness for evening. Whatever the reasons, designers of expensive clothes report that their lists of best-selling clothes for spring are studded with extravagant designs. The more exaggerated clothes have, in many cases, outshone the modified versions of the same design ideas. Women seem to be in a festive mood, designers assert, especially when they are thinking about getting dressed up at night.

Victor Maldonado, a groom employed by a trainer, Joe Aquilino, was suspended 60 calendar days by Aqueduct stewards for failing to report and concealing an electrical device of the type sometimes used illegally to stimulate horses into running faster. According to Manuel A. Gilman, the Jockey Club steward, Maldonado was returning to his lodging at the track about 4:30 A.M. Nov. 15 when he found the device, which Gilman termed a ''cattle prod,'' on the chute leading to the main track.
The driver of an N.J. Transit bus with no passengers aboard was killed yesterday morning when the bus struck a state highway sweeper.

The copper smelter that sustained the economy in this small border community while it polluted the air is about to close, leaving Douglas a company town without a company. After a long battle that pitted environmentalists and Government officials against the Phelps Dodge Corporation and its local supporters, the company was ordered to close the plant by Jan. 15. Phelps Dodge said the cost of equipment to reduce sulfur dioxide emissions to continue operating would be more than the smelter was worth.

Concern for the homeless, for needy children and for the elderly poor who are alone are recurring themes in letters that accompany contributions to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. Caryn Huberman, sending $25 from Palo Alto, Calif., wrote: ''As an ex-New Yorker who enjoys visits to the glittering, powerful, culture-laden city, how can I forget the other face of Manhattan? ''I think about the homeless, older woman in the Port Authority Bus Terminal, her belongings in two plastic bags, who shyly accepted a sandwich and some cash, telling me, 'Take care of yourself.' ''

Striking workers blocking the tracks yesterday at the station in Dijon. The Transport Ministry suspended a proposed salary system that is being contested by the nation's rail workers and named a mediator to try to resolve the 12-day-old walkout that has crippled rail service. (Agence France-Presse)

The Soviet Union captured the gold medals in the 27th World Chess Olympiad in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, but not without unexpected difficulties. The team, composed of Gary Kasparov, Anatoly Karpov, Artur Yusupov, Andrei Sokolov, Rafael Vaganian and Vitaly Tseshkovsky, scored 40-16 to top 107 teams in the 14-round Swiss-system tournament. Going into the last round, the United States held a half-point lead, but the Soviet players beat Poland 4-0, while the Americans stumbled into a 2-2 tie with Bulgaria. When England also won 4-0 against Brazil, it tallied 39 1/2 points to take the silver medals. The United States, at 38 1/2, won the bronze.
Britain and Guatemala have decided to resume diplomatic relations, broken by Guatemala in 1963 in a dispute over neighboring Belize, the Foreign Office said today.

H. Richard Wachtel, a senior partner of the Manhattan-based law firm of LeBoeuf, Lamb, Leiby & MacRae, died Friday at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn. He was 59 years old and lived in Stamford, Conn.

Hearing on S.R.O. Moratorium Mayor Koch holds a public hearing on measures recently passed by the City Council, including one that would extend by a month a moratorium on converting single-room-occupancy hotels and another that would broaden the city's anti-apartheid law. The Mayor is expected to sign both bills, thus making them law. 4:15 P.M., Blue Room, City Hall.

Diane Sawyer, the ''60 Minutes'' correspondent, has agreed to a new contract with CBS News after weeks of negotiations with all three major broadcast networks. Ms. Sawyer agreed to a five-year contract that will raise her salary from about $840,000 a year to about $1.2 million, according to sources close to the contract negotiations. The correspondent was in Louisville with her family yesterday and was ''not talking to the press,'' according to a CBS spokesman, Ann Morfogen.

The United States and Iran resumed negotiations today on the return of some $500 million owed to Teheran by Washington, and a top American official held out the hope that the talks might lead Iran to use its influence to free the American hostages in Lebanon. Earlier, a State Department spokesman had said there was ''no link whatsoever'' between the anticipated return of the $500 million and the possible release of the five Americans believed still held hostage in Lebanon. But the department's legal adviser said later this afternoon that the United States hoped that resolution of this case would persuade Iran to help free the hostages. The Speaker of the Iranian Parliament, Hojatolislam Hashemi Rafsanjani, has said in general terms several times recently that if the United States returned to Iran all of the Iranian assets in the United States, Iran would be sympathetic to using its leverage with the militant groups holding the hostages in Lebanon.

Backers of the immigration bill that President Reagan signed into law only last month are already gearing up for what they believe will be protracted battle in both Congress and the courts over its provisions and enforcement. The Washington-based Federation for American Immigration Reform, the major lobbying organization behind the bill, has spun off a new group, the Immigration Reform Law Institute, to fight legal challenges to the bill.

KRISHNAMURTI. A Biography. By Pupul Jayakar. Illustrated. 516 pages. Harper & Row. $22.95. ALIKE in this country and in his native India, Krishnamurti (1895-1986) was for generations the epitome of the unaligned spiritual teacher who founded no sect, never tried to collect disciples and successors and regarded the craving to ''belong'' as a weakness, if not positively an aberration.
Manager Jim Leyland of the Pirates, whose 64-98 record was the majors' worst last season, on his new house in Pittsburgh: ''Contrary to popular belief, it is not a mobile home.''

How do you turn a small stage into a beach with waves, dunes and the timeless rhythms of summer? With a lot of sand.About 170 large bags full, to be precise. Weight: six tons, and not just any sand, either. It has to be expertly mixed: half white sand (the kind you find in hotel lobby ashtrays), half fine yellow sand (the kind with thick pebbles). Be sure to rake well.

IN a recent letter to clients, Martin Lipton, the lawyer who often helps corporate boards fight takeovers, delivered an unusually stern lecture to the Delaware Supreme Court and two Federal circuit courts. Mr. Lipton said that those courts had failed to understand the dynamics of takeover battles - and ended up favoring raiders and hurting shareholders - when they ruled that corporate boards should not have sided with efforts of management to put together leveraged buyouts to thwart hostile bidders. In his letter, Mr. Lipton joined a heated debate in which many lawyers and judges say the courts should closely scrutinize management buyouts because management's interests in such situations can conflict with those of shareholders. In the cases that Mr. Lipton criticized, corporate boards had approved sweeteners - such as ''lock-up'' options to buy precious corporate assets -that helped induce investment firms to join management in making a defensive leveraged buyout bid for the company. However, the courts ruled that the boards were wrong to grant such sweeteners because they deterred higher bids, rather than encouraging them. Thus, the courts said, the boards failed to fulfill their primary duty: getting the maximum value for shareholders.

Thailand announced today that it was closing Indochina's most famous refugee camp, a symbol of hope to hundreds of thousands of Cambodians escaping a decade of death and dislocation. The closing of the camp, Khao I Dang, is to take effect Wednesday. It means not only that the camp's more than 26,000 Cambodians will be displaced but also that they will lose their legal status as refugees. Instead, they will become ''displaced persons'' who can be returned to their war-torn nation when conditions there permit.

Quintin Dailey, whose four-year N.B.A. career was interrupted by repeated drug problems, officially joined the Los Angeles Clippers yesterday. ''Everyone knows this is my last chance,'' Dailey said at practice.

NINETEEN EIGHTY-SIX was the year of the common scold. Almost everybody was severely criticized by almost everybody else - and usually with good cause. The United States was roundly attacked for fiscal irresponsibility. The National Consumers League, a nonpartisan group that calls itself the nation's oldest consumer organization, handed the Reagan Administration a grade of ''F'' for its economic policy, saying, ''The Administration has failed to exercise any real leadership on budget issues.'' Japan, West Germany and most of America's other allies agreed.

A collision less than a quarter-mile from the finish line cost French Kiss a victory over New Zealand today in the America's Cup challenger semifinals. Neither boat was damaged, but the mishap cost French Kiss the race as New Zealand powered away from the split-second encounter to win her third straight victory in the four-of-seven-race series by 13 seconds. On the other challengers' course, Stars & Stripes defeated USA by 2 minutes 23 seconds to record her third straight victory. The French were within minutes of smashing the 26-race winning streak of the boat that has come to be known as Kiwi Magic. The only other boat to beat New Zealand was Dennis Conner's Stars & Stripes, in a preliminary challengers' race Oct. 17.

Hazard E. Reeves, a communications entrepreneur who helped popularize the wide-screen Cinerama film system and magnetic stereophonic recording, died Dec. 23 of a heart attack at the Duck Cedar Inn in Tuxedo, N.Y. He was 80 years old and lived in Tuxedo Park, N.Y. Mr. Reeves, a leader in the electronics field, helped make popular the use of quartz crystals for radio transmitters, and, in a departure from communications, helped market the Waring Blendor, one of the first home blenders. He also helped to develop Realtron, the first company that offered computerized real-estate listings nationwide, and Catalogia, said to be the world's first computerized multi-catalogue shopping system.

To the Editor: Contrary to your Dec. 10 statement, others fighting for human rights in the Soviet Union who have died in Soviet prisons in the last two years alone include Mark Morozov, a labor activist, who died last August in the same Chistopol Prison where Anatoly Marchenko died, and the Armenian activist Iskhan Mkrtchyan and the Estonian activist Johannes Hint, both of whom died in 1985. Not to recall the many other Soviet citizens who have given their lives for human rights and dignity in their homeland would be a disservice to the cause Mr. Marchenko fought so long to defend. RICHARD SCHIFTER Asst. Secretary for Human Rights and Humanitarian Affairs Department of State Washington, Dec. 12, 1986

Nothing he studied at St. John's University Law School prepared Bruno Cappellini for becoming the temporary caretaker of a stable of racehorses. Or of the costume jewelry of Nita Naldi, a vamp of the silent screen. Or of a drug-ridden brownstone on the Upper West Side of Manhattan used as a ''crack house.'' When the owners of those properties died, however, they left no wills or close relatives to represent them. And so their estates landed on the desk of the the public administrator of Manhattan, Bruno Cappellini.

The Government index intended to predict the economy surged 1.2 percent in November, the biggest advance in seven months, the Commerce Department reported today. The latest reading, which was somewhat stronger than expected, was widely regarded as pointing to continued economic growth in 1987. But analysts differed markedly about how vigorous the fifth straight year of expansion was likely to be. Many contended that the sharp November jump in the index of leading indicators overstated the economy's strength, partly because the new tax law that takes effect this week has been spurring demand recently.

Ohio University officials have appointed a committee to investigate allegations that a professor plagiarized material from Soviet engineering books. The professor, Hollis C. Chen, who is on the faculty of the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, has denied the allegations, which were made in October in the Moscow weekly Literaturnaya Gazeta.

''The advantage of this strategy to the foreign company is that it retains access to our markets without any longer having to deal with anti-apartheid harassment at home.'' - Duncan Innes, a South African economist. [ D3:1. ]

Spectators in Pacifica, Calif., watching yesterday as huge waves battered the waterfront. A rare alignment of the Sun, Moon and Earth, a syzygy, caused high tides that forced offi-cials to close one lane of the Pacific Coast Highway between Huntington Beach and Seal Beach for two hours. The tides, up to one and a half feet higher than normal, caused no serious problems on the California coastline. (UPI)

The United States and Canada reached a last-minute settlement tonight of a softwood lumber dispute that had caused acrimony between the two Governments and threatened broader talks on free trade. The agreement, reached after lengthy negotiations in Washington, will void a 15 percent penalty on Canadian lumber imports to the United States valued at nearly $3 billion a year.

Water erupting from the jets of the fountain outside the Metropolitan Museum of Art seemed superfluous as a crowd waited in the rain yesterday for entry to the current Van Gogh exhibition. Mostly sunny skies are expected today. (NYT/Marilynn K. Yee)

The fear of AIDS does strange things to people who should know better. One by one, Federal agencies are trumping up reasons to screen people for the AIDS virus. Both the fear and the remedy are misplaced.

Getting to Walt Disney World took a bit longer than usual for holiday vacationers, as is evident in this aerial view of the inter-change between Interstate 4 and U.S. 192 in Lake Buena Vista, Fla. Disney World and other central Florida attractions had to turn away excess visitors. (AP)

Watching the Rangers is like watching climbers scaling a very difficult side of a mountain. You wonder when a piece of loose rock will give, causing them to tumble, and how, if at all, they will manage to catch themselves. Here tonight against Pittsburgh, the Rangers lost their grip, climbed back, fell again, and ultimately saved themselves by two dramatic means. Bob Froese, the backup goalie, performed like a star again, and with 5 minutes 44 seconds remaining, Walt Poddubny scored the goal that helped put away a 5-3 victory over the Penguins.

Rudolph W. Giuliani, the United States Attorney in Manhattan, announced yesterday new executive staff appointments in his office. Dennison Young Jr., 43 years old, who had been associate United States Attorney, moves up to the office's No. 2 position, deputy United States Attorney, succeeding William M. Tendy, who died last October.

The 1985-86 season ended with the Boston Celtics beating the Houston Rockets for the championship, Akeem Olajuwon being proclaimed the next dominant center and the Rockets, with their big, young, talented front line of Ralph Sampson, Olajuwon and Rodney McCray, hailed as the team of the future. Houston fans responded by purchasing 14,600 season tickets, the most in the league. With one third of the season gone, however, the optimism has turned to gloom. With the Rockets' record at 10-17 going into last night's game against the Los Angeles Clippers - a pace that would give them a place in the draft lottery, rather than in the playoffs - there had been reports that Bill Fitch would be dismissed and that the feud between the coach and Sampson had resurfaced.

TEMPUS FUGIT New Year's Eve is a night when prices can become sky-high. But one place they are not is the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, where the Fourth Annual New Year's Eve Concert for Peace will take place tonight, free. Ellen Burstyn will read the Prayer for Peace, Leonard Bernstein will be the principal speaker and Michael Barrett will conduct the Orchestra of St. John the Divine in Beethoven's ''Leonore'' Overture No. 3 and the aria ''Abscheulicher'' from ''Fidelio,'' Bach's ''Brandenburg'' Concerto No. 2; Bernstein's ''Meditations for Cello'' and Schubert's Mass in G. Soloists include the sopranos Elizabeth Coss and Lucy Shelton, the tenor Peter Kazaras, the baritone Ben Holt, the cellist Nathaniel Rosen, the folk singer Odetta and the New Year's Eve Massed Choirs. Odetta will close the concert with songs for peace as the audience takes part in a candle-lighting ceremony.

A woman has filed a $30 million lawsuit against the television figure Geraldo Rivera, law-enforcement officers and producers, charging that she was defamed when her arrest was shown on television as Mr. Rivera referred to ''a pimp and his prostitutes.'' The 28-year-old woman, Terry G. Rouse, also charges invasion of privacy, false imprisonment, malicious prosecution and conspiracy in her suit, which stems from her arrest Dec. 2 in a drug raid shown on ''American Vice: The Doping of a Nation.''
A Chicago-based investment group said that it had acquired 6.2 percent of Elgin National Industries and intended to purchase additional shares.

N.B.A. Pistons 103, Bucks 99: Adrian Dantley scored 25 points, including three free throws late in the game for the Pistons last night. Detroit won its third straight game, as Milwaukee's losing streak went to three games. The Bucks also lost for only the second time in 15 home games. The Pistons trailed, 90-84, in the fourth quarter before a free throw by Dantley tied at 95-95 with 1 minute 25 seconds left. Dantley went to the line when the Bucks' Terry Cummings was called for a technical foul for slamming the ball on the floor. A jump shot by Isiah Thomas put Detroit ahead, 97-95, with 1:08 to play, but a tip-in by Cummings with 38 seconds remaining pulled Milwaukee into a 97-97 tie. The Bucks' Paul Pressey was called for a foul with 33 seconds left, and Dantley made one of two free throws to put Detroit ahead to stay at 98-97. A layup by Thomas expanded the Pistons' lead to three, but two free throws by Pressey with 23 seconds left made it 100-99. Two free throws by Joe Dumars with 18 seconds left and one by Dantley with six seconds to play completed the scoring. Cummings led the Bucks with 24.(AP) Warriors 102, Bulls 99: Joe Barry Carroll scored 25 points and Chris Mullin added 23 to lead Golden State. The victory ended Golden State's four-game road trip on a high note, snapping a three-game losing streak.

Five seasons ago, in their first playoffs since 1963, the Giants were eliminated by the San Francisco 49ers. Joe Montana, the 49ers' quarterback, picked on an inexperienced substitute who was playing because the Giants' starting free safety was injured. This Sunday, the Giants and the 49ers will meet in the playoffs here. Montana is still the 49ers' quarterback, as dangerous as ever. And the Giants have a substitute in the defensive backfield because their starting free safety is injured.

A bomb explosion early today killed one man and wounded another in a bar in Maghera, 49 miles northwest of Belfast, the police said. The dead man was identified as Liam McShane, 24 years old, a part-time firefighter.

After suffering an apparent setback in court Monday, the Queens District Attorney conferred yesterday with aides and detectives investigating the racial attack in Howard Beach, Queens, to consider what to do next in the case. Second-degree murder charges against the three suspects were dismissed Monday after one of the victims, a black man who was beaten, failed to appear at a preliminary hearing. Yesterday, the Queens District Attorney, John J. Santucci, reviewed evidence and discussed legal options. Under state law, the authorities have 45 days from the preliminary hearing to obtain a grand jury indictment. The suspects were charged on Dec. 22 in the death of Michael Griffith, a 23-year-old black who belonged to a Brooklyn group that places minority group members in construction jobs. One of the suspects, Jon Lester, remained in custody yesterday on Rikers Island. The other two were released Monday after posting bail.

After a 12-year court battle, a man has lost his claim to two tons of Indian artifacts he secretly unearthed from Indian burial grounds. ''I don't feel like the Louisiana judiciary did me justice,'' said the man, Leonard Charrier, a treasure hunter. ''I could have sold this collection years ago very easily, and I didn't because I wanted to preserve it.''

Flying Tiger Line Inc., the troubled air cargo carrier, announced a cost-reduction program for its executive and administrative staff as part of its effort to return to profitability. The program, which affects 2,600 of Flying Tiger's 6,100 employees, would eliminate 124 jobs, reduce salaries and benefits for all workers, and expand a profit-sharing and stock-ownership program to all administrative employees.

To the Editor: Richard Lepkowski charges (''The Insurance Industry Puts One Over,'' Op-Ed, Nov. 29) that in enacting tort reform, ''New Yorkers have exchanged their legal rights for a plan that will not reduce liability insurance premiums.'' Mr. Lepkowski is wrong on two counts. First, in passing meaningful tort reform, New York took an important step toward restoring fairness to the civil justice system. In addition to other significant reforms, the New York Legislature limited liability for those with only minor responsibility for someone else's harm. Previously, a defendant in a New York lawsuit could be held responsible for all of a plaintiff's damages even if that defendant were responsible for only 1 percent of those damages. Opinion polls and a statewide referendum in California clearly show that the public favors this change in the law.

MOST of us in the music business look back on one or more mentor-figures who inspired us in youth with their dedication, intensity and commitment. Alexander Schneider has played that part in the lives of hundreds of young musicians, and his example as a leader and educator endears him even to those observers who receive his example as a musician with mixed feelings. Mr. Schneider gave the second concert of his annual New York String Orchestra workshop Monday evening in Carnegie Hall, leading 50 young string players (and 12 players on other instruments) from all over the country. His musical approach is best understood, probably, in the context of Stravinsky's ''Pulcinella,'' which (in the form of the familiar concert suite) closed his Carnegie program. Mr. Schneider (who worked with Stravinsky and played his music brilliantly) seems drawn to Baroque and Classical music for its tense energy of line, and for the latent violence in its disciplined, ordered contrasts. Stravinsky's dancing arrangement of Italian Baroque music lets those qualities peek in; Mr. Schneider's conducting of Mozart, Haydn and Vivaldi goads them forward. In the ''Pulcinella Suite,'' the match was good. The abrupt, dry pizzicato in the ''Serenata,'' the bright-light rush into the ''Scherzino''; interpretive details like these seemed related to the needs of the music.

FEW foods evoke the warmth and spirit of the holidays as roasted chestnuts do - preferably eaten on the street from a paper bag that is so hot it nearly scorches your hands. At the dinner table, a steaming bowl of chestnut puree makes a soothing accompaniment to all sorts of game, poultry and other roasts.

* Bankers Federal Savings and Loan Association elected Eldon C. Hanes chairman and Raymond A. Lein president and a director. * Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Atlanta, a bottler, appointed H. Richard Hiller Jr. senior vice president and Thomas D. Sherman general counsel, secretary and vice president.

A leader of a self-styled revolutionary group testified today that a defendant in the slaying of a state trooper was the armorer of the unit whose duties included buying guns for members. The leader, Raymond Luc Levasseur, testified that the defendant, Richard C. Williams, obtained a 9-millimeter pistol for the other defendant here, Thomas W. Manning, another member of the group. Both state and defense lawyers agree that the gun was the weapon used to kill State Trooper Philip J. Lamonaco when the trooper stopped a Chevrolet Nova driven by Mr. Manning on Interstate 80 in Warren County on Dec. 21, 1981. Mr. Levasseur's testimony was intended to bolster the defense side in one of the issues of the trial.

IN the midst of cooking fresh chicken livers recently, I realized that I was preparing one of the least expensive foods available. At the same time I realized that, despite the price, chicken livers are not high on people's lists of favorite foods. Still, I have cooked and served them to guests who subsequently revised their opinions of the dish. This is, I feel, a tribute to the technique I used in preparing the chicken livers. They should be coated with flour and cooked until they are deliciously browned and crisp. Once this is done, I add a special flavor by using a low-calorie accompaniment - sauteed onions plus capers and a slightly sweet-and-sour sauce made from a little red-wine vinegar and a dash of honey.

The Exxon Corporation said yesterday that it is selling its interests in South Africa because of the deteriorating economic and business conditions there brought on by the country's racial crisis. Exxon's involvement in South Africa is relatively minor.

The City Council today declared war on crows, giving the police the power to shoot the birds inside city limits. The officers will use shotguns to rid the city of thousands of unwanted crows, Police Chief Robert Dietzen said, adding that the bids would be shot only in nonresidential neighborhoods. City Health Commissioner Jerry Brown said the crows were a health hazard.

Excerpts from ''Prelude to Retaliation: Building a Governmental Consensus on Terrorism'' by George Bush, published in the winter-spring 1987 edition of SAIS Review, the journal of the Johns Hopkins University School of Advanced International Studies, in Washington: In characterizing terrorism as a threat to democratic governments, I am not saying that terrorism has been directed exclusively against democratic governments. Exclusively, no.
Shiite militiamen resting with their weapons nearby in Beirut. Despite a declared New Year's cease-fire, Shiite and Palestinian fighters battled at two Palestinian centers in the city. (Reuters)

President Kim Il Sung of North Korea called today for high-level talks to reunify the divided Korean peninsula. He also predicted a doubling of factory output by 1994. ''We deem it necessary to hold high-level political and military talks between the North and the South in order to settle the first and most urgent question for national reunification,'' the official North Korean Central News Agency quoted Mr. Kim as having said in a policy speech to the Eighth Supreme People's Assembly.

Three Republican legislators spent three days of the Christmas recess visiting research installations where work is under way on President Reagan's Strategic Defense Initiative, a space-based missile defense often referred to as a ''Star Wars'' plan. Senator Malcolm Wallop of Wyoming and Representatives Jim Courter of New Jersey and Jack F. Kemp of upstate New York traveled to Huntsville, Ala., Los Alamos, N.M., and Livermore, Calif.

ALL that glitters isn't gold, and all that bubbles sure isn't champagne. Literally hundreds of sparkling wines are made around the world - about 60 in California alone - and champagne is just one of them. In this part of the world we tend to think of champagne as the best of the lot. Even if we're right, we owe it to ourselves to discover a few of the other wines that are out there. They range from sticky-sweet California concoctions such as cold duck to the delights of an elegant Schramsberg Napa Valley blanc de blancs; from sulfurous brews such as the Soviet Union's Krim, which someone once described as an unpleasant lambrusco, to the delightful Vouvrays of Marc Bredif and the new cremants from Alsace. True Champagne, made in the region of the same name, probably constitutes less than 2 percent of the world's sparkling wine; there is even a pretty good one made in Peru. We tend to get confused because so many other sparkling wines are called champagne, the way much of the blended red wine in California is called burgundy.

Evidence piles up suggesting that television encourages people to read. Serious thinkers, you may recall, used to say the tube would be the death of the word, which shows that serious thinkers can be just as wrong as frivolous thinkers when they start telling us what it all means for generations yet unborn. Their error was demonstrated one morning recently on the Donahue show when the words ''obsessed with Michael Jackson'' appeared at the bottom of a screen which was otherwise filled with an adolescent female. I had just turned the set on, the way you do when you're looking for an excuse not to go to work. Suppose they've just discovered Jupiter is on a collision course with Earth. If so, going to work would be rather pointless, wouldn't it?

''The Golden Child'' remained No. 1 at the box office over the Christmas weekend as the top seven films brought in nearly $46 million, on a par with last year's successful holiday weekend. The top three films - ''The Golden Child,'' ''Star Trek IV: The Voyage Home'' and a resurgent ''Crocodile Dundee'' - grossed more than half that total.
1. Marking Time Begin the New Year with a compact cubic calendar. This black-and-white cube is made of durable coated card stock and is reversible, with six months on each side.

The morning after the biggest game of his life, Pat Ryan woke up with a bruised right arm. Despite the injury, he will again start at quarterback for the Jets when they face the Browns in the American Conference divisional playoffs Saturday at Cleveland. ''The way the game went last Sunday, we got our rhythm going again,'' Coach Joe Walton said today, explaining why he would be starting Ryan again. Walton, concerned about Ryan's arm, did not tell his quarterbacks until today which one would start, even though Ryan helped revive the Jets last Sunday.

The popularity of the Cajun specialty blackened redfish has forced Federal officials to ban commercial fishing for red drum in Federal waters in the Gulf of Mexico in l987, the Commerce Department has made known. The ban was required because of recent alarmingly high harvests of red drum, according to the department's National Marine Fisheries Service.

The ITT Corporation and Compagnie Generale d'Electricite completed the merger yesterday of their telecommunications businesses, a move that will give ITT $1.25 billion while taking the control of a difficult business out of its hands. The deal creates the world's second-largest telecommunications company, behind the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

The Drug Enforcement Administration said today that it achieved dramatic increases in arrests and seizures in the last fiscal year. The number of people arrested in major drug cases jumped 35.8 percent, to 12,819, while seizures of illicit drugs climbed an average of 30 percent, with a 53 percent gain in cocaine seizures alone, the agency said. Agents confiscated 17,613 kilograms of cocaine in the fiscal year ended Sept. 30.

On New Year's Eve, thousands of New Yorkers will have thronged to Times Square to watch a giant gold ball, dressed as an apple, fall from atop an office building at midnight. At the same time, in the nation's capital, thousands of Washingtonians will have gathered in front of a refurbished post office to watch a crane lower a giant postage stamp from the sky. A postage stamp? ''It's called 'the Love stamp,' '' said Wayne Anmuth, a spokesman for the Postal Service. ''Every year the post office unveils a new stamp which features some aspect of love. Last year's stamp had a puppy dog on it. There's a tremendous predisposition for the Love stamp. When people go to the post office, they'll always ask for the new one. How can you complain about love?''
By some accounts, the old parsonage for sale near Bradford, England, is no beauty. One biographer of its former tenants called it ''drab and little''; another described it as ''almost sordid.''

There was a time, a decade or two ago, when domestic disputes, even violent ones, stayed largely in the family. Women like Josephine Sorichetti, who begged repeatedly for police protection after her husband attacked her with a butcher knife, were left to fend for themselves. Two years ago, after Mrs. Sorichetti won a $2 million damage award for New York City's failure to protect her, the Police Department changed its policy dramatically. Instead of trying to mediate disputes, officers are now under orders to arrest men or women who seriously beat spouses or companions. In many cases, the offenders are jailed, even if the victims do not file formal complaints.

The Economy An index that predicts the economy's course surged 1.2 percent in November, the biggest advance in seven months, the Commerce Department said. The latest reading of the index of leading indicators was widely regarded as pointing to continued economic growth next year. But many analysts said that coming tax changes had spurred demand, causing the index to overstate the economy's strength. [ Page A1. ] New-home sales fell last month for the seventh time in eight months. Many analysts cited soaring prices. [ D3. ] International The President plans higher duties on some European products, including imported gin, brandy, cheese and inexpensive white wine. The Reagan action is in response to high tariffs imposed by the European Community on American feed-grain imports to Spain. The community said it would retaliate if the duties are enacted, but talks to resolve the issue are continuing. Meanwhile, the President has delayed a decision on retaliation in a dispute with Brazil on computer and investment trade. [ D1. ]

Doctors won the first round of a legal battle with the Government today in a suit over Medicare fees. Federal District Judge Halbert O. Woodward granted their request to postpone a deadline for deciding whether to participate in Medicare, the Federal health insurance program for the elderly. Judge Woodward granted a 10-day restraining order and scheduled a hearing Jan. 9 to hear more evidence from the American Medical Association and other plaintiffs against Dr. Otis R. Bowen, Secretary of Health and Human Services.

To the Editor: Richard Lepkowski presented a simplistic, one-sided assessment of the problems facing our society and the insurance industry. First, he indicated that the legislative changes made in New York and Florida radically altered the legal procedures available to wronged individuals.

AT this time of year, the resolve of even the most ardent exerciser can begin to falter. Who wants to jog when streets are icy, or bicycle under a shower of sleet. Not even swimming may beckon when it means stepping out into a cold, dark morning or night. Yet in several ways winter is the most important time to maintain an exercise routine. It is often a time of unwanted expansion - thicker waists, heftier thighs, rounder bellies. Appetites are naturally stimulated by the cold. Since eating and digesting food generate body heat, we often turn to food when we feel cold. The resulting layers of added body fat, so helpful to hibernating and foraging animals like squirrels, make us feel sluggish and less likely to want to exercise. Then there are those New Year's resolutions to start an exercise program. The latest national surveys show that, despite the explosive growth in sales of exercise clothing and equipment, 60 percent of Americans get no regular exercise. When people do exercise, too often it is the result of guilt rather than desire. Without a realistic understanding of what exercise can do for you, resolve tends to fade with the first gust of wintry wind.

The South African authorities said today that they were holding a white army officer on suspicion of spying for the outlawed African National Congress. The officer's arrest was the first disclosure of purported espionage within the military since 1983, when Dieter Gerhardt, head of the country's main naval base at Simonstown near Cape Town, was jailed for life for spying for the Soviet Union. A police spokesman said the officer, Maj. Andre Pienaar, a military intelligence operative, was being held under security legislation permitting indefinite detention without charge or trial or access to lawyers.

Jackie Sherrill, football coach at Texas A&M, responding to his paunchy Cotton Bowl counterpart, Ohio State's Earle Bruce, who had said that one reason he wouldn't want to be like Sherrill was that he could look in the mirror and feel good about himself: ''It was no big deal. I would have been more upset if Earle had said he looked in a full-length mirror.''

For the first time in weeks today, there were no student demonstrations reported from any Chinese city, A senior education official described the last four weeks of pro-democracy student protests as ''important,'' but added, ''We don't feel that these things should cause alarm among us.'' The official, He Dongchang, who is Deputy Chairman of the Education Commission, took a moderate posture in responding to questions about the demonstrations. ''The Chinese Government position toward the students is one of tolerance,'' he said. Despite the halt in demonstrations, posters were put up on several university campuses here in defiance of police regulations.

BASEBALL SAN DIEGO (NL) - Named Doug Duennes director of stadium operations. TEXAS (AL) - Signed Steve Buechele, infielder, to one-year contract. BASKETBALL CLEVELAND (NBA) - Traded the rights to World B. Free, guard, to Philadelphia for a second-round draft pick in 1990.

For a year that began with the Challenger shuttle disaster and ended in a muddle about Iran, hostages and contras, television has not come up with much that is new or especially appropriate in the way of New Year's Eve farewells. Although one station, WOR-TV, is doing something innovative by getting the Marx Brothers into the end-of-year act, elsewhere it is entertainment as usual. Beginning at 11:30 P.M., CBS will be broadcasting part of its festivities from New York's Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, long associated with Guy Lombardo and after his death with the Lombardo Orchestra. But there will be no Lombardo imprint on this year's ''Auld Lang Syne.'' The hosts of the Waldorf section of the show are Gladys Knight and the Pips, and there will be periodic breakaways to Air Supply, Melba Moore and Freddie Jackson at Walt Disney World in Florida. There will also be, of course, live coverage of the midnight countdown at Times Square.
Hervey F. Law, who guided the development of major airports in the Northeast, died Dec. 17 at the Lake Wales (Fla.) Hospital. He was 88 years old and lived in Lake Wales.

Through the timely acquisition of troubled savings and loan associations, Anthony M. Frank has built an organization that he says has now earned its name, First Nationwide Bank. ''We want to be the national consumer bank,'' he said. ''Nobody knows what those four words mean, but we are structured to serve middle America - just plain people.''

Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Patricia Lara, a Colombian journalist barred from the United States last fall, misstated a request she made to the Colombian Government. Miss Lara asked only whether it had evidence to substantiate an American official's assertion that she was a member of the guerrilla group M-19. She neither requested nor received a reply on whether Colombia had evidence that she had ever acted as a Cuban agent.

Sid Caesar, who was to appear in Arthur Miller's ''I Can't Remember Anything'' has withdrawn from the production, Lincoln Center Theater announced today. Mr. Caesar and Gregory Mosher, director of the production, ''have mutually agreed not to proceed with rehearsals,'' the theater's press representative, Merle Debuskey, said.

Coach Ray Perkins of Alabama met for several hours yesterday with Hugh Culverhouse, owner of Tampa Bay, and then called a news conference for today in Birmingham to announce whether he would leave the University of Alabama, where he doubles as athletic director and football coach, for a job as head coach of the Buccaneers, replacing the dismissed Leeman Bennett. Quoting an unamed Alabama official, The Dallas Morning News said he would.

Homelessness, once considered an urban phenomenon, is continuing to grow at an alarming rate throughout the region, according to government officials and advocates for homeless people. The most recent rough guess for Connecticut is 20,000, according to the emergency coordinator for that state's Department of Human Resources, Judy Walter. A report issued this year by Governor Kean's task force on the homeless puts the figure in New Jersey at 26,000. On Long Island, there are believed to be more than 12,000 homeless people, while in Westchester the number of homeless is generally thought to be around 3,500, up more than 65 percent in the past year alone, according to the county's Social Services Commissioner, John J. Allen.

Associate Justice William J. Brennan Jr., now in his 30th year on the Supreme Court, has had his clerks prepare at the end of each term a behind-the-scenes history of the evolution of important rulings, based on his conference notes and draft opinions and memorandums circulated among the Justices before a final decision. Ordinarily, in a security-conscious institution like the Supreme Court, papers like these are rarely made public, at least not until they have aged for some time.

Robert Osgood, who died Monday at 65, was a teacher to teachers and a guide to foreign-policy makers. Humanist, professor, policy maker, original thinker, gentle man, he left everyone he touched better off.

Tonight, as some couples head for Times Square to welcome the New Year, and others head for friends' apartments, Scott Johnston, Michael Kelly and a small coterie of other young investment bankers will make their way to Baja, a dance club on Columbus Avenue near 72d Street. They hope that hundreds of other fashionable young professionals will, too, for this group has poured $700,000 into it. Baja is one of New York's newest dance clubs, in a city where such clubs open and close at an eye blink. And Mr. Kelly, Mr. Johnston and eight other investors, all under the age of 33, are the latest in a stream of hopefuls betting that their club will be the club, at least for a time.

Judge Bernard Meyer has capped an eminent judicial career with seven years of distinguished service on New York's highest court. His retirement today poses a special challenge to Governor Cuomo, who's about to choose Judge Meyer's successor from a list of seven names provided by a nominating commission.

Westchester County will offer free bus rides tonight and a local hospital will offer free taxi rides to motorists who drink too much, officials said yesterday. County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke said no fares would be collected on county buses from 8 P.M. until the end of their evening routes, as late as 1:30 A.M. Thursday, as an incentive for those who have been drinking not to drive.

The highly publicized departure of American companies from South Africa is having a far more ambiguous effect than advocates of such divestment might have hoped for. These advocates, mostly in the United States, have urged that American companies shun South Africa as a message that South Africa's racist way of life is no longer tolerable and that refusal to change would bring increasing economic isolation. But in the short run, at least, the impact of American companies leaving South Africa seems to run counter to the aim of forcing the country's ruling white minority to moderate its political attitudes. Moreover, midway through a wave of departures by American enterprises, business analysts and others are concluding that the withdrawals are only partial, permitting the companies to continue earning profits in South Africa. By selling their businesses to local buyers, American companies are maintaining licensing arrangements and contracts to supply components and thereby earning money without the political hazards of direct investment.

The Swiss authorities said today that they would take further steps early in the new year to freeze accounts controlled by Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North and others involved in the covert arms sales to Iran. They said they would simultaneously lift banking secrecy regulations covering the accounts. Officials said these measures would set in motion procedures under which legal objections could be filed against the action, possibly blocking temporarily an investigation of account records. Study of the records is crucial to United States Justice Department investigators to determine whether proceeds from the arm sales were funneled to Nicaraguan rebels, and if so, how much.

The Unisys Corporation, the computer company formed by the merger of the Burroughs and Sperry Corporations, said yesterday that it would take a write-down of between $250 million and $275 million, causing a ''substantial'' fourth-quarter loss. Company officials say they did not know if the write-down would wipe out the profits of Unisys for the year. Such a write-down was expected in the wake of numerous closings of plants and offices belonging to the two merged companies.

DESPITE a sweeping restructuring that has left the Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation saddled with a mountainous debt, several analysts have expressed bullish opinions on the prospects of company, the world's largest maker of glass fiber products. The positive views of analysts on Owens-Cornings, based in Toledo, Ohio, are not reflective as much of the economic factors now aiding the building products industry - notably lower interest rates and improvements in housing starts - as they are of the recapitalization program the company took on to fight a hostile tender offer by the Wickes Companies in August. In warding off Wickes, Owens-Corning assumed an additional $1.5 billion in debt from nine banks to finance its recapitalization, raising its total debt to a huge $2.5 billion. But at the same time, the company announced plans to sell assets - including the aerospace unit it bought for $415 million from Armco Inc. last year - and to sharply reduce its work force of 28,000 employees by 13,000.

To the Editor: For years our union has warned of corruption and the possibility of corruption in New York City's process for awarding contracts to outside companies. No one paid heed; apparently, a union is a suspect source.

To the Editor: Three recent letters about fresh-water wetlands succeed in stating diametrically opposed positions, but none suggest a solution. In ''Wetland Designation on S.I. Is No Blessing'' (Nov. 9), the writer eloquently depicts the plight of the small private-property owner burdened by a wetlands designation. Severe use restrictions, imposed pursuant to the police powers of the state, placed on even small parcels of highly valuable Staten Island real estate result in significant economic loss. Moreover, to contest a designation, property owners must hire a biologist or environmentalist and an attorney - a considerable expense, with no guarantee of defeating the designation.

''Oh Coward!,'' the musical focusing on the songs of Noel Coward, will close after the evening performance on Saturday at the Helen Hayes Theater. Devised by Roderick Cook, the production will have given 56 regular performances and 14 previews.

Representative Charles B. Rangel, the senior black elected official from New York City, yesterday questioned the strategy of the attorneys for two black victims of the racial clash in Howard Beach, Queens, that ended in the death of a third black man. At the same time, he criticized the handling of the case by the Queens District Attorney, John J. Santucci. And at a City Hall news conference yesterday, Mayor Koch and Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward sharply criticized one of the attorneys, Alton H. Maddox Jr., calling on him to have his client cooperate with law-enforcement authorities without setting conditions. Mr. Ward also implied that Mr. Maddox might be motivated, in part, by the money he might make from a wrongful-death lawsuit. Main Counts Dismissed Mr. Maddox, the attorney for Cedric Sandiford, the key witness in the case, and C. Vernon Mason, the attorney for Timothy Grimes, refused to have their clients testify Monday before a Criminal Court hearing in Queens. When they did not testify, the judge in the proceeding, Ernest Bianchi, dismissed charges of murder, manslaughter and assault against three white youths in the Dec. 20 incident.

How about a video pizza (hold the 3-D)? Pizza Hut Inc. has adopted a videotape system to train more than 10,000 employees on such matters as making a pizza, dealing with customers and, of particular importance, increasing home deliveries. The Sony 8-millimeter system replaces conventional films and slide presentations, and was chosen over the more popular half-inch video format because of its smaller size, lower mailing cost and future adaptibility to new training programs, company officials said.

In the waning moments of the old year, some thoughts, some impressions, some misplaced notes surface. When Bill Veeck, one of our most charismatic sports figures, died early in the year, on Jan. 2, his friend Hank Greenberg recalled a moment in his life: ''It was between marriages for Bill, and he fell in love with a young woman when both were in Los Angeles. She was taking a train back to New York, and Bill arranged that at every stop of the train - and there were many over 3,000 miles - she would be presented with a bouquet of roses.'' Brian Bosworth may be the first all-America football player who combs his hair with Crayolas.

President Reagan is expected to make a major new appeal for financing for Nicaragun rebels in an attempt to keep Congress from scuttling a top foreign policy objective, White House officials said today. The officials said the appeal could emerge as a centerpiece of his State of the Union Address next month.

Using a relatively new recycling technique, construction engineers of the Lefrak Organization, a New York developer, are turning old concrete and brick from abandoned buildings into useful material to build a $10 billion waterfront development in Jersey City. The 160-million-square-foot development, to be known as Newport City, will contain 10,000 apartments and 10 million square feet of office space.

Darlene Billings being greeted by her son Lawrence yesterday at the Correctional Institution for Women on Rikers Island where she is being held for sentencing on a felony conviction for assault. They were among the guests at a Christmas party for incarcerated mothers. It was sponsored by the City Correction Department and the Edwin Gould Services for Children for about 50 mothers and about 125 children and family members. (NYT/Vic DeLucia)

International A3-11 U.S.-Honduras war games have begun involving 3,000 United States troops for four months, the armed forces announced. The exercise will include improving airstrips in the southern part of Honduras. Page A1 A U.S.-Soviet New Year's exchange of televised greetings from the two countries' leaders was rejected by Moscow, which cited what it called Washington's negative attitude on arms control issues. A6 Divestment's effect on South Africa is far more ambiguous than its advocates in the United States might have hoped. So far, the departures have tended to benefit the country's barons of corporate power.

Joseph A. Boyd, the chairman of the Harris Corporation of Melbourne, Fla., yesterday was named interim chief executive of the Microelectronics and Computer Technology Corporation in Austin, Tex. He may hold the job just for a matter of weeks until a permanent successor is named. Dr. Boyd is replacing Adm. Bobby R. Inman, who announced in September that he would resign as the head of the computer research consortium at the end of the year.

Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone, defending his Government's decision to breach a decade-old ceiling on military spending, said today that the action did not mean Japan would become a military power. He said the policy change had been made reluctantly to help Japan keep pace with its military needs. Nevertheless, the abandonment of the policy startled many people and touched off criticism from opposition parties. There was talk of a possible opposition boycott of Parliament, an action that could undermine the Government's hopes for an overhaul of the tax system.

The Public Securities Association has announced that the Government National Mortgage Association, known as Ginnie Mae, is converting its $250 million market of outstanding mortgage-backed securities from bearer form to a book-entry system, an electronic form of record-keeping whereby all ownership is transferred by computer, beginning Friday. All Ginnie Mae securities will be recorded in book-entry form by Oct. 1.

Short-term interest rates continued to climb yesterday as demand for credit to cover year-end needs intensified. But a late rally helped the longer-term Treasury debt issues recover most of their earlier losses. For example, the key long bond, the 7.5 percent issue of 2016, was offered late in the day at 100 23/32, down 3/32, for a yield of 7.44 percent. Earlier the bond was down 10/32 and the yield was as high as 7.46 percent.

Liberation Graphics, a wholesaler in Alexandria, Va., has signed an exclusive agreement with Mezhdunarodnaya Kniga, the Soviet book exporting agency, under which 500 Soviet posters a year will become available at retail outlets in this country. Only 10 days after the contract was signed, the first samples are already on sale at a Connecticut Avenue bookstore, Common Concerns, at capitalist prices: $10 for the smaller 19-by-25-inch size and $15 for 36-by-26.

Lawrence Taylor was named yesterday as the National Football League's most valuable player by The Associated Press. The 6-foot-3-inch, 245-pound outside linebacker of the Giants is only the second defensive player to achieve that honor.
Soviet Bars TV Greetings A renewed exchange of televised New Year's greetings by President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev was called untimely by Moscow.

WHETHER New Year's Day is celebrated on Jan. 1 according to the Gregorian calendar, in September or October as the Jews' Rosh ha-Shanah or in midwinter by Asians, foods serve as edible talismans to assure luck, happiness or prosperity in the coming year. The notion, for example, that eating gold-colored food will put money in your pocket is common in Peru, where papas a la huancaina, a potato dish tinted with tumeric or with a saffron-colored spice called tadillo, is served on New Year's Eve. In China, dumplings made from golden egg pancakes, crisply gilded spring rolls and oranges are the aureate foods appropriate for the Chinese New Year's celebrations in midwinter. The Chinese also value fish. A whole one is preferred, suggesting that prosperity has favored you with more than you can eat.

TONIGHT there will be revelers, of course, who will be satisfied simply hearing chorus after chorus of ''Auld Lang Syne'' interspersed with the hits of '86. At the same time there will be some 2,800 other celebrants whose evening will be filled with gentler melodies, such as ''Come Into the Garden, Maude,'' ''The Moon Has Raised Her Lamp Above,'' ''Watchman! What of the Night?'' and ''The Dicky Bird and the Owl.'' And about an hour before the New Year is rung in, the appetites of 300 of these fortunates will be sated with such savories as Victorian bisquits and Chatterly cheese rounds, and with sweets such as lemon curd in pastry cups, Yorkshire fat rascals and Richmond maids of honor. The gala, billed as ''An Evening of Victorian Songs and Music,'' begins in Carnegie Hall at 8 P.M. It is a delicious tie-in: The hall, still celebrating its restoration to its former splendor, opened in 1891 at the height of the Victorian era.

The City Council today approved a commemorative park to honor the author Jack Kerouac, chronicler of the 1950's Beat Generation. The approval came despite arguments that the action would glorify drug abuse. The lone dissenter on the seven member council, former Mayor Brenden Flemming, said approval of the park would honor Kerouac's way of life, which he found objectionable.

John T. Dolan, co-founder of the National Conservative Political Action Committee, a leading force in the New Right, died Sunday at his home here after a long illness. He was 36 years old. Mr. Dolan, widely known as Terry, had been in failing health for several years and withdrew from leadership of the committee six months ago. The immediate cause of death was listed as congestive heart failure, which the committee said his doctor attributed to diabetes and pernicious anemia.

The expression was not new to anyone who has frequented Madison Square Garden in recent seasons. The jaw was stern, the eyes were focused and the overall attitude was bold, almost daring, confidence. Yet the player with those looks was not Bernard King, the Knick forward whose scoring often was as close to unstoppable as one can imagine. It was Gerald Wilkins, and the results were just as thrilling. The second-year guard, who has devoloped into the Knicks' most exciting player, led the team to its most exciting victory of the season last night by scoring 12 of his 29 points during a furious fourth-quarter rally. It helped erase a 10-point deficit and culminated in a 103-97 triumph over the Washington Bullets.

The Supreme Court today unanimously upheld the convictions of five former military junta members accused of complicity in the torture and killing of thousands of political prisoners. But the court, on a vote of 4 to 1, slightly reduced the prison sentences of two of the defendants, former President Roberto Viola and Orlando Agosti, former commander of the air force.

Negotiations between the Government and railroad engineers began here today in an effort to end a two-week-old strike. The strike, among the worst in the last two decades, has tied up rail traffic and angered holiday travelers. It has come at the same time as a walkout by dockworkers and seamen and strikes by workers on the Paris subway and bus systems.

An underground Shiite Moslem group asserted early today that it had killed three Lebanese Jewish hostages in retaliation for Israeli shelling of southern Lebanon. The Shiite group, the Organization of the Oppressed on Earth, made the assertion in a statement that identified the victims as Youssef Yahuda Benesti, Henri Menn and Elie Srour. All three were kidnapped in West Beirut in the last two years.

Glen Pomeroy, a retired industrial engineer from Bettendorf, Iowa, has a lot of time on his hands, but he's getting weary of giving up more than three hours of it just to see a pro football game on TV. He also has a vague sense that most of that time is spent watching something other than the game.

The Security Pacific Corporation and the Nevada National Bancorporation said they had reached an agreement for a subsidiary of Security Pacific to acquire the Reno-based bank holding corporation for $38 million.

Ending a 19-day special session that had set suburban and New York City lawmakers against each other, the State Legislature voted today to finance a rebuilding of the city's mass-transit system and a three-year freeze of its fares. The vote averted the immediate fare increases on the city's subway, bus and commuter rail lines that had been threatened by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. The legislation won approval after Democrats, in an effort to appease Republicans from suburban areas, agreed to increased spending for the rebuilding of highways and to direct state aid for commuter rail lines. A Postponed Decision Although the legislation averts immediate fare increases and allows a five-year $8.6 billion M.T.A. capital-construction program to begin on the city's transit system and commuter rail lines, it does not fully resolve the transit matter.
