After weeks of proposals and counterproposals, the Legislature was unable to agree on how to raise the final $735 million for the program, and the measure puts off until March 15 that politically divisive decision. Governor Cuomo's original proposal, for a nickel-a-gallon increase in the gasoline tax, was blocked by suburban Republicans.

A former major general in the New York Army National Guard, Bernard G. Ehrlich, resigned yesterday as a director of the Wedtech Corporation, a South Bronx military contractor, according to the company. A Wedtech attorney, Martin Pollner, said that Mr. Ehrlich, a former law partner of Representative Mario Biaggi, cited ''personal reasons'' in resigning from the board.

A Manhattan judge read the diary of Jennifer Levin ''from cover to cover'' yesterday but said he would not rule for perhaps several weeks on whether it could be used in the defense of Robert E. Chambers Jr., the man accused of killing her. The diary, a black-bound book with a heart drawn on the back, was handed to the judge, Justice Howard E. Bell, in State Supreme Court in Manhattan late yesterday morning by the lawyer for the Levin family, Jeffrey Newman.

Patrick Jackson, a computer technician, reacting to a divorce decree, recently paid his wife's $1,000 legal fees in 400 pounds of pennies. Her lawyer, Robert Silva, is incensed. He has asked the Family Court in Newport to find Mr. Jackson in contempt and order him to remove the pennies and replace them with a more manageable check.

EVERY dental patient has a dream: that cavities could simply be washed away and that the torture of the drill and even the annoyance of the anesthesia could be forever done away with. Now a chemical process for removing tooth decay is bringing this dream closer to reality. The process, which has already ended the need for anesthesia and drilling for many, is known as the Caridex Caries Removal System, and was introduced in the United States last February. Last month it became available in Europe.

For many Israeli legal scholars, civil rights campaigners and security experts, a police commission's announcement Monday clearing Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of complicity in the 1984 killing of two Palestinian bus hijackers is hardly a reason for national joy. Too many wounds, they say, were inflicted on the Israeli legal system and on the rule of law by Mr. Shamir and other members of the Israeli Cabinet throughout the affair for anyone to celebrate. The only thing happy about the conclusion of the episode, these Israelis say, is that it closes one of the most troubling chapters in Israel's modern history - a chapter involving the deaths of handcuffed captives in the custody of Israeli agents, apparently a cover-up by an intelligence service, presidential pardons without any investigations and a myriad other challenges to the rule of law in Israel. Cloud of Suspicion For Prime Minister Shamir and his defenders, there is no doubt that the occasion was one for celebration. Mr. Shamir was under suspicion of having approved of the beating deaths of the two Palestinian cousins, Subhi and Majid Abu-Jumas, who were captured after hijacking an Israeli bus near Ashkelon in April 1984, and of sanctioning a subsequent effort by the head of Shin Beth, the domestic intelligence service, to cover up of the killings.

This holiday season has been marked by a flurry of public service announcements on radio and television stations around the country urging people who drink intoxicating beverages not to drive. ''Drunk driving is a deadly enemy that never takes a holiday,'' one announcement says. ''If you've been drinking, designate a driver to get you home safely.'' The announcements, using symbols, logotypes and themes developed by the Federal Department of Transportation, are the latest phase of a public awareness campaign by the broadcast industry that has become both ambitious and intense - and for good reason.
Tomorrow is New Year's Day. Following are holiday schedules: Parking - Sunday rules.

A highly accurate test for seminal fluid in sexual assault cases has been marketed by Humagen Inc., a diagnostics company in Charlottesville, Va. The test, developed by scientists at the University of Virginia with a grant from the F.B.I., is more sensitive than other tests because it employs monoclonal antibodies that detect minute quantities of seminal fluid even if the assailant lacked spermatozoa.
Pietro Cardinal Parente, one of the Roman Catholic Church's leading theologians and the oldest member of the College of Cardinals, died Monday, the Vatican announced today. He was 95 years old.

After a dozen years of futile efforts to raise the temperature at which materials become superconducting, researchers at the University of Houston and at A.T.&T. Bell Laboratories in New Jersey have achieved sudden and substantial increases. The discovery has vast implications for such diverse fields as electrical transmission and generation, energy storage and the generation of fusion energy. Possible Applications The achievements also mean that superconductivity, in which materials lose all resistance to electricity, can be more widely applied for scientific research and could substantially reduce the cost of the proposed superconducting atom smasher with a 60-mile acceleration ring. If used in electrical lines, according to one of the researchers, the technology could save billions of dollars in energy lost in transmission.

John Tonelli's first return to the metropolitan area since he was traded to Calgary by the Islanders late last season was rather impressive tonight. The hard-working Tonelli first tied the game against the Devils when he scored a goal with 5 minutes 35 seconds to go in the third period. He scored again with 23 seconds remaining to give Calgary a 4-3 triumph over New Jersey at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

Robert Endicott Osgood, an expert on foreign and military policy who taught at Johns Hopkins University for the last 25 years, died Sunday in Washington after suffering a heart attack. He was 65 years old and lived in Chevy Chase, Md. Dr. Osgood went to Johns Hopkins in 1961 as Christian A. Herter Professor of American Foreign Policy in the School of Advanced International Studies. He took a leave in 1969 to serve for a year as a staff aide on the National Security Council, headed by Henry A. Kissinger, in the Nixon Administration.

The tournament bridge world often serves to bring together in marriage two players who are widely separated geographically. The ultimate in this area occurred yesterday in New York City, when Tom Snow, one of the managers of the prestigious Cavendish Club, married Sue Hobley of Sydney, Australia. Since she was 19, and had been playing the game for just two years, Mrs. Snow has been a virtually automatic selection for the Australian women's team. She has competed in five world championships, and in 1985 was a member of the Australian team that captured the Far East Championship.

A Washington dispatch yesterday about post-election bonuses for employees of the National Republican Senatorial Committee misstated the origin of Thomas C. Griscom's bonus. Senator John Heinz, the Pennsylvania Republican who was chairman of the committee, made the decision to grant $50,000 to Mr. Griscom, the executive director. Mr. Griscom consulted the Senator on the other bonuses that were given.

Debt * Citicorp sold $50 million of 91-day paper at an average interest rate of 6.435 percent, down from 6.458 percent last week. It also sold $50 million of 182-day paper at an average rate of 6.10 percent, up from 6.096 percent.

Robert Getchell, the Hofstra University athletic director for the last 11 years, has resigned to accept a position with Meeting Management Associates, a division of Austin Travel as director of its newly created sports travel program. . . . Queen Elizabeth II's New Year honors list includes three sports figures. The former British Open champion Sandy Lyle was made a member of the Order of the British Empire.The racing driver Frank Williams, who was crippled in a car crash in March, was made a commander in the Order of the British Empire, and the soccer goalie Pat Jennings was made an officer of the Order of the British Empire.

Gov. George Deukmejian named five men and a woman as finalists today for three vacancies on the California Supreme Court. The vacancies were created Nov. 4 when the state's voters removed three justices who had voted to overturn scores of death sentences imposed by lower courts. As expected, Mr. Deukmejian included a woman and a Hispanic candidate on his list of finalists. In the election campaign, he indicated that he would try to appoint a woman to the court in place of Chief Justice Rose Elizabeth Bird, the court's first female justice, and a Hispanic-American to succeed Associate Justice Cruz Reynoso.

The Pepsi-Cola Bottling Group said it had acquired the San Francisco-area Pepsi-Cola bottling operation, franchises in Eureka, Calif., and in Reno and a 50 percent interest in the bottling operation in Oroville, Calif., from the New Century Beverage Company, owned by the Campodonico family of San Francisco. Pepsi-Cola Bottling, a subsidiary of Pepsico Inc., declined to disclose terms of the deal.

Sales of new homes fell in November for the seventh time in the last eight months, the Government said today. Many analysts blamed soaring prices for the decline. The Commerce Department said new single-family homes were sold at an annual rate of 661,000 units last month, down 2.2 percent from the October sales pace. Sales had fallen 7.8 percent in October. The rates are seasonally adjusted.

This sunwashed harbor town, home to the America's Cup sailing races, abounds with souvenirs, freshly painted storefronts and shopkeepers eagerly awaiting an invasion of American tourists. The only thing that Fremantle lacks, so far, is the American tourists. Although outdoor cafes and newly designed malls are bustling with visitors, most conversations are in the Australian idiom, with relatively few Americans or Europeans in the crowds. ''People expected a lot more,'' said Barbara McKeown, manager of the Oasis women's clothing store in Fremantle. ''Before the races started, everybody was saying it was going to skyrocket, and it never did.''

Organic Foods by Mail The Center for Science in the Public Interest, a Washington-based consumer organization, has organized Americans for Safe Food, a project to encourage the production and sale of foods produced without pesticides, herbicides, hormones and other synthetic chemicals. The group has developed a list of mail-order sources for organic food products, the majority of which it says have been certified organic by independent testing and inspection agencies. Copies of the list are available from Americans for Safe Food, Center for Science in the Public Interest, 1501 16th Street NW, Washington, D.C. 20036. All-Purpose Sip The conventional wisdom - that champagne can complement any food - has been given considerable encouragement from a study commissioned by Korbel, the largest producer of sparkling wine in California. Korbel Brut was tasted by 10 professional tasters in combination with 56 foods in a study conducted by Palatex, a New York-based food and beverage research company. Each food was camouflaged in tasteless edible wrappings such as lettuce leaves, bland crepes or wonton wrappers.
Sheriff's deputies, acting on an informant's tip, stopped Dwight Gooden last year and searched his car for drugs, it was revealed today. No drugs were found and no charges were filed.

The Koch administration yesterday sued Citisource Inc. and five company officers and directors, including Stanley M. Friedman, the former Bronx Democratic leader, for more than $14 million in damages over a city contract for a hand-held computer. The suit, filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan, accuses the company and the executives of fraud in obtaining the $22.7 million contract to manufacture the computer for the city's Parking Violations Bureau. Mr. Friedman and another defendant named in the civil suit, Marvin B. Kaplan, the chairman of Citisource, were among four defendants found guilty of criminal charges, including racketeering, conspiracy and mail fraud, by a Federal jury on Nov. 25.
Four players of the Swift Current Broncos were killed today when their team bus slid off an icy road into a ditch en route to a Western Hockey League game.

RICHARD DANNHARDT remembers the day two years ago when Homer Moeller first toured the Electrolux Company's vacuum cleaner factory on the rolling outskirts of this small Appalachian city. He had scarcely begun to show off the energy management prowess of the plant's only computer when Mr. Moeller smiled, said ''that's fine'' and strode out. The people at the 30-year-old Bristol plant soon learned why Mr. Moeller (pronounced MIL-ler) was in such a hurry. Less than two months after taking command of manufacturing strategy for Electrolux, he boldly announced plans to close its aging complex in Old Greenwich, Conn., (the company has its headquarters in Stamford) and to transform the Bristol plant into a model of automation and modern manufacturing practices.

Three Atlantic City police officers and a former officer were indicted yesterday on charges they used cocaine that had been stolen from evidence at police headquarters, prosecutors said. An eight-count indictment handed up by an Atlantic County grand jury accused one of the officers of stealing an unknown quantity of the drug from a vehicle in police custody nearly five years ago, said the chief assistant county prosecutor, Steven Rosenfeld.

Despite Steve Grogan's outstanding performance as the backup quarterback against the Miami Dolphins last week, enabling the New England Patriots to win the American Conference East title and make the playoffs, Tony Eason will start at quarterback Sunday against the Denver Broncos in the conference semifinal.

An Iranian exile group in Paris said today that Iranian soldiers protesting Government policies had set fire to a barracks of the Revolutionary Guards in Teheran. The exile group, Mujahedeen Khalq, said in a telex from its Paris headquarters that the fire had occurred Monday and heavily damaged the Vali Asr barracks.

IN the last few years East Harlem has strengthened its commercial base. So far, most of the investment has been made by local entrepreneurs who have opened or renovated and expanded modest retail businesses there. But at the neighborhood's southern edge, on 106th Street near Park Avenue, a nearly vacant and rundown 11-story building that for years was a film and television studio - the one-time home of the ''Howdy Doody'' show - has been turned into an office building. The city's Department of Transportation became the first office tenant when it signed a lease earlier this fall for 52,000 square feet of space. Its Bureau of Traffic Control is among the agencies moving into the space.

The Miami Dolphins have released Lyle Blackwood and signed nine players as free agents. Blackwood, a 14-year veteran at safety, started the first five games of 1986 for Miami in place of his brother Glenn, who was on injured reserve. Lyle Blackwood, 35, was placed on injured reserve Oct. 10 with a severely sprained ankle, and said at the time he did not expect the Dolphins to call him back.

The Polish security police, in a change of tactics in efforts to suppress underground publications, have begun confiscating the cars of distributors. The underground press has responded with its own tactic. Seven of the illicit publishing houses, which together produce 200 books a year in editions of up to 10,000, have banded together and formed an underground insurance company to cover the confiscation of cars, paper and materials.

The Soviet Union today rejected a proposal by the United States for an exchange of televised New Year's greetings between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, citing what it said was Washington's negative attitude on key arms control issues. The White House said in this desert resort, where Mr. Reagan is spending a vacation, that he would beam a broadcast message to the Soviet people anyway, using the Voice of America. Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman, said the President hoped the Russians would not jam the planned broadcast on New Year's Day. In Moscow, the Foreign Ministry spokesman, Gennadi I. Gerasimov, said the Soviet Union saw no basis for an exchange of messages in view of what he said was the United States reluctance to adhere to informal arms control agreements reached in Iceland.

''A Clockwork Orange,'' the novel by Anthony Burgess, contained 21 chapters when it was published in England in 1962. But the American edition published a year later omitted the final chapter, in which Alex, the violent young protagonist, becomes bored with violence and opts for a different kind of future. W. W. Norton plans to reissue a hard-cover edition of ''A Clockwork Orange'' in spring, this time with the missing chapter. The new edition will also include differing explanations - from the author and from the book's editor - of why Chapter 21 was originally omitted.

A senior Vatican official, discussing the controversy over John Cardinal O'Connor's itinerary in Israel, said today that the Vatican did not object to Cardinal's original plan to meet with senior Israeli leaders, but to the fact that the meetings were scheduled in Jerusalem. The Holy See does not recognize Jerusalem as as the Israeli capital. The Cardinal's decision, since reversed, to meet the President, the Prime Minister and other senior Government representatives in Jerusalem was termed a ''mistake'' by the senior Vatican official, who said a Vatican diplomat had urged the Cardinal to change his plans.

A former guard at a Nazi concentration camp has been stripped of his United States citizenship after he failed to appear at a hearing in Federal Court, the authorities said today. The former guard, Stefan Leili, who admitted shooting a young French Jewish prisoner in the back, fled to West Germany last August, they said. His citizenship was stripped Monday when he did not appear at a hearing on a Government motion to rescind his naturalization papers, the officials said.

ONE day I was standing in a bathroom in City Hall washing my hands when the City Council President stepped up to the sink beside me. (I will stop here, lest I precipitate another city scandal, to say that at the time the City Council President was a woman.) We began to chat, and eventually our chat turned to matters of moment, and eventually the matters of moment became newsworthy. I left the bathroom with a story. After years of worrying that the best stories were coming out of conversations in the men's room, I also left with the conviction that journalism was going to be all right for women after all. My mind goes back to that day when I think of what I consider the worst scare tactic employed by people opposed to the proposed equal rights amendment. This was the suggestion that passage of the measure would lead to unisex bathrooms. (Nearly as objectionable was the use of the word ''unisex,'' which should by law be applied only to certain hair salons to let you know that they are the kind of places you want to avoid.) I can assure everyone that if a piece of legislation took away restricted access to the jane - as I prefer to call the female john - I would march in the streets to protest its passage.

In retaliation for European trade policies that the United States says cost American farmers about $400 million a year, President Reagan plans higher duties on imported gin, brandy, cheese and inexpensive white wine, it was announced today. The decision, which is likely to increase the prices Americans pay for those and other products, was disclosed as the President and his wife vacationed at the home of the publisher Walter H. Annenberg. The trade action, which had been threatened, followed long negotiations between the United States and the European Community over compensation for high tariffs imposed by the community on American grain-feed imports to Spain, which was once a lucrative market for American corn and sorghum.

The Securities and Exchange Commission today announced two new insider-trading cases, involving a Chicago merger lawyer and a top executive of a high-technology company in California. The two individuals agreed to give up more than $340,000 in illegal profits, and the lawyer, who neither admitted nor denied the charges, agreed to pay a penalty of more than $228,000. The commission said today that the two cases were not related to its continuing insider-trading inquiry stemming from the Ivan F. Boesky case. Nevertheless, some market experts lamented that the cases provided further evidence that the illegal use of private corporate information by investors is widespread.
TO THE LIVING SECTION: Thank you and congratulations on your Food & Fitness article [ Dec. 17 ] ''Helping Nondrinkers Feel Part of the Party.''

Another viewer with a gripe - and a solution - is Richard Graham, a 56-year-old prop worker at the Metropolitan Opera. His pet peeve is the gap between the instant a penalty flag is thrown and the moment when broadcasters tell television viewers there is a penalty.

Following is a sampling, provided by the National Association of Broadcasters, of the recent public service announcements on drunken driving that have been aired around the country using local broadcast personalities: ''I'm (personality gives name). The holiday season is a time for giving . . . and for sharing joy with your friends.

New Woman magazine has reported that its January issue closed with 56 ad pages, a 17.4 percent gain over the previous year, while its February issue closed with 75.1 ad pages, a 25.5 percent gain over a year ago.

John Cardinal O'Connor met with King Hussein of Jordan today and said afterward that he was worried about the consequences of deepening tensions between Israel and its Arab neighbors and the Palestinians. The Cardinal, who is the Archbishop of New York, also told Jordan's Prime Minister and Foreign Minister that the Palestinian people have the right to ''self-determination'' and that Israel has a right to secure borders. ''Ultimately,'' the Cardinal said at a brief news conference, ''I can't see how a very severe conflagration can be avoided in the Middle East unless there is an honest and sincere dialogue by all parties about the rights of people in the area.'' The Cardinal, who is on a nine-day visit to the Middle East that has been clouded by a diplomatic controversy over appointments with Israeli leaders, spent more than two hours at the royal palace having lunch with the King.

CHASE MANHATTAN used to provide a friend. Manny was always on your side at Manufacturers Hanover. One bank said you could call it Irving. In its latest statement, Bankers Trust says it is providing a Relationship Manager to its private clients, who will be given the name, address and telephone number of this Relationship Manager.

Among the losers of 1986 you would probably have to include Vice President Bush, but you have to be careful. He may have a key role to play here in the coming year. You can never tell about Vice Presidents. John Adams said: ''My country in its wisdom contrived from me the most insignificant office that ever the invention of man contrived or his imagination conceived. . . . Today I am nothing, but tomorrow I may be everything.''

To the Editor: Senator Paul S. Trible Jr., in his diatribe against the United Nations (Op-Ed, Dec. 15), engages in considerable overkill. He castigates the world organization for such faults as administrative and budgetary shortcomings. These and other charges are not without factual basis, although he exaggerates. However, they are being corrected as the U.N. is now serious about reform. Would that the U.S. Congress, of which Senator Trible is a member, were as concerned about improving itself. Bogged down in partisan politics and overlapping committees, it flounders considerably.

TO THE LIVING SECTION: To readers interested in growing their own saffron, this reader, in response to Ellen Szita's article ''The Saffron Harvest Is In and the U.S. Has Got It'' [ Dec. 10 ] , would like to note that saffron can be grown in the New York area. The Crocus sativus bulbs are readily available.

When the Nobel Prizes were awarded in Stockholm earlier this month, there was a winner in the audience, too. George W. Johnson, president of George Mason University, had gone there to watch one of his faculty members receive the economics prize. But, in a larger sense, the prize for the economist, James M. Buchanan, was an honor for Mr. Johnson as well, in that it called worldwide attention to his development of their school. Founded in 1957 in an old high school building in a suburban shopping center, George Mason, with 17 students, was at first affiliated with the University of Virginia. Today it serves 12,300 undergraduates and 5,260 graduate students as a state university on wooded campus of 600 acres in Fairfax, Va.

Robert Collins, a Federal judge in New Orleans, took charge of the Roland Barbay steroid case yesterday and scheduled arguments to decide today whether the Louisiana State University defensive end would be eligible to play in the Sugar Bowl game against Nebraska tomorrow despite test results showing he used banned chemicals. Barbay was declared ineligible last Friday, but he has been practicing with the Tigers since Monday under an order issued by a state district judge, Gerald Federoff.

The President's Commission on Americans Outdoors sent the White House a summary report today urging a ''community by community'' effort to preserve open space for recreation. The report asked President Reagan to ''lead a crusade'' to improve and protect open land and natural resources for future generations. But it suggested that the chief responsibility for the effort be placed on local government, private industry and volunteer organizations. Under the recommendations, the Federal Government would create a $1 billion trust fund to help acquire and maintain open space.

By leaping into the production of a new jumbo jet, the McDonnell Douglas Corporation is entering a growth market, but one that may not yield big profits, analysts said yesterday. ''My gut feeling is that they will sell enough airplanes to break even and not much more,'' said Howard Mager, an aerospace analyst for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette in New York. Analysts said the MD-11 aircraft, which got McDonnell's go-ahead on Monday, would be ideal for many airlines - particularly those that fly to international destinations from ''secondary hubs,'' such as Chicago or Dallas, rather than from primary gateways like New York. Improved Efficiency That is because the MD-11, although based on McDonnell Douglas's three-engine DC-10, will be much more fuel-efficient and have a flying range of up to 8,870 miles - an increase of more than 30 percent. It will also carry as many as 405 passengers, compared with a maximum of 380 for the DC-10, and will have an advanced cockpit that will require only a two-man crew, compared with three for the DC-10.

T. Boone Pickens Jr., the oilman, issued some ire along with the eggnog and holiday cheer at the company Christmas party. He urged his 400 employees at Mesa Petroleum to cancel their subscriptions to the local newspapers to protest ''negative reporting'' of Amarillo news. A week later an uneasy truce had been called between two of this Panhandle city's most powerful corporate citizens. But the episode served to highlight the often stormy relationship between Mr. Pickens, a shrewd businessman whose efforts to take over other companies have attracted national attention, and his hometown, a city of 150,000 people far from the financial capitals. Adept at the national public relations game, Mr. Pickens has never quite received the same respect from the local press.
The Supreme Court today struck down a decree that liberalized Spain's law on abortion.

The Morgan Grenfell Group, a leading London merchant bank, quit today as advisers to Guinness P.L.C., the brewer that is the target of a Government investigation. And Roger Seelig, a director of Morgan Grenfell's securities subsididary who was considered one of the stars of its mergers and acquisitions staff, resigned today because of questions raised about his role in a $3.6 billion acquisition by Guinness last spring. Mr. Seelig, 41 years old, led the team that advised Guinness in its bid for the Distillers Company. He reportedly earned almost $300,000 a year.

THE current program at Film Forum 1 shows off contemporary American animation at its most exciting. It showcases three ingenious film makers, Jane Aaron, Robert Breer and Maureen Selwood, whose styles are distinct and disparate yet mesh well together. Miss Aaron's work has the lightest and most whimsical style, Mr. Breer's is the most varied and intricate, and Miss Selwood's has the greatest range and fluidity. Together, these short films present a rich and innovative sampler of an art that, demonstrably, is thriving.

One of the most breath-taking sights in Washington is the Mormon Temple, whose slender, glistening spires loom suddenly over westbound Beltway drivers as they top a crest in the road at Kensington, Md.
The New York Mercantile Exchange will close at 1 P.M. today for the New Year's holiday.

The Justice Department will consider turning over additional Iran arms investigations to a special Federal prosecutor named earlier this month, department officials said today. The move could significantly broaden the power of the special prosecutor, Lawrence E. Walsh, who has already been given authority to investigate American-sanctioned arms sales to the Iranian Government and the diversion of profits to Nicaraguan rebels. The other cases involve private citizens and Iranian agents accused of the unauthorized sale of American weapons to Iran. There are more than a dozen such prosecutions around the country, and they are apparently independent of any effort to aid the Nicaraguan rebels, known as contras.

Nearly two weeks after surgery in which a brain cancer was removed from William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, his doctors said again today that he was fully conscious and periodically sat in a bedside chair. The statement from Georgetown University Hospital gave no indication that Mr. Casey's condition had changed since late last week, when the hospital said the same thing in its last report on the patient. And it leaves a number of crucial questions unanswered, including when or whether he will be capable of talking, walking or resuming his duties. White House officials said today that President Reagan had not talked to Mr. Casey since his brain surgery. They did not say why. Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman, said he did not believe ''it was appropriate at this stage'' to explain if there was a medical reason why Mr. Reagan had spoken with Mr. Casey's wife, Sophia, but not to Mr. Casey. Nancy Reagan, the President's wife, has also spoken with Mrs. Casey. Mr. Speakes, who was with the President in Palm Springs, Calif., said he did not know if Mr. Casey was able to speak.

A leaky valve at the Nine Mile 2 nuclear power station in upstate New York could postpone the plant's commercial operations for up to four months and could add more than $240 million to the plant's multibillion-dollar cost. The 1,080-megawatt complex has already cost more than any other nuclear plant in the United States. With the added expenses included, the final price could surpass $6 billion.

When a player is traded from one team to another, his jewelry goes along with him, generally. But Butch Lee was gone so fast from the Atlanta Hawks that his N.C.A.A. championship ring just now caught up.

HARD to believe but true: ''The Nutcracker'' is still with us. Moreover, the New York City Ballet's production continues to come up with newcomers in major roles. Sunday night's performance at the New York State Theater included a guest artist, John Meehan, as the Sugarplum Fairy's Cavalier while the Saturday matinee featured David Otto in the same role. Mr. Meehan, originally with the Australian Ballet and seen in New York mainly with American Ballet Theater, has partnered the City Ballet's Merrill Ashley in frequent freelance appearances. Unsurprisingly, she was his Sugarplum Fairy on this occasion - with dazzling results.

Skies were clear today over the busy airport here, a welcome sight to airline officials after two days of fog that delayed thousands of flights. Fog cut the visibility to 1,000 feet or less Sunday morning and Monday morning, testing tempers and costing the airlines hundreds of thousands of dollars in a major travel period.

Little has changed over the years. He projects the same mannered style and manicured appearance as always, ever polite, ever respectful, and during the work week, ever casual. Today, walking among his San Francisco 49ers as they practiced for their playoff game Sunday against the Giants, the unbuttoned collars of his blue oxford shirt flapped lazily above a white cardigan sweater, buttoned only once, at the bottom. The brown corduroy slacks he wore looked too comfortable to be new.

A provision of Federal copyright law designed to prevent the sale of pirate recordings and cheap foreign copies of American albums has made hundreds of imported recordings unavailable in the United States. Alternative versions of songs and albums, collector packages, and compact disks that have not been released here have been the targets of legal action by American record companies that has caused the removal of many selections from record-store shelves. The provision, Section 602(a) of the 1976 United States Copyright Act, deals with pirated recordings and ''parallel imports'' (imported versions of works copyrighted in the United States). The section prohibits the unauthorized importation of works to which an American company holds the copyright, whether or not that material is in print in the United States.

The chairman of the New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission, in his first public criticism of the industry he regulates, said yesterday that the city's medallion cab system is fraught with ''fundamental structural problems'' and that the public is not being properly served. In an interview, the chairman, Gorman Gilbert, said that after six months in office, he believes inadequate service by medallion cabs can be traced to past mistakes by his agency and to lack of competition in the industry. He also said that New Yorkers who rely on nonmedallion cabs rather than yellow cabs are receiving more efficient and polite service in cleaner cars. Mr. Gilbert was referring to the estimated 5,000 ''black cars'' that primarily service corporate accounts and 20,000 community car-service vehicles that are mainly found in the boroughs outside Manhattan. Those cars cannot legally pick up street hails and, so, primarily answer telephone requests.

Bide-a-Wee, a shelter for animals, has begun a three-month print and broadcast campaign to raise $4.2 million in funds to rebuild and reopen its Manhattan shelter on East 38th Street between First Avenue and the East River.

Paul Hackett, a Dallas Cowboys assistant coach who had been regarded as one of the leading candidates for the Southern California head football coaching job, has withdrawn his name from consideration, The Los Angeles Herald Examiner reported yesterday.

P. T. Barnum would have liked Jerome Brown, Miami's defensive tackle, who apparently is a proponent of the hard-sell approach to the biggest college football game of the season. The Fiesta Bowl between Penn State and Miami on Friday night will determine the No. 1 team in the country, but here in the Sun Belt, where the pace is slower and passions burn on a low flame, it cannot hurt to fan emotions whenever possible, drumming up more interest than might already exist. It is called hype and Barnum could not have orchestrated Miami's walkout after a dinner for the two teams Sunday in what is now referred to simply as ''the steak fry incident'' any better than Brown, who claimed that the Hurricanes were miffed by the skits performed by some Penn State players. Came to Play Football No big deal, said Jimmy Johnson, the Miami coach. But then, he added: ''Our players had a skit too. But why carry it out? We said what we came to do, play a football game and go home.''

In describing how Bernie Kosar throws his passes, his coach, Marty Schottenheimer, revealed something of the character of his team, the Cleveland Browns. ''Bernie's not exactly pretty,'' said Schottenheimer. ''He'll throw it sidearm sometimes. But he gets the job done. He's like the Cleveland Browns. We're not pretty but we get the job done.''

The annual New Year's Concert of the Vienna Philharmonic will be televised by PBS at 9 P.M. Thursday, giving American viewers the chance to join a worldwide audience that is expected to number 700 million - by far the largest audience ever gathered for a musical event. The television and radio audience in more than 50 countries will receive a program devoted entirely to the music of the Strauss family of waltz fame. The program's unique popularity puzzles even its originators at ORF, the Austrian broadcasting service, who have been airing these concerts for 47 years.

Gov. William A. O'Neill said yesterday that he would ask the General Assembly to adjust Connecticut's capital-gains tax in 1987 so that the state would not reap a potential $200 million windfall under the new Federal tax law that takes effect tomorrow. Mr. O'Neill said the new law would require ''sweeping changes'' in the way capital projects were paid for through the sale of bonds.

The Farm Credit Funding Corporation, an arm of the Farm Credit System, the nation's largest farm lender, has announced that it does not expect to offer any bonds with maturities of 13 months or more until at least March 2. An official at the corporation noted that, as agricultural business had contracted, financing needs had also come down, reducing the necessity to raise as much cash in the public credit markets as in the past.

REAGAN'S AMERICA. Innocents at Home. By Garry Wills. 472 pages. Doubleday & Company. $19.95. RONALD REAGAN, as Garry Wills sees him, is ''the perfect Scout'' and the ''perfect Hollywood chastity symbol''; a ''company man,'' a ''Doctor Feelgood'' and ''a durable daylight 'bundle of meanings.' '' He is ''the faded idol as reachable ideal'' -''a muscular Christian, an independent Disciple, the Paul Revere of piety.'' More emphatically, ''he is the demagogue as rabble-soother, at a time when people do not need to be stirred up but assuaged, to have anxieties dispelled, complexities resolved.''

Alton H. Maddox Jr., the lawyer whose tactics have become a key element in the investigation of the racial attack in Howard Beach, Queens, is no stranger to the public eye. Over the years, he has frequently and publicly charged Mayor Koch, police officials and the city's district attorneys as being racist or at least insensitive to blacks Either as an adviser or lead counsel, Mr. Maddox and another black lawyer in the Howard Beach case, C. Vernon Mason, have been involved in many of the cases that have arisen in recent years that have involved questions of police brutality and racial attacks on blacks. In the Howard Beach case, Mr. Maddox is representing a key witness, Cedric Sandiford, a victim of the attack, and has advised him not to cooperate with the investigation. Mr. Mason is representing another victim, Timothy Grimes, whose testimony is not considered as important to the case. Similar Strategy The two lawyers have frequently worked in tandem before and have advised clients not to cooperate in investigations because of suspicions that law-enforcement officials were not serious about protecting the rights of blacks.

Gaston Green rushed for 266 yards and three touchdowns to lead U.C.L.A. to a 31-10 rout of Brigham Young in the third Freedom Bowl tonight. Green, a junior being touted for next year's Heisman Trophy, also threw for a score. He increased his season rushing yardage to 1,405, breaking Freeman McNeil's school mark of 1,396 set in 1979.

The Soviet statement rejecting an exchange of New Year's messages reflects disenchantment with the United States' conduct since the collapse of the Iceland summit meeting. It also offers a gloomier assessment of Soviet-American relations at year's end than President Reagan provided in a radio address on Saturday.

A RESTAURANT critic's note pad gets cluttered with all kinds of oddities and observations, not to mention butter smudges, wine stains and sauce splotches, in the course of a year's work. This week concludes another year of investigative dining, roughly 500 field expeditions by my estimate, and I find myself heading into the new year carrying a sack full of undistributed material - sort of like a belated Santa Claus operating with a skewed supply and demand curve. The following random impressions, some timely, some trivial, are my 1986 journalistic nightcap, which clears the agenda and the palate for another year of gustatory sleuthing. Pyrrhic victory of the year: Le Regence in the Plaza Athenee Hotel (East 64th Street), after garnering a two-star review, lost its chef and two assistants to Le Cirque (East 65th Street). Shortly after, the maitre d'hotel left to join a new venture. The Golden Kiwi Award, for keeping nouvelle cuisine alive: Tavern on the Green (Central Park West at 67th Street), which offered a dish in April called ''smoked chicken with strawberries, plums, raspberries and kiwis in a blueberry couli.''
During the Christmas holidays, 287 Polish tourists from three cruise ships stayed in West Germany, officials said today.

A DECADE hence, as pop historians look back on 1986, the year may well be remembered as the most musically conservative one since the early 1960's, when the first, impudent upsurge of rock-and-roll had subsided and Beatlemania had not yet arrived. In Billboard's annual chart tabulation of the year's most popular records, Whitney Houston ranked as the No. 1 artist of the year in combined singles and album sales. The tabulation, covering the 12 months that ended in mid-November, also placed Ms. Houston's eponymously titled debut album, which sold seven million copies, as No. 1 for the year. Ranked second was ''Heart,'' the comeback album by the West Coast rock group of the same name. Rounding out the Top 10 in order were John Cougar Mellencamp's ''Scarecrow,'' ZZ Top's ''Afterburner,'' Dire Straits' ''Brothers in Arms,'' Janet Jackson's ''Control,'' Mr. Mister's ''Welcome to the Real World,'' Sade's ''Promise,'' Phil Collins's ''No Jacket Required,'' and Miami Sound Machine's ''Primitive Love.''
The Detroit Athletic Club has women as members for the first time in 71 years.

As the police were investigating a murder yesterday in Pelham Bay Park in the Bronx yesterday morning, a passer-by found a second body along the same road, 150 yards away. Each body had a gunshot wound to the head but the police said they had no theories about the murders.

A police truck on the sidewalk outside 1 Times Square last night as the department prepared to marshal its crowd control forces for the masses that will descend on the Square tonight. (NYT/Larry C. Morris)

Viewers of college football bowl games this holiday season might notice something different. Instead of the plain old Sun Bowl, they saw the John Hancock Sun Bowl. The Gator Bowl was transformed into the Mazda Gator Bowl. And the matchup between Nebraska and Louisiana State University on New Year's Day will be the USF&G Sugar Bowl. Sponsorship of sporting events by advertisers is not new; it has been done in golf and tennis for years. But never before have companies been so willing to pay for the right to have their names attached to a prestigious event, and never before have the television networks and the event organizers been so eager to oblige.

Stock prices fell on Wall Street for the second consecutive session as weakness in the bond market and year-end tax-related selling continued to take their toll. Trading volume improved, but that was mainly due to maneuvers by corporate investors to capture dividends. The BellSouth Corporation, for instance, led the consolidated active list with volume of 4.4 million shares, helped by two block trades of nearly 2 million shares apiece. Its stock, which fell 7/8, to 58 1/8 yesterday, goes ex-dividend next Monday.

A judge who threw out a confession by Henry Lee Lucas, who once confessed hundreds of killings but then recanted, agreed Tuesday to drop a capital murder charge against him. ''I think we're all a little tired of it,'' State District Judge Brunson Moore said.
Florida became the fifth most populous state in the country in 1986, marking the only change in ranking among the 10 largest states, the Census Bureau said today.

A derailment spilled 15,000 gallons of lye into the Susquehanna River, forcing municipal water intakes to shut for several hours, an official said today. Sixteen cars of a 72-car train derailed near this rural community Monday night, according to a Conrail spokesman who refused to be identified.

A dormant AIDS virus can be stimulated by other viruses into reproducing itself, which may help explain why some people suddenly develop AIDS years after becoming infected, scientists reported today. Researchers at the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases found that an AIDS virus lying dormant in cells could be stimulated into reproducing by exposure to a different family of viruses, DNA viruses. The scientists reported on their work in a new supplement to the December issue of The Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.

All those year-end sports reviews neglected to make note of some remarkable achievements in major league baseball's 1986 season. For the record, then: PITCHERS Lowest winning percentage (minimum of 15 decisions): .263, by Rick Sutcliffe, Chicago Cubs, 5-14.

Governor Cuomo approved legislation today that will allow horse racing teletheaters situated more than 40 miles from race tracks to open without permission from the tracks. Previously, an offtrack betting teletheater needed the approval from tracks in its Offtrack Betting Corporation region to open anywhere in the region.

To the Editor: Reporting the death of the Soviet dissident Anatoly Marchenko (Dec. 10), you say he ''was the first well-known dissident to die in prison.'' But over the last three years, five prominent Soviet human-rights activists and Helsinki monitors have died in prisons and labor camps: three Ukrainian Helsinki Group members, Yuri Lytvyn, 50, a suicide in September 1984; Oleksy Tykhy, teacher, died of medical neglect May 6, 1984, and Vasyl Stus, 47, poet, died Sept. 9, 1985, from illnesses exacerbated by incarceration; Valery Marchenko (no relation), 37, died of kidney failure in a labor camp Oct. 6, 1984, and Aleksei Nikitin, an independent trade union activist, died in 1983.

A couple anonymously honored the teachers of severely handicapped children at a Queens public school by donating $50 to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. The donors, who have a son in the program at P.S. 201 in Flushing, wrote: ''The meaning of the Christmas appeal is brought home to us every day by the selfless spirit and total commitment of our son's teachers. ''These teachers, models of devotion whose concern for the handicapped, society's so-called less fortunate, have given us, parents of a Down's Syndrome child, patience, strength, courage and understanding.''

The Financial Accounting Standards Board, in a move that angered financial institutions, ruled yesterday that home-mortgage lenders must account for ''points'' and other loan-origination fees over the life of a loan, not at once up-front. The ruling by the accounting board will be especially harmful to certain savings and loan associations that have come to depend on points and other fees as an important source of income.

The following statement was signed by Raul Alfonsin, President of Argentina; Miguel de la Madrid, President of Mexico; Andreas Papandreou, Prime Minister of Greece; Rajiv Gandhi, Prime Minister of India; Ingvar Carlsson, Prime Minister of Sweden, and Julius Nyerere, President of Tanzania. It was released Monday in each of their respective capitals and made available to The New York Times by Parliamentarians Global Action, whose membership consists of legislators from 36 countries. On the eve of the new year, we wish to call attention once again to the threat of nuclear war which would affect all the inhabitants of our planet. But we also wish to underline the opportunities which 1987 provides for agreements which can strengthen our common security.

Willie Anderson sank two free throws with five seconds left to seal Georgia's 69-65 victory over Kentucky in their Southeastern Conference game tonight. Georgia improved its record to 8-3 over all and 1-1 in the S.E.C., and Kentucky fell to 6-2 and 0-1. Chad Keesler gave Georgia a seemingly comfortable 64-56 lead when he sank a free throw with 1 minute 6 seconds left in the game. Ten seconds later, Kentucky's James Blackmon completed a 3-point play off a rebound basket to trim the margin to 64-59.

The Reagan Administration's top Middle East official will visit the region early next month to assess Arab-Israeli peace prospects and to demonstrate that American foreign policy is not paralyzed by the Iran arms affair, State Department officials said today. The trip, by Richard W. Murphy, assistant secretary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian affairs, will be the first high-level American visit to the area since the revelations of secret American and Israeli arms shipments to Iran provoked widespread criticism in Arab countries. ''It's important to send the message that we're not dead in the water,'' a senior State Department official said. Phyllis Oakley, a State Department spokesman, said President Reagan, after consultation with Secretary of State George P. Shultz ''decided it would be useful for Assistant Secretary Murphy to travel to the Middle East next month to assess the current situation in the region, including where we are in the peace process, and to review bilateral issues in Egypt, Israel, and Jordan.''

Want to buy a piece of Amtrak? The Reagan Administration seems eager to sell off the passenger railroad's Northeast Corridor system for $1.5 billion. The prospects of Congressional approval are poor, and the President's motive may be merely to include the $1.5 billion on the revenue side of his new budget. Still, the idea is intriguing on the merits.

NBC's ''Nightly News'' broadcast, which has lagged behind the ''CBS Evening News'' for most of the last two decades, won the ratings competition for the fourth quarter of 1986. The ratings, released yesterday, showed that NBC had an average rating of 11.8 for the fourth quarter of 1986, compared with an 11.6 rating for CBS and 10.6 for ABC's ''World News Tonight.''
The Going Out Guide on Saturday misstated the time for a New Year's Day performance of George Bernard Shaw's ''Overruled'' at the South Street Theater. It is at 2:15 P.M.

Seeking to increase its role in the global information marketplace, Canada is building a $57 million information technology center where Canadian entrepreneurs and emerging companies can display their inventions and obtain financial, marketing and management advice. The center, called Exploracom, will also contain a large exhibition area where corporations that manufacture, market or use information technology can demonstrate its applications.

It's clear by now to most Americans that the White House scandal involved some sort of violation of Congressional restrictions on covert operations. Yet many people seem to forget that these restrictions were part of a careful deal worked out between Congress and the executive branch little more than a decade ago to protect our constitutional system while permitting covert operations. Apparently, this tacit deal was not enough, and it ought to be made more binding now. The intelligence scandals of the 1970's revealed that the Central Intelligence Agency, operating as the secret arm of the White House, had regularly acted in ways that threatened constitutional rights and procedures at home and were inconsistent with American principles abroad. The public and Congress alike were shocked by reports of C.I.A. assassination efforts and of spying on Americans -revelations that made a powerful case for simply prohibiting covert operations.

In a move that could further deregulate the banking industry, the Comptroller of the Currency, has asked a Florida court to allow the chartering of hundreds of limited-service banks. According to officials, the Comptroller, Robert L. Clarke, asked a Federal District Court judge in Jacksonville, Fla., last week to vacate a preliminary injunction that prohibits the Comptroller from granting final approval to Federal charters for concerns that offer less than a full range of banking services.
Jaguar P.L.C., the British auto manufacturer, said it had produced a record 41,437 cars this year, up 8 percent from 1985.

WELCOME to the universe of Food-1987, in which the forces of nutrition and convenience will determine the shape of things to come: what consumers buy, what supermarkets sell, what restaurants serve, what manufacturers produce. Periodically these forces will join - a nutritious meal will also be a tasty, quick one. More often, however, the need for convenience in the coming year will outweigh the desire for healthful food on the table. The forecast is gloomy, then, for products and services designed to save money - warehouse supermarkets and generic products (unbranded canned and packaged goods) - since speed of food purchase and preparation will likely override concerns about price. But manufacturers of microwave ovens, merchants of carryout food, fruit and vegetable farmers and ranchers who raise leaner meats should have cause to celebrate. The news is also good for purveyors of ethnic cuisines that rely more on vegetables and grains than on meats. While the future importance of nutrition is unquestionable, the direction nutrition concerns will take is in doubt. Some experts, such as Fabian Linden, executive director of the consumer research center of the Conference Board, a marketing information service, believe that concern is increasing. ''We are continuously creating a more sophisticated species of Americans, and they are taking a more cerebral approach to eating,'' he said.

A New Bedford metals company agreed today to pay a million-dollar fine for violating Federal environmental laws, the largest such fine ever levied. The USM Corporation, a subsidiary of the Emhart Corporation, pleaded guilty to all 41 counts of the Federal indictment. The fine imposed by Judge Walter S. Skinner in Federal District Court was $1,025,000, of which $225,000 would be suspended if the company completes construction of a system to treat waste water by Oct. 3, 1987.

A regulatory proposal that would have benefitted a thrift institution that has had extensive dealings with a member of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board has prompted a Congressional request for an investigation into possible conflicts of interest. The proposal was made earlier this month by Lee H. Henkel Jr., one of two new members of the board.

LEAD: The excitement of music for Erich Leinsdorf, who led the New York Philharmonic at Avery Fisher Hall on Tuesday night, seems to lie more in the understanding, analysis, appreciation of it - as expressed through playing - than in the physical or psychological thrill of performing itself. His appreciation (as one knows it from his lucid books) is not dusty or stern, but many listeners, this one included, find his actual performing style disappointingly cut and dried.

LEAD: The end of 1986 was the time of the monolith: Bruce Springsteen and the E Street Band's ''Live/1975-85.'' Selling as fast as it could be trucked into record stores, blanketing FM airwaves, the five-LP/three-CD set made its debut in Billboard's No. 1 position and has stayed there through December. It's a fine album - but its status as the year's major rock event isn't a good sign.
