LEAD: More than half of the state's elementary school students are using outdated science textbooks, according to a State Board of Education study of programs in Connecticut public schools.

LEAD: It had been so long since the Knicks last won a game at the Spectrum against the Philadelphia 76ers that the lone survivor of that team, Bill Cartwright, didn't remember it without prodding. He remembers the losses, however, almost all 17 of them - including two playoff losses - over more than five years.

LEAD: Phil Seghi, who hired Frank Robinson as baseball's first black manager with the Cleveland Indians in 1975 and signed Pete Rose for the Cincinnati Reds in 1960, died Thursday in Thousand Oaks, Calif., after a long illness with cancer. He was 68 years old. Mr. Seghi, who was the senior player-personnel adviser with the Indians, had served as vice president and general manager with the club after joining the organization in 1971.

LEAD: Europe is likely to have a new set of currency values when markets reopen on Monday, monetary officials indicated today.

LEAD: The unemployment rate fell two-tenths of a percentage point last month, to 6.6 percent, the lowest level since March 1980, the Labor Department reported today.

LEAD: Recruiting seasons were reduced in football and basketball and players received permission to give one complimentary game pass to someone other than a relative or student as delegates ended the National Collegiate Athletic Association convention today.

LEAD: Debate over the Interior Department's proposal to open the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to oil drilling opened here today amid seemingly irreconcilable differences between proponents and opponents of development.

LEAD: President Reagan in the study of the residence area of the White House working on his State of the Union Message. He is scheduled to deliver the speech on Jan. 27. It was his first full day home after undergoing prostate surgery Monday. Mr. Reagan is expected to resume a limited schedule next week.

LEAD: Several individuals have complained to the media in recent months that the United States Government denied them visas on ''ideological grounds.'' This is untrue. Those denied visas may coincidentally espouse positions that are unpopular in the United States. But that is not the reason they are refused entry.

LEAD: Victor Magnotta was the consummate movie stunt man. He drove cars off bridges, turned flips on horseback, rappelled down the sides of burning buildings and scrambled up 100-foot masts on tall ships. He was known as ''the Bear.''

LEAD: Texas Instruments said today that it had reached agreements settling its patent infringement lawsuits against two Japanese semiconductor manufacturers, but that it would continue its court action against seven other foreign companies.

LEAD: Walter F. Mondale's 1984 Presidential campaign has been ordered to pay $68,000 in fines for violating the election law's limits on spending and contributions, the Federal Election Commission said today.

LEAD: The stock of the Owens-Illinois Corporation rose sharply in heavy trading yesterday on Wall Street primarily because of rumors that a new bid, perhaps at $60 a share, might be forthcoming. The company received a takeover bid more than a month ago from Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company. At the end of the day, its stock was up $1.50 a share, to $55.25.
LEAD: The desire that made a lovesick moose devote 76 days to wooing Jessica the cow apparently dropped off with his antlers, and he deserted the Hereford of his dreams the next morning.
LEAD: 'Bookies' Will End, But No Whimpering

LEAD: Arthur Rosenblatt has just returned from a field trip to help him with the planning of Washington's newest museum. He shows off an album of color photographs he took on his trip, which was not a pleasant one.

LEAD: Pierre M. George, senior officer of the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of North and South America, died Thursday at Roosevelt Hospital after a long illness. He was 87 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: To judge by Governor Cuomo's annual report on New York, the state of the state is flourishing; the state of the candidate is not all it should be. Whether or not the report is intended to support a run for President, it shows him to be talented and successful but also, as the British say, too clever by half.

LEAD: Following are the texts of an intelligence finding authorizing clandestine operations by the United States Government signed by President Reagan on Jan. 17, 1986, and of an attached memorandum on the finding made public by the White House today:

LEAD: A Manhattan doctor arrested on bigamy charges will probably not be prosecuted because of a legal technicality here and the unwillingness of prosecutors to pursue the case in Iowa, where he is said to have married his second wife in December.

LEAD: The Cuomo administration, under increasing pressure from national Democratic figures to signal whether the Governor will run for President, sent not one but half a dozen signals over the last week, most of them contradictory.
LEAD: The Smithsonian Institution today announced plans, including a greater diversification of exhibits, to attract more minorities to its collections and programs.
LEAD: The baby boom generation now makes up nearly one-third of the nation's population, a new study by the Census Bureau shows.
LEAD: Questions appear on page 12.

LEAD: A new book says Dr. James C. Fletcher, head of the space agency, put the Marshall Space Flight Center in charge of the shuttle's ill-fated rockets because Federal budget cutters were threatening to close the Alabama center, not because it had any special expertise in the creation of solid-fuel rockets.
LEAD: Almost 34 years ago James Robert Thompson signed his high school yearbook, ''Jim Thompson, Pres. of U.S. 1984-1992.''

LEAD: * When one of Chemical Bank's British lending officers was reassigned to Manhattan's garment district not long ago, he began to study more than just the American rag trade. The heavily Jewish garment district is a place where speaking the language goes a long way, so the banker took up Yiddish.

LEAD: MIDAIR, by Frank Conroy. (Penguin, $5.95.) This collection of stories by Frank Conroy is as spare as his autobiographical novel, ''Stop-Time,'' was expansive, William H. Pritchard said in these pages in 1985. Some of the tales, he said, are ''dreamlike happenings reminiscent of Franz Kafka or Nathanael West, with perhaps a twist of Philip Roth,'' while others are ''admirable precisely for their realistic textures, the way they provide us with confirmation of common experiences.

LEAD: Barbara Basler's article ''Putting a Career on Hold'' (Dec. 7) causes me grave concern. The women she describes have ''made it to the top'' and yet choose not to juggle the demands of career, marriage and family, even with the supports that their salaries can provide. The attention paid to this minority of women serves to distract attention from the majority of women who have always juggled these demands.

LEAD: The article on the Dec. 28 Opinion Page by Joyce M. Lannert on zoning [ ''How Can Zoning Be Used to Create Housing Options?'' ] is of great interest, not only to me, but to all who are in need of affordable housing in our county.

LEAD: NEARLY a year after the defeat of Ferdinand Marcos, the Philippine economy remains capital-starved and in trouble - per capita economic growth fell for the second straight year in 1986. Frightened by political instability, both American and Philippine executives continue to withhold new investment.
LEAD: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone left today for Finland and Eastern Europe, a weeklong journey that seems to be part diplomatic overture, part consolation prize.

LEAD: THE Government crackdowns on the recent demonstrations in Shanghai, Beijing and other Chinese cities demanding greater democracy and freedom of expression are a striking example of the constantly shifting climate of intellectual freedom in China. Even in the more liberal ideological atmosphere of Deng Xiaoping's economic reforms, Chinese find it extremely dificult to gauge the boundaries on freedom of expression.

LEAD: In assembling the list of the best classical recordings released in 1986, I stumbled, all unawares, upon a trend. Critics love trends, just as bird-watchers delight in an especially exotic sighting; they make all that waiting and watching worthwhile.

LEAD: Communities confused or discontent in the present often strongly rediscover the moral and spiritual meaning of the traditional objects of their past. This has usually been associated with so-called ''traditional'' societies - certainly not industrial ones. Recently, however, the inexorable recognition that the technology of the industrial system is not a surefire solution to all life's problems has, in a strange paradox, begun to focus broad and appreciative attention on the old ''classical'' objects of the industrial way.
LEAD: ''Mercy or Murder?'' is not a satisfying television movie, in part because the real-life killing and trial it dramatizes had no satisfying conclusion. Did justice triumph?

LEAD: Because of a film distributor's change of plans, an article on page 21 of the Arts and Leisure section today and a film listing in The Guide, section 2A, carry outdated theater information for ''Comic Magazine.'' It opens Friday at the Lincoln Plaza 2, Broadway at 63d Street.

LEAD: GEORGE PRATT SHULTZ RAISED HIS HAND in the hushed committee room, took an oath not to lie, and then upbraided the assembled members of Congress. ''This is the first time in my 10 years of service as a Cabinet officer that I have been asked to take an oath of office before Congress,'' he told them.

LEAD: ''It's all in the mix - this is true of much 80's art,'' Bruce Sterling wrote recently in an essay intended to come to terms with trends and directions in the media culture of the present decade.

LEAD: SPORTS fans in East Haven take their high-school hockey team very seriously. So much so that at East Haven High School, hockey outdraws basketball, the most popular winter sport at most other high schools.

LEAD: THE announcement four years ago that New Haven ranked among the nation's 10 poorest cities sent officals there scurrying for explanations and solutions. Millions had been invested to fight poverty in this, the model for the Great Society. The Mayor quickly formed a Poverty Commission.

LEAD: THE first snowfall of the season always takes me by surprise. Despite endless forecasts and warnings from the ubiquitous weather announcers on radio and the tube, and despite repeated admonitions from the spouse, there is never enough time - for me, at least - to do the things that should be done before it snows.

LEAD: The Islanders scored three times in the first period and settled back in the next two, and that proved sufficient to eke out a 3-2 victory tonight against the Maple Leafs in the unelectric environs of Nassau Coliseum.

LEAD: Tony White hit 32 points, including 8 in a row in a second-half run, as the Volunteers beat Kentucky, 75-68, today in a Southeastern Conference game. White scored 22 of his game-high points in the second half when the Vols opened a 16-point lead. Tennessee raised its record to 8-4 over all and 2-1 in the S.E.C.

LEAD: The engagement of Debora Lee Freedman to Gregory Joseph Clower has been announced by Mrs. Henri Axel Schupf of Greenwich, Conn., and Walter Gary Freedman of Chicago, parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Clower of Wilmette, Ill.

LEAD: FOOTBALL N.F.C. Championship Giants vs. Redskins At Giants Stadium, 4 P.M. Television Channel 2, 4 P.M. Radio WNEW 1130, WNBC 660, 4 P.M. A.F.C. Championship Browns vs. Denver Broncos At Cleveland, 12:30 P.M. Television Channel 4, 12:30 P.M. Radio WNBC 660, 12:30 P.M.

LEAD: Winding along Stone Canyon Road, pausing for a better look at baronial estates tucked behind overhanging sycamores and high iron gates, first-time guests at the Hotel Bel-Air might wonder if they have taken a wrong turn. What would a hotel be doing amid all the wealth and splendor of Bel-Air, the fabled wooded retreat for dozens of

LEAD: Speculative sacrifices run a wide gamut from ''What kind of a stunt is that?'' through ''Well, he's a great tactician, maybe he can bamboozle his opponent,'' to ''Of course, it's so fantastically complicated that one cannot speak of a clear refutation.''

LEAD: To the Editor: We enjoyed Nicholas D. Kristof's views and coverage of Peru and Cuzco (Travel, Oct. 5), a country full of history and art. Unfortunately there is an underside to a trip to these areas; currently the country is living in fear and anxiety due to terrorism. As Mr. Kristof says, the Peruvian army is quite visible everywhere; military and security guards armed with machine guns are part of the landscape.
LEAD: In a city where shiny new office buildings stretch vacant out to the flat edges of town, some turn-of-the-century downtown warehouses are putting a gleam in a local developer's eye.
LEAD: FOR a long time, hundreds of automatic garage doors in San Bernardino, Calif., mysteriously failed to open. But only on certain days.
LEAD: Cryptoclearance and Mar Mar, 3-year-olds with bright futures, scored impressive victories in stakes races today at Hialeah Park while registering identical times of 1:09 4/5 for six furlongs.
LEAD: Representative Lee H. Hamilton, chairman of the special House committee that is investigating the Iran arms affair, at work yesterday at the Rayburn House Office Building. (NYT/Ken Heinen)

LEAD: LAST week's snowstorm in the Northeast got me out of the house and onto the cross-country ski trails for the first time this winter. North of the city, the snow was beautiful to behold, molding the landscape to a smooth pure white. For many, the urge to photograph at a time like this is too powerful to resist.

LEAD: AMERICANS hoping to improve education have cast many an envious glance at the Japanese. In Japan, 95 percent of high school students graduate, compared to about 75 percent in the United States. In subjects like math, the best American high school students barely reach the level of the average Japanese.

LEAD: The Chieftans, the 96-acre estate in Greenwich, Conn., long owned by the Gimbel family, is going to become a single-family home development, while retaining some of its former identity. Plans call for the division of the 26-room manor house into two or three residences and the adaptation of several of the outbuildings into homes.
LEAD: LAURENCE STERNE The Later Years. By Arthur H. Cash. Illustrated. 390 pp. New York: Methuen. $49.95.

LEAD: To the Sports Editor: Although I enjoyed the champions listed in the 1986 sports review section, I noticed it failed to include the National Collegiate Athletic Association women's volleyball champions. If there was room to list the men's winners, I'm sure there was room for the women's team - which, by the way, was the University of the Pacific, in Stockton, Calif.
LEAD: DON'T CROWD ME; I'm distancing myself from the hottest cliche in Scandalville.

LEAD: Some years ago, our dog, who, too, was being walked on a leash, was attacked by dogs who were running loose. [ ''Family's Suit Raises Issue of What a Pet Dog Is Worth,'' Dec. 21. ] They belonged to my neighbor. Charlie received 19 stitches in his rectum, and spent the night sedated in the Emergency Hospital on Tarrytown Road.

LEAD: Just how big a problem steroid use is among the professional athletes can only be determined through mutually agreed-upon testing procedures. But before a sweeping policy of testing is instituted, some important questions need to be answered: How reliable is the testing procedure? What would the consequences of steroid use be - suspension?
LEAD: SINCE two-platoon football came to the National Football League in 1950, the Giants, in lean years and good, have been celebrated for their defense.

LEAD: At the outset of a new year, engineering executives entrusted with long-range planning invariably wax eloquent about things to come. In television, they usually tell us that everything is obsolete, that we ought to chuck the whole system and start from scratch.

LEAD: Some classics, including two imports and lesser-known bargains top the film week on cable. Two Vittorio de Sica imports cited by the New York Film Critics are on Bravo: the raffishly endearing ''Miracle in Milan'' (1951), with its marvelous, skybound fadeout - Tuesday at midnight.; and ''Umberto D'' (1952), a poignant study of an elderly pensioner, with superb performance by Carlo Battista in the central role - 11 P.M.

LEAD: In his article ''A Silent Battle Surfaces'' (Dec. 7), Richard Halloran quotes a United States Navy admiral as saying that forward-attacks by American submarines on Soviet subs would reduce ''the attractiveness [ to the Russians ] of nuclear escalation by changing the nuclear balance in our favor.'' What neither the admiral nor Mr.
LEAD: Fishermen from Maine to Rhode Island are complaining that the Coast Guard's practice of routinely halting and boarding their vessels at sea is dangerous, costly and unnecessary.

LEAD: Releasing the Sponsor Question: When my apartment building was coverted into a cooperative, the sponsor promised in amendments to the plan to make some repairs, including patching some serious leaks in the parking garage. Recently, the board of directors gave the sponsor a general release from all claims concerning repairs in exchange for the sponsor's cooperation in renegotiating the building's mortgage at a lower interest rate.

LEAD: TEN years ago, George Steinbrenner introduced walkie-talkies to baseball. The Yankees' owner, an assistant college football coach in his earlier years, believed that someone sitting on the press level of a stadium could position the outfielders better than someone standing in the dugout. In more recent years, he has continued to borrow football techniques, making extensive use of films, as football coaches do.

LEAD: Movies based on ballets are back in vogue. ''El Amor Brujo,'' a new film by Carlos Saura and Antonio Gades, is inspired by the ballet of the same name originally created in 1915. The choreography was by the Spanish dancer Pastora Imperio, set to a now-celebrated score by Manuel de Falla. ''Nutcracker, the Motion Picture,'' as conceived by Maurice Sendak and Kent Stowell and directed by Carroll Ballard, is a version of the even more famous 1890 Russian ballet to

LEAD: WE HAVE dismantled the Christmas tree. And the little electric train, which had wound its way through the tiny village under the tree, no longer makes its scheduled stops. Also, I have put away the last of the red candles and plaid bows.

LEAD: In a poignant poem, ''The Nobel Prize,'' Boris Pasternak wrote in 1959 that he was treated like a bandit by Soviet authorities for ''the vile offense'' of winning the world's most coveted literary honor. He sought this solace: ''Nonetheless I still believe/ Though I feel my death is near / That the soul of men's goodwill / Will vanquish hate and fear.

LEAD: PJ. Carlesimo had sort of curled up at one end of the gymnasium, his knees tucked tightly under his chin, his back resting stiffly against a padded wall, as he studied the workout that unfolded before him. In the past few days, there had been a victory of great importance and a defeat of great disappointment, and these were two things that Carlesimo could not fully dispatch from his mind as he watched his Seton Hall basketball team practice the other day.

LEAD: Chinese and Japanese porcelains, mounted sparely and sumptuously in gilded and silvered metal mounts, were made to amuse aristocrats over more than six centuries. Today the charms of these extravagant decorations are enjoyed by enthusiasts from all levels of society, as could be seen on a recent morning in the mix of people filing through the exhibition ''Mounted Oriental Porcelains,'' at the Frick Collection, 1 East 70th

LEAD: The State Investigation Commission said last week that the New York State Agriculture Department had so badly mismanaged an investigation into adulteration of apple juice that it encouraged companies to sell fake apple juice throughout the state.
LEAD: A special panel has urged the State Legislature to prohibit companies from testing employees or job applicants for drug use.

LEAD: The police seized a Brooklyn man who had demanded to speak to the leader of a Black Muslim group today after passing a threatening note aboard a Continental Airlines plane that had flown from Newark to Washington, the authorities said.

LEAD: Seven members of the New York City Landmarks Commission last week issued a gratuitous warning against any proposal that would obscure part of the rear of the New York Public Library on 42d Street. It was an act of arrogance against normal process that calls not just for criticism but also for corrective steps.

LEAD: Gigi Mahon, a writer, and Thomas C. Theobald, a vice chairman of Citicorp and Citibank, one of its subsidiaries, were married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York. The Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony.

LEAD: To the Editor: I enjoyed Steven M. L. Aronson's review of ''Zeffirelli: The Autobiography of Franco Zeffirelli'' (Dec. 14). I'm quite sure Mr. Aronson picked out all the highlights and saved me 358 pages of reading, as well as $19.95.
LEAD: This Week:

LEAD: Good intention piled upon heightened concern last week as political, civic, religious, education and labor leaders denounced racism and condemned a white gang's attack on three black men in Howard Beach Dec. 20.
LEAD: SINCE two-platoon football came to the National Football League in 1950, the Giants, in lean years and good, have been celebrated for their defense.

LEAD: Improvements in Metro-North's rail service have been widely acclaimed in recent years in the press, by public officials and even by commuter groups that are usually critical of railroad service. Typical is the article ''Metro-North Basks in Progress'' [ Nov. 9 ] . The article discusses how bad conditions on the railroad were only three yeas ago and how good the service is today.

LEAD: To the Sports Editor: In the aftermath of my euphoria over the Giants' most convincing victory of the year, I sat down in my favorite chair to read the Sunday sports section. I had scanned it before the game looking for any last-minute injury reports, but otherwise was too keyed up about the game to really sit down and read it.

LEAD: To the Editor: Your Dec. 14 article on Woodhaven, Queens [ ''If You're Thinking of Living in Woodhaven'' ] says that houses there selling for $150,000 to $300,000 have taxes ranging from $600 and $1,200 a year, which means they are assessed at less than 5 percent of market value.
LEAD: Searching for the best deal in a cruise or tour can be a laborious and frustrating chore that may make you wonder, in the end, whether any money saved was worth the effort.
LEAD: It is an arguable distinction, but ''Comic Magazine'' may be the only Japanese film ever conceived in a jail cell.
LEAD: JOHN CARDINAL O'CONNOR'S visit to Jerusalem has left a bittersweet taste.
LEAD: To the Editor: I enjoyed Diana Trilling's review of ''Marilyn'' by Gloria Steinem (Dec. 21) and would like to add some relevant information of which Mrs. Trilling may not have been aware.

LEAD: JANUARY launches the sled dog racing season in this country, and in Bemidji, Minn., this weekend more than 2,000 dogs and 200 mushers, or drivers, are competing in the first leg of a three-part event known as Tuffy's Triple Trail.

LEAD: A Federal judge ruled last week that Farmland Dairies of Wallington, N.J., which drove down milk prices on Staten Island when it was allowed to compete there, could sell its milk throughout New York City.

LEAD: Whether fighting for their honor, their lovers or their fabulous multinational companies, the heroes and heroines of mini-series are in unusual jeopardy this year: Viewers have become bored with their problems. Except for Linda Evans as an American woman facing the Australian outback in ''The Last Frontier,'' ratings for these special events have ranged from disastrous (''George Washington: The Forging of a Nation'') to mediocre (''A Year in the Life.

LEAD: LOUIS BARRIOS used to walk through the hallways of his high school in a fog. In class, his mind wandered out the window and onto the streets. A dark shadow hung over his head, but he just didn't know how to put his feelings into words.
LEAD: NEW LANDS, NEW MEN America and the Second Great Age of Discovery. By William H. Goetzmann. Illustrated. 528 pp. New York: Viking. $24.95.

LEAD: IT costs corporations an average of $42,000 every time they transfer a valued employee. With such relocations reaching 500,000 each year, it is no wonder that businesses across the country are trying to save time and money - as well as to smooth the way for their employees - by getting more involved in the relocation process.
LEAD: CONSPIRACY OF KNAVES By Dee Brown. 392 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $17.95.

LEAD: Among the more familiar sights on Cape Cod this winter are the ''Help Wanted'' signs in virtually all the large supermarkets, department stores, pharmacies and restaurant chains, from Sandwich to Orleans.

LEAD: THE members of Congress most actively involved in education are critical of President Reagan's proposed budget, but not worried; several said last week that Congress would not endorse the proposed cuts in student aid. Nonetheless, colleges and universities are mobilizing for a battle.

LEAD: The prices of gold and other precious metals have risen recently, but little of that luster has rubbed off on copper. The price of this important base metal has been between 60 and 70 cents a pound, and actually felll by 5 percent last year.

LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

LEAD: At the couture shows in Paris last fall and earlier this winter, a few designers unleashed a parade of flamboyant coiffed hairdos to go with their elaborately poufed evening dresses. The fashion pundits instantly predicted that women would be racing to salons for false hairpieces and layers of teasing - a fad that had faded with the 1960's.

LEAD: In the surreal world of Lebanese politics, yesterday's blood-feuding enemies seem willing at times to suppress their memories and join forces. Over the years, both Christians and Moslems have zigzagged, sometimes allied and at other times contesting each other and such powerful outsiders as Syria, Israel and Yasir Arafat's Palestinians.

LEAD: Andrea Kim Feirstein, an associate at the New York law firm of Brown & Wood, and Frank Loren Schiff, an associate at the law firm of White & Case, also in New York, plan a summer wedding. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. George Feirstein of Maplewood, N.J., and Mr. and Mrs. Ronald K. Schiff of

LEAD: When the telephone rang at John Rehor's home near the Potomac River some 50 miles northwest of Washington last Sunday afternoon, the New York Giants were pulling away from the San Francisco 49ers on television. ''It had just started to become a rout,'' he remembered later.

LEAD: As John Cardinal O'Connor returned to New York yesterday after a trip to Israel and Jordan, virtually every major Jewish organization in the United States joined in issuing an unusually strong statement critical of several aspects of the nine-day visit.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: France and Libya crossed an important line in Chad last week. Libyan planes bombed two towns south of the 16th parallel, the so-called Red Line established by French forces as the southern boundary for Libyan incursions. In retaliation, French jets bombed an airstrip in Libyan-controlled territory.

LEAD: THE Charles Department Store in Katonah, established in 1924, bills itself as ''the store that has everything'' - clothes and shoes for the entire family, appliances and cookware, vacuum cleaners and stationery, fabrics and televisions, picture frames and camping gear. Everything is stacked, hung and layered in an area measuring only 5,000 square feet, presided over by the Raneri brothers - Jim, 31 years old, and

LEAD: The great days are gone - it is no matter; No lines come easy now upon my tongue. The world has been in crisis all my life What else could I do but hold on as it spun And say my little say and sing my song? My causes all were won - or they were lost; And now my friends depart and leave me lonely -And yet - to see the blossoms in the springtime To watch the sunset hover on the sea And know that the one I love is by my side Oh lucky was I - lucky I remain.

LEAD: Although the economy of the New York-New Jersey region continued to grow last year - adding 135,000 jobs -a report released last week said that several suburban counties were beginning to show some signs of decreased economic strength.

LEAD: SPECIAL circumstances - a pile of new furniture, weak safety regulation and a poorly equipped, understrength fire department - helped bring the death toll to 96 in the fire New Year's Eve at the Dupont Plaza Hotel. But safety experts say these factors should not divert Americans from the real lesson to be drawn from the disaster:
LEAD: THE BIGNESS COMPLEX Industry, Labor, and Government in the American Economy. By Walter Adams and James W. Brock. 426 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $22.95.

LEAD: A conciliatory meeting this morning between Alan Bond and Kevin Parry has resolved a dispute over a yacht-racing technicality that could have thrown the America's Cup defense effort into a legal quagmire.

LEAD: CLAY WALLS. By Kim Ronyoung. (Permanent Press, $18.95.) This earnest novel about Korean immigrants begins with a Los Angeles matron and her hired help bent over the rim of a toilet. The employer is pointing out a missed stain to the plucky Asian heroine, who calls her ungrateful benefactor sangnyun (''low woman'') and tells her where to put the job.
LEAD: Divining the Dow

LEAD: HART AND SOUL: Gary Hart's New Hampshire Odyssey . . . and Beyond. By Susan Berry Casey. (NHI Press, Box 825, Concord, N.H. 03301. Paper, $9.95.) These are the hard basics of running for President, particularly for an underdog like Senator Gary Hart in 1984: up before a cold New Hampshire dawn in a forlorn motel or a campaign worker's house to climb into a van driven by a campaign volunteer to accost hurrying factory workers at the plant gate or sleepy diners in a greasy spoon.

LEAD: IN the tormented inner world of Giant fans, it is still the long, hot summer of 1969 and they are still singing ''Goodbye Allie.'' These poor souls still fall into a tortured sleep at night watching Mike Battle of the despised Jets hurdling the crouched, frozen bodies of Giant tacklers.

LEAD: THE LAY OF THE LAND. By Dean Crawford. (Viking, $16.95.) Jeremy and Leslie are wayward, late 1960's spirits, free from their spouses, eager to start anew, anxious yet happy to be living near one another - only there's something peculiar about their titillatingly close friendship. They are brother and sister.

LEAD: The engagement of Cornelia Grant Quarles to Harry Brunie Wonham, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick S. Wonham of Stamford, Conn., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Very Quarles 3d of Atlanta, parents of the bride-to-be. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: NOT so long ago, an awesome force known as the business cycle drove the economy along much as the moon drives the tides and the sun the seasons. It was almost always there, a perpetual motion machine that propelled the nation through booms and busts. Yet for more than a couple of years now, the cycle has been dormant, with the economy moving listlessly month after month.
LEAD: THE ALLEY CAT By Yves Beauchemin. Translated by Sheila Fischman. 450 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $17.95.

LEAD: FOR a sport that attracts an upscale market, sailboat racing has attracted surprisingly little corporate support in the United States. That's all starting to change, however, thanks in part to the America's Cup and a recent decision to ease restrictions on advertising on racing boats.
LEAD: Nancy Jane Bregstein, a partner in the Washington law firm of Shea & Gardner, and Dr. Gary Victor Gordon of Philadelphia, a rheumatologist, plan to be married in March.

LEAD: I THINK it is past time to put aside other business and to turn our energies to the remystification of virtually everything. I am as firmly persuaded as anyone that things can be explained, or usefully described, but I am convinced that our methods at this point are crude, and premature, and that they lead us to ignore such experience or intuition as cannot be accommodated by them.
LEAD: THE advantages of buying into a condominium while it still is under construction are widely promoted and real, but the problems that may arise in an early purchase also should be considered.
LEAD: QUEEN OF HEARTS By Susan Richards Shreve. 354 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $17.95.
LEAD: AS he began his second full term as Governor last week, William A. O'Neill, a 20-year veteran of Democratic state politics, was looking ahead with a new agenda.

LEAD: Kelly Stouffer, the Colorado State quarterback, completed his first nine passes today, including two for touchdowns of 34 and 48 yards, to lead the West to a 24-21 victory in the 62d annual East-West Shrine Football Classic.
LEAD: Marion E. Martin, founder of the National Federation of Republican Women's Clubs, died Thursday at her home here. She was 86 years old.

LEAD: The United States Postal Service will issue a commemorative stamp Jan. 29 to honor the Tenth Pan American Games. The sports competition will be held in 23 sites throughout Indiana from Aug. 7 to 25. The first day of issue ceremony will be held in Indianapolis, the site for many events.

LEAD: Iran said today that its troops were advancing near the southern Iraqi city of Basra after having beaten back two counterattacks, and both sides reported continuing heavy fighting in the Persian Gulf war.
LEAD: PLANS are under way to rebuild the Hitchcock Presbyterian Church, the Scarsdale landmark that was destroyed in a suspicious fire seven months ago.

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Albert Dee Roberts of Dallas have announced the engagement of their daughter, Hillary Roberts, to Peter Alan Rinfret, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Pierre A. Rinfret of New York. The wedding is planned for March 21.

LEAD: FEWER hospitals in the county will treat acutely ill patients and more will offer drug rehabilitation and care for the elderly if a controversial plan for the future of the area's health-care system is put into effect.
LEAD: LOUISIANA BLACK By Samuel Charters. 253 pp. New York: Marion Boyars/Kampmann. $18.95.
LEAD: THE PANIC OF '89 By Paul Erdman. 304 pp. New York: Doubleday & Company. $17.95.

LEAD: NEW MILFORD Hospital has $5.6 million for renovation work thanks to an unusual cross section of donors - residents of both Connecticut and New York State, and New Yorkers who spend only weekends in the New Milford area.

LEAD: A 26-year-old Brooklyn truck driver who fled from an accident that left two people seriously injured in Queens Friday surrendered to the police yesterday. His lawyer said the suspect fled because a passer-by had fired gunshots he thought were aimed at him.

LEAD: My vegetable garden keeps acquiring interesting new foreign tenants. Last year I grew a luscious, ivory-hued Sicilin eggplant from seed my barber gave me. This year a French neighbor promised me an oversized shallot known by its shape as a ''cuisse de poulet'' -- a chicken thigh.

LEAD: WHEN Caroline Freeman Tunis was vice president of a large publishing house, she supervised the company's move to Virginia from Washington. About two years ago, tired of ''the rut of a day-to-day routine,'' she began assisting other corporations with relocations. Now her New York City consulting firm, Hire Intelligence Inc., has more business than it can handle.

LEAD: Two models of wires used in heart pacemakers have been malfunctioning at higher than normal rates, according to the manufacturer, which says the problem is not life-threatening to the hundreds of Americans with the devices.

LEAD: To the Sports Editor: In response to Marvin Miller's charge that George Steinbrenner was part of an owner conspiracy not to sign Jack Morris as a free agent, Steinbrenner is quoted as saying: ''If Marvin Miller can run a business better than me, then he should be rich. And he's not.''

LEAD: The Streisand Specials: My Name Is Barbra and Color Me Barbra. CBS/Fox Video. 60 minutes. $29.95. Barbra Streisand's landmark CBS television specials in the mid-60's turned the star of the Broadway show ''Funny Girl'' into a household face as well as a household voice. Both shows, staged by Joe Layton, are unrelenting star vehicles in which the singer, then in her mid-20's, paraded front and center, without the support of famous guests.
LEAD: SOMETIME before Easter, the 26-story spires of Newark's Sacred Heart Cathedral - a National Historic Landmark - will become visible at night from as far off as Manhattan.

LEAD: CHINESE food fanciers may have noticed a change in New York City's Chinatown, due to the influx of immigrants from Hong Kong. The restaurants opening in Chinatown reflect a new affluence and sophistication.

LEAD: THE first bit of business that Senator Bill Bradley and Representative William J. Hughes tended to on the opening day of the 100th Congress last week was to reintroduce legislation to protect three South Jersey rivers, a move that would thwart the state's efforts to place a toxic-waste dump in Maurice River

LEAD: BAYEUX TAPESTRY ''The Bayeux Tapestry as Unravelled by David Bernstein'' is not the chronicle of a horrendous act of vandalism, but an exhibition based on Mr. Bernstein's book ''The Mystery of the Bayeux Tapestry.'' It can be seen at the library of Sarah Lawrence College in Yonkers through Feb. 28.

LEAD: Bess Myerson, the city's Cultural Affairs Commissioner, invoked the Fifth Amendment last month before a Federal grand jury investigating a contractor, but did not tell Mayor Koch or any member of his administration about it until a television station broadcast a news report Friday night, the Mayor said yesterday.

LEAD: Three months after ending a six-week suspension from the PGA Tour, Mac O'Grady achieved his biggest victory so far when he overcame putting tremors today to win the 35th annual MONY Tournament of Champions by one shot over Rick Fehr.

LEAD: THESE AMERICAN LANDS: Parks, Wilderness, and the Public Lands. By Dyan Zaslowsky and the Wilderness Society. (Holt, $22.95.) The voice of Robert Marshall echoes loud in ''These American Lands.'' Marshall was a founder of the Wilderness Society in 1935 and his memory and spirit likely still guide the organization.
LEAD: The Soviet Union has privately informed the United States that it is upgrading the level of its representation to the Geneva arms talks, according to Soviet and American officials.

LEAD: Starring the Marx Brothers with Lucille Ball and Ann Miller. Directed by William Seiter and produced by Pandro S. Berman. 1938. RKO Home Video. 78 minutes. $29.95. Herewith rather claustrophobic Marx, obviously derived from a stage play, but still good, rowdy fun, with the brothers and a sporting cast mainly anchored inside a Broadway hotel suite, as members of a bill-swamped theater troupe shaping a new show.

LEAD: A former vice president of Merrill Lynch Capital Markets, who had recently lost his job, killed himself Friday night by jumping out the window of his 18th-floor penthouse apartment on the Upper East Side, the police said yesterday.

LEAD: AT the top of the MCA black tower, in the office recently vacated by Frank Price, Thomas Philip Pollock is hunched over a pastrami sandwich and a Diet Coke. As the new overlord of Universal movies, Mr. Pollock is at the peak of the Hollywood hierarchy. But his appointment is more than just another executive move in an industry where people change jobs as often as movie stars change cars.
LEAD: THERE he was, running easily around the practice field at the Denver Broncos' training site here, a tall, graceful athlete with a long stride.

LEAD: A Marine guard who had access to classified documents in the United States Embassy in Moscow is being held on suspicion of espionage after confessing he gave secrets to a female K.G.B. agent, Defense Department sources said today.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Carol Schnall Goldberg of Los Angeles and Dr. Melvin Freundlich of Cedar Grove, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter Julie Freundlich to Julius Francis Lang Jr., a son of Mr. Lang of Milton, Mass., and the late Ellin O'Malley Lang. A May wedding is planned.
LEAD: WHEN the Order of St. Benedict was revived in 19th-century Europe, one of its new congregations, the Ottiliens, set up abbeys in Africa, Manchuria, South America ''and other places.''

LEAD: WEDNESDAY night's ''Magic Flute'' by the Opera at the Academy company seemed specifically intended to enrage pious Mozarteans and at the same time cause the iconoclastic heart to beat a little faster.

LEAD: In the last two weeks, Naum Meiman has made many visits to Soviet Government offices, spending hours in the bitter cold chasing evanescent assurances that the next piece of paper he obtains will secure the promised exit visa for his cancer-stricken wife.

LEAD: A gazebo, proponents say, would enhance the artistic and recreational life of Chappaqua. It would provide a place for concerts, lectures, exhibits and plays. It would be esthetically pleasing, would attract audiences to school concerts and would become a focal point for the community. No one has publicly disagreed; nevertheless, the gazebo has remained only an idea for the last six years, and following the latest rejection of a proposed site, it is likely to remain so longer.

LEAD: The Commmission on the Bicentennial of the United States Constitution, like sponsors of any celebration of consequence these days, is preparing to bestow its official blessing on a range of ''programs, projects, goods and services'' by permitting them to use its logo. Since the observance is to run through 1991, the anniversary of ratification of the Bill of
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Edwin Nadel of Harrison, N.Y., and West Dover, Vt., has announced the engagement of his daughter Lauren Ann Nadel to Armin W. Nauser, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hans Nauser of Zurich.

LEAD: FIVE years ago, the Long Island Weekly examined the rapid rise and success of several entrepreneurs in an article headlined ''They're 'Making It' on Long Island.'' The entrepreneurs, in such fields as real estate and construction, electronics and horticulture, were achieving spectacular success while the national economy had its ups and downs.

LEAD: As a force in Bronx politics for decades and a Democratic Congressman since 1969, 69-year-old Mario Biaggi has been a target of several Federal inquiries; last week prosecutors in Brooklyn were reported to have asked the Justice Department for permission to seek a joint indictment naming Mr. Biaggi and Meade H.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor: Does booing a professional athlete help or hinder his performance?

LEAD: The engagement of Laura Susan Myers to Steven Hammond Poppe, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred C. Poppe of West Islip, L.I., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. W. Earle Myers of Long Valley, N.J., parents of the bride-to-be. A May wedding is planned.

LEAD: OFFICIALS and volunteers involved in preventing drunk driving are celebrating what they say is a major reduction of alcohol-related accidents on the county's roads, a change they credit to four years of intensified public education, better enforcement tactics and tougher penalties.

LEAD: BRASS RUBBINGS Brass rubbing is an old craft that produces quickly and easily a respectable piece of art at minimal cost. It requires no artistic skill and is an enjoyable way to spend half an hour or so. Those who have never tried it may treat themselves to an introductory workshop under the watchful eyes of experts from the Brass Rubbing Center in London and its branch in Washington D.C., courtesy of the Museum of Art, Science and Industry in
LEAD: THE MANLY ART Bare-Knuckle Prize Fighting in America. By Elliott J. Gorn. Illustrated. 316 pp. Ithaca, N.Y.: Cornell University Press. $24.95.

LEAD: A NEW house was going to be built on our block, but before that could be started, the old one had to be removed. When the bulldozer arrived, I walked over to have a look. Who isn't intrigued with a mighty bulldozer in action?

LEAD: ''I LOVE films,'' said Gen LeRoy of Sag Harbor and the Upper West Side of Manhattan. ''I have always loved them. They were a very important part of my childhood, and I'm a terrific audience in case anyone wants to hire me.''

LEAD: I ORDERED an individual salmon sandwich on whole-wheat toast, no dressing, and orange spice herb tea. This was a lunch I carefully selected for its low calories and because of the calcium in the salmon, the fiber and wheat in the bread and the absense of tannic acid or caffeine in the tea. Next to me at the counter, a man ordered a super-deluxe cheeseburger, rare, with french fries and a chocolate malt.

LEAD: For many years the anti-paradisal view that Richmond was a dull, conservative, rundown red-brick industrial town induced many travelers to skip the city. Things have changed so much, however, that visitors now wish they could spend more time in the Capital of the Confederacy.

LEAD: It is no secret that the Knicks win games when their two most important frontcourt players, Patrick Ewing and Bill Cartwright, play well enough to dominate their respective defenders. And when the two have failed, it has often been because the Knicks did not have a deep threat whose outside shot kept the opposing defense away from them.

LEAD: FRANK GANSZ was named the Kansas City Chiefs' head coach last night. The 48-year-old Gansz succeeds John Mackovic, who was dismissed Thursday despite the Chiefs' 10-6 regular-season record in his fourth season and Kansas City's first playoff appearance in 15 years.

LEAD: What is this, female chauvinism? Aren't there any fathers who are interested in taking care of their children? It is good to hear that Procter & Gamble, at least, has paternity leave. I hope the idea catches on, and fast.

LEAD: Nonprofit organizations fear that new proposals by the Internal Revenue Service will curb lobbying they have done for years to help shape government policies about anything from health and welfare, education and family planning to the environment and the needs of the young or the aged.

LEAD: To the Editor: In Marilyn Bender's article about the post-Christmas sales in London's department stores (Travel, Nov. 30), she ended with some advice on the V.A.T. incurred in most purchases. Experience has taught me that the business of V.A.T. refunds can be frustrating, at best.

LEAD: Aberdeen $170,000 19 Canfield Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 23-year-old colonial; central A/C, patio, wall-to-wall carpeting, new aluminum siding; taxes $2,887. Mahwah $220,000 174 Grandview Lane 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1-year-old condominium; fireplace in living room, den, loft, maintenance $126; taxes $3,000.
LEAD: A photograph on Dec. 21 of Phangnga Bay, Thailand, was incorrectly credited. It should have been credited to Adina Tovy/Stock Shop.

LEAD: WITH the release last year of the Macintosh Plus, it looks as if Apple is beginning to make real inroads on business computing. The current dominance of the I.B.M. standard has thrust into virtual oblivion the fact that brokers, insurance agents and financial analysts snapped up the original Apple II to computerize their work on their own individual machines.

LEAD: WHILE vehicular bridges and roadways in New Jersey continue to deteriorate faster than they can be repaired, funds for repairs are in danger of drying up by June, according to the state's Department of Transportation.
LEAD: The jury will hear summations beginning Monday in the two-month trial of two avowed revolutionaries charged with murdering a state trooper on Interstate 80 in December 1981.

LEAD: FIRST DOWN AND A BILLION: The Funny Business of Pro Football. By Gene Klein and David Fisher (Morrow, $17.95.) If you have never heard of George Halas, Don Coryell or Dan Fouts then you can stiff-arm Gene Klein's breezy story of what it's like to own your own National Football League team. But if you start browsing in it, Mr.

LEAD: Viewed from the west, the New York Public Library provides passers-by with a striking facade. Twenty-six bands of light marble alternate with dark, vertical windows, distinguishing the 75-year-old building from others in the Beaux-Arts style.

LEAD: To the Editor: Barry R. Chiswick (''A Troubling Drop in Immigrant 'Quality', '' Forum, Dec. 21) claims that an immigration policy that favors ''productive applicants'' would ease the competition between America's native minorities and newly arrived unskilled immigrants for low-skilled jobs.
LEAD: Additional titles of interest:

LEAD: DURING the early part of the 19th century, the whaling port of New London was one of Connecticut's most prosperous and colorful communities. Its bustling harrbor created riches that led to the building of fine homes and majestic red brick commercial buildings and storehouses, many of which still stand.

LEAD: Fiction 1 7 THE MAMMOTH HUNTERS, by Jean M. Auel. (Bantam, $4.95.) Ayla of ''The Clan of the Cave Bear'' resumes her prehistoric adventures. 2 6 LIE DOWN WITH LIONS, by Ken Follett. (Signet/ NAL, $4.95.) An Englishwoman in Afghanistan, caught between the C.I.A. and the K.G.B. 3 11 SECRETS, by Danielle Steel.

LEAD: Saying that their visit to New York had made them aware that ''the need for charity is not limited to our doorstep,'' Lilly and David Zohary of Israel have donated $100 to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

LEAD: High Up Downtown Jan. 11 - There will be a buffet, dancing, an open bar and songs by Jean Carne at the annual New Year's reception of the Manhattan branch of the New York Urban League at Windows on the World. Festivities from 1 to 5 P.M. Tickets, $75, at the door. A Switch for the ABT Jan. 19 - Dancers and directors of the American Ballet Theater will be displaying some of their lesser known talents as they host and help prepare a fund-raising black-tie dinner at the QV Restaurant, 63d Street at Madison Avenue.

LEAD: To the Sports Editor: I would like to put in a vote for the abolition of the National Football League's replay rule. It was a joy to watch Penn State play Miami in the Fiesta Bowl without having to wait 4 minutes 10 seconds between plays. (a la Rams vs. Redskins). ROBERT NISSEN

LEAD: New York drivers, like those almost everywhere, inch impatiently forward while waiting for a traffic light to change. But only in New York City do pedestrians seem afflicted with the same disease.

LEAD: REJECTING a defense request for a delay in the proceedings, a judge in St. Augustine, Fla., sentenced John Lee Paul, the race car driver, to 20 years in prison for attempting to murder a witness in a Federal drug case. Paul also faces charges that he and his son, John Paul Jr., conspired to smuggle 200,000 pounds of cocaine into the United States between 1975 and 1983.

LEAD: After two decades of cleanup and land reclamation, the Meadowlands area of New Jersey is shedding its image as an environmental wasteland and emerging as one of the busiest centers of commercial development in the Northeast.
LEAD: THE BISHOP By David Helwig. 234 pp. New York: Viking. $15.95.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Arthur Ochs Sulzberger Jr. has been named to the newly created position of assistant publisher of The New York Times. The appointment, effective Jan. 19, was announced yesterday by his father, Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, publisher of the newspaper and chairman and chief executive officer of The New York Times

LEAD: To the Editor: For over 35 years we have closely watched the short- and long-term effects of marketing American technology abroad, mainly through licensing (''The U.S. Giveaway,'' Dec. 7). More than any other nation we have generously offered our technology to outsiders. As a result, the entire world has been able to advance the automation of assembly line manufacturing, as well as the handling and processing of material.

LEAD: Richard Halloran's portrayal of the submarine-stalking games played by the United States and the Soviet Union sounds as if it's right off some admiral's drawing board. But his omission of any mention of the recent severe collision between an American nuclear submarine and a Russian counterpart does little to warn the public of the peacetime dangers of this ''cat and mouse'' technique.
LEAD: Four Iranians, stowaways on a freighter bound for Newark from Istanbul, were pulled from New York Harbor early yesterday morning after they jumped from the ship, the police said.

LEAD: ''I kept thinking about all the kids who got wiped out by 17 years of war movies before coming to Vietnam to get wiped out for good,'' Michael Herr remembers in ''Dispatches,'' his book of Vietnam memoirs published in 1977.

LEAD: Throughout his career, the Parisian chef and restaurateur Bernard Pacaud has lived by three common-sense rules: Keep the restaurant small, keep the menu simple, make sure the food is fresh. Those rules managed to win him two Michelin stars in a very short time, and so it only made sense that when he outgrew his nine-table restaurant, L'Ambroisie, on the Left Bank, the new one would follow the same principles.

LEAD: Most of the condominiums to emerge in recent years in Yorkville, the upper stretch of the Upper East Side, have tended to be tall, with 35 stories not uncommon. But the Louisiana, a new condominium building at 300 East 90th Street, is only 10 stories high.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: HE'S an assistant athletic director with an established interest in basketball and some of the best seats in the school arena, but Lefty Driesell hasn't used them to watch Maryland play this season.

LEAD: The basketball game between Fordham and Fairfield was suspended with 1 minute 42 seconds remaining today when the grandmother of one of the Fairfield players collapsed and died in the stands, officials said.

LEAD: EVEN when the Aldrich Museum in Ridgefield, was confined to one building, a handsome Colonial structure at 258 Main Street, its productions were not to be taken in at a glance. Now with its new wing, so cunningly grafted on by a Wilton architectural firm, Robert Faesy Associates, the exhibition space is almost twice what it was.

LEAD: IT has been several years since the Norwich Inn opened its doors, virtually new after being restored and renovated. At that time, the food served in the country-style dining room (with its antler chandelier, rose-patterned walls and wooden high-backed chairs) seemed very good indeed, with a promise of becoming even better.

LEAD: To the Editor: I would like to thank David Kirby, the reviewer of my book of poems, ''Dominion'' (Oct. 12), for his descriptive, nonjudgmental approach to my writing. I would also like to register a complaint, not so much against him as against the literary climate that makes it unremarkable to review a book of poetry without referring to its subject.

LEAD: Romare Bearden's intimate tapestries are about memory and forgetting, wisdom and laughter, silence and song. His human comedy is pieced together with the hard, racy, broken rhythms of New York City, where he has spent most of his life, and the communal rhythms of Mecklenburg County, N.C., where he spent the summers of his youth.

LEAD: RECYCLING, a fever of the 1970's that cooled when concern over shortages eased and markets for recycled materials were slow to develop, is on the rise again. New York, New Jersey and Connecticut are in various stages of implementing plans to recycle at least 25 percent of their solid waste and incinerate much of the rest to produce energy.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. J. Waide Howley of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Maureen Louise Howley to Peter John Brigham, a son of Janet McCarthy Brigham and John H. Brigham, both of Niantic, Conn. Miss Howley and her fiance are students at Connecticut College. A June wedding is planned.
LEAD: Last year was the first in more than a decade that Boston closed the books on a fiscal year without a deficit, Mayor Raymond L. Flynn said in his State of the City address this week.

LEAD: COUNTY officials responsible for disposing of Westchester's garbage ended last year with a sigh of relief -feeling that they had resolved several potential crises - but acknowledged last week that this year loomed with two major questions unresolved.

LEAD: Coming back to the leadership of both houses of the Congress for the first time in six years, the Democrats are confronted by both an opportunity and a danger. And how they handle this dilemma may very well determine whether they regain control of the White House in l988.

LEAD: GEORGE BALANCHINE'S works contain the most difficult dancing in all ballet. A prime exemplar is the New York City Ballet's ''Kammermusik No. 2,'' set to Paul Hindemith's score of the same title and performed for the first time this season Thursday night at the New York State Theater.

LEAD: Whether the use of anabolic steroids should be allowed is controversial; to deny their popularity and desired effect is foolish. I am amazed at the continued lack of acknowledgement that anabolic steroids increase muscle size and strength. Maybe there is little evidence to prove this but how many scientific studies have been conducted?

LEAD: Baseball fans are told within seconds when Pete Rose breaks a long-standing batting record, but in bridge everything is more leisurely. Unofficial calculations strongly indicate that the title of world's top-ranked woman player changed hands in September, but the World Bridge Federation does not appear to have noticed this, let alone revealed the fact to a waiting world or the players involved.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: For many, Andy Warhol was the quintessential Pop artist of the 1960's. Certainly he became the most journalistically celebrated, since his Campbell soup cans and Brillo boxes readily lent themselves to spectacle and ridicule. If in the public mind a five-year-old could make a painting that looked like a Picasso, it didn't even take an infant to make a Warhol.

LEAD: To the Editor: It is virtually impossible to retain an objective and reasoned viewpoint when discussing the facilities at the Miami airport. Several months have passed since my latest trauma, but time has done little to lessen the impact.

LEAD: Amityville $410,000 333 Grand Central Avenue 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 18-year-old waterfront colonial; family room, fireplace, central A/C, 2-car garage, in-ground pool; taxes $7,000. Bay Shore $127,000 13 Chestnut Drive 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 30-year-old split-level; dining room, eat-in kitchen, den, utility room; taxes $3,200.

LEAD: The last general-interest movie house in downtown Pittsburgh has closed. The owners of the Fulton Mini on Sixth Street said the theater was not profitable because of competition from theater complexes in suburban shopping malls.

LEAD: LIFE seemed gray and gloomily unpredictable in France last week. People waited hours for subway trains that never came. Patients in clinics that lacked emergency power had to do without X-rays. Stores were lighted by candles, and traffic lights went out, causing colossal tie-ups at major intersections.

LEAD: A CONTROVERSIAL and far-reaching tenants'-rights ordinance has been added to the city's municipal code, strengthening the rights of some 1.5 million renters and alarming many landlords. It allows tenants to withhold rent if landlords fail to make ''necessary'' repairs that the tenants request, or to have the repairs made themselves and deduct the cost from their rent.

LEAD: When Charles A. Blackburn moved to this hilly, rustic North Georgia county five years ago from the San Franciso Bay area, he thought is was a perfect balance: a cabin on a lake in woodsy country just 30 miles north of metropolitan Atlanta. Mr.Blackburn is a white man, and he did not notice at first, so close to that city of racial harmony, that there were no black people in Forsyth County.

LEAD: PRESIDENT REAGAN is back at the White House, recuperating from his third major operation since his inauguration, his second in 18 months. A trans-urethral resection of Mr. Reagan's prostate went smoothly last week, and a checkup found no evidence of a recurrence of the colon cancer removed in July 1985.

LEAD: Leslie Church Dearing, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Sears Dearing of Tallahassee, Fla., was married there yesterday to James McVickar Fleming, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter E. Fleming Jr. of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. P. Frank Dearing, the bride's uncle, performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal

LEAD: The acrostic puzzle in The Times Magazine today includes a construction error. In the word to be guessed for clue T, letter 24 fits the literary quotation correctly, but must be replaced by ''R'' to fit the book title.

LEAD: I'VE just come back from the supermarket and am trying to reassure myself that I am not a leper, nor (as yet) certifiably insane. The look on the face of the woman ahead of me in line is still lingering in my mind and insisting that I am one of the above, if not worse.
