LEAD: EVERYONE agrees that sailboats don't sell as well as they once did. But ask about reasons or solutions, and the agreement ends. Some suggest the slump is temporary. Others say the industry needs drastic change.

LEAD: Whenever two or more jazz musicians get together to play the same instrument on the same stage, tradition dictates a ''battle,'' an evening of virtuosic muscle-flexing and crowd-pleasing. The ''Trumpet Summit'' at Fat Tuesday's this week looks more complementary than competetive, though, and that's a good sign.

LEAD: Rhine Pollution Report A group of independent Swiss experts has decided that the long-term effects of a chemical spill Nov. 1 may be less devastating than feared. Page 4. Jet Noise Angers the West Westerners are planning a ''national call-in'' to protest the noise from increasing flights by military jet fighters and bombers.

LEAD: THE zeal and fervor, the secrecy and surprise that used to surround President Reagan's budgets gave way last week to a note of fatalism as his seventh annual blueprint for Federal spending went to Congress.
LEAD: INTERNATIONAL 3-13

LEAD: Governors Cuomo and O'Neill moved into new terms last week and greeted new legislators, Governor O'Neill happily addressing the question of how to spend Connecticut's money and Governor Cuomo concentrating on how not to spend New York's.

LEAD: When the new Speaker of the House, Jim Wright of Texas, gaveled the new Congress to order this week, he did it with an oversized gavel. It was, of course, a Texas product, and it was given to Mr. Wright by the Speaker of the Texas House, Gib Lewis. Both Speakers are from Fort Worth. Mr. Wright was given a leadership award last

LEAD: An item in the Postings column Dec. 28 on Butler Plaza, a new condominium development at 44 Butler Place off Grand Army Plaza in Brooklyn, incorrectly identified the architect. It is Hirsch/ Danois Partnership, Architects & Planners.
LEAD: YEARS AGO, A WRITER named Alexander King went on Jack Paar's late-night television show and zoomed to the top of the best-seller list. It was a terrible moment in the history of literature.

LEAD: Because of a production error, an article in the Westchester Weekly today about Scarsdale's offer of a house to the homeless appears with a section omitted. A corrected version will be printed next Sunday.

LEAD: No need to belabor the obvious: Everybody knows that the Giants had a great season, that they beat the Washington Redskins twice, that Joe Morris ran free the first time they played this season, that Lawrence Taylor ran wild the second time, that now they are playing for a third time, in the National

LEAD: Along with the Acropolis and a few other sites of antiquity, the museums of Athens are the principal attractions of a city that increasingly disappoints visitors by falling short of its renown. The museums compensate, by their variety and interest, for a capital that has suffered more than most from rapid urban growth and the effects of air pollution, noise and traffic.
LEAD: IT always makes me laugh to see a segment on a national news program in which the correspondent signs off, ''And this is so-and-so reporting from Long Island, New York.''

LEAD: An unsafe bridge the city has wanted to tear down for three years will not be dismantled until 1,500 salmon and sturgeon make their spring trek up the Connecticut River, a state engineer said Thursday.

LEAD: To the Editor: I was startled to read the description of John Updike's most recent novel, ''Roger's Version,'' in the first paragraph of the Rev. John P. Meier's fine article ''Jesus Among the Historians'' (Dec. 21). The young student pitted against Roger Lambert is not a divinity student but a computer programmer who has worked on computer research projects at the university where Lambert teaches, as the young man tells Lambert on page 18 of the novel.

LEAD: A retired Central Intelligence Agency official has confirmed to the Senate Intelligence Committee that on the secret mission to Teheran last May, Robert C. McFarlane and his party carried a Bible with a handwritten verse from President Reagan for Iranian leaders.

LEAD: WHEN the Secretary of State, George P. Shultz, spends a few hours here tomorrow on his eight-day African tour, he will be absorbing impressions of the continent's most populous country and one of its most fractious. Nigeria, shaken by seven military coups and a civil war in 26 years of independence, appears to be headed for new political stress.

LEAD: The yearnings of those who want to live by the water - both fresh and saline - may be quenched by a single-family house development planned for Westhampton, L.I. The 67-acre tract includes a nine-acre lake, and South Shore beaches are only a ''couple of minutes away by bicycle and a lot more minutes by car in summer traffic,'' according to Harvey K.

LEAD: Where do all those pinstriped Singapore yuppies go at the end of their air-conditioned days at the office? Rosalind Mowe knows. Some of them return to neighborhoods untouched by two decades of development: to the shop-houses of hundreds of Malay, Indian and Chinese craftsmen, to tearooms and to temples.
LEAD: New evidence ranks the mathematical ability of American primary and high school students ''among the lowest of any industrialized country.''

LEAD: MY mother was born in a tough section of Chicago, near the Loop. To her, this was a nonpareil social blight. It had to be erased at all costs. My mother's solution took the form of a frantic, lifetime pursuit of culture as she understood it.

LEAD: Amid assertions that they must act decisively and soon, thousands of United States-supported rebels have recently entered Nicaragua, and the Reagan Administration contended last week that the Sandinista Government might yet be overthrown.

LEAD: The engagement of Barbara Ann Fowler to Eric Lindsey Houston has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. J. Edward Fowler of Chappaqua, N.Y., and Mantoloking, N.J. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Warnock Houston of Urbana, Ill. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: A picture caption last Sunday in Portfolio of '86, the special Year in Review section, misstated the birthday of Martin Luther King Jr. He was born on Jan. 15, 1929, and the birthday is observed as a national holiday on the third Monday of January.

LEAD: A DECADE ago, the Federal Government embarked on an ambitious $2 billion program to rehabilitate passenger train service between Boston and Washington. Having created Amtrak five years earlier from the ruins of private passenger lines, the Government wanted to make service faster and safer while continuing to accommodate the freight and commuter lines that also used Northeast
LEAD: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 15 food establishments cited for violating the health code.
LEAD: ''The battleground and the waters of the lake are crowded with thousands of Iranian bodies.'' - The Baghdad radio.
LEAD: The Kingdom of the Down and Out is how the Marais district of Paris was described some 30 years ago.

LEAD: NO PARKING RANDY GOTTLIEB, a senior at Great Neck North High School, may have the definitive answer to the school's lack of student parking space: The family chauffeur delivers him to and from school each day in a limousine.

LEAD: IT'S pretty hard, maybe even impossible, not to hate them, but we've got to try. After all, it isn't their fault that they happen to have one of two gifts that are impossible to learn and that money can't buy. The gift is there or it isn't, that's all there is to it, and there's no point saying, ''Why not me?

LEAD: The Veterans Administration must pay an estimated $115,000 in penalties for trying to purge its files of potentially embarrassing documents, a Federal judge in San Francisco ruled last week. The agency had been ordered to supply the documents to a group representing 5,000 veterans who were exposed to radiation in Japan after World War II and in postwar tests of nuclear bombs.

LEAD: Many people in the medical community are relieved to hear that the ''Biotech revolution'' has stalled (''Biotech's Stalled Revolution,'' by Keith Schneider, Nov. 16). The danger of inadvertently creating new pathogens against which we have no effective treatment and no innate immune defense far outweighs the touted benefits of this technology.

LEAD: I WITNESSED AN EPILEPTIC seizure for the first time in 1979, when I was 18. In the center of my college dining hall, a young man who worked in the kitchen had collapsed in a convulsion. Four students quickly piled on top of him. His arms and legs jerked violently and, in the process of trying to hold him down, the students seemed to be smothering him.
LEAD: THE Connecticut Congressional delegation is hoping that Democratic control of the 100th Congress will spur passage of legislation that would provide a seventh Federal judgeship in the state.

LEAD: The engagement of Dawn Lisa Gordon to Ronald Charles Luks has been announced by her mother, Annette J. Gordon of New York. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Luks of North Royalton, Ohio. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: To the Editor: The day we read Fred Ferretti's article ''The Warp and Woof of a Tussle With Customs'' (Travel, Oct. 26) was most distressful in our home. We were leaving three weeks later for China with the hope of purchasing a handmade Chinese carpet. After reading the article, we thought seriously of going to Macy's sale of Chinese rugs and forgetting about this bit of memorabilia, but we decided to take a chance, and, on Nov.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: To the Sports Editor: Regarding the New York Yacht Club's America's Cup campaign, I would like to note that although it is the first time since the inception of the America's Cup in the 19th century that the club has not been involved in the final series, it is also the first time the New York Yacht Club has had to compete to be involved in the final series.
LEAD: REAGAN'S AMERICA Innocents at Home. By Garry Wills. Illustrated. 472 pp. New York: Doubleday & Company. $19.95.
LEAD: Don't Mess With Texas'' read the signs at the state line. It was the nonwimpy approach to highway beautification, an antilittering campaign that didn't say please.
LEAD: IN NEW JERSEY, where the right of the nonsmoker to breathe clean air supersedes the right of the smoker to smoke, it is a punishable offense to light up at the wrong place and time.
LEAD: OF THE 40,000 to 60,000 books published each year, many address a particular need (for example, how to raise a child successfully).

LEAD: Anne Veronica Mahoney, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas W. Mahoney of Milwaukee, was married yesterday to James T. Tynion 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Tynion Jr. of Brooklyn. The Rev. Owen W. Daley performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the chapel of the Convent of the Sacred Heart in New York.

LEAD: MY mother has become a ''snowbird.'' She flew to Florida before the first snowflake fell on Long Island, and she's not returning home until spring. I'm killing two birds with one stone this winter. I'll visit my mother and soak up some Florida sunshine at the same time.

LEAD: THE America's Cup challenge has brought new excitement - and new revenue - to sailing, and focused the eyes of the boating world on Australia. But the overwhelming message of the New York National Boat Show that winds up today at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center is that America's weekend sailors are still motorboat-mad.
LEAD: To the Editor: The question in the Nov. 9 Q & A column regarding intercity bus travel in Mexico struck a chord.

LEAD: It was interesting that R. W. Apple Jr.'s article ''Delivering the South'' (Nov. 30), offered glowing identifications of Democrats, liberals and blacks. But how was Jesse Helms identified? Oh, he is merely a ''former radio announcer.''

LEAD: To the Editor: It may be time to re-evaluate our stereotype of the Ugly American tourist in Europe. We travel to France often and enjoy the country, its culture and its cuisine. We find brasseries most enjoyable for good food at almost any hour, but the noise of the conversations is usually at near-shouting level.
LEAD: MOTORISTS on Interstate 395 near Preston may have thought they had taken a wrong turn recently when they came over the crest of a hill and saw the Statue of Liberty.
LEAD: DIVO Great Tenors, Baritones and Basses Discuss Their Roles. By Helena Matheopoulos. Illustrated. 338 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $25.

LEAD: WITH the United States trade deficit remaining stubbornly high, controversy has arisen about whether the dollar has fallen as far as the standard indexes say it has. Some analysts contend that the dollar has fallen hardly at all from its February 1985 peak, which explains the continuing large deficits.
LEAD: Since William J. Casey's surgery for removal of a cancerous brain tumor Dec. 18, the conviction has been growing that his eventful tenure as Director of Central Intelligence would end soon.
LEAD: Coach Bill Parcells of the Giants has said it over and over. The way to win football games is to run the ball when you have it and to stop the opponents from running it when they have it.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: At St. Agnes Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich, Conn., yesterday Kathleen Monica Grady, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Grady of Greenwich, was married to Thomas Francis Skelly Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Skelly of Westwood, Mass. The Rev. Stephen J. DeLuca performed the ceremony.
LEAD: McDill Boyd, a member of the Republican National Committee since 1965, died Friday of lung cancer. He was 79 years old.

LEAD: LINED up hull-to-hull at New York's passenger ship terminal on the Hudson River are six of the newest and largest ocean-going vessels in the world, each bigger than the Titanic, with a hull four stories high and a deck the length of three football fields.
LEAD: IF Michael Rush has his way, New Wave theater will not be new to New Haven for long.

LEAD: MEN in tights are becoming a more common sight these days in Manhattan, which means one of two things. Either there is a rash of ''Romeo and Juliet'' productions Off Broadway or we are once again on that precipice known as the cutting edge.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Theodore R. Safford of Gardiner, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Leslie Anne Safford, to Claude Robert Spiro, a son of Robert Spiro and Elaine R. Spiro of Great Neck, L.I. Ms. Safford, an associate editor of the Journal of the Audio Engineering Society, graduated from the Emma Willard School and Vassar College.
LEAD: FUNU The Unfinished Saga of East Timor. By Jose Ramos-Horta. Preface by Noam Chomsky. 207 pp. Trenton, N.J.: The Red Sea Press. Cloth, $29.95. Paper, $9.95.

LEAD: The tactics of resistance to South African apartheid took many forms last week, while the Government of P. W. Botha pursued a strategy aimed at counteracting what it regards as adverse publicity in the United States.
LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Cassata of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Donna Cassata, to Dr. Robert Mazziotta, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Mazziotta of White Plains.

LEAD: AT the outset of the 100th Congress last week, the leaders tried to strike a bipartisan chord. The new Democratic Speaker, Jim Wright of Texas, told the House of Representatives, ''We seek not confrontation but cooperation.'' At almost the same moment, Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader in the Senate, was saying, ''It is necessary that we start off on a totally nonpartisan, bipartisan basis.

LEAD: The Joyce Sampler lives up to its name as it continues this week at the Joyce with an assortment of six modern dance companies that is about as varied as the New York dance scene. Mitchell Rose and Diane Epstein open the week on Tuesday with a program that includes some comic classics by the madcap Mr.
LEAD: Richard Halloran notes in his article that ''the battleship dominated naval operations in World War I.''

LEAD: WHEN Governor Kean delivers his State of the State Message to the Legislature Tuesday, he will be firing the opening gun of what promises to be the most politically charged year in the Senate and Assembly in more than a decade.
LEAD: Arthur Lake, who portrayed the comic strip character Dagwood Bumstead and called for help with a high-pitched ''Blonnndie!'' in more than two dozen films, has died at the age of 81.

LEAD: The engagement of Michelle Ann Pagnucco to Eric Bostrup has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Robert I. Pagnucco of South Salem, N.Y., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Earl W. Bostrup of Purdys, N.Y. A June wedding is planned. Miss Pagnucco, a graduate of Marymount College in Tarrytown, N.Y., received a master's degree in nutrition last month from Case Western Reserve University.

LEAD: Caroline Hudson Lynch of New York and Palm Beach, Fla., a trustee of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine and the Gordon-Conwell Theological Seminary in South Hamilton, Mass., was married yesterday to Leonard K. Firestone of Beverly Hills, Calif., the retired president of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company of California.

LEAD: Assistant Secretary of State Richard W. Murphy, right, during a meeting yesterday in Cairo with Esmat Abdel-Meguid, Egypt's Foreign Minister. Mr. Murphy, who has been shuttling between Israel and Jordan to try to revive stalled peace initiative, is in Egypt to affirm American policy against supplying of arms to Iran, despite the recent revelation of the secret sale of arms to Iran by the United States.

LEAD: ''Why would successful, ambitious women choose to be simply mothers?'' There is nothing simple about the role of mother. It is the most complex, challenging and rewarding ''position'' I have ever held. It is a disgrace that more people don't understand this. KARLA STUEMPFLE MSALL Buffalo

LEAD: One of the last purchases I made in Papua New Guinea was a man's pocketbook. Clutch-shaped, it was deftly fashioned from natural-colored, dried sago palm fibers and worked in a herringbone pattern. But what clinched the sale were the decorations. To avert the potential hazard posed by the two sharp wooden sticks framing the mouth of the purse, the weaver had swaddled them in bubble-gum wrappers.
LEAD: NEW AND COLLECTED POEMS #1970-1985. By David Ignatow. 332 pp. Middletown, Conn.: Wesleyan University Press. Cloth, $30. Paper, $12.95.
LEAD: Columbia University announced yesterday the 65 newspaper editors, executives and others who will make up the jury to submit nominations for this year's Pulitzer Prizes in journalism.
LEAD: A NEW doctoral-degree program in business at the University of Connecticut has attracted more than 30 applicants for each seat to be available this fall.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Lowell I. Mazie of Huntingdon Valley, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Linda Sue Mazie, to Robert Martin Cohen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton H. Cohen of Stamford, Conn. The wedding is planned for April 5. Miss Mazie is director of residential services at the Boston Center for Residential Living.

LEAD: To the Sports Editor: In his article marking the contribution to basketball by Stanford University's legendary player, Hank Luisetti (''He Fired the Shot That Started the Revolution,'' The New York Times, Dec. 30), Malcolm Moran focuses on Luisetti's role in the contest against Long Island University in the old 50th Street Madison Square

LEAD: CONDOMINIUMS, which shot up alongside the birch and pine trees of Northeast ski resorts in the 1970's, seemed to push chalets and other single-family homes to the edge of extinction, as well as bruising motels a bit.

LEAD: THERE are very few problems confronting local government in New Jersey that cannot be traced directly to the state's onerous system of property taxation. And there should be no higher priority for the Governor and the Legislature than to find solutions for it.

LEAD: THE industry, now beginning its summer retail season, always paints a rosy picture for consumers at the boat show. Based on current projections, the retailers manning the show booths are entitled to be enthusiastic. But there is one area that industry officials openly admit could be a major impediment to growth: lack of waterfront facilities.

LEAD: Dashiell Hammett, who died a quarter-century ago owing the Government $100,000 in back taxes, apparently had something in the bank after all. Among the papers of Mr. Hammett, whose many detective novels include ''The Maltese Falcon'' and ''The Thin Man,'' curators at the University of Texas have found a half-dozen unpublished stories and many stories that never appeared in English.

LEAD: THE COLONIAL HAREM By Malek Alloula. Translated by Myrna Godzich and Wlad Godzich. Introduction by Barbara Harlow. Illustrated. 135 pp. Minneapolis: University of Minnesota Press. Cloth, $29.50. Paper, $13.95.

LEAD: To the Editor: I was saddened to read your story about the Binghams (''The Binghams, After the Fall,'' Dec. 21), not by their plight - for they are strangers to me - but by what has happened to one of my favorite newspapers, The Louisville Courier-Journal.

LEAD: The engagement of Sydney Guest Tritschler and Brian Hugh Sharples has been announced by her parents, Marigolden G. Tritschler of Shrewsbury, Mass., and Dr. Donald H. Tritschler of Worcester, Mass. Mr. Sharples is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth R. Sharples of Braintree, Mass.

LEAD: The Town Council will try to solve its budget problems with a raffle in which half the pot goes to the winner and half to Elsmere's general fund. Robert McWilliams, the town mansger, said he expected the first drawing to generate $200 to $400. The town, whose budget for 1987 is $925,000, just lost $125,000 through the elimination of the Federal revenue sharing program.

LEAD: IN the various embodiments of his stage life over a decade, the fictitious character David Levinsky has materialized in such diverse settings as the auditorium of a synagogue on Manhattan's Upper East Side and a regional theater in New Jersey.

LEAD: CELEBRATING BIRD: The Triumph of Charlie Parker. By Gary Giddins. (Beech Tree/Morrow, $15.95.) Charlie (Yardbird) Parker, coming out of Kansas City, Kan., in the Depression, struggled in Harlem to find a voice on saxophone. He hit his stride in the 1940's and liberated improvisational rhythms with brilliant innovations that have exerted a profound influence on jazz since World War II.

LEAD: Anne Hay Gurin and Stephen J. Tall plan to be married in June, the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Gurin of Richlandtown, Pa., have announced. Mr. Tall is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony D. Tall of Cheshire, Conn.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Francis Leahy of Bronxville, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Ann Leahy, to George Jonathan Renner 3d, a son of Mr. Renner Jr. of Bronxville and Cynthia Bjork of Greenwich, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: ''I don't see a lot of hootin' and hollerin','' but ''it ought to bring new confidence into the market.'' - Anthony Woodruff, co-director of equity trading at Kidder, Peabody, on the Dow breaching 2,000.

LEAD: FOR nearly three years, there has been talk of William Bolcom's massive setting, for a Symphony-of-a-Thousand-sized ensemble, of William Blake's complete poetic collection, ''Songs of Innocence and of Experience.'' Finally, Friday night, New Yorkers got a chance to hear this 140-minute score live, courtesy of the Next Wave Festival, Lukas Foss and the Brooklyn Philharmonic, who presented it at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Opera House (the third and final performance is today at 2 P.M.
LEAD: FROM Kunming in the far southwest to Beijing in the north, tens of thousands of college students have marched through the streets of China's cities in the last month, demanding more democracy.

LEAD: Geanne Perlman, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Israel Perlman of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., was married last night to Dr. Kenneth Paul Rosenberg, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Rosenberg of Philadelphia. Rabbi Elliot Spar performed the ceremony at the Roslyn (L.I.) Country Club.

LEAD: ''This was the Bloomingdale's of the Hudson Valley,'' said Nachum Kalka, a New York developer, who recently bought the building that once housed the Luckey Platt department store in Poughkeepsie, N.Y.

LEAD: To the Editor: I agree with Mr. Chiswick on the desirability of having an immigration policy that favors applicants for immigration who are most likely to be productive members of American society. However, I think Mr. Chiswick errs when he equates the educational level of the applicant with his probable productivity.

LEAD: To the Editor: ''What's New in the Funeral Business'' (Dec. 14) made no reference to the country's 150 Memorial Societies. These are consumer-controlled, non-profit organizations that help their 250,000 members plan in advance the service and disposition of body they want. Some societies negotiate low prices with funeral homes; others simply collect prices for a set of simple funerals.

LEAD: The first thing to understand about bidding for the services of opera's superstars is that it's a singer's market. There are far, far more blank slots on opera house calendars waiting to be filled by a Domingo or a Freni than there are nights in Placido Domingo's or Mirella Freni's datebooks waiting to be filled by an opera engagement.
LEAD: SINCE two-platoon football came to the National Football League in 1950, the Giants, in lean years and good, have been celebrated for their defense.

LEAD: Jonathan Rotenberg, president of the Boston Computer Society, tells a story about the day he met Steven Jobs, co-founder of Apple Computer. LEAD: FRAMED, life-size portraits of chickens hang on the walls of E. Lea Marsh's home in Old Lyme. About 40 chickens scratch and squawk in their coops in his yard. And sometimes the birds get their feathers fluffed and their toenails trimmed in his laundry room.

LEAD: THE weeping willow at our house was a constant annoyance from spring until late fall, when family life turned reluctantly indoors. Reigning over the backyard, the willow spread its spindly leaves into the barbecue, over the picnic table and onto the wooden deck designed to angle around its swollen trunk.

LEAD: Massachusetts, which after Hawaii has the worst inmate overcrowding problem in the country, has embarked on a program to construct two new state prisons, replace three county jails and renovate other aging facilities.
LEAD: Michael Jordan scored 31 points and Charles Oakley added 21 tonight, leading the Chicago Bulls to a 119-109 victory over the Nets.

LEAD: A LITTLE white house with a picket fence may become the home of a now-homeless family if the village of Scarsdale, which owns it, and the county, which has hundreds of homeless families to shelter, can come to an agreement.

LEAD: Central Intelligence Agency officers in Costa Rica were far more deeply involved than previously acknowledged in advising the Nicaraguan rebels on military and political strategy last year, according to rebel officers, Costa Rican officials and Congressional aides.

LEAD: Along Brighton Beach Avenue, under the El and within sight and scent of the sea, there are Russian groceries and doctors' offices, Russian nightclubs and movies - so many staples of the old life that the neighborhood has come to be called Little Odessa.
LEAD: MARY EURIST'S father was a tenor in a church in Moscow. Her mother was also a choir singer in Russia.
LEAD: In a major development in the Sri Lankan civil war, infighting among rival Tamil rebel groups has begun to anger India and damage the guerrillas' reputation in the eyes of sympathizers.
LEAD: GENEVA, Jan. 10 -

LEAD: To the Editor: Mr. Chiswick's contention that the amnesty provisions of the Simpson-Rodino Immigration Reform Act will make ''illegal aliens ... more likely to become a permanent feature of the labor market ...'' simply ignores the fact that the group to which amnesty applies is already a permanent feature of the labor market.

LEAD: To the Editor: ''When the Boss Is Unbearable'' (Dec. 28) omits discussion of why a boss acts that way. If the employee can understand the boss's motives there is a wider choice available than quitting the job or saying, ''When you...I feel...''

LEAD: Apparently life at the Royal Marine commando training camp was not too tough for Prince Edward, just too - well, common. There was quite a stir in Britain last week when word leaked out that the youngest son of Queen Elizabeth II was considering quitting the year-long commando course only four months after starting it.

LEAD: Two United States Army colonels have been implicated in efforts to sell arms to Iran for private gain while they were on active duty in sensitive European assignments, one as early as 1983, according to military sources, arms dealers and confidential documents.

LEAD: Ohad Naharin's choreography is notable for its movement quality -especially for its smoothness within technical difficulty. But there is also an undercurrent of feeling that makes itself evident at all times.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Burt Brown of Edison, N.J., and Rock Hill, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their M. Crock, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Crock of South Dartmouth, Mass., and Delray Beach, Fla. The wedding is planned for March.
LEAD: ALTHOUGH chemical drain cleaners often work well on clogged sinks, they seldom help a clogged toilet much.

LEAD: Given the evident difficulties of running New York's subways, as well as the bureaucracy they spawned, it might not seem wise to put 473 goals for the year in writing, much less project them in foot-high letters onto a screen at the front of a crowded auditorium.

LEAD: Ten years ago, Virginia Zabriskie took a leap of faith and opened a Paris branch of her Zabriskie Gallery, which she devoted exclusively to photography. Situated in the shadow of the Centre George Pompidiou, the elegant and intimate Galerie Zabriskie has presented the work of American photographers such as Harry Callahan and Lee Friedlander to a European audience.

LEAD: Gabelle Ada Aarons, a writer, and Michael Stewart Eisele, an artist, were married yesterday at Valeur, a historic mansion in Rhinebeck, N.Y., by Town Justice Joseph J. Waters. The bride is the daughter of Barbaralee Ross Kantrowitz of Brooklyn Heights and Newport, R.I., and Jonas Aarons of South Orange, N.J., and Clinton, N.Y.

LEAD: To the Editor: Regarding your Dec. 7 article on Brewster [ ''If You're Thinking of Living in Brewster,'' ] : You failed to mention that those young professionals moving into the area probably first heard of Brewster while watching television when they were growing up in the mid-60's.

LEAD: THE League-I.S.C.M. (a merciful abbreviation of the League of Composers-International Society for Contemporary Music, U.S. Section Inc.) presented a characteristically diverse and engrossing program at Merkin Concert Hall on Thursday night.

LEAD: To the Sports Editor: In the annual review of the year in sports (The New York Times, Dec. 28), Dave Anderson noted that the Celtics' overall record of 82-18, an .820 percentage, was the best in National Basketball Association history. Actually, two championship teams led by Wilt Chamberlain - the 1971-72 Lakers, who were 81-16 (an .835 percentage), and the 1966-67 Philadelphia 76ers, who were 79-17 (an .823 percentage) - had better records according to winning percentage.

LEAD: In Austria lederhosen are not so much a pair of trousers as a way of life. Worn summer and winter, casually and as Sunday best, these leather shorts or knickers are passed down from father to son, so that buying lederhosen is an investment that might cost anywhere from hundreds to thousands of dollars depending upon length (almost kneecap or knicker), embroidery (without or with, machine or hand) and whether the lederhosen is readymade or custom fit.
LEAD: When a political candidate in Monroe County believes his opponent has tried some dirty tricks, he can file a complaint with the county's Fair Campaign Practices Committee.

LEAD: EVEN though Washington seems overrun with memorials and the Federal Government says it is running out of space for new ones, Representative George Miller, a California Democrat, said he had substantial support for his proposal: a national peace garden in the capital.

LEAD: Does no writer on the subject of careers versus motherhood have the temerity to tell a probable truth: that many corporate women quit ''to raise my children'' purely and simply because working is just too tough?

LEAD: To the Editor: Your use of the term ''rent bills'' in the Dec. 7 Q. & A. column is incorrect. Practically all standard form leases in use today in New York that rent is payable in a certain fashion.

LEAD: After their second consecutive tie, this time 2-2 with the Vancouver Canucks today at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, the Devils were without a victory in their last 10 games. But they viewed the streak from a practical perspective.

LEAD: SINCE September, school boards and teacher representatives throughout the state have been negotiating to raise teachers' salaries, with the vast majority of Connecticut's communities expected to follow suit by the spring.
LEAD: FAIR-HOUSING advocates say that a case now before the courts could help provide a remedy for the problem of substandard housing on Long Island.
LEAD: True to its passing heritage, the American Football Conference features a pair of dominating quarterbacks in Sunday's championship game.

LEAD: THE winner of last year's Indianapolis 500, Bobby Rahal, was named the winner of the Jerry Titus award as the outstanding driver of 1986 by the American Auto Racing Writers and Broadcasters Association. . . . Kamie Eldridge, a point guard who led the University of Texas to the women's collegiate basketball championship, was given the Broderick Award as the nation's outstanding female athlete.

LEAD: To the Editor: Before Mr. Bennett continues to make broad-based accusations of ''scrappy marketing'' and misrepresentation by commercial banks (''Now, the Age of Fast Buck Banking,'' Dec. 14), let him attend a sales training session. The strong presence of integrity that he will encounter will far outweigh the wrongs some banks have done while entering the ''financial services revolution.

LEAD: The engagement of Rosayn DiRe to Eric Austen Anderson has been announced by Mrs. John J. DiRe of Bronxville, N.Y., mother of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Eugene Anderson of Northport, L.I. A May wedding is planned.

LEAD: Military jet fighters and bombers on training missions are increasingly shattering the serenity of the American West, sowing anger and bitterness among rural residents who in the past had little quarrel with military activities.

LEAD: THE photographer stood in the midday summer sun. Her subjects posed in the shade, standing or sitting in the doorway of the First Baptist Church in Riverhead, before a blank, black paper screen that sometimes wafted and billowed in a breeze.

LEAD: The New Preston Congregational Church in Connecticut was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Deborah Graham Ewen, a vice president of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States in New York, to W. Ward Whipple, a vice president and trust officer of the Scarsdale (N.Y.) National Bank and Trust Company.
LEAD: Unbeaten Patrizio Oliva of Italy retained his World Boxing Association junior-welterweight title tonight with a unanimous 15-round decision over Mexico's Rodolfo Gonzales.
LEAD: ANYWHERE BUT HERE By Mona Simpson. 406 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

LEAD: Leaders of the nation's oldest black civil-rights organization yesterday staunchly defended Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward's handling of the attack on three blacks by a group of whites in Howard Beach, Queens.

LEAD: The engagement of Kimberly Belden Switzer to Brian Devin Robbins has been announced by the future bride's parents, Ruth Gray Switzer and H. Kirtland Switzer 2d, both of East Sandwich, Mass. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Robbins of New York City, Bedford, N.Y., and Palm Beach, Fla. A summer wedding is planned.

LEAD: IT'S NO secret that public officials at the local, county and state levels are grappling with the unenviable task of determining what to do with the more than 9 million tons of garbage collected in New Jersey each year. Having it picked up from the curb and taken away for what amounts to little more than long-term storage in a landfill is a luxury we can no longer afford economically or, more importantly, environmentally.

LEAD: WHEN Stewart Gordon was offered the position of vice president of academic affairs at Queens College about a year and a half ago, he held off making a decision until he could investigate the local housing market.

LEAD: To the Editor: Our new book, ''Visiting the Art Museum,'' obviously made your reviewer, Grace Glueck (Dec. 21), very uncomfortable. It is a children's book after all, not an adult guide as she seems to assume. And it is just Ms. Glueck's didactic attitude toward the mix of children and art museums we are trying to dispel with this book.
LEAD: Prosecutors won a murder conviction today without the evidence of a reporter who refused to testify about an interview he had with the defendant.

LEAD: Pope John Paul II condemned the arms race today as a fundamental cause of friction between rich and poor countries, and he called on nations to cut their stockpiles of weapons to levels compatible with self-defense.

LEAD: There is a new phenonemnon in New York. Every night at 7:30 hordes of eager diners pour out of restaurants, from the intimate French bistros of Greenwich Village to the 874-seat ''Only Guacamole'' Yupeterias on the Upper West Side. Across Manhattan former ''foodies'' are forfeiting a final mousse, and leaving a souffle flat.

LEAD: WHETHER your preference is for solo recitals, chamber music or orchestral programs, you have quite a choice this afternoon.

LEAD: A PAIR of computer professionals began an unlikely charity two years ago -giving computers and computer instruction to nonprofit agencies around the state.

LEAD: OF the many socially engaged singer-songwriters who emerged out of the folk music movement of the 1960's, few have offered a more clearly focused vision of injustice than Buffy Sainte-Marie, the longtime crusader for American Indian rights.

LEAD: Jonathan Jay Pollard, the former Navy intelligence analyst who admitted last summer that he had peddled his employer's property to Israel, is not a man of high motives, according to prosecutors. Mr. Pollard, who is to be sentenced next month on spying charges, contended that it was for love of Israel that he stole and sold American defense secrets.

LEAD: I liken the recent steroid scare to the first warnings concerning cigarette smoking. In the early 1960's, the potential hazards of nicotine were made public. Most smokers continued to smoke and, in time, passed their dangerous habit to younger generations. Today, the initial warnings condemning the use of steroids are being similarly ignored.
LEAD: 'Even if you indict and convict every mobster involved in corruption, under current conditions, someone else will come along, recognize the potential and become the new predators.'

LEAD: THE chief distinctions of Samuel Ramey's singing, all discernible in the song recital he gave Friday night in a sold-out Carnegie Hall, arise from a vocal technique appreciably finer than that cultivated by his bass colleagues on the operatic scene. He sings with sonorous power, but stops short of the force that might jeopardize steadiness and control.

LEAD: THE Guarneri String Quartet is among the smoothest and most elegant of chamber ensembles, yet the group's Wednesday evening concert at Alice Tully Hall was only sporadically successful.

LEAD: Although it's true that players' use of cocaine and other illegal drugs sets a bad example, it is the players' use of legally prescribed anabolic steroids for which the National Football League itself must bear primary responsibility.

LEAD: In 1968, Jiri Menzel's ''Closely Watched Trains'' - a compassionately funny tale of a railway crew in Nazi-occupied Bohemia - won the Academy Award for the best foreign-language film. The Czech director remembers that it was a turbulent time in America and that he received the Oscar two days after the assassination of Martin Luther King Jr.

LEAD: THE withdrawal of Soviet troops from Afghanistan is not far off, the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, announced last week. ''This event,'' he predicted, ''is not behind the mountains.''

LEAD: At a branch gallery of the Whitney Museum of American Art here, the story of the artist Louise Nevelson's life is being told in a diary of terra-cotta, bronze, Plexiglas and, especially, in throwaway scraps of black-painted wood.

LEAD: Senator Edward M. Kennedy today issued an unabashed liberal manifesto calling for new programs to assist the needy and criticizing ''ideologies such as laissez-faire and survival of the fittest.''
LEAD: WITH advances in health-care contributing to longer lives, the market for barrier-free and assisted-living housing for the elderly has steadily increased.

LEAD: Prof. Alex B. Novikoff, a cellular biologist and a professor of pathology at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine for the last 28 years, died Friday at the college's hospital. He was 73 years old and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

LEAD: WHEN he got the results of a survey of salaries in the National Hockey League, Alan Eagleson, the executive director of the N.H.L. Players Association, thought he had stumbled on a financial anomaly. Goaltenders, he found, were the lowest-paid players on Canadian teams and the highest-paid on American teams.

LEAD: THE Connecticut Resource Recovery Authority has issued bonds for a $42 million waste-to-energy plant to be built in Wallingford. The action, taken in the final week of 1986, signaled the overcoming of another of many obstacles by the authority, which is seeking to erect six of the plants.

LEAD: As legislators streamed into town for the start of the 100th Congress, James Robert Jones, for almost 25 years one of this town's political power brokers, contemplated sleeping late and catching up on his reading. He was out of it, no longer a member of the House of Representatives.

LEAD: When Adm. John Poindexter was asked why he had condoned an apparently illegal diversion of funds from the Iranian arms sale to the ''contras'' trying to overthrow the Sandinista regime in Nicaragua, President Reagan's former national security adviser is reported to have replied: ''I felt sorry for the contras.
LEAD: To the Editor: Mr. Pearlman's article gave the exact picture of what is happening to the brush industry.

LEAD: To the Editor: Neither William F. Bolger nor Jack A. Blum have properly defined the problems in aviation (''Breaking a Budgetary Logjam,'' Forum, Dec. 7). For example, Mr. Blum refers to the ''continuing erosion of the margin of safety.'' No one has ever defined what ''margin of safety'' is, let alone figured out how to measure it.

LEAD: Amid the national celebration of the bicentennial of the Constitution, a group of prominent political figures and analysts here has concluded that the political structure the framers set up impedes solutions to many of today's problems and needs to be changed.

LEAD: The Soviet press began reporting new details this week of the violent anti-Russian rioting last month in the republic of Kazakhstan, and it placed part of the blame on ethnic segregation in local universities.
LEAD: Select committees were established in both houses to investigate the sale of weapons to Iran and the diversion of money to the Nicaraguan rebels, or contras.
LEAD: Proverbial truth is debatable.

LEAD: The engagement of Deborah Brewster Richardson to Richard Hinrichs Beinecke has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas deQuartel Richardson of Norwalk, Conn. Mr. Beinecke is the son of Mary Ann Beinecke of Williamstown, Mass., and Herbert H. Hinrichs of Tenafly, N.J. He is the stepson of Walter Beinecke Jr.

LEAD: The Fairchild family, which founded Women's Wear Daily and W, has long been a force in American fashion. Now Jill Fairchild, the daughter of Women's Wear's publisher, John Fairchild, is stepping into the family business with a line of fanciful shoe accessories.
LEAD: DR. MARVIN STEINBERG was neither amused nor pleased when a checkout clerk at a supermarket in Hamden tried to sell him a $1 lottery ticket while giving him his change.

LEAD: WHILE most eyes are again on Wall Street, as the Dow finally broke the magical 2,000 level, some experts argue that recent stirrings of life in precious metals prices may portend tougher times ahead for stocks and bonds.

LEAD: Reacting to all the concern about trade deficits and sagging productivity, some business people and members of Congress have decided that the main thing America needs to do is hone its competitive instincts.

The Rev. Herbert Draesel performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity in Manhattan.

LEAD: WHEN ANTONY WORRALL-THOMPSON MADE up his mind in 1978 to learn the secrets of the great chefs, he went about it methodically and boldly. He purchased a Michelin guide and traveled through France to visit the 18 restaurants that had been awarded its coveted top rating of three stars. At the end of each meal, he would ask the chef for his autograph.

LEAD: Europe's Trains Question:I want to visit West Germany, the Netherlands, Austria, Switzerland and Italy and would like to know about books and maps that give the best routes by rail and mention historic sites. - A. S. M., Valley Stream, N.Y. Answer:There is plenty of planning material available and there is no need for concern about the frequency of trains because services are so extensive.

LEAD: THE concert scene is beginning to emerge from its holiday hibernation, the Emelin Theater leading the way with three major recitals this week, and at least four major events vying for your attention next Sunday afternoon.
LEAD: OVER THE BEACH By Zalin Grant. 311 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $18.95.
LEAD: A popular Maine district judge is facing his second charge of misconduct in office in two years stemming from his policy of dealing severely with drunken drivers and juvenile offenders.

LEAD: France demanded again today that West Germany bear the cost of ending the speculation crisis that erupted on international currency markets last week as the French franc declined and the West German mark soared in value.

LEAD: The Soviet press routinely exposes the misdeeds of Government functionaries and agencies. But rarely does it attack top officials, let alone suggest that the K.G.B. might abuse its enormous powers.

LEAD: It isn't easy to be a major league baseball fan in Washington. Since the Senators left town in 1971 to become the Texas Rangers, only an occasional unsanctioned contest, usually between creaking old-timers, has raised any diamond dust at R.F.K. Stadium. But now local fans of the New York Mets are excited because their World Champions have been booked into R.F.K.
LEAD: Barbara Basler states that women who choose to leave the work force, even temporarily, to raise their children ''could undermine the standing of other women in their companies.''

LEAD: NEW YORK CITY is preparing to give tax breaks to developers of market-rate residential buildings in the core of Manhattan if they agree to generate affordable apartments elsewhere in the five boroughs.
LEAD: The Bohemians, which calls itself the New York musicians club, will celebrate its 80th anniversary this year.

Flyers 5, Bruins 4: A goal by Murray Craven at 13 minutes 5 seconds of the third period snapped a 4-4 tie and gave the Philadelphia Flyers a 5-4 victory over the Bruins yesterday in Boston. Craven took a pass from Tim Kerr in a scramble in front of the Boston net and whirled round to beat the Bruins' goalie, Bill Ranford.

LEAD: Fifteen years after the Clean Water Act, many rivers and lakes are still disgracefully polluted with sewage and poisonous chemicals. Congress ardently desires to make America's waters swimmable and fishable once again. But President Reagan persists in opposing a bill to renew the Clean Water Act. The new House has just insisted on this legislation and the new Senate is about to do the same.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: ON any given day, 2.5 million of the country's businesses are up for sale. And while much is heard about the large companies that come on the block, 98 percent of the businesses looking for buyers fall into the small- to medium-size category, those with yearly sales of less than $30 million. Yet, the number of business-brokerage offices equipped to serve this huge market are few; only 3,000 nationwide, compared with 150,000 real-estate brokerage offices - even though business sales account for $300 billion a year, $50 billion more than real-estate sales generate yearly.

LEAD: Day after day, Tommy Tune had been trying to teach a tap-dancing routine to Don Amendolia, a chubby, balding actor who had never danced before. Day after day Mr. Amendolia clomped and clattered, sweating with exertion as he stumbled through segments of the routine.

LEAD: The trouble with the deserted island of many travelers' fantasies is that it is, well, deserted. Aside from inhabitants, it also lacks hammocks, restrooms and bars. Now, half a dozen cruise ships plying the Caribbean are doing something about that problem.

LEAD: JAZZ GUITARIST AT 'Y' Barney Kessel had played jazz guitar with celebrity musicians for more than 40 years and had recorded 50 albums before he appeared in New York City for the first time as a headliner on his own.

LEAD: At the Plymouth Church in Framingham Center, Mass., yesterday Cheryl Ann Swaim, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd B. Dr. Daniel Leavitt performed the Congregational ceremony.
LEAD: Jim Wright, the Speaker of the House, pledged today to rush through Congress a $500 million program to build shelters for the homeless and to seek money for food aid this winter.

LEAD: WHEN I was in elementary school, I always did my homework at the kitchen table. As I worked, Mom ironed, and when I needed help Mom was there.
LEAD: In an effort to save money, the Army has ordered the early discharge of most enlisted men and women who will end their service in this fiscal year, according to an Army spokesman.

LEAD: The management of North Castle Partners of Greenwich, Conn., has bought the agency back from Foote, Cone & Belding Communications because of conflict-of-interest problems perceived by prospective clients. F.C.B., the nation's ninth-largest advertising agency, acquired North Castle two years ago.

LEAD: YESTERDAY afternoon's concert by the American Composers Orchestra at Carnegie Hall spoke several languages, all deriving from a common root. Tonality has been reasserting itself in music ever more strongly, and its magnetic pull on the ears of both composers and listeners was central to each of the four pieces heard here.

LEAD: Interest in teaching has increased among college freshmen for the fourth consecutive year but there has been a decline in students seeking careers in the computer field, according to a new study.

He and some other boys from the neighborhood challenged each other to a block race.

LEAD: On the night he was hurt, before the regular season even began, George McPhee cried. His shoulder was separated completely, and he was told that he would not return until February, if then. So he turned the collars of his coat up and left the lockerroom.

LEAD: Firefighters spraying the wreckage of a building in Murray, a suburb of Salt Lake City. Structure was destroyed in an explosion late Saturday after a car crashed into the building and ruptured a natural gas line. Three police officers, three firefighters and two medical technicians were injured slightly in the blast.

LEAD: The Bridge column on Wednesday referred erroneously to Maurice Paul, a Canadian expert. He died in Montreal last month at the age of 62.

LEAD: Businesses across the country are struggling with the new immigration law's attempts to curb the hiring of illegal aliens, and perhaps nowhere is the concern more evident than in southern California, where several million illegal aliens are believed to be employed.

LEAD: AS the seasons for the ducks that are more traditionally hunted draw to a close (in some Northeast states they are already over), a few enterprising waterfowlers turn to the sea ducks -scoters, eiders and old squaws - and of them the scoters, black, surf, and white-winged, are the most sought after.

LEAD: More than 104,000 fans are expected to fill the Rose Bowl for the Super Bowl Jan. 25, but city officials concede the stadium does not meet current fire and building codes, a newspaper reported today.

LEAD: Sixty-six students at William Alexander Junior High School in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn are spending two class periods a week in stores along Brooklyn's Fifth Avenue. They are learning the practical applications of science in beauty salons, plumbing stores, ice-cream parlors and other businesses.
LEAD: The United States plans to conduct its first nuclear test of the year on Feb. 5, according to Government officials.

LEAD: GALA performances of scenes stitched together from several operas have a long and honorable place in operatic history. They serve especially to celebrate great singers in the autumn of their careers. Dame Nellie Melba, for instance, bade her farewells in the 1920's in a program of acts from ''Romeo et Juliette,'' ''Boheme'' and ''Otello.

LEAD: Hampered by political and physical ailments, President Reagan has pared down his agenda for his final two years in office, and will focus on protecting past gains rather than on promoting new programs, White House officials say.

LEAD: IN his new play, ''North Shore Fish,'' Israel Horovitz focuses on the workers in a frozen-fish processing plant that is about to go out of business. LEAD: Excerpts from ''Challenger: A Major Malfunction'' by one of the finalists in NASA's Journalist-in-Space competition, Malcolm McConnell, published Jan. 2 by Doubleday:

LEAD: A Federal judge imposed a 20-year prison sentence Saturday on a man convicted of playing a leading role in the racketeering activities of an international Taiwanese gang, the United Bamboo. The gang leader, Chen Chih-yi, 35 years old, of Houston, was convicted, along with 10 other men, in a trial last year in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

LEAD: After six years of improved performances, city ambulances are taking longer to get to the scene of emergencies in New York City, according to figures provided by the city's Emergency Medical Services. The signficance of the increase is in dispute.

LEAD: Every weekday evening at 7:55, at least 50 million Brazilians scattered across this huge land, including one neatly dressed 82-year-old man with a telephone by his side, watch the day's news as chosen, interpreted and broadcast by Globo TV, the country's largest television network.

LEAD: California health officials have refused to participate in a Federal study of acquired immune deficiency syndrome, saying it violates the state's confidentiality laws because it tests blood specimens without patients' written permission.
LEAD: A Federal appeals court has upheld the power of the Comptroller General of the United States to block the awarding of Government contracts while he investigates possible irregularities.

LEAD: PERHAPS it is the maturity that comes with losing yachting's most valuable trophy and having the resiliency to try to win it back. But Dennis Conner has changed since his 1983 America's Cup campaign.

LEAD: A Brazilian federal court has banned the sales of powdered milk imported from Western Europe because it has been found to be contaminated with radioactive residue from the Chernobyl nuclear accident in the Soviet Union.

LEAD: Behind the gloss of South Korea's economic boom are thousands of disgruntled employees -workers who increasingly decry their inability to form independent trade unions. LEAD: New Yorkers, to say nothing of visitors, have a lot to do: working, shopping, going to the movies, the gym, the hairdresser. All that racing around can bring on a big appetite, which is where sidewalk food vendors come in handy. With hardly a break in stride, men, women and children on the go can grab a chewy pretzel (sometimes even a warm one), a hot dog (sometimes even a hot one) or a piece of fruit (bananas, which don't drip on fur coats, are extremely popular).

LEAD: IN the gospel according to Rudyard Kipling, East is East and West is West and never the twain shall meet. But then Rudyard Kipling was never in Giants Stadium when the wind was blowing. LEAD: For the past few weeks tourists have been asking the doorman at the Plaza in New York whether Mick Dundee is registered at the hotel.

LEAD: A flurry of account assignments made Friday a busy day in adland.
LEAD: A coincidence in which a City Council primary election falls this year on April 14, the same day as the first day of Passover, has stirred a controversy here.
LEAD: Most trains ran on schedule today and electrical service returned to normal as thousands of striking workers began returning to their jobs.
LEAD: West Germany, the Netherlands and Belgium agreed today to increase the value of their currencies in an attempt to end the turbulence that engulfed international currency markets last week.

LEAD: BECAUSE the number of Americans who suffer from Alzheimer's disease, a degenerative condition of the brain that causes dementia, is expected to triple in the next half-century, families should begin planning how they might care for aged relatives who suffer from the disorder.
LEAD: Britain, a nation that just a decade ago went to the International Monetary Fund for a bail-out loan, has become the world's second-largest international creditor, trailing only Japan.

LEAD: A police officer who fatally shot an elderly woman two years ago during an eviction will ask a judge, rather than a jury, to decide his guilt or innocence when his manslaughter trial begins today in the Bronx.

LEAD: President Reagan has been ordered by his doctors to limit his physical activities for the next six weeks in line with the usual regimen for a man who has just been discharged from a hospital for a transurethral resection of the prostate.
LEAD: A chart on Dec. 25, about the sequence of events in the Iran-contra affair, misstated the date of the Rev.
LEAD: A newcomer to Washington dialed information in quest of an exercise class the other day and asked for the telephone number for Great Bodies.
LEAD: The Soviet Union has given signs in recent pronouncements of tilting further toward Iraq in the Iran-Iraq war, according to Western and Arab diplomats and experts on Iran.
LEAD: The fishbowl life of the Royal Family has come under new and heavy public ogling in recent weeks.
LEAD: When it was over and the Giants had guaranteed themselves a spot in the Super Bowl, William F. Gloede wondered if he had been dreaming. It looked easy, too easy.

LEAD: Caroline Jones, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Jones of Princeton, N.J., was married last night to Peter Galison, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Galison of New York. Rabbi Peter Rubinstein performed the ceremony at the One Fifth Avenue restaurant in New York.
LEAD: It started Saturday afternoon. The downtown streets seemed to be full of barking dogs, or ''dawgs'' as they are called here.

LEAD: Stephania Aulicino, a daughter of Mrs. Armand D. Aulicino of Pelham, N.Y., and the late Mr. Aulicino, was married in Chicago yesterday to James Michael Condon, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Edward Condon of Stuart, Fla. The Rev. Douglas Cater, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Drake Hotel.

LEAD: Mayor Koch convened his top legal advisers yesterday to discuss the future of Cultural Affairs Commissioner Bess Myerson, who invoked the Fifth Amendment before a grand jury investigation into a city contractor.

LEAD: Police officer examines the remains of a split-level Cranford, N.J., home yesterday after an explosion leveled the structure early Saturday evening. The residents survived the blast. About 47 houses in area were evacuated. Page B6. (NYT/Bob/Glass)
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The Rev. William F. Lynch, the author of books on literature, media and theology, died Friday at Lennox Hill Hospital in New York City of complications from leukemia. He was 78 years old.

LEAD: Age has not dulled Soichiro Honda, one of Japan's most successful inventors and entrepreneurs and the founder of the Honda Motor Company. Now 80 years old, he still denounces Government interference in business and still dreams of new technology.
LEAD: Roy Murphy, a correspondent for Television New Zealand, was elected last week to a third one-year term as president of the Foreign Press Association.

LEAD: THE Gregg Smith Singers opened their New York season at St. Paul's Church Saturday evening with a program of music written between 1778 and 1952, about two-thirds of it by living composers. The first group of songs came from the singers' tour repertory - well-tuned, well-blended renditions all.

LEAD: Staff members of newly elected members of Congress are enjoying moving into their new quarters, and they are enjoying even more their housekeeping chores when it comes to throwing out the defeated previous occupants' flotsam and jetsam.

LEAD: AN enthusiastic and warmly sentimental audience filled Carnegie Hall and overflowed onto the stage Saturday evening to greet Turk Murphy, the 71-year-old trombonist who was a pillar of the traditional jazz revival in California almost 50 years ago, and who was here making his Carnegie Hall debut and his first appearance in New
LEAD: * Kenneth I. Roffe has been promoted to executive vice president and chief executive officer of Lowe Marschalk, Cleveland.
LEAD: Long before the trauma of the Baby M case ensnared them, the principals were pulled together by a single, almost magnetic emotion - torment over birth of a child.
LEAD: In tough times even cowboys get the blues. But events seem to be heading toward a happy ending at the National Cowboy Hall of Fame, scene of one of Oklahoma's longest-running soap operas.

LEAD: Retail gasoline prices jumped an average of 3 cents a gallon nationwide the last two weeks, a reflection of continuing volatility in the oil industry, the Lundberg Survey reported today. The average price was 87.9 cents a gallon.

LEAD: THE Giants could not reach the Super Bowl when they played in Yankee Stadium and Shea Stadium in New York, and they could not reach the Super Bowl when they brown-bagged it to the Yale Bowl in Connecticut, but yesterday they finally reached the Super Bowl from their base in New Jersey.

LEAD: A black man was burned to death in Soweto Saturday, the Government reported today, and a prominent black politician who refused to quit a community council was reportedly shot and seriously wounded.
LEAD: GEORGE BALANCHINE'S ''Ballo della Regina'' received two festive performances by the New York City Ballet over the weekend at the New York State Theater.
LEAD: Red tide has reappeared in the Gulf of Mexico, forcing an indefinite halt to shellfish harvesting along a part of the coast ravaged by an outbreak of the toxic bloom last year.

LEAD: BETTING on the ''AIDS market'' promises to be an up-and-down affair - a point driven home last week to investors in Wellcome P.L.C., whose share price jumped almost 15 percent through Thursday and then fell back more than 7 percent on Friday. The Wellcome swings illustrate the speculative excitement generated by companies working on AI

LEAD: John Cardinal O'Connor said yesterday that he was reviewing the decision of the rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral who refused to perform a Roman Catholic wedding in the church for a man who is dying with AIDS.

LEAD: Bob Bassen, who contributed a goal and assist in a 3-2 victory against Toronto Saturday night, sat back on the towel-strewn locker room bench at Nassau Coliseum and tried to remember the last time the Islanders had assembled a three-game winning streak. He could not. Actually, the team had enjoyed three straight victories, two of them courtesy of the Devils, in mid-December, but the five-game streak without a victory with which the club limped through the holiday season was more prominent in

LEAD: The marriage of Leigh Seong De Chen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Tze Chin Chen of Seremban, Negri Sembilan, Malaysia, to Douglas Schnapp, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Schnapp of New York, took place yesterday at the Town Club in Manhattan. Rabbi Richard Chapin officiated. The bride, a graduate of Seton Hall University, is a tax accountant at Oppenheim, Appel, Dixon & Company in New York.

LEAD: TEN minutes before the end of ''Stepping Out,'' the new English play at the Golden, a group of Londoners from many humdrum walks of life suddenly meld into a high-stepping chorus line. For two acts we've followed these characters, the middle-class participants in a weekly adult dance class, as they've prepared for this golden moment at center stage in a charity pageant.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Finance Secretary Mario Brodersohn said Friday that Argentina had reached agreement with the International Monetary Fund on a standby loan to help make payments on the nation's $50 billion foreign debt. Mr. Brodersohn told reporters the agreement would provide credits of more than .8 billion. Buenos Aires newspapers had said negotiators were seeking a standby loan of $1.2 billion, plus $350 million in drawing rights to compensate for lost exports.

LEAD: Following a slump in its trade surplus and foreign exchange reserves, Brazil is now planning to seek between $2 billion and $3 billion in ''new money'' from its creditors, as part of upcoming negotiations to restructure foreign debt, according to officials in Brasilia.

LEAD: More than 15,000 Denver Bronco fans were forced to wait another hour at Stapleton International Airport to greet the new American Football Conference champions because of a bomb threat to the team's charter plane at Cleveland.

LEAD: Drugs in Washington Sq. Despite thousands of arrests, Washington Square Park in Greenwich Village has become a growing center for the crack trade. Page B1. Currency Pact Reached Eight European finance ministers agreed to set new currency values to calm turbulent and costly market speculation.

LEAD: An off-duty correction officer shot another man twice early yesterday after the two got into a fight in a fast-food restaurant in the Melrose section of the Bronx, the authorities said. The wounded man was arrested.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: In the locker room about 30 minutes before kickoff today, Bill Parcells met, as he always does, with his kicker, Raul Allegre, and his punter, Sean Landeta, to discuss the weather conditions inside Giants Stadium.

LEAD: Less than a year after President Reagan and Prime Minister Brian Mulroney signed an accord on a joint approach to the problem of acid rain, officials here have begun questioning whether the United States is serious about tackling an issue that has sensitive political overtones.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: About 900 employees of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company can collect back pay and 130 laid-off workers can get their old jobs back under a $6 million settlement with the Communications Workers of America, according to the union.
LEAD: An Irish soldier in the United Nations peacekeeping force in southern Lebanon was killed Saturday by Israeli tank fire, the force's commander said today.
LEAD: A natural gas explosion destroyed a split-level home in Cranford, N.J., early Saturday night, but police officers arriving at the scene helped two elderly residents escape serious injury.

LEAD: Senior Israeli officials said today that the latest disclosures suggesting that Israel had led the United States into the Iran arms affair were baseless. But the Israeli officials continued to refuse to spell out their country's role in the affair from beginning to end.

LEAD: The American Motors Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation are apparently close to a deal for A.M.C. to produce a second line of Chrysler cars at its assembly plant in Kenosha, Wis. But labor and financing difficulties may still block the project, officials of both companies have said.

LEAD: The mood at Mister Days Restaurant was gloomier than the overcast skies. The Washington Redskins were trailing the Giants by 17 points at halftime and in the opinion of some of the Capital's opinion makers, some of whom were now seated at the oak bar in the downtown restaurant, the prospect of a comeback seemed unlikely.
LEAD: Recess appointees, chosen by the President while Congress is away, are strange creatures of the political process.

LEAD: Machine tool companies, which recently won protection against imports from Japan, Taiwan, West Germany and Switzerland, are hoping to increase exports under a new program set up with the Export-Import Bank.
LEAD: Children have an unerring instinct for nutritional food and reject it with contumely. So why do writers of medical texts insist that children will instinctively choose the right foods?

LEAD: Senator Albert Gore Jr., Democrat of Tennessee, has found an omission of just $7.4 million from President Reagan's trillion-dollar budget but one that the Senator says could end the hope of many people whose lives are endangered from the lack of quickly available body organs for transplants.

LEAD: Tennis Garrison Wins Final: Zina Garrison pounded out a 6-2, 6-4 victory over Pam Shriver yesterday to win the $150,000 New South Wales Open women's tennis championship in Sydney, Australia. The sixth-seeded Garrison returned superbly to negate Shriver's big serve, punched her groundstrokes on both the forehand and backhand sides and volleyed excellently.(AP) Mecir Triumphs: Miroslav Mecir of Czechoslovakia, playing despite an injured hand, captured the New Zealand International Open with a 6-2, 6-3, 6-4 victory over Michiel Schapers of the Netherlands.(AP) Skiing McKinney Takes Slalom:
LEAD: QUESTION: How many players have been unanimous selections to baseball's Hall of Fame?

LEAD: A Federal judge has at long last given New York City consumers what Governor Cuomo and the State Legislature would not - the chance to buy milk at competitive prices. The question now is whether consumers must continue to depend on Federal courts and a single, discount-minded New Jersey dairy to tame the dairy cartel.

LEAD: As college costs keep rising, so does reliance on loans - and so does fear that debt burdens will inhibit choices of college and career. The new Reagan Administration budget offers a creative plan to ease the loan burden, but then undercuts it by reducing scholarship grants.
LEAD: * Capital Holding Corp. is offering $100 million of A-2/AA rated 8 3/4 percent sinking fund debentures due in 2017 at par, through Goldman, Sachs & Co.

LEAD: One of this season's fashion hits, the longer, more fully proportioned coat, offers women enormous advantages. Hitting many wearers at the ankles, it keeps the legs warm. With more shoulder and hip room, it easily covers a dress-for-success suit or a fashionably bulky hand-knit sweater. And the wonderfully warm colors almost conquer the winter chill.

LEAD: BankAmerica, which formally rejected First Interstate Bancorp's acquisition offer last Monday, has suddenly heightened its efforts to remain independent. BankAmerica is lobbying Government officials, enlisting its own employees and retirees in a public relations campaign and circulating documents critical of the proposed merger to get regulators to reject it.
LEAD: The trial of a Manhattan gas station owner charged with cheating the state of $4 million in sales taxes begins today in Brooklyn.

LEAD: For the time being, the credit markets are focusing on forecasts of weak economic growth as a reason why the Federal Reserve and foreign central banks may move to reduce short-term interest rates in coming months.

LEAD: A new twist in the rules for the defense of the America's Cup has paved the way for the winner of the defense trials to substitute boats for the actual cup match.

LEAD: Wall Streeters with long memories had even more reason than most investors last week to cheer the new year's bullish burst that took the Dow Jones industrial average past 2,000 for the first time. Since 1950, early January gains have proved to be the forerunner of advances for the entire year in 20 out of 22 instances.

LEAD: About $70 million of the $130 million reserve fund that the E. F. Hutton Group plans to set up for the fourth quarter of 1986 will be used to repurchase certain tax-exempt securities it sold its customers in the early 1980's, according to Edward J. Lill, Hutton's chief financial officer.

LEAD: THREE of the principal roles in the Metropolitan Opera's production of ''La Boheme'' have changed hands in the past week, and these new faces were all present for Saturday night's performance. Hei-Kyung Hong, a Korean-born soprano who made her Met debut two years ago, sang Mimi. Peter Dvorsky, a tenor from Czechoslovakia, was Rudolfo.

LEAD: Andrew Cuomo, the son of Governor Cuomo, said yesterday that he has been asked to provide a written response to a conflict-of-interest charge filed this summer - but later withdrawn - by Abraham Hirschfeld, an unsuccessful candidate for lieutenant governor.
LEAD: Asserting that it had opened a ''second stage'' of its new offensive in the Persian Gulf war, Iran fired missiles today into the Iraqi cities of Baghdad and Basra.

LEAD: ''. . . I determine it is essential to limit prior notice, and direct the Director of Central Intelligence to refrain from reporting this Finding to the Congress . . .'' - Document signed Jan. 17, 1986, by President Reagan.
LEAD: In the absence of new Treasury note and bond issues, securities dealers expect another week of substantial financing in the corporate bond market.

LEAD: Nicholas Platt, a high-ranking State Department official, has become a leading candidate to be named the next United States Ambassador to the Philippines. Mr. Platt is a close adviser to Secretary of State George P. Shultz and holds two titles, Special Assistant to the Secretary and Executive Secretary of the Department.

LEAD: FAILURES of banks and thrift institutions this year and next will cost the Government a lot more than previously predicted - almost $10 billion more, according to numbers released in the President's budget last week.

LEAD: At the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I., yesterday Fran Alison Wallach, a vice president of the First Boston Corporation, and Eric Richard Rosenfeld, a government securities trader at Salomon Brothers, both in New York, were married by Rabbi Theodore Steinberg.

LEAD: Behind the acrobatic creativity of John Elway at quarterback, the Denver Broncos stunned this city and its Browns today, producing a sudden-death 23-20 overtime victory that propelled them into the Super Bowl as the American Conference champions.

LEAD: Having learned that the Army refused to lift the suspension on its taking a Government contract, N. W. Ayer, long the Army's ad agency, went into Federal District Court in Washington on Friday. It requested a temporary restraining order to keep the Army from announcing the winner of the competition for its $100 million recruiting account this week.

LEAD: American intelligence agencies provided Iran and Iraq with deliberately distorted or inaccurate intelligence data in recent years to further the Reagan Administration's goals in the region, intelligence sources said today.

LEAD: A diet cola with the name Jake's certainly deserves a down-home kind of promotion, even though it was created by the city slickers at Pepsico Inc. LEAD: Many black leaders agree that the racial attack in Howard Beach, Queens, has underscored the seriousness of New York City's racial problems and the need for strong actions to change the attitudes and conditions that prompt such attacks.
LEAD: Remember ''industrial policy''?

LEAD: Rumors that John S. R. Shad will shortly leave the Securities and Exchange Commission for a post as Ambassador to the Netherlands have re-emerged since the first of the year, according to S.E.C. officials. But Mr. Shad continues to decline to comment on his future plans.
LEAD: Kurt Vonnegut said that this city on the White River woke up once a year for the Indianapolis 500 race and then slept 364 days.
LEAD: For two months three lawyers with contrasting styles have maneuvered for the attention of jurors in the trial of two avowed revolutionaries accused of murdering a state trooper.

LEAD: An article on Dec. 24 about the nonstop round-the-world flight of the aircraft Voyager included an incorrect report from the craft's designer about its insurance status. A Voyager organization spokesman says the plane did carry liability insurance, provided by the Home Insurance Company and others.
LEAD: From California's Silicon Valley to Capitol Hill, controversy is growing about the proposed sale of a pioneering computer chip maker to Japan's largest computer company, Fujitsu Ltd.

LEAD: Governor Cuomo and District Attorney John J. Santucci of Queens will meet today to discuss the possibility of Mr. Cuomo naming a special state prosecutor to take over the Howard Beach racial assault case, which has been stymied by the refusal of a key witness to cooperate.
