LEAD: The monumental Tax Reform Act of 1986 is just starting to take effect, yet members of the 100th Congress have wasted no time in proposing changes.

LEAD: Antonio Gebauer, the former Morgan Guaranty Trust Company official who pleaded guilty to making millions of dollars in unauthorized withdrawals from Morgan accounts in Latin America, has repaid most of the accounts and is repaying the others, according to papers filed in court by his lawyer, Stanley S.

LEAD: Members of the New York Baroque Dance Company demonstrating a step yesterday at Fraunces Tavern in lower Manhattan. From left are Renovard Gee, Catherine Turocy and Patricia Beaman. The saraband, gigue and minuet were featured, along with bows and ballroom etiquette. (NYT/Dith Pran)

LEAD: Marion Hutton, a vocalist with the Glenn Miller Orchestra who for the last 20 years worked to help rehabilitate female alcoholics, died of cancer Saturday at her home in Kirkland, Wash. She was 67 years old.
LEAD: A Reagan Administration advisory council is deeply divided over how to address the growing problem of workers who lose their jobs because of imports or changes in the economy.

LEAD: A Brooklyn man was killed yesterday when a fire swept through an apartment building, but his wife and 10-year-old son survived when the woman threw the child out of a third-floor window and then jumped after him, the police said.

LEAD: Contributions to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund are running more than $200,000 ahead of those received at this time last year, a gain of 9 percent. As of Friday, 10,133 donors had given a total of $2,483,575.72. At the same point last year, 9,256 donors had given a total of $2,272,165.14.

LEAD: As Congress began reviewing President Reagan's proposed budget this week, officials from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut analyzed its effect on the region and concluded it would be devastating.
LEAD: Throughout his career in the Navy, Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter was regarded as the consummate military aide, the man who carried out orders with alacrity and, at times, brilliance.

LEAD: When Lionel Manuel, the Giants' elegant wide receiver, reached out to take in a crucial third-down pass from Phil Simms in the first quarter today, it was the first time he had caught a ball in a game since the third game of the season, against the Raiders in Los Angeles.

LEAD: SATURDAY'S Beethoven Society concert caught the composer in some of his serener moods. It was a program of chamber music - two duo sonatas and two trios, and most of the music emanates from one of the unhappier periods in Beethoven's life. Those who insist on relating life to art will have their troubles here.
LEAD: THIS evening's television movie on ABC, at 9 o'clock, is called ''Night of Courage.''

LEAD: INTAR: THE CREATIVE PROCESS To produce a musical creation for the theater, says Graciela Daniele, it is necessary to collaborate. For the 20-year-old Intar Hispanic America Arts Center, Ms. Daniele is conducting a series of workshops emphasizing teamwork. In the workshops are playwrights, lyricists and composers who spend a week together thrashing out the details of the creative aspects of producing a musical.

LEAD: For members of Congress, sponsoring bills with low numbers is a little like getting low-numbered license plates for their cars: Somehow or other, prestige has become involved. Having a low number doesn't make a bill any more likely to pass but makes it seem more distinctive and its shorthand designation easier to remember.

LEAD: Prosecutors won a murder conviction Saturday without the evidence of a reporter who refused to testify about an interview he had with the defendant.

LEAD: * Butterick Co., a maker and distributor of Butterick and Vogue sewing patterns, named John E. Lehmann president.
LEAD: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Palestinian Rights - 10:30 A.M.

LEAD: President Reagan has railed against big deficits for five years now, but his 1988 budget offers fresh proof that he doesn't really care. His outrage about ''big spenders'' is little changed. His priorities remain the same: Spend more for defense, but raise no new revenues. And the results remain the same: a mendacious Federal budget and unacceptable deficits.

LEAD: A San Francisco man was convicted Saturday of killing his wealthy employer on a cruise ship.

LEAD: Felix Garcia, master of the 98-foot trawler Endurance, stood in the center of the deck and talked of the prospects for the coming season when for the eighth year he will be captain of a ship that fishes American waters in the Bering Sea and sells the catch to foreign processing ships.
LEAD: ''Fencing is a lifetime sport,'' the chief organizer of the tournament in lower Manhattan was saying above the din of the mayhem around him.

LEAD: Robert C. McFarlane told Congress that Saudi Arabia had contributed millions of dollars for the Nicaraguan rebels, increasing to at least $40 million the amount gathered for the rebels that now cannot be accounted for, sources familiar with the Congressional investigation said today.

LEAD: The state agency that administers New York's crime victims law has ruled that one of the four youths shot by Bernhard H. Goetz in 1984 is ineligible for state aid because ''it appears'' he was ''in the process of robbing'' Mr. Goetz when the shooting occurred.

LEAD: A Federal judge in Washington last evening refused to grant the N.W. Ayer agency a temporary restraining order to prevent the Army from announcing the winner of the competition for its $100 million account, from which it had suspended Ayer, the incumbent agency.

LEAD: By all accounts, the contras and their sponsors in the State Department are trying desperately to make some headway in their war before the question of United States support for the insurgency comes up again in Congress. Nevertheless, it is not too soon to look ahead to the post-contra era that now seems in sight.

LEAD: Fellow academics have called her ''a living legend,'' one of the founders and a key developer of African studies in the U.S. At her 80th birthday party last year, Dr. Gwendolen Carter said she was greatly relieved that ''no one suggested I should resign or give up anything. That would have annoyed me very much.
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell its North American transit-bus manufacturing operations to the Greyhound Corporation for an undisclosed price.

LEAD: The police wounded 25 people today when they opened fire on demonstrators protesting the murder of a man and his two daughters, witnesses said. Rioters burned down scores of houses and shops, and army troops were called out.

LEAD: A front-page article yesterday about the Giants' playoff victory over the Redskins and a related article on the first page of SportsMonday misreported the results of the coin flip before the game. The Redskins' captain called tails and the coin landed heads.
LEAD: Governor Cuomo met with the Queens District Attorney here today to discuss turning the case of the Howard Beach racial assault over to a special prosecutor.
LEAD: United States airlines enjoyed one of their safest years in 1986, a turnaround from a 1985 toll that was one of the highest on record, according to official figures made public yesterday.

LEAD: Apple Computer Inc. today introduced an updated version of the Apple IIe personal computer that has as features an expanded keyboard with a built-in numeric keypad, improved training materials and the company's new platinum color scheme.

LEAD: The Supreme Court agreed today to resolve a conflict among Federal appeals courts on the liability of military contractors to military personnel injured or killed by defects in the contractors' products or services.

LEAD: The United States has assured Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir that the White House's disclosure last week of documents describing Israel's role in the decision to sell arms to Iran was not intended as a criticism of Israel's actions, a White House official said today.

LEAD: A Manhattan grand jury, in a report issued yesterday, determined that ''woefully'' inadequate care and repeated mistakes made by unsupervised interns and junior residents at a New York hospital resulted in the death of a young woman there in 1984.

LEAD: One of Canada's leading investment companies recently summoned electronics experts to its offices in a high-rise tower overlooking Lake Ontario and ordered anti-bugging devices installed on its top executives' telephones.

LEAD: A Chinese scientist who became a hero among thousands of students who demonstrated for greater democracy over the last month was dismissed today as the Communist Party moved to reassert control over intellectuals with unacceptable views.

LEAD: John Drew, a former Atlanta Hawks' forward who had been scheduled to go on trial yesterday on drug charges, instead pleaded guilty to selling and possessing cocaine. Under a negotiated plea, Drew was sentenced to six months in the Fulton County, Ga., jail. He already has served three months since his arrest Oct.

LEAD: After Derrick Chievous of Missouri hit 14 of 16 free throws to lead the Tigers to an 87-83 upset of Oklahoma on Saturday, Coach Billy Tubbs of the Sooners commented angrily: ''I've never seen a guy so protected. I don't know what his stats are, but I guess the officials must think he's an endangered species.

LEAD: President Reagan today telephoned an 82-year-old Belgian woman who saved more than 100 Allied fliers in World War II to tell her she would be granted permanent residency in the United States after a five-year quest.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A member of the Senate committee investigating the Iran-Nicaragua arms affair says the panel will decide soon whether to take up reports that some Nicaragua insurgents involved themselves in the cocaine trade to help finance their war against the Sandinista government.
LEAD: After several failed efforts to expand its military electronics business, the Loral Corporation has catapulted itself into one of the biggest companies in the field.

LEAD: The Veterans Administration today identified four of its hospitals, including two in the New York City area, where heart surgery is being halted because of concerns over death rates and quality of care.

LEAD: The dollar fell to a new six-year low against the West German mark in heavy trading on world currency markets yesterday, one day after European finance ministers acted to relieve tensions within the European Monetary System.

LEAD: Government intelligence officials say a far more comprehensive approach should be taken to verifying Soviet and American compliance with limits on nuclear testing than has been proposed by the Reagan Administration, according to newly obtained secret documents.
LEAD: Fifty-three years after his last visit and four decades since his association with Communism fractured his career as a screenwriter, Ring Lardner Jr. returned to Moscow last week.

LEAD: School officials have told high school students that they cannot stage the Broadway musical farce ''A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum'' because, the officials say, it is morally unacceptable and degrading to women.

LEAD: A defense lawyer in the trial of two men charged with killing State Trooper Philip J. Lamonaco today attacked the state's contention that one of the men had a silver gun the day of the shooting.

LEAD: This is the town of McCormick in the county of McCormick. It is a poor place, ingrown for decades, but it is the place that an editor, Ken Fortenberry, and his family decided to make their home.
LEAD: THE Hungarian State Folk Ensemble is not still another folk group. It is marvelous -crackling with dancing that snaps like a whip in a program framed successfully by a sophisticated context.

LEAD: Maria and David Hefner, a couple married in a civil ceremony who had been denied a Roman Catholic wedding at St. Patrick's Cathedral because Mr. Hefner is dying of AIDS, will be able to exchange their vows at the Cathedral after all.
LEAD: Interest rates were mixed yesterday with little change in short-term rates, while note and bond yields rose modestly.
LEAD: IT is common knowledge among marketers of diet food and drink products that the post-holiday-pigout period is their best time of the year. Oh, yes, there is profit to be made from guilt.

LEAD: Harold Eliot Krents, whose struggle to overcome blindness and become independent was the inspiration for the Broadway play ''Butterflies Are Free,'' died of a brain tumor yesterday at the Calvary Hospital Hospice in the Bronx. He was 42 years old and lived in Washington.

LEAD: Three banking companies sold 10-year notes through Salomon Brothers yesterday, joining a large and growing list of corporate borrowers attracted to the debt market this year by a combination of strong investor demand and interest rates that are near their lowest levels in nine years.

LEAD: RECENT discoveries in the southwestern United States, southern Greece and the South Pacific have persuaded a growing number of archeologists that primitive people were much more destructive to their habitat than had been generally believed.

LEAD: Gov. Rafael Hernandez Colon said today that the investigation into the fire at the Dupont Plaza Hotel had reached ''the final stage'' and that one or more suspects would be arrested ''very, very soon.''
LEAD: Jack L. Rivkin has been named director of equity research at Shearson Lehman Brothers, the investment firm said yesterday.
LEAD: A dispatch yesterday from Baton Rouge, La., about the trial of three men accused of killing a Government witness against drug smugglers, misstated the date of the killing. It was Feb. 19, 1986.

LEAD: INVESTORS have stood in line to buy shares, the stock market index has raced upward at a dizzying pace and a general investing frenzy has gripped Mexico as the nation's stock market enters what analysts here call a ''superboom.''

LEAD: MANY factors have been offered to explain the reading disorder dyslexia, among them impaired vision, head injuries, inner-ear disorders and even laziness.

LEAD: When Renaldo Nehemiah left track in 1982 to play for the San Francisco 49ers, he held four world best times for indoor hurdle events and the 10 fastest indoor clockings for the 60-yard and 55-meter events. Now, after leaving pro football and petitioning successfully to return as an amateur hurdler, his times remain unmatched.

LEAD: Wade Boggs and the Boston Red Sox turned in record-tying and record-breaking numbers yesterday in submitting their numbers for salary arbitration. Boggs, who has filed for arbitration for the third successive year, went in at $1.85 million, the Red Sox at $1.6 million. The Red Sox figure is the highest ever submitted by a club, eclipsing the $1.35 million they submitted for Boggs last year.

LEAD: In a significant expansion, Flying Tiger Line Inc. said it would increase its jet fleet by more than 18 percent and put 23 percent more pilots on its payroll. The move comes less than a month after the financially troubled Flying Tiger, the nation's oldest and largest scheduled air-cargo concern, was granted significant wage and benefit concessions by its unions and imposed similar cuts on its executive and administrative staff.

LEAD: An American Bar Association commission studying personal injury claims is recommending that there be no limits on awards for pain and suffering, but says the courts should try to make sure the awards are not excessive.
LEAD: Morton Thiokol has delayed until mid-March the first full-scale test-firing of its redesigned space shuttle booster, originally planned for the first week of February.
LEAD: Attorney General Robert Abrams today proposed legislation to repeal most existing marketing restrictions on the sale of milk in New York State.

But now he is venturing into the staging of the classics. He had already done Marc-Antoine Charpentier's Baroque opera ''Medee'' in Lyons, and, just last month, Gluck's ''Alceste'' in Stuttgart.

LEAD: Tennis Davis Advances in Australia: California-born Scott Davis, who once ranked as high as 11th in the world, struggled for 3 hours 25 minutes yesterday before defeating Peter McNamara of Australia, 7-6, 6-4, 2-6, 3-6, 6-4, to advance to the second round of the Australian Open. Davis, now rated 39th on the A.T.P.

LEAD: The Murray Ohio Manufacturing Company, maker of mowers and bicycles, said yesterday that Richard W. Sappenfield had resigned as president, chief executive and a director in differences over the ''future strategic direction of the company.'' William M. Hannon, the chairman, whose grandfather founded the company, was appointed interim chief executive.

LEAD: A Federal court yesterday upheld the law requiring Social Security recipients to include their income from municipal bond interest when calculating the tax they may owe on Social Security benefits. The ruling was issued in Manhattan by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

LEAD: The Supreme Court declined today to review a lower court's ruling that shields cigarette manufacturers from liability for injuries or death caused by smoking in suits based on allegedly inadequate health warnings or improper advertising.
LEAD: Mayor Koch paid tribute yesterday to the Brooklyn Academy of Music -one of the country's oldest performing arts centers - on its 125th anniversary.

LEAD: The one good thing to come of the tragic beating in Howard Beach last month was the hope it raised of rejuvenating a multiracial civil rights movement in New York City. But that hope is already vanishing, ruined by black extremists determined to exploit racial polarization rather than join forces with decent whites committed to a racially integrated city.

LEAD: It felt good watching the Giants crunch the Washington Redskins, 17 to 0, in Sunday's National Football Conference championship. Shades of the glory days of two decades ago, of Charley Conerly in Phil Simms, of Sam Huff in Lawrence Taylor, of Alex Webster in Joe Morris. Real pros these Giants, then and now, their victories workmanlike, not flashy.
LEAD: Rebecca Hourwich Reyher, a veteran suffragist, author and lecturer, died of pnuemonia last Saturday at the home of her daughter, Faith Jackson, in St. Inigoes, Md. Mrs. Reyher was 89 years old.

LEAD: The BankAmerica Corporation has tentatively agreed to sell its Charles Schwab & Company discount brokerage unit to a group headed by the unit's chairman, Charles R. Schwab, industry sources said today.

LEAD: Dominick Labino, an artist whose works made of glass are shown in more than 100 museums, universities and public and private collections, died Saturday in his home at Grand Rapids, Ohio. He was 76 years old.

LEAD: Momentum appears to be gathering for an attack on what many educators regard as Americans' ignorance about the world beyond their shores. Foreign failures and difficulties that have developed in recent years, from Vietnam to Iran, have led to calls for a general bolstering Americans' knowledge of unfamiliar languages and cultures.
LEAD: President Reagan's proposal to reduce drastically Federal anti-drug funding in fiscal 1988 and 1989 proves he never really believed in his own drug abuse policies.

LEAD: With the key Iowa Presidential caucuses a little over a year away, the Iowa Democrats are in the throes of choosing a new party chairman. The 30-member state central committee meets Saturday to pick a successor to A. Arthur Davis, who has announced he will not seek re-election.

LEAD: Governor Kean, in his State of the State Message today, called the state's welfare system a failure. He said he wanted to start a program to require all able-bodied recipients to go to work to support themselves and their families.

LEAD: Giants fans might say they knew all the time that their heroes would get to the Super Bowl. So it may shock them to learn that Coach Bill Parcells was not one of them, that for a time he did not think his team could get where it is.

LEAD: If Dennis Conner's Stars & Stripes is able to beat New Zealand today on the America's Cup race course in Fremantle, Australia, it may be due in part to a new ''secret weapon'' that Conner's syndicate revealed yesterday.

LEAD: The buoyant, optimistic American West, whose economic growth has outpaced the nation over much of the past 20 years, has begun the new year facing a new set of realities: declining population growth, persistent problems in important industries and growing apprehension about the future.

LEAD: President Reagan will soon ask Congress for changes in antitrust laws, restraints on imports of counterfeit goods and a $200 million war chest to help American companies sell goods abroad, according to Administration and Congressional officials.

The show became a popular success in England by using its puppets' wicked caricatures to spoof and puncture everybody from the Royal Family and Margaret Thatcher to the latest batch of rock stars.

LEAD: ''LA BATTAGLIA DI LEGNANO'' is one of several Verdi operas whose action, though set in remote times, sent patriotic juices surging through the veins of his countrymen in the 19th century, when Italy was a jumble of separate city-states. Although rarely revived, it is not an inconsequential work, a fact that could be glimpsed Monday night in the Opera Orchestra of New York's concert performance at Carnegie Hall.

And there is the Kansas City of the stomach: a metropolis devoted to lard, sugar, salt, beef and other dietary unspeakables.

LEAD: THE popularity of various foods, it seems to me, sometimes rests on the lure of their names. Catfish, for example, one of the most American of fish, immediately calls forth delectable possibilities. Food experts heartily list and promote its delightful qualities. The name monkfish, on the other hand, does not readily entice, and it has only recently caught on at American restaurants and in homes.

LEAD: A smoky fire damaged a showroom today at a resort hotel beset by labor problems, and investigators said it was arson.

LEAD: A new candidate has emerged in speculation around town concerning a possible successor to William J. Casey as Director of Central Intelligence. He is Donald H. Rumsfeld, the former Congressman, Secretary of Defense and corporate executive.

LEAD: Owens-Illinois Inc. said yesterday that its board of directors would consider ''in the near future'' an improved $3.6 billion buyout offer received Monday from Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company.

LEAD: Envy the indoor gardeners blessed with green thumbs: Bougainvillea cascades from hanging pots in their sun-filled windows; their desks overflow with ivy. LEAD: During the national holiday Monday honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., we will no doubt hear a number of high-toned official pronouncements that his legacy lives on. LEAD: It has been a splendid few days for New York's imbibers, whether their weakness be alcohol or cholesterol. Some writers and editors are decidedly unsympathetic toward the protesters, and while most would not speak for attribution, some were willing to speak on the record.

LEAD: A Trident 2 missile designed to be used by submarines was lofted from a launching pad here today on a maiden test flight of the Navy's newest and most powerful rocket. It was a success, the Navy said.

LEAD: John Lucas, a veteran guard who tested positive for drugs last year for the second time in two seasons, has reached an oral agreement to sign with the Milwaukee Bucks. Bill King, a spokesman for the Bucks, said that the contract for the remainder of this season must still be put in writing and signed before Lucas can practice with the team under National Basketball Association regulations, but that should take place by the middle of next week.

LEAD: The ad in Gaborone's Gazette says ''Now you can jet to Jo'burg in 40 mins.'' South African Airways adds that via Johannesburg it can provide connections with ''non-stop S.A.A. flights to London and direct flights to New York and various destinations in Europe.''

LEAD: A survey made public today by the Environmental Protection Agency found that no lakes in mountainous areas of the Western United States were currently polluted by acid rain but that a large number were potentially susceptible.

LEAD: Trans World Airlines said yesterday that D. Joseph Corr, its vice chairman, had been elected president. He will retain the title of chief operating officer.

LEAD: Martha Graham has been awarded Denmark's gold medal ''Ingenio et Arti'' for distinction in the arts and sciences. The American modern-dance pioneer has taken her company to Denmark several times in recent years. Only one other non-Danish artist, the Swedish soprano Birgit Nilsson, has received the irregularly presented medal.

LEAD: A former major league catcher, Barry Foote, who managed the Yankees' Class AAA team in Columbus, Ohio, last year before being replaced by Bucky Dent for this season, has had enough of that level. Yesterday, he was named the first manager of the Myrtle Beach Blue Jays, a Toronto affiliate in South Carolina that is on the Class A level - and Foote prefers the demotion.

LEAD: After 60 years, the tradition of sleek thoroughbreds preparing for the Kentucky Derby amid the palm trees and flamingos of Hialeah Park may be coming to an end.
LEAD: The Soviet Union said today that reports that Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, planned to give a speech today on arms control issues were wrong.

LEAD: TELEVISION, we all know, is impossible. Most of the programming we see in prime time is produced on an entertainment assembly line, not unlike the kind that used to churn out movies several decades ago. Budgets are limited, schedules are ridiculously tight, and artistic considerations are not quite as crucial as getting the thing done and moving on quickly to the next project.

LEAD: Benny's Good Men, former members of the Benny Goodman band, will perform Sunday at 5 P.M. at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue at 90th Street (369-8040). The group will include Peter Appleyard on vebraphone, Warren Vache Jr. on cornet and fluegelhorn, John Bunch on piano, Bucky Pizzarelli on guitar, and others.

LEAD: THERE was a party the other evening that was not as joyous as it might have been. It was planned by Margaret Whiting and Jean Bach to toast Larry Carr, a singer and piano player as well as record producer and writer on music and films, on the occasion of his new record. Mr. Carr died a few days before the occasion, but the evening went on as scheduled as his jazz musician pals made it a musical salute to their friend.

LEAD: The Chicago Board of Election Commissioners has ordered the name of Bernard Epton removed from the Feb. 24 Republican mayoral primary ballot. The board said Wednesday that Mr. Epton, who ran for Mayor in 1983, had fallen short of the required number of signatures on his nominating ballots.

LEAD: Stanley M. Friedman, the former Bronx Democratic leader, and two other men have been indicted on bribery and conspiracy charges in connection with seeking a contract to sell hand-held computers to the New York National Guard, prosecutors said yesterday.

LEAD: Experts from the United States nuclear laboratories today questioned Administration charges that the Soviet Union has probably exceeded the limits of an unratified 1974 treaty that limits the size of underground nuclear tests.

LEAD: The Mississippi Coast Jets of the Continental Basketball Association have dropped from their roster Billy Goodwin and Bobby Parks after they refused drug testing ordered by the league, The Sun Herald in Biloxi, Miss., reported yesterday. LEAD: UNTIL a full-scale museum retrospective is organized, the work of David Park, who died of cancer in 1960 at the age of 49, may be doomed to perennial rediscovery. LEAD: THERE never was a more implausible centenarian than Marcel Duchamp. Even in his 80's, he carried his age lightly, imperceptibly. Erect, steady and precise in all his movements, debonair in his bearing, he measured his every word, yet let it slip all but noiselessly. When present, he seemed to displace no air and demand no attention.

LEAD: LE REGENCE, the opulent French restaurant in the Hotel Plaza Athenee, wasted no time picking up the pieces after losing its chef, Daniel Boulud, and two sous chefs, to Le Cirque last fall. Managers of the hotel, which has a sister establishment in Paris, recruited the flying Rostang family - Jo, the chef-owner of the two-star (Michelin) La Bonne Auberge on the French Riviera; Philippe, his son and co-chef, and Michel, another son whose own two-star establishment in Paris bears his name - to oversee the new regime.

LEAD: The Quaker Oats Company said that it would close its pet foods plant in Rockford, Ill., leading to a $20.9 million after-tax charge against earnings. The Rockford plant, which employs 324 workers, is the oldest of its five pet food units and is unable to produce dry dog food, an area Quaker has chosen as a target for growth.

LEAD: The pieces that began and ended Thursday night's New York Philharmonic concert at Avery Fisher Hall shared not only a common tradition but an unusual informality. Thus the Mozart Symphony in A (No. 29) and Beethoven's ''Pastoral'' seem to burst in on the listener unannounced. LEAD: With six seconds remaining, a surprised Mark Bryant made a pair of free throws today that enabled Seton Hall to upset Georgetown, 66-65, in a Big East game at Byrne Meadowlands Arena. It was Seton Hall's second defeat of Georgetown this season, the only losses the Hoyas have in 14 games.

LEAD: A strong earthquake jolted the Pacific coast of northern Japan today, but the police said there were no immediate reports of injuries or damage. The Central Meteorological Agency said the quake, which struck at about 7 P.M., registered a preliminary 5.5 on the open-ended Richter scale.

LEAD: To the Editor: To get wet feet in Venice, it is not necessary to visit during the Carnival period. That evening we went from the Hotel Metropole to Piazza San Marco to hear the municipal band, which was playing selections from ''Norma'' and ''Tannhauser.

LEAD: Benares, India's ancient holy city astride the Ganges, houses the only temple built by Mohandas K. Gandhi. It has neither Sivas nor Gneshes, only a huge relief model of India. Gandhi included Tibet in his vision of a unified India. Mao Zedong disagreed.

LEAD: FOR years, the prevailing wisdom on how immigrants fare in the labor market has been based on the notion that assimilation is a key, even determining, factor. Drawing mainly on 1970 Census data, studies concluded that while earnings of new immigrants were lower than those of comparably situated native workers, earnings of immigrants who had been here for more than a decade exceeded those of native workers of the same age, education and so on.

LEAD: The opening of the Metropolitan Museum's expansive new Lila Acheson Wallace wing for 20th-century art is not only a major event in the history of this august institution, but in the history of New York as a center for that art. With the $26-million Wallace addition - housing an international survey of painting and sculpture from 1900 to now - the Met has established, in essence, a separate museum that becomes the fourth big one in Manhattan devoted solely to the present century.

LEAD: The Christiania office building in Tarrytown, N.Y., was dedicated in 1984 by Crown Prince Harald and Crown Princess Sonja of Norway, but even that royal cachet was not enough to make it profitable. Now Morris Bailey of Morris Bailey Enterprises in Manhattan's financial district is taking a crack. He purchased the six-story, 210,000-square-foot building at the end of last year for $35 million from Christiania, a Norwegian insurance company.

LEAD: RECENTLY, WHILE I WAS CON-valescing from an operation, Bert and Buddy, two old friends whom I rarely see because they live far away, visited me. I couldn't use the stairs, so my wife brought them up to my study and left us alone. For hours, we talked nonstop, pouring ourselves out for one another, drinking one another in, joyously celebrating the sacrament of friendship.

LEAD: Jean-Baptiste Lully was the great operatic composer of the high French Baroque, the man who defined French opera in the age of Louis XIV. His works are rarely heard today, but that omission may be ending now that the French early-music movement has grown so confident and accomplished. Friday night at the Salle Favart, the Paris Opera presented Lully's ''Atys'' for the first time since 1760, when Lully's works were swept aside in the enthusiasm for the new music of Rameau and then Gluck.

LEAD: To the Editor: While Michael Brenson is haunted by the faces in van Gogh's landscapes [ Jan. 4 ] , I am haunted by many of his statements: First of all, by his contention that ''van Gogh has never been identified with reason.'' I do not know (nor do I care) with what Mr. Brenson identifies van Gogh, but let him show us, in the three volumes of the painter's collected letters, a single unsound passage or argument.

Though Barbados only gained independence from Britain in 1966, the lower house of its Parliament, the House of Assembly, has been active since 1639.

LEAD: To the Editor: Prof. Robert Blakey asserts that if Congress had passed the reform of the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (RICO) proposed last session, financier Ivan Boesky would no longer have been subject to a treble-damage RICO civil action (''The Public's Secret Weapon vs.

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Parviz Meghnot of Ann Arbor, Mich., have announced the engagement of their daughter Roya Lesa Meghnot to Keith Andrew Schuman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert C. Schuman of Ardsley, N.Y.

LEAD: IT BEGAN IN A NEW YORK minute after a piece about geographical derogations, the use of place names as modifiers to sneer at a trait or an occupation. My colleague Russell Baker passed along a cryptic message - ''Larchmont lockjaw'' - which I took to mean the pronunciation affected by yuppies. I then passed it along to the Philadelphia lawyers who read this column as the speech affected by ''upper-class lowerclassmen returning to suburbia.

LEAD: A small private plane apparently flew into the path of a larger commuter aircraft before the two collided over this Salt Lake City suburb Thursday, killing all 10 people aboard the planes, a Federal safety official said Friday night.

LEAD: Having worked as a newspaper reporter, wire-service foreign correspondent, magazine editor and publisher for more than 50 years, I found myself in complete agreement with A. M. Rosenthal's articulate defense of the First Amendment (''Learning on the Job,'' Dec. 14). It would be a better world if the freedom to write and the freedom to think were universal.

LEAD: The engagement of Patricia Anne Wiener to David F. Freeman Jr., the son of Dr. and Mrs. Freeman of Chapel Hill, N.C., has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Howard E. Wiener of Hewlett Neck, L.I., parents of the bride-to-be. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: As Justice Minister of Colombia, Enrique Parejo Gonzalez received so many death threats from cocaine traffickers that he was named Ambassador to Hungary and rushed out of the country in August. But last week, the barons of Colombia's multibillion-dollar drug racket claimed vengeance. In what the State Department deplored as a ''narco-terrorist'' attack, Mr.
LEAD: To the world, the infant known as Baby M is the central figure in a landmark custody fight.

LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

LEAD: The emotional courtroom battle for custody of Baby M has cast a sharp and disquieting light on the tangle of ethical and legal uncertainties surrounding the growing practice of surrogate motherhood.

LEAD: WITH BLACK MODELS among the stars of the fashion industry, and with the proliferation of skin-care and makeup lines for black consumers, the 1960's slogan ''black is beautiful'' is finally reaching commercial fulfillment. As Susan L. Taylor, the editor in chief of Essence magazine, explains: ''Black skin is such an incredible canvas.

LEAD: GIVING foreign aid is the process of doing good for somebody else in pursuit of your own self-interest. That seemed to be the governing proposition of Secretary of State George P. Shultz's 14,889-mile trip, concluded last week, to six countries in Africa. As he arrived at one airport or presidential palace after another, often to the accompaniment of drums and dancers brought out in his honor, Mr.

LEAD: St. John's may not be back in the same groove that allowed it to win its first nine games this season. But after two straight losses and a couple of mediocre victories, the Redmen have apparently moved into a higher gear.

LEAD: The debate is always are players asking for too much? I would like to know how much income the owners derive from the team. I know how much each player and the managers of the Steinbrenner Yankees and the Wilpon/Doubleday Mets earn, but how much money did George and Fred make in 1986 on their respective teams?
LEAD: ON A RECENT EXPEDITION in Sonoma County, Calif., my hunting partner, Bob Cooley of California's Hacienda Winery, and I netted a wild boar.
LEAD: WHILE a tall, clean-cut boy of 17 galloped around the ring throwing punches in too-rapid succession for his balance, a rugged 16-year-old hit a heavy bag that hung across the room.

LEAD: A PROPOSAL to build three towers containing 278 luxury condominiums and an 11-story office building lined up over the railroad tracks in White Plains was made to the White Plains Common Council early this month by the Penn Central Corporation.
LEAD: THAT NEW PET! By Alane Ferguson. Illustrated by Catherine Stock. Unpaged. New York: Lothrop, Lee & Shepard Books. $11.75. (Ages 3 to 8)
LEAD: THE GREAT FAKE BOOK By Vance Bourjaily. 305 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $17.95.
LEAD: CHINESE PUPPETS AT YALE

LEAD: Katharine Balfour Tiernan, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Thomas Tiernan of Essex Fells, N.J., was married there yesterday to Peter Michael Rooney, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Charles Rooney of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Dr. David St. George performed the ceremony at St. Peter's Episcopal Church.

LEAD: A YEAR and a half ago, East of Athens, in Port Jefferson, was a gem of a restaurant. There was wonderful, authentic Greek country food, an appealing dining room and a staff full of pride. Little touches like a complimentary appetizer and a small portion of fresh fruit between courses were symbols of the restaurant's care, quality and effort.

LEAD: To the Editor: We were most interested to read Bernard Holland's recent account of the music-publishing industry and pleased by the attention he devoted to the new management of G. Schirmer [ ''For Music Publishing, Technology Means Hard Times,'' Dec. 7 ] . Still, there were a number of inaccuracies in the account that we wish to point out.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Donald Joseph Fager of New Canaan, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter Geraldine Maria Fager to Daniel Nelson Fish, a son of Dr. and Mrs. James Bartlett Fish of Watertown, N.Y.

LEAD: TROOPER JIM BARNES is persuaded he had to tell teen-agers about the results of drunken driving he had seen. As he carried a microphone while pacing in front of the stage in the auditorium of the Francis T. Maloney High School in Meriden this month, the 31-year-old trooper recalled an accident in Montville four and a half years ago.

LEAD: To anyone unfamiliar with the ongoing controversy over the disposition of two surplus schools in District 14 (Hewlett-Woodmere), Dr. Bert Nelson's letter to the editor (Dec. 28) in response to an article by Saul Schindler, ''Let's Save Our 'Surplus' Schools'' (Opinion Page, Dec. 7), would appear to be a model of clarity.

LEAD: Japan's central bank bought billions of American dollars last week, and officials in Bonn hinted at a tax cut to stimulate the West German economy. Both countries were also said to be considering lowering interest rates as they scrambled to slow the precipitous drop in the value of the dollar, which closed Friday at 153.10 yen in Tokyo and 1.8465 marks in

LEAD: To the Editor: Your article headed ''New York Plays Reluctant Landlord'' on Dec. 14 misses one very important point: Many of these buildings coming under city control were previously rent-controlled or -stabilized. The consequent severe restrictions on rent increases caused the buildings to be unprofitable, and therefore neglected, and finally abandoned by their owners.

LEAD: As the trout and salmon season on inland lakes begins today, officials are warning anglers to beware of thin ice. ''Most of the lakes that are usually frozen and safe by now aren't,'' said John Hall of the Fish and Wildlife Department. ''There are dangerous conditions near the mouth of rivers, near points of land, bridges, and over reefs.

LEAD: PERHAPS no animal is possessed of a shorter memory than the bull who lives on Wall Street. So it seems useful amid the euphoria over the breaching of the 2,000 barrier on the Dow - and the buying spree of last week - to step back and put a historical perspective on the index's recent climb.
LEAD: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 27 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

LEAD: At Temple Emanuel in New Hyde Park, L.I., last night Gail Robin Weisen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Weisen of Merrick, L.I., was married to Louis Alan Gossert, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Gossert of Palm Harbor, Fla. Rabbi Robert Benjamin officiated. Mrs. Gossert, a certified public accountant for Ernst & Whinney in New York, graduated from the State University of New York at Buffalo.

LEAD: Because of a production error in last Sunday's Westchester Weekly, the following story appeared with a section omitted. A LITTLE white house with a picket fence may become the home of a now-homeless family if the village of Scarsdale, which owns it, and the county, which has hundreds of homeless families to shelter, can come to an agreement.

LEAD: A maintenance worker has admitted setting the fatal fire at the Dupont Plaza Hotel, apparently because he was angry at the management, Federal and Puerto Rican officials said last week. Hector Escudero Aponte, who had worked at the San Juan hotel for 10 years, was charged with arson and with separate counts of murder for each of the 96 people who died in the New Year's Eve blaze.

LEAD: It's not true that Congress and the White House have inadvertently cornered the market on political humor in Washington. The Capitol Steps, a troupe of Congressional staff members that specializes in musical satire, has been in such demand that it has been compelled to advertise for a full-time scheduler and public rela-tions agent.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: When Israel Sack, a Lithuanian immigrant, began selling New England highboys and Philadelphia chairs to Bostonians at the turn of the century, the experience of collecting American antiques was akin to high adventure. That, in any case, is the way Harold Sack and Max Wilk describe it in ''American Treasure Hunt,'' published recently by Little, Brown and Company ($24.95).

LEAD: Vice Adm. Donald S. Jones, the top military aide to Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger, will retire March 1 after more than 35 years of active service, the Defense Department said Friday. Admiral Jones, 58 years old, a native of Madison, Wis., has been Mr. Weinberger's military assistant since last spring.

LEAD: SELF-CRITICISM is an art not many are qualified to practice. Despite our best efforts it is probable that, apart from the most immediate, pragmatic, technical revisions, the writer's effort to detach himself from his work is quixotic: knowing too much is a way of knowing too little; or, conversely, how can we expect to know more about ourselves than we know about anything else?

LEAD: The judge in a murder trial, angered that the police seized documents in the home of the chief defendant while jury selection was under way, has put off the trial to determine if the case involving members of the Billionaire Boys Club has been tainted.

LEAD: WITH the stock market flying on afterburners, analysts are hard-pressed to find stocks that look undervalued by such traditional measures as price-earnings ratio and book value. Indeed, among many analysts surveyed, few could come up with a classic value play. John Johnson, of Johnson, Valliant & Broadfoot, noted that the entire ''emerging growth'' sector - generally smaller companies with fast earnings gains -looked undervalued from one perspective: the average price-earnings ratio about matches the overall market's; in 1983, smaller growth companies commanded twice the market's P/E ratio.

LEAD: IF 1982 marked the emergence of the international debt crisis, 1987 could the year the notion of debt relief becomes respectable. Developing countries in Latin America and Africa, whose outstanding debt totals an estimated $973 billion, have been rumbling about relief for at least two years. Stringent adjustment programs, they say, which buy them payment extensions from creditors, also sap their economies and threaten their political stability.

LEAD: Ossining, N.Y. $230,000 14 Bracket Road 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 22-year-old raised ranch; paneled den, deck, central A/C, 0.5 acre; taxes $3,822. Pound Ridge, N.Y. $495,000 Knapp Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new colonial; study, Jacuzzi, lake rights, abuts nature preserve, 2.2 acres; taxes not yet assessed.

LEAD: Basketball Celtics vs. Houston Rockets At Boston, noon Television Channel 2, noon COLLEGE North Carolina St. at North Carolina Television Channel 4, 1 P.M. L.S.U. at Kentucky Television Channel 7, 2 P.M. Louisville at Purdue Television Channel 7, 4 P.M.

LEAD: During the 1984 Presidential campaign, I suddenly noted that, from the preambles, I couldn't differentiate between commercials extolling the virtues of the President and those promoting raisin bread (''Master of the Sentimental Sell,'' by Art Kleiner, Dec. 14). Distressed, I monitored other facets of my cognitive processes and was comforted to find no other evidence of deterioration.

LEAD: THE big trick for most small businesses is knowing when to change direction, something Robert O'Brien, president of the Workingman's Closet in New Rochelle, is familiar with. Starting with an industrial laundry and uniform rental company as a nucleus, Mr. O'Brien added the Workingman's Closet, a direct factory sales division, six years ago.

LEAD: THIS was going to be a joyous midwinter review of the videotapes of the Mets' World Series victory, a last chance to revel in the glories of baseball before Super Bowl mania hits us like a ton of Twinkies.

LEAD: IN a front-page photograph last week, L'Osservatore Romano showed Pope John Paul II standing soberly beside the equally unsmiling Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski. The Vatican newspaper added only a 40-word caption stating that the Polish leader had been received in a private audience Tuesday.
LEAD: MY wife nudged me awake. ''I heard the doorbell ring,'' she said.

LEAD: Not long after Mrs. Rivlin gave the speech from which the accompanying article is excerpted, President Reagan sent his proposed Federal budget for the fiscal year 1988, touching off the annual scramble that consumes much of official Washington's time and energy. In an interview this week, the former director of the Congressional Budget
LEAD: Retracing a Flight Of Mythology

LEAD: George Bernard Shaw's contemporaries would have been astonished to know that his plays were still being performed around the world toward the end of the 20th century (''You Never Can Tell'' is now winding up a revival in New York). A playwright was the last thing they considered him to be. If theater reviewers agreed on nothing else, they were certain that he could not write for the stage.

LEAD: IF the Legislature goes along, as expected, New Jersey may soon be the first state in the nation to require every able-bodied welfare recipient, including mothers of young children, to work or attend school. Governor Kean, announcing the new direction for the state's $1 billion welfare system last week in his State of the State message, called it ''a bold and reasonable plan.

LEAD: In striking down a New York law last week, the United States Supreme Court may have made liquor less expensive in the state, but some in the industry said small retailers would pay a heavy price as a result.

LEAD: In his new budget, President Reagan has proposed raising Congressional salaries to $89,500 a year, from $77,500. The increase will take effect automatically next month unless both houses of Congress vote to block it.

LEAD: In his article ''The Cult of Ceausescu'' (Nov. 30), David Binder is mistaken when he writes, ''. . . it appears that Ceausescu has not allowed torture or killing to be part of his style of governance.'' Amnesty International consistently receives reports of prison mistreatment and police beatings in

LEAD: We can all rejoice, presumably, that Shirley MacLaine went to Peru and found inner peace. Unfortunately, however, ABC-TV has given her five hours of prime time to tell us all about it - in minute detail. For those of us who remain skeptical, at best, about reincarnation, extraterrestrials, out-of-body trippers and trance channelers, ''Out on a

LEAD: State officials say they have offered to help New York City find foster homes for the growing number of healthy babies in hospitals who are awaiting placement, but the city says the state's proposals are inadequate.
LEAD: What does one call a city that has nearly 80 recorded names, 7 of them coined by Goethe's Mephistopheles as he was flying toward it on his magic cloak with Dr. Faust?

LEAD: 'ANNE FRANK' IN TEANECK ''The Diary of Anne Frank,'' produced by the professional American Stage Company of Teaneck, opened this weekend at the Becton Theater on the Teaneck campus of Fairleigh Dickinson University.

LEAD: The Republican Party is expected to decide in the coming week to hold its 1988 Presidential nominating convention in New Orleans. The choice signals the importance of the South as a battleground in the next contest for the White House; only rarely has the Republican Party ventured below the Mason-Dixon line for its quadrennial celebration.

LEAD: As a former Bureau of Land Management ranger, I witnessed firsthand the archeological-site destruction in southern Utah and Colorado documented by Derek Goodwin in ''Raiders of the Sacred Sites'' (Dec. 7). Artifact collectors are professional and elusive; despite back-country patrols and aircraft surveillance, most of my time was spent reburying the remains of Native Americans scattered across the surface of prehistoric sites.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas L. Phillips of Weston, Mass., and Center Harbor, N.H., have announced the engagement of their daughter Deborah Ann Phillips to John Lee Robertson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Pat Robertson of Houston. The wedding is planned for April 11. The future bride was until recently the director of international rights for CBS Educational and Professional Publishing in New York.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Charles Sanclementi of Wayne, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Karen Sanclementi, to Richard Alan Balter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Balter of Woodcliff Lake, N.J. Miss Sancelementi is vice president of corporate services at Murphy Realty-Better Homes and Gardens in Ramsey, N.J.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:
