''It'' is covert action, and Carlucci, who took office two weeks ago as President Reagan's fifth assistant for national security, knows what he is talking about. His immediate predecessor, Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter, resigned last

LEAD: CABINS AND KINGS ANNIE OAKLEY, Will Rogers, even the Duke of Windsor would have been pleased. What John H. Meyer calls their ''old hangout'' in Massapequa is being preserved by the local Kiwanis Club.
LEAD: This Week:

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur R. Schwalb of Stamford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Karen Robin Schwalb, to Joel Daniel Hollander, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Milton B. Hollander, also of Stamford.

LEAD: Judge and Mrs. Burton J. Ironson of Springfield, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Ann Ironson, to Jordan Irving Katz, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Katz of New York and Remsenburg, N.Y. The wedding is planned for March. Miss Ironson, a vice president of the North American department at Chemical Bank in New York, graduated cum laude from Princeton University and received an M.B.A.
LEAD: THE WAR AGAINST THE PRESS Politics, Pressure and Intimidation in the 80's. By Peter Stoler. 226 pp. New York: Dodd, Mead & Company. $17.95.

LEAD: Since Gerry Mulligan, the baritone and soprano saxophonist who is also an arranger, organized his 13-piece Concert Jazz Band in 1960, it has been an on-again, off-again part of his career. The original Concert Jazz Band was active until 1967 when Mr. Mulligan gave it up because, he said, ''it got to be taken for granted, like an old shoe.
LEAD: To the Editor: You are to be commended for your recent article ''What's Doing in Berkeley'' in which most of the highlights of that delightful city were discussed.

LEAD: This small college town was decked in blue and white today as a crowd estimated at 30,000 by the State Police honored Penn State's national championship football team at a parade through the campus and downtown. Penn State (12-0) defeated Miami, 14-10, in the Fiesta Bowl Jan. 2 for the title.

LEAD: Advance ticket sales for the Broadway run of ''Les Miserables,'' a rock musical of Victor Hugo's 1862 novel, reached $6.7 million, breaking record that was set in 1982 by ''Cats.'' The show begins previews next month at the Broadway Theatre. (NYT/Keith Meyers)
LEAD: The numbers for 1986 suggest that the nation's airlines are flying closer than ever to disaster, but by some combination of wit and luck are emerging with an improving safety record.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Eugene J. McCabe of Rumson, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Mary Ellen McCabe to Robert D. Kirschner, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton I. Kirschner of Brooklyn. The wedding is planned for May 2.

LEAD: That was a fascinating story in this newspaper the other day about the retarded child who, without musical training, could sit down at a piano, reproduce a melody and immediately improvise four-part harmony to it. Such ''idiots savant,'' as the French call these mysteriously gifted persons, turn up in music now and then, to the astonishment of us all.
LEAD: IT'S back again - the season of my discontent, and of my content. The season I hate, the season I love. Winter.

LEAD: 'Black Americans enter 1987 besieged by the resurgence of raw racism, persistent economic depression and the continued erosion of past gains.' - John E. Jacob, president of the National Urban League, releasing a report on ''The State of Black America.''

LEAD: WINTER, when the ground is rock-hard, the meadows covered with snow and the branches on trees turned to icicles, is not the gardener's favorite time of year. The scenery seems especially bleak in January, yet at the Bartlett Arboretum in Stamford there are plenty of visitors strolling along the paths.

LEAD: THE number of traffic accidents on Connecticut's three major Interstate highways increased substantially in 1986, according to figures provided last week by the state police. In particular, the figures showed a large increase in the number of fatal accidents involving trucks.

LEAD: YOU CAN always tell a new resident of an adult condominium community from the other gray-haired types because one shoulder is always lower than the other. This comes from carrying the prospectus around from condo meeting to condo meeting. What is this prospectus? It is the thick, telephone directory-size book of rules and regulations for living in a condominium, the thing that all condo real-estate ads clearly state you can't buy one of their homes or apartments without.

LEAD: THE New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, which was expected to issue new rules for governing the city's 950,000 rent-stabilized apartments, instead has issued yet another set of proposed regulations. This document, the third proposal published by the agency in 15 months, contains hundreds of minor changes - including new provisions affecting a tenant's right to pass an apartment to family members.

LEAD: The engagement of Jody Leigh Harrison to Martin Lehrman Grass has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Stanley L. Harrison of Norfolk, Va. Mr. Grass is a son of Alexander Grass and Lois Lehrman Grass, both of Harrisburg, Pa. The wedding is planned for May 17.

LEAD: ACCESSORIES of alligator and crocodile skin have long been chic. But since laws were passed to protect those reptiles, such adornments have not been as visible as they were a couple of decades ago, when they added a special touch to many a smart woman's attire. Now, however, handbags and belts made from the skins are back and despite their price tag - bags start at around $800 and can run into the thousands - customers have been lin ing up to buy them.
LEAD: Not if there's somebody willing to pay them. MIKE SEGHINI New York

LEAD: ONCE upon a time, when I still believed that mothers had the duty and power to grant wishes, I promised my last child, then an 11-year-old girl who dreamed of owning a horse, that if we ever moved away I would buy her one. It was an easy promise, one I thought I would never have to keep. Friends who passed down to her their own daughters' castoff velvet riding caps, hoof-pickers, horsefly spray and crops assured me that Kate, too, would automatically trot out of the horsey stage when she was 13 or so.

LEAD: Capping a drive that some officials predict will shatter the influence of the most powerful organized crime syndicate here, a Federal magistrate ruled Thursday that a reputed Mafia leader, Nicodemo Scarfo, was a public danger and ordered him held without bail pending trial on charges that he had planned an extortion scheme with a City

LEAD: Confirmed incidents of racial bias in New York City, after dropping sharply in most of 1986, have jumped more than 150 percent in the month since the racial attack in Howard Beach, Queens, according to police officials who investigate crimes of bias.

LEAD: Her former campaign manager, David Garth, described Bess Myerson as a fighter, ''not the sort of person who pulls the bedspread over her head.'' But last week the city's Cultural Affairs Commissioner quietly began a leave of absence pending an inquiry into issues stemming from a Federal grand jury investigation of a contractor who has been her regular companion for several years.

LEAD: Last year, Ecuador locked up Gen. Frank Vargas Pazzos, an Air Force commander, after he staged two revolts within a week. The authorities turned aside General Vargas's insistence that he was merely protesting against corruption in the armed forces. Later the national congress voted to grant the officer amnesty, and he became something of a folk hero.

LEAD: THE Suffolk County Legislature recently voted for a bill to ban the use of steel-jaw traps to capture animals. I was amazed to read that this is the first ban of these in this state, as I would have thought that these barbaric and cruel traps would have been banned long ago, particularly in the suburbs where the population is increasing and the habitat of small wild animals is rapidly dwindling.

LEAD: There's good home viewing in some of the week's newer film fare, like Bravo's ''Bring On the Night'' (1985), a rock feature with Sting and his new group, done with originality and skill - Sunday at 8 P.M. and 2 A.M.; and the station's ''Camila'' (1984), a passionate, beautifully played and fact-based costume drama about the love of an aristocrat and a priest in Argentina - Monday at 8 P.M.

LEAD: Lawyers for the two surviving victims of the Dec. 20 racial assault in Howard Beach declared a ''people's victory'' last week after Governor Cuomo assigned a special prosecutor to take over the case.

LEAD: THE Consort of Musicke's Wednesday night concert at Weill Recital Hall, devoted to English and Italian music of the 17th century, provided an ample impression of the group and its charms even to this listener who was pushed into an early departure by the flu.

LEAD: To the Editor: In his interesting article on the troubles facing the music publishing industry, Bernard Holland writes that the time is long gone when the market for printed music was ''voracious'' and reminds us of the success of the old Etude magazine as a sharp contrast to today's sad situation.

LEAD: The birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., actually Jan. 15, will be observed tomorrow in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. Following are holiday schedules: Parking - Alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation - Regular collections. Governmental offices - Closed. Post offices - Closed; special delivery and express-mail delivery only.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:
LEAD: TO catch up on the backlog of mail, this week's column is again devoted to readers' questions about common home-repair and maintenance problems.
LEAD: LIGHT snow fell on the D. Fairchild Wheeler municipal golf course in Fairfield, atop the four inches from a previous storm. It looked like no day for a round of golf. Not even for a diehard.

LEAD: THE American Economic Association did not choose New Orleans for its annual convention to spur the ailing local conomy, but the 6,000 economists and perhaps 2,000 spouses who descended on the city certainly did not hurt.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Gerard B. Ruiz of New York of the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Deborah Geraldine Ruiz, to Anthony Blenk, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Blenk of New York. A May wedding is planned. Dr. Ruiz, an ophthalmologist in New York, graduated from Barnard College and the Albany Medical College of Union University.

LEAD: MORE than two decades after the birth control pill launched a sexual revolution in the United States, the Japanese Government is close to officially condoning its use. Instead of praise, however, the move has met with criticism from feminists and wariness from the public, which is not expected to switch en masse to oral contraception.

LEAD: THE Joyce Theater gave a performance Friday night, but the choreographer of honor seemed conspicuously absent. The program by the Kathryn Posin Dance Company, the closing group in the Joyce Sampler Series, proceeded from one trivial or poorly thought-out dance to another, performed with an understandable lack of conviction.

LEAD: The Federal Government is not finished with John A. Walker Jr. and his spy ring, law-enforcement officials said last week. A new grand jury is investigating what happened to a million dollars in espionage payments and whether the ring involved people other than the four Navy men already convicted.
LEAD: JOHN LUCAS, twice waived from the N.B.A. for cocaine use, returned to basketball yesterday when he signed to play the remainder of the season with the Milwaukee Bucks.

LEAD: To the Editor: ''When the Boss Is Unbearable'' (Dec. 28) offers a variety of ''solu tions'' for dealing with ''weak, willful and devious'' bosses. All of these so-called solutions, be they ''keeping your distance,'' ''apple polishing'' or ''grinning and bearing,'' have one fatal flaw. All are based on the assumption that an individual worker can and must continue to deal on an individual basis with a monstrous boss.

LEAD: THE most widely watched market barometer continues to soar. Is the surge a long-term rally or a speculative binge reminiscent of the 1920's? A look back - and ahead. Archives of Business. Page 16. (NYT/Keith Meyers)

LEAD: The Adaptors, whose ''movement theater'' piece ''Autobahn'' has just enjoyed a resounding critical success, are not billed as mimes. Nonetheless, the troupe's founders, Tony Brown and Kari Margolis, both studied in Paris with the master of classical mime, Etienne Decroux, and they performed with the Montreal mime group Omnibus.

LEAD: At a moment of considerable interest in the possibilities of abstraction, the Luise Ross Gallery, 50 West 57th Street, has brought together four little known artists whose work defines, each in its own way, an edge between abstraction and figuration. The diptychs of Cynthia Gallagher and the vertical slabs of George Hildrew are paintings with precise figurative and sculptural associations.

LEAD: ONE can hardly imagine how remote the newborn republic of Nicaragua must have been from the world's cosmopolitan centers during the last century. It was perceived, not quite correctly, as a tropical backwater, steamy, inert and destitute of learning and culture. Yet from a wretched Nicaraguan village, by some amazing mystery, emerged Ruben Dario, the vagabond poet who was to influence Latin American and Spanish literature forever and dazzle Europe as no provincial ever had.

LEAD: FOR the thousands of individuals who own second homes, 1987 will mark a key turning point for tax benefits. People who rent out their vacation houses must decide whether to begin using the home as a second residence, so they can deduct the mortgage interest, or whether to continue renting so they can claim a loss on the business venture.

LEAD: The last time the Knicks lost to the youthful Cleveland Cavaliers, the coach emerged from the locker-room looking drawn and drained, and he spoke in terms of ''I'' and not ''we'' in an effort to divorce himself from his team. Two days later, Hubie Brown was dismissed.

LEAD: A developer from Forest Hills, Queens, who is making his first foray into Ulster County is planning a $50 million town-house development on the west bank of the Hudson River, across from Poughkeepsie, N.Y.

LEAD: For many years, the three major television networks and the National Football League have formed a partnership that has handsomely benefited everyone involved. ABC, CBS and NBC paid top price for exclusive rights to the games, filling the coffers of team owners, helping to fund increased player salaries, and, most years, earning millions of dollars in profits for themselves.
LEAD: If you're a writer and if you're by nature Sublime and Magisterial,

LEAD: N.H.L. Bruins 4, Penguins 2: Third-period goals by Steve Kasper, Tom McCarthy and Nevin Markwart led the Bruins at home yesterday. They trailed by 2-1 entering the third period. (AP) Capitals 6, Whalers 1: At Hartford, Kevin Hatcher and Dave Christian each scored twice as the Capitals scored five goals on their first 12 shots against Mike Liut.

LEAD: It is unusual for a game to be seriously considered for a brilliancy prize if it does not feature sacrifice of material. One may surmise that, if a player ingeniously maneuvers to obtain a clearly better position and presses the attack relentlessly and with great style, the judges still feel he is not venturing anything and hence is not making the supreme prize effort.

LEAD: To the Editor: While the gathering of evidence regarding the effects of passive smoking on the non-smoker may eventually put an end to this controversy, there is already a Federal law that should be used to eliminate smoking in public places - the one insuring equal access to public places for handicapped people.

LEAD: Diane Schwebel, an assistant district attorney in Brooklyn, and Perry Dean Freedman, a lawyer in private practice in New York, were married yesterday at the Old Oaks Country Club in Purchase, N.Y. Rabbi Amiel Wohl performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Record cold weather has disrupted sports schedules in Europe, with soccer, the national sport in Britain, severely hit. Scores of English and Scottish League matches were postponed today because of the sub-zero temperatures.

LEAD: RATING AMERICA'S CORPORATE CONSCIENCE A Provocative Guide to the Companies Behind the Products You Buy Every Day. By Steven D. Lydenberg, Alice Tepper Marlin, Sean O'Brien Strub and the Council on Economic Priorities. 499 pp. Reading, Mass.: Addison-Wesley. Cloth, $21.95. Paper, $14.95.
LEAD: BREAKING BREAD By Joyce Reiser Kornblatt. 206 pp. New York: A William Abrahams Book/ E. P. Dutton. $16.95.
LEAD: THE ONLY THING HARDER than getting people to accept a good idea is getting them to abandon a bad one. A relevant example: the almost universal reverence for old wines.
LEAD: Land claims by descendants of the Sioux Indians have been rejected by a Federal appeals court in a case lawyers said might affect similar claims to about 1.5 million acres nationwide.

LEAD: The remaining undeveloped segment of one of Garden City's most venerable sites will soon be home to one of Long Island's newest condominium projects. Construction will start this spring on the Wyndham at Garden City, a $125 million, 316-unit condominium complete with pond, gazebo and health club. The development will cover the 12.5 acres that form part of the historic 21-acre site of the 100-year-old, Georgian-style Garden City Hotel, which was razed in 1974 and replaced with a new hotel in 1983.

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Louis Simeone of Somerset, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Angela Simeone, to Ben Yagoda, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Yagoda of New Rochelle, N.Y. A May 17 wedding is planned.

LEAD: The controversy over arms sales to Iran has substantially altered the campaign for the 1988 Democratic Presidential nomination, politicians say, by increasing the value of the nomination and thus slowing the race down as potential candidates and political professionals reassess their hopes and interests.

LEAD: The London police, who have traditionally disdained the widespread use of firearms to combat criminals, have announced that they will further reduce the number of officers authorized to use guns.

LEAD: With the racial violence last month in Queens still on their minds, organizers of religious and cultural activities over the weekend commemorating the birth of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. emphasized that the civil rights leader's vision is as relevant today as it was during his lifetime.

LEAD: I take issue with the methods proposed to control swans reported in the article on swan control [ ''Controls on Swans Proposed,'' Jan. 4 ] . I get the feeling that Nobel Proctor, albeit a professor of ornithology, truly hates swans. I 've read other articles in which he maligns swans.
LEAD: A picture caption on Jan. 4 with an article about Kariba, Zimbabwe, misidentified a herd of animals in a field. The animals were African buffaloes, which are also known as Cape buffaloes.

LEAD: AS lower Fairfield County becomes more and more urban, the quiet, rustic charm and spacious lots of bucolic communities like Woodbridge become more desirable and less remote to many home buyers.
LEAD: An American advocacy group on Soviet Jewry has told the Government that it will not contest the decision on Thursday to allow exports of gas and oil technology to the Soviet Union.

LEAD: EVERY Giant football fan has a vivid recollection of the Philadelphia Eagle game on Nov. 19, 1978, which football history refers to as The Fumble game. That disaster, and the resulting loss, did not cost the Giants a division title, a playoff game, or even a winning season. Yet, it set into motion a chain of events that can best be described as total fan outrage.

LEAD: The Lyon Opera Ballet comes from France, the cradle of the classical ballet. Its name brings to mind the Paris Opera Ballet, which just this summer offered a season of glittery French stars and spectacle at the Metropolitan Opera House. And so, the ballet classics - a ''Swan Lake'' here or a ''Giselle'' there -might be expected from the Lyon troupe, which opens at City Center on Tuesday for a two-week engagement that marks the company's
LEAD: Colin Eglin, the leader of the Progressive Federal Party, the official white opposition, rejected a suggestion Friday by Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu that the party withdraw from Parliament.

LEAD: Sheila Harrington, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick J. Harrington of the Bronx and High Falls, N.Y., and Lieut. Paul J. Sweeney, U.S.M.C.R., were married yesterday. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward F. Sweeney Jr. of Garden City, L.I., and Monroe, N.Y. The Rev. Sabas Kilian performed the ceremony at St.

LEAD: Gen. Maxwell R. Thurman underscores his place as the No. 2 officer in the Army by telling friends, ''I'm Avis, not Hertz.'' Adm. James B. Busey 4th stays so far from the limelight that two middle-ranking Navy staff officers say they don't know what he does and a third couldn't recall his name right away.

LEAD: THE delicate pianism of George Shearing, who combines one of the most feathery touches in jazz with an English-parlor gentility, has an almost sleight-of-hand quality in club performance. Especially when Mr. Shearing calmly wings his way through a series of interlocking blues progressions, the music almost seems to emanate from a magical source separate from the pianist's fingers.

LEAD: The Crans-Montana plateau in Switzerland was once scorned by local peasants as fit for little more than cow grazing; 60 years ago it was a destination for tuberculosis patients seeking crisp, dry air. Since then, skiers and golfers seeking the same weather conditions for winter and summer sports have come to predominate the 5,000-foot-high resort community.

LEAD: IN the 19th century, an inspector would sit up on the roof of the Customs House in New London and peer through his spyglass at the busy harbor ''to make sure nobody got away without paying customs,'' said the president of the New London Maritime Society, Lucille Showalter.

LEAD: THE Westchester Holocaust Memorial Committee is planning a $1 million ''living memorial'' to victims of Nazi atrocities, and county agreement is expected this month, members of the group said last week.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Wade Carroll Stephens of Lawrenceville, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Wade Stephens to James Stephen Hebb 4th, a son of Mrs. John Steven Slorp of Memphis and Mr. Hebb 3d of Alexandria, Va. The wedding is planned for June 20. Miss Stephens, who is known as Betsy, is the director of student activities, a history teacher and an admissions associate at the Madeira School.
LEAD: By ALICE M. RIVLIN;

LEAD: For both general and specific reasons, the New York Philharmonic records far less often than it used to. Still, on two labels with three conductors recorded in three locations, the orchestra has been represented on four new releases in recent months.
LEAD: If Dr. Frankenstein were around today, he could offer a very useful reminder to some Democratic members of Congress: it's mighty dangerous trying to breathe new life into a dead body.
LEAD: FAMILY LAUNDRY By Dorie Friend. 300 pp. New York: A Peter Weed Book/ Beaufort Books. $17.95.

LEAD: IN the four years since the quartet Sphere made its debut with a repertory that emphasized the compositions of Thelonious Monk, it has not only become less dependent on Monk in its programming but has moved away from its earlier use of Monk's performances of his compositions as a guide.

LEAD: The engagement of Betsy Bowman Phillips to Edward Safford Mandel has been announced by Melvin Burdette Phillips of Liberty, Ky., father of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Frank Mandel of Darien, Conn. A May wedding is planned.
LEAD: Darryl Kennedy's basket with 12 seconds remaining carried Oklahoma to an 89-88 victory over top-ranked and previously unbeaten Nevada-Las Vegas today.

LEAD: IT did not take the New Year's Eve inferno at the Dupont Plaza Hotel in San Juan to focus Alfred Menziuso's attention on the subject of designing safe means of escape from burning high-rise buildings.

LEAD: SOMEONE looking for a man in his 95th year could not be faulted for taking the search to a hospital. And in the case of Jack Horwitz, the search would bear fruit when it reached the Long Island Jewish Medical Center in New Hyde Park.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: They come from two different worlds: she is a se rene thoroughbred, he's a street-smart scoundrel with radical ideas. They meet through friends and fall in love, and he does what he can to show her the world. ''Aw, come on, kid, start building some memories,'' he urges. But she wants a stable and conventional life, while he wants freedom to roam.
LEAD: China offered no further clues today to the forced resignation of Hu Yaobang as the Communist Party leader and the naming of Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang as his acting successor.
LEAD: Controversy, a columnist here warned the other day, is threatening to ''rend the fabric'' of Kansas City civility and ''divide the citizenry.''

LEAD: Linda Liefland's essay on ''Finding a Surname for Baby'' [ Dec. 28 ] reminded me of my childhood in Hungary where many of us came from mixed marriages, the mothers being Catholic and the fathers Protestant. For most of us the egalitarian division fell so that the girls went to the Catholic church and the boys to the Protestant church, which made us believe that the niceties, colors and elaborate decorations in our church were meant for women while the men went to more down-to-earth and masculine houses of worship.

LEAD: SOME OF THE MOST AD-vanced men's clothing to reach the stores this spring is, in a sense, the most traditional. Even the most novel designs are loosely modeled on the conventional English gentleman's suit.

LEAD: Seymour J. Phillips, chairman of the board of Phillips-Van Heusen Corporation and vice president of Beth Israel Medical Center, died of a heart attack Friday in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 83 years old and lived in Manhattan and Palm Beach.

LEAD: We need to take a long hard look at the people who concoct ''warm-hearted, gentle, spirited and emotion-laden commercials'' selling junk food, junk beer, junk wine and junk presidents, and, thereby, take a desperately needed look at ourselves and our very foolish buying habits. GEORGE WINSHIP

LEAD: A caption in last Sunday's Westchester Weekly section accompanying an article about a playwriting contest incorrectly identified two of the judges, Ruis Woertendyke and Norman Kline, whose names were transposed.

LEAD: CONNECTICUT transportation officials are eagerly awaiting enactment of a highway bill that would enable the state to begin and continue major projects. The projects have been delayed because of a Congressional deadlock.

LEAD: In percent Passbook Savings 5.50 At savings institutions Tax-Exempt Bonds 6.65 Bond Buyer 20-Bond Index Money Market Funds 5.61 Donoghue's Money Fund 7-Day Compound Yield Bank Money Market Accounts 5.44 Bank Rate Monitor Home Mortgage 10.01 Federal Home Loan Bank, national average

LEAD: WHILE preaching free trade, the Reagan Administration has made protectionist concessions to a number of powerful domestic industries, from steel and lumber to semiconductors. But its piecemeal approach, aimed at slaking demand for trade restraints, might instead have increased it.

LEAD: Continuing a Cause Jan. 26 - Sports will be the theme at the seventh annual Thurman Munson Award Dinner - an event to aid the mentally retarded - at the Grand Hyatt Hotel starting with 6:30 P.M. cocktails. Before his death in a plane crash in 1979, the Yankee catcher had been active in promoting programs for the retarded.

LEAD: The brooding grandeur of Giovanni Battista Piranesi's thousands of architectural prints and drawings of ancient Roman buildings and ruins have made them immensely popular, and the prison scenes in the series of large prints called ''Carceri'' have inspired artists and writers for 200 years. Piranesi, who was his own etcher, engraver and printer, made hundreds of changes not only in different editions of the prints but in individual prints in the same issue.

LEAD: SOON after Saul Cooperman became the state's Commissioner of Education in 1982, he attended a meeting with some nationally prominent educators and began to talk about his ideas for change, especially his plan to overhaul the state's system of teacher certification.

LEAD: THE FOLK OF THE AIR (Del Rey/Ballantine, $16.95) by Peter S. Beagle, a fantasy novel set in contemporary California, mixes science and the supernatural so seamlessly that the bedazzled reader soon ceases to care which is which. Certainly none of the characters in this book stay up nights worrying about such distinctions.

LEAD: Maura Theresa Liptack, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Edward Liptack of Eastchester, N.Y., was married yesterday to Christopher Joseph McMahon, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Jordan McMahon of Silver Spring, Md. The Rev. Patrick Walsh and the Rev. James Beattie performed the ceremony at Immaculate Conception Roman Catholic Church in Tuckahoe, N

LEAD: A tougher drunken driving law, approved by the State Legislature last year just in time for Christmas and New Year's Eve, has set off a heated debate here about civil liberties and public safety.
LEAD: FREDERICK MOYER, a concert pianist, is proud that he can talk about music to just about anyone.

LEAD: THE Kronos Quartet, which seems poised to unseat a lot of assumptions about what can be expected of audience response, played a program of contemporary music to an enthusiastic standing-room-only crowd Friday night at Weill Recital Hall.

LEAD: Marlene Manes, whose husband, Donald, left a rather large estate for a public employee, has agreed to share her inheritance with the city's elderly and sick, municipal officials announced last week. Mr. Manes, the Queens Borough President who committed suicide last year after being implicated in the municipal corruption scandal, left an estate of slightly more than $1 million, as much as $300,000 of which, investigators charged, came from bribes.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The President of Ecuador said today that he was punched, kicked and repeatedly told he was going to be killed during the 12 hours he was held captive Friday.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The Giants held their final practice at home today before their Super Bowl game Jan. 25 against the Denver Broncos in Pasadena, Calif.

LEAD: IN 1956, when Martin Luther King Jr. wished to inspire his followers to continue their boycott of the segregated buses of Montgomery, Ala., he would refer to Gandhi's principles of nonviolent resistance and to Gandhi's successful use of the method of noncooperation with an evil system. Because Dr.

LEAD: Chapters of American history most regretted by Americans have sometimes been those for which people in the rest of the world have most admired the United States. Watergate comes to mind. What many in the international community remember most about Watergate is not the criminality of a President but the effective working of the civil machinery that removed him from office - the way in which the will of the people truly prevailed.

LEAD: The two Lebanese men arrested this week carrying explosives through the Milan and Frankfurt airports may have been part of a new terrorist offensive planned by radical Lebanese Shiites, according to senior American and Italian officials.

LEAD: LAST year I wrote for this page about how I hated the Chicago Bears, and had hated them since I was a kid growing up in Wisconsin hard by the shores of Lake Michigan some 60 miles north of Chicago. Being then a youngster with visions of becoming another Don Hutson, I took every Bear victory over my Green Bay Packers very personally.

LEAD: Seven of the eight men convicted in November of operating or helping operate a New York-based Mafia ''commission'' were sentenced last week to jail terms of 100 years; the eighth received 40 years. Included among the seven were three men convicted as bosses of major crime families: Anthony (Fat Tony) Salerno, 75 years old, of the Genovese family; Anthony (Tony Ducks) Corallo, 73, of the Lucchese family, and Carmine (Junior) Persico, 53, of the Colombo group.

LEAD: IN one of the more important criminal law disputes of the decade, the Supreme Court will hear arguments Wednesday on the constitutionality of the ''preventive detention'' of allegedly dangerous but unconvicted criminal defendants. The issue is at the center of the great divide between civil libertarians and advocates of tougher law enforcement.
LEAD: IN NEW YORK I USED to stay in no-power hotels. It was awful. Nobody interviewed me for press or television.

LEAD: To the Editor: I can't help but think that I have met the enemy - and he is Jerry K. Pearlman of Zenith Electronics Corporation (''Save the Lectures, Give Us Some Help,'' Forum, Dec. 14). Why shouldn't I be allowed to trade peacefully with any other citizen of the world? Why shouldn't I be allowed to buy a color TV from Korean, Japanese or

LEAD: To the Editor: A question was raised in your Q. & A. column on Nov. 16 about creating exempt status on rent-regulated apartments. The answer stated: ''The only way to rid a building of its rent-regulated status is through a gut-rehabilitation includingnew ceilings, floors, walls, etc.''
LEAD: This town in western Massachusetts has been paying for years for electrical service to run an air-raid siren no one can find, town officials say.
LEAD: NEVER mind what to do about increasing state aid to the cities, improving the professional training of the state's schoolteachers or continuing the death penalty.

LEAD: WHEN PEOPLE PUBLISH: Essays on Writers and Writing. By Frederick Busch. (University of Iowa, $19.95.) A novelist and short story writer who teaches at Colgate, Frederick Busch hastens to assure his readers that this collection isn't intended as ''formal instruction, but as talk about writers and books among admirers of grown-up writing.
LEAD: Additional titles of interest:

LEAD: A new set was issued Jan. 5 by Palau, one of the United Nations Trust Territories administered by the United States. The block of four depicts butterflies from the south Pacific island nation and enhances a popular topical specialty: butterflies-on-stamps. As with the butterflies themselves, the stamps are collected because of their beautiful colors and great variety.

LEAD: New York State's Court of Appeals -now entirely the handiwork of Governor Cuomo - has begun to take a leading national role in the protection of individual liberties, according to legal observers.

LEAD: THIS city's original United States Courthouse and Post Office, a Romanesque and Gothic Revival structure on the National Register of Historic Places, has undergone a $10 million renovation in time for its centennial this year. But it might never have reached its 100th birthday had it not been for an unusual partnership between a prominent local law firm and municipal officials.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Dr. Gari Ellen Goldberg, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Maurice Goldberg of Brooklyn, and Dr. Charles Henry Bloom, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis M. Bloom of Edison, N.J., were married last evening. Rabbi Alvin Kass performed the ceremony at the Harmonie Club in New York.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Jules Reiner of Kings Point, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Wendy Ellen Reiner to Dr. Ross G. Stone, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Stone of Pottsville, Pa., and Boynton Beach, Fla. A March wedding is planned.
LEAD: The Don Redlich Dance Company will present a new version of ''Pierrot Lunaire'' in performances Feb. 5 through 7 at 8 P.M. at the Washington Square Methodist Church, 135 West Fourth Street.

LEAD: GUY SAVOY, the restaurant named after the chef who opened it several years ago in Greenwich, has undergone a name and ownership change and the results are an all-round improvement - in food, in decor and in the welcome accorded guests.

LEAD: PRESIDENT REAGAN appears to be trapped in a web of paradox over the secret sale of arms to Iran, vulnerable if he knew more about the deal than he has acknowledged and vulnerable if he knew less about it than his critics insist any President should have known.

LEAD: THE appointment recently of State Senator John R. Dunne, a Garden City Republican, as deputy majority leader of the State Senate is a step forward in his career. But the significance of his new post for Long Island was less than clear.

LEAD: American college freshmen are more interested in financial success according to a new survey by the University of California at Los Angeles and the American Council on Education, and less interested than their predecessors in helping others. The study, based on responses from 204,491 students who entered college last fall, also reported less support for the preservation of the environment and a significant drop in support for the legalization of marijuana.

LEAD: As officials said the investigation of Amtrak's worst accident was focusing on ''human performance issues,'' the National Transportation Safety Board recommended the wider use of technology that takes over if a human lapses.

LEAD: Iran and Iraq agree that their battles of the last 10 days have been epic, even by the grisly standards of their seven-year war. But in what has become a ritual, both countries claimed victory last week and issued grandiose assertions.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Conley of Madison, N.J., of the engagement of his daughter M. Eileen Conley to Clive Edward Benedict Schlee, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robin A. Schlee of Woodbridge, Suffolk, England. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: I can only say that a man by the name of Rich Gedman, the catcher of the Boston Red Sox for the last six seasons, recently turned down a three-year contract that would have guaranteed him $2.65 million. Is that asking for too much? I'd say that's not only asking for too much, I'd say that's something only an extremely greedy individual would do.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: THE other night an executive, dining at a moderately sized restaurant, paid his check with a credit card and added a rather generous tip. When the young waitress returned his card she said, ''Thank you very much, Charles.'' The two had never met - she had seen his name on the credit card.

LEAD: Colombia's newspapers and radio and television stations, reacting in concert to a surge of drug-related violence, are warning that this country is in danger of falling under the ''total domination'' of narcotics traffickers.

LEAD: The card-playing enthusiasm of the British aristocracy has added more than one word to the English language. In the 18th century the third Earl of Sandwich, a diplomat and politician of some notoriety nicknamed Jeremy Twitcher, was unwilling to take time out from his game to eat. He asked the waiter to bring him some meat between two slices of bread and millions now use his name daily.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: AFTER seven years of delays, backhoes are finally scratching a foundation into the frozen ground at Queens Boulevard and Union Turnpike in Kew Gardens, Queens. But Sidney Esikoff, the developer, still is not certain exactly what he can build there.

LEAD: The photographs of Jacques-Henri Lartigue, who died last summer at the age of 92, are art photography's best-known version of primitivism. Most were taken in the early years of this century, when Lartigue was a boy, and they have the freshness and spontaneity of an eye unjaundiced by the conventions of the photography of the day.

LEAD: SOME seasonings are roughly interchangeable. Tarragon can stand in for chervil and, in a pinch so can parsley. Vinegar instead of lemon is another effective substitution as is black pepper for cayenne. But no seasoning does exactly the same job of bringing up flavor as salt. When a diet requires salt to be restricted it becomes a challenge for the cook.
LEAD: George Deukmejian, a Republican, has begun his second term in office as he began the first one: fighting over money with Democratic legislators and the state's influential public schools lobby.

LEAD: To the Editor: I read with much interest Anne Marshall Zwack's article ''Splendor of a Fading Art'' (Travel, Dec. 14). The descriptions of Jesurum's museum and shop brought back wonderful memories. In October 1980 while on vacation in Italy, I visited Jesurum with a specific task in mind. My oldest daughter was to be married the following August and was going to wear my wedding gown, which was then 30 years old.

LEAD: ''But you see, the harp is not so difficult,'' Nicanor Zabaleta, one of the few musicians who can make that statement truthfully, said with a gentle grin. ''I'll make you a drawing - I always do this for composers, for all the composers who are frightened of the harp. I tell them to imagine that they are are playing a piano only on the white keys - the pedals will fill in the missing black keys.

LEAD: On the 27th of January, 1987, President Reagan will deliver his seventh annual State of the Union address to the 100th Congress of the United States at the beginning of the 200th anniversary of the Federal Constitution.

LEAD: Wendy Turgeon's ''Won't Anybody Here Talk to Me?'' (Opinion Page, Dec. 14), painfully refers to the isolation many of us can feel here on Long Island. Often, those who express these feelings blame their situation on the fact that they are ''employed women'' lacking time to develop relationships or homemakers claiming underexposure for their lack of contacts.

LEAD: At the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York yesterday Hillary Ann Holland and Russell Fogarty, both vice presidents of Christie's, the fine-arts auctioneer, were married by the Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley.

LEAD: The marriage of Robin Judith Seigerman, a third-year law student at New York University, and Jonathan Richard Eiseman, a lawyer in the real estate department of the New York law firm Weil, Gotshal & Manges, took place last evening at the Mamaroneck (N.Y.) Beach and Yacht Club. Rabbi Isaac Swift officiated.
LEAD: The event is nearly a decade away, but the Greek Government may already have lost what it considers a historic right: the ''Golden Olympiad'' of 1996.

LEAD: SPORTS SPECTATORS. By Allen Guttmann. (Columbia University, $24.95.) In the introduction to ''Sports Spectators,'' Allen Guttmann, a professor of American studies at Amherst College, gives his working definition of a sports fan - an ''emotionally committed 'consumer' of sports events.'' Unfortunately, ''Sports Spectators'' lacks emotion.

LEAD: Christian Okoye, a Little all-American from Azusa Pacific College, a member of the National Association for Intercollegiate Athletics, set a Senior Bowl record with four touchdowns today as the South edged the North, 42-38. Three of Okoye's scores came on 1-yard runs, and he had a 6-yard touchdown with 1 minute 6 seconds to play.
LEAD: WHEN a borrower takes out a mortgage loan, the lender customarily offers insurance to cover payment of the outstanding balance in the event of the borrower's death or disability.

LEAD: Fiction 1 8 THE MAMMOTH HUNTERS, by Jean M. Auel. (Bantam, $4.95.) Ayla of ''The Clan of the Cave Bear'' resumes her prehistoric adventures. 2 7 LIE DOWN WITH LIONS, by Ken Follett. (Signet/ NAL, $4.95.) An Englishwoman in Afghanistan, caught between the C.I.A. and the K.G.B.

LEAD: WHIPSAWED by automation, increasingly anti-union managements and a large pool of unemployed people willing to break a strike, many union members are finding that ''givebacks'' - cuts in wages and benefits - have become a fact of life. One result appears to be fewer but longer strikes. While the rank and file often regarded concessions as onerous from the start, labor leaders strove mightily to put the best face on them, calling them temporary measures to strengthen companies and, above all, protect jobs.

LEAD: With the possibility that unions of the Long Island Rail Road will go on strike today, officials provided these telephone numbers for information about transportation arrangements: L.I.R.R. L.I.R.R. strike hot line: (718) 468-8600 or (516) 422-4040, taped message. L.I.R.R.

LEAD: WITHIN the walls of a turreted castle on a hilltop in Rye Brook, N.Y., an exhibition of more than 150 drawings, watercolors and painted celluloids from Walt Disney films and comic strips depicts a crucial chapter in the history of cartooning.

LEAD: THE CASE OF THE FRAGMENTED WOMAN. By Cleo Jones. (St. Martin's, $15.95.) Mary Sable, the heroine of Cleo Jones's third novel, is a Marin County housewife and aspiring writer; she takes care of a husband who neither appreciates nor understands her, and three children, who treat her as little more than a maid.
LEAD: Ducks Unlimited's VideoGuide to Waterfowl and Game Birds Written, directed and narrated by Michael A. Godfrey. MasterVision. 75 minutes. $74.95.

LEAD: Forty years after he paid dearly for his faith in Communism, Ring Lardner Jr. concedes some disappointment but no regrets. Mr. Lardner, whose promising career as a screenwriter was aborted in 1947 when he was blacklisted after refusing to answer questions from the House Un-American Activities Committee, reflected on his long association with Communism while visiting Moscow as a tourist last week.

LEAD: French dance is enjoying a renaissance. And the venerable Paris Opera Ballet is not the only important French choreographic center today. The enterprising Lyon Opera Ballet opens Tuesday at the City Center with Maguy Marin's ''Cinderella,'' which promises to be like no other version of the fairy tale.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Cantor of Rye, N.Y., have announced that their daughter Julie Ann Cantor and Andrew Charles Peskoe are to be married Feb. 21. The future bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd F. Peskoe of Colts Neck, N.J., and New York.

LEAD: MARK GASTINEAU, the Jets' defensive end, has reportedly been fined for a flagrant hit on Bernie Kosar, the Cleveland Browns' quarterback, in the American Conference divisional playoffs two weeks ago.

LEAD: As a new high-school teacher in New York City, I do what I can to awaken, in each successive brood, love of the principles Mr. Rosenthal articulated in his article. I am going to use his essay to teach my students about the opportunities that I believe are available to them, just as they were available to him.

LEAD: Suzana Amaral was married at age 20, and in the next 10 years had eight children. At 37, she entered the University of Sao Paulo film school, and went on to get a master's degree in film at New York University. She is now 54, and her first full-length theatrical feature, ''The Hour of the Star'' - a film about the troubled life of a young woman in Sao Paulo that the Brazilian director shot in four weeks for $150,000 - opens Wednesday at Film Forum 1, after having won awards at the Berlin, Brasilia, Havana and International Woman's Film Festivals and having been selected as

LEAD: Competition for the accolade of the most idyllic outpost in the Caribbean is stiff, but for tranquil shallow waters, Liliputian villages with an 18th-century flavor and sun-drenched beaches, the Abacos are arguably the best.

LEAD: The boat with a racing record so exemplary that she has acquired the nickname Kiwi Magic sailed in the America's Cup challenge finals today as if someone had cut a hole in her bag of tricks.
LEAD: California law requires employers to grant as much as four months of unpaid leave to women when childbearing makes them physically unable to work.

LEAD: GREG FOSTER was jubilant, with good reason. It was one of the rare times in Foster's track career that he had beaten Renaldo Nehemiah in the hurdles. LEAD: I think it's only natural that in a free enterprise system some ''market correction'' develops. It was the owners who were responsible for the explosion of player salaries in the 1970's; they have now realized the risky economics of continued bidding wars and longterm contracts. There is no premeditated ''collusion'' here - it's just that they're all thinking and acting the same way.

LEAD: IN Norwalk, Gwendolyn Gaither has found a new friend in Christine Kantzas, an 8-year-old student at the Fox Run Elementary School. LEAD: IN his private conference room on the 46th floor of the Pan Am building, C. Edward Acker, chairman and chief executive of Pan American World Airways, reacts calmly when asked if his strategy is to declare the troubled airline bankrupt.
LEAD: New Mexicans are trying to shed as much as 200,000 pounds by the end of March as part of the nation's first statewide campaign to reduce heart disease through health education.
LEAD: EAST WINDSOR is more than 100 miles from Broadway, which is why ''Sweet Charity,'' still running in New York, has been allowed to be presented at the Coachlight Dinner Theater.
LEAD: ''Everybody and his brother went out and bought a car to take the sales tax deduction.'' - Michael K. Evans, analyst, on the December surge in retail sales.
LEAD: THE CARE OF THE SELF Volume Three of The History of Sexuality. By Michel Foucault. Translated by Robert Hurley. 279 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $18.95.

LEAD: THE END OF JANUARY may be when some people flee the city to escape winter doldrums, but for the serious collector New York is the only place to be. The annual Winter Antiques Show, which opens to the public Saturday at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and 67th Street and runs through Feb. 1, has traditionally been a catalyst for antiques events in New York - a time when galleries dress up their windows with knock-em-dead pieces and auction houses conduct some of the most important

LEAD: WHEN the Giants were winning six Eastern Division titles in eight seasons, from 1956 through 1963, their Hall of Fame defensive end, Andy Robustelli, was known as the Pope in the locker room. To his teammates, the Pope was infallible. When the Pope spoke, they agreed. They still do. When the Pope invited several Giants alumni to a dinner for the National Society for the Prevention of Blindness at ''21'' the other night, they agreed.
LEAD: The discoveries of the bodies of six young black women has set off a police search crossing state lines and has aroused anxiety among the capital area's blacks.

LEAD: Cheered on by tens of thousands of people shouting ''Death to the Russians!'' Afghan guerrilla leaders at a rally here today vowed to step up their war against the Afghan authorities in Kabul and said they would try to form their own government in exile.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: WHAT was described as the nation's only free-roaming colony of monkeys came under state condemnation at Silver Springs, a junglelike tourist attraction in Florida.

LEAD: MORGAN BEQUEST ON VIEW Five years ago, the Wadsworth Atheneum began assessing its bequest of European decorative arts, made decades ago by J. Pierpont Morgan Jr., son of the railroad and steel leader, who collected them.
LEAD: THE pace of the concert season quickens somewhat next weekend, with two of the county's fine orchestras leading the way.

LEAD: For women serious about both career and family, life can quickly become a difficult balancing act. A new Supreme Court decision promises to make the balancing a bit easier. It allows states to guarantee job-protected leave to pregnant workers.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: An article Jan. 4 on Guiding Eyes for the Blind included incorrect information about how new guide dogs are provided. The organization, which retains ownership of the dogs, requests a voluntary tuition fee of $150 for the 26-day training course given to blind people who receive the dogs.

LEAD: Development in the seven national forests surrounding Yellowstone National Park is fragmenting and eroding the natural systems that support the park, the Wilderness Society charged in a report released today.

Lawrenceville $197,000 38 Morton Court 2-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 4-year-old condominium town house; central A/C, dining room, 2-car attached garage, maintenance $205; taxes $3,600.

LEAD: Rupert Murdoch came out on top of the battle of the media titans in Australia. In a deal struck with his rival, Robert Holmes a Court, Mr. Murdoch cleared the way to take control of the Herald and Weekly, Australia's largest media group. In turn, Mr. Holmes a Court, who agreed to withdraw his $1.4 billion bid, is to purchase the group's two Perth newspapers and its Melbourne television stations, which many analysts said were what he really wanted.

LEAD: UNLESS all of West Germany's opinion polls have made a huge miscalculation, Chancellor Helmut Kohl's center-right coalition will be re-elected next week.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Stone Tarbell of Binghamton, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Nancy Jane Tarbell, to Dr. Jay Steven Loeffler, a son of Dr. and Mrs. John G. Loeffler of Carlisle, Pa.
LEAD: SPHINX By D. M. Thomas. 248 pp. New York: Viking. $17.95.

LEAD: THE software selection available for word processing is probably greater than that for any other form of computing. There are packages like Words & Figures, limited in text-handling capabilities but specifically fashioned for spreadsheet users.
LEAD: THE busiest booth in the convention exhibit hall was the one where Ruth Polak was handing out invitations to the first annual meeting of FAUG.

LEAD: David Binder's article shows only the darker side of the President of Rumania. Mr. Binder reports that he had to submit his questions ahead of time when he requested an interview with Mr. Ceausescu. Is it not the same when you request an interview with a United States President? And what about protocol?

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Max Harry Weil of Beverly Hills, Calif., and Chicago have announced the engagement of their daughter Carol Juliet Weil to David Medine, the son of Ruth Medine of New York and the late Dr. Myer Medine. The wedding is planned for July.

LEAD: To the Editor: When the Environmental Protection Agency and the Surgeon General join hands to argue that the slightest involuntary exposure to tobacco smoke is worse than anything else, except breathing asbestos, are they playing a political game?

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Peter F. Cowles of Westfield, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jacqueline Ann Cowles, to Mark D. Resnick, the son of Paula Menard of Cranston, R.I. A June wedding is planned. Ms. Cowles, who is known as Jackie, and her fiance graduated from the University of Rhode Island.

LEAD: The overnight transformation of Rupert Murdoch's Australian newspaper holdings into a national chain with two-thirds of the country's circulation has raised concerns here about the concentration of so many newspapers in the control of one individual.

LEAD: YEARS from now - maybe next year, even - audiences who go in for marathons may get the chance to see the Neil Simon autobiographical trilogy ''Brighton Beach Memoirs,'' ''Biloxi Blues'' and ''Broadway Bound'' in one ''Nicholas Nickelby''-like day's journey into real enlightenment.

LEAD: Harlem Harmonies Volume I - Dorothy Dandridge, Erskine Hawkins, others. 35 minutes. Volume II - Count Basie, Duke Ellington, Nat King Cole, Billie Holiday, others. 34 minutes. Jazz Classics. Distributed by Audiofidelity Enterprises, Inc. $19.95.

LEAD: Scarcely a major city in the United States has not been touched, or even transformed, by preservation. From coast to coast, the impulse to save old buildings - from the gabled house on Main Street, to the Beaux-Arts railroad terminal - has helped to preserve the past, and provide an anchor for our collective memory.

LEAD: RUDOLF FIRKUSNY'S first concerto performance was given with the Czech Philharmonic, in 1922, and one of the first major works he inaugurated was the Second Piano Concerto of Bohuslav Martinu, in 1935. LEAD: ALTHOUGH the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was born on Jan. 15 - he would have been 58 years old last Thursday - the Federal holiday is tomorrow and celebrations have been planned throughout the country, including New Jersey.
LEAD: SEE YOU AT THE MOVIES The Autobiography of Melvyn Douglas. By Melvyn Douglas and Tom Arthur. Illustrated. 258 pp. Lanham, Md.: University Press of America. Cloth, $24.50. Paper, $9.75.

LEAD: The president of the Chicago Bears today denied reports that the Atlanta Falcons, who are still searching for a coach, had asked permission to talk to Mike Ditka, who has one year remaining on his contract with the Bears.

LEAD: An executive of Morton Thiokol Inc. has said in sworn testimony that the space agency's chief astronaut asked about booster rocket seals in late 1985, and he replied, ''It appears to be a problem.''

LEAD: To walk with a spring in one's stride is no longer a mere phrase. Scientists at Leeds in England have measured the springiness in the arch of the human foot. Running, in their analysis, is a matter not of sweat and endurance but of storing and expending energy between strides - ''like a rubber ball bouncing along.

LEAD: THEY stand like sentinels at the southwest corner of Third Avenue and 60th Street - a trio of sleek, smoothly curved black towers with only white back-lighted symbols of a telephone receiver hinting at their purpose.
LEAD: GOVERNOR KEAN delivered what he called an ''opportunity agenda'' to the Legislature last week, and one of the opportunities will be for heightened debate over his program in the coming months.

LEAD: The game seemed to turn during one forgettable stretch in the second period. In the aftermath, Coach Dave Wohl would blame himself for a series of ill-advised substitutions, but it was clearly just another example of what ails the Nets these days: When a lead dissolves, they are simply unable to grab it back.

LEAD: A tentative agreement to settle the steel industry's longest work stoppage was reached early today, and officials of the USX Corporation and the United Steelworkers of America said it would achieve the objectives of both sides.
LEAD: Sentiment counts for little when the Federal budget ax is swinging but power is still power. That's quite evident in two scholarly footnotes to President Reagan's plan for fiscal 1988.
LEAD: A boat carrying participants in a Roman Catholic festival sank near an island in the central Philippines on Friday, killing at least 50 people, the authorities said today.

LEAD: Confronted last summer with complaints that some Audi 5000's with automatic transmissions lurched forward or backward when shifted into gear, the manufacturer blamed drivers for stepping on the gas instead of the brake.

LEAD: The only survivor of the Galaxy Airlines crash that killed 70 people in Nevada on Jan. 21, 1985, has settled his lawsuit against the airline, his attorney says. George Lamson Jr., whose father died of injuries suffered in the crash, reached agreement on Wednesday with lawyers for the Florida-based airline for an undisclosed sum, said attorney, Charles Hvass Jr.

After that, veteran officials say, the politics of the 1988
LEAD: LAST year was a long, strenuous year. Like 3.5 million other Americans, I turned 40 -several times.

LEAD: Pace University is expanding - again. On the Pleasantville campus, construction of a $3 million science building is now complete, and work on the second of three planned town-house residence halls is well under way. Next month, the 80-year-old university will hold a ribbon-cutting ceremony to celebrate the opening of its latest project, the $12 million Evelyn and Joseph I.

LEAD: The jury will begin a fifth day of deliberations Sunday morning in the trial of two avowed revolutionaries charged with murdering a New Jersey state trooper on Interstate 80 in 1981.

LEAD: ON May 16, Dr. Carolyn Falk will place a top over the billiard table in her basement recreation room in Middlebury, converting it into an appropriate setting for the annual meeting of the Falk Foundation of Excellence. The foundation, which Dr. Falk started ''to encourage dreamers,'' she said, has given monetary awards to artists, schoolchildren and even a skier, and this year's applicants promise to be no less exciting, she said.
LEAD: IT is the confluence of the Rocky Mountain myths: here, in one glorious weekend, there is the convocation of cowboys, Indians and Broncos.
LEAD: THE key player in Super Bowl XXI may be John Elway, the Denver Broncos' exciting young quarterback.

LEAD: JUDGING by the grateful praise it elicited from consumer groups and local politicians, a Federal court ruling 10 days ago allowing more competition in New York City's milk markets verged on divine deliverance.

LEAD: The South Korean Government has announced that it will investigate the treatment of a college student who died when he was being questioned by the police last week. Relatives and others say the student may have been tortured, and the United States Government has expressed concern about the matter.

LEAD: A SECOND greenbelt trail across Long Island has been mapped and blazed for 22 miles from Massapequa to Cold Spring Harbor. It passes through parks and preserves and rights of way acquired for a railroad and road that were never built, offering an intimate look at not only the Island's nature but also its historic roots.

LEAD: IN 1982, when the state announced plans for a $100 million upgrading of Bradley International Airport in Windsor Locks, it was expected that the improvements would carry the airport through the late 1990's.

LEAD: THE bare facts are, I got in the car and just as I was passing my next-door neighbor's driveway, wham, slam! she backed up, bang into the side of my car. What a way to meet. I had not seen Kathie since she went off to college. Shaken up as I was, I could not help noticing what a pretty woman she had turned out to be.

LEAD: THERE are a great many enjoyable elements in the program Pooh Kaye and her Eccentric Motions company presented on Thursday at the Joyce Theater, as part of the Joyce Sampler series. Ms. Kaye, one of the wilder and wackier young leading experimentalists, has merged her antic humor and anarchically organic brand of movement into a distinctive style in the decade she has been choreographing.

LEAD: WEDNESDAY night's curious collection of clarinet pieces at Merkin Concert Hall had a common denominator - their personal associations with the featured performer, Gervase de Peyer. Mr. de Peyer arranged the sonatas by Handel and Schubert and has given the premieres of all the other items on this program except one.
LEAD: Yale converted 15 of 16 foul shots in the final two minutes to earn a 76-66 Ivy League victory over Columbia tonight.
LEAD: Good News Starring Peter Lawford, June Allyson. Screenplay by Betty Comden and Adolph Green. Directed by Charles Walters. 1947. MGM Home Video. 90 minutes. $29.95.

LEAD: Quick now, who was the last bona fide Presidential candidate - one with a chance to win - to have written a novel? Did any President do so, before or after the White House?

Raff, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Raff of Livingston and Rancho La Costa, Calif., took place last evening. Rabbis Barry H. Greene and Stanley Asekoff and Cantor Norman Summers officiated at Congregation B'nai Jeshurun in Short Hills, N.J.

LEAD: FORTUNATELY, all of the wolfsbane in the world will not keep ''Dracula'' from appearing and reappearing in theaters everywhere. At the moment, this denizen of the dark side, this precursor to Darth Vader and the forces of evil past and present, is ensconced at Theater Three in Port Jefferson.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: I am in the minority who believe that baseball players are not asking too much. First of all, for most of the game's history, ballplayers were virtual slaves of the owners. Secondly, ballplayers are entertainers just as actors are. Yet there is no outcry when stars receive millions of dollars for cameo roles in films, even though those fees help push up the cost of our ticket prices.

LEAD: When the BBC Symphony Orchestra made its first tour in 1936, it took along Schoenberg's Orchestral Variations, Op. 31, and played it in the composer's native city of Vienna. The work caused total mystification for an audience used to Mozart and Schubert, and when the conductor, Adrian Boult, was introduced to the Austrian President after the performance, the President asked, ''Who is this Schoenberg anyway?

LEAD: Hardly anyone here was surprised the other day when two puppies were found killed, one bludgeoned, one poisoned. It was widely believed that the motivation was a grudge against the town's biggest employer, Iowa Beef.
LEAD: MUTINY ON THE AMISTAD The Saga of a Slave Revolt and Its Impact on American Abolition, Law, and Diplomacy. By Howard Jones. Illustrated. 271 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $22.95.

LEAD: A man identified as a Black Muslim was arraigned here today in the fatal stabbing of an internationally known Islamic scholar and his wife, but the authorities said they did not know what motivated the slayings.

Schwengel of Santa Monica, Calif., and the late Lynn Kenworthy Schwengel. The Rev. Harry E. Chase performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Howard Nemerov, the author of some 30 books of poetry and fiction, has been chosen as the first winner of the Aiken Taylor Award for Modern American Poetry. The $10,000 prize, administered by the Sewanee Review and its publisher, the University of the South in Sewanee, Tenn., is awarded for the work of a substantial and distinguished career.

LEAD: Less than two weeks before its report is due, the White House panel examining the National Security Council's role in the Iran-contra affair has uncovered almost no new information. It faces the prospect of making recommendations about the council's future that may already be outdated.
LEAD: Do as I say, not as I do. That would seem to be President Reagan's maxim on Medicare for the elderly.

LEAD: Ivan Lendl conquered a court surface he didn't care for and Boris Becker defeated his best friend today as the two top-seeded men advanced to the fourth round of the $1.65 million Australian Open tennis championships.

LEAD: LUKAS FOSS, that indefatigable champion of contemporary and American music, brought his customary zeal and a widely diversified program to Cooper Union Friday night as part of the Brooklyn Philharmonic's ''Meet the Moderns'' chamber series.

LEAD: To the Editor: Shopping malls are of interest to sociologists for reasons other than esthetics and traffic patterns. ''Why Everyone Goes to the Mall'' (Dec. 21) refers to malls as the new town squares and as rigidly programmed selling machines, without ever pondering the implications of this conjunction.

LEAD: Just two months ago, it seemed that New York City would have to start sailing closer to the wind. Mayor Koch projected a $623 million deficit for the fiscal year beginning July 1 and warned that services might have to be cut.

LEAD: Beans for the Critic Just as some Americans try to go through Europe on $5 a day, a character in Bernard Malamud's ''Last Mohican'' rations his perceptions in Rome. This is one of many stories in ''The Art of the Tale'' (Elisabeth Sifton/Viking), edited by Daniel Halpern.

LEAD: New 2d-Home Tax Rules Question: I own vacation property on the Jersey Shore that has two homes, one I use for myself and the other a rental. For tax purposes, I proportioned the buildings on a 30-70 percent basis. On the rental, which is much larger, I take deductions for repairs, interest, taxes, insurance and depreciation.

LEAD: More than 100 protesters, including Dr. Benjamin Spock, the pediatrician, were arrested today when they scrambled over a fence at Cape Canaveral Air Force Station as thousands of demonstrators protested the test launching Thursday of a Trident 2 missile.

LEAD: SOUNDING disappointed but not surprised, educators met in Washington last week to confront the news that in mathematics American pupils score dismally, compared to those in other industrialized countries. The symposium was sponsored by the National Research Council's Mathematical Sciences Education Board, which had issued three comparative studies pointing to serious shortcomings in American elementary and secondary schools.

LEAD: It's not hard to figure why South Africa's white rulers are excluding foreign journalists, like reporters for The Times, and stifling what was once the freest press in Africa. President P. W. Botha wants fewer television pictures and better newspaper headlines. He wants his National Party to overwhelm all opponents in the election looming this spring.
LEAD: Thanks to Hal Riney for his Norman Rockwell approach to advertising. In a world as harsh and complex as ours is, his sentimental approach is refreshing! MANDY VICTOR Fairfield, Conn.

LEAD: Given the burgeoning throng of Presidential aspirants, it is increasingly difficult to find a novel way to make one's availability known - short, of course, of some gaucherie like, ''Well, for my part, I'd like to be President of the United States.''

LEAD: To the Editor: Shouldn't we fault the Federal Government for speaking with a forked tongue where tobacco consumption is concerned? On the one hand, the Surgeon General cautions against use of the weed; on the other, Washington continues its generous subsidies to tobacco growers. THOMAS G.
LEAD: Two Israeli men were stabbed today in the Old City market area, and the police said they suspected Arab guerrillas were responsible.

LEAD: THOSE who track the efforts of the United States Department of Education to stem the ''rising tide of mediocrity'' characterizing American education may know that, under the department's aegis, a new report (completed by the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching) has just been released.
LEAD: A NEW labor contract covering janitors and porters in 1,200 commercial buildings in New York City has triggered monthly rent increases for most tenants of nearly $3 a square foot.
LEAD: Regina Winters, 17 years old, grew up in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn, the daughter of a single woman on welfare. She now lives next door to a ''crack house.''

LEAD: President Reagan said today that the United States approached the current round of the arms talks with a ''sense of anticipation'' and asked Congress to support the Administration's military spending request.

LEAD: Outside the financial stocks, definitions of ''undervalued'' must be stretched for many names to surface. One money manager scanned his entire list for a cheap stock before coming back with a verbal shrug, ''None.'' The rare companies with low P/E multiples or large discounts from book value generally have problems that discourage analysts from recommending them.

LEAD: Terry Waite, the Anglican Church envoy, returned to Beirut last week seeking the release of more hostages. But his visit was the occasion for another kidnapping. Gunmen seized Roger Auque, a French free-lance reporter and photographer, not long after he finished photographing Mr. Waite on the seafront in Moslem West Beirut.
LEAD: Mexico's political left, traditionally divided, is trying to unite into a single party that could present a greater challenge to the governing party.

LEAD: IF the Philadelphia Phillies want a precedent, they need look back only three years. The Kansas City Royals finished the 1983 season in second place, 20 games behind the Chicago White Sox, then won the American League West championship the following season.

LEAD: Two cult writers of mystery fiction have published new books featuring series characters -and both live up to their reputation. Joseph Hansen's latest book is THE LITTLE DOG LAUGHED (Holt, $15.95), and Tony Hillerman's is SKINWALKERS (Harper & Row, $15.95). They are cult figures because they write well, have staked out an area of their own and have attracted a discriminating and faithful audience.

LEAD: The peasant and commercial farmers of Zimbabwe, both highly successful in recent years, have piled up a big stock of white maize, a milled corn much in demand internationally. LEAD: That fun couple of rodentdom - we're speaking here, of course, about Mickey and Minnie Mouse - are nothing if not enduring. Besides their notable career in films, the pair have appeared in countless children's books and on the face of watches that are often worn by grown-up children. Mr. Mouse also serves as guest host at huge amusement parks in California and Florida and for several years, about a generation ago, had his own club on television (he was the leader of the band that's made for you and me).

LEAD: QUESTION: Let's say the Yankees and Red Sox are playing in an inning with none out, a Boston player perched on each base and Wade Boggs at bat. On a 3-2 pitch, all three runners begin advancing, confident that Boggs will make contact and most likely hit the ball on the ground.
