LEAD: ELLEN FISHER, Isabelle Marteau and Diane Martel, the choreographers represented on the program that Dance Chance offered Thursday night at the Bessie Schonberg Theater, cleverly combined movement with scenic effects and contemporary music to achieve a true mixing of media. However, they were less persuasive in their presentation of ideas.

LEAD: Steve Krieckhaus will return to Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater, 219 West 19th Street, for performances at 8 P.M. on Feb. 9 and 10. The Philadelphia-based choreographer and performer is to present ''Missouri Driver's License,'' a popular solo seen in the workshop's ''Out-of-Towners'' series last summer.

LEAD: Weill Recital Hall, the newly refurbished chamber auditorium on the third floor of Carnegie Hall, has bright, blaring acoustics that are immediate to a near-painful degree. For this reason, one was grateful that the New York Trumpet Ensemble, which presented a concert entitled ''The Italian Influence'' at Weill Thursday night, was outside the hall when it played the two rousing fanfares by Monteverdi and Girolamo Fantini that began and ended the first half of the program.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The latest rise of the yen against the dollar has heightened concerns here about the effect that the shift in currencies is having on the domestic economy.

LEAD: Volunteers placing Christmas trees along the dunes at the Robert Moses State Park as part of a program to help prevent erosion of beach areas. The project was sponsored by Long Island Beach Buggy Association in cooperation with the Long Island State Park region. (NYT/Tony Jerome)
LEAD: What's in store for the gun lobby in the new Congress?
LEAD: Asian-American leaders say their young people are encountering increasing discrimination when they apply to the nation's most selective universities.

LEAD: The two directors of Guinness P.L.C. who were asked to resign Wednesday in the widening investigation of the big British brewing company are a Washington lawyer and a powerful Swiss businessman who is chairman of Bank Leu and former chief executive of Nestle S.A.

LEAD: The Afghan leader today denounced as a ''crime against the people'' an Islamic guerrilla rejection of his cease-fire bid, and he said Soviet troops would stay in Afghanistan until the civil war was over.

LEAD: IF the years have picked his dreams of glory bare, the ageing angler can gain some sustenance from the knowledge that with a lot of luck, savvy and dexterity he could achieve a small measure of immortality by creating a fishing fly that is so effective it will be treasured by his kind 100 years hence.
LEAD: KAREN MARCING, a Chicago purchasing agent, planned to spend a recent evening working on an oil painting, but she never had a chance to pursue her hobby because an old friend stopped by.

LEAD: Too little and six years late, the Reagan Administration has finally come to appreciate the importance of the International Development Association. An affiliate of the World Bank, this agency aids the poorest of the poor, nations whose per capita income is less than $790. The Administration stopped its growth in 1981.
LEAD: The Market Place column in Business Day on Friday, about a surge in technology stocks, misidentified two companies. The correct names are Pansophic Systems Inc. and the Maxtor Corporation.

LEAD: ''Jazz Is My Passport,'' presented by Highlights in Jazz, brought a multinational lineup of musicians to the Loeb Student Center at New York University on Thursday. Judging by the jam session-concert, American dominance of jazz is not in any danger.

LEAD: THE Collegiate Chorale and its young conductor, Robert Bass, performed Brahms's ''German'' Requiem at Carnegie Hall Saturday night the way it should always be performed - unadorned, without intermission or other works, a somber, unified hour of musical meditation.

LEAD: Five anti-apartheid groups said Friday that protests and shareholder actions would continue against most American companies that have ended their direct investment in South Africa. The groups said that the divestment plans announced by a number of large companies have done nothing to stop the flow of their products to South
LEAD: After the replacement of Hu Yaobang as Communist Party leader, China's intellectuals were warned today that the recent atmosphere of freer expression and discussion would be sharply curtailed.

LEAD: Far be it from me to put the kibosh on Pat Buchanan's possible run for the Presidency, but it's better that the secret come out now: conservative True Believers should know that he is a member of the Judson Welliver Society.
LEAD: IT might be that Michael Weiss, 25-year-old entrepreneur, has struck upon a winning idea for a campus publication: Make national campus ''celebrities'' out of certain students.
LEAD: Gentlemen's Wear-House, operator of a 29-unit retail chain, has assigned its $2 million account to Kornhauser & Calene. The previous agency was MJA Advertising Associates.
LEAD: For a time last week, the clock seemed turned back 15 years: Mario M. Cuomo, Queens lawyer, was once again mediating a racial dispute centered in his home borough but of interest nationwide.
LEAD: A sea of orange-and-blue-bedecked fans -63,277 of them - sent the Broncos off to the Super Bowl with a highly charged pep rally today.

LEAD: A week before a national election that it seems assured of winning, Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Government is growing deeply anxious about the implications of a rapidly sinking dollar and a rising mark for West Germany's export-based economy.

LEAD: It was a battle to avoid last place at Byrne Meadowlands Arena tonight, and the Devils fell to the bottom of the Patrick Division for the first time this season after their 6-1 loss to the Washington Capitals.

LEAD: Members of the University Club, bitterly divided over whether to admit women to New York City's largest male club, have voted on a resolution that would allow female members if a city antidiscrimination law is upheld in the courts.

LEAD: At Super Bowl XX last January in New Orleans, a rumor circulated that several foreign terrorists had been spotted in the area and intended to disrupt activities leading to the National Football League's championship game.

LEAD: Skiing A First for Gaspoz: Joel Gaspoz of Switzerland won his first World Cup slalom yesterday with a skillful performance on the steep Lauberhorn course in Wengen, Switzerland. The 24-year-old Swiss was timed for the two heats in 1 minute 36.86 seconds. Dietmar Koehlbichler of Austria finished second in 1:37.40, giving an unexpected lift to the Austrian team, which has been lackluster this season.
LEAD: The sharp decline in the dollar early last week sent a shiver through the bond markets, where securities dealers and the Treasury have come to rely on the purchases of foreign investors.

LEAD: Nassau and Suffolk commuters today put together car pools, made hotel reservations and imposed on friends and relatives with apartments in Manhattan as they mapped strategies for getting to work with the nation's busiest commuter railroad paralyzed by a strike.

LEAD: ''TIME marches on,'' the saying goes. But on Wednesday night at the Theater of the Riverside Church, the years danced by as Dance Through Time, a San Francisco company directed by Carol Teten, presented ''Dancing the 20th Century,'' an anthology of popular dances that have flourished in our century.

LEAD: The rush has already begun in Congress to pass major banking bills. Lobbyists say they cannot remember when the chairmen of the two banking committees, Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, and Representative Fernand J. St Germain, Democrat of Rhode Island, have worked so feverishly to pass early legislation.

LEAD: In the days of Empire, Bolton's smokestacks were towering red-brick symbols of the prosperity earned by spinning textiles for the world. There were about 200 textile mills and enough jobs and money for everyone. The spinning jenny was invented here; William Hesketh Lever cut his first bar of soap here.

LEAD: Civil rights leaders meeting here today said they would pursue ''the gamut of legal activity'' in a desegregation campaign aimed at all-white Forsyth County, where violence broke out Saturday at a march for brotherhood.

LEAD: Interest in Friday evening's ''Rigoletto'' at the Metropolitan Opera centered on two new principals in the cast - Gwendolyn Bradley singing the role of Gilda and Denes Gulyas as the Duke of Mantua.

LEAD: President Reagan will decide this month whether the United States should build a $6 billion atom smasher about 50 miles in circumference and he may express support for the project in his State of the Union Message, Administration officials said.
LEAD: A major housing study to be released this week by the Cuomo administration will advocate elimination of leases for rent-stabilized apartments, according to officials familiar with the document.

LEAD: An unusual double was achieved last Thursday at the Tri-State Regional Championships in Port Chester, N.Y. While Allan Stauber of Wappingers Falls, N.Y., was winning the Men's Swiss Teams event, his wife, Marcia Warner Stauber, was capturing the Women's Swiss Teams title.

LEAD: The image was clear, the intention evident. Saturday night, amid the quiet aftermath of one of the Knicks' more discouraging defeats under their new coach, Gerald Henderson didn't talk basketball, but bricklaying.

LEAD: ''Notification requirements were intended not only to insure the propriety of covert operations, but also to insure their effectiveness. In this particular case, notification could have prevented what proved to be a costly setback for U.S. foreign policy.'' - Staff report prepared for the Senate Intelligence Committee.

LEAD: The police, firefighters and immigration officials quelled what one official called ''a small disturbance'' yesterday involving Cuban inmates at the Federal Immigration and Naturalization Service detention center in lower Manhattan, where two prisoners had escaped a day earlier.
LEAD: At Road Runner speed, Senator Gordon J. Humphrey raced into the hearing of the Labor and Human Resources Committee and skidded into his seat.

LEAD: Everybody at the Hollywood Greyhound Park outside Miami is watching the clock nowadays, at least on the nights when P's Rambling runs. LEAD: WOMEN who choose to become surrogate mothers have motivations ranging from selflessness to egocentricity, from guilt to joy, according to the handful of researchers who have studied them.

LEAD: A senior Mozambican official answered the general question about his country's direction with a wry smile. ''What you in the West used to say about us was never quite right, and what you're saying now isn't quite right either,'' he said.

LEAD: John F. Malone, head of the regional F.B.I. office in New York from 1962 to 1975, died of a stroke last Thursday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Carbondale, Pa. He was 76 years old and had lived in Carbondale since his retirement in 1975.

The plant will be used to stamp and assemble such components as hoods, fenders, quarter panels and doors.

LEAD: THE New York City Ballet offered George Balanchine's ''Episodes'' for the first time this season Sunday night at the New York State Theater. ''Episodes'' is just what its name implies: a series of choreographic sketches to brief orchestral pieces by the 20th-century composer Anton von Webern. Yet, though none of the ballet's scenes last long, all are rich in implication.

LEAD: Twice as much airborne pollution is deposited above 3,000 feet in the Appalachian Mountains as in lowland areas, two Yale University geochemists have found. Dr. William C. Graustein, an associate research scientist, and Dr. Karl K. Turekian, chairman of geology and geophysics, also found that 40 percent to 60 percent of the pollutants came from the lowest layer of the atmosphere and were, therefore, more likely to be deposited within 50 miles to 100 miles of where they originated.

LEAD: During the wake for a taxi driver killed in late December in the western town of Amambai, word reached mourners that a murder suspect had been found. A few hours later, his bullet-riddled and mutilated body was dumped beside an outlying road. He was the victim of a lynch mob.

LEAD: Alan Bond spent nearly a decade and millions of his own dollars trying to win the America's Cup for Australia before finally succeeding in 1983. Now he has lost his chance to defend it.

LEAD: A senior Administration official today raised the possibility that the United States would try to arrest the monthlong decline of the dollar if it goes on much further.
LEAD: There was a ''golden age'' for United Nations tour guides, Thamar Tchenkeli says, a heady era when thousands waited patiently to be escorted by Thai princesses and maharajahs' daughters.

LEAD: THE galleries of the new Lila Acheson Wallace Wing of the Metropolitan Museum of Art are the best museum spaces in New York for the display of 20th-century art. This is not to say that they represent an architectural triumph: as a building, the Wallace wing is dull and not a little clunky. But what is banal on the outside is both inventive and serene within, and it manages the difficult trick of accommodating the needs of art without capitulating into complete neutrality.

LEAD: Two leading cable television home- marketing companies - the Home Shopping Network of Clearwater, Fla., and the COMB Company of Minneapolis - are considering a $650 million merger, the companies said late yesterday.

LEAD: Teachers went on strike today after a 20-hour bargaining session failed to produce a new contract. Despite the strike by 2,300 teachers, the district hoped to keep schools open for the 44,000 students with the help of 700 substitute teachers who would be paid $140 a day. Normal pay for substitutes is $52 to $89 a day.

LEAD: Mario Lemieux, the leading vote-getter in the National Hockey League All-Star balloting, will return to the Pittsburgh Penguins' lineup tonight after being sidelined for a month. Lemieux twisted his right knee in a Dec. 20 game against the Philadelphia Flyers. ''He'll be a big lift,'' said Eddie Johnston, the Penguins' general manager.
LEAD: Karl Mecklenburg's active mind is on Joe Morris this week, conjuring ways to bedevil the little speedster.

LEAD: TWO recent discoveries in the esoteric field of superconductivity - a phenomenon in which materials lose their resistance to electricity at very low temperatures - could eventually save the electrical industry billions of dollars and result in a variety of new electronic intruments and computer elements, according to scientists and power industry experts.

LEAD: A former New Haven police officer and a New York City firefighter were credited yesterday with a daring rescue in which they pulled an 8-year-old boy from a submerged van that was being dragged into the frigid currents of a Connecticut river.

LEAD: One day last fall, with liabilities of $2.1 million and assets of $1.7 million, Virginia and Doyle Lay filed for Chapter 11 protection in the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Dallas. The Lays, whose real estate operations near here had been sliding toward foreclosure, were not alone.

Zenith said $700,000 of job training aid from government agencies would help in the expansion.

LEAD: STEPHEN WHITTLESEY'S furniture is made from salvaged wood, which for this artist possesses a personality, smell or patina that new wood does not. His pieces are whimsical and expensive. ''Mummy's Cupboard,'' $3,200, second from left, is of lumber from the floor of an 18th-century whaling supply building in Woods Hole, Mass., that still had a briny odor.
LEAD: Representative John P. Hiler, Republican of Indiana, won a recount Tuesday in the nation's closest Congressional race by a margin of 47 votes, a state official said.
LEAD: The United States and Japan said tonight that their currencies had been buffeted by ''temporary instability'' and that the markets ''warrant monitoring.''

LEAD: Connecticut's Chief Justice proposed today the creation of nine new judgeships to help meet what she called ''the destabilizing effect'' of recent legislation that has increased the judiciary's workload.

LEAD: A former president of the teamsters' union, Roy Lee Williams, has been denied a request to be paroled from a Federal prison hospital in Missouri, where he is serving a 10-year term for conspiring to bribe a United States Senator, the Justice Department said today. The Parole Commission made the decision Tuesday.
LEAD: President Reagan will submit to questioning Monday by his special commission that is examining the National Security Council in light of the Iran-contra affair, the White House announced today.

LEAD: Rafael Villa Vicencio was approached some time ago, he said, and offered ''a blank check'' to move out of his room at the St. Clair Hotel at 69 West 38th Street. ''They told me to pick the amount,'' he said yesterday. ''I didn't accept it. I asked them to fix the room I had.''
LEAD: Two California brothers were indicted today on charges of trading with the enemy in connection with the sale of 87 helicopters to North Korea.

LEAD: YOU can almost smell the fetid air in a dormitory of the Long Kesh Internment Camp, the setting of Gregory Teer's play ''The Tunnel.'' In the drab space crowded with footlockers and bunk beds, half a dozen imprisoned Irish Republicans play Monopoly, swill homemade booze, bicker about politics and plot an underground escape.

LEAD: The Unisys Corporation lost $188.5 million in the fourth quarter because of a huge one-time charge to cover the costs of its creation through the merger of the Burroughs Corporation and the Sperry Corporation, the computer maker said today.

LEAD: The American Civil Liberties Union is in the midst of a petition campaign urging President Reagan to remove Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d from office. It reports an enthusiastic response to its mailings but concedes the campaign is unlikely to actually bring about Mr. Meese's ouster.

LEAD: Ben Hinson, a high-scoring forward for the basketball team at Baptist College in Charleston, S.C., is considered the best player in the Division I Big South Conference. It wasn't until he was a teen-ager, though, that he could beat his sister in a game of one-on-one.
LEAD: Mayor Koch may have refused to give the Giants a ticker-tape parade at city expense, but he does have an offering for them - champagne.
LEAD: There were signs today that the West German Government was hesitating to extradite an accused Lebanese terrorist being sought by the United States.

LEAD: ''It's hard to look at any aspect of contemporary life and not see some kind of revival of interest in the shapes, substance, look and feel of products from the past,'' says Alan Wellikoff, a freelance writer living in Springfield, Mass.

LEAD: A judge in United States Appellate Court has ruled against Leon Wood, the Nets' guard, in a case that tested the legality of the National Basketball Association's college draft and its salary cap provisions. Judge Ralph Winter, on behalf of a unanimous three-judge panel, held that the draft and salary cap were governed by labor law rather than antitrust law, and since they were subject to collective bargaining with the union, the draft and the cap were not subject to challenge by an individual player.

LEAD: A chart yesterday on the New York State tax reduction to take effect this year incorrectly described state income tax rates. Currently, 9.5 percent is the maximum rate on earned income; 13.5 percent is the maximum rate on unearned income. The maximum rates are to be reduced to 9 percent and 13 percent, respectively.

LEAD: In moves protesting the racial attack in Howard Beach, Queens, last month, 3,000 marchers chanted noisily through Manhattan and small groups gathered to discuss racial violence. But black shoppers, for the most part, ignored calls for a boycott of white-owned businesses.

LEAD: N.B.A. Jazz 112, Pistons 108: Karl Malone had 23 points and John Stockton sank two free throws with nine seconds left as Utah held back a late Detroit surge. Detroit trailed, 109-99, with 2:50 left, but Isiah Thomas and Joe Dumars sparked a 9-1 Piston rally that closed the gap to 110-108 with 11 seconds left.

LEAD: For the Soviet Union to invite a defector to return as an honored guest once was unthinkable. A 1985 film, ''White Nights,'' was based on the opposite premise - that any defector unlucky enough to crash land in Soviet territory would be abducted by the K.G.B. The star of that film was Mikhail Baryshnikov, the dancer who in real life defected in 1974.

LEAD: The largest faction of the Nicaraguan rebels unveiled a strategy today for the coming year aimed at putting the Sandinista forces on the defensive with widespread hit-and-run raids in central Nicaragua.
LEAD: The chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation warned today of a ''sizable'' increase in the number of bank failures in 1987 over last year's record levels.

LEAD: An article on Monday about the financial troubles of American orchestras misstated tour plans for the San Francisco Symphony. It will tour Europe for three weeks starting next month. Because corporate support fell short, the orchestra has canceled performance plans for the Soviet Union.

LEAD: After six years and two summit meetings, the Reagan Administration's arms control policy remains in near-total disarray. The State and Defense Departments remain consistently at war. The weak National Security Council staff still fails to enforce order. And now even the most elemental coordination between decisions on strategic weapons and negotiating positions approaches breakdown.

LEAD: Chase Church, a son of Senator Frank Church of Idaho, now dead, has pleaded guilty to growing hallucinogenic ''magic mushrooms.'' Mr. Church, 29 years old, of Bethesda, Md., was arrested at his family's home in June. The police said the mushrooms contained the illegal substance psilocybin. Mr. Church pleaded guilty Tuesday in Chester County to one count of manufacturing a controlled substance.

LEAD: Les Skah Shah, Sounds of Brazil, 204 Varick Street (243-4940). Haitian rock lilts unlike anything else in the Caribbean, cruising along at medium tempos with a rhythm that, sooner or later, insinuates itself into every listener's hips. The Haitian compas direct beat is related to the Dominican Republic's merengue (from the other half of the island), but where the merengue has grown more and more uproarious, the compas direct has grown suaver.

LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said it planned to spend about $2.5 billion in 1987 to expand its digital long-distance telephone network. Industry analysts said the announced expansion was a direct response to the aggressive marketing tactics of US Sprint. A.T.&T. has 11,000 miles of fiber optic lines in service and plans to build another 24,000 miles by 1989, when the company would offer digital service to 350 cities.

The merger of zoning lots makes it possible to continue residential development in locations with high land values without demolishing all the buildings on the site, which would dispossess all tenants.

LEAD: Charter 77 - the Czechoslovak human rights movement - is 10 years old this month. It has endured longer than any other human rights movement in Eastern Europe. This fact seems all the more remarkable, given the nature of the Czechoslovak regime. Any hope for change in Czechoslovakia resides with the charter movement rather than in outside influences coming from either the East or the West.

LEAD: IT is more than a decade now since Susan Rothenberg's horses began appearing in galleries and museums. They were peculiar creatures. They looked like horses, but they were invariably flat, featureless and tailless, and they stood and rocked in dense, nondescript spaces. There was nothing romantic about them, but they were not anti-romantic either, and here and there they nodded in the direction of their illustrious ancestors.

The company said it did not plan to discount its steel products to recapture the market share it lost during a six-month labor shutdown.

LEAD: IN A 1983 survey of its 8,200 members, the American Hotel and Motel Association found that, while more than 70 percent of respondents had smoke, fire or heat detectors in guest rooms, less than 10 percent had installed automatic sprinklers. The absence of sprinklers in guest rooms, fire protection experts said, is a glaring deficiency in hotel safety measures and could result in future fires and needless deaths.

LEAD: Steinway and Sons, 109 West 57th Street, is currently exhibiting a display of memorabilia pertaining to the life and work of the American pianist William Kapell, who lived from 1922 to 1953. Many of the same items are shown that were displayed at the International Piano Library in College Park, Md., last summer, including a wide variety of photographs (both personal and professional), letters from Virgil Thomson and Aaron Copland, press notices, recording documentation, diaries and other effects.

LEAD: AFTER suffering through a fourth straight disappointing season at Stanford last year, Tom Davis, the Cardinal's head coach, decided, somewhat regretfully, that he had had enough.

LEAD: THE hoopla that has come to characterize Super Bowl week has never been in keeping with Andy Robustelli's style. And so today, when the New York Giants make their first appearance in the Super Bowl, Mr. Robustelli, one of the greatest players in Giants history, will watch the game as most Americans will - on television.

LEAD: THE scene following the New Year's eve fire that killed 96 people at the Dupont Plaza Hotel in San Juan, Puerto Rico, was a familiar one: officials parading before the television cameras, calling for tougher fire prevention laws. Similar appeals were heard after fatal fires in 1980 at the MGM Grand Hotel in Las Vegas, Nev., and at a Stouffer's Inn in Harrison, N.Y.

LEAD: SOCIAL Security has not been in the news much lately, and with good reason. In 1983, Congress ended the financial crises that had plagued the Social Security System since the 1970's. It did so principally by modifying benefits in several ways and by moving to 1988 some of the previously scheduled 1990 contribution rate increase.

LEAD: Exactly half a millennium ago a man named John Morton became Archbishop of Canterbury. Within a few years he was Lord Chancellor of England and a Cardinal. For the supporters of Richard III, he is the villain who originated the Tudor and Shakespearean portraits of their hero. As Lord Chancellor he was the inventor of Morton's Fork: A system in lieu of taxes in which a free-spending merchant has proved by his spending that he can afford a ''gift'' to the king.
LEAD: West Germans are to vote Sunday in a parliamentary election that Chancellor Helmut Kohl's center-right coalition is strongly favored to win.

LEAD: THINGS are not tiptop in the Atlas household as ''The Square Root of Three'' begins. Elliot is a car salesman who hasn't sold a car since Japanese imports took over. Pretty soon a collection agency is going to take over his furniture. His wife, who believes he is carrying on the business mainly to carry on with his 19-year-old secretary, is getting ready to leave him.

LEAD: Only days after Ecuador got its President back from renegade air force commandos, the National Congress tried last week to get rid of him. The majority of the legislators voted to ask Leon Febres Cordero to resign, arguing that his kidnapping would not have occurred if he had not blocked their amnesty of a rebellious general.

LEAD: Albert Goode, the grandson of a North Carolina slave who was the father of Philadelphia's first black Mayor, W. Wilson Goode, died Thursday of complications from Parkinson's disease. He was 83 years old.

LEAD: STATE alcoholism officials and others who have referred troubled alcoholics and their families to the Gabrielsen Group, a private team of state-certified counselors here, say that the group's clients get better sooner and seem to maintain their sobriety.

LEAD: Mikhail Baryshnikov was invited last week to dance as a guest at Moscow's Bolshoi Theater. The ballet star, who defected from the Soviet Union in 1974, said he would have to think about the invitation, which was extended by Yuri Grigorovich of the Bolshoi Ballet. (NYT/Richard N. Greenhouse)

LEAD: Anyone wondering what happens when music video meets number theory will get a first glimmering of an answer tomorrow in the opening minutes of ''Square One,'' public television's most ambitious attempt at educating younger viewers since ''Sesame Street'' began 18 years ago.

LEAD: On the surface, Richard Harris's ''Stepping Out'' and Israel Horovitz's ''North Shore Fish'' are totally dissimilar. The former, an English play with music, deals with Londoners from disparate backgrounds who are taking an evening class in tapdancing. The latter, a drama set in Gloucester, Mass., is concerned with a group of workers who are employed in a frozen-fish processing plant.

LEAD: The economy grew at a dull 1.7 percent rate in the fourth quarter, and just 2.5 percent for all of 1986, which had been heralded by many as a 4 or 5 percent growth year. The fourth-quarter gain was below what most Government and private economists had expected. Much of the blame goes to the trade deficit, which has remained stubbornly high despite the falling dollar, and lackluster performances in energy and business investment.

LEAD: ONE HUNDRED employees of the state's Department of Education, including Dr. Saul Cooperman, the Commissioner of Education, are enrolled in a volunteer training project here to become tutors for illiterate Trenton adults.

LEAD: The sports-car racing season opens next weekend with the running of the most challenging event on the schedule, the SunBank 24 at Daytona Beach, Fla. Outright speed doesn't win at Daytona. For cars that were designed for races that are no longer than six hours, Daytona and the 12-hour race in March at the Sebring,
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Village of Southold, midway up the North Fork at the eastern end of Long Island, is about to acquire an empty parcel of land in the middle of the town that will forever be preserved as the village green, or public park.
LEAD: Don Maynard, Len Dawson, Larry Csonka, Joe Greene, Jim Langer and Gene Upshaw were chosen today by the Pro Football Hall of Fame selection committee as the six finalists for 1987 induction.
LEAD: Answer: The Giants. Why: Lawrence Taylor. JEFF DORSEY Baltimore

LEAD: The office building at 625 Madison Avenue, which occupies the entire blockfront between 58th and 59th Streets on the east side of the avenue, is going to get a facelift, and the surgeon will be one of the city's better-known architects, Der Scutt.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Meredith Fisher of Boulder, Colo., have announced the engagement of their daughter Claudette Marie Fisher to Ridgely Couper Johnson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Dudley Johnson of New York and Edgartown, Mass. The wedding is planned for March 21.

LEAD: Despite the size of this sprawling city, its location and profusion of intellectual and technical expertise, Shanghai has stumbled almost blindly through the last three decades shackled by radical politics, neglect from the national Government and bureaucratic obstinacy.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Brian A. O'Hanrahan of Dublin have announced the engagement of their daughter Ellenore O'Hanrahan to Robert Kellner Benjamin, the son of Mrs. Edward N. Benjamin of New York and the late Mr. Benjamin. A May wedding is planned.
LEAD: ''It might not be the right way to play the game, but it might be the only way.'' - Albert M. Wojnilower, First Boston economist, on Treasury Secretary Baker's strategy on the dollar.
LEAD: A Villanova sophomore, Gary Massey, came off the bench to score a career-high 21 points tonight and lead the Wildcats to an 86-82 Big East Conference triumph over Seton Hall.

LEAD: On a darkening afternoon seven or eight years ago, I sat with my small daughter in Giants Stadium watching Roger Staubach drive the Cowboys 60 or 70 yards for a winning field goal in the last few seconds. As Rafael Septien's kick went through the uprights, my daughter burst into tears. The next day, she saw a photo in The Times of Harry Carson sitting in dejection on the Giants' bench and told me she wanted to write to him.

LEAD: The state will close two developmental centers for the mentally and physicially handicapped in New York City in the next few years as part of its effort to move the disabled out of large institutions.

LEAD: Last Nov. 23 the Giants defeated Denver, 19-16, at Giants Stadium, with a 4 to 2 edge in turnovers and without the Giants' offense scoring a touchdown.
LEAD: ARTHROSCOPIC knee surgery has become commonplace among athletes in recent years, and Tony Dorsett had it done twice on Friday. The Cowboys running back had surgery on both knees.

LEAD: A RAT'S TALE By Tor Seidler. Illustrated by Fred Marcellino. 186 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $12.95.

LEAD: It is hard not to be skeptical about the ''new approach to medical education'' described in Amy Wallace's article ''Teaching the Humane Touch'' (Dec. 21). In fact, the title itself is trendy enough to make one want to run to the nearest technocratic physician he can find.

LEAD: THE Rose Bowl sits in a dry river bed called the Arroyo Seco, its west bank at the foot of the Linda Vista Hills. In the distance, the San Gabriel Mountains offer a picture-postcard view, especially on these sometimes chilly winter southern California mornings when a brisk wind clears the clouds and thick, yellow smog.

LEAD: I am a firm believer in the saying that good things happen for those who wait. Well, I've waited for 23 years. I know it's time. The only question that should be asked is how many points will those Giants win by? JOHN FERREIRA Elmhurst

LEAD: Looking Down, Up, Out Like a statue in a public park, the Jew in literature is exposed to the climate. In his latest novel, Philip Roth is a weatherman reading the signs, scanning the heavens. This is from ''The Counterlife'' (Farrar, Straus & Giroux).
LEAD: Congressional Republicans and Democrats made leadership choices of enormous importance last week, one good and one troubling.

LEAD: Two bombs exploded a minute apart today near the homes of local politicians in Bolzano, the capital of Alto Adige, an Alpine region racked by tensions between ethnic Germans and Italians. The explosions blew out windows but caused no injuries. No immediate claim of responsibility was reported. The explosions occurred near the homes of a provincial assessor, Remo Ferretti, a Christian Democrat, and of Andrea and Piero Mitolo, who are local leaders of the Italian Social Movement, a neo-Fascist party.
LEAD: The Giants will win the Super Bowl because how else can Bill Parcells get his sweet revenge by dumping a bucket of Gatorade on Harry Carson's head? KATHERINE NEWELL SMITH New York

LEAD: THE KREMLIN AND THE WEST: A Realistic Approach. By Wolfgang Leonhard. (Norton, 7.95.) Wolfgang Leonhard would seem well qualified to deliver what he promises here - a ''new policy toward [ the ] USSR.'' Arriving in Moscow in l935 as a l4-year-old German, Mr. Leonhard spent the war years in the Soviet Union and at war's end was whisked off to Berlin as one of the original members of the ''Ulbricht group,'' charged with setting up a Communist state in what became East Germany.

The reader must guess at the identity of the speaker by solving sphinx-like riddles: ''I am and I was in many eyes.

LEAD: CRAFT criticism, as a pursuit apart from art criticism, is coming into its own as a subject for discussion. Although scattered in place and time, more panel discussions and seminars are being devoted to the subject.

LEAD: The engagement of Marion Sue Waskover and Dr. David Alan Frank has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Robert Waskover of New York and Miami, the parents of the future bride. Dr. Frank is a son of Mrs. Hilton Kimless of Hartsdale, N.Y., and Newton Frank of New York.

LEAD: The sculpture court of the Metropolitan Museum's new Lila Acheson Wallace Winge for 20th-century art. The $26-million, 40,000-square-foot addition (inset) opens to the public Feb. 3. Members got their first look at it last week (NYT/Angel Franco)

LEAD: Nishikikoji (familiarly referred to as just Nishiki), a narrow arcaded street in the heart of central Kyoto, is the market basket of Kyoto's food lovers. Extending several blocks west of the Teramachi arcade, both sides of the street are bursting with the best Kyoto has to offer. Fishmongers and butchers, greengrocers and noodle makers, the shops are stocked with the freshest of the season, and many offer regional specialties rarely seen in other parts of Japan.

LEAD: A THREE-YEAR nightmare for White Plains railroad commuters - climbing temporary wooden stairs to stand on narrow, windswept platforms - should end tomorrow morning with the opening of the city's new $2.57 million train station.
LEAD: SOME homeowners sent photographs of pristine landscapes.

LEAD: William G. Bowen, who led Princeton University into co-education and guided it through 15 years of academic expansion, announced today that he was stepping down as its president.

LEAD: In a Presidential campaign's early going, much of the news involves those hardy quadrennials of Des Moines, Manchester, Concord. The earliest voting is in Iowa and New Hampshire, and the Presidential hopefuls slog into their snows at least a year ahead of time.

LEAD: THESE days fake-fur fanciers have little to growl about. That's because of the preponderance of big-cat facsimiles, which are uncannily like the real thing. The coats are made of lightweight but warm synthetics printed with mirror images of the cats' markings. Among the most eye-catching are the Somali leopard fakes (top right), with small, ringlike spots, and the ocelot (bottom, second from right), with a distinctive dot-and-broken-line pattern.

LEAD: If a new Democratic Congress were to make a difference in only one thing, it probably ought to be in President Reagan's plan for a ''Star Wars'' strategic defense. Now the Pentagon is talking of deploying elements of such a defense in the early 1990's - a dubious notion that Congress should dispel promptly and firmly.

LEAD: David Bradley amusingly underrates the ingenuity of bigots to fashion racist motivations in suggesting that Richard Wright's portrait of Bigger Thomas in ''Native Son'' was a needed peg for the stereotyping of black males as muggers (''On Rereading 'Native Son,' '' Dec. 7).

LEAD: MORE THAN any other item of makeup, red lipstick is capturing the imagination - and the dollars - of American women. For most of these women, coming to red after seasons of wearing more subtle lipstick is logical. Women today are putting extra effort into dressing up for evening, and sophisticated makeup seems to be a natural accompaniment.

LEAD: THE first hospital in the state to lose a budgetary dispute with its regulatory agency is returning $1.1 million in fees charged its patients, but in many cases it costs more to process the check than the check is worth.

LEAD: Kneeling at the bedside of AIDS patients at St. Clare's Hospital in Manhattan, Britain's Minister of Social Services, Norman Fowler, yesterday talked to the gaunt victims about their illness and the medical care they were receiving.
LEAD: EACH week in New Jersey, there are 1,500 meetings of Alcoholics Anonymous, a self-help fellowship established by alcoholics in 1935. It offers a 12-step program of treatment.

LEAD: At the Park Avenue Synagogue in New York last night Cindy Jo Chernuchin, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Paul Chernuchin of New York and Palm Beach, Fla., was married to Daniel Jonathan Barsky, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jay Barsky of Bala Cynwyd, Pa. Rabbi Judah Nadich performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Peter Schaufuss, the Danish ballet star who now directs London Festival Ballet, suffered a severe back injury in 1976 while he was a member of the New York City Ballet. He was treated in London by his osteopath, Demetri Papoutsis, who claims that since then he has stretched Mr. Schaufuss's height by an inch and a quarter.
LEAD: THE playground at the Timothy Dwight School in Fairfield was filled one recent morning with children running around a large yellow metal object that looked at if it had just landed from space.

LEAD: WE had hoped for a white Christmas and got drizzle instead. It forced the young cast of ''The Living Creche'' to abandon its rustic lean-to on the church lawn and pose instead, rather self-consciously, before the altar inside. It was a lovely Christmas Eve, nonetheless.

LEAD: Alpine Spring Question: I will be in France late in March and would like to know if the ski season typically extends into the first week of spring. Are there weeks in which resorts are likely to be overcrowded? - B. F., San Antonio Answer: Assuming average snowfall - and there has been a lot of snow already - the ski season in the French Alps will be in full swing at the end of March.

LEAD: One of the gags in Richard Pryor's new comedy, ''Critical Condition,'' is about a plan to build a 32-screen, so-called multiplex theater with 18 seats per screen. Yet, even as audiences are laughing at this idea, a $10 million, 18-screen multiplex is under construction at Univeral City in California.

LEAD: This small town in Forsyth County was overwhelmed today by civil rights marchers, members of the Ku Klux Klan and their sympathizers and an army of National Guardsmen and law-enforcement officers who kept the opposing groups separated.

LEAD: Administration officials said today that the abduction of four teachers in Beirut, three of them Americans, appeared to be linked to the capture by West Germany of a Lebanese hijacking suspect wanted in the United States.

LEAD: In visiting the world's cities, one becomes fairly attuned to the voice of a place, whether the sounds are heard in Leningrad or Fez, Kyoto or Rio. It didn't take long to hear that Prague was like an opera singer at rehearsal, singing merely at half-voice. And an alto at that.

LEAD: RESEARCH on smoke detectors, as with most fire safety research, has focused on the issue of speeding up the warning time, giving guests a chance to get out and firefighters a chance to get in before dense smoke and toxic gases make approaching the fire hazardous or even impossible.

LEAD: Dr. Ben Bumsun Lee and Dr. Hyang Won Lee of Manhasset, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Carol Miyoung Lee, to Dr. Brian Richard Apatoff, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Apatoff of Chicago and Venice, Fla. A May wedding is planned.

LEAD: NO matter how well he does in the Super Bowl today, Lawrence Taylor has strengthened his credentials as the top player of the 1986 National Football League. Besides many other honors, he has won the 1986-87 Gillette Most Valuable Player Award.

LEAD: AFTER slashing away the sand that covered a steel seawall in front of Robert and Gail Saum's 38-year-old home in Beverly Shores, Ind., Lake Michigan storms are now working on the house. In anticipation of losing it to the lake, the Saums are packed and ready.

LEAD: WHEN THE PARIS designers get onto something, they are certainly capable of putting it across. Buttressed by that city's formidable battery of talented background performers - seamstresses, tailors, embroiderers, fabric and accessory suppliers and the like - designers are free to let their individual imaginative talents fly.

LEAD: THE displacement of residents by the reclamation of inner-city property continues to give gentrification a bad name around the country. It has posed a policy quandary for social-welfare officials who must help the dislocated find new homes, and it has become an embarrassment for the developers and preservationists who make up the vanguard of the back-to-the-old-neighborhoods movement.

LEAD: ''I'm of many minds about competitions,'' says Ellen Highstein, executive director of Concert Artists Guild, a 36-year-old organization that has been running one such contest for the last 33 years. ''Their negative side is that, no matter how often you try to make it clear that one can't equate musical competitions with the Olympics, there are people who feel that if someone can run the fastest, then someone can play the Chopin Second Concerto the best.

LEAD: Is it permissible for one who is not a licensed seer to offer a few speculations about the future of opera in America? For some years it has seemed to me that in New York we have a laboratory in which certain volatile developments in the art form may be observed at close range. Under the microscope we see, side by side, a Metropolitan Opera committed to an international star system that no longer works with any consistency and a New York City Opera that, on a shoestring, has gone a long way toward building a repertory company of mostly American artists.

LEAD: The lack of senior staff and operating managers with an international perspective is the major weakness of most companies doing business on the world market, contends Thomas Gross of Communications International, a management-consulting firm in White Plains that specializes in facilitating successful international business partnerships.
LEAD: Let no one believe that Congress, for all its wisdom and cool impartiality, has escaped the pervasive hoopla surrounding the Super Bowl.

LEAD: As President Reagan heads into the final two years of his term, he will try to re-invigorate his lagging Administration on Tuesday with a State of the Union Message that attempts to shift public attention away from the Iran arms scandal by announcing new initiatives in jobs, education and economic growth.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. James K. Strong of Redondo Beach, Calif., of the engagement of their daughter, Judith Eleanor Strong, to Gregory Arnold Jorgensen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard A. Jorgensen of Salt Lake City. The wedding is planned for April 25.

LEAD: IN the second chapter of Joyce's ''Ulysses'' Stephen Dedalus is admonished by his employer, Mr. Deasy, ''We are a generous people, but we must also be just.'' ''I fear those big words,'' Stephen answers, ''which make us so unhappy.'' He does not specify the big ones: presumably they include ''generous,'' ''people,'' ''just'' and ''must,'' words that lodge an ethical or a nationalist claim.

LEAD: OLD-FASHIONED stews make perfect meals for cold winter evenings. Hearty and comforting, they are also immensely practical, because they can be made in one pot and cooked a day or two in advance - and they improve in flavor when left overnight.

And as the group's musical interests have shifted from swing and rhythm-and-blues nostalgia to be-bop, her singing style has toughened and sharpened.

LEAD: BEFORE THE unthinkable happened on that bitterly cold January day in Florida, they were the elite's elite, operating in that strange, unforgiving stratosphere where only several hundred humans have ever been. They were trained to set aside their feelings, groomed to spout clipped, noncommittal responses in public.

LEAD: Every so often a disaster serves to remind travelers that they cannot take their safety for granted. Such was the case with the New Year's Eve fire at the Dupont Plaza Hotel in San Juan, P.R., as a result of which 96 people died. It reminded travelers everywhere of their vulnerability and of the need for precautions.

LEAD: An art museum may sound like a strange place to begin a musical tour, but for the visitor to Prague who is interested in Czech music, the Gallery of 19th-Century Czech Art is a striking introduction. The museum, part of the National Gallery, is imaginatively housed in the former Convent of the Blessed Agnes, a vast and magnificent 13th-century complex, the largest and oldest Gothic monument in the city, still being restored, rescued after centuries of neglect.

LEAD: WESTCHESTER'S representatives in the State Legislature say that major priorities for the county this year would be creating affordable housing, providing permanent shelter for the homeless, acquiring funds for education and adequate solid-waste disposal, and cutting state taxes.

LEAD: WHEN the skipper announced he was coming to the boatyard in Mamaroneck to inspect his nearly completed 12-meter yacht, the boat builder had to act quickly. By the time Tom Blackaller, captain of the America's Cup contender, USA, arrived at the Robert E. Derecktor Yacht Building yard, the second boat was shrouded in curtains.

LEAD: Until this past fall, when the Music Center Opera mounted its first real season, Los Angeles had no top-line resident opera company. Perhaps this lack explains the enthusiasm that greeted the Long Beach Opera, an apparently spunky smaller outfit given to innovative productions.

LEAD: Yoshiko Chuma calls her company the School of Hard Knocks advisedly. It is often hard to believe that any of the dancers will survive an evening of her dance, so fast-paced and physically demanding is it. But exhilaration is in store for Ms. Chuma's audiences, for this is dance of an infectious physicality.

LEAD: To the Editor: Scott Edward Stapf's reference to a nonsmoker's nicotine-equivalent exposure and to other red herrings is an exercise that contributes nothing to the social debate on passive smoking (''A Propaganda War Against Cigarettes,'' Forum, Jan. 4).

LEAD: 'I have been underestimated for decades. I've done very well that way.' - Helmut Kohl West German Chancellor, discussing today's national election, which the coalition he leads is favored to win.

LEAD: THE NEWSPAPER BILLBOARD I sighted on my last drive to Johannesburg's Jan Smuts Airport bore the message ''Evicted U.S. Newsman Regarded as Hostile.'' I was, in fact, being expelled by a Government that no longer wished me to chronicle its country's internal struggle. But hostile? Had I been hostile to South Africa in my three years as chief of The Times's bureau in Johannesburg, then surely that last ride along the freeway would have been laden with relief.
LEAD: Coach Bill Parcells of the Giants called off today's scheduled team walk around the Rose Bowl, so the players who wanted to stretch their legs did so on their own.
LEAD: Philip C. Habib, President Reagan's special envoy, has begun a tour of six Western European capitals by meeting with Prime Minister Jacques Chirac.

LEAD: As we commemorate in 1987 the 200th anniversary of the Constitution, we will inevitably be pulled toward two seductive but ultimately inappropriate impulses. We will be tempted, first, to trivialize the event - to turn it into a glitzy collage of fireworks, essay contests and 30 second television moments.
LEAD: THE television series ''Miami Vice'' might appropriately symbolize the conflicting views of Americans and Colombians about narcotics traffic.
LEAD: MUSIC dating from the Middle Ages to music composed just last year will be heard in the state in the next two weeks.

LEAD: NOT long before the most significant game of his eight seasons with the Giants, during a week when quarterbacks of Super Bowl teams have been known to produce enough news to fill a forest worth of newsprint, Phil Simms inadvertently capsulized the rise of himself and his team without a word.

LEAD: THE wood ducks and mallards that live here year-round come out to feed more often now on the food left for them. The Canada geese have settled in for the winter. And not too long ago an unannounced guest, a peregrine falcon, swooped through for a visit.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. John B. Wingate of Mount Kisco, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jennifer Reese Wingate, to John Edward Schott, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Schott of New Canaan, Conn.
LEAD: ''SOMEBODY tell me one good thing that happened today,'' one man said to 15 others sitting in a circle.

LEAD: THE SKINS OF TWO RATTLESNAKES, TROPHIES OF A sort, were nailed to boards in my great-uncle's library. They were stiff, like old parchment documents, and flattened, as if run over, and crinkled, like discarded tinfoil.

LEAD: THE state has 5.2 million licensed drivers who must deal with the Division of Motor Vehicles at least twice a year, and recently the experience has been anything but pleasant.

LEAD: Ray Dolby, the British inventor who now maintains his laboratory in San Francisco, has been known mainly for his patented method of reducing tape hiss. These noise-reduction circuits were the spur for the transformation of the audio cassette - originally intended merely as a dictating device - into a medium suitable for music.

LEAD: BASSDRUMBONE - the trio of Mark Helias on bass, Gerry Hemingway on drums and Ray Anderson on trombone - romps through its music, artfully pulling compositions in three directions at once. Like the trio Air and a very few other jazz ensembles, BassDrumBone's collective improvisations can be bluesy or ethereal, pensive or raucous in the space of a few seconds.

LEAD: Acapulco, it seems, grows larger every year, and the city is paying a price for its growth. But the qualities that give the city its charm and attract so many visitors are still the same.

LEAD: Landlord-Access Rules Question: Does someone have the right to buy the apartment I rent in a co-op building even though I'm living there? Secondly, does the new owner have the right to enter my apartment whenever he wishes? This would seem an invasion of my privacy and would give the landlord access to my possessions.

LEAD: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d is expected to tell President Reagan Monday that the two-year fall of the dollar that accelerated late last month has been good for the economy, an Administration aide said today.

LEAD: WITH carnage reminiscent of the trench warfare during World War I, the battle for the Iranian port city of Basra, at the head of the Persian Gulf, is about to go into its second month. Both Iraq and Iran made what seemed to be exaggerated reports of enemy casualties last week, with Baghdad citing 100,000 Iranian casualties and Teheran saying 30,000 Iraqis had been killed or wounded.
LEAD: THE number of elderly people in Connecticut is growing at a faster rate than the rest of the nation.

LEAD: Health for Africa Feb. 1 - While attending the 1985 United Nations Decade for Women conference in Kenya, Dr. Sorosh Roshan, an obstetrician and gynecologist practicing in Millburn, N.J., helped establish the International Health Network, in which volunteers - medical specialists and others - work with local authorities to bring medical treatment and education to African villages.

LEAD: On the boardwalk in the 1940's, dancers did the Lindy to music from a juke box in front of ''Meyer's Knishes.'' Nearby was the Takee-Cup stand where you bought chow mein served in a cup made out of noodles. You ate the chow mein, then you ate the cup. The bars featured a kind of juke box with a screen that played ''soundies,'' short subjects of big bands playing their hits, like Artie Shaw and his Orchestra doing ''Star Dust.
LEAD: China's Communist Party has expelled a prominent journalist known for his scathing attacks on corruption in party ranks, it was disclosed today.

LEAD: Leaders of the United Democratic Front, the big anti-apartheid coalition in South Africa, have long accused Chief Mangosuthu Gatsha Buthelezi, the Zulu leader, of cooperating with the white Government. Last week, the Front blamed the Chief's followers for an attack on the home of one of its prominent members in which seven children and five adults were killed.

LEAD: I recently read ''Native Son,'' and I must say that any shortcomings in the writing style were not so apparent to me. Perhaps my not being a critic permitted me the freedom of approaching the book simply from the standpoint of its emotional impact. As far as I'm concerned, it did the job.

LEAD: WINTER-SURVIVAL TACTICS An ice-fishing and winter-survival clinic that is, from 1 to 5 P.M. today at the Bolton Lake Boat Launch, deals with such topics as down clothing not offering as much protection from Connecticut winters as many people might think.

LEAD: I KNOW that winter is probably not your favorite season. Once the holidays are past, all you have to look forward to is a succession of cold, gray days, slush-spattered windshields and heating bills that make your temperature rise, literally and figuratively.
LEAD: NESTLED among affluent homes in the Dix Hills-Melville area are 500 acres of seemingly untouched, rolling woodlands.

LEAD: With the spread of stereo television broadcasting, there has been growing interest in the sound quality of video presentations, and many videophiles cling to the notion that stereo means high-quality sound. This is simply not so; and with so many stereo TV sets now being sold, the distinction between stereo and fidelity should be clarified.

LEAD: AT less than eight square miles, Shaw Island is one of the smallest of the green-forested San Juan Islands in the far northwest corner of the lower 48 states. With 125 year-round residents, it is also one of the most tranquil.

LEAD: Earlier this month, when he reported on the city's financial condition, Mayor Koch's rhetoric was fanned by a landward breeze. ''I can now say we sail in calmer waters,'' he said. Last week, commenting in his State of the City Address on the corruption scandals that had ''wounded us all,'' the Mayor modeled his ship of state after the hospital vessel Hope: ''The knife of corruption endangered the life of New York City.

LEAD: Whatever else ''Amerika'' is - at 14 1/2 hours, it is, if nothing else, a very large piece of prime time - it is now the source of great controversy.

LEAD: THERE is considerable unease in the American financial community about Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d's apparent decision to pursue an aggressive devaluation strategy against West Germany and Japan. It is feared that a sharply lower dollar could reignite inflation and trigger a collapse in the bond market by discouraging foreign purchases of United States financial assets.

LEAD: CELLIST AND PIANIST Fred Sherry, cellist, and Bernice Silk, pianist, will play a recital next Sunday for the New Jersey Chamber Music Society at the Union Congregational Church in Upper Montclair.

LEAD: WHEN Ajai Singh Mehta leaves London in March to replace Robert A. Gottlieb at Alfred A. Knopf, he will be one of very few foreigners who have become editors in chief of an American book publisher. But if foreigners are rare in editorial sanctums, they have become increasingly familiar in the publishers' management suites.

LEAD: Historically as a nation, Turkey has not always been on the friendliest of terms with its neighbors, but the Turkish Embassy in Washington has its own record for hospitality. Years ago, these narrow waterways gave this Long Island community its name; today, they continue to add to its nonpareil beauty.

LEAD: ON Friday, as the stock market roared upward by 64 points and then plunged by 115, one stockbroker said: ''It's berserk. It's total confusion. No one knows what the heck is going on.'' The apparent chaos on Wall Street was closely linked to financial events around the world. In foreign exchange markets last week, the weak dollar plunged and the mighty yen climbed.

They reasoned that with a top tax bracket of 28 percent, executives would prefer to take their money now, rather than deferring payment and risking a tax rise later.

Roosevelt's New Deal after the Democrats' huge majorities in Congress were cut sharply in a Republican surge in 1938 and the President became preoccupied by foreign policy. As Ronald Reagan prepares for his State of the Union address this week, they have a similar worry about the ''Reagan Revolution.

LEAD: A POLICE officer answers a call to a burglary in progress and spies a figure on a dark fire escape brandishing a gun. He calls ''Stop!'' but sees the weapon turned on him and fires. A 12-year-old boy is killed.
LEAD: Hana Mandlikova hopes she has finally buried the tag that has followed her throughout her tennis career.

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. John A. Taylor Jr. of Bronxville, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Catherine Shawhan Taylor to John Gordon Hawkins, a son of Patricia Hawkins of Chestnut Hill, Mass., and David Hawkins of Brookline, Mass. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: To the Editor: As a master builder/construction consultant, I take strong exception to the statements about the construction industry by Donald Watson, the architect for the Noble house, as reported in ''Custom Building With an Architect'' on Dec. 21.
LEAD: THOSE who should know say the New Jersey pinelands are unique on this planet: 1.1 million acres of ''outer coastal plain pinelands forest'' that are duplicated nowhere.

LEAD: The Long Island Rail Road continued to hold talks yesterday with the union for the train engineers in an effort to end the strike that has shut the railroad since last Sunday. But the union's leader, Joseph A. Cassidy Jr., said a settlement was not likely this weekend.
LEAD: The Giants will win because, on behalf of their long-suffering loyalists, even masochism has its limits. ALAN C. MILLER New York
LEAD: On the arid flatlands south of this capital, a cemetery is growing quickly.

LEAD: To the Editor: In his Oct. 26 story on the Swiss hotel Haus Paradies, Israel Shenker says, ''Swiss Germans have quaint notions about spelling.'' There is nothing quaint about ''Paradies.'' It's the regular German spelling of ''paradise.''
LEAD: INTERNATIONAL 3-15

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Schaus of Farmington, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Wendell Walton Schaus to Robert Otis Brown, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward M. Brown of Providence, R.I.

LEAD: ''My overriding duty is to preserve the manuscript. No one will be allowed to see it again,'' says Frederic Vergne, the curator at the Conde Museum housed in the moated Chateau of the Dukes of Aumale in this small town a few miles north of Paris.

LEAD: In the bowels of this city's worst slum, people walk about on paths that seem like tunnels. The buildings are so close together that the sky is just a thin crack in the blackness, 15 stories above a jumble of contorted alleys and dripping pipes.
LEAD: THE strike that began last week against the Long Island Rail Road underscored a number of factors about the Island, its geography and its economy.
LEAD: Three Bergen County communities are embroiled in a legal battle over whether an affluent white community continues to send teen-agers a predominantly black high school in Englewood.

LEAD: OBBA BABATUNDE, the actor-singer-dancer-choreographer who originated the role of C. C. White in ''Dreamgirls'' and subsequently took over the lead role from Ben Vereen in the ill-fated musical ''Grind,'' is a graceful dancer with a mellow pop baritone, a pleasant personality and the good looks of a contemporary matinee idol.

LEAD: HE isn't scheduled to appear in court in Houston until tomorrow, but Ron Darling, the Mets pitcher who was arrested along with the team's second baseman, Tim Teufel, after a scuffle with two off-duty police officers working as bouncers at a Houston nightclub last July, may have already achieved an important legal victory.
LEAD: More Americans want the Giants to win the Super Bowl than prefer the Denver Broncos, a New York Times/ CBS News Poll shows. But even more say they don't care or don't know who they want to win.

LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz told members of the House Foreign Affairs Committee at a closed session last week that United States officials met with the Iranians in London Dec. 6, even as President Reagan was saying that the effort to establish a relationship with ''moderates in Iran'' had been ''broken off.

LEAD: Two people were killed and another person was injured when a two-alarm fire swept through two ninth-floor apartments in a 23-story building in the Riverdale section of the Bronx last night. Several firefighters and two police officers were injured fighting the blaze.
LEAD: Julius Erving and his high school basketball coach, Ray Wilson, in Radnor, Pa., during filming of a music video honoring the career of the retiring 76ers star. (AP)

LEAD: IN the alphabet soup of municipal government, the letters ''S.R.O.'' have taken on special meaning. New York City officials have wrestled for months over the fate of the city's remaining 52,000 rooms in S.R.O., or single-room-occupancy, hotels. They arrived at a solution last week, but it was not easy and it was not popular.

LEAD: IN the six years since its passage, fewer than a third of the towns in Connecticut have complied with a state law requiring local subdivision ordinances to consider the passive solar potential of developments.

LEAD: The swelling euphoria spawned by unexpected victories and steady improvement is gone. Patrick Ewing is tired, Bill Cartwright is slumping, Coach Bob Hill's fuse is short and the Knicks are losing once again.
LEAD: Only days after taking office, Gov. William Donald Schaefer, the autocratic former Mayor of Baltimore, is already being called ''the Mayor of Maryland.''

LEAD: Mark Aguirre scored 35 points and Brad Davis came off the bench to add a season-high 21 today, carrying the Dallas Mavericks to a 132-117 victory over Los Angeles that broke the Lakers' six-game winning streak.

LEAD: The engagement of Marianne Bardach to Dr. Richard Allen Dornfeld has been announced by Peter H. Bardach of Providence, R.I., and Lesta Summerfield Stacom of New York and Palm Beach, Fla., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of Carolyn Dornfeld of West Orange, N.J., and Norman Dornfeld of New York, Sag Harbor, L.I., and West Dover, Vt.
LEAD: Sunglasses aren't just for summer anymore. Nor are they always functional, as these eye-accessory eyefuls prove.

LEAD: Beirut University College, where four faculty members were kidnapped by gunmen yesterday, is a small private co-educational institution founded in Moslem West Beirut by American missionaries 63 years ago and has continued to function despite civil war and chaos in Lebanon.

LEAD: Ten years ago tomorrow, the pianist Bruce Hungerford died in an automobile accident in the Bronx at the age of 54. Since then all of his recordings have gone out of print, and one will search in vain for his name in the New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians. Yet Hungerford has not been forgotten.
LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev has rebuked farm officials for failing to reverse chronic agricultural problems, the press agency Tass reported today.

LEAD: To the Editor: Plastic is prominent in litter not only because it is non-biodegradable (''Plastic Falls to Pieces,'' Prospects Jan. 11) but because of its lightness. The wind carries plastic everywhere while metal and glass, which are also non-biodegradable, stay put. Similarly, metal and glass sink to the bottom of streams while plastic floats.

LEAD: ON the day after he called for the dissolution of Parliament last week, and scheduled a national election, Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald, an economist by profession, said the election would be won and lost on economic issues. Did that not mean, asked a reporter, that Dr. FitzGerald would be running against his own record?

LEAD: I WAS on the telephone when my neighbor stopped by for a cup of rice. Motioning to the cupboard, I expected her to grab the grain and run. Instead, she opened the cupboard door, paused and let out a loud guffaw. She had discovered my ''Batterie de Cuisine,'' a computerized list of my pots and pans by size and capacity.
LEAD: SUPER Bowls used to match a team from the American Conference against a team from the National Conference.

LEAD: When she is skiing across a windswept and dazzling field here, Debby Hoover says, the things she notices most are the sounds: snow that ''squeaks,'' ''crunches'' or ''hums, like a telephone line,'' the constant barking of a nearby dog, the shouts of other skiers.

LEAD: The United States and the European Community appeared to be edging toward a compromise today in a conflict over feed-grain sales to Spain that has threatened to develop into an Atlantic trade war.

LEAD: A total of 19 foreign hostages were known to be held in Lebanon as of Friday, before the latest kidnappings. The number does not include two men who were reported to have been bundled into a car in Beirut on Friday but who have not been identified.
LEAD: THE time-worn and gentle Catskill Mountains have been described as a sublime natural wonder that is best viewed from a cabin porch.

LEAD: For centuries, the elite of China dismissed as trivial the crafts made by villagers for their own use - the leather shadow puppets, paper cutouts, embroideries, batiks and woodblock prints. Today these handcut and stitched works are gaining recognition in China and in the West, a change that seems long overdue after viewing ''Chinese Folk Art: The Small Skills of Carving Insects,'' at the Yale University Art Gallery.

LEAD: The engagement of Carol Helen Buttenwieser and John R. Sharp has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence B. Buttenwieser of New York and North Salem, N.Y. Mr. Sharp is the son of Helen L. Sharp of Brookline, Mass., and Richard H. Rubin of Newton, Mass.

LEAD: The attempt to incorporate compassion and understanding into the medical student is a noble concept, but it is a self-selecting process that appeals to the very individuals who need it least. The overwhelming remaining majority will see this curriculum as the gesture that it is, an isolated course or two in the context of a highly competitive environment populated by compulsive overachievers.

LEAD: Hans Haacke, a diligent provocateur whose controversial art is aimed at political and corporate might, has not exactly had a high-profile career. LEAD: THE JOHNSTOWN FLOOD, by David McCullough. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $8.95.) On the afternoon of May 31, 1889, an earthen dam burst in the mountains above Johnstown, Pa., and in the resulting flood the booming coal-and-steel town was devastated and more than 2,000 people died. David McCullough's re-creation of the catastrophe, its causes and its aftermath is ''a superb job, scholarly yet vivid, balanced yet incisive,'' Alden Whitman said in The Times in 1968.

LEAD: EVERYONE knows a dollar is no longer worth a dollar, but that didn't stop the Government last year from selling $1 and $2 bills for more than they were worth. Demand was good, the Bureau of Engraving and Printing said.

LEAD: ''GOODNIGHT MOON,'' the classic bedtime book of the American nursery, will be 40 years old this year.

And to judge from the comments of bookmakers, police officers and gambling industry observers, a good number of those people will have made a wager on the outcome.

LEAD: THE chief of the State Lottery, J. Blaine Lewis Jr., says he might as well become a member of the Shuttle Meadow Country Club in Berlin, since he has come to know so many of its employees.

LEAD: Great capitals are usually hard to ignore: as cultural, economic and political centers, they attract crowds of travelers year after year, and are, if anything, overexposed. Yet right in the center of Europe, one of the most attractive cities ever built, long the residence of the Holy Roman Emperors, is often overlooked - a fact all the more surprising because, unlike many of its neighbors, it largely escaped the ravages of the last world war.

LEAD: The wild gyrations in Friday's stock market, which sent the Dow Jones industrial average soaring first by 64 points, then plunging by 114 points and ending the day with a 44.15-point decline, have stunned the financial markets. And although few analysts said yesterday that they understood what happened or what it would mean for the nation's economy or the markets, they are predicting the wild swings will continue.
LEAD: THE FATAL SHORE By Robert Hughes. Illustrated. 688 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $24.95.
LEAD: The engagement of Susan Dobbs Pratt and David Teale Clark has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Philip Gorton Pratt of Lawrenceville, N.J., parents of the future bride.

LEAD: In the House of Commons this week, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, half-moon spectacles perched on his nose, spent several hours fending off attacks by opposition members aroused by a sense that his 28-month-old administration has suffered an irrecoverable blow.

LEAD: On Friday, the United Nations Postal Administration will issue a set of three commemorative stamps to honor Trygve Lie. Mr. Lie served as the first Secretary-General of the United Nations from Feb. 1, 1946, to April 10, 1953.

LEAD: At the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York yesterday Diane Edna Damerell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Reginald G. Damerell of Bronxville, N.Y., was married to Michael D. Rhea, the son of Mr. and Mrs. D. J. Rhea of Hinsdale, Ill. The Rev. Charles A. Amstein performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by J. James Gordon of Greenwich, Conn., and Helen H. Gordon of Hartsdale, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter Lysa Ann Gordon to Joseph Walton, a research analyst at Colin A. Houston & Associates in Mamaroneck, N.Y. The bridegroom, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John Joseph Latue Walton of Sunderland, England, graduated from the Imperial College of Science and Technology of the University of London.

LEAD: Syracuse, facing St. John's for the first time since a 1-point loss in the Big East championship game last season, remained unbeaten in the conference with a 64-63 victory today in another classic battle at the Carrier Dome.

LEAD: Voicing a concern for its employees' health that went mostly unappreciated, a Chicago company announced last week that it would ban smoking - on the job and at home, too - conduct lung tests to make sure workers comply and dismiss those who do not.

LEAD: The attorney for Michael Stewart's family said yesterday he was pleased with a new report that indicated transit officers used excessive restraint in the 1983 arrest of Mr. Stewart, who lapsed into a coma and subsequently died.

LEAD: A Federal judge awarded a year's free lodging on Friday to a fair-housing official who had accused a landlord of refusing to rent a home to him because he was black, according to an attorney in the case.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: DAVID MAMET'S laconic style can lure one into thinking there must be something more to his plays than reaches the ear. Just as the pauses of Harold Pinter are rife with suggestiveness and tension, the clipped cadences and sentence fragments, the repetitions, sometimes even the grunts, of Mr. Mamet's characters have come to represent the poetic innuendos of the inarticulate.
LEAD: A BETTER START New Choices for Early Learning. Edited by Fred M. Hechinger. 172 pp. New York: Walker & Company. Cloth, $16.95. Paper, $10.95.

Murphy of Buffalo of the engagement of their daughter Anne Marie Murphy to Robert Lewis Banner Jr., the son of Dr. and Mrs. Banner of Richmond. A May wedding is planned. Miss Murphy, an export specialist for the International Trade Administration in Washington, graduated from Georgetown University.

LEAD: RULES prohibiting football players from ''spearing'' - tackling opponents helmet first and ramrod straight - have dramatically cut the number of paralyzing injuries in the sport, according to Dr. Joseph Torg of the University of Pennsylvania Sports Medical Center.

LEAD: A woman who insists she is the sister of the late Greek shipping tycoon Aristotle Onassis has been indicted by a Bergen County grand jury on forgery and other charges. The authorities said she was trying to swindle clothes, money and lodging from residents and businesses. The woman, identified by the police as Rowena Riggs Powell, a 59-year-old native of Virginia, was charged in the indictment Thursday.

LEAD: I.B.M. watching, long a leading sport in Silicon Valley, consists in large measure of following Big Blue's every move with an eye toward making a few million dollars here or there by producing cloned or compatible products. The International Business Machines Corporation, meanwhile, zigzags through the marketplace trying to avoid giving the competition any clues concerning the destiny of computing.

LEAD: The role played by Governor Cuomo's son, Andrew, in the state's rental of a downtown building has become a major issue in a politically charged suit filed against the state by a Manhattan thrift institution.

LEAD: AT a time when national studies rank American students among the lowest in the industrialized world in math skills, a survey released this month indicates that Connecticut elementary pupils are spending more than twice as much time in class studying English than mathematics.

LEAD: In 1951, 12 years before his death, Jean Cocteau began keeping a diary. Its existence was kept a secret until 1983, when the first of six volumes was published in Paris. The initial volume covers the years 1951 to 1953, when Cocteau, in his early 60's, was living partly in Paris, partly in relative solitude at his villa Santo Sospir at Cap-Ferrat in the South of France.

LEAD: NICHOLAS KAZONIS, senior project manager for corporate real-estate needs with the Amdahl Corporation of California, could not believe what was happening when he started negotiating a few months ago for a lease for 4,000 square feet of office space in downtown Hartford.
LEAD: The World Health Organization, citing a sharp increase in smoking in the third world, has increased its budget for anti-smoking activities for the first time, an agency official said today.

LEAD: What's new, coming up on the President's report to Congress, is not the State of the Union but the state of the President. Starting suddenly, on successive days last November, the Reagan Administration changed. Six years of genial invincibility have faded fast and that's why this address to Congress ranks in importance with his first one.
